Within our healthcare system there have been incidental polyps found on pathology after surgical resection that were not detected on pre-operative colonoscopy.  This portends the possibility that additional polyps may have been missed and remain in the colon. In addition, over 50% of patients nationally are non-compliant with guidelines for postoperative surveillance colonoscopy.  Further elucidation of the significance of incidental polyps and its potential effect on surveillance is needed.  Therefore, the objective our study was to determine the relationship between unexpected polyp on colectomy specimen and findings on post-operative surveillance colonoscopy.

Methods:  A retrospective chart review was performed on all patients that underwent colorectal resection at our institutions from 2018 to 2019.  Surgical pathology reports were reviewed for identification of any polyp.  If detected, pre-operative colonoscopy report was referenced to determine if any lesion was expected.  Incidental polyps were stratified based on reason for being missed on pre-operative colonoscopy.  Each chart was then reviewed for post-operative colonoscopy report, including any identification of new lesion. Odds ratio was used to compare the incidence of new lesion on post-operative colonoscopy between the cohort with incidental polyp on colectomy specimen versus the cohort without incidental findings.

Results:  243 colorectal resections were performed at the two institutions between 2018 and 2019.  Incidental polyp was noted in 60 cases (24.7%). The most commonly identifiable reason was suboptimal bowel prep on pre-operative colonoscopy (n=15, 25%).  In this cohort, post-operative colonoscopy has been completed in 47 cases (19%). Of these cases, new polyp was detected in 18 cases (38.3%).  Of those, 9 were identified in patients with incidental polyp in operative specimen, and 9 were identified in patients without incidental polyp.  Therefore, the patients with incidental polyp on operative specimen were over three times more likely to have polyp found on interval colonoscopy (unadjusted odds ratio 3.41, 95% confidence interval 1.29 to 9.05, p=0.01).

Conclusion:  Our results show a high incidence of unexpected polyp on surgical specimen, as well as a higher rate of lesions detected on post-operative colonoscopy within this cohort.  Therefore, incidental findings on final surgical pathology may be interpreted as a risk factor for the presence of other missed lesion still within the patient.  Given suboptimal compliance with surveillance within our cohort and nationally, it is imperative that providers and patients understand the potential implications that these incidental lesions confer.  Therefore, we must strive for high quality pre-operative colonoscopies and consider potential modification of surveillance interval on a case by case basis.

abstract_title: Ketorolac After Colectomy: is There a Clinically Significant Risk of Postoperative Bleeding?
author_block: S. S. Ballakur<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Juprasert<sup>2</sup>, H. L. Yeo<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Weill Cornell Medical College,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>New York Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medicine,Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Weill Cornell Medical College,Department Of Healthcare Policy And Research,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) are a common non-opioid analgesic used for postoperative pain control. Ketorolac is an NSAID that has been utilized sparingly in the postoperative period due to a presumed increased risk of bleeding. Although this relationship has been examined in various surgical disciplines, the association between ketorolac and bleeding has not yet been studied in colorectal surgery.

Methods: This is a retrospective chart review of all patients undergoing laparoscopic colectomy between 2015 and 2018 at a single institution for benign and malignant indications. Patients were sorted into two cohorts based on postoperative ketorolac administration. Perioperative data and outcomes including hemoglobin, hematocrit, blood transfusions received, length of stay and need for operative reintervention were collected.

Results: 420 patients who underwent laparoscopic colectomy were included in the analysis. Patients receiving ketorolac (n=131) were compared to those who did not (n=289). There were no significant differences in sex (p=0.07), ethnicity (p=0.4), race (p=0.4), resection type (p=0.1), or operative length (p=0.2). In terms of postoperative outcomes, there were no significant differences in estimated blood loss (p=0.3), blood transfusion requirements (p=0.6), or reinterventions for bleeding (p=0.6). Daily hemoglobin and hematocrit trends were similar between these two groups in the first three postoperative days. Additionally, those receiving ketorolac were found to have a significantly shorter hospital length of stay (p=0.002) and quicker return to bowel function (p=0.01), despite no differences in 30-day readmission (p=0.5) and complication rates (p=0.4).

Conclusion: Ketorolac use after colorectal surgery is not associated with an increased risk of clinically significant postoperative bleeding and is associated with decreased length of stay and quicker return to bowel function. The conclusions from this study are limited by the retrospective methods used which are subject to selection bias. Further blinded randomized control studies are required to further elucidate the risks of postoperative bleeding with ketorolac.

abstract_title: Investigating the Cost-Effectiveness of Hub Hospitals in Hospital Networks for Colorectal Surgery
author_block: J. K. Tong<sup>1</sup>, C. Wirtalla<sup>2</sup>, C. W. Lancaster<sup>1</sup>, A. Ahn<sup>3</sup>, E. S. Brooks<sup>3</sup>, N. N. Mahmoud<sup>1</sup>, C. B. Aarons<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Center For Surgery And Health Economics,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There has been an increasing trend towards the consolidation of hospitals into networks with Hub (HH) and Spoke (SH) hospitals. Theoretically, this consolidates complex care from smaller SH into their HH to improve efficiency and patient outcomes. The SH also financially benefit by sharing in the increased bargaining power of the growing network. Limited evidence exists on the achievement of this purported goal. We sought to examine the differences in costs and outcomes at HH and SH using a colorectal resection model.

Methods: Using state discharge data from 5 geographically diverse states (2013 to 2016), we identified patients greater than 18 years of age who underwent a colon or rectal resection (CRS) at a networked hospital. Colorectal resection was used given the inclusion of common and complex cases, and the detectable rate of adverse events. Networked hospitals were included when the entire hospital network was contained within the 5 study states. HH were defined as those that performed over 75% of the rectal surgeries for that network. All other hospitals within that network were designated as SH. Financial and clinical outcomes were compared between HH and SH using mixed-effects multivariate regression models. Costs were calculated in 2016 USD. Analyses were performed for colon and rectal resections separately.

Results: Of 13,565 CRS patients included in the study, mean age was 61.5 years, 53.5% were female, and 77.3% were white. Differences were seen in the distribution of patients treated at Hub and Spoke hospitals (see Table). The characteristics of the hospital differed between the HH and SH. For example, the mean number of beds in HH was 254.8 (SD 123.9), relative to 74.4 (SD 67.2) at SH. In the linear regression models, performing colon operations at HH was found to be more expensive than at SH ($1,872.59, p < 0.001, 95%CI: $967.00 - $2,778.18). An even greater effect was found for rectal operations ($3,533.66, p = 0.004, 95%CI: $1,137.78 - $5,929.54). In the mixed-effects logistic regression models, there was a 55% decreased odds of complications (OR 0.55 95%CI: 0.44-0.69; p < 0.001) among patients that underwent colon operations at HH. However, there was no difference in the rates of death or 30-day readmissions between HH and SH for rectal or colon resection.

Conclusion: Colorectal resections performed at HH are associated with higher costs and lower odds of complications than those performed at SH. The use of the Hub and Spoke model in hospital network consolidation may be an effective approach to achieving high-value care when patients are distributed fluidly to the hospitals ideally suited to their unique needs.

abstract_title: Cost of Complications Post-Colectomy Above and Below Peritoneal Reflection With and Without Diversion
author_block: K. Carsky<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Antonacci<sup>2</sup>, G. Husk<sup>1</sup>, S. P. Dechario<sup>4</sup>, M. Jarrett<sup>3</sup>, A. C. Antonacci<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Lenox Hill Hospital, Northwell Health,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine,New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>3</sup>Northwell Health,Manhasset, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>Institute for Spine & Scoliosis (ISS),Lawrenceville, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is well established that post-operative complications are associated with higher costs to hospital systems. The cost to hospital systems in the setting of post-operative complications of colectomy is not clearly defined. Financial penalty for SSI after colectomy as part of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services Hospital-Acquired Condition Reduction Program was established in 2017. Perioperative bundles have been promoted to decrease SSIs after colectomy. This project is intended to provide information to health systems on the effects of post-operative complications on fixed (FC) and variable costs (VC) to systems, surgery time, and length of stay (LOS) within our system in 4 different categories of colectomy.

Methods: Colectomy cases were collected from 3 major centers within our system in 2019. Administrative data was mined to evaluate the number of colectomy cases with complications within 4 categories, including colectomies above and below the peritoneal reflection (PR), with and without diversion. Expense by accounting category was evaluated per case. Complications reported from our concurrent reporting system were compared to administrative secondary diagnosis codes to assess the accurate identification of complications following colectomy and evaluate financial and LOS cost. Net revenue, FC, VC, surgery time (mins), and LOS (days) were evaluated on cases with and without post-operative complications. Total margin was calculated by subtracting FC and VC from revenue.

Results: Of 922 colectomy cases in 2019, 144 (15.6%) sustained complications. Complications were associated with increased FC and VC in all four categories. Colectomy above PR without diversion had the greatest increase in both FC (45.95%) and VC (40.51%). In colectomy below PR, total margin was decreased with complications vs. without, both with and without diversion. Over all categories, average LOS was increased with complications v. without (14.57 v. 9.18 days). Surgery time and LOS increased by more in the setting of colectomy below the PR, regardless of diversion. With complications, LOS increased by 4.53 days (39.81%) in colectomy below PR without diversion and 4.18 days (41.42%) with diversion. Total LOS excess of 5.39 and surgery time excess of 337.22 minutes is directly related to opportunity cost.

Conclusion: Morbidity of colectomy complications includes financial, LOS and opportunity costs to health systems and clinical morbidity to patients. Excess LOS was approximately 5.39 days across categories. Our data suggests that the excess financial cost is greatest in colectomies below PR with and without diversion. Total margin in colectomy decreased by $3473.79 per case below PR with diversion and $5465.23 without diversion.

abstract_title: Multidisciplinary Clinics for Colorectal Cancer May Not Provide More Efficient Coordination of Care
author_block: S. Bajpai<sup>1</sup>, L. Wood<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Gunnells<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Hardiman<sup>1</sup>, G. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Morris<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,General Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Treatment of colorectal cancer often requires a multidisciplinary approach and national accreditation requires rectal cancer patients to be evaluated in a multidisciplinary clinic (MDC). We evaluated an MDC for colorectal cancer and its effect on time to evaluation and treatment.

Methods: We queried our institutional ACS NSQIP database for all patients undergoing surgical intervention for colorectal cancer between January 2017 and February 2020. Clinical characteristics, sociodemographic factors, insurance status, and timelines for diagnosis and treatment were retrospectively reviewed. Patients were stratified into those seen in MDC or not. Our primary endpoint was the time to start treatment (TST), either initiation of neoadjuvant therapy or surgery from the date of diagnosis, which was defined as the date of colonoscopy. Wilcoxon and Kruskal Wallis tests were used for continuous and categorical data, respectively, at an alpha level of 0.05.

Results: A total of 405 patients were evaluated: 115 patients in the MDC cohort and 290 controls. The overall median age was 61.8 years (IQR, 52.0-69.6) and 52.4% were men.  There was no difference between MDC and standard clinics in terms of time from diagnosis to complete staging for rectal cancer patients (13 vs 14 days; p=0.48). There was also no significant difference between the groups TST for all patients with colorectal cancer (30 vs. 37 days; p=0.07). When comparing MDC to control groups for initial treatment, median time to start of neoadjuvant therapy (30 vs 34 days; p=0.28) and time to surgery (32.5 vs 38 days, p=0.35) from initial diagnosis were not statistically different. We further examined impact of social determinants of health on MDC visits. TST from diagnosis for MDC patients with different insurance types (Medicare/Medicaid 32 days, Private 30 days, Self-pay 23 days; p=0.51), ethnicities (Caucasian 32 days, African American 32 days, Hispanic 14 days; p=0.12), and distances from the clinic (<50miles 29 days, >100miles 30 days; p=0.76) were similar. When comparing MDC to controls, TST from diagnosis for Caucasians (32 vs 35 days; p=0.17) and minorities (28 vs 41 days; p=0.19) as well as for people who were self-pay (23 vs 38 days, p=0.26) or had any type of insurance (30 vs 37 days; p=0.12) were decreased, but not to a significant degree.

Conclusion: Implementation of an MDC provides slight but not significant reduction in time to start of treatment for colorectal cancer patients as compared to regular clinics bringing into question this requirement for accreditation.

abstract_title: Impact of Metformin use on survival in patients undergoing resection for colorectal cancer metastasis
author_block: C. T. Kaltenmeier<sup>1</sup>, B. Morocco<sup>1</sup>, K. Meyer<sup>1</sup>, K. Reitz<sup>1</sup>, D. Geller<sup>1</sup>, M. Molinari<sup>1</sup>, S. Tohme<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The recent use of more effective chemotherapy and the development of surgical procedures have expanded the pool of resectable patients with colorectal liver metastases (CRLM). However, the recurrence rate remains high for patients with CRLM undergoing resection. Observational and preclinical studies have suggested that Metformin has antitumor effects in many solid tumors including colorectal cancer. Thus, we aimed to assess recurrence-free (RFS) and overall survival (OS) among individuals with CRLM undergoing surgery with or without postoperative prescriptions for metformin.

Methods: This cohort study obtained data from the electronic health record of a multicenter, single health care system. Included were adults with CRLM who underwent liver surgery with curative intent between 2010 and 2020. Patients were divided into two groups based on their use of Metformin after surgery as documented in the electronic medical record. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to assess RFS and OS among the two groups.

Results: Among the 270 individuals who underwent resection for CRLM, 62 (23%) were on metformin. There were no significant differences in tumor characteristics (CEA level, size of largest tumor, number of tumors, among others) between the groups. Patients on Metformin had significantly longer RFS (HR: 0.44, 95% CI: 0.26-0.75, p<0.002) with a median RFS of 63 months versus 39 months compared to patients not on metformin. On multivariable analyses the use of metformin was independently associated with prolonged RFS (HR: 0.54, 95% CI: 0.32-0.94, p<0.028). Similarly, patients on Metformin had significantly longer overall survival (OS) (HR: 0.60, 95% CI 0.31-0.97, p<0.048) with a median OS of 87 months versus 67 months. Compared to patients not on metformin.

Conclusion: Metformin exposure in patients with CRLM undergoing surgery may be associated with improved recurrence-free and overall survival. Further studies are warranted to evaluate if there is a therapeutic role for metformin in the treatment of CRLM.

abstract_title: Water consumption during pre-operative hand sanitization: A QI project for the post COVID-19 world
author_block: A. Altinoz<sup>1</sup>, S. Al Sheebani<sup>1</sup>, M. Mirza<sup>1</sup>, M. Al Ameri<sup>1</sup>, P. Aravind<sup>2</sup>, R. Dembinski<sup>2</sup>, M. Habibi<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tawam Hospital,Breast Surgery,Al Ain, ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Water is a scarce and precious resource in many parts of the world and in the context of achieving appropriate surgical hand scrubbing this calls into question if alternative hand sanitization techniques are equally effective. Hand scrubbing or using alcohol-based hand sanitizers are the available options for preparation prior to surgery. The COVID -19 pandemic has reemphasized the importance of handwashing and sanitization. As the world is moving back to opening the surgical procedures once again, we looked at the impact of water consumption and cost associated with this common practice.

Methods: This is a  quality improvement project, members of the surgical team were asked to scrub & amount of flowing water for 5 minutes was collected in a measuring bucket. The hospital sinks are equipped with either manual or automatic motion sensor taps. This was reflected in the total amount of water and cost that was calculated for the operative cases of 2019. An estimate of water consumption was calculated using the mean of participants’ scrub time.

Results: An average of 3 minutes was the scrub time for the 6 participants, including 2 senior surgeons, 1 senior resident, 1 junior resident, and 2 scrub nurses. Six operation theatres had manual tap sinks and 3 had motion sensor tap sinks, both taps had water flow rate of 6 liters per minute. Thirty liters of water was consumed using a manual tap sink with continous water flow in 5 minutes. In comparison just 7.5 liters of water was consumed using a motion sensor tap sink in 5 minute.  Overall, motion sensor taps use 75% less water than manual taps, and only 8 liters (27%) of water from the manual tap sinks was actually used for hand scrubbing per 5 minute interval. A total of 7060 cases were operated in the year of 2019 in our institute. On average 4 members scrubbed in per case, including the primary surgeon, assistants and scrub nurse. Cost of annual water consumption in Abu Dhabi, UAE is 10.41 AED per 1000 liter. Our analysis showed that the annual cost of water consumption for surgical scrubbing alone ranged from 1.8 to 7.5 million AED. This range suggests that use of motion sensor taps instead of manual taps could save up to 5.6 million AED (1.46 million USD) per year.

Conclusion: The surgical hand washing technique is associated with a considerable amount of water. Motion sensor taps have the advantage to decrease a great amount of water wastage with water flowing only during actual washing. Techniques to decrease that amount are available and can be considered to preserve the water.

abstract_title: Are Some Surgical Patients Unintended Victims of the Pendulum Swing in Opioid Prescribing Policies?
author_block: J. S. Marwaha<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Robinson<sup>1</sup>, A. Fleishman<sup>1</sup>, J. Yu<sup>1</sup>, G. A. Brat<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Department Of Biomedical Informatics,Brookline, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Since 2017, multiple states, insurance companies and pharmacies have placed blanket regulations on opioid prescribing. A seven-day limit on opioid prescriptions is the most common restriction across these institutions, however some have also placed 50 morphine milligram equivalents (MME) per day limits, restricting total opioid prescriptions to 350 MME. We sought to determine how patients undergoing surgery would be affected by these new restrictions.

Methods:  3,000 patients were enrolled from 2016-2018 who were opioid naïve and underwent surgery at one of four academic medical centers. These patients were called within a month of discharge and asked to report their post-discharge opioid consumption. 49 distinct procedures were included in the analysis. The percentage of patients by procedure type whose post-discharge opioid consumption exceeded 350 MME was calculated.

Results: For 26 of 49 procedures, no patients reported taking more than 350 MME. For the remaining 23 procedures, 1.7-53% of patients required greater than 350 MME (Figure 1). Under this new policy, these patients may not be able to obtain a prescription of the appropriate size. Orthopedic and neurosurgical procedures were the most common types of surgeries where at least 10% of patients required greater than 350 MME.

Conclusion: The goal of post-operative pain management policies should be to optimize prescribing to individual needs, rather than simply to minimize all opioid prescribing. The increase in opioid misuse and mental health issues prompted by the current global pandemic makes personalized prescribing even more important. Current one-size-fits-all opioid prescribing policies could negatively impact 6.8% of patients undergoing surgery who require more than 350MME to appropriately control their pain after discharge. This represents 1.2 million postsurgical patients nationwide annually.

abstract_title: Use of Psychotropic Drugs Among Bladder Cancer Patients in the United States
author_block: E. P. Freudenburg<sup>1</sup>, U. Jazzar<sup>1</sup>, Y. Shan<sup>1</sup>, G. Movva<sup>1</sup>, C. D. Bergerot<sup>2</sup>, C. J. Wallis<sup>3</sup>, S. J. Freedland<sup>4</sup>, A. M. Kamat<sup>5</sup>, D. S. Tyler<sup>9</sup>, J. Baillargeon<sup>6</sup>, Y. Kuo<sup>6</sup>, Z. Klaassen<sup>7,8</sup>, S. B. Williams<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>The University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston,Division Of Urology,Galveston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>City of Hope Comprehensive Cancer Center,Department Of Medical Oncology,Duarte, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Department Of Urology,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>4</sup>Cedars Sinai Medical Center,Department Of Urology,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>5</sup>The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Department Of Urology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>6</sup>The University of Texas Medical Branch,Department Of Preventive Medicine And Community Health, Sealy Center Of Aging,Galveston, TX, USA <sup>7</sup>Medical College of Georgia – Augusta University,Department Of Surgery, Section Of Urology,Augusta, GA, USA <sup>8</sup>Georgia Cancer Center,Augusta, GA, USA <sup>9</sup>The University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston,Department Of Surgery,Galveston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Bladder cancer patients are at increased risk of physical and emotional distress, where psychotropic drugs continue to be a core component for symptomatic management. However, prescription utilization patterns largely remain to be elucidated. Our primary study objective was  to utilize neuroscience-based nomenclature to assess a comprehensive list of psychotropic drugs, and to explore prescription patterns and predictors in bladder cancer patients. 

Methods:  A total of 10,516 patients diagnosed with clinical stage T1-T4a, N0, M0 bladder urothelial carcinoma from January 1, 2008, to December 31, 2012 from the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER)-Medicare were analyzed. Prescription rates throughout 2-years post-diagnosis and patient adherence using MPR of 80% were captured. We used multivariable analysis to determine predictors associated with psychotropic prescription rates. Medication Possession Ratio (MPR) was used as an index to measure adherence in intervals of 3-months, 6-months, 1-year, and 2-years. Medication exposure was collected throughout 2-years from the time of bladder cancer diagnosis. Participants reported to take 1 or more psychotropic drugs were identified. The main outcome was an evaluation of psychotropic prescribing patterns and adherence across different drugs and demographic factors.

Results: Of the 10,516 patients, 5,621 (53%) were prescribed psychotropic drugs following cancer diagnosis. Overall, 3,972 (38%) patients had previous psychotropic prescriptions prior to cancer diagnosis, and these patients were much more likely to receive a post-cancer diagnosis prescription. Prescription rates for psychotropic medications were higher among patients with higher stage bladder cancer (P < .001). GABA modulators/stimulators and serotonin reuptake inhibitors/stimulators were the highest prescribed psychotropic drugs in 21% of all patients. Adherence for all drugs was 32% at 3-months and continued to decrease over time.

Conclusion: Over half of bladder cancer patients received psychotropic prescriptions within two years of their cancer diagnosis. In the oncology setting, anxiolytics (e.g. benzodiazepines) and hypnotics were significantly less prescribed in bladder cancer patients. First-line antidepressants and anxiolytics prescription rates were found to be similar to the general population and raise concerns of under treatment in cancer patients. Given the chronicity of psychiatric disorders, significantly low adherence to medications warrants an emphasis on prolonged patient monitoring and further investigation for underlying reasons.

abstract_title: Clinician-Reported Barriers to Post-Discharge Communication after Gastrointestinal Surgery
author_block: M. L. Shallcross<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Brajcich<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Holl<sup>2</sup>, R. P. Merkow<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Chicago,Center For Healthcare Delivery Science And Innovation,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Northwestern Memorial Hospital,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: More than 30% of patients experience a major complication after gastrointestinal (GI) surgery. Nearly half of these complications occur post-discharge from the hospital where the responsibility of monitoring primarily falls on the patient and their caregivers. Effective communication between the clinical care team and patient is vital for early identification and management of post-discharge complications. Our objective was to identify and characterize major barriers to effective clinician-patient post-discharge communication after GI surgery.

Methods:  We conducted semi-structured interviews and focus groups that were audio-recorded and transcribed with GI surgery clinicians, including surgical oncologists and colorectal surgeons, registered nurses (RNs), and advanced practice providers (APPs). Clinicians were asked about their current post-discharge communication practices with patients and about barriers and facilitators impacting post-discharge symptom monitoring. Independent coding of two transcripts by four coders, with iterative reconciliation, was used to create a codebook, which was then used to code the remaining transcripts. Codes were then grouped into themes.

Results: Interviews/focus groups were completed with 12 clinicians. Four key themes about clinician-reported barriers to post-discharge communication (Table 1) emerged and revealed issues of (1) Patient health literacy: Patient inability to communicate clinically concerning symptoms, reflecting varying levels of clinical knowledge and ability to self-monitor; (2) Patient access to care team: Inefficient process for patients to contact the care team through the call center and/or the electronic health record, leading to communication delays; (3) Clinician time constraints: Lack of clinician time to proactively communicate with patients post-discharge to adequately monitor problems, leading to “reactive” identification and management of complications; and (4) Inconsistent composition of care team: Current staffing model frequently results in care team members who are unfamiliar with post-discharge GI surgery complications and care.

Conclusion: Both patient and clinician barriers contribute to ineffective post-discharge communication after GI surgery and may lead to inadequate or lack of early identification and management of complications. Addressing these barriers is essential when developing and implementing an effective post-discharge monitoring system for GI surgery patients.

abstract_title: Health Literacy in the Internet Era: Assessing the Quality of Opioid Information in Search Engine Results
author_block: C. Bunn<sup>1</sup>, D. Hubbs<sup>1</sup>, S. Kulshrestha<sup>1</sup>, J. Minalt<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Baker<sup>1</sup>, F. A. Luchette<sup>1</sup>, O. Akbilgic<sup>2</sup>, M. Afshar<sup>3</sup>, F. Modave<sup>4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Maywood, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Informatics And Systems Development, Health Sciences Division,Maywood, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin,School Of Medicine And Public Health,Madison, WI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Florida,Department Of Health Outcomes And Biomedical Informatics,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Opioids remains one of the leading causes of injury related death in the United States. National data shows that nearly 80% of Americans search the Internet for health information. In this study, we evaluated the quality and comprehensiveness of information available on the internet for patients seeking information on opioids. 

Methods: Commonly used search queries were generated from a systematic approach using a local survey, autocomplete and national trends data. The first five links were collected. Websites were each independently classified and evaluated by four surgical trainees. To control for unblinded review, scoring was based on a 51-point rubric on authorship (identifiable author, credentials listed, credibility), content (pharmacology, dosing/safety, indications, side effects, abuse potential, opioid use disorder (OUD), epidemiology, disposal, alternatives, references, reading level, last update) and website design (structure, font/background, graphics, layering, ad-free). Scores were weighted to account for sites categorized as more than one type and analyzed using descriptive statistics and 2-sided test of significance with analysis of variance.

Results: Thirty-seven search queries were generated, identifying 106 websites that met search criteria. Websites were categorized into the following for comparisons: 28.4% Government (GOV), 18.2% commercial, 18.5% academic/physician, 10.3% non-profit, 8.8% news/media, 15.8% not otherwise classified (NOC). GOV and academic/physician sites achieved the highest total scores with mean scores of 17.13, (SD 6.67) and 12.8, (SD 6.48) respectively, while NOC and commercial achieved the lowest total scores with respective mean scores of 6.59 (SD 4.61) and 7.21 (SD 4.13), p < 0.001 for comparison across group means. There was a difference between all groups regarding the quality of information on abuse potential (p=0.019), alternatives (p=0.012), disposal (p=0.007), epidemiology (p=0.036), OUD (p=0.006) and pharmacology (p <0.001) but not indications (p=0.208) or dosing (p=0.248). Content scores related to abuse potential, pharmacology and OUD were higher in academic/physician and GOV sites. The lowest content scores overall were on information related to alternatives (mean=0.26, SD 0.70) and disposal (0.26, SD 0.78). 

Conclusion: The quality and scope of public information on the internet regarding opioids is limited, particularly on non-opioid alternatives and safe disposal. GOV and academic/physician websites achieved the highest quality scores, yet account for only a third of the sites encountered from a systematic search approach. Given the low proportion of websites with adequate quality of information, physicians should help direct patients to appropriates websites for information on opioid use.

abstract_title: Preoperative Advance Care Planning for Older Adults Undergoing Major Abdominal Surgery
author_block: J. Bleicher<sup>2</sup>, L. McGuire<sup>2</sup>, R. Robbins<sup>2</sup>, J. Esplin<sup>2</sup>, S. Fischbuch<sup>2</sup>, S. Gupta<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Beck<sup>1</sup>, J. N. Cohan<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Huntsman Cancer Institute At The University Of Utah,Oncology,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Utah,Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Advance care planning (ACP) is recommended for older patients undergoing surgery. ACP consists of creating advance directives (ADs), identifying surrogate decision makers (SDMs), and documenting goals of care. We identified factors associated with the completion of preoperative ACP to identify opportunities to optimize ACP for older surgical patients.

Methods:  This was a retrospective study of surgical patients ≥70 years old who underwent elective colectomy, proctectomy, hepatectomy, esophagectomy, or pancreatectomy between 01/2015-08/2019. Demographic and clinical data were obtained from our institution’s 100% capture ACS NSQIP database. ACP metrics were extracted from the electronic medical record. We investigated possible predictors of ACP including age, sex, race, need for English interpreter, and ASA class. Using factors with a p<0.20 on univariable analysis, we created 2 multivariable Poisson models to determine factors associated with ACP metrics (available AD and identified SDM). Goals of care documentation was not analyzed in multivariable fashion, as no factors were significantly associated with this metric. We also analyzed whether ACP was more frequent for patients who experienced postoperative complications or death.

Results: 267 patients met inclusion criteria. Median age was 75.3 years and 149 (56%) were male. 156 (58%) patients underwent colorectal resection, 78 (29%) pancreatectomy, 25 (9%) hepatectomy, and 8 (3%) esophagectomy. Most patients (187, 70%) had an AD, although this was only available on the day of surgery for 97 (36%) patients. 57 (21%) patients had a SDM identified and 31 (12%) had a documented goals of care conversation. On multivariable analysis, older age and white race were associated with an increased likelihood of having an AD available on the day of surgery (Table 1). Women were 1.7 times more likely to have a SDM on multivariable analysis (p=0.02). No factors were significantly associated with goals of care documentation on univariate analysis. ACP was not performed more frequently in patients who experienced postoperative complications or death (available AD, p=0.94; SDM identified, p=0.37; and documented goals of care, p=0.44). Of the 5 patients who died following surgery, none had documented goals of care preoperatively and only 1 had an AD available at the time of surgery.

Conclusion: ACP was not routinely documented for older patients undergoing major surgery. ACP was not more frequent in patients who experienced complications or death, demonstrating the importance of universal preoperative ACP in older patients. We plan to identify barriers to ACP at our institution and implement interventions to improve access to ACP for older adults undergoing surgery.

abstract_title: A Pre/Post Comparison After Introduction of a Female External Urinary Collection Device
author_block: N. Jasperse<sup>4</sup>, O. Hernandez-Dominguez<sup>3</sup>, J. S. Deyell<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Prasad<sup>1</sup>, C. Yuan<sup>1</sup>, M. Tomy<sup>1</sup>, A. Baraghoush<sup>5</sup>, C. Kuza<sup>6</sup>, A. Grigorian<sup>1</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Division Of Trauma, Burns, And Critical Care,Orange, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Cleveland Clinic,Department Of General Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>Harbor UCLA Medical Center,Department Of Emergency Medicine,Torrance, CA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Department Of Medicine,Orange, CA, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Southern California,Department Of Anesthesia,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Catheter associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) are the most common hospital acquired infections in the United States. External urinary collection devices (EUCDs) may serve as an alternative to indwelling urethral catheters (IUCs), thereby decreasing the rate of CAUTIs. PureWick® is a novel female EUCD, with early case reports suggesting safe and efficacious use. However, no study has demonstrated the PureWick® to reduce the incidence of CAUTIs. Therefore, we sought to compare the CAUTI rate and median indwelling catheter days before and after availability of PureWick® at a single academic institution.  We also performed a descriptive analysis of female surgical patients receiving an EUCD.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of adult female patients admitted to our institution on a surgical service, including intensive care unit and floor patients, who received an IUC and/or an EUCD. Patients admitted in the 3 months before (PRE) and 12 months after (POST) PureWick® availability were included. The longer POST period was to allow sufficient time and usage of EUCD to occur. Two groups were compared: PRE patients who received an IUC vs. POST patients who received an IUC and/or EUCD.

Results: Out of 906 patients, 127 received an EUCD in the POST cohort and overall, 879 received an IUC (433 (99.5%) PRE vs. 446 (94.7%) POST). There were no differences in the PRE and POST cohorts regarding age and comorbidities except end stage renal disease (3.7% PRE vs. 6.8% POST, p=0.036). The number of IUC days were similar between the PRE and POST cohorts (median, 2 vs. 2 days, p=0.188). Compared to the PRE cohort, the POST cohort had a higher rate of CAUTI (infections per 1,000 catheter days, 11.2 vs. 4.6, p=0.017) and overall UTI (infections per 1,000 catheter days, 5.4 vs. 4.8, p=0.036). In the POST cohort, the rate of UTI associated with EUCD use was 4.6 infections per 1,000 device days. Most patients (80.3%) who received an EUCD also received an IUC. Measurement of strict ins and outs (59.1%) was the most common indication for EUCD use. Trauma surgery (44.1%) and neurosurgery (18.9%) were the services that most frequently ordered an EUCD.

Conclusion: While EUCDs might appear to be a promising alternative to IUCs for female patients, this single center pre/post analysis found the CAUTI rate increased after introduction of an EUCD. This may be related to selection bias, with EUCDs being ordered for patients who would not have otherwise received an IUC. Nonetheless, adoption of EUCDs did not change the median number of indwelling catheter days. Further research is needed to clarify if female EUCDs can be effective in decreasing IUC days and/or CAUTI rates prior to any widespread adoption.

abstract_title: A Text Messaging System to Provide Sustainable Post-Discharge Surgical Opioid Use Data
author_block: P. Scalise<sup>1</sup>, K. Robinson<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Marwaha<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Fleishman<sup>1</sup>, J. Yu<sup>1</sup>, L. A. Nathanson<sup>3</sup>, G. A. Brat<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Department Of Biomedical Informatics,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Emergency Medicine,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There are few studies that evaluate patient-reported opioid consumption after discharge from surgery. Our group has developed an automated text message-based system for collecting post-discharge opioid consumption data from patients. Our system requires minimal manual effort when compared with the current method of collecting patient-reported opioid consumption data that involves calling patients by telephone after surgery. This study seeks to compare demographics between text message-based survey responders and non-responders amongst surgical patients post-discharge. This may help determine if text messaging is an appropriate and unbiased modality for collecting data on post-surgical opioid consumption.

Methods: Patients who underwent a surgical procedure at our institution from 10/1/2018-10/1/2020 were enrolled in a text message-based survey study to quantify opioids consumed after discharge and to measure overall satisfaction with pain control. Text messages were automatically sent to patients after discharge. 4,923 patients were included in the analysis. Patient information was abstracted from the medical record via automated extraction and manual chart review. Factors including patient age, gender, race, type of surgery, and amount of opioids prescribed were analyzed amongst survey responders and non-responders.

Results: There were 1,094 responders (22% response rate). Survey responders were older (mean age 57 y vs. 56 y). Patients who were white (26% response rate) and underwent orthopedic surgery (28% response rate) were more likely to respond compared to other races and types of surgery, respectively. Responders were more likely to have undergone inpatient surgery than outpatient (24% vs. 20%). There was no difference amongst responders and non-responders in the amount of MMEs prescribed upon discharge, gender, or time of year.

Conclusion: After testing text-message based opioid consumption surveys, we conclude that this system of automated data collection has comparable limitations from bias between responders and non-responders when compared with phone call surveys. Since our text messaging system obtains post-discharge opioid consumption data in an automated fashion and requires minimal manual effort, text messaging could be used to track larger patient populations in future studies. Future efforts may focus on improving patient engagement to increase the current response rate.

abstract_title: Effects of Community Engagement on Implicit Bias in Healthcare Workers
author_block: A. Amoabin<sup>1</sup>, C. Bence<sup>1</sup>, S. Siddiqui<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Pediatric Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multiple studies, including the Institutes of Medicine 2003 report, have shown that racial and ethnic minorities experience lower quality of care (are less likely to receive routine care and experience higher rates of morbidity/mortality when care is provided) than their white counterparts.  Further research suggests that implicit (unconscious) bias amongst healthcare professionals contributes to health disparities. We sought to evaluate the effects of community engagement on implicit bias in healthcare providers, and gauge the feasibility of conducting this research in a healthcare setting.

Methods: Subjects were identified based on their participation in a community youth trauma outreach program, and included medical students, general surgery residents, and hospital staff. All subjects were directed to an anonymous web survey at Harvard University’s Project Implicit web server (https://implicit.harvard.edu/implicit). De-identified data was self-submitted to a protected REDCap database. Data collection period was immediately three weeks following the community engagement program (Aug 21, 2019-Sept 20, 2019).

Results: A total of 12 subjects completed the implicit bias surveys, and all reported a history of volunteering “sometimes” (75%) or “often” (25%). Average implicit bias scores demonstrated little-to-no preference for black people over white people, and little-to-no preference for other people over Arab/Muslims. Overall, volunteers rated their comfort in different social situations as “comfortable”.  There were no differences in implicit bias or comfort scores based on volunteer frequency (all p>0.05).

Conclusion:   Our data showed that implicit bias screening in healthcare workers is feasible, and that bias in our volunteer cohort was overall low.  While not the purpose of this study, interestingly a significance difference within groups was discovered, showing increased implicit bias towards Arab-Muslims as compared to African Americans. This may suggest the increased need for targeted community engagement within the Arab-Muslim population. However, our study is limited by small sample size and selection bias in our cohort of volunteer respondents.  Further study is needed to determine the effects of community engagement on implicit bias in healthcare providers.

abstract_title: Motoric-Cognitive Syndrome Assessment in Parkinson's Disease by using Instrumented Trail-Making Test
author_block: R. Mishra<sup>1</sup>, B. Najafi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Despite the high life-long risk of dementia in Parkinson’s disease (PD), early identification of the onset of dementia remained challenging. Recent studies suggest that a dual decline in motor and cognition, known as motoric-cognitive risk (MCR) syndrome, is a strong predictor of early dementia onset. However, current tools to detect MCR are resource-intensive, educationally, and culturally biased, and often impractical for busy clinics and home settings. To address the gap, we designed an instrumented trail-making task (iTMT) based on a wearable sensor (worn on the shin) with interactive game-based software installed on a tablet. The iTMT test includes reaching to 5 indexed circles, a combination of numbers (1-to-3) and letters (A&B) randomly positioned inside target circles, in a sequential order, which virtually appears on a tablet-screen, by rotating one’s ankle-joint while standing and holding a chair for safety. By measuring time to complete iTMT task (iTMT time), iTMT enables quantifying cognitive-motor performance. The present study's objective is to examine the feasibility of iTMT to detect early cognitive-motor decline in PDs.

Methods:  Four groups of volunteers, including 12 healthy-young adults, 15 PDs, and14 cognitively-intact older adults (CI-older), were recruited. Participants completed three trials of iTMT, Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), single- and dual-task walking tests.

Results: All participants enabled to complete iTMT with less than 3 minutes, indicating high feasibility. The average iTMT time for healthy-young, CI-Older, PD, and MCI participants were 18.5±0.6s, 20.1±0.9s, 34.3±3.0s, and 49.2±6.2 s, respectively. The pairwise comparison suggested large effect sizes for iTMT between PD vs healthy-young  (Cohen’s d=1.91, p=0.028) and CI-older (d=1.67, p=0.049), and between MCI vs PD (d=0.81, p=0.031), healthy-young  (d=1.85, p<0.01), and CI-Older (d=1.74, p<0.01) as shown in the figure below. Significant correlations were observed when comparing iTMT time with MoCA (r=-0.31, p=0.026), ST gait speed (r=-0.51, p<0.001), and DT gait speed (r=-0.44, p<0.01).

Conclusion: This study demonstrated the feasibility and early results supporting the potential application of iTMT to determine cognitive-motor and distinguishing MCI cases. Future studies are warranted to test the ability of iTMT to detect MCR syndrome and track its subtle changes over time.

abstract_title: Analysis of Surgical Case Cancellations at a Tertiary Care Hospital
author_block: N. Wadhwani<sup>1</sup>, B. L. Corey<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Morris<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Operating room (OR) productivity is one of the most important determinants of economic success for most healthcare centers with surgical facilities. Various factors contribute to the turnover in the OR, which in turn affects the efficiency of the system. One of the factors that adversely impact OR productivity is surgical case cancellations. These canceled cases not only prolong turnover which incurs a significant financial loss but also affects patients psychologically and often, financially. This study was undertaken to explore common etiologies of case cancellations at a tertiary care center and identify potential areas of intervention.

Methods: Data for all surgical cases canceled during the period of October 2018 to September 2019 in a tertiary care center were collected and retrospectively analyzed using STATA software v.16. Student’s t-test and 2 statistics were used, with p < 0.05 significant.

Results: Cancellations accounted for 6 % of the total scheduled cases. 64% of the case cancellations were attributed to surgeon related factors such as surgeon’s request or surgeon not certified. Surgeon’s gender or years in practice did not correlate with the surgeon’s requests for these cancellations. Additionally, certain sub-specialties had a higher rate of cancellations such as orthopedics (33%) and cardiothoracic (12%). Other reasons included patient-related factors, such as no show and medical optimization, which were responsible for 18% cancellations, whereas administrative and scheduling issues resulted in 16% of the cancellations.

Conclusion: We found that surgical case cancellations are, in general, infrequent at a tertiary care center. Surgeon requests account for the majority of the cancellations, which did not correlate with specific factors such as gender or years in practice. Lastly, the cancellation rate has a skewed distribution amongst different sub-specialties, with most cancellations observed for orthopedics surgery.

abstract_title: Neurogenic Pulmonary Edema in Trauma - A Case Report and Systematic Review
author_block: A. Papa<sup>1,2</sup>, D. Lapoint<sup>2</sup>, M. B. Roberts<sup>2</sup>, A. Carrillo<sup>2</sup>, J. Collins<sup>1</sup>, S. Galiczynski<sup>1</sup>, A. Ratnasekera<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Crozer-Keystone Medical Center,Upland, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neurogenic Pulmonary Edema (NPE) is a rare syndrome characterized by acute pulmonary edema following a central nervous system (CNS) injury with the absence of a primary cardiogenic or pulmonary insult. There are multiple causes, including traumatic brain injury (TBI), seizures, and cerebral hemorrhage, however, the frequency, risk factors, morbidity and mortality of the disease remains widely unknown. First, we present a case report of NPE in a 22-year-old African-American male with a single gunshot wound to the head. Second, we perform a systematic review of NPE related to TBI in order to examine risk factors associated with mortality.

Methods: PRISMA guidelines were used to conduct the study (figure 1). 1,399 articles specific to NPE were identified by searching Pubmed and Scopus. 128 records remained after applying exclusion criteria and 29 studies were included in quantitative analysis, identifying 45 patients total. Acquired patient data included admission vital signs, demographics, and mortality. Frequency data, t tests, and odds ratios were generated using IBM SPSS Version 26 to examine risk factors for mortality. Non-numerical data, such as common radiographic imaging findings, physical exam findings, pharmacologic treatments used, and ventilation strategies were also reviewed for discussion.

Results: Overall mortality from NPE in traumatic brain injury was found to be 44.20%. Of the patients who survived, 63.6% (n=14) made a full recovery from NPE and 78.3% were discharged home. Median hospital stay was 11 days. Admission vitals, such as systolic blood pressure (mean [SD], 113.13 [20.17]) (P = .088) and heart rate (97.93 [19.89]) (P = .057) were not significant in predicting mortality. While the majority of patients were male (83.7%, n = 36), there was no associated significant risk in mortality based on sex; male (OR, 1.050; 95% CI, 0.248 – 7.913) female (OR, 0.750; 95% CI, 0.171 – 3.291). Median age was 19 years, however, age was not a significant risk factor for mortality (22.92 [12.61]) (P = .385).

Conclusion: NPE is a syndrome defined by acute interstitial and alveolar edema following a CNS injury without a primary cardiogenic or pulmonary insult. NPE caused by TBI is rare and carries a significant mortality and morbidity. To our knowledge this is the first systematic review of NPE associated with TBI. While the generated data may provide an idea of a typical presentation of NPE, there is insufficient evidence to establish risk factors associated with mortality.

abstract_title: Dual Neurostimulant Use May Optimize Short-Term Neurorecovery in Severe Traumatic Brain Injuries
author_block: B. M. Tracy<sup>1</sup>, M. Cordero-Caballero<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Durr<sup>2</sup>, R. B. Gelbard<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,Trauma, Critical Care, Burn,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Grady Memorial Hospital,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Acute Care Surgery,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The use of neurostimulants, such as amantadine, after a traumatic brain injury (TBI) can improve neurological recovery during inpatient rehabilitation.  However, amantadine’s clinical effect when given during the index hospital admission for a TBI is unknown.  Using support vector machines (SVM), we sought to identify the clinical patient profile in which amantadine use would be associated with the optimal short-term neurorecovery. 

Methods:  We performed a retrospective review of all patients at our level 1 trauma center from 2016-2019 who sustained a severe TBI (defined as a Glasgow Coma Scale score [GCS] ≤ 8 with radiographic evidence of brain injury). We excluded penetrating injuries, patients who expired, and those not receiving amantadine.  We collected data on demographics, admission neurologic status (GCS1), injury severity score (ISS), amantadine prescribing details, dual neurostimulant use (amantadine + methylphenidate), and discharge neurologic status (GCS2). Neurorecovery was defined as: (GCS2 - GCS1) / (GCS2). The resulting quotients were categorized as minimal recovery (≤ 0.4), moderate recovery (0.4 to < 0.7), and good recovery (≥ 0.7). Patients were grouped according to these three ratios, and data was compared between groups.  Using SVMs, significantly different variables (p<.05) and potential confounders (p ≤.1) were used to predict good neurorecovery.

Results: There were 76 patients; 19.7% (n=15) had mild recovery, 29% (n=22) had moderate, and 51.3% (n=39) had good recovery.  There was no difference between groups regarding age (p=0.9), sex (p=0.1), race (p=0.4), neurosurgical decompression (p=0.2), time until amantadine administration (p=0.4), duration or dose of amantadine therapy (both p=0.6), or ISS (p=0.1).  However, GCS1 varied significantly (p<.0001) between groups.  Our SVM model predicting neurorecovery had a low misclassification rate (14%) and high accuracy (AUC 0.95).  When the predicted probability of good neurorecovery for each patient was analyzed with our SVM model variables, only dual neurostimulant therapy and GCS1 were significantly associated. Specifically, predicted probabilities were higher with combination therapy (56.6% vs 34.8%, p=0.01) and a lower GCS1 (75.8% [GCS 3] vs 5% [GCS 8], p<.0001).

Conclusion: Following a severe TBI, short-term neurorecovery associated with amantadine use may be improved in patients with a lower GCS1 and in those receiving dual neurostimulant therapy.  Larger prospective trials are warranted to validate these findings in the index, acute hospitalization.

abstract_title: Contrast Study After Traumatic Gastric Repair: Is it Necessary?
author_block: N. Samuels<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Wesley<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Mubasher<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Butler<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Smith<sup>2,3</sup>, J. Nguyen<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Udobi<sup>1,2</sup>, S. R. Todd<sup>2</sup>, R. Sola<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Morehouse School of Medicine,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>Grady Hospital,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Variation exists regarding the routine use of contrast studies after traumatic gastric injury repair. We hypothesized there is no difference in clinical outcomes between patients who received a contrast study compared to those who did not. To that end, our study aimed to evaluate the need for routine contrast study following traumatic gastric repair. 

Methods:  This is a retrospective review of all trauma patients admitted to an urban level 1 trauma center and sustained gastric injuries with subsequent repair between 2016-2018. Demographics, surgical interventions, complications, and clinical outcomes were evaluated. Statistical analysis included mean (± standard deviation), Chi square/Fisher Exact and multivariate logistic regression methods with a 5% significance level.

Results: A total of 96 patients received a gastric repair, of whom 17 (17.7%) had a contrast study performed. Overall, mean age was 34 ± 14 years; 89% male; 77% African American; 95% penetrating injury. Mean injury severity score was 23 ± 12. The most common gastric repair was primary suture repair (76%) followed by stapled resection (17%). Mean length of stay was 23 ± 25 days. Mortality within 30 days was 4%. Out of 17 patients with a contrast study, none were found to have a gastric leak.  Mean time to contrast study was 5.6 ± 1.4 days.  There was no statistically significant difference in post-operative complications between groups (41% vs. 37%; p = 0.73). Specifically, there was no statistically significant difference in post-operative bleeding (18% vs. 4%; p = 0.10) and intraabdominal infection (12% vs. 24%; p = 0.17).  Multivariate logistic regression analysis supported our hypothesis and demonstrated a lack of statistical significance in the likelihood of having a contrast study performed when comparing those with and with without multiple injuries (OR: 1.5; 95% CI: 0.4-4.9; p = 0.54), primary suture repair versus other types of repair (OR: 1.9; 95% CI: 0.6-6.8; p = 0.31), and length of operation of  > vs ≤ 200 minutes (OR: 1.6; 95% CI: 0.5-5.0; p = 0.41).

Conclusion: Gastric leak after repair is rare and there is no statistically significant difference in clinical outcomes when comparing patients who underwent contrast study to those who did not. Routine contrast study after traumatic gastric repair is not necessary and the selective use of a contrast study is recommended.

abstract_title: Elderly Patients with Isolated Intracranial Hemorrhage: Is Full Trauma Team Activation Necessary
author_block: J. Diaz<sup>1</sup>, A. Rooney<sup>1</sup>, R. Calvo<sup>1</sup>, D. Benham<sup>1</sup>, M. Carr<sup>1</sup>, J. Badiee<sup>1</sup>, B. Sise<sup>1</sup>, M. Sise<sup>1</sup>, V. Bansal<sup>1</sup>, M. Martin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Scripps Mercy Hospital,Trauma,San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) is a highly morbid injury, particularly among individuals ≥ 55 on preinjury anticoagulants (AC). Many trauma centers initiate full trauma team activation (FTTA) for these high-risk patients. We sought to determine if FTTA was necessary in these patients compared with those who were evaluated as a trauma consultation (CON).

Methods: We identified patients aged ≥55 on preinjury AC who presented to our Level I trauma center from January 2015 to December 2019 with blunt isolated head injury (non-head AIS ≤2) and confirmed ICH. CON patients and FTTA patients were matched by age and head AIS. Demographic and clinical factors, time to evaluation, length of stay, and clinical course were compared. Cox proportional hazards model evaluated risk factors for mortality or adverse discharge disposition.

Results: There were 45 CON patients and 45 FTTA patients. Mean age was 80 years in both groups. Fall was the most common injury mechanism (98% CON vs. 91.6% FTTA). Although admission GCS was lower in FTTA (14 vs. 15, p<0.01), there were no di!erence between groups in ISS or head AIS. CON had a longer time from arrival to CT scan (1.3 vs. 0.4 hrs, p<0.01). Hospital days were similar (CON: 3.9 vs. TTA: 3.7 days). However, CON had increased ventilator use (p=0.03). Lower admission GCS was the only factor associated with increased risk of death, while CON status, AC type, time to CT scan, head AIS, AC reversal, and age were not related to mortality. Among survivors, only head AIS increased the risk of discharge to a level of care higher than that preinjury (p=0.01).

Conclusion: FTTA patients had a significantly shorter time to head CT than CON patients, but there was no diference in mortality or adverse discharge disposition. Any alteration in GCS was strongly associated with mortality and should prompt evaluation by FTTA.

abstract_title: No Additional Benefit to Post-Operative Antibiotics for Operative Traumatic Forearm Fractures
author_block: N. Khoshab<sup>1</sup>, A. Grigorian<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Melucci<sup>1</sup>, M. Chan<sup>1</sup>, D. Placido<sup>1</sup>, S. Stopenski<sup>1</sup>, E. O. Yeates<sup>1</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Trauma, Burns, Critical Care, And Acute Care Surgery,Orange, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Operative forearm fractures (FFs) may require antibiotics, but the optimal duration and timing of antibiotic regimens remains unclear. This study sought to compare the rates of post-operative surgical site infection (SSI) between patients receiving only pre-operative antibiotics and those receiving pre-operative and post-operative antibiotics. We hypothesized similar rates of SSI between the two groups. 

Methods: A single-center retrospective review of adult trauma patients (2014-2018) with FFs was performed. The primary outcome was SSI. Patients who underwent operative repair of FFs were compared by antibiotic regimen: patients receiving pre-operative antibiotics only (PRE) vs. patients receiving pre-operative and post-operative antibiotics (PRE-POST). Chi-square and Mann-Whitney U tests were used to compare categorical and continuous variables respectively. A univariate analysis was performed for risk of infection in both open and closed FFs.

Results: From 683 patients with FFs, 233 (34.1%) underwent an operation. Of which, 63 (27%) received PRE and 33 (14%) PRE-POST. When comparing PRE to PRE-POST, there was no difference in demographic variables including age, sex, comorbidities, or injury severity score (all p>0.05). The most common procedure in both groups was open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) (56 in PRE group (88.9%) and 24 in PRE-POST group (72.7%)). Patients in the PRE group had a shorter median antibiotic duration (2 days vs. 6 days, p < 0.0001). No difference was observed in SSI (0% vs. 3%), median time to repair (19 vs. 22 hours), or mortality (1.6% vs 0%) (all p>0.05) (Table 1). When compared to patients with closed fractures, patients with open fractures had similar risk of SSI (OR 0.19, 0.01-3.08, p=0.24). Patients in the PRE-POST group more frequently returned to the operating room (OR) (0% vs 6.1%, p = 0.05) and return to emergency department (ED) (7.9% vs. 27.3%, p=0.01).

Conclusion: This study demonstrated similarly low rates of SSI between FF patients receiving pre-operative antibiotic therapy compared to patients receiving additional post-operative antibiotics. Interestingly, patients receiving post-operative antibiotics were found to have significantly greater rates of return the OR and ED, although this may be related to selection bias. This study supports the discontinuation of antibiotics post-operatively for traumatic FFs. However, future multicenter prospective studies are needed to confirm these findings.

abstract_title: Traumatic Iatrogenic Injuries in Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation: A Meta-Analysis
author_block: M. Chun<sup>1</sup>, Y. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Toraih<sup>1</sup>, P. R. McGrew<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine,Surgery,New Orleans, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the past decade, there has been a lack of systematic review on significant iatrogenic injuries caused by mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) in comparison to manual CPR. The purpose of this systematic literature review is to describe, review, and compare the significant life-threatening iatrogenic injuries caused by mechanical CPR versus manual CPR via a meta-analysis of studies. 

Methods: A systematic review of PubMed and Embase was performed according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines. All studies published after January 1st, 2009 were reviewed using inclusion/exclusion criteria and completed by January 1st, 2020. A total of 1,814 patients were enrolled in 7 studies were included in our meta-analysis.

Results: It was found that significant life-threatening iatrogenic injuries had a higher odds ratio when mechanical CPR was used rather than manual CPR. Chest wall fractures had the highest prevalence rate (55.7%), followed by lung injuries (3.7%), and then liver (1.0%) and diaphragm (0.2%) lacerations. Manual CPR in-hospital patients had a higher odds ratio for risk of mortality.

Conclusion: Mechanical CPR led to more injuries as compared to manual CPR. The opposite trend was seen for mortality rate. Further research on evaluating the appropriateness of when to use mechanical CPR in comparison to manual CPR is important in determining impacts of patients receiving CPR.

abstract_title: Prospective Testing of the Abdominal Hernia-Q: Reliability, Burden, and Longitudinal Validity
author_block: V. Patel<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Chrstopher<sup>1</sup>, M. P. Morris<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Cunning<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Rios-Diaz<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Nathan<sup>1</sup>, C. B. Whitely<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Messa<sup>1</sup>, R. B. Broach<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Fischer<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Our group previously developed and validated the Abdominal Hernia-Q (AHQ) patient-reported outcomes instrument, as a means to measure the disease burden associated with ventral hernia repair (VHR). Here, we aim to further establish the AHQ as a useful clinical tool for surgeons, by demonstrating its inter-test reliability, low patient burden and ability to capture long term changes in quality of life (QoL) after VHR.

Methods: For the patient burden and test-retest portion of the study, VHR patients were prospectively identified and manually timed completing the AHQ. A subset of these patients, were then re-sent the AHQ, and asked to complete it again, to measure its reliability in a rest-test methodology. Demographics were abstracted from the medical record, and Kruskal Wallis tests were used to assess differences in patient burden based on demographics. Another set of patients who underwent VHR, were tested both pre- and post-operatively using the AHQ, HerQles and Short-Form 12 (SF-12), up to over 13.5 months after surgery. QoL scores from the different surveys were correlated and Wilcoxon Rank Sum tests were used to determine changes in QoL after VHR.

Results: A 419 AHQ surveys (209 pre-operative and 210 post-operative) were assessed for patient burden. The AHQ demonstrated low patient burden, with median time to completion of 1.1 and 2.7 minutes, for the pre-operative and the longer post-operative instrument, respectively. The elderly (>65 years) took significantly longer to complete both the pre- and post-operative instruments (p =0.04, 0.002), but there were no differences in patient burden based on race, ethnicity, or socioeconomic status. For the post-operative instrument, the use of an iPad significantly reduced patient burden, when compared to a paper survey (2.5 vs 3.0 minutes, p= 0.005). In test-retesting, the AHQ showed high reliability, with significant correlations for all questions, and excellent reliability coefficients for both pre-operative and post-operative instruments (r= 0.91, 0.89). 106 patients were included in the longitudinal portion of the study. Median AHQ QoL scores significantly improved one-month after VHR (pre 52 vs. post 83, p<0.001), and were not significantly changed twelve months after surgery (92, p=0.86). The AHQ was significantly correlated with 6/7 (86%) times points of HerQles and SF-12 PS and 5/7 (71%) SF12-MS time points, ranging from pre-operative to over 13.5 months after VHR (Figure 1).

Conclusion: The AHQ is a valuable clinical tool for any surgeon treating patients with VH. We have shown that it has low patient burden, excellent inter-test reliability, and can effectively capture hernia related QoL information over a year after VHR.

abstract_title: The Impact of a Structured Prehabilitation Program on Patient-Reported Outcomes After Surgery
author_block: M. H. Purdy<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Anidi<sup>1</sup>, P. R. Martin<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Muzaurieta<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Englesbe<sup>1,2</sup>, V. Gunaseelan<sup>2</sup>, R. A. Howard<sup>2</sup>, J. F. Waljee<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Hallway<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Prehabilitation, or optimizing individual patient risk factors prior to surgery, has the potential to improve postoperative outcomes. Prior studies have demonstrated reduction in complications and healthcare costs. However, the impact of prehabilitation on patient-reported outcomes is unknown, and patient experiences may not align with clinical measures of value. We evaluated the association of participation in a structured prehabilitation program with patient-reported outcomes after surgery.

Methods:  We conducted a retrospective study of patients who participated in prehabilitation and underwent abdominal surgery, thoracic surgery, or hysterectomy between 2014 and 2019 at a tertiary medical center. The prehabilitation program engaged patients in four daily exercises prior to surgery: physical activity, pulmonary rehabilitation, nutritional optimization, and stress reduction. We used propensity score weighting to control for confounders, including age, sex, race/ethnicity, operation, Charlson comorbidity score, marital status, education, and occupation. Average treatment effect (ATE) was then calculated for composite patient-reported outcome scores collected one month postoperatively in the following areas: physical function, life satisfaction, pain, anxiety, and depression.

Results: A total of 116 patients who participated in prehabilitation and 528 propensity-weighted control patients were included in the analysis. Mean (SD) age was 52 (14) years and 607 (78%) patients were female. Both groups reported low levels of pain, depression, and anxiety, and high satisfaction (Table 1). After propensity weighting, compared to controls, prehabilitation patients had no significant difference in patient-reported outcomes measuring physical function (ATE=-0.253, P=0.559), life satisfaction (ATE=-0.232, P=0.305), Michigan Body Map Score (ATE= -0.092, P=0.701), pain severity (ATE=0.108, P=0.658), anxiety (ATE=0.184, P=0.525), or depression (ATE=0.169, P=0.487) at one month after surgery.

Conclusion: Prehabilitation did not result in significant differences in aspects of patient-reported postoperative quality of life. Though prehabilitation may improve objective outcomes, opportunities exist to design surgical prehabilitation programs that will optimize patient-reported outcomes that are critical to recovery. Future studies could explore the modification of prehabilitation programs to improve patient-reported outcomes, which may compound the benefits of these programs for patients.

abstract_title: Patient-Reported Outcomes After Opioid-Sparing Surgery Compared to Standard of Care
author_block: R. Howard<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Hallway<sup>2</sup>, M. Yoshida<sup>2</sup>, M. Anderson<sup>1</sup>, C. Brummett<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Waljee<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Englesbe<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Opioid Prescribing and Engagement Network,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Opioid-sparing postoperative recovery pathways have been shown to be well-tolerated by patients and may significantly reduce the risk of opioid-related morbidity. To date, however, there has been no comparison of patient-reported outcomes between novel opioid-sparing recovery pathways and standard of care.

Methods:  We compared prospectively collected data from patients participating in an opioid-sparing postoperative pathway with patients who received standard of care from 2018-2019. Surgical procedures included laparoscopic cholecystectomy, inguinal and umbilical hernia repair, and thyroidectomy/parathyroidectomy. Patients who participated in the opioid-sparing pathway at a single institution received preoperative counseling to use non-opioid analgesics as their primary method of pain control and were provided with a small “rescue” prescription of no more than 10 opioid pills for breakthrough pain. Patients who received standard of care were sampled from a collaborative of 73 hospitals in Michigan. Patients were contacted between postoperative days 30-90 to complete follow-up surveys. Outcomes included number of opioid pills prescribed, number of opioid pills taken, pain score in the 7 days after surgery (0=no pain, 1=minimal pain, 2=moderate pain, 3=severe pain), satisfaction (scale 0=extremely dissatisfied, 10=extremely satisfied), regret (scale 1=absolutely regret surgery, 5=absolutely no regret), and quality of life (scale 1=terrible quality of life, 5=excellent quality of life).

Results: During the study period, 321 patients participated in an opioid-sparing pathway and 2474 patients received standard of care and responded to a postoperative follow-up survey. Mean (SD) age was 55 (15) years old and 51% of patients were female. Patients in the opioid-sparing pathway received smaller prescriptions, used fewer pills, and reported similar pain scores compared to patients who received standard of care (Table 1). There were no significant differences in satisfaction, regret, or quality of life scores between the two groups.

Conclusion: Compared to patients receiving standard of care, patients who participated in an opioid-sparing recovery pathway received and used fewer opioids but reported similar satisfaction and pain control. Expanding this strategy to other surgical procedures may be an effective way to reduce opioid-related morbidity after surgery without compromising the patient experience.

abstract_title: Increased Morbidity after Cholecystectomy without Pre-Op MRCP or ERCP for Suspected CBD Stones
author_block: A. C. Cioci<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Urrechaga<sup>1</sup>, K. Abdul Jawad<sup>1</sup>, H. J. Quiroz<sup>1</sup>, K. D. Rakoczy<sup>2</sup>, Y. M. Rodriguez<sup>2</sup>, L. R. Barda<sup>1</sup>, G. D. Pust<sup>1</sup>, R. Rattan<sup>1</sup>, E. Q. Ginzburg<sup>1</sup>, N. Namias<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Yeh<sup>1</sup>, R. B. Gelbard<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami,DeWitt-Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery Divison Of Trauma, Critical Care, And Burns,Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami,Miller School Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma/Critical Care,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The optimal workup and management of a patient with suspected common bile duct stones remains controversial. The purpose of this study was to compare outcomes between patients undergoing magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP), endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), and cholecystectomy (CCY) ± intraoperative cholangiogram (IOC). 

Methods: We performed a post-hoc analysis of a multicenter, prospective study of patients with suspected common bile duct stones from 2016-2019. Patients were grouped according to initial study/treatment (MRCP vs ERCP vs CCY±IOC). Pairwise propensity score matching was performed to control for probability of retained common bile duct (CBD) stones. Clinical factors, management strategies, and outcomes, which included a composite endpoint (30-day readmission, any Clavien-Dindo complication, and mortality), were compared between matched groups.  

Results: Of the 989 subjects included for analysis, 308 (31%) underwent MRCP, 261 (27%) underwent ERCP, and 420 (42%) were taken for CCY without further pre-operative assessment. IOC was performed in 253 (60%) of CCY subjects. Total bilirubin (mg/dl) was significantly higher in ERCP (2.8 [1.7-4.6]) compared to MRCP (2.2 [1.2-3.6]) or CCY subjects (1.3 [0.7-2.4], p<0.001). CBD diameter (cm) was similar between ERCP (0.9±0.2) and MRCP (0.9±0.3) but was significantly lower in those proceeding directly to CCY (0.8±0.3, p<.001). Propensity scores were generated and 1:1 matching was performed to create three pairwise matched cohorts: MRCP vs ERCP (n=430), MRCP vs CCY (n=528), and ERCP vs CCY (n=430). The presence of CBD stones was significantly higher in ERCP compared to MRCP (83% vs 42%, p<0.001) or CCY subjects (83% vs 29%, p<.001). Post-operative ERCP was performed more frequently in CCY compared to MRCP (22% vs 6%, p<.001) or ERCP subjects (23% vs 2%, p<.001). The rate of retained CBD stones, as determined by the presence of stones on post-operative ERCP, was higher for CCY compared to MRCP (18% vs 6%, p<0.001) or ERCP subjects (20% vs 2%, p<.001), and in MRCP compared to ERCP subjects (6% vs 2%, p=.04). The incidence of the composite endpoint was significantly higher in CCY compared to both MRCP (37% vs 26%, p=.01) and ERCP subjects (38% vs 17%, p<.001); there was no significant difference in this composite endpoint between MRCP and ERCP (25% vs 17%, p=.08). 

Conclusion: In modern clinical practice in the United States, proceeding directly to cholecystectomy ± intraoperative cholangiogram in patients with suspected common bile duct stones is common.
