However, the incidence of retained CBD stones is 20% and post-operative ERCP is commonly required. Compared to ERCP and MRCP, CCY (IOC) is least successful at detecting and clearing CBD stones and is associated with overall worse outcomes at 30 days.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Laparoscopic vs Open Repair of Perforated Peptic Ulcers: an ACS-NSQIP Study
author_block: R. Allen<sup>1</sup>, S. Jayaraman<sup>1</sup>, C. B. Feather<sup>1</sup>, J. Turcotte<sup>1</sup>, J. Klune<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Anne Arundel Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Annapolis, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Perforated peptic ulcer (PPU) is a surgical emergency that necessitates swift operative resolution.  Repair can be performed either laparoscopically or open, though laparoscopic repair has historically accounted for a small number. We use the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database to compare perioperative and 30-day postoperative (30POP) outcomes of open and laparoscopic repair of PPUs. 

Methods: The 2016-2018 ACS-NSQIP database was used to create the patient cohort, using ICD-10 and procedure (CPT) codes. An unmatched analysis was performed to identify factors that likely contributed to the laparoscopic vs open treatment allocation. Propensity score matching (PSM) was then used to reduce confounding and identify outcomes that were not explained by the underlying differences in the patient cohorts.

Results: A total of 3375 patients were included in the study: 3135 patients in the open group (OG) and 340 (~10%) in the laparoscopic group (LG). The use of laparoscopy remained the same at 10%, 9.7% and 9.7% of repairs during 2016, 2017 and 2018 respectively. In this complete study cohort, septic shock was present in 10.5% of patients in OG, and 4.4% in LG (p<0.001). Patients in OG were older, more likely to be male, be functionally dependent, have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), ascites, hypertension, acute renal failure (ARF), and weight loss (p < 0.05 for all). Patients in OG were also more likely to be American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Class 4 or 5 (31% vs 18%, p < 0.001). There was no difference in ulcer location (gastric vs duodenal) between groups. After PSM to control for comorbidities and illness severity that differed between groups on univariate analysis, 288 patients remained in each group; no significant differences in comorbidity burden or illness severity remained after matching. ASA, which was held out of the PSM to assess cohort balance, was also equivalent after matching. Analysis of the matched cohorts revealed that there is no statistically significant difference in in-hospital mortality when comparing OG (5.9%) and LG (3.8%) repairs of PPUs (p=0.245). The LG was associated with significantly longer operative times (92 vs 79 min, p = 0.003), shorter lengths of stay (8.2 vs 9.4 days, p = 0.044) and a higher probability of being discharged home (81% vs 73%, p = 0.017). Outcomes in the 30POP were largely equivalent, except that OG still carried a higher risk for bleeding (14.6% vs 8%, p = 0.012) and pneumonia (8.7% vs 4.5%, p = 0.044). 

Conclusion: While laparoscopic repairs take longer, they lead to shorter hospital stays and higher likelihood of discharge home. There is no difference in in-hospital mortality between open and laparoscopic repair. However, there has not been an increased adoption of this technique over time.  Further study to identify patients that are candidates for this technique is warranted.

abstract_title: Outcomes Following Cholecystectomy: Can Chief Residents Provide Care Equivalent to Their Attendings?
author_block: H. E. Werenski<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Bosley<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Powell<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Meredith<sup>1</sup>, R. W. Randle<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine,Department Of General Surgery,Winston-Salem, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cholecystectomy is a core procedure for general surgeons, but it is unclear if graduating residents can manage patients with gallbladder disease to achieve outcomes equivalent to those of faculty surgeons. The Chairman’s service is designed to provide chief residents with an attending supervised opportunity to maximize responsibility and continuity and feel the pressure that responsible surgeons experience. They evaluate patients in their own clinic, determine surgical candidacy, schedule operations, and direct post-operative care. In the operating room, supervised chiefs perform the operation using their preferred approach and techniques rather than adapt the approach to satisfy the attending’s preferences. We compared outcomes and complications of cholecystectomy performed on the Chairman’s service to those performed on standard services where faculty direct most decision making.

Methods: We matched adults undergoing cholecystectomy from July, 2016 through June, 2019 on the Chairman’s service 1:2 to standard service patients based on indication (primary ICD-10) and age (within 10 years). We compared patients, operative details, outcomes, and complications.

Results: The study included 186 cholecystectomies; the primary indication was most often cholelithiasis (90.3%). Chairman’s service patients were slightly younger (42.2 years vs 48.8, p<0.01) and healthier (mean Charlson Comorbidity Index 0.9 vs 1.4, p=0.16) than standard service patients. Operative approach was similar (open 4.8% vs 2.4%, laparoscopic 95.2% vs 94.4%, and conversions 0.0% vs 3.2%, p=0.14) between the Chairman’s and standard services, respectively. Residents on the Chairman’s service were more likely to perform a cholangiogram (48.4% vs 22.6%, p<0.01) and have longer operative times during laparoscopic cholecystectomy both with cholangiogram (146±28 min vs 85±22, p<0.01) and without (94±31 min vs 76±35, p<0.01) compared to the standard service. Post-op complication rates were similar (5.2% Chairman’s vs 5.0% standard, p=0.95) which included surgical site infection, hematoma, hernia, retained stones and intraoperative injury. No patients suffered bile leak, bile duct injury, or reoperation. Despite a higher proportion of same-day discharges on the Chairman’s service (90.3% vs 70.2%, p<0.01), post-op ED visits were similar (12.1% Chairman’s vs 7.4% standard, p=0.32), and readmissions were less frequent (0.0% Chairman’s vs 5% standard, p=0.03).

Conclusion: With appropriate supervision, chief residents provide safe care for patients undergoing cholecystectomy even when they are directing medical decisions and practicing according to their preferences. Longer operative times and a higher proportion of cholangiograms performed on the Chairman’s service may indicate a more cautious intraoperative approach appropriate for younger surgeons, but Chairman’s service patients were no more likely to experience complications or be readmitted than those on standard services.

abstract_title: The Association of Non-Opioid Analgesic Prescriptions with Patient Reported Outcomes
author_block: A. Hallway<sup>2</sup>, M. Yoshida<sup>2</sup>, J. Waljee<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Brummett<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Englesbe<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Howard<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Opioid Prescribing Engagement Network,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is now widely recognized that opioids have long been overprescribed after surgery. To combat this, surgeons around the US are now discharging patients with much smaller prescriptions and instructions to use non-opioid alternatives. However, it is unclear whether there is any difference in patient-reported outcomes between simply recommending non-opioid analgesic medications and prescribing them.

Methods: Patients undergoing 6 common surgical procedures at our institution participated in an opioid-sparing pain management pathway between February 1, 2018 to April 30, 2019. Patients were given in-depth preoperative counseling regarding safe use and risks of opioids, advised to use non-opioid medications such as acetaminophen and ibuprofen for primary pain control, and provided with a small rescue prescription of oxycodone 5 mg for breakthrough pain. While all patients were advised to use non-opioids, due to variation in practice, some patients actually received prescriptions for one or both of these medications in their discharge paperwork. Patient-reported outcomes and opioid use were surveyed postoperatively. Satisfaction was measured on a scale of 0-10 and pain was reported on a scale of 0 (none), 1 (minimal), 2 (moderate), and 3 (severe). Student’s t-test and Chi-squared analyses were used to compare patient-reported outcomes in patients who received a non-opioid analgesic prescription and those who did not.

Results: A total of 418 patients participated in the opioid sparing pathway during the study period. Mean (SD) age was 55 (14) and 66% of patients were male. 251 (60%) patients received a prescription for a non-opioid while 167 (40%) did not. Patients who received a prescription used fewer opioids (1.8±2.5 vs. 2.4±3.0 pills, p<0.019) and reported lower pain scores in the week after surgery (1.2±0.8 vs. 1.5±0.7, p<0.002). Patients who received a prescription also reported higher satisfaction (9.1±1.4 vs. 8.8±1.7, p<0.049) and were more likely to report that their pain was manageable with an opioid-sparing recovery pathway (94% vs. 87%, p<0.019). The proportion of patients who reported using non-opioid analgesic medications was not different between the two groups (83% vs. 85%, P=0.575).

Conclusion: Patients participating in an opioid-sparing pathway after surgery reported less opioid use, higher satisfaction, and lower pain scores if they received a prescription for a non-opioid pain medication compared to receiving only counseling to use non-opioids. While all patients should be encouraged to utilize multimodal analgesia after surgery, prescribing non-opioid pain medication has a greater impact on the patient experience than counseling alone.

abstract_title: Is Same-Day Discharge After Laparoscopic Appendectomy Safe?
author_block: E. M. Urrechaga<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Cioci<sup>1</sup>, J. Parreco<sup>2</sup>, K. Abdul Jawad<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Saberi<sup>1</sup>, G. P. Gilna<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Yeh<sup>1</sup>, N. Namias<sup>1</sup>, R. Rattan<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami,Division Of Trauma Surgery & Critical Care,Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Lawnwood Regional Medical Center,Department Of Trauma,Fort Pierce, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous single-center studies have shown that same day discharge (SDD) after laparoscopic appendectomy is safe in well-selected adults. We sought to determine the safety of SDD after appendectomy in adults using the metric of readmission rate in a sample that is both nationally representative and also captures readmissions to a different hospital. 

Methods: The 2010-2014 Nationwide Readmissions Database (NRD) was queried for adults ≥18 years admitted with uncomplicated acute appendicitis who underwent laparoscopic appendectomy. Subjects were stratified into SDD or discharge after one night of observation in the hospital (OBS) groups. Those who died on index admission or were hospitalized >1 day were excluded. Demographics, comorbidities, and hospital characteristics were evaluated. The primary outcome of interest was 30-day non-elective readmission. Univariable analysis identified factors associated with readmission, and multivariable logistic regression identified significant predictors of outcomes.

Results: There were 322,576 subjects identified: 154,028 (48%) were female with a mean age of 36.8 (±15) years. Of these, 32,857 (10%) patients were SDD and 289,719 (90%) were OBS. In unadjusted analyses, OBS patients tended to be older (Age 45-64, 23.4% vs 18.9% and Age ≥65, 5.7% vs 3.9%, p<0.001) and have more comorbidities, including pulmonary disease (6.3% vs 5.8%, p<0.001), diabetes (4.2% vs 3.4%, p<0.001), and hypertension (14.4% vs 11%, p<0.001). However, only age ≥45 years (45-64y OR 1.29 [1.25-1.33]; ≥65y OR 1.51 [1.38-1.65]) and hypertension (OR 1.18 [1.13-1.23]) remained independently associated with OBS on adjusted analysis.  The 30-day unplanned readmission rate was 2% (n=7,001). After controlling for covariates, SDD had a lower odds of readmission compared to OBS (OR 0.84 [0.78-0.92]). Risk factors for 30-day readmission overall included age (45-64y OR 1.43 [1.35-1.52]; ≥65y OR 1.17 [1.03-1.34]) and co-morbidities (hypertension OR 1.33 [1.24-1.42]; diabetes OR 1.16 [1.02-1.32]). The sole distinct risk factor associated with failure of SDD, as measured by 30-day readmission, was the presence of obesity (OR 1.7 [1.31-2.21]).

Conclusion: Same-day discharge after laparoscopic appendectomy for uncomplicated appendicitis is not associated with increased odds of non-elective readmission at 30 days. Age and comorbidities are predictors of readmission. Further study is needed to identify the ideal candidates for safe same-day discharge.

abstract_title: Use of Patient-Reported Outcomes to Predict Preoperative Frailty
author_block: R. C. Tang<sup>1</sup>, M. C. Chia<sup>1</sup>, B. Yu<sup>1</sup>, C. D. Etkin<sup>1</sup>, R. Huang<sup>1</sup>, J. Stulberg<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Surgical Outcomes & Quality Improvement Center,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Frail patients undergoing surgery face increased risk of perioperative complications and death. The American College of Surgeons and the American Geriatrics Society recommend use of a validated frailty assessment for all surgical patients ≥65 years of age, comprising 53% of over 103 million procedures in the US per year. However, many frailty metrics require in-person evaluation and specialized training. Our objective was to validate the predictive ability of a survey instrument to screen for preoperative frailty.?

Methods: Data were obtained retrospectively from the electronic health record (EHR) of a large urban hospital from 2018-19. Patients undergoing colorectal or general surgery procedures age 65+ were included for analysis. Frailty assessments were performed in the preoperative clinic using the Fried Phenotype. Scores of Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) instruments for fatigue and physical function were abstracted from the EHR. Patient demographics were categorized using the Charlson Comorbidity Index. Bivariate analysis was performed using Wilcoxon rank-sum, Fischer’s exact, and two-sample t-tests. Predictive ability of PROMIS scores was assessed using receiver-operating characteristic curves with cutoffs assigned by metric performance.

Results: A total of 158 patients met study criteria, with 28 (17.7%) prefrail, 5 (3.2%) frail. All frail patients had PROMIS – Fatigue scores >47 and PROMIS – Physical Function scores <41. The cohort had 87 (55.1%) female patients, of which 15 (17.2%) were prefrail/frail compared to 18 of 71 (25.4%) male patients (p = 0.241). Median Charlson scores of prefrail/frail patients were similar compared to those of non-frail patients (p = 0.724). The mean PROMIS - Fatigue score was higher for prefrail/frail patients than non-frail patients (52.5, SD 8.5 versus 48.4, SD 6.8; p = 0.006). The mean PROMIS - Physical Function score was lower for prefrail/frail patients than non-frail patients (41.4, SD 6.9 vs 48.4, SD 8.1; p < 0.001). A PROMIS - Fatigue score cutoff of >47 predicted frailty with 76% sensitivity and 34% specificity. A PROMIS - Physical Function score cutoff of <44 predicted frailty with 71% sensitivity and 69% specificity. 

Conclusion: Our analysis found that PROMIS scores were associated with preoperative frailty status in older patients undergoing colorectal and general surgery. Scores were sensitive to predict frailty status but were limited by low specificity. PROMIS instruments may have a role in screening patients for frailty in advance of in-person evaluation to decrease provider and patient burden, and future work may be used to validate these metrics in a broader surgical population.

abstract_title: Sternal Fractures in their Entirety
author_block: T. Dickhudt<sup>1</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>2,3</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>2,3</sup>, R. Grady<sup>2,3</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>2,3</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,3</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>2,3</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The sternum is the keystone of the sternal-rib-vertebral complex, which is integral to thoracic cage stability. This study’s aim was to evaluate the injury characteristics and outcomes in patients with all types of sternal fractures (SF) after blunt chest trauma.

Methods: This retrospective chart review study included 404 patients admitted to two level 1 trauma centers between January 2015 and March 2020 with radiologically confirmed SF. Primary stratification was based on presence of concomitant rib, vertebral, clavicular, or scapular fracture. Analyzed variables included: age, gender, mechanism of injury (MOI), injury severity score (ISS), incidence of traumatic brain injury (TBI), need for blood transfusion, need for mechanical ventilation (including tracheostomy), intensive care unit (ICU) admission, ICU length of stay (ICULOS), hospital LOS (HLOS), rates of surgical stabilization, complications, and mortality.

Results: Isolated SF (ISF) were present in 33.9% (n=134) of patients and sternal fractures with concomitant fractures of bony structures (CSF) were present in 66.1% of analyzed patients (n=270). The primary MOI in both groups was motor vehicle accident (82% in both groups). Compared to ISF patients, CSF patients had significantly higher ISS (9.3 vs 15.8), TBI incidence (8.2% vs 15.6%), ventilation requirements (11.9% vs 29.3%), tracheostomy rates (3.0% vs 9.3%), ICULOS (4.1 vs 7.9 days), HLOS (7.6 vs 11.1 days), complications (11.9% vs 26.3%), and mortality (0.7% vs 11.9%), all p<0.004. CSF with rib fracture (CSF-R) was the most frequent CSF pattern (21.5% incidence), followed by CSF with vertebral fracture (CSF-V, 17.8% incidence), and CSF with both vertebral and rib fracture (CSF-RV, 15.6% incidence) [Figure 1]. CSF-V and CSF-R had similar characteristics except CSF-R were more likely to have a pulmonary co-injury. CSF-RV had higher ISS, need for blood transfusion, ventilation requirements, and ICU admission than CSF-V or CSF-R. CSF with clavicular fracture (CSF-C) had greater ISS, pneumo-hemothorax, and TBI incidence when compared to CSF-R and CSF-V (all p<0.002). CSF-C with ipsilateral rib fractures were associated with greater thoracic instability, leading to greater need for surgical stabilization, morbidity, and mortality. Compared to other CSF subgroups, CSF with scapular fracture did not have worse characteristics or outcomes.

Conclusion: Combined SF comprise two-thirds of all SF and are most often combined with rib or vertebral fractures. Isolated SF are generally nonthreatening and are often managed without surgical intervention, while combined SF may lead to destabilization of the chest wall, necessitate surgical stabilization more often, and are a predictor of increased mortality.

abstract_title: Age Is But A Number: Damage Control Laparotomy Outcomes In Geriatric Emergency General Surgery
author_block: S. Iacono<sup>1</sup>, A. Niroomand<sup>1</sup>, N. Krumrei<sup>1</sup>, D. Walls<sup>1</sup>, M. Lissauer<sup>1</sup>, J. To<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Butts<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rutgers Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital,Division Of Acute Care Surgery, Department Of Surgery,New Brunswick, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Damage control laparotomy (DCL) with associated temporary abdominal closure has been increasingly utilized in non-trauma emergency general surgery (EGS). As the population ages, geriatric patients are undergoing EGS operations with increased frequency. Concern exists for their ability to tolerate DCL. We hypothesize that DCL in geriatric EGS does not increase morbidity or mortality and has similar rates of primary closure when compared to a younger cohort.

Methods: A retrospective chart review from 2015-2020 was conducted at a Level 1 trauma center on all non-trauma EGS patients who underwent DCL with an open abdomen. Demographics, admission lab values, blood product and fluid amounts, length of stay(LOS), rate and time of closure, number of operations, complications, and mortality was collected. Patients aged <65 were compared with those ≥65. Results were analyzed using Chi square and Wilcox signed rank test.

Results: 98 patients (n=50 <65 years; n=48 ≥65 years) met inclusion criteria. There was no significant difference in median number of operations (3 vs 2; p=0.07), time to primary closure (2.5 days vs. 3 days; p=0.45), hospital LOS (19 days vs 17.5 days; p=0.53), ICU LOS (11 days vs 8 days; p=0.33), ventilator days (6.5 days vs 5 days; p=0.56), rate of primary closure (66 % vs 56%; p=0.32), post op ileus(44% vs 48%; p=0.70), abscess (14% vs 10%; p=0.59), need for surgery after closure (32% vs 19%, p=0.14), anastomotic dehiscence (16% vs 6%; p=0.13), or mortality (34% vs 42%; p=0.43). Average time to initial take back did not vary significantly between both groups (45.8hrs vs 38.5 hrs; p=0.88).  Patients ≥65 were more likely to have hypertension (50% vs 83%; p< 0.05) or atrial fibrillation (4% vs 25%; p<0.05). There was no difference in reason for open abdomen (p=0.33), presenting vital signs or lab values. Initial SOFA score was similar for both groups(p=0.75).

Conclusion: DCL with temporary abdominal closure in geriatric EGS patients achieves similar outcomes and mortality to younger patients. Indication, not age, should factor into the decision to perform DCL.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Barrier Coated Versus Uncoated Polypropylene Mesh in Open Abdominal Wall Reconstruction
author_block: S. A. Ayuso<sup>1</sup>, E. B. Deerenberg<sup>1</sup>, T. Prasad<sup>1</sup>, K. W. Kent<sup>1</sup>, V. A. Augenstein<sup>1</sup>, B. T. Heniford<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Carolinas Medical Center,GI & Minimally Invasive Surgery,Charlotte, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Barrier coated meshes were designed to reduce adhesion formation between mesh and the surrounding viscera. Coated mesh has, however, also been purported to have a prolonged inflammatory response and to pose an increased risk of infection compared to uncoated mesh. The objective of this study is to determine if a difference exists in postoperative infection or complication rates between coated and uncoated mesh in patients with CDC Class 1 and 2 wounds.

Methods: A prospective, institutional database at a tertiary hernia center identified patients undergoing open preperitoneal ventral hernia repair (OPPVHR) with polypropylene mesh who had CDC class 1 and 2 wounds. Using propensity score matching, a coated and uncoated group were matched based on age, BMI, comorbidities, CDC wound class, and defect size.

Results: There were 273 patients each in the matched coated and uncoated mesh groups for a total of 546 patients. Patient characteristics for the coated vs uncoated mesh were similar: average age 57.1±12.5 vs 58.0±12.8 (p=0.26), BMI 33.9±7.5 vs 33.8±7.4 kg/m2 (p=0.77), smoking 15.0% vs 14.6% (p=1.00), diabetes 25.6% vs. 24.5% (p=0.85), CDC Class 1 93.8% vs 94.9% and CDC Class 2 6.2% vs 5.1% (p =0.71), defect size 200.6±194.3.4 vs 203.7±173.8 cm2 (p=0.99), and mesh size 258.67 vs 283.56 cm2 (p=0.06). The incidence of panniculectomy (33.8% vs 29.1%, p=0.36) was similar, but the coated group had a lower rate of component separation (37.4% vs 51.1%,p<0.01). The coated meshes that were included in this analysis were Ventralight (79.1%) and Proceed (20.9%). The noncoated meshes used were Prolene (66.7%), Bard Soft (23.0%), Prolite (5.5%), and Marlex (4.8%). Overall wound infection rate was significantly higher for the coated mesh group (9.5% vs 4.9%, p=0.04) as were wound dehiscence (5.0% vs 0.8%, p<0.01) and need for IV antibiotics (10.7% vs 4.6%,p=0.01). There was no significant difference in mesh infection (1.9% vs .4%, p=0.12) or intra-abdominal abscess formation (1.3% vs 1.3%, p=1.00). Those patients with coated mesh who developed a wound infection did not have a higher relative rate of reintervention (need for wound vac, drain placement, or re-exploration) compared to the uncoated group (8.4% vs 4.8%, p=0.79). Of the patients with coated mesh who developed a wound 68% had Ventralight mesh and 32% had Proceed mesh. For the patients with wound infections in the uncoated group, 76.9% were Prolene, 7.7% were Prolite, and 5.4% were Bard Soft. Only one patient with a wound infection was from CDC Class 2.

Conclusion: In CDC Class 1 and 2 wounds, the operations in which coated polypropylene mesh was deployed had a significantly higher rate of overall wound complications; however, despite this, there was no increase in mesh infection when compared to uncoated mesh. Coated polypropylene mesh can be used safely in open VHR with no increase in mesh-related complications.

abstract_title: Patient Reported Experience on Consenting for Surgery – Elective versus Emergency Patients
author_block: D. Maher<sup>1</sup>, J. Serpell<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Lee<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Alfred Health,Monash University Endocrine Surgery Unit,Melbourne, VICTORIA, Australia <sup>2</sup>Monash University,Department Of Surgery,Melbourne, VICTORIA, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Informed consent for surgery is a medical and legal requirement, but satisfying these does not necessarily translate to high patient satisfaction. This patient-reported experience study aimed to examine the surgical consent process, comparing the patients’ experience in elective and emergency settings.

Methods:  Postoperative patients from January 1st to July 31st 2020 were invited to participate in a survey on the surgical consent process – including perceived priorities, information provided, and overall experience. Included elective cases were breast and endocrine procedures; emergency procedures were appendicectomy, cholecystectomy, trauma laparotomy, abscess drainage and repair of incarcerated or strangulated hernias. Incomplete surveys were discarded. Standard statistical techniques were used, with a significant p-value of < 0.05.

Results: A total of 257 patients were invited, with 75 (29 %) completed responses. More patients underwent elective surgery (N = 46, 61 %; 54 % male; mean age 53 ± 17 years) than emergency surgery (N = 29, 39 %; 45 % male; mean age 39 ± 17 years). Emergency patients were more likely to sign the consent form regardless of its contents (93 % vs 52 %, p < 0.001) and more likely to be influenced by external pressures (69 % vs 2 %, p < 0.001), such as pain (55 %), analgesia (45 %) and fatigue (38 %). Elective patients were more likely to want to discuss their surgery with a senior surgeon (65 % vs 24 %, p = 0.001) and more likely to seek advice from external sources (76 % vs 14 %, p < 0.001). Elective patients sought advice from sources such as their family doctor (77 %), the internet (57 %) and family members (29 %), whereas Emergency patients universally used the internet to source additional information (100 %), if at all. The majority of elective and emergency patients had confidence in the information provided (98 % vs 93 %, p = 0.55), had the opportunity to ask questions (100 % vs 90 %, p = 0.55) and were satisfied with the consent process (100 % vs 90 %, p = 0.55). When asked to prioritise statements surrounding their consent experience, the top 3 priorities were: the ability to ask questions (61 %), meeting the operating surgeon (44 %), and details of the expected post-operative course (44 %).

Conclusion: This study shows patients have a range of different priorities in preparation for surgery. Therefore, each consent process should be tailored and patient-focused. Emergency patients are significantly more likely to perceive their decision is impaired and would give consent regardless of the information provided; while elective patients put more emphasis on sourcing additional information. Most patients value meeting the treating surgeon and the opportunity to ask questions.

abstract_title: Recurrence not Increased with Absorbable Mesh in Clean Contaminated, Contaminated and Infected Hernia
author_block: M. Nisiewicz<sup>1</sup>, V. Wagner<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Plymale<sup>1</sup>, A. Bettis<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Davenport<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Roth<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Kentucky,General Surgery/Surgery/Medicine,Lexington, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Given the frequency of incisional hernia following laparotomy and the complications associated with hernia repair, materials to serve as alternatives to permanent, synthetic mesh have been developed with the goal of optimizing repair. Despite unique features, wound contamination remains a distinct challenge with all mesh materials. The purpose of this study was to compare absorbable  mesh hernia repair outcomes in relation to wound contamination [clean (I) vs contaminated (II-IV)].

Methods: With IRB approval, databases were searched to identify all cases of open ventral hernia repair with absorbable mesh implant performed at an academic medical center from 2013 to 2017. Local NSQIP data was utilized for patient demographics, perioperative characteristics, CDC Wound Class, comorbidities, and preoperative lab values. Variables obtained via electronic medical record review included hernia defect size, mesh size, postoperative wound events to six months, length of all follow up, and incidence of hernia recurrence. Fisher’s Exact Test, Pearson’s Chi Square, independent t-test, and Mann-Whitney U test were used as appropriate for data analyses. Statistical significance was set at p<0.05.

Results: 112 cases meeting inclusion criteria were identified, 76 patients with CDC Wound Class I,  36 in CDC Wound Class II-IV. Both cohorts were comparable in baseline characteristics, risk factors and comorbidities, excluding diabetes (33.3% vs 15.8%, p=0.048), prior hernia repair (61.1% vs 34.2%, p=0.009) and parastomal hernia (44.4% vs 3.9%, p<0.001) for classes II-IV and I, respectively. Preoperative laboratory values did not vary between groups. Wound Class II-IV expressed greater lengths of hospital stay, emergent/urgent presentation (p=.03), requirement of bowel resection as part of surgical procedure (p<0.001), mesh size implanted (p =0.04), surgical site infection (excluding deep infection), and wound disruption (p-values <0.05). Correspondingly, higher wound class was associated with increased need for hospital readmission (38.9% vs 11.8%, p=0.002). Despite higher rates of complications, cohorts did not differ in the frequency of hernia recurrence (8.3% for Wound Class I vs 5.3% for Wound Class II-IV, p=0.679).

Conclusion: Absorbable mesh repair patients with contaminated wounds exhibited more emergent presentations, more often requiring bowel resection, readmission, and increased mesh size compared to patients with clean wounds. Despite these differences, absorbable mesh is effective in minimizing hernia recurrence regardless of wound classification.

abstract_title: The Obesity Paradox: Underweight Patients are at Greatest Risk of Mortality Following Cholecystectomy
author_block: S. E. Rudasill<sup>1</sup>, K. Karunungan<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Mardock<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While elevated body mass index (BMI) is a risk factor for the development of gallstone disease, it has also been associated with inferior outcomes following cholecystectomy. Given the controversy regarding the perioperative impact of obesity, we examined the effect of BMI on postoperative morbidity and mortality following cholecystectomy.

Methods: The 2005-2016 American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program was retrospectively analyzed to identify adult patients undergoing laparoscopic and open cholecystectomy. Patients were stratified into five groups: BMI<18.5 (Underweight), BMI 18.5-24.9 (Normal Weight), BMI 25-29.9 (Overweight), BMI 30-34.9 (Obese), and BMI>35 (Morbidly Obese).  The primary outcome of the study was 30-day mortality, while secondary endpoints included postoperative bleeding, wound infections, and 30-day readmission. Logistic models were used to identify independent associations of covariates with outcomes of interest.

Results: Of 327,473 patients undergoing cholecystectomy, 1.0% were underweight, 19.5% normal weight, 30.3% overweight, 24.0% obese, and 25.2% morbidly obese. Underweight patients were on average older (38.8 vs. 31.7 years, p<0.001) but had lower rates of diabetes mellitus (7.2 vs 17.9%, p<0.001) and hypertension (29.5 vs. 40.9%, p<0.001) relative to morbidly obese patients. Underweight patients also had higher rates of metastatic cancer (1.6 vs 0.3%, p<0.001) and were more likely diagnosed with chronic cholecystitis (10.7 vs. 6.1%, p<0.001). After accounting for surgical indication, approach, and baseline differences, we found underweight patients to be at significantly higher risk of mortality (adjusted odds ratio (AOR)=1.53; p=0.029) and postoperative bleeding (AOR=1.45; p=0.011) relative to normal weight patients. In contrast, morbidly obese patients were at lower risk of mortality (AOR=0.63; p<0.001) and postoperative bleeding (AOR=0.63; p<0.001). However, morbidly obese patients were at increased risk of postoperative wound infection (AOR=1.24; p<0.001) relative to normal weight patients, whereas underweight patients were not at increased infectious risk (AOR=0.93; p=0.636). Notably, readmission rates were higher for underweight (AOR=1.37; p=0.004) but lower for morbidly obese (AOR=0.75; p<0.001) patients relative to normal weight patients.

Conclusion: After controlling for patient and hospital characteristics, underweight patients were at increased risk of mortality, postoperative bleeding events, and readmission relative to normal weight patients. Morbidly obese patients with BMI>35 appear to only be at increased risk for infection. These findings may better guide choice of intervention and preoperative optimization.

abstract_title: Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy (HIPEC) in Septuagenarians, is it safe?
author_block: S. Yadegarynia<sup>1</sup>, A. Collier<sup>1</sup>, O. Picado<sup>1</sup>, F. Macedo<sup>2</sup>, F. Marchetti<sup>1</sup>, M. Moller<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Miami - Miller School of Medicine,Division Of Surgical Oncology; The DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery,Miami, FLORIDA, USA <sup>2</sup>North Florida Regional Medical Center, University of Central Florida College of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Gainesville, FLORIDA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cytoreductive surgery (CRS) with hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) is increasingly used for several gastrointestinal and gynecological malignancies. While new chemotherapeutics and targeted agents have provided survival benefits, CRS with HIPEC is the only potentially curative treatment, providing longer survival rates. In the same time, there are recommendations against the use of CRS/HIPEC in elderly patients as it’s short- and long-term outcomes are still unclear.

Methods:  From January of 2011 to July of 2019, patients with peritoneal malignancies at 70 years of age or older who underwent CRS/HIPEC at University of Miami Hospital or Jackson Memorial Hospital were prospectively identified. Pre- and post-resection Peritoneal Cancer Index (PCI) scores, extent of resection, complications, and length of hospital/ICU stay, overall survival and follow-ups were analyzed.

Results: Out of 195 patients, ten patients were identified: the median age was 74 years (70-83), 60% were female, and 40% Hispanic. All patients had an ASA score of 3. The primary tumors were appendiceal mucinous (30%), mesothelioma (20%), intestinal (20%), gastric (10%), and unknown primary (20%). Four patients had received neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Mean length of operation was 8.8 hours (7.6-10.5). Mean estimated blood loss was 325 mL (100-2,000), with 60% patients receiving blood transfusion. Mitomycin-C was the chemotherapy agent most commonly used (70%), then oxaliplatin (20%) and cisplatin (10%). Peritoneal cancer index (PCI) ranged from 3 to 27 and eight of ten patients achieved a completeness of cytoreduction score (CCR) of 0. Mean length of hospital stay was 10.5 days, with mean ICU admission of 4 days. Postoperative complications were: 4 pleural effusions which required drainage, one anastomotic leakage, and one deep vein thrombosis. No postoperative ileus or intra-abdominal abscess was found. The median follow up was 11 months and 1-year overall survival rate was 100%. Seven patients are alive, four with no evidence of disease.

Conclusion: In this preliminary series, CRS with HIPEC seems to be a safe and feasible surgical option in elderly patients with peritoneal carcinomatosis. Careful patient selection and implementation of proper postoperative care can reduce risk of complications. Given a rapidly aging patient population and limited literature, further studies are required to elucidate better predictors of surgical outcomes and assess quality of life in patients over the age of 70.

abstract_title: Effect of ED Arrival Time on Appendicitis Outcomes: Post Hoc Analysis of the EAST MUSTANG Study
author_block: Y. Rodriguez<sup>1</sup>, Q. Wu<sup>2</sup>, E. M. Urrechaga<sup>2</sup>, K. Abdul Jawad<sup>2</sup>, A. C. Cioci<sup>2</sup>, Y. Rodriguez<sup>3</sup>, G. D. Pust<sup>2</sup>, R. Rattan<sup>2</sup>, N. Namias<sup>2</sup>, D. D. Yeh<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Miami Miller School of Medicine/ Jackson Memorial Hospital,Department of Surgery,Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami,Division Of Trauma Surgery & Critical Care,Miami, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Miami,Miller School Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For patients presenting with acute appendicitis, we sought to determine whether time of arrival to Emergency Department (ED) triage is associated with time-to-intervention and clinically important outcomes.

Methods: The EAST Appendicitis Study database was queried for adults presenting with acute appendicitis treated with either appendectomy (appy) or percutaneous drainage (PD) from 01/17-06/18. Subjects were stratified into groups according to ED Triage Time: 7a-3p (Day), 3p-11p (Swing), and 11p-7a (Night). Outcomes of interest were time from ED triage to intervention (TTI) recorded in 6-h intervals, length of stay (LOS), and in-hospital complications (surgical site infection, intra-abdominal abscess, wound complications, and all Clavien-Dindo complications) . Bivariate analysis, ANOVA, and Chi-square test were used to compare outcomes between groups.

Results: 3372 subjects were included: median age was 38 [27-54] years, 1917 (53%) were male, and median hospital LOS was 1 [1–2] days. 3262 patients were treated with appy and 110 with PD. Subjects fell into the three groups as follows: Day (n=1274), Swing (n=1400), and Night (n=698). Demographics and outcomes are summarized in the Table. TTI was significantly longer for Swing shift compared to Day shift (p=.016), however there was no difference in outcomes or LOS between these groups. There was no difference in TTI between Day and Night shifts (p=0.38), however LOS was longer for Day (1[1-2] days) compared to Night (1[0-2] days) shifts (p=.036). There was no observed difference between shifts for any in-hospital complications. 

Conclusion: In patients presenting to the ED with acute appendicitis, ED arrival during Swing shift is associated with an increased time-to-intervention, however this was not associated with worse clinical outcomes. Arrival during Day shift was associated with longer hospital stay.

abstract_title: Complications after Pancreaticoduodenectomy for Pancreatobilliary Malignancy: Impact of Biliary Flora
author_block: A. Nayyar<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Williams-Perez<sup>1</sup>, M. O. Suraju<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Mott<sup>2</sup>, B. T. Loeffler<sup>2</sup>, M. B. Schmitt<sup>1</sup>, S. K. Sherman<sup>1,2</sup>, H. Hoshi<sup>1,2</sup>, J. R. Howe<sup>1,2</sup>, C. H. Chan<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Department Of Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa,Holden Comprehensive Cancer Center,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bacterial colonization of bile has previously been demonstrated to be associated with a higher risk of postoperative complications after pancreaticoduodenectomy. Whether the risk of postsurgical complications varies by the composition of biliary flora identified intraoperatively, currently remains unclear.

Methods: A single-institution, retrospective analysis was performed; all patients who underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy with intraoperative bile cultures (aerobic and anaerobic) for pancreatobilliary malignancies between January 2010 and May 2020 were included.  Linear and logistic regression models were used to assess the impact of organisms isolated with biliary cultures on outcomes of interest - surgical site infection (SSI), delayed gastric emptying (DGE), pancreatic fistula, duration of drains and total hospital length of stay (LOS).

Results: A total of 110 patients were included; 55% of which were male and 45% female. Sixty-seven percent of the patients had preoperative endoscopic stenting. Overall, 20% of the patients developed SSI, 15% developed DGE, and 11% developed a pancreatic fistula. The mean LOS was 9.1 days (SD 4.6) and the mean duration of drains was 12.1 days (SD 16.1). Only 18% of the patients did not demonstrate any growth (sterile), and the majority of patients had polymicrobial growth on cultures; with Enterococcus being the most commonly isolated organism (41%). Upon univariate analysis, Candida (9%) was associated with an increased risk of SSI (OR 4.77, 95% CI 1.25, 18.29; p=0.02) and an increased risk of pancreatic fistula (OR 5.67, 95% CI 1.21, 26.48; p=0.03). Patients with Streptococcus had 5.2 days longer duration of drains (p=0.05); however after adjusting for patient and cancer characteristics, this was no longer statistically significant. No meaningful differences were observed in rates of DGE and hospital LOS by microbial type.

Conclusion: This study demonstrates significant variations in the risk of postoperative complications based on the composition of biliary flora. Interestingly, Candida was demonstrated to be associated with postoperative pancreatic fistulas, which has not been previously reported. This study highlights the need for further investigation into identification of biliary flora and its impact on immune microenvironment, which may explain the differences observed in postoperative complications.

abstract_title: Surgical Treatment of Colorectal Liver Metastases in Rural Patients: Potential for Improved Survival
author_block: E. J. Olecki<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Stahl<sup>1</sup>, W. Wong<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Peng<sup>2</sup>, C. Shen<sup>3</sup>, N. J. Gusani<sup>2</sup>, M. E. Dixon<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,General Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,Program For Liver, Pancreas, And Foregut Tumors,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,Division Of Outcomes Research, And Quality,Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With advancement in the surgical treatment of metastatic liver disease, many patients with stage IV colorectal cancer (CRC) are experiencing improvement in overall survival (OS). However, given that rural patients often experience disadvantages when accessing specialized healthcare, there is a concern that a rural-urban disparity may exist regarding surgical treatment and survival in patients with CRC liver metastases.

Methods: National Cancer Data Base was used to identify patients from 2006-2016 with stage IV CRC with a confirmed liver metastasis. Univariate Chi square test and multivariable logistic regression was used to examine subgroup differences based upon urban-rural status (Metropolitan/Urban/Rural). Kaplan Meier Method and Cox proportional hazard model were used to examine associated survival in patients with hepatic CRC metastases based upon rural-urban status. Further analysis was performed to examine these differences in patients who received metastectomy only stratified by rural-urban status. 

Results: A majority of the patients included in this study were residents of metropolitan areas, with 16.6% (6,441/38,833) of patient residing in non-metropolitan communities.  Patients in rural communities were more likely to be male, Caucasian, have government insurance, and receive treatment at a community cancer program as opposed to an academic institution compared to patients residing in metropolitan areas.  When comparing overall survival of all patients with CRC liver metastases, rural status was associated with worse median survival (15.2 months) compared to patients in a metropolitan area (17.7 months) (p=.007).  When controlling for demographic characteristics including age, race, facility type, and insurance type, rural status was associated with 13.3% higher mortality when compared to metropolitan residents (HR 1.13, p=.032). However, when limiting analysis to only those who had received metastectomy (n=5,220), there was no difference in overall survival when comparing rural-urban status (HR 0.98, p=0.88). 

Conclusion: This study demonstrates an existing disparity of rural-urban status regarding overall survival in metastatic CRC liver disease, with rural patients experiencing significantly worse overall survival compared to patients in metropolitan areas. However, when comparing patients who underwent surgical resection of metastatic disease, there was no difference in overall survival when comparing metropolitan and rural residents.  These results suggest that appropriate access to facilities with specialized capabilities of hepatic surgical resection could potentially decrease survival disparities among rural patients with CRC liver metastases.

abstract_title: Two-Surgeon Whipple Leads to Dramatic Decreases in Total Costs of Care at a Healthcare System Level
author_block: J. A. McKenzie<sup>1</sup>, J. L. McKenzie<sup>1</sup>, H. Vildibill<sup>1</sup>, R. Prescott<sup>3</sup>, S. Kayea<sup>3</sup>, B. Adam<sup>1</sup>, E. J. Kruse<sup>2</sup>, D. Albo<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College of Georgia at Augusta University,Department Of Surgery,Augusta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Georgia,Division Of Surgical Oncology, Department Of Surgery,Augusta, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>Augusta University Health,Augusta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Whipple is a complex procedure with associated high costs of care. We hypothesized that two attending surgeons working together simultaneously would have improved total costs of care at a healthcare system level. These cost reductions would be driven by improved efficiency and quality metrics during the perioperative period.

Methods: This was a retrospective study at a single institution. Patients who had undergone a Whipple procedure or total pancreatectomy were identified by chart review. Two groups were identified based on the presence of two fellowship trained surgeons operating together versus a single surgeon with a resident or non-simultaneous support. We collected financial data from our business office for these groups. Quality metrics were then collected.

Results:   There was reduced costs in the two-physician group compared to the single physician group. Direct operating room (OR) costs were a mean of $5,964 vs $8,872 (p<0.001). Indirect OR costs of $5,149 vs $8,052 (p<0.001), with the sum of OR costs an average of 34% lower; $11,113 vs $16,925 (p <0.001), a difference of $5,811. Total costs, to include everything within the 90-day period, were also significantly lower, $38,070 vs $56,663, (p =0.038). Overall, the total costs were 33% lower in the two-physician group with an average reduction of $18,593. Most of the cost reduction, 69%, was in post-operative care. We then evaluated our quality metrics to identify the main drivers of cost reduction. Patients who underwent two-surgeon Whipple had statistically significant lower operative time (383 versus 611 minutes, p<0.001), length of stay (11.4 versus 15.6 days, p=0.01), 90-day ICU admission rates (43.2% versus 70.8%, p=0.002) and overall complications (41.9% versus 62.0%, p=0.04).

Conclusion: Patients who underwent Whipple procedure with simultaneous two surgeons had remarkedly reduced operating room costs and total costs within the 90-day window. These were driven by improved quality metrics, including reduced operative time, length of stay, ICU admissions and complication rates. Overall, we feel the two-surgeon Whipple model should be incentivized at healthcare system and payer level to improve quality and reduce costs of care for the Whipple operation.

abstract_title: 1-stage vs 2-stage approach for managing Cholelithiasis with Choledocholithiasis.A Meta-analysis
author_block: M. Osama<sup>1</sup>, S. H. Syed<sup>3</sup>, A. A. Khan<sup>1</sup>, O. Gul<sup>1</sup>, H. Saeed<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Masood<sup>2</sup>, Q. Jawed<sup>1</sup>, S. R. Zaidi<sup>3</sup>, S. Rasool<sup>1</sup>, J. Ahmed<sup>1</sup>, F. Zaheer<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Dow University of Health Sciences,General Surgery,KARACHI, SINDH, Pakistan <sup>2</sup>Trinitas Regional Medical Centre, NJ,Internal Medicine,Elizabeth, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>St. Mary Mercy Hospital,Internal Medicine,Livonia, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC) and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) remain the standard of care for the gallstone disease with concomitant common bile duct (CBD) stones. The purpose of this study is to compare the efficacy and post-procedural safety outcomes of intraoperative ERCP (IOERCP) during LC in a single setting with that of preoperative ERCP (POERCP) + LC conducted in two separate sessions.

Methods:  Randomized controlled trials and retrospective or prospective cohorts that compared one-stage laparo-endoscopic (rendezvous) technique with a two-stage (POERCP+LC) approach were included and data were pooled in the form of metanalysis. The primary outcomes of the study were CBD stone clearance, overall mortality rate, hospital length of stay, postoperative complications, and total operative time while secondary outcomes were the rate of conversion of laparoscopic to an open procedure and cost-effectiveness.

Results: A total of fourteen studies comprising 1599 participants were recognized, out of which 747 patients underwent single-stage while 852 had two-stage procedures performed. No significant differences were observed between the two groups in terms of stone clearance from CBD (OR=1.85, p=0.10), post-operative pancreatitis (OR=0.52, p=0.11), complication rate (OR=0.66, p=0.10) and operative time (MD=19.58, p=0.20). However, the study reported significantly decreased conversion rate to open surgery (OR=0.50, p=0.02), decreased length of stay in the hospital (MD= -2.81, p=0.005), and significant cost reduction (SMD= -0.59, p=0.005) in one-stage as compared to two-stage procedures. Mortality was reported in only one patient in a single-stage group in one study.

Conclusion: One-stage approach is found to be similar in efficacy and safety in terms of stone clearance, postoperative pancreatitis, complications, and operative time, but is superior to two-stage with respect to conversion rate, hospital length of stay and cost-effectiveness. Therefore, it is proving to be a preferred modality of treatment in patients with cholelithiasis and concomitant choledocholithiasis.

abstract_title: Trends and Outcomes of Simultaneous Resection of Colorectal Cancer and Colorectal Liver Metastases
author_block: D. I. Tsilimigras<sup>1</sup>, K. Sahara<sup>1</sup>, J. Hyer<sup>1</sup>, A. Diaz<sup>1</sup>, A. Guglielmi<sup>2</sup>, A. Ruzzenente<sup>1,2</sup>, F. Bagante<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Alexandrescu<sup>3</sup>, G. A. Poultsides<sup>4</sup>, K. Sasaki<sup>5</sup>, F. Aucejo<sup>5</sup>, A. Ejaz<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Department of Surgery, Division of Surgical Oncology, The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center and James Comprehensive Cancer Center,Columbus, OHIO, USA <sup>2</sup>Department of Surgery, University of Verona,Verona, ITALY, Italy <sup>3</sup>Department of Surgery, Fundeni Clinical Institute,Bucharest, ROMANIA, Romania <sup>4</sup>Department of Surgery, Stanford University,Palo Alto, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>5</sup>Cleveland Clinic,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The role of simultaneous resection of colorectal cancer (CRC) and colorectal liver metastases (CRLM) remains ill-defined. We sought to assess trends in the use, as well as outcomes of patients undergoing simultaneous versus staged resection for synchronous CRLM.

Methods:  Patients undergoing resection for CRLM between 2008 and 2018 were identified using an international, multi-institutional database.Utilization of simultaneous resection of CRC and CRLM was examined over time. Short- and long-term outcomes following simultaneous versus staged resection for synchronous CRLM were evaluated following propensity-score matching (PSM).

Results: Among 1,116 patients undergoing resection for CRLM, 690 (61.8%) patients had synchronous disease. Among individuals with synchronous disease, 314 (45.5%) patients underwent simultaneous resection, while 376 (54.5%) had staged resection. The proportion of patients undergoing simultaneous resection for synchronous CRC and CRLM increased over time (2008: 37.2% vs. 2018: 47.4%, ptrend=0.02). The temporal trend was almost entirely due to an increase in simultaneous minor liver resections (2008: 32.6% vs. 2018: 47.4%, ptrend=0.03), whereas simultaneous major liver resections remained limited over time (2008: 4.7% vs. 2018: 0%, ptrend=0.10)(Figure). The use of minimally invasive surgery for simultaneous CRLM resection remained low over time (2008: 2.3% vs. 2018: 0%, ptrend=0.27). After PSM (n=168 per group), patients undergoing simultaneous resection for synchronous CRLM had a higher incidence of overall complications (52.4% vs. 32.1%, p<0.001) and severe complications (Clavien-Dindo > III)(22.0% vs. 4.8%, p<0.001). The incidence of severe morbidity did, however, decrease over time (2008: 50% vs 2018: 11.1%, ptrend=0.02) (Figure). In addition, 90-day mortality (3.6% vs. 1.2%, p=0.15) and 90-day readmission (7.7% vs 4.2%, p=0.17) were similar among patients undergoing simultaneous versus staged resection, respectively. Median and 5-year overall survival were also comparable among patients undergoing simultaneous versus staged resection of CRLM (simultaneous vs. staged resection; median OS, 58.1 months [95%CI: 42.9-73.2] vs. 45.2 months [IQR: 38.9-51.5]; 5-year OS, 48.4% vs. 37.8%, p=0.41). 

Conclusion: The utilization of simultaneous resection for synchronous CRC and CRLM has increased over time at major hepatopancreatobiliary centers. While simultaneous resection was associated increased morbidity, the incidence of severe morbidity decreased over time. Long-term survival was comparable following simultaneous versus staged CRLM resection. Simultaneous resection of synchronous CRLM should be strongly considered at major centers.

abstract_title: Pretreatment PALBI Score as Prognostic Factor for Transarterial Radioembolization in HCC Patients
author_block: J. Sanchez-Garcia<sup>1</sup>, F. Lopez-Verdugo<sup>1</sup>, R. Riegler<sup>2</sup>, M. Jepperson<sup>3</sup>, A. Gagnon<sup>1,4</sup>, D. Alonso<sup>1</sup>, S. Fujita<sup>1,4,5</sup>, M. I. Rodriguez-Davalos<sup>1,5</sup>, R. Thota<sup>6</sup>, G. Cannon<sup>7</sup>, J. Krong<sup>8</sup>, S. Dow<sup>8</sup>, R. Gilroy<sup>1</sup>, M. Kringlen<sup>3</sup>, I. R. Zendejas-Ruiz<sup>1,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Intermountain Medical Center,Liver Transplant Service,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>Intermountain Medical Center,Imaging Research Service,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>Intermountain Medical Center,Interventional Radiology Service,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>4</sup>Canyon Surgical Associates,Hepatobiliary And Liver Transplantation Service,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>5</sup>Primary Children's Hospital,Liver Transplant Service,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>6</sup>Intermountain Medical Center,Oncology/Hematology Service,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>7</sup>Intermountain Medical Center,Radiation Oncology Service,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>8</sup>Intermountain Medical Center,Transplant Research Department,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the third most common cause of cancer-related death in the world. It is widely perceived that survival depends on tumor stage. Recently, platelet-albumin-bilirubin (PALBI) score was reported to be superior to Child-Pugh classification and albumin-bilirubin (ALBI) score in terms of mortality prediction. Trans-arterial radioembolization (TARE) is a minimally invasive therapy used as bridge for liver transplantation or resection. The aim of this study is to assess pre-TARE PALBI score prognostic performance among other liver function scores and/or inflammatory markers.

Methods: We retrospectively assessed all patients with HCC that underwent TARE between February 2008 and January 2020. Demographic characteristics; and laboratory values were collected to calculate Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD), ALBI, PALBI, platelet-lymphocyte ratio (PLR) and neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) within six months before TARE. Results are presented as proportions and median (IQR). Continuous variables were transformed into qualitative or ordinal variables according to maximally selected rank statistics of the given parameter. Multivariate Cox regression analysis was performed to identify risk factors for overall survival.

Results: A total of 212 patients were included, 72% were males and the median age was 64 (57-69). TARE was used as intention-to-bridge in 60% of cases. Of all cases, 82% were treatment-naïve. The median tumor size was 3.7 (2.6-6.2) cm with 57% having unifocal lesions. The median pretreatment values were: neutrophils (NE) 2.8 (2.1-3.9) x 103/mL, MELD 9 (7-11), ALBI -2.09 (-2.45 to -1.72), PALBI -2.23 (-2.45 to -2.01), PLR 100 (66.2-141.4), and NLR 2.61 (1.85-4.36). Destination therapy (OR=3.6: 95%CI 2.5-5.3; p<0.0001), pretreatment with chemotherapy alone (OR=7: 95%CI 3.3-15; p= <0.0001), size (OR=1.1 per cm increment: 95%CI 1.1-1.2; p<0.0001), NE (OR=1.2: 95%CI 1.1-1.3; p<0.0001), and PALBI (OR=1.7: 95%CI 1-2.8; p=0.035) were significant in univariate Cox regression. MELD and ALBI score were not significant. NE, PALBI and tumor size were transformed into binomial variables. Optimal cutoffs for NE and PALBI were calculated at 2.5 and -2.33, respectively. Size cutoff was set at 3cm to follow our institutional algorithm. Multivariate Cox regression showed a C-index of 73 with a global p-value <0.0001 (Figure 1).

Conclusion: To our knowledge, this is the first report of PALBI as prognostic factor in patients undergoing TARE. Interestingly, the multivariate cox regression showed us other important factors available at the time of medical decision-making. These results can improve our patient selection for TARE.

abstract_title: Use of Neoadjuvant Therapy and Outcomes in BR-C Pancreatectomy Patients
author_block: P. M. McCarthy<sup>1</sup>, P. M. Kemp Bohan<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Vreeland<sup>2</sup>, G. E. Peoples<sup>3</sup>, R. W. Krell<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brooke Army Medical Center,General Surgery,Fort Sam Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Brooke Army Medical Center,Surgical Oncology,Fort Sam Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Cancer Vaccine Development Program,San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neoadjuvant therapy (NAT) is utilized with increasing frequency for patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and is associated with fewer pancreatic leaks.  It is unclear whether these associations apply to patients with advanced age, marginal performance status, or lifestyle-limiting comorbidities; considered ‘borderline-C’ (BR-C).  Some argue that NAT will decrease their ability to tolerate pancreatectomy.  We sought to investigate the relationship of NAT use and BR-C status on outcomes following pancreatectomy.

Methods: We used National Surgical Quality Improvement Program targeted pancreatectomy data from 2014-2018 and analyzed adults undergoing pancreatectomy for PDAC.  We characterized the utilization of NAT according to patients’ BR-C status and assessed the relationship of NAT and BR-C on postoperative outcomes using propensity score matching techniques.

Results: We identified 14,100 patients who underwent pancreatectomy for PDAC in ACS-NSQIP hospitals between 2014-2018, of which 4,446 (32%) were BR-C by age, performance status, or comorbidities.  NAT use increased over time, but was consistently less utilized in BR-C patients.  BR-C patients underwent proportionally more pancreatoduodenectomies (PD) compared with more robust patients (78.1% vs 75.4%, p<0.01).  Overall complications were increased in NAT patients regardless of BR-C status, explained entirely by increased rates of post-operative blood transfusion (22% vs 15% in robust patients, p<0.001; 31% vs 23% in BR-C patients, p<0.01).  In robust and BR-C patients, NAT was associated with decreased rates of clinically relevant postoperative pancreatic fistula (CR-POPF) (6% vs 11% in robust patients, p<0.01; 6% vs 9% in BR-C patients, p=0.03).  In BR-C patients NAT was associated with decreased delayed gastric emptying (DGE) (12% vs 18%, p=0.02), especially for patients undergoing PD that received chemotherapy and radiation.  NAT was not associated with increased mortality in BR-C patients (p=0.428). 

Conclusion: Despite their frailty, BR-C patients are more likely to undergo PD and less likely to receive NAT.  NAT is safe even in BR-C patients as the relationship between NAT and associated complications, particularly fewer clinically relevant pancreatic leaks and DGE, is the same for BR-C and robust patients. NAT should be considered more strongly in BR-C patients.

abstract_title: Early Post-op Serum Hyperamylasemia: Harbinger of Morbidity Hiding in Plain Sight?
author_block: S. P. McGuire<sup>1</sup>, T. K. Maatman<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Keller<sup>2</sup>, E. P. Ceppa<sup>1</sup>, M. G. House<sup>1</sup>, A. Nakeeb<sup>1</sup>, T. K. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, M. Schmidt<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Zyromski<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The clinical significance of post-operative serum pancreatic enzyme (amylase, lipase) elevations following pancreatoduodenectomy (PD) is understudied. We therefore sought to characterize the incidence and impact of this condition. We hypothesized that elevations in serum enzymes would increase morbidity and mortality following PD.

Methods:  Retrospective review of 677 patients undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy at a single institution from 2013-2019. Patients with at least one serum lipase or amylase value within 48 hours post-operatively were included. Patients were categorized into three groups: (1) Normal: post-operative serum enzyme values within normal limits; (2) Post-operative serum hyperamylasemia (POSH): post-operative serum enzyme values greater than the upper limit of normal (ULN) but less than three times the ULN; and (3) Post-operative acute pancreatitis (POAP): post-operative serum enzyme values greater than three times the ULN. Pancreatic gland texture was identified by the operating surgeon, major morbidity was defined as Grade 3+ according to the Clavien classification, and post-operative pancreatic fistula and delayed gastric emptying were classified using the ISGPS definition.

Results: 415 of 677 patients had post-operative serum amylase or lipase values within 48 hours post operatively. Of these 415, 243 (59%) were classified as normal, 96 (23%) were classified as having POSH, and 76 (18%) were classified as having POAP. Tobacco use, incidence of diabetes mellitus, and pre-operative weight loss differed among groups (Table). Soft pancreas gland texture was less common in patients with normal enzymes (26%) compared to patients with POSH (66%) and POAP (81%) (p <0.001). This finding was similar when considering etiology (see table). Patients with normal enzyme levels had larger pancreatic ducts (23% >6mm) compared with POSH (10% >6mm) and POAP (0% >6mm) (p <0.001). Major morbidity following PD was lower among patients with normal enzyme levels (10%) and higher in patients with POSH (23%) and POAP (18%) (p = 0.008). Specifically, patients with normal enzymes were less likely to develop post-operative pancreatic fistula (5%) compared with patients with POSH (26%) and POAP (21%) (p <0.001) and less likely to develop delayed gastric emptying (9% versus 23% and 20%, respectively); p = 0.002. No difference was seen among groups with regard to mortality (Table).

Conclusion: Elevated serum pancreatic enzyme levels occur frequently after PD and are associated with an increased risk of post-operative morbidity. Serum enzyme concentration should be considered in post-PD management.

abstract_title: Outcomes and Resource Use in Open, Laparoscopic and Robotic Hepatectomy for Hepatocellular Carcinoma
author_block: K. Karunungan<sup>1</sup>, J. Madrigal<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, E. Aguayo<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Laparoscopic and robotic approaches to hepatic resection have been increasingly adopted for the treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Previous studies have reported an association between minimally invasive approaches and improved outcomes, though data on the national use of these procedures are limited. The purpose of the present study was to examine trends in utilization as well as clinical outcomes and resource use following open, laparoscopic and robotic hepatic resection over an 8-year period.

Methods: All adults (≥18 years old) undergoing hepatic resection for HCC were identified using the 2010-17 National Inpatient Sample. International Classification of Diseases, Ninth and Tenth Revisions codes were used to tabulate relevant patient and operative characteristics. Parametric (P-Trend) and nonparametric rank-based (NP-Trend) tests were used to assess temporal trends in categorical and continuous variables, respectively. The primary outcome was in-hospital mortality while secondary outcomes included any perioperative complication (neurologic, renal, cardiovascular, respiratory, infectious), length of stay and inflation-adjusted hospitalization costs.

Results: Of an estimated 67,051 patients undergoing hepatic resection, 82.9% utilized an open approach while 10.7% and 6.4% used laparoscopic and robotic methods, respectively. Although overall hepatectomy volume remained steady during the study period, utilization of laparoscopic and robotic approaches significantly increased (Figure). In-hospital mortality decreased significantly in all patients undergoing hepatic resection, from 2.7% in 2010 to 1.2% in 2017 (P-Trend<0.001) (Figure). This reduction was primarily driven by improvements in open approaches (2.6 to 1.2%, P-Trend<0.001). Similarly, the incidence of perioperative complications decreased in all cohorts (P-Trend<0.001). Although length of stay decreased during the study period (7.7 to 6.1 days, NP-Trend<0.001), no significant changes in costs were appreciated across all groups.

Conclusion: Utilization of laparoscopic and robotic approaches to liver resection have significantly increased in the United States from 2010-2017. Concomitantly, there were overall improvements in outcomes including in-hospital mortality, complications and resource utilization, primarily driven by improvements in those undergoing open liver resection. With each operative approach demonstrating improved overall safety, appropriate patient selection will further optimize outcomes among those with HCC amenable to resection.

abstract_title: Surgery is Associated with Longer Survival for Resectable Pancreatic Cancer Compared to Chemotherapy
author_block: K. Landa<sup>1</sup>, N. E. Farrow<sup>1</sup>, C. Rushing<sup>1</sup>, D. Niedzwiecki<sup>1</sup>, M. Cerullo<sup>1</sup>, R. Schmitz<sup>1</sup>, G. Herbert<sup>1</sup>, K. Shah<sup>1</sup>, S. Zani<sup>1</sup>, D. G. Blazer<sup>1</sup>, P. Allen<sup>1</sup>, M. Lidsky<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Surgery,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Resectable pancreatic cancer is best treated with surgical resection (SR) and multiagent chemotherapy (MCT); however, many patients only complete a single modality due to treatment-related complications or disease progression. We aim to determine whether SR or MCT is associated with superior long-term survival for patients receiving single-modality therapy.

Methods:  Patients with stage I-IIb pancreatic head adenocarcinoma who received either MCT (+/- radiation) or SR (pancreaticoduodenectomy/total pancreatectomy) alone were identified in the National Cancer Database (2013-2015). Patients who received single agent chemotherapy or had an unknown treatment status were excluded. Following a piecewise approach to estimating hazards over the course of follow-up, conditional overall survival (OS) at 30, 60, and 90 days after treatment initiation was estimated using landmark analyses. 

Results: Of 5,146 eligible patients, 3,103 received MCT alone (60.3%) and 2,043 underwent SR alone (39.7%). SR had an OS disadvantage at 30 (HR 3.99, 95% CI 3.12-5.11) and 60 days (HR 1.85, 95% CI 1.4-2.45), but an OS advantage after 90 days (HR 0.59, 95% CI 0.55-0.64). In a landmark analysis conditioned on 90 days survival post treatment initiation (Figure), median OS was improved for SR (17.0 vs. 12.2 months, log-rank p<.0001); SR improved OS at 1 (+4.5%), 2 (+20.4%), 3 (+21.3%), and 4 (+15.3%) years (p<.05 for each difference), despite patients being older (median age 72 vs. 67 years, p<.0001) with higher Charlson-Deyo comorbidity scores (≥2: 11.2 vs. 8.6%, p=0.006).

Conclusion: For patients with resectable pancreatic cancer receiving single-modality treatment, SR was associated with superior long-term survival compared to MCT, supporting a role for upfront surgery in this population, especially those at risk of receiving a single therapy.

abstract_title: Does Minimally Invasive Pancreaticoduodenectomy Increase Textbook Oncologic Outcomes?
author_block: P. J. Sweigert<sup>1</sup>, E. Eguia<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Baker<sup>1</sup>, S. Kulshrestha<sup>1</sup>, D. Tsilimigras<sup>2</sup>, A. Ejaz<sup>2</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Surgery,Maywood, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University,Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Traditional “siloed” outcomes metrics may inadequately reflect expectations surrounding an optimal surgical outcome. Rather, “Textbook Oncologic Outcome”(TOO) has been described in an effort to improve upon the definition of optimal care after pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) for adenocarcinoma. We sought to examine whether minimally invasive pancreaticoduodenectomy (MIPD) increased the likelihood of an optimal postoperative TOO.

Methods:  Patients undergoing PD for adenocarcinoma between 2010-2015 were identified in the National Cancer Database. TOO was defined as: R0 resection with AJCC compliant lymphadenectomy (LAD), no prolonged length-of-stay (LOS), no 30-d readmission/mortality, and receipt of adjuvant chemotherapy. Overall survival (OS) was calculated using Kaplan-Meier and Cox proportional hazards models.  In addition, MIPD and open PD cohorts were examined after 1:1 propensity score matching (PSM) based on age, sex, ethnicity, insurance, comorbidity index, facility type and volume, tumor stage, size, grade, lymphovascular invasion, and use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Patients were further stratified based on operative approach and TOO.

Results: Among 12,854 patients who underwent PD, 6,208 (48.3%) were female and median patient age was 66 years.  At the time of surgery, 11,246 (87.5%) underwent an open PD, while 1,608 (12.5%) underwent MIPD. On unadjusted analysis, no difference was seen in composite TOO rates after an open versus MIPD (23.5% vs. 24.7%, p=0.28). Several individual factors did vary based on operative approach. Specifically, R0 resection (80.4% vs 78.1%), adequate LAD (77.2% vs 73.4%), non-prolonged LOS (80.3% vs 77.0%), as well as no readmission (93.2% vs 91.7%) were more likely among patients who underwent MIPD (all p<0.05). However, on subsequent PSM analyses, there were no differences in the likelihood of R0 resection, adequate LAD, non-prolonged LOS, no readmission, no 30-d mortality, or adjuvant chemotherapy among patients who underwent open versus MIPD; in fact, the overall chance of TOO after open versus MIPD was the same (Figure). Of note, TOO was associated with an improved median OS (no TOO: 21.3 mo vs. TOO: 27.6 mo, p<0.001).  While MIPD demonstrated superior OS among patients who did achieve a TOO (median OS, open: 26.5 vs. MIPD: 29.0 mo, p = 0.03), those who did not achieve a TOO demonstrated no difference in median OS (open: 20.5 mo vs. MIPD: 22.2 mo, p=0.08).

Conclusion: Although TOO was associated with a long-term survival advantage, it was only achieved in one in four patients undergoing PD for adenocarcinoma. A minimally invasive approach to PD was not associated with improved outcomes, including the likelihood to achieve TOO, on adjusted analyses.

abstract_title: Whipple ERAS: takes more than a pathway to achieve target length of stay
author_block: C. I. Ayala<sup>1</sup>, A. Li<sup>1</sup>, A. Lu<sup>2</sup>, A. Wilson<sup>2</sup>, J. R. Bergquist<sup>1</sup>, G. A. Poultsides<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Norton<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Visser<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Dua<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Department Of General Surgery, HPB And Surgical Oncology Division,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Stanford University,Department Of Anesthesiology,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) is a complex surgical procedure that requires attentive perioperative care. Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocols have emerged to enhance functional recovery, decrease complications, and reduce hospital length of stay (LOS). We successfully implemented an ERAS pathway for PD to optimize patient care; however, our current mean LOS remains over the proposed ERAS target of 7 days. This study identifies those patients that fail to meet target LOS to determine the causes and areas of ERAS pathway improvement.

Methods: Four surgeons worked with the hospital quality team to develop our own institutional ERAS pathway for PD and implemented it in 2017. This study period includes all PD procedures that utilized the ERAS pathway over 3 years (May 2017-2020). Robotic PD procedures were excluded. We reviewed all the medical records of those patients that failed to meet target LOS.

Results: A total of 214 PD procedures utilized the ERAS pathway over 3 years. We observed a LOS reduction from pre-ERAS vs post-implementation (mean LOS 10.5 vs 8.5 days, p<0.05); but still failed to achieve our target LOS for the whole cohort. There were 90 patients (42%) that failed to meet the 7 day LOS. The main reason to fail pathway LOS was either ileus or delayed gastric emptying (46/90, 51%), with a mean LOS of 11.5 days. Within this subgroup, patients who required a nasogastric tube (NGT) during the admission had longer LOS (12.4 vs 9.3 days, p<0.05). Additional reasons for patients not meeting LOS are shown in Table 1 (44/90, 49%). These primarily included non-gastrointestinal reasons with the top three including work-up based on leukocytosis and/or concern for pancreatic leak (16/44, LOS 15), desire for additional observation (13/44, LOS 8.5), and orthostatic hypotension (3/44, LOS 10). Of these additional 44 patients, 18 patients underwent computed tomography (on or after POD 7) and 12 patients received an inpatient intervention during the extra LOS (1 drain study, 4 percutaneous drain manipulation or placement, 4 NGT and 10 TPN). In this subgroup, 4 patients had 2 or more of these interventions. ERAS implementation did not increase perioperative complications, 30-day readmission, or mortality. Renal, respiratory, cardiac, and superficial site infections all remained below NSQIP benchmarks.

Conclusion: The most common reasons for PD pathway failure included slow return of gastric or bowel function which are perhaps inevitable in some patients undergoing PD. The remaining patients not meeting ERAS target were often kept for observation without additional intervention. This group represents an actionable cohort to target for improving LOS through surgeon awareness rather than pathway modification.

abstract_title: Is Margin Status Associated with Improved Survival in Patients with Resectable Gallbladder Cancer?
author_block: M. J. Littau<sup>1</sup>, S. Kulshrestha<sup>1</sup>, C. Bunn<sup>1</sup>, D. Patel<sup>1</sup>, F. A. Luchette<sup>1,2</sup>, M. S. Baker<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Surgery,Maywood, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Edward J. Hines VA Hospital,Surgery,Hines, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Achieving microscopically negative (R0) surgical margins in gallbladder cancer often requires an en bloc or revisional partial hepatectomy with associated risk of post-operative morbidity and potential to delay adjuvant therapy. Prior studies on the value of margin status in resectable gall bladder cancer have primarily been retrospective case series including small numbers of subjects with histologically positive (R1) margins. The value of a microscopic negative margin remains unclear.

Methods: We queried the National Cancer Database to identify patients undergoing surgical resection to R1 or R0 margins for clinical stage I to III adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder between 2004 and 2015. Patients receiving neoadjuvant therapy, those with fewer than 3 lymph nodes assessed, and those with resection to residual macroscopic (R2) disease were excluded. Patients undergoing R0 resection were 1:1 propensity matched to those undergoing R1 resection for age, demographics, Charlson comorbidity index, surgical approach, histopathologic grade, pathologic stage, and adjuvant therapy. Overall survival (OS) profiles for the matched cohorts were compared using the Kaplan Meier method. Statistical significance was determined by log rank test.

Results: 1,444 patients met inclusion criteria.1,314 underwent R0 resection; 130 underwent an R1 resection.
