On univariate comparison, patients undergoing R0 resection tended to be younger (66.2 +/- 0.17 years vs 69.5 +/- 0.44 years, p = 0.004), were more likely to have private insurance (37.8% vs 26.2%, p = 0.029), had smaller tumors (3.29 +/- 0.50cm vs 4.03 +/- 0.89cm, p = 0.003), were less likely to have pathologic stage III disease (12.7% vs 21.5%, p = 0.002), and were less likely to receive adjuvant radiotherapy (29.7% vs 41.5%, p = 0.005). 130 patients undergoing R1 resection were matched to 130 patients undergoing R0 resection. After propensity matching, there were no statistical differences between matched cohorts with regards to age, demographics, comorbid disease state, histologic grade, pathologic stage, and receipt of adjuvant treatment. On Kaplan Meier analysis of matched cohorts (Fig 1), those undergoing R0 resection demonstrated a median overall survival 13 months longer than those undergoing R1 resection (28.7 +/- 0.88 vs 15.2 +/- 1.85 months, p = 0.002).

Conclusions: In patients presenting with resectable adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder, margin-negative resection is associated with significant improvement in OS. Decisions regarding extent of resection should be individualized. Hepatectomy to clear surgical margins is warranted in patients generally fit for such procedures.

abstract_title: Textbook Oncologic Outcome in Pancreaticoduodenectomy: Do Regionalization Efforts Make Sense?
author_block: S. Kulshrestha<sup>1,4</sup>, P. J. Sweigert<sup>1</sup>, C. Tonelli<sup>1,6</sup>, C. Bunn<sup>1</sup>, F. Luchette<sup>1,6</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>5</sup>, M. S. Baker<sup>1,6</sup> <sup>1</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Maywood, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Burn And Shock Trauma Research Institute,Maywood, IL, USA <sup>5</sup>Ohio State University,Department Of Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>6</sup>Edward J. Hines VA Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Hines, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Advocacy groups continue to promote regionalization in pancreatic cancer care. There is little empiric evidence to suggest regionalization is resulting in improved clinical outcomes. We examine the effects of contemporary trends in regionalization on a composite metric of clinical quality for pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD), a textbook oncologic outcome (TOO).

Methods: We queried the National Cancer Database to identify patients presenting with resectable (clinical stage I and II) pancreatic adenocarcinoma undergoing PD between 2006 and 2015. TOO was defined as a margin negative resection with formal lymph node assessment, no prolonged hospitalization, readmission, or 30-day mortality, and receipt of adjuvant chemotherapy within 12 weeks of surgery. Facility volume was classified by annual number of pancreatectomies performed based on Leapfrog Group criteria: centers performing 20 pancreatectomies per year were designated as high volume; those performing 11-19 as moderate, 5-10 as low, <4 as very low volume.

Results: 16,394 patients met inclusion criteria. 9,514 (58.0%) underwent PD at high, 2,665 (16.2%) at moderate, 2,635 (16.0%) low and 1,580 (9.6%) very low volume centers. 2,643 (16.1%) patients had a TOO. The proportion of patients treated in high volume centers increased yearly from 46% in 2006 to 64% in 2015 (p<0.01). Annual rates of TOO increased each year from 12.4% in 2006 to 19.6% in 2015 (p<0.01). On univariate analysis, mean TOO rates correlated directly with surgical volume (7.4% at very low facilities vs. 20.0% at high volume facilities (p<0.01). On mixed effects multivariable regression adjusting for patient, tumor, and facility characteristics surgical volume was consistently associated with rates of TOO. Very low (OR 0.35, 95%CI [0.27,0.45]), low (OR 0.47, 95%CI [0.39,0.57]), and moderate (OR 0.74, 95%CI [0.63,0.87]) volume centers all demonstrated lower adjusted odds of achieving TOO than high volume centers (all p<0.01). Positive regional lymph nodes (OR 1.38, 95%CI [1.23,1.54) and facility location in the East North Central United States (OR 1.50, 95%CI [1.11,2.02], p<0.01) were independently associated with increased odds of TOO while age over 75 (OR 0.44, 95%CI [0.37,0.52]) and Charlson comorbidity score >3 (OR 0.52, 95%CI [0.36,0.75]) were associated with lower odds of TOO (all p<0.05). Academic affiliation was not associated with TOO.

Conclusions: Rates of TOO in PD are relatively low across all thresholds of surgical volume. There is a direct association between volume and rate of TOO. Rates of TOO have increased over time as has the percentage of cases done in high volume centers. Such trends support continued efforts to promote regionalization in pancreatic cancer care.

abstract_title: Delay in Care For Pancreatic Cancer Patients During COVID19
author_block: M. Tariq<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Lever<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Mullins<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Vickers<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Heslin<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Rose<sup>1</sup>, S. Reddy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is a deadly disease, with most patients requiring referral to a high-volume, tertiary care center for expert evaluation. During the COVID19 pandemic, access to healthcare has become limited, and disproportionately so for those in lower socioeconomic demographics. In Alabama, there is a single tertiary care referral center for pancreatic neoplasms. We therefore sought to examine the effect of the COVID19 pandemic on pancreatic cancer patient referrals and subsequent therapy in Alabama.

Methods:  A retrospective analysis of patients presenting to a high-volume tertiary care hospital with a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer was performed. Two different time intervals were chosen: 10/1/2019-12/31/2019 (pre-COVID19) and 4/1/2020-6/30/2020 (COVID19). Each patient was evaluated in a multidisciplinary clinic and their case was reviewed in tumor board prior to initiating therapy. Clinical and sociodemographic characteristics were compared. Diagnostic date was determined by the first appearance of an abnormality on cross-sectional imaging. Zip code of residence was used to estimate median household income using the IRS Individual Income 2017 Tax Statistics.

Results: A total of 101 patients were seen during the time intervals assessed (Pre-COVID19 N=72, COVID19 N=29). Both groups showed similar demographic characteristics with regards to age (median, Pre-COVID19 vs. COVID19: 66 vs. 67 years, P=0.76), sex (%Female, Pre-COVID19 vs. COVID19: 51% vs. 51%, P=1.0), race (%Caucasian: Pre-COVID19 vs. COVID19: 80% vs. 79%, P=1.0), insurance type (%Commercial Pre-COVID19 vs. COVID19: 63% vs. 59%, P=0.82), and median income (Pre-COVID19 vs. COVID19: $51,601 vs. 55,265, P=0.94). Patients diagnosed during COVID19 had a significantly longer time to referral (mean, 46.7 days vs. 27.4 days, P=0.015*), although there was no detectable difference in time to therapy initiation (mean, Pre-COVID19 vs. COVID19: 42.3 days vs. 37.4 days, P=0.69).  When analyzed by income quartile, patients in the lowest three quartiles had the greatest delay in referral to the tertiary care center (Table 1). 

Conclusion: Less than half as many patients diagnosed with pancreatic cancer are being referred for expert evaluation during COVID19. In this limited data set, there is a significantly longer wait for patients to be referred, especially for those in lower income groups. As the COVID19 pandemic persists, proactive communication to referring physicians about the safety of care should be a priority for patients with pancreatic cancer.

abstract_title: Ensuring Goal-Concordant Care in Patients with Pancreatic Cancer: Is Early Palliative Care the Answer?
author_block: L. Demyan<sup>1,2</sup>, G. Wu<sup>4</sup>, G. B. Deutsch<sup>1,4,5</sup>, V. Patel<sup>4</sup>, J. M. Herman<sup>7</sup>, M. J. Weiss<sup>1,4,5</sup>, E. A. Burns<sup>6</sup>, D. Deperalta<sup>1,4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Northwell North Shore/Long Island Jewish,Surgical Oncology,New Hyda Park, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory,Cold Spring Harbor, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell,Surgery,New Hyda Park, NY, USA <sup>5</sup>Northwell Health Cancer Institute,New Hyda PArk, NY, USA <sup>6</sup>Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell,Geriatric Medicine,New Hyda Park, NY, USA <sup>7</sup>Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell,Radiation Oncology,New Hyda Park, NY, USA

abstract_title: Impact of Perioperative Blood Transfusions on Outcomes after HIPEC: A Propensity-Matched Analysis
author_block: B. Kubi<sup>1</sup>, R. Nudotor<sup>1</sup>, N. Fackche<sup>1</sup>, J. Cloyd<sup>2</sup>, T. Grotz<sup>3</sup>, K. Fournier<sup>4</sup>, S. Dineen<sup>5</sup>, B. Powers<sup>5</sup>, J. Veerapong<sup>6</sup>, J. Baumgartner<sup>6</sup>, C. Clarke<sup>7</sup>, S. H. Patel<sup>8</sup>, L. Lambert<sup>9</sup>, D. Abbott<sup>10</sup>, K. V. Walle<sup>10</sup>, M. Raoof<sup>11</sup>, B. Lee<sup>11</sup>, S. Maithel<sup>12</sup>, C. Staley<sup>12</sup>, F. Johnston<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Greer<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University,Department Of Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Mayo Clinic,Division Of Hepatobiliary And Pancreatic Surgery,Rochester, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Department Of Surgical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute,Department Of Gastrointestinal Oncology,Tampa, FL, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of California - San Diego,Division Of Surgical Oncology,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>7</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Department Of Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>10</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Madison, WI, USA <sup>11</sup>City Of Hope National Medical Center,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Duarte, CA, USA <sup>12</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (CRS/HIPEC) is a complex procedure with the potential for significant blood loss. Using multi-institutional data from the US HIPEC Collaborative, we sought to determine the impact of perioperative allogenic blood transfusions (PABT) on patients undergoing CRS/HIPEC.

Methods:  This is a retrospective cohort study of patients who underwent CRS/HIPEC for peritoneal surface malignancy between 2000 and 2017. The association between PABT and demographic, preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative variables was assessed. Propensity score matching was performed to mitigate bias. Univariate analysis was used to compare demographic, preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative variables. We identified factors independently associated with PABT using multivariate analysis. 

Results: There were 1717 patients that met inclusion criteria, of which 510 (29.7%) required PABT. The mean PCI of our cohort was 14.8 ± 9.3. After propensity score matching (using the covariates of age, sex, BMI, operative time, baseline albumin level, liver resection status, estimated blood loss and baseline hemoglobin level), PABT was independently associated with an increased postoperative risk of pleural effusion, hemorrhage, pulmonary embolism, enteric fistula formation, Grade III/IV morbidity, lengthened hospital stay and reoperation (all p < 0.05 on multivariate analysis). Compared to patients that received 1-5 RBC units, patients that received > 5 units had an increased risk of renal impairment, longer ICU stay, and postoperative infections. Finally, PABT was an independent predictor of worsened survival in patients with tumors of appendiceal (RR 3.02, CI 1.79 – 5.10, p = 0.001).  and colorectal (RR 4.33, CI 1.56 – 12.00, p = 0.005) origin. 

Conclusion: Even low levels of PABT in patients undergoing CRS/HIPEC are independently associated with increased risk of infectious and non-infectious postoperative complications, and this risk is increased in patients receiving > 5 RBC units. PABT was an independent predictor of worsened survival in peritoneal carcinomatosis from appendiceal and colorectal primaries.

abstract_title: Readmissions from Venous Thromboembolism after Major Cancer Surgery - An Underappreciated Burden
author_block: S. Mallick<sup>1</sup>, A. Taylor<sup>2</sup>, P. Varley<sup>2</sup>, D. E. Abbott<sup>2</sup>, C. D. Tzeng<sup>3</sup>, S. M. Weber<sup>2</sup>, N. Wasif<sup>4</sup>, S. N. Zafar<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College,School Of Medicine,Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Mayo Clinic In Arizona,Department Of Surgery,Phoenix, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) is a major cause of preventable morbidity and mortality after cancer surgery. One-third of VTE events occur after discharge and can be serious enough to warrant readmission. However, there is limited data on readmissions due to VTE. We aimed to determine the rates, outcomes, predictive factors, and costs of readmissions due to VTE at 30, 90, and 180 days after complex cancer operations using a national data set.

Methods: Using the 2016 Nationwide Readmissions Database, adult patients who underwent cystectomy, colectomy, esophagectomy, gastrectomy, liver/biliary resection, lung/bronchus resection, pancreatectomy, proctectomy, prostatectomy or hysterectomy for a corresponding cancer diagnosis were identified using ICD 10 codes. Outcomes included 30-day, 90-day, and 180-day readmissions to index and non-index hospitals. Readmissions with a primary cause of acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and Pulmonary embolism (PE) were selected. Hospital costs, length of stay, and mortality associated with VTE readmissions were analyzed. Factors present at the index operation and associated with readmissions were identified using multivariable logistic regression.

Results: Of the 126,104 patients included in the study, 30-day, 90-day, and 180-day VTE readmission rates were 0.62%, 1.07%, and 1.74% respectively. A total of 1,449 (1.74%) patients were readmitted within 6 months of surgery for VTE, of which 810 patients (0.96%) were readmitted for PE, and 639 (0.77%) for DVT. The rates of VTE readmissions continued to rise well beyond the 30-day period. The highest rates were seen after cystectomy (3.28%), followed by pancreatectomy (3.14%) (Figure 1). Of the patients that were readmitted for VTE; 473 (32.64%) were readmitted to a different hospital, 74 (5.11%) died, the median length of stay was 4 days (IQR 2.50-6.75), and total hospital cost for the readmissions were $25.6 million. Independent factors associated with readmission for VTE included type of procedure, increasing age (OR=1.17; 95% CI=1.05-1.28), female gender (OR=1.23; 95% CI=1.11-1.37), emergent admission (OR=1.31; 95% CI=1.03-1.68), increased number of comorbidities (OR=1.30; 95% CI=1.06-1.60), and suffering a major postoperative complication during the index admission (OR=2.08; 95% CI=1.85-2.33).

Conclusion: Readmissions due to VTE after major cancer surgery continue to increase well beyond 30 days after surgery. They occur frequently at non-index hospitals and bear a significant mortality/cost burden. These results suggest that the burden of VTE after complex cancer surgery is grossly underappreciated by registries focused on 30-day outcomes. High risk patients would likely benefit from extended VTE prophylaxis.

abstract_title: Pulmonary Complications After Esophagectomy and Neoadjuvant Radiation for Malignant Neoplasm
author_block: M. A. Beier<sup>1</sup>, A. Greenbaum<sup>1</sup>, A. Kangas-Dick<sup>1,2</sup>, D. A. August<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Rutgers Cancer Institute And Rutgers Robert Wood Johnson Medical School,New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Maimonides Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Brooklyn, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Post-operative pulmonary complications (POPC) are common in patients undergoing esophagectomy, and recent literature suggests neoadjuvant radiotherapy (nRT) may exacerbate POPC. The aim of this study was to assess whether nRT increases the incidence of POPC in patients undergoing esophagectomy, and especially in patients with pre-existing pulmonary disease (PEPD).

Methods:   The American College of Surgeons-National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database was queried from 2016-2018 for patients undergoing esophagectomy for malignant neoplasm.  Inverse Probability Treatment Weighting (IPTW) was used to create balanced cohorts on baseline characteristics in which the control cohort received neoadjuvant chemotherapy (nCT) alone and the treatment cohort received neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (nCRT). POPC were defined as pneumonia (PNA), unplanned intubation (UI), and prolonged mechanical ventilation (PMV). The roles of chest incision and tumor pathology were also considered in an odds ratio (OR) analysis. In addition to an analysis on the overall population undergoing esophagectomy for malignancy, a subset analysis was performed on patients with PEPD, which was defined as pre-existing COPD and/or dyspnea.

Results:  A total of 1,611 patients met inclusion/exclusion criteria; 227 received nCT and 1,384 received nCRT.  After IPTW, there remained an imbalance on pathology with more squamous-cell carcinoma (SCC) in the nCRT vs the nCT cohort (8.3% vs 6.6%, p=0.08) and on chest incision with fewer open thoracotomies in the nCRT vs the nCT cohort (36.5% vs 41.1%, p=0.01).  All-patient analysis did not demonstrate a consistent association between nRT and POPC. However, on sub-analysis of patients with PEPD, POPC occurred more often in the nCRT cohort. When comparing nCRT to nCT, PNA occurred in 16.8% vs 8.4% (p=0.02), UI in 16.2% vs 9.0% (p=0.05), and PMV in 14.1% vs 4.4% (p=0.002) of patients. There was a trend toward higher odds of POPC in patients with open chest incision in both all-patient and PEPD sub-analysis across all three POPC. In particular, PMV was more frequent in the nCRT cohort (all-patient: OR=1.63, p=0.02; PEPD: OR=2.80, p=0.02) as was UI in patients with PEPD (OR=2.60, p=0.01). UI occurred more frequently in patients with SCC in comparison to adenocarcinoma (AC) in both all-patient (OR=2.01, p=0.02) and PEPD (OR=3.31, p=0.03) analyses. 

Conclusion:  In patients with PEPD, there is a statistically and clinically significant increase in POPC with receipt of nRT.  The absence of a significant association in the general esophagectomy population suggests any effect of nRT on pulmonary function is not great enough to impact POPC.

abstract_title: Decisional Conflict in Patients with Different Maximizing-Minimizing Preferences Following MSLT-II
author_block: N. M. Mott<sup>1</sup>, B. Bredbeck<sup>2,3</sup>, B. Ellsworth<sup>1</sup>, J. Miller<sup>3</sup>, T. M. Hughes<sup>2</sup>, K. Kummerow Broman<sup>4</sup>, L. A. Dossett<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Institute For Healthcare Policy And Innovation,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute,Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  In 2017 the second Multicenter Selective Lymphadenectomy Trial (MSLT-II) demonstrated that immediate completion lymph node dissection (CLND) for sentinel lymph node biopsy positive (SLNB+) melanoma offers local disease control but not a survival benefit.1 National Cancer Center Network guidelines now promote ultrasound (US) surveillance as an alternative to CLND for these patients. The single-item maximizer-minimizer elicitation question (MM1) is a recently validated question that can quickly categorize an individual as a medical “maximizer” who generally pursues intervention regardless of necessity or a “minimizer” who generally refuses intervention unless deemed essential. It is unclear whether patients’ maximizing-minimizing preferences impact their level of decisional conflict or anxiety related to cancer surveillance and recurrence in this context.

Methods:  As part of an explanatory mixed-methods study, we administered online surveys to patients recently diagnosed with SLNB+ melanoma at a high-volume institution. Questions included a satisfaction with decision scale (SDS) and 5-point unipolar and bipolar Likert scales addressing cancer surveillance and anxiety. A sample of these patients participated in an explanatory semi-structured interview. We classified interviewees as medical maximizers or minimizers based on their responses to the MM1. We then analyzed quantitative data descriptively and qualitative data thematically according to these groups.

Results: Participants were distributed across the MM1 as follows: maximizer 60%, neutral 20%, minimizer 20%. Most providers (87.5%) recommended US surveillance over CLND. All maximizers and minimizers followed their providers’ recommendations. Three-fourths agreed that their decision for US surveillance or CLND was the best for them personally and in line with their personal values; one-fourth were unsure. Despite this, survey data demonstrated that on average maximizers were slightly to moderately anxious when getting ultrasounds (2.2 on unipolar Likert scale), while minimizers were not at all anxious (1.0 on unipolar Likert scale). Moreover, maximizers reported some concern about residual cancer in the lymph node basin compared to minimizers who did not report any concern (4.0 vs 3.0 on bipolar Likert scale). Interviews in which participants discussed decisional conflict touched on ideas of feeling overwhelmed, “labeled” by a cancer diagnosis, and inadequately treated with SLNB alone.

Conclusion: Medical maximizers may accept their providers’ recommendations for conservative treatment despite generally preferring to receive intervention regardless of necessity. Decisions that do not align with their underlying maximizing tendences can result in increased decisional conflict, which impacts their overall medical care. This finding highlights the need for ongoing counseling throughout cancer surveillance and survivorship.

abstract_title: During Cancer & Beyond – Understanding Cancer Survivorship & Quality of Life
author_block: K. S. Ahmed<sup>1</sup>, M. I. Sajid<sup>1</sup>, U. Waqar<sup>1</sup>, F. Aamir<sup>1</sup>, H. Khan<sup>2</sup>, R. Akhund<sup>1</sup>, M. Ali<sup>1</sup>, A. Sidhwa<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Arain<sup>3</sup>, S. Zafar<sup>4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College,Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>2</sup>Dubai Medical College,Dubai, DUBAI, United Arab Emirates <sup>3</sup>Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre,Department Of Surgery,Karachi, SINDH, Pakistan <sup>4</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cancer causes significant disruptions to Quality of life (QoL) from diagnosis to well beyond completion of treatment. As such, QOL, assessed by physical function, mental status, and ability to engage in basic social interactions has emerged as an essential patient centric outcome. We aimed to perform a systematic review to summarize QoL issues faced by cancer patients and to identify gaps in knowledge.

Methods: We performed a systematic review of literature using PubMed, CINAHL, and Science Direct. Keywords used were ‘Survivorship’, ‘Quality of Life’, and ‘Cancer’ and their MeSH derivatives. Original articles published in English, and between the years 2005-2020 were included. Original research articles that utilized a validated questionnaire to measure HRQoL were included while articles using unvalidated questionnaires were excluded. Two independent authors reviewed the title and abstract, and four independent authors reviewed the full-text, with any discrepancies resolved by an independent author. The quality of life was categorized using macro indicators (MAQoL) defined by the National Association of State Directors of Developmental Disabilities Services. The indicators included work, community inclusion, choices and decisions, self-determination, relationships and satisfaction

Results: Of 9,888 studies identified, 269 articles were included for review. These represented a total of 141,875 patients. Cancer survivorship and QOL was most commonly studied for Reproductive cancers (66 articles; 24.6%) followed by Breast (40; 14.9), Head & Neck (36; 13.4%) and Gastrointestinal cancers (34; 12.7%). Majority of studies focused on the Extended and Permanent phase of cancer survivorship (195; 74.3%). By treatment, 206 studies (76.9%) reported QoL outcomes after surgical intervention, 171 (63.8%) after radiotherapy and 165 (61.6%) after chemotherapy. Across all studies, the most affected MAQoLs were Self-Determination (24.3%) and Work (23.1%), revealing the disruptive impact of various oncologic processes and/or their treatment modalities on physical functioning (76.9%) and social functioning (68.3%) specifically, but also indirectly on emotional well-being (64.8%) and pain levels (18.0%) of cancer patients and long-term survivors.

Conclusion: Most studies assessing QoL of cancer patients focus on the post-treatment time period during the Extended and Permanent phase of survivorship. Further research is required to evaluate HRQoL during the Acute phase to help understand the issues patients face after diagnosis and during treatment.

abstract_title: Preoperative Serum Chromogranin-A is Predictive of Survival in Locoregional Small Bowel Neuroendocrine Tumors
author_block: P. D. Chatani<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Aversa<sup>1</sup>, J. D. McDonald<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Khan<sup>1</sup>, N. N. Nilubol<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>National Cancer Institute,Surgical Oncology Program,Bethesda, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Small bowel neuroendocrine tumors (SB-NET) often exhibit an indolent course despite frequently metastasizing to regional lymphatic or distant sites. Most investigations aiming to improve prognostication in SB-NET have centered on lymph node involvement. Unlike other NETs, the prognostic utility of preoperative serum chromogranin-A (CgA) in non-metastatic SB-NET is not well studied.

Methods:  Using the National Cancer Database (2004-2016), we analyzed patients with locoregional SB-NET who underwent curative resection including an adequate lymphadenectomy (n = 1,274). A statistically optimized cut-point was used to dichotomize the patient cohort based on their preoperative serum CgA levels. Clinical features associated with overall survival were analyzed. 

Results: Using a CgA cut-point of 139ng/mL, patients with CgA ≥ 139ng/mL were older (63 years vs. 57 years, p = 0.001), more likely to have well-differentiated tumors (83.6% vs. 78.8%, p = 0.014) or primary tumors ≥1cm (88.2% vs. 79.2%, p = 0.001), and had a significantly shorter estimated mean overall survival (6.6 years vs. 7.6 years, log-rank p = 0.00001). Independent clinical features associated with shorter overall survival included: preoperative CgA ≥139ng/mL (HR = 2.21, 95% CI 1.24 – 3.95; p = 0.007), age at diagnosis (HR = 1.06, 95% CI 1.03 – 1.09; p < 0.001), Charlson-Deyo score >2 (HR = 3.39, 95% CI 1.44 – 7.99; p = 0.005), and poorly-differentiated tumors (HR = 11.26, 95% CI 4.14 – 30.65; p < 0.001). Lymph node metastasis is common in this cohort (n = 1,157; 91%), however, neither lymph node metastasis nor T-stage had an independent association with overall survival in patients with locoregional SB-NET. 

Conclusion: Preoperative serum CgA ≥139ng/mL is an adverse prognostic marker associated with shorter overall survival in patients with locoregional SB-NET. Neither lymph node metastasis nor T-stage was independently associated with overall survival.

abstract_title: Characteristics of Exceptional vs Poor Survivors in Appendiceal Cancer Patients Undergoing CRS/HIPEC
author_block: G. SenthilKumar<sup>1</sup>, S. Thalji<sup>1</sup>, C. N. Clarke<sup>1</sup>, C. Kimbrough<sup>2</sup>, K. Fournier<sup>3</sup>, A. Lee<sup>3</sup>, C. Pokrzywa<sup>4</sup>, D. E. Abbott<sup>4</sup>, V. Dhar<sup>5</sup>, S. Patel<sup>5</sup>, J. Greer<sup>6</sup>, F. Johnston<sup>6</sup>, S. Dineen<sup>7</sup>, S. Dessureault<sup>7</sup>, J. Baumgartner<sup>8</sup>, J. Veerapong<sup>8</sup>, J. Leiting<sup>9</sup>, T. Grotz<sup>9</sup>, S. K. Maithel<sup>10</sup>, C. Staley<sup>10</sup>, B. Lee<sup>11</sup>, M. Raoof<sup>11</sup>, L. Lambert<sup>13</sup>, R. Hendrix<sup>12</sup>, J. Cloyd<sup>2</sup>, H. Mogal<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Surgical Oncology,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center,Surgical Oncology,Columbus, OHIO, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Surgical Oncology,Houston, TEXAS, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Surgical Oncology,Madison, WI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>6</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>7</sup>Morsani College of Medicine,Gastrointestinal Oncology And Oncologic Sciences,Tampa, FLORIDA, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of California - San Diego,Surgical Oncology,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>9</sup>Mayo Clinic,Hepatobiliary And Pancreas Surgery,Rochester, MN, USA <sup>10</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Surgical Oncology,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>11</sup>City Of Hope National Medical Center,Surgical Oncology,Duarte, CA, USA <sup>12</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Surgical Oncology,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>13</sup>Huntsman Cancer Institute At The University Of Utah,Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Outcomes after cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (CRS/HIPEC) for disseminated appendiceal cancer (dAC) vary greatly based on pathologic subtype. Characterizing exceptional (ES) and poor survivors (PS) may help improve prognostication and patient selection for surgery. 

Methods:  Data from a retrospective, 12-institution cohort of low and high grade appendiceal (LGA, HGA) patients treated with CRS/HIPEC that had complete cytoreduction (CC0/1) was utilized. ES and PS were defined as ≥75th and ≤ 25th percentile of overall survival (OS) respectively. Perioperative variables, OS, and recurrence-free survival (RFS) were compared between ES and PS. Univariate and multivariate analyses (UVA, MVA) identified factors associated with OS and RFS.

Results: Of the 888 dAC patients with CC0/1 resection, 664 were LGA and 224 were HGA. In both HGA and LGA patients, OS was significantly different between ES, intermediate, and PS subgroups (Fig.1). For LGA, median RFS for ES vs. PS was 80.6mo vs 13.9mo, p=0.096; for HGA, 36.1mo vs 28.4mo, p=0.001.  In comparison to LGA-PS, ES had significantly lower mean BMI (27.3 vs 28.7, p=0.024), higher median CA125 levels (27.7U/ml vs 17.0U/ml, p=0.030), and higher % of patients with CRS without HIPEC (15.1% vs 1.8%, p<0.0001). All LGA patients had PCI scores ≤ 20. In LGA-ES, neoadjuvant chemotherapy (HR 5.2, CI 1.7-15.9, p=0.004) and elevated CA19-9 levels (>37U/ml; HR 10.2, CI 1.1-91/6) were associated with worse OS, however, only elevated levels of CA19-9 remained significant for OS (HR 10.2, CI 1.1-91.6, p=0.038) and RFS (HR 4.5, CI 1.6-12.7, p=0.004) on MVA. In LGA-PS, Clavien-Dindo Grade ≥ 3 (HR 7.2, CI 1.9-26.2, p=0.003) and elevated CEA (>5ng/ml; HR 8.313, CI 0.95-71.7, p=0.05) were associated with worse OS, and remained significant on MVA (HR 10.3, CI 1.1-92.9, p=0.04 and HR 10.3, CI 0.988-106.9, p=0.05 respectively). HGA-ES had significantly lower nodal positivity (17.1% vs 62.5%, p<0.0001) and higher proportion of patients with CRS without HIPEC (33.9% vs 14.3%, p=0.015). In HGA-ES, perioperative systemic chemotherapy (4.2, CI 1.2-13.9, p=0.021) was associated with worse OS only on UVA. In HGA-PS, higher CA125 level (HR 1.02, CI 1.0-1.04, p=0.044) was associated with worse OS in UVA and remained significant (HR 1.02, CI 1.0-1.04, p=0.044) on MVA.

Conclusion: In this large cohort of dAC patients undergoing CC0/1 resection, perioperative characteristics of ES vs PS patients varied based on histological subtype. Elevated tumor biomarkers independently predicted worse OS in LGA and HGA-PS patients. Stratification of outliers by histologic subtype and survival category may provide insight into tumor biology and improve patient selection for surgery.

abstract_title: Oncologic Outcome of Low Testosterone in Male Patients with Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: A. Kazarian<sup>5</sup>, H. Conger<sup>5</sup>, S. Mott<sup>1</sup>, B. Loeffler<sup>1</sup>, S. Dempewolf<sup>1</sup>, M. Rupe<sup>1</sup>, A. Tomanek-Chalkley<sup>3</sup>, K. Coleman<sup>1</sup>, A. Pearlman<sup>4</sup>, E. Talbert<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Chan<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Holden Comprehensive Cancer Center,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa,Department Of Health And Human Physiology,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Iowa,Department Of Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Iowa,Department Of Urology,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Iowa,Carver College Of Medicine,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) is one of the leading causes of cancer-related death. Treatment for PDA involves an intensive combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and/or radiation that is often difficult for patients to tolerate. Recent studies have found that patients with PDA have worse quality of life (QOL) measures in all categories compared to patients with other cancer types. Testosterone deficiency is associated with chronic fatigue and weakness in addition to male sexual dysfunction. We have recently discovered that male PDA patients are rarely screened for testosterone deficiency despite reporting symptoms. Additionally, it has been shown that PDA may overexpress androgen receptors playing a role in tumorigenesis and disease progression. Our study aims to determine if male PDA patients have low testosterone levels and if testosterone levels correlated with oncologic outcome.

Methods: Serum samples were obtained from a cohort of male PDA patients enrolled in an institutional prospective repository at a National Cancer Institute-designated comprehensive cancer center from 2012-2020. Total testosterone (ng/dL) of each sample was measured using ELISA methods. Low testosterone was defined as a level <300ng/dL per the American Urology Association guideline. Demographic and clinicopathologic variables, treatment and outcome data were abstracted. Cox regression models were used to assess the effect of patient and disease characteristics on progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). 

Results: Serum samples were available from 89 male PDA patients. Of these patients, 69.7% reported symptoms of low testosterone prior to sample collection, and nearly half (49.4%) were found to have a low testosterone level (median: 202ng/dL; range: 123-294ng/dL). Only 2.2% of patients had a prior testosterone level measured; none received testosterone replacement therapy. Fatigue was the most commonly reported symptom consistent with testosterone deficiency. After adjusting for metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis and treatment, testosterone level had no statistically significant effect on PFS (p=0.66) or OS (p=0.95).

Conclusion: Nearly half of the male PDA patients in this cohort were found to have low serum testosterone levels, but very few were tested in the clinical setting despite reporting symptoms. The overlapping symptoms between cancer and testosterone deficiency including fatigue and weakness may be the main reason for the lack of testosterone testing. Since there was no apparent difference in oncological outcome between PDA patients with low or normal testosterone levels, testosterone supplementation is most likely safe and may improve patients’ QOL allowing them to better tolerate the intense treatment for PDA. Further prospective studies are warranted to explore the role of testosterone supplementation in improving men’s health and overall well-being during PDA treatment.

abstract_title: Risk of Leukopenia on Appendectomy and Cholecystectomy Outcomes in Children with Cancer
author_block: P. P. Patel<sup>1</sup>, J. H. Weller<sup>1</sup>, C. R. Westermann<sup>1</sup>, D. S. Rhee<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Children undergoing cancer treatment often develop leukopenia, which may impair wound healing and increase surgical complication rates. In leukopenic children who develop an acute surgical process, the optimal management strategy remains unclear. This study examined the effect of preoperative leukopenia on postoperative outcomes in children treated for cancer who underwent an appendectomy or cholecystectomy.

Methods: This was a retrospective cohort study of pediatric cancer patients in the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program-Pediatric database from 2012-2018. Patients <18 years old with any active cancer who underwent an appendectomy or cholecystectomy were included. Children receiving other major concurrent operations were excluded. Patient demographics and perioperative characteristics were compared by leukopenia status (WBC <4 vs. ≥4 x 10^3/mL) using chi-squared and Kruskal-Wallis tests for categorical variables and Mann-Whitney U tests for continuous variables. Primary outcomes of 30-day composite complications, including infections, reoperations, and readmissions, as well as postoperative length of stay (LOS) were analyzed by leukopenia status for each procedure using multivariate logistic and log-transformed linear regression.

Results: A total of 328 children met inclusion criteria, with 227 (69.2%) appendectomy and 101 (30.8%) cholecystectomy cases. Children were typically male (n=202, 61.6%) and white (n=243, 74.0%) with a median age at operation of 12 years (IQR 8.7-15.1). Leukopenia was seen in 93 (41.0%) appendectomies and 57 (56.4%) cholecystectomies. There were no significant differences in operative time or use of laparoscopy by leukopenic status for either procedure. Nineteen (8.4%) appendectomy patients developed a postoperative complication as compared to six (5.9%) cholecystectomy patients. The mean postoperative LOS was 4.5 days (SD 5.9) for appendectomies and 3 days (SD 4.8) for cholecystectomies. After multivariate analyses, leukopenia was not associated with an increase in postoperative complications for children undergoing appendectomies (OR 0.55, p=0.36) or cholecystectomies (OR 0.39, p=0.37). There was also no significant different in postoperative LOS for patients with versus without leukopenia who underwent an appendectomy (1.27 days, p=0.15) or cholecystectomy (1.08 days, p=0.71).

Conclusion: In children with active cancer, leukopenia was not associated with increased short-term postoperative complications or longer postoperative LOS after either an appendectomy or cholecystectomy. This suggests delaying procedures for leukopenia in this population might not be necessary.

abstract_title: Imatinib-Resistant Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors: Does Surgery Have a Role?
author_block: T. L. Sutton<sup>4</sup>, K. G. Billingsley<sup>1,5</sup>, B. Sheppard<sup>4,5</sup>, E. Dewey<sup>4</sup>, C. Corless<sup>3,5</sup>, M. C. Heinrich<sup>2,5</sup>, S. C. Mayo<sup>1,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Oregon Health And Science University,Surgical Oncology,Portland, OR, USA <sup>2</sup>Oregon Health And Science University,Hematology And Oncology,Portland, OR, USA <sup>3</sup>Oregon Health And Science University,Pathology,Portland, OR, USA <sup>4</sup>Oregon Health And Science University,General Surgery,Portland, OR, USA <sup>5</sup>Oregon Health And Science University,Knight Cancer Institute,Portland, OR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Imatinib-resistance (ImR) is the strongest determinant of disease progression and mortality in recurrent and metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). While 2nd and 3rd-line tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) have prolonged progression-free and possibly overall survival (OS) in ImR GIST, the role of resection in this population remains unclear. We sought to investigate factors predictive of OS and progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with ImR GIST.

Methods: A query of our prospectively maintained Comprehensive Cancer Center registry was performed from 2003-2019 for patients with ImR GIST. Clinicopathologic characteristics along with medical and surgical treatments following progression or recurrence on first-line imatinib were collected; OS and PFS were analyzed with Kaplan-Meier and Cox proportional hazards modeling.

Results: N=84 patients developed ImR during the study period at a median age of 59 years and median time to ImR of 50 months following initiation of imatinib. The majority of patients were men (n=49, 58%) and non-metastatic (n=47, 56%) at original diagnosis, with small bowel being the most common primary tumor location (n=37; 44%). ImR most commonly emerged in the liver (n=37, 44%) and peritoneum (n=28, 33%). Sunitinib was the most common second-line TKI (n=71, 85%). The median OS following development of ImR was 51 months (95% C.I. 32-70 months). After being diagnosed with ImR, n=17 (20%) patients underwent resection (either curative-intent or cytoreduction) along with 2nd line TKI therapy, while n=62 (74%) underwent TKI therapy alone and n=5 (6%) did not receive further therapy. On multivariable analysis, age at ImR (HR 1.04 per year, 95% C.I 1.01-1.06, p<0.01), KIT mutation (HR 8.38, 95% C.I. 1.9-37.2, p<0.01), and time to failure of 2nd-line TKI (HR 0.97 per month, 95% C.I. 0.95-0.99, p<0.001) were independently associated with OS; similar results were noted on subgroup analysis of KIT-mutated tumors. On multi-variable analysis, treatment with sunitinib was associated with worse PFS than other agents (HR 3.70, 95% C.I. 1.44-9.50, p<0.01), while resection after ImR was independently associated with improved PFS (HR 0.50, 95% C.I. 0.27-0.92, p<0.05). In patients treated with 2nd-line sunitinib, surgical resection of metastatic disease was the only factor independently associated with PFS (HR 0.50, 95% C.I., 0.27-0.93, p<0.05).

Conclusion: Long term survival can be achieved in patients who develop imatinib-resistant GIST treated with additional lines of TKI therapies. Surgical intervention should be considered in imatinib-resistant GIST in appropriately selected patients and is associated with improved PFS.

abstract_title: Partial Gastrectomy Confers a better Overall Survival in Signet-ring Cell Gastric Cancer
author_block: M. A. Moslim<sup>1</sup>, E. Handorf<sup>2</sup>, S. S. Reddy<sup>1</sup>, S. H. Greco<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Farma<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Surgical Oncology,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Biostatistics And Bioinformatics,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Signet-ring cell gastric cancer (SRGC) is a variant of gastric adenocarcinoma (GAC) with worse prognosis compared to non-signet-ring cell gastric cancer (NSRGC). To our knowledge, the overall survival among patients with SRGC histology variant undergoing total/subtotal versus partial gastrectomy has never been reported in a large cohort in the literature.  

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) from 2004-2016 was queried to identify patients with GAC stratified according to histopathology, tumor location and extent of gastrectomy. We performed a Cox proportional hazards regression to assess the impact of surgery type and histo-pathology on overall survival, adjusting for age, race, tumor location in the stomach, clinical stage, histologic grade and chemotherapy. We assessed whether the effect of surgery type differed by histology by including an interaction between the two variables.  

Results: Out of 153917 patients with GAC, 17086 (11.1%) were eligible for the analysis. Patients who underwent total/subtotal versus partial gastrectomy were 25.5% (n=770) versus 74.5% (n=2246) for SRGC, and 20.9% (n=2943) versus 79.1% (n=11127) for NSRGC histology variants, respectively. It was noted that patients who had SRGC were more likely to undergo total/subtotal gastrectomy (25.5% vs. 20.9%. p<0.0001). Distal gastric tumors were less likely to undergo total/subtotal gastrectomy (16.5% vs. 25.4%. p<0.0001). Patients undergoing partial gastrectomy for the SRGC histology variant have better overall survival (HR=0.68, CI=0.61-0.76; p<0.0001). This is also validated in the NSRGC histology variant, but to a lesser extent (HR=0.91, CI=0.85-0.96; p=0.002). Overall, patients treated with partial gastrectomy for GAC have a better prognosis compared to total/subtotal gastrectomy, although the overall survival benefit is more profound in the SRGC histology variant (p<0.0001).  

Conclusion: Our results show that total/subtotal gastrectomy is not associated with improved overall survival in patients who undergo gastrectomy for GAC, even when adjusted for tumor location. The survival benefits of partial gastrectomy are more pronounced in the SRGC histology variant. The worst survival is observed in patients with SRGC who undergo total/subtotal gastrectomy after adjusting to different covariates.

abstract_title: Necessity of Post-Treatment Surveillance for Low Grade Appendiceal Mucinous Neoplasms
author_block: A. R. Gupta<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Brajcich<sup>1,2</sup>, B. A. Pagni<sup>1</sup>, A. D. Yang<sup>1,2</sup>, D. J. Bentrem<sup>1,2</sup>, R. P. Merkow<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement Center,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center, Northwestern University,Northwestern Institute For Comparative Effectiveness Research In Oncology,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Low-grade appendiceal mucinous neoplasms (LAMNs) are rare tumors characterized by a dilated, mucus-filled appendix. Surgical resection is generally curative for LAMNs, but post-treatment surveillance protocols are not well-established. The objectives of this study were to 1) assess the utilization of post-treatment surveillance monitoring and 2) determine the risk of recurrence of LAMNs following surgery.

Methods: Patients who underwent surgical resection of localized LAMNs in a regional healthcare system from 2000-2019 were identified. Patients were assigned to cohorts based on whether post-treatment surveillance was performed. Post-treatment surveillance regimens were characterized based on use of imaging, laboratory testing, and endoscopy. Rates of disease recurrence were evaluated.

Results: A total of 114 patients with LAMNs were identified, including 71 (62.3%) with incidentally found lesions and 39 (34.2%) who presented with symptoms of appendicitis. T stage was pTis for 92 (80.7%), pT3 for 7 (6.1%), pT4a for 14 (12.3%), and pT4b for 1 (0.9%) patient. Ninety-one (79.8%) patients were treated with appendectomy alone and 23 (20.2%) were treated with hemicolectomy. Two patients (1.8%) had a positive resection margin, both after appendectomy. Post-treatment surveillance was performed for 36 (31.6%) patients.  Surveillance regimens included office visits for 31 (86.1%) patients, CT scan for 29 (80.6%), MRI for 4 (11.1%), colonoscopy for 13 (36.1%), and serum tumor marker measurement for 12 (33.3%). After a mean duration of 3.4 years following surgery (range: 0.02-16.5), no patients in either cohort experienced tumor recurrence.

Conclusion: To our knowledge, this is the largest study to date evaluating surveillance and recurrence rates for LAMN without peritoneal spread. Surveillance was common among patients following surgical treatment of LAMN, however, no patients experienced tumor recurrence, regardless of stage or margin status. These findings suggest that routine surveillance following surgical resection of LAMN may be unnecessary and represent overutilization of healthcare resources for most patients.

abstract_title: Neoadjuvant and Adjuvant Therapy Limits the Prognostic Value of Lymph Node Ratio in Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: S. E. Hopkins<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Moslim<sup>1</sup>, E. A. O'Halloran<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Minarich<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Julian<sup>2</sup>, A. B. Roitman<sup>2</sup>, M. D. Lefton<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Reddy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Surgical Oncology,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Temple University,Lewis Katz School Of Medicine,Philadelpha, PA, USA

abstract_title: Postoperative Peritoneal Carcinomatosis Index on Survival of Patients with Peritoneal Surface Malignancy
author_block: A. Collier<sup>1</sup>, S. Yadegarynia<sup>1</sup>, F. I. Macedo<sup>1</sup>, J. Kronenfeld<sup>1</sup>, O. Picado<sup>1</sup>, D. Briggi<sup>1</sup>, M. Moller<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mucinous appendiceal tumor-derived peritoneal surface disease (PSD) occurs in 4 cases per million population/year and can progress to Pseudomyxoma Peritonei (PMP). Intraoperative peritoneal carcinomatosis index (I-PCI) and completeness of cytoreduction surgery (CRS) are predictors of survival in patients with peritoneal surface malignancy (PCM) from multiple gastrointestinal malignancies. However, I-PCI is not a reliable predictor in patients with PCM from appendiceal origin. We sought to analyze the impact of postoperative radiological PCI (PR-PCI) on survival rates in this population.

Methods: From August 2002 to July 2019, 40 consecutive patients with PCM from appendiceal origin undergoing CRS/HIPEC were included in the analysis. Pre- and post-resection Peritoneal Cancer Index (PCI) scores, extent of resection, complications, and length of hospital/ICU stay were documented and follow-ups were analyzed. Kaplan-Meier survival analysis and Cox proportional hazards model evaluated factors associated with increased mortality. PCI cutoff of 16 was used for both PR-PCI and I-PCI.

Results:The median age of patients were 55 years old (rang of 37-71); 55% were female and 55% Hispanic. 57.5% of the patients had no significant comorbidities; 55% with an ECOG status of 0. 33% had a ruptured appendix on primary resection, 68% extra-appendiceal mucin, 37% intraperitoneal mucin. Pathology revealed adenocarcinoma in 67.5% and low-grade appendiceal neoplasm in 30%. Median exploratory PCI of 20 (0-37); median post-op PCI of 0 (0-34) with 75% had cytoreductive score 0. 75% had no postoperative complications. Complications included:  3 had anastomotic leak, 2 wound infections, 2 ileus, 2 fistulas, and 1 DVT. Median follow-up time after CRS/HIPEC was 12.9 months (range 0.5-50), 75% were alive, 42.5% without disease, 22.5% with cancer-specific death. Tumor characteristics, intraoperative variables (including PCI, HR 1.05, 95% CI 0.94-1.16) and postoperative complications were not identified as predictors of survival. Mean I-PCI and PR-PCI were 19.1 ± 11.3 and 4.8  ± 9.3 (p<0.001), respectively. PR-PCI <16 was associated with increased survival rates (HR 1.20, 95% CI 1.06-1.36,, p=0.005). 

Conclusion:PR-PCI seems to be a more reliable predictor of survival than conventional I-PCI in patients with PCM from appendiceal origin undergoing CRS/HIPEC, likely due to a superior correlation with completeness of resection. In conclusion, to decrease mortality risk, patients with peritoneal carcinomatosis of appendiceal origin require achievement of lowest possible postoperative PCI.

abstract_title: Merkel Cell Carcinoma: Evolution in Management of a Rare Malignancy
author_block: A. C. Esposito<sup>1</sup>, D. Jacobs<sup>3</sup>, E. White<sup>1</sup>, J. Clune<sup>2</sup>, S. Ariyan<sup>2</sup>, K. Olino<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Surgical Oncology,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Plastic Surgery,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>3</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Merkel Cell Carcinoma (MCC) is a rare but aggressive cutaneous neuroendocrine malignancy with increasing incidence in the United States. Historically, treatment was limited to surgery, radiation and chemotherapy which was marked by disease progression and survival of 15% in the metastatic setting. More recently immunotherapy has led to nearly 50% early treatment responses. Here we provide our large single institution experience with this diagnosis and changes in management over the last 18 years. 

Methods: This was a single institution retrospective review where the medical record system was queried for ICD-9 and ICD-10 codes corresponding to MCC from 2002-2020. In all, 166 patients were identified to have biopsy proven MCC. Nine were excluded due to incomplete clinicopathologic data, leaving 157 patients evaluable.

Results: Consistent with previous data, 96% of patients were Caucasian, 60% were male with a median age of 75 (range: 41-98). The primary sites were the head and neck 63/157 (40%), trunk or extremities 81/157 (52%) and unknown primary site 13/157 (8%).  At the time of most recent follow up 56/157 (35%) of all patients were deceased, with an MCC disease specific mortality of 24%. Twenty-eight of 156 (18%) patients were found to have in-transit disease (ITD), with 19/156 (12%) initially presenting with ITD. The remaining 9 developed ITD after initial presentation. A surgery was performed on 151/156 (96%) patients. The surgeries performed included: wide local excision (WLE) in 57/151 (38%), MOHS in 2/151 (1%), WLE and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) in 70/151 (46%), WLE and complete lymph node dissection (CLND) in 13/151 (9%), parotidectomy with SLNB in 1/151 (1%), with CLND in 2/151 (1%), CLND alone in 2/151 (1%) of patients. Radiation therapy was performed in 89/156 (57%). Initial radiation therapy targets included the primary alone in 42/89 (47%), nodal basin alone 3/89 (3%), primary and nodal basin 24/89 (27%), site of metastatic disease 3/89 (3%), and unknown 17/89 (19%). Since the initiation of use of  immunotherapy in 2015, 27/88 (31%) of patients received immunotherapy with anti-PD-L1/PD-1 antibodies Of those treated with immunotherapy, 25/27 (93%) were initially treated with pembrolizumab (anti-PD-1) and 9/27 (36%) of these patients recurred requiring additional treatment.  

Conclusions: MCC is a rare yet fatal disease with multiple treatment algorithms utilized since it was first described in 1972. This institutional experience demonstrates the evolving approach to treatment with increasing utilization of immunotherapy since 2015.

abstract_title: Does Surgeon Training Affect Patient Perception of Surgeon Skill in DIEP Flap Breast Reconstruction?
author_block: D. Bhat<sup>1</sup>, T. Kollu<sup>1</sup>, A. Patel<sup>1</sup>, J. Ricci<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Albany Medical College,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Albany, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Bronx, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As social media becomes a more pervasive means of marketing and patient education in plastic surgery, it is important to investigate what factors on a social media profile are most important to patients. Platforms such as Instagram have a limited amount of space in which surgeons can describe their training and background on their profile. The aim of this study is to investigate whether a surgeon’s training background and years of experience advertised on a social media platform influences perception of surgeon competence, patient recruitment likelihood, and referral likelihood. 

Methods: A mockup of an Instagram post was created using a before and after picture of a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap patient (Figure 1). The caption under each post was changed to reflect one of six possible training categories: 1 year of experience, 10 years of experience, 20 years of experience, fellowship, Ivy-league training, and a null case (against which all other cases were compared). Surveys were designed to ask female responders to evaluate surgeon competence, likelihood of becoming a patient, and likelihood of making a referral to their friends or family. Amazon MTurk crowd-sourcing was used to distribute the survey. Demographic data including age, ethnicity, education level, and personal history of breast cancer was collected. 

Results: A total of 675 survey responses were recorded. The majority of responders were Caucasian (57%). Both the surgeon with 20 years of experience and the fellowship-trained surgeon had significantly higher patient recruitment scores compared to the null (p=0.0035, p=0.0304). The majority of responders (67%) preferred a female surgeon. Responders with a personal history of  breast reconstruction assigned lower surgeon competence scores compared to women without a history of breast cancer (p<.0001). Women who underwent breast reconstruction were also less likely to make referrals to their family and friends (p=.0005).        

Conclusion: Surgeon experience influences whether a patient is likely to to seek care from a plastic surgeon. A personal history of breast cancer has a negative impact on perceived surgeon competence as well as patient recruitment likelihood and referral likelihood. Emphasizing lesser years of training or ivy-league training did not make an appreciable difference in patient perception of competence or likelihood of recruiting a new patient.

abstract_title: Predicting Lymphatic Drainage of the Ear: Is Pre-operative Lymphoscintigraphy Sufficient?
author_block: S. Noorbakhsh<sup>1</sup>, K. Olino<sup>2</sup>, S. Weiss<sup>2</sup>, D. Pucar<sup>2</sup>, S. Ariyan<sup>2</sup>, J. Clune<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>West Virginia School of Medicine,Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) for invasive auricular melanoma is standard of care. However, lymphatic drainage from the ear is incompletely understood. The goals of this study are to: 1) assess lymphatic draining patterns in auricular melanoma and 2) to prospectively compare pre-operative lymphoscintigraphy and intra-operative radioisotope sentinel node identification to determine if the methods are equally effective.

Methods: From 1997-2018, patients with melanoma of the ear requiring SLNB were prospectively evaluated with pre-operative lymphoscintigraphy followed by intraoperative radioisotope identification. To identify this cohort of patients, 122 consecutive cases of invasive auricular melanoma were reviewed. Lesion site, pathology, demographic information, and outcomes data were recorded for each patient. Both pre-operative lymphoscintigram and SLNB were performed in 64 patients. Site of pre-operative mapping and site of sentinel node biopsy were recorded as parotid, mastoid, and/or cervical (I-V) for each patient. Comparisons between preoperative lymphoscintigraphy and intraoperative radioisotope identification were made at both the individual level and in aggregate.

Results: Sixty-four patients underwent both pre-operative lymphoscintigram and intra-operative injection of radiotracer with SLNB in this study. On pre-operative lymphoscintigram, 89.1% showed pre-operative drainage to cervical levels I-V, 21.9% showed drainage to the parotid region, and 4.7% showed drainage to the mastoid region. In contrast, intra-operative biopsy was taken from the cervical region in 95.3% of cases, the parotid region in 43.8% of cases, and the mastoid region in 17.2% of cases. Significantly more parotid nodes (p=0.01) and mastoid nodes (p=0.03) were biopsied intra-operatively than were mapped pre-operatively. In total, 33 nodes were biopsied intra-operatively that were not mapped pre-operatively, the majority in the parotid and mastoid regions. Additionally, there were no cases of pre-operative lymphoscintigraphic mapping or intra-operative SLNB outside of the head and neck.

Conclusion: In this study, higher rates of intra-operative sentinel lymph node identification relative to pre-operative mapping indicate that sole reliance on pre-operative lymphoscintigraphy may be insufficient in the operative planning and treatment of auricular melanoma. Our data indicate that the surgeon should diligently survey the head and neck intra-operatively with radioisotope injection and gamma probe to uncover sentinel nodes not visualized pre-operatively. Furthermore, the ipsilateral parotid and mastoid regions require particular attention during intra-operative sentinel node identification. Lymphatic drainage from the ear occurs reliably to the ipsilateral head and neck, and the parotid and mastoid regions were sites of frequent biopsy in our study without corresponding pre-operative mapping.

abstract_title: Mind the Difference: Characterizing the Impact of Behavioral Health Disorders on Craniofacial Trauma
author_block: D. Dugue<sup>1</sup>, G. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, J. Spaniol<sup>1</sup>, J. Maroney<sup>1</sup>, F. Ramsey<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Jones<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University,Philadelphia, PENNSYLVANIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Patients with psychiatric diagnoses carry a greater risk for traumatic injury than the general population. Although the development of behavioral health disorders (BHD) following facial trauma is well-described, current literature fails to characterize how premorbid BHD complicate craniofacial trauma. This study sought to describe the characteristics and outcomes of patients with premorbid BHD sustaining facial fractures. 

Methods:  All adults in the 2013-2016 Trauma Quality Improvement Program (TQIP) datasets who sustained craniofacial fractures were identified using ICD-9 codes. BHD were defined per DSM-V guidelines, using ICD-9 codes for major psychiatric illnesses, alcohol or drug use disorders, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or dementia. Patient demographics, injury characteristics, and fracture patterns were abstracted. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to compare in-hospital outcomes in patients with BHD to those without.  

Results: Of 1,006,618 subjects in the TQIP datasets analyzed, 240,104 experienced craniofacial fractures.  64,217 patients (25%) had one or more premorbid BHD. Patients in the BHD group were older (46.29 vs 45.77, p <0.001) and more likely to be male (75.5 vs 73.7, p <0.001), with higher rates of smoking, hypertension, and advanced hepatic or respiratory disease.  BHD patients were more likely to suffer penetrating injuries (4.9% vs 4.3%, p<0.001), assault (29.9% vs 23.9%, p<0.001), and self-inflicted injuries (2.9% vs 1.2%, p<0.001.  BHD patients more frequently experienced nasal fractures (47.0% vs 42.8%, p<0.001), multiple facial fractures (p<0.001), and severe concomitant injuries, including head injuries (odds ratio [OR] 1.08, p<0.001). Operative management of facial fractures was performed at the same rate among patients with and without BHD (79.8% vs 79.8%, p=0.881). BHD patients displayed significantly higher rates of nearly all in-hospital complications measured, including pneumonia (OR 1.41, p<0.001), drug and alcohol withdrawal (4.0% vs 0.3%, p<0.001), unplanned intubation (OR 1.65, p<0.001) and unplanned transfer to the intensive care unit (1.3% vs 0.8%, p<0.001). Overall, BHD was associated with longer length of hospital stay (7.26 vs. 6.12 days, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Patients with BHD represent a substantial subset of facial trauma patients that is characterized by different mechanisms of injury, injury patterns, and premorbid health status. BHD are associated with higher in-hospital complication rates and higher resource utilization.  Understanding the relationship between craniofacial trauma and premorbid BHD creates opportunities for intervention that may decrease the morbidity and resource utilization of this group.

abstract_title: Trends in Opioid Prescription for Craniofacial Trauma in the US: An 11 Year Retrospective Study
author_block: J. Shah<sup>1</sup>, R. Lesko<sup>1</sup>, J. Ricci<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Montefiore Medical Center,Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Bronx, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Facial trauma can be disfiguring and painful, with a wide spectrum of possible mechanisms and injury patterns. It can occur in patients of all ages and is associated with significant long-term morbidity and pain. Consequently, patients suffering craniofacial trauma are routinely prescribed opioid medication, and are at risk for opioid dependence. In this study, National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NAMCS) and National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NHAMCS) data was analyzed for trends in opioid prescription for the management of craniofacial trauma.

Methods:  NAMCS and NHAMCS data was extracted from the United States National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) for the years 2006-2016. These databases capture annual samples of ambulatory visits made to hospital emergency departments (EDs) and non-federally employed, office-based physicians respectively. Craniomaxillofacial trauma, as identified by ICD codes, represented 7,997,454 visits in the United States over this time period. Trends in opioid and non-opioid prescription were studied, with variables of interest including demographics, geographic region, and expected source of payment.

Results: From 2006-2016, 1,209 observations were recorded in the combined NCHS dataset representing 7,997,454 visits. 58% of visits were male, and 42% were female. Patients aged 18-44 represented 46% of all visits for craniomaxillofacial trauma. Binomial logistic regression revealed multiple factors independently associated with increased odds of opioid prescription. Age 18-44 (OR 2.51, CI 1.28-4.94, p=0.01), black ethnicity (OR 1.67, CI 1.09-2.55, p = 0.02), private insurance (OR 2.27, CI 1.13-4.58, p=0.02), Medicaid (OR 2.65, CI 1.23-5.72, p=0.01), and self-pay (OR 3.31, CI 1.57-6.97, p=0.002) were all associated with increased opioid prescription. There was no significant difference in opioid prescription across geographical regions. Linear regression found no significant trend of visits over time where opioids were prescribed (coefficient: 0.0045, 95% CI: -0.003-0.012, p=0.24). Multiple linear regression of visits where opioids were prescribed, visit year, and age group similarly showed a non-significant trend of opioid prescription over time (p=0.214). From our analyses, there were comparable average rates of opioid and non-opioid prescription from 2006-2016 (13% of visits, range 6%-31% for opioids comparted to 12% of visits, range 6% -18% for non-opioids).

Conclusion: Craniofacial trauma is a common cause of presentation to ambulatory clinics and emergency rooms with opioid analgesics being utilized as an essential treatment modality for pain control. Despite increased awareness and emphasis on multimodal pain management, opioid prescription trends have remained relatively stable over time. Ages 18-44, black ethnicity, private insurance, Medicaid and self-pay were factors all associated with increased odds of opioid prescription.

abstract_title: Use of Synthetic Mesh in Contaminated Ventral Hernia Repair: A Meta-Analysis and Systematic Review
author_block: M. P. Morris<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Mellia<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Christopher<sup>1,4</sup>, M. Basta<sup>3</sup>, V. Patel<sup>1</sup>, K. Qiu<sup>2</sup>, R. Broach<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Fischer<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Biomedical Library,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Brown University,Department Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Providence, RI, USA <sup>4</sup>Thomas Jefferson University,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ventral hernia is a common and complex problem that often requires surgical intervention. It is well accepted that mesh reinforcement of ventral hernia repair (VHR) leads to lower postoperative hernia recurrence rates. The use of mesh, however, has been linked to higher mesh-related complications, specifically in regards to synthetic mesh implants. For these reasons, the use of synthetic mesh in contaminated fields has fallen out of favor.  We aim to systematically assess the incidence of complications of synthetic mesh in VHR with a contaminated field.

Methods: A literature search of PubMed, Embase, Scopus, CINAHL, and Cochrane identified all articles published between 2000 and 2020. Two independent reviewers evaluated all relevant articles and included articles that had a subgroup of VHRs in which synthetic mesh was used in a contaminated field. Outcomes data was extracted and categorized by mesh type: synthetic mesh (SM) and biologic mesh (BM). Mesh in the SM group included 100% synthetic nonabsorbable mesh, while the BM group included 100% biologic mesh, excluding biosynthetic meshes. Primary outcomes included hernia recurrence, surgical site occurrences (SSO), and surgical site infections (SSI). A random effects meta-analysis of proportion was used to calculate pooled complication rates. Odds ratios (OR) were calculated to compare the two cohorts.

Results: Our initial search resulted in 882 articles, which was narrowed to 104 after title and abstract review. After careful review of inclusion and exclusion criteria, in addition to cross referencing, 16 articles remained in our study. 5 studies reported SM and BM subgroups and were included in this analysis. Across studies, there were 535 SM patients and 232 BM patients. Pooled mean follow-up time was 40.4 months for SM and 43.9 months for BM. All patients were CDC Wound Class 2, 3, or 4 (41.3%, 45.5%, 13.2% for SM, and 57.4%, 38.1%, 4.5% for BM, respectively). Incidence of hernia recurrence was significantly lower for SM when compared to BM (p=0.009, Figure). Use of SM was not associated with increased formation of SSO or SSI in a contaminated field (p>0.05).

Conclusion: This analysis suggests lower rates of hernia recurrence in patients undergoing VHR with synthetic mesh in a contaminated field than in patients with biologic mesh. Based on these results, use of synthetic mesh should be wholly considered in pre-operative evaluation of contaminated VHR patients.

abstract_title: Analysis Of Burn Patients Referred For Specialized Burn Care In The Absence Of Guidelines In Rwanda.
author_block: Y. Nezerwa<sup>1,3</sup>, E. Miranda<sup>4,6</sup>, L. Velin<sup>4,7</sup>, M. Mukeshimana<sup>1</sup>, D. Mushimiyimana<sup>1</sup>, L. Uwimana<sup>1</sup>, B. Mukambasabire<sup>1</sup>, M. Nkundabantu<sup>1</sup>, J. Bamurange<sup>1</sup>, Y. Uyisaba<sup>1</sup>, L. Nayisire<sup>1</sup>, I. Shyaka<sup>1,3</sup>, F. Mukagaju<sup>1,3</sup>, C. Furaha<sup>3</sup>, F. Ntirenganya<sup>1,9</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>4,8</sup>, W. Williams<sup>4,8</sup>, F. Busomoke<sup>1,9</sup>, J. Nsanzimana<sup>1,9</sup>, L. Pompermaier<sup>4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Teaching Hospital of Kigali, Rwanda,Department Of Reconstructive And Plastic Surgery,Kigali, KIGALI, Rwanda <sup>3</sup>Rwanda Military Hospital,Department Of Reconstructive And Plastic Surgery,Kigali, KIGALI, Rwanda <sup>4</sup>Harvard Medical School,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Linkping University Hospital,Department Of Hand Surgery, Plastic Surgery And Burns,Lund, LINKPING, Sweden <sup>6</sup>University of Southern California,Department Of Vascular Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>7</sup>Lund University,Department Of Clinical Sciences,Lund, LUND, Sweden <sup>8</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>9</sup>University of Rwanda,College Of Medicine & Health Sciences,Kigali, KIGALI, Rwanda
abstract_body:
Introduction: In low- and middle-income countries, burns are an increasing public health burden. Patients living far from urban centers are especially affected, as access to specialized burn care is limited or absent. In Rwanda, the University Teaching Hospital in Kigali (CHUK) is the largest national referral hospital and admits burn patients referred from all over the country. However, specific referral guidelines do not exist, thus it is unknown whether these patients needed transfer to a tertiary hospital or not. We aimed to compare burn patients referred to CHUK from the district hospitals (Pat-DH) with those referred from health care facilities within Kigali (Pat-K).

Methods: This retrospective study included all patients with burns admitted to the CHUK burn unit from 2005 to 2019. Data source was the burn unit ward logbooks. We compared characteristics and management of Pat-DH with Pat-K using Fisher’s exact test or nonparametric tests for equality of medians.

Results: Between 2005 and 2019, 1104 burn patients were admitted to CHUK, data were missing for 37 patients. Median age was 6.3 years (IQR 2.5 – 23.1) in Pat-DH and 2.7 years (IQR 1.6 – 7.4) in Pat-K, p<0.05. Scalds were the dominant cause of injury in both groups. Flame burns were more common among Pat-DH than Pat-K (in 55% vs. 30% of the patients), p<0.05. There was not a significant difference in burn size. Full thickness burns were present in 56% of Pat-DH and in 30% of Pat-K, p<0.05. Pat-DH required surgical treatment more often than Pat-K (25% vs. 12%, p<0.05). LOS was longer in Pat-DH than in Pat-K, 42 days (IQR 11-164) and 28 days (IQR 9-132), respectively, p<0.05. Mortality in Pat-DH was 19% as compared with 10% of Pat-K, p<0.001.

Conclusion: When official guidelines are missing, there is risk that criteria adopted to refer patients to tertiary hospitals are arbitrary and inadequate. However, a third of patients with burns admitted at the CHUK were referred from district hospitals and their burns were more severe, their need of surgical intervention greater, and LOS longer as compared to patients from Kigali. Though there are no clear guidelines, current referral patterns indicate that patients are being appropriately referred for specialized burn care in Kigali. However, the creation of referral criteria will be essential to reduce delay in reaching care and to avoid unnecessary transfer.

abstract_title: A Weight Off My Chest? Body Mass Index After Gender Affirming Top Surgery
author_block: L. Luther<sup>3</sup>, E. R. Boskey<sup>1</sup>, H. A. McGee<sup>3</sup>, D. Kwan<sup>2</sup>, D. Jolly<sup>1</sup>, O. Ganor<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Boston,Plastic Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brown University School Of Medicine,Plastic Surgery,Providence, RI, USA <sup>3</sup>Brown University School Of Medicine,Providence, RI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gender-affirming chest surgery has been associated with increased quality of life and decreased levels of gender dysphoria in transmasculine patients, but limited research exists on physical health outcomes associated with these procedures. Previous research has suggested that pre-surgical chest dysphoria is associated with the avoidance of swimming, exercise, and other physical activity. This may be directly attributable to dysphoria but also reflect difficulty participating in activities when engaging in binding to reduce the visible appearance of the chest.  We hypothesized that gender affirming chest reconstruction could therefore lead to increased physical activity, and that such an increase might be detectable through observed changes in patient body mass index (BMI) after the initial healing period. Our secondary hypothesis was that such changes were more likely to be seen for patients who initially presented with higher BMIs, as a proxy for those likely to be less active prior to surgery.  

Methods: A retrospective two-center chart review identified 118 transmasculine patients who underwent gender-affirming chest surgery between February 2016 and January 2019. Age at surgery, BMI within 1 month of surgery, and BMI within 8-18 months after surgery were collected. 65 patients were included in the final analysis, as the remainder of the patients did not have BMI data within the appropriate time frames. For the purpose of analysis, patients were grouped according to their BMI as “normal weight” (BMI 18-25) and “overweight” (BMI>25).  Paired t-tests were used to determine whether there were differences in peri-operative and post-operative BMI.

Results: Individuals who started out at a BMI <=25 saw no change in BMI from surgery in the post-operative period. However, on average, those who started out with a BMI of over 25 saw a small but significant decrease (p<.03). The mean decrease in BMI was 1.5 (95% CI [0.04, 2.93]. A significant decrease in BMI was not seen when data for patients whose only post-operative BMI was measured at <8 months was included in the study. 

Conclusion: These data suggests that, after the initial period of healing, chest surgery may help transmasculine individuals whose BMI falls into the overweight/obese range lose weight. Limitations of our study include a lack of consistent follow up and a relatively homogeneous population.  In addition, these data suggest that BMI has substantial disadvantages when used as a marker for overall health and activity, and therefore future research is needed to more directly assess the effects of gender affirming chest surgery on both behavior and metabolic markers.

abstract_title: Understanding the patient and provider experience with telehealth in Plastic Surgery.
author_block: T. Spargo<sup>1</sup>, C. Brown-Johnson<sup>2</sup>, M. Park<sup>3</sup>, S. Kling<sup>2</sup>, E. Gustafsson<sup>2</sup>, A. Sophia Lestoquoy<sup>2</sup>, S. Vilendrer<sup>3</sup>, M. Winget<sup>2</sup>, S. Asch<sup>2</sup>, P. Maggio<sup>3</sup>, D. Garvert<sup>2</sup>, R. Nazerali<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Department Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Stanford University,Division Of Primary Care And Population Health,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Stanford University,School Of Medicine,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, there has been an unprecedented adoption of telemedicine as a means for the continued delivery of pre- and post-operative surgical care. Given the limited understanding of the impact of virtual visits in plastic surgery, particularly in pre-operative care, the aim of this study was to understand patients’ and providers’ perceptions about the efficacy, value, accessibility and long-term viability of telemedicine in plastic surgery. 

Methods:  This study used a mixed-methods approach that included provider-level scheduling data collected through institution’s management dashboards to quantify the shift towards telemedicine, and semi-structured phone interviews with patients and providers to elucidate their perspective on video visits. Ten plastic surgeons who had performed at least one video visit and 20 patients who had video visits with a plastic surgeon between April 13, 2020 and April 24, 2020 participated in semi-structured phone interviews.
