All interviews were analyzed using a multi-phase analysis approach leveraging rapid analytic procedures. 

Results: One month prior to the pandemic, our plastic surgery clinic did not perform video visits. Following the stay-at-home order, 45.5% of post-operative visits and 21.4% of pre-operative visits were performed via video. The primary benefits of telemedicine identified by patients and providers were increased accessibility to care, decreased time spent traveling, and cost-savings related to fuel/transportation costs and time off from work. The primary limitations identified by providers were effective physical exams and building rapport virtually. Patients also acknowledged these limitations, however, were generally satisfied with their video visits and expressed trust that their surgeon would schedule an in-person visit if necessary. There was a marked diversity of provider opinions regarding the future of telemedicine in plastic surgery. Overall, patients and providers expressed willingness to participate in future video visits if clinically appropriate.

Conclusion: Despite the sudden shift to telemedicine in plastic surgery, our clinic was able to successfully accommodate and provide care to many pre- and post-operative patients. The findings of our study are consistent with prior studies describing video visits to be acceptable in many clinical settings but offer several new insights that may inform timely improvements in the virtual delivery of care in plastic surgery. Patients’ trust in the surgeon’s judgment may help overcome skepticism related to the virtual exam and rapport-building. With increased patient education and standardized clinical guidelines for use of surgical telehealth, this technology has the potential to help facilitate and improve patient care in plastic surgery, although further investigation is required.

abstract_title: Gravity Flow Irrigation Increases Odds of Infectious Complications in Chronic Wound Patients
author_block: K. Charipova<sup>2</sup>, J. C. Bekeny<sup>2</sup>, E. G. Zolper<sup>2</sup>, C. M. Akbari<sup>3</sup>, J. S. Steinberg<sup>4</sup>, K. L. Fan<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Attinger<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Evans<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Department Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine,Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Department Of Vascular Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>4</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Division Of Podiatric Surgery,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Wound irrigation for infection eradication is essential to successful debridement and ultimate closure. High-pressure irrigation with pulse lavage has similar outcomes to low-pressure irrigation in the acute traumatic population but has not been thoroughly analyzed in comorbid chronic wound patients.1 We investigated outcomes following the change from pulsatile flow to gravity flow irrigation at our tertiary wound center.

Methods:  A single-center retrospective review was performed on patients who underwent surgical debridement of a lower extremity wound from 2017 to 2019 and had documented follow up. Number of prior debridements was used to create a sample representative of the average chronic wound patient. Data were collected on demographics, comorbidities, and infectious complications.

Results: This study included 436 patients, 208 in the gravity flow group (47.7%) and 228 in the pulsatile flow group (52.3%). There were no differences in Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI), body mass index, and hemoglobin A1c between the groups. The most common comorbidities were diabetes mellitus (n=257, 58.9%), peripheral vascular disease (n=227, 52.1%), and chronic kidney disease (n=55, 12.6%) with no differences between groups. Median wound area was 24 cm2 (IQR 7.1-60 cm2) with no difference between groups (p=0.772). Patients in the gravity flow group underwent a median of 1 prior debridement (IQR 0-2) while patients in the pulsatile flow group underwent 0 prior debridements (IQR 0-1, p<0.001). The incidence of prior positive cultures was similar between groups (gravity 84.8% versus pulsatile 85.2%, p=0.932). Infectious complications occurred more frequently in the gravity flow (n=22, 10.6%) versus pulsatile flow group (n=11, 4.8%). On bivariate logistic regression, patients undergoing debridement with gravity flow irrigation were found to have 2.3 times increased odds of developing an infectious complication (95% CI 1.10-4.93, p=0.027). When controlling for number of prior debridements and CCI, gravity flow irrigation remained independently associated with increased odds of infectious complications (OR 2.16, 95% CI 1.01-4.64, p=0.047).        

Conclusion: In chronic wound patients, use of gravity flow irrigation leads to an increased risk of infectious complications. These findings are at odds with prior literature supporting non-inferiority of gravity flow irrigation in the acute traumatic population. The highly comorbid nature of the chronic wound population limits the generalizability of these prior studies. Studies specific to the chronic wound patient are critical to optimizing outcomes in this challenging population.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. FLOW Investigators, Bhandari M, Jeray K, et al. A trial of wound irrigation in the initial management of open fracure wounds. N Engl J Med. 2015;373(27):2629-2641. doi:10.1056/NEJMoa1508502

abstract_title: Dual-Port vs Single-Port Tissue Expanders in Post-mastectomy Breast Reconstruction
author_block: N. Parmeshwar<sup>1</sup>, M. Piper<sup>1</sup>, J. Viner<sup>1</sup>, R. Foster<sup>1</sup>, E. Kim<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Department Of Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The immediate placement of tissue expanders is a common first stage in post mastectomy breast reconstruction prior to implant based or autologous reconstruction. This interim time to final reconstruction may be complicated by seromas or infection, often requiring further imaging studies or interventions. The purpose of our study was to compare dual port tissue expanders, which have both an aspiration and expansion port, and single port expanders in terms of post-operative complications and further interventions.

Methods: A retrospective review was performed of patients who underwent immediate tissue expander placement after mastectomy from March 2019 to March 2020. Delayed expander placement or autologous reconstruction with expanders were excluded. Demographics, intraoperative details, and post-operative course until final reconstruction were recorded. Complications included seroma, infection, hematoma, nipple or skin flap necrosis, and malposition of the expander. Further intervention included aspiration, ultrasound imaging, interventional radiology (IR) drainage placement, or return to operating room.

Results: A total of 128 dual port expander breast reconstructions were compared to 125 single port expander reconstructions over the same time period. Single port expanders were associated with slightly younger (p=0.022) and lower BMI (p=0.01) patients, with greater percentage of nipple sparing mastectomy (93% vs 82%, p=0.005) and greater subpectoral expander placement (86% vs 67%, p=0.001). There were no significant differences in key complications between these groups. Dual port expanders were associated with significantly decreased post operative ultrasound imaging (p=0.000). Mean time to IR drain placement in the dual port group was approximately 30 days after placement in single port (51.1 vs 21.4 days, p=0.013), despite no difference in IR drain placement (p=0.881). Up to 34% of dual port had at least one aspiration in clinic performed by Plastic Surgery, versus single port that required IR ultrasound-guided aspiration (p=0.000).

Conclusion: There were no differences in key post-operative complications between the dual port and single port expander cohorts. However dual port expanders significantly reduced the need for post-operative ultrasound imaging, and delayed IR drain placement up to 30 days. The added convenience of clinic aspirations likely reduced costs related to utilization of resources from other departments.

abstract_title: Recidivism Amongst Facial Fracture Patients: Analysis of a Level 1 Trauma Center Registry
author_block: J. Lapidus<sup>1</sup>, A. Nguyen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Plastic Surgery/Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Injury recidivism is a major public health issue in the United States that disproportionately affects vulnerable populations. This phenomenon has been previously investigated in regard to general trauma, burns, and other pathologies; the relationship of recidivism with facial fractures, however, has not yet been investigated. The aim of this study is to describe patients who repeatedly present with facial fractures, to elucidate the nature of these injuries, and to identify potential points of intervention and recidivism prevention.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study was conducted using a Level 1 Trauma Center patient registry, which is a database containing clinical information on all patients for whom the surgical trauma team was consulted in the emergency department upon patient arrival. Patients ≥ 18 years who were diagnosed with any type of facial fracture based on International Classification of Disease (ICD)-9 code 802 between 2011-2016 were included. Recidivists were defined as patients with two or more unique presentations during the study period in which any facial fracture was diagnosed. Descriptive analyses were performed to compare the injury characteristics and hospital courses of the initial and repeat presentations among patients in the recidivism group.

Results: Among 2,204 patients with facial fractures, 39 patients (1.8%) presented multiple times with unique episodes of facial trauma during the study period. Recidivists were largely males (63%) of middle age (average 45 years, range 18-79) at initial presentation. The prevalence of homelessness was more than twice as high in the recidivism group compared to the overall cohort (25.6 vs. 12%, p<0.0001). Time to repeat presentation ranged from 0 days to 4.8 years, with an average of 1.6 years between injuries. Preliminary analyses suggest higher injury severity sustained on second presentations compared to initial visits. Injury Severity Scores (ISS) were higher amongst a majority of patients (average increase 2.4 points, range -15-28), with 69% having repeat ISS greater than or equal to initial ISS. Hospitalizations for repeat injury were also associated with higher proportions of patients being admitted to ICU (43.6 vs. 30.8%), longer ICU stays (average 7.8 vs. 4.4 days), and longer overall lengths of stay (9.8 vs. 3.9 days) when compared to initial hospitalizations.

Conclusion: Our results demonstrate that facial fracture recidivism was a rare occurrence amongst this cohort. Interestingly, patients who suffer multiple episodes of facial trauma might be at risk for higher injury severity on repeat presentation. Further analysis will be conducted to assess differences of this group compared to single-episode patients and to identify risk factors for recidivism.

abstract_title: Evaluating Microsurgical Pedicle Lengthening in Free Tissue Transfer, a Systemic Review
author_block: E. Soto<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Ananthasekar<sup>2</sup>, A. Clark<sup>2</sup>, P. Peacock<sup>3</sup>, J. Patel<sup>2</sup>, R. P. Myers<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery, Division of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Traumatic injuries that require free tissue flaps for reconstruction may require vascular pedicle extension between the flap and recipient vessels to form a clear anastomosis. Reports in the literature conflict on the reliability of pedicle extensions of vessels in free flap surgery. The objective of this study is to assess the outcomes of arteriovenous loops and vein pedicle extensions in free flap reconstruction through a systemic review of literature and the retrospective information from a tertiary hospital center. We will also discuss in detail the vein graft characteristics, flap indications, arteriovenous loop and interposition and patient comorbidities.

Methods:  A comprehensive search in MEDLINE, EMBASE, and the Cochrane library was performed for relevant studies published up to January 2020. Study quality was assessed according to the Cochrane Collaboration risk of bias assessment tool, and a set of 27 predetermined parameters was extracted by 2 investigators independently for further analysis. The parameters were combined with a retrospective analysis of patients requiring free flap reconstruction to the head and neck at a tertiary referral hospital between January 2007 and December 2018. All patients utilizing any vein graft, vein loops, arterial grafts and interposed free flaps were identified as a pedicle extension group. Data collection included medical, surgical, demographic and outcome variables. Relevant comparisons between the different reconstructions were made. The primary outcome measure was overall flap loss (total and partial).

Results:  The search yielded 1 randomized, 2 prospective and 37 retrospective studies totaling 1,103 patients identified over the study period as reconstruction involving pedicle extension. Overall, study quality was low and heterogeneity was large. Of the  initial cases, 21 % were returned to the operating room for flap concerns. The free flaps most often used were radial forearm and gracilis. Approximately 65% of pedicle extensions were planned and the majority were performed in the initial operation 71%. Rates of post-operative complications of the pedicle extension group were consistent with or lower than those of free flap reconstructions without pedicle extension.

Conclusion: Available evidence on the safety of pedicle lengthening is limited due to diversity in study conduct, patients included, and outcomes reported. Future publications concerning free flap reconstruction will benefit by a standardized reporting of surgical procedures and outcomes in terms of pedicle graft and length used. The series strongly suggests that pedicle extensions in the free flap setting are a practical and effective option for preventing complications in high risk complex and traumatic defects.

abstract_title: In-hospital Mortality And Mortality Prediction Tools In The Largest Rwandan Referral Hospital.
author_block: I. Shyaka<sup>1</sup>, E. Miranda<sup>3,5</sup>, L. Velin<sup>3,6</sup>, Y. Nezerwa<sup>1</sup>, F. Mukagaju<sup>1</sup>, C. Furaha<sup>1</sup>, F. Ntirenganya<sup>2</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>3,7</sup>, L. Pompermaier<sup>3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rwanda Military Hospital, Kigali, Rwanda,Plastic Surgery,Kigali, KIGALI, Rwanda <sup>2</sup>University Teaching Hospital Kigali (CHUK) Kigali, Rwanda,Plastic Surgery,Kigali, KIGALI, Rwanda <sup>3</sup>Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Linkping University Hospital,Plastic Surgery,Linkping, LINKPING, Sweden <sup>5</sup>University Of Southern California,Department Of Vascular Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>6</sup>Lund University,Department Of Clinical Sciences,Lund, LUND, Sweden <sup>7</sup>Brigham and Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Globally, burn injuries are responsible for 250,000 deaths and 90% of this occurs in low and middle-income countries. In Subsaharan Africa, mortality is estimated to be 1 in every 5 burn patients. Baux score, Lethal Area 50 Index (LA50), and point of futility are calculated using the patient’s age and TBSA to predict mortality risk from burns. They reflect the local standard of burn care and have been adjusted upwards in high-income countries (HICs) in the last decades. It remains to verify whether these tools are reliable in low-income settings This study aimed to analyze in-hospital mortality and tools to predict the mortality risk among burn patients in Rwanda  

Methods: This was a retrospective study done at the University Teaching Hospital in Kigali (CHUK), the largest referral hospital in Rwanda. Between 2005 and 2019, 1104 burn patients were admitted to the CHUK burn ward, Rwanda’s only designated burn ward. In the present analysis we included 532 patients who had complete data regarding age, TBSA%, outcome, and their Baux score, LA50 and point of futility calculated. Data were collected from the ward logbook and analyzed using STATA v16.

Results: In the studied population; median age, TBSA% and Baux score were 3.4 years (IQR 1.9-17.1), 15% (IQR 11-25) and 23.5 (IQR 15.6-37.5), respectively. 13% of the patients died during the admission. LA50 was 46.9% TBSA (95% CI 41.2%-52.5%), Baux score 90 (94.6% CI 75.2-104.8) was significantly associated with death and the point of futility was 115.9 (IQR 94.6-137.2).

Conclusion: Our study population consisted of young individuals with burns of moderate severity. However, the mortality was higher and  the LA50 was lower and the Baux score higher as compared to data reported previously from HICs. Lack of complete data on both age and TBSA% for almost half of the patients was a limitation of this study. Furthermore, the in-hospital mortality may be underestimated as it does not include those patients who died after admission at the general ICU. Baux score and LA50 are reliable and useful tools to verify the level of burn care even in low income settings. Systematic data collection is essential to develop accurate outcome prediction model in burn patients.

abstract_title: Nutritional Markers for Predicting Lower Extremity FTT Outcomes in the Chronic Wound Population
author_block: K. G. Kim<sup>1</sup>, M. Mishu<sup>2</sup>, E. G. Zolper<sup>1</sup>, P. Bhardwaj<sup>2</sup>, A. Rogers<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Fan<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Evans<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>MedStar Georgetown University Hospital,Department Of Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction

Good nutritional status is essential for proper wound healing. Postoperatively, free tissue transfer (FTT) patients are in a hypermetabolic state. Thus, optimizing nutritional status is critical to maximize flap success and healing. Historically, prealbumin and albumin have been utilized as easily obtained proxies for overall nutritional status, indicating acute and chronic changes, respectively. The aim of this study was to investigate whether these markers are correlated with healing time and overall flap healing after lower extremity (LE) FTT in the chronic wound population.

Methods

A retrospective review of LE chronic wound FTT patients treated by a single surgeon at our institution from 2011-2020 was performed. Inclusion criteria was defined as (1) albumin within 30 days prior to FTT, (2) prealbumin within 3 days prior to FTT, and (3) documented follow-up. Data collection included demographics, comorbidities, flap characteristics, and perioperative labs. The outcomes of interest were flap healing (FH) and time to flap healing (TFH). Patients were stratified according to perioperative nutritional markers, using initial thresholds of albumin <3.5 g/dL and prealbumin <10 mg/dL for poor nutritional status. Additional analysis at various thresholds for albumin and prealbumin was performed. Fisher’s exact testing was used to assess overall healing rates and Mann-Whitney testing was used to assess association between perioperative nutritional markers and TFH.

Results

We identified 69 patients undergoing LE FTT for limb salvage with a mean age of 56.0 years (standard deviation [SD] 12.1). Mean Charlson Comorbidity Index was 3.4 (SD 2.1) and median follow up was 11.1 months. When using a threshold of <3.5 g/dL for low albumin, no significance was found between FH or TFH and preoperative albumin, preoperative prealbumin, or postoperative albumin (Table 1). With low albumin defined as <2.8 g/dL, TFH was significantly increased and FH was significantly decreased compared to the defined normal preoperative albumin group (Table 1). No significance was found between FH or TFH and preoperative prealbumin or postoperative albumin. An independent prealbumin threshold of < 20 mg/dL did not cause significant change in outcomes.

Conclusion

Low preoperative albumin, when defined as <3.5 g/dL, and prealbumin did not increase TFH. Contrarily, when defined as <2.8 g/dL, low preoperative albumin significantly increased TFH and FH rates. The reliability of albumin and prealbumin as markers for nutritional status, however, has come into question. Further investigation into validated biomarkers and their thresholds is needed to assess the effect of nutritional status on wound healing and guide perioperative optimization.

abstract_title: Outcomes of The Vertical Contour Calcanectomy: A Novel Technique for Diabetic Heel Ulcerations
author_block: H. Cook<sup>1</sup>, K. Delijani<sup>1</sup>, D. Popovsky<sup>1</sup>, C. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, C. Attinger<sup>1</sup>, T. Elmarsafi<sup>1</sup>, J. Steinberg<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute,Plastic/Podiatric Reconstructive Surgery,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Heel ulcers severely impact a patient’s mobility, morbidity, and often lead to major lower extremity amputations. Diabetic ulcerations are the single highest independent risk factor for nontraumatic major lower extremity amputation (MLEA). Such amputations have been found to increase patient mortality between 20% and 50% at 3 years and 40% and 70% at 5 years. The Vertical Contour Calcanectomy (VCC) is a novel surgical procedure for the surgical management of these often recalcitrant and complex heel ulcerations which provides a technique to achieve consistent osseous and soft tissue reconstruction and reduce lower extremity amputations. The aim of this retrospective analysis was to report the long term outcomes of the VCC and provide guidance on the risks and benefits

Methods: A retrospective search of available electronic medical records from January 2014 – 2019 was carried out at two institutions. Physician reviewers identified patients who underwent VCC, and reviewers collected data on demographics, medical history, and performed an analysis of procedure and outcome.

Results: 51 total patients were identified meeting inclusion criteria, 38 with follow-up exceeding 1 year and 13 with MLEA or death within 1 year. The mean age was 64 (35-87) years. Mean body mass index was 30 (±8.6) kg/m 2. The most common comorbidity was diabetes (n=44;  83.0%). 27.4% of the cohort experienced loss of limb at 1 year with the average time to amputation being 136+- 149 days. Thirty day and 1 year major outcomes following VCC are outlined in table 1. 30-day readmission, MLEA, and mortality were 14;(27.5%), 4;(7.8%), and 1(1.96%), respectively. In regards to lower extremity function, roughly half (n=14;51.9%) of the cohort had no observable change in function, n=8; 28.6% improved and n=5;18.5% declined.

Conclusion: This is the largest cohort of VCC patients reported on and the only study evaluating outcomes at 1 year. The duration of ulcer burden prior to VCC had a mean of 333 days ± 404, and has a major impact on quality of life. The VCC is an emerging technique and its effect on patient morbidity and mortality are promising.

abstract_title: Percutaneous Needle Fasciotomy for Dupuytren's: Versatility Across a Spectrum of Disease Severity
author_block: M. I. Patel<sup>1</sup>, I. A. Patel<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Cambridge,School Of Clinical Medicine,Cambridge, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom <sup>2</sup>Royal Devon & Exeter NHS Foundation Trust,Department Of Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery,Exeter, DEVON, United Kingdom
abstract_body:
Introduction: Percutaneous needle fasciotomy (PNF) is a well-established minimally invasive technique for release of Dupuytren’s contracture. However, factors relating to surgeon preference and uncertainty regarding potential risks of digital nerve damage or flexor tendon rupture results in limited provision of PNF, in favour of open fasciectomy, which many surgeons consider to be the gold standard. Amongst its advantages, PNF requires minimal staffing and resources and additionally facilitates full function of the treated hand with immediate mobilisation in the post-operative period. The study aim was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of PNF when delivered as the treatment of choice amongst 118 consecutive rays of varying Dupuytren’s disease severity.

Methods: In this retrospective cohort study, data were collected for all patients who opted to receive PNF by a single surgeon between 2017-2020. Demographic data including age, comorbidities, smoking status and Dupuytren’s diathesis were recorded. Patients were divided into 3 cohorts on the basis of joint contracture severity as per Tubiana staging (TS): 0-45°, 46-90°, 91-130°. An analysis of the degree of release achieved from baseline was made across cohorts and compared with χ2 analysis. The incidence of post-operative complications including permanent or transient sensory disturbance, flexor tendon rupture, arterial transection or infection was assessed. Patient satisfaction and recurrence (>20° contracture in a single joint) were secondarily analysed.

Results: 118 rays were treated amongst 74 patients (mean age, 68 years (R,32-86), males: 74%) with mean follow-up 51 weeks (IQR 28-76 weeks). Patient cohorts were not significantly different at baseline. No cases of permanent sensory disturbance, flexor tendon rupture, arterial transection nor infection were observed. Neuropraxia was seen in 6 patients, resolving with mean recovery of 6 weeks. 86% (n=166) of joints had satisfactory release (residual passive extension deficit (PED) ≤10°) with full release in 67%. Full release was most likely in MCPJ (93%) than DIPJ (67%) or PIPJ (45%) (p<0.0001). Mean release was 54° in MCPJ and 56° in PIPJ. All TS1 patients achieved release with ≤10° residual PED versus 75% of TS2 patients and 22% of TS3 patients (p<0.05), the latter of whom had a mean residual PED of 12°. Recurrence was observed in 19% of rays. 92% of patients stated they would undergo PNF again if necessary, in preference to open fasciectomy.

Conclusion: We find PNF to facilitate a safe, effective yet minimally invasive approach in patients of varying disease severity. Patients report high satisfaction in preference to undergoing open procedures. We conclude that this method offers a favourable alternative to open fasciectomy, as it consistently yields clinically acceptable contracture release, conserving full function of the hand in the immediate post-operative period.

abstract_title: Tertiary Breast Reconstruction Following Two Infected Device Removals: When Should We Stop?
author_block: C. Slovacek<sup>1</sup>, M. Asaad<sup>2</sup>, D. Mitchell<sup>1</sup>, J. Selber<sup>2</sup>, A. Mericli<sup>2</sup>, M. Clemens<sup>2</sup>, C. Butler<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mcgovern Medical School,Houston, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>MD Anderson Cancer Center, Houston, TX,Department Of Plastic Surgery,Houston, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Infection is the most common reason for device explantation in implant-based breast reconstruction (IBR). Although it is reasonable to offer secondary IBR following first device removal, these patients are still at risk for subsequent infections which can lead to a repeat explantation. Whether further attempts of IBR should be pursued following two failed IBR is unknown. The goal of this study is to evaluate the outcomes of the third IBR following two failed attempts of IBR due to infection.

Methods:  We conducted a retrospective review of all patients who underwent a third IBR attempt following two sequential infected IBR explantation between 2008 and 2019. Our primary outcome measure was reconstructive failure. Secondary outcome measures included overall complications and infection.

Results: A total of 6093 IBR were performed between 2008 and 2019, out of whom 298 (5%) underwent first IBR removal due to infection and 116 underwent secondary IBR (24 of whom with LD). Out of 16 patients who had two failed IBRs due to infection, we identified 13 patients who attempted a third reconstruction while 3 patients did not pursue reconstruction. The mean age of the third reconstruction group was 53±6 years and mean BMI was 29±8 kg/m2. Six patients (46%) received previous radiotherapy. In total, 7 patients (54%) underwent reconstruction with a permanent implant, 2 (15%) received a tissue expander (TE), 2 (15%) received TE followed by an implant, and 2 (15%) had a free flap. The mean follow-up was 43 ± 29 months.   Overall complication rate was 31% (n=4). Infection developed in 3 IBR patients (23%), 2 of whom ultimately had their device removed. One patient with a free flap developed flap venous thrombosis which was salvaged during an operative take-back. Overall, 11 (85%) had successful tertiary reconstruction.

Conclusion: In patients who had failed secondary IBR due to infection, a third breast reconstruction should be considered. However, this is associated with high infection and failure rates. This information would help in patients’ counseling and decision making.

abstract_title: Robotic Approach Mitigates the Risk of Complications from Pancreaticoduodenectomy in Elderly Patients
author_block: S. L. Starr<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Mederos<sup>2</sup>, J. C. King<sup>2,3</sup>, J. S. Tomlinson<sup>2,4</sup>, O. J. Hines<sup>2,3</sup>, T. R. Donahue<sup>2,3</sup>, M. D. Girgis<sup>2,3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>VA Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System,Surgical Oncology,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) has a significantly higher rate of post-operative complications in elderly patients compared to younger patients. The aim of this study is to evaluate whether robotic assistance mitigates the risks of complications in patients ≥ 75 years old undergoing PD. 

Methods: The 2015-2018 American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS NSQIP) database was queried to identify patients ≥75 years of age who underwent open or robotic assisted (RA) PD. The cohorts were matched 1:1 using propensity score matching for patient characteristics and risk factors for pancreatic fistula to assess the 30-day outcomes of interest: perioperative complications, duration of hospital stay, discharge destination, reoperations, and readmissions. Patients hospitalized >14 days were excluded from the readmission analysis to avoid immortal time bias. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to predict differences in outcomes.

Results: A total of 3,079 patients were identified of which 138 underwent RAPD. A propensity-score matched sample of 274 total cases (136 open PD and 138 RAPD) was analyzed. Baseline demographics/patient characteristics were similar between the two cohorts except for race/ethnicity where the RAPD cohort had less non-white patients (12.3% vs. 29.4%, p=0.003). On univariate analysis, RAPD was associated with a lower rate of pancreatic fistula (11.6% vs 22.3%, p<0.001), delayed gastric emptying (26.1% vs 35.4%, p=0.001), superficial infection (3.6% vs 10.3%, p=0.030), organ/space surgical site infection (SSI) (13.8% vs 34.6%, p<0.001), and sepsis (5.8% vs 21.3%, p<0.001). Duration of hospitalization was significantly shorter in the RAPD cohort with a median of 8 days vs 15 days for the open PD cohort (p<0.001), and patients in the RAPD cohort were more likely to be discharged home (76.1% vs 56.6%, p=0.001). However, readmissions were increased with RAPD compared to open PD (28.2% vs 8.1%, p<0.001). Reoperations were similar between the cohorts (12.3% vs 14.0%, p=0.686). On multivariate analysis, the RAPD cohort showed decreased odds of developing fistula, delayed gastric emptying, bleeding/transfusions, deep organ space SSI, sepsis, and septic shock.

Conclusion: RAPD in patients ≥75 years of age appears to be safe and is associated with decreased duration of hospitalization and more patients discharged to home compared to open PD. The complication profile is similar in many regards, but RAPD was associated with decreased fistula rate, delayed gastric emptying, and infectious complications.

abstract_title: Robotic Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Missed Opportunity for Cost Savings?
author_block: R. Shah<sup>1</sup>, A. Diaz<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Hyer<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,National Clinician Scholars Program At The Institute For Healthcare Policy And Innovation,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The use of robotic total knee arthroplasty (rTKA) has become increasingly more prevalent. Proponents of rTKA tout its potential to not only improve outcomes, but also reduce costs compared with traditional total knee arthroplasty (tTKA). Despite its potential to deliver on the value proposition, whether rTKA has led to improved outcomes and cost savings within Medicare’s Bundled Payment for Care Improvement (BPCI) initiative remains unexplored.

Methods:  Medicare beneficiaries who underwent TKA designated under Medicare severity diagnosis related group (MS-DRG) 469 or 470 in 2017 were identified using the 100% Medicare Inpatient Standard Analytic Files; hospitals participating in BPCI were identified using the BPCI analytic file. We calculated risk-adjusted, price-standardized payments for the surgical episode from admission through 90 days post discharge. Outcomes, utilization, and spending were assessed relative to variation between robotic and traditional TKA. 

Results: Overall, 194,020 patients underwent TKA (tTKA: n=189,669, 97.8% vs. rTKA: n=4,351, 2.2%); among the 3,200 hospitals that performed TKA, only 300 (9.3%) performed rTKA; among the 213 participating in BPCI, only 40 (19%) hospitals performed rTKA. Risk-adjusted 90-day episode spending was $14,264 (95% CI: $14,233 to $14,295) among patients who underwent tTKA versus $13,600 (95%CI: $13,404 to $13,796) among patients who had rTKA. Patients who underwent rTKA had a shorter length-of-stay (tTKA: 2.3 days, 95%CI: 2.2-2.3 vs. rTKA: 1.9 days, 95%CI: 1.9-2.0), as well as a lower incidence of complications (tTKA: 3.3%, 95%CI: 3.2-3.3 vs. rTKA: 2.5%, 95%CI: 2.2-3.0). Of note, patients who underwent rTKA were less often discharged to a post-acute care facility than patients who underwent tTKA (tTKA: 22.5%, 95%CI: 22.4-22.7 vs. rTKA: 15.6%, 95%CI 14.6-16.7). Of note, average hospital spending decreased as rTKA utilization reached and surpassed 50% of total TKA operative volume among both BPCI and non-BPCI hospitals (Figure). 

Conclusion: Overall 90-day episode spending for rTKA was lower than tTKA (D-$664, 95%CI: $466-$862). The decrease in spending was attributable to shorter length-of-stay, fewer complications, as well as lower utilization of postacute care facility. The cost-savings associated with rTKA was only realized when rTKA volume surpassed 50% of total TKA volume, reflecting a need to overcome fixed initial costs. Hospitals participating in BPCI may experience cost-saving with increased utilization of rTKA.

abstract_title: Paraconduit Hiatal Hernia Following Esophagectomy: Characteristics & Repair Outcomes
author_block: S. K. Chung<sup>1</sup>, B. Bludevich<sup>1</sup>, N. Cherng<sup>1</sup>, T. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, C. Allison<sup>1</sup>, M. Maxfield<sup>1</sup>, G. Whalen<sup>1</sup>, K. Uy<sup>1</sup>, R. Perugini<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Surgery,Worcester, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Paraconduit hiatal hernia (PCHH) is an understudied complication of minimally invasive esophagectomy (MIE) with significant morbidity. PCCH incidence ranges up to 6% for open techniques and 20% with minimally invasive approaches, and may be increasing with improved survival with the advent of adjuvant chemoradiotherapies. Commonly proposed risks include neoadjuvant therapy, transhiatal surgical approach, female sex, tumor location, and minimally invasive technique. There is limited consensus and continued debate on the surveillance and management of hiatal hernias following minimally invasive esophagectomies.

Methods: We retrospectively reviewed records of patients who underwent esophagectomy at an academic tertiary care center between 2013-2019. We divided the cohort into those who did and did not develop PCHH, identifying differences in demographics, perioperative characteristics/factors, and outcomes. In patients who developed PCHH, we further evaluated the hernia characteristics and repair outcomes.

Results: In 49 patients who underwent esophagectomy, six (12.2%) developed PCHH at a median of 160 days (60-350 days) postoperatively. They were younger (57 vs 65 years, p=0.006), and in cases of resection for cancer, more likely to develop tumor recurrence (83% vs 21%, p=0.005) at a median of 287 days. There was no significant difference in two-year cancer-free survival (PCHH 33% vs no hernia 63%, p=0.20) or five-year overall survival between the two groups (PCHH 67% vs no hernia 69%, p=0.87). Five PCHH were symptomatic, of which four were addressed laparoscopically. Three of four PCHH repairs were without mesh and recurred at 186, 242, and 588 days. One of the three PCHH recurrences required more than one attempt at repair. One repair utilized biosynthetic mesh in a pledgetted sublay fashion and is intact 560 days postoperatively.

Conclusion: PCHH is a common occurrence following MIE. We found paraconduit hernias to be associated with younger age and tumor recurrence, without change in two-year cancer-free survival or five-year overall survival. PCHH likely does not confer additional mortality. Repair in symptomatic patients may be accomplished laparoscopically. Mesh reinforcement should be considered to minimize the high risk of recurrence. Further long-term studies are needed to address modifiable risk factors and identify optimal techniques for durable repair of post esophagectomy PCHH.

abstract_title: Long-Term Outcomes in Septuagenarians Following Bariatric Surgery
author_block: D. I. Athanasiadis<sup>1</sup>, R. C. Dirks<sup>1</sup>, D. Stefanidis<sup>1</sup>, A. Banerjee<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Bariatric And Minimally Invasive Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for obesity; however, its utilization in older patients remains low. There is a dearth of literature on the long-term effectiveness and safety of bariatric surgery in septuagenarian patients. The aim of this study was to compare the short and long-term outcomes of bariatric surgery in this population.

Methods:  After obtaining institutional review board approval, patients who underwent primary laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) or laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) at our institution between 2011 and 2015 were included in this retrospective study. Patients were divided into two age groups: <70 years and ≥70 years. Their baseline demographic characteristics were collected. Outcomes including postoperative hospital length of stay (LOS), 30-day reinterventions, 30-day readmissions, 90-day mortality, and mean percentage excess weight loss (%EWL) at 4 years were recorded and compared between the study groups. Reinterventions included both reoperations as well as endoscopic interventions. The comparisons were performed with ANOVA and multivariate binary and linear logistic regressions controlling for gender, preoperative BMI, and type of procedure using SPSS statistical software, Version 26.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL). 

Results: Twenty-nine septuagenarians were included and underwent 21 LRYGB (72.4%) and 8 LSG (27.6%). The mean follow-up was 2.5 ± 1.5 years, while thirteen patients had a 4-year follow-up. When compared with 1011 patients aged <70 years operated on during the same time period, the septuagenarians demonstrated lower preoperative BMI (p=0.001). Patient baseline characteristics can be found in Table 1. When we controlled for gender, preoperative BMI, and type of procedure the septuagenarians had higher LOS (3 vs 2.3 days, p=0.01) and 4-year reinterventions (38% vs 23%, p=0.015), but similar 4-year %EWL (55.1% vs 51.2%, p=0.633), and 30-day reinterventions (10% vs 6%, p=0.316). 90-day mortality was observed only in one patient in the control group.

Conclusion: Bariatric surgery in carefully selected septuagenarians can be accomplished with acceptable safety and comparable postoperative weight loss at 4 years. Surgeons may consider broadening their selection criteria to include this patient subgroup.

abstract_title: Attending Surgeon Influences Operative Time More than Resident Level in Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy
author_block: J. Wiseman<sup>1</sup>, T. Riall<sup>1</sup>, C. O'Grady<sup>1</sup>, L. Morris-Wiseman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Department Of Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Prior studies on laparoscopic cholecystectomy have concluded that resident involvement lengthens operative time but does not impact outcomes. Previously-described similarities in operative times per case across post-graduate year (PGY) resident levels have not been clearly explained. We hypothesized that attending-specific average operative time for laparoscopic cholecystectomy was more predictive than resident PGY level.

Methods:  We retrospectively analyzed laparoscopic cholecystectomy cases between November 2018-March 2020. Surgeons who performed >10 laparoscopic cholecystectomies over the study period were included. Residents were grouped by junior (PGY1-3) and senior residents/fellows (PGY4-7). Primary outcome measures evaluated included operative time, as well as the occurence of any complication. Any adverse event directly related to the operation, including patient return to emergency department after discharge, was considered a complicaton for the purposes of this analysis. Patient and operative factors related to cases that included junior or senior residents were compared using Chi-squared, Fisher’s Exact test, or t-tests. ANOVA was used performed to evaluate the relative influence on operative time of attending and resident level.  

Results: 296 laparoscopic cholecystectomies performed by 12 surgeons in the study period were analyzed.  Comparing cases performed with junior residents (n=113) and senior residents/fellows (n=183), there were no differences in patient age (43.2+16.2 vs. 41.9+16.6, p=0.51), gender (p=0.15), body mass index (BMI, 32.4 vs. 34.2, p=0.13), American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Classification (p=0.16), or presence of any major co-morbidity (p=0.92). Total operative time was significantly shorter in operations with junior residents compared to senior residents (82.5+37.4 min vs. 92.9+42.5 min, p = 0.034).  Intraoperative cholangiogram (IOC) was performed in 12.5% of cases (n=37), and demonstrated no impact on operative time.  There were no significant differences between groups in terms of complication rates (8.7% versus 10.7%, p=0.624) or conversion to an open procedure (1.9% vs. 2.9%, p=1.0). An ANOVA analysis demonstrated that both the attending surgeon and the resident level had a significant influence on operating time; the attending influence on operating time was more pronounced (F-statistic 20.52, p<0.0001) than the resident influence (F-statistic 5.02, p=0.026).

Conclusion: Operative time for laparoscopic cholecystectomy was significantly higher in cases involving senior residents with no difference in patient factors, conversion to open operation, or complication rate. Attending influence on operative time was more pronounced than resident level influence. These results suggest that the specific attending surgeon is a more important determinant of operative time than resident level or performance of an intraoperative cholangiogram, although resident level does have an effect.

abstract_title: Outcomes after Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy in Hyperkinetic Biliary Dyskinesia
author_block: L. F. Whitaker<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Powell<sup>1</sup>, J. Refugia<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Bosley<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Koch<sup>2</sup>, P. Bennett<sup>3</sup>, A. Z. Fernandez<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine,General Surgery,Winston-Salem, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine,Gastroenterology,Winston-Salem, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine,Radiology,Winston-Salem, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Hyperkinetic biliary dyskinesia is a poorly understood and documented functional gallbladder disorder specified by a gallbladder ejection fraction (GBEF) of >80% on hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan with cholecystokinin stimulation (CCK-HIDA testing).  Laparoscopic cholecystectomy for treatment of hypokinetic biliary dyskinesia (GBEF <35%) has been shown to improve symptoms. However, the clinical characteristics and treatment of hyperkinetic biliary dyskinesia has not been well defined. The aim of this study was to assess whether laparoscopic cholecystectomy improves symptoms of patients with hyperkinetic biliary dyskinesia postoperatively.

Methods:  With IRB approval, records of patients 18 years and older with GBEF >80% who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy by two surgeons at a tertiary care center between 2012-2020 were retrospectively reviewed. Demographic information, HIDA results, preoperative testing, operative details, and postoperative pathology and determination of symptom resolution at follow up were collected from electronic medical records.   Descriptive statistics were utilized with qualitative data described in percentages and quantitative data reported in averaged with associated standard deviations.

Results: One thousand two hundred seventy-eight patients underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy by two surgeons between 2012-2020. Of these patients, 76 had a documented GBEF >80% on CCK-HIDA testing.  56 patients were female and 20 were male with an average age of 47.8 years (±14.6) and a median BMI 31.1 kg/m2 (±7.4).  The most common preoperative symptoms documented were nausea and right upper quadrant pain.  The average GBEF was 92.4% (±5.3).   Postoperatively, of those available for follow up (n=68), 89.7% of the patients reported improvement or complete resolution of their symptoms.  The average time to follow up was 23.8 days (±10.6).   79% of the patients had histologic findings of chronic cholecystitis and/or cholesterolosis.

Conclusion: Hyperkinetic biliary dyskinesia is a poorly defined clinical entity.  Although it is not well understood, it appears to result in gallbladder mucosal inflammation and associated pain. As demonstrated, laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a beneficial treatment option for hyperkinetic biliary dyskinesia.

abstract_title: Safety and efficacy of laparoscopic microwave ablation in the management of HCC in cirrhotic livers
author_block: J. Garcialopez De Llano<sup>1</sup>, V. Vasudevan<sup>1</sup>, A. Sastry<sup>1</sup>, R. Arrangoiz<sup>1</sup>, M. Mijares Olivo<sup>1</sup>, G. Fernandez Christlieb<sup>2</sup>, A. Legaspi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Palmetto General Hospital- Center for Advanced Surgical Oncology,Surgical Oncology,Hialeah, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>ABC Medical Center, Mexico City,Surgery,Mexico City, CDMX, Mexico
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the world. The standard of care for the surgical point of view is either resection or transplant which is associated with significant morbidity and high costs. The role of loco-regional treatments has become an available alternative. MWA offers a focused and efficient energy source, hence a predictable zone of ablation (Fig.1). We report 66 patients with HCC treated with laparoscopic, ultrasound-guided MWA. 

Methods: We performed a retrospective chart review of 66 patients treated with laparoscopic microwave liver tumor ablation from 2013-2019. All patients with either imaging or biopsy-proven HCC were included in the study. Patient demographics, average tumor size, number of MWAs, operating room (OR) time, length of stay (LOS), complications, mortality and tumor recurrence were recorded.

Results: A total of 83 MWA were performed on 66 patients, with 80.3% patients treated with a single ablation. The mean age of the patients was 72.5 years, M: F ratio 2:1 and the average tumor size was 5.1cm. No blood transfusions were required in any patient. The average OR time was 110 min. The mean HCC-MELD score was 32 (HCC+MELD-Na). The average LOS was 2.5 days. There were post-operative complications in 7.6% (n=5) of the patients. The mortality rate was 1.5% (n=1). There was recurrence in 19.7% (n=13) of the patients with an average time of 22 months. After recurrence or new primary tumors, patients were treated with a second MWA or Y-90 radioembolization Conclusion This report is the largest series compiled to date. Laparoscopic ultrasound-guided MWA is a safe technique with minimal morbidity and mortality; effective for the treatment of cirrhosis associated HCC. This data supports the use of MWA as a viable alternative to resection and transplantation. We recommend increased surgical participation in minimally invasive liver ablation for treatment of HCC.

abstract_title: YAG Capsulotomy Rates Between two Types of Trifocal Intraocular Lenses
author_block: M. Ali<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Abdul Jabbar<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Zahid<sup>1</sup>, M. Siddiqui<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College,Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan
abstract_body:
Introduction: To evaluate YAG capsulotomy rates following implantation of two types of trifocal intraocular lenses (IOLs).

Methods: Eyes which either had an AT Lisa Tri or Alcon PanOptix IOL implant were included. The primary outcome measure was Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy. The rate of laser capsulotomy between the groups was compared using Chi-Squared test. A p-value of < 0.05 was taken as statistically significant.

Results: A total of 328 eligible eyes were identified. Nine eyes were excluded due to incorrect procedure code or missing files. Out of the 319 eyes of 177 patients included in this study, 180 received AT Lisa Tri while 139 of them received Alcon PanOptix Trifocal IOLs. The mean (SD) age of the patients was 52.29 years (±11.04). Gender was equally distributed with 91 male patients (51.4%). Median (IQR) time to laser capsulotomy was 8 months (3-16). Clinically posterior capsular opacification (PCO) was present in 75 eyes (23.5%). A total of 39 eyes (12.2%) underwent Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy. Among the AT Lisa Tri group 29 eyes (16.1%) underwent laser capsulotomy compared to 10 (7.2%) (n=10) in Alcon PanOptix group (p=0.016).

Conclusion: In this study cohort, eyes implanted with AT Lisa Tri showed a significantly increased rate of YAG capsulotomy. A prospective randomized control trial is recommended to confirm these findings.

abstract_title: Repair of the Iliac Artery Injury in Trauma: An Endovascular Operation?
author_block: H. Abdou<sup>1</sup>, M. Ottochian<sup>1</sup>, R. Kundi<sup>1</sup>, J. DuBose<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Scalea<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Morrison<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Maryland,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Endovascular techniques for the treatment of non-traumatic iliac disease are often considered first line therapies that are both durable and lower risk than operative intervention. The role of these techniques in traumatic lesions is unclear but has potential benefits. The aim of this study is to use a national registry to compare outcomes for open versus endovascular management of traumatic iliac injuries.

Methods: The National Trauma Data Bank was searched for all adult patients from 2002-2016 with iliac arterial injury as identified by either Abbreviated Injury Scale or International Classification of Disease scores. Patients were excluded who were transferred between hospitals, declared dead prior to the operating room, had a non-survivable head injury, traumatic amputation, multiple arterial injuries or were treated using open and endovascular techniques. Patients were considered by method of repair (open or endo) and mechanism (blunt or penetrating) and matched based on mangled extremity score variables: age, hypotension and time until operative repair. Using unpaired Student’s t-test and a p value of 0.05, comparison was made between 30-day rates of amputation in the groups.

Results: Overall, 2856 iliac injuries were identified: 1892 (66%) blunt and 964 (34%) penetrating injuries. In the blunt group, 342 (18%) had open surgery and 1550 (82%) underwent endovascular repair. Post-matching, 335 patients were matched in each group. Despite a higher proportion of chest, abdomen and extremity injuries in the endo group, and well-matched physiology and time to the operating room between the groups, endo repair was associated with a significantly lower rate of amputation than open repair (0.6% vs. 3.6%, p=0.015). A higher rate of venous injury was noted in the open versus endo group (13.7% vs. 1.8%, p<0.001). Within the penetrating injury group, 755 (78%) had open and 209 (22%) had endo repair. Post-matching, 198 patients were matched per group, with endo patients having a higher rate of fracture and extremity injury, but open patients sustaining more venous injury (48.5% vs. 37.4%, p=0.03). Endo repair was associated with a lower rate of amputation than open repair (0% vs. 5.1%, p=0.004).

Conclusion: Endovascular repair of iliac arterial injury was associated with a significantly lower rate of amputation than open surgery regardless of mechanism. However, open repair was also associated with traumatic venous injury and it is unknown whether this represents a data collection phenomenon (ie: observed at surgery, but not at angiography) or a real clinical entity. Further work is required to delineate the benefit of endovascular intervention and the role of iliac vein injury in limb salvage.

abstract_title: Effect of Tourniquets on Bleeding Control and Outcomes in Non-Traumatic Vascular Access Hemorrhage
author_block: J. Holloway<sup>1,3</sup>, C. M. Marsh<sup>1,3</sup>, C. De Virgilio<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Moazzez<sup>2</sup>, D. Kim<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harbor-UCLA Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Torrance, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science,College Of Medicine,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There has been increased public awareness of the role of tourniquets for extremity hemorrhage control due to national efforts such as the Stop the Bleed campaign. Although much of the focus has been placed on traumatic bleeding, hemorrhage from vascular access (AV fistula and graft) is an uncommon yet potentially fatal complication for which the optimal method of bleeding control has yet to be defined. We aim to To describe the use of tourniquets and examine their effect on outcomes in patients with vascular access hemorrhage.

Methods: We performed a 5-year retrospective cohort analysis of adult patients presenting to our Level 1 trauma center with vascular access bleeding. Variables analyzed were demographics, type and location of access, admission vital signs, method of hemorrhage control, transfusion requirements, loss of access, complications, and mortality. Patients who had tourniquets placed were compared to those who did not.

Results: Of 91 patients, the mean age was 65 years old and hemorrhage occurred outside of the dialysis center in 71%. Tourniquets were placed in 34 (37%), of which 62% were successful in controlling bleeding. In 50 patients (55%), non-medical personnel were responsible for initial attempts at bleeding control. 26 (29%) presented in shock and 17 (19%) received blood products in the emergency room. Mortality was 3%, and loss of access occurred in 23%. There was no difference between the tourniquet and non-tourniquet groups with respect to the presence of shock, need for transfusion, mortality, or loss of access (p=NS).

Conclusion: Vascular access hemorrhage occurs more commonly in non-healthcare settings and, in the majority of cases, initial attempts at bleeding control are dependent on non-medical personnel. Although mortality is low, nearly ¼ end up losing their access site. Further studies are required to determine the effectiveness and safety of routine tourniquet use for patients with vascular access bleeding complications.

abstract_title: Increased Mortality in Hip Fracture Patients with Aortic Stenosis and Pulmonary Hypertension
author_block: C. Cignoni<sup>1</sup>, S. Vuu<sup>1</sup>, J. Clark<sup>1</sup>, J. Hagan<sup>1</sup>, D. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, C. Watson<sup>1</sup>, L. Ferber<sup>1</sup>, W. Richards<sup>1</sup>, D. Ang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Central Florida,General Surgery,Ocala, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hip fractures are one of the most common traumatic injuries in the United States, secondary to an aging population. Multiple co-morbidities are found in patients who present to Trauma Centers (TC) with isolated hip fracture (IHF) including significant cardiac disease. Aortic stenosis (AS) among these patients has been recently shown to increase mortality. However, factors leading to death from aortic stenosis are unknown. We hypothesize that pulmonary hypertension (PHTN) is a significant mechanism of death among IHF patients with AS.

Methods: This is a multi-center retrospective cohort study examining IHF patients treated at Level I and II TC within a large hospital system from 2015-2019. Patients who had IHF and AS were compared to those who had IHF, AS, and PHTN. Multivariable logistic regression was used to risk adjust by age, race, insurance status, and other comorbidities. The primary outcome was inpatient mortality. The secondary outcomes were hospital acquired complications.

Results: A total of 1,388 IHF patients with AS were included in the study. Eleven percent of these patients also had PHTN. The crude mortality rate was higher if IHF patients had both AS and PHTN compared to IHF with AS alone, 9% vs. 3.7%, p-value 0.003. After risk adjustment, higher risk of mortality was still significant aOR 2.56 (95% CI 1.28, 5.11). In addition, IHF patients with both AS and PHTN had higher complication rates; specifically, cerebrovascular accident (2.8% vs 0.6% p-value 0.01), acute kidney injury (31.0% vs 21.9%, p-value 0.01), and hemorrhagic shock (2.1% vs 0.4%, p-value 0.01).

Conclusion: PHTN among IHF with AS increases the likelihood of inpatient mortality by 2.5 times. This is an important mechanism of death to identify because it will alter the peri-operative management in a significant subset of these patients.

abstract_title: Blunt Bowel and Mesenteric Injury: the Utility of CT in Diagnosis
author_block: A. E. Aicher<sup>1</sup>, M. Zawin<sup>2</sup>, M. Samuel<sup>2</sup>, J. Vosswinkel<sup>1</sup>, R. Jawa<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stony Brook University Medical Center,Trauma, Emergency Surgery, And Surgical Critical Care,Stony Brook, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Stony Brook University Medical Center,Radiology,Stony Brook, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Blunt bowel and mesenteric injury (BBMI) is a rare occurrence associated with substantial morbidity. Diagnosis remains challenging. We sought to evaluate the demographics, imaging findings, and outcomes of BBMI patients who had a CT abdomen/pelvis (CT/AP) at admission.

Methods:  We queried the trauma registry at an ACS Level 1 suburban trauma center for adults (≥18 years) admitted from 1/2009 to 12/2019 who had injury to the small bowel, colon, and/or mesentery after blunt trauma. Patients without admission CT and ED deaths were excluded. Chart review was conducted on BBMI patients and controls matched for age, sex, year of injury, and mechanism of injury.

Results: During the study period, 73 patients of 14,452 blunt trauma admissions met all criteria.  Median patient age was 45 (IQR 26,56) and 61.6% were male. The most common MOI was MVC (52, 71%). The median Injury Severity Score was 25 (IQR 14,36) and median hospital stay was 15 days (IQR 8,29). Nine patients died: 7 had complications of intraperitoneal injury including hemorrhage, fecal peritonitis, or sepsis, 1 with TBI, and 1 with thoracic aortic injury. Abnormal CT findings (Table 1) were recorded in 97%—CT alone was 91% sensitive and 91% specific for detecting BBMI confirmed on operation or with serial scans. 27 BBMI patients had 1 of the below CT findings, 31 had 2, 11 had 3, and 4 had 4. The most common concomitant findings were bowel wall pathology with hemoperitoneum/hematoma (14 cases). Non-operative patients were more likely to have only one finding (10/15) than operatively-managed patients (17/58). Of 73 BBMI patients, 15 were managed non-operatively. Of the 58 patients who had laparotomy, 48 BBMI were identified and operated on shortly after imaging.  There were 2 non-therapeutic laparotomies. Six patients had surgery at 20 hours to 8 days later. The PPV (therapeutic laparotomy/all laparotomies) of laparotomy was 96% but the NPV (non-op management/(successful non-op+failed non-op) for non-operative management was 71%. Of the 147 control patients, one had diaphragm rupture, one had bladder rupture, 5 had splenic laceration grades I-III, 4 had liver laceration grades I-III, and 2 had pancreatic contusion. 3 had ex-lap. 

Conclusion: BBMI occur infrequently.  The highest sensitivity CT finding is the presence of hemoperitoneum (74%).  However, pneumoperitoneum has the greatest specificity (100%). To avoid delays of care, a high level of clinical suspicion in patients with mechanism and/or radiologic findings is necessary to optimize the care of BBMI patients.

abstract_title: Direct Peritoneal Resuscitation for Damage Control: A Retrospective Study
author_block: J. Martinson<sup>2</sup>, L. O'Meara<sup>1</sup>, C. Cain<sup>1</sup>, R. Vesselinov<sup>1</sup>, M. Ghneim<sup>1</sup>, J. Diaz<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Maryland,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While direct peritoneal resuscitation (DPR) been shown to improve outcomes after damage control surgery (DCS), complications associated with DPR remain unexplored. The aim was to evaluate post-operative hypothermia, intra-abdominal hemorrhage (IAH), and abdominal fungal infection (AFI) in patients undergoing DCS with and without DPR.

Methods: This was a retrospective review of patients receiving DPR following initial DCS from 1/2016 to 7/2019 at a Level I trauma center.  Demographic, clinical, and operative characteristics were collected.  Outcomes evaluated included post-operative hypothermia, IAH, AFI, hospital length of stay (LOS), primary fascial closure (PFC), and in-hospital mortality (IM), and were compared against patients who did not receive DPR. Univariate and multivariate analysis was performed with a priori significance at p ≤ 0.05. Similar analyses were conducted for those undergoing DCS with and without DPR in the setting of abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) or involvement of large bowel from injury or perforation (LB).

Results: 139 patients were included in the study; 39 underwent DPR (33 EGS, 6 Trauma) and 100 underwent DCS with conventional resuscitation (64 EGS, 36 Trauma). Baseline characteristics and injury severity were similar among both groups. While post- operative hypothermia, IM, AFI, and LOS were also similar, DPR was associated with decreased IAH (OR 0.34 ,95% CI [0.12,0.96], p=0.049). When the analysis was restricted to those presenting with ACS (n=26), DPR was not associated with an increased risk of IAH or AFI but did have lower incidence of PFC (OR 0.11, 95% CI [0.017,0.74], p=0.041). For those presenting with LB (n=62), DPR was associated with increased AFI (OR 5.8, 95% CI [1.2, 28], p=0.03) but not IAH (Table).

Conclusion: In our study, while DPR in the setting of DCS reduced the risk of IAH, it may be associated with increased AFI in LB.  Further prospective and large-scale studies are needed to better elucidate these observed trends.

abstract_title: Trauma Patient ED Dwell Time is Associated with Patient Outcomes
author_block: Z. M. Bauman<sup>1</sup>, A. Raposo-Hadley<sup>1</sup>, C. Roessner<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Evans<sup>1</sup>, E. Cantrell<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Omaha, NE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Emergency Department (ED) dwell time is a metric many EDs focus on for a variety of reasons.  Patients spending excess time in the ED utilize resources that are not only costly to the institution and patient, but also occupy beds needed by other patients.  Furthermore, literature demonstrates crowed EDs lead to increased patient mortality.  However, little is known how this relates to trauma patients.  We hypothesize trauma activations significantly increase ED throughput and therefore overall outcomes.

Methods: Retrospective review of all trauma patients admitted to our Level 1, academic trauma center from 1/2018 - 1/2020.  Given we are not an accredited pediatric trauma center, we excluded patients < 18 years of age.  Furthermore, all direct admit patients were excluded given this was an analysis of ED dwell time.  Basic demographics were obtained and trauma activation criteria (based on ACS recommendations) for our institution was followed.  Primary outcome included total ED dwell time for trauma activation patients versus non-activations.  Secondary outcomes included association with hospital complications, specifically mortality and readmission rates, between trauma activation and non-activation patients based on ACS metrics.  Chi-square was used for categorical data and statistical significance was set at p<0.05.

Results:4924 patients were included.  2821 (57.3%) activations and 2103 (42.7%) non-activations.  Demographics breakdown can be seen in the table.  Mean ED dwell time for trauma activation patients was 2 hours 51 minutes (±2 hours 2 minutes) compared to 5 hours 26 minutes (±2 hours 41 minutes) for non-activation trauma patients (p<0.001).  Trauma activations (and therefore less ED dwell time) were associated with less overall hospital complications (20.1% vs 32.3%; p<0.001).  Mortality rates for trauma activations were higher (5.7% vs 1.3%; p<0.001).  However, readmission rates were lower for trauma activation patients (3.2% vs 30%; p<0.001).

Conclusion:Trauma patients presenting as activations not only have significantly shorter ED dwell times by approximately 2.5 hours but also experience decreased hospital complications and lower readmission rates when compared to non-activated trauma patients.  Given the acuity of activated trauma patients, one would expect the mortality to be higher.  Emphasis should be placed on moving trauma patients through the ED as quickly as possible to avoid unwanted outcomes.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Early Venous Thromboembolism Prophylaxis in Isolated Traumatic Brain Injuries
author_block: D. W. Kim<sup>1</sup>, A. Humayun<sup>1</sup>, S. Seng<sup>1</sup>, A. Lee<sup>2</sup>, S. Durgin<sup>1</sup>, A. Papa<sup>2</sup>, D. Lapoint<sup>2</sup>, A. Lowenfeld<sup>2</sup>, J. Palmbach<sup>2</sup>, N. Pantle<sup>2</sup>, A. Lozano<sup>3</sup>, A. Hanlon<sup>3</sup>, A. Ratnasekera<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Crozer Chester Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Upland, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University,Center For Biostatistics And Health Data Science,Roanoke, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The ideal timing for initiating chemical venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis in patients with isolated traumatic brain injury (TBI) is not clearly defined. We aimed to determine if early initiation of VTE prophylaxis was associated with lower rates of intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) expansion and VTE.

Methods: A single center, retrospective cohort study was conducted in a Level II Trauma Center from 2012 to 2018. Patients with isolated TBI who had initiation of chemical VTE prophylaxis within 24 hours of stable head CT (early) were compared to those who had VTE prophylaxis initiated after 24 hours of stable head CT (late). The primary outcomes of the study were ICH expansion and VTE.  Secondary outcomes were ICU length of stay (LOS), hospital LOS, and mortality. Statistical comparisons were accomplished using chi-square tests and non-parametric Kruskal-Wallis tests for categorical and continuous variables, respectively.

Results: Among 631 patients with isolated TBI, 199 were started on VTE prophylaxis. 61 patients had early initiation of VTE prophylaxis, and 138 were initiated late. The rate of VTE was 1.7% in the early group, 8.7% in the late group (p<0.0001), and 1.2% in the group that did not received chemical VTE prophylaxis. The rate of ICH expansion was 6.6% in the early group and 4.3% in the late group (p=0.5698). ICH expansion rate was 3.7% (n=16) in the group who received no chemical VTE prophylaxis. Patients in the late VTE prophylaxis group had longer hospital LOS (p<0.001) and ICU LOS (p<0.001). 

Conclusion: The study shows early initiation of chemical VTE prophylaxis in TBI patients decreased VTE complications without an increased risk of ICH expansion.

abstract_title: Subtotal Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy: A Safe Alternative
author_block: A. Byskosh<sup>1</sup>, B. Stocker<sup>1</sup>, D. Liu<sup>1</sup>, J. Li<sup>1</sup>, C. Devin<sup>1</sup>, G. Quach<sup>1</sup>, H. Weiss<sup>1</sup>, J. Posluszny<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Subtotal laparoscopic cholecystectomy (SUB) is a frequent alternative to total laparoscopic cholecystectomy (TOT) when the critical view of safety (CVS) cannot be achieved. Little is known about the clinical factors and outcomes associated with SUB. Our objective was to determine predictive factors and outcomes of SUB as compared to TOT.

Methods: We retrospectively reviewed the clinical factors and outcomes for patients who were admitted from our ED to the acute care service (ACS) and underwent SUB or TOT by an ACS surgeon for acute biliary disease (2017-2020). Wilcoxon rank sum and Fisher’s exact tests were used for continuous and categorical data, respectively.

Results: 450 patients underwent cholecystectomy; 19 (4.2%) were SUB. The 19 SUB and 170 randomly selected TOT patients were then reviewed. SUB patients were more likely to be male (57.9% v 25.9%; p=0.006), present to the ED with a longer duration of pain (3d v 1.5d, p=0.041), have a positive Murphy’s sign on exam (68.4% v 31.2%; p=0.002), have greater leukocytosis (14.0 v 10.8; p=0.043), receive pre-operative antibiotics (100% v 74.7%; p=0.008) and have a higher Tokyo Grade (2 v 1; p<0.001). Operative findings associated with SUB included perforated gallbladder on first visualization (15.8% v 0.6%; p=0.003), gallbladder decompression at the beginning of dissection (84.2% v 13.5%; p<0.001), inability to achieve the CVS (89.5% v 1.2%; p<0.001), higher blood loss (50mL v 25mL; p=0.009) and intraoperative drain placement (100% v 12.9%; p<0.001). SUB patients had an increased length of stay (4d v 3d; p<0.001), more 1-year readmissions related to their procedure (37.5% v 3.5%; p<0.001) and more often underwent post-discharge ERCP (31.6% v 4.1%; p<0.001). No major biliary tree or vascular injuries occurred in either group.

Conclusion: SUB is more often performed in patients presenting with greater severity of illness based on both preoperative and intraoperative factors. While there were no biliary or vascular injuries, suggesting that SUB may represent a safe alternative when the CVS cannot be achieved, SUB patients do have a more complicated postoperative course. More studies examining the indications for and outcomes of SUB are needed.

abstract_title: Additional Urgent Procedures May Confound Observed Benefits of Early Stabilization of Rib Fractures
author_block: J. R. Coleman<sup>1</sup>, K. Leasia<sup>2</sup>, E. E. Moore<sup>1,2</sup>, C. C. Burlew<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Lawless<sup>1,2</sup>, K. B. Platnick<sup>1,2</sup>, F. M. Pieracci<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Colorado-Denver,Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>Denver Health Medical Center,Surgery,Denver, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous studies suggest that surgical stabilization of rib fractures (SSRF) should be performed within 48 hours of injury. However, these data may be confounded by the fact that patients who require additional urgent procedures (AUP) experience delay to SSRF. The objective of this study was to characterize the prevalence and order of AUPs among patients who undergo SSRF. We hypothesized that AUPs occur before SSRF and increase time to SSRF.

Methods: This is a retrospective review of a prospectively maintained database from an urban, Level-1 trauma center (2010-2020). Patients who underwent isolated SSRF were compared to those who underwent SSRF plus ≥ 1 AUP. AUP was defined as any operative or endovascular procedure ≤ 5 days from injury.

Results: Overall, 202 patients underwent SSRF. The average age was 53 years, the majority (72%) were male, with an average injury severity score of 21. There were 68 patients (34%) who required ≥1 AUP; 62% underwent one AUP, 26% underwent two AUPs, and 12% underwent ≥3 AUPs. The most common AUPs were long bone operations (40%), pelvic fixation (28%), and exploratory laparotomy (26%). Compared to patients who underwent SSRF alone, AUP patients were more severely injured (median injury severity score 26 versus 17, p<0.01) and more commonly presented after high mechanism blunt trauma. AUP patients also incurred worse outcomes, including longer hospital length of stay (13 versus 8 days, p<0.01), higher rates of mechanical ventilation (72% versus 23%, p<0.01), and higher tracheostomy rates (72% versus 23%, p<0.01).   Among AUP patients, 56% underwent SSRF before the first AUP, 12% simultaneously with AUP, and 32% after the first AUP. Patients who required AUPs underwent SSRF significantly later than patients with no AUPs (hospital day 1.5 versus 0, p<0.01). The greatest delay to SSRF was in spine surgery patients (Figure). Subgroup analysis of AUP patients demonstrated that delay to SSRF was more pronounced patients who underwent SSRF after AUP (n=38) versus prior to AUP (n=22)(2 versus 1 day delay, p=0.01).

Conclusion: The occurrence of ≥ 1 AUP was associated with both increased injury severity and delayed SSRF. Future studies addressing timing of SSRF should stratify by AUPs, as they likely confound the perceived benefit of early repair.

abstract_title: Assessment of Intravascular Volume in Critically Ill Patients using Alveolar Recruitment Maneuvers
author_block: J. Goswami<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Junker<sup>1</sup>, T. Miles<sup>1</sup>, A. Kurjakto<sup>1</sup>, E. Antpack Filho<sup>1</sup>, J. Pescheman<sup>1</sup>, V. Strajina<sup>1</sup>, M. Rivera<sup>1</sup>, S. Henry<sup>1</sup>, E. Loomis<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mayo Clinic,Rochester, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Optimizing volume status is essential to ICU management and patient outcomes. Ultrasound (US) of the inferior vena cava (IVC) reliably assesses intravascular volume status; however, results are affected by provider technique, body habitus, and surgical dressings. Positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP) prevents and reverses atelectasis. Human and animal studies have shown that elevated PEEP can lead to hemodynamic changes, particularly in hypovolemic subjects. The transient decrease in systolic blood pressure identified in hypovolemic patients during recruitment maneuver appears to be a simple, non-invasive measure of intravascular volume status.   This pilot study was performed to validate the use of recruitment maneuvers to assess volume status.

Methods: Single institution prospective study of mechanically ventilated, hemodynamically unstable patients admitted to a surgical/trauma intensive care unit from December 2015 to March 2019. Consent for the study was obtained from a power of attorney or next of kin. IVC US and recruitment maneuvers were performed concurrently pre-resuscitation and post-resuscitation.   Resuscitation status was determined by treating team.  IVC measurements were performed in triplicate; mean distensibility index [dIVC = (IVCmax – IVCmin)/IVCmin x 100] was calculated with dIVC > 18% the cutoff for defined hypovolemia. Recruitment maneuvers were performed by increasing PEEP to 30 for 30 seconds. Systolic blood pressure decrease to <90mmHg or decrease by ≥ 40 mmHg from baseline was considered consistent with hypovolemia. Results from the two methods were compared.

Results: A total of 22 patients were enrolled in the study. Three were excluded for incomplete data (1) or incorrect collection (2). A total of 19 patient data sets were analyzed. Pre-resuscitation, US identified 14/19 (73.6%) patients as hypovolemic; whereas, recruitment maneuver identified 17/19 (89.5%) patients as hypovolemic. Post-resuscitation, US identified 12/19 (63.2%) as hypovolemic; whereas recruitment maneuver identified 9/19 (47.4%) as hypovolemic. US and recruitment maneuver were concordant on 13/19 (68.4%) patients for both pre and post-resuscitation.

Conclusion: Alveolar recruitment maneuvers to assess volume status is feasible.  Results from this small pilot study show modest concordance with IVC U/S. Both techniques support that Clinical judgment is not sufficient for assessing hypovolemia and response to volume resuscitation. Further larger studies are necessary to determine the applicability and generalizability of recruitment maneuvers in determining volume status.

abstract_title: Bleeding Control for Medical Students: Advocacy and Results
author_block: J. Fridling<sup>1</sup>, B. M. Chernock<sup>5</sup>, T. Nelson<sup>2</sup>, A. Tutunjian<sup>3</sup>, B. Moriarty<sup>4</sup>, A. Fox<sup>5</sup>, D. S. Shapiro<sup>6</sup>, L. Punch<sup>7</sup> <sup>1</sup>Frank H.
