Netter MD School of Medicine,Quinnipiac University,Hamden, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Tufts University School of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School,Newark, NJ, USA <sup>5</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School,Department Of Surgery,Newark, NJ, USA <sup>6</sup>Saint Francis Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Hartford, CT, USA <sup>7</sup>Washington University in St. Louis,Department Of Surgery,St. Louis, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Extremity hemorrhage is the most frequent cause of preventable death from trauma, and exsanguination can occur prior to the arrival of first responders. The American College of Surgeons (ACS) created the Bleeding Control Basic (BCON) course to teach members of the public to stop the bleed, and one million people have participated since its 2015 inception. A 2019 letter to the editor of the ACS Bulletin called for BCON to be incorporated into the curriculum at all medical schools, and several offer training through their curricula, faculty coordination, or student organization. Medical student-champions are working to expand opportunities so that all medical students may be certified in bleeding control. We hypothesized that medical students would be empowered by BCON training and would support efforts to include BCON in medical education.

Methods: First-year medical students who completed BCON training between January and August 2019 were administered optional surveys immediately following and six months after completing the course. Surveys inquired about students’ demographic information, previous experience, and reaction to the course using free text, select an answer, and five-point Likert-scale responses. Two-sample t-tests were performed on the coded Likert-scale responses.

Results: More than 1800 medical students completed BCON training; 442 first-year students completed post-course surveys, and 213 completed 6-month follow-up surveys. Immediately following the course, the average response was between Agree (4) and Strongly Agree (5) that the course taught the student the basics of bleeding control (4.65), the student would apply the skills to a live person (4.61), and the student is able to save a life (4.14). Follow-up responses were positive but significantly lower at 3.87, 4.19, and 3.56 respectively (p < 0.001). Students supported recommending the course to other medical students at both time points (4.68, 4.31), though the follow-up response was again lower (p < 0.001). Eleven surveyed students (5.2%) registered as instructors during the survey period. Notably, six students (2.8%) used course skills on a live person. Five reported control of the hemorrhage using direct pressure, and one was unable to control the hemorrhage using direct pressure, wound packing, and a tourniquet.

Conclusion: Through BCON, medical students have been empowered to save lives and advocate for and in their communities. Students learn life-saving interventions they can use immediately and develop teaching skills that will be valuable as future physicians. Our efforts, which do not catalog every BCON program, demonstrate benefits of using students as BCON advocates. All medical students should learn how to stop the bleed.

abstract_title: Designing a Resident-Led Intimate Partner Violence Screening Program in Trauma Patients
author_block: M. L. Rosser<sup>1</sup>, J. Wang<sup>1</sup>, H. Decker<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Schwab<sup>1</sup>, V. Petersen<sup>1</sup>, D. M. Stein<sup>1</sup>, T. Bongiovanni<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA

abstract_title: Did a COVID-19 Pandemic Shelter-in-place order impact Nonaccidental Traumatic (NAT) Injuries?
author_block: S. Strotmeyer<sup>1</sup>, M. Madill<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Gaines<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg,Pediatric Trauma,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Child advocates raised alarms about a potential uptick in child abuse during shelter-in-place (SIP) mandates amid the coronavirus pandemic. Previous research found seasonal variation for NAT during summer break, and during the financial crisis in 2008. 1,2  The aim of this study was to identify pandemic variation in non-accidental trauma in children presenting to a level 1 trauma facility.

Methods: Retrospective review of a regional pediatric trauma registry using External-cause-of injury codes and mechanism of injury descriptions. Data was analyzed via exact test analysis in order to test for independence between time and incidence for NAT. Odds ratios were calculated by logistic regression adjusting for age. Significant was considered at <.05 with a 95% confidence interval.

Results:There were 322 trauma admissions (153 pre-pandemic; 169 during). Confirmed NAT injuries were proportionally higher in the pre-pandemic group (17%) versus the pandemic group (6%). Children were more likely to be admitted for NAT prior to the pandemic (p = .002). When adjusting for age NAT outcomes were higher in the pre-pandemic group (p<.000).

Conclusion:Admissions for NAT injuries in children decreased during the SIP pandemic orders. This unanticipated outcome raises awareness about dangers faced by kids at home, this year, they say it's even more urgent because of the pandemic which presents the perfect storm for the escalation of NAT.   1. Huang MI, O’Riordan MA, Fitzenrider BA, McDavid L, Cohen AR, Robinson S. Increased incidence of nonaccidental head trauma in infants associated with the economic recession. J Neurosurg Pediatr. 2011;8(2):171-6. 2. Leaman, Laura, William Hennrikus, and Adam Y. Nasreddine. "An evaluation of seasonal variation of nonaccidental fractures in children less than 1 year of age." Clinical pediatrics 56.14 (2017): 1345-1349.

abstract_title: Missing in Action: Military Manuscripts in the Medical Literature Since 1950
author_block: J. W. Cannon<sup>1,2,3</sup>, A. Bergman<sup>3</sup>, R. Allard<sup>2</sup>, T. Davis<sup>2</sup>, J. Rolfing<sup>1</sup>, K. Gross<sup>4</sup>, E. A. Elster<sup>2</sup>, T. E. Rasmussen<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Traumatology, Surgical Critical Care & Emergency Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Uniformed Services University Of The Health Sciences,Department Of Surgery,Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Leonard Davis Institute Of Health Economics,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>US Army Trauma Training Center at Ryder Trauma,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We hypothesize that military-relevant publications are under-represented in the medical literature and that such publications decline rapidly following active conflict.

Methods: We queried PubMed for military-relevant publications from 1950 to 2020 in the highest impact journals listed in the Journal Citation Report (JCR) in three practice areas: Medicine, Surgery, and Trauma/Critical Care. Boolean searches were developed using National Library of Medicine Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) terms for both inclusion and exclusion. Baseline publication rates were defined using general military MeSH terms, and the MeSH term “warfare” was used to identify combat-specific publications. The proportion of military physicians relative to the civilian sector was used to estimate expected publication rates. The start of major combat operations was noted for Korea, Vietnam, Gulf War I, and Operation Enduring + Iraqi Freedom (OEF+OIF). A quadratic function was developed to assess publication rate trends controlling for the start of active conflict and conflict intensity. Comparisons were performed using Pearson’s Chi Square with p<0.05 considered a significant difference.

Results: From 1950 to 2020, a total of 713,350 manuscripts were published in the JCR high-impact journals queried. Of these, military-relevant manuscripts totaled 4,103 (0.58%), significantly less than the proportion of military physicians in the US (1.2%, p<0.001). Subgroup analysis found 2,567 of 499,211 (0.51%) manuscripts in Medicine journals, 483 of 126,627 (0.38%) manuscripts in Surgery journals, and 1,052 of 87,512 (1.20%) manuscripts in Trauma/Critical Care journals. Relative to the beginning of each conflict, military-relevant publications peaked at 3.1 years (95% CI, 2.5 to 3.7) and then decayed back to low baseline rates of publication within 6.2 years (95% CI, 5.0 to 7.4). Over the past 70 years, both Medicine and Surgery jurnals demonstrated consistently low rates of military-relavant publications in contrast to a significant upward trend in these publications in Trauma/Critical Care journals (Figure).

Conclusion: Military-relevant publications are significantly under-represented in the medical literature. Notable exceptions include periods of active conflict and publications in Trauma/Critical Care journals. Efforts to fund, conduct, and disseminate military-relevant research in high-impact journals should increase to reflect the societal investment in military medicine.

abstract_title: Implementation of Ethics Morbidity and Mortality Conference into Surgical Training
author_block: N. H. Moraco<sup>1</sup>, Y. Joo<sup>2</sup>, R. Jhunjhunwala<sup>1</sup>, M. F. McKneally<sup>2</sup>, D. W. Hanto<sup>2,4</sup>, A. C. Mosenthal<sup>3</sup>, R. I. Whyte<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Lahey Clinic,Burlington, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>VA St. Louis Health Care System,St Louis, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ethics and professionalism are core medical competencies with limited directed didactic education in surgical training. Traditionally, the morbidity and mortality (M&M) conference is a weekly non-punitive peer-reviewed forum designed to reflect upon and take ownership of adverse events; and while ethical issues may be raised, the focus is largely on technical or clinical errors. Just as formal review of these clinical errors is fundamental to the development of sound surgical judgement, it is imperative to allow space to exercise the development of ethical decision-making. We present a quality initiative created to integrate ethics as a core component of surgical M&M.

Methods: In 2019, our institution instituted a 20-minute Ethics M&M into regularly scheduled M&M assuring full attendance by residents and staff, and enabling lively discussion to enhance resident education. This allowed review of cases that were ethically complex or presented an element of moral ambiguity as determined by the involved surgeons. Topics have included compassionate extubation, moral distress, concepts of entrustment, directed organ donation, and the role of trainees in the COVID pandemic. As is traditionally done, a resident presents a brief synopsis of the case; however, unlike traditional M&M a second resident facilitates a discussion interspersed with questions and relevant literature to enhance ethical learning. A post-conference survey with semi-structured interview questions was conducted to evaluate the impact of this conference on residents. Axial coding was performed to elicit themes, as we begin developing a grounded theory.

Results: The preliminary survey-response rate was 24% (12/49 residents). All resident responses indicated utility of the Ethics M&M to promote bioethics discourse, to improve surgical judgment, and to enhance the surgical educational experience. Themes elicited from the semi-structured interview questions suggest that Ethics M&M provides a meaningful bioethics discussion, allows for different perspectives, and is a useful tool to reduce moral distress.

Conclusion: Based on resident respondents, this forum promotes open discussion of ethically complex events leading to an experience that was meaningful and has the potential to reduce moral distress among residents and faculty alike. We demonstrate that the implementation of an ethics-specific M&M is both a feasible and an effective platform for ethics discourse in which to integrate ethics didactics and enhance surgical curricula.

abstract_title: Reflective Cartooning with Surgical Students
author_block: K. Doshi<sup>1</sup>, T. Maatman<sup>1</sup>, T. Maatman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Students encounter considerable stress on their clerkships, specifically the surgical clerkship is a difficult environment for medical students. Previous research has shown that students who completed surgical clerkships were more cynical and intolerant to ambiguity. It was also found that students who completed surgical clerkships early in their first clinical year were less confident as the year progressed.  Art has been a form of reflection that is used to counter this effect.  A study used Rational Emotive Behavior Therapy (REBT) and art therapy (engraving method) found that REBT and art therapy increase the self-esteem and resilience in students.  There is some research that indicates that artmaking helps students gain understanding in relation to self, patients, pain, suffering, and the role of a doctor.  Comics are an art form that allows for sharing of medical experiences without high artistic skill expectations.  In fact, Surgeons are a particular group reported to singled out in comics drawn by medical students. We sought to understand how drawing comics of the surgical experience helped students reflect and manage stress.

Methods:  The Medical College of Wisconsin Surgery clerkship for third-year medical students offered a 1-hour session on reflective cartooning to combat stressors. The session consists of a warm up drawing activity, brief explanation, time to draw a comic about both a positive and negative situation, and time to share comics. The sessions occur after the first month of the two-month rotation.

Results: There were 198 participants who took part in cartooning sessions in the surgical clerkship. There was 131 (66%) completion of the post session survey. Of the students who completed the survey 59(45%) reported being highly stresses and 30(22) reported being stress on the surgery clerkship. Seventy-two(80%) reported decreased levels of stress after completing the cartooning session. Seventy-nine(88%) reported that it helped them reflect on the situations they depicted. 16 (18%) of participants drew a comic about a negative experience they had not shared before. Fifty percent and 36% of the participants were highly satisfied and satisfied respectively with the session.

Conclusion:  Overall, the session is successful in helping students reflect and share. They have been able to share situations they have not shared before. Participants reported it helped reduce their stress levels. Additionally, satisfaction with the sessions was high. The session helps participants in a short time to process some of the challenges in a safe and structured environment.

abstract_title: Learner Drawing and Sculpting in Surgical Education: A Systemic Review
author_block: E. B. Card<sup>1</sup>, J. T. Mauch<sup>1</sup>, I. C. Lin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Division Of Plastic Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Historically, surgery was born and developed through the visual work of artist-scientists, yet visual art courses in modern surgical education are rare. In the 21st-century, some medical school and residency curriculums have incorporated visual art courses to foster skills such as empathy and observation, as well as to improve anatomical understanding. The aim of this study was to evaluate the existing literature of learner creation of visual art as an educational tool in surgery and to discuss its potential in augmenting surgical learning.

Methods:  A systematic review of surgical educational interventions involving learner drawing, painting, and sculpting was conducted searching PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, Embase, Cumulative Index of Nursing and Allied Health Literature, and Education Resources Information Center. Articles written in a language other than English and articles detailing historical figures and practices were excluded.

Results: Our search yielded 388 unique articles, and of those 12 met inclusion criteria. Seven reported educational interventions for plastic surgeons (58.3%), followed by obstetrics and gynecology residents (16.7%), medical students with plastic and orthopaedic surgeons (8.3%), neurosurgeons (8.3%), and any surgeon (8.3%). Seven articles were descriptions of drawing and sculpting courses designed to develop the “art” of surgery such as judgement or aesthetic sense (58.3%). The other five publications described initiatives aimed at teaching or assessing surgical anatomy or knowledge (41.7%). Common goals and subjective outcomes included the measurement and observation of live models to enhance judgement of proportions, improved understanding of three-dimensional (3D) anatomical structure, improved hand-eye coordination, and improved communicative drawing ability for live patient education and the medical record. Notable objective findings included significantly improved retention of anatomy, correlation of drawing and image labeling with in-service exam scores, and correlation of procedural drawing with ability to perform the same procedure in a simulation. Themes about the impact of drawing and sculpting on surgical practice included benefits in the areas of observation, aesthetic sense, surgical anatomy and knowledge, surgical skills, doctoring, and wellness.

Conclusion: While most identified articles focused on honing principles common to both realistic art and aesthetic surgery, our review suggests that all surgical disciplines could benefit from artistic training through improved visual communication and deeper understanding of 3D anatomy. We propose that visual art education serves as an interesting and important educational tool to improve perceptual skill and anatomical understanding in the modern surgeon.

abstract_title: Qualitative Assessment Of Online Patient Resources For Deep Vein Thrombosis
author_block: P. Tolbert<sup>3</sup>, J. Treffalls<sup>3</sup>, W. Clothier<sup>3</sup>, Z. Harbin<sup>3</sup>, Q. Yan<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Davies<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio,Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery,San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>South Texas Medical Center,South Texas Center For Vascular Care,San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio,Long School Of Medicine,San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients in the U.S. are seeking information on their health conditions from the internet at an increasing rate. In this study, we seek to evaluate the quality and readability of freely available patient information resources found on the internet for deep vein thrombosis.

Methods:  Internet searches for “deep vein thrombosis” were conducted on a cleared-cache web browser in July 2020 across three search engines: Google, Bing, Yahoo!, and the two metasearch engines Dogpile and Yippy. Two raters independently scored websites on four dimensions and resolved discrepancies via consensus. The Flesch Reading Ease (FRE) formula, Flesch-Kincaid (FK) Grade Level, Simple Measure of Gobbledygook (SMOG) Index, and Dale-Chall (DC) Readability Index were used to assess readability. Statistical analysis was performed with RStudio with ANOVA.

Results: Out of 125 websites collected, 35 met inclusion criteria. Reasons for exclusion included: duplications 78, no original written patient education material about DVT 6, for physician use 2, not accessible 2, closed access websites 2. The type of website included: open access 13 (37.14%), government agency 8 (22.86%), hospital/healthcare organization 7 (20.00%), professional medical society 4 (11.43%), industry-sponsored 3 (8.57%). Quality scores are outlined in Table 1. The majority of websites (71.4%) discussed pulmonary embolism as a complication in detail. Most websites (85.7%) also described preventative measures. Anticoagulation (94.3%) was the most discussed treatment option. Placement of an IVC filter (71.4%) was the most commonly discussed procedure, followed by thrombolysis (65.7%), surgical thrombectomy (31.4%), and catheter-directed thrombectomy (20.0%). Professional medical society sites (3.00 [IQR 2.38-3.50]) had significantly poorer accountability than government agency (8.50 [IQR 5.25-8.75]), hospital/healthcare provider (6.50 [IQR 2.75-7.50]), industry-sponsored (7.0 [IQR 6.50-11.00]), and open access (11.00 [IQR 9.00-12.00]) (p=0.005). Overall readability was slightly difficult with a median FRE 61.95 (IQR 56.60–70.05) (interpreted as grade level 8-9 [IQR 8-10]), an FK grade level 9 (IQR 7-10), a SMOG grade level 9 (IQR 7-10), a DC grade level 9-10 (IQR 9-10).

Conclusion: Quality of freely available online patient information resources on deep vein thrombosis is quite variable and readability is not ideal for patients. While professional medical society sites did have poorer accountability, type of website did not significantly predict any other quality scores. Providers are encouraged to provide a direct list of websites with information on deep vein thrombosis to their patients due to the variability in quality and readability present.

abstract_title: The Correlation Between Altmetric Score, Impact Factor, and Citations in Orthopaedic Literature
author_block: C. S. Collins<sup>1</sup>, N. P. Singh<sup>1</sup>, S. Ananthasekar<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Boyd<sup>1</sup>, T. W. King<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Plastic Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clinicians and researchers across medicine are turning to online platforms, such as Twitter, Facebook, and blog posts to share their research. The Altmetric Attention Score (AAS) is a quantitative and fluid measurement of the online influence of research. The objective of this study is to determine if AAS of articles correlates with traditional bibliometrics such a journal impact factor and citation count in the Orthopaedic Surgery literature.

Methods:  The 10 most cited articles from each of the 15 Orthopaedic Surgery journals with the highest impact factor in 2014 and 2017 were reviewed. For each article, the AAS was collected using the Altmetric Bookmarklet application and number of citations was recorded from SCOPUS. Journal impact factor was recorded from Journal Citation Reports. Statistical analysis was completed using descriptive statistics and Pearson’s correlation coefficient in Microsoft Excel.

Results: A total of 300 articles published in either 2014 or 2017 were analyzed. A significant weak positive correlation was found between citation count and AAS for 2014 (r = 0.2802, p = 0.0014) while there was no correlation found for 2017 (r = 0.0202, p = 0.8138) (Figure 1). There was a no significant correlation between impact factor and AAS in either 2014 ( r = 0.0700, p = 0.8041) or in 2017 (r = 0.0701, p = 0.8015) (Figure 2).

Conclusion: A possible correlation between AAS with citations and impact factor may be seen in the Orthopaedic Surgery literature. Articles published in 2014 had longer online exposure, possibly explaining the lack of correlation seen between the AAS and citations for 2017 articles. However, at this point in time AAS and traditional bibliometrics are not strongly correlated with one another in the Orthopaedic Surgery literature. Citations take years to accumulate while AAS provides an immediate evaluation of the scholarly impact of an article. An amalgamation of traditional bibliometrics including citation count and impact factor, and AAS may prove useful in determining the short and long term impact of publications in Orthopaedic Surgery.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 on Surgical Education: Evaluating Resident and Faculty Satisfaction
author_block: M. B. Nagaraj<sup>1</sup>, H. B. Weis<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Weis<sup>1</sup>, G. S. Cook<sup>1</sup>, L. W. Bailey<sup>1</sup>, T. H. Shoultz<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Farr<sup>1</sup>, K. R. Abdelfattah<sup>1</sup>, L. A. Dultz<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,General Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: At the onset of social distancing, our general surgery residency transitioned its educational curriculum to an entirely virtual format with no gaps in conference offerings. The aim of this study is to describe our evolution to a virtual format and report program attitudes toward the changes. 

Methods: On March 15, 2020, our institution restricted mass gatherings. We immediately transitioned all lectures to a virtual platform. The cancellation of elective surgeries in April 2020 then created the need for augmented resident education opportunities. We responded by creating additional lectures and implementing a daily conference itinerary. To evaluate the success of the changes and inform the development of future curriculum, we surveyed residents (N=61) and faculty (N=94) regarding the changes. Classes and faculty answers were compared for perception of value of the online format.

Results: Pre-COVID-19, residency-wide educational offerings were concentrated to one half-day per week. Once restrictions were in place, our educational opportunities were expanded to a daily schedule and averaged 16.5 hours/week during April. Overall, 41/63 residents and 25/94 faculty completed the survey. The majority of residents reported an increased ability (56%) or similar ability (34.1%) to attend virtual conference while 9.9% indicated a decrease. Faculty responses indicated similar effects (64% increased, 32% similar, 4% decreased). PGY-1 residents rated the changes negatively compared to other trainees and faculty. PGY-2 residents reported neutral views and all other trainees and faculty believed the changes positively affected educational value (Figure 1). Comments from PGY-1 and 2 residents revealed they could not focus on virtual conference as it was not “protected time” in a classroom and that they felt responsible for patient care during virtual lectures. A majority of both residents (61%) and faculty (84%) reported they would prefer to continue virtual conferences in the future.

Conclusion: The necessity for adapting our academic offerings during the COVID-19 era has afforded our program the opportunity to trial new platforms and expand our educational offerings. The majority of participants report stable to improved attendance and educational value. Virtual lectures should still be considered protected time in order to maximize the experience for junior residents.

abstract_title: Association and Impact of Resident and Senior Author Gender on Surgical Publications
author_block: W. J. Kane<sup>1</sup>, A. H. Denton<sup>2</sup>, A. T. Schroen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia,Surgery,Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Virginia,Claude Moore Health Sciences Library,Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  It is unknown whether the gender of surgical resident authors and the gender of their surgical faculty senior authors are associated, and whether certain resident-senior author gender pairings have differential publication metrics.

Methods:  PubMed queries were performed for categorical general surgery resident publications with a department of surgery faculty senior author at a single institution from January 2017 - May 2020. Publication metrics were extracted for each publication using the Web of Science Core Collection. Author characteristics, including resident and faculty member gender, were obtained from an institutional database. Publication activity and metrics were compared between genders.

Results: 360 total publications, representing 193 unique publications, were authored by 33 residents, of which 10 (30.3%) residents were female. 100 out of 360 (27.8%) publications were authored by female residents. 174 out of 193 (90.2%) publications had identifiable Journal Impact Factor and times cited data. Female resident publications, as compared to male resident publications, were significantly more likely to have a female faculty senior author (28/100 [28.0%] publications vs. 34/260 [13.1%] publications, p=0.001). Similarly, female resident first-author publications were significantly more likely to have a female faculty senior author (11/37 [29.7%] publications vs. 9/77 [11.7%] publications, p=0.02). At the resident level, female residents, as compared to male residents, were significantly more likely to publish with a female faculty senior author (median 27.2% vs. 0% of resident total publications, p=0.01). There was no difference in Journal Impact Factor or citations per year between male and female residents. There was no difference in Journal Impact Factor between male and female senior authors, however female senior authors tended to be less cited (median [IQR] 1.0 [0.2-1.3] vs. 1.8 [0.9-2.5] citations per year, p=0.06) (Figure).

Conclusion: Female surgery residents, as compared to male surgery residents, were more likely to publish with female surgical faculty senior authors. While male and female faculty senior authors published in similar caliber journals, there was a trend toward fewer citations garnered by female senior authors. These findings may help explain ongoing gender disparities in academic surgery.

abstract_title: Gender Disparity in Cholecystectomy: Examining Teaching Resident Cases
author_block: S. Rivedal<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Stahl<sup>1</sup>, J. Barrett<sup>1</sup>, P. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Aiken<sup>1</sup>, S. Acher<sup>1</sup>, L. M. Cherney Stafford<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Abbott<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Evaluating gender bias in general surgical residency is crucial for providing equitable and high-quality education, but few studies have quantitatively examined whether gender impacts resident operative autonomy. This study addresses gender disparity in cholecystectomies as teaching case opportunities for senior residents.

Methods:  All patients undergoing cholecystectomy at an academic medical center were retrospectively queried from January 2016 to March 2020. The cohort included PGY4 and PGY5 general surgery residents who performed teaching cases as the senior resident. Bivariate and multivariable analyses were performed to examine the association between resident gender, PGY level, and number of teaching cases performed.

Results: 688 non-teaching (one-resident) cholecystectomy cases and 372 teaching cases (two-resident) cholecystectomy cases were identified. Of the senior residents at PGY levels 4 and 5, 33 were male and 40 were female. Resident gender had no impact on the total number of teaching cases, nonteaching cases, or average percentage of teaching cases per total number of cases. Multivariable analysis showed that PGY 5 level and case type significantly impacted whether a cholecystectomy was a teaching assistant case (p = <.001).

Conclusion: At our institution, resident gender did not change exposure to teaching assistant cholecystectomy opportunities in residency; residents at PGY level 5 perform significantly more teaching assistant cases than PGY 4 level residents, regardless of gender. These results may partially be explained by the relatively large number of female residents in our General Surgery residency program, but future, prospective evaluation of gender equality within the OR is critical to ensure all learners have equal access to operative learning and teaching.

abstract_title: Qualitative Insight into Ranking of General Surgery Residency Programs by URM Applicants
author_block: C. E. Richburg<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Shehirian<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Smith<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Iyengar<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Santos-Parker<sup>1</sup>, G. Kwakye<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite the ACGME requirement of “diversity” in residency programs, underrepresented minorities are disproportionately underrepresented in academic surgery. While efforts are being made in surgery to improve this gap, there is still a wide variation in URM representation in each residency program. This qualitative study aimed to gain insight into factors underrepresented minority (URM) interns identify as important in their rank list of General Surgery residency programs to aid institutions in increasing URM representation and creating supportive training environments in academic surgery.

Methods: URM general surgery interns who matched in 2020 were interviewed through semi-structured telephone interviews from June to August 2020 to identify factors impacting their residency ranking. Participants were recruited through social media platforms, emails, and a snowballing method. Interview guides were created by identification of important themes through a focus group of current URM medical students and review of existing literature on the subject.

Results: From 15 URM interns contacted, 5 were interviewed. Overall major themes identified influencing URM intern’s rank list decisions include 1) presence of URM representation in the program, 2) program support of resident-led goals, 3) active inclusivity efforts and programs in place, and 4) direct experiences of current-URM residents who highlighted camaraderie amongst peers and empowerment of their voices being heard and respected by their department. Additionally, applicants found it difficult to determine how diverse programs were and relied on program photos of faculty and residents or day-of-interview interactions. All participants relied heavily on current URM residents at their program of interest as a source of information, and personal communication and relationships developed with these residents helped guide their decisions. Detractors from programs included interns concerned with being the only person of color in their program and no concrete initiatives or goals in place to support diversity and inclusion revealing a concern of performative allyship.

Conclusion: These findings provide insight into important factors for URM applicants when evaluating general surgery residency programs, including current representation and support of URMs, active diversity and inclusion initiatives within a program, and lived experiences of current URM residents. General surgery residency programs should take steps to not only intentionally recruit URM applicants, but also create a supportive training environment that is diverse, inclusive, and empowering to ultimately improve representation in general surgery.

abstract_title: Assessment of Transplant Trainee Education and Recruitment
author_block: D. E. Cassidy<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Santos-Parker<sup>1</sup>, A. E. Gomez-Rexrode<sup>1</sup>, L. M. McElroy<sup>3</sup>, S. Waits<sup>2</sup>, V. S. Valbuena<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Transplantation,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Department Of Transplantation,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The demand for fellowship training in abdominal transplantation has been decreasing over the past two decades. With general surgery residents having less exposure to the specialty and evolving personal and professional needs, the appeal of the field continues to change. Targeted interventions to increase trainee engagement are needed to fortify the pipeline for transplant surgery. We aimed to evaluate training factors that attracted the rising transplant surgery workforce to inform recommendations for best recruitment and education interventions. These best practices can be used to optimize the experience of trainees and attract the most talented workforce into transplant surgery. 

Methods:  A 38-question survey was distributed electronically to candidate members of the American Society of Transplant Surgeons (ASTS). Participants were surveyed about demographics, medical school and residency training settings, exposure to transplant surgery, and the career and academic mentorship they received. Descriptive statistics and t-test analyses were performed.

Results: Of the 324 ASTS candidate members surveyed, 94 individuals responded (29% response rate). Most (57%) participants reported having exposure to transplant surgery in medical school. At the start of residency training, those who had medical student exposure to transplant surgery had a higher interest level in transplant (p<0.05). When exposed to transplant surgery in medical school, the average reported interest rating was 6.9±3.0, on a Likert scale of 1 (not interested) to 10 (very interested), vs 3.4±3.0 for no medical student exposure. A majority of respondents (73%) interacted with other residents who were excited about transplant surgery, while only 29% reported interacting with a transplant fellow who excited them about the field. The majority of trainees (76%) spent dedicated research time during residency, and felt supported by faculty during research time (64%) and their fellowship application cycle (73%).  

Conclusion: Mentorship, pipeline programs, and early exposure to transplant surgery in medical school can optimize recruitment and interest in transplant. Those with medical student exposure to transplant surgery had higher interest at the beginning of residency, emphasizing the need for early exposure and engagement throughout training. A high percent of transplant surgery trainees reported having mentorship in the specialty, suggesting that intentional mentorship may provide an important avenue for engagement with transplant. Given that less than one third of respondents had meaningful interactions with transplant fellows, there is an opportunity to improve the resident-fellow experience to optimize recruitment.

abstract_title: Title: Quality Improvement Tools in Total Joint Arthroplasty: A Systematic Review
author_block: H. Bonner<sup>1</sup>, J. Jones<sup>1</sup>, A. Arguello<sup>1</sup>, T. He<sup>1</sup>, B. Ponce<sup>1</sup>, E. Brabston<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Orthopaedic Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Systems review and quality improvement (QI) is a significant need within orthopaedic surgery. The key focus of this paper is to systematically review QI principles and techniques utilized in total joint arthroplasty to determine most successful QI tools.

Methods: A systematic search on MEDLINE/Pubmed, Embase, Cochrane Library and other sources was conducted from September 1991 through October 2018 using key terms orthopedic, plan do check act, statistical quality control, lean process, six sigma, lean six sigma, lean, and quality improvement. Inclusion criteria were implementation of a QI tool in orthopaedics written in English. The included studies were categorized into their specific quality and process improvement tool. The three primary improved outcomes from each article were recorded along with the date, author and subspecialty.

Results:Thirty – four eligible studies related to joint arthroplasty were identified for inclusion in the systematic review. The most common outcomes that were improved in these publications were: length of stay (LOS) – 35%, cost – 26%; medication management – 17%; and patient education 11%. Lean and clinical care pathways most commonly improved length of stay and cost; plan-do-check-act (PDCA) most commonly improved medication management; and shared decision-making improved patient education and satisfaction.

Conclusion:We found four metrics that were consistently improved by certain quality improvement tools. Further research is warranted to continue to build a framework for quality improvement in orthopaedic surgery.

abstract_title: How Applicants to General Surgery Residency Define Wellness
author_block: C. Buonpane<sup>1</sup>, S. Hayek<sup>1</sup>, R. Shabahang<sup>1</sup>, K. Young<sup>1</sup>, M. Shabahang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Medical Center,Danville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite a national focus on trainee burnout, resident wellness is still a significant issue.  This study sought to determine how applicants to general surgery residency define wellness. 

Methods: This is an IRB approved (#2020-0330) qualitative study of in person interviews to general surgery residency at a single tertiary care academic center.  The interviews took place over one application season from 2019-2020.  During the institution’s standard interview process, each applicant was asked, “what does wellness look like for you in residency?”  Responses were documented by the interviewer.  Applicants were not aware that their responses were being recorded.   Qualitative content analysis was conducted by a research team consisting of faculty, research staff and residents.  Initial codes were developed and defined.  The research team members then independently coded the responses and an iterative group consensus process was used to develop the final themes. 

Results: A total of 91 applicants were interviewed.  The responses were categorized into four themes: relationships, positive culture, time and self-worth (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Applicants to General Surgery residency categorized wellness into the following four categories: relationships, positive culture, time and self-worth.  These findings shed light on what areas programs need to focus wellness efforts on.  Next steps are to further delineate what each of these categories mean to individual learners in order to aid in the development and implementation of initiatives that promote resident wellbeing.

abstract_title: Impact of COVID-19-Compliant Surgical Boot Camp on Resident Knowledge and Confidence
author_block: A. Metchik<sup>1</sup>, D. F. Mason<sup>6</sup>, R. Evangelista<sup>1</sup>, K. C. Benson<sup>6</sup>, K. Kalber<sup>6</sup>, P. A. Filomena<sup>6</sup>, K. M. Bradshaw<sup>6</sup>, L. R. Becker<sup>7</sup>, J. F. Lazar<sup>4,5</sup>, W. B. Al-Refaie<sup>1</sup>, E. Felger<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Department Of General Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>Washington Hospital Center,Division Of Endocrine Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Division Of Endocrine Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>4</sup>Washington Hospital Center,Division Of Thoracic Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>5</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Division Of Thoracic Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>6</sup>MedStar Health,Simulation Training & Education Lab,Washington, DC, USA <sup>7</sup>MedStar Health,Learning Research & Design, SiTEL,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clinical boot camps have been validated to significantly improve skills, knowledge and confidence, and have been widely adapted by surgical residencies to introduce interns to crucial skillsets. In June, 2020, social-distancing guidelines secondary to COVID-19 rendered many traditional boot camp methods impossible. Herein, we report quantitative and qualitative data from a multi-hospital academic center’s innovative surgical boot camp that used group learning and reflective practices to engage interns in a socially-distant manner while improving clinical skills, knowledge and confidence.  

Methods:  To maintain the value of in-person experiential learning in spite of distancing requirements and subsequent resource constraints, a team of surgical educators and simulation experts re-engineered boot camp to optimize individual learner impact through group learning and reflective practice. Interns from six specialties were divided across six sites arranged to minimize physical contact. Brief lectures were delivered via Zoom Meetings for content consistency. Faculty received proctor guides to facilitate group simulations, with pre- and post-briefings for individual engagement. Attendees completed a multiple choice and free response survey assessing the effectiveness of boot camp across multiple domains. Faculty feedback was also elicited. Free text evaluations were analyzed with a constructivist grounded theory approach as described by Mills et al., 2006.

Results: Of 39 boot camp participants, 22 completed a survey (56% response rate). 82% of surveyees agreed or strongly agreed the modified training expanded their ability to apply theory or knowledge to their current level of practice. 73% agreed or strongly agreed it provided practical experience appropriate for their work duties. Qualitative analysis affirmed that group simulations were instructive, briefings allowed for individualized feedback in spite of activities being team-based, and an emphasis on systematic care approaches increased attendees’ confidence. 12 of 20 faculty provided feedback (60% response rate) which supported the use of small groups and reflective teaching to reinforce key principals and increase learner interest.

Conclusion: This analysis supports the feasibility of teaching crucial technical and non-technical skills in COVID-compliant conditions while facilitating learner engagement with positive results. Follow-up studies will assess long-term impacts of boot camp and further evaluate effects of group learning and reflective practices. This study suggests that these methodologies enable quality surgical education in the setting of limited social interactions and physical resources, which is imperative in light of COVID-19 resurgences.

abstract_title: Evaluation of the Accessibility and Content of Urology Residency Websites
author_block: A. P. Nocera<sup>1</sup>, H. Boudreau<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Boyd<sup>1</sup>, K. D. Martin<sup>2</sup>, S. Rais-Bahrami<sup>3,4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Epidemiology,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Urology,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Radiology,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,O'Neal Comprehensive Cancer Center,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Students applying for urology residency often have limited resources for obtaining information on prospective programs. Applicants commonly rely on institutional websites to compare and contrast program elements. The information on these websites can attract or deter applicants and can have a major impact on their application costs, rank lists, and career goals. The objective of this study was to determine the accessibility and content of urology residency program websites.

Methods:  A list of accredited urology residency programs was obtained from the American Urological Association residency directory. A total of 141 program websites were evaluated for the presence of 53 criteria, which were categorized into 5 groups: personnel information, applicant information, program information, training/research, and resident benefits. Residencies lacking an available website or functional links were excluded from the study.

Results: Of the 53 criteria analyzed, only 24 were featured on more than 50% of the websites. Less than 10% of the programs had available information regarding resident contact information (5.67%), alumni contact information (2.84%), frequently asked questions (9.22%), electives (9.93%), night float (5.67%), and board pass rates (5.67%). The 3 factors most commonly available included program description (100%), coordinator contact information (88.65%), and clinical sites (87.94%). None of the 141 programs had all 53 criteria available on their website.

Conclusion: The majority of current urology residency websites may lack the accessibility and content necessary for candidates to make application decisions for desired programs. Residency programs should consider revising their websites to enhance resident recruitment and facilitate applicants’ decision-making process.

abstract_title: Immune Profiling of Colitis Associated Cancer in vitro Co-Cultures with Single Cell RNA-Sequencing
author_block: R. K. DeHaan<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Sarvestani<sup>2</sup>, E. H. Huang<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Cleveland Clinic Foundation,Department Of Colorectal Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Cleveland Clinic Foundation,Lerner Research Institute,Clevealnd, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colitis-associated cancer (CAC) is a feared consequence of ulcerative colitis. The inflammatory microenvironment, especially the stromal fibroblasts, is associated with increased development of neoplasia. Further, even in the absence of histological neoplasia, transcriptional inflammatory and neoplastic signatures exist. Patient-derived epithelial organoids and fibroblasts, with high-resolution single cell analysis, permit unprecedented dissection of transcriptional expression. Single cell nuclear analysis was used to discriminate cell identity and individual cell transcriptional expression. We hypothesize that co-cultures of CAC epithelial organoids with cancer associated fibroblasts (CAFs) will have a richer immune profile when compared to co-cultures of CAC epithelial organoids and proximal, histologically normal fibroblast.

Methods: Matched patient derived epithelial organoids were co-cultured with fibroblasts from an area of CAC, or with an area of proximal colon that was histologically normal. Single-nucleus RNA-sequencing (sn-RNA-Seq) was performed (10x Genomics). Data analysis was performed in R utilizing the Seurat package for clustering and differential expression analysis.  Epithelial cells were removed from the analysis through gene filtering. Dimensionality reduction was performed using Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection. Differential expression testing was performed using a Wilcoxon rank-sum test with correction for multiple comparisons.

Results: Integrated analysis of the two co-culture conditions generated 8 distinct cell clusters, one of which was unique to the proximal fibroblast co-culture condition. Both groups show broad transcription of IL-24, as has been previously shown in patients with ulcerative colitis, along with IL-11, a cytokine with both anti-inflammatory and pro-tumorigenic roles. The cancer fibroblast co-culture transcriptional profile contains a unique inflammatory profile including IL6, IL33, CCL3 and CCL5, which have been shown to play key roles in tumor immune evasion and trafficking of immune cell-types including tumor-associated macrophages (Figure 1).

Conclusion: We demonstrate that in vitro modeling of colitis-associated cancer epithelia with matched normal colon and CAC stromal fibroblasts allows for the generation of a phenotype specific immune signature. Consistent with the underlying ulcerative colitis phenotype of both co-culture conditions, we see strong transcription of the anti-inflammatory IL-24 and IL-11. Despite the presence of only fibroblast and cancer epithelia, our in vitro model showed a distinct immune phenotype when CAFs were co-cultured with cancer organoids.

abstract_title: Angiogenin Regulates Tumor Growth via PKD and COX-2 in a Mouse Model of Colitis-Associated Cancer
author_block: J. Luo<sup>1</sup>, T. Liu<sup>1</sup>, J. Yoo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The myofibroblast is a gastrointestinal stroma cell that regulates epithelial proliferation, mucosal repair, and fibrosis through paracrine signaling, and has been implicated in the pathophysiology of colitis-associated cancer.  The myofibroblast is the predominant nonmalignant stromal cell of the tumor microenvironment and a major reservoir of cyclo-oxygenase-2 (COX-2), the rate-limiting enzyme in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxanes, that is inducibly expressed in the setting of colitis.  Angiogenin, a secreted 14-kDa member of the ribonuclease superfamily, enhances cell growth and survival.  We have recently reported that angiogenin regulates pro-inflammatory mediator signaling within the myofibroblast, directly regulating COX-2 production via protein kinase D signaling.  However, the physiologic impact of angiogenin signaling within the myofibroblast on colitis-associated cancer has not been previously studied. 

Methods: Angiogenin knock-out (ANG-KO) C57BL/6 mice (n=8), a whole-body homozygous knockout strain, along with wild-type mice (n=8) were given azoxymethane (AOM, 5mg/kg I.P.), a colon carcinogen, 2 days in advance of three cycles of 3% dextran sodium sulfate (DSS).  Each cycle consisted of 5 days of 3% DSS in the drinking water, followed by 16 days of regular water.  This AOM-DSS colitis model leads to predictable and reproducible dysplasia/cancer.  Disease activity index (DAI) was recorded during the “colitis” phase of each cycle.  A colonoscopy was performed 1 week after each DSS treatment, and mice were euthanized 1 week after the 3rd DSS cycle.  Gross pathology was analyzed. 

Results: Of the 16 mice, 1 ANG-KO mouse died during AOM-DSS treatment.  Of the remaining mice, there were no differences between WT and ANG-KO C57BL/6 mice in terms of disease activity index (weight loss, stool consistency, rectal bleeding) or colon length following AOM-DSS treatment.  ANG-KO mice developed significantly fewer and smaller tumors compared to WT mice.  In 7 ANG-KO mice only 3 distal tumors formed (0.4 tumors/mice) and all were <2mm in diameter.  In comparison, 23 tumors formed in 8 WT mice (2.8 tumors/mouse). 11 tumors were >2mm and 12 were <2mm in diameter.  13 of the 23 tumors that formed in WT mice were in the mid-colon. 

Conclusion: In a mouse model of colitis-associated cancer, AOM-DSS treatment leads to significantly diminished tumor growth in ANG-KO mice with no apparent impact on the severity of colitis.  These results suggest that targeting stroma-mediated COX-2 expression via angiogenin may be a novel therapeutic approach for the treatment of colitis-associated cancer.

abstract_title: Novel Percutaneous Access to Large Intestine for Endolumenal Therapy: Preclinical Trial
author_block: S. Urakawa<sup>1</sup>, T. Hirashita<sup>1</sup>, Y. Hirashita<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Milsom<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Weill Cornell Medicine / New York Presbyterian Hospital,Department Of Surgery, Section Of Colon & Rectal Surgery,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Endolumenal therapies in cardiac and vascular surgery have led to improved outcomes and excellent safety profiles compared to open or laparoscopic methods, and percutaneous access (PA) to the upper GI tract has gained popularity for tube placement and excision of superficial mucosal lesions.  We explored the hypothesis that PA to the large intestine may expedite complex endolumenal therapy, improve safety, and access sites can be reliably closed.

Methods:   Using a 3D ex-vivo model with a porcine colorectum and abdominal wall, we secured the intestine to the abdominal wall with T-bar (gastrointestinal anchor set, HALYARD) and created 8Fr and 10 Fr holes under an endoscopic visualization (PCF-H180AL, OLYMPUS).  We closed puncture sites with endoscopic clips (EZ clips, OLYMPUS) in two ways; (1) closing only puncture sites: P group and (2) closing both puncture sites and T-bars: PT group, and measured the leak pressures.   Next, 3 cm mucosal “lesions” were created at the posterior and lateral walls of the cecum. We performed an endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) with a 5 mm margin in three ways; (1) using a standard technique with ESD knife (DualKnife, OLYMPUS): STD group, (2) using percutaneous access (PA) with laparoscopic grasper (Gimmi, 2.8 mm, Germany) through 8 Fr sheath and ESD knife: PA with G group, and (3) using percutaneous access with laparoscopic grasper and electrocautery through 8 Fr sheaths (PA with GE group).  We evaluated the procedural outcomes of these groups.  

Results:   Of 20 trials (10 in each group), the P group had significantly shorter closing time than the PT group (3.2 vs 7.6 min, P < 0.001), and required less number of clips (3.8 vs 7.2, P < 0.001). Only one case in the PT group had the air leakage from 10 Fr hole (leak pressure: 44 mmHg).  There was no leakage up to 60 mmHg in other cases.    Next, a total of 46 lesions were removed successfully.  There was no perforation in all procedures.  PA with G and PA with GE groups had significantly shorter total procedure time, faster dissection speeds, and fewer muscular injuries than the STD group.  Moreover, the dissection speed of the PA with GE group was significantly faster than the PA with G group (Table).  Regarding the PA with GE group, there were no differences in procedural outcomes between posterior and lateral wall lesions.  

Conclusion:    In an ex vivo porcine colon model, complex endolumenal procedures (ESD of large “polyp”) appear to be greatly expedited with fewer colon wall injuries using percutaneously inserted tools.  The PA sites appear to be able to be reliably closed endoscopically.  Future development of PA along with endolumenal therapies of the colon in vivo appears to be warranted.

abstract_title: Replication of Genetic Associations with Diverticular Disease in a Large Clinical Population
author_block: H. D. Schaeffer<sup>1</sup>, D. Smelser<sup>2</sup>, J. Dove<sup>2</sup>, K. C. Long<sup>1</sup>, C. Buzas<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Carey<sup>2</sup>, R. L. Hoffman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Medical Center,Surgery Institute,Danville, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Geisinger Medical Center,Department Of Molecular And Functional Genomics,Danville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While there has been significant evidence for an inherited component to diverticular disease, the specific genes associated with the disease remains elusive. To date, there have been three genome wide association studies (GWAS), all of which have originated outside of the United States, which have suggested possible genetic candidates. Using the DiscovEHR MyCode biobank, the aim of this study was to replicate the findings of prior genome-wide association studies in a US population.

Methods: The DiscovEHR project has created a database of whole exome sequences linked to clinical EHR data from patients in the Geisinger health system who consented to participate in the MyCode Community Health biobanking program. This analysis included all non-Hispanic White patients with existing exome sequence data who were >18 years of age. Diverticular disease cases were identified by querying the EHR database for relevant ICD-9/10 diagnostic codes. Controls were defined as individuals with no recorded history of diverticular disease. Additional clinicopathologic and demographic information was obtained from the EHR database. In selected patients open chart reviews were also conducted to confirm the phenotype. Rare coding variants (minor allele frequency <.0001) were identified from whole exome sequence data in the ARHGAP15, COLQ, FAM155A, ABO and ANO1 genes, which has been identified in previous genome wide association studies. The prevalence of rare variants in the diverticular patients was compared to the variants in the control population using a chi-square and Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel analysis.

Results: The study population consisted of 135,841 MyCode participants with exome sequence data. The mean age was 57.3 years (SD 18.1), and 61.0% of patients were female. There were 16,358 (12.0%) patients identified with diverticular disease, and 119,483 controls. Study participants with diverticular disease were significantly more likely to be male (43.6%), be former or current smokers (57.9%) and to consume alcohol (61.8%) compared to controls (38.4%, 54% and 60.6%, respectively). Cases were older than controls (mean of 70.9 years compared to 55.7). Median BMI did not differ between cases and controls (31.2 compared to 31.5). Rare variants were identified in each of the target genes; these were observed in 46 diverticular disease patients and in 93 controls (p<.0001, OR and 95% CI: 3.5 (2.25-5.0)).

Conclusion: This analysis replicates previously reported genetic associations with diverticular disease, lending increased evidence to the genetic underpinnings of a common, and often, very morbid disease. Initial follow-up analyses have further identified rare coding variants which may be causal for the association. Future studies are ongoing which may enable us to identify patients who are at most risk for development of more serious forms of disease, and therefore, allow the development or application of novel treatment strategies.

abstract_title: Cystathionine-γ-Lyase (CSE) Activity is Required for TNFα Signaling in Colonic Epithelial Cells
author_block: F. Arroyo Almenas<sup>1</sup>, E. Higgins<sup>1</sup>, K. Modis<sup>1</sup>, M. Hellmich<sup>1</sup>, C. Chao<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch,Surgery,Galveston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Tumor necrosis factor α (TNFα) is a cytokine that regulates inflammation and tissue repair in colitis. In previous studies, patients with ulcerative colitis have lower expression of the transsulfuration pathway enzyme CSE in the colonic mucosa compared to non-UC colons, suggesting that CSE activity may limit the inflammatory process. TNFα signals through the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and the nuclear factor kappa β (NFkB) pathways. The aim of this study was to determine if there is a relationship between CSE and TNFα signaling in human colonic epithelial cells (HCEC).

Methods: The HCEC is a diploid epithelial cell line derived from non-malignant colonic tissue; it has been immortalized with ectopic expression of cyclin-dependent kinase 4 and human telomerase reverse transcriptase. TNFα (1 or 10ng/ml) was used as an inflammatory stimulus.MAPK was inhibited by one hr pretreatment with either the p38 inhibitor (SB 203580, 10uM) or ERK inhibitor (PD 98059, 30 uM). CSE activity was inhibited by pretreating for one hr with beta-cyano-alanine (BCA 3.0 mM). To assess cell migration, cells were seeded in transwells and allowed to migrate toward % calf serum over time; cells were then stained and quantified. Immunoblots were assessed with primary antibodies to the activated forms of MAPK: pERK, pp38. Nuclear translocation of the p65 subunit of NFkB was assessed by immunocytochemistry.

Results:HCECs treated with TNFα showed a significant increase in migration at 16 hrs compared to vehicle (p<0.0001). Pretreatment with either MAPK inhibitors or CSE inhibitor BCA significantly decreased both basal cell migration (p<0.0001) and TNFα-stimulated migration (p<0.0001). TNFα activated both pERK and pp38 in HCEC at 30 min by immunoblot (both p<0.0001 compared to vehicle treated); pretreatment with BCA decreased TNFα-stimulated pERK (p<0.01) but not p38. TNFα significantly increased nuclear translocation of p65 NFkB compared to vehicle (p<0.0001). BCA pretreatment inhibited TNFα-stimulated nuclear translocation of p65 NFkB (p<0.0001).

Conclusion:TNFα stimulates migration of HCECs and activates the MAPK and NFkB pathways.  CSE is necessary for TNFα-stimulated migration of HCECs and its actions are mediated through pERK but not p38. CSE is also required for TNFα stimulated nuclear translocation of the p65 subunit of NFkB. Taken together, our data in this in vitro model of colonic epithelial cells demonstrates that TNFα mediated inflammatory processes are attenuated by CSE through both the MAPK and NFkB pathways.

abstract_title: Transcriptomic Analysis of Cancer Stem Cell Surface Markers in Colorectal Cancer
author_block: J. Huang<sup>1</sup>, M. Oshi<sup>1</sup>, K. Takabe<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Roswell Park Cancer Institute,Surgical Oncology,Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colon cancer stem cells (CSC) have been shown to be involved with tumor formation, chemotherapy resistance, and the progression of metastatic disease. Putative CSCs include cell surface markers CD133, CD24, and CD44.  The clinical relevance of CSCs are mostly based on institutional studies. Using a bioinformatics approach, we hypothesize that a combination of these CSC markers has prognostic value in a large cohort of patients with colorectal cancer. 

Methods: Clinicopathologic and gene set transcriptional data were collected from a cohort of 594 patients with colorectal cancer from The Cancer Genome Atlas. The expression of CD133, CD24, and CD44 was individually defined as “high” or “low” based on the median expression as demonstrated in the literature. The R software was used to perform statistical analyses and survival curves using Kaplan-Meier method with log-rank test. Gene Set Enrichment analysis (GSEA) was performed on hallmark genes pathways important in cancer development and progression. 

Results: Disease specific survival (DSS) and overall survival (OS) were not associated with tumors that are CD133-high or CD44-high alone. Patients with CD24-high tumors have significantly better DSS (p<0.001) and OS (p=0.04). CD24-high, CD44-high and CD133-high tumors were associated with significantly greater EGFR, KRAS and Ki67 expression (p<0.001). CD133-high tumors are not associated with conventional signaling pathways in preservation of stemness, such as NOTCH and Hedgehog signaling pathways. However, CD24 and CD44-high tumors are enriched for NOTCH signaling pathway (p=0.03). In the analysis of a combination of CSCs, there was no survival difference linked to patients with CD133-high/CD44-low tumors. Patients with CD44-high/CD24-low tumors have worse DSS (p=0.005) but no difference in OS compared to patients with CD44-low/CD24-high tumors. No specific gene sets associated with the hallmarks of cancer were significantly enriched in this group. Tumors that are CD133-high/CD24-low show significant negative enrichment of MYC targets (p<0.002), E2F targets (p= 0.03), and G2M checkpoint pathways (p= 0.04), suggesting lower proliferation in these tumors. Patients with CD133-high/CD24-low tumors have worse DSS (p = 0.004) and OS (p = 0.04), after a 10-year follow up, and are more likely to have early and late recurrences. 

Conclusion: This study uses bioinformatics data to suggest the clinical relevance of putative colon cancer stem cell markers, and demonstrates that CD133-high/CD24-low tumors may be prognostic.

abstract_title: Anti-Proliferative Effects of Carfilzomib on Human HT-29 Adenocarcinoma Colon Cancer Cells
author_block: A. NGUYEN<sup>2</sup>, M. CHATURVEDI<sup>3</sup>, H. T. NGUYEN<sup>2</sup>, L. S. CHATURVEDI<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>CALIFORNIA NORTHSTATE UNIVERSITY,MEDICINE,ELK GROVE, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>2</sup>CALIFORNIA NORTHSTATE UNIVERSITY,PHARMACY,ELK GROVE, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>UNIVERSITY OF NORTH DAKOTA,MEDICINE,GRANK FORKS, NORTH DAKOTA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer worldwide and a leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States. Surgery, Chemotherapy, and radiation are the most interventions to treat patients. However, these patients have a high risk of recurrence. It is important to investigate other novel agents that can be used alone or in combination with other treatments to increase efficacy and reduce the progression of colorectal tumors. Carfilzomib (CFZ), The second-generation irreversible proteasome inhibitor (PI) has been clinically shown to be effective for hematological cancers. CFZ is the 2nd PI to be approved by the FDA as a 3rd line treatment for multiple myeloma. However, the role of proteasome inhibition as anti-tumorigenic potential and molecular mechanism has not been fully investigated in the solid tumors such as colon cancer. The present study investigated and compared the anti-proliferative and cytotoxic effects of second-generation irreversible proteasome inhibitor CFZ alone and in a combination well known chemotherapeutic drugs doxorubicin (DOX) and elucidate potential molecular targets on human colon HT-29 cells.

Methods: HT-29 cells were cultured in McCoy's 5A medium with FBS at 37C with humidified conditions. Cells were treated with various concentrations of CFZ (0-500nM) or DOX (0-1.5µM) or a combination of both for 24 and 72 hours to access cell viability using a Cell Counting (CCK-8) Kit. Total RNA was extracted using GenEluteTM Universal kit and concentration and quality were measured using Nanodrop. High-Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit with RNAse inhibitor used to convert total RNA to cDNA. Genes involved in cell cycle regulation and signaling pathways were analyzed by quantitative-RT-PCR and relative expression performed using the delta-delta Ct method, also known as the 2–??Ct method. RPLP0 (Ribosomal Protein Lateral Stalk Subunit P0) was used as a housekeeping gene.

Results: CFZ and DOX significantly inhibit cell proliferation in a dose-dependent manner in HT-29 cells at 72 hours of the treatment. However, CFZ is more potent than DOX. Furthermore, a combination of CFZ with DOX found to no have any further effect on the rate of growth inhibition. CFZ, DOX, and a combination of both down-regulate Cyclin E1, CDK4, and AKT1 gene Expression. Furthermore, only CFZ alone down-regulate the E2F1 transcription factor while DOX and a combination of both do not change the expression of the E2F1 transcription factor.

Conclusion: CFZ inhibits proliferation by down-regulate the expression of Cyclin E1, CDK4, and AKT1 genes and the E2F1 transcription factor. Our data suggest second-generation PI CFZ might have therapeutic potential as an anti-cancer drug for colorectal cancer patients.

abstract_title: Does The Hypoxia Correlate With Anastomotic Healing? A Pilot Study
author_block: S. Makanyengo<sup>1,2,4</sup>, B. Goggins<sup>2,4</sup>, S. Smith<sup>1,3</sup>, P. Pockney<sup>1,3</sup>, S. Keely<sup>2,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>John Hunter Hospital,Surgery,Newcastle, NSW, Australia <sup>2</sup>University of Newcastle,School Of Biomedical Sciences And Pharmacy,Newcastle, NSW, Australia <sup>3</sup>University of Newcastle,School Of Medicine And Public Health,Newcastle, NSW, Australia <sup>4</sup>Hunter Medical Research Institute,Gastrointestinal Research Group,Newcastle, NSW, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anastomotic leaks (AL) are a major complication following gastrointestinal surgery that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Despite decades of improvements in surgical techniques and patient care, leak rates (1-24%) have not improved. Tissue hypoxia has been shown to increase anastomotic complications. However, it is unclear if hypoxia is the most important determinant of anastomotic healing outcomes as healing has been shown to occur when intraluminal antibiotics are administered. We hypothesised that hypoxia would alter the gut microbial profile in a manner that would influence anastomotic healing outcomes and therefore a correlation between hypoxia and healing outcomes would be seen. We performed a pilot study to develop a mouse model to investigate this hypothesis.

Methods: The study consisted of two groups: resection and anastomosis (R&A) (n=23) and control (n=9); Controls underwent a laparotomy without bowel resection. Throughout the study, optimisation of surgical technique and mouse recovery were undertaken to establish model consistency. These included optimising the suture number, preservation of local blood supply, as well as establishing methods of administering analgesia. The mice were sacrificed at day 3 and day 7 after surgery. Pimonidazole was administered to the mice one hour prior to sacrifice. Anastomotic healing was assessed and scored at time of sacrifice and isolated tissue samples were examined histologically by a pathologist blinded to the groups. Massons trichrome stain was used to quantify collagen deposition. Immunohistochemical staining was performed on anastomotic tissue to determine the quantity of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) as a measure of neoangiogenesis, hypoxia (Pimonidazole) and cellular proliferation (Ki67). Halo analysis was used determine the H-score for each stain. Statistical analysis was performed on graph pad prism v7 and the spearman correlation test was performed to determine the relationship between these parameters.

Results: Significant correlations were noted between the extent of hypoxia and VEGF (r = 0.6093, p = 0.0007) as well as hypoxia and Ki67 (r = 0.6452, p = 0.0007). Also, a significant correlation exists between VEGF and Ki67 (r = 0.6725, p = 0.0002). No correlation was noted between the extent of hypoxia and collagen deposition, infiltration of inflammatory cells, anastomotic healing and the development of anastomotic leaks.

Conclusion: These findings further re-inforce findings in other pre-clinical trials that have shown that no correlation exists between hypoxia and the development of anastomotic leaks. This is surprising considering that a significant correlation that exists between hypoxia and neoangiogenesis as well as cellular proliferation. This suggests that other factors are at play which affect anastomotic healing outcomes. Further studies are needed to determine to what extent factors such as gut microbiota influence these outcomes.

abstract_title: Color-coded Labeling of Colon-cancer Liver Metastasis and Liver Segment in Orthotopic Mouse Model
author_block: H. Nishino<sup>1,2,3,4</sup>, H. M. Hollandsworth<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Amirfakhri<sup>1,2</sup>, F. Filemoni<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Turner<sup>1,2</sup>, T. M. Lwin<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Yamamoto<sup>1,3</sup>, Y. Tashiro<sup>1,3</sup>, N. Sugisawa<sup>1,3</sup>, B. B. Singer<sup>5</sup>, R. M. Hoffman<sup>1,3</sup>, M. Bouvet<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego,Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>VA San Diego Healthcare System,Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>AntiCancer, Inc.,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>Graduate School of Medicine, Kyoto University,Surgery,Kyoto, Japan <sup>5</sup>Medical Faculty, University of Duisburg-Essen,Institute Of Anatomy,Essen, Germany
abstract_body:
Introduction: During resection of primary liver cancer or liver metastases, it is difficult to distinguish between the tumor and its liver segment with traditional use of indocyanine green (ICG) alone. ICG labeling has been shown to be helpful for definition of liver tumors or liver segments but does not provide clear demarcation between tumor and the corresponding liver segment. In the present study, a spectrally-distinct fluorescently-labeled tumor-specific antibody against human carcinoembryonic antigen-related cell-adhesion molecules (CEACAMs) was used in combination with ICG for color-coded visualization of colon-cancer liver metastases and the corresponding liver segment in an orthotopic mouse model.

Methods: Anti-CEACAM monoclonal antibody (mAb 6G5j) was conjugated to near-infrared dye IR700DX (6G5j-IR700DX) with a fluorescence peak of 700 nm, which is sufficiently spectrally distinct from ICG with a fluorescence peak of 800 nm. Nude mice (n=10) received sutureless surgical orthotopic implantation of colon-cancer liver metastases derived from a patient. After three weeks, mice were administered 50 μg 6G5j-IR700DX via tail vein injection 48 hours before surgery. 10 μg ICG was intravenously injected after ligation of the left or left lateral Glissonean pedicle under magnification with a MVX10 microscope (Olympus), resulting in labeling of the segment with preserved blood flow in the liver. Intra-vital imaging of tumor and liver was performed with the Pearl Trilogy Small Animal Fluorescence Imaging system (LI-COR) and FLARE Imaging System (Curadel).

Results: On the 700 nm channel, the tumor had a clear fluorescence signal due to selective tumor targeting of 6G5j-IR700DX (Image A). On the 800 nm channel, the liver segment with preserved blood flow in the liver had a clear fluorescence ICG signal, while the left or left lateral segment had no fluorescence signal (Image B). Overlay of the images showed clear differentiation between the tumor and the liver segment.

Conclusion: Color-coded imaging of primary and metastatic hepatic tumors and the corresponding liver segment may improve the outcomes of anatomic resection due to clear distinction of tumor margins and distinct visualization of pertinent liver segments.

abstract_title: HOTAIR-Loaded MSC EVs Increase Revascularization in an In Vivo Excisional Wound Healing Model
author_block: L. J. Born<sup>1</sup>, K. Chang<sup>2</sup>, F. Lay<sup>2</sup>, P. Shoureshi<sup>2</sup>, J. W. Harmon<sup>2</sup>, S. M. Jay<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Maryland,Fischell Department Of Bioengineering,College Park, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery, Hendrix Burn And Healing Lab,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Despite the development of a variety of therapies, complex wounds resulting from disease, surgical intervention, or trauma remain a major source of morbidity. Extracellular vesicles (EVs) derived from mesenchymal stem/stromal cells (MSCs) have been shown to improve wound healing, especially via enhanced wound angiogenesis. However, despite their clearly established potential, EVs have limitations that may limit clinical relevancy, such as low potency. We hypothesized that increased content of pro-angiogenic lncRNA HOTAIR within MSC EVs enhances their pro-angiogenic effects and thus their wound healing properties.

Methods:  LncRNA HOTAIR was loaded into MSC EVs by delivering a CMV-based HOTAIR plasmid to MSCs for endogenous loading via a concentration gradient. EVs were collected by differential centrifugation. HOTAIR content within EVs was confirmed by gel electrophoresis and RT-qPCR. Effects on migration of HDMECs by HOTAIR-loaded MSC EVs were determined using an in vitro scratch assay. Revascularization of healed tissue by HOTAIR-loaded MSC EVs was quantified in a 12mm circular excisional wound healing model administered on the dorsum of Sprague-Dawley rats. Wounds were created on day 0. Treatments were administered intradermally on day 3 and included a PBS negative control, plasmid backbone MSC EVs as negative control, unaltered MSC EVs as a control, and HOTAIR-loaded MSC EVs. Healed tissue was harvested on day 21. H&E histology and CD31 immunohistochemistry was performed to quantify the amount of new blood vessels within the healed tissue.

Results: HOTAIR was visually confirmed in HOTAIR-loaded MSC EVs by gel electrophoresis, but was undetectable in unmodified MSC EVs. RT-qPCR confirmed a 900-fold increase of HOTAIR compared to control MSC EVs. HDMECs showed a more statistically significant rate of gap closure when treated with HOTAIR-loaded EVs (p<0.01) than compared to unaltered MSC EVs (p<0.05) compared to basal media. Total vessels originating from the dermis was increased in the HOTAIR-loaded MSC EVs compared to PBS (p<0.05). There was no statistically significant difference between plasmid control MSC EVs or unaltered MSC EVs compared to PBS.

Conclusion: Loading lncRNA HOTAIR into MSC EVs is achievable by a concentration gradient-dependent method and offers potential to enhance the angiogenic properties of MSC EVs. The enhanced angiogenic properties of these EVs may be beneficial in healing chronic wounds and increase survival of skin flap.
