abstract_title: Prevention of Scarring by Compounds Modulating Circadian Gene
author_block: Y. Roca<sup>1</sup>, Y. Shibuya<sup>1</sup>, A. Clements<sup>1</sup>, I. Nishimura<sup>2</sup>, R. Jarrahy<sup>1</sup>, A. Hokugo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA,Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>UCLA School of Dentistry,Weintraub Center For Reconstructive Biotechnology,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Abnormal collagen biosynthesis and deposition can result in hypertrophic scar (HTS) formation. HTS demonstrate increased collagen biosynthesis compared to normal scar (Craig et al., 1975) and overexpression of collagen I and III (Wong et al., 2014). The circadian rhythm helps to maintain physiological homeostasis and disruption of the circadian rhythm can lead to impaired wound healing (Sapahi et al., 2014). Neuronal PAS domain 2 (Npas2), a core circadian clock gene, is expressed in dermal fibroblasts (Landgraf et al., 2016) and has been shown to play a critical role in regulating collagen synthesis. (Sasaki et al., 2019). Previous studies showed Npas2 knockout mice demonstrated faster dermal wound closure suggesting that Npas2 can be a novel therapeutic target for pathological scarring and wound healing. (Sasaki et al., 2019). We have performed high throughput drug screening using mouse dermal fibroblasts with Npas2-lacZ reporter system and identified 5 FDA-approved hit compounds (Dwn1, Dwn2, Dwn3, Dwn4, and Dwn5) that suppress Npas2 expression in fibroblasts. We hypothesized that the therapeutic suppression of Npas2 by hit compounds will result in collagen synthesis downregulation and reduced collagen-related gene expression.

Methods:  Collagen synthesis and collagen-related gene expression in clonal and primary human fibroblasts was compared between 5 groups treated with 5 compounds at 0, 0.1, 1, and 10 µM. Fibroblast behaviors were characterized by quantitative RT-PCR (qPCR) for collagen-related genes and in vitro collagen accumulation was evaluated by Picrosirius red staining. The statistical analysis was performed by one-way ANOVA and Dunnett's test.

Results: In clonal human dermal fibroblast, Dwn1 was found to have no significant effect on collagen deposition but interestingly, collagen type I and III gene expression was decreased. Dwn2 was discovered to simultaneously suppress collagen type III expression and increase collagen deposition in vitro. Dwn3 and Dwn4 had no effect in collagen deposition or gene expression. Dwn5 exhibited a tendency of increased collagen deposition and collagen type I down-regulation but no significant differences were observed. Additionally, some of the compounds significantly down-regulated collagen synthesis in primary human dermal fibroblasts.

Conclusion: Our study demonstrated that Npas2 suppression in human dermal fibroblasts by some compounds modified cell behaviors resulting in changes in collagen deposition and collagen-related gene expression. This study suggests that Dwn1, and Dwn2 may be novel therapeutic agents for promoting collagen homeostasis and accelerated wound healing with minimal hypertrophic scarring.

abstract_title: Low Intracellular pH is Associated with T cell Activation and Clonal anti-tumor Response
author_block: A. Shadaloey<sup>1</sup>, J. Leinwand<sup>1</sup>, J. Vlahos<sup>1</sup>, G. Miller<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>New York University School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intracellular pH (pHi) is tightly regulated, but different metabolic programs characterize specific T cell phenotypes. We hypothesized that pHi is modulated by T cell receptor (TCR) ligation and corresponds with anti-tumor immunity.

Methods: Intracellular pH-sensitive dye was used to measure pHi in combination with surface markers by flow cytometry. T cells were activated in vitro via anti-CD3/28 antibodies or antigen-restricted ovalbumin peptide. pHi was modulated with 2-(6-chloro-1H-benzimidazol-2-yl)guanidine (Cl-GBI) and/or amiloride. Murine pancreatic tumors were injected orthotopically and harvested at 3 weeks. TCR sequences were obtained from genomic DNA.

Results: We found a distinct low-pHi T cell population in activated mouse and human T cells, with a smaller population among murine splenic T cells, but none in mouse or human peripheral blood T cells. pHi was independent of extracellular pH. Intratumoral T cells exhibited a large low-pHi population compared with other organs. Antigen-restricted tumor-infiltrating or splenic T cells from tumor-bearing mice exhibited a larger low-pHi population compared with control T cells (Figure), as did Nur77-expressing T cells in both compartments. Low-pHi intratumoral T cells had decreased TCR diversity compared with controls, suggesting a clonal anti-tumor response. Low-pHi T cells exhibited higher surface activation markers (CD44, CD69, LFA-1, PD-1) and intracellular free Ca2+ compared with controls. These differences increased with in vitro activation. Low-pHi T cells also expressed higher surface Hv1, a voltage-gated channel that allows H+ transport across the cell membrane. Hv1 blockade with Cl-GBI diminished low-pHi populations in both naïve and activated T cells in a time- and concentration-dependent manner. These differences persisted in Na+-free media or in combination with the Na+-H+ exchanger inhibitor amiloride.

Conclusion: T cell activation, TCR ligation, and anti-tumor immunity are associated with low pHi. The critical role of pH in homeostasis suggests that pHi may mediate T cell phenotype. The role of H+ flux in T cell activation requires further study.

abstract_title: SETDB2 Regulates Diabetic Macrophage-Mediated Inflammation in COVID-19
author_block: W. J. Melvin<sup>1</sup>, C. Audu<sup>1</sup>, A. Joshi<sup>1</sup>, F. Davis<sup>1</sup>, E. Barrett<sup>1</sup>, K. Mangum<sup>1</sup>, A. Obi<sup>1</sup>, B. Moore<sup>2</sup>, K. Gallagher<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Pulmonary/Critical Care,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Patients with diabetes have worse outcomes from COVID-19, possibly due to an increased cytokine storm; however the mechanisms underlying these changes remain unclear. Our recent work has identified that SETDB2 is an epigenetic enzyme that is downregulated in diabetic macrophages (Mφs) and may regulate inflammatory cytokine expression. We hypothesize that in diabetes exposure to coronavirus displays an increased Mφ-mediated inflammatory response due to decreased SETDB2 in diabetic Mφs.

Methods:  Bone marrow derived Mφs (BMDMs) and splenic Mφs were sorted from C57BL/6 wild type mice and two murine models of diabetes, db/db and DIO mice. Cells were infected with an established murine coronavirus model, MHV, at MOI of 0.5 and subsequent expression of TNFα, IL-1β, and SETDB2 were analyzed by quantitative PCR. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) was performed to evaluate H3K9me3, a repressive mark set by SETDB2 on the promotors of TNFα and IL-1b. Cells from mice with Mφs lacking SETDB2 (SETDB2f/fLyZCre+) were also isolated from BMDMs and infected as described above. Further, human monocyte derived Mφs were exposed to serum from critically ill adult male patients infected with confirmed SARS-CoV-2 for 24 hours. Subsequent expression of SETDB2 was analyzed by quantitative PCR.

Results: DIO and db/db BMDMs and in vivo splenic Mφs exposed to MHV displayed increased expression of IL-1β and TNFα compared to nondiabetic controls at 24 hours post infection. Further, ChIP demonstrated decreased H3K9me3 at the promoter of IL-1β and TNFα. In mice lacking expression of SETDB2 in Mφs, expression of IL-1β and TNFα, and IL-6 was significantly higher in response to infection with MHV. Finally, human MφMs exposed to serum from critically ill patients infected with SARS-CoV-2 demonstrated decreased expression of SETDB2.

Conclusion: SETDB2 appears to regulate inflammatory cytokine expression in Mφs exposed to coronavirus.

abstract_title: No Difference in Circulating Tumor Cells in Filtered, Salvaged Blood in Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma
author_block: A. S. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, N. Goel<sup>2</sup>, W. Kwon<sup>1</sup>, K. Sughahara<sup>1</sup>, B. Schrope<sup>1</sup>, J. Chabot<sup>1</sup>, M. D. Kluger<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Columbia University Irving Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami,Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Department Of Surgery,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Allogeneic transfusions are expensive and have been shown to increase perioperative morbidity and mortality, and decrease recurrence-free and overall survival. Operative blood loss can be cell-salvaged for immediate transfusion by recovery devices. Despite transfusion rates during pancreatic surgery as high as 75%, these devices are not used during pancreatic cancer surgery due to a belief that this will seed distant metastases. Though intuitively reasonable, this belief is belied by our modern understanding of metastasis biology. This study is the first to compare PDAC CTCs in the systemic circulation prior to surgery, at the time of surgery, and in cell-salvaged filtered blood collected to evaluate whether recovered blood contains a greater concentration of CTCs.

Methods: We conducted a prospective study of 50 patients with PDAC who underwent a pancreas resection at a high-volume academic center. Demographic, clinical, treatment, surgery type, estimated blood loss (EBL), intra-operative and post-operative transfusion data were collected. Pre-operative systemic, intra-operative systemic, and cell salvaged filtered blood was collected to evaluate CTCs using GEDI-captured PDAC-specific nucleated cells. Salvaged intraoperative blood was filtered through either a leukodepletion filter or a 40µm microaggregate filter. Wilcoxon matched-pairs signed-ranks test was used to compare CTCs in pre-operative systemic, intra-operative systemic, and cell-salvaged filtered blood.

Results: Median age was 67.5 years and 29 (58%) were male. Thirty-two (64%) had borderline or locally advanced disease. Twenty-six (52%) received neoadjuvant treatment. Thirty-one (63%) had a preoperative biliary stent placed. Forty-three (89%) had a pancreaticoduodenectomy and venous reconstruction was performed in 16 (32%) patients. On final pathology 2% were T1, 26% were T2, 52% were T3, and 16% were T4. Thirty-six (18%) had N1 disease and 32 (16%) had N2 disease. The median EBL was 1000ml, 32% were transfused POD0, and 13 had transfusions POD1-7. There was no significant difference in the number of CTCs from systemic-intraoperative blood (p=0.5) or from cell-salvaged filtered blood (p=0.665) vs. pre-operative systemic blood.

Conclusion: This prospective study is the first to objectively evaluate and compare the number of CTCs in systemic pre-operative, systemic intra-operative, and cell-salvaged filtered blood. Given no significant difference in the number of CTCs, this study serves as a foundation to consider autologous transfusion during PDAC surgery given the deleterious effects of allogeneic transfusions. Further study is warranted.

abstract_title: High Molecular Weight Hyaluronan Attenuates Scarring in Acute Kidney Injury
author_block: A. Kaul<sup>1</sup>, S. Manson<sup>2</sup>, L. Yu<sup>1</sup>, S. Balaji<sup>1</sup>, P. Austin<sup>2</sup>, S. Keswani<sup>1</sup>, X. Wang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Urology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Renal fibrosis induces morbidity in pediatric patients, which can persist into adulthood. Hyaluronan (HA), a major extracellular matrix component, regulates fibrosis based on its molecular weight (MW). We reported that IL-10 upregulates high MW-HA synthesis via fibroblasts to attenuate fibrosis in a chronic kidney disease model. However, the effect of high MW-HA in acute kidney injury is unknown. Our data also suggests that HA is upregulated in epithelial tubular cells in an acute kidney injury model. We hypothesize that tubular cell-specific high MW-HA reduces fibrosis caused by acute kidney injury.

Methods:  We performed unilateral ischemia/reperfusion(I/R) on C57BL/6J male mice treated with/without IL-10 and/or 4-methylumbelliferone(4MU), an HA inhibitor. 100 mg/kg BrdU was given 24h before harvest via IP injection. I/R or sham kidneys were collected at D3/7/14 for the levels of HA synthases(HAS1-3) and hyaluronidases(HYAL1-2) by qPCR, total HA by ELISA, and fibrosis outcome and tubular cell proliferation by IHC/IIF. In vitro, human proximal tubular HK-2 cells were used to determine the effect of IL-10 on HA enzymes with/without TGFβ, which mimics the fibrotic phenotype. Data mean ± SD; p < 0.05 by ACNOVA(n>2) or T test(n=2).

Results: I/R significantly increases HA production, and enzymes peak at D3. With IL-10 treatment, we observe upregulated total HA at D3&D7, increased tubular cell proliferation, and reduced fibrosis. These effects are lost while HA is inhibited by 4-MU. In vitro, TGFβ significantly alters expression of HAS1&3 and HYAL1 compared to control, and IL-10 treatment increases HA and restores HAS1 level compared to control (1±0.23 fold).

Conclusion: Tubular-specific HA plays a protective role in response to acute renal injury, and the upregulation of HA by IL-10 can attenuate fibrosis. We identified a previously unreported role for high MW-HA that occurs in response to kidney injury. We also elucidated the mechanisms underlying HA-attenuated fibrosis to inspire novel therapeutics.

abstract_title: Inflammation Modulating Biomesh for Surgical Hernia Repair
author_block: R. Lee<sup>1</sup>, J. Kim<sup>2</sup>, R. A. Veettill<sup>1</sup>, F. Cabrera<sup>1</sup>, A. Adumbumkulath<sup>3</sup>, M. Zaheer<sup>1</sup>, K. Mhatre<sup>1</sup>, P. M. Ajayan<sup>3</sup>, S. Curley<sup>1</sup>, B. G. Scott<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Shin<sup>1</sup>, G. Acharya<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch,Galveston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Rice University,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Development of a hernia repair mesh with minimal postsurgical complications is a compelling clinical need. A key challenge is the design of multifunctional biomaterials with optimal mechanical fidelity for 3D-fabrication, withstand biophysical rigor, and possesses intrinsic immunomodulatory attributes. In this study, we demonstrate the development of an intrinsically inflammation modulating in situ phosphate crosslinked poly(vinyl alcohol) and its application as a 3D-fabricated soft, pliable Biomesh for surgical hernia repair.

Methods: A Biomesh with in situ phosphate crosslinked poly(vinyl alcohol) polymer (PVA-P) was fabricated by 3D-printing. To evaluate the efficacy of the Biomesh in preventing adhesions formation, it was implanted in rat ventral hernia model. To compare the Biomesh efficacy, a commercial polypropylene (PROLENE) mesh was used as a control. After 4 weeks of implantation, tissues were harvested for further analyses.

Results: The Biomesh is soft, pliable, and easy to handle during its surgical implantation. After 4 weeks of implantation, the PROLENE mesh was completely covered with adhesions, the sutures and mesh were not visible. In the case of Biomesh implanted rats, no adhesions formation was observed at 4-week timepoint and the margins of the Biomesh and the sutures are clearly visible.

Conclusion: In vivo efficacy studies in rat ventral hernia model have demonstrated an enhanced efficacy of the Biomesh in modulating inflammation by downregulating proinflammatory cytokine expression levels without the need for exogenous anti-inflammatory agents. The Biomesh is significantly more efficacious in inhibiting visceral adhesions formation compared to the present standard of care hernia repair meshes. Development of a broadly applicable multifunctional Biomesh will be a major advancement in the surgical hernia repair and pelvic floor reinforcement.

abstract_title: Creating A New Model To Understand Vaginal Fibrosis
author_block: J. M. McCracken<sup>1</sup>, G. Calderon<sup>1</sup>, S. Balaji<sup>2,4</sup>, S. Keswani<sup>2,4</sup>, J. C. Hakim<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology, Division Of Pediatric And Adolescent Gynecology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology, Division Of Pediatric And Adolescent Gynecology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Little is known about the cellular and molecular processes underlying abnormal mucosal wound healing response leading to the production of fibrotic tissue. This is especially true in vaginal tissue repair. Vaginal fibrosis is a debilitating problem effecting 73% of females who undergo vaginal surgery and more than 80% of post-radiation women. The understanding of the mechanisms of vaginal fibrosis development are limited, as are treatment options. To improve patients’ quality of life, we sought to create a novel injury model of murine vaginal fibrosis in order to develop techniques and therapies aimed at prevention and early targeted intervention.

Methods: 6 week old CD1 female mice underwent vaginal instillation of bleomycin.  Mice were exposed to low dose (1.5U/kg, LD), high dose (2.5U/kg, HD), or combination of wire brush epithelial disruption followed by high dose (2.5U/kg, EDHD) bleomycin. Normal saline (NS) instillation was done as a control. Instillations +/- epithelial disruption occurred 5 times over 7 days. Tissues were harvested 3 weeks after the last instillation. Inflammation and extracellular matrix (ECM) changes were evaluated using qRT-PCR and immunohistochemistry. p-values were determined by ANOVA followed by Dunnett’s post hoc.

Results: ECM changes were most notable in EDHD-exposed vaginal tissue compared to NS, LD, and HD-exposed groups. Following EDHD, vaginal Col1a1 expression (p=0.052) was increased and percent positive vaginal Picro Sirius red staining was slightly elevated compared to NS control. LD, HD, and EDHD resulted in decreased vaginal leukocyte numbers (CD45+ cells) compared to NS control. F480+ macrophages were lower in EDHD mice (p=0.051) while Ly6G+ neutrophils were slightly elevated compared to controls. Vaginal hyaluronan (HA) was overall reduced in EDHD mice compared to NS controls, due to the mediated contributions of increased expression of both hyaluronan synthases, Has1 and Has2, and the hyaluronidase, Hyal1. No changes in macrophage or neutrophil numbers, nor total HA levels, were observed in LD or HD compared to NS controls.

Conclusion: We developed a novel murine model of vaginal fibrosis using a combination of vaginal epithelial disruption and bleomycin vaginal instillation. This model led to increased but disorganized collagen deposition and reduction in inflammatory cell populations. We also found alterations of the HA, which has been shown in other tissues to be an important factor in regenerative versus fibrotic healing. Future studies will include elaboration of other fibrotic markers and evauation of collagen metabolism. The development of this model will also allow future studies in potential prevention and treatment programs targeted to vaginal fibrosis. These discoveries will contribute to novel insights on the pathogenesis of vaginal fibrosis and yield targets to develop additional therapies for vaginal wound healing.

abstract_title: Implementing an Electromagnetic Navigational Bronchoscopy Program: Predictors of Success
author_block: R. Palumbo<sup>1</sup>, K. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, T. Garwe<sup>1</sup>, Z. Sarwar<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Reinersman<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Oklahoma City, OK, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine,Division Of Cardiac, Thoracic And Vascular Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Oklahoma City, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the advent of lung cancer screening, lung nodules are being discovered with an increasing rate.  Thoracic surgeons should be at the forefront of management of lung nodules due to their unique skillsets.  Implementation of an electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy (ENB) program can assist with growing a surgical program.  Also, with the addition of more advanced bronchoscopic systems, it is imperative that thoracic surgeons learn these techniques.  We aimed to determine the factors predictive of successful navigation and biopsy using electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of patients referred to the thoracic surgery service from 2014-2019 for evaluation of lung nodules was performed.  Patients who underwent electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy and biopsy were included.  Patient demographics, pulmonary nodule characteristics, biopsy instrument type were obtained.  Recursive partitioning (CART) and multivariable regression analyses were used to identify predictors of both successful navigation and biopsy. 

Results: There were 73 patients who underwent ENB evaluation of 91 nodules from 2014-2019.  There was successful navigation in 75.8% (69/91) of nodules with the average size being 2.9 cm (p=0.002).  Bronchus sign was present in 68.1% (p=0.002) of cases. On multivariable analysis, bronchus sign, size of lesion, and distance to pleura were significant independent predictors of successful navigation. Based on CART analysis (Table 1), there was a 0.99 probability of successful navigation when the nodule was >= 2.6 cm with a positive bronchus and a 0.93 probability when distance from the nodule to the edge of the pleura was >=1.4cm.  In comparison, the lowest probability of successful navigation (0.32) was observed when pulmonary lesion size was <2 cm, a pleural distance <3.4 cm, and negative bronchus sign.  Of the lesions that had successful navigation, 45/69 (65.2%) had a diagnostic biopsy. The mean nodule size of diagnostic biopsy was slightly larger at 3.1 cm (p=0.23) and bronchus sign was present in 75.5% of successful biopsies. Based on CART analysis (Table 1), positive bronchus sign and lesion size >=1.3 cm were most predictive of obtaining a diagnostic biopsy with a probability of 0.75. The lowest probability (0.27) was observed when lesion size was < 1.3 cm.

Conclusion: Nodule size, distance to pleura, and bronchus size are independent variables of successful navigation when using ENB. However, of the lesions that were successfully reached, combined lesion size > 1.3 cm and a positive bronchus sign were highly predictive of obtaining a diagnostic biopsy.  These factors should be considered when implementing an ENB program in practice to optimize yield, particularly when first beginning a program.  These data also support primary surgical intervention for more peripheral lesions in patients that are surgical candidates.

abstract_title: Primary Pericardial Mesothelioma: A Population-Based Propensity Score-Matched Analysis
author_block: H. Brydges<sup>2</sup>, K. Yin<sup>1</sup>, R. Balasubramaniyan<sup>2</sup>, K. W. Lawrence<sup>2</sup>, K. J. Karlson<sup>1</sup>, N. M. Edwards<sup>1</sup>, D. B. McAneny<sup>2</sup>, N. Dobrilovic<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston University,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston University,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Primary pericardial mesothelioma is an extremely rare cardiac malignancy with a very poor prognosis. This study aimed to evaluate the population-based survival outcomes of primary pericardial mesothelioma using a US national cancer database. 

Methods:  We queried the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results program for primary mesothelioma patients from 1973 to 2015. We included primary pericardial mesothelioma patients with complete follow-up data as well as primary pleural mesothelioma patients who were identified as controls. Demographic and clinical variables, including age, sex, race, year of diagnosis, history of malignancy, histological subtypes, and treatment modalities, were extracted. Propensity-score matching, calculated with a multivariable logistic regression model, was used to balance baseline characteristics. Kaplan-Meier analysis and log-rank tests were performed to compare overall survival between subgroups. 

Results: Forty-one pericardial mesothelioma and 15,970 pleural mesothelioma patients were identified. Before matching, when compared to the pleural mesothelioma counterparts, pericardial mesothelioma patients were younger (53.9 ± 17.5 vs. 71.5 ± 11.4 years, p < 0.001), had higher percentages of female patients (46.3% vs. 20.2%, p < 0.001), non-white patients (24.4% vs. 8.4%, p = 0.001), and were less likely to have been diagnosed in the most recent study decade (2006-2015) (34.1% vs. 43.5%, p = 0.002). The overall one- and two-year survival rates of the pericardial mesothelioma patients were 22.0% and 12.2%, respectively, with a median survival of 2 months (interquartile range: 1-6 months). Both chemotherapy and surgical resection showed survival benefit in the first 12 months, but the overall effects were not statistically significant (chemotherapy: log-rank p = 0.57; surgical resection: log-rank p = 0.25). After 1:2 nearest neighbor propensity-score matching, 38 pericardial mesothelioma and 76 matched pleural mesothelioma cases were identified. Compared to their matched pleural mesothelioma counterparts, pericardial mesothelioma patients were less likely to receive chemotherapy (23.7% vs. 50.0%, p = 0.013) and were associated with worse survival (median survival: 2 vs. 11 months, log-rank p = 0.0025; Figure 1). 

Conclusion: On a population-level, primary pericardial mesothelioma is an extremely rare cardiac malignancy with a relatively young age at diagnosis and a very poor prognosis. Surgical intervention and chemotherapy seem to improve short-term survival but are rarely curative. Multidisciplinary treatment is required to maximize patient survival.

abstract_title: Outcomes and Resource Utilization in Cardiac Surgery for Patients with Human Immunodeficiency Virus
author_block: C. G. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, M. Gandjian<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Advances in antiretroviral therapy have improved the prognosis of patients diagnosed with Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV).  As a result, HIV positive patients (HIV+) are living longer and are therefore more susceptible to cardiovascular disease. However, data on the safety of major operations for HIV+ patients remains limited. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of HIV on clinical outcomes and resource utilization following major cardiac operations in a national cohort.

Methods: The 2010-2017 National Inpatient Sample (NIS) was used to identify all patients who underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), valvular surgery, or aortic replacement. The NIS is the largest publicly available inpatient database in the US and provides accurate estimates for 97% of all hospitalizations. International Classification of Diseases 9th and 10th Revision diagnosis codes were utilized to identify HIV+ patients. Inverse probability weighting (IPTW) was used to assess the independent association of HIV+ status with mortality, acute kidney injury, sepsis, routine discharge, duration of hospitalization (LOS) and adjusted costs. Propensity scores for IPTW were estimated from a multivariable regression model, which controlled for demographic, comorbid and hospital covariates.

Results: Of an estimated 2,336,865 who met study criteria, 2,916 (0.12%) were identified as HIV+. Cardiac operations on HIV+ patients increased from 262 (0.09%) in 2010 to 555 (0.19%) in 2017 (p<0.001). Compared to others, HIV+ patients were on average younger (54.7 vs 65.1 years p<0.001), more likely to be Black (32.5 vs 7.5% p<0.001) or Hispanic (12.9 vs 7.1% p<0.001) and on Medicaid (18.9 vs 7.3% p<0.001). They also had lower prevalence of comorbid conditions, except for endocarditis (10.4 vs 2.0% p<0.001) and liver disease (11.8 vs 3.2% p<0.001). However, rates of CABG, CABG-valve, valvular surgery and aortic replacement were similar between groups (p>0.05). While HIV+ patients were admitted electively less often (44.2 vs 55.2% p<0.001), they experienced longer LOS and higher costs but similar discharge status and in-hospital mortality (Table). After matching, HIV+ was independently associated with increased odds of acute kidney injury and sepsis. Furthermore, it was correlated with incremental increases in LOS and costs but not routine discharge or in-hospital mortality.

Conclusion: Cardiac procedures for HIV+ patients have increased steadily over the past decade. Although cardiac surgery in this population results in acceptable outcomes, this condition may be associated with increased risks of complications, LOS and costs. These findings may better stratify patient candidacy and operative risk in this vulnerable patient cohort.

abstract_title: The Impact of Team Familiarity on Intra- and Postoperative Cardiac Surgical Outcomes
author_block: M. R. Mathis<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Yule<sup>2,3</sup>, X. Wu<sup>4</sup>, R. D. Dias<sup>5</sup>, A. M. Janda<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Krein<sup>6</sup>, M. M. Manojlovich<sup>7</sup>, M. D. Caldwell<sup>1</sup>, K. Stakich-Alpirez<sup>4</sup>, M. Zhang<sup>8</sup>, J. Corso<sup>9</sup>, N. Louis<sup>9</sup>, F. D. Pagani<sup>4</sup>, D. S. Likosky<sup>4</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Anesthesiology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Edinburgh,Clinical Surgery,Scotland, United Kingdom <sup>3</sup>Harvard Medical School,Surgery-Brigham & Women's Hospital,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan,Cardiac Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>Harvard Medical School,Emergency Medicine-Brigham & Women's Hospital,Boston, MA, USA <sup>6</sup>University of Michigan,Internal Medicine,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>7</sup>University of Michigan,School Of Nursing,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of Michigan,Biostatistics, School Of Public Health,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of Michigan,College Of Engineering,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intraoperative teamwork among cardiac surgery providers is an important facet of non-technical performance demonstrated to impact patient outcomes.  Scalable methods to assess team familiarity and its impact on teamwork, workflow efficiency, and outcomes have not been sufficiently evaluated. The impact of intraoperative provider teamwork on intra- and postoperative outcomes was evaluated using an electronic-health record derived measure of team familiarity, based upon prior shared working patterns.

Methods: The study cohort comprised 3,290 adult cardiac surgical procedures performed by any combination of  providers [cardiac surgeons (n=12), anesthesiologists (n=23), perfusionists (n=25), physician assistants (n=14), scrub nurses (n=71)] at an academic center between 2016-18. We computed  team familiarity as the mean of prior cardiac surgical operations performed for all surgeon - non-surgeon pairs, during the 2 years prior to the date of surgery. Terciles of team familiarity (low: <18 prior operations; medium: 18-28, high: >28) were included in regression models to predict cardiopulmonary bypass duration (primary outcome) and postoperative outcomes (major morbidity, operative mortality, renal failure, intensive care unit hours, and hours of ventilator support), adjusted for provider experience and predicted risk (demographics, comorbidities, admission acuity, procedure type) using Euroscore II. The effect of team familiarity on outcomes was assessed across terciles of predicted risk.

Results: Median (IQR) cardiopulmonary bypass duration was 132 minutes (88-194), and 510 (15.5%) patients developed major postoperative complications. The relationship between team familiarity and cardiopulmonary bypass duration significantly differed across terciles of predicted risk (p=0.0014) although not for the secondary outcomes (p>0.05). Relative to low team familiarity, high team familiarity was associated with -14min (p=0.006) of cardiopulmonary bypass duration for medium-risk patients and -28min (p<0.001) for high-risk patients, Figure. Increasing team familiarity was associated with a significant 1.9% decreased odds of renal failure (OR=0.98, p=0.045), while non-significant -0.14 ICU hours (SE.0.20, p=0.51), -0.18 ventilation hours (SE.0.14, p=0.19), 1.0% lower odds of major morbidity (OR=0.999, p=0.84) and 1.2% lower odds of 30-day mortality (OR=0.99, p=0.35).

Conclusion: Increased team familiarity was significantly associated with reduced cardiopulmonary bypass duration (greatest among highest risk patients) and renal failure. A significant protective effect was not found for other outcomes. Intraoperative processes of care that are reliant upon teamwork independently account for variation in care efficiency and may serve as future quality improvement targets.

abstract_title: Wait List Change in BMI in Underweight and Obese Patients Associated with Lung Transplant Mortality
author_block: C. Liu<sup>1</sup>, K. Li<sup>1</sup>, J. Pruszynski<sup>2</sup>, C. Heid<sup>2</sup>, P. Bajona<sup>2</sup>, J. Murala<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Wait<sup>2</sup>, L. Huffman<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Medical School,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Department Of Cardiovascular And Thoracic Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Lung transplantation is the definitive treatment for end-stage lung diseases. Selection of lung transplant patients includes an evaluation of body mass index (BMI), as obesity is a relative contraindication. However, BMI changes may occur during the waiting list period, resulting in lower or higher BMI at the time of transplant. Previous single center studies have assessed the effects of waiting period BMI change on short-term outcomes of lung transplantation. The aim of this study is to assess the long-term outcomes of waiting list BMI changes.  

Methods:  The internal prospectively maintained Society of Thoracic Surgery (STS) transplant database and electronic medical records were reviewed for single and bilateral lung transplants between February 2004 and December 2018. Patients were classified as underweight (< 20 kg/m2), obese (> 30 kg/m2), or control (20-30 kg/m2). Obese and underweight patients were then further stratified based on whether they lost (-) or gained (+) weight during the waiting list period. The primary endpoint was overall mortality. Secondary outcomes were initial intensive care unit (ICU) hours, initial mechanical ventilator (MV) hours, initial hospital length of stay (LOS), and a composite of in-hospital complications. Kaplan-Meier curves and log rank test were used to compare overall mortality between the BMI groups. A modification of the z-test using Greenwood's formula for variance was used to compare the survival rate at 1, 3, and 5 years. Kruskal-Wallis, chi square, and Fisher exact test were used to compare the distribution of secondary variables. Statistical significance was indicated by p < 0.05.

Results: A total of 644 cases were included in this study. The groups and their sizes are as follows: underweight and lost weight (BMI < 20, -), 46/644 (7%); underweight and gained weight (BMI < 20, +), 59/644 (9%); obese and lost weight (BMI > 30, -), 80/644 (12%); and obese and gained weight (BMI > 30, +), 32/644 (5%). 423/644 (66%) patients were in the control group (BMI 20-30). Log rank test indicated an association between overall survival and change in BMI from listing to transplantation (p = 0.01). There was also a significant difference in the initial MV hours between the BMI cohorts (p = 0.014).

Conclusion: Obese and underweight patients who trended toward control BMI (20-30 kg/m2) during the waiting list period had better overall survival rates than obese and underweight patients who trended away. The waiting list period presents an opportunity for obese and underweight patients to improve their preoperative health status and long-term outcomes.

abstract_title: Outcomes and Readmissions following Cardiac Operations in Patients with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
author_block: J. Madrigal<sup>1</sup>, V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) remains one of the most common hematologic malignancies in the United States. Outcomes of cardiac operations in CLL have been examined in limited series and are conflicting. Thus, the present study examined the association of CLL on clinical outcomes and resource use following cardiac operations in a nationally representative cohort.

Methods:  All patients (≥35 years) undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting, valve repair or replacement or a combination thereof were identified from the 2010-17 Nationwide Readmissions Database. The presence of CLL, as well as relevant patient and hospital characteristics were tabulated utilizing International Classification of Diseases, Ninth and Tenth Revisions. The primary outcome of interest was in-hospital mortality while secondary outcomes included blood transfusion, perioperative complications (cardiac, respiratory, thromboembolic, stroke, renal, infectious, intraoperative), length of stay, inflation-adjusted hospitalization costs and unplanned readmission within 30 days of discharge. Inverse probability of treatment weighting was utilized to adjust for patient and hospital differences. The aforementioned outcomes were subsequently compared using the adjusted Wald and Pearson’s Chi-Square tests.

Results: Of an estimated 2,288,576 patients included for analysis, 0.2% (n=5,248) had a diagnosis of CLL. Compared to their counterparts, patients with CLL were more likely to be male (79.4 vs. 69.3%, p<0.001) and to be older (73.4 vs. 66.2 years, p<0.001) but with a similar burden of comorbidities as measured by the Elixhauser Comorbidity Index (3.4 vs. 3.5, p=NS). After adjusting for baseline patient and hospital characteristics, CLL was not associated with increased in-hospital mortality (3.2 vs. 2.8%, p=NS) nor perioperative complications (37.6 vs. 35.8%, p=NS) (Figure). Notably, CLL did not increase risk for postoperative infection (2.5 vs. 3.3%, p=NS). However, CLL was independently associated with requirement of blood transfusion (32.1 vs. 28.8%, p=0.04). The presence of CLL did not increase length of stay (10.8 vs. 10.6 days, p=NS) or hospitalization costs (50,776 vs. $51,461, p=NS). In addition, patients with CLL had similar rates of readmission at 30 days compared to their counterparts (14.2 vs. 11.7%, p=NS).

Conclusion: CLL is not associated with excess mortality or complications following cardiac operations. However, the presence of CLL is associated with requirement of blood transfusion. Although cardiac operations may be safely performed in patients with CLL, inherent risks of transfusion should be considered and discussed in this population.

abstract_title: Gender Disparities in Pre-operative Quality of Life among Aortic Valve Replacement Patients
author_block: K. Johnson<sup>2</sup>, M. Mims<sup>3</sup>, S. Pereira<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, K. W. Eudailey<sup>1</sup>, P. Vardas<sup>1</sup>, W. Holman<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Kirklin<sup>1</sup>, J. Davies<sup>1</sup>, R. Xie<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery/Department Of Surgery/School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>3</sup>Auburn University,College Of Science And Mathematics,Auburn, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Aortic valve replacement (AVR) is a common procedure used to improve patient symptoms associated with aortic stenosis and/or regurgitation. The purpose of this study aimed to examine pre-operative quality of life (QoL) reported by AVR patients, focusing on identifying associated predictors and assessing gender disparities. 

Methods:  We prospectively enrolled AVR patients into a patient-engagement program—a mobile application—SeamlessMD. This application provided educational materials and collected patient-reported outcomes at pre-op, 30-day, and 90-day post-discharge using multiple QoL instruments including the Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ-12). Patient demographics and characteristics, operative details, and post-operative outcomes were obtained using the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) Adult Cardiac Surgery Database (ACSD). Descriptive statistics and multivariable analyses were performed to evaluate pre-operative QoL and quantify gender disparities. 

Results: We enrolled 130 AVR patients from July 2019 to May 2020, and 75 (58%) of them completed pre-operative KCCQ-12. Among these patients, 43% were females, and their KCCQ scores were significantly lower than those of their male counterparts in all the domains of QoL, including Physical Limitation (60.9 vs. 80.4; p < .01), Symptom Frequency (57.4 vs. 77.3; p < .01), Social Limitation (56.6 vs. 75.9; p < .01), Quality of Life (41.8 vs. 52.6; p = .05), and Overall Score (54.0 vs. 71.2; p < .01). Multivariable regression models identified female as a predictor consistently associated with lower scores in all the domains of KCCQ-12 among AVR patients (Table).

Conclusion: Females have significantly lower pre-operative QoL scores in all the domains of KCCQ-12. Improved understanding of the contributors to reduced pre-operative QoL may facilitate tailored intervention strategies that could enhance outcomes and eliminate gender disparities.

abstract_title: The Heart of the Matter: Cardiac Contusion in Geriatric Patients with Sternal Fractures.
author_block: A. T. Abid<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>1,2</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Grady<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,3</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1,2</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Incidence of cardiac contusion (CC) in patients with sternal fractures (SF) has long been debated. There is limited data available on CC in geriatric patients (≥ 65 y.o) with SF. The aim of this study was to compare incidence of CC in geriatric (GP) vs non-geriatric patients (NGP) with SF.

Methods: This IRB approved retrospective cohort study included 202 GP and 202 NGP with SF admitted to two level 1 trauma centers. Compared variables included age, gender, race, Body Mass Index (BMI), cardiac comorbidities, mechanism of injury (MOI), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), results of electrocardiogram (ECG), cardiac enzymes, echocardiogram (ECHO), sternal surgery, cardiac surgery, ICU admission and ICU length of stay (ICU LOS), discharge disposition, and mortality. CC was defined as abnormal ECG in combination with elevated enzymes, or an abnormal ECHO.

Results: GP were significantly older (79.3 vs 44.0 y.o, p<0.01) and were predominantly white females while NGP were mainly white males. BMI was similar in both groups. Cardiac comorbidities, including coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation and hypertension, were more common in GP (69.3% vs 21.8% p<0.001). Predominant MOI was motor vehicle collisions (>78.5%) in both groups, reflecting the most common “steering wheel trauma” injury in SF. GP had lower ISS (12.1 v 15.1 p<0.002) and higher GCS (14.4 vs 13.2 p<0.001). Frequencies of manubrium and sternum body fractures were similar in both groups. GP had higher rates of an abnormal ECG (60.4% vs 41.2% p<0.001), while rates of elevated enzymes (43.3% vs 36.1%) and abnormal ECHO (34.6% vs 32.8%) were not statistically different (p>0.3). CC was diagnosed statistically more often in GP (27.7% vs 14.9%) [Fig 1]. Rates of surgical stabilization of SF (9.9% vs 11.9%, p=0.5) and cardiac procedures (2.0% vs 5.0%, p=0.1) were comparable. ICU admissions (55.9% vs 55.4%) and ICU LOS (6.2 vs 7.8 days) were not statistically different (p>0.1). GP were discharged to skilled nursing facility (SNF) most often, while NGP were mainly discharged home (SNF: 25.7% vs 8.9%, home: 39.4% vs 68.3%, p<0.001). Mortality (11.4% vs 5.0%, p=0.02), including hospice discharge, was statistically higher in GP. Main reason for mortality in GP was thoracic trauma and in NGP was traumatic brain injury.

Conclusion: Despite being less injured, geriatric patients with a sternal fracture had higher rates of diagnosed cardiac contusion, possibly due to the higher incidence of pre-existing cardiac comorbidities. Geriatric patients with sternal fractures should be thoroughly screened for cardiac contusion even if cardiac injury is not directly related to an increased mortality in geriatric patients.

abstract_title: Impact of Hospital Volume on Resource Use following Elective Cardiac Surgery
author_block: J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, M. Gandjian<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Shemin<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and valve repair or replacement remain among the most common operations performed in the United States, wide variation in associated costs have been reported. Given the growing emphasis on value-based care, we examined the impact of hospital volume on index hospitalization costs, non-home discharge, and 30-day nonelective readmissions at a national level.

Methods: All adults undergoing elective CABG or valve operations were identified in 2016-2017 Nationwide Readmissions Database. Institutions were divided into volume quartiles based on annual elective cardiac surgery caseload, and comparisons made between lowest (low volume hospitals, LVH) and highest (high volume hospitals, HVH) quartiles. Categorical variables were studied using the chi-square test and continuous variables using the adjusted Wald or Mann-Whitney U test. The primary outcome was inflation-adjusted costs at the index hospitalization while secondary outcomes were non-home discharge and nonelective readmission within 30 days of discharge. Generalized linear models were fit to evaluate the independent association of volume with outcomes.

Results: Of an estimated 560,660 patients included for analysis, 23.9% were treated at LVH and 28.8% were treated at HVH. Compared to LVH, patients treated at HVH were younger (65.3 years, standard deviation, SD, 10.2 vs 65.9 years, SD 11.5, P=0.003), less commonly male (69.3% vs 70.9%, P=0.009), and had a greater burden of comorbidities as measured by the Elixhauser Index (4.3, SD 1.6 vs 4.1, SD 1.9, P=0.008). Compared to LVH, HVH less commonly performed isolated CABG (44.3% vs 61.0%, P<0.001) but more frequently performed combined CABG-valve (13.5% vs 11.9%, P<0.001) and multi-valve operations (6.0% vs 2.6%, P<0.001). Unadjusted mortality, non-home discharge, and 30-day nonelective readmission rates were lower at HVH compared to LVH, as were costs (Table). After adjustment for patient and hospital characteristics, operations at HVH were associated with a $8,400 reduction (95% confidence interval, CI, $5,600-11,100) in index hospitalization costs relative to LVH. HVH were also associated with reduced odds of mortality, non-home discharge and 30-day nonelective readmission compared to LVH (Table).

Conclusion: In this contemporary analysis, high operative volume was independently associated with reduced hospitalization costs and improved mortality following elective cardiac operations. Given a reduction in non-home discharge and readmissions, this effect likely extends beyond the index hospitalization, despite the increased complexity observed at high volume hospitals. Further study of practice patterns in high volume centers may guide efforts to reduce resource use.

abstract_title: Impact of Prehospital Triage on Postoperative Outcomes in Acute Thoracic Aortic Conditions
author_block: A. Shmelev<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Sill<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Sanchez<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ascension Saint Agnes Healthcare,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We examined how prehospital events affect postoperative mortality in patients with acute thoracic aortic conditions (AAC).

Methods: Linkage between the Maryland State Inpatient Database and the State Emergency Department (ED) Database from 2013-2017 was established to retrospectively examine the impact of 30-day prehospital triage postoperative outcomes following thoracic aortic repair for dissection or rupture.

Results: Of 1750 total patients diagnosed with AAC during the study period, 664 underwent surgery for AAC. ED visits (n=292) or admissions (n=39) to sites other than site of surgery caused delays in definitive repair of more than 1 day in 42.3% patients and increased postoperative in-hospital mortality (OR 1.8; 95% CI 1.0–3.1 on bivariate analysis). 60% of patients initially sent home from ED or other hospitals did not have a discharge diagnosis of aortic pathology.   Absence of a chest CT (CCT) scan on preceding ED encounters (19% of ED visits) increased subsequent in-hospital mortality (OR 3.28, 95% CI 1.46–7.39, logistic regression). Among socio-demographic factors, only age ≥ 70 was linked to increased mortality (OR 2.88, 95% CI 1.38–6.02). Transfer to definitive surgery site from less populated counties showed higher mortality but did not reach statistical significance (OR 3.98, 95% CI 0.94–16.90). 

Conclusion: Diagnostic errors, no prehospital CCT, and distance to definitive care, delay surgery and increase mortality following surgery for AAC.

abstract_title: Broken Bones and Broken Hearts: Cardiac Contusion in Patients with a Sternal Fracture.
author_block: J. S. Lozada<sup>1</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>2,3</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>2,3</sup>, R. Grady<sup>2,3</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>2,3</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,3</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>2,3</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Due to the rarity of sternal fractures (SF), data examining the relationship of cardiac contusion (CC) in patients with SF is scarce. The aim of this study was to characterize patients with SF who were diagnosed with a CC.

Methods: This retrospective cohort analysis included 404 adult (≥18 years old) patients with SF who were treated at two level I trauma centers between January 2015 and May 2020. Patients were compared in two groups: with diagnosed cardiac contusion (CC) n=86, or without cardiac contusion (WCC) n=318. CC was defined as the presence of an abnormal electrocardiogram in conjunction with elevated cardiac enzymes, or as a wall motion abnormality seen during an echocardiogram. Analyzed variables included: age, comorbidities, Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), pulmonary co-injuries, SF pattern, sternal and cardiac procedures, ventilation requirements (including tracheostomy rates), ICU admissions, ICU length of stay (ICULOS), hospital LOS (HLOS), and mortality.

Results: CC was diagnosed in 21.3% of patients with SF. Mean age in CC patients was 67.4, while in WCC patients it was 60.1 (p=0.004), with a significantly higher prevalence of geriatric population (≥ 65 y.o.) in the CC group (65.1% vs 45.9%, p=0.002). Comorbidities (94.0% vs 80.2%, p=0.02) and particularly cardiac comorbidities (atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hypertension) were more common in CC patients (73.5% vs 48.2%, p=0.001) [Fig. 1]. ISS (15.5 vs 13.2), GCS (13.2 vs 14.0), and SF pattern (body, manubrium, dual, isolated, combined) were similar in CC and WCC groups, all p>0.1. Pulmonary co-injuries (45.3% vs 31.4%, p=0.02) and particularly pulmonary contusion were significantly more common among CC patients (29.1% vs 18.2%, p=0.03). Sternal plating procedure rate was not different (5.8% vs 12.3%, p=0.09), while cardiac procedures were statistically more common in the CC group (8.1% vs 2.2%, p=0.008). Ventilation requirements (33.7% vs 20.8%, p=0.01) and tracheostomy rates (16.3% vs 4.7%, p<0.001) were higher in CC patients. The CC group was admitted to the ICU more often (75.6% vs 50.3%, p<0.001), but ICULOS was not statistically different (8.7 vs 6.3 days, p=0.09). CC patients had an increased HLOS (13.9 vs 8.9 days, p=0.02), and a statistically higher mortality (14.0% vs 6.0%, p=0.03).

Conclusion: Although the patterns and severity of sternal injury in itself were similar, patients with cardiac contusion had higher mechanical ventilation requirements and mortality rates, which could be attributed to their cardiac trauma, advanced age and pulmonary co-injuries. Thus, patients with a sternal fracture and cardiac comorbidities should be thoroughly screened for possible cardiac contusion.

abstract_title: Assessment of Microbial Etiologies of LVAD Infections to Guide Development of Bacteriophage Therapy
author_block: I. Kamat<sup>1</sup>, H. Lamba<sup>1</sup>, C. Hines-Munson<sup>1</sup>, S. Hudson<sup>1</sup>, K. Liao<sup>1</sup>, K. Muldrew<sup>1</sup>, A. Terwilliger<sup>1</sup>, H. Kaplan<sup>2</sup>, R. F. Ramig<sup>1</sup>, A. Maresso<sup>1</sup>, B. Trautner<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College of Medicine,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As more ventricular-assist devices (VADs) are implanted for destination therapy, VAD infection is an increasingly common complication. To initiate development of bacteriophage therapy for VAD infections, particularly drive line infections (DLIs), we isolated, quantified, and categorized bacterial pathogens from retrospective and prospective cohorts of patients with VAD infections.

Methods: The study populations were: 1) a retrospective cohort of patients who received VADs from November 2003 to August 2017, and 2) a prospective cohort of patients with DLIs from September 2018 to May 2019. We classified each patient’s VAD infection into three non-mutually exclusive subcategories: DLI, bacteremia, and pump/device infection. We also isolated or evolved bacteriophage and quantified each phage’s ability to kill the prospectively collected organisms using plaque assays.

Results: In the retrospective cohort of 572 patients who underwent VAD placement, 186 patients (32.5%) developed a VAD infection, and 372 bacterial strains were isolated from these infected patients. Among these patients, 148 had DLIs, 83 had bacteremia, and 93 patients had pump infections. The most commonly isolated organism was Staphylococcus aureus with 80 isolates (21.5%). Of the 146 bacterial strains causing bacteremia in 83 patients, enterococcal species were the most frequent organisms with 36 isolates (24.7%) compared to 29 (19.9%) S. aureus isolates. Table 1 delineates the organisms isolated from DLIs, both retrospective and prospective. In the prospective DLI samples, 96 strains were isolated from 54 unique VAD infections. S. aureus was the most common single organism in this cohort with 31 isolates (32.3%). When focusing on DLIs, the percentage of infections caused by gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria was similar in both the retrospective and prospective studies, P = 0.3. We isolated or evolved 93 bacteriophage able to lyse (kill) bacteria causing DLIs from the prospective study (24 gram-positive-killing phage and 69 gram-negative-killing phage).

Conclusion: In this study, similar pathogens caused LVAD DLIs in our retrospective and prospective collections, implying that our prospectively created strain bank can be used to develop bacteriophage cocktails against future DLIs. Although the most common organism in both cohorts was S. aureus, we isolated the fewest phage against this pathogen. Future work will use DLI-sourced S. aureus as the host to isolate phage from S. aureus-rich environmental sources, such as human nares and wounds. As bacteriophage therapy becomes more established, we plan to use our bacteriophage bank to develop phage treatments tailored for the specific pathogens causing each patient’s infection.

abstract_title: Management and Outcomes of Esophageal Perforations Among Racial Groups
author_block: J. T. Bui<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Hendrickson<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Long<sup>3</sup>, B. E. Haithcock<sup>3</sup>, P. D. Strassle<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,School Of Medicine,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Esophageal perforation (EP) is a life-threatening emergency that requires emergent surgical intervention and is associated with a high mortality rate (15%-40%). In the US, racial disparities in surgical treatment and outcomes have been widely documented. However, little is known about potential disparities among patients with EP.

Methods:  Hospitalizations of adult (≥18 years old) patients diagnosed with EP were identified in the 2000-2017 National Inpatient Sample. Since several states do not report race hospitalizations, hospitalizations missing race were excluded (n=1,574 unweighted). Race was categorized as White, Black, Hispanic, and other race. Multivariable Cox proportional hazards regression was used to estimate the association between race and in-hospital mortality. Inpatient complications were assessed using multivariable logistic regression. Survey-specific analysis methods were used to account for clustering and stratification, and analyses were weighted to obtain national estimates.

Results: There were 36,531 EP hospitalizations. One quarter of hospitalizations were among racial minorities (Black 13%, Hispanic 8%, other 5%). White patients were significantly older at admission (median age 58 vs. 41 and 47, p<0.0001), and more likely to be transferred in from outside hospitals compared to Black and Hispanic patients (19% vs. 14% and 13%, p<0.0001 and p=0.0003, respectively). The rate of EP admissions, per 1,000,000 US adults, significantly increased among all groups over time, Figure 1A. Similar rates of surgical intervention were seen among races, including esophageal stents. In-hospital mortality decreased for both White and Black (10.2% to 4.6% 8.3% to 4.9%) but increased for Hispanic and other races (2.9%  to 4.7% and 3.4% to 6.9%), p<0.0001 for all, Figure 1B. After adjusting for patient and hospital characteristics, including income and hospital teaching status, there was no difference in in-hospital mortality among all racial groups. However, Black patients were more likely to have sepsis (OR 1.34, 95%CI 1.08, 1.66), and pneumonia (OR 1.26, 95% CI 0.98, 1.63). Other race patients were more likely to be diagnosed with pneumonia (OR 1.44, 95% CI 1.01, 2.07).  

Conclusion: Rates of EP admissions have increased for all racial groups since 2000. Mortality rates have decreased among White and Black patients but have increased among Hispanic patients and other races. Despite similar rates of in-hospital mortality across groups, Black and other race patients were more likely to experience postoperative complications. This study suggests that potential disparities in quality or access to care exists among Black, Hispanic and other race patients that warrants future research.

abstract_title: Marital Status and Sex-Based Differences in Outcomes After Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement
author_block: P. Newell<sup>1</sup>, S. Hirji<sup>1</sup>, A. Malarczyk<sup>1</sup>, F. Yazdchi<sup>1</sup>, E. Percy<sup>1</sup>, M. Harloff<sup>1</sup>, S. McGurk<sup>1</sup>, P. Shah<sup>2</sup>, A. Sabe<sup>1</sup>, P. Sobieszczyk<sup>2</sup>, T. Kaneko<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Division Of Cardiology,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies have shown improved outcomes among married patients with cardiovascular disease. However, the outcomes of marital status after the transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) has not been studied. We examined the impact of marital status and sex on post-discharge outcomes over the first year after TAVR.  

Methods: Patients who underwent TAVR from January 2015 to June 2018 were retrospectively reviewed and stratified into 3 groups: Single (149), Married (413) and Widowed (223). The interaction of marital status and patient sex (male vs female), and postoperative outcomes (30-day mortality and home disposition) was assessed using a stepwise, selection logistic regression analysis. Cumulative survival was estimated using Kaplan-Meier analysis, and adjusted survival was evaluated using multivariable Cox proportional hazards modelling, stratified by marital status and patient sex. Median follow-up was 2.25 years.

Results: Widowed patients were older than married patients (84 vs 79 years) with higher STS scores (6.79% vs 5.51%, both P≤0.001). Neither marital status or sex was associated with 30-day mortality, home discharge or readmissions (all P≥0.2). However, Kaplan-Meier analysis of 1-year survival revealed a differential survival penalty for marital status in each sex.  In women married status was associated with lower survival whereas in men widowed status was associated with lower survival (overall p=.017).  This survival penalty persisted in the adjusted analyses (married women HR=2.24, P=0.009 and widowed men HR= 2.42, P=0.057), demonstrating that married status may not improve TAVR outcomes in both sexes as previously seen in the cardiovascular disease literature. For patients with readmissions during the first year (N=175), adjusted analysis showed widowed status was associated with higher 30-day readmissions (nearly 60% of readmissions, HR=1.91, P=0.012), regardless of sex (Figure).

Conclusion: Our findings raise concerns that marital status and sex may impact 1-year TAVR outcomes. Identifying at-risk individuals and targeted interventions, such as adjusting discharge planning to ensure adequate home social support, may help improve outcomes.

abstract_title: Blood Transfusion is Associated with a Survival Decrement in Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery.
author_block: Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, R. Shemin<sup>2</sup>, M. Madani<sup>3</sup>, N. Young<sup>4</sup>, B. Kiaii<sup>4</sup>, T. Deuse<sup>5</sup>, J. C. Sun<sup>6</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - San Diego,Cardiac Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of California - Davis,Cardiac Surgery,Sacramento, CA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Cardiac Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Cardiac Surgery,Orange, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The negative impact of preoperative anemia and blood transfusions on morbidity and mortality have been extensively studied in cardiac surgery literature. Despite the observed association of these factors with worse short- and long-term survival, transfusion practices remain variable and controversial. The present study aimed to examine the independent impact of anemia and blood transfusions on mortality and complications using a state-wide collaborative. 

Methods: An academic health-system, statewide, cardiac surgery consortium repository was used to identify all adult patients undergoing isolated coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) from 2013 to 2018. Preoperative anemia was defined as a hematocrit (HCT) level ≤30%, while those with missing HCT values were excluded. The administration of any packed red blood cells (pRBC) and blood component therapy (BCT) were studied as binary variables. Multivariable logistic regression models, adjusting for patient and operative characteristics including age, gender, urgent/emergent operative status, hospital and year of operation were developed for 30-day mortality, postoperative stroke, and renal failure. The effect of preoperative anemia, pRBC transfusion, or BCT on each outcome was studied in these models. Model discrimination was evaluated using receiver-operating curve characteristics (AUC).

Results: Of the 2,778 patients who met study criteria (median age 64 years, Interquartile Range 57-71 years), 19.6% were female. Among the cohort, mortality was 2.7%, while postoperative stroke and renal failure incidence were 1.3% and 3.3%, respectively. The prevalence of preoperative anemia was 10.9%. Overall, 49% of patients received at least 1 unit of pRBC, while 58.1% were transfused at least 1 unit of BCT. Inclusion of pRBC and BCT within each established regression model resulted in greater odds of mortality and renal failure, but not stroke (Table 1). Furthermore, model discrimination for mortality and renal failure improved when adjusting for pRBC or BCT, as demonstrated by a greater AUC when compared to models that only adjusted for preoperative anemia (Table 1)

Conclusion:Using a statewide cardiac surgery consortium we found red blood cell transfusion and other blood component therapy, but not preoperative anemia to be associated with higher odds of mortality and complications after isolated CABG. Our findings indicate a strong correlation between red cell transfusions and mortality irrespective of the presence of anemia. Therefore, ongoing efforts targeting reduction of packed red blood cell transfusion, but also blood component therapy, are needed.

abstract_title: Patient Satisfaction is Equivalent for Inpatient and Outpatient Minimally-Invasive Adrenalectomy
author_block: R. A. Pigg<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Porterfield<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Same-day surgery in the carefully-selected patient decreases costs, improves inpatient capacity, and decreases patient exposure to hospital-acquired conditions. Outpatient adrenalectomy has been shown to be safe and effective, but patients’ perspectives have yet to be addressed. This study compares patient satisfaction following inpatient and outpatient adrenalectomy.

Methods:  An institutional database was queried for minimally-invasive adrenalectomies performed from 2017 to 2020. Patients were contacted up to two times to participate in a phone survey consisting of 25 questions modeled after the Outpatient and Ambulatory Surgery Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems Survey (OAS CAHPS®) assessing preparation for surgery, discharge experience, post-operative course, and overall satisfaction. Statistical analysis was performed using Kruskal Wallis, Wilcoxon-Mann Whitney, and Chi-square tests, as appropriate.  

Results: One hundred five adrenalectomy patients were identified, of which 98 were contacted and 52 responded (53%). Outpatient adrenalectomy patients had slightly higher overall experience scores, but this difference was not statistically significant (9.17 ± 1.39 vs 8.57 ± 1.70, p=0.16). Patients undergoing outpatient adrenalectomy were more likely to have their discharge plan discussed pre-operatively (93% vs 63%, p=0.014), but no significant differences were noted between inpatient and outpatient groups regarding preparation for surgery, readiness for discharge, night of surgery experiences, or self-reported pain or complications (p>0.05 for all). Significantly higher overall experience scores were reported by patients counseled about their discharge plan (9.31 vs 7.67, p=0.12), felt prepared for recovery (9.43 vs 5.5, p<0.001), received information about pain control (9.13 vs 7.00, p=0.04), felt prepared at time of discharge (9.36 vs 5.80, p<0.001), and received information about potential complications (9.30 vs 7.00, p=0.001). Outpatient adrenalectomy patients were significantly more likely to agree they would choose the same approach if facing surgery again (97% vs 83%, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Patient satisfaction following adrenalectomy is significantly associated with patients’ self-reported degree of preparation for surgery and discharge, with no significant difference in patient satisfaction between inpatient and outpatient groups. Patients undergoing outpatient adrenalectomy would be likely to choose the same approach compared to inpatients. Targeted pre-operative counseling can contribute to enhanced patient outcomes for all patients undergoing adrenalectomy.

abstract_title: Maintenance of a Therapeutic Thyroid State Following Pediatric Total Thyroidectomy is a Challenge
author_block: B. P. Mehr<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Malek<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Milan<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Scott & White Healthcare,Department Of Surgery,Temple, Texas, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Persistent hypothyroidism has potential detrimental effects on physical and intellectual development in children. Appropriate management of postoperative thyroid hormone replacement is critical in pediatric patients following total thyroidectomy, yet a lack of postoperative literature exists in this population. We aimed to identify pediatric populations at-risk for persistent or recurrent hypothyroidism after total thyroidectomy. 

Methods: A single-center retrospective analysis included all pediatric total thyroidectomies from February 2002 to June 2019. Chart review determined age, sex, height, weight, pathology (benign versus differentiated thyroid malignancy), behavioral diagnosis (i.e. depression, attention deficit disorder), preoperative comorbidities, and number of daily preoperative medications. Patients were classified as child (≤  12 years) or teen (≥  13 years). Body Mass Index Percentile (BMI%) was tabulated. Overweight (BMI% >85%) and obese (BMI% >95%) individuals were compared to all others. All Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) levels measured from discharge through age 18 were tabulated. Hypothyroidism was defined as a TSH greater than 4.0mU/L. A TSH-index variable accounted for varying follow-up intervals and frequency by dividing the total number of hypothyroid TSH values over the total number of TSH values. SAS 9.4 was used for all descriptive and logistic regression analysis.

Results: 50 patients (median age 14.5 years (Interquartile Range (IQR)=6)) were studied. 72% were female (n=36). 43% (n=21) were overweight or obese. Differentiated thyroid malignancy was detected on pathology in 20% of patients (papillary n=9, follicular n=1). A behavioral diagnosis was present in 22% of patients (n=11). The median number of preoperative daily medications was 2 (IQR=3). TSH levels were measured a median of 6.5 times (IQR=7) per patient. The TSH index was significantly higher in patients with 7 or more follow-ups (p=0.0195). There was no difference in TSH index when comparing sex (p = 0.4936), BMI percentile (p=0.9748), or age (p=0.9091). Hypothyroid TSH measurements were lower in malignant (39%) versus benign (45%) patients (p=0.3058). TSH measurements meeting hypothyroid criteria were higher in patients without a behavioral diagnosis (47%) versus those with a behavioral diagnosis (34%, p=0.4078). Increasing pre-operative home medication use and increasing pre-existent comorbidities were not associated with improved management of thyroid state.

Conclusion: Maintenance of appropriate pediatric thyroid hormone levels following total thyroidectomy is difficult to achieve irrespective of patient demographics, pathology, or comorbidities. Improving preoperative counseling and postoperative follow-up is warranted in these patients to prevent the detrimental sequelae of pediatric hypothyroidism. Future studies are needed to address this vulnerable postoperative population.

abstract_title: Opioid-free Thyroid And Parathyroid Operations: Are Patients Satisfied?
author_block: P. W. Leader<sup>1</sup>, D. R. Oyler<sup>4</sup>, T. M. Carter<sup>2</sup>, D. S. Damron<sup>2</sup>, C. Y. Lee<sup>2</sup>, D. A. Sloan<sup>2</sup>, W. B. Inabnet<sup>2</sup>, R. W. Randle<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Kentucky,Department Of Otolaryngology,Lexington, KY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Kentucky,Department Of General Surgery,Lexington, KY, USA <sup>3</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine,Department Of General Surgery,Winston-Salem, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Kentucky,Department Of Pharmacy Practice And Science,Lexington, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Postoperative opioid use may increase risk of overdose, misuse, and opioid use disorder. We recently implemented an opioid-free analgesic regimen following thyroidectomy and parathyroidectomy, but patient satisfaction with pain control was unclear. The aim of this study was to evaluate pain control and patient satisfaction using an opioid-free pain control regimen following thyroid and parathyroid operations.

Methods: Surveys were distributed to all postoperative patients following total thyroidectomy, thyroid lobectomy, and parathyroidectomy from 01/2020 through 4/2020 at their postoperative visit.  After surgery, patients received no opioids except in rare cases based on patient needs and surgeon judgement.  We measured patient reported pain scores using the Numeric Rating Scale and satisfaction using a 4-point Likert scale. Satisfaction ratings were categorized as either satisfied (happy or very happy) or dissatisfied (unhappy or very unhappy).

Results: We received 90 of 198 surveys distributed, for a response rate of 45.45%.  After excluding neck dissections (n=6) and preoperative opioid use (n=4), the final cohort included 80 patients after total thyroidectomy (26.3%), thyroid lobectomy (41.3%), and parathyroidectomy (32.5%). The majority were satisfied with their pain control (87.5%) and their entire surgical experience (95%).  Patients who were satisfied with their pain control were more likely to be satisfied with their entire experience than those who were not satisfied with their pain control (97.1% vs 70.0%, p= 0.008). Only 6.3% of the entire cohort required opioid pain medication, and those who were satisfied with their pain control were less likely to require opioids postoperatively (2.9%) than those dissatisfied with pain control (30%, p=0.008). A similar proportion of patients reported being satisfied with pain control after total thyroidectomy (90.9%), thyroid lobectomy (90.5%), and parathyroidectomy (80.8%) indicating that the procedure did not significantly impact overall satisfaction with pain control (p=0.47).  Additionally, patient reported pain scores were similar following the three operations at all time points (Figure).

Conclusion: Even with an opioid free postoperative pain regimen, the majority of patients are satisfied with their pain control after thyroid and parathyroid operations and most patients who were dissatisfied with their pain control reported satisfaction with their overall surgical experience.  Taken together, these data indicate that an opioid free postoperative pain control regimen is well tolerated and unlikely to decrease overall patient satisfaction in this patient population.

abstract_title: Routine Computerized Neurocognitive Tests Show Benefit of Successful Thyroid & Parathyroid Surgery
author_block: R. Nowrouzi<sup>1</sup>, R. Grogan<sup>1</sup>, J. Suliburk<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neurocognitive symptoms are common in thyroid and parathyroid disease. The formal diagnosis and quantification of the extent of neurocognitive dysfunction can be challenging. The purpose of this project was to analyze the initial results from the routine implementation of neurocognitive testing in an endocrine surgery clinic of an academic medical center. We hypothesized that patients would demonstrate improvement in neurocognitive performance following successful surgery.

Methods: A single center prospective study was conducted over a 4-month time period at our institution’s endocrine surgery clinic. We initiated routine neurocognitive testing including immediate and delayed recall (memory- IM, DM), Stroop test (executive function- EF), trail testing A and B (visual attention- VA), and Symbol Substitution test (cognitive performance- CP) in patients undergoing thyroidectomy for hyperthyroidism or parathyroidectomy for primary or tertiary hyperparathyroidism. All tests were administered using BrainCheck™, a computerized cognitive assessment aid. Scores were collected and analyzed preoperatively and again after at least 2 weeks postoperatively.

Results: 94 tests were administered in total. Pre-post test results were available for 36 parathyroid & 8 thyroidectomy cases. Patients not receiving postop testing occurred as a result of declined follow up. Post-operative data showed 77.2% of all studied patients demonstrated improvement in at least 2 categories of neurocognitive performance. The most common area of improvement overall was in EF and VA where 62% of all patients experienced neurocognitive improvement in these two areas. 75% of patients undergoing parathyroidectomy had improvement in at least 2 neurocognitive performance categories with the most common area of improvement being CP and EF & least common area IM. CP and EF both improved equally with 62% of parathyroidectomy patients experiencing improvement. All parathyroidectomy cases had intraoperative PTH measurement consistent with cure. All patients undergoing thyroidectomy had detectable PTH following surgery. Following surgery, 87.5% of patients who had undergone thyroidectomy experienced improvement in at least 2 neurocognitive measures. 75% of thyroidectomy patients demonstrated DM improvement.

Conclusion: The majority of patients experience improvements in neurocognitive performance after successful endocrine surgery. Routine neurocognitive testing facilitates the identification of patients who did not have neurocognitive benefits and thereby facilitates the referral of these patients for further neurocognitive rehabilitation.
