The demonstration of significant cognitive impairment prior to surgery and improvement after surgery in hyperthyroidism is a novel finding and represents an area for further investigation.

abstract_title: Patient-Reported Financial Toxicity of Thyroid Cancer
author_block: H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, C. Li<sup>1,3</sup>, J. Broekhuis<sup>1,3</sup>, C. C. Lubitz<sup>2,3</sup>, S. Duncan<sup>1</sup>, B. Lopez<sup>3</sup>, P. Hasselgren<sup>1,3</sup>, P. Mowschenson<sup>1,3</sup>, B. C. James<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Brookline, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The incidence of thyroid cancer is increasing at a rate higher than all other types of cancer in the United States. Prior studies have demonstrated a decrease in quality of life in these patients, however it is not known the extent to which this is attributable to financial toxicity. We sought to quantify and characterize patient-reported financial toxicity in patients with thyroid cancer at our institution.

Methods:   We identified patients within a clinical database who underwent thyroidectomy for thyroid cancer at our institution from 1990 to 2018. Patients were contacted by telephone to complete a questionnaire assessing financial toxicity and its related psychological financial hardship. Specifically, treatment costs, income loss, bankruptcy, debt, and job loss after their cancer diagnosis were explored. Our primary outcome was having negative financial consequences due to thyroid cancer diagnosis and treatment.

Results: Respondents (n=147) were 73% female, 74% white, and had a mean age of 51. Half of all respondents reported an annual household income over $100k. The majority of respondents  (82%) reported private health insurance, while 13% had Medicare and 5.5% were either on Medicaid or uninsured.  A subset of patients (16%) reported having negative financial outcomes after their personal diagnosis of thyroid cancer. Respondents attributed this to income loss post-thyroidectomy (14%), debt (3%), and bankruptcy (1%). Many patients (40%) reported experiencing worry related to their medical costs. Financial impact was not found to be associated with age, sex, education, employment, or insurance status (Table 1).

Conclusion: The majority of patients undergoing thyroidectomy for cancer at our institution are financially affluent, insured, and well-educated. However, despite this, 16% of patients report financial toxicity related to their thyroid cancer diagnosis and treatment. This burden is likely increased in a non-affluent population. Social determinants of health in the thyroid cancer patient population and their association with financial toxicity should be further studied as this burden likely contributes to a decrease in quality of life in thyroid cancer survivors.

abstract_title: Both Safe and Effective: Parathyroidectomy for Normocalcemic Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism
author_block: K. Ramonell<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Parathyroidectomy is the standard management for patients with tertiary hyperparathyroidism (THPT) and hypercalcemia. However, a subset of patients with THPT have normal or mildly-elevated serum calcium levels in the setting of significantly elevated PTH. Prolonged exposure to elevated PTH can have deleterious effects on bone health. Despite this, the role of parathyroidectomy in these patients has not been previously studied. The purpose of this study is to determine the effectiveness and safety of parathyroidectomy in normocalcemic THPT. 

Methods:  A multicenter retrospective review of patients diagnosed with THPT who subsequently underwent four-gland exploration and subtotal parathyroidectomy between 2000-2019 was performed. Patients were categorized as “normocalcemic THPT” (Ca < 10.4 mg/dL) or “hypercalcemic THPT” (Ca? 10.4 mg/dL). Pre- and post-operative calcium and PTH levels, specimen weight, complications, evidence of biochemical cure, and disease recurrence were recorded. T-tests and chi-squared analysis was used, where appropriate.

Results: Two-hundred twenty-eight THPT patients were included with a mean age of 53 years and 57% female. Ninety-four (41.2%) were normocalcemic with a mean pre-operative Ca of 9.6±0.1 mg/dL compared to 11.2±0.1 mg/dL in the hypercalcemic group (p=0.001). Pre-operative PTH levels were markedly higher in the normocalcemic group (449±61 pg/dL) compared to the hypercalcemic group (294±21 pg/dL; p=0.007). Post-operative Ca levels in the normocalcemic group were slightly lower, but not statistically significant (8.6±0.1 mg/dL vs. 9.5±0.6 mg/dL). Post-operative PTH levels were higher in the normocalcemic group 113±14 pg/dL compared to the hypercalcemic group 78±9 pg/dL (p=0.03). Despite the higher pre-operative PTH levels, normocalcemic patients had significantly smaller glands compared to hypercalcemic patients (973±109 vs. 1,292±96; p=0.03).Notably, there was no difference in length of stay (0.36 days vs. 0.51 days) or cure rate (99% vs. 100%) when comparing normocalcemic vs. hypercalcemic groups, respectively. Recurrence was lower in the normocalcemic group (4%) than hypercalcemic group (9%), although not statistically significant.

Conclusion: Patients with normocalcemic THPT undergoing parathyroidectomy have similar outcomes including cure and recurrence rates to those with hypercalcemic THPT. This data demonstrates that lowering the threshold for surgical intervention to include patients with mild THPT disease can be performed efficaciously, while shortening the duration and systemic impact of prolonged hyperparathyroidism.

abstract_title: Intraoperative Hypotension in Posterior Retroperitoneal vs Transperitoneal Laparoscopic Adrenalectomy
author_block: F. Chen<sup>1</sup>, M. Adhami<sup>1</sup>, M. Tan<sup>1</sup>, S. Grodski<sup>1,2</sup>, J. W. Serpell<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Orr<sup>3</sup>, A. Stark<sup>3</sup>, J. C. Lee<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Alfred Hospital,Department Of General Surgery, Monash University Endocrine Surgery Unit,Melbourne, VIC, Australia <sup>2</sup>Monash University,Department Of Surgery,Melbourne, VIC, Australia <sup>3</sup>The Alfred Hospital,Department Of Anaesthesia And Perioperative Medicine,Melbourne, VIC, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hemodynamic instability is a major challenge during adrenalectomy. We hypothesized that the prone jack-knife position for posterior retroperitoneoscopic adrenalectomy (PRA) is associated with greater intraoperative hypotension than transperitoneal laparoscopic adrenalectomy (TPA). The aim of this study was to compare intraoperative hemodynamic parameters between PRA and TPA.

Methods: A retrospective study of patients undergoing PRA and TPA without conversion or concomitant intra-abdominal pathology from 2008 to 2019. The primary outcome was intraoperative hypotension defined by mean arterial pressure (MAP) <60 mm Hg or a need for ≥2 intravenous vasopressors at least 30 minutes after anaesthetic induction.

Results: Overall, 108 patients met the inclusion criteria; 33 (30.6%) had pheochromocytoma, 26 (24.1%) Conn's syndrome, 8 (7.4%) Cushing’s disease, and 41 (38.0%) non-functioning adrenal tumours. Of these, 68 (63.0%) underwent PRA and 40 (37.0%) TPA. Age, sex, body mass index, pre-induction blood pressure (BP), number of pre-operative anti-hypertensives, and histopathological diagnosis were similar in the 2 groups. Tumour size was greater in the TPA group. The lowest MAPs of PRA patients were lower than TPA patients (Figure 1, P=0.04). Multivariate analysis showed PRA was more likely to be associated with a lowest MAP of < 60 mmHg (OR 4.44, 95% CI 1.27-15.54, P=0.02), and a need for ≥2 intravenous vasopressors (OR 5.44, 95% CI 1.52-19.46, P=0.009) compared with TPA. When pheochromocytoma patients were excluded from analysis, PRA patients were more likely to require ≥ 1 intravenous vasopressors (OR 21, 95%CI 4.61-96.65, P=0.001); but the risk of the lowest MAP being < 60 mmHg was similar in both groups. PRA was associated with reduced operative time (P=0.01) and length of hospital stay (P=0.03) compared with TPA.

Conclusion: While PRA offers several advantages over TPA, it carries a greater risk of intraoperative hypotension. Both surgeons and anaesthetists should be aware of this association to minimize periods of hypotension, in order to avoid adverse outcomes. A larger multi-centre prospective trial is required to validate these findings.

abstract_title: Adequacy of Lymph Node Yield for Papillary Thyroid Cancer in Children
author_block: A. Yap<sup>1</sup>, A. Shui<sup>2</sup>, J. Gosnell<sup>1</sup>, C. Huang<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Sosa<sup>1</sup>, R. Sanziana<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,General Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Epidemiology And Biostatistics,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The 2015 ATA guidelines recommend that children with papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) undergo prophylactic central neck dissection in selected cases to reduce recurrence. To date, no study has assessed at the adequacy of prophylactic lymph node yield (LNY) necessary to accurately stage patients. Our aim was to determine the optimal LNY for pediatric patients undergoing thyroidectomy for clinically node-negative PTC.

Methods: Patients aged ≤18 years with clinically node-negative PTC (cN0) who underwent thyroid surgery were reviewed in the National Cancer Database between 1998-2016. Patients who had ≥1 LNY were compared to those that did not, using Chi-squared and Wilcoxon rank-sum tests. Comparisons were made based on demographic, clinical, and pathological characteristics. To estimate the number of lymph nodes needed for accurate pathologic nodal staging, a truncated beta-binomial distribution was used. LNY was calibrated to achieve 90% sensitivity in nodal staging, and model prediction was stratified to clinical tumor size staging, pT1-3.

Results: A total of 1,948 children with cN0 disease were included; median age was 17 years; 83.2% were female. Preoperatively, 47.6% were clinical stage T1, 25.3% T2, and 9.3% T3. 1,272 (65.3%) had lymph nodes resected. Of the patients who had ≥1 LNY, the median LNY was 5 nodes (interquartile range [IQR] 2-12); 45.9% of patients were found to have at least one metastatic lymph node. Compared to the patients without LNY, patients who had ≥1 LNY removed were more likely to come from a household with higher annual income of >$35,000 (73.1% vs 67.5%, p=0.009), more likely to undergo total thyroidectomy (93.6% vs 74.9%, p<0.001) and more likely to receive post-operative radioiodine (56.8% vs 47.5%, p<0.001). In the group that had  ≥1 LNY, probability of a falsely negative lymph node resection was 59% when a single node was examined, but reduced to <10% when 12 lymph nodes (95% confidence interval [CI] 9-19) were examined. Based on clinical tumor T-stage, LNY for 90% sensitivity of finding a positive metastatic lymph node was 14 lymph nodes for T1, 8 for T2, and 6 for T3.

Conclusion: This is the first study to estimate the LNY necessary to accurately assess lymph node status in children with PTC who are cN0 in the preoperative setting. Our findings can guide judicious lymph node resections to optimize the LNY while being thoughtful about the potential risks of central lymph node resections in children. Adequate LNY for pediatric PTC patients is different from that of adult patients based on higher likelihood of lymph node metastasis in pediatric PTC.

abstract_title: Molecular Testing Has Limited Utility in the Surgical Evaluation of Bethesda III Thyroid Nodules
author_block: R. Handelsman<sup>1</sup>, O. Picado<sup>1</sup>, S. Linhares<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, M. Jeraq<sup>1</sup>, Z. Khan<sup>1</sup>, J. Farra<sup>1</sup>, J. I. Lew<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami,Division Of Endocrine Surgery/DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery/ Leonard M. Miller School Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology has 6 diagnostic categories, each with an implied cancer risk. Bethesda III thyroid nodules have atypia or follicular lesions of undetermined significance (AUS/FLUS) on fine needle aspiration (FNA) and carry a rate of malignancy (ROM) between 5% to 15%. This presents a clinical dilemma regarding appropriate surgical management. Gene Expression Classifier (GEC) and Thyroid Genomic Classifier (TGC) molecular testing can further stratify AUS/FLUS nodules as suspicious or intermediate/high risk for thyroid cancer, respectively. This study investigates the utility of GEC and TGC tests in predicting malignancy in AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules.

Methods: A retrospective review of prospectively collected data for 1457 patients with index thyroid nodules who underwent FNA and thyroidectomy from 2010 to 2020 at a single academic institution was performed. The use of GEC or TGC testing in patients with AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules that underwent initial thyroid surgery for definitive diagnosis was examined. GEC testing was reported as benign or suspicious for malignancy while TGC testing was reported on a spectrum of low, intermediate or high risk for malignancy. Positive TGC was separated into intermediate or high risk based on gene mutations or fusions. Descriptive statistics were utilized to compare the ROM among AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules.

Results: Of 1457 patients with FNA thyroid cytology, 358 (25%) corresponded to AUS/FLUS results. Most patients were women (83%, n=298), with a median age of 49 years (IQR: 40-59) and nodule size of 20 mm (IQR: 13-29). Sixty-nine percent of AUS/FLUS patients (n=247) underwent total thyroidectomy. Of this AUS/FLUS group, 132 (37%) had GEC testing, 88 (24%) had TGC testing and 139 (39%) had no additional molecular testing. Overall, 197 (55%) had thyroid malignancy on final histopathology. ROM for AUS/FLUS nodules with a suspicious GEC was 55% (71/128), whereas ROM for AUS/FLUS nodules without GEC or TGC testing was 49% (68/139). ROM for AUS/FLUS nodules with a positive TGC was 73% (n=48/66). Amongst these patients, 43 had intermediate-risk mutations (e.g. BRAF+), of which 60% were malignant, and 23 had high-risk mutations (e.g. TERT, RET, multiple mutations), of which 96% were malignant (p<0.01).

Conclusion: Surgical patients with AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules have a high ROM. While high-risk TGC testing may have some utility in predicting malignancy in AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules, GEC and intermediate-risk TGC results have limited value. Surgeons should carefully consider the utility of molecular tests in determining the extent of thyroidectomy as it may lead to overtreatment and increased morbidity.

abstract_title: Trends and Outcomes of Surgical Management of Primary Papillary Carcinoma in the Pediatric Population
author_block: B. Huang<sup>1</sup>, R. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, J. Lee<sup>1</sup>, J. Kuo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Columbia University College Of Physicians And Surgeons,Division Of Endocrine Surgery,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Childhood papillary thyroid cancer is more aggressive than carcinomas in adults. Current American Thyroid Association pediatric guidelines recommend a total or near-total thyroidectomy for all pediatric patients without gross evidence of lymph node metastases. Our objective is to analyze trends in the surgical management of pediatric papillary thyroid cancer and assess how well the guidelines are implemented. 

Methods:  A retrospective cohort study of pediatric patients (ages 19 years and under) who underwent a thyroidectomy was conducted using the SEER database 2006-2017. Procedure type was classified as lobectomy or less and sub-total/total thyroidectomy. Analysis was stratified staging of the primary tumor and size. Descriptive statistics were performed to illustrate patient and tumor characteristics as well as with chi-square analysis to evaluate frequency of treatment with total thyroidectomies versus lobectomy or less. Logistic regression analysis controlling for age, sex, size of tumor, rural vs. urban institutions, and surgery year was conducted to identify factors predictive of procedure type. 

Results: 2,271 unique patients underwent surgical management of papillary thyroid cancer between 2006-2016. Most patients received a sub-total or total thyroidectomy as surgical management (N=2,085, 89.3%). 186 patients (8.19%) received a lobectomy or less. The number of lobectomies or less increased with time, with 41(6.7%) patients between 2006-2009, 98 (8.0%) between 2009-2015, and 47 (11.1%) between 2016-2017. Mortality rates were low (N = 15, 0.6%). On logistic regression analysis, later stages, larger sizes, and earlier operative years were predictive of a near-total or total thyroidectomy. 

Conclusion: Despite the American Thyroid Association Guidelines recommending a total thyroidectomy for pediatric well-differentiated thyroid cancer, the results of this study demonstrate that thyroid lobectomies are being performed in increasing frequency for smaller tumors in earlier stages of disease. Further investigation of whether this trend actually affects the outcomes in this patient cohort is needed.

abstract_title: Prophylactic Central Neck Dissection in Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma: All Risk, No Reward
author_block: J. E. Dismukes<sup>1</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, R. Obiarinze<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Hernndez-Mrquez<sup>1</sup>, E. Buczek<sup>2</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Otolaryngology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Prophylactic central neck dissection (pCND) remains a controversial intervention for papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) patients in the absence of radiologic evidence of nodal metastasis (N0). Proponents state that pCND prevents recurrence, while opponents deem that the risks of complications outweigh any potential benefit. To this point, there are conflicting studies identifying the outcomes of pCND for PTC patients with N0 disease. Therefore, we performed an analysis of N0 PTC patients at our institution to determine the efficacy of pCND.

Methods: An institutional cancer registry and supplemental electronic medical records (EMRS) were queried for patients who underwent thyroid surgery for papillary thyroid cancer with N0 staging as identified by preoperative imaging. Patients with PTC were then stratified by the presence or absence of a prophylactic central neck dissection (pCND). Standard statistical analyses was performed, such as ANOVA/t-test and chi-square, using Microsoft® Excel® PivotTable and IBM® SPSS® software to determine statistical significance in patient outcomes and complications based on the difference in their treatment protocol.

Results: Between 1998 and 2018, 695 patients with PTC had thyroid surgery at our institution. Of these 695 patients, 492 (70.8%) had N0 disease. The mean age was 50±1 years old and 368 (74.8%) were female. Of those with N0 disease, 61 patients (12.4%) underwent pCND. pCND patients were found to have higher pre-operation thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) values, 2.8±0.8 vs. 1.5±0.2 mU/L (P=.028), and had lower BMIs, 29±0.9 vs. 31±0.4 (P=.024).  No statistically significant difference was found between pCND and no pCND for recurrence/distant metastasis of disease (P=.105) or persistence of disease (P=.069) at time of follow-up (mean 38±3 months). However, following surgery, pCND patients had a higher occurrence of transient hypocalcemia (36.1% vs.14.4%, P<.001), transient recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury (19.7% vs. 7.0%, P<.001), and permanent RLN injury (3.3% vs. 0.7%, P<.001).

Conclusion: The majority of PTC patients at our institution with N0 disease did not undergo pCND. Those that did were characterized by higher pre-operation TSH values and had lower BMIs at the time of surgery. Additionally, pCND was associated with no improvement in outcome as measured by decreased recurrence or distant metastasis rates, but did result in increased post-operation complications. Therefore, we conclude that pCND should not be routinely performed for PTC patients with N0 disease.

abstract_title: The Clinical Utility of Preoperative Thyroglobulin for Surgical Decision Making in Thyroid Disease
author_block: M. Kang<sup>1</sup>, T. S. Wang<sup>1</sup>, T. W. Yen<sup>1</sup>, K. Doffek<sup>1</sup>, D. B. Evans<sup>1</sup>, S. Dream<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Surgical Oncology,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Serum thyroglobulin (Tg) levels are used to monitor for thyroid cancer recurrence and have been correlated with post-treatment disease burden. However, the clinical significance of Tg in the preoperative setting to predict the risk of underlying differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC) is not clear.  Our aim is to examine the clinical utility of preoperative Tg levels in those undergoing thyroidectomy for thyroid disease.

Methods: From a prospectively collected database, we identified 1191 patients who underwent initial thyroidectomy from January 2014 to December 2019.  Those who underwent thyroid resection for hyperparathyroidism (n=2), medullary thyroid cancer (n=3), anaplastic thyroid cancer (n=1), and lymphocytic thyroiditis (n=1) were excluded. Of the 1184 patients, one-third (n=385) had a preoperative Tg level. Data collected included demographics, preoperative Tg levels, operative indication, operation performed, and presence of DTC on final pathology. Preoperative Tg levels were compared across groups by preoperative indication for surgery (hyperthyroidism, nodular thyroid disease, and papillary thyroid cancer), highest Bethesda category of biopsied nodules, presence of DTC on surgical pathology, and number of metastatic lymph nodes. Statistical analysis was performed in SPSS.

Results: Of the 385 patients, 97 (25%) were male and the mean age was 50 ± 1 years. Patients underwent total thyroidectomy (n=306), thyroid lobectomy (n=78), thyroid isthmusectomy (n=1).  Preoperative indications for operation included thyroid nodule (n=109), multinodular goiter (n=53), Graves’ Disease (n=44), PTC (n=163), or other benign disease (n=16).   There was significant variation in preoperative Tg levels (mean 351 + 61). There was no difference in mean preoperative Tg level when compared across preoperative indication for surgery (p=0.209). Tg levels did not differ by nodule Bethesda classification (Table 1, p=0.392).  Mean preoperative Tg levels were lower in patients with DTC (n=237, mean 238 ± 77) compared to those who did not have DTC (n=148, mean 532 ± 97) on final pathology (p=0.018).  Among 188 DTC patients who had lymph nodes removed, there was no significant correlation between the preoperative Tg level and number of positive lymph nodes on final pathology (p=0.414).

Conclusion:Preoperative Tg levels were lower in patients with DTC compared to those with benign disease on final pathology and did not correlate with extent of lymph node metastasis in patients with DTC. We do not recommend using preoperative Tg levels to guide extent of surgery for differentiated thyroid cancer.

abstract_title: Preoperative Imaging Findings and Change in Lumbar Bone Mineral Density After Parathyroidectomy
author_block: G. Steinl<sup>1</sup>, R. Yeh<sup>2</sup>, M. D. Walker<sup>3</sup>, C. McManus<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Lee<sup>1</sup>, J. H. Kuo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Columbia University College Of Physicians And Surgeons,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Endocrine Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center,Radiology,New York, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Columbia University College Of Physicians And Surgeons,Department Of Medicine, Division Of Endocrinology,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although the majority of patients with primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) are asymptomatic, increased bone turnover and decreased bone mineral density (BMD) increase the risk of debilitating fractures. The potential for improved BMD after parathyroidectomy (PTX) is often discussed but poorly understood. Elucidating the factors which predict change in BMD would allow physicians to better counsel patients about the risks and benefits of PTX. No studies to date have evaluated whether a relationship exists between preoperative imaging findings, such as gland size and Tc-99m Sestamibi (MIBI) uptake, and postoperative change in BMD. We hypothesized that larger, MIBI-avid glands would be associated with greater increase in BMD after curative PTX.

Methods: Retrospectively, patients with PHPT who underwent combined MIBI and 4D-CT (SPECT/CT) prior to PTX were considered for inclusion. Only patients with both preoperative and 1-year postoperative dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) at our institution were included to avoid potential disparity in measurements. From SPECT/CT, data were collected on each parathyroid gland including estimated weight (using the ellipsoid formula), MIBI uptake, and contrast enhancement. Total (4-gland) estimated parathyroid weight was calculated for each patient. Our primary endpoint was the percent change in BMD at the lumbar spine (LS). We evaluated all variables potentially related to bone metabolism along with the imaging variables and used stepwise regression to construct a multivariate model to predict the change in BMD.

Results: 28 patients met inclusion criteria. The mean age was 60.9 ± 12.4 y, 82% were female, 68% had a history of osteoporosis, and 36% had ≥ 2 abnormal glands. Median total parathyroid weight was 270 mg (range 66 – 2133), and 68% had MIBI-avid glands. Complete DXA data was available in 25 patients. All demonstrated biochemical cure (normalized serum calcium ≥ 6 months after PTX). An increase in BMD at the LS was observed in 76% of patients (mean change 2.4 ± 4.3%). The change in BMD at the LS was best predicted by preoperative serum calcium, total estimated parathyroid weight, and MIBI uptake (Table 1).

Conclusion: To our knowledge, we are the first to report a relationship between preoperative imaging findings and bone recovery after PTX. The most logical explanation for our findings would be that larger, more metabolically active adenomas mobilize more calcium from bone. Subsequently, these patients may have greater potential for recovery of BMD after PTX. Despite our limited sample size, our preliminary findings add important insight into bone recovery after PTX and, if verified, may prove helpful when counseling patients regarding potential benefits of PTX.

abstract_title: Variations in Pre-Operative Blockade for Older Patients with Pheochromocytoma
author_block: J. A. George<sup>1</sup>, R. N. Obiarinze<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Porterfield<sup>1</sup>, T. N. Wang<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. M. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, S. Reddy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Pheochromocytomas (PC) are tumors of the adrenal medulla that produce catecholamines.  Surgical resection is curative, but careful blood pressure management is necessary to avoid catastrophic intraoperative adrenergic surges. Pre-operative alpha blockade with phenoxybenzamine has been the primary strategy used in PC patients, though its non-selective nature can result in significant side effects, especially for older patients, with costs significantly higher than selective agents. Here we examine various pre-operative treatment strategies used in PC patients.

Methods:  A retrospective, single institution review of patients with resected PC from 1996 through 2020 was performed. Clinicopathological characteristics were analyzed. Special attention was given to determine specific pre-operative blockade strategy.  Elderly patients were defined as 70 years or older at the time of resection.

Results: One hundred sixty-six patients underwent resection of a PC during the study period. Most patients were female (N=91, 55%) and Caucasian (N=95, 58%). The median age was 54 years (range, 18-93). The pre-operative blockade strategy could be determined for 165 patients. Most received phenoxybenzamine (N=90, 55%), followed by selective alpha-1 agents (N=40, 24%), and calcium channel blockers (N=11, 7%). No pre-operative blockade was employed in 24 cases (15%). There was no difference in phenoxybenzamine use based on race (Caucasian vs. Black: 54% vs 52%, P=0.87) or sex (female vs. male: 51% vs 56%, P=0.53). There also was no difference in use of selective alpha-1 agents based on race (Caucasian vs. Black: 19% vs. 28%, P=0.25) or sex (female vs. male: 24% vs. 19%, P=0.45). Twenty-three patients (14%) were elderly. Elderly patients had similar demographics as compared to their younger counterparts (Caucasian, elderly vs. younger: 72% vs. 56%, P=0.19; female, elderly vs. younger: 48% vs. 56%, P=0.52). Elderly patients were less likely to receive phenoxybenzamine (59% vs. 26%, P=0.006) and more likely to get an alpha-1 selective agent (61% vs. 18%, P<0.0001) compared to younger patients (see Figure). There was no difference in the use of calcium channel blockers (younger vs. elderly: 7% vs. 13%, P=0.40) or no pre-operative blockade (younger vs. elderly: 15% vs. 9%, P=0.53) in the two age groups.

Conclusion: Elderly patients comprise a large cohort of PC patients. Selective alpha-1 agents were more likely to be used in this population.  Given the equivalent therapeutic efficacy of these agents in managing hypertension in older PC patients, and the relatively higher cost and potentially worse side effects of phenoxybenzamine, pre-operative use of selective alpha-1 antagonists may be justified in all PC patients.

abstract_title: Diagnostic Impact of Adrenal Vein Sampling in Cushing's Syndrome due to Adrenal Adenoma
author_block: P. P. Raje<sup>1,2</sup>, B. Sacks<sup>1,2</sup>, B. James<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,General Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adrenal vein sampling (AVS) is a procedure involving simultaneous sampling of both adrenal veins to measure autonomous hormone production. AVS is routinely performed in hyperaldosteronism to differentiate adenoma from hyperplasia. AVS is not routine in the workup of adrenal Cushing’s syndrome prior to surgical planning. We aim to assess whether AVS provides a significant benefit for treatment planning.

Methods: A search of patients with adrenal Cushing's whose workup included AVS revealed 8 patients at our institution from 2015 to 2020. 1 was lost to follow up after undergoing AVS. The remaining 7 patients were included for final analysis. Patients ranged from ages 37 to 75, 3 were male and 4 were female, and 5 were Caucasian and 2 were African American. Clinical improvement was defined as either reduced serum cortisol or symptomatic improvement, or both.

Results: AVS results were concordant with imaging results in 3 out of 7 (43%) patients and discordant in 4 out of 7 (57%). AVS changed management to medical therapy in 1 discordant case, confirmed management with ablation in 1 concordant case, and did not appear to affect management in 5 cases. Management consisted of unilateral adrenalectomy for 2 patients, radiofrequency ablation for 2 patients, and medical therapy for 2 patients. All 3 management strategies were employed in both concordant and discordant cases. Ultimately, 5 out of 7 patients had clinical improvement, 1 that underwent medical therapy is still being evaluated for response, 1 patient was lost to follow up after AVS. In 2 out of 4 discordant cases, AVS suggested bilateral disease while CT suggested unilateral disease.

Conclusion: The role of AVS in in adrenal Cushing’s is still unclear. Our results suggest AVS may impact management in some patients. AVS results were discordant with CT results in over half our patient cohort, suggesting that basing management on cross sectional imaging alone may not be reliable. Indeterminate AVS results in 1 patient whose CT lateralized disease to the right side led to the decision for medical therapy instead of surgical. The decision was also influenced by the patient’s mild symptoms. In an institution with AVS technical expertise, the procedure is low risk and may provide useful information. In patients with discordant results and more severe symptoms, surgery or radiofrequency ablation guided primarily by imaging was pursued. Interpretation of the AVS is nuanced and dependent on symptom severity, clarity of CT results, and discussion of options with the patient. The role of AVS needs to be studied in larger cohorts to decide whether it should routinely be adopted as a diagnostic tool in adrenal Cushing’s.

abstract_title: Vitamin D Deficiency is Associated with Single Gland Parathyroid Disease
author_block: A. Gillis<sup>1</sup>, K. Ramonell<sup>2</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>2</sup>, H. Chen<sup>2</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Albany Medical College,Department Of General Surgery,Albany, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery/ Division Of Breast And Endocrine Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The active form of vitamin D [1,25 (OH2D)] plays a key role in calcium homeostasis and ultimately the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Accepted dogma is that vitamin D (vit D) deficiency leads to a physiologic imbalance and resultant increased PTH secretion, rather than true autonomous gland dysfunction as seen in the majority of primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT) cases. The purpose of this study is to review final parathyroid pathology in relationship to preoperative vit D levels.

Methods: A retrospective review of all patients with pHPT who underwent parathyroidectomy by two surgeons from 2001 to 2019 was performed. Patients were stratified into 3 groups based on their preoperative vit D levels; “low” (<20 ng/mL), “low-normal” (20-30 ng/mL), or “normal” (>30 ng/mL). Patient demographics, pre- and postoperative labs, and final parathyroid pathology were reviewed and compared amongst groups. Statistical analysis was performed using T-test and Chi-squared analysis, as appropriate. 

Results:Two-thousand two-hundred thirty patients were included in the analysis, the majority of which were female (78.1%) with a mean age of 59 years. Groups were stratified according to vit D levels: <20 (n=319), 20-30 (n=1,108), and >30 (n=803). Among patients with low vit D levels, there was a higher rate of males (31%) compared to those with normal vit D levels (16%, p=0.008). Patients with low vit D also had significantly higher preoperative PTH levels (161±9 pg/dL) compared to both the low-normal (128±3 pg/dL) and normal groups (113±5 pg/dL; p<0.001). Similarly, postoperative PTH levels were higher in the low vit D group (63±7 pg/dL) compared to low-normal (49±1 pg/dL) and normal groups (49±1 pg/dL; p<0.001). There was no difference in pre- or postoperative Ca levels amongst the 3 groups. Notably, when comparing pathologic diagnoses, patients with low vit D levels had a significantly higher frequency of a single adenoma (71%) compared to normal vit D group (62%; p<0.001). Hyperplastic glands were pathologically confirmed in fewer low vit D level patients (19%) compared to normal vit D level patients (25%). 

Conclusion:These large database retrospective results reveal a surprisingly increased association of low vit D levels with single-gland parathyroid disease instead of hyperplastic disease. Further investigation into the complex interplay between vit D levels and autonomous parathyroid function is warranted.

abstract_title: Assessing the impact of operative approach on outcomes among patients with pheochromocytoma
author_block: J. J. Hue<sup>1</sup>, C. Alvarado<sup>1</sup>, K. Bachman<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Wilhelm<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Ammori<sup>1</sup>, C. W. Towe<sup>1</sup>, L. D. Rothermel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center,Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland, often managed with an adrenalectomy. Most of the literature focused on postoperative outcomes are from single institutions. The purpose of this study was to describe the outcomes of adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma. We hypothesize that minimally invasive approaches would be associated with improved short-term outcomes, and similar oncologic efficacy.

Methods:  Patients who underwent a resection for pheochromocytoma were identified in the National Cancer Database (2010 to 2016). Patients were categorized as minimally invasive adrenalectomy (MIA) or open adrenalectomy (OA). Short-term outcomes were compared, including positive margin, length of stay, unplanned 30-day readmission rate, and 90-day mortality rate. Long-term survival was assessed using the Kaplan-Meier estimate and a multivariable Cox model.

Results: Among 888 patients with pheochromocytoma, 532 patients (60%) underwent an adrenalectomy. There was an even distribution of tumors based on laterality. 50.7% of patients underwent an OA, 35.9% were laparoscopic, 7.6% were robotic, and 5.8% required conversion. The proportion of MIA did not increase during the study period (coef 0.01, p=0.63). Patients receiving MIA and OA were similar, except those who underwent OA had larger tumors (median 8.3 cm) relative to MIA (4.8 cm, p<0.001). Size was the only factor associated with MIA (relative to OA) in a multivariable model (OR 0.83, p<0.001)  OA was associated with longer length of stay relative to MIA (6 vs 3 days, p<0.001). There was no difference in the rates of positive margins (13.4% OA vs. 13.7% MIA, p=0.95), unplanned readmissions (4.3% vs. 2.2%, p=0.33), or 90-day mortalities (5.1% vs. 3.4%, p=0.60) based on operative approach. Median survival of all patients who underwent an adrenalectomy was approximately 12 years regardless of operative approach (p=0.23). For comparison, median survival of patients with a pheochromocytoma who did not undergo an adrenalectomy was 5.3 years. There was no association between overall survival and operative approach using a multivariable Cox analysis.

Conclusion: Among patients with pheochromocytoma, those with larger tumors were more likely to undergo an open adrenalectomy. With the exception of an increased length of stay, there were no differences in short- or long-term postoperative outcomes. These data suggest that tumor size and surgeon experience are the main drivers of operative approach. Surgeons may consider increased utilization of MIA, as over 50% of adrenalectomies in patients with pheochromocytomas are still being performed via an open approach.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Subtotal or Total Parathyroidectomy with Reimplantation for Secondary Hyperparathyroidism
author_block: R. Vetter<sup>3</sup>, J. Shank<sup>1</sup>, J. Hettenbaugh<sup>2</sup>, R. Mullane<sup>2</sup>, A. L. Fingeret<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Surgery,Omaha, NE, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Medicine,Omaha, NE, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Omaha, NE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Parathyroidectomy (PTx) is indicated for patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHP) of renal origin that persists despite medical management with calcimimetic therapy. Parathyroidectomy may be performed as subtotal gland excision, total gland excision, or total gland excision with reimplantation. We sought to determine whether extent of surgery with subtotal gland excision or total gland excision with reimplantation was associated with a difference in patient outcomes.  

Methods: We performed a single institution, retrospective cohort study of consecutive adult patients undergoing PTx for SHP of renal origin between January of 2017 and June of 2020. Inclusion criteria were patients with end stage renal disease on dialysis undergoing index PTx. Exclusion criteria included remedial parathyroidectomy, concurrent thyroidectomy and age less than 19 years. Data collected included extent of surgery, patient demographics, clinical variables including laboratory and pathologic analysis, length of hospital stay, complications including readmission, hungry bone syndrome, recurrent hyperparathyroidism, and reoperation, and transplant status. Data analysis was performed with Mann-Whitney U testing for continuous variables and Fisher’s exact for categorical variables.   

Results: Thirty patients were identified for inclusion, 25 (83.3%) with subtotal PTx and 5 (16.7%) with total PTx and reimplantation. There were no differences between the groups with regard to sex, ethnicity, preoperative serum calcium, parathyroid hormone (PTH), or vitamin D. Patients undergoing total PTx with reimplantation had a greater difference in their intraoperative PTH levels from baseline to final 2413pg/ml versus 1651pg/ml (p = 0.048) [Table 1]. There was no difference in parathyroid gland weight removed, length of stay, complication rate, recurrence, reoperation, mortality or transplant status. Patients with total PTx and reimplantation had significantly lower serum calcium levels on postoperative day 1 with 7.22mg/dL versus 8.17mg/dL (p = 0.022) and were more likely to be readmitted with hungry bone syndrome with 2 (8.6%) versus 3 (60%). In the subtotal PTx group, one patient had a myocardial infarction within 30 days of surgery and one patient had recurrence of SHP with PTH > 800. In the total PTx with reimplantation group one patient had temporary recurrent laryngeal nerve neuropraxia. Mean follow up was 23.5 months and did not differ between the groups.  

Conclusion: In this cohort of patients subtotal and total PTx with reimplantation have similar outcomes for patients with SHP of renal origin, though total parathyroidectomy and reimplantation is associated with a higher rate of readmission for hungry bone syndrome.

abstract_title: Disparities in Hospital Selection and Outcomes of Black Patients
author_block: E. S. Brooks<sup>4</sup>, J. K. Tong<sup>1</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>1</sup>, C. Wirtalla<sup>3</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>, C. W. Lancaster<sup>1</sup>, A. Ahn<sup>4</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Center For Surgery And Health Economics,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Black patients often use underperforming hospitals for their surgical care. Hospital selection may play a critical role in surgical disparities. Given increased hospital consolidation into health networks, we evaluated surgical outcomes based on hospital network affiliation and compared the use of networked hospitals by Black relative to White patients.

Methods: Using the Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project State Inpatient Database, we identified adult patients undergoing one of 10 operations in 10 states (2013-2016). Operations were classified as common: cholecystectomy, mastectomy, colon resection, inguinal femoral hernia, and small bowel resection or complex: esophagectomy, total gastrectomy, Whipple, hepatic lobectomy, and rectal resection. Hospitals were classified by network affiliation using the American Hospital Association survey. Hospitals were classified as non-networked (NNH), networked without a hub (NH-H) or with a hub (NH+H). The Hub Hospital (HH) was defined as the hospital that performed at least 75% of the total complex operations within a NH+H. Spoke hospitals represented the other hospitals within NH+H (SH). Logistic regression with covariates for adjustment was used to evaluate the odds of death or serious morbidity (DSM) by hospital type. In separate models, we also examined the likelihood of Black patients selecting each hospital type. Within the NH+H, we also evaluated the outcomes at HH and SH hospitals.

Results: Among 245,088 discharges, 123,087 (50.2%) occurred at NNH, 69,494 (28.4%) at a NH-H, and 52,507 (21.4%) at a NH+H. The overall rate of DSM was 15.1% with the highest percentage seen in NH-H (15.5%) and the lowest at NH+H (14.4%). Within NH+H, DSM was significantly lower at the HH than the SH (13.7% vs. 15.6%). The majority of Black patients were treated at NH (56.7%), with 37.7% treated at a NH+H. In unadjusted analysis, Black patients treated at a NH+H were more likely to be treated at SH than white patients (39.1% vs 35.0%). After adjustment for potential confounders, there was no difference in DSM between NNH and NH. Within NH, the odds of DSM were significantly lower at NH+H relative to NH-H. Within NH+H, the odds of DSM were significantly lower at HH than SH. Black patients were more likely than White patients to use NH+H than NH-H. Black patients were less likely to use HH when compared to White patients. See Table 1.

Conclusion: Network affiliation alone does not confer a quality advantage. However, care at NH+H is associated with improved outcomes. Black patients more often selected NH+H but were more likely to use the SH, and therefore, did not get the quality advantage. Improving hospital selection and increasing HH use among Black patients may help eradicate disparities.

abstract_title: A Targeted Alert Encouraging Best Practice Does Not Curb Potentially Excessive Opioid Prescribing
author_block: E. M. White<sup>1</sup>, A. Esposito<sup>1</sup>, S. Chilakamarry<sup>2</sup>, A. Chiu<sup>1</sup>, M. Freedman-Weiss<sup>1</sup>, P. S. Yoo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Evidence-based guidelines recommend that post-operative inpatients who require no opioids in the final 24 hours of their hospital admission should not be prescribed opioids at discharge. However, we noted that at our large academic medical center, 59.4% of patients meeting the no-opioid criteria were discharged with a prescription for an opioid. We present here a quality improvement initiative directed at this potential source of excess opioid prescribing.

Methods:  Over a 10-week pilot on two surgical inpatient units, a Best Practice Alert (BPA) was programmed in the electronic medical record. The BPA appeared when a provider attempted to sign a discharge prescription for an opioid for a patient who had not received opioids in the prior 24 hours. The provider could accept or disagree with the BPA; acceptance removed the opioid prescription while disagreement required typing a reason. Quantitative and qualitative data on providers’ interaction with the BPA was collected and summarized.

Results:  The BPA was seen by 41 different providers for 66 post-operative inpatients. The BPA was accepted in only 1 case, however that patient was ultimately discharged with a narcotic prescription from another provider. Reasons given for prescribing opioids largely fell into three categories (See Table): 1. General pain control (due to post-op status, admitting injury, or unspecified) 2. Anticipating increased pain at home due to increased mobility 3. Discontinuation of multimodal pain control that could not be continued at home  

Conclusion: A targeted BPA, designed to decrease opioid prescriptions at discharge for post-operative patients requiring no  opioids in the 24-hour pre-discharge period, did not appear to change prescriber behavior on its own. Current practice appears to be driven largely by beliefs that post-operative patients will have pain requiring opioids at home, either due to increased ambulation or merely due to their post-operative status. This suggests a need for additional prescriber education about the existing data and published guidelines that refute this belief. This study also identified that inpatients receiving multimodal pain control may represent a population for which these prescribing guidelines should be waived.

abstract_title: It Takes a Village: Strategies To Foster Surgeons' Pursuit of Basic Science Research
author_block: D. Livingston-Rosanoff<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Park<sup>1,3</sup>, E. Alagoz<sup>2</sup>, S. Thibeault<sup>1</sup>, A. Gibson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Wisconsin,Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Wisconsin Surgical Outcomes Research Program,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgeons have made many important contributions to basic science research and are in a unique position to innovate scientifically. However, the number of surgeons pursuing basic science research has been declining over the past 20 years. We sought to describe perceived barriers to surgeons’ pursuit of basic science research and identify interventions to mitigate these obstacles.

Methods: An online convenience sample survey was sent to chairs of academic general surgery departments and practicing surgeons involved in basic science research identified by NIH funding, membership in the Society for University Surgeons, and involvement in the Association of Academic Surgery. A subset of participants were interviewed about their experiences. Interviews were audio-recorded, transcribed, and uploaded to NVivo. Two coders iteratively developed a codebook and co-coded the data using inductive content analysis to identify relevant themes. All authors were involved in the higher-level analysis.

Results: Ninety-seven people responded to the online survey; 27 (29%) were departmental chairs. The initial survey identified lack of funding, clinical duties and lack of dedicated time for research as major barriers to basic science research. Nine practicing surgeons who had participated in basic science research as attendings, two early-career (<5y in practice), three mid-career (6-20y in practice), and four later career (>20y in practice) surgeons as well as three departmental chairs were interviewed. A common theme from both practicing surgeons and chairs was that while not everyone who wants to pursue basic science research will or can be successful, cultivation of highly motivated surgeon scientists is possible and worthwhile. Approaches to maximize the success of surgeon scientists mentioned by both groups included the surgeon having clear goals and timetables with specific plans for attaining funding as well as having multiple mentors for different aspects of their careers. Applying for funding early and often as well as limiting additional clinical or administrative responsibilities were important actions surgeons could take. Chairs described the usefulness of embedding early surgeon scientists in their scientific mentors’ labs in a “Post-Doc model” to facilitate scientific success. Basic science research must be a priority of the department and included in departmental budgets for surgeon scientists to be successful. Department chairs and surgical administration also have to actively support surgeon scientists to protect themselves from encroaching clinical and administrative demands.

Conclusions: While barriers to surgeons’ pursuit of basic science research exist, the surgeon scientist is a phenotype that can and should be fostered.  Successful development of basic science surgeon researchers requires focused dedication and commitment from both the surgeon as well as departmental leadership.

abstract_title: What if You Live Alone? Association of Social Support and Post-Op Care for Older Patients.
author_block: C. M. Sokas<sup>1</sup>, F. Hu<sup>1</sup>, M. Dalton<sup>1</sup>, M. Jarman<sup>1</sup>, Z. Cooper<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery & Public Health,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Post-acute care represents an area of significant health expenditure for older adults, and a growing body of research is focused on anticipating those who will need it and exploring alternate strategies, such as home care. The role of informal caregiving for older adults, by friends and family, is well-described in those with chronic illness such as dementia and cancer, yet little is known about the role of social support on post-operative outcomes after routine surgical procedures. We hypothesized that older patients who lived at home with others would be more likely to be discharged home after surgery than those who lived alone. 

Methods: Retrospective cohort study using the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program Geriatric Surgery Pilot Project that collected geriatric-specific data on patients from 33 hospitals between 2014-2018. Patients were included if 65 years or older, were living at home prior to surgery, underwent general or vascular surgery procedure with length of stay greater than or equal to 3 days and had known baseline functional status, living situation and discharge destination. The exposure of interest was living situation, defined as “lives at home with support (family/friends)” or “lives at home alone.” The primary outcome was discharge destination (home vs. post-acute care). Multivariate logistic regression adjusting for  pre-operative variables (age, sex, BMI, history of falls, use of mobility aid, cognitive impairment, case type) was used to determine the association between living situation and discharge destination. A second regression model included both pre- and post-operative variables (loss of independence, defined as new need of mobility aid and/or decline in functional status, length of stay, and composite major complications). 

Results: 9,339 patients met inclusion criteria. The average age of the cohort was 74.3 years and 52% were male. One-quarter (25.1%) of patients lived alone at home prior to surgery. Patients who lived alone were more likely to be independent (p<0.01). There was no difference in loss of independence after surgery. Nevertheless, patients who lived alone were more frequently discharged to post-acute care (20.2% vs. 10.7%, p<0.01). In adjusted analysis, patients who lived alone were two times more likely to be discharged to a post-acute care facility, whether controlling for pre-operative variables only or both pre- and post-operative variables (OR 2.0, CI: 1.7-2.3, OR 2.4, CI: 2.0-2.8) (Table 1). 

Conclusion: Living alone independently predicts discharge to post-acute care irrespective of postoperative functional status. These findings suggest that informal caregivers who live with older patients are providing post-acute care that is otherwise provided in facilities. More studies are needed to examine the impact of informal caregiving on outcomes and caregiver burden.

abstract_title: Rural Patient Perceptions on Post-Surgical Recovery: Healthcare, Community, and the Opioid Epidemic
author_block: J. Esplin<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Blumling<sup>2</sup>, J. Bleicher<sup>1,2</sup>, J. N. Cohan<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Savarise<sup>1</sup>, D. W. Wetter<sup>2</sup>, A. Sox-Harris<sup>3</sup>, K. A. Kaphingst<sup>2</sup>, L. C. Huang<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>Huntsman Cancer Institute At The University Of Utah,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>Stanford University,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Rural populations encounter many disparities in healthcare, including access to surgical care and pain management. Factors such as economic conditions and unique social structure play a role in perpetuating these disparities. While prior studies have documented challenges in rural access to surgery, the beliefs, perceptions, and experiences of rural patients have not been well-studied. The purpose of this qualitative study was to identify factors contributing to surgical health disparities in rural areas by analyzing barriers to post-operative recovery and access to healthcare.

Methods:  Semi-structured, qualitative interviews were conducted with a convenience sample of 30 adult participants from rural areas. Rurality was defined by Rural-Urban Commuting Area (RUCA) codes provided by the Rural Health Information Hub. All participants had recently undergone a general surgery operation. Interviews focused on participants’ experiences accessing healthcare and resources for postoperative recovery in a rural community, including the use of opioids for pain management. These interviews were completed within two months of surgery and lasted around 40 minutes. Interviews were transcribed verbatim and coded using content and thematic analysis.

Results: All participants interviewed commented on the quality of healthcare in their respective areas. Some enjoyed the trust developed through long-standing relationships with providers in their communities; however, most reported that that their local healthcare systems lacked resources. Participants described a lack of money, equipment, and/or provider knowledge as barriers to care. Following surgery, most participants preferred family support over community support during recovery, and several participants preferred to recover without help from others. Some patients worried about being seen while experiencing their condition or disease, as well as being stigmatized for having a condition or disease, citing instances where people thought they were attention-seeking or even faking. Regarding opioids, several participants reported difficulty keeping pain medication private from their community. Participants described family members and friends requesting or stealing medication, and some even reported break-ins for theft of opioids.

Conclusion: Future interventions aimed at improving access to and recovery from surgery for rural patients should take into account the unique perspectives of rural patients and their communities. Addressing the socioecological factors surrounding rural surgery patients such as surgeons, family, and community resources, will be key to improving postoperative recovery, including improved opioid stewardship.

abstract_title: Social Determinants of Health in Appalachian and Urban/Suburban Emergency General Surgery Patients
author_block: S. Wong<sup>1</sup>, H. Baselice<sup>2,3</sup>, E. Cooksey<sup>4</sup>, J. Caterino<sup>5</sup>, K. Rose<sup>6</sup>, G. Brock<sup>2,7</sup>, H. P. Santry<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,College Of Medicine,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University,Center For Surgical Health Assessment, Research, And Policy (SHARP),Columbus, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio State University,Department Of Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>Ohio State University,Center For Human Resource Research,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>5</sup>Ohio State University,Department Of Emergency Medicine,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>6</sup>Ohio State University,College Of Nursing,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>7</sup>Ohio State University,Department Of Biomedical Informatics,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Social determinants of health (SDH) play a role in outcomes for life-threatening intra-abdominal emergencies and necrotizing soft-tissue infections (NSTIs). We hypothesized that rural Appalachian residents requiring emergency general surgery (EGS) would have more adverse SDH and worse outcomes compared to urban/suburban counterparts.

Methods:  We prospectively enrolled patients (>18) undergoing EGS at an urban quaternary care hospital in proximity to N. Central Appalachia. Sociodemographic characteristics (age, race, sex, education-level, insurance), psychosocial variables (social support, self-efficacy), and functional status (instrumental activities of daily living) seven days prior to presentation were assessed from patients/proxies. Length of stay (LOS) among survivors was recorded. Differences between Appalachian and urban/suburban Ohio residents were measured using appropriate tests of association.

Results: Between September 2019 and July 2020, we enrolled 21 EGS patients from Appalachian and 33 from urban/suburban Ohio. Appalachian patients were more likely to be age ≤64 (89% vs. 59%, p=0.03), white (95% vs. 73%, p=0.03), and lacking college education (71% vs. 22%, p=0.02). Though not statistically significant, they were more often male (62% vs. 45%), Medicaid-insured (45% vs. 21%), and suffering NSTI (38% vs. 27%). Appalachian patients were somewhat more likely to have lower social support (42% vs. 16%, p=0.04), functional status (60% vs. 14%, p=0.06), and self-efficacy (50% vs. 16%, p=0.06). Excluding 13% who died overall, Appalachian residents had longer median LOS (10 [8,16] vs. 9.5 [6.5,20.5] days, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Rural Appalachian residents experience longer hospitalizations for EGS than urban/suburban residents. Further research is warranted to identify opportunities for regional and health system-level changes to address the adverse SDH that may lead to this outcomes disparity.

abstract_title: Impact of Preoperative Mobility on Discharge Disposition in Older Adults undergoing Emergency Surgery
author_block: F. Y. Hu<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Sokas<sup>1</sup>, M. Jarman<sup>1</sup>, Z. Cooper<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery & Public Health,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Older adults undergoing emergency surgery have longer hospital lengths of stay than their elective counterparts. Identifying those at highest risk for discharge to a post-acute care facility would improve postoperative planning and facilitate earlier discharge. We sought to examine the role of preoperative cognitive and functional status on discharge destination in older adults receiving emergency surgery. We hypothesize that preoperative mobility is most strongly associated with non-home discharge in older adults following emergency surgery.

Methods:  Using data collected from 33 hospitals participating in the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program Geriatric Surgery Pilot Project between 2014-2018, we conducted a retrospective cohort study to examine discharge destination in adults 65 years or older undergoing inpatient emergency surgery. Multivariate logistic regression determined the association between preoperative variables and discharge to a non-home destination (i.e., rehab facility, skilled care facility), with the inclusion of geriatric-specific variables (i.e, living situation prior to admission, cognitive impairment, consent signed by surrogate, fall within the past year, preoperative use of mobility aid, and preoperative functional status).

Results: We included 3,494 patients, of whom 1,882 (53.9%) were discharged to a non-home destination. Patients discharged to post-acute care facilities were older (80.5 years vs 75.8 years, p<0.0001) and more frequently ASA class 4 or 5 (31.9% vs 17.4%, p<0.0001). In multivariate analysis adjusting for age, sex, race, ASA, and BMI, fall within the past year was most strongly associated with non-home discharge (OR 5.3, 95% CI 4.4-6.5, c-statistic=0.81). Non-home discharge was also independently associated with partially dependent functional status before surgery (OR 1.9, 95% CI 1.4-2.6) and preoperative use of a mobility aid (OR 2.0, 95% CI 1.7-2.5) (Table 1).

Conclusion: Fall within the past year, preoperative use of a mobility aid, and partially dependent functional status increase the risk of non-home discharge in older patients undergoing emergency surgery. This information may be used for early identification of older adults who need post-acute care to set patient and family expectations and expedite discharge planning.

abstract_title: Financial Toxicity Among Surgical Patients: An Analysis of the National Health Interview Survey
author_block: K. K. Taylor<sup>1,5,6</sup>, P. U. Neiman<sup>1,5,7</sup>, J. W. Scott<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Center For Healthcare Outcomes & Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of General Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Michigan,National Clinician Scholars Program,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>6</sup>Stanford University,Department Of General Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>7</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Department Of General Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is an increasing awareness of the negative financial consequences of surgical care on patients, often described in relation to out-of-pocket payments. However, the financial impact of surgery likely extends beyond direct payments, and may affect subsistence spending such as the ability to pay for food, housing, and other medical care. This study aims to quantify these broader financial consequences.

Methods: We analyzed a nationally representative sample of adults (age >18 years) from 2014-2017 using the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS), an in-person cross-sectional household survey. Patients who reported undergoing surgery in the past 12 months were compared to those who did not. We evaluated for differences in medical debt and measures related to subsistence spending. We used multivariable logistic regression to adjust for age, gender, race, employment status, income, education, marital status, number of dependents, insurance type, region, number of hospitalizations, and year. A subgroup analysis of surgical patients aged 18-64 years was performed to evaluate the financial outcomes by insurance coverage.

Results: The NHIS included 130,163 respondents in the adult sample (weighted 423 million), 16,717 (13%) of whom reported having surgery in the past year (weighted 53 million). Compared to the non-surgical cohort, risk-adjusted analyses revealed that surgical patients were more likely to report problems paying medical bills, delaying medical care due to cost, and altering medication doses to save money; as well as worry about running out of food each month and paying for housing (Table). Compared to privately insured nonelderly adults, those with Medicaid were less likely to report problems paying medical bills (adjusted odds ratio (aOR) of 0.6 (95% CI 0.5-0.7)), while uninsured patients were more than twice as likely to do so (aOR of 2.6 (95% CI 2.0-3.3)).

Conclusion: Nearly one in five surgical patients report problems paying medical bills. Moreover, surgery is associated with significant long-term financial consequences that extend beyond payment for the operation. The results of this nationally representative survey demonstrate that those who undergo surgery within the past year are at an increased risk of reporting difficulty with subsistence spending, controlling for demographics and number of hospitalizations. Insurance coverage appears to provide some risk protection among surgical patients, however privately insured nonelderly adults report worse financial toxicity than those enrolled in Medicaid. Improving financial risk protection after surgery should be a policy priority to mitigate the financial toxicity which may have a long-lasting and far-reaching impact on patients’ lives.

abstract_title: Postoperative Opioid Prescribing Patterns in the Geriatric Patient Population
author_block: J. M. Dias<sup>2</sup>, S. Zaveri<sup>1</sup>, C. Divino<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai Hospital,Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Treating postoperative pain in geriatric patients can be complex in lieu of age-related physiologic changes, presence of comorbidities and polypharmacy management. It is a common misconception that elderly patients experience pain as part of the aging process, which may lead to undertreatment of pain. There is a lack of consensus regarding ideal postoperative pain control measures, and opioid prescription patterns in elderly patients undergoing general surgery are not well characterized. The purpose of this study is to identify trends in postoperative opioid prescriptions in geriatric patients following common general surgery procedures and determine differences between opioid prescribing in geriatric and non-geriatric patients.

Methods: We retrospectively evaluated non-geriatric patients (18 to 64 years of age) and geriatric patients (greater than 65 years of age) undergoing the most frequently performed open and laparoscopic general surgery procedures at our institution from 2014 to 2019. Postoperative opioid prescriptions were quantified as milligrams (mg) of oxycodone for standardization. Differences in opioid prescriptions by age group and year of surgery were analyzed using the Kruskal-Wallis, Mann-Whitney U and Chi-square tests. Univariate and multivariate ordinal regression analyses were also completed to evaluate predictors of opioid prescribing in the geriatric population.

Results: Using the Institutional Data Warehouse, we identified 7,195 non-geriatric and 4,054 geriatrics patients who underwent the included procedures at our institution. Of those patients, 6,318 (87.8% of non-geriatric patients) and 3,122 (77.0% of geriatric patients) received a perioperative opioid prescription. Geriatric patients were significantly less likely to receive an opioid prescription (p<0.001), but amongst those who received opioids, the amount prescribed did not vary significantly between geriatric and non-geriatric patients (p=0.558). Within the geriatric population, pairwise comparisons between older and younger geriatric patients showed that prescription amounts were significantly higher in patients aged 65-74 (145 mg ± 72.3, Mean ± SD) compared to patients aged 75-85 (138 mg ± 56.3, p=0.006), and 85 or older (134 mg ± 56.7, p=0.002). Compared to 2019, the amount prescribed in the geriatric population decreased significantly each year between 2014-2019 (p<0.001). Adjusted multivariate analysis showed that male gender (p<0.001), younger age (p<0.001), length of stay greater than four days (p=0.035), and open procedures (p=0.025) predicted higher prescription amounts in the geriatric population.

Conclusion: Reduced opioid prescription over time in the geriatric population reflect trends seen in the non-geriatric adult population, likely as a result of the opioid epidemic. Postoperative opioid prescribing patterns differ in geriatric and non-geriatric patient populations, and warrant further investigation.

abstract_title: Making it Complicated: Does Disparity in Access to Care Lead to More Perforated Appendicitis?
author_block: J. B. Estrella<sup>3</sup>, H. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, Q. W. Myers<sup>2</sup>, S. Lee<sup>3</sup>, C. G. Velopulos<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Division Of GI, Trauma, And Endocrine Surgery (GITES),Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Clinical Research Office, Department Of Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,School Of Medicine,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Appendectomies comprise a high proportion of the national burden of emergency general surgery. Delays in obtaining medical care lead to increased rates of perforated appendicitis, increasing risk of morbidity and mortality. We previously explored the role of social determinants in patients undergoing cholecystectomy, finding that emergent presentation and more complicated disease are associated with disparities in both individual patient factors and neighborhood social vulnerability index (SVI). We hypothesize that social determinants also account for increased incidence of perforated appendicitis. 

Methods:  We retrospectively identified patients presenting to our urban, academic hospital with acute appendicitis during a 9-month timeframe (11/2019 – 7/2020), extracting demographics, diagnostic findings, and treatment from our electronic medical record. Patients were classified as perforated or non-perforated and assigned a grade per the AAST grading system to further define disease severity. For patients with multiple presentations managed non-operatively during, only the index presentation was used. Neighborhood SVI for patients was determined using geocoding at the census tract level. Because rates of perforation were higher in older patients, we performed a subset analysis of patients ≥ 40 years.

Results: 202 patients were treated for appendicitis; of these, 190 patients had an in-state address that could be geocoded and were included in analysis. Patients with perforated appendicitis (n=48, 25%) were older and were more likely to initially present to a clinic versus the ED (p=0.009). Perforated patients also had longer delay before seeking care (56% vs. 6% with >72 hours of symptoms, p<0.001). However, there were no differences between groups in terms of sex, race/ethnicity, insurance type, language barrier, having a primary care physician, or any of the SVI subscales. There were also no differences in these social determinants according to AAST severity. Of patients ≥ 40 years, a higher proportion were perforated (28/80, 35%) despite similar rates of delayed care. In this cohort, higher overall SVI as well as the socioeconomic status and household composition/disability subscales were associated with higher risk of perforation.

Conclusion: Contrary to our hypothesis, while perforation was associated with delayed care in this population, we did not find overall that social vulnerability or individual social determinants accounted for this delay. In contrast to our previous study of cholecystectomy, appendectomy does not have an elective component for the index case, thus delays in care for truly emergent surgical disease appear to be related to disease presentation rather than systemic disparities.

abstract_title: Appendiceal Cancer Presenting as Acute Appendicitis: A Clinical Prediction Model Using ACS-NSQIP
author_block: R. Atwood<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Bradley<sup>1</sup>, S. Blair<sup>2</sup>, C. Rodriguez<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Walter Reed National Military Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>John Peter Smith Health Network,Department Of Surgery,Fort Worth, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The risk of underlying cancer as the cause of acute appendicitis is not inconsequential and should be considered when offering non-surgical management. Therefore, we sought to develop a predictive algorithm to classify appendectomy cases that are high risk of appendiceal cancer. 

Methods:  We developed a predictive model utilizing the American College of Surgeons Appendectomy Procedure Targeted NSQIP data for patients with acute appendicitis between 2016-2017. Patient characteristics and pre-operative factors were identified as candidate predictors. A subset of predictors was selected using regularized logistic regression, applying the least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (Lasso) to minimize prediction error. Discrimination and calibration were assessed using 200 bootstrapped samples. To explore temporal generalizability, we refit the model using only 2016 data and assessed validity in 2017 data.

Results: Of 24,438 patients who had pathology proven appendicitis, 381 (1.6%) had appendiceal cancer. The Lasso model selected Age and WBC as predictors, which were fit to develop a percent risk nomogram (Figure 1). The prediction model resulted in an index-corrected c-statistic of 0.75 and near-perfect calibration slope (~1.00). Classification of high risk was based on a threshold value using Youden’s index of 0.02, which balances false positive and true positive rates. In the 2017 data, the c-statistic increased to 0.76, while the calibration slope increased to 1.09.

Conclusion: Predictive modeling allowed for the development of a tool to identify patients at risk for appendiceal cancer using only Age and WBC with satisfactory discrimination. The nomogram is a practical tool that may assist in clinical decision making.

abstract_title: Effect of Policy-Based and Institutional Interventions on Postoperative Opioid Prescribing Practices
author_block: A. A. Doyle<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Titan<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Pfaff<sup>1</sup>, I. Baiu<sup>1</sup>, A. Lee<sup>2</sup>, L. A. Graham<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Shelton<sup>1</sup>, M. T. Hawn<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Department Of Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Washington University,Department Of Surgery,St. Louis, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Of the more than 10 million Americans who admit to abusing opioids, many are first exposed postoperatively. To prevent excessive prescribing, California implemented CURES (Controlled Substance Utilization, Review and Evaluation System) program, which restricts new opioid prescriptions. To combat opioid prescribing variability, our institution developed prescribing guidelines. This study aimed to investigate outcomes associated with both CURES implementation and our institutional guidelines on opioid prescribing practices.  

Methods: We compared opioid prescribing at discharge from surgery at our institution for 3 periods: Jan-Mar 2018 (pre-CURES), Jan-Mar 2019 (post-CURES/pre-Intervention), and Jan-Mar 2020 (post-Intervention) across 4 procedures. We investigated the number and type of opioids prescribed, oral morphine equivalents (OMEs) at discharge, prescribing of adjuncts, and change in outpatient refill requests. For the post-intervention period, we conducted a mixed-methods patient survey to further assess patient satisfaction concerning pain management.  

Results: Comparing pre-CURES (n=93) with post-CURES (n=110), we identified a significant decrease in mean opioid tabs prescribed (24.5, SD 7.7 vs. 15.0, SD 7.2, p<0.001) and mean OME dosage (153.6, SD 98.4 vs. 100.0, SD 55.3, p <0.001) at discharge. After our institutional intervention (n=144), there was a significant decrease in mean number of tabs prescribed (15.0, SD 7.2  vs 10.0, SD 4.6, p <0.001) and in mean OME dosage prescribed and variability (100.0, SD 55.3 vs. 96.6, SD 34.8, p=0.04). Mean post-intervention prescribing achieved the recommended number of tabs (10 tabs). The number of refills did not differ significantly between any of the 3 periods. Patient survey results (n=62; 60% response rate) found that 88.7% of patients reported their pain was sufficiently controlled following surgery. 56.7% of patients reported having leftover opioids and 95.2% of patients felt they did not need an opioid refill. Qualitative responses indicate lack of knowledge of opioid disposal and lack of desire to use opioids for pain management.  

Conclusion: Formalized opioid-prescribing guidelines and statewide prescribing regulations can significantly decrease postoperative opioids while maintaining patient satisfaction. These findings support data from other specialties that reductions in opioid use are not associated with changes in pain scores. Surgeon education may further minimize narcotic over-prescription without compromising pain management and reduce the number of circulating opioids among the population at large.

abstract_title: National Trends in Operative Management of Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infection in Safety-Net Hospitals
