This excludes law-enforcement related homicides. For the autopsy and law enforcement summary narratives, a preliminary 10% random sample was coded using grounded theory to discover themes amenable to interventions. Trends of patient demographics, illicit substance use, homicide causes and circumstances, and attempts at resuscitation were identified.

Results: A total of 473 cases of violent deaths while incarcerated were recorded over 14 years. Mean age was 39.6±14.0 years, 99% were men, and 37.2% were Black, compared to 55.4% White and 11.6% Hispanic or Latinx (p < 0.001). Of inmates who were murdered, 8.9% had a current mental health diagnosis, and 1.7% had a history of alcohol use disorder. Gang violence-related homicide occurred in 7.2%, with no significant difference between races (p=0.24). An argument preceded the homicide in 29.8% of cases whereas the victim was a bystander 18.8% of the time. Primary manner of violent death was by blunt force (28.1%), followed by penetrating trauma (23.7%) and hanging/strangulation or suffocation (23.3%). Only 34.5% of victims were transported to the Emergency Department.

Conclusion: NVDRS homicides while incarcerated averaged at 33 deaths/year. Black men are overrepresented as incarcerated homicides compared to population demographics, with similar rates of mental illness and gang-related violence. Only 1 in 3 victims were transported to the Emergency Department for urgent care prior to dying.

abstract_title: The Short and the Long of it: Timing of Mortality in a State Trauma System
author_block: E. J. Kaufman<sup>1</sup>, A. Zebrowski<sup>3</sup>, D. J. Wiebe<sup>2</sup>, D. N. Holena<sup>1,2</sup>, B. G. Carr<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine,Division Of Traumatology, Surgical Critical Care, And Emergency Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Biostatistics And Epidemiology,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine,Department Of Emergency Medicine,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The impact of injury extends beyond the hospital stay, but trauma centers performance metrics typically focus on in-hospital mortality. We compared risk adjusted rates of in-hospital and long-term mortality among Pennsylvania trauma centers. We hypothesized that centers with low rates of in-hospital mortality would also have low rates of long-term mortality.

Methods: We identified injured patients age ≥ 65 admitted to Pennsylvania trauma centers, 2013-2014 using the Pennsylvania Trauma Outcomes Study, a robust, state-wide trauma registry. We used probabilistic matching with supervised machine learning to link trauma registry records to Medicare claims. Matching variables were injury date, patient demographics, and injury characteristics. Outcomes were inpatient, 30-day, and 1-year mortality. Multivariable logistic regression models were developed to calculate expected mortality rates for each trauma center at each time point. Center performance was assessed using observed-to-expected ratios. Models included presenting physiology, comorbidities, injury characteristics, and demographics. Center-level ranks for in-hospital, 30-day, and 1-year mortality were compared using Spearman’s rho.

Results: We included 15,451 patients at 28 centers. Median, unadjusted in-hospital mortality was 6.4% (interquartile range [IQR] 4.5-7.6%). There were 3 high outliers and 2 low outliers for in-hospital mortality. Median 30-day mortality was 11.1% (IQR 10.3-12.4%). Just 46.3% of those who died within 30 days died in the hospital. There were 0 low and 1 high outlier, also an outlier for in-hospital mortality. The correlation between in-hospital and 30-day mortality ranks was 0.7. Median 1-year mortality was 26.1% (IQR 24.0-28.8%). There were 0 low and 7 high outliers, including 2 of the 3 high outliers for in-hospital and 30-day mortality. The correlation between in-hospital and 1-year mortality ranks was 0.4.

Conclusion: Nearly half of injured older adults who die within 30 days of injury do so after hospital discharge. Hospital rankings for in-hospital mortality correlate poorly with long term outcomes, underscoring the importance of looking past survival to discharge for quality improvement and benchmarking.

abstract_title: Fibrinogen Concentrate In Massively Transfused Patients: Is There a Potential Benefit?
author_block: N. Pollack<sup>1</sup>, S. Asmar<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, M. Khurrum<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, M. Chehab<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, B. Joseph<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burn And Emergency Surgery/Department Of Surgery/College Of Medicine,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fibrinogen concentrate (FC) was developed for the treatment of inherited and acquired coagulopathies. The role of FC in massively transfused (MT) trauma patients is still speculative. Our study aims to assess the role of FC as an adjunct to MT in trauma patients.

Methods:  We performed a 2015-2017 analysis of the ACS-TQIP database and included all adult (age ≥ 18 years) trauma patients who received a MT (>10pRBCs/24-hour) excluding those with cryoprecipitate transfusion. Patients were stratified into two groups based on receipt of FC within the first 24-hours (FC vs. No-FC). Outcome measures were blood products transfused, in-hospital complications, and mortality. Multivariate logistic and linear regression analyses were performed along with a Kaplan-Meyer survival curve. 

Results: We analyzed a total of 593,818 trauma patients, of whom 4,510 (FC: 229; No-FC: 4,281) were included in our analysis. Mean age was 40±20 years, median ISS was 29 [20-41], and GCS was 10 [3-15]. Overall volume of pRBCs transfused in the first 24-hours was 14 [11-19] units, plasma was 9 [6-13] units, and platelets were 2 [1-3] units. The overall complication rate was 44%, mortality was 43%, and 31% of the patients died in the first 24 hours. Patients in the FC group received a lower volume of plasma (p<0.01) and pRBCs (p<0.01). Additionally, patients who received FC had lower rates of 24-hrs mortality (p<0.01) and in-hospital mortality (p<0.01). However, there was no difference between the two groups regarding complications (p=0.67), or volume of platelets transfused (p=0.11). Table 1 On logistic regression, the use of FC was associated with decreased 24-hrs mortality (OR: 0.78 [0.67-0.93], p=0.01) and decreased in-hospital mortality (OR: 0.89 [0.70-0.96], p=0.01), but was not associated with in-hospital complications (OR: 1.57 [0.81-1.94], p=0.62). On linear regression, the use of FC was not associated with 24-hr pRBCs (β= -0.07[-0.12 to 0.88], p=0.16), 24-hr plasma (β= 0.46[-3.88 to 4.81], p=0.83), and 24-hr platelets transfusions (β= 1.27[-1.49 to 4.04], p=0.36). Overall survival improved in the FC group. 

Conclusion: The use of FC as an adjunct to MT may reduce mortality without affecting in-hospital complications and transfusion requirements. Further studies are needed to understand its potentially beneficial effects in massively transfused patients.

abstract_title: Whole Blood in Trauma Resuscitation: What is the Real Cost?
author_block: K. Bush<sup>1</sup>, L. Shea<sup>2</sup>, J. San Roman<sup>2</sup>, E. Pailloz<sup>3</sup>, J. Gaughan<sup>4</sup>, A. Goldenberg-Sandau<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Cooper Medical School of Rowan University,Camden, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Cooper University Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Camden, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>Cooper University Hospital,Department Of Pathology,Camden, NJ, USA <sup>4</sup>Cooper University Hospital,Cooper Research Institute,Camden, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Whole blood has gained popularity as a means of trauma resuscitation within the past 5 years. Historically the military has utilized whole blood since World War I and most recently during the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. However, its overall use has diminished due to technological advances in blood component fractionation as well as fears of hemolysis and infectious disease transmission. Although there are studies and review articles on the efficacy of whole blood, the analysis of cost pertaining to whole blood’s expense is limited.

Methods: We performed a retrospective 1:1 case control study of 280 subjects comparing trauma patients receiving resuscitation with blood component therapy to those receiving whole blood plus component therapy between January 2014 and July 2019. Patient matching was completed based on age, sex, injury severity score (ISS), and mechanism of injury (MOI) (blunt vs. penetrating). Endpoints included the number of units of whole blood (WB), packed red blood cells (PRBCs), fresh frozen plasma (FFP), platelets, and cryoprecipitate each patient received. Data analysis utilized ratios of price for each unit where PRBCs=1, WB=1.24, FFP=0.2, platelets=2.27, and cryoprecipitate=1.21. Due to proprietary nature of the cost of individual blood components, absolute price numbers are not included here.  Comparisons were made with Wilcoxon two sample ranked sum tests with a p-value of <0.05 deemed to be statistically significant.

Results: There is a statistically significant decrease in the number of units PRBCs used in WB patients compared to component therapy. There is also a statistically significant decrease in the cost of PRBCs when price is controlled.  FFP, platelet, and cryoprecipitate use showed an absolute decrease in units used (Table 1), but did not yield statistical significance. Total cost is decreased from 16.79 cost units to 11.70 in whole blood recipients as well (p=0.1660).

Conclusion: Red blood cell use and cost is decreased when adding whole blood to component therapy for trauma resuscitation. Utilizing whole blood decreases absolute total cost as well as absolute cost of FFP, platelets, and cryoprecipitate. A larger, prospective study is needed to increase the subject size and determine additional statistical significance.

abstract_title: Efficacy of Noninvasive Measurements in Triaging TBI and Correlation with ICP: A Prospective Study
author_block: T. E. Wallen<sup>1</sup>, T. Jalbert<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Singer<sup>1</sup>, D. Wakefield<sup>1</sup>, A. Spuzzillo<sup>1</sup>, S. Sharma<sup>2</sup>, V. Heh<sup>1</sup>, B. Foreman<sup>2</sup>, M. D. Goodman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Trauma/General Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Cincinnati,Neurology,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in military and civilian populations. There is increasing interest in noninvasive testing, including pupillometry, ultrasonographic transcranial Dopplers (TCD), and optic nerve sheath diameter (ONSD), to aid in diagnosing TBI in far forward limited resource environments where advanced imaging is not available. Although these techniques have been used to estimate intracranial pressure (ICP) in patients with severe brain injury, whether these technologies can effectively assess for TBI or approximate ICP remains to be elucidated. We hypothesized that noninvasive testing including ONSD, pupillometry, and TCD could both accurately distinguish severe TBI and correlate to ICP. 

Methods:  A prospective observational study of 135 patients was conducted at a level 1 trauma center over 36 months. Four groups were enrolled based on clinical examination and head CT findings: nontrauma patients who required ICP monitoring (n=39), trauma patients without TBI (n=30), trauma patients with mild TBI (n=30), and trauma patients with severe TBI requiring ICP monitoring (n=36). All patients underwent bilateral daily measurements of ONSD using L12-3 linear array transducer, pupillometry using NeurOptics pupillometer, and TCD with both CX50 SONOSITE and Spencer ST3 Yi Pencil probe for three consecutive days post-injury.

Results: ONSD differed significantly between patient groups.  The mean ± standard deviation of ONSD was 0.57±0.9 cm for severe TBI patients, compared to 0.49±0.1 cm and 0.47±0.08 cm for mild and no-TBI on post-injury day 2 (p<0.01) but did not correlate with ICP. Pupillometric constriction velocity, dilation velocity and percent change in pupil diameter were significantly different in the severe TBI patients on postinjury days 1 and 2, but did not correlate with ICP (Table). TCD measurements were similar between severe TBI patients and those with mild or no-TBI, but middle cerebral artery (MCA) peak systolic velocity, MCA flow velocity, and carotid flow velocity, did correlate with ICP on Pearson analysis (Table). 

Conclusion: Non-invasive screening methods including ONSD and pupillometry reliably discern patients with severe TBI as early as the first day post-injury. In contrast, TCD may correlate with ICP. These technologies have not been validated as a replacement for radiologic or invasive methods of diagnosing and managing TBI. However, these methods show promise for use in far forward, low-resource environments, as a supplementary screening tool for severe TBI, and pragmatic validation is warranted.

abstract_title: Propensity Match Comparison of Geriatric and Non-Geriatric Traumatic Brain Injury Trauma Transfers.
author_block: S. Viitaniemi<sup>1</sup>, N. Menzione<sup>1</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,2</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1,3</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4</sup> <sup>2</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FLORIDA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Advanced age is a recognized risk factor for disability and mortality in trauma patients, especially in the cases of traumatic brain injury (TBI). Currently, publications detailing the outcomes in geriatric patients diagnosed with a TBI following an inter-facility transfer are rare. Therefore, the goal was to analyze differences in clinical characteristics, management and outcomes of geriatric (≥65 y.o.) and non-geriatric TBI patients transferred from an Acute Care Facility (ACF) to a level 1 Trauma Center (TC).

Methods:  This retrospective study included 1118 TBI patients following a transfer from ACF to TC (2016 - 2019). There were 798 geriatric patients (GP) and 320 non-geriatric patients (NGP). To ensure comparability in the severity of trauma, 317 GP and 317 NGP were matched (without replacement) by Injury Severity Score and Head Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS). Analyzed variables included: demographics, pre-injury anticoagulation, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), rates of blood transfusions, repeat head CT, craniotomies, transfer timing, Intensive Care Unit (ICU) admission and length of stay (ICULOS), hospital LOS (HLOS), discharge disposition, complication, and mortality.

Results: GP had twice the mean age of NGP (82 vs 45 years), were mostly female (57% vs 30%), had more comorbidities (94% vs 70%) and higher anticoagulation use (54% vs 9%), all p<0.001. Both groups had similar GCS of 14. GP had higher rates of blood transfusions (32% vs 13%) and repeat CT scans (94% vs 86%), both p<0.001. In GP, especially patients ≥75 years old, 61% did not undergo craniotomy due to terminal bleeding or presence of advanced directives. There was no statistically significant difference between transfer times from ACF to TC (3.9 hours), ICULOS (3 days in both), HLOS (4 vs 5 days), or complications (13% vs 12%), all p>0.1. TC discharge disposition was different between groups, with GP having statistically higher discharge to hospice (8% vs 1%, p<0.001). GP had higher ICU admissions (57% vs 46%, p=0.003) and mortality (10% vs 3%, p=0.001) [Fig 1].

Conclusion: Geriatric TBI patients constituted twice the amount of non-geriatric patients transferred from an Acute Care Facility to a Trauma Center. GP had higher rates of blood product transfusions, anticoagulant use, ICU admissions, and more than 3 times higher morality than NGP. Based on the prevalence of anticoagulation therapy and higher mortality in GP, we recommend geriatric patients with suspected TBI be considered for direct transportation to TC.

abstract_title: Can Social Vulnerability Indices Predict Trauma Fatality Rates?
author_block: H. M. Phelos<sup>1</sup>, A. Deeb<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Brown<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh,Department Of Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Social vulnerability indices were created to measure regional resiliency to environmental disasters based on several socioeconomic and population characteristics of a discrete geographic region. They contain multiple validated constructs that may also identify geographically vulnerable populations after traumatic injury. Our objective was to determine if these indices correlate with injury fatality rates in the US.  

Methods: We evaluated two social vulnerability indices: The Hazards & Vulnerability Research Institute's Social Vulnerability Index (SoVI) and the CDC’s Social Vulnerability Index (SVI). We also analyzed SVI sub-indices the make up the composite score (socioeconomic status, disabled populations, minority populations, and housing & transport status). These indices are composite scores calculated at the county-level and transformed into percentile ranks for all US counties, ranging from 0 to 100 where larger values indicate greater social vulnerability. Outcomes included age-adjusted county-level overall, firearm, and motor vehicle collision (MVC) deaths per 100,000 population. Linear regression determined the association of injury fatality rates each index. Bivariate choropleth mapping identified variation and spatial autocorrelation of all-cause fatality and SoVI. 

Results: 3,137 US counties were included. SoVI and SVI were moderately correlated with each other (+0.48). Despite this, both indices were associated with increasing fatality rates for overall (SoVI 0.28; 95%CI 0.25-0.30, p<0.01; SVI 0.26; 95%CI 0.23-29, p<0.01), firearm (SoVI 0.08; 95%CI 0.07-0.09, p<0.01; SVI 0.09; 95%CI 0.09-0.10, p<0.01), and MVC deaths (SoVI 0.11; 95%CI 0.10-0.13, p<0.01; SVI 0.14; 95%CI 0.13-0.15, p<0.01). Among SVI sub-indices, disabled population was the strongest predictor of overall injury fatalities (0.34; 95%CI 0.32-0.37, p<0.01) and MVC fatalities (0.18; 95%CI 0.17-0.19, p<0.01). Socioeconomic sub-index was the strongest predictor of firearm fatalities (0.11; 95%CI 0.10-0.12, p<0.01). There is significant geographic variation in both SoVI and injury fatality rates at the county-level across the US (Fig 1), with moderate spatial autocorrelation of SoVI (Moran's I 0.35, p<0.01) and high autocorrelation of injury fatality rates (Moran's I 0.77, p<0.01). 

Conclusion: Although SoVI and SVI are not interchangeable, higher social vulnerability is associated with higher injury fatality rates in both indices. These social vulnerability indices may be useful in the epidemiologic and geographic assessment of trauma-related fatality rates. Further study is warranted to determine if these indices outperform traditional measures of socioeconomic status and related constructs used in the trauma research.

abstract_title: Trauma Transport in Rural America
author_block: J. Woodard<sup>1</sup>, J. Warwick<sup>2</sup>, A. Bernard<sup>2</sup>, J. Coughenour<sup>1</sup>, J. Quick<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Missouri,Surgery,Columbia, MO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Kentucky,Surgery,Lexington, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Injury pattern, resource availability, and distance to tertiary care contribute to mortality rates of injured patients in rural America. We aimed to examine the effects of prehospital time and distance, on trauma outcomes in the rural setting.

Methods: Following IRB approval, we performed a 10-year retrospective review of trauma registry data from the Universities of Missouri and Kentucky. We collected and calculated demographics, transport, injury severity and illness data, as well as hospital and discharge characteristics. Predictions were determined by univariate and multivariate regression, in addition to standard statistical evaluation, to identify differences in outcomes based on transport time.

Results: 32,869 patient records (mean age 47.8±20.5 yrs) were reviewed. Median transport distance was 33.6 miles by air, and 42.4 miles by ground. Median transport time was 125 minutes, with 56.1% reaching the trauma center within 2 hours of injury. When controlling for distance, blunt trauma patients had longer transport times than those with penetrating injuries (7.2 min/mile vs 4.9 min/mile, p <0.0001). Shorter transport times were predictive of worse shock indices, injury severity scores, and mortality. Patients transported between 2-3 hours (10.7%) were most likely worsen prior to arrival (p 0.001), based on increasing Revised Trauma Scores from scene to admission. Patients transported in the 2-3-hour window were also most likely to require prehospital blood products (77%), ICU admission (27.8%), and operation (77%), and had the second highest mortality(6.8%) following those arriving within an hour (8.5%). Figure 1.

Conclusion: Most severely injured patients were transported to definitive care within 2 hours. However, patients whose transport was delayed up to 3 hours, had significantly elevated risk to require escalated care. An opportunity exists to improve transport time for these patients.

abstract_title: Do Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors Increase Nonunion Rates Following Long Bone Fractures? ?
author_block: S. Bhattacharjee<sup>1</sup>, H. Seidel<sup>1</sup>, S. Pirkle<sup>1</sup>, L. L. Shi<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Lee<sup>1</sup>, J. Strelzow<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Chicago,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are one of the most frequently prescribed classes of medication. Although this therapy was originally viewed as side effect free, particularly in comparison to its predecessors, it has been suggested that SSRIs may have additional systemic effects rather than those simply existing within the confines of the blood brain barrier. More recently, SSRIs have been implicated in altering the quality of bone mineral density and potentially the process of bony fusion. We sought to investigate the effects of preoperative SSRI use on long bone fracture healing.

Methods: This study was performed using the PearlDiver national orthopaedic insurance claims database. All patients with a diagnosis of a long bone shaft fracture of the humerus, femur, radius and/or ulna, or tibia and/or fibula were stratified based on their preoperative history of SSRI’s. A chronic SSRI cohort was created from all patients with both an active SSRI prescription filled within 3 months prior to, and additional prescriptions within 4-6 months prior to an index fracture diagnosis. An SSRI naïve cohort was created including patients without SSRI prescriptions within 6 months prior to the fracture diagnosis. The rate of nonunion within 18 months was assessed for all patients using identification of non-union procedure codes. Univariate and multivariate logistic regression analyses were performed for chronic preoperative SSRI use as well as other patient comorbidities on the outcome of nonunion repair procedures.

Results: 27,651 shaft fracture patients were identified. Of these, 4,065 were of the humerus, 6,005 of the radius and/or ulna, 4,770 of the femur, and 12,811 of the tibia and/or fibula. 4,634 (16.8%) of all patients had chronic preoperative SSRI prescriptions. In the univariate analyses, chronic preoperative SSRI prescriptions were significantly associated with increased rates of nonunion repair for each fracture subtype (Table 1). In the multivariate regression analyses, we observed a significant association between nonunion repair procedures and chronic preoperative SSRIs in humerus, femur, and radius and/or ulna shaft fracture populations.

Conclusion: Our findings suggest that preoperative SSRI prescriptions may be associated with higher rates of nonunion in patients with long bone shaft fractures. This represents an important step in gaining a better understanding of the potential effects this medication class may have on the fracture healing process. Closer follow-up in patients with these prescriptions may be warranted.

abstract_title: Improving Patient Satisfaction in Trauma: An Action Plan for Success
author_block: K. C. Kelley<sup>1</sup>, J. Cipolla<sup>1</sup>, R. Wilde-Onia<sup>1</sup>, A. Benton<sup>1</sup>, J. Stoudt<sup>1</sup>, R. Castillo<sup>1</sup>, P. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, S. P. Stawicki<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>St. Luke's University Health Network,Surgery,Bethlehem, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patient satisfaction has become a critical outcome measure, highlighted by the 2010 Affordable Care Act. Although patient satisfaction has not been a traditional focus of Trauma centers, it is a key clinical performance indicator, albeit with unique challenges in the Trauma population. A Patient Satisfaction Action Plan (PSAP) was implemented at our Level 1 Trauma Center (L1TC) to target this measure. The aim of this project is to examine our PSAP’s impact on patient satisfaction scores, measured by Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (HCAHPS) post-discharge surveys.

Methods: A retrospective review of our 2015-2018 L1TC HCAHPS data was conducted, prompting our PSAP. The plan, implemented in June 2018, included the following key action items: daily structured patient rounds and multidisciplinary rounds, emphasis on communication with nursing staff, and post-discharge phone calls. A comparison of pre-PSAP data (Jul 2016-Jun 2018) to post-PSAP data (Jul 2018-May 2020) was performed utilizing descriptive statistics and non-parametric testing, with statistical significance set at α<0.05.

Results: A total of 1,221 patient surveys were reviewed (707 pre-PSAP, 514 post-PSAP). When comparing pre-PSAP and post-PSAP data, we noted a significant increase in overall patient satisfaction (Figure 1). Specifically, the overall patient satisfaction increased by nearly 50% (205/707 pre-PSAP, 217/514 post-PSAP, p<0.01). When examining individual HCAHPS domains, we noted a 66% increase in physician communication score and 27% increase in patient-perceived respectfulness of hospital staff (all, p<0.01).

Conclusion: In the 2-year period since its implementation, our institution’s Patient Satisfaction Action Plan has proven to have significant success in improving several facets of the patient care experience. We pose that this model has applicability in Trauma Centers with a similar patient/case mix, given motivated staff and clear organization. While our institution identified communication as a main center of focus, we acknowledge that other Trauma Departments may identify alternative areas of improvement that may be more relevant and critical to their particular center’s patient experience. Further research is warranted in this area, with specific focus on factors that will highly correlate with greater patient satisfaction.

abstract_title: An EAST Multicenter Trial Sub-Analysis of Aspirin Monotherapy for Grade I Blunt Vertebral Injuries
author_block: T. W. Wolff<sup>1</sup>, C. Spalding<sup>1</sup>, E. Esposito<sup>2</sup>, J. Simpson<sup>3</sup>, J. A. Dunn<sup>7</sup>, L. Zier<sup>7</sup>, S. Burruss<sup>5</sup>, L. E. Jacobson<sup>6</sup>, J. Williams<sup>6</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>12</sup>, A. Grigorian<sup>12</sup>, L. Harmon<sup>7</sup>, A. Gergen<sup>7</sup>, M. Chatoor<sup>11</sup>, R. Rattan<sup>11</sup>, A. J. Young<sup>8</sup>, J. L. Pascual<sup>8</sup>, J. Murry<sup>9</sup>, A. W. Ong<sup>10</sup>, A. Muller<sup>10</sup>, R. S. Sandhu<sup>15</sup>, R. Appelbaum<sup>15</sup>, N. Bugaev<sup>14</sup>, A. Tatar<sup>14</sup>, K. Zreik<sup>13</sup>, L. Hustad<sup>13</sup>, S. Deas<sup>4</sup>, J. A. Kufera<sup>2</sup>, D. M. Stein<sup>2</sup>, T. M. Scalea<sup>2</sup>, M. H. Lauerman<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Grant Medical Center,Division Of Trauma, Surgical Critical Care, And Acute Care Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Maryland,Division Of Critical Care And Trauma,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Greenville Hospital System,Greenville, SC, USA <sup>4</sup>UCHealth Medical Center of the Rockies,Loveland, CO, USA <sup>5</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine,Loma LInda, CA, USA <sup>6</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>9</sup>University of Texas Health Science Center,Tyler, TX, USA <sup>10</sup>Reading Hospital,Reading, PA, USA <sup>11</sup>University Of Miami,Miami, FL, USA <sup>12</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Orange, CA, USA <sup>13</sup>Sanford Health,Sioux Falls, SD, USA <sup>14</sup>Tufts Medical Center,Boston, MA, USA <sup>15</sup>Lehigh Valley Health Network,Allentown, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Treatment for blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) includes antiplatelets (AP) or anticoagulation (AC) and is without standardized guidelines. We hypothesized that treatment of grade I vertebral BCVI with aspirin alone would be associated with similar stroke rate compared to additional AP or AC therapies. 

Methods: This was a sub-analysis of an EAST multicenter, prospective, observational trial including 16 centers. Only grade I vertebral BCVI receiving medical therapy were included. Aspirin monotherapy (ASA) was defined as aspirin alone without alteration during the hospitalization. Non-aspirin therapy (non-ASA) was any other pharmaceutical therapy separate from or in combination with aspirin, or a change from aspirin to another agent. Bivariate and survival analyses were used to evaluate the stroke rate between ASA and non-ASA. 

Results: We analyzed 140 grade I vertebral BCVI (116 ASA, 24 non-ASA). Mean neck abbreviated injury scale score was slightly higher for non-ASA compared with ASA (2.67 vs. 2.12, p=0.01) as was injury severity score (22.00 vs. 16.00, p=0.14). Time to therapy was shorter in non-ASA compared with ASA (15 vs. 27 hours, p=0.03). Treatment complications were similar for non-ASA compared with ASA (4.2% vs. 1.7%, p=0.43). One patient in each group had a BCVI-related stroke, without difference in stroke rate for non-ASA compared with ASA (4.2% vs. 0.9%, p=0.31). The ASA patient with a stroke had aspirin started after the stroke, while the non-ASA patient had medical therapy started prior to the stroke. Tarone-Ware survival analysis did not show a difference in stroke between non-ASA and ASA (p=0.69).

Conclusion: Stroke risk is low in patients with grade I vertebral BCVI, regardless of therapy. Stroke and complications using ASA are equivalent to other AP and AC strategies even though it was started later.

abstract_title: Palliative Care at a Level 1 Trauma Center: A Ten Year Experience
author_block: L. D. Allan<sup>1</sup>, C. Reddi<sup>2</sup>, C. Galet<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Acute Care Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa,Carver College Of Medicine,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  A retrospective review showed that the mortality rate of trauma patients intubated more than 48 hours has increased while injury severity has decreased over the past ten years at our Institution. Noting that the time on the ventilator in those who died corresponded to the time of tracheostomy discussion prompted investigating the patterns of involvement of palliative care (PC). The results of this study are presented.

Methods: This is a 10-year retrospective review of trauma patients intubated more than 48 hours admitted to our Level I Trauma center between June 2009 and May 2018. Demographics, injury type and severity, comorbidities, mortality and PC consult data were collected. ANOVA, Chi-square tests as well as COX regression analysis were performed using SPSS 26.0. P < 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Our PC consult rates significantly increased over the years (Figure 1). Further analysis of longitudinal data showed significant increases in mortality rates of patients 18-64 (p = 0.026) and less severely injured patients (ISS 16-24; p = 0.042); paralleled by a significant increase in PC for patients age 40 to 64 (p = 0.002) and a trending increase in PC for less severely injured patients (ISS 16-24; p = 0.087). Mortality has not changed based on severity of head, chest, or abdominal injuries. However, PC is more often consulted for patients with no or less severe head injuries (AIS<3) (p = 0.023). Comorbidity rates did not affect PC rates. Cox regression analysis showed that our mortality rate is affected by age (OR = 1.016 [1.008-1.024], p < 0.001), ISS (OR = 1.023 [1.012-1.044], p < 0.001), ventilator days (OR = 0.966 [0.944-0.988], p = 0.003), obesity (OR = 1.464 [1.137-1.886], p = 0.003), and PC consult (OR = 4.475 [1.008-1.024], p < 0.001), which effect increased over time (log rank test p < 0.001).

Conclusion: Our data show that the increase in PC consultation mirrors the mortality increase. PC is consulted more often on younger and/or less severely injured patients, specifically patients with no or less severe head injuries. This may be partly explained by a societal movement to increase and improve end of life care discussions with patients and families. Further investigation into standardizing the approach to PC involvement is needed.

abstract_title: Assessing the Impact of Hands-Free Georgia on Serious Motor Vehicle Accidents
author_block: C. J. Wehrle<sup>1</sup>, P. Martinez Quinones<sup>1</sup>, E. D. Fox<sup>1</sup>, S. B. Holsten<sup>1</sup>, C. Q. White<sup>1</sup>, A. Lawson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Georgia,Augusta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Hands-Free Georgia Law (HB673), implemented July 1, 2018, was designed to prevent motor vehicle collisions (MVCs) by banning drivers from using their hands for non-driving related activities, most notably cell phone use. HB673 initially received widespread acclaim for its hardline stance on texting while driving. This study aims to investigate the effects of this law on trauma activations secondary to MVCs in the state of Georgia.

Methods: The Georgia Trauma Registry was queried to obtain data regarding MVCs in Georgia for 2017-2019, representing the 18 months immediately prior to, and following implementation of, the Hands-Free Law. Data collected focused on the absolute number of MVCs for each time period and severity of MVC as designated by the average injury severity score (ISS) for each individual trauma case.  

Results: In the 18 months prior to implementation, a total of 43,080 traumas were recorded in the Georgia Trauma Registry, of which 11,111 (25.8%) were attributed to an MVC. The average ISS was 12.1(95% CI 12.0-12.3). Following implementation, of 51,331 trauma cases reported 12,130 (23.6%) occurred secondary to MVCs, with an average ISS of 11.7 (95% CI 11.5-11.9). There was a significant (p<0.0001) decrease in ISS per trauma of 0.4. There was an increase in statewide MVC-related traumas per 1000 residents from 1.07 to 1.14 following enactment of HB673. There was also an increase in mortality rate per MVC from 4.10% to 4.15% following implementation.

Conclusion: Since implementation, there was an overall increase in the number and frequency of MVC-related traumas as well as in overall statewide trauma. The average ISS experienced a mild, but significant overall decrease. This indicates the Hands-Free Georgia has not been entirely successful at preventing injury caused by distracted driving. A more comprehensive program should be explored to target this issue.

abstract_title: The Impact of Pre-Injury Anticoagulants on the Outcomes of Traumatic Cervical Spinal Cord Injury
author_block: A. L. Alayon<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Grady<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>1,2</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,3</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1,2</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Broward Health North,Trauma Services,Deerfield Beach, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While anticoagulation therapy (ACT) in trauma patients has been implicated as a risk factor for bleeding, the impact of ACT on the outcomes of cervical spinal cord injury (CSCI) has not been addressed. The aim of this study was to examine if ACT was associated with worse outcomes following CSCI.

Methods: This IRB-approved retrospective cohort study included 255 CSCI patients with corresponding neurological deficit admitted to one of three Level 1 Trauma Centers between 2015 and 2020. Patients (n=62) on pre-injury ACT (PACT) were compared to patients (n=193) not on pre-injury ACT (NPACT). Analyzed variables included: age, comorbidities, Injury Severity Score (ISS), Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for spine, American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) impairment grade, neurological level of injury (NLI), presence of cervical vertebral fracture, facet dislocation, paravertebral hematoma (PVH), incidence of traumatic brain injury (TBI), need for blood transfusion, requirement for mechanical ventilation (MV), and rates of ICU admission and mortality.

Results: The PACT group was significantly older (75.0 vs 52.1) and comprised mainly of geriatric patients (82.3% vs 27.5%), defined as ≥65 years old, with a higher incidence of comorbidities (95.2% vs 57.5%), all p<0.001. The groups were comparably injured, as they had no difference in mean ISS (19.2 vs 21.6, p=0.2), AIS for spine (p=0.2), ASIA impairment grade (p=0.3), or NLI (p=0.5). There was no difference in prevalence of cervical spine vertebral fracture (56.5% vs 54.9%, p=0.8), facet dislocation (17.7% vs 23.3%, p=0.4), or TBI (6.5% vs 6.2%, p=0.9). Paravertebral hematoma resulted in spinal cord impingement in 80% of all patients, with a significant rate of PVH development (45.2% vs 25.4%, p=0.003) in the PACT group [Fig. 1]. Multivariable analysis confirmed PACT as a statistically significant (p=0.005) predictor for PVH formation. Significantly more patients in the PACT group required packed red blood cell transfusions within the first 24 hours of admission (25.8% vs 10.4%, p=0.002) and had more transfusions throughout their hospital stay (46.8% vs 25.4%, p=0.001). The necessity for MV (30.6% vs 35.8%, p=0.5) or ICU admission (75.8% vs 74.1%, p=0.8) were similar in groups. However, 30-day post-discharge mortality was significantly higher in the PACT group (16.1% vs 6.7%, p=0.03).

Conclusion: Patients with cervical spinal cord injury and neurological deficits on pre-injury anticoagulation therapy were older and had more comorbidities. Pre-injury anticoagulation in CSCI patients with neurological deficits was found to be a risk factor for an increased transfusion requirement, the development of a paravertebral hematoma, and a higher 30-day post-discharge mortality rate.

abstract_title: Machine Learning for Military Trauma: Novel Massive Transfusion Predictive Models in Combat Zones
author_block: D. T. Lammers<sup>1</sup>, C. Marenco<sup>1</sup>, K. Morte<sup>1</sup>, J. Conner<sup>1</sup>, J. Williams<sup>1</sup>, M. Martin<sup>1</sup>, M. Eckert<sup>1</sup>, J. Bingham<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Madigan Army Medical Center,Department Of General Surgery,Tacoma, WA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Damage control resuscitation has become the standard of care in military and civilian trauma. Early identification of blood product requirements may aid in optimizing the clinical decision-making process while improving trauma related outcomes. This study aimed to assess and compare multiple machine learning models for predicting patients at highest risk for massive transfusion on the battlefield.

Methods:  Supervised machine learning approaches using logistic regression (LR), support vector machine (SVM), neural network (NN), and random forest (RF) techniques were used to create predictive models for massive transfusion using standard prehospital and arrival datapoints from the Department of Defense Trauma Registry, 2008-2016. 70% of the population was used for model development and performance was validated using the remaining 30%. Models were tested for accuracy and compared by standard performance statistics.

Results: 22,158 patients (97% male, 58% penetrating injury, median age 25-29 years old, average ISS 9, with an overall mortality of 3%) were included in the analysis. Massive transfusion was required by 7.4% of patients. Overall accuracy was found to be over 90% in all models tested (LR 91.0%, SVM 94.6%, NN 92.0%, RF 96.7%). Following cross validation and model training, the random forest model outperformed the alternatively tested models (Table 1).

Conclusion: Machine learning techniques may allow for more optimal and rapid identification of combat trauma patients at highest risk for massive transfusion. These powerful approaches may uncover novel correlations and help improve triage, activation of massive transfusion resources, and trauma-related outcomes. Further research seeking to optimize and apply these algorithms to trauma-centered research should be pursued.

abstract_title: Weather and Prehospital Predictors of Trauma Patient Mortality in Rural American State
author_block: O. -. Nzewunwa<sup>1</sup>, C. Falank<sup>2</sup>, J. Ontengco<sup>2</sup>, B. Chung<sup>2</sup>, D. Carter<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Maine Medical Center,Surgery,Portland, MAINE, USA <sup>2</sup>Maine Medical Center,Trauma And Surgical Critical Care,Portland, ME, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In rural settings, factors such as weather, emergency services availability and location can significantly impact total prehospital time and thus survival after injury. We sought to determine what prehospital conditions affect mortality and morbidity in severely injured patients. We hypothesized that shorter pre-hospital clinical and weather would predict trauma patient in-hospital morbidity and mortality.

Methods: We retrospectively reviewed the trauma registry at the only level 1 trauma center in Maine, a rural American state. We extracted demographic, clinical, and geospatial data for each trauma patient and linked weather conditions using data from the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) database. A sub-analysis of patients with low Glasgow Coma Score (GCS≤ 9), hypotension (SBP≤ 90mmHg), or both, was conducted to identify the effect of weather and prehospital conditions on patient outcomes including ICU admission, need for emergent surgery and mortality. We used the student’s t-test, Chi-Square, ANOVA, Bonferroni tests, Kruskall-Wallis, and Dunn tests for data analysis. Lastly, we built bivariate and multivariate logistic regression models to predict ED and in-hospital mortality using Stata version 11.0

Results: Over the three-year study period, 442 subjects were captured. These were predominantly middle-aged (median 52 years [IQR 33, 67]) Caucasian (98%) males (71%) transferred from an outside hospital (54%) with an injury severity score above 15 (56%). Falls (36%) and motor vehicle collisions (33%) were the commonest injury mechanisms with a smaller incidence of burns (8%) and penetrating trauma (9%). The median time on the scene (field time) was 15 minutes [IQR =10, 20.5]. Ground ambulance (85%) and helicopter (7%) were the most common transport methods. The median time to definitive care was 129 minutes [IQR= 61, 247]. Patients with field GCS ≤ 9 had higher odds of ICU admission (OR=2, p=0.029). Hypotension in the field was the single greatest predictor of ED mortality (OR=11, p=0.004). Other predictors of in-hospital mortality were ISS >15 (OR=3, p=0.006) and field hypoxia (OR=3, p=0.007). Among trauma transfers, increasing prehospital time correlated with ED mortality while injury during warmer weather showed lower odds (OR =0.94, p=0.019) of in-hospital mortality. For patients that presented directly from the field, no weather condition (temperature, snow, visibility, sky conditions, precipitation, humidity, or sleet) predicted mortality.

Conclusion: This study shows that among severely injured patients in our rural catchment area, being injured during cold weather was associated with higher in-hospital mortality among trauma transfer patients. Prehospital blood pressure, pulse oximetry, GCS (hypotension, hypoxia, GCS) are predictors of inpatient mortality. Future analysis will explore other factors impacting transport and field time in order to improve outcomes in our rural setting.

abstract_title: Re-defining High Volume Gastric Cancer Centers: The Impact of Operative Volume on Surgical Outcomes
author_block: M. R. Ju<sup>1</sup>, J. Blackwell<sup>2</sup>, S. C. Wang<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Porembka<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Surgical Oncology/Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Department Of Population And Clinical Science,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Performance of technically complex surgery at high volume (HV) centers has been associated with improved outcomes. The aim of this study was to assess whether hospital volume is associated with surgical outcomes in gastric cancer, and what threshold of case volume meaningfully impacts operative outcomes and survival. 

Methods: We identified adult patients with stage I-III gastric adenocarcinoma undergoing gastrectomy between 2004-2015 in the National Cancer Database (NCDB). A multivariable Cox proportional hazards model with restricted cubic splines (RCS) was used to examine the association of annual hospital gastrectomy volume and overall survival, after adjusting for demographic and clinicopathologic factors. The average annual gastrectomy volume was calculated as the number of gastric cancer cases treated at a given facility divided by the number of years the facility had participated in the NCDB. Our RCS model identified 2 ranges of values of average annual gastrectomy volume that corresponded to changes in the log hazard ratio. Further analysis was conducted with bootstrap simulation that estimated 17 cases/year as the cut point that corresponded to maximum change in log hazard ratio. On the basis of this estimated cut point, hospitals were divided into HV (≥ 17 cases/year) and low volume (LV, <17 cases/year) groups. Patients with missing data capture of surgical margins, lymph node exam, or date of last contact/death, and those treated at facilities that contributed <1 case/year, were excluded. Chi-square tests were used to analyze group differences. Logistic regression was utilized to assess the impact of hospital volume on surgical outcomes. Kaplan-Meier and Cox Proportional Hazard methods were used for survival analysis.   

Results: Our final cohort consisted of 27,910 patients (8.3% treated at HV center). All HV centers were academic centers. Patients treated at LV centers were more likely to be minority race/ethnicity, uninsured, and live in census tracts with lower median incomes and education levels. Compared to LV centers, treatment at a HV center was associated with an increased likelihood of adequate lymph node examination of 15 nodes (OR 2.08, 95% CI 1.90-2.28) and decreased thirty- and ninety-day postoperative mortality (OR 0.67, 95% CI 0.49-0.89 and OR 0.70, 95% CI 0.57-0.85; respectively) after adjusting for age, sex, race, comorbidities, and stage. For all stages combined, treatment at a HV center was associated with a survival advantage (median overall survival 47.6 vs 45.0 months; p<0.05).

Conclusion: Treatment at a HV gastrectomy center is associated with significantly improved surgical outcomes. Our study identified 17 cases/year as a clinically meaningful distinction between HV and LV centers. This definition of a HV center should be considered when evaluating regionalization of gastric cancer care to improve patient outcomes.

abstract_title: Hospital Surgical Volume and Racial Disparities in Abdominal Cancer Care
author_block: A. B. Shannon<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Straker<sup>1</sup>, L. Keele<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>2</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>2</sup>, R. E. Roses<sup>2</sup>, J. T. Miura<sup>2</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Endocrine And Oncologic Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Race has been frequently reported to be associated with worse cancer outcomes, including perioperative morbidity and overall survival. While higher volume centers (HVC) have been associated with improved post-surgical outcomes overall, the impact of surgical volume on racial disparities in oncologic surgery is less defined.

Methods: Patients who underwent surgical resection for stage I-III esophagogastric, pancreatic, or rectal adenocarcinoma from the 2004-2015 National Cancer Database were divided into cohorts based on race and hospital surgical volume as defined by Leapfrog Group guidelines. Outcomes were analyzed following 1:1 propensity-score matching using adjusted logistic, Poisson, and Cox proportional hazard regression analysis with marginal effects.

Results: Between 2004-2015, 103,846 (90.5%) Non-Black Non-Hispanic (NBNH) and 10,926 (9.5%) Black Non-Hispanic (BNH) patients underwent surgical resection. Following 1:1 matching, 77% of NBNH (N=10,695) and BNH underwent resection at an HVC. Ninety-day mortality was reduced in both NBNH (average marginal effects [AME] -0.01, p 0.004) and BNH (AME -0.02, p 0.001) when comparing HVC patients to low volume center (LVC) patients both overall and in pancreatic cancer, but not in esophagogastric or rectal cancer. Length of stay was significantly longer for BNH as compared to NBNH patients with rectal cancer in both LVC (AME 1.17, p<0.001) and HVC (AME 1.49, p<0.001) but was shorter for esophagogastric (AME -0.80, p<0.001; AME -0.38, p 0.003) and pancreatic (AME -1.53, p<0.001; AME -1.45, p<0.001) cancers, respectively. BNH patients with rectal cancer demonstrated worse OS as compared to NBNH patients with rectal cancer following covariate adjustment when treated at an LVC (AME 4.01, p 0.043), but this survival difference between BNH and NBNH patients disappeared when treatment occurred at an HVC (AME 1.61, p 0.159).

Conclusions: Racial disparities in long-term survival outcomes appear to be more pronounced in LVC versus HVC settings for patients with rectal cancer. Further study is needed to better understand the complex relationship between hospital volume and racial disparity in abdominal cancer outcomes in order to develop strategies to resolve these differences.

abstract_title: Regression is a Significant Predictor of Outcomes for Patients with Melanoma
author_block: S. Subramanian<sup>1</sup>, G. Han<sup>2</sup>, N. Olson<sup>2</sup>, S. P. Leong<sup>3</sup>, M. Kashani-Sabet<sup>3</sup>, R. White<sup>4</sup>, J. S. Zager<sup>5</sup>, V. K. Sondak<sup>5</sup>, B. Pockaj<sup>6</sup>, J. Vetto<sup>1</sup>, S. Schneebaum<sup>7</sup>, D. Han<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Oregon Health And Science University,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Portland, OR, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas A&M University,Department Of Epidemiology And Biostatistics, School Of Public Health,College Station, TEXAS, USA <sup>3</sup>California Pacific Medical Center and Research Institute,San Fransico, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>4</sup>Levine Cancer Institute, Carolinas Medical Center, Atrium Health,Charlotte, NORTH CAROLINA, USA <sup>5</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center,Tampa, FLORIDA, USA <sup>6</sup>Mayo Clinic,Phoenix, AZ, USA <sup>7</sup>Tel Aviv Sourasky Medical Center,Tel Aviv, TEL AVIV, Israel
abstract_body:
Introduction: The prognostic significance of regression for melanoma is debated since studies have shown contradictory results, with some associating regression with poor outcomes, while others correlating regression with a favorable prognosis. We present a large multicenter study correlating regression with sentinel lymph node (SLN) metastasis and melanoma-specific survival (MSS).

Methods: The Sentinel Lymph Node Working Group database was reviewed from 1998 to 2018.Patients with known regression and SLN status were included. Clinicopathologic factors were correlated with regression, SLN status and MSS.

Results:In total, there were 4790 patients, with an overall median follow-up of 39.6 months and a median age of 58.9 years. Median thickness, minimum thickness and range were 1.4 mm, 0.1 mm, 52.9 mm, respectively. Overall, 495(10.3%) patients had T1a tumors. Regression was present in 1081 of 4790(22.6%) cases and 187 of 1081(17.3%) had T1a tumors. On multivariable analysis, significant predictors of regression were male gender, tumors on the trunk, and decreasing thickness (all p<0.05), while tumors on the head/neck or lower extremities were significantly less likely to have regression (p<0.05). Positive SLN status correlated inversely with regression (p=0.0012). Overall, SLN metastases were seen in 798 of 4790 patients (16.7%), of which 125 of 798 cases (15.7%) had regression. Significant predictors of a positive SLN on multivariable analysis were male gender, tumors on the trunk or lower extremities, increasing thickness, ulceration, lymphovascular invasion (LVI), and microsatellitosis (all p<0.05). Decreasing age was a predictor, and regression was a correlate of decreased risk of SLN disease (regression:OR 0.68, 95% CI 0.54-0.85, p=0.0008; age:OR 0.98, 95% CI 0.98-0.99, p<0.0001). Patients with regression had significantly better MSS(p<0.001), with a 5-year MSS of 92.2% and 86.7% for patients with and without regression, respectively. Multivariable analysis showed that increasing age, male gender, increasing thickness, ulceration, LVI and microsatellitosis significantly predicted worse MSS(all p<0.05). Positive SLN correlated with poor MSS(p<0.05). In contrast, the presence of regression correlated significantly with better MSS (HR 0.75, 95% CI 0.57-0.99, p=0.043).

Conclusion:This is the largest retrospective multicenter study to evaluate regression in melanoma, and the results show that regression is seen more frequently with decreasing tumor thickness, in males and in tumors on the trunk, while regression is present at a significantly lower rate in head/neck and lower extremity tumors and in positive SLN cases. More importantly, regression is an independent and significant predictor of outcomes, correlates with lower SLN metastasis rate and better MSS. Our results show that regression is a favorable prognostic marker and has the potential to be used with other known prognostic markers to predict outcomes in patients with melanoma.

abstract_title: Morbidity and Mortality of Palliative Bypass Procedures for Pancreatic Cancer: An ACS-NSQIP Analysis
author_block: A. M. Adams<sup>1</sup>, B. N. Reames<sup>2</sup>, R. M. Krell<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brooke Army Medical Center,General Surgery,Ft Sam Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Surgical Oncology,Omaha, NE, USA <sup>3</sup>Brooke Army Medical Center,Surgical Oncology,Ft Sam Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with unresectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) may undergo palliative operations including intestinal or biliary bypass. The value of these procedures remains debated, and a recent survey of their postoperative mortality and complication rates is lacking. It remains unclear which patients present with prohibitive operative risk.

Methods: We used American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program data from 2005-2018 to assess patients undergoing gastrojejunostomy (GJ), biliary bypass (BB), double bypass (DB), or explorative surgery alone (ES) for PDAC. Using multivariable logistic regression, we compared 30-day mortality and complications across procedures and over time periods (2005-2010, 2011-2014, and 2015-2018). We identified patient and operative factors associated with postoperative mortality.

Results: We identified 4,810 patients undergoing non-pancreatectomy operations for PDAC, including 978 (20.3%) GJ, 764 (15.9%) BB, 631 (13.1%) DB, and 2,437 (50.7%) ES. Adjusted 30-day mortality and serious complications respectively were 26.0% and 11.8% for GJ procedures, 26.4% and 7.9% for BB, 23.5% and 5.2% for DB compared to 5.6% and 13.0% for ES (p<.001). Specific complications including any SSI, organ-space SSI, wound disruption, pneumonia, VTE, and post-operative reintubation were significantly higher for bypass procedures (Figure 1). Adjusted 30-day mortality did not change significantly over time (8.1% in 2005-2010, compared to 6.6% from 2015-2018, p=0.08). Independent risk factors for post-operative mortality included pre-op albumin <3.5 (OR 2.60, 95% CI 1.90-3.57), disseminated cancer (OR 2.06, 1.57-2.72), emergency operation (OR 2.00, 1.13-3.50), age >74 (OR 1.95, 1.47-2.60), ASA class 4 (OR 1.94, 1.39-2.70), pre-op bleeding disorder (OR 1.72, 1.08-2.73), pre-op WBC >10.6(1.81, 1.31-2.48), pre-op Hct <30(1.45, 1.05-2.01), and INR >1.2 (OR 1.52, 1.10-2.12). 30-day mortality after bypass procedures was 2% in patients with 0-1 risk factors, compared to 8% with 2-3 risk factors and 18% with 4 or more risk factors (p<0.001).

Conclusion: Palliative bypass for PDAC has not become safer over time, and 30-day mortality and complications remain unacceptably high. The presence of multiple risk factors such as disseminated cancer, low albumin, bleeding disorders, age >74 years, and emergent situations present prohibitive operative risk and alternative palliative measures should be pursued.

abstract_title: Factors Associated with Inability to Return to Intended Oncologic Treatment in Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: T. A. Mickel<sup>1</sup>, O. C. Kutlu<sup>2</sup>, E. R. Camp<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Medical University Of South Carolina,Charleston, SC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Survival in pancreatic cancer is associated with implementation of multidisciplinary treatment protocols, systemic therapy in addition to surgery. Despite the NCCN recommendations almost 40% of patients fail to receive systemic therapy. Return to Intended Oncologic Treatment (RIOT) has been proposed as a quality metric in care of these patients. Failure to RIOT may decrease the benefits of curative resection and decrease survival. In this study we sought to identify the frequency, the factors associated with failure to RIOT, and the impact on survival.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was used as the data source. Patients diagnosed with head of the pancreas adenocarcinoma (PAC) between 2010-2016 were included in the study. The selection criteria were: age 18-90, stage IB, IIA, IIB, known grade, tumor size, nodal status, comorbidities, systemic treatment sequence (pre-operative, post-operative, peri-operative chemotherapy), known hospital stay, margin status, surgical approach (MIS vs open), type of institution and known survival. Binary logistic regression models were used to identify the factors associated with failure to RIOT. For each stage, Kaplan-Meier Survival analysis was performed to estimate and compare survival for failure to RIOT, and Cox regression models were used to correct for confounders and to demonstrate the impact of failure to RIOT on survival.

Results: 10630 patients fit our criteria for data completeness. The rate of RIOT was 77.6% (8251). Logistic regression models showed increased risk of failure to RIOT with sex (female, p<0.001), race (Hispanic, p=0.002), 2 or more comorbidities (p=0.001), stage (p<0.001), and hospital stay (p<0.001). However surgical approach (MIS, p=0.024), negative margins (p=0.048), and academic institutions (p=0.001) were associated with lower risk. Kaplan Meier Survival analysis showed RIOT to be significantly associated with longer survival (20.63 months vs 16.97 months, p<0.001), and Cox regression analysis showed RIOT to be associated with lower hazard ratios at every stage (stage IB HR 0.715 p=0.001, Stage IIA HR 0.702 p<0.001, Stage IIB HR 0.622 p<0.001). Neoadjuvant chemotherapy on the other hand was associated with better survival in case of failure to RIOT.

Conclusion: Failure to RIOT was associated with worse survival in PAC. This was seen less in academic centers and the effect of failure to RIOT was seen to be compensated by administration of neoadjuvant chemotherapy. These findings support RIOT as an independent factor in survival and emphasize importance of academic institutions for pancreatic cancer care and the possible benefit of neoadjuvant treatment in these patients.

abstract_title: Guideline Adherence and Survival Benefit of Radiation Therapy for Early Stage Merkel Cell Carcinoma
author_block: W. G. Wong<sup>1</sup>, K. Stahl<sup>1</sup>, E. Olecki<sup>1</sup>, C. Pameijer<sup>1</sup>, C. Shen<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,General Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,Division Of Outcomes Research And Quality,Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Merkel Cell Carcinoma (MCC) of the skin is a rare malignancy that is rising in incidence in the United States. Adjuvant radiation therapy (RT) has been reported to decrease the risk of locoregional recurrence and improve overall survival, but clinical evidence of its efficacy is inconsistent. In addition, to our knowledge, adherence to RT guidelines is unknown.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was queried for stage I/II MCC patients who have received surgical intervention from 2005-2016. The cohort was divided into two groups: patients who had indication(s) for adjuvant RT and patients who had no indication for RT based on National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines. We created a binary variable of whether patients actually received RT or not. We captured demographics, socioeconomic characteristics, and clinical characteristics of MCC. Five-year survival rate was assessed using the Kaplan Meier method. For each group, chi-square test and logistic regression analysis examined differences between the patients who received RT and patients who did not receive RT.

Results: We identified 6651 stage I/II MCC patients who have undergone surgical intervention. Within the cohort, 5694 (85.6%) met NCCN criteria for RT, of which 2786 (48.9%) received adjuvant RT and 2908 (51.1%) did not receive RT.  957 (14.4%) did not meet criteria for RT, of which 408 (42.6%) received RT and 549 (57.4%) did not receive RT. Five-year overall survival advantage was identified for patients who received RT both when RT was indicated (59% vs 46.7% when no RT was received) and not indicated (77.5% vs 68% when no RT was received) (P < .001). Among patients who had indication for RT, females were less likely than males to receive RT (OR 0.86, P <.01); patients over 75 years old were less likely to receive RT than younger patients (OR 0.63, P <.001); patients with multiple comorbidities were less likely to receive RT than patients with no/few comorbidities (OR 0.73, P <.01). Patients in comprehensive community cancer programs were more likely to receive RT than patients in academic/cancer research centers in both indicated and not indicated groups (OR 1.65, P <.001 and OR 2.48, P <.005, respectively).

Conclusion: Surgical resection with adjuvant RT has an overall survival benefit for local MCC. However, this study found certain groups are not receiving postoperative care concordant with NCCN guidelines: over 50% of patients did not receive RT when indicated and over 40% of patients received RT when not indicated. In addition, the survival benefit observed in patients who did not meet criteria for RT but received it warrants investigation. With the rise in incidence of MCC and in the associated survival benefit of multi-modality therapy, it is important to be aware of and further identify the socio-demographic and oncologic reasons for guideline non-adherence in the treatment of MCC.

abstract_title: Location-An Important Variable in Pancreatic Cancer Outcomes: NCDB Study of Medicaid Expansion
author_block: D. V. Cherla<sup>1</sup>, H. Cao<sup>2</sup>, A. Fonseca<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of South Alabama,General Surgery,Mobile, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>MD Anderson Cancer Center,General Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
INTRODUCTION

The 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act facilitated Medicaid expansion in select geographic regions of the United Status.  Limited data has linked the expansion of public health insurance with increased oncologic screening rates, early-stage diagnoses, and colorectal cancer survival.  The aims of this study were to assess if Medicaid expansion was associated with an improvement in the treatment and outcomes of non-metastatic pancreatic cancer.

 

METHODS

The National Cancer Database patients was queried for patients diagnosed with non-metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma from 2006 to  2016. Univariate associations were assessed with the Kruskal-Wallis test for quantitative variables and the Pearson Chi-square test for categorical variables. Multivariable logistic regression analysis was performed, and Cox proportional hazards regression analysis was conducted for overall survival.

 

RESULTS

This study identified 31,651 patients who met criteria, of which 15,410 patients received curative intent resection. Medicaid expansion was associated with increased likelihood of patients receiving curative intent resection (p <0.001). Additionally, in the cohort of resected patients, Medicaid expansion was associated with receipt of neoadjuvant chemotherapy (18.15% vs. 10.17%,p<0.001), multiagent chemotherapy (29.09% vs.18.22%,p<0.001), treatment at an academic center (65.30% vs. 60.87%,p=0.008), high volume center (63.83% vs. 36.17%,p<0.001), decreased 30-day mortality (1.54% vs. 3.64%, p<0.001) and decreased 90-day mortality (3.24% vs. 7.42%, p< 0.001). Logistic regression analysis demonstrated that after controlling for variables including age, gender, race, facility type, insurance status, geographic location and demographic variables, Medicaid expansion was independently associated with the receipt of curative intent resection (Odds Ratio (OR) 1.54, p<0.001), neoadjuvant chemotherapy (OR 2.47, p<0.001), multimodality treatment with surgery & multiagent chemotherapy (OR 2.3, p<0.001), treatment at a high volume center (OR 1.48, p<0.001), decreased 30-day mortality (OR 0.49, p<0.001) and decreased 90-day mortality (OR 0.46, p<0.001). Cox proportional hazards regression analysis demonstrated that after adjusting for age, gender, race, facility type, insurance status, geographic location and demographic variables, Medicaid expansion status was associated with improved overall survival (OR 0.86, p=0.001).

 

CONCLUSIONS

Medicaid expansion is associated with increased curative intent surgery in non-metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. In resected patients, Medicaid expansion is associated with the receipt of neoadjuvant chemotherapy, multimodality treatment at high volume centers, as well as improved 30-day and 90-day mortality and overall survival.

abstract_title: Emergency Department "Catch-and-Release" After Surgery: Breakdowns in Post-Discharge Care
author_block: B. C. Brajcich<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Y. Bilimoria<sup>1,2</sup>, J. K. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, M. L. Shallcross<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Chung<sup>1</sup>, H. Joung<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Odell<sup>1</sup>, R. P. Merkow<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>American College Of Surgeons,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For surgical populations, readmission is primarily indicative of complications requiring inpatient management. Current readmission measures fail to capture emergency department encounters resulting in discharge (EDD), which may directly measure quality of post-discharge care by identifying patients who could have been managed in the outpatient setting. Our objectives were to (1) characterize the incidence of and reasons for EDD, (2) identify predictors of EDD, and (3) evaluate hospital variation in EDD among patients undergoing gastrointestinal surgery for cancer.

Methods: Patients who underwent gastrointestinal surgery for cancer from 2015-2016 were identified in the Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project (HCUP) State Inpatient Databases (SID) and State Emergency Department Databases (SEDD) for New York, Florida, and Maryland. The primary outcome was EDD within 30 days of discharge. The diagnoses most frequently associated with EDD were identified. A hierarchical multivariable logistic regression model was constructed to identify predictors and estimate hospital-specific odds ratios (OR) of EDD.

Results: A total of 34,120 patients from 402 hospitals underwent an esophageal (4.0%), gastric (5.9%) pancreatic (11.7%), hepatobiliary (11.7%), small bowel (2.7%), or colorectal (64.0%) operation for cancer. The overall rate of 30-day EDD was 8.1%, ranging from 7.1% following hepatobiliary to 13.3% following esophageal surgery. The most common reasons for EDD were pain (12.3%), wound care or complaints (11.9%), device/ostomy problems (11.8%), renal/GU complaints (8.4%), and general GI complaints (8.0%). EDD was less likely for older patients (OR 0.99 [95% CI 0.98-0.99] per year, p<.01) and more likely for non-Hispanic Black compared to non-Hispanic White patients (OR 1.23 [95% CI 1.09-1.39], p<.01) and for non-privately insured patients (Medicaid: OR 1.96 [95% CI 1.70-2.26], p<.01, Medicare: OR 1.35 [95% CI 1.20-1.52], p<.01, other: OR 1.39 [95% CI 1.11-1.76], p<.01). Likelihood of EDD was also increased for patients who had esophageal (OR 1.83 [95% CI 1.53-2.18], p<.01), gastric (OR 1.41 [95% CI 1.21-1.65], p<.01), or pancreatic (OR 1.34 [95% CI 1.18-1.53], p<.01) procedures versus colorectal operations. Among hospitals, the OR for EDD ranged from 0.61 (95% CI 0.47-0.79) to 1.89 (95% CI 1.26-2.86), with 4 hospitals (1.0%) performing better and 7 hospitals (1.7%) performing worse than expected.

Conclusion: EDD occurs frequently after gastrointestinal surgery for cancer. Non-privately insured patients and certain racial and ethnic groups are disproportionately affected by EDD and hospital rates of EDD vary widely. Many EDDs may be avoidable through improved post-discharge coordination and monitoring. EDD is a unique measure of post-discharge surgical quality and may be more actionable than current readmission indicators.

abstract_title: Gastrectomy in Stage IV Gastric Adenocarcinoma
author_block: M. Papageorge<sup>1</sup>, S. De Gues<sup>1</sup>, A. P. Woods<sup>1</sup>, S. Ng<sup>1</sup>, D. McAneny<sup>1</sup>, M. Cassidy<sup>1</sup>, J. Tseng<sup>1</sup>, T. E. Sachs<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Palliative surgery has been identified as a viable option in preserving quality of life for select patient populations in the context of complex cancer care. Despite the potential benefits of palliative surgery, its utilization in gastric cancer is poorly understood. The purpose of this study was to identify predictors of gastrectomy and survival of patients with stage IV gastric adenocarcinoma.

Methods:  The National Cancer Database (2010-2016) was queried for cases of stage IV gastric adenocarcinoma. Multivariable logistic regression was used to identify patient and institutional characteristics predicting gastrectomy in patients with stage IV disease. Propensity scores were created for the odds of undergoing gastrectomy and patients were matched 1:1. Survival analyses were performed using the Kaplan-Meier method.

Results: We identified 20,184 patients with clinical stage IV gastric adenocarcinoma, of which 1244 (6.2%) underwent gastrectomy. On multivariable logistic regression, patients were more likely to undergo gastrectomy if they were younger (OR 0.977, 95% CI 0.970-0.983, p<0.0001), non-white (vs white OR 1.229, 95% CI 1.076-1.404, p=0.0024) or female (vs male OR 1.259, 95% CI 1.118-1.418, p=0.0001). Patients were also more likely to undergo gastrectomy if they lived in areas with lower rates of high school education (vs higher rates OR 1.310, 95% CI 1.086-1.579, p=0.0047) or private insurance (vs no insurance OR 1.587, 95% CI 1.223-2.060, p=0.0005). In addition, patients who underwent gastrectomy were more likely to have not received chemotherapy (vs chemotherapy OR 1.815, 95% CI 1.602-2.056, p<0.0001). Before matching, median overall survival was 11.24 months for gastrectomy versus 5.13 months for those who did not undergo gastrectomy. After matching, median overall survival was 11.20 months for gastrectomy versus 4.17 months for those who did not undergo gastrectomy (log-rank, p<0.0001) (Figure 1).

Conclusion: The use of palliation surgery has increased over the past several years. The findings of this study suggest that predictors of gastrectomy in stage IV gastric adenocarcinoma include age, gender, education and insurance status. Surgery may be underutilized in certain populations and could provide a survival benefit in well selected patients with stage IV gastric adenocarcinoma.

abstract_title: Factors and Outcomes Associated with Pre-operative Biopsy of Non-Metastatic Retroperitoneal Sarcoma.
author_block: R. J. Straker<sup>1</sup>, Y. Song<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Shannon<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Marcinak<sup>2</sup>, J. T. Miura<sup>3</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>3</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Division Of Endocrine And Oncologic Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Routine pre-operative biopsy (PBx) of retroperitoneal sarcoma (RPS) remains poorly defined. Potential benefits include its ability to influence perioperative treatment decisions, namely with respect to neoadjuvant treatment strategies. Using a large national cohort, we sought to identify the incidence of, and describe factors and outcomes associated with, PBx for non-metastatic, resectable RPS.

Methods:  The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was used to perform a retrospective review from 2004 to 2015 of patients who underwent therapeutic surgical resection of non-metastatic RPS. Comparison was made between patients who did and did not undergo PBx of the primary tumor; excisional biopsies were excluded. Factors associated with PBx were analyzed with logistic regression, and factors associated with survival were analyzed using Cox proportional hazards regression. Survival analysis was performed by the Kaplan-Meier method and log rank test.

Results: Of 2,210 patients with non-metastatic, resectable RPS, 993 (44.9%) underwent PBx. Pre-procedural factors significantly associated with PBx included tumor size ≤5cm (OR 1.7, p<0.01), tumor size between 5 and 10cm (OR 1.4, p<0.01), non-well differentiated liposarcoma histology (OR 2.0, p<0.001) and treatment at an academic facility (OR 1.4, p<0.01). Patients who underwent PBx were significantly more likely to receive neoadjuvant radiation (OR 8.5, p<0.001) and neoadjuvant systemic therapy (OR 3.6, p<0.001), and were more likely to undergo radical resection (OR 1.6, p<0.001) (Table 1). Of these three post-procedural factors, receipt of neoadjuvant radiation was associated with a survival advantage (HR 0.76, p=0.03). 5-year overall survival (OS) was worse for those who underwent biopsy compared to those who did not (59.0% vs 62.9%, p=0.02), but PBx was not associated with overall survival (HR 1.1, p=0.19) by multivariate analysis. The proportion of patients who underwent PBx did not significantly differ from year to year over the study time period (p=0.31).          

Conclusion: A minority of patients undergo PBx. Smaller tumor size, treatment at an academic center, and concern for more aggressive histology is associated with the decision to pursue biopsy. Despite theoretical concerns of tumor seeding, PBx does not appear to negatively impact survival, and may indirectly improve outcomes in select patients with RPS by virtue of receipt of neoadjuvant therapy. These findings underscore the need to improve standardization of the pre-operative workup for patients with RPS.

abstract_title: Current Reporting Practices Related to New Operative Standards for Axillary Staging in Breast Cancer
author_block: K. E. Goodsell<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Soegaard<sup>2</sup>, J. P. Ermer<sup>2</sup>, J. C. Tchou<sup>2</sup>, P. Gabriel<sup>3</sup>, L. N. Shulman<sup>3</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Pennsylvania,Abramson Cancer Center,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In 2021, the American College of Surgeons’ Commission on Cancer’s (CoC) Operative Standards will require synoptic documentation for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) and axillary dissection (AD) for breast cancers of epithelial origin. We sought to assess existing operative reporting practices and identify potential compliance gaps in operative documentation for oncologic breast procedures at our institution.

Methods: Operative reports of SLNB and AD performed within our health system over a 12-month period (1/1/2018-12/31/2018) were reviewed. Records were processed chronologically until a maximum of 100 operative notes were reviewed (SLNB) or until the entire 2018 patient list was exhausted (AD). Two independent reviewers categorized operative notes as compliant if each of the required elements (for SLNB: what substrate was utilized (dye, radiotracer, and/or clips), as well as removal of all applicably abnormal nodes; for AD: boundaries of dissection, preservation of relevant nerves, and approach to level III nodes) was explicitly documented.  The mean of reviewer scores and kappa statistics for interrater reliability were calculated. Data analysis was performed using R.

Results: A total of 100 SLNB operative reports were documented by 5 unique surgeons; a total of 89 AD reports were documented by 7 surgeons. Overall compliance with CoC standards was 66% for SLNB and 12% for AD. Rates of compliance varied by surgeon. Among surgeons performing SLNB, compliance ranged from 6% to 100%. The most common missing elements were documentation that all colored nodes or non-colored nodes present at the end of dye-filled lymphatic channels and/or all significantly radioactive nodes were removed when dye/radiotracer were used. Among surgeons performing AD, compliance ranged from zero to 47%. The most common missing elements were documentation of attempts to spare the intercostobrachial nerve or whether level III nodes were removed. Interrater reliability was substantial, with kappa 0.77 and 0.78 for SLNB and AD, respectively.
