Conclusion: In this study, we found significant variability between both surgeons and procedures in current operative documentation of common breast oncology procedures.  Compliance was notably lower in AD than SLNB.  Interrater reliability was substantial, suggesting that our data is reproducible. Future work will investigate the value of a standardized documentation tool in improving synoptic operative report compliance.

abstract_title: Using Electronic Medical Records Search Engine (EMERSE) to Improve Research Involving Rare Cancers
author_block: A. Bhattacharya<sup>1</sup>, L. Hoff<sup>1</sup>, C. Harter<sup>1</sup>, E. Olsen<sup>1</sup>, N. Mott<sup>1</sup>, T. Hughes<sup>2</sup>, C. Angeles<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The digitization of medical records has allowed researchers to aggregate cohorts of patients for large-scale retrospective studies. While many data points are structured and easily retrievable from the electronic health record (EHR) systems, other relevant clinical information is more difficult to reliably retrieve due to its inclusion in free-text notes. For cancer patients, the text in non-synoptic pathology reports and provider notes are common sources that may be missed with traditional chart review. Moreover, International Classification of Diseases (ICD) codes within the EHR may be ambiguous, making it difficult to identify the maximum number of patients with these conditions. We sought to explore if the Electronic Medical Records Search Engine (EMERSE), a highly robust clinical text mining tool, could meaningfully augment the manual chart review process for patients with cutaneous leiomyosarcoma (cLMS), a rare sarcoma of the skin and soft tissue.

Methods: EMERSE allows users to define single-word and multi-word phrases to search over 80 million free-text clinical documents from the EHR of our large tertiary care health system. We used terms such as “leiomyosarcoma” and “cutaneous leiomyosarcoma” along with specifiers like keyword proximity (distance of each term in a single document) as well as other identifiers (e.g. “dermal” and “subcutaneous”) to generate a list of potential cLMS patients. To assess how many true cLMS patients were identified using EMERSE, we manually chart reviewed the list and also obtained the associated ICD-0-3 tumor and primary site classification from the institutional Cancer Registry.  

Results: From EMERSE we identified 311 potential cLMS candidates in the EHR. Through chart review, 140 patients were deemed to have cLMS. However, only 101 patients of the 140 were identified by ICD-0-3 classification in the Cancer Registry. If only traditional ICD-codes were used to query the 311 patient cohort, nearly 28% of the positive cLMS patients found by chart review would have been missed. The remaining 173 false positives captured by EMERSE was mainly due to standardized language from genetic consult notes stating, “risk for cutaneous leiomyosarcoma”.

Conclusion: This study demonstrates how EMERSE can be used as an efficient and sensitive method for identifying patients with a rare cancer diagnosis directly from free-text clinical notes. Although use of EMERSE had significant false positives it still managed to detect patients who may otherwise have been missed by traditional methods of querying. Applying more granular search criteria that excludes standardized language may yield even better results. For larger, multi-institutional studies, this type of resource could prove to be an advantageous approach for cohort research studies on rare pathologic diagnoses.

abstract_title: A Population-Based Analysis of Complex Surgery in Cirrhotics: What is the Current Risk?
author_block: A. W. Kangas-Dick<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Greenbaum<sup>1</sup>, P. Hilden<sup>4</sup>, V. Gazivoda<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Turner<sup>3</sup>, V. Gall<sup>1</sup>, J. Sesti<sup>3</sup>, S. Paul<sup>3</sup>, T. Kennedy<sup>1,3</sup>, M. S. Grandhi<sup>1,3</sup>, H. R. Alexander<sup>1,3</sup>, J. Maggi<sup>1,3</sup>, D. August<sup>1,3</sup>, R. C. Langan<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rutgers Cancer Institute of New Jersey,Surgical Oncology,New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Maimonides Medical Center,Surgery,Brooklyn, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Saint Barnabas Medical Center,Surgery,Livingston, NJ, USA <sup>4</sup>Saint Barnabas Medical Center,Biostatistics,Livingston, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Historical surgical data warns against abdominal surgery in patients with cirrhosis (CP) due to increased morbidity and mortality. However, these published mortality rates may not represent modern medical practices.  We postulate more CP are undergoing major abdominal surgery however a paucity of data remains on outcomes. This project aimed to identify trends in mortality and morbidity among patients with cirrhosis undergoing major non-transplant, non-hepatic cancer surgery and to quantify the increase in such cases over time.

Methods: The National Inpatient Sample (NIS) was queried for patients undergoing both open and minimally invasive pancreatectomy, colectomy, esophagectomy, gastrectomy, or pulmonary resection from 2005-2015. Inclusion criteria were met for 928,156 patients. Of these 7647 (0.8%) were cirrhotic. Propensity matching of non-cirrhotic patients (NCP) was performed on the basis of demographics and comorbidities. Mortality over time and differences in outcomes were compared using a conditional logistic regression model.

Results: For all procedures, the number of major operations performed on CP increased over time (odds ratio for year 1.01 (1.00-1.02, P=0.031), while overall mortality decreased for all surgical cases in NCP (HR 0.94 (0.93-0.94, p<0.001) and even more so in CP (HR 0.93 (0.91-0.95, p<0.001) over time; indicating that for every one year increase in time the odds of mortality decreased by 6% in NCP and 7% in CP. In the propensity matched analysis, CP had an increased length of stay (median of 9 versus 8 days, p<0.001), rate of inpatient mortality (12.8% versus 5.6%, p<0.001), were more likely to be discharged to a skilled nursing facility (22.3% versus 18.1%) and less likely to be a routine discharge (60.1% v. 53.8%, overall p<0.001) as compared to non-cirrhotic patients. CP did not have a clinically significant increase in complications.

Conclusion: The number of major operations performed on CP increased over time despite higher mortality as compared to NCP. Overall mortality for major operations in CP also decreased over time and at a faster rate than in NCP. Although cirrhosis remains a significant comorbidity, more major operations are being performed on this patient population, complications were not increased and survival outcomes may be improving.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Adrenalectomy for metastatic melanoma
author_block: M. A. Rose<sup>1</sup>, J. Miura<sup>2</sup>, G. Karakousis<sup>2</sup>, R. E. Roses<sup>2</sup>, L. E. Kuo<sup>3</sup>, B. M. Lindeman<sup>4</sup>, M. A. Nehs<sup>5</sup>, A. Tavakkoli<sup>5,6</sup>, S. Parangi<sup>7</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>2</sup>, B. C. James<sup>8</sup>, A. A. Carr<sup>9</sup>, T. S. Wang<sup>10</sup>, C. C. Solorzano<sup>11</sup>, C. C. Lubitz<sup>7</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery And Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Temple University,Department Of Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery And School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>5</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>6</sup>Laboratory for Surgical and Metabolic Research,Boston, MA, USA <sup>7</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>8</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of Southern California,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>10</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>11</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The adrenal glands are common sites of metastases. Metastasectomy is an increasingly utilized component of multi-modality oncologic therapy. The goal of this study is to analyze survival outcomes with adrenal metastasectomy in melanoma.

Methods:  This multi-institutional retrospective cohort study included patients who underwent adrenal metastasectomy for melanoma (2003-2019) at 6 institutions. Demographic and clinical data was abstracted. The primary outcomes were overall survival (OS), disease-free interval (DFI), and progression free survival (PFS). Kaplan Meier survival analysis was performed. Cox proportional hazards regression evaluated associations between survival and clinical characteristics.

Results: Of the 33 subjects in the multi-institutional cohort the median OS was 8.6 years. The median DFI from diagnosis of the primary tumor to adrenal metastasis was 3.2 years (IQR:1.1,9.0). On Cox regression analysis, size of adrenal metastasis (HR:1.207, p=0.0383) and oligometastases (>1 and ≤5 metastases) at primary diagnosis (HR:2.906, p=0.0453) were associated with higher rates of recurrence. Granular treatment data was available for a single institution subgroup (n=11). The mean age at initial melanoma diagnosis was 52.7±10.8 years. 37.5% of the primaries were T1a (n=3), 25.0% were T2a (n=2), and 12.5% each were T2b, T3b, and T4b. Mean primary tumor depth was 2.6±3.2mm, 87.5% had mitoses present, and 42.9% demonstrated ulceration. Two patients had tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes. The mean DFI from primary tumor to adrenal metastasis was 4.6±2.5 years. 36% were oligometastatic at the time of the first metastasis to any location. Neoadjuvant pembrolizumab was administered in 1 patient. Surgery was the most common treatment for metastases to any location (81.8% of first metastasis, n=9; 80.0% of second metastasis, n=8; 66.7% of third metastasis, n=4; 100.0% fourth metastasis, n=2). Adrenal metastasectomy was performed with curative intent in 72.7%, and for diagnostic purposes in 27.3% of patients. Adjuvant therapy included chemotherapy (n=3), radiation (n=4), targeted therapy (n=2), and immunotherapy (n=6). Median OS was 16.37 (IQR:12.7, NR) years (Fig. 1A). After adrenal metastasectomy, median PFS was 0.4 (IQR 0.3,7.9) years (Fig. 1B). 45.5% of patients had no evidence of disease at their last follow-up.

Conclusion: Multi-modality oncologic therapy in the current era of immune checkpoint inhibitors and targeted therapy may include multiple metastasectomies. Although recurrences are common, long-term survival is observed in selected patients undergoing adrenal metastasectomy for melanoma. OS in a single institution subgroup was longer than the multi-institutional cohort, potentially reflecting patient selection.

abstract_title: Information is Power: Evaluating Language Translation Content on Cancer Center Websites
author_block: P. C. Cevallos<sup>1,4</sup>, A. S. Baskin<sup>2</sup>, L. A. Dossett<sup>3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Dartmouth Medical School,Hanover, NH, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Michigan Center for Health Care Outcomes & Policy,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Health disparities in cancer disproportionately affect minority patients and arise due to sustained systemic racism in society. Minority patients receive less guideline-concordant care, report greater dissatisfaction with treatment outcomes, and participate less in shared decision-making. Without language translation services, minority patients with cancer face challenges accessing and understanding their diagnoses, affecting active participation in decision-making. Recognizing patients seek information online, cancer centers provide web-based information to complement what is provided in person. However, the extent to which hospital cancer websites target information to diverse populations is unknown and presents an opportunity to understand how we engage minority patients in their treatment.

Methods: We reviewed the websites of the U.S. News & World Report’s top 25 “Best Hospitals for Cancer” to characterize how treatment-related information is communicated to patients seeking online resources in languages other than English. We assessed websites’ translation services and the extent of translated material available.  Given videos and visual aids can overcome language barriers and enhance patients’ understanding of treatment-related material, we evaluated the videos and visuals available on these websites for breast and colon cancer.

Results: Of the 25 websites accessed, 40% (n=10) offered language translation functions, three of which were through Google Translate. Two websites with language translation capabilities only offered hospital information translation (e.g. “Preparing for your visit,” “Food services available,” “Parking & Visiting Hours”) but did not include translation of cancer-specific information. Patient educational videos were available on 76% (n=19) of hospitals’ breast cancer webpages and 48% (n=12) of colon cancer webpages. No videos featured language translation options. Visual aids were utilized by 60% (n=15) of the breast cancer webpages and 60% (n=15) of the colon cancer webpages. Most visual aids were diagrams without language translation (e.g. anatomical graphics).

Conclusion: Cancer care aims to employ shared decision-making to navigate the complex and varied treatment options. Hospitals provide substantial treatment-related information on their websites to engage patients in the decision-making process. However, the lack of translated educational material online represents a gap contributing to compromised dissemination of cancer-related information to minority patients. To provide important clinical information to all patients, website language translation should be comprehensive, encompassing disease-specific information and utilizing multi-lingual video and visual aids when appropriate. Ultimately, hospital websites should strive to build equitable information platforms to facilitate the dismantling of structural racism contributing to health disparities in cancer care.

abstract_title: Pancreaticoduodenectomy can be Safely Performed in Appropriately-Resourced Rural Health Care Centers
author_block: Z. Morrison<sup>1</sup>, H. Van Steenburgh<sup>2</sup>, S. Gabel<sup>3</sup>, R. Gabor<sup>4</sup>, R. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, J. Wernberg<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Marshfield Clinic Health Center,Marshfield Medical Center,Marshfield, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,School Of Medicine And Public Health,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Sparrow Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Lansing, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>Marshfield Clinic Health System,Marshfield Clinic Research Institute,Marshfield, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Demonstration of improved patient safety and treatment outcomes has led to regionalization of complex surgical oncology procedures to high-volume centers which are often located in urban areas. This trend can have unintended negative consequences for rural patients, their families, and rural health care systems. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) is a complex procedure for which data is available regarding volume-outcome relationships. We hypothesize that outcomes following PD performed at an appropriately-resourced rural health care facility are comparable to published national standards, which have been reported mostly by large urban academic institutions.

Methods: A retrospective review was conducted of a prospectively-maintained, single-institution database of pancreatic resections. We extracted demographic, surgical, and hospitalization-related information from patients who underwent PD between October 2007 and February 2019. Primary outcomes were the 90-day rates of patient mortality and morbidity. Secondary outcomes were the 30- and 90-day rates of hospital readmission, indications for readmission, and statistical associations between readmission and clinical variables. Institutional hospital readmission rates were compared to published national data.

Results: 118 patients met study criteria. Half of the patients were female (n=58, 49.2%), and the mean age was 64.6 years. Almost all surgeries were performed by a fellowship-trained surgical oncologist or hepatobiliary surgeon (n=113, 95.8%). There was one death (0.9%). 41 patients (34.7%) had a postoperative complication. The most common complication was pancreatic fistula / leak (n=23, 19.5%). The institution-specific 30- and 90-day readmission rates were 14.41% and 24.58%, respectively. The most common reason for readmission was deep space infection (n=7, 24.1%). The only clinical variable statistically associated with hospital readmission at 90 days was the requirement for a blood transfusion (41.4% of patients readmitted vs 9.0% of patients not readmitted, p=0.016). A meta-analysis published in 2018 reporting data from almost 20,000 patients found a mean 30-day readmission rate of 17.63% and a mean 90-day readmission rate of 26.14%. These rates were statistically similar to our institutional data, with p-values of 0.36 and 0.70, respectively.

Conclusion: PD is a complex operation with historically high morbidity and mortality. Regionalization of these cases to high-volume hospitals and high-volume surgeons has improved surgical outcomes, but this trend has tended to concentrate pancreatic surgery, especially PD, to urban hospitals. Our data show that comparable patient safety and surgical outcomes are possible in appropriately-resourced rural hospitals with properly-trained staff and high case volumes. Medical professionals and the public can be reassured that high-quality care for complex surgical oncology patients is accessible outside of major metropolitan areas.

abstract_title: Association Between Succinate Dehydrogenase Pathogenic Variants and Cancer
author_block: L. R. Kelz<sup>1</sup>, M. Rose<sup>3</sup>, K. L. Nathanson<sup>2</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Genetics,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) germline pathogenic variants (PVs) are associated with development of gastrointestinal stromal tumors, pheochromocytomas, paragangliomas and renal cell carcinomas. Associations with other cancers, including breast cancer, have been suggested. The goal of this study was to determine the prevalence of SDH PVs in patients undergoing multigene testing for cancer.

Methods:  Patients ages 18-90 years old who underwent multigene panel testing for cancer predisposition genes (Ambry Genetics, Aliso Viejo, CA) between March 2012 to December 2016 were included in Interactive Prevalence Tables (www.ambrygen.com/providers/resources/prevalence-tool). The prevalence tables were queried to identify the association between SDH subunits (SDHA, SDHB, SDHC, and SDHD) and common cancers (breast, colorectal, endometrial or uterine, kidney, melanoma, ovarian, pancreatic, prostate, or thyroid). Frequency of PVs, cancer status, and cancer type were evaluated.  Odds ratios (OR) for cancer were calculated; a p-value of ≤0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Of the 150,319 subjects included in the prevalence tool, 9,626 were tested for SDHx mutations. Within this cohort, 20 patients had SDHA PVs (0.21%), 27 SDHB PVs (0.28%), 10 SDHC PVs (0.10%), and 18 SDHD PVs (0.19%). When evaluating subjects by personal cancer history, of 41,058 subjects with no personal history of cancer, 2,704 were tested for SDHx.  Of these, PVs were identified in 10 subjects (5 SDHA (0.18%), 5 SDHB (0.18%)). Of 102,824 subjects with a personal history of any cancer, 6,154 were tested for SDHx. In this subgroup, PVs were identified in 12 SDHA (0.19%), 12 SDHB (0.19%), 9 SDHD (0.15%), and 4 SDHC (0.06%). When analyzing patients by cancer type, breast cancer was the only cancer in which SDHx PVs were identified at ≥0.01%prevalence. Of the 79,368 subjects with a personal history of breast cancer, 4,010 were tested for SDHx. Germline PVs were 8 SDHA (0.2%), 7 SDHB (0.17%), and 6 SDHD (0.15%). Compared with patients with no SDHx PVs, PVs in neither SDHA (OR: 1.055, p=1.000) nor SDHB (OR: 1.055, p=1.000) were associated with a significantly increased risk of cancer of any type. In breast cancer specifically, compared with patients with no SDHx PVs, PVs in neither SDHA (OR: 1.079, p=1.000) nor SDHB (OR: 0.944, p=1.000) were associated with a statistically significant risk of breast cancer.

Conclusion: In this study of subjects undergoing multigene panel testing for hereditary cancers, patients with no personal history of cancer in general, or breast cancer specifically did not have higher prevalence of SDH PVs. Further investigations are required to determine the SDH-associated cancer risk, compared to reference populations.

abstract_title: Comparing cancer care provider perceptions relative to their role in the provision of spiritual care
author_block: E. Palmer Kelly<sup>1</sup>, M. Hyer<sup>1</sup>, D. Tsilimigras<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The provision of spiritual care by an interprofessional healthcare team is an important, yet frequently neglected, component of patient-centered cancer care. In particular, providers may be uncertain about their role in patient spiritual care. We sought to define cancer care provider perspectives relative to spiritual care behaviors, as well as characterize how different members of the healthcare team perceive offering religious and spiritual (R&S) care.

Methods:  A cross-sectional R&S survey was administered to healthcare providers (i.e. someone authorized to diagnose and/or treat physical or mental health disorders) employed at a large Comprehensive Cancer Center in the Midwest. Pearson’s chi-square test was used to compare provider perspectives.

Results: Among 340 participants, most participants were female (82.1%) and White (82.6%); median age was 35 years (IQR: 31-48). Providers included nurses (64.7%), physicians (17.9%), and “other” providers (17.4%). Most respondents identified as religious (57.5%), followed by spiritual (30.2%) or neither religious nor spiritual (12.3%). There was a difference in provider perceptions about discussing patient R&S issues. Specifically, nurses more frequently inquired about R&S (60.3%), while physicians were less likely (41.4%)(p=0.02). Among providers who did engage patients about R&S, self-reported time spent on R&S with patients (“right amount” vs. “too little”) was similar (nurses, 63.8% vs. physicians, 50.9%)(p=0.106). When faced with a patient in need of support, nurses more frequently used chaplaincy or another R&S resource (65.5%), while physicians and other providers more often consulted psychology or psychiatry (57.1% and 47.5%, respectively; p<0.001). Only 10% of physicians self-reported the belief that provision of spiritual care was within their role; in contrast, 25% and 64% of “other” providers and nurses reported that their role included providing spiritual care to patients (p=0.006). Perceived barriers to not discussing R&S topics included potentially offending patients (56.5%) and time limitations (47.7%) (Figure).

Conclusion: Health care providers markedly differed in their self-perceived roles to offer R&S assistance in the clinical setting. Identifying barriers to providing services – including R&S support – is critical to inform strategies to improve holistic care of cancer patients.

abstract_title: Virtual, Synchronous, and Decentralized Resident Training for Open and Laparoscopic Skills
author_block: P. Conroy<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Lin<sup>1</sup>, H. Chern<sup>1</sup>, M. Karimzada<sup>1</sup>, A. Alseidi<sup>1</sup>, P. O'Sullivan<sup>1</sup>, J. Rapp<sup>1</sup>, S. Syed<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of California San Francisco,Department Of Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Given the challenge of training residents during COVID-19, we instituted virtual (exclusively by video conference) and hybrid (mixed video conference and limited small-group in-person coaching) sessions for open and laparoscopic skills. Synchronous instruction was provided to decentralized residents. We aimed to study feasibility, outcomes, and resident perceptions of these adaptations.

Methods: Residents participated via smartphone and webcam either individually at home or in small groups at clinical sites. First-year residents (R1s) received open skills kits for hybrid sessions; second-year residents (R2s) received laparoscopic practice boxes for virtual sessions. We assessed the following: feasibility by execution of planned sessions and attendance, outcomes by comparing video skills assignment scores with those of historic R1 cohorts since 2017, and perceptions by using web-based surveys distributed to 49 R1s and 13 R2s.

Results: Feasibility: All skills sessions (7/7) and site-based small groups (20/20) were held as scheduled, despite two residents and three instructors quarantined. Attendance was 94% for hybrid (92/98 resident-sessions) and 76% for virtual (34/45 resident-sessions). Some hybrid sessions were converted to virtual due to instructor quarantines. 65% of small groups (13/20) had in-person coaching. Outcomes: 49 R1s in the hybrid cohort and 135 R1s in historic cohorts completed 4 video skill assignments. One-handed square knot-tying scores significantly decreased from 42.5±4.5 to 35.0±7.3 (p<0.001) out of 45, but scores were unchanged for three other skills: two-handed square knot-tying, instrument tying, and simple running suturing. Perceptions: 76% (37/49) of R1s and 62% (8/13) of R2s responded to the survey. Of R1s, 90% (28/31) perceived hybrid sessions as safe for physical distancing and 10% (3/31) perceived them as possibly safe. 54% (15/28) felt sessions contributed to a sense of community. 88% (30/34) found the hybrid curriculum helpful; 12% (4/34) found it possibly helpful. Of R1s who experienced small groups with and without in-person coaching, 80% (8/10) found in-person coaching more helpful and 20% (2/10) felt it made no difference. Of R2s, 86% (6/7) found virtual sessions useful, 43% (3/7) found them equivalent to prior in-person sessions, and all felt they could put the developed skills into practice. Residents found the virtual modality convenient, effective for focused feedback, and helpful for observing peer skills and feedback. Broadly, residents favored returning to centralized in-person instruction when possible.

Conclusion: Virtual, synchronous, decentralized skills training is feasible with stable outcomes for most skills. One-handed knot-tying likely required tactile coaching. This model is an important adaptation to surgical training in the era of COVID-19 and can be applied to future challenges in delivering skills instruction, including outside of traditional skills lab facilities.

abstract_title: Predictors of Early Career to Independent Grant Conversion Among Surgeon Scientists
author_block: G. M. Rossmiller<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. S. Keswani<sup>1,2,3</sup>, K. L. Singampalli<sup>1,2,3,4,5</sup>, U. M. Parikh<sup>1,2,3</sup>, M. Sadhukhan<sup>1,2,3</sup>, B. Xie<sup>1,2,3</sup>, G. Shankar<sup>1,2,3</sup>, L. Masri<sup>1,2,3</sup>, M. Potturu<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,The Laboratory For Regenerative Tissue Repair,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Medical Scientist Training Program,Houston, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Rice University,Department Of Bioengineering,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The National Institutes of Health (NIH) provides research funding to scientists at different stages of their career through a range of grant awards. Early stage researchers are eligible for Career Development (K) awards, which are mentor-based awards that aid in the transition to independent funding, typically an R-series grant. Factors such as education, subspecialty, and time to funding have been studied as predictors of obtaining independent awards in some specialties. However, in surgery, the importance of these factors has yet to be clearly elucidated. We aim to identify predictors of K to independent award conversion among surgeon scientists to understand how to better support early stage researchers transitioning to independent careers.

Methods: In July 2020, the NIH Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools database was queried for individuals affiliated with surgery departments who received NIH Career Development Awards (K01, K08, or K23) between 2010 and 2020. Data gathered include: year of the K award, number of manuscripts published using the K award, receipt of independent funding (I01, R01, R03, R34, R37, R41, R44, R56, or U01), number and years of independent awards, and total independent NIH funding. Demographics, including educational background, subspecialty, and the year of completion of clinical training, were collected using faculty biography webpages. Clinicians with an MD or equivalent degree who underwent surgical residency were included. Statistical significance was defined at p<0.05.

Results: Between 2010 and 2020, 127 surgeons received K Awards, of which 35 (28%) transitioned to independent funding. Of the 67 surgeons who received K awards prior to 2015, 29 (43%) successfully transitioned. 112 (88%) of the surgeons with K awards and 31 (88%) of those with independent awards trained in general surgery, with Trauma and Critical Care being the most common fellowship. 40% of those who converted, compared to 30% of those who did not, hold dual degrees. Furthermore, 40% of those who converted went from a K08 to an R01, making it the most common pathway. On average, surgeons received a K award 4.3 years after completing fellowship training and an independent award 4.4 years after receiving a K grant. The time to a K award did not predict independent funding, the number of independent grants, or independent funding amount. Those with independent funding had a significantly greater number of publications per year of their K-award (4.8 vs. 3.0, p<0.05).

Conclusion: Surgeon scientists demonstrate success in transitioning to independent NIH awards; however, the timeline is extensive, taking approximately 9 years after the end of fellowship. Publication track record is the main factor contributing to successful conversion from a K award. As such, surgery departments should emphasize manuscript productivity and develop strategies to minimize time to independent funding to help K-awardees begin independent research careers.

abstract_title: Are Surgeons Discussing Ethics? Analysis of Ethical Concepts in Surgical and Medical Journals
author_block: K. Popli<sup>1</sup>, M. F. Amendola<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University School of Medicine,Richmond, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hunter Holmes McGuire Veteran Affairs Hospital,Richmond, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Surgical ethics has been suggested as a distinct field of study separate from clinical ethics by virtue of a unique practice type and treatment dynamic. Previous quantitative analysis found an ‘ethics gap’ in the surgical literature compared to comparable medical journals. We wished to update this analysis to examine if the ethics gap has persisted and to detail what ethical issues surgeons are discussing in their literature to understand if ethics should become a larger component of continuing medical education.

Methods:  PubMed was examined from 2008 to 2018 for the MeSH term “ethics”. The top twelve impact factor journals in medicine and surgery were examined. Surgical articles were examined for the ethical concepts (autonomy, justice, beneficences and nonmaleficence), number of words used and specialty.

Results: Medical journals had an average impact factor of 25.3 ± 23.9 and average number of ethics articles of 208.3 ± 264.8 while surgical journals had an average impact factor of 4.2 ± 2.4 and average number of articles of 19.1 ± 20.2 (p=0.006 for impact factor and p=0.03 for article count, t-test). Surgical journals had statistically higher mean word counts of 2100.8 ± 1285.4 compared to medical journals 1254.2 ± 1035.3 (p=0.0001, t-test). Examining for the ethical principles shown in the table attached, any of the four principles of autonomy, justice, beneficences and nonmaleficence was statistically mentioned more often (p=0.0001**) in surgical journals (100/229; 43.7%) compared to medical journals (480/2065; 23.2%)

Conclusion: Top impact factor surgical journals continue to statistically lag behind medical journals in describing ethical issues in practice. However, when surgical articles present ethical issues, they use more average words and more likely to have one of the four clinical ethical principles present in the content. These data should inform the surgical community of the need to describe and publish on ethical issues that are commonly found in surgical practice to close the previously described surgical ethics gap. These data should also guide potential topics for future continuing medical education focusing on surgical ethics to encourage more discussion, as well as demonstrate the importance of teaching surgical ethics at the undergraduate and graduate medical education level so students are exposed to these issues early on and are encouraged to contribute to the literature on surgical ethics during their careers.

abstract_title: Inconspicuous Anguish: Gender Differences in Coping Strategies
author_block: J. D'Angelo<sup>1</sup>, R. Busch<sup>2</sup>, S. Tevis<sup>3</sup>, S. Lund<sup>4</sup>, K. Mathis<sup>1</sup>, S. Kelley<sup>1</sup>, A. D'Angelo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mayo Clinic,Colon And Rectal Surgery,Rochester, MN, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Division Of Acute Care And Regional General Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Breast Surgical Oncology,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>4</sup>Mayo Clinic,General Surgery,Rochester, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: At some point in their career, a surgeon will make an operative error. While post-operative coping strategies among surgeons have been identified, and medical errors have been found to have a significant impact on physicians, little research has considered the physical and psychological steps taken by a surgeon immediately after making an error in the operating room (OR). Hence, the first study aim is to assess for different types of intra-operative coping strategies along with post-operative coping strategies. While gender differences have emerged in research on surgeon psychological well-being, no research has investigated gender differences in operative coping strategies. Thus, the second study aim is to evaluate differences in how male and female surgeons cope with errors.

Methods: An electronic survey was distributed to surgical faculty and trainees at three institutions. Variables included coping techniques after making an error in the OR. Participants were asked to report how effective their overall coping strategy was (5-point Likert scale, 1=not effective at all to 5=extremely effective), and whether they identified short term or long term effects on their own operative performance (5-point Likert scale, 1=very negative to 5=very positive). Chi-Square tests with a Bonferroni Correction were used to test for gender differences in coping strategies. Welch’s t-tests were used to test for differences in views of coping.

Results: A total of 168 participants (56% male, 45% faculty) experienced an operative error and answered questions regarding coping strategies. There were significant differences between males and females in both intra- and post-operative coping strategies (Figure 1). Males (M=3.69/5, SE=.09) viewed their overall coping strategy as more effective than females (M=3.38/5, SE=.09), t(158.86)=2.47, p=.015. Females (M=2.47/5, SE=.08) were more likely to report that errors had a negative impact on their immediate subsequent performance compared to males (M=2.73/5, SE=.08), t(156.41)=2.32, p=.022. Males (M=3.68/5, SE=.07) were more likely to report a positive impact on their long term operative performance compared to females (M=3.45/5, SE=.09), t(145.10)=2.06, p=.042..

Conclusion: While both male and female surgeons reported making errors in the OR, there exist differences in the strategies surgeons use to cope with these mistakes. Importantly, females were more likely to view their coping strategies as less effective and identify the error as having a more negative impact on operative performance. These findings may provide important insight into prior work demonstrating that female surgeons experience burnout at higher rates and have poorer psychological well-being.

abstract_title: Impact of Public Service Loan Forgiveness on Trainees
author_block: M. K. Khoury<sup>1,2</sup>, R. E. Jones<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Gee<sup>1</sup>, L. R. Taveras<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Boniakowski<sup>3</sup>, D. M. Coleman<sup>3</sup>, K. R. Abdelfattah<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Rectenwald<sup>2</sup>, R. M. Minter<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Vascular Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) program is a frequently utilized loan forgiveness program among medical trainees with federal educational debt. To qualify for forgiveness via PSLF, medical graduates must serve for ten years working for non-profit institutions. PSLF has been criticized in the lay press because of poor success rates, with the program granting forgiveness to only 1% of applicants. Moreover, it is unknown if anticipation of forgiveness from PSLF impacts trainee decisions regarding specialty choice or length of training. The purpose of this study was to understand the prevalence, impact, and understanding of PSLF participation on medical trainees.

Methods:  An anonymous Web-based survey was created to assess federal debt, awareness of PSLF and participation, and PSLF influence on career choices. This was distributed to 2,483 residents of all specialties at three major academic medical centers.

Results: There were 934 respondents, yielding a response rate 37.6%. The median amount of debt was $230,000 [IQR $160,000-$300,000]. A total of 416/934 (44.5%) respondents were actively or planning on participating in the PSLF program with 175/934 (18.7%) belonging to a surgical specialty. There were no differences in amount of debt between surgical and non-surgical trainees ($223,778 [IQR $154,250-$300,000] versus $230,000 [IQR $163,000-$300,000], P=.305). Those belonging to a surgical specialty were more likely to be actively participating or planning to participate in the PSLF program when compared to medical specialties (53.1% versus 42.6%, P=.012). For those participating in PSLF, 82/416 (19.7%) either elected for longer training (academic years, additional training, etc.) or chose a less lucrative specialty in anticipation of receiving loan forgiveness; with no differences between surgical versus medical specialties (16.1% versus 20.7%, P=.376). The majority (70.4%, n=239/416) of PSLF participants did not take low success rates into account when deciding whether or not to participate in the program. A total of 275/934 (29.4%) respondents obtained and 437/934 (46.8%) wanted to receive formal training/lectures in regards to the PSLF program; with 15/934 (1.6%) respondents never knowing the program existed prior to the survey. Of those actively or planning on participating in the PSLF program, only 58/416 (13.9%) were able to correctly identify the qualifications/criteria to complete the program.

Conclusion: A large proportion of trainees are relying on the PSLF program for loan forgiveness. In addition, reliance on this program affects trainee decision making in regards to specialty choice and length of training. However, the majority of trainees do not appear to understand the qualifications/criteria of this program, which may be contributing to low success rates of the program. Residency programs should strongly consider providing a formal curriculum in finance and loan forgiveness to their trainees.

abstract_title: Virtual or in-person? Grand rounds in the era of Covid-19
author_block: R. C. Bynum<sup>1</sup>, A. Holder<sup>1</sup>, D. Chu<sup>1</sup>, D. Sutzko<sup>1,2</sup>, B. Corey<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Birmingham Veteran's Affairs Medical Center,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The COVID-19 pandemic has presented significant challenges to all aspects of clinical and operative activity as well as surgical education. As academic medical centers have pivoted to provide on-going education while appropriately socially distancing, virtual conferences have quickly become commonplace. While this technology has allowed for increased flexibility and the potential for greater inter-institutional collaboration, the change in format has not been without challenges, from technological to limited interpersonal interactions. As such, this study seeks to evaluate the overall effectiveness of virtual surgical grand rounds (VGR) using survey data from grand rounds attendees and attendance data from before and after the implementation of VGR.

Methods:  Attendance data was compared from before and after the implementation of VGR at one large academic institution. Demographics of attendees that were recorded in attendance data include gender and academic rank. Additionally, a voluntary survey developed from prior data and analysis of focus groups regarding the effectiveness of surgical grand rounds was administered to attendees using Qualtrics survey software. Demographics of the survey participants were self-reported and included current academic rank, years in practice, and gender. Reponses and attendance rates were then compared across groups. All responses were anonymous.

Results: Attendance at virtual grand rounds averaged 145 individuals versus 121 for in-person grand rounds (IGR). Of the survey results that were collected, 26% were from residents, 3% instructor/fellows, 20% assistant, 14% associate, and 20% professors. 65% of respondents were male, 32% female, and 3% preferred not to answer. IGR was considered to be moderately effective at disseminating knowledge by 69%, very effective by 14%, and 3% found it extremely effective. In contrast, VGR was considered to be moderately effective 37%, very effective by 34%, and extremely effective by 14%. VGR was more likely to be considered valuable with 37% rating it as very valuable versus 14% for IGR. Overall, 70% of individuals preferred VGR over IGR.

Conclusion: This study sought to define the audiences’ perception of virtual surgery grand rounds as compared to in-person surgery grand rounds. Overall, VGR was preferred by attendees, both male and female, when compared to in-person Grand rounds. VGR is perceived to be as effective or more at imparting knowledge and building a departmental identity as IGR. Increased attendance was also seen at VGR. These findings support maintaining some form of virtual Grand Rounds into the future.

abstract_title: Surgeon Opioid Behaviors and Patient Counseling
author_block: K. Vu<sup>1</sup>, G. H. Rosen<sup>1</sup>, K. S. Murray<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Missouri,Department Of Surgery,Columbia, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Overdose deaths involving opioids are increasing in the United States. Patients are prescribed more opioid than required, and unneeded medications are abused. A majority of patients store and dispose of opioids improperly, partially due to gaps in knowledge. Since 2017, the American Medical Association (AMA) has recommended three steps to increase appropriate storage and disposal of opioids by patients; talking with patients about proper use; reminding them to safely store; and urging disposal of unused medications. We examine the personal use, storage, and disposal of narcotics by surgeons and evaluate how this modulates patient counseling.  

Methods: After institutional review board approval, we crafted a survey of provider opioid use, storage, and disposal patterns and patient counseling knowledge and behaviors, which was sent to all faculty surgeons at our institution. Statistical analyses were performed in R with student’s t-tests, chi-squared tests, and Fisher’s exact test.

Results: The survey was distributed to 98 physicians with 30 responses (funding cap) in January 2020, for a 31% response rate. Respondents and non-respondents were similar in age, gender, and medical school graduation year; however, they differed in surgical specialty (Fisher’s test, P = 0.01), with the bulk of respondents being general surgeons (43%). In the last 5 years, 47% of respondents were prescribed an opioid, and 23% disposed of opioids. Thirty percent had unneeded opioids at home. The majority (73%) knew proper opioid disposal. Fewer respondents (67%) were comfortable counseling, and even fewer (17%) regularly provided disposal counseling. None reported supplying an opioid to family members or friends. Participants who regularly provided disposal counseling were more likely female (60% vs 12%, P = 0.04) but did not differ significantly from those who did not in any other assessed way.

Conclusion: For the first time, we describe physician opioid use, storage, and disposal patterns and link this to knowledge, confidence, and patient counseling about opioid disposal. Physicians do not have ideal self-reported behaviors. Among only those prescribed opioids in the last 5 years, 57% reported having unneeded opioids in their homes and only 36% reported having disposed of opioids in the last 5 years. The AMA recommends counseling patients regarding safe opioid storage and disposal. To our knowledge, there have been no studies examining implementation of this practice. Only 17% of surgeons endorsed regularly counseling on opioid disposal, while 67% felt comfortable having this conversation, demonstrating a knowledge and action gap. Overall, future studies will link reported behaviors to prescribing practice and define the link between physician counseling and patient behaviors. This early pilot serves as a starting benchmark regarding physicians’ personal narcotic safety behaviors and counseling practices.

abstract_title: Measuring Robotic Operative Participation – Does Gender Matter?
author_block: W. M. Oslock<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Lansing<sup>1</sup>, S. Maroney<sup>2</sup>, E. Huang<sup>2</sup>, H. Pieper<sup>2</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>2</sup>, S. Noria<sup>2</sup>, S. Husain<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,College Of Medicine,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University,Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although recent studies have raised concern that gender impacts resident operative participation, robust quantitative analyses are lacking. Robotic surgery offers embedded data to directly probe this question via percentage time trainees directly control the console (CONSOLE TIME). We sought to determine if trainee operative participation differed based on surgeon characteristics. 

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed prospectively collected case-level robotic surgery data from a single institution, examining trainee console time and surgeon characteristics. Surgeon characteristics included trainee gender and PGY level, and attending gender, specialty, and experience: ESTABLISHED (5+ years) or EARLY CAREER (<5 years). Only cases with an attending-trainee dyad that allowed identification of surgeon characteristic were included. We compared average trainee console time across these categories using 2-tailed t-tests or ANOVA. We developed a multivariable regression model to predict factors associated with increased operative participation by trainees.

Results: Over a one-year study period, 777 robotic operations from 7 specialties met inclusion criteria. Most specialties had a specific procedure make up the majority of their robotic cases: 6/7 (85.7%) colorectal cases were partial colectomies, 19/33 (57.6%) thoracic surgery cases were lobectomies, 55/82 (67.0%) gynecology oncology cases and 20/37 (54.1%) gynecology cases were hysterectomy without nodal dissection. The most common procedure for urology was radical retropubic prostatectomy with node dissection 127/271 (49.6%), for general surgery it was cholecystectomy 94/287 (32.8%), and for surgical oncology it was adrenalectomy 8/60 (13.3%). 40 female trainees (62.5% of trainees) performed 312 (40.2%) of the analyzed operations while 13 female attendings (32.5% of surgeons) performed 112 (14.4%) of the analyzed operations. The majority of attendings (72.5%) were early career and performed 662 (85.6%) of the operations. In univariate analysis (Table), increased trainee console time was significantly associated with female trainees, PGY7, and female attendings. In multivariate analysis, only trainee level and specialty maintained significance. Specific surgeon had the largest impact on univariate analysis, accounting for 46% of variance while specialty accounted for 24% of variance.

Conclusion: Differences in trainees’ robotic operative experiences appear primarily driven by specialty and trainee level, with individual surgeons’ practices being the most important factor. While these findings reflect practices at a single, relatively diverse institution and do not control for case complexity, we did not find female trainee gender or attending inexperience associated with decreased trainee participation.

abstract_title: Impact of Resilience on Healthcare Providers' Experiences During COVID-19
author_block: N. E. Anton<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Athanasiadis<sup>1</sup>, L. A. Haskett<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Huffman<sup>1</sup>, D. Doster<sup>1</sup>, D. Stefanidis<sup>1</sup>, N. K. Lee<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Healthcare providers on the front lines during the COVID-19 pandemic may be experiencing heightened stress due to concerns about managing COVID positive patients, spreading illness to their families, among other factors. Resilience is a psychological factor defined by the ability to thrive in the face of adversity, cope effectively with stress, and maintain stable psychological functioning. Our team sought to determine if resilience was a protective factor against healthcare providers’ stress during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Methods: Following an iterative survey design process, the study team developed a 42-item survey examining providers’ psychological well-being, stress level, and sources of stress due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The survey also included the 2-item version of the Connor-Davidson Resilience Scale, which includes items related to a respondent’s ability to adapt when changes occur and their tendency to bounce back after hardships. The survey was distributed to physicians, residents, and fellows at a large academic institution for departmental distribution among multiple departments including internal medicine and surgery, among several others. Survey results were analyzed using descriptive statistics and multivariate linear regressions adjusting for potential confounders such as role, specialty, resilience score, and years of experience. 

Results: Five hundred and ninety-seven clinicians (403 - 67.5% attendings, 40 - 6.7% fellows, 154 - 25.8% residents) completed the survey. We found that resilience was a predictor of significantly lower anxiety, change in stress, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and loss of professional identity since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic (p<0.01). Upon further analysis on the impact of the two resilience subscale items, adaptability and tendency to bounce back, we found that these aspects of resilience predicted significantly lower psychological disturbances since the start of COVID-19 (p<0.05). However, the resilience factors were not predictive of less worry from providers about spreading illness to their families. When comparing surgeons (n=71) to internal medicine physicians (n=177), both groups were similar in years of professional experience (median of 10-14 years, p=0.870). Surgeons reported significantly lower anxiety/nervousness, change in stress, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and perceived ability to perform professional duties since the start of COVID-19 (p<0.01). 

Conclusion: In the current study, we found that resilience, including both adaptability to challenges and a tendency to bounce back from hardships, are predictive of lower psychological disturbances since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. Surgeons reported lower psychological disturbances than internal medicine physicians, but less satisfaction with their roles since the start of COVID-19. Hospital systems should consider offering interventions to enhance healthcare providers’ resilience, including mental skills training.

abstract_title: Representation of Women on Surgical Journal Editorial Boards
author_block: M. Potturu<sup>1,2,3</sup>, L. Masri<sup>1,2,3</sup>, K. L. Singampalli<sup>1,2,3,4,5</sup>, U. M. Parikh<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. S. Keswani<sup>1,2,3</sup>, G. M. Rossmiller<sup>1,2,3</sup>, B. Xie<sup>1,2,3</sup>, G. Shankar<sup>1,2,3</sup>, M. Sadhukhan<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,The Laboratory For Regenerative Tissue Repair,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Medical Scientist Training Program,Houston, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Rice University,Department Of Bioengineering,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Though the representation of women in medicine has been rising, surgery remains a male-dominated specialty, especially in leadership positions. Surgeon scientists who are a part of journal editorial boards generally hold distinguished academic and professional roles, and this position serves as a marker of accomplishment in the research world. However, it is unclear whether the representation of women in these positions is reflective of the field. Our goal is to examine the differences between the male and female composition of surgical editorial boards to better inform the sex disparity among surgeon scientists.

Methods: Surgical journals from the Clairvate Web of Science Group Master Journals List with impact factors greater than 2 were analyzed for editorial board composition. Surgical journal websites and faculty biography pages were used to record demographic information for U.S.-based members of each editorial board, including sex, education, and subspecialty. For each editor-in-chief, the NIH Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools database was searched for funding history between 1985 and 2020, and the Scopus database for H-index and number of publications. Statistical analysis was performed via t-tests and ANOVA; significance was defined as p<0.05.

Results: 52 surgical specialty journals with impact factors ranging from 2 to 10.668 were analyzed. 2980 editorial board members were identified, of which 593 (20%) were female and 2387 (80%) were male. On average, 19% of the editorial board members for each journal were female, with no significant difference based on impact factor. Of the 57 chief editors from these journals, 4 (7%) were female. 28% of male chief editors were either a Chair or Vice-chair of a surgical department, while 75% of the female editors held the same role. Additionally, there was a wider distribution of degrees among males, with 33% of males and 25% of females having additional non-MD degrees. All of the female chief editors and 96% of the male chief editors had published manuscripts, with an average H-index of 41 and 50, respectively. Comparison of the H-index or total number of publications showed no statistical difference between male and female chief editors.

Conclusion: The editorial board composition of the top surgery journals based on sex shows a bias towards male editors, similar to the composition of the surgery physician workforce. Women are not only further underrepresented in editor-in-chief positions, but female editors-in-chief also tend to hold higher academic titles than their male counterparts, suggesting that women may be held to a higher standard to reach the same position. Therefore, achieving sex equality among journal leadership can act as a mechanism for reducing the sex disparity in surgery and promote the engagement of female surgeon scientists in impactful research.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 On Resident Education and Well-Being During and After the Surge
author_block: B. Chernock<sup>1</sup>, N. Glass<sup>1</sup>, Z. Sifri<sup>1</sup>, D. Livingston<sup>1</sup>, A. Kunac<sup>1</sup>, F. Sheikh<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rutgers, New Jersey Medical School,Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Department Of Surgery,Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 surge in the New York/New Jersey (NJ) metropolitan area necessitated a rapid expansion of ICU capacity and shift of work responsibilities for residents of all specialties.  Concern exists about the effect the surge had on resident education, responsibility for patient care, and wellbeing.

Methods: We administered a survey to trainees at a single academic institution with multiple teaching hospitals in Northern NJ where an ACGME Stage 3 Emergency Pandemic Response status was declared in April and May 2020. The survey, consisting of Likert-like scales, was distributed electronically with the initial survey during the surge (DS) on 4/21/2020 and a follow-up survey after the surge (AS) on 6/21/2020.  Data were analyzed using Chi square analysis to assess differences in responses over time.

Results: 106 residents across ten specialties completed 129 surveys (77 responses for initial survey and 52 for follow-up).  No differences were found between resident perceptions during and after the surge.  The majority of residents who responded were rotating at the main hospital (65%) and were Medicine, Surgical, Anesthesia or Emergency Medicine Residents (73% DS, 83% AS).  Nearly all residents (91% DS, 96% AS) felt that the pandemic impacted their education with the majority reporting negative consequences (69% DS, 77% AS). During the surge, residents reported increased or similar responsibility for patient care (Figure 1).  While most residents felt prepared for their clinical duties, there was a decrease in feelings regarding preparedness after the surge. Feelings of being overwhelmed were noted on both DS and AS surveys.  50% of residents felt the pandemic put a strain on both their physical and mental health, and >60% felt supported by their residency programs.  

Conclusion: Residents perceived that COVID-19 negatively affected their education and mental/physical well-being. These opinions did not change once the surge ended.  Since resurgence of COVID-19 infections is possible in the near future, programs must adapt to fulfill their educational mission. Training programs should work toward adequate preparedness, and should support physical and mental well-being both during and after pandemic crises.

abstract_title: Receiving Serious News Via Telemedicine: The Standardized Patient Experience
author_block: K. Kieran<sup>1,2</sup>, K. McDonough<sup>2</sup>, J. Struijk<sup>2</sup>, M. K. Johnston<sup>2,4</sup>, E. A. Kaplan<sup>2</sup>, A. Burke<sup>2,3</sup>, M. G. Sardesai<sup>2,3</sup>, M. Jackson<sup>2</sup>, K. O'Connor<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Seattle Children's Hospital,Urology,Seattle, WA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Washington,Seattle, WA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harborview Medical Center,Seattle, WA, USA <sup>4</sup>Montana State University,Bozeman, MT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Traditionally, serious conversations between providers and patients have been held in person. The COVID-19 crisis has prompted the rapid adoption of telemedicine for almost all health care.  We undertook this study to explore the perceptions of standardized patients (SPs) on the experience of receiving serious news in the telemedicine setting.

Methods:  Five SPs participated in a scenario wherein a medical student is asked to give serious news to the SP.  Five students and one SP participated in a “rolling” role play and were asked to provide concerning test results to the SP while attending to the SP’s emotional state and readiness, and developing a plan for next steps.  All SPs received an emailed survey asking them to comment on the specific experience of receiving serious news remotely.

Results:  Four (80%) SPs responded.  SPs rated their ability to perform as patients highly (mean 4.75/5) and to provide feedback to student learners (mean 4/5).  The perception of the SPs from the “patient” perspective is shown in the table below.  SPs commented that the most difficult parts of receiving serious news in the telemedicine setting related to empathy: perhaps not recognizing subtle language or nonverbal cues, lack of touch, and the “impersonal” nature of a computer screen.  All indicated that they would prefer to receive serious news in person. 

Conclusion:   SPs found that the cognitive aspects of medical visits could be readily accomplished via telemedicine.  However, verbal and nonverbal expressions of empathy were not readily apparent in the virtual setting.  Clinicians and patients should be aware of the limitations of the telemedicine setting and should consider strategies to foster strong relationships with patients in the virtual setting.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 on Surgical Resident Moral Distress
author_block: M. Fiorentino<sup>2</sup>, C. Goldstein<sup>2</sup>, A. C. Mosenthal<sup>3</sup>, A. Kunac<sup>2</sup> <sup>3</sup>Lahey Hospital Medical Center,Burlington, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>New Jersey Medical School,Surgery,Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Moral distress affects healthcare workers, especially in the setting of end of life care, futile care, or lack of resources. During the COVID-19 pandemic our hospital admitted over 600 COVID-19 patients, necessitating the creation of additional intensive care units (ICU) to accommodate the surge.  Surgery residents were deployed in this “surge” schedule to care for the high influx of critically ill patients. We hypothesized that moral distress was prevalent among surgical residents during the pandemic. 

Methods: We performed a cross sectional observational study to assess moral distress in surgical residents at a single academic institution.  We administered The Moral Distress for Health Care Professionals Survey (MMD-HP) to all residents in June 2020 following the COVID-19 peak in our region and the disbanding of our surge schedule. All residents deployed to an ICU were invited to attend a debriefing session led by a counselor. The MMD-HP is a 27-question survey that asks about frequency and level of distress for each scenario. It is scored from 0-432 with a score of >168 representing a high level of moral distress.  The debriefing session was analyzed qualitatively using the Sort and Sift method to identify themes. 

Results: A total of 34 residents completed the survey. The mean score of moral distress was 106.  Almost one fifth (18%) of residents met the threshold of having a high level of moral distress. The top five most distressing situations are described in Table 1. During the debriefing session, residents noted the “no visitor policy” prevented families from truly understanding the critical illness of their loved one resulting in prolonged futile care.  Other sources of distress discussed included the lack of appropriately trained staff and uncertainty about the treatments used for this new virus. All participants in the debriefing session praised COVID specific education from faculty and emotional support from faculty and peers.

Conclusion: During the COVID-19 pandemic, surgical residents experienced significant moral distress around providing futile care to patients. Peer support from fellow residents and emotional support from department leadership mitigates moral distress.

abstract_title: Research Year Interest among Medical Students Pursuing Surgical Residencies
author_block: T. C. Hunt<sup>1</sup>, A. Gusev<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine,Greenville, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Worcester, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Research years during medical school are becoming increasingly common as students aim to strengthen their residency applications for competitive specialties. Surgical fields have long valued research, and the average number of research items per applicant has risen steadily over the past decade in general surgery and the subspecialties. Recent curricular changes in reaction to COVID-19, coupled with the upcoming transition to pass/fail USMLE Step 1 scoring, may place an even larger emphasis on research productivity in resident selection. Our aim was to assess pre- and post-COVID-19 views on research years among medical students pursuing surgical residencies, using urology as a proxy for competitive surgical fields.

Methods:  An anonymous 11-item survey was distributed via the online urology applicant Google spreadsheet in May 2020. Responses were collected over a 10-day period via convenience sampling. Items consisted of multiple-choice questions and 0-100 rating scales assessing interest in taking a research year, underlying motivations, career intentions, and basic demographics.

Results: In total, 80 complete responses were collected. Precise response rate is difficult to discern due to convenience sampling; however, a very conservative estimate using the average number of applicants in the urology match from 2016-2020 yields a rate of 17.4% (80/460). Respondents were predominantly male (61%), aged 25-34 (93%), at US MD (84%) or DO (10%) institutions with a home urology program (88%), and applying for residency in the upcoming cycle (93%). Nearly half (44%) of respondents indicated that COVID-19, current academic policy changes, and/or uncertainty in the upcoming match had affected their interest in taking a research year. Of those, 89% indicated their interest in taking a research year had increased. Across all respondents, the pre-COVID-19 mean interest in taking a research year was 21/100; post-COVID-19 this rose to 31/100. In those who previously reported increased interest, scores rose from 34/100 to 54/100. Most frequently cited motivations for increased interest were to avoid the ban on away rotations, improve one’s CV or ERAS application, and skip this year’s match entirely. Interest in a future academic career or enjoying research activities were less often cited.

Conclusion: Medical students pursuing urology residency are significantly worried about this year’s match due to academic changes and uncertainty stemming from the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, their interest in pursuing a research year has markedly increased. Similar sentiments are likely present among applicants to other competitive surgical fields. Notably, interest in research itself appears less important to students while improving residency application strength is a primary concern. Given these findings, additional resources and opportunities for medical student research years in surgical fields may be needed to accommodate increased demand.

abstract_title: Root Cause Analysis: a Workshop to Engage Residents in Quality Improvement
author_block: A. C. Filiberto<sup>1</sup>, L. A. Cooper<sup>2</sup>, G. A. Sarosi<sup>1</sup>, S. Tan<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Florida,Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida,Office For Educational Affairs,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We developed a workshop to engage general surgery residents in quality improvement (QI) using the root cause analysis (RCA) model. The workshop allowed for a robust learning experience through a virtual platform to address important aspects of a frequently used QI tool in the systematic assessment of an adverse event.

Methods: A general surgery resident and a faculty moderator with experience in QI facilitated the workshop. A group of residents were actively engaged in the workshop. Facilitators followed a scripted model to teach important patient safety concepts with case presentations and application of the QI tools. During the workshop, participants reviewed two clinical cases and addressed key concepts of a RCA. A survey was created and administered pre and post workshop to assess knowledge and comfort with participating in one.

Results: Over the course of one academic year, the workshop was implemented 2 times with roughly 20 general surgery residents in attendance at each workshop. Participants completed a survey indicating that 73% learned something new, 69% felt they could apply the material to their work, and 76% would recommend the workshop to a colleague.

Conclusion: This 60-minute RCA workshop can provide hands-on QI experience in a standardized format to achieve the dual objectives of teaching QI to clinicians and allowing them to generate innovations. This stands as an effective way to expose residents to the RCA model for future application to practical clinical scenarios.  The workshop will be repeated again with more residents in the future.

abstract_title: A Survey of the Impact of the COVID-19 Crisis on Skill Decay Among Surgery and Anesthesia Residents
author_block: C. P. Nofi<sup>1</sup>, B. K. Roberts<sup>1</sup>, L. Demyan<sup>1</sup>, N. Sodhi<sup>2</sup>, D. Deperalta<sup>1,3</sup>, A. Zimmern<sup>1,3</sup>, J. Arohnson<sup>4</sup>, E. Molmenti<sup>1,3</sup>, V. Patel<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Northwell NorthShore/Long Island Jewish,Department Of Surgery,New Hyde Park, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Northwell NorthShore/Long Island Jewish,Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery,New Hyde Park, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Hofstra University,Zucker School Of Medicine,New Hyde Park, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>Northwell NorthShore/Long Island Jewish,Department Of Anesthesia,New Hyde Park, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) pandemic has profoundly impacted healthcare delivery and strained medical training. This study explores resident and faculty attitudes regarding the impact of the COVID-19 crisis, reduced caseloads and redeployment on surgery, surgical subspecialty and anesthesia residency training in the epicenter of the pandemic in New York. We hypothesized that residents and faculty alike are concerned about resident technical skill decay and fulfillment of ACGME requirements, however are not concerned regarding the development of critical care skills and core competencies.

Methods: A web-based cross-sectional survey was distributed to residents and faculty at two large, urban academic medical centers of one health system in New York. Residents and teaching faculty of general surgery, plastic surgery, cardiothoracic surgery, orthopaedic surgery, oral maxillofacial surgery, urology, podiatry, and anesthesiology programs were included. 

Results: The majority of residents (87% of 91) reported a significant impact on their training. Residents (82%) and faculty (94%) reported a significant reduction in case volumes due to the COVID pandemic (p<0.001). 64% of residents reported a reduction in technical skills, and 75% of faculty perceived a decrease in resident technical skills. Residents expressed several concerns, including returning to the operating room with less skill, progressing to the next clinical year, practicing as independent physicians, and fulfilling case requirements. However, faculty were overall confident in residents’ ability to overcome a temporary decay in technical skill. Residents and faculty felt that resident critical care skills improved as a result of redeployment to care for COVID-19 patients (66% and 94%). Residents reported increased confidence in their ability to care for critically ill patients and positive impact on professional competency.

Conclusion: Irrespective of specialty, the majority of procedural and anesthesia residents perceived that their technical ability diminished but that their critical care skill improved. Faculty endorsed the perception of resident skill decay.  However, they were confident in the ability of trainees to achieve level-appropriate proficiency. Effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on residency training are multi-dimensional.  Longitudinal surveillance of residents may reveal the long lasting, if any, effects the COVID-19 crisis will have on core and specialty competency attainment.

abstract_title: Implementation of a Virtual Sub-internship for Neurosurgical Education and Resident Recruitment
author_block: A. Harbert<sup>2</sup>, R. R. Barnett<sup>1</sup>, M. G. Piazza<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Quinsey<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Neurosurgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,School Of Medicine,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Acting internships (AIs) have historically been a major mechanism in residency selection for students to gain better perspectives of the learning environment and culture of specific programs and for programs to match skilled, culturally well fit residents. The elimination of away rotations in 2020 poses unprecedented challenges in the upcoming match process. Virtual encounters do not readily give students an opportunity to showcase their surgical skill, ability to handle a stressful workload, nor performance under pressure. We conducted a 4 week virtual neurosurgical AI in order to determine what types of virtual experiences best allow students to get to know a program, develop neurosurgical knowledge and skills, and show characteristics of predicted surgical resident success. 

Methods:  Nine 4th year medical students from US medical schools participated in a 4 week virtual neurosurgery AI at UNC. The rotation was comprised of a variety of daily educational activities such as lectures, physical surgical skills sessions, interactive didactics, and live patient care. They were sent a survey at the beginning and end of the month to assess expectations and obtain feedback. Participation and data from the students was blinded and deidentified from all members of the residency program. Faculty and residents that participated in teaching components of the rotation were sent a survey at the end of the month assessing their ability to evaluate students and barriers of the virtual format. 

Results: 8/9 medical students completed pre and post rotation surveys, and 14 educators (8 residents and 6 faculty) completed post rotation surveys. In the pre-rotation survey,  8/8 students expressed that they felt they would not be able to adequately portray themselves or it would be greatly limited by the virtual format. 6/8 students expressed that being able to showcase themselves was not at all a barrier on the post rotation survey, while 2/8 found it to be a moderate barrier. Students rated live patient care activities such as patient rounds and virtual ORs as the most limited in these domains. 6/8 students stated that medical student skills sessions were extremely effective in developing clinical and physical surgical skills, and the remaining 2/8 stated these sessions were very effective. 7/14 educators participated in 6 or more educational activities. 7/14 of the educators felt that there were little to no barriers in being able to evaluate learners. 

Conclusion: Based on feedback from both students and educators, the virtual rotation was successful in accomplishing some of the goals that both a residency program has in selection and an applicant has in demonstrating performance. Specifically, every student felt they were able to adequately get a sense of what residency training would be like at the program. This provides useful information to help structure further virtual educational and resident recruitment opportunities for surgical programs.

abstract_title: Bioadhesive Performance of a Plant-derived Structural Heteropolysaccharide Sealant of the Bowel Serosa
author_block: Y. Zheng<sup>1</sup>, A. F. Pierce<sup>1</sup>, W. L. Wagner<sup>3</sup>, A. B. Servais<sup>2</sup>, A. Kienzle<sup>4</sup>, M. Ackermann<sup>5</sup>, S. J. Mentzer<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham and Women's Hospital,Division Of Thoracic Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham and Women's Hospital,Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Hospital of Heidelberg,Department Of Diagnostic And Interventional Radiology,Heidelberg, Germany <sup>4</sup>Charit University Hospital,Center For Musculoskeletal Surgery, Clinic For Orthopedics,Berlin, Germany <sup>5</sup>University Medical Center of the Johannes Gutenberg-University Mainz,Institute Of Functional And Clinical Anatomy,Mainz, Germany
abstract_body:
Introduction: The mesothelium is the surface layer that regulates the healing of all visceral organs, but the bowel serosa has particular clinical importance.  Impaired serosal healing can lead to enteric leaks, fistulas and bowel adhesions. Despite the potential clinical utility of an effective serosal sealant, there is no widely used and FDA-approved bowel sealant. Recently, a plant-derived bioadhesive polymer called pectin was shown to demonstrate remarkable structural similarities to the endogenous mesothelial glycocalyx.  Here, we investigated the sealant properties of this naturally-occurring bioadhesive on the bowel serosa.

Methods: To evaluate pectin adhesivity to the bowel serosa, the tensile strength and shear resistance of pectin film adhesion to human and porcine bowel serosa was measured with millinewton (mN) force sensitivity using a computer-controlled materials analyzer (TA.XTplus, Stable Micro Systems, UK) . A custom fixture was developed to approximate the tensile and shear forces observed clinically. The work of adhesion, reflecting the area under the force-distance curve, was quantitatively assessed. The branched-chain pectin was compared to linear-chain nanocellulose fibers (NCF), and pressure-sensitive adhesives (PSA). To evaluate sealant performance under extreme luminal pressure, standardized linear defects were created in segments of porcine bowel sealed using commercially available sealant products.  The bowel segments were subsequently pressurized to detect sealant leaks.  Biologic replicates were performed (N=3 each data point) and expressed as mean + 1 standard deviation.
