Significance assessed by Student’s t-test.

Results: The modal tensile strength (3658+251 mN) and shear resistance (5997+762 mN) of pectin adhesion to the bowel serosa was significantly greater than that of NCF (1477+512 mN, 1036+641 mN) or PSA (986+439 mN, 298+362 mN), respectively (p<0.01).  The work of adhesion, reflecting an integrated assessment of tensile strength and shear resistance, was also significantly greater than the NCF and PSA controls (p<0.01 asterisk; Figure 1A and 1B). The luminal pressure assay demonstrated that pectin effectively sealed the bowel serosa at luminal pressures that exceeded 60 cmH2O (Figure 1C).  With luminal pressures sustained for more than 10 minutes, pectin was the only sealant to maintain luminal pressures greater than 60 cmH2O (p<.001).

Conclusion: In these studies, the bioadhesive performance of the pectin sealant easily exceeded the surface forces and luminal pressure encountered in clinical applications.  We conclude that pectin is a promising new class of high-performance bioadhesives with potential application in the treatment of bowel injuries.

abstract_title: Mechanical Tension Regulates MSC Signaling on Dermal Fibroblasts via Exosomes and Influences Fibrosis
author_block: U. M. Parikh<sup>1</sup>, H. E. Strang<sup>1</sup>, H. C. Vangapandu<sup>1</sup>, D. Colchado<sup>1</sup>, H. Li<sup>1</sup>, M. Robertson<sup>2</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1,4</sup>, C. Coarfa<sup>3</sup>, S. Balaji<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Advanced Technology Cores,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Molecular And Cellular Biology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Dermal injury results in fibroblast-mediated scar formation potentiated by mechanical tension. Mesenchymal stromal cell (MSCs)-derived exosomes are new frontiers in regenerative wound healing. It is unknown how 1) mechanical tension regulates MSC-derived exosomes (MSC-exo), and 2) how tension-induced MSC exosomes regulate a fibrotic phenotype end-point of the wound repair process. These may underlie intrinsic fibroblast heterogeneity and why different people scar differently. We hypothesize that tension regulates MSC-exo production and cargo and influences wound healing via paracrine signaling effects on dermal fibroblasts.  

Methods: Human MSCs were cultured on silicone membranes ±2.5%, 5% and 10% strain for 24h and analyzed for phenotypic changes (morphology;alpha-SMA; exosome biogenesis – Rab27a,b, RAB35 and SMPD; fibrosis-superarray). Exosomes were isolated and their size (zetasizer), protein level (BCA-assay), surface markers (CD63, HSP70, CD9), and cargo (Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS)) were analyzed. 6mm excisional full thickness wounds in SCID mice were treated with MSCs-exo±tension to determine their impact on wound healing phenotype. Dermal fibroblasts derived from patients with differences in baseline scar-forming propensities (high/low scarrers) were treated with MSCs-exo±tension and changes in their functional (scratch assay) and fibrotic phenotype (fibrosis super-array) were analyzed. p-values by ANOVA; (n=3/group)  

Results: Increase in tension correlated with the loss of characteristic MSC spindle-like morphology and an increase in alpha-SMA and fibrotic gene expression(>2-fold) at 10% strain, whereas gene expression of RAB27a, b, SMPD was downregulated, with an increase in MSC-exo size and protein cargo (p<0.05). NGS of the MSC-exo revealed that miRNAs and lincRNAs were reduced under tension. KEGG gene pathway analysis of miRNAs showed enrichment for intracellular/extracellular wound healing processes. The top miRs (has-miR-625-5p, has-let-7b-3p, has-miR-889-3p), corresponded to Hippo (growth/homeostasis), Ras, PI3K(proliferation) and AMPK (energy-sensing) signaling. Tension-induced MSC-exo decreased expression of YAP1, GSK3B and PPP2R1A genes (p<0.05) implicated in these pathways in dermal fibroblasts, validating our KEGG findings. While control MSC-exo induced regenerative healing, tension-MSC-exo treatment produced a characteristic scar phenotype in mouse wounds. Fibrotic phenotype and migration of human dermal fibroblasts of ‘low’ and ‘high’ scarring phenotypes were differentially regulated when treated with MSC-exo, with ‘high scarrer’ fibroblasts responding more to tension induced MSC-exo.  

Conclusion: Mechanical tension induces a fibrogenic phenotype in MSCs. Understanding how bioactive MSC-exo cargo influences fibroblast behavior will contribute to the development of exosome-based precision medicine therapies to improve wound healing and fibrosis.

abstract_title: 3D-Printed Nitric Oxide Releasing Antimicrobial Polymer Matrix as a Bandage
author_block: D. C. Wang<sup>1</sup>, J. Clark<sup>2</sup>, A. Maresso<sup>2</sup>, B. Trautner<sup>1</sup>, G. S. Acharya<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Shin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Molecular Virology And Microbiology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lack of effective treatment against multidrug-resistant microorganisms has caused wound infections to remain one of the biggest threats to patients, leading to prolonged hospitalization, increased morbidity and slow rehabilitation. For this reason, nitric oxide (NO) has been explored as an alternative antimicrobial agent, since it employs multiple antimicrobial mechanisms simultaneously to reduce the likelihood of developing antimicrobial resistance. Although advantages of NO against infection are well reported, its intrinsic nature (as a highly reactive gas) limits suitable delivery vehicles, thereby hindering its use as a therapeutic agent. However, diazeniumdiolate (NONOate), a small molecule NO donor, represents a new strategy for delivery of NO. Each NONOate molecule contains a diolate group, which can release two molecules of NO upon contact with moisture. NONOates can be incorporated into biocompatible polymers to allow delivery of NO in an efficient and controlled fashion, thus overcoming challenges in NO delivery.

Methods: NO releasing polymer matrix (NOmatrix) was prepared via 3D-bioprinting technology. Three different NONOates, PROLI-, DPTA-, and DETA-NONOates, were used in this study. Biopolymer solutions of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and ethylcellulose (EC) were prepared and mixed with a solution containing one of three NONOates. The resulting solutions were then bioprinted as NOmatrices. In-vitro NO release was evaluated through 48-hour release studies. Samples were collected at predetermined time points and evaluated using nitrite colorimetric assay. Antimicrobial effect of NOmatrices was evaluated in bacterial cultures of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and toxicity was evaluated in human fibroblast cells.

Results: PVP-NOmatrices showed sustained release of NO over 48 hours, whereas EC-NOmatrices exhibited burst release, with NO production only occurring within the first two hours. Nevertheless, all NOmatrices inhibited the growth of MRSA and P. aeruginosa in culture, however, P. aeruginosa showed greater susceptibility to treatment with NOmatrices in comparison to MRSA. PVP-NOmatrix was more efficient in preventing the growth of P. aeruginosa than EC-NOmatrix. Specifically, DPTA/PVP and DETA/PVP-NO matrix were most effective, exhibiting 90% inhibition. For MRSA, PROLI/EC-NOmatrix showed the greatest inhibition (~50%) out of all NOmatrices. Overall NOmatrices showed minimal to no toxicity in human fibroblast cells.

Conclusion: We demonstrated the development of NO-releasing biopolymers that can be applied as an antimicrobial bandage. The use of polymers allowed for efficient/easy delivery of NO and extended NO release up to 48 hours from NOmatrix to inhibit the growth of MRSA and P. aeruginosa.

abstract_title: Role of CD4<sup>+</sup> T Lymphocyte IL-10 expression in Murine Dermal Scarring
author_block: W. D. Short<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Kaul<sup>1,2</sup>, X. Wang<sup>1,2</sup>, H. Li<sup>1,2</sup>, Q. Miao<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Balaji<sup>1,2</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Laboratory For Regenerative Tissue Repair,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Postnatal dermal wounds heal with scar formation, which can result in severe functional and psychosocial morbidity. We recently reported a spatial/temporal influx of lymphocytes in murine skin wounds where the recruitment of the CD4+ subset correlated with the proliferative and remodeling phases of wound healing. Furthermore, in severe combined immunodeficient (SCID) mice known to heal skin wounds with increased fibrosis, adoptive transfer of CD4+ total lymphocytes reduced scarring in an IL-10-dependent manner. However, the contributions of distinctive CD4+ subsets is unknown. We hypothesize that IL-10 producing CD4+ subsets such as Tr1, Th2, and Treg differentially regulate postnatal dermal scarring via IL-10-dependent signaling.  

Methods: In vitro: CD4+ T cells were isolated from C57BL/6J(WT) mice spleens and cultured with mouse T-Activator CD3/CD28 Dynabeads in conditioned media to induce polarization into subsets: Tr1 (IL-2), Th0 (IL-2), Th1 (IL-2/IL-12/Anti-IL-4), and Th2 (IL-2/IL-4/Anti-IFNg). T cell polarization was confirmed using qPCR to verify cytokine profile and supernatant from cell culture was analyzed for IL-10 expression using ELISA. In vivo: 1x106 cells of CD4+ subsets were adoptively transferred into B6.CB17-Prkdcscid/SzJ(SCID) mice lacking functional lymphocytes that received two full-thickness (6mm) stented excisional dorsal wounds. Stents were maintained until day 7 to prevent contraction, wounds were harvested at day 7 and 28 and analyzed using H&E, Trichrome, a-SMA, and anti-CD31 staining.

Results: qPCR demonstrated expected cytokine profiles from polarized T-cell subsets, with elevated production of IL-10 from Th2 (3,484 pg/ml) and Tr1 subsets (918 pg/ml) confirmed by ELISA. In comparison to SCID control wounds which were about 50% re-epithelialized at day 7, wounds of mice treated with Tr1 cells were completely epithelialized at 7 days, while wounds of mice treated with Th0, CD4+, and combined CD4+/Tr1 cells were all ~15% re-epithelialized. At day 28, Tr1-treated wounds had reduced fibrosis with lowest amount of collagen content compared to Th0, CD4+, or CD4+/Tr1 cells (97.8pixels/HPF vs 111.6, 120.2, and 116.9). However, a-SMA percentage at day 7 was greatest in wounds of mice treated with Tr1 cells compared to Th0, CD4+, or CD4+/Tr1 cells (51%cells/HPF vs 41%, 31%, and 44%). Quantification of microvascular density at day 30 showed increased vessel density in wounds treated with combined CD4+/Tr1 cells followed by CD4+ and Tr1 cohorts (17.3vessels/HPF vs 12.0 and 5.5).  

Conclusion: Our study shows that IL-10 producing Tr1 cells contribute to expedited wound closure and reduced dermal scarring. Our data also suggest Tr1 cells interact with CD4+ cells to improve wound neovascularization. With future studies involving the interaction of innate and adaptive immune systems, we can uncover new paradigms of IL-10-producing lymphocyte subsets in wound physiology and their therapeutic value to ameliorate dermal scarring.

abstract_title: Fecal Transplant Affects Neointimal Hyperplasia after Arterial Injury in Antibiotic-Treated Mice
author_block: V. Pamulapati<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Guitart<sup>3</sup>, L. Xiong<sup>2</sup>, C. H. Plunkett<sup>3,4</sup>, P. C. Seed<sup>3,4</sup>, K. J. Ho<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Vascular Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital,Stanley Manne Children's Research Institute,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neointimal hyperplasia after arterial injury is an inflammatory process resulting in restenosis and failure of bypass surgery, angioplasty, and stenting. We previously showed that germ-free (GF) mice have diminished susceptibility to neointimal hyperplasia after arterial injury, which is reversed by fecal transplantation (FT), suggesting that arterial remodeling is influenced by microbiota. However, GF mice have broadly impaired immune development, which could impact causative pathways. We hypothesized that gut microbiota transfer to adult antibiotic-treated conventional mice would result in recipient microbiota resembling the donors and would confer the injury-induced arterial remodeling of the fecal donor.

Methods: Adult C57BL/6 mice were treated with cefoperazone (cefo) for 3 weeks followed by FT using donors from rat strains which are known to be susceptible (Sprague-Dawley; SD) or resistant (Lewis; LE) to neointimal hyperplasia. Control cohorts either received cefo alone or had neither cefo nor FT.  All mice underwent left femoral artery wire injury (WI) 2 weeks after FT. Neointimal hyperplasia was assessed by morphometric analysis of arterial sections 2 weeks after injury. The gut microbiota were assessed using 16S rRNA qPCR and sequencing of stool samples collected at various time points.

Results: Two weeks after WI, neointimal hyperplasia was not different between control and cefoperazone-treated cohorts. In contrast to our hypothesis, LE recipients had significantly more neointimal hyperplasia compared to both controls and SD recipient (Figure). There were no histologic differences in the uninjured right FA among all groups. In cefo-treated cohorts, bacterial load was significantly depleted compared to the non-cefo control cohort following cefo treatment, but was restored to near baseline levels by the time of arterial injury. However, microbial taxonomic profiling revealed broad differences between the 4 groups over time, thus suggesting a significant change in the recipient microbiomes after FT. LE recipient mesenteric lymph nodes (MLN) had significantly more reactive changes compared to SD and control MLN and may signal modulation of the intestinal inflammatory response by LE microbiota that altered peripheral arterial remodeling. 

Conclusion: We demonstrate that FT subsequent to antibiotic treatment in adult conventionally-raised mice impacts neointimal hyperplasia susceptibility after arterial injury, providing a model that avoids the impaired immunologic responses observed with GF mice. Ongoing studies aim to identify causal microbiota constituents driven by cefoperazone and FT and their impact on inflammatory pathways that correlate with neointimal hyperplasia susceptibility.

abstract_title: Non-Structural Fat: Efficiency of Mechanical Dissociation Techniques for Clinical Practice
author_block: S. J. Loder<sup>1</sup>, P. A. Leftwich<sup>1</sup>, L. E. Kokai<sup>1</sup>, K. G. Marra<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Rubin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg,Plastic Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Micronization of adipose has gained popularity as smaller graft are used to superficial or attenuated skin. Total mechanical dissociation of adipose allows us to non-enzymatically generate a stem cell rich, non-structural emulsion useful for intra-dermal injection. Several techniques exist to generate non-structural fat; however, it is unknown how current methodologies compare in operative efficiency. Here we examine three of the most common techniques currently in practice and assess the relative efficacy of each paradigm.

Methods: Lipoaspirate from elective body contouring procedures was obtained as discarded tissue under IRB exemption. Tissue was either maintained as a lipoaspirate control or mechanically dissociated by one of the following: A) Inter-syringe Dissociation  (1.0 mm aperture); B) Serial Meshing (coarse, moderate, fine steel mesh), C) Percussive Dissociation (bead milling) prior to a final filtration step through a mesh nanotransfer chamber to achieve a consistent non-structural adipose product.

Results: Independent of volume, a per-pass loss of ~0.64+/-0.11 g of lipoaspirate occurred secondary to dead space when utilizing nanotransfer kit filtration. With serial meshing this loss was cumulative across each filtration step (2.26+/-0.15 g) with no significant differences between other techniques. Dead space loss was correctable by addition of subsequent positive-pressure washing. Stromal entrapment during filtration was significantly lower after inter-syringe dissociation vs. other techniques (A: 0.13+/-0.01 g; B: 0.36+/-0.02 g; C: 0.32+/-0.35 g; p<0.05) for 5 cc of starting lipoaspirate. Stromal capture was volume dependent (5 cc: 0.13+/-0.01 g; 20 cc: 0.30+/-0.01). Fractional oil release was utilized as a proxy for lysis of lipid-laden mature adipocytes. Oil release increased significantly with inter-syringe and percussive dissociation but serial meshing (Control: 0.18+/-0.02%; A:0.20+/-0.03%; B: 0.34+/-0.04%; C: 0.39+/-0.02%). Samples of non-structural fat from each group were digested in collagenase to assess cellular yield and viability. All groups were normalized to inter-syringe dissociation. We found a significant decrease in cell count with percussive dissociation vs. both other techniques (A:1.0+/-0.12 cells; B:1.19+/-0.17 cells; C: 0.61+/-0.13 cells). 

Conclusion: Given the increasing popularity of non-structural fat products in the operative sphere for both reconstructive and aesthetic procedures a critical review of current processing techniques is necessary to ensure operative efficiency and therapeutic efficacy moving forward. Our data suggests that while effective fractionation may be generated by each of the available techniques to generate non-structural fat there are significant difference in per volume efficiency, yield, and stromal purification between each. This is critical data to the surgeon who must choose which of these characteristics is most desired for their given clinical need.

abstract_title: Shock-Induced Endothelial Dysfunction Is Present in Patients with Occult Hypoperfusion After Trauma
author_block: H. R. Kregel<sup>1</sup>, K. D. Isbell<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>1</sup>, L. S. Kao<sup>1</sup>, G. E. Hatton<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Occult hypoperfusion (OH), or hypoperfusion in the setting of normal vital signs, has increasingly been recognized to result in similar or worse outcomes as shock after trauma. Shock has been demonstrated to induce endothelial dysfunction, evidenced by elevated soluble thrombomodulin (sTM) and syndecan-1 (Syn-1). However, it is unknown if OH is also associated with endothelial dysfunction. We hypothesized that sTM and Syn-1 would be elevated in patients with OH, similar to patients with shock, when compared to patients with normal perfusion.

Methods: A single-center study of patients requiring highest-level trauma activation (2012-2016) was performed. Trauma bay arrival plasma Syn-1 and sTM were measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Shock was defined as systolic blood pressure (SBP) <90mmHg or heart rate (HR) ≥120 bpm. OH was defined as SBP ≥90, HR<120, and base excess (BE) ≤-3. Normal perfusion was assigned to all others. Univariate and multivariable analyses were performed, adjusted for known or suspected confounders: injury severity score, age, and sex.

Results: Of 520 patients, 35% presented with OH and 26% with shock. The median age was 40 (IQR 27-55) while male sex (77%) and blunt mechanism of injury (72%) were predominant in all groups. Median transfusion requirements were highest in those with shock (4 units, IQR 1-17), followed by OH (2, IQR 0-9), and finally by normal perfusion (1, IQR 0-6). Patients with normal perfusion had the lowest Syn-1 and sTM, while patients with OH and shock had similarly elevated levels. (Figure) Although the associations were imprecise on multivariable analysis, OH was associated with increased sTM by 0.9ng/mL (95% CI 0.3-1.5, p=0.005) and Syn-1 by 9.5ng/mL (-6.5-25.5, p=0.25). Shock was associated with increased sTM by 0.5ng/mL (95% CI -0.1-1.2, p=0.13) and increased Syn-1 by 16.8ng/mL (-0.7-34.3, p=0.06).

Conclusion: Occult hypoperfusion after trauma, like shock, is associated with elevated serum sTM and Syn-1, indicating endothelial dysfunction. Treatments aiming to stabilize the endothelium, such as plasma products, may be beneficial for injured patients with evidence of hypoperfusion, regardless of vital signs.

abstract_title: Fetal Base Editing Ameliorates Cardiac Pathology in a Mouse Model of Mucopolysaccharidosis Type I
author_block: S. K. Bose<sup>1,2</sup>, B. White<sup>1</sup>, M. Kashyap<sup>1</sup>, H. Li<sup>1</sup>, P. W. Zoltick<sup>1</sup>, W. Peranteau<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Of Philadelphia,Center For Fetal Research,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mucopolysaccharidosis I (MPS-IH) is a pediatric disease caused by a G→ A mutation in the IDUA gene which results in undetectable IDUA enzyme and the buildup of glycosaminoglycans (GAG). Disease involves multiple organs but is particularly severe in the heart. GAG deposition in the aortic wall, mitral and aortic valves, and cardiac muscle leads to root dilation, valvular insufficiency, and cardiomyopathy. Children develop these pathologies early in life, require numerous surgical interventions, and ultimately die by age 10. Current treatments include enzyme replacement therapy and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation both of which have significant morbidity and cost. Investigative postnatal gene therapies are limited by inefficient cardiac correction. In contrast, fetal gene correction offers the potential to correct the mutation before the onset of irreversible pathology.

Methods: Using adeno associated vectors, we delivered an adenine base editor and guide RNA targeting the murine MPS-IH mutation in embryonic day 15.5 fetuses via the vitelline vein, a hepatic tributary. Echocardiography (TTE) was assessed at 4 and 6 months. At 6 months, cardiac tissue was assayed for enzyme function and GAG levels. Myocytes, endothelial cells, and fibroblasts were isolated using flow cytometry to evaluate gene editing. Histologic specimens were assessed with Alcian blue and Masson’s trichrome stains to evaluate structural morphology. Controls included age and sex-matched MPS-IH disease mice and healthy C57/B6 mice.

Results: Next generation sequencing at 6 months demonstrated efficient gene editing in cardiac myocytes (~12.6%), endothelial cells (~3.0%), and fibroblasts (~2.3%). At 4 and 6 months, TTE in treated mice demonstrated systolic and diastolic function that was normalized. LV systolic and diastolic diameters were reduced, and ejection fraction and fractional shortening were increased in treated mice. Disease mice with aortic diameters>3.5cm at 4 months had 100% mortality by 6 months. In contrast no treated mice developed aortic dilation, and none died during the study. At 6 months, robust enzymatic activity was detected in the heart with decreased GAGs compared to disease controls. Histology in treated mice revealed reduced GAGs in the left ventricle and interventricular septum, reduced valvular thickening, and improved aortic cellular architecture.

Conclusion: Fetal correction of the G→ A mutation in the MPS-IH mouse leads to normalization of cardiac function and is associated with improved survival. We found efficient and precise correction in the heart in multiple cell types. Due to early onset of cardiac pathology associated with significant mortality, in utero treatment of MPS-IH has significant relevance for clinical translation. Although this proof-of-concept intervention is promising, further work to characterize the safety of fetal gene therapies will be essential.

abstract_title: PEDF Deficiency Accelerates Pulmonary Growth and Function
author_block: V. H. Ko<sup>1</sup>, L. J. Yu<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Secor<sup>1</sup>, A. Pan<sup>1</sup>, M. Puder<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Pulmonary hypoplasia (PH), characterized by immature lung development, is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). We previously demonstrated that FG-4592, a prolyl hydroxylase inhibitor, accelerates pulmonary growth and development in a compensatory lung growth (CLG) model following pneumonectomy. This accelerated growth is potentially through downregulation of pigment epithelium-derived factor (PEDF). Here, we further investigate the role of PEDF in pulmonary growth and development in wild type (WT) and PEDF-deficient mice. 

Methods:  Eight-week old PEDF-deficient mice underwent left pneumonectomy. On post-operative days (POD) 0, 2, and 4, lung volume measurements and morphometrics were performed to study the natural history of CLG in PEDF-deficient mice. In a separate study, eight-week old PEDF-deficient and WT mice underwent left pneumonectomy. On POD 4, lung volume measurements and morphometrics were performed. In another study, eight-week old PEDF-deficient and WT mice underwent left pneumonectomy followed by either twice daily oral gavage of FG-4592 at 40 mg/kg or a volume equivalent normal saline control. On POD 2, lung volume measurements and morphometrics were performed.

Results: PEDF-deficient mice complete CLG by POD 4 demonstrated by lung volume, alveolar volume, and septal surface area similar to non-operative controls. Historically, WT mice require eight days for completed CLG. PEDF-deficient mice had significantly increased lung volume, alveolar volume, and septal surface area on POD 4 compared to WT controls following pneumonectomy. Compared to untreated WT controls, both FG-4592 treated and untreated PEDF-deficient mice exhibited increased lung volume, alveolar volume, and septal surface area similar to FG-4592 treated WT mice on POD 2.

Conclusion: PEDF downregulation significantly accelerates pulmonary growth and development. This is demonstrated by completed CLG in PEDF-deficient mice on POD 4 in comparison to POD 8 in WT. Additionally, PEDF-deficient mice, compared to WT mice had significantly accelerated CLG following pneumonectomy. Finally, both FG-4592 untreated and treated PEDF-deficient mice demonstrated accelerated CLG following pneumonectomy similar to WT mice treated with FG-4592. Taken together, these results further confirm our hypothesis that FG-4592 accelerates CLG through PEDF downregulation. FG-4592 is currently in Phase III clinical trials for the treatment of anemia with minimal side effects. Therefore, studies in the treatment of PH and diseases of pulmonary development such as CDH could proceed expeditiously.

abstract_title: CNP-miR146a Rescue of Inflammation and Protein Leak in Lipopolysaccharide-Injured Lungs
author_block: S. M. Niemiec<sup>1</sup>, A. Wallbank<sup>2</sup>, A. E. Louiselle<sup>1</sup>, E. Grayck<sup>3</sup>, B. Smith<sup>2</sup>, C. Zgheib<sup>1</sup>, K. W. Liechty<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Department Of Surgery, Laboratory For Fetal And Regenerative Medicine,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Department Of Bioengineering,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Department Of Pediatrics,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) accounts for 10% of intensive care unit admissions, and this incidence is rising due to Coronavirus (SARS-coV-2). Risk factors for the development of acute lung injury (ALI) and ARDS include pneumonia, major abdominal surgery, and post-operative sepsis. ARDS is characterized by an unyielding pro-inflammatory state leading to pulmonary edema, hypoxia, and a need for mechanical ventilation. Current treatment is limited to supportive care. CNP-miR146a is the conjugation of cerium oxide nanoparticles (CNP), a free radical scavenger, to the anti-inflammatory microRNA(miR)-146a. miR146a is an inhibitor of IRAK1 and TRAF6, which are early promoters of the NFκB inflammatory pathway that increases IL-6 and IL-8 levels. We hypothesized that treatment with intratracheal (IT) CNP-miR146a would result in early reductions of pro-inflammatory gene signaling and stabilization of the alveolocapillary barrier with decreased protein leak in a well-established lipopolysaccharide (LPS) model of ALI.

Methods:  Age-matched, female C57BL/6 mice (n = 12) were given 50μg IT LPS to induce lung injury or saline as a control. Four hours after injury, LPS-injured mice were given 1ng of IT CNP-miR146a (LPS + CNP-miR146a, n = 4). Remaining LPS-injured mice and control mice were given an equivalent volume of saline (LPS + Sal, n = 4; Sal + Sal, n = 4). Eight hours after injury, a tracheostomy was performed through which 0.8mL phosphate-buffered saline was twice instilled for collection of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF). Fluid was analyzed using a bicinchoninic acid (BCA) protein assay kit for colorimetric quantification of protein concentration. Following BAL, whole lungs were harvested and processed for total RNA extraction. Real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) analysis was performed to evaluate expression levels of pro-inflammatory genes NFκB, IRAK1, and TRAF6.

Results: There was an increase in NFκB and IRAK1 gene expression in LPS-injured lungs (p = 0.0039 and p = 0.0097, respectively), with similar trends in TRAF6. NFκB and IRAK1 gene expression were suppressed with IT CNP-miR146a four hours after injury (p = 0.0385 and p = 0.0162). LPS-injury increased BAL protein concentration compared to controls (p = 0.0282). CNP-miR146a treatment reduced BAL protein levels to 417.0 μg/mL compared to 643.1 μg/mL in LPS-injured mice (p = 0.0282).

Conclusion: IT administration of CNP-miR146a is able to rescue the lung from early pro-inflammatory gene signaling following injury, correlating to an early reduction in bronchoalveolar protein leak. This represents a potential therapeutic for the rescue of ALI in inflammatory conditions, such as post-operative sepsis.

abstract_title: Protein Phosphatase 2A Activation Decreases the Malignant Phenotype in Neuroblastoma
author_block: L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, C. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, A. Beierle<sup>1</sup>, J. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, J. Whitaker<sup>1</sup>, M. Ohlmeyer<sup>2</sup>, E. Beierle<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine,Department Of Structural And Chemical Biology,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Protein Phosphatase 2A (PP2A) functions as a tumor suppressor and is an important inhibitor of proliferation and cell cycle progression. PP2A has been found to be suppressed in multiple cancers, thus losing its tumor suppressor function. Our lab has previously shown that FTY720, a PP2A activator, decreased the malignant phenotype in neuroblastoma. Amplification of the MYCN oncogene is the most important negative prognostic indicator in neuroblastoma. Beta-catenin is an upstream regulator of MYCN and has been shown to increase neuroblastoma cell proliferation. We wished to investigate the effects of two novel PP2A activators, ATUX-792 (792) and DBK-1154 (1154), on neuroblastoma growth and motility in vitro and the relation between PP2A activation, MYCN, and beta-catenin.

Methods:  Four neuroblastoma cell lines were used, SK-N-AS (AS) and SH-EP (MYCN non-amplified) and SK-N-BE(2) (BE) and WAC(2) (MYCN amplified). PP2A activation was measured with a phosphatase activation kit following treatment of AS cells with 792 or 1154 for 24 hours. Neuroblastoma cells were treated with increasing doses of 792 or 1154 (0, 5, 10, 15 μM) for 24 hours. Cell viability and proliferation were examined using alamarBlue® and CellTiter96® assays, respectively. To evaluate motility, cells were treated with 792 or 1154 (10 - 15μM). Migration was measured using a cell monolayer wounding assay at 36 hours. Invasion was examined using modified Boyden chambers where treated cells were allowed to invade for 24 hours. Immunoblotting was used to detect the effects of PP2A activation on the expression of MYCN and beta-catenin.

Results: Treatment with 792 and 1154 resulted in significant PP2A activation in AS cells (118% ± 6 % and 139% ± 18 % vs untreated, respectively, p<0.05). Cell survival (fig A, B) and proliferation (fig C, D) were significantly decreased following treatment with 792 or 1154. Treatment with 792 or 1154 also significantly decreased ability of cells to migrate across a scratch wound (fig E) and invade through a Matrigel layer (fig F). Immunoblotting revealed a decrease in MYCN and beta-catenin protein expression with increasing concentrations of 792 and 1154.

Conclusion: PP2A activation with 792 and 1154 decreased survival, proliferation, and motility of neuroblastoma cells. Furthermore, treatment with both drugs resulted in decreased expression of the oncogenic proteins MYCN and beta-catenin. These findings indicate a potential therapeutic role for these novel PP2A activators in neuroblastoma.

abstract_title: Human milk oligosaccharides 2'-fucosyllactose and 6'-siayllactose attenuate NEC-related brain injury
author_block: A. J. Gonzalez Salazar<sup>1</sup>, Q. Zhou<sup>1</sup>, M. L. Kovler<sup>1</sup>, D. Nino<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Sampah<sup>1</sup>, Y. Yamaguchi<sup>1</sup>, P. Lu<sup>1</sup>, H. Jia<sup>1</sup>, W. B. Fulton<sup>1</sup>, T. Prindle<sup>1</sup>, S. Wang<sup>1</sup>, R. Buck<sup>2</sup>, K. Goehring<sup>2</sup>, C. P. Sodhi<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Hackam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Abbott Nutrition,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: One of the most debilitating complications of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the development of persistent cognitive impairment. We have determined that NEC-associated brain injury in humans and mice requires activation of toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) on the hypothalamic microglia, which causes inflammation and white matter injury. Breast milk which is rich in the human milk oligosaccharides 2'-FL and 6'-SL - prevents NEC and improves long-term cognition through mechanisms that remain unknown. We now hypothesize that these human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs) act as anti-inflammatory molecules to prevent NEC-associated brain injury by inhibiting TLR4.

Methods: NEC was induced in 7-day-old C57BL/6 mouse pups through four days of gavage-fed formula mixed with NEC bacteria, and periods of brief hypoxia. The brains were examined histologically and by qRT-PCR after oral administration of the key HMOs: 2-fucosyllactose (2'-FL) and 6-siallylactose (6'-SL) and compared to breastfed (BF) and NEC formula-fed (FF) mice. To evaluate the mechanisms involved, we developed a brain organoid culture system from embryonic brains (e14.5-16.5) in the presence of the TLR4 ligand lipopolysaccharide HMOs.

Results:Administration of 2'-FL and 6'-SL significantly reduced brain inflammation in a dose-dependent manner, as revealed by reduced TNF-a expression (BF:0.40.05,FF:10.1,FF+2-FL:0.50.1,FF+6-SL:0.50.05, p<0.001) and decreased neuronal apoptosis by PUMA expression (BF:443,FF:695,FF+2-FL:464,FF+6-SL:444, p<0.001) in the periventricular regions. Strikingly, 2'-FL and 6'-SL reduced TLR4 signaling in cultured brain organoids, as manifest by the significant reduction of ROS generation by dihydroethidium staining, reduced expression of IL-6 (LPS:20025,LPS+2-FL+6-SL:102, p<0.001) and TNF-a (LPS:1,000500,LPS+2-FL+6-SL:20020, p<0.001), and reduced apoptosis by TUNEL staining, consistent with the cerebral protection seen in vivo.

Conclusion:These findings reveal a novel mechanism to explain the neuroprotective effects of breast milk in NEC, by revealing an anti-inflammatory role for the HMOs 2'-FL and 6'-SL, suggesting that HMO supplementation can offer neuroprotective strategies for patients with NEC.

abstract_title: Establishment of a Metastatic Neuroendocrine-Like Tumor for Pre-clinical Testing
author_block: C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>2</sup>, H. R. Markert<sup>2</sup>, A. M. Beierle<sup>2</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>2</sup>, J. M. Aye<sup>3</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>2</sup>, E. Mroczek-Musulman<sup>4</sup>, K. J. Yoon<sup>5</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Medical Scientist Training Program,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Pediatric Hematology-Oncology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>4</sup>The Children's Hospital Of Alabama,Department Of Pathology,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Pharmacology And Toxicology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Pediatric neuroendocrine tumors are rare and limited data are available to guide treatment. Our lab previously established a patient-derived xenograft (PDX) from a high-grade neuroendocrine-like tumor in a pediatric patient to evaluate targeted therapeutics. Additionally, the patient had extensive abdominal tumor metastasis at presentation. Identifying drugs capable of impeding metastatic growth is crucial for improved patient survival. Next-Generation Sequencing identified an ALK mutation and crizotinib, an ALK inhibitor, has been effective in other ALK-mutated pediatric malignancies. We hypothesized that we could create a metastatic model with this PDX and that crizotinib would affect the metastatic phenotype of this PDX both in vitro and in vivo.

Methods:  Cells (2 x 106) from a dissociated PDX flank tumor were injected into the peritoneal cavity of athymic nude mice. Weekly abdominal exams were performed to detect metastasis. Histology was performed on harvested metastatic tumors. Dissociated metastatic tumor cells were treated with increasing doses of crizotinib. Viability was measured with alamarBlue® and immunoblotting examined the effects of crizotinib on downstream cell signaling cascades. Mice bearing intraabdominal metastasis were treated with crizotinib (75 mg/kg/day per os, n = 5) or vehicle (n = 4) for 31 days. Metastatic tumor burden was determined by tumor weight at the time of euthanasia. 

Results: We successfully established a metastatic PDX model with this neuroendocrine-like PDX. Histology revealed that the established abdominal metastasis recapitulated the original patient tumor and original flank PDX (Figure 1a-b). The metastasis stained chromogranin positive, indicating neuroendocrine properties (Figure 1c). Crizotinib treatment in vitro significantly decreased viability of the metastatic PDX cells with an LD50 of 2.2 µM. Immunoblotting revealed a decrease in phosphorylation of STAT3 with increasing doses of Crizotinib (Figure 1d). Following peritoneal injection of PDX cells, mice treated with Crizotinib had significantly less metastatic burden than those treated with vehicle (63 mg ± 49 mg vs. 251 mg ± 98 mg, Crizotinib vs. vehicle, p = 0.05, Figure 1e). 

Conclusion: We established a metastatic PDX model of a neuroendocrine-like tumor that maintained a similar profile to that of the patient’s original tumor. Additionally, we have shown that crizotinib successfully decreased metastatic tumor cell viability in vitro and metastatic tumor growth in vivo. Immunoblotting suggests decreased activity of STAT3 may be the mechanism responsible. These findings indicate that crizotinib may be a successful targeted therapeutic for metastatic, high-grade neuroendocrine-like tumors.

abstract_title: Heparin Inhibits Lung Endothelial Cell Proliferation and Pulmonary Function
author_block: L. J. Yu<sup>1</sup>, V. H. Ko<sup>1</sup>, S. T. Tsikis<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Secor<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Fligor<sup>1</sup>, A. Pan<sup>1</sup>, D. T. Dao<sup>1</sup>, L. Anez-Bustillos<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Cho<sup>1</sup>, M. Puder<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Department Of Surgery And Vascular Biology Program,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neonates with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) suffer from pulmonary hypoplasia (PH) and may require extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and systemic anticoagulation. Expeditious pulmonary growth on ECMO is required to reduce mortality, which approaches 50%. In addition to the critically ill CDH patients requiring ECMO and therapeutic anticoagulation, many patients receive subtherapeutic anticoagulation to maintain patency of venous catheters and prevent venous thrombosis. Previously, our lab demonstrated that therapeutic dose heparin impairs compensatory lung growth (CLG) following pneumonectomy in a murine model. We now investigate the effects of therapeutic and subtherapeutic dose heparin on lung endothelial cell proliferation and pulmonary functional outcomes.

Methods: Lung endothelial cells were treated with increasing doses of heparin and cell proliferation was assessed. C57BL/6 mice were treated with saline control, subtherapeutic (low-dose, 250U/kg), or therapeutic (high-dose, 500U/kg) heparin via intraperitoneal injection every 12 hours for three doses. Plasma anti-factor Xa levels were measured one hour after the last dose. A separate cohort of mice underwent baseline treadmill exercise tolerance testing (TETT) followed by pneumonectomy and treatment with saline or low- or high-dose heparin for eight days. TETT was repeated on post-operative day eight.

Results: Heparin induced a dose-dependent decrease in lung endothelial cell proliferation (A). High-dose heparin significantly increased plasma anti-factor Xa to therapeutic levels while low-dose heparin and saline did not (B). On post-operative day eight after pneumonectomy, mice treated with low- (C), and high- (D) dose heparin ran for significantly less time and shorter distance compared to saline control.

Conclusion: Heparin inhibits lung endothelial cell proliferation in a dose-dependent manner and decreases post-pneumonectomy exercise tolerance at therapeutic and subtherapeutic doses. These data suggest that therapeutic and subtherapeutic heparin may worsen outcomes for neonates with CDH and other pulmonary hypoplastic diseases through inhibiting pulmonary endothelial proliferation and impairing pulmonary function. Accordingly, the choice of drug, dose, and duration of therapy for neonates with hypoplastic lung disease requiring anticoagulation should be reconsidered.

abstract_title: The Role of Neoadjuvant Treatment in Thymoma - When Should We Use Induction?
author_block: Z. Muslim<sup>1</sup>, M. Baig<sup>1</sup>, J. Weber<sup>1</sup>, C. Connery<sup>2</sup>, F. Bhora<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Nuvance Health,Rudy L. Ruggles Biomedical Research Institute,Danbury, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Nuvance Health,Vassar Brothers Medical Center,Poughkeepsie, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Induction chemotherapy (IC) is administered to increase resectability in thymoma. Deciding between IC and up-front surgery involves an evaluation of tumor resectability via assessment of pre-operative CT imaging findings and is largely dependent on surgical experience and expertise. Incomplete resection has been linked to a larger tumor size and higher-risk World Health Organization (WHO) B1-B3 subtypes. We aimed to identify objective criteria which may be used to determine the need for IC by testing the hypothesis that IC in 8 cm or larger, WHO B1-B3 subtype thymoma improves survival and/or resectability.

Methods:  We used the National Cancer Database to identify a retrospective cohort of patients undergoing surgical resection for ≥8cm, B1-B3 thymoma, with or without IC. Those with Masaoka-Koga stage IVb disease were excluded. Multivariate logistic regression was used to identify predictors of IC. Overall survival (OS) was evaluated using Kaplan-Meier analysis and multivariate Cox-regression.

Results: 2876 patients met the inclusion criteria, out of which 450 (15.6%) patients had ≥8cm, B1-B3 thymoma. IC was administered in 265 (9.2%) patients and was more likely to be used in younger individuals, males, advanced disease stage, ≥8cm, B1-B3 thymoma and academic centers, all p<0.05. In a propensity matched analysis of 160 patients with ≥8cm, B1-B3 thymoma, IC did not significantly increase median survival time compared to surgery alone (p=0.64) and was not a significant prognosticator of survival (HR: 1.21, 95% CI 0.62-2.34, p=0.57). A younger age at diagnosis was the only predictor of improved OS in this cohort (p=0.04). IC significantly increased the median time to definitive surgery (135 days vs. 13 days, p<0.01) and did not increase the likelihood of an R0 resection (p=0.22).

Conclusion: IC is likely to be administered in 8 cm or larger, B1-B3 thymoma although it may not improve survival time or resectability in this population. Tumor size and WHO histology may not adequately determine the need for IC in patients with thymoma.

abstract_title: Hospital Factors Associated with Surgical Re-exploration Following Lung Resection
author_block: Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, C. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, M. Gandjian<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical re-exploration following lung resection remains poorly characterized, though institutional series have reported an association between postoperative bleeding and mortality. The present study sought to examine the impact of institutional lung resection volume on incidence of and short-term outcomes following surgical re-exploration.

Methods: All adults undergoing elective lobectomy or pneumonectomy were identified using the 2007-2017 National Inpatient Sample (NIS). Diagnoses and procedures were tabulated using International Classification of Diseases 9/10 codes. Thoracoscopic and robotic-assisted approaches were categorized as minimal access. Hospitals were divided into low- (LVH), medium- (MVH) and high-volume (HVH) tertiles based on institutional lung resection caseload. Trends were examined using nonparametric tests and Chi-square or Wald’s tests were used to compare categorical or continuous variables, respectively. Multivariable regression was used to identify associations between patient and hospital factors on re-exploration and mortality, duration of hospitalization (LOS) and costs.

Results: Of an estimated 324,174 patients who met study criteria, 3,547 (1.09%) required re-exploration, which declined in frequency over time (p<0.001). Relative to others, the re-exploration group had a greater proportion of open resections (82.3% vs 60.9%, p<0.001). Furthermore, mortality (8.51% vs 1.79%), LOS (13.5 days vs 7.0 days), and costs ($29,634 vs $26,495) were all higher in the re-exploration cohort compared to those not having re-operation (p<0.001). After adjustment (C-statistic: 0.74), several factors were associated with increased likelihood of re-exploration including infectious or inflammatory etiologies relative to malignancy (AOR 3.14, 95% CI 2.65-3.74) and pneumonectomy (AOR 1.82, 95% CI 1.48-2.25). Meanwhile, minimal access was associated with decreased risk of re-exploration compared to open (AOR 0.43, 95% CI 0.35-0.53). Although LOS, costs, and rates of re-exploration were similar across volume tertiles, re-exploration at MVH and HVH was associated with significantly reduced odds of mortality relative to LVH (Figure). Moreover, the indication for resection was not correlated with increased mortality following re-exploration.

Conclusion: Re-exploration after lung resection is uncommon nationally; however, when occurring is associated with significantly increased in-hospital mortality. Following re-exploration, medium and high-volume center status was associated with reduced odds of mortality relative to low volume status. This demonstration in failure-to-rescue at lower volume centers suggests the need for optimization of perioperative factors to decrease incidence of re-exploration.

abstract_title: Disparities in Neoadjuvant Treatment Among Patients with Stage IIIA-N2 Lung Cancer in the NCDB
author_block: D. G. Kindell<sup>1</sup>, J. Herb<sup>1</sup>, P. Rivera<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Long<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Consensus guidelines recommend neoadjuvant chemotherapy or chemoradiation in patients with Stage IIIA-N2 non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who are determined to be surgical candidates. However, data assessing adherence to this approach are lacking. The purpose of this study was to determine the prevalence and disparities in guideline concordant neoadjuvant therapy in patients with Stage IIIA-N2 NSCLC who underwent surgery.

Methods:  We performed a retrospective analysis of patients with clinical stage IIIA-N2 NSCLC who underwent surgical resection between 2010-2016 in the National Cancer Database. Multivariable logistic regression was used to assess the association of race, insurance status, rurality, and area income with receipt of neoadjuvant therapy while controlling for other demographics and disease factors.

Results: We identified 8968 patients who underwent surgical resection for stage IIIA-N2 NSCLC between 2010-2016. Of these, 3934 (44%) received guideline concordant neoadjuvant therapy. Factors associated with receiving neoadjuvant therapy were private insurance status (OR 1.47 95% CI 1.04;2.06) and zip-code median income (>$40,227 OR 1.18, >$50,354 1.37, >$63,333 OR 1.58). Of note, in our cohort 1676 (19%) patients underwent surgical resection only. The sole factor associated with undergoing surgery only versus guideline concordant treatment was uninsured insurance status (OR 2.54 95% CI 1.59-4.07).

Conclusion: In the NCDB, over half of patients undergoing surgery for Stage IIIA-N2 NSCLC did not receive recommended neoadjuvant therapy. This includes a significant number of patients who underwent surgical resection only. Private insurance and higher neighborhood income, proxy measures of higher socioeconomic status, are associated with higher likelihood of neoadjuvant therapy. Targeting patients most sensitive to the financial demands of neoadjuvant therapy, such as those without private insurance or from poorer areas, may result in population improvements in guideline concordance in patients with locally advanced NSCLC.

abstract_title: Axillary Artery Cannulation is Associated with Pectoralis Muscle Atrophy
author_block: E. P. Rotar<sup>1</sup>, W. Z. Chancellor<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Beller<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Dahl<sup>1</sup>, J. Keiler<sup>1</sup>, R. B. Hawkins<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Kern<sup>1</sup>, G. Ailawadi<sup>1</sup>, L. T. Yarboro<sup>1</sup>, C. Tribble<sup>1</sup>, N. R. Teman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cannulation of the axillary artery is an important approach for cardiopulmonary bypass and transcatheter valve delivery in select cardiac operations. However, little is known about the long-term musculoskeletal consequences of this approach. The purpose of this study was to investigate the incidence of postoperative pectoralis muscle atrophy and functional impairment.   

Methods: Records of all patients undergoing cardiac surgery requiring axillary artery cannulation between 2011-2019 were extracted from an institutional Society of Thoracic Surgeons database. Patients with follow-up CT scans between 1 month and 1 year postoperatively were selected for analysis. Bilateral pectoralis major and minor muscle area was measured at the level of the aortic arch. The cannulated ipsilateral muscle was compared to the contralateral muscle area as control. Area differences were compared utilizing paired analysis. Patients were contacted for a follow-up survey of their functional status. Pearson correlation coefficients were calculated to determine association between relative atrophy and variables of interest.   

Results: A total of 187 patients were identified as requiring axillary artery cannulation with 58 (31.0%) having follow-up imaging appropriate for study inclusion. The average age was 64.1±10.8 years and 62.1% (36/58) were male. Median time between surgery and follow-up CT scan was 126.5 days. The right axillary artery was cannulated for 94.8% (55/58) of patients. The mean muscle area ipsilateral to the cannulation site was significantly smaller for both pectoralis major, 496.0±230.6 mm2 vs. 648.6±289.9 mm2 (p<0.001) and pectoralis minor, 180.6±66.1 mm2 vs. 207.3±70.7 mm2 (p=0.004). Atrophy of the pectoralis major was evident in 77.6% (45/58) of patients with a median decline of 34.3% (IQR 11.3%-46.3%). Pectoralis minor atrophy was present in 65.5% (38/58) patients with a median decline of 20.9% (IQR 10.6%-41.4%). There was no significant association between the degree of pectoralis atrophy and the urgency of the operation (emergent vs. non-emergent), medical comorbidities, or baseline nutrition status (all p>0.05). Patient surveys revealed no significant correlation between reported functional limitations and radiographically apparent muscle atrophy.  

Conclusion: These finding suggest significant radiographic evidence of pectoralis muscle atrophy does occur after axillary artery cannulation for cardiopulmonary bypass.  Although no functional differences were observed in our survey data, surgeons should consider this potential sequela and consider this novel finding when determining an optimal, patient-specific perfusion strategy.

abstract_title: Anatomic Resection versus Wedge Resection for Second Primary Lung Cancers (SPLC)
author_block: M. Baig<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Razi<sup>2</sup>, Z. Muslim<sup>1</sup>, J. Weber<sup>1</sup>, C. Connery<sup>1</sup>, F. Y. Bhora<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Nuvance Health,Surgical Oncology,Danbury, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Memorial Healthcare System,Thoracic Surgery,South Broward, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Extent of surgical resection for early-stage second primary lung cancer (SPLC) in patients with previous lobectomy is controversial. Such patients pose significant challenges for thoracic surgeons with regards to technical aspects of re-operative surgeries as well as suboptimal preoperative lung function tests. In this study, we sought to compare anatomic lung resections (lobectomy and segmentectomy) and wedge resections for small peripheral SPLC using a population-based database. 

Methods:  The Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) database was queried for all patients with early-stage peripheral SPLC (≤ 2cm, N0, M0) diagnosed between 1998 and 2015. Only patients treated with a prior lobectomy for their first primary were included. American College of Chest Physicians (ACCP) guidelines were used to classify SPLC. Patients whose records included a malignancy other than lung or had SPLC of small cell histology were excluded. Kaplan-Meier and multivariate cox regression were used to compare overall survival. Figure 1 summarizes our strict selection criteria for this study.

Results: A total of 437 patients met the inclusion criteria with 240 (54.9%) treated with wedge resection and 197 (45.1%) treated with anatomic resection. Thirty-day and ninety-day mortality was significantly higher with anatomic resection (3% vs 0%, p = 0.006 and 6.6% vs 2.1%, p = 0.02 respectively). However, patients who underwent anatomic resection demonstrated better median survival than those treated with wedge resections on Kaplan Meier (88 vs 68 months, p = 0.006) and multivariate cox regression (HR: 0.68, CI: 0.50 – 0.92 p = 0.01).  No survival difference was observed when anatomic resection was compared with wedge resection with at least one lymph node sampled (88 vs 73 months, p = 0.27), [HR: 0.77, CI: 0.52 – 1.13 p = 0.18]. 

Conclusion: Anatomic resections may provide better survival than wedge resections for patients with early-stage peripheral SPLC after prior lobectomy albeit with higher perioperative mortality. Significant improvement in survival is observed with wedge resection for SPLC when lymph node sampling is performed.

abstract_title: Clinical Outcomes of Surgeon Adherence to Hernia Patient Preoperative Optimization
author_block: A. S. Chen<sup>1</sup>, M. Kattapuram<sup>1</sup>, G. Quiroga<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Haidar<sup>1</sup>, L. D. Delaney<sup>1,3</sup>, R. Howard<sup>2,3</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>2,3</sup>, D. A. Telem<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Optimizing preoperative risk factors, such as obesity and tobacco use, prior to surgery is a well-accepted approach to improve patient outcomes after abdominal wall hernia repair. Despite this benefit, nearly 20% of patients are not adequately optimized prior to surgery. It is currently unknown how surgeon-level adherence to optimization impacts outcomes. In this context, we evaluated the association between surgeon adherence to optimization practices and surgeon-level postoperative outcomes to motivate quality improvement efforts. 

Methods:  A retrospective analysis of Michigan Surgical Quality Collaborative (MSQC) data from 2014-2018 was performed to examine rates of surgeon adherence to optimization guidelines when performing elective ventral incisional hernia repair (VIHR). Adherence to preoperative patient optimization guidelines was defined as patients at the time of surgery who were non-tobacco users, with a BMI >18.5 kg/m2 and <40 kg/m2. After adjusting for patient and clinical covariates (age, sex, race, ASA class, functional status, unhealthy alcohol use (>2 drinks/day), hypertension, CHF, COPD, CAD, PVD, bleeding disorder, prior DVT, OSA, surgical approach (open vs MIS), inpatient vs ambulatory, admission source (home vs facility), and year of surgery), surgeons were assigned a risk and reliability adjusted adherence rate which was used to divide surgeons into tertiles (low adherence, moderate adherence, high adherence). Logistic regression was used to describe the association between surgeon adherence and adverse postoperative outcomes. 

Results: In this cohort across 70 hospitals in Michigan, there were 21,524 patients who underwent VIHR, cared for by 457 surgeons. After adjusting for comorbidities, there was wide variation in surgeon adherence to preoperative optimization (Figure 1). Surgeons in the lowest tertile of optimization had patients with significantly higher rates of emergency department visits within 30 days (adjusted rate 8.78% vs 7.05% vs 7.03%, p<0.001), serious complications (adjusted rate 2.12% vs 1.56% vs. 1.84%, p=0.041), and any complication (adjusted rate 4.08% vs 3.37% vs 4.04%, p= 0.043), compared to surgeons in the middle and highest tertiles of optimization. 

Conclusion: Surgeons’ clinical outcomes, including rates of emergency department visits and complications, are affected by their proportion of patient optimization with regard to obesity and tobacco use. These results suggest that surgeons can significantly improve their overall postoperative outcomes by addressing patient tobacco use and weight prior to surgery.  Quality improvement efforts focused on maximizing surgeon-level adherence may be warranted to help improve patient clinical outcomes.

abstract_title: An Epidemiological Study of Births After Bariatric Surgery
author_block: G. F. Chao<sup>1,2,3</sup>, J. Yang<sup>4,5</sup>, A. Peahl<sup>4,6</sup>, J. Thumma<sup>4,5</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>4,5</sup>, D. E. Arterburn<sup>7</sup>, D. A. Telem<sup>4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Veterans Affairs Ann Arbor,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>National Clinician Scholars Program,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>4</sup>Institute for Healthcare Policy and Innovation,Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>7</sup>Kaiser Permanente Washington,Department Of Internal Medicine,Seattle, WA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Women of childbearing age comprise approximately 70% of all patients who undergo bariatric surgery in the United States every year. Weight loss from bariatric surgery may decrease complications of pregnancy, including gestational diabetes, fetal growth disorders, and cesarean delivery. Current consensus guidelines recommend women delay conception by 12-24 months after bariatric surgery to prevent potential adverse outcomes for both the mother (e.g. unrealized weight loss) and infant (e.g. prematurity, low birth weight). Still, little is known about rates or timing of births following bariatric surgery. Thus, the objective of this study was to define the epidemiology of births after bariatric surgery.

Methods:  Using IBM MarketScan claims data, we performed a retrospective cohort study of all women age 18-52 undergoing bariatric surgery from 2011-2017 with at least 6 months of continuous follow-up after surgery. We calculated the number of births occurring before 21 months, as this is 9 months (the usual length of pregnancy) following the least conservative recommendation for conception post-surgery. Kaplan-Meier survival curves were constructed using birth as the dependent variable. We examined pregnancy rates by procedure type (laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy, laparoscopic gastric bypass, and other) using Cox regression analysis, controlling for age, geographic state, and Elixhauser comorbidities.

Results: Of the 71,976 included women, 87% had full 1-year and 56% had full 2-year follow-up. Within the first 2 years after surgery, 2.1 in 100 women (1,511) gave birth. Time to first birth is shown below: 76% of births occurred before 21 months after bariatric surgery. Finally, Cox regression analysis showed no association between procedure type (sleeve gastrectomy vs gastric bypass) and likelihood to give birth (HR: 0.93, 95%CI: 0.83 - 1.03, p=0.17). The age group with the highest likelihood of birth was age 25-29 (HR: 1.43, 95%CI: 1.21 - 1.68, p<.0001, reference group: age 18-24).

Conclusion: This is the first nationally representative cohort study of pregnancy after bariatric surgery in the United States. We found a high level of discordance between current guidelines and pregnancy. Approximately 2 of every 100 women of childbearing age undergoing bariatric surgery give birth within the first two years after surgery, the majority of whom conceive prior to the least conservative recommendation of 12 months. Given that the number of individuals with obesity and undergoing bariatric surgery are growing yearly, more attention to maternal and fetal outcomes after bariatric surgery is needed to better assess the true risks and benefits of birth after bariatric surgery to inform evidence-based guidelines.

abstract_title: Social vulnerability and utilization of high-volume hospitals in hepatopancreatic cancer surgery
author_block: A. Diaz<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Hyer<sup>1</sup>, D. Tsilimgras<sup>1</sup>, A. Abbas<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Ohio State University,Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,2. National Clinician Scholars Program At The Institute For Healthcare Policy And Innovation,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  In an effort to improve perioperative and oncologic outcomes, there has been extensive centralization of complex cancer surgery over the past decade. However, high-volume centers are often located in urban areas, which may hinder access to high-quality surgical care for certain patient populations. In particular, patients living in areas with high social vulnerability may be disproportionally affected by centralization, leading to under-utilization of high-volume hospitals and worse postoperative outcomes. 

Methods:  Medicare beneficiaries who underwent liver or pancreas resection for cancer were identified using the 100% Medicare Inpatient Standard Analytic Files. Hospitals were designated as high-volume based on Leapfrog criteria. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)’s social vulnerability index (SVI) database was used to abstract community level vulnerability information based on each beneficiary’s county of residence at the time of surgery. The probability of high-volume hospital utilization was assessed relative to social vulnerability of the patient’s county of residence. Risk-adjusted postoperative outcomes were compared across low-, average-, and high- levels of vulnerability at both low- and high-volume hospitals.

Results: Overall, 16,987 patients underwent either pancreatic (n=13,393, 78.8%) or liver resection (n=3,594, 21.2%) for cancer. Mean age was 73.3 (SD 5.8) years and roughly one-half of the cohort was male (n=9,168, 54%); the majority of patients were White (White: n=15,034, 88.5%), while a subset of the cohort was a non-White minority (Black: n=1,031, 6.1%; Hispanic: n=75, 0.4%; Asian: n=845, 5.0%). The average SVI was 49.8 (SD 24.8)(White: 48.9, SD 24.8 vs. minority: 57.0, SD 24.1). Surgery was performed at a high-volume hospital in one-half of patients (n=8,251, 48.6%)(White: n=7,447, 49.5% vs. minority: n=804, 41.2%;p<0.001). On risk-adjusted analyses, minority patients had lower odds of surgery at a high-volume hospital (OR 0.74, 95%CI: 0.66-0.84). Similarly, patients from high SVI had lower odds of an operation at a high-volume hospital (OR 0.86, 95%CI:0.76-0.98). While postoperative complications and mortality were lower at high-volume hospitals, there was an increased risk of postoperative complications as SVI increased both at high-volume and low-volume hospitals (Figure). In particular, the incidence of complications at high-volume hospitals among low SVI patients was 20.3% (95%CI: 18.8-21.7) versus 25.7% (95%CI: 24.0-27.7) among high SVI patients. Similarly, mortality at high-volume hospitals among low SVI patients was 2.9% (95%CI: 2.3-3.5) versus 4.4% (95%CI: 3.6-5.1) among high SVI patients.

Conclusion: Patients from areas of higher social vulnerability were less likely to undergo pancreatic and liver resection at a high-volume hospital.  High SVI patients had a higher risk of postoperative complications and mortality following pancreatic and liver resection at both high- and low-volume hospitals. These data highlight the “double disparity” facing patients from high SVI areas and serve to emphasize the need to focus on community based factors to improve perioperative outcomes of patients undergoing complex cancer surgery.

abstract_title: "Trends and Outcomes in Older Adults with Kidney Re-transplantation: A Descriptive Analysis"
author_block: J. B. Ahn<sup>1</sup>, S. Sandal<sup>3,4</sup>, M. Cantarovich<sup>3,4</sup>, N. M. Chu<sup>1,2</sup>, D. L. Segev<sup>1,2</sup>, M. A. McAdams-DeMarco<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health,Department Of Epidemiology,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>McGill University,Division Of Nephrology, Department Of Medicine,Montreal, QC, Canada <sup>4</sup>Research Institute of the McGill University Health Centre,Montriol, QC, Canada
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Access to kidney transplantation (KT) has increased among patients aged ≥65 years. Older recipients often experience graft failure; however, little is reported on re-KT. We characterized the trends in and outcomes after re-KT among older adults

Methods:  Among kidney-only recipients aged ≥65 years (1995-2016) we identified those with re-KT in the Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients. We analyzed trends by pre-defined eras (1995-2002, 2003-2014 and 2015-2016) based on policies affecting older adults. The risk (%) of outcomes (death-censored graft failure [DCGF], all-cause graft failure [ACGF], death) was analyzed using Kaplan-Meier estimator. We compared outcomes stratified by age (65-69 vs. ≥70) and explored age as a continuous variable using the restricted cubic splines regression. 

Results: Among 44,149 kidney alone transplants in recipients ≥65 years from 1995-2016, only 3.9% were re-KTs; however, there has been a significant increase in this percentage over time (1995-2002:2.7%, 2003-2014:4.2%, 2015-2016:5.7%, p<0.001) (Figure). Recipients at higher risk are undergoing re-KT; patients with PRA 80-100 (1995-2002:22.0%, 2003-2014:32.7%, 2015-2016:48.7%, p<0.001), median survival of first KT in years (1995-2002:2.7, 2003-2014:6.5, 2015-2016:8.6, p<0.001), years spent on dialysis after first graft failure (1995-2002:1.4, 2003-2014:1.5, 2015-2016:2.2, p=0.003) and those living with assistance (1995-2002:9.0%, 2003-2014:12.6%, 2015-2016:24.8%, p<0.001) have increased. No major change in pre-emptive KT and living donation were noted. The 5-year cumulative incidence of DCGF, ACGF and death was 13.2% and 18.8%, 36% and 43.1%, and 29.4% and 38.5%, for re-KT recipients aged 65-69 and ≥70, respectively. Compared with recipients aged 65, the risk of DCGF started to significantly increase at age 77, ACGF at age 72, and death at age 70. 

Conclusion: We report increasing trends in re-KT among older adults and favorable outcomes. While we acknowledge that only a subset is considered for a re-transplant, our results support increasing access to re-KT to older adults including those ≥70 years. Further research is needed to understand the risk and benefit of re-KT among older population.

abstract_title: Living Donor Kidney Transplantation Racial Disparities Persist Independent of Social Vulnerability
author_block: A. C. Killian<sup>1</sup>, M. C. McLeod<sup>1</sup>, B. Shelton<sup>1</sup>, R. Reed<sup>1</sup>, P. MacLennan<sup>1</sup>, H. Qu<sup>1</sup>, B. Orandi<sup>1</sup>, V. Kumar<sup>1</sup>, D. Sawinski<sup>2</sup>, R. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, D. Anderson<sup>1</sup>, M. Hanaway<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Locke<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Comprehensive Transplant Institute,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Living donor kidney transplantation (LDKT) confers a significant survival benefit over deceased donor transplantation. Racial disparities in access to LDKT are well recognized, yet they have increased in the last two decades. LDKT inequities have been largely attributed to contextual poverty and socioeconomic variability, however the association between LDKT and comprehensive measures of social vulnerability has not been characterized.

Methods:  This retrospective study utilized the Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients to identify adult, kidney-only transplant recipients between 1/1/2018-12/31/2018. Census tract-level data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s 2018 Social Vulnerability Index (SVI), were linked to recipients by zip code. Logistic regression was utilized to evaluate the association between LDKT and SVI and race, controlling for patient- and community-level characteristics. Average adjusted predicted probabilities of LDKT across SVI were plotted by race.

Results: 20,380 kidney-only transplant recipients were included, of which 30% received LDKT. Higher SVI (e.g., greater social vulnerability) was significantly associated with lower odds of LDKT (adjusted odds ratio (aOR): 0.47, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.40-0.57, p<0.0001). After controlling for SVI, African Americans (AAs) had 57% lower odds (aOR: 0.43, 95%CI: 0.39-0.48, p<0.0001) and other races had 45% lower odds (aOR: 0.55, 95%CI: 0.48-0.63, p<0.0001) of LDKT compared to their white counterparts. Average marginal effects for LDKT at the lowest SVI were 13% and 9% for AAs and other races, respectively, relative to white recipients (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Greater social vulnerability is significantly associated with lower odds of LDKT. Racial disparities in LDKT persist independent of social vulnerability, suggesting that other factors, such as sociocultural barriers and unconscious biases require greater attention to mitigate inequities.

abstract_title: Disparities in Outcomes for Patients Undergoing Liver Transplantation for Hepatocellular Carcinoma
author_block: M. Zope<sup>1</sup>, K. McElroy<sup>1</sup>, S. Luu<sup>1</sup>, R. Lee<sup>2</sup>, A. Gamboa<sup>2</sup>, S. Maithel<sup>2</sup>, M. Russell<sup>2</sup>, M. Turgeon<sup>2</sup>, A. Yopp<sup>3</sup>, E. Ryan<sup>4</sup>, N. Goel<sup>4</sup>, A. Wang<sup>5</sup>, A. Lee<sup>5</sup>, C. Hsu<sup>1</sup>, E. Silberfein<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Miami,Miami, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>New York University School Of Medicine,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Curative intent treatment for patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) meeting MILAN criteria consists of liver transplantation. However, how socioeconomic differences factor into treatment and outcomes for eligible patients is poorly defined.  This purpose of this study is to assess disparities in patient characteristics and survival outcomes between cohorts transplanted at safety net hospitals and their corresponding academic hospitals as part of the US Safety Net Collaborative (USSNC).

Methods:  All patients with primary HCC in the USSNC database were included.  A retrospective analysis of 881 patients meeting MILAN Criteria for liver transplant from 2012-2014 was undertaken.  Patient demographics, comorbidities, and etiology of disease were analyzed using chi-square tests. Overall survival and recurrence free survival analyses were performed on 201 patients receiving liver transplant using the Kaplan-Meier method and Cox proportional hazards regression analysis.

Results: Of 201 patients meeting MILAN criteria, 14.3% (n=44) were transplanted in the safety net hospital setting and 27.4% (n=157) were transplanted in the academic setting (p<0.0001). The 5-year overall survival rate of patients undergoing liver transplant was 89% in academic hospitals and 75% in safety net hospitals (p=0.022). The 3-year recurrence free survival rate of transplanted patients was 94% in academic hospitals and 96% in safety net hospitals (p=0.3). Patients transplanted at safety net hospitals were at increased risk of mortality (HR=8.51, p=0.007).

Conclusion: An increased proportion of patients with HCC meeting MILAN criteria in the USSNC undergo liver transplantation at academic hospitals when compared to safety net hospitals and their long-term survival outcomes are better.  Better understanding of the factors that lead to these disparities are paramount.  Safety net hospitals are important for understanding how different hospital resources contribute to patient care and outcomes.

abstract_title: Underutilization of SLNB and Radiation Therapy in Merkel Cell Carcinoma Leads to Worse Survival
author_block: C. M. Julian<sup>3</sup>, M. J. Minarich<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Handorf<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Moslim<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Roitman<sup>3</sup>, S. E. Hopkins<sup>3</sup>, J. M. Farma<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Department Of Surgical Oncology,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Department Of Bioinformatics And Biostatistics,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University,Doctor Of Medicine Program,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is a rare, aggressive cutaneous malignancy with increasing incidence in recent years. Five-year survival rates from MCC range from 41-77%. Standard of care treatment includes concurrent radical excision of the primary tumor and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB), followed by adjuvant radiation therapy (RT). We examine, from a contemporary large-scale Western cohort, the role of RT and SLNB on overall survival (OS).

Methods: All patients with MCC were identified using the National Cancer Database (NCDB) from 2004-2016. Patients who underwent R0 surgical resection of MCC were stratified into four groups: SLNB, adjuvant RT, both SLNB and RT, and neither. Overall survival was calculated overall and stratified by clinical T stage using Kaplan-Meier curves, with hazard ratios (adjusted for age) calculated via Cox proportional hazards regression models.

Results: 2,346 patients underwent surgical resection of their primary MCC with 290 (12.4%) receiving only RT, 842 (35.9%) receiving only SLNB, 368 (15.7%) receiving neither SLNB nor RT, and 846 (36%) receiving both. The addition of RT alone to radical excision demonstrated improved survival over surgical resection alone (median= 4.09 vs. 2.75 years, respectively, p=0.016). The utilization of SLNB is associated with a greater survival benefit on its own compared to RT (median= 7.18 vs. 4.09 years, respectively, p=.0114). The greatest survival benefit was appreciated with the combination of both RT and SLNB (median: 8.35 years, HR 0.59). This survival benefit was maintained in all MCC patients regardless of clinical T stage.

Conclusion: The combination of both RT and SLNB has a profound survival benefit in MCC, regardless of initial tumor size. We emphasize the underutilization of this standard-of-care combination in the NCDB. Despite the known benefit of RT, SLNB demonstrated a greater overall survival advantage. This is likely explained by an improved staging and subsequent tailored loco-regional management. Our results reiterate the importance of SLNB utilization and adjuvant radiotherapy in the management of MCC at all clinical T stages.

abstract_title: A Textbook Oncologic Outcome following Cancer Surgery: Hospital Variation and Its Impact on Survival
author_block: C. T. Aquina<sup>1</sup>, A. Z. Becerra<sup>2</sup>, J. Wiseman<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Cloyd<sup>1</sup>, A. Tsung<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup>, A. Ejaz<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Rush University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  A “textbook oncologic outcome” (TOO) is a composite quality measure representing the “ideal” outcome for patients undergoing cancer surgery.  This study sought to evaluate possible variation in TOO across hospitals in the U.S. and its impact on overall survival (OS).

Methods:  The National Cancer Database (2006-2015) was queried for curative-intent resection of lung, esophageal, gastric, pancreatic, colon, rectal, or bladder cancer.  Organ-specific TOO was defined as: adequate lymph node yield, R0 resection, non-length of stay outlier, no hospital readmission, and receipt of guideline-concordant chemotherapy and/or radiation. Mixed-effects analyses assessed factors associated with TOO, hospital organ-specific resection volume, and OS.
