Results: Among 502,173 cancer resections, TOO rates varied across cancer types (lung=32.9%, esophagus=30.3%, stomach=30.1%, pancreas=23%, colon=65.2%, rectum=43%, bladder=34.9%).  There was wide hospital-level variation in risk-adjusted TOO rates with as much as 25-fold differences between the best and worst-performing hospitals (lung=3.5–75.3%; esophagus=3.3–63.3%; stomach=8.2–54.8%; pancreas=2.9–72.4%; colon=8.5–89.4%; rectum=17.7–72.6%; bladder=8.5–59.9%).  Increasing hospital volume was independently associated with higher odds of TOO across cancer types (Table).  After risk-adjustment, TOO was independently associated with improved OS (lung: HR=0.73, 95%CI=0.72-0.74; esophagus: HR=0.75, 95%CI=0.72-0.79; stomach: HR=0.57, 95%CI=0.54-0.60; pancreas: HR=0.75, 95%CI=0.73-0.78; colon: HR=0.56, 95%CI=0.55-0.57; rectum: HR=0.68, 95%CI=0.65-0.72; bladder: HR=0.74, 95%CI=0.71-0.77).

Conclusion: TOO achievement varied widely across hospitals, and there was a direct association between hospital volume and TOO.  Furthermore, TOO was independently associated with improved OS across all cancer types.  Selective referral to high-volume centers for complex oncologic procedures is recommended to improve the likelihood of achieving optimal cancer outcomes.

abstract_title: Neighborhood Socioeconomic Disparities Impact Pediatric Access to Surgical Care
author_block: R. Powers<sup>2</sup>, A. A. Mokdad<sup>1,2</sup>, K. J. Van Arenkdonk<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Of Wisconsin,Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A growing body of literature stresses the impact of neighborhood characteristics on access to care and healthcare utilization. In this study, we aimed to investigate the association between neighborhood deprivation status and outpatient and emergency care utilization among pediatric surgical patients.  

Methods: We queried patients seen at pediatric surgery outpatient clinics in a tertiary children’s hospital between 2017 and 2019. We also reviewed records of patients who underwent an operation during the same period. We included children younger than 18 years old residing in-state. We collected data on demographics, payer source, travel distance, and Area Deprivation Index (ADI), a neighborhood-level metric of socioeconomic disadvantage. Using multivariable logistic regression models, we evaluated predictors of missed outpatient visits, as well as predictors of missed postoperative outpatient visits and 30-day postoperative ED visits among those who underwent appendectomy or umbilical or inguinal hernia repair.  

Results: A total of 10,162 patients made 24,576 outpatient clinic visits. Patients were 57% male, 52% white, 28% black, and 17% Hispanic. The median age was 5 years (interquartile range [IQR], 1–13 years). 46% used commercial insurance whereas 52% were covered by Medicaid. Most patients lived in urban areas (93%) and relatively close to clinic; median distance was 15 miles (IQR, 9­–40 miles), a median 21-minute drive (Figure 1). 14% of patients lived in neighborhoods classified within the most affluent ADI decile, whereas 21% presented from the most deprived [decile] neighborhoods. Among those in the most deprived neighborhoods, 91% were non-white, and 88% were covered by Medicaid. 16% missed at least one scheduled clinic visit. ADI (most deprived decile: odds ratio [OR], 3.2; 95% CI, 2.2–4.6), black race (OR, 3.5; 95% CI, 2.9–4.2), and Medicaid insurance (OR, 2.7; 95% CI, 2.3–3.3) were significant predictors of missed outpatient visits. Among 2,543 patients who underwent an appendectomy or inguinal/umbilical hernia repair, 20% missed their postoperative outpatient visit, and 5% presented to the ED within 30 days of the operation. ADI, black race, and Medicaid coverage were again significant predictors of access to care.  

Conclusion: Notable variability in access to and utilization of healthcare resources was identified among pediatric surgical patients. Those presenting from deprived neighborhoods were less likely to access clinic and more likely to utilize ED resources. These findings highlight the need to promote health services programs targeting populations in deprived neighborhoods to mitigate emergency care costs and promote quality outpatient care.

abstract_title: A Critical Threshold for Global Pediatric Surgical Workforce Density
author_block: M. E. Bouchard<sup>1</sup>, Y. Tian<sup>1</sup>, S. Linton<sup>1</sup>, C. DeBoer<sup>1</sup>, J. Justiniano<sup>2</sup>, F. Abdullah<sup>1</sup>, M. Langer<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgery/Northwestern University,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Maywood, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  An estimated 1.7 billion children worldwide lack access to surgical care, especially in low- (LIC) and low-middle income (LMIC) countries. Congenital and complex care requires specialist pediatric surgeons, thus the pediatric surgical workforce density (PSWD) is an indicator of progress toward access to complete pediatric care.  Studies have demonstrated correlations between adult specialist surgical workforce density and maternal mortality rates, and between PSWD and improved survival of complex pediatric surgical problems.  However, it is unknown if PSWD correlates with population-level health outcomes for children.  We compared PSWD with neonatal, infant and under 5 childhood mortality rates and calculated the minimal PSWD associated with a significant reduction in mortality. 

Methods:  Using the WHO Global Surgical Workforce Database and publicly available medical licensing registries, the number of pediatric surgeons practicing in a convenience sample of 26 countries between 2015 – 2018 was identified.  Corresponding national children’s (<15 years) population and neonatal-, infant- and under 5-mortality rates were obtained for each country. PSWD was calculated as the ratio of pediatric surgeons per 100,000 children.  Each mortality rate was plotted as a function of PSWD and Spearman’s correlations were used to assess the strength of correlation.

Results: A total of 4 LIC, 8 LMIC, 10 UMIC and 4 HIC countries were analyzed.  The mean proportion of children < 15 of the total population was 42.8% (LIC), 38.2% (LMIC), 21.6% (UMIC) and 18.7% (HIC).  The median PSWD by income group was 0.03 (LIC), 0.12 (LMIC), 1.34 (UMIC) and 2.13 (HIC).  PSWD strongly correlated with neonatal (0.70008, p<0.003), infant (0.73878, p<0.001) and under 5 (0.74337, p<0.001) mortality rates. Population childhood survival rates increased significantly with increases in PSWD to a threshold of 0.3, beyond which further increases in PSWD correlated with small improvements in survival.

Conclusion: PSWD correlates with population mortality rates for children, with a critical threshold of 0.3 PSWD associated with a significant increase in survival.  This mirrors survival improvements seen for congenital and complex surgical care with a PSWD >0.4/100,000 children. These novel findings suggest the current pediatric surgical workforce in LIC and LMICs, where a greater proportion of the population is less than 15 years old, is inadequate to meet UN Sustainable Development Goal 3.2 for infant and under 5-mortality.  While PSWD is only one indicator of a system’s ability to care for children, pediatric surgeons are an essential component of a functional health system and efforts to increase the training and retention of surgeons are needed to improve the survival of children globally.

abstract_title: Use and Disparities in Parathyroidectomy for Symptomatic Primary Hyperparathyroidism in Older Adults
author_block: J. N. Herb<sup>1,3</sup>, B. S. Staley<sup>2</sup>, M. L. Roberson<sup>2</sup>, P. D. Strassle<sup>1</sup>, L. T. Kim<sup>4</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Epidemiology, Gillings School Of Global Public Health,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Cecil G. Sheps Center For Health Services Research,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Primary hyperparathyroidism (HPTH) is one of the most common endocrine disorders surgeons encounter, and can have significant long-term health effects if left untreated. Few studies assess utilization and disparities in parathyroidectomy for HPTH outside of high-volume institutions. The objective of this study was to evaluate national usage and disparities in parathyroidectomy by race, geography and socioeconomic status (SES) for symptomatic HPTH among older adults with universal health insurance.

Methods: A 20% random sample of Medicare claims files were used to identify patients >67 years old (to allow for a two-year lookback period) with a new diagnosis of HPTH from 2006-2017. “Symptomatic” was defined as having an additional diagnosis code for symptoms classically related to HPTH (eg. nephrolithiasis, osteopenia, pathologic fracture, etc.). Patients were followed from the first date they had documentation of both HPTH and at least one symptom, until receipt of parathyroidectomy, death, or December 31, 2017. Primary study variables were race (as reported in the claims), rurality (defined at county level using Rural Urban Continuum Codes) and SES (defined at the census-tract level using the Social Deprivation Index [SDI] categorized into quartiles). Multivariable Cox proportional hazards regression models were used to identify the association of our factors of interest with parathyroidectomy while adjusting for age, sex, comorbidities and symptoms.

Results: We identified 107,758 older adults with new diagnoses indicating symptomatic HPTH. The median age was 76 years (IQR 71-82). The cohort was 70% female, 82% non-Hispanic White, and 82% lived in urban areas. With a median follow-up time of 32 months (IQR 13-59), only 8.7% of patients (n=9,318) underwent parathyroidectomy. After adjustment, non-Hispanic Black patients compared to non-Hispanic White patients (HR 0.80 95% CI 0.73,0.87) and living in a low SES neighborhood compared to a high SES neighborhood (lowest SES quartile vs highest SES quartile HR 0.87 95% CI 0.81,0.92) were both associated with significantly lower incidences of parathyroidectomy. Patients from rural areas were more likely to undergo parathyroidectomy (isolated rural vs urban HR 1.43 95% CI 1.27,1.62).

Conclusion: To our knowledge, this is the largest examination of the use of parathyroidectomy for symptomatic HPTH. Rates of parathyroidectomy were surprisingly low, even among an older patient population. Similar to disparities in access to other surgical procedures, racial minorities and those who live in poorer areas had a lower likelihood of parathyroidectomy even among a population with identical healthcare coverage. In contrast, rural patients had an increased likelihood of parathyroidectomy, but selection bias may contribute to this finding. Quality improvement efforts, rooted in equitable care, should be undertaken to increase access to parathyroidectomy for this disease.

abstract_title: Patient Reported Outcome Measures of Health-Related Quality of Life and Fatigue after Thyroidectomy
author_block: M. K. Luddy<sup>1</sup>, J. Shank<sup>2</sup>, A. Kotwal<sup>3</sup>, A. Patel<sup>3</sup>, W. Goldner<sup>3</sup>, A. L. Fingeret<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Omaha, NE, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Surgery,Omaha, NE, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Medicine,Omaha, NE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  After thyroidectomy some patients experience a chronic fatigue syndrome called asthenia. The purpose of this study was to determine the post-operative health related quality of life (HRQoL) and risk of asthenia in patients undergoing thyroidectomy.  

Methods:  We performed a prospective observational cohort study of adult patients undergoing thyroidectomy from September 2016 to July 2019 at a single institution who provided consent and completed four HRQoL surveys: preoperative baseline, two weeks-, six months- and twelve months postoperatively. Patients were surveyed using Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), Short Form 36 version 2 (SF-36v2) and the Brief Fatigue Inventory (BFI). Exclusion criteria were prior thyroidectomy, concurrent parathyroidectomy, thyroid nodule or cancer over four centimeters, gross or lateral neck lymphadenopathy, Graves’ disease or a baseline BFI > 60 or PHQ-9 > 15. Patients with a BFI > 60 at 12 months were defined as having asthenia. Demographic and clinicopathologic variables were assessed. HRQoL scores were compared between patients undergoing thyroid lobectomy (TL) or total thyroidectomy (TT) with benign or malignant final pathology. Our primary outcome was chronic asthenia by extent of surgery and final pathology. Continuous variables were analyzed using Mann-Whitney U and Kruskal-Wallis tests and categorical variables using Chi-squared.   

Results: A total of 182 patients were included: 67 (37%) with TL and benign pathology (TL-B), 32 (17%) with TL and cancer (TL-Ca), 40 (22%) with TT and benign pathology (TT-B), and 43 (24%) with TT and cancer (TT-Ca). There were no differences between the groups with regard to age, body mass index, comorbidities, or preoperative thyroid stimulating hormone level. Patients with benign pathology were more likely to report preoperative compressive symptoms 57% versus 35% (p = 0.002). There were no differences in complications except for TT which had a higher rate of temporary hypoparathyroidism in 6 (7%) versus none with TL.  Cancer patients had longer mean follow-up of 21.5 months versus 13.1 months (p < 0.001). Baseline Physical Component (PCS) and Mental Component (MCS) Scores were similar between the groups, though BFI was higher in the cancer groups (p = 0.001) (Figure 1). In the TL-B group, 2 patients (3%) developed asthenia, compared with 2 (6.25%) in the TL-Ca group, 14 (35%) in the TT-B group, and 21 (48.8%) in the TT-Ca group (p=0.0001).  

Conclusion: Patients with low risk well differentiated thyroid carcinoma report higher levels of moderate fatigue at baseline. In patients with both benign and malignant pathology who do not report high levels of fatigue at baseline, TT is associated with a higher rate of asthenia compared with TL.

abstract_title: Should BIRADS scores be used in Adolescent Patients with Breast Lesions?
author_block: V. E. Polcz<sup>1</sup>, R. H. Frayman<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, R. Petroze<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Larson<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Mustafa<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida,Pediatric Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Breast Imaging Reporting and Database System (BI-RADS) score is a validated classification system used for defining risk of malignancy, management and follow-up of breast masses identified on MRI and ultrasound imaging in the adult population. Prior studies validating the use of this system have failed to include significant proportions of pediatric patients in their analysis, despite its use in evaluation of breast masses in this population. While pediatric breast masses remain uncommon, with negligible malignancy potential, they can be of considerable concern to patients and families, and no clear consensus has been established regarding their evaluation and surgical management. Our study aims to evaluate for association between BI-RADS classification of pediatric breast masses and correlation to surgical pathology, as well as evaluating management practices at our institution.  

Methods: Patients with ultrasound-confirmed breast masses with associated BI-RADS classification over a 9 year period were included. Demographic, clinical and imaging variables were collected. Patients were stratified based on ultrasound imaging characteristics as purely benign (BI-RADS ≤ 2) or increased risk (BI-RADS ≥3). Analysis of continuous variables was performed using t-test and categorical variables using two sample proportion test.  

Results: A total of 780 pediatric patients were identified as having undergone surgical evaluation for breast mass over the time period studied. 507 were found to have had further evaluation with sonographic imaging and associated BI-RADS classification. Of these, 220 had purely benign imaging (BI-RADS ≤ 2) and 287 were identified with BI-RADS classification of ≥ 3. Patients in both groups were found to be similar in age at presentation, age at menarche, BMI and laterality of lesions. The majority of masses were self-identified (83%). Patients with elevated risk based on radiographic classification had significantly larger average breast mass size (2.21 vs 1.47, p < 0.0001). Surgical excision was performed in 14 patients with purely benign imaging, and 116 patients with BI-RADS ≥3 (6% vs 40%, p<0.0001). Surgical pathology was found to be benign in all but one case, with fibroadenoma being the most commonly observed pathology.  

Conclusion: This study represents one of the largest cohorts evaluating the role of the BI-RADS classification in guiding management of adolescent breast masses. These data suggest that use of the BI-RADS system in adolescents may not be helpful, with surgical excision leading to benign surgical pathology in almost all cases. Further work is needed to establish a separate radiographic classification system of breast masses in the pediatric population.

abstract_title: The Role of Implicit Bias in Surgical Resident Evaluations
author_block: A. P. Turner<sup>1</sup>, A. Dill-Macky<sup>1</sup>, L. Neumayer<sup>1</sup>, V. N. Nfonsam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Implicit bias is a key factor preventing the advancement and retention of women and underrepresented minorities in academic surgery.  Implicit bias is insidious and difficult to measure objectively.  Recent work has identified implicit bias in granting of operative autonomy as well as the language used in residency training evaluations.  We sought to examine the role of implicit bias as it pertains to the technical component of the residency performance evaluation.  An objective, blinded measure of technical performance, the Fundamentals of Laparoscopic Surgery (FLS) score was compared to a subjective measure of performance, the technical evaluation score given by attending surgeons.

Methods: FLS scores and the average technical evaluation scores from chief resident performance evaluations at a university training program were analyzed from 2015-2019 (n=29 residents; female 21%, underrepresented minorities 31%).  The residency performance evaluation contains 7 domains of practice which are scored on a scale of 1-4.  The average technical skills score for each chief resident was determined from this evaluation; residents were evaluated by an average of 10 attending surgeons.  Results were analyzed for subjects’ gender, ethnicity and race. 

Results: There were no significant differences in FLS scores between male and female trainees (p=0.3).  There was a trend toward decreased technical evaluation scores for female trainees, but it was not significant (p=0.27).  There were no significant differences in FLS or technical evaluation scores between racial/ethnic groups (p=0.56, 0.52).  FLS and technical evaluation scores, respectively, were dichotomized into above and below the mean for the training program, in order to compare the relationship between individual residents’ FLS score and their technical evaluation score.  The Kappa correlation coefficient between the two dichotomized scores was significantly lower for female (-0.50) vs. male (0.23) trainees (p<0.01).  The Kappa correlation coefficient was not significantly different between racial/ethnic groups (p=0.51).

Conclusion: This is the first study to examine implicit bias in the technical component of the surgical resident evaluation.  The subjective technical performance evaluation score was compared to the blinded Fundamentals of Laparoscopic Surgery score.  Although there were no differences in average scores between groups, there was a statistically significant difference in agreement between the FLS and technical evaluation scores for individual female and male trainees.  This suggests the presence of implicit bias in our pilot study.  Identification of implicit bias is the first step toward its eradication.  Further research with a larger sample size is warranted.

abstract_title: Race, Gender, and International Medical Graduates: Leadership Trends in Academic Surgical Societies
author_block: L. F. Morris-Wiseman<sup>1</sup>, C. Canez<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Romero Arenas<sup>2</sup>, C. Hsu<sup>1</sup>, V. N. Nfonsam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Department Of Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Texas Rio Grande Valley,Department Of Surgery,Harlingen, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Non-White and female surgeons are underrepresented in academic surgery faculty, with lowest representation at the highest academic ranks or positions. We hypothesized that leadership of major US general surgery societies over the last decade reflected these same disparities. We aimed to determine whether there is an association between attending a prestigious medical school or residency program and surgeons attaining national societal leadership positions.

Methods:  Race (using personal knowledge or publicly available information) and visible (binary) gender of the 2020-21 executive council members of 11 major general surgery societies and the presidents of these societies 2012-2021 was assessed. Top 10 and Top 20 medical school and surgery residency programs were identified using public ranking programs. International medical graduates (IMGs) were excluded from the “Top programs” analysis. Fisher’s exact test was used to compare groups and Cochran-Armitage trend test was used to assess change over time.

Results: Surgical society executive council members in 2020-21 (n=77) were predominantly White (74%, n=57) and male (67.5%, n=52). The 20 non-White council members were Asian (80%), Black (10%), and Latino (10%). Nine (11.7%) executive leaders were IMGs; five were White (55.6%). Many 2020-21 executive leaders (41%, n = 28) attended Top 10 and majority (58.8%, n=40) attended a Top 20 medical school/residency. When evaluated by race and gender, 30% of White men, 43.5% of women, and 66.7% of non-White men in executive leadership roles attended Top 10 schools/residency. In the last decade, surgical society presidents (n=105) have been mostly White (85.7%, n=90) and male (78.1%, n=82). Non-White male surgical society presidents have been Asian (39%, n=9), Black (23.1%, n=3), and Latino (7.7%, n=1). Of the 23 female surgery society presidents, 91.3% have been White, 8.7% Asian, and none Black or Latina. Eleven society presidents were IMGs (10.5%); most were White (80%). Society presidents attended Top 10 (36.2%) or Top 20 (56.4%) schools/residency. Fewer White male society presidents attended Top schools/programs compared to non-White male presidents (Top 10: 32.3% vs. 60%; p=0.15; and Top 20: 56.5% vs 80%; p=0.3). There has been no significant change over the last decade in society presidents in terms of race or gender.  

Conclusion: Women, non-White surgeons, and IMGs are underrepresented in US surgical society leadership. Most IMGs in societal leadership are White. Nearly 60% of societal leaders in the last 10 years attended a Top 20 medical school or residency program. While not statistically significant, a higher percentage of non-White men in leadership attended a prestigious school/residency program compared to White men. These data suggest that increasing racial diversity in US surgical societies may require mentorship and sponsorship particularly for surgeons who did not attend prestigious medical schools or residency programs.

abstract_title: Barriers to Parental Leave During Training: Time for Change
author_block: I. C. Bostock<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Corsini<sup>1</sup>, M. B. Antonoff<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Thoracic Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Parental leave policies for trainees and practicing physicians are crucial for wellness in the workplace, yet standardized practices are lacking.  While exploring options for our institutional trainee parental leave policy, we performed a widespread survey through social media. In this study, we aimed to compare experiences of individuals who became parents during surgical training programs compared to those in non-surgical training programs.  

Methods: We designed and distributed an electronic survey to physician-parents via social media groups and a graduate medical education database between October 2019 and February 2020. Responses were collected using a web-based application, and standard descriptive and comparative analyses were performed. 

Results: We received 64 responses from participants practicing or training in various medical specialties including 48 (74%) non-surgical respondents (NSR) and 16 (26%) surgical respondents (SR). All respondents had experienced the entry of a child/children into their families during their training (including college, medical school, residency, or fellowship). Of NSR, 93% delivered their child vs. 95% of SR (p=0.84); 5% of SR had their partner deliver their child.  Among all-comers, respondents took a mean of 7.5 ± 5.2 weeks off (range, 0-14) after child delivery. Interestingly, NSR took 8.7 ± 5.8 weeks of leave, while SR took 4.7 ± 2.7 (p=0.006, Figure 1). A minority of respondents (25/64, 39%) reported a formal institutional policy for parental leave during their training. Most (49/64, 76%) respondents wished they could have had more time off.  When asked to identify barriers for taking more leave, respondents reported similar issues across specialties, including challenges with graduation requirements (NSR 58% vs. SR 68% p=0.46), peer pressure or colleague perception (NSR 59% vs. SR 58% p=0.97), and pressure from institutional leadership (NSR 31% vs. SR 35% p=0.77).  Forty-three percent (28/64) respondents had additional children during training. Overall, parent-trainees took less time off for the second child with a mean of 5.1 ± 7.4 weeks (range, 0-12) after delivery. 

Conclusion: Less than half of respondents reported the presence of formal parental leave policies for trainees at their institutions. The majority of trainee-parents reported wishing they had more time off. Surgical trainees took less time off after delivery than their non-surgical counterparts, which may be related to procedural volume-related requirements. Cultural and professional changes are crucial in o promoting wellness and healthy transitions into parenthood for surgical trainees.

abstract_title: Trends in Diversity and Inclusion Publications: General Surgery
author_block: J. D. Blum<sup>1</sup>, M. Reghunathan<sup>2</sup>, W. Chen<sup>3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego,School Of Medicine,La Jolla, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Diego,Division Of Plastic Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Department Of Orthopedic Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Over the last thirty years, the proportion of women and under-represented minorities (UIM) in general surgery has increased; however, since 2011 there has been a significant decrease in UIM trainee representation (ACGME and AAMC data). We aim to assess the scholarly interest level in diversity and inclusion of the academic general surgery community over the last three decades and compare this with other surgical subspecialties.

Methods: PubMed/MEDLINE, EMBASE, and The Grey Literature Report databases were evaluated for publications from 1990 to 2020 regarding women and racial/ethnic minorities in surgery and surgical subspecialties in the United States. Search terms included, "women/female," "gender," "minorities," "race/racial," "ethnic/ethnicity," "pipeline," "underrepresented/underrepresentation/ representation," "african/black," "latino/hispanic," "diversity/diverse," AND "(neuro, general, plastic, etc.) surgery," "academic," "faculty," "resident," "fellow," "student," “department/division.” First-generation, low-income (FGLI) and LGBT+ data was excluded from general surgery analysis due to a paucity of literature and overall lack of available information.  

Results: Thirty-eight publications have examined diversity in general surgery (gender, n=25; race/ethnicity/UIM, n=10; gender + race/ethnicity/UIM, n=3). General surgery has significantly more literature published per year regarding gender diversity (0.81 publications/ year) than ethnic/ racial diversity (0.32 publications/ year) (p = 0.036). Every specialty demonstrated a significant increase in publications about diversity over time (p<0.05), with the most marked increases seen in general surgery (+0.10 publications/year, R= 0.5, p= 0.002), plastic surgery (+0.10 publications/year, R = 0.6, p<0.001), and orthopedic surgery (+0.13 publications/year, R = 0.5, p= 0.01). Trends in UIM trainee representation revealed no significant increase in residents and fellows in any surgical specialty (p> 0.05), while gender diversity has increased significantly for all specialties (p<0.05), with plastic surgery exhibiting the highest growth rate in female residents (+1.6% per year, R = 0.985, p< 0.001) compared to all other surgical specialties.

Conclusion: Scholarly interest from general surgery in women and UIM surgeons has increased over time (p<0.05), yet this increased interest has only correlated with an increase in women's representation. While general surgery has more diversity publications than many surgical subspecialties, this does not translate to a parallel increase in UIM surgeon representation. Especially in the context of recent events, in order to enact meaningful change in the landscape of academic general surgery, our field must change its culture to prioritize diversity and inclusion.

abstract_title: Closing the Gap: Increasing Female Representation in Surgical Leadership
author_block: S. L. Rakestraw<sup>1</sup>, D. Sutzko<sup>1</sup>, B. Corey<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Female medical students now outnumber their male counterparts. Female representation is increasing in general surgery residency (41.3% in 2019) and in the surgical work force (20.6% in 2017).  However, women remain under represented in surgical leadership (18% of program directors in 2018 and 3% of department chairs in 2015). With the current growth rate, women are not expected to reach professorship parity in surgery until 2136. Suggested reasons for this discrepancy are lack of female role models, lack of mentorship and support, and gender discrimination.  

Methods: Leadership data from an academic Department of Surgery in 2016 and 2020 was reviewed. Demographic data included gender, division, age, and leadership position. Leadership positions were defined as chair, vice chair, director (division, program, medical education), program leader, or associate chief. Comparisons were analyzed using chi-squared testing.   

Results: Female representation in leadership roles increased significantly from 2016 to 2020. One hundred percent of female professors hold leadership roles in 2020 compared to 0% in 2016 (p<.001). Among associate professors, 90% hold leadership roles in 2020 compared to 25% in 2016 (p<.001). Among assistant professors, 71% hold leadership roles compared to 7% in 2016 (p<.001). There was no significant difference in the age of female surgeons in leadership from those not in leadership (44 years vs 44 years, p=.521). Significantly more women in leadership roles held an MD than a PhD (91.3% vs 4.3%, p=.001), while one woman in leadership had an MD, PhD. There was no significant difference in leadership roles based on subspecialty (p=.058). During this period, there was a trend towards increasing numbers of women on the faculty (19.8% vs 26.4%, p=.27).  

Conclusions: Female leadership in an academic Department of Surgery has increased significantly since 2016. Promoting qualified female candidates to leadership roles provides role models for upcoming female surgeons. Resources should be allocated to continue the growth of gender equity in surgical leadership.

abstract_title: Gender Differences in Medical Specialty Decision Making: the Importance of Mentorship
author_block: K. Morte<sup>1</sup>, D. Nelson<sup>2</sup>, D. Lammers<sup>1</sup>, C. Marenco<sup>1</sup>, M. DeBarros<sup>1</sup>, J. Bader<sup>2</sup>, J. Bingham<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Madigan Army Medical Center,Tacoma, WA, USA <sup>2</sup>William Beaumont Army Medical Center,El Paso, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While previous studies have explored factors influencing medical students’ choice of specialty, there remains a relative paucity of data examining how these factors differ between males and females. With females now comprising over 50% of all medical students, it is unclear if this shift in demographics will translate to differences in how students ultimately choose a medical specialty. Therefore, the aim of this study was to determine if differences exist in how male and female medical students value various factors when choosing a career path in medicine.

Methods: A survey of basic demographic information and a Likert-based questionnaire addressing various factors in specialty choice was sent to all military medical students in the class of 2019. Univariate analysis was conducted for continuous variables using T-test and categorical variables using χ2 analysis.

Results: The survey response rate was 30%, of which 72% were male and 28% were female. The majority of students were less than 27 years old (52%) and Caucasian (77%).  After analyzing the factors that impacted specialty choice, female medical students placed greater importance on exposure to third year clerkships (p=0.004) and gender diversity within the specialty (p=0.03) than their male counterparts. Presence of mentors (p=0.07) and diverse ethnic representation within the specialty (p=0.07) trended towards greater importance among female students compared to males, but this difference was not statistically significant. Statistically more female medical students had a mentor in the specialty they applied to as compared to males (p=0.009). There were no gender-specific differences with regard to opinions of significant others or family members, desire to have a family, or having a well-balanced life. 

Conclusions: Female medical students valued exposure during third year clerkships, mentorship, and gender and ethnic diversity more than their male colleagues when choosing a future specialty in medicine. Although female applicant’s desire to have a family and work-life balance is often touted as justification for the lack of gender equality in particular specialties, our study did not find this to be the case. Our findings support the need for diverse representation in medical leadership and highlights the importance of early career mentorship beginning at the medical student level in order to ensure diversity and equality in the medical workforce.

abstract_title: Psychosocial Experience Among Cancer Patients – What Drives Perioperative Anxiety?
author_block: M. C. Bamdad<sup>1</sup>, B. Sinco<sup>1</sup>, E. Mubarek<sup>1</sup>, C. Harter<sup>1</sup>, M. Motamed<sup>2</sup>, C. Brummett<sup>2</sup>, J. Waljee<sup>1</sup>, T. Hughes<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Anesthesiology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anxiety and distress following a cancer diagnosis is pervasive, although its impact on decision-making and care delivery is incompletely understood. Anxiety and depression among breast cancer patients are well described during survivorship, but data from earlier phases of diagnosis are lacking. Additionally, little is known about differences in distress across cancers. We explored differences in peri-operative negative affect in breast cancer patients compared to other cancer patients undergoing surgery similar in scope. We hypothesized that expressed or experienced anxiety and stress is higher in patients with breast cancer compared to patients with melanoma.

Methods: We identified all adult patients undergoing surgery for breast cancer or melanoma in a large, prospective registry of surgical patients that includes pre- and post-operative psychosocial measures. Men with breast cancer were excluded due to small sample size. Patients were grouped based on cancer type (breast cancer, melanoma) and subsequently gender and cancer type. PROMIS Anxiety and Depression Scores and Perceived Stress Scale responses were compared across groups using Student’s T-test, with a p-value of less than 0.05 indicating statistical significance.

Results: A total of 951 patients were included: 386 women with breast cancer (mean age 57 yrs), 232 women with melanoma (mean age 56 yrs), and 333 men with melanoma (mean age 63 yrs). Patients with breast cancer had higher anxiety scores overall compared to patients with melanoma (8.4 vs 6.9, p<0.001). However, when comparing women with breast cancer and women with melanoma, PROMIS Anxiety scores were similar (8.4 vs 7.9, p=0.122), and this did not change when adjusting for age. Men with melanoma had significantly lower anxiety scores compared with women with melanoma (6.3 vs 7.9, p< 0.001), an effect that also persisted despite age adjustment. Perceived stress was similar for women with breast cancer or melanoma (4.8 vs 4.6, p=0.519), though women with melanoma had modestly higher stress scores than men with melanoma (4.1 vs 4.6, p=0.042). 

Conclusion: Overall, women with breast cancer expressed higher levels of anxiety and stress compared to individuals with melanoma; however, when melanoma patients were sub-grouped based on gender, there was no significant difference between women with breast cancer and women with melanoma. This may indicate that women undergoing treatment for cancers have psychosocial needs that are currently unmet by existing systems of care. This patient population may benefit from further qualitative study to identify drivers of anxiety and stress at the time of surgery, in order to improve their experience of cancer care. This may indicate underlying gender differences in patterns of response to negative affect measures such as PROMIS Anxiety and Perceived Stress Scale, although both have been previously shown to maintain validity across gender.

abstract_title: CNP-miR146a Enema Decreases Gross Pathologic and Histopathologic Colon Changes in a Murine IBD Model
author_block: A. E. Louiselle<sup>1</sup>, S. Niemiec<sup>1</sup>, M. Azeltine<sup>1</sup>, L. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, M. Stager<sup>2</sup>, M. Krebs<sup>2</sup>, C. Zgheib<sup>1</sup>, K. Liechty<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Laboratory For Fetal And Regenerative Biology, Department Of Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>Colorado School of Mines,Chemical And Biological Engineering,Golden, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Increased inflammation and oxidative stress are key features in the pathogenesis of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). We have previously shown that local delivery of a CNP-miR146a-Chitosan gel enema into the Dextran Sodium Sulfate (DSS)-murine model of colitis/IBD results in decreased TNF-alpha expression within the injured colon as well as clinical improvements including decreased blood in stool and more formed stools. CNP-miR146a is a novel conjugate that combines free-radical scavenging cerium oxide nanoparticle (CNP) and anti-inflammatory microRNA, miR146a, that synergistically targets both oxidative stress and inflammation, as is seen in IBD. Here we propose that local administration of CNP-miR146a in a Chitosan gel enema would also result in decreased gross pathologic and histopathologic findings of the mouse colon.

Methods:  C57BL/6J age-matched mice (n=15) were divided equally into three groups. The control group received regular water and a PBS enema on experiment day three. The IBD colitis mice received 3% DSS water to induce colitis and a PBS enema or a CNP-miR146a enema on experiment day three. Mice were sacrificed on experiment day six and their colon length was measured and then placed in 10% formalin solution, fixed and then stained with H&E. We used a modified published scoring model to score each of the H&E slides for all groups. The division of points fell broadly into three categories: Inflammatory cell infiltrate (0-7 points), epithelial changes, (0-25 points) and mucosal architecture alterations (0-25 points) for a maximum total score of 57.

Results: The average colon length for the control group was 6.75 cm, which was shortened in the diseased group at 4.9 cm, and improved for the treated group at 5.6 cm. The average histology score of the control group was 1.25, of the diseased group was 20.8, and of the treated group was 13.4 (p<0.05 for all groups). We observed improvement in crypt and villous architecture, decreased inflammatory cell infiltrate, and less goblet cell loss and variability in the treatment group as compared to the diseased group.

Conclusion: These results demonstrate that there is improved colon length along with lessened histological disease severity in the colon tissue of DSS-colitis mice when treated with a single therapeutic CNP-miR146a enema as compared to a PBS enema. These finding support the clinical improvements previously observed and highlight the potential of CNP-miR146a as a promising treatment for IBD.

abstract_title: Single-cell Analysis Shows Postnatal Enteric Glial Cells Closely Resemble Embryonic Neural Stem Cells
author_block: R. A. Guyer<sup>1</sup>, S. Bhave<sup>1</sup>, R. Stavely<sup>1</sup>, R. Hotta<sup>1</sup>, Z. Li<sup>2</sup>, E. Ngan<sup>2</sup>, A. M. Goldstein<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Pediatric Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Hong Kong,Surgery,Hong Kong, HK, Hong Kong
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intestinal neuropathies such as Hirschsprung disease may be amenable to cellular therapies to replace missing enteric neurons. Identifying an autologous source of neuronal progenitors would obviate the need for immunosuppression. Patient-specific induced pluripotent stem cells are a potential autologous source, but induction protocols are inefficient and time consuming. Enteric glial cells are capable of undergoing neurogenesis when stimulated by inflammation in vivo or when cultured in differentiation conditions ex vivo. This suggests glial cells are a persistent pool of neuronal progenitors in the postnatal gut. In this study, we use single cell RNA sequencing to test the hypothesis that postnatal enteric glial cells maintain a transcriptional program resembling embryonic neuronal precursors.

Methods: Plp1::GFP reporter mice expressing GFP from the glial-specific Plp1 promoter were euthanized on day 14 of postnatal life and the longitudinal muscle-myenteric plexus layer (LMMP) of the small intestine was isolated. The LMMP was enzymatically digested and glial cells isolated by sorting for GFP+ cells. cDNA libraries were constructed using a 10X Genetics Chromium Controller. Sequencing was performed on an Illumina NextSeq instrument. Genome alignment was performed with the Cell Ranger pipeline. Spliced and unspliced RNA counts were determined with the Velocyto software package. Data were processed and analyzed using Seurat and scVelo software packages. Gene ontology analysis was conducted with the ClusterProfiler R package. Data from GFP+ glial cells was compared with a published dataset of embryonic enteric nervous system (ENS) cells. The datasets were integrated using two algorithms, one using embryonic cells as a reference set and one with a joint learning approach for unbiased integration.

Results: Lineage inference based on spliced/unspliced RNA ratios in the embryonic dataset reveals a clear differentiation trajectory from ENS stem cells to early neurons. Dataset integration demonstrates that postnatal enteric glial cells have transcriptional profiles closely matching both ENS stem cells and proliferating embryonic neuronal progenitors. Some transcriptional differences exist between embryonic cells and postnatal glia.

Conclusion: Postnatal enteric glial cells have a transcriptional signature closely resembling embryonic ENS stem cells and embryonic neuronal progenitors, supporting our hypothesis that postnatal glia represent a persistent pool of incompletely differentiated ENS cells. This finding may explain the ability of glial cells to transition to a neuronal phenotype in the postnatal gut. Enteric glia are an attractive source of autologous cells for regenerative therapies for Hirschsprung disease and other intestinal neuropathies.

abstract_title: Endothelial to Mesenchymal Transition in Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Pulmonary Hypertension
author_block: J. Gilley<sup>1,2</sup>, L. Hui<sup>1</sup>, A. Kaul<sup>1</sup>, S. Keswani<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Laboratory for Regenerative Tissue Repair, Baylor College of Medicine and Texas Children's Hospital,Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Houston, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Division Of Neonatology, Department Of Pediatrics,Houston, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is one of the most complex congenital disorders, often accompanied by progressive pulmonary hypertension (PH). Studies show that pulmonary arteries of neonates with CDH have reduced intraluminal diameter, low vascular compliance, and altered flow patterns due to pathologic vascular extracellular matrix (ECM) remodeling. This pathological ECM encases the lumen to become a virtual “lead pipe,” blocking the efficacy of vasodilatory anti-PH drugs. Prior data suggest that abnormal remodeling of the pulmonary vascular ECM results from endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndoMT), which contributes to PH. During EndoMT, endothelial cells lose the expression of markers CD31 and vWF and acquire an elongated and fusiform myofibroblast-like morphology and express mesenchymal lineage specific markers α-SMA and type I collagen. Our pre-clinical and clinical data show that CDH is accompanied by increased expression of EndoMT markers, leading to our hypothesis that EndoMT contributes to the pathologic vascular ECM remodeling seen in CDH.

Methods:  A biobank of pulmonary samples of deceased CDH patients with respective pre- and post-natal clinical data was used to investigate the reciprocal loss of endothelial markers and acquisition of a mesenchymal lineage in human and Slit3-/- murine CDH models. Three pairs of control and diseased human and murine samples were stained with CD31 and α-SMA using immunohistochemistry (IHC). Expression of DII4, a transmembrane protein of the Notch ligand pathway, was evaluated by qRT-PCR. CDH vessels were then isolated using laser capture microdissection (LCM) with subsequent proteomic evaluation to determine pathways upregulated in the pathologic vessels. 

Results: Data from IHC of lung tissue sections from human CDH patients revealed co-labeling of CD31 and α-SMA in the pulmonary artery endothelium, indicating ongoing EndoMT that could lead to vascular ECM remodeling and PH. Similarly, lungs from Slit3-/- mice showed α-SMA and CD31 double-stained endothelial cells, suggestive of EndoMT. Expression of Dll4, a vascular endothelial ligand associated with EndoMT, was upregulated in both human and mouse CDH samples. Consistent with IHC data, proteomic profiling of LCM-dissected vessels from human CDH tissues detected fifty-three proteins associated with ECM pathways, suggesting a role for EndoMT in vascular remodeling and CDH-PH development. 

Conclusion: Our results reveal that infants with CDH have increased expression of biomarkers associated with EndoMT. The results of our study also suggest that EndoMT may play a role in the pathologic vascular ECM remodeling leading to CDH-PH. Due to this new data, there is a significant need to further investigate the underlying pathogenesis of CDH-PH for potential therapeutic targets to develop effective anti-PH drugs.

abstract_title: Friend or Foe: The Duality of Furin in Hepatic Malignancy
author_block: C. M. Lake<sup>1</sup>, K. Glaser<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Bondoc<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center,Pediatric Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Hepatoblastoma (HB) is the most common primary liver malignancy in children. Several cell lines are used to study the underlying cellular mechanisms and potential therapeutics in vitro. HB is a heterogenous disease process; however, the most common pathologic subtypes are epithelial. In many other epithelial cancers proprotease enzymes, such as furin, have been implicated as molecular targets with a focus on the ability of furin inhibitors (FI) to decrease proliferation. The combination of an unknown underlying mechanism and low mutational burden in HB coupled with furin’s regulatory role in growth pathways, such as TGF-B, IGF, and Wnt, make furin a interesting target for further investigation.

Methods: Lyophilized FI (Sigma Aldrich, SCP0148) was resuspended in DMSO. Either FI or DMSO was added to media to reach a final concentration of 200 µM.  HepG2 and SK Hep1, two liver derived cell lines, were incubated with either FI/media or DMSO/media and a WST proliferation assay (Takara, MK400) assessed for variations in the proliferation response. At 72 hours a WST assay was performed.

Results: In HepG2 cells, the addition of FI resulted in increased proliferation at 72 hours at the 200 µM concentration. On the contrary, the SK Hep1 cells demonstrated decreased proliferation after incubation with FI compared to DMSO controls at 72 hours for this specific concentration of FI.  

Conclusion: FIs have shown therapeutic promise in several epithelial cancers, including breast, head and neck and gastrointestinal cancers. However, in hepatic cell lines used to study HB we have shown a disparate proliferation response to the addition of a single concentration of FI. SK Hep1 mirrors other epithelial cancers with a decrease in proliferation at 200 µM FI concentration likely due to the regulatory role of furin in key growth pathways. However, HepG2 cells showed an increased proliferation rate in response to 200 µM addition of FI at 72 hours. Further elucidation of the mechanisms underlying this difference, in coordination with continued study of additional dose responses, may clarify the role of FI as a potential therapeutic for HB.

abstract_title: Selective Fetal Absorption for Neural Tube Teratogenesis Hinges on Maternal Natural Killer Cell Function
author_block: K. C. Ott<sup>1</sup>, M. Oria<sup>2</sup>, C. R. Redden<sup>1</sup>, H. K. Kang<sup>1</sup>, L. E. Turner<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Alhajjat<sup>1</sup>, S. Duru<sup>2</sup>, J. L. Peiro<sup>2</sup>, A. F. Shaaban<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Center for Fetal Cellular and Molecular Therapy,Ann And Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Center for Fetal and Placental Research,Division Of Pediatric General And Thoracic Surgery, Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neural tube defects (NTDs), such as exencephaly and spina bifida are common and severe malformations of the developing central nervous system. The recurrence risk for an NTD in a subsequent pregnancy is 20x higher.  The risk for a second recurrence is 40x.  The predisposition to having children affected by NTDs has not been explained and may relate to differential surveillance by the maternal immune system.  Given that natural killer (NK) cells are the most prevalent lymphocyte at the maternal-fetal interface, we hypothesized is that maternal NK cells are necessary for selective fetal absorption with the development of an NTD.

Methods: We challenged this hypothesis in an outbred murine model of valproic acid (VA)-induced fetal neural tube teratogenesis (NTT). VA-induced teratogenesis was performed of pregnant CD1 dams at E8.  To evaluate protection from NTT’s, maternal NK cells were either selectively eliminated (mAb PK136) or functionally augmented (IFNg) prior to VA administration (E7). All litters were harvested on E14 and prevalence of NTT compared between each treatment group and untreated controls.

Results: We found that the frequency of litters with VA-induced NTT was significantly higher when maternal NK cells were selectively depleted (100% vs 83%, p<0.05).  Importantly, NK-depleted dams also had more litters with pups affected by exencephaly that were not absorbed (96.8% vs 74.3%, p<0.05). Conversely, IFNg-augmented litters were less likely to be affected by NTT (69.2%; p<0.05) and were less likely to have fetuses with exencephaly that were not also being absorbed (53.8%, p<0.05). Litter sizes were similar between the groups.

Conclusion: These findings demonstrate that selective fetal absorption for NTT hinges on intact maternal NK cell function.  Enhanced protection from NTT can be achieved through augmented maternal NK cell function. Further studies are needed to define the mechanisms by which maternal NK cells recognize and prevent aberrant fetal development.

abstract_title: Parabiotic Pairing Leads to Improved Intestinal Adaptation and Protection from Weight Loss in Mice
author_block: M. Sampah<sup>1</sup>, A. Gonzalez Salazar<sup>1</sup>, M. Kovler<sup>1</sup>, C. Sodhi<sup>1</sup>, P. Lu<sup>1</sup>, H. Jia<sup>1</sup>, M. Ladd<sup>1</sup>, W. Fulton<sup>1</sup>, S. Wang<sup>1</sup>, Y. Yamaguchi<sup>1</sup>, T. Prindle<sup>1</sup>, D. Hackam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Short bowel syndrome (SBS), a clinical condition which affects over 5000 children in the USA each year, occurs when the body is unable to absorb food after loss of large segments of intestine. We have previously shown that circulating factors can protect against intestinal injury in models of intestinal inflammation, suggesting the possibility that parabiotic pairing can improve adaptation in SBS. We now hypothesize that the presence of a parabiotic partner will improve outcome in the setting of short bowel syndrome. 

Methods: Four to six-week-old wild-type (WT) (recipient) and red labelled tdTomato (donor) mice were engineered into parabiotic pairs, in which mice were surgically joined to create a shared circulation. 75% of small bowel was removed and a primary jejuno-ileal anastomosis created on the recipient mouse within each pair. Weights were monitored over 7 days, after which mice were euthanized and gut tissue collected to assess for expression of various proliferation and differentiation genes.

Results: We discovered that the presence of a parabiotic partner with intact bowel surprisingly protected the WT mouse with short gut from the extent of weight loss observed in singleton short gut WT mouse. WT short gut mice in parabiotic pairs were found to be close to their original body weight by day 7. For each parabiosis pair, assessment of expression levels of various proliferation and differentiation genes such as GLP-2, Wnt, Notch and Lgr5 in gut tissue obtained from recipient WT mice and donor TdRed showed substantial differences in levels and patterns of expression between short gut pairs and control pairs. 

Conclusion: In support of the hypothesis, we discovered that the presence of a parabiotic partner improved adaptation in the setting of short bowel syndrome, bringing us a step further in the goal of discovering novel treatments for this devastating condition.

abstract_title: The Role of Bile Acid Metabolites on Cell Death in the Intestinal Epithelium
author_block: K. Anderson<sup>1,2</sup>, D. Handler<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Gayer<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Pediatric,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California,Pediatric/Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bile acids are becoming increasingly recognized as important signaling molecules in the intestine. Previous work from our lab suggests that different bile acid metabolites can contribute to either cell death or cell protection within the intestinal epithelium. These processes are major contributors to injury in intestinal disease. Mechanisms of controlled cell death can be categorized at apoptotic and necroptotic. The goal of our investigation was to examine the role of bile acid metabolites on cell death in the intestinal epithelium and the pathways of cell death.

Methods: Rat small intestinal epithelial cells (IEC-6) were purchased and maintained in cell culture media, Cells were synchronized in serum starved media for 24 hours prior to treatments with LCA, UDCA, or the combination. Cell death was measured using a modified MTS-based assay. Protein levels were assessed with Western blot analysis using antibodies for cleaved caspase 3 (CCSP3), caspase 3, RIPK3, and mixed lineage kinase domain-like (MLKL).

Results: LCA caused 50% cell death at a concentration of 50 uM when IEC6 cells were treated for 24 hours, while it took a concentration of 500 uM of UDCA to product the same affect, again over 24 hours. To determine the mechanism of LCA-induced cell death, we probed cell lysates exposed to LCA for CCSP3. LCA caused a dose- and time-dependent increase in CCSP3 expression, which was maximized at a concentration of 75uM versus untreated controls. Expression was first noted to increase at the 15 minute time point, becoming most robust at one hour. There was no change in RIPK3 or MLKL expression, suggesting that the necroptosis pathway was not involved. UDCA treatment did not change CCSP3 expression in the dose or time dependent trials. Interestingly, treating cells with UDCA at concentrations of both 200mM and 500 mM blocked LCA-induced CCSP3 expression. When cells were co-treated with UDCA and LCA, the cytotoxic effects of LCA were blunted.

Conclusion: LCA seems to cause cell death via increasing cleavage of caspase 3 promoting the apoptotic pathway but does not alter the necroptosis pathway. UDCA protects cells from LCA-induced cell death in part by blocking caspase 3 cleavage, preventing cells from undergoing apoptosis. These opposing effects of bile acids may provide a role for manipulation of bile acid concentrations in diseases where intestinal epithelial cell death is abundant.

abstract_title: Modulation of Zinc Homeostasis in the Offspring Gut Following Maternal Stress During Gestation
author_block: V. A. Yeramilli<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Brawner<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Martin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Uncontrolled activation of inflammatory cascades by the immature neonatal immune system contributes to the development of many pediatric diseases including necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Infants develop NEC in the first 2-3 weeks of life characterized by mucosal injury, necrosis, perforation, and microbial dysbiosis. While the mechanism(s) of pathogenesis is unknown, it is believed to have multifactorial causes. Because women in psychologically stressful environments have a higher incidence of adverse birth outcomes, we hypothesized that psychological stress during pregnancy negatively impacts the development of intestinal tissues in offspring. To understand how stress affects gut development, in this study, we investigated the molecular changes in the offspring gut following prenatal psychological stress. 

Methods: Pregnant dams were subject to psychological stress during gestation days 7-20 and the offspring were analyzed after birth. To identify differentially expressed genes (DEGs), RNA was isolated from the colon of 2wk old mice derived from dams that were either stressed or not stressed and sequenced at a high-resolution.

Results: 15 DEGs were identified in the colon tissues. In a principal component analysis, unlike males, stressed females clustered separately from controls. 13 genes were downregulated and 2 Metallothionein (MT) genes (MT1 &MT2) were upregulated in females. No DEGs were found in males indicating that the effects of gestational stress are sex-dependent. Quantitative PCR analysis revealed a 4 fold increase in the expression of MT1 and MT2 in colon tissues. MTs are a family of metal-binding proteins that regulate homeostasis of zinc (Zn) and copper (Cu). In recent years, MTs have emerged as an important, yet largely underappreciated component of the immune system.

Conclusion: Several critical genes and relevant pathways were revealed in this study, notably the modulation of genes involved in zinc metabolism. These findings are consistent with reports that show a decrease in serum zinc levels following acute stress, indicating a link between cortisol and zinc.  Ongoing studies are focused on understanding how alterations in the zinc metabolism in the neonatal gut following maternal stress lead to the development of tissue injury and inflammation.

abstract_title: Early Cardiac Dysfunction In Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia May Be Due To Hypoxia
author_block: V. S. Gupta<sup>1</sup>, S. Zhaorigetu<sup>1</sup>, D. Jin<sup>1</sup>, N. K. Berg<sup>2</sup>, H. Eltzschig<sup>2</sup>, M. T. Harting<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>McGovern Medical School at UTHealth,Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>McGovern Medical School at UTHealth,Anesthesia,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early cardiac dysfunction is common amongst infants with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) and has been uniquely implicated as a cause of morbidity and mortality amongst CDH patients. Despite the recognition of this clinical problem, the underlying pathogenesis of CDH-related cardiac dysfunction remains unclear. Our objective was to uncover molecular derangements in the pathogenesis of CDH-associated cardiac dysfunction.

Methods: We used the well-characterized nitrofen CDH rodent model. At birth, hearts were collected from both control and CDH pups. Only pups with large diaphragmatic defects (CDH study group stage C or D equivalent) underwent tissue harvest. Whole tissue RNA was extracted and submitted to NOVOGENE Corp. for RNA sequencing. The resulting fragments per kilobase million data were used to estimate gene expression levels, and genes with an adjusted p-value <0.05 and an absolute fold change >1 were considered to be differentially expressed. Pathway analyses were performed using differentially expressed genes with DAVID 6.8 and Revigo. Biological pathways with a false discovery rate (FDR) <0.05 were considered significant.

Results: Of 26,690 analyzed genes, 50 had significantly different expression between CDH and control heart tissue (n = 3 for both groups). 26 genes were downregulated in CDH hearts (median fold change 1.29, range 1.15 – 6.5), and 24 genes were upregulated (median fold change 1.65, range 1.17 – 12.99). Pathway analyses of these genes revealed that, compared to controls, CDH cardiac tissue RNA was significantly upregulated in hypoxia-related biological pathways (Figure). One pathway, glycolytic processes, was significantly downregulated in CDH pups (FDR <0.001).

Conclusion: In conclusion, CDH cardiac tissue shows significant upregulation of RNA related to biological processes involved in both the tissue and cellular responses to hypoxia. CDH-associated cardiac dysfunction may be strongly linked to hypoxia in the immediate postnatal period. Additionally, these data pinpoint specific areas for further investigation and potential therapeutic targets.

abstract_title: Placental Mesenchymal Stromal Cells: Preclinical Safety Evaluation for Fetal Myelomeningocele Repair
author_block: J. E. Jackson<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Pivetti<sup>2</sup>, S. C. Stokes<sup>1,2</sup>, C. M. Theodorou<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Kumar<sup>2</sup>, Z. J. Paxton<sup>2</sup>, A. Hyllen<sup>2</sup>, L. Reynaga<sup>2</sup>, A. Wang<sup>2</sup>, D. L. Farmer<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of California Davis Medical Center,Division Of Pediatric General, Thoracic And Fetal Surgery,Sacramento, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of California Davis Medical Center,Surgical Bioengineering Laboratory,Sacramento, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Myelomeningocele (MMC), the most severe form of spina bifida, is the congenital failure of neural tube closure in utero, resulting in progressive spinal cord damage via chemical and mechanical trauma from amniotic fluid and the uterine wall. This results in loss of lower limb motor function, causing paralysis. Historically MMC was treated with postnatal repair of the spinal cord defect, but after the landmark Management of Myelomeningocele Study, prenatal repair became the standard of care. Prenatal surgery resulted in improvements in motor function, however 55% of prenatally repaired children were still unable to walk independently, representing an opportunity to further augment the recovery of the damaged neurologic tissue.  We have developed a PMSC-ECM product [placental derived mesenchymal stromal cells (PMSCs) seeded on a Dural Extracellular Matrix (ECM)] to augment the prenatal repair of the defect. In order to support the clinical use of the stromal cell products manufactured under Current Good Manufacturing Practice (CGMP), we conducted preclinical safety testing of our PMSC-ECM in an established tumorigenicity murine model. Our hypothesis was that the clinical grade PMSC-ECM product would not result in local or distant tumor formation.

Methods: PMSCs were obtained from consented donor human placentas. Prior to surgery, the cells were seeded onto a 6mm diameter ECM at a density of 3x105 cells/cm2. Immunodeficient Nod SCID gamma mice were randomized to receive either ECM only or PMSC-ECM, delivered via a 1-2 cm skin incision on the back and placed in a subcutaneous pocket. Mice were monitored weekly for tumor formation until two study endpoints: 4 weeks and 6 months. Post-mortem analysis included pathology and histology on all tissues to examine for tumors and biodistribution by QPCR analysis of the implantation site and lung tissue for the presence of human DNA.

Results: In total, 54 mice were included, 13 ECM only and 14 PMSC-ECM in the 4-week group and 13 ECM only and 14 PMSC-ECM in the 6-month group. No mice had gross or histological evidence of tumor development or specific histologic findings suggesting treatment-related adverse effects. There was no evidence of impaired wound healing at the site of implantation of PMSC-ECM. PCR results showed that no mice had human DNA detected at either 4 weeks or 6 months in either the implantation site tissue or lung tissue.

Conclusion: Subcutaneous implantation of our PMSC-ECM product did not result in tumor formation in the permissive environment of an immune deficient murine model. We found no evidence that PMSCs persisted after implantation, therefore the likelihood of future tumor formation or cell therapy related complications is low. In combination with our other efficacy and safety data in our established ovine MMC model, the safety results in our murine model support initiation of a Phase 1/2a clinical trial for patients with MMC using our PMSC-ECM product.

abstract_title: Echocardiographic Parameters Predicting Discrete Subaortic Stenosis Development and Recurrence
author_block: K. L. Singampalli<sup>1,2,3,4,5</sup>, A. Nieuwsma<sup>6</sup>, R. K. Birla<sup>7</sup>, K. J. Grande-Allen<sup>4</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>7</sup>BIOLIFE4D,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,The Laboratory For Regenerative Tissue Repair,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Rice University,Department Of Bioengineering,Houston, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Medical Scientist Training Program,Houston, TX, USA <sup>6</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Pediatrics, Division Of Pediatric Cardiology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Discrete subaortic stenosis (DSS) is a pediatric cardiac disease in which a fibrous membrane forms below the aortic valve, likely due to altered blood flow patterns. DSS is typically diagnosed and staged using echocardiographic findings, mainly the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) pressure gradient. Though the membrane can be surgically excised, in up to one-third of cases, it recurs. One of the main challenges in managing this condition is identifying who will develop DSS or a recurrence before symptoms appear. Therefore, we aim to define predictive echocardiographic factors in DSS development in order to recognize children at risk for membrane formation and recurrence.

Methods: Pre-operative echocardiograms performed between 2012-2019 from patients with DSS and age- and sex-matched controls were analyzed. Parameters measured include demographics, cardiac function, left ventricular volume and geometry, LVOT pressure gradients, valve annulus diameters, and associated flow changes. The measurements were normalized using 50th percentile age and sex-matched values for body surface area or 50th percentile age-matched reference values. Variability within the data was analyzed using principal component analysis (PCA) to identify parameters involved in the development or recurrence of DSS.

Results: Echocardiograms from 42 DSS patients, 23 male and 19 female, and 29 controls were analyzed. 18 of the 42 DSS patients (43%) developed a recurrence. On average, patients with recurrence were younger at the time of surgery compared to those without recurrence (4.9 years vs 8.0 years, p<0.05). PCA was conducted using 12 echocardiographic and demographic parameters. Principal components (PCs) 1 and 2 accounted for 31.4 and 26.5% of the variability in the samples, respectively. As seen in the figure, the control and patient samples clustered separately along PC2, defined by variability in the LVOT pressure gradient, minimum LVOT diameter, and aortic insufficiency. All patient samples showed low variability in PC2, but non-recurrent and recurrent samples separated in PC1 due to variability in left ventricular ejection fraction, heart rate, and valve annulus diameters.

Conclusion: Variability in echocardiographic parameters successfully separated patients who develop DSS from healthy controls, and non-recurrent from recurrent DSS. The parameters responsible for the variability, including altered geometries and cardiac output, support the role of dysregulated flow patterns in the development of DSS, and ventricular function in its recurrence. These factors, in addition to further clinical and histologic findings, can aid in predicting DSS pathogenesis, allowing for earlier disease identification and appropriate management.

abstract_title: Application of an Inductor-Capacitor Resonant Sensor Allows for Differentiation of Tissue Viability
author_block: A. M. Beierle<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, H. R. Markert<sup>1</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, S. Charkhabi<sup>2</sup>, A. R. Carr<sup>2</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, N. F. Reuel<sup>2</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Pediatric Surgery,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>Iowa State University,Chemical And Biological Engineering,Ames, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Passive inductor-capacitor (LC) resonant sensors have been applied to a variety of biological conditions including monitoring hydrolytic enzyme activity and wound healing in animal models. We aimed to develop a LC sensor apparatus that could be applied to a murine model and utilized to differentiate between viable and non-viable tissues in various biologic tissue types. We hypothesized that there would be a significant difference in resonant frequency between both viable and non-viable abdominal and tumor tissues.

Methods: The model created consisted of an LC resonant sensor embedded in Tegaderm transparent film. The resonant sensor was connected in series with a Vector Network Analyzer (VNA), which allowed identification of the resonant frequency of the tissue in question (Fig. 1A). Athymic nude mice were injected with patient-derived neuroblastoma, hepatoblastoma, osteosarcoma, and neuroendocrine cell lines to obtain flank tumors. The resonant sensor was placed on the abdomen or the tumor-bearing area of the flank and the resonant frequency of the tissue was determined three times in each location. The resonant frequency of the tissue was measured on alive, non-anesthetized animals and repeated in the same location five minutes after the mice were euthanized. The data were analyzed with MATLAB MathWorks Software and significance determined at p < 0.05.

Results: The inductor-capacitor resonant sensor model proposed successfully obtained the resonant frequency values of various tissues of athymic nude mice. The resonant frequency obtained for the outside abdomen demonstrated a significant difference between alive and dead abdomen tissue (7.9 x 107± 3.5 x 106 vs. 3.4 x 107± 9.3 x 104 Hz, alive vs. dead, p < 0.001, Fig. 1B). The resonant frequency obtained for the alive and dead tumor tissue also demonstrated a significant difference (5.5 x 107± 4.7 x 105 vs. 9.1 x 107± 3.7 x 105 Hz, alive vs. dead, p < 0.001, Fig. 1C).  

Conclusion: A LC resonant sensor was designed for application to a murine model. The LC resonant sensor was applied to the abdomen and to established flank tumors in mice and was able to detect a specific resonant frequency that was significantly different between alive and dead tissue. The resonant sensor developed has potential clinical applications in the real-time identification of viable versus non-viable tissue including, but not limited to, detection of intestinal ischemia and adequacy of tumor biopsy specimens.

abstract_title: Modelling Human Stomach Development: Self-Organising 'Mini-Stomachs' in Floating Hydrogel Culture
author_block: B. C. Jones<sup>1,5</sup>, C. Luni<sup>2</sup>, E. Zambaiti<sup>1,3</sup>, S. Perin<sup>1</sup>, F. Sgualdino<sup>1</sup>, N. Thapar<sup>1,8</sup>, D. Cacchiarelli<sup>6,7</sup>, S. Eaton<sup>1</sup>, N. Elvassore<sup>1,2,3,4</sup>, G. G. Giobbe<sup>1</sup>, P. De Coppi<sup>1,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>University College London,Great Ormond Street Institute Of Child Health,London, LONDON, United Kingdom <sup>2</sup>ShanghaiTech University,Shanghai Institute For Advanced Immunochemical Studies,Shanghai, SHANGHAI, China <sup>3</sup>Veneto Institute of Molecular Medicine,Padova, VENETO, Italy <sup>4</sup>University of Padova,Department Of Industrial Engineering,Padova, VENETO, Italy <sup>5</sup>Great Ormond Street Hospital,Specialist Neonatal And Paediatric Surgery,London, LONDON, United Kingdom <sup>6</sup>Telethon Institute of Genetics and Medicine,Armenise/Harvard Laboratory Of Integrative Genomics,Pozzuoli, NAPLES, Italy <sup>7</sup>University of Naples Federico II,Department Of Translational Medicine,Naples, NAPLES, Italy <sup>8</sup>Queensland Children's Hospital,Department Of Gastroenterology, Hepatology, And Liver Transplant,Brisbane, QUEENSLAND, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lgr5+ gastrointestinal stem cells are capable of self-organising into 3D organoids resembling the tissue of origin. However, compared to other endodermal epithelial organoids, human gastric epithelial organoids (HGEOs) lack morphological complexity and diversity of differentiated cellular subsets. We examined the ability of HGEO to self-organise into more complex structures by culture in floating extracellular matrix (ECM) hydrogel rings and through interaction with mesenchymal and endothelial cells.

Methods: ECM hydrogels (decellularized small intestinal mucosa or collagen I) were prepared and tested for cytocompatibility and gelation. HGEO from 11- and 20-week foetuses and 11-year-old patient were expanded in Matrigel, then released and encapsulated in ECM hydrogels.  The HGEO-loaded gels were plated in a ring shape (200µL/well) in 24-well plates, and following gelation were detached by forceful addition of culture medium. For co-culture experiments, human fibroblasts and umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) were encapsulated in the ECM hydrogel with HGEOs and plated in the same fashion.  The rings were maintained in floating culture for 13 days, following which some ­rings were implanted in immunodeficient mice for 4 weeks. Analysis was performed using immunofluorescence (IF), real time PCR (RT-PCR), and micro-computed tomography (microCT).

Results: By Day 6, each condition showed spontaneous organisation of HGEO into a continuous tube by growth and fusion of adjacent organoids. Formation of the tubes occurred together with contraction of the hydrogel ring. The external surface of the tubes showed smooth and budding areas, and whole-mount confocal imaging demonstrated gland-like structures opening into a continuous lumen. IF and RT-PCR demonstrated mature gastric epithelial cell subtypes including, chief (pepsinogen), enteroendocrine (chromogranin A), and mucus secreting cells (MUC5AC, MUC6). Tubes showed appropriate polarisation with the apical surface of cells orientated towards the common lumen. Tubes also formed when HGEO were co-cultured with fibroblasts and HUVECs, the latter two of which formed a subepithelial lamina propria-like network. The self-organisation into tubes was associated with nuclear translocation of YAP, a transcription factor in the Hippo signalling pathway. Morphology, epithelial polarisation, and differentiated cell subtypes were maintained in the tubes after 4 weeks in vivo and there was evidence of luminal mucus by IF and microCT analysis of explants.

Conclusion: HGEO self-organise into complex stomach-like tubular structures with a continuous common lumen in floating hydrogel culture. The tubes demonstrate appropriate epithelial polarity and evidence of mature epithelial cell subtypes.  These characteristics are preserved following in vivo transplantation. This increase in complexity is associated with activation of the Hippo pathway.

abstract_title: Resonant Frequencies as a Means of Detecting Metastases and Characterizing Pediatric Tumor Type
author_block: H. R. Markert<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Beierle<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, S. Charkhabi<sup>2</sup>, A. R. Carr<sup>2</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, N. F. Reuel<sup>2</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Iowa State University,Department Of Chemical And Biological Engineering,Ames, IOWA, USA
abstract_body:
