Introduction: Children with advanced-stage or metastatic pediatric cancers often have poor prognoses. However, outcomes are markedly improved when these cancers are identified early. The use of resonant frequencies is a novel approach that potentially allows early identification of tumor subtype. Every biologic system, including tumors, has a naturally occurring resonant frequency. Through the use of an inductor-capacitor (LC) resonant sensor, this frequency may be detected and identified by applying an outside frequency and measuring the resonance at the peak amplitude. Using this technique, we investigated whether pediatric cancers varying in type and metastatic activity could be characterized specifically by their resonance.

Methods:  Two approaches were taken using patient-derived xenografts (PDX) in athymic nude mice: (1) hepatoblastoma, neuroblastoma, neuroendocrine, and osteosarcoma tumors were grown in the flank and (2) a metastatic model of a neuroendocrine tumor was established in the abdominal cavity. The abdomens of mice with and without metastatic tumors were scanned using the LC resonant sensor prior to euthanasia. Additionally, a controlled core sample of the tumors was obtained using a trephine needle. The tumor cores were scanned to identify the specific frequencies of each xenograft. Each scan was completed in triplicate. Data were analyzed using MATLAB®, and frequencies of tumor type and location were compared. Statistical significance was evaluated with ANOVA tests, and data were reported as a mean ± standard error of the mean.

Results: Resonant sensor scans of the abdomen in animals bearing neuroendocrine tumor metastasis showed resonant frequencies significantly lower than those of animals with a neuroendocrine flank tumor (p<0.001, Fig 1A). Tumor cores obtained from these metastatic PDX tumors also had significantly lower resonant frequencies than cores obtained from the flank PDX (p<0.001, Fig 1B). Significant differences were observed between the resonant frequencies of hepatoblastoma, neuroblastoma, neuroendocrine, and osteosarcoma tumors when both external tumor and tumor core scans were evaluated (Fig 1C, D). Furthermore, all resonant frequencies of each tumor type were relatively clustered in specific frequency ranges (Fig 1E).

Conclusion: We found significant detectable changes in the resonance of tumors based on their anatomic location and tumor type, indicating resonance may be a useful tool in identifying tumor metastatic activity and assisting differential diagnoses. These findings have important potential clinical applications to facilitate safe, inexpensive, and rapid diagnoses of pediatric cancers and to evaluate the extent of disease.

abstract_title: Increased expression of miRNA 874-3p is seen in Infants with Necrotizing Enterocolitis
author_block: H. L. Liebe<sup>1</sup>, C. Buonpane<sup>1</sup>, X. Cai<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Schlegel<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Hunter<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital at Oklahoma University Medicine,Pediatric Surgery,Oklahoma City, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a devastating disease that primarily affects premature infants. Micro-RNA (miRNA) have recently been identified to play an important role in a variety of human diseases such as cancer, inflammatory bowel disease and intestinal infections. miRNA 874-5p expression is increased during intestinal ischemia and is associated with intestinal barrier dysfunction and altered tight junction expression (occludin). Other miRNA are also associated with modulating intestinal permeability during inflammatory states (miRNA 155-5p, miRNA 21-5p). However, little work has been done to determine the role that miRNA may play in the pathophysiology of NEC. This study aims to test the hypothesis that miRNA associated with adult intestinal disease are also altered in NEC.   

Methods: Following IRB approval and parental consent, discarded surgical samples were collected from infants with NEC and control infants undergoing resection for other reasons (ostomy take down, atresia). Total RNA was isolated from the epithelium of surgical samples using Qiagen miRNeasy mini kit. Taqman Advanced miRNA cDNA Synthesis Kit was then used to reverse transcribe total RNA into cDNA. The TaqMan Advanced miRNA assays for miRNA 874-3p, 155-5p, 21-5p, 30e-5p were used for quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) to determine gene expression. The miRNA 16-5p was selected for use as a housekeeping gene. Samples were also processed and stained with immunofluorescence for tight junction proteins (occludin, claudin-1, 4, and zonula occludens). Data was analyzed with Student’s t-test.

Results: Increased expression of miRNA 874-3p in NEC samples vs. controls was seen (p<0.05). miRNA 21-5p was also increased though not significantly compared to control (p=0.88). miRNA 155-5p demonstrated a trend towards lower expression in NEC epithelium compared to controls (p=0.37). Significantly decreased expression of occludin and claudin-4 were found in NEC vs. control samples. No significant differences were noted in zonula occludens or claudin-1 compared with controls.

Conclusion: miRNA 874 appears to have increased expression in NEC and is associated with altered occludin expression.  This represents an interesting biomarker for future study. miRNA represent an exciting new area of research in the field of NEC and may provide a novel therapeutic target in the future.

abstract_title: Fn14 is Associated with Fibrogenesis in Biliary Atresia
author_block: C. Short<sup>1</sup>, J. Xu<sup>1</sup>, E. Mahdi<sup>1</sup>, A. Glazier<sup>1</sup>, A. Zhong<sup>1</sup>, K. Asahina<sup>2</sup>, K. S. Wang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Pediatric Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California,Southern California Research Center For ALPD & Cirrhosis, Department Of Pathology, Keck School Of Medicine,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Biliary Atresia (BA), the leading indication for pediatric liver transplantation, is characterized in part by progressive intrahepatic biliary fibrosis. We previously demonstrated that the expansion of Prominin-1 (Prom1)-expressing hepatic progenitor cells (HPCs) is functionally linked to  biliary fibrosis in BA and cholestatic injury (Zagory et al. Hepatology 2018; Fenlon et al. Physiologic Reports 2020). We have also previously reported that Fn14, the receptor for TWEAK (TNF-like weak inducer of apoptosis) known to play a role in various fibrotic diseases, is upregulated along with Prom1 and Tweak in the murine model of BA. We hypothesized that Fn14 plays an important role in Prom1-mediated fibrogenesis in BA. To test this hypothesis further, we utilized RNA-seq transcriptome analysis of human BA patients.    

Methods:   Raw RNA-seq data from liver biopsies of BA infants and controls were collected from the Childhood Liver Disease Research Consortium and processed by Luo et al. (Gastroenterology 2019). This data was obtained from the Gene Expression Omnibus database under accession number GSE122340 and was analyzed using Partek Flow Genomic Analysis software. Differential gene expression was further analyzed using Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) software and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA). 

Results:  Differential gene expression analysis of the RNA-Seq data revealed 3805 differentially expressed genes, comprising 2498 upregulated and 1307 downregulated genes in BA patients compared to controls.  PROM1 and FN14 were significantly upregulated in BA infants compared to controls (FDR 2.17E-7, fold change 6.03 and FDR 8.86E-10, fold change 5.98, respectively). GSEA revealed FN14 to be significant in the top enrichment gene sets included epithelial-mesenchymal transition and apoptosis. IPA showed that the most activated upstream regulator was TGFB1, with FN14 as a significant downstream target molecule. Pathway analysis of differential genes expression data demonstrates significant upregulation throughout the TWEAK signaling pathway with predicted activation of endothelial cell proliferation. This is consistent with ductular reactions and HPC proliferation in BA.

Conclusion:  FN14 is strongly upregulated as is PROM1 in BA infants compared to controls. Given the role of both genes in liver fibrosis and the known co-expression of FN14 in HPC, the functional link between the two is important to clarify.

abstract_title: Comparing Patient Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs) Among Common Breast Reconstruction Options
author_block:
S. Char<sup>1</sup>, J. Bloom<sup>2</sup>, Z. Erlichman<sup>1</sup>, M. Jonczyk<sup>2</sup>, A. Chatterjee<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tufts University School of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA 
<sup>2</sup>Tufts Medical Center,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast cancer continues to be the most prevalent cancer affecting women. Several reconstructive options may exist after its oncologic resection. Breast reconstruction can have a lasting impact on many areas of the patient’s life, and therefore, a high consideration for patient satisfaction is crucial. Patient reported outcome measures (PROMs) provide an important tool in the evaluation of different breast reconstruction techniques, and it can aid in shared decision-making between the surgeon and the patient. The aim of this systematic review is to look at various common surgical modalities in breast reconstruction as they relate to patient satisfaction. Thus, this study will provide a deeper insight of a patient's perspective on the array of reconstruction options. 

Methods: A PubMed PRISMA search for articles published between 2000 and 2020 was performed. Criteria for inclusion included nipple-sparing or skin-sparing mastectomy with autologous or implant-based reconstruction, level 2 volume displacement (breast mastopexy or reduction designs) or volume replacement oncoplastic surgery, and measurement of patient-reported outcomes using the BREAST-Q or other validated PROMs. Studies that used PROMs that were not validated were excluded. Analysis looked primarily at PROMs and how they compared when looking at level 2 volume displacement oncoplastic surgery, volume replacement oncoplastic surgery, mastectomy with implant construction, and mastectomy with free flap reconstruction. 

Results: After obtaining 254 full text copies, 43 articles were included. There were 8181 patients included (4363 BREAST-Q, 3818 other PROMs). When comparing types of reconstruction, oncoplastic breast surgery had the highest patient reported outcome measures. BREAST-Q scores (Table 1) demonstrated oncoplastic breast surgery was preferred over mastectomy regardless of the type of reconstruction used in all BREAST-Q categories. Specifically, level 2 volume displacement oncoplastic surgery represented the most favorable PROMs results. Mastectomy with autologous reconstruction was preferred over implant-based reconstruction. When using validated PROMs other than BREAST-Q, we note similar patient preferences to those found using the BREAST-Q.

Conclusion: In this comprehensive systematic literature review comparing breast reconstructive options, oncoplastic surgery showed highest PROMs when compared to other reconstructive modalities. Furthermore, mastectomy with autologous reconstruction is preferred over implant-based reconstruction. These trends were true when using BREAST-Q in addition to other validated PROMs.

abstract_title: Influence of Race, Insurance, and Geospatial Heterogeneity on Equity of Breast Cancer Care
author_block: C. Markey<sup>1</sup>, J. Weiss<sup>2,3</sup>, A. Loehrer<sup>4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth,Hanover, NH, USA <sup>2</sup>Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth,Department Of Biomedical Data Science,Hanover, NH, USA <sup>3</sup>Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center,Norris Cotton Cancer Center,Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>4</sup>Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>5</sup>Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth,The Dartmouth Institute For Health Policy And Clinical Practice,Lebanon, NH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Racial, socioeconomic, and geographic disparities have been studied independently in regards to stage at diagnosis and receipt of optimal treatment with curative intent surgery for breast cancer. However, considerable gaps in knowledge remain regarding the intersectionality between rurality, race, insurance status, and other aspects of socioeconomic deprivation that contribute in concert to disparities in cancer care delivery.  

Methods:  The study cohort included non-Hispanic women aged 18-64 years old with either private or no insurance coverage and a diagnosis with breast cancer from the North Carolina Central Cancer Registry (2010-2015). Logistic regression models examined the impact on advanced stage (III, IV) and receipt of curative intent surgery (CIS) from race, rurality, insurance, and the Social Deprivation Index (SDI). Models were adjusted for age at diagnosis, diagnosis year, and comorbidities and included two-way interactions among race, rurality, insurance, and SDI. The CIS model was among women with non-metastatic breast cancer and also adjusted for stage.

Results: Of the study population (n=20,530), 13.1% were diagnosed with advanced stage (III, IV), and 97.4% of women with non-metastatic breast cancer (n= 19,709) received curative intent surgery (CIS). 20.8% of women were non-Hispanic Black (NHB), 6.0% were uninsured/self-pay, 19.1% of women resided in rural areas, and 17.4% resided in communities of highest quartile SDI. NHB race/ethnicity (vs non-Hispanic White [NHW]), residence in rural (vs urban) or high social deprivation (vs lower quartiles) areas, and uninsured/self-pay status (vs private) were associated advanced stage breast cancer (Table). Among women presenting with non-metastatic breast cancer, NHB and uninsured/self-pay women were significantly less likely to receive CIS than NHW and women with private insurance, respectively (Table). Evaluating intersectionality between Black race, residency in a rural or high social deprivation community, and uninsured/self-pay status, there were no statistically significant interactions influencing stage at diagnosis or receipt of curative intent surgery.

Conclusion: In a large and heterogeneous population across the state of North Carolina with breast cancer prevalence comparable to the United States at large, uninsured status, non-Hispanic Black race/ethnicity, and residency in a rural or high social deprivation community are independently associated with decreased access to and receipt of breast cancer care. However, there was no measured interactions between these factors. Future studies on socioeconomic inequity and systemic racism should account for important geospatial heterogeneity of populations.

abstract_title: Unintentional Benefits from the COVID19 Pandemic on Breast Cancer Care at a Safety Net Hospital
author_block: A. Tang<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Mooney<sup>1</sup>, A. Mittal<sup>1</sup>, K. B. Knopf<sup>2</sup>, G. P. Victorino<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Khoury<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of California San Francsco - East Bay,Surgery,Oakland, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Alameda Health System,Oncology,Oakland, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID19 pandemic has negatively impacted early detection efforts due to interruption and delays in breast cancer screening.  At the onset of shelter in place, alterations in the delivery of care were enacted in order to preserve resources, including changes in breast cancer screening and treatment protocols. Our aim was to evaluate the effects of the COVID19 pandemic on breast cancer screening, diagnosis, and treatment at a safety net community hospital.

Methods: Since shelter in place was initiated in our community on March 16, 2020, a retrospective review of patients who received mammograms during March 16 to July 16, 2020 was conducted and compared to a similar cohort of patients from March 16 to July 16, 2019. Patient demographics, BIRADS distribution, cancer diagnosis, and time to treatment (time of biopsy diagnosis to surgery or chemotherapy) were obtained and compared between the 2019 and 2020 cohorts. Outcomes were analyzed for significance using the chi-square and Fisher exact test for categorical variables and t-test analysis for continuous variables.

Results: There were 1631 patients who received mammograms in 2019 and 807 patients in 2020 with 21 and 14 newly diagnosed breast cancer patients who started treatment in 2019 and 2020, respectively. Compared to 2019, less screening mammograms were performed, 491 (60.8%) in 2020 vs 1099 (67.4%) in 2019. Although there was no difference in the number of patients diagnosed with cancer (p=0.99), a higher percentage of patients were clinically detected in 2020 than 2019 (85.7% vs 52.4%, p=0.04). There was no change in time to initial consult (12 vs 17 days, p=0.11). Time to treatment was shorter in the 2020 cohort (28 vs 47 days, p=0.02).

Conclusion: The COVID19 pandemic has exacerbated disparities in breast cancer resulting in a higher rate of clinically detected breast cancer patients at our safety net hospital. Despite sudden constraints of already limited resources, our coordinated efforts led to a decrease in time to treatment for newly diagnosed breast cancer patients. Rapid changes in resource allocation, increase in telehealth use, and coordination between multidisciplinary teams led to improved treatment times.

abstract_title: Prepectoral Versus Subpectoral Breast Reconstruction Outcomes: a Retrospective Analysis
author_block: K. Marrero<sup>1</sup>, L. Gates-Tanzer<sup>2</sup>, A. Higham<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Carle Foundation Hospital,Urbana, ILLINOIS, USA <sup>2</sup>Univeristy of Illinois College of Medicine,Urbana, ILLINOIS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   While subpectoral implant-based reconstruction (IBR) is the mainstay of post-mastectomy reconstruction, prepectoral reconstruction is gaining popularity due to reduced postoperative pain, animation deformity and muscle spasms, plus increased aesthetic outcomes and patient satisfaction. Most studies comparing subpectoral and prepectoral reconstruction have centered on cosmetic outcomes and patient satisfaction. Few have compared post-surgical outcomes, taking into account oncologic treatments like chemotherapy or radiation therapy (RT). The goal of this study was to determine if type of IBR affected clinical outcomes.

Methods: Our retrospective analysis included 197 females with breast cancer who underwent mastectomy and IBR between 2014–2018 (110 prepectoral, 87 subpectoral). Primary endpoints were postoperative complications: unexpected return to OR for hematoma or explantation, percutaneous procedures, infections, and contracture. We also evaluated these endpoints for patients undergoing chemotherapy, RT, or history of RT.

Results: Of the 197 patients, characteristics were similar between groups including BMI, smoking status, diabetes, prior breast surgery and/or radiation, clinical stage, grade, and receptor status. Overall complication rate was similar between groups; unexpected return to OR was 14.74%. Of these, 18 had prepectoral and 15 subpectoral IBR. Between groups, a similar number required chemotherapy and/or RT. Regardless of additional therapies, outcomes were comparable (Table 1).

Conclusion: Our research supports that both types of IBR are viable options, regardless of patient history of/need for additional therapies. While continued long-term data collection is necessary, especially in patients with history of RT, undergoing chemotherapy or adjuvant RT, initial data is promising for IBR options in breast cancer patients.

abstract_title: Bills, Bills, Bills: A Characterization of Financial Burden in Breast Cancer Care
author_block: T. M. Neilson<sup>1</sup>, V. Huynh<sup>1</sup>, A. Macdonald<sup>1</sup>, K. Romandetti<sup>1</sup>, G. Ahrendt<sup>1</sup>, S. Tevis<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus,Department Of Surgical Oncology,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  While the economic burden of cancer care has been highlighted at a national level, the financial impact of breast cancer care at the patient level remains poorly understood. A recent study of breast cancer patients found that financial distress was highest during treatment and remained high after treatment. This study thus aims to characterize the financial burdens experienced by patients and the resources utilized to address them.?

Methods:  All patients diagnosed with invasive breast cancer at an academic center who were either enrolled in copay assistance or indicated financial concerns on an intake distress screen between 2014 – 2019 were included. A web-based survey assessing baseline sociodemographic details, financial effects of breast cancer care, supportive resources used, and financial engagement of the medical team was distributed to those meeting criteria. Responses were evaluated with descriptive statistics.  ?

Results: The study included 241 patients. Of the 66 patients who responded to the online survey, 77.4% of patients reported financial distress. Patients rated their distress level on a scale (0-10) and reported a median of 5 [IQR =4-8]. A majority of patients had private insurance (72.6%) and indicated having a good or excellent understanding of their insurance plan (87.9%). Nearly one-third of patients reported an average loss of $501-2000 in monthly income (range: $0- >10,000). More than half of patients reported paying $1-500 monthly (range of $1-10,000) in out-of-pocket medical expenses. Patients reported many changes in their finances: 86.0% made changes in their budget, 84.2% used savings, 70.2% cut down on certain expenses, and 3.5% lost their homes. 36.4% of patients stated they never received any financial support or resources. 64.2% of patients did not receive financial advice or resources from their medical team, and of those, 47.6% reported wanting it to be discussed. Additionally, 58.2% of patients reported discussing finances with a social worker, and of those, 68.4% stated they felt like their concerns were addressed. ?

Conclusion: Breast cancer patients encounter significant financial stressors throughout their treatment course, yet many do not receive the counseling needed to address them. In this study, patients express a need for financial guidance, highlighting the need for more supportive services around finances at the time of diagnosis.?

abstract_title: Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy for Clinically Node-Negative, Early-Stage Breast Cancer Patients
author_block: A. Patel<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Carr<sup>2</sup>, E. McClure<sup>1</sup>, W. Sun<sup>2</sup>, Y. Kim<sup>2</sup>, J. Whiting<sup>2</sup>, M. C. Lee<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine,Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute,Breast Oncology,Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) has become the standard of care for treating operable, advanced stage breast cancer, and equivalent outcomes have been demonstrated when compared to adjuvant chemotherapy. Use of NAC has also led to increased rates of breast conservation surgery. There are few studies that compare NAC and upfront surgery (SX) for clinically node-negative (cN0), early-stage breast cancer patients. We hypothesized that NAC for patients with T2 cN0 breast cancer does not affect rates of breast conserving surgery or local-regional recurrence (LRR).

Methods: A single-institution retrospective chart review was conducted for patients with cT2N0 breast cancer between January 2008 and July 2019. Patients were clinically node negative, with histologically confirmed disease. Data was analyzed with descriptive statistics for demographic and disease characteristics as well as with Kaplan-Meier method, log-ranked tests and Cox proportional-hazard tests to compare LRR between NAC and SX.

Results: Of the 269 patients, 161 (60%) were treated with NAC while 108 (40%) were treated with SX. All patients had sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB). The patients treated with NAC were younger (median 50 vs 54 years; p=0.004) and had a slightly larger clinical T size (median 32 vs 31 mm; p=0.14). NAC patients also had a smaller pathological tumor size upon resection (median 3 vs 22 mm; p<0.001). Significantly more NAC patients had hormone unresponsive (p<0.001) and Her2Neu negative tumors (p<0.001). There was a difference seen in breast conserving surgery, as patients that had a lumpectomy were more likely to be NAC patients (p<0.001). NAC patients were also more likely to undergo SLNB only compared to SLNB followed by an axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) (p<0.001). There was no significant difference between NAC and surgery for local or distant recurrence. On univariable analysis, there was no difference in LRR between NAC vs SX, node surgery, NAC response, or adjuvant chemotherapy, radiation or hormone therapy use. On multivariable analysis, there was no difference in LRR between NAC and SX (HR=0.3, p=0.08).

Conclusions: There was no difference in LRR between clinically T2, N0 breast cancer patients that had NAC or upfront surgery. NAC patients were, however, less likely to undergo ALND, and had a higher rate of breast conservation surgery than SX patients. NAC for early stage breast cancer should be used judiciously.

abstract_title: Patient Perceptions of Physician Communication Scores Before and After the Onset of COVID-19
author_block: S. Bergstresser<sup>1</sup>, M. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, L. Lawler<sup>1</sup>, T. Redford<sup>1</sup>, J. Dodd<sup>1</sup>, H. Krontiras<sup>1</sup>, R. Lancaster<sup>1</sup>, C. Parker<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Dept Of Surgery, Division Of Breast And Endocrine Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Clinician and Group Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (CG CAHPS) is a standardized metric by which patients assess their perception of physician care in the ambulatory setting.The survey asks patients to rate their providers on a scale of 0-10 in categories related to physician communication and access to care. A top box score is defined as the percentage of patients who assigned a score of 9 or 10 in each category.  The COVID-19 pandemic has caused a major upheaval in the US healthcare system and the way in which physicians provide care to patients. During the early stage of COVID-19, there was a transition to telemedicine to reduce the number of personal contacts. With this change in the way patients are treated, we set out to assess how their perception of quality of care changed with implementation of video and phone visits during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Methods: Top box data for selected surgeons were extracted by visit date from Press Ganey. Months sampled included December 2019-February 2020 (pre-COVID) and April-June 2020 (post-COVID onset). March was excluded due to transition of care related to COVID-19. Surveys were 90%-10% blend of email/ paper, respectively. The survey tool used is a modified ACO CAHPS survey. A paired t-test was conducted to evaluate the difference in arrived appointments prior to and after the onset of COVID-19. An independent samples t-test was conducted to determine if there was a significant difference between physician communication scores, overall doctor rating, and telephone answering after hours before and after the onset of COVID-19.

Results: Prior to the onset of COVID-19 there were 671 in person patient visits. After the onset of COVID-19 there were 560 patient visits. Of those visits, there were 325 in person, 190 phone, and 45 video visits. There was no significant difference in the number of arrived visits before and after the onset of COVID-19 (p = 0.74, 0.15, 0.22). The average pre-COVID physician communication score was 99.2 and the post onset score was 97.4. There was no significant difference in scores between the two groups, t=0.1, p=0.5. The average overall doctor rating (ODR) scores before and after the onset of COVID-19 were 100 and 94.8, respectively. There was no significant difference in ODR scores between the two groups, t=1.0, p= 0.5. The average pre-COVID after hours phone answering score was 100 while the average score post onset was 76.2. There was no significant difference in Answer Phone after Hours scores between the two groups, t=1.0, p=0.5.

Conclusion: The use of telemedicine to provide patient care during COVID-19 did not cause a statistically significant decline in patient’s perceptions of communication or overall satisfaction with their providers. As our health care climate continues to evolve, investigations into the effect of virtual care on patient satisfaction could help to further define the role of telemedicine in clinical practice.

abstract_title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer Location: Patterns of Metastasis and Survival
author_block: S. Leonard-Murali<sup>1</sup>, C. Burmeister<sup>2</sup>, L. Susick<sup>2</sup>, P. Baker<sup>2</sup>, S. Nathanson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Henry Ford Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Detroit, MICHIGAN, USA <sup>2</sup>Henry Ford Health System,Department Of Public Health Sciences,Detroit, MICHIGAN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Associations of primary breast cancer (BC) location with the development of regional lymph node metastases (RLNM), distant metastases (DM), and mortality are unclear, especially for triple negative BC. Previous research has cited increased risk of metastasis with more medial BC, but recent studies have argued against locational effects. None of these studies specifically analyzed triple negative BC. The impact of location for triple negative BC is of particular interest as their biology is unique from other BC. Based on previous studies of BC lymphatic spread, we hypothesized that location would not be associated with increased RLNM, DM, or increased mortality, and aimed to characterize these outcomes using a large, retrospective single-center database.  

Methods: Hormone-receptor negative, HER2-neu negative BC patients who underwent surgery (including RLN sampling) at a tertiary-care hospital system from 1995-2017 were prospectively reviewed. Data collection was performed by an experienced team, with frequent auditing of data. BC location was described as lower-inner quadrant (LIQ), lower-outer quadrant (LOQ), upper-inner quadrant (UIQ), upper-outer quadrant (UOQ), or central (C). Demographic and clinicopathologic data were compared between location groups. Kaplan-Meier curves were constructed to analyze mortality by location. Multivariable logistic regression models were constructed to identify associations with RLNM or DM. Significance was established at p<0.05.  

Results: A total of 383 patients were identified and analyzed. Patients were older (median age=59.0 years) and evenly split by race (black=44.4%, white=46.7%, other=8.9%). Location was most often UOQ, and least often C (C=7 [1.8%], LIQ=46 [12.0%], LOQ=28 [7.3%], UIQ=86 [22.5%], UOQ=216 [56.4%]). There was no difference in RLNM between groups (RLNM positive %: C=14.3%; LIQ=10.9%; LOQ=10.7%; UIQ=24.4%; UOQ=17.6%; p=0.28), and no difference in DM between groups (DM positive %: C=0.0%; LIQ=19.6%; LOQ=7.1%; UIQ=11.6%; UOQ=8.8%; p=0.27). Kaplan-Meier analysis showed no difference in survival between groups (logrank test: p=0.12; median survival not reached by any group at 15 years). By multivariable analyses, no specific BC location was associated with RLNM, while LIQ BC was associated with increased risk of DM (reference group: UOQ; odds ratio=3.23, 95% confidence interval=1.22-8.52; p=0.02); no other locations had significant associations with DM.  

Conclusion: There were no consistent differences in RLNM, DM, or survival between BC locations. Though LIQ BC was associated with increased risk of DM on multivariable analysis, the finding was not supoorted by LIQ RLNM and survival analyses. Location does not appear to be a prognostic factor in triple negative BC.

abstract_title: Upgrade to Malignancy When Radial Scar is Found on Breast Core Needle Biopsy: A 20 Year Experience
author_block: M. Kim<sup>1</sup>, J. Kraus<sup>1</sup>, C. Hsu<sup>1</sup>, E. Silberfein<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Surgical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  A pathologic diagnosis of a breast radial scar has been associated with surrounding proliferative disease and malignancy and therefore surgical excision has been routinely recommended.  The purpose of this study is to quantify the rate of upgrade to malignancy following surgical excision of a core needle biopsy proven radial scar.

Methods:   A retrospective review of a prospectively maintained breast surgical database at Ben Taub Hospital was queried for all patients referred to breast surgery clinic with a pathological diagnosis of a radial scar from 2000 to 2019. Exclusion criteria included a history of a BRCA mutation, breast cancer, and concurrent pathological diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or any invasive breast cancer.

Results: Ninety-six women met the inclusion criteria. The median age was 51.5 years, and the majority (64%) were Hispanic. Fifteen lesions were completely excised by core needle biopsy alone and 49 lesions were surgically excised.  Following surgical excision, six lesions (12.2%) were upgraded to DCIS. Upgrade to DCIS was not associated with calcifications or architectural distortion on preoperative imaging (p=0.80 and p=0.47, respectively). However, while not reaching statistical significance, the presence of mass on preoperative imaging was two times more prevalent in patients who upgraded to DCIS (83.3% vs. 44.2%; p=0.072). Similarly, the presence of radial scar associated with cellular atypia on core needle biopsy was two times more prevalent in patients who upgraded to DCIS (83.3% vs. 41.9%; p=0.057). With a mean follow-up of 30.6 months, two patients (4%) who did not undergo surgical excision of the radial scar were diagnosed with ipsilateral invasive breast cancer.

Conclusion: Radial scars found on core needle biopsy are associated with malignancy and strong consideration should be given to surgical excision.  Special attention should be taken in patients whose radial scars are associated with concurrent cellular atypia or mass on preoperative imaging as these findings might represent a higher risk group of patients. Larger studies are needed to identify imaging and clinical predictors of malignancy on final pathology.

abstract_title: Trends in Primary Axillary Surgery and Outcomes of Males with Clinical N0 Breast Cancer
author_block: M. M. Carter<sup>1</sup>, C. Reyna<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Shaughnessy<sup>1</sup>, D. Hanseman<sup>3</sup>, T. Meier<sup>2</sup>, M. Barrord<sup>2</sup>, J. D. Lewis<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Radiation Oncology,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Research/Biostatistics, Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB) is standard of care for women with clinically N0 breast cancer. However, there are no randomized controlled studies in men determining optimal surgical axillary management. There are limited case series reporting use of SLNB. We examined trends in surgical axillary management and outcomes of male breast cancer patients.

Methods: Using the National Cancer Database, men diagnosed from 2006-16 with clinical T1-4 N0 tumors treated with primary surgery were identified. Categorical variables were compared between SLNB (1-5 nodes examined) and axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) (≥ 10 nodes) using chi-square methods.  Continuous variables were compared using Wilcoxon rank-sum tests.  Kaplan-Meier analysis was used to compare survival between the ALND and SLNB groups.

Results: We identified 2646 males meeting criteria. Use of SLNB alone increased from 65.9% during 2006-11 to 72.8% during 2012-16 (p<.01) (Figure). For those who underwent ALND from 2006-11 compared with 2012-16, there were no differences in median age, race, treatment facility type, Charlson/Deyo scores, tumor grade, estrogen receptor and HER2 statuses, pathologic T and N stages, and surgical procedures (mastectomy versus partial). Administration of chemotherapy (58.6% vs 56.7%, p=0.5) was not different while administration of radiation (31.1% vs 48.8%, p<0.01) and endocrine therapy (70.2% vs 80.7%, p<0.01) increased for those diagnosed 2012-16. There was no difference in survival between the two timeframes (p=0.42). For those who underwent SLNB from 2006-11 compared with 2012-16, median age, treatment facility type, Charlson/Deyo scores, estrogen receptor and HER2 statuses, and pathologic N stages were not different. Tumor grade (81.8% grades 2-3 vs 85%, p=0.02) and pathologic T stage (55.6% T2-4 vs. 64.4%, p<0.01) were higher and more patients underwent mastectomy (74.9% vs 79.4%, p=0.02) in the group diagnosed in 2012-16. Administration of radiation (29.7% vs 29.6%, p=0.95) was not different while administration of chemotherapy (35.1% vs 27.2%, p<0.01) decreased and endocrine therapy (72.1% vs 81.3%, p<0.01) increased in the group diagnosed 2012-16. Survival of those diagnosed 2012-16 was worse than those diagnosed 2006-11 (p=0.01).

Conclusion: Use of SLNB alone has increased while ALND use has declined in clinically N0 men with breast cancer. However, patients who underwent SLNB alone in the later time period had worse clinical characteristics and experienced differences in adjuvant therapy. This suggests increased acceptance of the use of SLNB for axillary management. Further analysis is warranted to evaluate methods of axillary staging and the impact on outcomes in males with breast cancer.

abstract_title: Impact of Disparities on Delay in Breast Cancer Management in Women Undergoing Second Opinions
author_block: A. Blazek<sup>1</sup>, S. Terranella<sup>1</sup>, E. Ritz<sup>1</sup>, R. Alvarado<sup>1</sup>, C. B. Perez<sup>1</sup>, A. Madrigrano*<sup>1</sup>, C. O'Donoghue*<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Delay in breast cancer treatment is associated with poor response to treatment, lower quality of life, and decreased survival rates. There are many well-documented factors that contribute to delay in treatment. The objective of this study is to examine disparities that impact time intervals during the full sequence of care, from diagnosis through the subsequent treatment course.

Methods: A retrospective chart review was performed on patients who presented to a single academic institution from Jan 2017-July 2019 for second opinion of breast imaging, diagnosis, or treatment for a breast-related complaint. Patients (N = 584) with a breast cancer diagnosis who received treatment at this institution were identified using an electronic medical records system (EPIC EMR). Patient demographics and specific timepoints throughout treatment were collected. Student t-test and ANOVA were performed to assess the impact of age, tumor stage, race, median income by zip code, and insurance status on time to management at all stages.

Results: This study found disparities in breast cancer treatment based on race, income and insurance status. Difference based on income was statistically significant for time from diagnosis to surgery (p<0.001) and initial encounter at the academic institution to surgery (p=0.01). Difference based on race was significant for time from diagnosis to surgery (p<0.001) and initial encounter to surgery (p=0.009). Difference based on insurance status was only significant for time from initial encounter to surgery (p=0.005). Patients in the lowest income quartile (<$46,000/year), of non-white race, or with no insurance/self-pay exhibited the longest time to surgery in each category (Table 1). Time to chemotherapy was only significantly different based on income. Overall, there were no significant differences for time to surgery based on patient age or formal cancer stage.

Conclusion: Time to treatment for second opinion breast cancer patients is significantly impacted by income, race, and insurance. Disparities were more evident in time to surgery than in time to systemic treatment. Delays in management noted in this study are consistent with documented disparities in literature and demonstrate that patients with low incomes, of non-white race, and without insurance have longer times from breast cancer diagnosis and initial encounter to surgery. Interestingly, less disparity in time to treatment existed for initiating chemotherapy as compared to surgery. Based on this study, there is need for further exploration into why these factors lead to delay in treatment. This will allow for implementation of institutional changes, such as increased navigation for particular populations, to address disparities.

abstract_title: Post-Operative Complications in Coordinated Versus Staged Breast and Gynecologic Surgeries
author_block: K. C. Vossler<sup>1</sup>, V. Huynh<sup>1</sup>, G. Ahrendt<sup>1</sup>, J. Arruda<sup>1</sup>, C. Kaoutzanis<sup>1</sup>, S. Tevis<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Anschutz Medical Campus,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Many patients who have breast cancer or are at high risk for breast cancer undergo coordinated surgery with breast, plastic, and gynecologic surgeons. While there is some evidence that patients who undergo coordinated surgery are more likely to have complications than patients who undergo breast surgery alone, less is known about outcomes in patients who undergo coordinated versus staged procedures. We sought to evaluate post-operative outcomes in patients who underwent coordinated versus staged gynecologic, breast, and/or plastic surgery procedures.

Methods:  We performed a retrospective review of patients who underwent breast surgery and staged or coordinated risk-reducing gynecologic surgery between 2014 and 2020. Short term outcomes including readmission, reoperation, surgical site infection, hematoma, seroma, cardiac complication, DVT/PE, and expander/implant removal were compared between patients who had coordinated versus staged procedures. Chi square analyses were used to evaluate differences in post-operative outcomes, sociodemographic information, clinicopathologic factors, and operative characteristics. Independent t-tests were used for continuous variables. All statistics were performed in R and p values <0.05 were considered significant.

Results: Of the 140 patients included in the study, 125 patients underwent staged breast and gynecologic surgeries, and 15 patients received coordinated breast and gynecologic surgeries. 102 (87.2%) of the staged patients were diagnosed with breast cancer compared to 14 (93.3%) of the coordinated patients (p = 0.78). 70 (56.0%) of the staged patients and 10 (66.7%) of the coordinated patients had a high risk gene mutation (p = 0.61). The two groups had no significant differences in age, BMI, smoking use, family history of breast cancer, or comorbidities. Between staged and coordinated surgeries respectively, there were no significant differences in 30-day post-operative complications (41 vs. 3, p = 0.47), total operating time (395 vs. 329 minutes, p = 0.22), or length of stay (1 vs. 2 days, p = 0.52). Furthermore, patients who elected coordinated surgery had shorter time to adjuvant chemotherapy (29 vs. 39 days, p = 0.02).

Conclusion: Patients undergoing breast and gynecologic surgery for breast cancer or a high risk gene mutation may consider pursuing a coordinated surgery without compromising post-operative outcomes. The coordinated procedure is associated with quicker time to adjuvant chemotherapy, which may represent a potential improvement in patient outcomes. Further work is needed to classify which patients are the best candidates for coordinated surgery.

abstract_title: Access to Breast Health During COVID-19
author_block: M. N. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, S. Bergstresser<sup>1</sup>, L. Lawler<sup>1</sup>, T. Redford<sup>1</sup>, J. Dodd<sup>1</sup>, H. Krontiras<sup>1</sup>, R. Lancaster<sup>1</sup>, C. Parker<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 has significantly impacted access to healthcare across the U.S. as health systems have been forced to adapt to increasing numbers of infected patients. With the addition of telemedicine visit options, it is unclear how this pandemic has shaped access to breast healthcare appointments. Measures including total number of arrived appointments and new patient appointments within 10 days of scheduling can be used as quality metrics to evaluate patient access to care. The purpose of this study was to characterize patients’ access to breast health prior to and during the COVID-19 pandemic utilizing standard quality metrics.

Methods: Patient data from our insitution’s Breast Health Clinic, including arrived appointments and new appointments within 10 days, was extracted from IDX Systems from December 2019-June 2020. Data from December 2019-February 2020 was classified as pre-COVID-19, while data from April 2020-June 2020 was considered during COVID-19. Data from the month of March was excluded due to clinical transition during that period. The total number of arrived patient appointments was used to evaluate volume, and the number of new patient appointments within 10 days were used to evaluate timeliness of access. The institutional goal for new appointments within 10 days was 80% or greater. Statistical analysis was performed using QI macros.

Results: The total number of arrived appointments decreased in April and May 2020, but returned to pre-COVID-19 levels in June 2020. There was no significant difference in arrived appointments between pre-COVID-19 and during COVID-19 time periods (p=0.205). The number of telemedicine visits initially increased during the early COVID period, but began to decline in June when in-person visits returned to prior levels. The percentage of new appointments scheduled within 10 days was below 80% (range 38-65%) from November-April but increased to above the 80% goal (84-85%) from May-June 2020, though there was no significant difference between the pre-COVID-19 and COVID-19 periods (p=0.213).

Conclusion: While it is too early to assess the full impact of COVID-19 on access to breast health, initial increases in telemedicine visits and new appointments scheduled within 10 days may prove to be significant as the pandemic continues. Further evaluation is necessary over the coming months to determine how fluctuations in visit restrictions and COVID-19 cases impact access to breast health.

abstract_title: Axillary Lymph Node Dissection after Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy in Node-Positive Breast Cancer
author_block: J. L. Kraus<sup>1</sup>, M. Kim<sup>1</sup>, E. J. Silberfein<sup>1</sup>, C. Hsu<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Surgical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Approximately 25% of breast cancer patients receiving neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NCT) will have a pathologic complete response (pCR). Patients with node-positive breast cancer have traditionally undergone axillary lymph node dissection (ALND), but surgical practices are shifting with many centers offering less extensive surgery to selected patients after NCT. This study aims to quantitate residual axillary lymph node disease after NCT and identify factors predicting an axillary pathologic complete response.

Methods: A retrospective review of a prospectively maintained surgical database identified women who underwent ALND for breast cancer from 2015 to 2020 at Ben Taub Hospital. Only women who presented with clinically positive lymph nodes and received NCT were included.  

Results: A total of 150 patients met the study criteria. For the entire cohort, 44% had an axillary pCR at the time of surgery following NCT. This effect was most frequent in patients with triple-negative (60.5%) and HER2+ (68.4%) cancers compared to those with hormone receptor positive, HER2- cancers (17.9%). In a bivariate analysis, HER2+ disease (p = 0.022), triple negative disease (p = 0.01), grade 3 disease at presentation (p = 0.011), increased Ki67 (p = 0.0005), Hispanic race (p = 0.026),BMI of less than 35 (p = 0.009), and age  younger than 45 (p=0.002) were all significantly associated with an axillary complete response. Clinical T-stage 0 to 3 and clinical nodal stage were not found to be significantly associated with axillary pCR. Linear regression analysis(Table 1) identified clinical  T4 (OR = -0.22, 95%  CI: -0.42 - -0.031, p = 0.023), grade 2 disease at presentation (OR = -0.22, 95% CI: -1.11 - -0.012, p = 0.045), HR positive, HER2- disease(OR = -0.26, 95% CI: -0.47 - -0.039, p = 0.015) and age greater than 45 (OR = -0.23, 95% CI: -0.39 - -0.064, p = 0.007) to be negative predictors of an axillary complete response.

Conclusion: Breast cancer patients with axillary lymph node metastases frequently convert to node-negative after NCT, especially those with triple-negative and HER2-postive breast cancers. Clinicopathologic factors related to tumor biology as opposed to extent or volume of disease were predictive of axillary pCR. This data may help guide clinicians in selecting patients for sentinel lymph node biopsy in lieu of axillary lymph node dissection.

abstract_title: Use of HER2 FISH Testing for IHC 1+ Cases: A Facility Specific Outlook of 2018 ASCO/CAP Guidelines
author_block: E. E. McDonnell<sup>1</sup>, L. Batarseh<sup>1</sup>, J. Seibel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>St Agnes Hospital,Surgery/Pathology,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although there have been multiple studies on the yield of HER2 FISH testing on IHC 2+ equivocal cases, there have been few studies regarding the additional HER2 Testing on IHC 1+ cases since the application of the 2018 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO)/College of American Pathologists (CAP) guidelines. The purpose of the 2018 Guidelines helped guide treatment for breast cancer specimens as HER2/Neu receptor + specimens have been known to respond more effectively to Herceptin treatment. According to the updated 2018 ASCO/CAP Guidelines, HER2 Immunohistochemistry (IHC) Testing 3+ cases correlate to a positive HER2 FISH without further studies needed. If the IHC result is 2+, a recount of ISH is recommended having an additional observer, blinded to previous ISH results, count at least 20 cells that include the area of invasion with IHC 2+ staining. This IHC category is deemed equivocal and necessitates the additional FISH Testing. However, IHC 1+ and 0 are diagnosed HER2 negative with comment that the efficacy of HER2 targeted therapy is limited to those small subset of cases that HER2/CEP17 ratio >/= 2.0 and an average HER2 copy number of < 4.0 per cell.  

Methods:   At St Agnes Hospital Ascension, Baltimore, MD, HER2 FISH has continually been tested on IHC 1+ for 2018 and 2019 despite the new recommendations made in 2018 in order to better examine the specimens for the possibility of false negatives. Within SAH testing for 2019, 204 cases underwent Her2 IHC; 164 from SAH and 40 from affiliated Pathology Services.

Results: Of the 164 cases, 65% were IHC negative (Score 0/1+), 42 cases were IHC 1+, and 41 cases were IHC 2+. Along with the IHC 2+ specimens, each of the IHC 1+ were sent for HER 2 FISH Testing per SAH Tumor Board agreement, which showed only a single FISH+ case in comparison to IHC2+ cases that showed 21% (9 cases) to be FISH +. This was similar to our 2018 data collected in which of the 38 IHC 1+ cases tested, only one FISH+ case and one FISH equivocal case were detected. This is in comparison to 31 IHC 2+ cases in which 6% were FISH +, 25% equivocal. These findings support a continuation of HER2 Testing for IHC 2+ equivocal cases as yield percentage of positive FISH + 6-20% whereas the yield of HER2 FISH+ for IHC 1+ continues to be as low as 2%.

Conclusion: Based on these findings and the 2018 ASCO/CAP Guidelines, our research supports a justifiable proposition to discontinue routine FISH testing on all IHC 1+ cases as is currently recommended by 2018 ASCO/CAP guidelines. Instead, to specify FISH testing continuation for IHC 1+ Grade 3 tumors as the few FISH + IHC 1+ cases, each were Grade 3 tumors. It is also reasonably supported to continue FISH for IHC 2+ cases deemed equivocal by the guidelines .

abstract_title: Patterns of Care in Patients with Increased Breast Cancer Risk
author_block: M. Su<sup>1</sup>, V. Huynh<sup>1</sup>, E. Su<sup>2</sup>, J. Goode<sup>1</sup>, A. Lock<sup>1</sup>, S. Banden<sup>1</sup>, G. Ahrendt<sup>1</sup>, A. Afghahi<sup>1</sup>, J. Arruda<sup>1</sup>, S. Tevis<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus,Department Of Surgical Oncology,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University of California, Los Angeles,Department Of Biostatistics,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: An estimated 200,000 new cases of breast cancer are diagnosed yearly in the United States. Little is known about how patients with increased risk of breast cancer choose to partake in risk managing options, whether it be prophylactic mastectomies, risk-reducing medications, or imaging surveillance. We sought to characterize care management longitudinally and evaluate the relationship between various patient factors and the likelihood of choosing a particular risk-reducing behavior.

Methods: A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate all adult female patients who had at least one clinic visit with a surgical provider for discussion of breast cancer risk assessment between January 2017 and July 2020 at an academic center. Patients with prior history of breast cancer were excluded. Relevant sociodemographic and clinical information, level of risk from various calculators, and any imaging and biopsy findings were recorded from the electronic medical record at initial and subsequent clinic visits. The initial risk management option pursued and the amount of time between risk management changes were noted. A piecewise mixed-effects logistic regression was performed to determine associations between patient characteristics and patients pursuing risk-reducing medication or bilateral mastectomies as part of their care management.

Results: The study cohort included 349 patients, of whom 332 (95%) chose to undergo imaging surveillance screening at their initial visit. In characterizing treatment preference over time, the average time for patients to change their risk management strategy from imaging surveillance alone to taking risk-reducing medication was 2.61 years (n=22; SD=3.73). Likewise, the average time for patients to change strategies from imaging surveillance alone to pursuing bilateral mastectomies was 1.99 years (n=11; SD=2.82). We found that patients were more likely to choose risk-reducing options than surveillance imaging alone within the first 3 years of follow-up (adjusted odds ratio (aOR), 2.33 [95% Cl, 1.54-3.53], p<.001) and less likely after 3 years of follow-up (aOR, .73 [95% Cl, .17-5.80], p=.027). Compared to those choosing imaging surveillance alone, patients with known gene mutations (aOR, 24.68 [95% Cl, 3.96-153.81], p=.001) and history of high-risk proliferative changes (aOR, 23.64 [95% Cl, 4.63-120.86], p<.001) were more likely to pursue risk-reducing medication or mastectomies as part of their care management.

Conclusion: In a cohort of adult female patients at increased risk for breast cancer, gene mutations and history of high-risk proliferative changes are factors predictive of patients choosing risk-reducing medications or bilateral mastectomies as part of their risk management over imaging surveillance alone. These findings, when paired with patient reported outcome measures, may help engage and guide shared decision-making in risk management.

abstract_title: Prognostic Outcomes of Signet Ring Cell Carcinoma of the Breast
author_block: M. Mehdi<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Kong<sup>1</sup>, J. Frebault<sup>1</sup>, S. Huang<sup>1</sup>, C. Huang<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Cortina<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Surgical Oncology,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer in women in the United States. Tumors are usually of ductal or lobular origin; however, several less common variants exist. Signet ring cell carcinoma (SRCC) is classified as a mucin-producing, rare variant of invasive lobular carcinoma. Although there is growing data characterizing SRCC of the breast, there are no large series characterizing its long-term prognosis. Using the National Cancer Database (NCDB), we aimed to characterize and analyze the prognostic and survival outcomes of patients with SRCC of the breast.

Methods: The American College of Surgeons NCDB was queried from 2004-2016 to identify patients with breast cancer with SRCC histology.  Patients excluded were those diagnosed as stage 0 (DCIS), with multiple malignancies, or had incomplete treatment data. Kaplan Meier (KM) survival analysis was performed based on tumor stage.

Results: A total of 324 patients met inclusion criteria. The majority of patients were non-Hispanic, White, and ≥50 years of age. Nineteen (19) percent of patients were stage I, 26% were stage II, 20% were stage III, and 35% were stage IV. The majority (78%) of patients had estrogen-receptor (ER) positive tumors. Sixty-three (63) percent of patients underwent surgery, of which 30% underwent lumpectomy and 33% underwent mastectomy. Forty (40) percent of patients received radiation therapy, 55% received hormonal therapy, and 50% received chemotherapy. KM survival analysis revealed significant differences at 5 and 10 years based on stage (p<0.001) (Figure 1). Five- and ten-year survival analysis, respectively, based on stage was 89.7% and 72.8% for stage I, 80.1% and 59.9% for stage II, 68.2% and 48.2% for stage III, and 26.9% and 8.8% for stage IV.  Univariate analysis revealed significant differences in treatment (surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy) based upon tumor stage (p<0.001). Lower stage patients were more likely to undergo surgery and/or radiation compared to more advanced stages, who received systemic chemotherapy at higher rates compared to those with lower stage disease.

Conclusion: Significant differences in survival exist for SRCC of the breast based upon tumor stage.  The majority of tumors are ER positive and treatment differences exist based upon tumor stage with early stage patients more likely to receive surgery and/or radiation therapy, while later stage patients are more likely to receive systemic chemotherapy. This study is the largest cohort of patients with SRCC of the breast examining treatment patterns and survival outcomes.

abstract_title: Efficiency and Short-Term Outcomes for a Rapid Deployment Aortic Valve System
author_block: P. Vardas<sup>1</sup>, W. Kim<sup>1</sup>, C. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, K. Eudailey<sup>1</sup>, S. Pereira<sup>1</sup>, R. Xie<sup>1</sup>, J. Davies<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Cardiothoracic Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The purpose of this study was to assess the safety, efficiency and short-term outcomes for aortic valve replacement (AVR) with a rapid deployment aortic valve (RDAVR).

Methods: 182 patients underwent RDAVR with the Intuity Elite valve system (Edwards Lifesciences, Irvine, CA) between January 2014 and June 2019 at our institution. A retrospective analysis was performed and univariate and risk adjusted models were used. Primary outcomes were 30-day mortality and new permanent pacemaker (PPM) incidence. We also analyzed the pre- and post-operative gradients, incidence of renal failure, stroke, post-operative bleeding, and the 30-day readmission rate.

Results: The Intuity valve was used mostly for primary AVR in concomitant procedures. While 46 patients (25.3%) received primary isolated AVR and 23 patients (12.6%) underwent redo-sternotomy, 113 patients (62.1%) underwent primary AVR with concomitant procedures including coronary artery bypass grafting, mitral valve repair or replacement, ascending aortic replacement, and others (58.4% vs 18.6% vs 14.2% vs 8.8%, respectively). Overall, mean age was 68 ± 8.3 years and mean BMI was 31.1 ± 6.6 kg/m2. The mean STS Predicted Risk Score for Mortality was 3.1. All-cause mortality at 30 days for primary and concomitant RDAVR was 2.7% and post-operative pacemaker implantation was 7.8%. The mean pre-operative gradient was 39.8 ± 15.7 mmHg and the mean post-operative gradient was 10.1 ± 4.0 mmHg. The median valve size implanted was 23mm (28.6% of all RDAVR). The mean cross-clamp times for primary isolated RDAVR and overall RDAVR were 27.4 ± 11.2 minutes and 43.0 ± 16.8 minutes, respectively. With regards to secondary outcomes, the rate of renal failure was 3.8%; stroke, 1.6%; major bleeding, 1.1%; readmission within 30 days, 12.1% (Table 1). There was no incidence of more than trivial paravalvular leak post-operatively. 

Conclusion: The Intuity valve system yielded excellent short-term outcomes and is an efficacious adjunct to aortic valve surgery. The hemodynamic results were remarkable and our cohort had a short aortic cross-clamp duration for both primary and more complex concomitant procedures. Further comparison to standard surgical aortic valve replacement with longer term follow-up is needed to assess the durability of the system.

abstract_title: Short Term Outcomes for Robotic Bilateral Cardiac Sympathetic Denervation
author_block: K. Melinosky<sup>2</sup>, K. Giuliano<sup>1,3</sup>, E. W. Etchill<sup>1,3</sup>, C. R. Johnson<sup>1,3</sup>, H. Tandri<sup>4</sup>, M. V. Brock<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Ha<sup>1</sup> <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Division Of Cardiology,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Division Of Thoracic Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cardiac sympathetic denervation (CSD) is an operation performed to reduce sympathetic innervation to the heart in patients with refractory tachyarrhythmias. This operation has been performed using video-assisted thoracoscopy, and the feasibility and safety of a robot-assisted approach has not yet been established. We investigated the short-term outcomes for patients who underwent robot-assisted CSD.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed adult patients who underwent robotic CSD at a single institution over a one year period. The da Vinci Xi robot system was used to remove the sympathetic chain from the inferior portion of the stellate ganglion to the fourth intercostal space. Pre and post-operative arrhythmia management and outcomes were analyzed.

Results: 14 patients (13 men) underwent robotic CSD with a median age of 55 (IQR 51-67) years. The median follow-up was 39 (13-72) days. Indications for surgery included non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy, radiation induced, idiopathic; 64%), ischemic cardiomyopathy (21%), and postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (7%). All patients were pre-operatively managed on at least one antiarrhythmic medication, with a median of 2.0 (1.3-2.8) medications. 71% of patients were previously treated with a median of 2.5 (2.0-3.0) cardiac ablations. 79% of patients received implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) shocks in the year prior to surgery, with a median of 5.5 shocks (2.8-6.3) in the prior year. All 14 patients underwent robotic bilateral CSD without conversion to VATS or open procedure. Median operative time was 148 (138-164) minutes, with a median hospital stay of 3.0 (3.0-4.8) days. There were no intraoperative complications. One patient experienced post-operative complications, specifically ventricular tachycardia and atrial fibrillation on post-op days (POD) three and five, respectively, requiring transfer to the intensive care unit and treatment with intravenous lidocaine. Two patients were lost to follow-up. One patient was successfully weaned from all antiarrhythmic medication. The remaining patients were prescribed a median of 2.0 (1.0-2.0) antiarrhythmics. Overall, 79% of patients had a dosage reduced or medication stopped in at least one antiarrhythmic class; 36% had a dosage increased or class added. One patient experienced compensatory sweating post-operatively. Two patients experienced ICD shocks post-CSD. One patient experienced a shock on POD24. The second patient had ICD shocks on POD154 and POD268. This was the only patient treated with repeat ablation post-CSD. One patient died two months after the operation from pneumonia.

Conclusion: Robot-assisted CSD is a safe adjunctive therapy for the management of recurrent malignant arrhythmias. This technique can potentially reduce the need for ablations, ICD shocks, and reduce anti-arrhythmic medication doses in patients with refractory arrhythmias.

abstract_title: Robotic Hiatal Hernia Repair with Gastric Fundoplication without Mesh
author_block: J. K. Sadeghi<sup>1</sup>, V. A. Singh<sup>2</sup>, J. E. Jurado<sup>2</sup>, L. R. Glassman<sup>2</sup>, D. Zeltsman<sup>2</sup>, K. M. Hyman<sup>2</sup>, V. M. Patel<sup>1</sup>, F. Manetta<sup>2</sup>, P. C. Lee<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>North Shore University Hospital and Long Island Jewish Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Manhasset, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>North Shore University Hospital and Long Island Jewish Medical Center,Department Of Cardiovascular And Thoracic Surgery,Manhasset, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Newer minimally invasive techniques have supplanted laparotomy and thoracotomy for management of hiatal hernias. Limited data exists on outcomes after robotic hiatal hernia repair despite increasing popularity of this approach. We report our high-volume multicenter experience with durable robotic-assisted laparoscopic hiatal hernia repair with gastric fundoplication without mesh.

Methods: Utilizing the Society of Thoracic Surgeons General Thoracic Surgery Database (STS GTSD), a retrospective review of our cases at the two largest tertiary medical centers in our health system carrying a primary diagnosis of a type I-IV hiatal hernia with or without gastric volvulus who underwent a robotic-assisted repair from 2015 through 2019 was conducted. Cases were excluded if mesh was used or approached via thoracotomy or laparoscopy-alone. All five surgeons used a common approach: closure of the hiatus occurred with a combination of V-loc suture and nonabsorbable suture, and either partial or complete fundoplication. Main outcomes included length of stay, readmission rate, and recurrence rate.

Results: 216 cases (67% women, average age 60.47years, average BMI 29.34 kg/m2) were identified. <5% of cases were done urgently or emergently. The median operating time was 165 minutes (interquartile range 135.5 – 215 minutes). There was one open conversion due to inability to reduce a gastric volvulus associated with a chronic hiatal hernia. The average length of stay was 2.89 days. All patients were discharged home alive. The 30-day readmission rate for any reason and reason related to initial operation was 6.94% and 5.09% respectively. Reasons for readmission related to operation included dysphagia requiring EGD (4), abdominal pain and vomiting (4), hernia recurrence (2), facial swelling from subcutaneous air (1), and fever (1). The hernia recurrence rate was 1.29%; all recurrences were managed operatively. One patient required reoperation for a surgical site infection, and another patient required reoperation for a port site hernia. 6.02% of patients had a pneumothorax due to the operation and required a chest tube.  

Conclusion: Elective robotic hiatal hernia repair with fundoplication and closure of the hiatus with V-loc and nonabsorbable suture without mesh is safe and effective. The robotic approach has similar operative time, lengths of stay, and complications compared to published data on laparoscopic hiatal hernia repairs. Comparison to a national cohort using the STS GTSD, and longer-term surveillance with comparison to laparoscopic repairs is recommended to help define the ideal candidate for the robotic approach.

abstract_title: Cathepsin-Targeted Probe for Detection of Surgical Margins During Pulmonary Resection
author_block: E. Bernstein<sup>1</sup>, G. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, F. Azari<sup>1</sup>, L. Frenzel Sulyok<sup>1</sup>, M. Bryski<sup>1</sup>, S. Singhal<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Thoracic Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Over 135,000 Americans die from lung cancer each year. Complete (R0) surgical resection remains the best option for cure; however, almost half of lung cancers will recur postoperatively. Surgeons rely on imprecise tactile and visual feedback to assess margins intraoperatively, resulting in incomplete resection and recurrence. Improved detection methods are needed to increase long-term survival rates. The purpose of this study was to assess the ability of the Akrotome Probe, a cathepsin-targeted quenched fluorescent agent, to distinguish malignant tissue and assess back-table margins.

Methods: After receiving approval from the University of Pennsylvania Institutional Review Board, 6 consecutive patients suspected of having malignant lesions were enrolled. Normal lung tissue and tumor tissue were collected during wedge resection surgery. Healthy and cancerous tissue samples were incubated with saline and a 50 µM solution of Akrotome Probe in DMSO separately for 10 minutes. Fluorescence was detected using a near-infrared (NIR) imaging system. Signal-to-background ratios (SBRs) were assessed using ImageJ (National Institutes of Health) software. Final diagnosis was confirmed by the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania Pathology Department.

Results: Average patient age was 61.5 years (SD=17.48). Three patients had known smoking history. Tumor pathology included adenocarcinomas (n=2), squamous cell carcinomas (n=2), a synovial sarcoma (n=1), and a granuloma (n=1). Common locations were the right upper lobe (n=3), left upper lobe (n=2), and right hilum (n=1). Four of the nodules were PET avid and the average SUV was 12.8 (SD=7.5). The mean SBR was 4.82 (SD=8.192). Excluding the granuloma (TBR = 23.103), the mean SBR was 1.163 (SD=0.552). The average SBR detected through back-table imaging with the Akrotome fluorescent probe was well below the accepted cut-off (2.0).

Conclusion: The Akrotome Probe is not currently amenable for clinical margin detection during pulmonary resection. Further refinement of this technology in animal and clinical trials is needed, potentially targeting different proteases or other proteins more selectively expressed in non-small cell lung cancers.

abstract_title: Resource Utilization in Patients Bridged to Heart Transplant with Mechanical Circulatory Support
author_block: A. Verma<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, C. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, M. Gandjian<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: UNOS heart transplant allocation policies currently prioritize patients requiring temporary mechanical circulatory support (tMCS). While an existing body of literature has examined outcomes of such patients, large-scale studies on the financial impact of this strategy are lacking. The present study examined national trends in the utilization of tMCS as a bridge to transplantation and its associated financial and clinical outcomes over the past decade.

Methods: The 2005-2017 National Inpatient Sample (NIS) was queried to identify adults undergoing orthotopic heart transplantation. The cohort was stratified into Bridged and nBridged based on utilization of tMCS prior to transplantation. The International Classification of Diseases 9/10th Revision codes were used to tabulate relevant operative and patient characteristics. Inpatient costs were derived from NIS charges using hospital-specific cost-to-charge ratios and inflation adjusted to the 2017 Personal Health Index. Temporal trends were studied using non-parametric tests (NPtrend), while multivariable regression was used to identify independent associations of tMCS utilization with mortality, hospitalization costs, and post-transplant length of stay (PTLOS).

Results: Of an estimated 36,347 patients who met study criteria, 8.3% comprised the Bridged group. On average, nBridged patients were older (52.5 vs 51.3 years, p=0.01), but had a similar burden of chronic diseases as measured by the Elixhauser Index (4.5 vs 4.6, p=0.22) and distribution of female sex (25.7 vs 24.4%, p=0.56). Utilization of tMCS significantly increased from 5.5% in 2005 to 9.6% in 2017 (NPtrend<0.001). Over the study period, mortality decreased significantly in the Bridged (19.7 to 8.5%, NPtrend=0.044) but not the nBridged group (4.6 to 4.9%, NPtrend=0.14). While both groups experienced a steady increase in hospitalization costs, this effect was more pronounced in the Bridged compared to the nBridged group ($18,300 vs $8,300 per year). On multivariable analysis, tMCS utilization prior to transplantation did not impact odds of mortality and PTLOS but was linked to increased hospitalization costs (Table).

Conclusion: Temporary mechanical circulatory support was increasingly used as a bridge to cardiac transplantation over the study period. While tMCS status was not associated with altered in-hospital mortality, it was associated with increased resource utilization. Given the increased use of tMCS and its associated financial burden, efforts to optimize and standardize patient selection are imperative to providing value-based healthcare.

abstract_title: Efficacy of Telerehabilitation on Mobility and Frailty in Patients with Heart and Lung Disease
author_block: G. Kang<sup>1</sup>, A. Sharafkhaneh<sup>2,3</sup>, M. S. Bryant<sup>2,4</sup>, C. Nguyen<sup>2</sup>, I. Ruiz<sup>1</sup>, S. Sharafkhaneh<sup>1</sup>, B. Najafi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Michael E. DeBakey Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Michael E. DeBakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Margaret M. And Albert B. Alkek Department Of Medicine,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,H. Ben Taub Department Of Physical Medicine And Rehabilitation,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Congestive heart failure (CHF) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) affect millions of Americans, and are leading causes of death in the United States. Decreased mobility, often measured with 6-minute walk distance, is a key feature in CHF and COPD, and has been often a primary outcome in many clinical trials. Additionally, emerging evidence suggests frailty, defined as decrease in physiological reserve, is prevalent in patients with CHF and COPD. Although frailty is now considered a reversible and manageable condition, evidence on frailty from clinical trials is sparse. We aimed to investigate the efficacy of 12-week cardiopulmonary telerehabilitation on 6-minute walk distance and frailty status in patients with CHF and COPD.

Methods: We performed a single arm 12-week open-label uncontrolled prospective study for 13 patients with CHF and COPD (11 men; 65.9 ± 9.8 years; 32.5 ± 5.1 kg/m2). For baseline and at week 12, we measured 6-minute walk distance as the primary outcome. As the secondary outcome, we assessed frailty status using the five Fried criteria composed of weight loss, weakness, slowness, exhaustion and low physical activity (Non-frail = meeting no criterion; Pre-frail = meeting one or two criteria; Frail = meeting three or more criteria).

Results: We found a significant improvement in the primary outcome, 6-minute walk distance, at week 12 (308.31 ± 79.13 m) compared to baseline (263.32 ± 70.37 m) (17.1% improvement; p = 0.020; effect size = 0.61, medium effect). For frailty status, at baseline, two patients (15.4% of all patients) were Non-frail; 11 patients (84.6% of all patients) were Pre-frail or Frail. At week 12, the number of Non-frail patients increased from two to five (38.5% of all patients; 150% improvement); the number of Pre-frail or Frail patients decreased from 11 to eight (61.5% of all patients; 27.3% improvement). However, these improvements did not reach a statistically significant level (p = 0.224).

Conclusion: The 12-week cardiopulmonary telerehabilitation is effective in improving exercise capacity in patients with CHF and COPD. The cardiopulmonary telerehabilitation may also have positive effects on improving frailty status for patients with CHF and COPD.

abstract_title: Outcomes After Operative Intervention for Esophageal Perforation
author_block: W. S. Brandt<sup>1</sup>, A. S. Chiu<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Jean<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Blasberg<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Yale New Haven Hospital,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Esophageal perforations are rare events but are associated with significant morbidity and mortality. There is a paucity of data regarding operative approach and associated outcomes following esophageal perforation.

Methods: We evaluated patients in the National Surgical Quality Improvement Project [NSQIP] database with the diagnosis of esophageal perforation treated with an operative intervention by the end of hospital day one between 2005-2018. Outcomes including demographic data, type of surgery, length of stay, complications and survival were collected. We compared outcomes in patients who had an esophagectomy (partial or total) versus repair for esophageal perforation. Our primary outcome was morbidity and secondary outcome was mortality.

Results: A total of 175 patients underwent either esophagectomy (N=79, 43%) or repair (N=103, 57%) for esophageal perforation during the study period. The two groups were relatively similar in age, ASA, and pre-op functional status. The esophagectomy group had more females (N=32, 40%) compared to the repair group (N=23, 22%) (p=0.01). In total, 125 patients (68.7%) developed a complication, including bleeding, wound, and respiratory complications. There was no difference in rate of complication between the esophagectomy group (N=59, 74.7%) compared to the repair group (N=66, 64%) (p=0.12). The esophagectomy group trended towards increased risk for readmission (N=8, 10.1%) compared to the repair group (N=4 [3.9%])(p=0.08). In a multivariable model, only the presence of sepsis (2.94, 95% CI 0.147-0.763) was associated with a significant risk of developing a post-operative complication. The 30-day mortality was 7 (3.85%); 1 (1.27%) in the esophagectomy group compared to 6 (5.83) in the repair group (p=0.1).

Conclusion: Patients who undergo operative intervention for esophageal perforation have a relatively low mortality rate but high morbidity. The presence of sepsis, not type of operative intervention, is associated with the development of post-operative complications.
