abstract_title: Endovascular Intervention for Tracheo-Innominate Fistula: A Systematic Review
author_block: T. J. O'Malley<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Jordan<sup>1</sup>, K. W. Prochno<sup>1</sup>, A. Saxena<sup>1</sup>, E. J. Maynes<sup>1</sup>, B. Ferrell<sup>2</sup>, T. S. Guy<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Entwistle<sup>1</sup>, H. T. Massey<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Morris<sup>1</sup>, B. Abai<sup>3</sup>, V. Tchantchaleishvili<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Thomas Jefferson University,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine,Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Thomas Jefferson University,Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While the standard of care for suspected tracheo-innominate artery fistula (TIF) necessitates sternotomy, perioperative mortality remains high. Endovascular interventions have been attempted, but reports have been anecdotal. The aim of this systematic review was to evaluate the outcomes of endovascular management of TIF by pooling the existing evidence.

Methods: An electronic database search of Ovid MEDLINE, Scopus, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, and Cochrane Controlled Trials Register was performed to identify all studies examining endovascular treatment of TIF. Patients greater than 14 years of age who underwent endovascular intervention for TIF were included. 25 studies consisting of 27 patients met the inclusion criteria.

Results: 48.1% (13/27) of patients were male and median age was 39 [IQR 16, 48] years. Tracheostomy was present in 96.3% (26/27) of cases. Most common indications for tracheostomy were respiratory (42.3%, 11/26) and neurologic (38.4%, 10/26). Median duration from tracheostomy to TIF presentation was 2.2 months [0.5, 42.5]. 81.5% (22/27) presented with tracheal hemorrhage. On presentation, 22.8% (6/27) were hemodynamically unstable, including cardiac arrest in 14.8% (4/27). 96.3% (26/27) of cases underwent covered stent placement while one patient (3.8%) had coil embolization. The median stent diameter was 10 mm [9, 12] and the median length 50 mm [30, 58]. 18.5% (5/27) of patients required repeat endovascular procedure for recurrent bleeding, while 11.1% (3/27) required rescue open surgery via sternotomy. 33.3% (9/27) were on postoperative antibiotics and there was one case of postoperative sepsis (3.7%). In-hospital mortality was 18.5% (5/27), while median hospital length of stay was 30 days [16, 47]. Overall mortality was 29.6% (8/27) at the median follow-up time of 5 months [1.2, 11.5].  Kaplan-Meier survival analysis is shown in the figure.

Conclusion: While uncommon, endovascular treatment of TIF may be a feasible alternative to sternotomy. The approach may be useful in those who are unable to undergo surgery or are likely to have adhesions from prior chest operations.

abstract_title: Treatment and Survival Outcomes for T4a and T4b Esophageal Adenocarcinoma using the NCDB
author_block: J. Jadi<sup>1</sup>, M. Roberson<sup>2</sup>, P. D. Strassle<sup>2</sup>, J. Long<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina at Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Outcomes for patients with T4 esophageal adenocarcinoma are generally poor. For T4a adenocarcinoma, NCCN guidelines recommend chemoradiotherapy followed by surgery or definitive chemoradiotherapy therapy. For T4b adenocarcinoma, recommendations include definitive chemotherapy, chemoradiotherapy or a combination of both. The aim of this study was to characterize course of treatment in T4 esophageal adenocarcinoma and assess survival outcomes.

Methods:  The National Cancer Database was queried to identify adult patients (≥18 years old) diagnosed with AJCC clinical T4a and T4b N0-3 esophageal adenocarcinoma between 2010 and 2016 (n=1,206). Chi square tests were used to assess differences in the type of treatment received across patient demographics and facility characteristics. Cox proportional hazards regression was used to estimate the association between T-stage and 1-year and 5-year overall survival.  To ensure adequate follow-up time, patients diagnosed in 2016 were excluded from survival analyses

Results: Of 1,206 patients with cT4a or cT4b esophageal adenocarcinoma, 502 were T4a and 704 were T4b. There were minimal differences in patient characteristics (e.g. median age, gender, race) across T status; however, T4b patients were more likely to be treated at a community cancer program (12% vs. 7%, p=0.02). Overall, 321 patients received no treatment (26% T4a, 27% T4b), 437 received radiation only (40% T4a, 34% T4b), 125 received chemotherapy only (7% T4a; 13% T4b), and 314 received both radiation and chemotherapy (27% T4a, 26% T4b).  Utilization of surgery was low (<2%) in this patient population. Patients who did not undergo any treatment, compared to those who received chemotherapy and/or radiation were more likely to be older (median age: 67yr vs 62yr p<0.05).  Among those who had no comorbidities, 76% received some treatment while only 66% with one or more comorbidities received treatment (p<0.05). Overall 1-year survival was 28% (95% CI 25, 31) and 5-year survival was 2% (95% CI 1,4). While T4b patients appeared to have worse overall survival (HR 1.14, 95% CI 1.00, 1.29), there was no significant difference after patients were stratified by the type of treatment received.

Conclusion: There appears to be no consistent use of a single treatment regimen among patients with cT4a or cT4b esophageal adenocarcinoma; however, the impact of treatment on mortality appears to be minimal. Interestingly, very few patients with cT4a disease were offered surgery despite NCCN guidelines. Future studies are needed to assess whether specific patient populations may benefit from systemic therapy and/or surgery.

abstract_title: Diagnostic Algorithms for Cardiac Contusion after Sternal Fracture.
author_block: K. Yoshinaga<sup>2,3</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>2,3</sup>, R. Grady<sup>2,3</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>2,3</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>2,4</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>2,3</sup>, I. Puente<sup>2,3,4,5</sup> <sup>4</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction

Cardiac contusion (CC) is a dangerous consequence of chest trauma involving sternal fractures (SF), and while often well-tolerated can occasionally cause morbidity and mortality. Unspecific CC symptoms and inconclusive diagnostic algorithms lead to unreliable findings and misdiagnosis. Our aim was to determine a practical and comprehensive algorithm for diagnosing CC in patients with SF.

Methods

This retrospective cohort study included 268 patients with radiologically confirmed SF admitted to a level 1 trauma center from January 2015 to March 2020. All patients were assessed with various combinations of electrocardiogram (ECG), cardiac enzyme analysis, and echocardiogram (Echo). Abnormal ECG findings were defined as arrythmia, AV block, bundle branch block, or ST segment deviation. Enzymes elevation was defined as Troponin >0.04ng/mL, Creatine Kinase-MB >5.0%, or Brain Natriuretic Peptide >180 pg/mL. Abnormal Echo was defined as wall motion abnormality, intramural hematoma, or intrapericardial hemorrhage. CC was defined by abnormal findings in both ECG and enzymes, or abnormal Echo.

Results

Mean age of the study population was 70.5 y.o., 58.6% of whom were geriatric (≥65 y.o). ECG was the most often performed test (n=264 tested) and was abnormal most often (49.6%, n=131), followed by enzymes (n=150 tested) with fewer abnormal tests (34.0%, n=51), and Echo (n=120 tested) with the fewest abnormal tests (22.5%, n=27). Echo is considered the most accurate test for diagnosing CC, however the presence of anterior chest wall trauma can affect the test’s precision. Dual-testing with both ECG and enzymes was performed for 149 patients and yielded both tests abnormal in 20.8% (n=32). Combination of both ECG and Echo were performed for 146 patients, with both tests abnormal in 12.3% (n=18). Both enzymes and Echo were performed for 147 patients, with both tests abnormal in 10.2% (n=15).

Triple-testing, with full combination of ECG, enzymes, and Echo, was conducted for 90 patients, and all tests were found to be abnormal in 15.6% (n=14).

The most common diagnostic algorithm in the study included ECG test combined with enzymes analysis supplemented by Echo, and was implemented for 179 patients with SF. Out of these 179 patients, 50 patients (27.9%) were diagnosed with CC [Figure 1]. A notable presence of geriatric patients may have contributed to a greater detection of CC.

Conclusion

Rate of CC in patients with sternal fractures ranged between 10% and 28%, depending on the diagnostic algorithm. ECG or enzyme results alone are likely to overestimate the true CC incidence. Applying combined ECG and enzyme testing together with associated Echo will form the most accurate diagnostic algorithm for cardiac contusions.

abstract_title: The Use of Grape Juice in the Detection of Esophageal Leaks
author_block: M. J. Malfitano<sup>1</sup>, J. T. Bui<sup>1</sup>, R. M. Swier<sup>1</sup>, B. E. Haithcock<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,School Of Medicine,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Esophagectomies and repair of esophageal perforations are operations used for a variety of clinical indications including malignancy, traumatic ruptures, and iatrogenic injuries. Anastomotic leaks are a major post-operative complication after these procedures. Swift detection is key to initiating appropriate management to limit morbidity and mortality. At our institution, in addition to contrast-mediated barium swallow studies, computed tomography (CT) imaging, or upper endoscopy, we routinely use grape juice to detect esophageal leaks in the post-operative setting. We hypothesize that grape juice can provide similar diagnostic sensitivity and specificity to other modalities for leak detection.

Methods:  A retrospective review of all patients who underwent an esophagectomy or repair of esophageal perforations from 2013-2019 by the thoracic surgery service at our institution was performed. Data collected included demographics, treatment strategy, operative findings, imaging results, and grape juice test results. All patients underwent a barium swallow study, CT imaging or upper endoscopy, as well as ingesting purple grape juice on post-operative day 5 or greater. Purple grape juice observed in the tube thoracostomy drainage system was identified as a positive esophageal leak.

Results: Sixty-four patients were included in the study period (25% female, 88% white, median age 62). The majority of patients underwent a partial esophagectomy (69%) that mainly involved the lower esophagus (88%). Treatment of a malignant neoplasm was the primary reason for an esophageal operation (58%).  Sixty-one patients had both a barium swallow study and grape juice test, while one and two patients underwent CT imaging and upper endoscopy, respectively. Grape juice test sensitivity and specificity were found to be 80% and 98.3%, respectively. The positive predictive value was 80%, while the negative predictive value was 98.3%.

Conclusion: This pilot study demonstrates the effectiveness of using grape juice in detecting esophageal leaks after esophageal operations in patients with tube thoracostomies.  Grape juice may be cheaper and potentially less morbid than other studies performed to detect esophageal leaks.  Further research is needed to justify the increase use of grape juice in patients who undergo esophageal operations.

abstract_title: Thoracotomy for Chest Trauma-Indication, Operative finding and Outcome
author_block: K. E. Okonta<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Amadi<sup>1</sup>, P. D. Okoh<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>university of Port Harcourt,Cardiothoracic Surgery Unit/Surgery/Health Sciences,Port Harcourt, RIVERS STATE, Nigeria
abstract_body:
Introduction

To determine the rate,  indication  and case fatality of open thoracotomy in our country, we reviewed the chest trauma cases managed surgically.

Method

It was a case series of all the patients of thoracic injuries who presented in two tertiary hospitals-University of Port Harcourt and Federal Medical Centre Owerri all in Nigeria  for a 5 year period. The demographic data of the patients , the type of chest injury, the mechanism of the chest injury, the clinical diagnoses of the patients , the operative findings, the Injury Severity Score(ISS), the case fatality rate, the complications. The descriptive statistics were analysed and presented in percentage and fraction.

Results

Out of 306 patients with chest truma, 23 patients (7.5%) had thoracotomy.The mean age and standard Deviation  were 31.2(SD+ 13.10) years, the male to female ratio of 7:1.The causes of chest trauma were Gunshot injury 12(52.2%) patients, motor vehicular accident 5(21.7%) patients, stab injury 5 (21.7%) patients, fall 1(4.4%) patient. Diagnosis was made by assessing the quantity and quality of the output of  inserted  chest tube following trauma, evidence of bowel sounds, chest radiograph and chest ultrasound. The Operative findings were, diaphragmatic injury in 13 patients(56.5%), Lung laceration in 4 patients (17.3%),  negative in 2 patients(8.7%), Bullet in the pleural space in 2 patients(8.7%),trachea-bronchial injury in 1patient(4.4%)and bleeding internal mammary artery in 1 patients(4.4%).The case fatality rate was in 4(17.4%) patients.

Conclusion

Massive haemothorax still remains the commonest reason for thoracotomy following chests trauma with diaphragmatic injury the commonest intraoperative finding. There is a need to rule out diaphramatic rupture before the insertion of chest tube for traumatic haemothorax or pneumothorax.

abstract_title: Impella Use: A Single Center Five-Year Total Experience with Over 150 Patients
author_block: C. E. Hironaka<sup>1</sup>, S. Kitadai<sup>1</sup>, T. Nordan<sup>1</sup>, M. Kawabori<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tufts University Medical School,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Tufts Medical Center,Cardiothoracic Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Impella devices (Abiomed Inc., Danvers, MA) are percutaneous ventricular assist devices that provide short-term support for patients. Impella use has begun to change as centers gain experience with the device. Here, we characterize our single-center Impella use experience, strategies, and outcomes to demonstrate the evolving landscape of use.

Methods:  This was a single-center retrospective study. All adult patients implanted with Impella devices between April 2014 and August 2019 were included. Patient demographics, indications, devices used, complications, and survival were analyzed. Indications for use and survival were sub-analyzed for each year of study. Continuous data is represented as mean ± standard deviation.

Results: 154 patients (29.9% female) were supported with 10 combinations of four types of Impella device. 46.1% (n=71) of patients were supported with an Impella CP only, 2.6% (n=4) were supported with an Impella 2.5 alone, 12.3% (n=19) underwent only Impella 5.0 support, and 9.1% (n=14) were supported with an Impella RP alone. 9.7% (n=15) of patients were maintained on Bipella (CP/RP or 5.0/RP) support. 9.1% (n=14) of patients received upgraded Impella support (2.5 to 5.0, CP to 5.0, or 2.5 to CP). The remaining 11.0% (n=17) of patients were supported with both ECMO and an Impella device (ECPELLA). Patients were 62.0 ± 12.7 years old at the time of implantation, with a BMI of 28.6 ± 6. 2 kg/m2. Patients were supported for 4.7 ± 5.7 days. The most common indication for implant was cardiogenic shock (53.2%, n=82), followed by high risk percutaneous coronary intervention (34.4%, n=53), and bridge to transplant/durable device (12.3%, n=19). Hemolysis was the most commonly reported complication, and was experienced by 14.9% of patients (n=23). Other complications included: bleeding requiring transfusion (12.3%, n=19), limb ischemia (3.9%, n=6), vascular complications requiring surgical repair (3.9%, n=6), and cerebrovascular injury (3.2%, n=5). 64.9% (n=100) of patients survived one-week post-explant, and survival was similar at one month (61.7%, n=95) and six months (59.1%, n=91) post-explant.  

Conclusion: The Impella device can be used in a wide variety of support strategies based on clinician experiences. Our institution demonstrates these various strategies for Impella use and how they have changed over a five-year experience.

abstract_title: Cognitive Implications of High Teaching Burden in Academic Cardiac Surgery
author_block: L. R. Kennedy-Metz<sup>1,2</sup>, R. D. Dias<sup>3,4</sup>, S. J. Yule<sup>5,6</sup>, M. A. Zenati<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>VA Boston Healthcare System,Cardiac Surgery,West Roxbury, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard Medical School,Emergency Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Brigham & Women's Hospital,STRATUS Center For Medical Simulation,Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Edinburgh,Clinical Surgery,Edinburgh, United Kingdom <sup>6</sup>Brigham & Women's Hospital/Harvard Medical School,Center For Surgery & Public Health,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Psychophysiological monitoring of an individual’s underlying cognitive state has enabled various performance-assistive interventions in high-risk work domains. Extending this approach to monitor surgical teams offers significant opportunities for system improvement, especially at teaching hospitals. There is also a knowledge gap regarding the potential for cognitive workload to be distributed across individuals in a team that includes trainees. The goal of this preliminary study was to investigate consecutive peaks in cognitive workload across surgical team members in the academic cardiac operating room (COR) and to characterize the primary activity of team members associated with each peak.

Methods: Data collection included audio, video, and physiological data capture in the COR during one coronary artery bypass graft procedure. Heart rate variability (HRV) from the attending surgeon, attending anesthesiologist, and primary perfusionist was analyzed by calculating the low frequency-high frequency ratio (an HRV component reflecting cognitive workload states) for every 1-minute interval, and audio/video data were consulted to determine activity analysis during peaks identified in the HRV data.

Results: Trainees were present in each of the four COR teams during this case, including an anesthesiologist, surgeon, cardiac nurse, and perfusionist in-training. Based on HRV analysis, we identified three intraoperative instances of consecutive peaks in cognitive workload involving all three team members monitored, including 13 total peaks. Across the 13 individual peaks comprising these segments, the most common activities observed within the corresponding minute in the videos could be characterized by either a deviation from standard practice (4/13, 30.77%), situations involving high temporal demands (4/13, 30.77%), or a combination of these features (2/13, 15.38%). The remaining 3 peaks occurred during standard practice (3/13, 23.08%). Notably, in 62% of the cases identified, one peak due to these factors led to a cascade and subsequent peaks observed in other team members within the subsequent five minutes.

Conclusion: As a teaching hospital, intraoperative teaching activities are not considered deviations from standard practice. However, in the case we analyzed, unanticipated educational frustrations were often attributed to interactions with trainees (e.g. incorrect instrument use or instrument delivery by the cardiac nurse in-training). While these deviations did not result in medical errors in the case observed, cognitive factors are known to contribute to preventable errors, as noted in recent literature. This observation underscores the necessity to detect and mitigate elevations in cognitive workload related to teaching activities. This analysis additionally suggests the effect of distributed cognition across team members over time, supporting the potential utility in recognition and management of high workload states.

abstract_title: Comparing Altmetric Score to Traditional Bibliometrics within the Cardiothoracic Surgery Literature
author_block: W. B. Swicord<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Sisson<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Boyd<sup>2</sup>, Z. Burns<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, R. Dabal<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>New York University School Of Medicine,Hansjrg Wyss Department Of Plastic Surgery,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Citation count and impact factor have been the measures by which the quality of academic literature is evaluated. Novel bibliometrics such as Altmetric are used to quantify the digital impact of academic literature not accounted for by traditional bibliometrics. The objective of this article was to identify any correlations between Altmetric scores and traditional bibliometrics within the cardiothoracic surgery literature.

Methods: Citation count, impact factor, and Altmetric scores were collected for the 20 most-cited articles from the 10 cardiothoracic surgery journals with the highest impact factor for 2013 and 2016. The presence and creation date for Twitter accounts associated with these 10 journals were recorded. These data were analyzed using Pearson’s correlation testing.

Results: 400 articles were analyzed in total. Within the 2013 cohort, there was no significant correlation between Altmetric score and citation counts (r=0.064, p=0.365) or impact factor (r=0.122, p=0.085). Within the 2016 cohort there was a significant positive correlation between Altmetric score and both citations count (r=0.290, p<0.001) and impact factor (r=0.151, p=0.033). The 2016 cumulative Altmetric score decreased from the 2013 total. Nine of the 10 journals have Twitter accounts, none of which were founded prior to 2014.

Conclusion: The relationship between Altmetric score and traditional bibliometrics will continue to evolve in the field of cardiothoracic surgery. At this time, Altmetric score should not replace traditional bibliometrics, but rather should be an adjunct to these measures within the field. Substantial opportunity exists within cardiothoracic surgery for the utilization of social media for research promotion.

abstract_title: Sex-Based Perioperative Outcomes in Type A Aortic Dissection: A Meta-Analysis of 5936 Patients
author_block: K. W. Lawrence<sup>1</sup>, K. Yin<sup>1</sup>, H. Brydges<sup>1</sup>, R. Balasubramaniyan<sup>1</sup>, K. J. Karlson<sup>1</sup>, N. M. Edwards<sup>1</sup>, N. Dobrilovic<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston Medical Center,Division Of Cardiac Surgery, Boston University School Of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Epidemiologic variation with respect to sex has been well established in acute aortic dissection, however literature reports on sex-based outcomes in patients with aortic dissection have generated heterogeneous results. We sought to conduct a meta-analysis to compare the perioperative outcomes by sex in patients with type A aortic dissection who received surgical treatment.

Methods:  We performed a comprehensive search of PubMed and MEDLINE for studies published after 2000 reporting sex-based differences in perioperative outcomes among patients with type A aortic dissection. Studies that included type B dissection or that did not stratify preoperative characteristics and perioperative outcomes by sex were excluded. The primary outcome was 30-day mortality, and secondary outcomes included postoperative stroke, postoperative acute renal failure requiring dialysis, and reoperation for bleeding. Data were aggregated using the random-effects model as pooled risk ratio (RR). Meta-regression was applied to examine potential confounders of primary outcome, including age, DeBakey classification, medical history (e.g., hypertension and diabetes), and clinical presentation (e.g., shock and cardiac tamponade).

Results: Seven out 207 studies were included for final analysis, comprising 2210 females and 3726 males. Compared with male sex, female sex was associated with comparable 30-day mortality (RR, 1.04; 95%CI: 0.89-1.22; Figure 1), postoperative stroke risk (RR, 1.00; 95%CI: 0.81-1.24), and postoperative risk of acute renal failure (RR, 0.71; 95%CI: 0.44-1.15). However, we observed a significantly decreased risk of reoperation for bleeding (RR, 0.31, 95%CI: 0.24-0.39) in females when compared to males. No important confounders were identified in the meta-regression analysis.

Conclusion: Among patients treated surgically for acute type A aortic dissection, female sex is not associated with significantly increased risk of 30-day mortality or major postoperative complications, but is associated with a significantly decreased risk of postoperative bleeding requiring reoperation.

abstract_title: Thyroidectomy for advanced medullary thyroid cancer achieves long-term survival independent of stage
author_block: N. L. Kesby<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Aniss<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Sywak<sup>1,3</sup>, S. B. Sidhu<sup>1,3</sup>, A. R. Glover<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Royal North Shore Hospital,Endocrine Surgical Unit,St. Leonards, NSW, Australia <sup>2</sup>Garvan Institute of Medical Research,Endocrine Cancer Program, The Kinghorn Cancer Centre,Sydney, NSW, Australia <sup>3</sup>University Of Sydney,Endocrine Surgical Unit,Sydney, NSW, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a rare neuroendocrine malignancy, for which the only potentially curative treatment is surgery, however for Stage III and IV (advanced) disease it is often not possible to achieve complete resection. Recently the introduction of tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI) has shown promise in the metastatic setting. Here we sought to evaluate surgical outcomes and overall survival for Stage III/IV patients treated by surgery and the impact of TKIs for these patients.

Methods: A prospectively collected surgical database was used to select patients with a diagnosis of MTC, treated by total thyroidectomy between 1986-2020. Survival analysis was performed from the stage at surgery and TKI use using the log-rank test. The primary outcome was overall survival reported as 5- or 10-year survival with 95% confidence intervals. Patients with less than 12 months of follow up were excluded.

Results: Over a median follow up of 6 years (range 0.1-40), 197 patients had surgery for MTC, 96 of which were stage III-IV, six patients were excluded due to inadequate follow-up. The 90 patients included had a median age of 50 years (range 10-85), 60% were male and 15% had familial disease. The median primary tumour size was 24 mm with 15% of patients stage III, 68% IVa, 1% IVb and 16% stage IVc. For initial surgery, 64% underwent a therapeutic lymph node dissection at the time of surgery where 14% had invasion of their recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) requiring sacrifice, 5% sustained a temporary RLN injury and 9% had temporary hypoparathyroidism. During follow up, 30% of patients were subsequently started on a TKI, the most common agent being Selpercatinib (LOXO-292) in 11% and 43% developed recurrent disease requiring re-operation. During follow-up, 28% died, with a median survival of 19 years (range 0.1-27.4) and 10-year survival of 73.0% (60.0-82.2%). Most patients regardless of stage achieved long-term survival, and there was no significant difference in 5-year survival between stage III 91.7% (53.8-98.6%) stage IV disease 83.6% (72.1-90.5%, P=0.8), however as expected stage IVc MTC was associated with worse outcomes (P=0.01, Fig. 1a). There was no significant difference in overall survival for the use of TKIs, except for patients with stage IVc MTC (P<0.01, Fig. 1b).

Conclusion: In this large series of advanced MTC patients, patients selected for surgery can achieve long term survival regardless of stage which supports an aggressive initial surgical approach however many patients require reoperation and there is a substantial rate of operative morbidity. In this unselected series, patients presenting with stage IVc disease have been observed to have a longer survival time with the use of TKIs.

abstract_title: Telemedicine During COVID-19 Pandemic: Endocrine Surgery Clinic Perspective
author_block: M. W. Jeraq<sup>1</sup>, D. Kaplan<sup>1</sup>, M. Mulder<sup>1</sup>, J. I. Lew<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Farra<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami Leonard M. Miller School of Medicine,Division Of Endocrine Surgery; DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many medical providers have turned to telemedicine as an alternative method to provide ambulatory patient care. Proponents of telemedicine advocate the patient convenience, accessibility, reduced potential for disease transmission and reduced healthcare costs. However, perspectives of endocrine surgery patients regarding this mode of healthcare delivery remains unclear. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the opinions and perspectives of endocrine surgery patients regarding telemedicine.

Methods: The first 93 adult patients (18 years and older) who had their initial video-conference telemedicine appointment with two endocrine surgeons from May-August 2020 were contacted at the conclusion of their visit. The survey assessed satisfaction with telemedicine, satisfaction with the provider, and whether attire or video background played a role in their perception of the quality of care received using a 5-point Likert scale. Mean and standard deviation were obtained for each survey item, and differences in perspective between new and returning endocrine surgery patients were evaluated. IRB approval was obtained to conduct the study.

Results: Telemedicine endocrine surgery patients (n=93) stated excellent satisfaction with their visit (4.88 out of 5) and their provider (4.90 out of 5). While slightly fewer patients perceived that telemedicine was equivalent to in-person or face-to face clinic visits (4.13 out of 5), patients still recommended to others a telemedicine visit in the future and most agreed that this modality made it easier to obtain healthcare (4.68 out of 5). Overall, attire of the provider did not influence patient opinion in regards to the quality of care they received during the telemedicine visit. Additionally, video background during the telemedicine visit did not influence patients’ opinions of the care received. Returning patients were more likely to be satisfied with this modality (4.93 vs 4.70, p = 0.02) and perceived that their provider gave them an appropriate amount of time (4.96 vs 4.70, p =0.01) compared to new patients. The responses from both groups were overwhelmingly positive. Both groups showed no attire or background preference.

Conclusion: This study shows that telemedicine does not compromise patient satisfaction or healthcare delivery for patients and therefore is a viable clinic option for endocrine surgery practice. Most patients were satisfied with their experience and this modality. However, returning patients are more likely to be satisfied with their provider compared to new patients. In addition, surgeon attire and video background did not influence patients’ opinion regarding the care they received.

abstract_title: Comparison of Dosing Schemes for Thyroid Hormone Replacement After Thyroidectomy for Benign Disease
author_block: F. Valenzuela<sup>1</sup>, L. Berrios<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Robledo<sup>3</sup>, S. Snyder<sup>2</sup>, J. M. Barney<sup>4</sup>, H. Reinhart<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Romero Arenas<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Texas Rio Grande Valley School of Medicine,School Of Medicine,Edinburg, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Texas Rio Grande Valley School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Edinburg, TEXAS, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Texas Rio Grande Valley School of Medicine,Population Health And Biostatistics,Edinburg, TEXAS, USA <sup>4</sup>Doctors Hospital at Renaissance Health,Edinburg, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Current thyroid hormone replacement therapy (THRT) is built on weight-based standard calculation of dose. A novel Poisson regression model, which accounts for seven clinical variables, was recently proposed to improve accuracy of THRT. We aimed to compare the accuracy of estimated THRT dose to reach euthyroid and the difference in predicted dose between the Poisson (scheme A) and the weight-based standard (scheme B) in patients following total thyroidectomy for benign disease.

Methods:  We retrospectively reviewed medical record of patients who underwent total or completion thyroidectomy for benign disease at a single institution between 2011-19. The THRT dose was calculated using both schemes. We compared the difference between calculated THRT and prediction rates for optimal THRT dosing needed to achieve a euthyroid state between dosing schemes. Patients were evaluated for achieving euthyroid state, defined as TSH 0.45-4.5 mIU/L. We also compared dosing error rates (>25 mcg) between schemes. Prediction rates were compared by BMI tertiles to account for the effect of BMI extremes in achieving euthyroid state. The difference in predicted dose between schemes was calculated in both the total sample size and patients that met euthyroid. A measure of agreement, Kappa, was used to estimate agreement between dosing schemes.

Results: A total of 406 patients underwent total thyroidectomy for benign disease, with 184 having sufficient follow up data confirming euthyroid state. Of the 184 patients, 85.9% (n=158) were women, 81% (n=149) were Hispanic, and 56.5% (n=104) were obese with a median BMI of 30.8 kg/m2. Scheme A resulted in a higher, but not statistically significant, accuracy rate (A: 60.3%, n=111 vs. B: 53.8%, n=99; p=0.21). Overdosing errors were lower with Scheme A (A:17.9% vs. B: 32.1%; p=0.0025) and less extreme >25 μg (A: 17.9% vs. B: 26.1%; p=0.08). A trend in improved accuracy in patients with a BMI >35 kg/m2 was noted (A: 46.9% vs. B: 34.4%; p=0.20). The average difference in predicted dose between schemes was an entire dose difference, mean of 16.0 μg and 15.6 μg for the total and euthyroid samples respectively. Furthermore, for the majority of patients the predicted dose did not match between the two dosing schemes for total and euthyroid samples, 76% (n=311) and 76% (n=141) respectively. In patients that achieved euthyroid, agreement between dosing schemes was low to moderate (Kappa=0.360).

Conclusion: Lower rates of overdosing were found for scheme A. No statistically significant differences in predicted THRT dose was observed between schemes. The difference in predicted dose between schemes was on average 15 ug, correlating with an entire dose. The consideration of clinical variables other than weight (scheme A) when determining optimal THRT dosing may be of importance to prevent overdoses, with particular clinical relevance in patients with higher BMIs.

abstract_title: Predicting Health-Related Quality of Life from Narratives: Qualitative Codes as Computable Data
author_block: V. Hsiao<sup>1</sup>, N. P. Connor<sup>1</sup>, C. Macdonald<sup>2</sup>, S. E. Robbins<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Sippel<sup>1</sup>, D. F. Schneider<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,General Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Qualitative Health Research Consultants, LLC,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Health-related quality of life (HRQOL) is a vital outcome for thyroid cancer due to low mortality rates, as treatment complications can result in lifelong morbidity. Narrative data, readily available from patient interviews, provide a rich source of HRQOL. Qualitative coding analyzes narrative data, but predictive models cannot utilize qualitative coding in its common forms. This study aims to determine whether qualitative coding can be converted into computable data and used to identify the most important elements for predicting HRQOL in thyroid cancer patients.

Methods: We used a novel dataset from a recently completed randomized prospective trial that pairs semi-structured patient interviews with validated HRQOL surveys (EORTC QLQ-30) taken at five pre-defined time points before and after surgery for thyroid cancer. Interview transcripts were coded using thematic content analysis. Coding was represented by a logical vector for each transcript. To identify important predictors of HRQOL, Lasso regularized regression was used to identify the model with the fewest predictors (sparsest model) while still retaining strong predictive accuracy. Lasso was trained on 80% of the dataset and identified the sparsest model within 1 standard error of minimum deviance across all tested models. It then predicted whether a patient’s score fell above the 50th percentile for Global-QLQ. Accuracy was tested on the remaining held-out 20% of the data.

Results: In total, 100 patients completed 380 interviews. Of 285 possible qualitative codes, each transcript received on average 125. Mean Global-QLQ was 73.68 (SD 19.13). The sparsest model contained 26 predictors, compared to the minimum-deviance model which contained 50. The model predicted held-out data with 76.81% accuracy and identified elements complementary to, but not explicitly included in the EORTC QLQ-C30 questionnaire. Specifically, codes that positively predicted higher Global-QLQ included attribution of symptoms to life stage or universal experience, development of knowledge, clinician-initiated patient education, cancer survivorship, suggestions of measures to improve patient experience, and discussion of a return to normal. Negative predictors included discussion of previous cancer experiences, treatment interactions, comparison of reality to aspiration, monetary or non-monetary sources of support, mental symptoms including depression and anxiety, and voice-related symptoms.

Conclusion: We demonstrated a novel method for converting qualitative codes into a computable format suitable for predictive modeling. Furthermore, this approach revealed­­ important HRQOL not explicitly stated by surveys like the EORTC QLQ-30, which may inform development of new disease specific QOL instruments. Finally, the high predictive accuracy suggests that in the future, narrative data may be used to identify patients at risk for decreased HRQOL and may replace surveys as a measure of these outcomes.

abstract_title: Impact of a Prospective Quality Improvement Initiative on Primary Aldosteronism Screening
author_block: A. P. Woods<sup>1,2</sup>, T. Feeney<sup>1</sup>, M. V. Papageorge<sup>1</sup>, S. W. De Geus<sup>1</sup>, S. Ng<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Tseng<sup>1</sup>, F. T. Drake<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston University,School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Primary aldosteronism (PA) is a potentially reversible cause of hypertension. Despite clear guidelines from the Endocrine Society, prior work suggests that most patients meeting PA screening criteria do not undergo screening. We implemented an institutional adrenal incidentaloma quality improvement (QI) program and examined changes in completion of appropriate screening for PA in patients with hypertension and an adrenal incidentaloma.  

Methods: This quasi-experimental study was conducted in an academic safety-net hospital system. Our QI initiative targeted primary care providers (PCPs) after their patients were found to have an adrenal incidentaloma; the initiative incorporated (1) messages sent via electronic health record, email, and/or hard copy, with follow-up reminders if no action was taken; (2) access to an institutional adrenal incidentaloma workup algorithm; and (3) for a subset of the sample, a standardized radiology report template that specified follow-up needs. Data was collected prospectively from records of all patients found to have a new adrenal incidentaloma from January 1, 2018 to June 30, 2019, and compared to a historical cohort of adrenal incidentaloma patients diagnosed from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016, who received usual care. The primary outcome was the proportion of patients with adrenal incidentaloma and hypertension who were ordered for aldosterone and plasma renin levels to screen for PA. Outcomes were assessed using Fisher’s exact test as well as univariate and multivariate logistic regression.  

Results: A total of 349 patients with adrenal incidentalomas were identified in the QI cohort and 251 patients were identified in the historical cohort. Hypertension treated with medication was present in 60.5% (211/349) of patients in the QI group and 60.2% (151/251) of patients in the control group. Patients without a PCP within our health system and those with severe comorbid conditions (e.g., end stage cancer) were excluded from further analyses. Among patients in the QI cohort, 22.6% (25/116) were screened for PA, compared to 5.9% (8/135) in the historical cohort (p=0.0003). More patients had follow-up imaging ordered in the QI cohort (31.0% [36/116]) than the historical cohort (18.5% [25/135], p=0.027). The unadjusted odds ratio for completion of PA screening in the QI cohort was 4.18 (95% CI 1.91 – 10.05). After adjustments for patient insurance status and the setting in which the original imaging was ordered, the adjusted odds ratio for PA screening was 3.80 (95% CI 1.51 – 10.67).  

Conclusion: Patients with hypertension and an adrenal incidentaloma discovered after the implementation of a quality improvement initiative had higher odds of PCP-initiated screening for PA. Although the proportion of patients screened tripled after the QI initiative was implemented, screening for PA remains low, and additional work is needed to further improve adherence to recommended guidelines.

abstract_title: Association Between Treatment of Secondary Hyperparathyroidism and Post-Transplant Outcomes
author_block: W. Sutton<sup>1</sup>, J. Ahn<sup>2</sup>, J. D. Prescott<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Zeiger<sup>3</sup>, D. L. Segev<sup>1,2</sup>, M. McAdams-DeMarco<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Mathur<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Epidemiology,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>National Cancer Institute,Surgical Oncology Program,Bethesda, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT) affects nearly all patients with kidney failure on maintenance dialysis therapy, and severe SHPT has been independently associated with increased mortality and cardiovascular comorbidity. While medical treatment of SHPT has considerably evolved over the past two decades to include calcimimetics, parathyroidectomy is typically reserved for refractory cases. However, the association between treatment choice for SHPT and outcomes after kidney transplantation (KT) is not well understood. The primary objectives of our study were to understand the impact of treatment modality for SHPT on post-transplant outcomes and identify patient characteristics that modified these outcomes.

Methods:  Using the SRTR and Medicare claims data, we identified 5,094 adults (age≥18) who received treatment for diagnosed SHPT prior to undergoing KT between 2007-2016. We quantified the association between treatment method for SHPT and development of tertiary hyperparathyroidism, delayed graft function, graft failure, and death using adjusted Cox proportional hazards models and assessed whether these outcomes differed by patient characteristics.

Results: Of 5,094 patients with a diagnosis of SHPT, 4,866 (95.5%) received cinacalcet and 228 (4.5%) underwent parathyroidectomy. Compared to patients treated with cinacalcet, those treated with parathyroidectomy had a lower risk of developing tertiary hyperparathyroidism (aHR=0.49, 95% CI: 0.29-0.82) post-KT.  Among patients on maintenance dialysis therapy for ≥3 years prior to KT (n=3,477, 68.3%), the risk of developing tertiary hyperparathyroidism was reduced by 57% (aHR=0.43, 95% CI: 0.24-0.79, pinteraction=0.039) compared to those on maintenance dialysis for <3 years. There was no association between treatment of SHPT and post-transplant delayed graft function, graft failure, or death.

Conclusion: Compared to patients treated with cinacalcet, patients who underwent parathyroidectomy for SHPT prior to transplant had lower risk of developing tertiary hyperparathyroidism post-KT, and this risk reduction was greatest among patients who were on maintenance dialysis for ≥3 years. Therefore, parathyroidectomy should be considered for patients on maintenance dialysis for ≥3 years while awaiting transplant to reduce the risk of developing tertiary hyperparathyroidism post-KT.

abstract_title: Risk Stratifying Indeterminate Thyroid Nodules with Machine Learning Using Available EHR Data
author_block: G. Luong<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Idarraga<sup>1</sup>, V. Hsiao<sup>1</sup>, D. F. Schneider<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,School Of Medicine And Public Health, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Endocrine Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Up to 30% of thyroid nodules are classified as indeterminate after fine needle aspiration biopsy. These indeterminate thyroid nodules (ITNs) require surgical pathology for definitive diagnosis. Molecular testing provides additional cancer risk stratification but adds expense and invasive testing. The purpose of this study is to utilize a machine learning algorithm to predict malignancy of ITNs using available data from the electronic health record (EHR).

Methods: We conducted a retrospective study using records from two centers: an academic center and a community hospital. Clinical information and notes were obtained from the EHR; ICD-9 codes identified patients with thyroid nodules from 2005 to 2016. We extracted structured data (demographics, TSH values) and unstructured text reports from the EHR. Using a previously reported natural language processing system, we extracted nodule features from text cytology, ultrasound, and pathology reports. Malignancy was defined as cancer greater than one centimeter in size from pathology reports. To predict cancer on pathology, we tested tree-based, rule-based, Bayesian, and ensemble methods for accuracy using 10-fold cross validation. All models were evaluated by area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) and precision and recall scores.

Results: A total of 279 subjects had an ITN on cytology. Of these, 99 (35.5%) were ultimately diagnosed with cancer. For the entire ITN cohort, Random Tree with AdaBoostM1 performed the best, producing an AUROC of 0.985. Subgroup classification for cytological diagnoses yielded the following results (n, AUROC): suspicious for papillary carcinoma (45, 0.951), follicular neoplasm (84, 0.970), Hurthle cell carcinoma (26, 0.648), and follicular lesion of undetermined significance (FLUS) (124, 0.889). Additional model information is shown in Table 1.

Conclusion: Machine learning methods accurately risk stratify ITNs using data gathered from existing, non-invasive, and inexpensive diagnostic tests. Applying a machine learning predictive model with existing data can become a cost-effective alternative to molecular testing. Future studies will prospectively evaluate the performance of this machine learning approach when combined with expert judgement.

abstract_title: Factors Associated with Non-Operative Management of Resectable Adrenocortical Carcinoma
author_block: J. Tseng<sup>1</sup>, T. DiPeri<sup>1</sup>, Y. Chen<sup>1</sup>, D. Shouhed<sup>1</sup>, A. Ben-Shlomo<sup>1</sup>, M. Burch<sup>1</sup>, E. H. Phillips<sup>1</sup>, M. Jain<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Cedars-Sinai Medical Center,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) is a rare and aggressive endocrine malignancy. Complete surgical resection is the initial treatment of choice for patients with AJCC/ENSAT Stage I-III disease; however some surgical candidates still do not undergo an operation. We sought to determine factors associated with non-operative management of potentially resectable ACC.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was queried from 2004-2016 to identify all patients with a diagnosis of ACC. Patients with metastatic (M1) disease were excluded. Patient, disease, and treatment characteristics were compared between patients who underwent surgery (S) and who did not undergo surgery (NS). Multivariate logistic regression was used to identify factors associated with NS. Kaplan-Meier estimates were used to assess differences in survival between the S and NS cohorts. The level of statistical significance was set to p<0.05.

Results: A total of 3,163 patients with ACC were identified, from which 1,093 patients with M1 disease were excluded. Of the remaining 2,070 patients with Stage I-III ACC, 17.5% were NS patients. NS patients were older (60 vs. 54 years, p<0.01) and less likely to receive care at an academic center (63.5% vs. 69.9%, p=0.019) or a center with high surgical volume (³10 cases during the entire study period, 14.7% vs. 25.6%, p<0.01). Centers in the Southern US had a significantly greater proportion of NS patients (Northeast 18.1%, West 15.9%, Midwest 13.3%, South 24.0%, p<0.01). Clinically, NS patients were more likely to have advanced T stage (T4, 28.4% vs. 15.5%) and N1 disease (3.6% vs. 1.8%, p<0.01). On multivariate regression, factors associated with lower odds of undergoing surgery include older age (OR 1.03, 95% CI 1.02-1.05), T4 disease (OR 3.00, 95% CI 1.26-7.10), N1 disease (OR 2.48, 95% CI 1.06-5.81), and treatment at a community center (OR 2.58, 95% CI 1.51-4.40). Overall survival was significantly poorer for NS patients (50.4 vs 78.4 months, p<0.01). Of the NS patients, 85.9% were not offered surgery, 3.9% had contraindications to surgery, 2.8% declined surgery, 1.4% died prior to surgery, and 6.1% had an unknown cause for not undergoing surgery. 69.9% of NS patients also did not undergo chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy. All centers performing ≥ 10 cases (≥ 95th percentile for case volume) were academic centers, and 91.4% of community centers performed £4 ACC operations throughout the duration of the study.

Conclusion: Non-operative management of potentially resectable ACC was associated with treatment at community or low-volume medical centers. Those not undergoing surgery were often not offered any treatments, demonstrating significant deviation from the standard of care for ACC. Given the complexity of the operation for and overall management of ACC, patients with potentially resectable ACC appear to be optimally served at high-volume centers with multidisciplinary adrenal specialty teams.

abstract_title: Treatment Delays in Endocrine Surgery Patients During the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: J. P. Ermer<sup>1</sup>, B. Philipson<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Go<sup>1</sup>, P. Gabriel<sup>1,2</sup>, D. Pryma<sup>1,2</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>1,2</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1,2</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 delayed treatment for many patients. We tracked endocrine surgery patients with treatment delays due to COVID-19 to investigate the relationship between physician assigned priority scoring (PAPS), the Medically Necessary, Time Sensitive (MeNTS) scoring system and time to surgery.

Methods:  Patients scheduled for endocrine surgery or clinically evaluated during COVID-19 related elective surgery hold at our institution (2/26/20–5/1/20) were prospectively entered into a quality-assurance database which was automatically updated from the electronic medical record. Patients were classified by diagnosis category and procedure type.  PAPS was assigned based on categories of high, moderate, or low risk, consistent with the American College of Surgeons’ priority system. MeNTS scores were calculated.  The primary outcome was time to surgery. Descriptive statistics were performed, and receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curves and area under the curve (AUC) were calculated for PAPS and MeNTS.

Results: Of 149 patients included, 68% (n=101) were female with the median age being 60 yo (IQR:43-67).  Self-declared race was Caucasian in 77% (n=114), African-American in 16% (n=24), and 7% (n=11) were other or unknown. 153 procedures were planned. 54%(n=81) were thyroid surgeries, 35%(n=53) parathyroid surgeries, 5% (n=9) lymph node dissections, 4% (n=6) adrenalectomies, with 4 miscellaneous procedures. Diagnosis was thyroid disease in 90 subjects (60 subjects had thyroid malignancy or suspicion for malignancy, and 30 subjects had benign thyroid disease), parathyroid disease in 53 subjects, adrenal disease in 6 subjects, and other in 2 subjects. Time to surgery was analyzed by PAPS score.  High risk patients (n=13) had a significantly shorter time to surgery at an average of 35 days, compared with mean time to surgery of 61 days in moderate risk patients (n=34), and 79 days in low risk patients (n=59). PAPS score was significantly associated with time to surgery (p=0.01). MeNTS scores were provided for 80 patients and were analyzed by diagnosis.  Patients with benign thyroid disease (n=12) had a significantly higher MeNTS score than patients with thyroid disease which was malignant/suspicious for malignancy (n=35)(51.5 vs. 47.3, p=0.014). However, when all diagnostic groups were compared, differences in MeNTS scores were not statistically significant (p=0.09). Higher PAPS correlated well with a time to surgery of <30 days (AUC: 0.72). MeNTS score did not correlate well with time to surgery <30 days (AUC: 0.63).

Conclusion: PAPS better predicted time to surgery than MeNTS scores. This suggests that PAPS may incorporate more complex components of clinical decision-making which are not captured in the MeNTS score.

abstract_title: Trends in Thyroid Surgery and Guideline-Concordant Care in the United States, 2007-2018
author_block: A. Toumi<sup>1,2,4</sup>, C. DiGennaro<sup>1,2,4</sup>, V. Vahdat<sup>1,2,4</sup>, M. Jalali<sup>1,4</sup>, S. Gazelle<sup>1,4</sup>, J. Chhatwal<sup>1,4</sup>, R. Kelz<sup>3</sup>, C. Lubitz<sup>1,2,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>MGH Institute of Technological Assessment,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>MGH,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania,Center For Surgery And Health Economics,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Harvard Medical School,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  In an effort to minimize overtreatment of low-risk thyroid cancer, the American Thyroid Association (ATA) published the 2015 Management Guidelines for Patients with Thyroid Nodules and Differentiated Thyroid Cancer recommending a shift to less aggressive diagnostic, surgical, and post-operative treatment strategies. At the same time and perhaps related to the new guidelines, there has been a shift to outpatient thyroid surgery. The aim of the current study was to assess physician adherence to these recommendations by identifying and quantifying temporal trends in the rates and indications for thyroid procedures in the inpatient and outpatient settings.

Methods:  Using the IBM® MarketScan® Commercial database, we identified employer-insured patients in the United States who underwent outpatient and inpatient thyroid surgery from 2007 to 2018. Thyroid surgery was classified as total thyroidectomy (TT), thyroid lobectomy (TL) or a completion thyroidectomy. The surgical indication diagnosis was also determined and classified as either benign or malignant thyroid disease. We compared outpatient and inpatient trends in surgery between benign and malignant thyroid disease before and after the release of the 2015 ATA guidelines.

Results: A total of 220,088 patients who underwent thyroid surgery were included in the analysis. Approximately 80% of thyroid lobectomies (TL) were performed in the outpatient setting vs. 70% of total thyroidectomies (TT). Longitudinal analysis showed a statistically significant changepoint for TT proportion occurring in November 2015 following the release of the ATA guidelines in October 2015. The proportion of TT as compared to TL decreased from 80% in September 2015 to 39% by December 2018. For thyroid cancer, there is an increasing trend in performing TL over TT, increasing from 17% in 2015 to 28% by the end of 2018. 

Conclusion: The release of the 2015 ATA guidelines was associated with a significant changepoint in the operative and management trends for benign and malignant thyroid disease.

abstract_title: Electrothermal Vessel-Sealing Systems Alone are Safe and Effective for Ligation of the Adrenal Vein
author_block: R. K. Sharma<sup>1,2</sup>, J. H. Kuo<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Lee<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Columbia University College Of Physicians And Surgeons,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Columbia University Irving Medical Center,Section Of Endocrine Surgery,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Vessel-sealing systems have become widely used in laparoscopic procedures. However, at many institutions, surgical clips remain the preferred option to control small-caliber named vessels. We analyzed our institution’s clinical outcomes after adopting an electrothermal sealing device-only approach to laparoscopic adrenalectomy. 

Methods:  An IRB approved, retrospective single-institution analysis of all adrenalectomies (2007-2019, N=420) was conducted. 24 patients were excluded due to incomplete data. Open adrenalectomies (n=38) or laparoscopic procedures converted to open (n= 6) were excluded. No conversions were due to hemorrhage during adrenal vein ligation. Patients with ligation using both clips and electrothermal sealing or where the adrenal vein was spared were excluded (n=27). T-test and Chi-2 analysis were used to compare outcomes.

Results: A total of 329 patients were analyzed. 71.4% were performed via retroperitoneoscopic approach (N= 234) and the rest were transabdominal (N=94). The average age was 53 y/o (IQR:44-63y/o) and 58.7% were women. The most common indications for surgery were primary aldosteronism (n=107, 32.5%), pheochromocytoma (n=74, 22.5%), autonomous cortisol secretion (n=60,18.2%), and nonfunctional incidentalomas (n=46, 14.0%). The majority of operations used only the electrothermal sealing system for ligation of the adrenal vein: 92.1% overall and 98.2% of operations after 2012. Median operative time was 60 minutes (IQR:50-90 min). The complication rate was 8.2% with an average Clavien-Dindo score of 1.4, SD:0.69). No complications were hemorrhage. Post-operative complications were more frequent in operations where surgical clips were used (p=.03).

Conclusion: Electrothermal vessel-sealing systems alone are safe and effective for ligation of the adrenal vein during laparoscopic adrenalectomy.

abstract_title: Less Extensive Surgery for Low-Risk PTCs Post 2015 American Thyroid Association Guidelines
author_block: M. Adhami<sup>1</sup>, C. R. Bhatt<sup>1</sup>, S. Grodski<sup>1,2,3</sup>, J. Serpell<sup>1,2</sup>, J. C. Lee<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Alfred Hospital,Department Of General Surgery, Monash University Endocrine Surgery Unit,Melbourne, VIC, Australia <sup>2</sup>Monash University,Department Of Surgery,Melbourne, VIC, Australia <sup>3</sup>Monash Health,Department Of Surgery,Melbourne, VIC, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The 2015 American Thyroid Association guidelines (ATA15) consider hemithyroidectomy (HT) a viable treatment option for low-risk papillary thyroid cancers (PTCs) between 1 and 4cm. We aimed to examine the impact of ATA15 in a high-volume Australian endocrine surgery unit.

Methods:  A retrospective study of all patients undergoing thyroidectomy from January 2010 to December 2019. Inclusion criteria: PTC histopathology, Bethesda V-VI, size 1-4cm, and absence of clinical evidence of lymph node or distant metastases pre-operatively. Primary outcome was rate of HT before and after ATA15.

Results: Of 5,408 patients, 339 (6.3%) met the inclusion criteria – 186 (54.9%) pre-ATA15 (2010-2015) and 153 (45.1%) post-ATA15 (2016-2019). The patient groups were similar; there was no significant difference between age, sex, tumour size, and the proportion with Bethesda VI cytology, compressive symptoms, or thyrotoxicosis. Post-ATA15, there was a significant increase in HT rate from 5.4% to 19.6% (P=0.0001). However, there was no corresponding increase in completion thyroidectomy rate (50.0% versus 27.6%, P=0.2). The proportion managed with prophylactic central neck dissection (pCND) fell from 80.5% to 10.8% (P<0.0001). Pre-ATA15, the only factor significantly associated with HT was Bethesda V. In contrast, post-ATA15, HT was more likely in patients with younger age, smaller tumours, and Bethesda V.

Conclusion: After the release of 2015 ATA guidelines, we observed a significant increase in HT rate and a significant decrease in pCND rate for low-risk PTCs in our specialized thyroid cancer unit. This reflects a growing clinician uptake of a more conservative approach as recommended by ATA15.

abstract_title: The Prevalence of Standardized Reporting System Usage of Sonographically Detected Thyroid Nodules
author_block: B. Golbon<sup>1</sup>, R. Hsiao<sup>1</sup>, N. Nigil Haroon<sup>1,3</sup>, A. Eskander<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Pasternak<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Health Network,General Surgery,Toronto, ONTARIO, Canada <sup>2</sup>Sunnybrook Health Sciences Center,General Surgery,Toronto, ONTARIO, Canada <sup>3</sup>Health Sciences North,Endocrinology,Sudbury, ONTARIO, Canada
abstract_body:
Introduction: The rising incidence of identified thyroid nodules has contributed to the overdiagnosis of thyroid cancer, with many patients undergoing unnecessary surgery for investigational purposes. Ultrasounds are the most frequent imaging modality performed for these nodules. Inconsistent and subjective reporting has led to the popularization of standardized ultrasound reporting systems. The 2015 American Thyroid Association (ATA) guidelines and the 2017 American College of Radiology Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System (ACR TI-RADS), have emerged as the most commonly used frameworks to identify both suspicious and low-risk thyroid nodules in a consistent manner. Nonetheless, the utilization of these systems is variable across different healthcare systems and practitioners. This project investigates the implementation of standardized ultrasound reporting systems in a large, publicly funded, provincial healthcare system.

Methods:  A cross-sectional survey was performed targeting all provincial outpatient radiology facilities to determine the prevalence of standardized reporting for thyroid ultrasounds. The survey outlined various features of the radiology facility including the use of a standardized thyroid reporting system, the year of implementation, previous attempts to standardize, and the barriers to standardization.

Results: Of the 440 radiology facilities surveyed, 169 centers (38.4%) responded. Of these, 127 facilities used a standardized system (75.1%), which included 114 centers using ACR-TIRADS (90%) and 15 centers using ATA (10%). The majority of respondents implemented a standardized reporting system between 2017-2019 (90.6%). Of the 114 radiology facilities currently using ACR-TIRADS, 32 centers (28.1%) updated to this system from the ATA scheme.

Conclusion: Within a publicly funded healthcare system, most centers have only recently adopted a standardized reporting system for thyroid ultrasounds. We found that ACR-TIRADS was preferred both as the first adopted standard framework among radiology facilities, as well as after a period of using the ATA scheme. As clinical thyroidologists perform more thyroid ultrasounds, the implementation of an effective and practical standard tool should be considered, and ACR-TIRADS may be a suitable option.

abstract_title: Fluorescence Guided Surgery Identifies Parathyroid Glands in Anatomic and Ectopic Locations
author_block: G. T. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, F. S. Azari<sup>1</sup>, A. Newton<sup>1</sup>, L. Frenzel Sulyok<sup>1</sup>, M. Bryski<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>1</sup>, S. Singhal<sup>1</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Intraoperative identification of the parathyroid glands is of paramount importance for both avoidance of iatrogenic injury to normal glands, as well as localization of abnormal or ectopic glands during parathyroidectomy. No intraoperative adjuncts to aid parathyroid identification are in widespread use. We conducted a proof-of-principle clinical trial to assess the efficacy of near-infrared (NIR) fluorescence guided surgery (FGS) using indocyanine green (ICG) for localization of parathyroid glands in both anatomic and ectopic positions.  

Methods: After Institutional Review Board approval, five patients undergoing thyroidectomy or parathyroidectomy were enrolled. Patients were administered 5 mg ICG intravenously after exposure of the central neck. FGS was performed with a NIR imaging system to confirm presence of parathyroid glands in their normal anatomic position or to aid the search for ectopic glands. Surgical specimens were imaged ex vivo for fluorescence. To quantitate fluorescence, ImageJ software (NIH) was used to generate signal-to-background ratios (SBRs). Fluorescence was measured in arbitrary units based on the number of photons that reached the camera detector. Parathyroid fluorescence was based on the entire gland, with background readings taken from surrounding tissue. Operative success was measured by intraoperative parathyroid hormone (IOPTH) monitoring, and was defined as ≥50% decrease.

Results: Three male patients and two female patients were enrolled, with an average age of 48.8 years. Three patients underwent thyroidectomy and two patients underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism. In those undergoing thyroidectomy, FGS confirmed in vivo fluorescence in all (9/9) parathyroid glands located by conventional surgical methods (mean SBR: 2.59). In patients undergoing parathyroidectomy, ectopic parathyroid glands were unable to be located by conventional surgical methods. FGS successfully identified a fluorescent parathyroid gland in the thymus in both cases (mean in vivo SBR: 2.25, mean ex vivo SBR: 2.10). Parathyroid adenoma was confirmed by histopathology and IOPTH fell by >50% in both cases. One patient experienced mild asymptomatic hypocalcemia postoperatively but no other complications were observed. There were no adverse effects related to ICG infusion.

Conclusions: This proof-of-principle clinical trial demonstrated that FGS is an accurate and reproducible method of localizing parathyroid glands in both anatomic and ectopic locations. Parathyroids demonstrated a high fluorescence signal and FGS accurately identified ectopic glands that were missed by conventional surgical methods. This technology shows promise for further clinical use, and is the subject of ongoing trials.

abstract_title: Comparison of Laparoscopic and Robotic Adrenalectomy Using Propensity-score Matching
author_block: C. A. Ortega<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Baechle<sup>2</sup>, T. S. Wang<sup>3</sup>, M. F. Peters<sup>4</sup>, C. C. Solorzano<sup>5</sup>, C. M. Kiernan<sup>5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University School of Medicine,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Meharry Medical College,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Department Of Anesthesiology,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>5</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Division Of Surgical Oncology And Endocrine Surgery,Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Robotic adrenalectomy has been shown to be safe and feasible. However, due to concerns of access, increased operative times, and cost it has not been widely adopted. The purpose of this study is to analyze the transition from laparoscopic transabdominal (LTA) to robotic transabdominal (RTA) and posterior retroperitoneoscopic (PRA) to robotic posterior retroperitoneoscopic (RPRA) among two high-volume adrenal practices and compare operative parameters using propensity-score matching.

Methods: This is an IRB-approved, retrospective cross-sectional review of consecutive minimally invasive (MIS) unilateral adrenalectomies performed by two high-volume adrenal surgeons at teaching institutions between 2007-2020. Transitions to robotic technique were analyzed by comparing polynomial regression of operative time and estimated blood loss (EBL) consecutive unilateral MIS adrenalectomies for both surgeons by each approach. Operative times, EBL, hospital length of stay, and complications were compared by operative approach (LTA vs RTA and PRA vs RPRA) before and after propensity-score matching according to patient age, sex, BMI, tumor size, and history of prior abdominal surgery.

Results: A total of 327 patients underwent unilateral MIS adrenalectomy, of which 68% (n=223) were performed by Surgeon A and 32% (n=104) by Surgeon B. In total, 36% were LTA (n=116), 14% were PRA (n=47), 39% were RTA (n=128), and 11% were RPRA (n=36). After propensity-score matching according to patient age, sex, BMI, history of a previous abdominal operation, tumor size, and surgical indication, LTA (n=73) and RTA (n=73) were similar in median operative time (LTA: 120 vs RTA: 111 min, p=0.31), EBL (LTA: 50 vs RTA: 23 mL, p=0.10), LOS (LTA: 2.0 vs RTA: 1.0 days, p=0.23), and complication rate (LTA: 11.0% vs RTA: 9.6%, p=1.00), and PRA (n=20) and RPRA (n=20) were similar in median operative time (PRA: 94.5 vs RPRA: 100 min, p=0.86), EBL (PRA: 15 vs RPRA: 5 mL, p=0.30), LOS (PRA: 1.0 vs RPRA: 1.0 day, p=0.47), and complication rate (PRA: 5.0 vs RPRA 0.0%, p=1.00).

Conclusions: Utilization of robotic approaches for adrenalectomy did not lead to increased operative times or complication rates in two high-volume adrenal practices when compared to laparoscopic approaches. When operative time and EBL were used as a surrogate for surgeon proficiency, there was minimal disruption transitioning from laparoscopic to robotic adrenalectomy, if any at all. Concerns over increased operative times should not dissuade the high-volume adrenal surgeon from utilizing robotic adrenalectomy.

abstract_title: Higher Prevalence of Concomitant Hyperparathyroidism in African Americans Undergoing Thyroidectomy
author_block: G. C. Hernandez-Marquez<sup>1</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, R. Obiarinze<sup>1</sup>, J. Dismukes<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hyperparathyroidism occurs in about 1% of the general population. Previous studies have suggested that the incidence is higher in those patients with thyroid disease who are undergoing thyroid surgery. The study purpose was to examine the incidence of concomitant hyperparathyroidism in patients already undergoing a thyroid procedure and to identify risk factors.

Methods: A prospective database of all patients who had thyroidectomy by the endocrine surgery team was reviewed. Per institutional protocol, all patients having thyroid surgery were screened for concomitant hyperparathyroidism. ANOVA/T-Test and Chi-square were conducted to compare those with and without hyperparathyroidism.

Results: The mean age was 43±1 and 79% were female. Of the 481 patients undergoing thyroidectomy, 31 (6%) had hyperparathyroidism. The mean pre-operative calcium and parathyroid hormone levels were 9.6±0 mg/dL and 67±5.2 pg/mL, respectively.  When comparing the groups, patients with concomitant hyperparathyroidism were older (53±4 vs. 42±1 years, p=0.005). African American race was a significant risk factor for concomitant hyperparathyroidism. While African Americans were only 29% of patients having thyroid surgery, 58% of those with concomitant hyperparathyroidism were African American (p=0.007). 

Conclusion: In patients having thyroid surgery, concomitant hyperparathyroidism was present in 6% of the population, higher than the general population. While we understand that PHPT incidence increases with age, to our knowledge, this is the first study to document that African Americans are at a higher risk for concomitant hyperparathyroidism. Thus, we conclude that routine screening for hyperparathyroidism in patients undergoing thyroid surgery is especially in valuable in vulnerable populations, such as the older and African American population.

abstract_title: Referral Healthcare in Nyarugusu Refugee Camp, Western Tanzania: A Retrospective Study
author_block: S. Rapaport<sup>1</sup>, H. Ngude<sup>2</sup>, O. Abrahim<sup>1</sup>, K. Stevens<sup>1</sup>, E. Etchill<sup>1</sup>, P. Winch<sup>3</sup>, Z. O. Enumah<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Tanzania Red Cross Society,Dar es Salaam, Tanzania <sup>3</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Individuals living in refugee camps have complex health needs requiring accessible and affordable health systems and political support from the host country. Referral care is an integral component of a functioning health system, yet it is understudied in refugee camp populations. We aimed to assess the pattern of referrals from Nyarugusu Refugee Camp to Kabanga Referral Hospital in western Tanzania. 

Methods: A retrospective review of referrals from Nyarugusu camp to Kabanga Hospital was performed using a paper logbook containing entries between January 2016 to May 2017. Data included status defined as patient or caretaker, age, sex, address, diagnosis, country and reason for referral. Diagnostic data were coded by organ system (e.g. neurological, cardiovascular, infectious disease (ID), musculoskeletal (MSK), neoplastic, etc.) and reasons for referral were coded as either dental, further management, imaging, specialist, or missing. Diagnoses that involved multiple organ systems were assigned up to three codes (e.g. tuberculosis was coded as ID and pulmonary). Reasons for referral coded as specialist were further coded as either surgery, ophthalmology, gynecology, otolaryngology, or orthopedics. Entries were excluded if both the diagnosis and reason for referral fields were missing/illegible or the status indicated was caretaker (not patient).

Results: The mean age of the 427 referrals analyzed was 29.9 and 50.7% of the patients were female. MSK was the most common diagnostic code (n=118, 29.1%) followed by head and neck (n=102, 25.1%) and ID (n=73, 18.0%). Renal was the least common diagnosis code (n=3, 0.7%). Imaging was the most common referral code (n=157, 38.0%) followed by specialist (n=145, 35.1%) dental (n=57, 13.8%) and further management (n= 56, 13.6%). Out of the referrals to a specialist, ophthalmology was the most common (n=69, 47.92%) followed by surgery (n=44, 30.56%), otolaryngology (n=16, 11.11%), orthopedics (n=11, 7.64%), and gynecology (n=4, 2.78%). Exhibit 1 displays reasons for referral by diagnostic code.

Conclusion: These data represent the burden of disease beyond the treatment capacity of the primary care site, the camp hospital. Imaging and specialist care were the primary reasons for referral, and out of specialist care, ophthalmology and surgery referrals are most common. Further research is needed to investigate the epidemiology of surgical referrals in this population, and future implementation science research might focus on purchasing dental and imaging equipment for the camp, which might significantly decrease referrals to secondary care.

abstract_title: Size and Key Predictors of the Surgical Subspecialist Workforce in West Africa.
author_block: F. P. Parvin-Nejad<sup>1</sup>, E. Akbulut<sup>2</sup>, M. S. Linz<sup>3</sup>, D. M. Nogoy<sup>3</sup>, L. A. Hutnik<sup>3</sup>, G. S. Hoffman<sup>3</sup>, V. Padmanaban<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Nwomeh<sup>4</sup>, P. M. Mshelbwala<sup>5</sup>, Z. C. Sifri<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School,Department Of Surgery,Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Rutgers University-Newark,Newark, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School,Newark, NJ, USA <sup>4</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Abuja Teaching Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Abuja, Nigeria
abstract_body:
Introduction: In many low and middle-income countries, the relative shortage of surgical subspecialists, defined as non-general surgeons, represents one dimension of low surgical capacity that is poorly understood. The West African College of Surgeons (WACS) accredits training programs in multiple surgical specialties across West Africa, yet little is known about the subspecialist surgical workforce produced in the region. This study aims to quantify the number of WACS subspecialist fellows and to identify underlying factors predicting the number of surgical subspecialists in member countries.

Methods: The roster of fellows and list of WACS-accredited training programs was obtained from the WACS organizational website with WACS approval. Countrywide socioeconomic data (GDP, gross population, percent GDP expenditure on healthcare and education) and number of medical schools were obtained from World Bank and World Health Organization data. Statistical analysis was completed in Microsoft Excel using linear regression models to identify predictors of subspecialist surgical workforce.

Results: Of 4911 total WACS fellows, 477 (10%) were subspecialist surgeons: 225 otolaryngology (4.6% of WACS fellows), 84 orthopedic surgery (1.7%), 64 urology (1.3%), 42 plastic and burn surgery (0.9%), 35 pediatric surgery (0.7%), 17 neurosurgery (0.4%), and 10 cardiac surgery (0.2%). The mean number of subspecialists per country was 28 (± 88), with fewer than 10 fellows in 14 (82%) of the 17 WACS member countries. The mean number of WACS-accredited subspecialty surgery training programs per country was 9 (± 31), with 13 countries (76%) containing no programs. On univariate analysis, the total number of subspecialists was significantly correlated with countrywide GDP, population, number of medical schools, and number of WACS-accredited subspecialty training programs (Pearson’s R coefficients ≥0.98, p<0.0001), but not with percent GDP spent on healthcare or education (p=0.6).
