However, on multivariate analysis, only the correlation with the number of training programs remained significant (adjusted R-square 0.997, p<0.005).

Conclusion: The 477 subspecialist surgeons in WACS represent 10% of all fellows, with an average of 28 subspecialists per country. Although WACS member nations have on average 9 subspecialty training programs, many currently lack accredited programs. The number of subspecialty surgical providers in West African countries is significantly correlated with the number of WACS subspecialty training programs. These results suggest that investing in training programs is the most valuable potential strategy to address the shortage of surgical subspecialists in West Africa.

abstract_title: Understanding Referrals for Surgical Evaluation in Chiapas, Mexico
author_block: M. Stankey<sup>1</sup>, Z. Fowler<sup>1</sup>, F. Carrillo<sup>2</sup>, R. Jhunjhunwala<sup>1</sup>, E. Moeller<sup>3</sup>, L. Roa<sup>4</sup>, S. Cervantes<sup>5</sup>, S. Mohar<sup>6</sup>, J. G. Meara<sup>1,7</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>1,8</sup>, T. Uribe-Leitz<sup>1,8,9</sup>, V. Macias<sup>5</sup>, C. McClain<sup>1,10</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Tecnolgico de Monterrey,Guadalajara, JALISCO, Mexico <sup>3</sup>University of Miami School of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Alberta,Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology,Edmonton, ALBERTA, Canada <sup>5</sup>Compaeros en Salud,Jaltenango, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>6</sup>Hospital Bsico Comunitario ngel Albino Corzo,Jaltenango, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>7</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Department Of Plastic And Oral Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>8</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>9</sup>Technical University Munich,Epidemiology, Department Of Sport And Health Sciences,Munich, BAVARIA, Germany <sup>10</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Department Of Anesthesiology, Critical Care And Pain Medicine,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Timely access to surgery is needed to prevent morbidity and mortality in surgical disease, and a lack of surgical capacity limits the ability of hospitals to provide surgery. Patients are referred to other public centers or instead utilize private hospitals, which can delay care and increase hospital burden. This study aims to assess workforce, infrastructure, and consumables as they relate to surgical referrals in Chiapas, Mexico.

Methods:  Surgical capacity data were obtained with an adapted, validated Surgical Assessment Tool in Chiapas. Consistent availability of predictors were defined by hospitals reporting 100% availability at all times. Hospital infrastructure included electricity, running water, autoclave, and oxygen. Surgical workforce included 24-hour availability of a general surgeon, OBGYN, and anesthesiologist. Blood transfusion availability was the ability to provide a transfusion within 2 hours. Surgical volume and number of referrals were acquired from hospital records and clinicians. A referral ratio (RR) was calculated for level 1 and 2 public hospitals and private hospitals. RR was calculated as the number of referrals per 100 procedures. Wilcoxon rank sum was used to compare the median RR between public and private hospitals. Public and private subgroup analyses were performed to further compare RR based on availability of infrastructure, workforce, and transfusion capabilities.

Results: 18 private hospitals and 13 public hospitals were analyzed. Median RR was higher in public hospitals compared to private hospitals (25 vs 2, IQR 5-33 vs 0-12, p=0.048). For all hospitals, median RR was lower in those with consistent infrastructure availability (1.3 vs 25.7, IQR 0-11 vs 5-53, p=0.029) or with a 24-hour workforce (0.28 vs 26.3, IQR 0-10 vs 7-55, p<0.001). Within private hospitals, median RR in those with infrastructure was 1.3 versus 31.3 (IQR 0-9 vs 16-45, p=0.31). Median RR was lower in those with 24-hour workforce (0 vs 21.9, IQR 0-2 vs 8-69, p=0.016). Within public hospitals, median RR in those with infrastructure availability was 15.5 versus 25 (IQR 1-31 vs 5-52, p=0.35). Median RR was lower in those with 24-hour workforce (1.3 vs 26.3, IQR 1-2 vs 15-43, p=0.048)(Figure). There was a non-statistical association between transfusion availability and decrease in referrals.

Conclusion: These results suggest that limited 24-hour access to surgical workforce or infrastructure is associated with increased surgical referrals in Chiapas. Targeted interventions to increase surgical workforce density and key infrastructure may reduce referral rates and prevent care delays. Fewer referrals can help reduce the burden on higher level hospitals and strengthen Chiapas’ surgical systems.

abstract_title: Gender Disparities in Surgical, Anesthesia, and Obstetric Providers in Chiapas, Mexico
author_block: R. Jhunjhunwala<sup>1</sup>, Z. Fowler<sup>1</sup>, F. Carillo<sup>2</sup>, M. Stankey<sup>1</sup>, E. Moeller<sup>3</sup>, L. Roa<sup>5</sup>, S. Cervantes<sup>4</sup>, S. Mohar<sup>6</sup>, J. G. Meara<sup>1,8</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>1,7,10</sup>, T. Uribe-Leitz<sup>1,7,9</sup>, V. Macias<sup>4</sup>, S. Juran<sup>1,9</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Tecnologico de Monterrey,Guadalajara, JALISCO, Mexico <sup>3</sup>University Of Miami,School Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Companeros en Salud,Jaltenango, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>5</sup>University of Alberta,Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology,Edmonton, ALBERTA, Canada <sup>6</sup>Hospital Basico Comunitario Angel Albino Corzo,Jaltenango, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>7</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>8</sup>Children's Hospital Boston,Department Of Plastic And Oral Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>9</sup>Technical University Munich,Department Of Sport And Health Sciences,Munich, Germany, Germany <sup>10</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Women's participation in surgery advances gender equity, empowers women, and affects both the range of surgical issues considered and the types of solutions that are proposed. The study of gender balance of Surgical, Anesthesia, and Obstetric (SAO) providers is a growing field. Chiapas, Mexico has an SAO density below 20 per 100,000 population, the threshold defined by the Lancet Commission on Global Surgery to manage the volume of surgical need. The gender disparity across specialties further compounds the dearth of providers. We characterize the gender makeup of surgical subspecialties in Chiapas across the private and public sectors of healthcare.

Methods:  A validated surgical assessment tool (SAT) was developed through collaboration with the World Health Organization and the Harvard Program in Global Surgery and Social Change.  It was translated into Spanish and used to evaluate surgical capacity in a sample of public hospitals stratified by level and all consenting private hospitals providing cesarean delivery, laparotomy, and/or open fracture repair. Questions exploring surgical workforce and gender were added. Fisher’s exact test was used to compare the share of female SAO providers in 19 private and 17 public hospitals and further disaggregated by specialty.

Results: 706 SAO providers were identified via the SAT. Of these,168 (23.8%) were female (Figure). There was a significant difference in the overall percentage of female providers in public and private sector subgroups (20.7% vs 27.4%, p=0.042), however there was no statistical significance between sectors within specialties. There were no specialty groups in which female providers constituted the majority, but of all specialties there were the most women in OB/GYN at 38.6% (73 women of 189 total providers), 39.8% in the public sector and 37.5% in private. The next highest group of female providers was in anesthesia, with 30.6% (75/245) women total. The percentage of female providers in pediatric, general, and orthopedic surgery dropped precipitously, with 12.9% (4/31) female pediatric surgeons, followed by 8.4% (15/179) general surgeons, and 1.6% (1/62) female orthopedic surgeons.

Conclusion: There are notable disparities in gender across surgery and anesthesia providers in Chiapas, indicative of a need to actively recruit more females to SAO fields. It is imperative to invest in gender equity at the local level, particularly in resource limited settings, in order to meet sustainable development goals, notably SDG 3 and SDG 5. Finally, a gender variable should be included in further SAT assessments to better characterize SAO workforce in areas with low provider density.

abstract_title: Anal Cancer Screening for MSM with HIV in Colombia Limited by Lack of High-Resolution Anoscopy
author_block: K. J. Blair<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Martnez-Vernaza<sup>3</sup>, I. T. Ordez-Blanco<sup>3,4</sup>, W. Hernandez<sup>5</sup>, C. Quiroga<sup>3,4</sup>, E. Lowenstein<sup>3</sup>, S. L. Valderrama-Beltrn<sup>3,4</sup>, J. L. Clark<sup>2,5</sup>, J. E. Lake<sup>2,7</sup>, C. Juillard<sup>1</sup>, L. J. Lombana Amaya<sup>6</sup> <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,South American Program In HIV Prevention Research (SAPHIR),Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Pontificia Universidad Javeriana - Hospital Universitario San Ignacio,Unidad De Infectologa,Bogota, Colombia <sup>4</sup>Pontificia Universidad Javeriana - Hospital Universitario San Ignacio,Facultad De Medicina,Bogota, Colombia <sup>5</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Division Of Infectious Diseases, Department Of Medicine,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>6</sup>Pontificia Universidad Javeriana - Hospital Universitario San Ignacio,Departamento De Ciruga,Bogota, Colombia <sup>7</sup>McGovern Medical School, The University of Texas Health Sciences Center at Houston,Department Of Internal Medicine,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Men who have sex with men (MSM) and have HIV are at significantly increased risk of anal cancer. Anal Papanicolau (Pap) cytological testing can be used to screen for anal dysplastic changes. Due to low anal Pap sensitivity, abnormal results should undergo diagnostic workup via high-resolution anoscopy (HRA), with identified dysplasia treated to limit progression to cancer. However, HRA is not available in Colombia. This study describes the limitations of screening for anal cancer in a setting without HRA in order to determine need for a pilot HRA program.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective cohort study of MSM with HIV who were ≥18 years of age and received anal cancer screening via anal Pap at a single institution in Bogotá, Colombia between January 2019 and February 2020. Data from coloproctology follow-up were collected through July 2020. Cytologic results follow the Bethesda System: atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US), low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL), and high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). Categorical and continuous variables were compared via Pearson’s χ2 statistic and t-test, respectively.

Results: A total of 212 MSM were screened (Figure), and 63 (29.7%) had abnormal cytology results - ASC-US (n=21), LSIL (n=38), and HSIL (n=4). Of the men with abnormal results, 56 (88.9%) were referred to coloproctology, and 49 (77.8%) attended ≥1 appointments. At initial coloproctology assessment, 17 were referred for anorectal exam under anesthesia (EUA), and 20 for rectosigmoidoscopy by gastroenterology (GI). Those recommended to undergo EUA were more likely to have a visible abnormality on anal exam (p<0.001), had a lower mean CD4+ T lymphocyte (CD4) count (272.8 v. 408.1 cells/ml, p=0.012), and lower nadir CD4 count (186.6 v. 280.1 cells/ml, p=0.040). Specific anal Pap result was not significantly associated with EUA referral. Only 12 (19.0%) of those with abnormal cytology underwent EUA, all of which had resection of visibly abnormal tissue. Mean time from cytology to EUA was 3.9 months.

Conclusion: Lack of HRA in Colombia limits management of abnormal anal cytology results. Those with visible abnormalities, such as condyloma, may undergo EUA with resection, but diagnostic exam with HRA is necessary to localize and treat less obvious dysplastic tissue, even in those with condyloma. Referral to GI for rectosigmoidoscopy, which adds an additional invasive procedure and referral step, and increases loss to follow-up, was done given lack of management options, and could be avoided with access to HRA. Implementation of HRA in Colombia may decrease unnecessary referrals and increase detection of dysplasia for treatment in MSM with HIV.

abstract_title: Indigenous patients and non-medical out of pocket expenditure for surgery in Chiapas, Mexico
author_block: Z. Fowler<sup>1</sup>, F. Carrillo<sup>2</sup>, E. Moeller<sup>3</sup>, L. Roa<sup>4</sup>, S. Mohar<sup>5</sup>, R. Jhunjhunwala<sup>1</sup>, M. Stankey<sup>1</sup>, S. Cervantes<sup>6</sup>, T. Uribe-Leitz<sup>1,7</sup>, J. G. Meara<sup>1,8</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>1,7</sup>, V. Macias<sup>6</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Tecnologico de Monterrey,Guadalajara, JALISCO, Mexico <sup>3</sup>University Of Miami,Leonard M. Miller School Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Alberta,Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology,Edmonton, AB, Canada <sup>5</sup>Hospital Basico Comunitario Angel Albino Corzo,Jaltenango, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>6</sup>Companeros en Salud,Jaltenango, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>7</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>8</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chiapas is the poorest state in Mexico and has one of the largest indigenous populations in the country. Greater than 90% of this subset live below the national poverty line, and indigenous communities are largely located in rural areas. The Lancet Commission on Global Surgery defines timely access to essential surgery as 2-hour access to a facility providing the Bellwether procedures (cesarean delivery, laparotomy, and open fracture repair). Patients from these communities may have long travel times to reach hospitals, resulting in high non-medical costs. The objective of this study was to compare non-medical out-of-pocket expenditure for surgery at hospitals with either a majority or minority of patients identifying as indigenous.

Methods: A cross-sectional study in Chiapas was done in 2019. Data on patient demographics, travel time, and non-medical costs were collected with a validated Surgical Assessment Tool developed jointly by the World Health Organization and the Harvard Program in Global Surgery and Social Change from a stratified sample of public hospitals and all consenting private hospitals. Estimates of patient population and expenditure were obtained from social workers, accountants, and healthcare providers. Costs were compared using Wilcoxon rank-sum test and converted to United States dollars (USD) adjusted by purchasing power parity (PPP).

Results: Of 37 hospitals, 34 reported sufficient data for inclusion. 17 had patient populations that were at least 50% indigenous, and 17 had patient populations that were less than 50% indigenous. Median expenditure on transportation was $51.20 (IQR 64.45) in hospitals with high indigenous population and $22.10 (IQR 16.17) in hospitals with low indigenous population (p=.03). Median expenditure on other non-medical needs was $32.33 (IQR 32.33) in high indigenous population hospitals and $21.56 (IQR 52.00) in low indigenous population hospitals (p=.96). 25.6% of hospitals with high indigenous populations and 40% of hospitals with low indigenous populations reported that at least 75% of patients in the catchment population could reach the hospital within 2 hours.

Conclusion: While all Mexicans are entitled to free or low-cost healthcare through the government social insurance program, non-medical expenses are higher in hospitals with high indigenous patient volume compared to those with low indigenous patient volume. These patients often travel more than 2 hours to reach a facility with surgical capabilities, and transportation represents a large out of pocket expense. Indigenous patients need better access to surgical care, and financial risk protection should be considered to provide equitable access to surgical care in the state of Chiapas.

abstract_title: Impact of national health insurance scheme on devastating surgical costs at Kenyan referral hospital
author_block: H. W. Li<sup>1</sup>, K. Carpenter<sup>1</sup>, E. Rutto<sup>2</sup>, E. Chepkemoi<sup>2</sup>, S. I. Saruni<sup>2</sup>, C. Keung<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital,Surgery,Eldoret, UASIN GISHU, Kenya
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical care costs in low and middle-income countries can cause financial devastation for patients. The National Health Insurance Fund (NHIF) in Kenya is a national health insurance scheme that aims to protect beneficiaries from catastrophic health expenditures. There exists few data on the actual cost burdens on patients and local hospitals, particularly within surgical care. We investigated the impact of NHIF on the surgery service at a tertiary hospital in Eldoret, Kenya.

Methods: All surgical patients ≥13 years of age admitted to Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital (MTRH) from January 2018 to July 2018 were enrolled in the study. We reviewed medical records and collected information on NHIF enrollment, cost of surgical procedures and total hospital bill, amount covered by NHIF, amount waived by hospital for uninsured patients, and overall net cost to patients. We also collected demographic information regarding patient sex, marital status and category of diagnosis (cancer or trauma). Descriptive analyses were completed with Pearson’s Chi-square and two-sample T-test. Costs were converted from Kenya Shillings (KES) to US Dollars (USD) at a rate of 100 KES to 1 USD.

Results: 300 patients were included for analysis. 51% (n=151) were enrolled in NHIF. Being male and married was significantly associated with having NHIF. Trauma or cancer diagnoses did not have significant difference in enrollment rates compared to control. The average total cost for care was significantly higher among those who had NHIF (mean USD 1,496) compared to those who were not insured (mean USD 950) (Table 1). On average, NHIF covered 88% of the total costs of care, and patients with NHIF on average paid only USD 7.5. Among those without NHIF, on average the hospital paid 30% of the cost (mean USD 2,893) while patients were responsible for the remaining (mean USD 3,790).   

Conclusion: Among surgical patients, NHIF was highly effective in protecting patients from catastrophic health expenditures and paid for the majority of care costs. Those without NHIF, which was almost half of our sample, were at high risk for devastating financial cost following receipt of surgical care. Additionally, a high cost burden existed for the hospital, who must often waive a significant proportion of care cost for patients who do not have NHIF and are unable to pay their hospital bills. Significant enrollment differences within gender and marital status amongst surgical patients can help to target future efforts in the expansion of NHIF.

abstract_title: Alleviating The Economic Burden Associated With Obstetric And Gynecological Surgery In Rural Mexico
author_block: S. Cervantes<sup>1</sup>, Z. Aranda<sup>1</sup>, P. Refugio<sup>1</sup>, S. Samaniego<sup>1</sup>, T. Snchez<sup>1</sup>, S. Mohar<sup>1</sup>, V. Macas<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Partners In Health Mexico,ngel Albino Corzo, CHIAPAS, Mexico
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Lancet Commission of Global Surgery proposed in 2015 that to prevent morbi-mortality and catastrophic expenditures in low- and middle-income countries, basic surgeries to be performed should include: laparotomy, cesarean delivery, and open fracture. In early March 2019, we reopened an operating room that had not been used for more than 4 years at the “Ángel Albino Corzo” Basic Community Hospital (HBCAAC) in the state of Chiapas in Mexico. The procedures performed from March to November 2019 included: cesarean delivery, laparotomy, and hysterectomy, with a total of 110 procedures performed. Before the operating room reopened in March 2018, patients requiring emergency or elective obstetric-gynecological surgery had to be referred to the nearest facility, the Villaflores Hospital, which is a 90-minute drive away.

Methods: The objective of our study was to assess the cost for patients and their families when women need to be referred to Villaflores Hospital and to assess the reduction of referrals after the reopening of the HBCAAC operating room in March 2019 and the corresponding economic savings. The HBCAAC databases were searched for referrals made between October 2018 and January 2020, procedures performed from March to November 2019, and the socio-economic assessment of the women undergoing surgery and their families.

Results: A total of 110 procedures were performed: 39 cesarean sections, 66 tubal ligations, 1 cerclage, and 3 hysterectomies in a total of 100 women. The operating room reopened in March 2019 and ceased to function due to the remodeling by the Ministry of Health in November 2019. Between October 2018 and January 2020, the 8 months with the operating room in operation (M=21.4, SD=4.1) compared to the previous 8 months with the operating room closed (M=27.5, SD=5.1) showed significantly fewer obstetric and gynecological referrals, t(14)=2.7, p=.01. The cost of referral to Villaflores Hospital by ambulance was $51.6 and the cost of surgical supplies requested was $75, with a total cost of each referral of $126, while the average income per family was $121. Taking into account the estimated number of referrals that were not made due to the reopening of the operating room (n=49), the women who underwent surgery and their families saved a total of $6,174.

Conclusion: We can conclude that the reopening of the operating room has allowed reducing the referrals of women from Ángel Albino Corzo to Villaflores, eliminating the economic burden associated with the estimated number of 49 referrals for obstetric and gynecological surgery. The importance of this study is to demonstrate that the provision of accessible, quality surgical services not only prevents morbidity and mortality in women but also has a positive impact on the economy of women and their families.

abstract_title: Evaluation of a First Responders Course in Rural North India
author_block: S. Cherukupalli Mohan<sup>1,5</sup>, M. Bhatia<sup>2</sup>, C. Martinez<sup>3</sup>, N. Suria<sup>7</sup>, I. Helenowski<sup>5</sup>, N. Thakur<sup>6</sup>, A. Bhalla<sup>4</sup>, R. Narwal<sup>7</sup>, S. Bhoi<sup>6</sup>, M. Swaroop<sup>5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Cedars-Sinai Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Palmetto University of South Carolina,Department Of Surgery,Charleston, SC, USA <sup>4</sup>Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education & Research,Chandigarh, CHANDIGARH, India <sup>5</sup>Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>6</sup>The All India Institute Of Medical Sciences,New Delhi, India, India <sup>7</sup>Civil Health Center,Kalka, HARYANA, India
abstract_body:
Introduction: The majority of mortality in trauma occurs in the prehospital setting when the golden hour is spent accessing healthcare facilities rather than to resuscitate and stabilize. The World Health Organization recommends layperson first responder training courses to strengthen pre-hospital care. In India, as many as 80% of trauma patients are unable to access safe, appropriate and affordable trauma care within the first hour. Assessments performed in the rural community of Nanakpur, in North India demonstrated a significant paucity of and limited access to trauma and healthcare facilities. In order to address a deficiency in prehospital care, the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) in New Delhi, India, constructed the Basic Emergency Care Course (BECC) in 2009. In partnership with AIIMS, this study evaluated the efficacy of the AIIMS BECC in Nanakpur through pre- and post- course knowledge assessments testing.

Methods: The first responder courses took place in January 2017 in Nanakpur, rural Haryana. A local government physician recruited local community health workers, known as Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHAs) as participants. Each 8-hour course included adult and infant cardiopulmonary resuscitation, vehicle extrication, and trauma management. Instruction was mixed methodology using PowerPoint lectures, audio-visuals and mannequin-training. Local physicians led the course and participants completed both a pre- and post-course evaluation to assess participants’ baseline knowledge and improvement. A signed rank test was used to determine significance of knowledge improvement. Participants then took a one-year post-course assessment to assess knowledge retention. The results were analyzed with a student t-test.

Results: The course included 204 individuals. Pre- and post-course test results were available for 70 participants. Participants included 109/204 (53.4%) ASHAs. The majority (n=108/204) passed at least eighth standard in school. Participants demonstrated a significant improvement in knowledge (p<0.0001).  The one-year knowledge retention assessment was completed by 48.6% (n=53/109) of the original ASHA participants. The comparison between both the pre- and post-course assessment tests with the 12-month retention assessment demonstrated a significant decay in knowledge (p<0.0001). 

Conclusions: This study demonstrates the feasibility of utilizing AIIMS BECC to train Nanakpur’s ASHAs as first responders. Participants demonstrated a significant improvement in knowledge based on pre- and post-course test results. However, after one year, there was a significant loss in knowledge, highlighting the need for refresher courses. These data suggest potential for the use of BECC for training ASHAs countrywide in order to strengthen India’s pre-hospital care system. Overall, the ASHA system is a constant throughout India and has the potential to be employed to develop pre-hospital capacity.

abstract_title: Characterization of Pediatric Surgical Care Provisions in Nablus, West Bank in 2018
author_block: M. T. Mohammad<sup>1</sup>, A. Bowder<sup>1</sup>, M. Abushamma<sup>2</sup>, S. Siddiqui<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>An-Najah University,Faculty Of Medicine And Health Sciences,Nablus, WEST BANK, Palestinian Territory
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Lancet Commission on Global Surgery estimates that at least 5 billion people worldwide lack access to surgical care; 1.7 billion of these patients are children, a majority of whom reside in LMIC’s such as the West Bank (2). Limited data exists on the access and types of pediatric surgical procedures performed in the West Bank. The aim of this study is to explore the pediatric surgical conditions treated at Rafidia Hospital in the city of Nablus, West Bank and compare it to the care provided by visiting subspecialized teams.

Methods: After obtaining local IRB approval, we performed a retrospective chart review of the operative log of a district hospital in Nablus between May 1st, 2018, and July 31st, 2018. Data was pulled for all patients <18 years of age. We compared the patient age, surgical volume and complexity of the care provided by local general surgeons to the care provided by a visiting pediatric surgical team during a 1 week educational mission supported by a local NGO. Complexity for this study was defined by the classification of a procedure as “major” or “minor” in the operative log.

Results: Over the three-month period, 197 pediatric surgical procedures were performed at Rafidia Hospital.  One-hundred and seventy-nine of these cases were performed by local surgeons over the course of three months (average of 15 cases/week). Fifteen cases were performed by the visiting pediatric surgeon during the week-long mission trip. Of the total surgeries, 45.4% (n=89) were classified as major procedures while 54.6% (n=107) as minor. The majority of procedures (93.3%) conducted by the visiting surgeons were major procedures. Out of the 179 procedures done by local surgeons, the most common were appendectomies (48/179) and herniotomies (48/179). Meanwhile, the most common procedures done by the visiting surgeons included sistrunk procedures (3/15), laparoscopic cholecystectomies (3/15), and anoplasties (5/15). One third of the procedures completed by the visiting surgical team were revisions of major procedures. 

Conclusion: There is a steady volume of pediatric surgical services provided by the local surgeons at the district hospital level.  The local NGOs have successfully identified and filled a gap in provisions by hosting visiting surgical teams to perform cases that otherwise are not done by the local general surgeons. Further studies need to be completed to further understand pediatric surgical resources available in the region and to build further capacity for pediatric surgical care.

abstract_title: Expansion of the Surgical, Anesthesia and Obstetric Workforce (SAO) in Brazil from 2012 to 2017
author_block: R. S. Semco<sup>2</sup>, I. M. Faria<sup>4</sup>, A. Buda<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Bowder<sup>1</sup>, A. Guilloux<sup>5</sup>, D. P. Mooney<sup>1</sup>, H. E. Rice<sup>3</sup>, B. C. Lopes<sup>7</sup>, F. M. Botelho<sup>6</sup>, N. Alonso<sup>5</sup>, P. Truch<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Duke University School of Medicine,Duke Global Health Institute,Durham, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais,Faculdade De Medicina,Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil <sup>5</sup>Universidade de So Paulo,Plastic Surgery,So Paulo, SP, Brazil <sup>6</sup>Hospital das Clnicas da UFMG,Pediatric Surgery,Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil <sup>7</sup>Instituto de Medicina Integral Prof Fernando Figueira,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Recife, PERNAMBUCO, Brazil
abstract_body:
Introduction: Since the Lancet Commission on Global Surgery introduced surgical, anesthesia, and obstetric (SAO) density as a core surgical metric in 2015, there has been increasing interest in understanding the speed of surgical workforce expansion and the optimal ratios of S:A:O. In this study we aim to determine the rate of growth of the Brazilian surgical workforce from 2012 to 2017, compare the rate of growth of the surgical workforce compared to the total physician workforce, and analyze the ratio of surgeons to anesthesiologists to obstetricians.

Methods:  The total number of physicians, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and obstetricians in Brazil was extracted from the Brazilian Medical Demography, an official report from the Brazilian Federal Council of Medicine which collects data on the physician workforce through registration records and provider surveys. We defined SAO density as the totality of all general surgeons, obstetrician/gynecologists, anesthesiologists as well as 14 surgical subspecialists per 100,000 population using Brazilian Census data for each year that physician workforce numbers were available (2012, 2014, and 2017). We then calculated the total percent change, absolute growth, average annual rate of change in physician density and SAO density, and the ratio of surgeons to anesthesiologists to obstetricians.

Results: Between 2012 and 2017, national SAO density increased by 27% from 54.7/100,000 to 69.5/100,000 with an average annual growth rate of 4.8%. In contrast, the growth of the total physician workforce density increased by 9% from 200/100,000 to 217.6/100,000 with an average annual growth rate of 1.7%. The density of surgeons (subspecialists and generalists) increased by 35% from 32.4 to 43.8/100,000, anesthesiologist density increased by 18% from 9.4 to 11.1/100,000, and obstetrician density increased by 13% from 12.9 to 14.7/100,000. Surgeons comprised 59.2% of the SAO workforce in 2012, vs 63.0% in 2017; anesthesiologists comprised 17.2% of the SAO workforce in 2012, vs 15.9% in 2017; and obstetricians comprised 23.6% of the SAO workforce in 2012, vs 21.1% in 2017.

Conclusion: In Brazil, national SAO density is increasing at a higher average annual growth rate than the national physician workforce, while the ratio of surgeons to anesthesiologists to obstetricians has remained relatively constant over this same time period. This suggests that physicians may be becoming more interested in entering surgical specialties despite the emphasis of national policy on primary care strengthening. Further research into the mechanisms of this growth is warranted to inform surgical system strengthening in other nations.

abstract_title: Referral Process for Surgical Management of Tuberculosis in Lima, Peru: A Qualitative Study
author_block: S. B. Shu-Yip<sup>1,4</sup>, M. Wong<sup>2</sup>, K. Iverson<sup>3,4</sup>, L. Roa<sup>4,5</sup>, L. Lecca<sup>2,8</sup>, G. Mody<sup>6</sup>, A. Sotomayor<sup>7</sup> <sup>1</sup>Universidad Peruana Cayetano Heredia,Alberto Hurtado Medical School,Lima, LIMA, Peru <sup>2</sup>Socios en Salud,Lima, LIMA, Peru <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Davis,Department Of Surgery,Sacramento, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>Program on Global Surgery and Social Change,Harvard Medical School,Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Alberta,Department Of Obstetrics & Gynecology,Edmonton, ALBERTA, Canada <sup>6</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>7</sup>Hospital National Hipolito Unanue,Department Of Thoracic Surgery,Lima, LIMA, Peru <sup>8</sup>Harvard Medical School,Department Of Global Health And Social Medicine,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Surgery plays an important role in the management of multi-drug resistant Tuberculosis (MDR-TB) and its complications as a complementary therapy. Access to this health service is scarce worldwide, particularly in limited resource settings. The patients’ journey for surgical management, from the primary care center to the operating room, is underreported in the literature especially in high burden countries, such as Peru. The study aimed to describe the health cares’ perspective on the referral process for surgical management of patient with MDR-TB in Lima, Peru.

Methods: A qualitative study based on focus groups and interviews was conducted to health care providers in charge of the TB program in health centers of northern and eastern Metropolitan Area of Lima. Subjects included general practitioners, nurses, pulmonologists, and thoracic surgeons who participated in semi-structured focus groups and/or interviews. Audio recordings were transcribed by native Spanish speakers. Thematic analysis and referral process reconstruction were performed using DeDoose software.

Results: A total of 12 sessions were recorded (7 interviews and 5 focus groups) which gathered 36 participants. The main themes identified were: 1. Selection criteria for surgery, 2. Administrative process, 3. Inter-institutional communication, 4. Barriers to surgical management of TB. The referral process structure was mapped, and functions were documented (Table 1). Patients’ evaluations by different provider from different institutions were reported to be challenging due to limited inter-institutional communication, lack of resources and high emotionally demanding for patients and health care workers.

Conclusion: Health care providers involved in the referral process of surgical management of TB in Lima reported limited standardization of selection criteria, a stepwise administrative structure and limited communication between stages of evaluation of the patient. Interinstitutional communication might be an important interventional point to improve a patient's quality of care during the referral.

abstract_title: Association Between Subnational Surgical Workforce Density and Human Development Index Among Brazilian States
author_block: I. M. Faria<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Semco<sup>2</sup>, A. Buda<sup>3</sup>, A. N. Bowder<sup>3</sup>, A. G. Guilloux<sup>4</sup>, D. P. Mooney<sup>3</sup>, H. E. Rice<sup>5</sup>, B. C. Lopes<sup>8</sup>, F. M. Botelho<sup>7</sup>, N. Alonso<sup>6</sup>, P. Truch<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais,Faculdade De Medicina,Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Universidade de So Paulo,Preventive Medicine,So Paulo, SP, Brazil <sup>5</sup>Duke University School of Medicine,Duke Global Health Institute,Durham, NC, USA <sup>6</sup>Universidade de So Paulo,Plastic Surgery,So Paulo, SP, Brazil <sup>7</sup>Hospital das Clnicas da UFMG,Pediatric Surgery,Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil <sup>8</sup>Instituto de Medicina integral,Pediatric Surgery,Recife, PE, Brazil
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Lancet Commission on Global Surgery recommends a target of 20-40 surgeons, anesthesiologists, and obstetricians (SAO) per 100,000 population. Currently, subnational variation in SAO density remains understudied but may represent a useful metric to capture subnational disparities in access to surgical care. In this study, we assess the change in SAO density among Brazilian states between 2012-2017 and determine if SAO density is associated with increases in Municipal Human Development Index (MHDI) at the subnational level.

Methods: Population and number of SAO in each Brazilian state were extracted from the Brazilian Medical Demography from 2012-2017. We calculated the density of all general surgeons, obstetrician/gynecologists, anesthesiologists, and 14 surgical subspecialties per 100,000 population from 2012 to 2017 at state level using census data for each year. Data on Brazil's subnational MHDI was obtained from the 2019 MHDI Radar, Atlas of Human Development in Brazil. The association between SAO density and MHDI was compared longitudinally using a linear mixed effects model.

Results: National SAO density increased by 27% (54.7 per 100,000 in 2012 to 69.5 per 100,000 in 2017). In 2017, SAO density among states ranged from 25.0 to 160.3 with a median of 44. In 2012, 2 states (Maranhão, Pará) did not meet the minimum SAO density target of 20, and 13 states exceeded the target of 40. By 2017, all states met the minimum target and 22 states exceeded the target of 40. Increases in SAO density among states ranged from 12% to 89%. MHDI ranged from 0.63 to  0.2 with a median of 0.7. SAO density was positively correlated with MHDI status over the study period with an estimated increase of 4.7 SAO for each 0.1 increase in MHDI (P<.001)

Conclusion: All 27 Brazilan states currently meet the minimum SAO density targets, and 22 exceeded the target recommendation of 40.  Given the wide range of SAO densities among states, additional metrics are needed to capture workforce disparities at the subnational level including rural municipalities in need of improved access to surgical care. State-level Municipal Human Development Index is closely tied to increased surgical workforce, suggesting that other economic and social indicators may be useful in identifying subnational disparities in surgical workforce density in low and middle-income countries.

abstract_title: Recommendations for Distribution and Prioritization of Surgical Services in LMICs: a Delphi Study
author_block: J. A. Henry<sup>1</sup>, A. E. Lelchuk<sup>2</sup>, E. Ameh<sup>3</sup>, C. H. Yip<sup>12</sup>, P. Nthumba<sup>4</sup>, S. De Jonge<sup>14</sup>, M. Mehes<sup>5</sup>, E. Stieber<sup>6</sup>, L. Hollier<sup>7</sup>, H. Ifereimi Waqainabete<sup>8</sup>, D. Noor Hisham Abdullah<sup>9</sup>, A. Hill<sup>10</sup>, M. Langer<sup>13</sup>, M. K. Ferguson<sup>11</sup> <sup>1</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Department Of Surgery,Boca Raton, FLORIDA, USA <sup>2</sup>RWJ Barnabas Health Jersey City Medical Center,Department Of Surgery And Trauma Critical Care,Jersey City, NEW JERSEY, USA <sup>3</sup>National Hospital,Division Of Paediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Abuja, Nigeria <sup>4</sup>AIC Kijabe Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Nairobi, Kenya <sup>5</sup>Global Alliance for Surgical, Obstetric, Trauma and Anaesthesia Care,The G4 Alliance,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>6</sup>Smile Train,Vice President For Global Affairs,New York, NY, USA <sup>7</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Division Of Plastic Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>8</sup>Minister for Health and Medical Services Of Fiji,Ministry Of Health,Fiji, Fiji <sup>9</sup>Ministry of Health Of Malaysia,Director General For Health,Malaysia, Malaysia <sup>10</sup>University Of Auckland,Auckland, -, New Zealand <sup>11</sup>University Of Chicago,Section Of Thoracic Surgery , Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>12</sup>University of Malaysia,Department Of Surgery,Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia <sup>13</sup>Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>14</sup>Amsterdam UMC, University of Amsterdam,Department Of Surgery,Amsterdam, Netherlands
abstract_body:
Introduction: To date, no recommendations on the optimal distribution and prioritization of surgical services exist to guide low- and middle- income countries (LMICs) on the safe and efficient scale-up of quality surgical care. The Delphi consensus method was used to develop such recommendations.  

Methods: International surgeon experts from LMICs developed draft statements then participated in two rounds of anonymous voting via Delphi consensus. Only statements with an approval rate of >80% were accepted in the recommendations.       

Results: Out of 75 nominated LMIC surgeon experts, 70% (n=53) from 27 countries in four continents (Africa, Asia, and the Americas) representing 13 specialties voted on twenty-seven statements in Round 1 with 22 achieving >80% consensus. After incorporating comments from Round 1, 16 revised statements were relaunched with 15 reaching more than >80% agreement. The final recommendations covered three major themes: 1) whether services should be decentralized or centralized based on three dimensions: surgical volume, acuity, and complexity; 2) how the implementation of these services should be prioritized at the district level; and 3) the role of international surgical partnerships and how they can contribute to improving the overall quality and safety of surgical care in LMICs.

Conclusion: These recommendations currently constitute the best available expert-informed guidelines for policy making, planning, and allocation of resources for health systems strengthening in LMICs.

abstract_title: A Systematic Review of Inhalation Injury Associated with Burns in Low- and Middle-Income Countries
author_block: C. Jacobs<sup>1</sup>, J. Vacek<sup>2,3</sup>, B. Many<sup>2,3</sup>, J. Peterson<sup>1</sup>, F. Abdullah<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago,Pediatric General Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Burn injuries are the fourth most common type of trauma worldwide, and disproportionately occur in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). When inhalation injury is present in association with burn injuries, the morbidity and mortality significantly increase. Frequently, management of this injury is resource intensive. The objective of this review is to assess inhalation injury treatment and outcomes in LMICs.

Methods:  Pubmed, Embase, and Cochrane literature reviews were performed from 1976 through March 2019 for articles published in World Bank-defined LMICs that discussed burn injury treatment and outcomes in LMICs. Two independent reviewers screened articles and a third party reviewer settled inclusion disputes. Full text articles were screened for discussion of inhalation injury treatment and outcomes. 

Results: Articles reporting burn treatment and management in LMICs totaled 336 with 50 (14.9%) at least partially discussing inhalation injury in 14 LMICs. Only one article studied inhalation injury exclusively. Inhalation injury prevalence ranged from 0.8% to 97.2% among the included articles. Of the 19 articles reporting diagnostic criteria, 5 used bronchoscopy reliably. Two hospitals cited lack of funding or reliable access to bronchoscopy as a barrier. All but one article found males more likely to develop an inhalation injury. Prevalence of inhalation injury increased with increasing total body surface area of burn (TBSA). Mortality with inhalation injury ranged from 10.4-100% and was found to increase independently of TBSA. Inhalation injury was associated with increased incidence of nosocomial infection (17-36% v. 12%) and multiorgan dysfunction (60.4% v. 39.6%). One study attributed intensive care unit bed availability to the mortality of seven patients. 16 articles mentioned treatment which included: early tracheostomy for 16-100% of patients, prophylactic antibiotics for 100% of patients, and mechanical ventilation for 45-100% of patients. Two articles stratified the severity of inhalation injury in their respective analysis. 

Conclusion: Evaluation of inhalation injury associated with burns in LMICs is underreported, and is often only reported in industrial accidents. Inhalation injury in LMICs has an increased association with poor outcomes independent of TBSA. Areas of improvement for inhalation injury include investing in health services infrastructure, standardization of diagnosing, scoring severity, and treatment algorithms.

abstract_title: Cervical Cancer Care in the Gambia: Geographic Distribution of Available Services and Personnel
author_block: M. Mali<sup>1</sup>, F. Lopez-Verdugo<sup>1</sup>, M. K. Moustafa<sup>1</sup>, M. Bittaye<sup>5,6</sup>, R. Njie<sup>2,5</sup>, Y. Singhateh<sup>6</sup>, A. N. Sambou<sup>6</sup>, M. Nuredin<sup>7</sup>, J. Nellermoe<sup>1</sup>, A. Goldsmith<sup>1,4</sup>, R. Price<sup>1</sup>, E. Sutherland<sup>1,3</sup>, O. Sanyang<sup>1,2,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah,Center For Global Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>Edward Francis Small Teaching Hospital,Banjul, BANJUL, Gambia <sup>3</sup>Ensign College of Public Health,Kpong, EASTERN REGION, Ghana <sup>4</sup>University Of Utah,Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>5</sup>University of The Gambia,School Of Medicine And Allied Health Sciences,Banjul, BANJUL, Gambia <sup>6</sup>The Gambia Ministry of Health,Banjul, BANJUL, Gambia <sup>7</sup>Medical Research Council,Unit The Gambia,Fajara, WEST COAST REGION, Gambia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cervical cancer, the most common cancer affecting women in The Gambia, accounts for 22% of cancer related deaths across genders. The “Strategic Plan for the Prevention and Control of Cervical Cancer in The Gambia: 2016-2020” aimed to train more healthcare providers in screening, diagnosis, and treatment of cervical cancer and precancerous lesions, and expand the number of facilities offering services. We sought to catalog the number of trained providers and available services for management of cervical cancer currently available in The Gambia.

Methods: A facility-based survey, developed based on the Surgeons Overseas’ Personnel, Infrastructure, Procedure, Equipment and Supplies tool, WHO’s tool for situation analysis, and expert opinion was conducted in The Gambia Mar 9 - Apr 9, 2020. Publicly owned secondary and tertiary health facilities were surveyed as well as privately owned medical centers and clinics. Local research assistants (RA) were trained to administer the survey, enter data, and obtain GPS coordinates. Facilities were provided with the survey prior to an in person visit by an RA and were allowed to choose the most appropriate person in the facility to complete the survey.

Results: 102 facilities were surveyed: 1 teaching, 7 general, and 4 district hospitals; 3 major, 56 minor, and 31 private medical centers or clinics. 35% of the facilities, and the majority of services, are located in Western 1 Region (WR1), which houses about 25% of The Gambia population. Visual inspection with acetic acid is available at 23 facilities and human papilloma virus testing at 13, 61% and 62% of which are located in WR1 respectively. All facilities offering cervical biopsy (10), cryotherapy (13), thermoablation (1), loop electrosurgical excision (1), and cone knife conization (3) are in WR1. For invasive cancer treatment, 10 facilities offer radical hysterectomy (90% in WR1), 3 chemotherapy (all in WR1), and radiation therapy is not available. Many healthcare providers are trained in services not offered in their facility (Table 1).

Conclusion: The majority of cervical cancer services are concentrated in the WR1 region of The Gambia, and 75% of the population is without access to care in their home district. In WR1, comprehensive cervical cancer care (screening, diagnosis, treatment) is available with exception of radiation therapy. Perhaps as a result of expanded training through the “Strategic Plan…,” many health care providers are trained in procedures that are not offered at their facility. This presents a unique opportunity for expanding access to care by focusing on infrastructure development in areas that already have trained healthcare workers.

abstract_title: Diagnostics Required For Provision Of the Disease Control Priorities Essential Surgical Package
author_block: A. Jayaram<sup>1</sup>, D. El-Gabri<sup>1</sup>, Z. Fowler<sup>1</sup>, P. Truche<sup>1</sup>, K. DeStigter<sup>3</sup>, S. Sayed<sup>4</sup>, S. Corlew<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Meara<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Plastic Surgery,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Larner College of Medicine at the University of Vermont,Burlington, VT, USA <sup>4</sup>Aga Khan University Hospital,Nairobi, Kenya
abstract_body:
Introduction: A core set of essential surgical procedures was defined in Disease Control Priorities 3rd edition, Essential Surgery (DCP3), and has been used as a basis to scale up surgical systems in low-resource settings. Here we aim to identify the diagnostic modalities required for safe and appropriate diagnosis and treatment of conditions related to the procedures included in the DCP3’s essential surgical package.

Methods: We outlined search terms for each of the 44 surgical procedures listed in the DCP3. We entered these search terms in UpToDate to identify and extract all necessary laboratory tests, imaging, and pathology services. For procedures that did not have information on UpToDate, we searched Dynamed. We considered a normal disease course for all procedures and excluded tests for complications or pregnant patients. We included all recommended tests that UpToDate or Dynamed listed. For procedures with multiple diagnoses, the most common diagnosis for the procedure was used. If multiple diagnostic tests were acceptable, in an effort to reduce the number of discrete tests needed, we included the test or modality that was needed for other DCP3 procedures. To indicate what diagnostics are needed for procedures at each hospital level, we grouped the diagnostics based on the DCP3’s stratification of surgical procedures into three tiers of care: community facilities/primary health centers, first level health facilities, and second/tertiary level health facilities.

Results: There are 24 unique recommended laboratory tests, seven imaging modalities, and six surgical pathology and cytology tests for the 44 procedures. The diagnostic tests required for each platform are shown in Figure 1, and each subsequent level of care includes the diagnostics required in the level below.  At community level institutions, there are nine recommended procedures that require five laboratory tests and two imaging modalities. At a first level community hospital, there are a total of 37 recommended procedures, which require 22 laboratory tests, five imaging modalities, and four surgical pathology and cytology requirements. The second and third level hospitals require  22 laboratory tests, seven imaging modalities, and six surgical pathology and cytology requirements.

Conclusion: A broad range of diagnostic testing is required at all hospital levels in order to support the DCP3 essential surgery package. Scale up of surgical care will require significant investment in laboratory testing, diagnostic imaging, and pathology requirements in order to ensure that safe, high quality surgery can be performed at all hospital levels. In this study we created a list of diagnostics required for scaling up essential surgery according to the DCP3.

abstract_title: Surgical Service Distribution Among The Indigenous Population In Chiapas, Mexico
author_block: F. Carrillo<sup>1</sup>, E. Moeller<sup>2,3</sup>, Z. Fowler<sup>2</sup>, L. Roa<sup>2,4</sup>, S. Mohar<sup>5</sup>, R. Jhunjhunwala<sup>2</sup>, M. Stankey<sup>2</sup>, S. Cervantes<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Meara<sup>2,7</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>2,6</sup>, T. Uribe-Leitz<sup>2,6,8</sup>, V. Macas<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Compaeros en Salud,Surgical Department,ngel Albino Corzo, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Miami,Institute For Advanced Study Of The Americas,Miami, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Alberta,Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology,Edmenton, ALBERTA, Canada <sup>5</sup>Hospital Bsico Comunitario ngel Albino Corzo,Secretaria De Salud,Jaltenango, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>6</sup>Brigham and Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>7</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Boston, MA, USA <sup>8</sup>Technical University Munich,Department Of Sport And Health Sciences,Munich, BAVIERA, Germany
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chiapas, Mexico’s poorest state, is home to 5.3 million people with 36% identifying as indigenous. 28% of the population speak an indigenous language, and one-third of those do not speak Spanish. There is little information about surgical services in Chiapas and even less regarding the impact of service distribution on the indigenous population. The purpose of this study is to understand surgical care delivery among hospitals serving indigenous patients in Chiapas.

Methods: We conducted a cross-sectional study in hospitals in Chiapas from September to December 2019 using a validated, translated Surgical Assessment Tool. Data about workforce, surgical volume, and patient demographics were collected. Stratified convenience sampling was utilized to sample hospitals located throughout nine of the ten health districts in the state. Hospitals included both government-funded public hospitals and private hospitals. We compared hospitals that reported either a minority (<?) or majority (>?) of their patient population identifying as indigenous. 

Results: Of 37 sampled hospitals, 17 (46%) reported their patient population as minority indigenous (median bed size 12, IQR 19) and 12 (32%) reported it as majority indigenous (median bed size 16, IQR 26.8). Of minority indigenous hospitals, 17.6% (n=3) had at least one staff member who spoke an indigenous language compared to 91.7% (n=11) of majority indigenous hospitals. In hospitals serving majority indigenous patients, the number of surgical providers and procedures was lower, with a median of 0 general surgeons (IQR 2.5),0.5 obstetricians (IQR 1), and 52.2 monthly operations (IQR 70.3). Conversely, there were a median of 2 general surgeons (IQR 2) and 2 obstetricians (IQR 4) in minority indigenous hospitals, with a median of 68 operations per month (IQR 91). 

Conclusion: Translation services are essential in all hospitals in Chiapas to provide equitable high quality care for indigenous populations. Limited surgical workforce in hospitals treating majority indigenous patients may lead to worse surgical outcomes for these patients. Interventions considering the specific needs of indigenous communities and the hospitals they utilize is essential.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Laparoscopic Versus Open Repair of Meckel's Diverticulum and Risk Factors for Conversion
author_block: M. Grunvald<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Skertich<sup>1</sup>, M. Ingram<sup>2</sup>, E. Ritz<sup>3</sup>, S. Pillai<sup>1</sup>, M. Madonna<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Shah<sup>1</sup>, M. V. Raval<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center,Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago,Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Chicago, ILLINOIS, USA <sup>3</sup>Rush University Medical Center,Rush Bioinformatics And Biostatistics Core,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Meckel’s Diverticulum (MD) is a common congenital anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract caused by a persistent vitelline duct. It accounts for half of pediatric gastrointestinal hemorrhages and can cause obstruction, intussusception, and infection. Although the laparoscopic technique has gained popularity, no large scale studies exist comparing open and laparoscopic approaches and conversion rates remain high. We sought to compare postoperative outcomes associated with each approach and to determine risk factors for conversion to an open procedure. 

Methods: The National Surgical Quality Improvement Program-Pediatric was used to identify patients who underwent surgical repair of a Meckel’s diverticulum from 2012-2018.  Outcomes between patients who were treated with a laparoscopic versus open surgery were compared. Chi-square tests and adjusted logistic regression analysis were used to determine significant differences in patient outcomes between treatment groups and factors associated with conversion.

Results: Among the 681 patients identified, there were 295 (43.3%) open, 386 (56.7%) laparoscopic, and 119 (30.8%) laparoscopic converted to open patients.  Patients undergoing laparoscopic compared to open procedures had shorter length of stay (LOS) (3 vs. 4 days, p<0.001), fewer unplanned intubations (0.0 vs. 2.4%, p=0.003), less bleeding requiring transfusion (3.4 vs. 6.8%, p=0.04) and lower mortality (0.0 vs. 1.7%, p=0.015) without significantly different overall complication rates (11.9 vs. 14.9%, p=0.25) or longer mean operative times (77.3 vs. 76.6 minutes, p=0.84).  On adjusted logistic regression analysis, only a higher American Society of Anesthesiologists Classification (ASA Class) was predictive of higher overall morbidity rate, not operative technique. Patients requiring conversion to open did not have significantly different morbidity rates (14.3 vs. 10.9, p=0.34), but did have longer operative times (90.1 vs 71.6 minutes, p<0.001) and length of hospital stay (4 vs. 3, p=0.001). They were also more likely to have a history of cardiac risk factors on adjusted logistic regression analysis (Odds ratio 5.5. 95% Confidence Interval 1.1, 27.5, p=0.038).

Conclusion: Laparoscopic MD repair has fewer complications, lower mortality, shorter LOS, with no significant increase in operative time compared to an open approach. Despite a high laparoscopic to open conversion rate, overall morbidity remained low and not significantly different, although LOS and operative time increased.

abstract_title: Readmissions for Secondary Infection in <15% TBSA Pediatric Burn Injury Patients
author_block: D. S. Feuer<sup>1</sup>, B. Fenner<sup>2</sup>, O. Sharaf<sup>1</sup>, R. Hawkins<sup>2</sup>, S. D. Larson<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida,College Of Medicine,Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida,Department Of Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Florida,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pediatric burn-related injuries are a common cause of hospitalization and are a major contributor to morbidity and mortality. Larger total body surface-area (TBSA) burns are associated with prolonged immunosuppression and increased risk of secondary infection. However, there is little data regarding the consequences of smaller area burns. We hypothesize that smaller burn wounds (<15% TBSA) carry significant risk of immunosuppression and secondary infection in children.

Methods: Using the DiCorp V6 Burn Database, we performed retrospective analysis of all pediatric patients admitted to our institution from July 2016–February 2020 with second or third degree burn < 15% TBSA. Baseline data collected included demographic data, burn type, and grafting requirements. Outcome measures include any infection other than burn site, within 30 days of injury.

Results: There were 494 pediatric patients that met inclusion criteria. Seventeen (3.4%) presented to our institution with a non-burn site infection < 30 days. Two (0.4%) patients required hospital admission (herpes simplex virus and a retropharyngeal abscess).  The most common infection was upper respiratory infections (URIs)–present in 11 of 17 children (64.7%).  Two (18.2%) patients with a URI, developed advanced complications of their URI (scarlet fever, and retropharyngeal abscess). Other infections included urinary tract infection, conjunctivitis, molluscum contagiosum, impetigo, and diffuse abscesses. The median age for infected children was 1 year old, compared to 3 years old for all studied patients.

Conclusion: Secondary infection following a minor burn is a potential contributor to morbidity among children. While this study is limited by its retrospective nature, the data suggest that children may be in an immunocompromised state after relatively small burns. Scarlet fever and retropharyngeal abscesses are both rare complications of URIs. It is likely that the rate of infection in this population is significantly higher compared to our results, as many patients likely presented to a primary pediatrician outside of our hospital network. Future prospective work is needed to confirm the higher rate of secondary infection in pediatric burn patients and to identify the factors most predictive of this complication.

abstract_title: Two for the Price of One: Concurrent Diagnoses of Biliary Dyskinesia and Gastroparesis in Children
author_block: N. C. Applebaum<sup>1</sup>, M. Michel<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida,Pediatric Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Biliary dyskinesia (BD) and gastroparesis (GP) are both poorly understood functional disorders involving the foregut that can cause substantial issues in children, with chronic pain and nausea. Both diagnoses have similar presentations and symptoms which may result in confusion, and surgical treatment of either condition frequently results in recurrent problems, which is frustrating to both patients and surgeons. The purpose of this study is to present and discuss patients who had both diagnoses occurring, and to highlight the potential for management.  

Methods: Patients who had either undergone a cholecystectomy for BD or stimulator placement for GP were included over a 13-year period. Those who had both diagnoses occur in a metachronous or synchronous fashion were selected for further analysis, and clinical variables on their course were collected and analyzed. Descriptive statistics were performed.  

Results:  Of the 26 patients identified, 16 had an initial diagnosis of BD (61.54%) while 10 had that of GP (38.46%). Mean age at initial diagnosis was 15.4 years (+/- 3.58), with 96% being female. Average time between the initial and secondary diagnosis was 471.88 days (+/- 899.42). Mean ejection fraction on CCK-HIDA was 29.8% (+/- 34.6) and 19 patients had symptom reproduction with CCK (73.1%). Gastric Emptying tests were noted to be moderate to severely delayed in 80.8% of cases, with an average half time emptying of 123.11 minutes (+/- 49.26). The etiology of GP was idiopathic in 23/26 cases, with 8 patients having stimulators implanted after a succesful temporary trial. Over half of recurrences were noted within 6 months of either cholecystectomy or placement of gastric electrical stimulator (GES). All patients responded to the secondary intervention and at last follow up (average 706.36 days (+/- 758.04)), had improvement in their overall symptom scores using the gastroparesis index.  

Conclusions: Functional foregut disorders (BD and GP) have similar symptoms and recurrence after surgical management occurs. While persistent symptoms may suggest a recurrence in these cases, these data suggest that further evaluation should include testing for the other diagnosis before considering the patient to have failed from their initial intervention (cholecystectomy or gastric stimulator). Substantial and maintained improvement in children can be obtained from the secondary procedure. Patients and families should be educated regarding the potential for secondary diagnoses. Further understanding of these functional disorders is needed in the future to help improve outcomes.

abstract_title: Describing Anesthesia Capacity for Children in Somaliland
author_block: A. M. Grimm<sup>1</sup>, M. Mohamed<sup>2</sup>, C. F. Cotache-Condor<sup>1</sup>, T. L. Concepcion<sup>3</sup>, S. Dahir<sup>2</sup>, E. Adan Ismail<sup>2</sup>, D. Poenaru<sup>4</sup>, H. E. Rice<sup>3</sup>, E. R. Smith<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor University,Department Of Public Health,Waco, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Edna Adan University Hospital,Hargeisa, Somalia <sup>3</sup>Duke University,Global Health Institute,Durham, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>McGill University,Montreal, QUEBEC, Canada
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Similar to many low- and middle-income countries, Somaliland has a high burden of surgical conditions in children and a lack of pediatric infrastructure and workforce, although the pediatric anesthetic capacity of Somaliland is poorly defined. Without quality anesthesia care, there are increased risks during perioperative care, particularly among children. Moreover, the World Health Organization-World Federation of Societies of Anesthesiologists (WHO-WFSA) has developed standards for global anesthesia care including metrics for capacity, equipment, infrastructure, and workforce. The purposes of this study are to describe anesthesia capacity in Somaliland for children, and to make recommendations for scale-up of pediatric anesthesia care. 

Methods:  Data on pediatric anesthesia capacity were collected using a hospital capacity survey and surgical record review. A total of 15 private, charity, and government hospitals were included. Data included hospital characteristics (location, type, catchment population), workforce (anesthesiologists and anesthetists), infrastructure, and anesthetic equipment. A total of 1,255 children’s surgical records were reviewed to collect data on who administered anesthesia and the type of anesthesia given. Of the available data, Somaliland’s anesthesia capacity was compared to WHO-WFSA standards.

Results: Overall, Somaliland did not reach most of the target goals for anesthesia capacity defined by the WHO-WFSA, with four indicators lagging by 77% or more. The greatest need was for anesthesiologists, especially pediatric trained anesthesiologists. The majority (85%) of the pediatric surgical procedures used general anesthesia administered exclusively by anesthetists. Compared to rural regions, urban regions have most of the country’s anesthesia workforce (52%), infrastructure (55%), and equipment (61%), as well as provide more pediatric surgical procedures (76%).

Conclusion: Our study found a vast need for anesthesia capacity, workforce, and equipment for children’s surgical care across Somaliland. The disparities in anesthesia capacity between urban and rural regions in Somaliland are indicative of complex disparities and barriers to accessing healthcare, as the majority of surgical resources are concentrated in few places. Scale-up of surgical care will require expansion of anesthetic manpower, resources, and infrastructure. Without this necessary scale-up to pediatric anesthesia care, children and their caretakers are unable to seek or receive life changing surgical operations for the children most in need of them.

abstract_title: Determining the significance of bladder opacification in pediatric enteral contrast studies
author_block: M. B. Bhatia<sup>1</sup>, L. McDuffie<sup>5</sup>, M. R. Wanner<sup>3,4</sup>, B. Karmazyn<sup>3,4</sup>, D. F. Billmire<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Riley Hospital for Children,Pediatric Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Clinical Radiology And Imaging Sciences,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>5</sup>Medical University Of South Carolina,Pediatric Surgery,Charleston, SC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bladder opacification on abdominopelvic x-ray series after administration of enteric water-soluble contrast has previously thought to be indicative of a bowel perforation or anastomotic leak. However, more recent animal studies and rare clinical case reports have demonstrated bladder opacification without frank perforation or leak, but rather in the setting of small bowel obstruction or mucosal abnormality. We sought to evaluate our experience with bladder opacification after enteric contrast in children. We investigated clinical factors that might identify patients who would require surgical exploration.

Methods: This retrospective IRB-exempt study (3/2010-10/2019) was performed at a pediatric tertiary referral hospital. We identified 25 children from the Radiology Information System who underwent studies with enteric water-soluble iodine contrast and had opacification of the urinary bladder. Demographic and clinical information for the 24 hours preceding the contrast study, findings from the radiographic studies, and surgery and pathology results were recorded. We identified patients who required surgical intervention within three days of the contrast study. We evaluated the correlation of presence of urinary contrast with need for surgery for bowel perforation or obstruction and pathologic findings. Statistical significance was calculated with chi-square test for categorical variables and ANOVA for continuous variables.

Results: Seven of the 25 children underwent surgery after demonstration of opacification of the bladder with iodinated enteric contrast. Six patients had bowel perforation or necrosis. The remaining patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy for concern of obstruction secondary to Hirschsprung’s disease and was found to have no ganglion cells in the proximal small bowel. Four of the seven patients had two or more hemodynamic or lab derangements. All seven patients who underwent laparotomy with bladder opacification were younger than four months and had evidence of necrotizing enterocolitis and/or intestinal obstruction.

Conclusion: Bladder opacification after enteral contrast in children may be seen without bowel perforation or necrosis. Presence of tachycardia, hypotension, fever, leukocytosis, or metabolic acidosis did not correlate with the need for operation.

abstract_title: Single Site Versus Conventional Laparoscopic Appendectomy: Some Pain for No Gain?
author_block: L. F. Goodman<sup>1</sup>, A. Lin<sup>2</sup>, M. Sacks<sup>1</sup>, J. J. McRae<sup>3</sup>, A. Radulescu<sup>1</sup>, F. Khan<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine,Pediatric Surgery,Loma LInda, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine,General Surgery,Loma LInda, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine,Loma LInda, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Minimally invasive techniques for acute appendicitis have been shown to decrease post-operative pain, length of stay, complications and improve cosmesis compared to open surgery, but the optimal minimally-invasive approach has not been identified. Single site laparoscopic appendectomy (SILA) has not yet been shown to have superiority over conventional 3-port laparoscopic appendectomy (CLA). There may be a cosmetic benefit to a single intra-umbilical scar, but the technique can be technically challenging. We investigated the outcomes in pediatric patients undergoing SILA compared to CLA, including length of operation, length of stay, time to resumption of regular diet, follow up, and rehospitalization.

Methods:  After IRB approval (#5200119), data was collected from medical records of children 1-18 years who underwent laparoscopic appendectomy at Loma Linda University from 2018 to 2020. Interval appendectomies were excluded. Data were analyzed using two-sample T, chi-squared, and Fisher’s exact tests as appropriate, using Python software.

Results: 173 patients were included, of whom 77 underwent SILA and 96 had CLA. 85 patients were female (49%), while 88 were males, with no difference between the operative groups. The average age was 10.3 years (range 2.3-17.9), with no significant difference between the operative groups. The patients were mostly Hispanic (84 percent, or 144 individuals), with no difference between the groups. The mean leukocyte count (WBC) upon presentation was 17.5 x103/mL in the SILA group, compared to 15.3 x103/mL in the CLA group (p=0.004). The mean length of operation was 47.0 for SILA compared 49.5 minutes for CLA (p=0.269). Of the SILA cases, 55.8% were simple appendicitis on pathology findings, while 53.3% of the CLA cases were simple appendicitis (p=0.857), as opposed to complex, including perforated. Regular diet was resumed after 1.7 days in the SILA group, compared to 1.1 days in CLA (p= 0.018). Average length of stay was 2.9 days for SILA, compared to 2.4 days for CLA (p=0.144). Seven children required hospital readmission, 5 in the SILA group and 2 in the CLA group (p=0.244). Five of the children who returned had intra-abdominal abscesses, of whom four had undergone SILA technique.

Conclusion: The two operative techniques had similar outcomes and operative times. However, the SILA group had slightly higher WBC upon presentation, and longer time to resumption of regular diet despite no difference in simple versus complex pathology. There was a trend toward more intra-abdominal abscesses in the SILA group. This study was limited by including a small number of patients analyzed in retrospect at a single institution with two surgeons. Further study and longer follow up is needed to determine if there is an advantage to one laparoscopic approach over another.

abstract_title: Perioperative Ketorolac is Not Associated with Increased Bleeding After Appendectomy in Children
author_block: P. Kingston<sup>2</sup>, D. Lascano<sup>1</sup>, S. Ourshalimian<sup>1</sup>, E. Kim<sup>1</sup>, C. Russell<sup>1,2</sup>, L. Kelley-Quon<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Ketorolac (Toradol®) – a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug – can be used as part of an opioid-sparing regimen for postoperative pain management. However, surgeons may avoid ketorolac due to a possible increased risk of bleeding. We hypothesized that perioperative ketorolac used in children undergoing appendectomy for perforated appendicitis was not associated with clinically significant postoperative bleeding requiring blood transfusion. 

Methods:  A retrospective cohort analysis of healthy children 2-18 years who underwent appendectomy for perforated appendicitis from 2009-2019 was performed using the Pediatric Health Information System® (PHIS). Receipt of blood transfusion within 30 days of surgery was evaluated. Multivariable logistic regression with mixed effects modeling was used to evaluate the association between perioperative ketorolac use and postoperative blood transfusions, adjusting for patient and hospital characteristics. An interaction was evaluated between ketorolac and perioperative ibuprofen administration due to the risk of NSAID-related adverse effects.

Results: Overall, 56,719 children with perforated appendicitis underwent appendectomy and 189 (0.3%) received a blood transfusion within 30 days of surgery. Of the 46,489 (82%) children who received perioperative ketorolac, 14,929 (32%) also received ibuprofen during hospitalization. On unadjusted analysis, children who received ketorolac were less likely to require blood transfusions than children who did not receive ketorolac (0.3% vs. 0.5%, p<0.001). This relationship persisted on multivariable regression analysis; perioperative ketorolac was associated with a decreased likelihood of receiving a blood transfusion within 30 days (aOR = 0.54, 95% CI: 0.36-0.82). A significant interaction between ketorolac and ibuprofen was noted as patients who received both analgesics were more likely to require a blood transfusion within 30 days compared to ketorolac exposed patients (OR = 2.12, 95% CI: 1.52-2.96). Use of ibuprofen alone was not associated with increased risk of postoperative blood transfusion. 

Conclusion: Significant postoperative bleeding requiring transfusion is rare after appendectomy for perforated appendicitis. Perioperative ketorolac alone was not associated with clinically significant bleeding requiring blood transfusions in children undergoing appendectomy for perforated appendicitis. Use of both ketorolac and ibuprofen was associated with an increased likelihood of bleeding requiring a blood transfusion. Ketorolac alone may be safe to administer for post-appendectomy pain control, but surgeons and anesthesiologists should ensure that patients have not also received ibuprofen during hospitalization.

abstract_title: Room for Improvement: A Study of the Trephination (Gip's) Procedure for Pediatric Pilonidal Disease
author_block: G. A. Metzger<sup>2</sup>, L. Nishimura<sup>2</sup>, J. C. Apfeld<sup>2</sup>, C. Lutz<sup>2</sup>, K. J. Deans<sup>1,2</sup>, P. C. Minneci<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital,Research Institute,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
