Introduction: Pilonidal disease is common amongst adolescent males and females and often leads to recurrent symptoms and life-altering morbidity.  Studies have failed to show a clear advantage for any single treatment strategy, leading to a heterogeneous assortment of treatment options and a wide variation in provider approach.  Traditionally, surgery included wide excision of the involved area, but recurrence was not infrequent and complication rates were high.  A minimally invasive (trephination) approach was described by Gip’s in 2008 and has since been widely adopted by many surgeons.  The aim of this study was to explore outcomes of the minimally invasive approach to pilonidal disease by evaluating wound healing and disease recurrence following surgical trephination. 

Methods: A retrospective cohort study of all patients that underwent the trephination (Gip’s) procedure as part of standard of care for the treatment of pilonidal disease from November 1, 2019 to July 31, 2020 was performed.  Patient demographics, individual risk factors, and any previous treatment related to pilonidal disease were identified and recorded.  Post-operative outcome measures included development of a chronic wound, signs of recurrent disease, and need for re-operation.   

Results: In total, 17 patients underwent the trephination procedure as part of standard of care.  The majority of patients were male (53%) and white (65%).  Prior to surgery, 11 (65%) of patients had documented hair in the gluteal cleft and 1 (6%) had a history of trauma to the area.  The mean number of disease episodes prior to surgery was 1.76 (SD 0.17), with the most common symptoms being pain (100%) and drainage (78%).  In the operating room, the mean number of pits excised was 3.82 (SD 1.94) and there were no reported complications or changes in diagnosis.  Following trephination, 8 (47%) patients required at least 1 application of silver nitrate, 3 (18%) underwent a second operation, and only 11 (65%) were ultimately found to be completely healed at the conclusion of the study period. 

Conclusion: The use of the trephination procedure has grown in recent years as surgeons explore less invasive alternatives to the more extensive operations traditionally used to treat pilonidal disease.  Early results for trephination at our institution shows a high rate of post-operative healing complications, leading to frequent office procedures and re-operation.  Given the impact on quality of life for those that are affected, it is important that future research be directed toward discovery of the best practices for treating this challenging disease.

abstract_title: Barriers to Outpatient Care following Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Repair
author_block: C. Tragesser<sup>2</sup>, N. Hafezi<sup>1</sup>, M. Kitsis<sup>3</sup>, T. Markel<sup>1</sup>, B. Gray<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Illinois At Chicago Metropolitan Group Hospitals,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) carries high morbidity and mortality, and survivors commonly have neurodevelopmental, gastrointestinal, and pulmonary sequela requiring multidisciplinary care well beyond the initial repair. We predict that following initial hospitalization for repair, CDH survivors face many barriers to receiving this care.

Methods:  After IRB approval, a retrospective review of all CDH patients who underwent repair at Riley Hospital for Children (RHC) at Indiana University Health from 2010 through 2019 between ages of 0 to 12 years was conducted. CDH survivors’ follow up status was reviewed and all were contacted via phone, mail, and/or email. Each family was asked to complete a survey regarding various aspects of their child’s care, including functional status, quality of life, and barriers to care.

Results: One hundred fourteen patients underwent a CDH repair during this time; 70 were eligible for contact after exclusions (deceased (n=43), age>12 years at repair (n=1)). Of the eligible patients, 33 (47%) were lost to follow up to all providers or pediatric surgery at RHC, while 37 (53%) had either graduated from regular follow-up or continued to follow-up with the necessary providers at RHC. Patients lost to follow-up were as sick as those who maintained follow-up with respect to their CDH study group defect severity type (A-D, p=0.5663) and ECMO requirements (p=0.3533). Seventeen (32%) families completed the survey. Of these, 88% continued to follow up at RHC for at least one healthcare need, seeing an average of 2 specialist providers (range 0 to 7), and 81% of patients’ follow-up needs were coordinated through their primary pediatrician. Of survey responses, common themes to barrier to care were ascertained; Table 1 demonstrates those affected by each barrier. The largest barrier to care was related to the physical distance and time constraints making compliance to follow-up with provider(s) difficult (62.5%), while the next largest barrier was access to a pediatric surgeon for questions and information when there was a perceived issue surrounding the CDH repair (37.5%). One hundred percent of survey responders expressed interest in a multi-disciplinary CDH clinic for their child’s care.

Conclusion: The CDH population is a group of patients with many needs beyond initial repair, but attrition to follow-up after discharge is high. The most common perceived barrier to this care relates to problems with access to care. Multidisciplinary efforts, such as dedicated CDH clinic with a pediatric surgeon and nurse care coordinator, may offer an opportunity to address these barriers.

abstract_title: The Birthday Effect: A Retrospective Analysis of Correlations Between Trauma and Birthdays
author_block: P. S. Tretiakov<sup>1</sup>, E. Tay<sup>1</sup>, C. Barrios<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma, Burns, Critical Care & Acute Care Surgery,Orange, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  In the United States, over 65% of motor vehicle accident (MVA) victims tested positive for commonly abused drugs or alcohol, with a sharp upward trend in mortality occurring at age 21. Studies have also shown a correlation between birthdays and Emergency Department visits. However, there is a lack of studies on the relationship between birthdays and trauma. Similar to previous studies, we hypothesize that alcohol is often associated with birthday celebrations and poor decision-making, which may play a role in increasing injury severity and inhibiting recovery rates.

Methods:  This was a retrospective institutional study using data collected from January 2017 to December 2019. There were 12,044 unique patients over age 18 included. Patients were identified as those admitted within seven days of their birthday (W+), and those who were not (W-). Patients were stratified as young adults (18–30 years old), middle-aged (31–54 years old), older adults (55–70 years old), or elderly adults (71+ years old). Injury Severity Score (ISS) and Length of Stay (LOS) were correlated with Blood Alcohol Content (BAC). All data was analyzed using unpaired, 2-tailed Student’s T-tests, and the results were assessed at a 95% confidence interval. 

Results: In total, 373 patients (3%) were admitted within ±7 days of their birthdate (W+) When comparing mean ISS, BAC, and LOS in the W+ vs W- cohorts overall, no statistically significant differences were found (p=0.10, 0.69, 0.66). When stratified by age, however, the W+ 31–54 age group showed not only a significantly lower mean ISS (p=0.04), but also the highest mean BAC amongst the age strata. Interestingly, female W+ trauma patients had higher BAC levels than average, reaching comparable levels to W+ males (W+ male vs female BAC) than females in general (W+ vs W- female BAC). Mean LOS data reported no statistical differences between W+ and W- cohorts when stratified by age, though patients in the W+ 55–70 age group had the highest mean LOS.  

Conclusion: Patients sustaining alcohol-related trauma near their birthdays demonstrate similar attributes to the general trauma population. However, our data indicated that younger patients had a higher risk of injury severity despite similar alcohol levels across ages. Opportunities remain for targeted programs related to alcohol-related injury awareness. Future studies for effective education and intervention are warranted.

abstract_title: Trends in Traffic-Related Crashes among People Experiencing Homelessness
author_block: M. J. Presser<sup>1</sup>, A. Nwabuo<sup>1</sup>, L. Li<sup>2</sup>, S. Petersen<sup>2</sup>, R. Plevin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Nearly 6,000 American pedestrians are killed annually in traffic crashes, and 140,000 are injured. There were 550,000 people experiencing homelessness (EH) in the US in 2018, and their traffic exposure differs from that of housed pedestrians. We aim to characterize the sociodemographic factors of people EH who sustain traffic crashes and evaluate differences in injury severity and hospital course when compared to housed individuals. 

Methods:  Trauma registry data was obtained from the only level 1 trauma center in a large, urban area from 2008-2016. Sociodemographic and clinical characteristics were compared for traffic crashes involving injured pedestrians or cyclists with and without a fixed address, as a conservative proxy for homelessness. Chi-squared and nonparametric tests were used to analyze 8,765 victims of traffic crashes. 

Results: In total, 6.6% of pedestrian and cyclist traffic crash victims were EH. Compared to housed victims, people EH were older (42 vs. 38, p<0.05), more often male (84% vs. 64%, p<0.05) and Black (23% vs. 10%, p<0.05), had Medicaid coverage (47% vs. 20%, p<0.05) and were injured between midnight and 6:00am (21% vs. 11%, p<0.05). Victims EH were more likely to require the highest-level trauma activation (relative risk 1.6, 95% CI 1.2-2.0); require hospitalization (RR 1.8, CI 1.5-2.1), ICU admission (RR 1.5, CI 1.2-2.0), or surgery (RR 1.8, CI 1.3-2.4); and be discharged to a medical-based transitional facility (RR 6.3, CI 4.9-8.0). Injury severity scores were higher for victims EH (8.4 vs 7.3, p<0.05) as were the lengths of hospital admission (9.7 vs. 4.2 days, p<0.05) and ICU admission (8.2 vs. 6.3 days, p<0.05). Mortality rates did not differ by housing status.

Conclusion: Traffic injuries sustained by people EH were more severe and led to longer hospitalization and ICU stays compared to housed individuals. Furthermore, people EH were likely to require ongoing health services after discharge. Addressing traffic injuries in the homeless population requires a multidisciplinary approach including initiatives to decrease traffic injuries, upstream public health interventions to address homelessness, and coordinated discharge planning to promote recovery after injury in this vulnerable population.

abstract_title: Do Race, Sex, Insurance and Socioeconomic Status Affect Timing and Outcomes of Trauma Treatment?
author_block: P. De Angelis<sup>1</sup>, E. J. Kaufman<sup>2</sup>, M. Narayan<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Winchell<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian Hospital - Weill Cornell Medical College,Division Of Trauma, Burns, Acute And Critical Care,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Division Of Trauma, Surgical Critical Care & Emergency Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Disparities are common in trauma; studies have shown that race, sex, age, socioeconomic and insurance status affect morbidity and mortality after injury. Mechanisms behind such disparities are not fully understood. Differences in outcomes may be due to unconscious bias and/or proven inequalities in imaging, interventions and discharge disposition. Times to diagnosis and definitive treatment are key in trauma care and delays have a crucial impact. In this study we investigate the effects of patient characteristics on timing of transfer from the emergency department (ED) to definitive care (i.e. floor, intensive care unit and operating room); we also explore whether patient factors influence likelihood of admission from the ED, hospital length of stay (LOS) and rates of in-hospital complications and death.

Methods:  Patients ≥18 referred to the trauma service via activation between 1/1/16 and 12/31/18 were recruited retrospectively. Data were abstracted from the institutional trauma registry and via chart review. Outcomes were explored with negative binomial and logistic regressions.

Results: 1219 patients were included; most of them were male (68.5%), white (56.8%) and between 25-50 years of age (41.3%). 12.9% of patients were Black and 9% Asian/Pacific Islander. 13.7% were uninsured. Most presented with Glasgow coma scale score (GCS) ≥13 (88.5%) and injury severity score (ISS) <9 (63.3%), but 14.7% were major traumas (ISS>15). Average hospital LOS was 5 days and mortality was 5.9%. Time to definitive care was not associated with sex, age, race, insurance type, day and/or time of presentation to the ED. Shorter time to transfer was associated with higher activation level (incidence rate ratio (IRR) 0.78, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.64-0.93, p=0.0064), higher ISS (IRR 0.96, 95% CI 0.95-0.97, p<0.0001) and lower GCS (IRR 1.07, 95% CI 1.03-1.11, p=0.0020). Time to definite care was not associated with overall LOS, complication rates and/or in-hospital mortality. Similarly, race, sex and socioeconomic status were not associated with likelihood of admission from the ED, overall LOS, in-hospital mortality or complications. On the other hand, uninsured patients were significantly less likely to be admitted from the ED (odds ratio (OR) 0.29, 95% CI 0.17-0.51, p<0.0001) while being more likely to experience shorter hospital stays (IRR 0.41, 95% CI 0.22-0.78, p=0.0068) and higher death rates (OR 486.62, 95% CI 11.9-19816.76, p=0.0011). As expected, all secondary outcomes were also associated with markers of injury severity.

Conclusion: Insurance status was a major determinant of outcomes; we found no sex, race, age or socioeconomic disparity in timing of transfer to definitive care at least at our single center, perhaps indicating that trauma protocols for the acute management of injury preserves equity. Further investigation on the mechanism of disparities in trauma must investigate processes of care after the initial evaluation.

abstract_title: Outcomes After Transfer of Trauma Patients to Pediatric ICU
author_block: M. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, D. Tamura<sup>1</sup>, S. Castle<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Valley Children's Hospital,Madera, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In transfers of pediatric trauma patients who are likely to require care in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU), there are no formal guidelines for transfer through the trauma bay versus transfer directly to the ICU. Protocols can be widely variable between institutions. The aim of this study is to evaluate if there were differences in mortality between the two groups, and if initial intervention was delayed by care in the ICU after transfer from another institution versus patients who were first evaluated in the trauma bay.

Methods: We analyzed trauma transfers with admission to the PICU from our institution’s trauma registry between January 2016 and December 2018. Demographics and interventions were analyzed using multivariate statistical models, with primary outcome being mortality.

Results: A total of 192 patients were admitted to the ICU, as direct transfers or after evaluation in the trauma bay. Trauma bay patients had a mortality rate of 3.6% (n=4) versus 12.2% (n=10) for direct admits. Mean time to imaging for the direct group was 124.82 minutes (SD=138.03) and for the trauma bay group was 83.51 minutes (SD=155.84, p=0.001). There was no difference in time to imaging (p=0.82) between survivors and non-survivors. Patients with a lower Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score were more likely to be directly admitted (n=9.53, p≤.001) and were also more likely to have died, even when adjusted for other variables. (n=4.0, p<0.001)

Conclusion: Patients who were directly admitted to the ICU saw higher mortality rates, but this may be due to physician bias to transfer non-survivable injuries who would not benefit from operation or additional imaging to the ICU since we did not find any delays to imaging or to intervention. This is supported by our finding that those with a lower GCS were more likely to be directly admitted to the PICU.

abstract_title: Decompressive Craniectomy Outcomes in Stabilized and Non-Stabilized Pediatric TBI Patients
author_block: R. Collins<sup>1</sup>, A. Kopacz<sup>1</sup>, C. Ludwig<sup>1</sup>, P. Presto<sup>1</sup>, W. Lilitwat<sup>1</sup>, L. Nagy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center,Department Of Pediatrics,Lubbock, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is a leading cause of death among the pediatric population and yet does not have a universally accepted treatment protocol. Due to the differences between pediatric and adult cranial distensibility and response to changes in intracranial pressure (ICP), treatment options in adults may not translate to successful treatment of children. According to trauma protocol, Decompressive Craniectomy (DC) is a Tier 3 approach to lowering ICP in pediatric TBI cases. A key factor in outcomes is the time from onset of injury to completion of DC. Moreover, early versus late DC is not well defined and the impact of stabilization prior to DC in the pediatric population is unknown. 

Methods: This is a retrospective chart review of children from 0-18 years of age and a diagnosis of TBI presenting to the Emergency Room (ER) to assess the benefit of stabilization treatments prior to DC and the associated surgical outcomes. Patients with any significant congenital comorbidity (e.g. Chiari malformation), psychiatric diagnosis, and pregnant women were excluded. We compared discharge Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) values, as well as our own defined variable, Outcome at Discharge: death (6), resolution of hematoma and symptomatic (5), behavioral change (4), persistence of hematoma and symptomatic (3), persistence of hematoma and asymptomatic (2), and complete resolution (1). A one-way ANOVA test was used to examine whether the administration of stabilization treatments (ventilation or intubation, ICP monitoring, external ventricular drain, sedatives, 3% saline, muscle relaxants, or ventriculoperitoneal shunt) prior to DC affects the outcome of such patients relative to those who did not receive such treatment. 

Results: 155 patients fit the inclusion criteria: 95 were male (61.3%) and 60 were female (38.7%) with a mean age of 6.35±6.01 and admit GCS of 11.08±5.03. 61 (39.4%) patients underwent DC and, of those, 36 received stabilization treatment and 25 received no stabilization treatment. Within our sample of TBI patients undergoing DC, there was a difference in Outcome at Discharge and discharge GOS between patients receiving pre-surgery stabilization and those who did not receive pre-surgery stabilization (p-value <0.05). Post hoc comparisons using the Tukey HSD test indicated the mean Outcome at Discharge and mean discharge GOS for patients receiving no stabilization treatment (2.33±1.71 and 4.66±0.97, respectively) were significantly different than those who did (3.34±1.80, and 3.74±1.39, respectively).

Conclusion: This information has potential application for all pediatric patients presenting with TBI. For surgical TBI patients, physicians might consider limiting extensive stabilization treatment prior to decompressive craniectomy and instead immediately performing the procedure upon intake in the ER. This data could be useful in establishing an effective standard of care and contribute to better outcomes for pediatric patients who present with TBI.

abstract_title: Circumstances of Suicide Among Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Individuals
author_block: M. Patten<sup>1</sup>, H. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, A. Moore<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Velopulos<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Division Of GI, Trauma, And Endocrine Surgery (GITES),Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Suicide rates for sexual minorities are higher than the heterosexual population, particularly for the young. The purpose of this study is to explore circumstances surrounding suicide completion for identified men and women in these populations as compared to their heterosexual counterparts to inform future intervention strategies for suicide among lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) individuals.

Methods:  We completed an analysis of data from the National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS) from 2013-2017. Victims identified as transgender were considered separately, as this is an important population with unique characteristics. Data was further excluded from state/year combinations when sexual orientation was documented for <20% of patients. We stratified analysis by identified sex of the victim (male or female) for the LGB population.

Results: Of the 16,831 victims whose sexual orientation or transgender status was known, 3886 (23.1%) were identified as female and 12,945 (76.9%) were identified as male. 479 (2.8%) were identified as LGBT; of these, 53 (11%) were transgender. LGBT victims were younger than non-LGBT victims.  Male LGB victims were more likely to have a history of prior suicide attempts, past or current mental illness diagnosis, and were less likely to use firearms than male heterosexual victims.  Female LGB victims were more likely to have known problems in an intimate partner relationship (IPV) than heterosexual women, while LGB men were more likely to have problems in family or other relationships.  Transgender victims were again more likely to have mental health problems and a history of prior attempts, but less likely to have intimate partner problems and more likely to have a history of child abuse (6% vs. 1%, p=0.01).  All LGBT victims were more likely to disclose intent, with female LGB victims most often disclosing to an intimate partner, while male LGB and transgender individuals most likely to disclose to a family member.

Conclusion: Our analysis reveals that circumstances surrounding suicide have important distinctions between LGBT and heterosexual individuals. It is important to note that post-mortem identification of sex presents issues of misgendering, and could contribute to a degree of bias in understanding the way suicide circumstances differ in LGBT individuals, particularly for transgender individuals. These results highlight the importance of promoting suicide interventions that recognize the complex intersection between stated gender, sex, and sexuality and the different cultural impacts these interplaying identities can have, which underscores the importance of being able to identify these patients correctly in the context of large datasets.

abstract_title: Targeting Zero Preventable Trauma Readmissions: A Billion-Dollar Problem
author_block: P. U. Neiman<sup>2,3,4</sup>, C. S. Brown<sup>1,4</sup>, J. R. Montgomery<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Hemmila<sup>1</sup>, N. F. Sangji<sup>1,4</sup>, J. W. Scott<sup>1,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>National Clinical Scholars Program,Institute For Healthcare Policy And Innovation, University Of Michigan,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Michigan,Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Last year, over 2,500 U.S. hospitals were penalized for above average readmission rates under the Affordable Care Act’s Hospital Readmission Reduction Program, which will lead to >$500 million in lost reimbursement from CMS. Our study aims to quantify the Potentially Preventable Readmissions (PPRs) in trauma care to serve as the anchor point for ongoing efforts to curb hospital readmissions and ultimately, bring preventable readmissions to zero.

Methods: We identified inpatient hospitalizations after trauma as well as readmissions within 90 days in the 2017 National Readmissions Database (NRD). PPRs were defined as the AHRQ-defined Ambulatory Care Sensitive Conditions, in addition to superficial surgical site infection, acute kidney injury/acute renal failure, and aspiration pneumonitis. Mean costs for these admissions were calculated using the NRD. A multivariable logistic regression model was utilized to characterize the relationship between payer type (Private, Medicare, Medicaid, Uninsured) and PPR.

Results: 712,008 patients were admitted for trauma care in the 2017 NRD and 102,267 (14.4%) were readmitted within 90 days of discharge. Of these readmissions, 38.8% were potentially preventable. The mean cost was $10,088/PPR, resulting in $1.13 billion in cost to the US healthcare system. Of readmitted trauma patients < 65 years old, Medicaid patients had 3-fold increased odds (OR 2.99, CI 2.78-3.20), and uninsured patients 47% increased odds (OR 1.47, CI 1.30-1.65), of PPRs compared to private insurance patients. Furthermore, as the days from discharge increased, the proportion of readmissions due to PPRs increased (Figure).

Conclusion: Almost 40% of all trauma readmissions are potentially preventable, which account for over $1 billion in healthcare costs. As the days from discharge increase, as do the proportion of readmissions due to potentially preventable conditions. Improved access to post-discharge ambulatory care may be key to minimizing PPRs, especially in the Medicaid and uninsured populations.

abstract_title: Facet Dislocation as a Risk Factor for Worse Outcomes in Patients with Cervical Spinal Cord Injury.
author_block: A. A. Fokin<sup>1,2</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Grady<sup>1,2</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,3</sup>, M. Gomez<sup>3,4,5</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Broward Health North,Trauma Services,Deerfield Beach, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The significance of a facet dislocation in patients with cervical spinal cord injury (CSCI) continues to be debated. The aim of this study was to examine if the presence of a cervical facet dislocation was associated with greater neurological deficit and increased ventilation requirements.

Methods: This IRB-approved retrospective cohort study included 255 CSCI patients with neurological deficit admitted to one of three Level 1 Trauma Centers between 2015 and 2020. There were 56 patients with radiologically-confirmed facet dislocations (FD) compared to 199 patients without facet dislocations (NFD). Analyzed variables included: age, Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for spine, American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) impairment grade, presence of cervical vertebral fracture, formation of paravertebral hematoma, rate of ICU admission, requirement for mechanical ventilation, rate of tracheostomy, and rate of cervical spine surgical intervention.

Results: Facet dislocations were present in 21.9% of CSCI patients with neurological deficits. Patients in the FD and NFD groups were similar in age (55.1 vs 58.4, p=0.3), ISS (23.3 vs 20.3, p=0.1), and GCS (13.4 vs 13.2, p=0.7) rendering them comparable. The distribution of AIS for spine between the two groups was found to be significantly different (p=0.008), with the FD group having more patients with combined critical and maximal AIS spine severity scores (39.3% vs 22.1%). The distribution of ASIA impairment grades between the two groups was also found to be statistically different (p=0.006). Neurological deficit was more pronounced in FD patients, as indicated by a more severe ASIA grade (A and B) and a larger likelihood of developing motor paralysis (41.1% vs 19.6%). Cervical vertebral fractures were significantly more common in the FD group (89.3% vs 45.7%, p<0.001). Paravertebral hematomas developed in 30% of all patients, with 80% of paravertebral hematomas causing spinal cord impingement. Significantly more paravertebral hematomas were found in the FD group (44.6% vs 26.1%, p=0.008). Rate of ICU admission was significantly higher for the FD group (91.1% vs 69.8%, p=0.001), so was the rate of mechanical ventilation (51.8% vs 29.6%, p=0.002), which included tracheostomy (30.4% vs 13.6%, p=0.003) [Fig. 1]. In addition to traction, cervical spine surgery was performed at a significantly higher rate in the FD group (85.7% vs 58.3%, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Facet dislocations occurred in one-fifth of CSCI patients with neurological deficit, and were associated with more severe neurological deficit and a greater need for mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy.

abstract_title: Incidental findings in Trauma: Infrequent Followup and Opportunities for Improvement.
author_block: M. Pahlkotter<sup>1</sup>, J. Bleicher<sup>1</sup>, C. Sciarretta<sup>1</sup>, B. Cowan<sup>1</sup>, E. Earl<sup>1</sup>, M. Mccrum<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Incidental findings are common occurrences on CT imaging for trauma patients, however, data on patient follow-up and clinical outcomes is limited. We aimed to determine the incidence of clinically relevant incidentalomas (CRIs), the rate of documentation, frequency of patient follow-up and subsequent need for intervention.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of all level 1 and 2 trauma patients at a single academic center from 1/2017-12/2019. All patients > 18 years of age with at least one CT scan were included. CRIs were defined as masses with potential for malignancy. Patients with CRIs who were notified during index trauma admission were prospectively surveyed to determine frequency of follow-up and subsequent intervention for CRIs.

Results: 3,464 patients met inclusion criteria, of which 310 patients (9%) had CRIs. Median [IQR] age was 60 [42-73], with 88 (28.4%) residing out-of-state and 115 (37.1%) uninsured. Thyroid (n=71, 22.9%) and pulmonary nodules (n=80, 25.8%) were the most common CRIs. Of these patients, 144 (46%) had documentation that they were notified of the finding. 44 patients with CRIs participated in the phone survey (response rate 30.1%) (Fig 1). 23 (52%) were aware of their CRI, 16 (70%) of whom received the recommended follow-up. 6 patients (37.5%) who followed-up ultimately required surgical intervention, with 4 malignancies identified.

Conclusion: CRIs were identified in 9% of trauma patients at a single level 1 trauma center. Documentation and patient notification were inconsistent and nearly half of patients presumed to be notified were unaware of their findings. Of patients who were aware and completed follow-up, one third ultimately required surgical intervention for a potentially life threatening condition. Efforts to systematize communication with patients and their outpatient follow-up are needed to ensure necessary treatment is received.

abstract_title: Value of Serial MRSA Surveillance Cultures After an Initial Negative Surveillance on SICU Admission
author_block: M. Amick<sup>1</sup>, J. M. O'Marr<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Schuster<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Department Of General Surgery, Trauma & Surgical Critical Care,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Empiric antibiotic coverage for patients in surgical intensive care units (SICUs) typically cover methicillin-resistant staph aureus (MRSA). Nasal surveillance for MRSA upon SICU admission may mitigate against the need to use anti-MRSA antibiotics empirically. This study aims to examine the clinical value of serial MRSA surveillance nasal swabs during a SICU admission. We hypothesized that a negative MRSA swab on admission can effectively exclude a MRSA diagnosis on subsequent surveillance and precludes the need for MRSA coverage when empiric antibiotics are initiated.

Methods:  This retrospective cohort study was conducted at a tertiary-care medical center with 39 SICU beds. For all patients admitted to any of the 3 adult surgical intensive care from 6/1/2014 through 6/1/2019, all results of MRSA nasal surveillance cultures on SICU admission were collected along with weekly MRSA surveillance and clinical cultures during their respective admission. Each patient was reviewed for their initial MRSA surveillance culture at admission and any subsequent MRSA surveillance cultures during their stay in the SICU. Demographic and test outcomes were determined for each group.

Results: 7,269 MRSA surveillance cultures from 6,036 unique individuals were identified. 1,125 (18.64%) unique individuals had two or more MRSA nasal surveillance cultures during a SICU stay over the 5-year period. Of those patients with multiple MRSA surveillance cultures, there were 38 (0.63%) unique patients across 101 tests who had a least one positive test during their SICU stay. Of the patients that tested positive with multiple surveillance cultures during their SICU stay, 13 (0.22%) unique patients were identified who presented with an initial negative MRSA surveillance culture and subsequently tested positive later in the same SICU stay. For these individuals, the mean transition period from negative to positive using MRSA nasal surveillance cultures was found to be 8.8 days (Median: 5.9 days; Range: 0.7 days to 28.3 days).

Conclusion: While current MRSA surveillance guidelines suggest regular cultures, the rate of positive detection following a negative initial MRSA surveillance culture is low, suggesting serial MRSA surveillance swabs may have little clinical value. Further analysis is needed to determine the detection of MRSA in subsequent cultures, done for diagnostic purposes, to fully assess the utility of regular MRSA surveillance cultures.

abstract_title: If At First You Don't Succeed: Trauma Patients Failing Extubation Warrant Thought For Repeat Attempts
author_block: M. D. Trust<sup>1</sup>, S. Roward<sup>1</sup>, P. G. Teixeira<sup>1</sup>, S. Ali<sup>1</sup>, T. Cardenas<sup>1</sup>, B. Coopwood<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Aydelotte<sup>1</sup>, L. Brown<sup>1</sup>, C. V. Brown<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Texas at Austin Dell Medical School,Austin, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Failed extubation in critically ill patients has been associated with poor outcomes.  In critically ill trauma patients who have failed extubation, providers are often faced with the decision of whether to proceed with tracheostomy or attempt extubation again.  The natural history of trauma patients who fail extubation and predictors of subsequent failure have not been well documented. The specific aim of this study was to describe the natural history and patient characteristics of failed extubation in trauma patients, and determine whether tracheostomy or another attempt at extubation is more appropriate. We hypothesized that patients undergoing tracheostomy would have more severe traumatic brain and chest injuries.

Methods:  Adult trauma patients admitted to our urban American College of Surgeons verified Level I trauma center from 2013 to 2019 were identified from the trauma registry.  Patients met inclusion criteria if they had at least one failed extubation during admission, defined as an unplanned intubation within 48 hours of extubation.  Demographics, injury patterns, and outcomes were abstracted from the registry and chart review.  Patients who underwent tracheostomy were compared to those who had subsequent attempts at extubation.  Patients were excluded from the analysis if they transitioned to comfort care and underwent a palliative extubation.  The primary outcomes included mortality, intensive care unit (ICU) length of stay (LOS), ventilator days, and hospital LOS.

Results: The population included 96 patients who failed extubation and met inclusion criteria.  The mean age was 55±18, 70% were male, and 90% were the results of a blunt mechanism.   A total of 56 patients (58%) were ultimately successfully extubated, while 40 patients (42%) underwent a tracheostomy.  There was no statistically significant difference in age, gender, mechanism of injury, admission vital signs, admission Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, Injury Severity Scores, or head and chest Abbreviated Injury Scale scores.  Patients who underwent tracheostomy had a longer ICU length of stay (LOS) (19±8 vs 14±9, p=0.02) and more ventilator days (15±6 vs 11±8, p=0.003).  There was no difference in mortality or hospital length of stay between the two groups.

Conclusion: Although injury patterns typically play a role in decisions regarding tracheostomy, we found no differences in characteristics between patients who underwent tracheostomy versus those who were successfully extubated.  Additional attempts at extubation did not increase mortality, and tracheostomy was associated with longer ICU LOS and ventilator days.  Trauma patients who fail extubation warrant consideration for subsequent attempts at extubation rather than proceeding directly to tracheostomy.

abstract_title: Factors Influencing Replantation of Traumatic Upper Extremity Amputated Digits
author_block: S. Panjwani<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Fazzalari<sup>2</sup>, A. Palesty<sup>2</sup>, M. Cahan<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Surgery,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>St. Mary's Hospital,Surgery,Waterbury, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although upper extremity traumatic digit amputations are not a life threatening injury, they may have a substantial impact on a patient’s dexterity, function and occupation. Digit replantation is the ideal procedure for such injuries under appropriate conditions. We aimed to evaluate the various factors that may affect the surgical management for these patients.

Methods: The National Trauma Data Bank 2007-2016 was queried to identify patients that underwent an upper extremity traumatic single digit/thumb amputation. Patients with severe trauma (ISS≥ 15) were excluded. Patients that underwent either a formal replantation or replantation were evaluated. Patient, injury, socio-economic and institutional characteristics were assessed between groups of patients that underwent formal amputation vs. replantation. Multivariable analysis was performed to identify independent factors affecting odds of replantation vs. formal amputation.

Results: We identified 17,931 patients who suffered an upper extremity traumatic single digit amputation and had either a formal amputation or replantation performed. Majority were finger injuries (81% vs. 19% thumb injuries). Demographic characteristics of the two groups are represented in table 1. Thumb injuries were more commonly replanted (31% vs. 12% finger). Comparing replantation to amputation revealed that the incidence for the former were higher in the Northeast (18% vs. 11%) and West (16% vs. 14%) regions (p<0.0001). Majority of the replantations were performed at university hospitals (77%), hospitals with > 400 beds (83%) and at level 1 trauma centers (85%). On multivariable analysis, having a thumb injury (OR 3.28, p<0.0001), age < 18 years (OR 6.13, p<0.001), having private insurance (OR 1.17, p 0.01), presenting to a hospital in the northeast (OR 1.6, p<0.0001) or west (OR 1.40, p 0.001) US region, level 1 trauma center (OR 1.49, p <0.0001) or a university teaching hospital (OR 1.59, p=0.002) were all independent factors for undergoing a replantation vs. formal amputation.

Conclusion: Replantation is favored for traumatic thumb amputations. Age, insurance status along with institutional characteristics including region impact choice of procedure performed.

abstract_title: Obesity is Associated with Increased Blood Loss in Trauma Patients with Liver Injury
author_block: K. Abdul Jawad<sup>1</sup>, A. Cioci<sup>1</sup>, E. Urrechaga<sup>1</sup>, R. Saberi<sup>1</sup>, G. Gilna<sup>1</sup>, R. Epstein<sup>2</sup>, R. Dudaryk<sup>2</sup>, R. Rattan<sup>1</sup>, G. Pust<sup>1</sup>, K. Gross<sup>1</sup>, N. Namias<sup>1</sup>, D. Yeh<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami,Division Of Trauma & Surgical Critical Care, DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery,Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami,Division Of Trauma Anesthesia, Department Of Anesthesiology,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The association between nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and increased blood loss in elective liver surgery is well-established. We sought to investigate a similar association in liver trauma using obesity as a proxy for NAFLD.

Methods: The American College of Surgeons Trauma Quality Improvement Program (TQIP) database was queried for adults (≥18 years) with liver lacerations. Because NAFLD is not accurately captured by TQIP, we selected obesity as a proxy, as there is a strong link between the two, with step-wise increase in NAFLD with increasing obesity severity. Subjects were divided into 3 groups based on traditional body mass index (BMI, kg/m2) definitions of obesity: underweight (<18.5), non-obese (18.5-29.9), and obese (≥ 30) then stratified by liver Abbreviated Injury Scale (Grade 2-5). Kruskal-Wallis tests were performed for multiple comparisons followed by Dunn’s tests for pairwise analysis to compare transfusion requirements of each pair among the groups using the number of blood units transfused in the first 24 h after admission. Holm-Bonferroni correction was applied for multiple comparisons, and p-values < .05 were considered statistically significant.

Results: 17,953 subjects were included in the study: 3% underweight with mean age of 37±19 years and 48% male, 69% nonobese with mean age of 38±17 years and 67% male, and 28% obese with mean age of 41±16 years and 60% male. For almost every liver injury grade, there were higher red blood cell transfusion requirements in the first 24 h among obese patients compared to both nonobese patients and underweight patients. Corrected p-values are listed in the Table respectively for the group pairwise comparisons: obese vs. underweight and obese vs. non-obese.

Conclusion: In liver trauma, obesity is associated with increased blood transfusion requirements in the first 24 hours. The relationship between obesity and NAFLD raises the possibility that underlying liver disease, not obesity itself, may be a factor associated with increased transfusion requirements. Additional research is needed to study the potential effect of other covariates.

abstract_title: Accurate Preoperative Prediction of Need for Postoperative Intensive Care
author_block: A. Dyas<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Rozeboom<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Bronsert<sup>2,3</sup>, W. Henderson<sup>2,3,4</sup>, K. Colborn<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Lambert-Kerzner<sup>2,4</sup>, K. Hammermeister<sup>2,3,5</sup>, R. McIntyre<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Meguid<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Department Of Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Surgical Outcomes And Applied Research Program,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Adult And Child Center For Health Outcomes Research And Delivery Science,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Department Of Biostatistics And Informatics, School Of Public Health,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Division Of Cardiology, Department Of Medicine,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Accurate estimation of postoperative ICU need could be important in surgical planning during crisis situations such as the COVID-19 pandemic to maximize resource utilization and improve outcomes. Surgical Risk Preoperative Assessment System (SURPAS) uses 8 variables to predict 12 adverse outcomes for >3000 operations in 9 specialties. We sought to determine whether SURPAS can accurately predict postoperative ICU need.

Methods:  This was a retrospective observational analysis of the 2009-2018 American College of Surgeons’ National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database. The 8 variable SURPAS model was compared to a model using all 29 preoperative variables available in the database. The main outcome was “ICUneed,” defined as one or more of the following: cardiac arrest requiring cardiopulmonary resuscitation, unplanned intubation, prolonged postoperative ventilation, septic shock, or in-hospital death. Internal, chronological validation of the SURPAS model was performed, using the years 2009-2017 for development and 2018 for model testing.

Results: A measure of discrimination, c-index (c), and a combined metric of both discrimination and calibration, Brier score (BS), for the eight-variable SURPAS model (c=0.909, BS=0.0151) were close to those of the full 29-variable model (c=0.921, BS=0.0139) representing accurate modeling of the data. The SURPAS c-index and Brier score for the test (c=0.911, BS=0.0121) and training dataset (c=0.909, BS=0.0156) were virtually identical. Calibration as measured by Hosmer-Lemeshow analyses showed excellent calibration of the SURPAS model.

Conclusion: SURPAS accurately predicted postoperative critical care need using only eight variables and could assist in decision-making regarding surgical care during a pandemic such as COVID-19.

abstract_title: A Novel Geospatial Approach for Routine Intrastate System Strengthening in Pediatric Trauma Care
author_block: J. M. Dittman<sup>1</sup>, A. G. Rosenberg<sup>2</sup>, O. S. Lee<sup>1</sup>, F. Yuan<sup>2</sup>, J. H. Haynes<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University,School Of Medicine,Richmond, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>VCU Health,Department Of Surgery,Richmond, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Hospital of Richmond,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Richmond, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Over the last decade, the number of pediatric trauma centers (PTCs) has nearly doubled in the United States. Optimizing timely access to trauma care for all injured children has been and continues to be a core goal for state trauma system leaders. Prior evaluations of pediatric trauma access have been infrequent, requiring proprietary geospatial software and technical expertise. We set forth to determine whether a simple, accessible geospatial approach could achieve similar results while conveying actual injury data to better inform state level systems strengthening efforts and empower more routine analyses.

Methods:  Virginia was utilized as a test state due to its complex population distribution and mature trauma system. Transport boundaries were defined using one hour driving radii from all state designated trauma centers (TCs) versus PTCs which were simultaneously mapped using the Oalley drive-time visualization tool. Coverage in individual localities was applied across 2017 American Community Survey child population estimates and state-provided child injury hospitalization totals, respectively, for children from 0-14 years. Χ2 with Yates correction was used to compare estimates. A geospatial boundary heat map was developed to visualize three components: transport boundaries in relation to facilities, actual injury data by locality, and top quartile localities for ratio of child injury hospitalizations per child census population.

Results: 964,000 (62%) of children living in Virginia in 2017 were estimated to live beyond a one hour drive of a state PTC, 200,000 (13%) of any state trauma center. 1,928 (49%) of children hospitalized for injury in Virginia from 2016-2018 were estimated to live beyond a one hour drive of a state PTC. A geospatial boundary heat map indicated regions farthest from intrastate PTCs, including Northern Virginia, Southern Virginia, and the Eastern Shore, in perspective with annual injury hospitalizations (Figure).

Conclusion: A simple geospatial method produced remarkably similar estimates for pediatric injury access to those published by national studies and was useful to identify localities where pediatric trauma system strengthening could have maximum impact. The geospatial boundary heat map differentiated need areas of high volume, which may support designation of additional facilities or reciprocity agreements, versus low-volume where alternative strategies for critical care access would be required. State leaders should consider this data in conjunction with air transport utilization data, which is readily available to them, and this method could be similarly applied in other states to help monitor access to trauma care in state pediatric populations over time.

abstract_title: Improved Prediction of Older Adult Discharge After Trauma Using a Novel Machine Learning Paradigm
author_block: R. S. Morris<sup>1</sup>, C. Tignanelli<sup>2</sup>, C. Trevino<sup>1</sup>, L. Napolitano<sup>3</sup>, T. Webb<sup>1</sup>, M. De Moya<sup>1</sup>, D. Stein<sup>4</sup>, B. Chen<sup>2</sup>, R. Sparapani<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College of Wisconsin,Trauma,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Minnesota,Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The ability to reliably predict outcomes after older adult trauma (age > 65 years) is critical for clinical decision making, counseling of patients and families and quality benchmarking.  Most clinical predictive models mistakenly assume that outcomes are linear and independent. Using novel machine-learning techniques, we sought to design a non-linear, competing risks paradigm for prediction of older adult discharge disposition and mortality following injury. 

Methods: The National Trauma Databank (NTDB) was used to identify patients 65+ years between 2007 and 2014.  Trauma centers with annual volume > 48.2 patients per year (10%-percentile) were included.   The data was partitioned by stratified random sampling based on Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), such that each stratum contained patients that were effectively independent.  Training was performed on 224 strata (90% of the data) and inference was performed on 26 strata (10%).  Factors included age, co-morbidities, length of stay (LOS) and physiologic parameters to predict in-hospital mortality and discharge disposition (home vs. other).  The training was enriched by reducing the sampling rate of over-represented variables (down-sampling) to develop a predictive model for all patients (not just at the extremes).   LOS and discharge status were analyzed via competing risks survival analysis with Bayesian additive regression trees (BART) and a multinomial mixed model.  The existing Elderly Mortality After Trauma (EMAT) mobile application will be updated to predict discharge disposition.  

Results: The resulting sample size was 47,037 patients.  Emergency department pulse > 120 bpm and systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg were not predictive of death or discharge disposition. Admission GCS, age, year of admission were important in predicting mortality and discharge disposition.  As GCS decreased by 2 points, patients were more likely to die (risk ratio[RR] increased by average of 1.4 per 2-point drop in GCS, p <0.001) and be discharged to a nursing home instead of returning home (RR decreased by 0.08 per 2-point decrease in GCS, p <0.001) see figure 1.  RR for death increased by an average of 0.15 per 5-year increase in age and RR for discharge home decreased by an average 0.05 of per 5-year increase in age over 65 (p <0.001). The AUC for prediction of discharge home was improved in the competing risks model 0.71 vs. 0.43 in the traditional multinomial mixed model.

Conclusion: Predicting discharge home in older adults is improved using machine learning over traditional regression analysis.  Accurate prediction of discharge disposition is an integral tool to bedside shared decision making for older trauma patients and their families, and the updated EMAT mobile application based on this study is now available for use.  We confirmed that a non-linear, competing risks paradigm is required for prediction of older adult discharge disposition following injury.

abstract_title: Increasing Firearm Injury During The Intense Period of the COVID-19 Pandemic: A Hidden Urban Burden
author_block: C. Zhao<sup>1</sup>, H. O. Abdallah<sup>1</sup>, E. Kaufman<sup>2</sup>, J. Hatchimonji<sup>2</sup>, R. A. Swendiman<sup>2</sup>, L. J. Kaplan<sup>2</sup>, M. C. Seamon<sup>2</sup>, W. Schwab<sup>2,3</sup>, J. L. Pascual<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Division Of Traumatology, Surgical Critical Care And Emergency Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Public health measures (lockdown, social distancing) were instituted to reduce SARS-CoV-2 spread. A decrease in total emergency department (ED) volume followed, but the impact on trauma is unknown. We hypothesized that social distancing restrictions increased intentional injuries.

Methods:  Trauma/ED registries revealed adult patient data at an urban, academic, Level I trauma center. We compared injury characteristics 6 weeks pre and 10 weeks post a statewide stay-at-home order (SAHO, 3/16/2020) and compared 2020 to 2015-2019 data.  Demographics, mechanism of injury (MOI), and diagnoses were extracted. Total ED visits during the same time periods were assessed as baseline data. The Fisher exact and Wilcoxon tests were used to compare proportions and means.

Results: 357 and 480 trauma patients presented before and after SAHO, respectively. Groups demonstrated differences in sex (35.6% vs. 27.9% female, p = 0.02), age (47.4 ± 22.1 vs. 42 ± 20.3, p = 0.009), and race (1.4% vs. 2.3% Asian, 63.3% vs. 68.3% Black, 4.8% vs. 7.1% Other, 30.5% vs. 22.3% White, p=0.03). MOI after SAHO demonstrated a decrease in non-intentional trauma and an increase in intentional (GSWs, SWs, assaults) trauma (Fig 1A; p=0.0008) occurring when citywide Covid-19 infection rates increased (Fig 1B). Compared to prior years, 2020 had a significantly greater proportion of intentional violent injury (Fig 2A) and specifically, firearm injury (Fig 2B).  There were no differences in injury severity (7.5 ± 9.1 vs. 7.9 ± 8.8) or mortality (96.1% vs. 96.0% alive) between time periods.

Conclusion: While pandemic-related public health measures reduced ED and unintentional injury volume, they did not reduce intentional trauma. Instead, an increase in urban firearm-related injury occurred. These data suggest that pandemic-related public health measures should also embrace intentional injury prevention and management strategies.

abstract_title: Death Of The Cardiac Box In Contemporary Era Of Ultrasound For Trauma
author_block: B. S. KARAM<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Pearl<sup>1</sup>, A. McCormick<sup>1</sup>, S. Bou Zein Eddine<sup>1</sup>, A. Baskaran<sup>1</sup>, T. W. Carver<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Milia<sup>1</sup>, A. Elegbede<sup>1</sup>, L. Somberg<sup>1</sup>, C. Trevino<sup>1</sup>, M. De Moya<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The cardiac box was historically used to identify patients that required a pericardial window in the setting of a penetrating chest injury. Gunshot wounds (GSW) to the chest have an unpredictable trajectory and even stab wounds outside of the traditional landmarks have been associated with cardiac injury. Given the widespread availability of ultrasound we question whether the cardiac box has any clinical relevance.

Methods: This is a retrospective review of the trauma registry and EMR charts of adult patients with a penetrating thoracic injury admitted to a Level 1 urban trauma center between 2013 and 2017.  Our primary outcome was penetrating cardiac injury requiring intervention. Descriptive statistics and multivariate regression were performed using SPSS.

Results: We identified 634 patients with penetrating thoracic injuries and 265 (42%) had an injury within the cardiac box. Of those, a pericardial window was performed in 17% (45/265) and 8% (20/265) had a cardiac injury. Eighty four percent (16/19) of stab victims versus only 57% (4/7) of gunshot victims with cardiac injury sustained penetrating trauma within the box (Figure 1). Ultrasound (US) was performed in 32% (208/634) of patients with a penetrating thoracic injury and 51% (135/265) of patients with a cardiac box injury. On multivariate regression, the cardiac box was not a significant predictor for cardiac injury due to stab wounds (OR 23.3 [95% CI 0.58-926.4]) or GSWs (OR 3.14 [95% CI 0.48-20.73]). US had a higher sensitivity (83% vs 80%), specificity (93% vs 59%), and positive predictive value (54% vs 8%) than the cardiac box.

Conclusion: The majority of penetrating injuries to the cardiac box do not result in a cardiac injury and a fourth of our cardiac injuries were outside the box. We recommend eliminating the use of a predefined anatomical cardiac boundary and favor US imaging for any penetrating thoracic injury due to its superior diagnostic performance.

abstract_title: Repeat Imaging of Blunt Splenic Injuries by Standard Protocol Identifies Early Complications
author_block: L. L. Perea<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Fletcher<sup>5</sup>, M. E. Morgan<sup>1</sup>, B. W. Otaibi<sup>4</sup>, K. E. Bresz<sup>2</sup>, J. P. Hazelton<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Hospital,Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Lancaster, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Hospital,Research Institute,Lancaster, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Division Of Trauma, Acute Care And Critical Care Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>5</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Institutional variance exists in the management of blunt splenic injuries. Currently, there are no definitive recommendations guiding the utilization or timing of repeat imaging in these patients. This study examines the rate of delayed complications (pseudoaneurysm, increased hemoperitoneum, injury progression, abscess, vascular thrombosis, pancreatic fistula, arteriovenous fistula, delayed contrast extravasation, etc.) and subsequent intervention (operative or interventional radiologic) in patients with blunt splenic injuries who undergo repeat imaging.

Methods: A three-year (2017-2019), retrospective, two-institution study was conducted of adult patients (≥18 years) with blunt splenic injuries. Patients were stratified based on whether repeat imaging was performed, and reason for reimaging: standard protocol (SP) or physician discretion (PD) based on clinical findings. The incidence of organ specific complications and need for subsequent intervention was examined.

Results: Of 235 patients included in the study, 105 (45%) underwent repeat imaging [computed tomography (CT), n=102 or ultrasound (US), n=3]. Thirty-eight (36%) patients underwent imaging due to SP and 67 (64%) due to PD. The mean time to repeat imaging was shorter in the SP group than in the PD group (2.4 ± 1.9 days versus 5.2 ± 4.4 days, p=0.0004). Organ specific delayed complications were found in 18 (47%) SP patients versus 28 (42%) PD patients (p=0.683). Interventions for complications were performed in 10 (56%) SP patients versus 6 (21%) PD patients (p=0.027).

Conclusion: Our data demonstrates that patients with blunt splenic injuries should undergo repeat imaging following a standard protocol to assess for delayed complications. Nearly half of patients with splenic injuries reimaged based on a standard protocol were found to have a complication, with more than half of this group requiring intervention. These complications were identified and treated earlier than complications found on repeat imaging performed due to physician discretion. A standard approach to early repeat imaging of blunt splenic injuries will allow for prompt identification and treatment of delayed complications.

abstract_title: Equity for All: Identifying Barriers to Diversity and Inclusion in Trauma Surgery
author_block: L. Zebib<sup>1</sup>, E. S. Teng<sup>2</sup>, T. L. Zakrison<sup>3</sup>, B. Williams<sup>3</sup>, B. Joseph<sup>12</sup>, H. M. Kaafarani<sup>4</sup>, R. D. Winfield<sup>17</sup>, E. Kiselak<sup>14</sup>, B. Bruns<sup>6</sup>, M. J. Martin<sup>7</sup>, A. C. Bernard<sup>8</sup>, E. R. Haut<sup>9</sup>, A. B. Christmas<sup>13</sup>, J. A. Claridge<sup>2</sup>, C. Sims<sup>11</sup>, D. K. Joseph<sup>10</sup>, J. Weaver<sup>15</sup>, S. Soklaridis<sup>16</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>MetroHealth Medical Center,Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burns, And Emergency General Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Critical Care,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Division Of Trauma, Emergency Surgery, And Surgical Critical Care, Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Maryland Medical School,Prince George's Hospital Center,Cheverly, MD, USA <sup>7</sup>Scripps Mercy Hospital,Department Of Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of Kentucky College of Medicine,Department Of General Surgery,Lexington, KY, USA <sup>9</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>10</sup>NYU Long Island School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Mineola, NY, USA <sup>11</sup>Ohio State University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma, Critical Care And Burn,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>12</sup>University Of Arizona College of Medicine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma, Acute Care, Burn, And Emergency Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA <sup>13</sup>Atrium Health,Department Of Surgery,Charolette, NC, USA <sup>14</sup>Hackensack University Medical Center,Department of Surgery,Hackensack, NJ, USA <sup>15</sup>UC San Diego School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>16</sup>University of Toronto,Department of Psychiatry,Toronto, Ontario, Canada <sup>17</sup>University of Kansas Medical Center,Division Of Acute Care Surgery, Trauma, And Surgical Critical Care,Kansas City, KS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  It is now well established that diversityand inclusion enhance team performance and, in healthcare, can improve patient outcomes. We sought to explore the existing barriers to diversity and inclusion in trauma surgery.?

Methods:  An anonymous, web-based, mixed methods (closed and open-ended questions) survey focused on diversity and inclusion was sent to trauma surgeons identified through the Eastern Association for the Surgery of Trauma (EAST). Qualitative analyses of sub-themes were performed using an inductive, iterative approach. ?

Results: Of 306 (13%) respondents, 193 trauma and Acute Care surgeons (63%) provided narrative answers. Most identified as white, non-Hispanic (72%), male (59%), aged 38-58 (64%), and heterosexual (89%). Qualitative analyses identified 5 barriers to inclusivity: (1)-belief that surgeons must be perceived as tough and aggressive to garner respect; (2)-lack of supportive employee benefits (i.e. parental leave, child care); (3)-difficulty in reporting acts of discrimination/harassment and follow-up; (4)-lack of opportunity to hold discussions on equity and inclusion; and (5)-lack of representation within leadership positions. Participants suggested potential solutions that included improving general awareness about bias, especially implicit bias, and improving recruitment and promotion of women and under-represented groups. ?

Conclusion: We have identified concrete barriers to diversity and inclusion in trauma and acute care surgery. Our report can serve as a framework to establish roadmaps to improve diversity and inclusion in our field. ?

abstract_title: Variation in Prehospital Tranexamic Acid Administration Patterns Across Trauma and Non-Trauma Centers
author_block: T. J. Martin<sup>1</sup>, A. H. Stephen<sup>1</sup>, S. N. Lueckel<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Adams<sup>1</sup>, T. Kheirbek<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brown University School Of Medicine,Division Of Trauma And Critical Care, Department Of Surgery,Providence, RI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In many trauma systems, patient handoff may be the only opportunity for constructive feedback and relationship building between emergency medical services (EMS) personnel and trauma surgeons. The degree to which exposure of EMS personnel to high-performing trauma centers (TC) vs non-trauma centers (NTC) translates into meaningful difference in prehospital quality of care and patient outcomes remains unknown. We aimed to examine these relationships through characterizing prehospital tranexamic acid (TXA) administration patterns.

Methods: The National Emergency Medical Services Information System (NEMSIS) 2017 dataset was queried for all injured adult patients who were transported either to a TC or NTC. Demographics of patients, geographic differences, physiologic parameters, and TXA administration were compared between the two groups. We used alpha of 0.05 for statistical significance.

Results: Of 390,000 adult trauma patients identified, 90% were transported to TC, 3.7% to level I TC, 47.6% were male, 84.5% were from urban settings, 5.5% had a shock index (SI)>1, 2.4% had at least one episode of hypotension, and 2.1% were transported by air (TC 8.9% vs NTC 1.4%, p<0.001). Patients who were transported to a TC were relatively younger (51.7 ± 22.5 vs 57.8 ± 22.9, p<0.001), had higher rate of at least one episode hypotension (4.6% vs 2.2%, p<0.001) and higher rate of having SI>1 (9.2% vs 4.9%, p<0.001). TXA was more likely to be given en route to TC vs NTC (0.2% vs 0.03%, p<0.001, OR 5.8, 95%CI: 4.3-7.8). There were significantly higher rates of administering TXA for patients transported to TC who were hypotensive (1.43% vs 0.46%, p<0.001), had SI>1 (2.56% vs 0.92%, p<0.001), or were transported by air (8.8% vs 0.33%, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Prehospital administration of TXA remained very low overall in our sample, and as expected, was concentrated among young, male, trauma patients transported directly to a TC. While this is likely a function of urban setting and indication for direct transport, it is important to note that significant variation in prehospital protocols and TXA availability also bias against use in rural systems without a local TC. Further work should investigate methods to optimize feedback between trauma surgery and EMS personnel - especially within rural systems - to maximize quality of care and increase rates of appropriate interventions in the field.

abstract_title: Pediatric Liver Injury Mortality is Equivalent Amongst Pennsylvania Trauma Centers
author_block: O. R. Pulido<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Morgan<sup>2</sup>, E. Bradburn<sup>2</sup>, L. L. Perea<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Hospital,Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Lancaster, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pediatric trauma patients who sustain solid organ injury receive non-operative management (NOM) in the setting of hemodynamic stability. It has been shown that pediatric patients have higher success with NOM at pediatric trauma centers (PTC). We sought to evaluate the differences in outcomes of pediatric trauma patients with liver injuries. We hypothesized that there would be no difference in mortality between adult trauma centers (ATC) and PTC.

Methods: The Pennsylvania Trauma Outcome Study database was retrospectively queried from 2003-2018 for all pediatric patients (<15y) who sustained liver injury defined by ICD9/10 codes. Patients transferred in/out were excluded. Patients were categorized based on admission to PTC/ATC. Primary endpoint was mortality with secondary endpoints being operative intervention and length of stay (LOS). Multivariate logistic regressions controlling for demographic and injury covariates assessed the adjusted impact on mortality and surgical intervention.

Results: There were 1600 patients who suffered liver trauma, 608 met inclusion criteria. 78.4% were treated at PTC. Characteristics of patients are in Table 1. Patients underwent hepatobiliary surgery more frequently at ATC [11.45% (n=15) vs. 3.14% (n=15), p<0.001]. Adjusted analysis showed that while abdominal surgery was not different (AOR 2.66, p=0.395), there were lower odds of surgical intervention for hepatobiliary injuries at PTC (AOR: 0.20, p=0.027). There was no decrease in mortality at PTC compared to ATC (AOR: 0.30, p=0.064).

Conclusion: Pediatric trauma patients cared for at ATC have no difference in mortality rate, but, have higher incidence of operative management specifically for hepatobiliary injuries, when compared to PTC. Given these findings, this study demonstrates that pediatric trauma patients who present with liver injuries can be successfully managed at ATC with decreased LOS.

abstract_title: Optimizing Opioid Prescribing in Trauma Patients: A Quasi-Experimental Study
author_block: W. J. Peppard<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Karam<sup>1</sup>, A. Elegbede<sup>1</sup>, C. Trevino<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is well established that patients prescribed higher opioid dosages are at a higher risk of overdose and death despite achieving no added long-term pain reduction. Yet increases in opioid prescribing continue to fuel the epidemic in the US. We hypothesized that implementing a comprehensive guideline to standardize opioid prescribing would decrease the dosages prescribed at discharge for trauma patients.

Methods: This quasi-experimental study compared opioid prescribing by trauma providers before and after the implementation of a departmental guideline on April 1, 2019, aimed at aligning opioid prescription patterns with CDC recommendations. Patients prescribed opioids between April and December 2018 were assigned to the control group, whereas those prescribed opioids between April and December 2019 were assigned to the intervention group. Our primary outcome was the proportion of patients receiving ≥ 50 Morphine Milligram Equivalents (MME) per day. A subgroup analysis of patients age ≥ 64 years was performed. Chi squared and Mann-Whitney U test were used to compare the two groups.

Results: We identified 560 and 535 trauma patients in the control and intervention group, respectively. Total MME and maximum MME per day were 7% and 50% lower, respectively, in the intervention group as compared to the control group (p<0.001). The proportion of trauma patients prescribed ≥ 50 MMEs per day decreased from 66% to 22% after policy implementation (p<0.001). The proportion of trauma patients prescribed ≥ 90 MMEs per day also decreased, from 53% to 18% (p<0.001). The median supply of opioids increased from 3 to 3.3 days over the same period (p=0.004). There was no change in the proportion of patients receiving a supply of > 7 days (Table 1). Lower total MME, maximum MME, and proportion of trauma patients prescribed ≥ 50 and ≥ 90 MMEs per day was again seen in the subgroup of patients ≥ 64 years old.

Conclusion: A departmental guideline aimed at optimizing opioid prescription patterns is successful in lowering the amount of MMEs prescribed to trauma patients and thereby improving compliance with CDC best practice recommendations.

abstract_title: Graft and Patient Survival after A2-incompatible Donor Kidney Transplantation
author_block: S. Bisen<sup>1</sup>, S. Getsin<sup>1</sup>, T. Chiang<sup>1</sup>, S. Yu<sup>1</sup>, K. Jackson<sup>1</sup>, D. Segev<sup>1</sup>, A. Massie<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: ABO type B and O recipients have increased difficulty identifying a compatible donor for living donor kidney transplantation. They are also harder to match in incompatible kidney transplantation (IKT) registries due to a shortage of ABO-compatible donors. The Kidney Allocation System (KAS), implemented in 2014, increased offers of ABO type A2 donor kidneys to type O and B recipients, and A2B to B recipients (A2i). To better inform the living donor selection process and ensure the safety of patients, we sought to evaluate the association between A2i deceased donor kidney transplantation (DDKT) or A2i living donor kidney transplantation (LDKT) and graft and patient survival.  

Methods: Using SRTR data from 2000-2019, we identified adult, first-time kidney transplant recipients with blood type O or B who underwent ABO-compatible or A2i DDKT, or ABO-compatible or A2i LDKT. Inverse probability weighted Cox regression was used to compare post-transplantation mortality, all-cause graft failure, and death-censored graft failure between A2i and compatible recipients.  

Results: We identified 1232 DDKT recipients and 345 LDKT recipients reported as A2i. Patient mortality was comparable between A2i and compatible DDKT recipients (wHR 0.710.931.21, p=0.6). There was no evidence of a difference between A2i versus compatible DDKT recipients with regards to all-cause graft failure (wHR 0.881.111.40, p=0.4) and death-censored graft failure (wHR 0.931.241.66, p=0.14). When comparing A2i versus compatible LDKT recipients, there was no difference in weighted post-transplant survival (wHR 0.801.061.39, p=0.7). When death was regarded as graft failure (all-cause), the weighted hazard ratio of graft failure was 1.051.351.73 (p=0.02), when comparing A2i to compatible LDKT recipients. When death was regarded as censorship rather than graft failure (death-censored), the weighted hazard ratio was 1.241.712.36 (p=0.001), meaning that the hazard of death-censored graft failure was 1.71 times higher in A2i LDKT recipients than compatible LDKT recipients.   

Conclusion: There is no evidence of harm resulting from prioritizing A2i DDKT in the KAS era. There is, however, some evidence of harm resulting from prioritizing A2i LDKT in the KAS era with regards to death-censored graft failure.

abstract_title: Outcomes for pediatric living donor liver transplantation: a systematic review and meta-analysis
author_block: A. Barbetta<sup>1</sup>, S. Barhouma<sup>4</sup>, C. M. Butler<sup>4</sup>, R. Hogen<sup>1</sup>, H. Schillperoort<sup>2</sup>, Y. K. Kwon<sup>1</sup>, R. Kohli<sup>3</sup>, J. Emamaullee<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Southern California,Surgery/ Abdominal Transplant Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California,Information Services/Nursing Liaison Librarian,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Gastroenterology, Hepatology And Nutrition,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Southern California,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Liver transplantation (LT) is a life-saving treatment for children with end-stage liver disease. Technical variant donation including split liver transplantation, reduced size and living donor liver transplantation (LDLT) have increasingly been used to meet deceased organ shortage. Single institution and national registry studies have shown that pediatric LDLT decreases waitlist mortality and offers superior post-transplant survival when compared to deceased donor liver transplantation (DDLT). In this study, outcomes for pediatric LDLT and DDLT were evaluated through a systematic literature review and meta-analysis.

Methods:  A systematic literature search was performed on December 2, 2019 in PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library, Web of Science, Clinicaltrials.gov, and Google Scholar to identify studies reporting outcomes of pediatric recipient (<18 year) LDLT and DDLT published between 2005 and 2019. Studies including adult patients, multi-organ/re-transplant recipients, or those with overlapping cohorts were excluded. Perioperative and survival outcomes of pediatric-LDLT recipients were pooled and compared to those underwent pediatric-DDLT using fixed- and random-effects models. 

Results: Overall, 2518 abstract were screened, from which 11 studies were identified and included in this analysis. In total, 1704 pediatric LDLT and 6351 pediatric DDLT patients were examined. LDLT recipients had superior overall survival when compared to DDLT recipients at 1, 3, and 5 years post-LT [ 1-year OS, OR 0.52, CI 95% 0.34-0.80, =0.003; 3-year OS, OR 0.56, 95% CI 0.35-0.90, p= 0.02; 5 years OS, OR: 0.54 CI 95% 0.4-0.72, p<0.0001] (Figure 1). Similarly, LDLT resulted in superior graft survival at 1-, 3- and 5-year post-LT when compared to DDLT [ 1-year graft survival, OR :0.38 CI 95% 0.29-0.50, p<0.0001]. Paradoxically, LDLT was associated higher PELD at LT. There was no difference in the rate of post-LT vascular complications, biliary complications, or rates of acute rejection.

Conclusion: In this comprehensive, global meta-analysis, LDLT was associated with higher rates of graft and patient survival post-transplant for children at all time points assessed, without any observed difference in rate of technical complications. These data support the continued expansion of LDLT for pediatric LT candidates, even in regions where DDLT is currently predominant.

abstract_title: Efficacy of HOPE: Analysis of Quality HIV+ Deceased Donor Organ Availability
author_block: G. E. Owens<sup>1,3</sup>, B. Shelton<sup>1</sup>, P. MacLennan<sup>1</sup>, D. Sawinski<sup>2</sup>, J. Locke<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Virginia,Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Because of the effectiveness of HIV treatment, people living with HIV (PLWH) live longer and develop age related chronic kidney and liver diseases requiring transplantation. PLWH, however, are less likely to achieve transplantation. In 2013, the HIV Organ Policy Equity Act (HOPE) amended the National Organ Transplant Act to allow PLWH to be organ donors. Studies related to the efficacy of HOPE vary widely as to the number of potential organs available. The purpose of this study is to analyze data on a national scale, while taking into account organ quality in order to understand the number of organs actually available for HIV+ to HIV+ transplant.
