Methods: Using data collected at Center for AIDS Research Network of Integrated Systems (CNICS) centers (1995 – 2018), 6,223 deaths (potential deceased organ donors) among PLWH were identified. 1,137 were excluded due to cancer diagnosis. The remaining 5,086 were studied to assess organ quality/suitability. Potential deceased organ donors were further characterized as high (viral load > 200 copies/mL and CD4 < 200 cells/mm3) or low (viral load <  200 copies/mL and CD4 > 200 cells/mm3) risk for transmission of resistant virus. Kidney quality was assessed using the Kidney Donor Profile Index (KDPI) with a KDPI > 85 indicating poor quality. Liver viability was assessed via Fibrosis-4 (FIB-4) score, which measures AST, ALT, platelet count, and age, with a FIB-4 score > 3.25 indicating severe cirrhosis rendering the donor liver not suitable for transplantation.

Results: In 1995, 100% of PLWH were considered high risk compared to just 42% in 2017 [figure]. 3,907 potential donors were high risk. Among low risk potential donors, 605 (9.72%) had a KDPI < 85, suggestive of high quality kidneys for transplant, and 967 (15.54%) had minimal (FIB-4 < 1.45) to moderate cirrhosis (FIB-4 1.45-3.25), suggestive of high quality livers for transplant. Importantly, 316 (32.7%) of potential liver donors were coinfected with hepatitis C.

Conclusion: Since the introduction of antiretrovirals in the 1990’s, HIV care is increasingly more accessible, targeted, and effective, and thus, over time fewer potential donors were high risk. During the 23 years covered by this study, only 25% of deaths occurred among low risk PLWH with laboratory and clinical features suggestive of high quality, transplantable organs.

abstract_title: UMOD Variants Are Associated With Increased Odds Of CKD Development Among Persons Living With HIV
author_block: A. Aluri<sup>1</sup>, H. Fatima<sup>1</sup>, B. Shelton<sup>1</sup>, V. Kumar<sup>1</sup>, J. Locke<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,College Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the advent of anti-retroviral therapy, people living with the human immunodeficiency virus (PLWH) have improved life expectancy. As a result, PLWH have developed age-related illnesses such as chronic kidney disease (CKD). Of the 1.1 million PLWH in the United States as many as 30% of them have CKD. In fact, overlying CKD on a complex condition such as HIV infection may lead to worse outcomes among PLWH. Multiple risk factors for CKD development have been identified, including genetic risk factors. While APOL1 has been well-studied in this population, UMOD, a gene located on chromosome 16, also associates with CKD in the general population but has not yet been studied among PLWH. As such, we examined the association of UMOD variants with CKD development and characterized the histologic findings of CKD among PLWH.

Methods: PLWH enrolled in CNICS were genotyped using expanded Illumina Multi-Ethnic Genotyping Array. SNPs were excluded from analysis if the call rate was <98%, discordant in >1 duplicate, missing in > 10% of samples, and/or had a Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium P-value ≤1x10-5.  We selected variants +/- 250 kb from the UMOD gene and conducted logistic regression to assess the association between each SNP and CKD development. Each model was also adjusted for age at study entry, sex, genetic ancestry, and follow-up time and was stratified by self-reported race. The effects within each race were meta-analyzed using METAL to generate one summary association. Biopsy images were read by a central pathologist.

Results: The strongest association among African Americans was at 16:20353435 with a risk allele frequency of 2.3% and conferring 2-fold higher odds of CKD development as compared to those with no variants at that location (aOR: 2.06, 95% C: 1.22-3.48, p=0.007). Among European Whites, the strongest association was at rs76621572, 16:20384729, which had a risk allele frequency of 2.2% and conferred 3-fold higher odds of CKD development as compared to those with no variants at that location (aOR: 2.98, 95% CI: 1.32-6.73, p=0.009).  After meta-analysis the strongest overall measure was located at 16:2035343 with a risk allele frequency of 0.8%. This variant conferred 2-fold higher odds of CKD development as compared to those with no variants (aOR: 2.06, 95% CI: 1.22-3.48, p=0.006).

Conclusion: Some SNP variants within the uromodulin gene have a significant association with CKD development among PLWH. However, top SNP variants differ in risk allele frequency and effect size between African-Americans and European Whites. Variants at 16:20353435 and 16:20384729 were most strongly associated with CKD among  African-Americans and European Whites, respectively. Further analysis of biopsies from patients with these variants are needed to determine the mechanism by which increased risk is conferred, specifically among PLWH.

abstract_title: Characterization of Retransplantation following Graft Failure due to BK Virus Nephropathy
author_block: K. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, H. Curtis<sup>1</sup>, H. Resweber<sup>1</sup>, J. Panichella<sup>1</sup>, A. Di Carlo<sup>1</sup>, S. Karhadkar<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Temple University,Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Following kidney transplantation, immunosuppressive regiments that aim to prevent allograft rejection may simultaneously leave the patient susceptible to opportunistic infections, including the reactivation of BK polyomavirus (BKV). Although BKV Nephropathy (BKVN) was first characterized nearly fifty years ago and has since been frequently implicated in the failure kidney allografts, there is still inadequate understanding of the disease and a lack of effective therapies. For patients whose grafts fail due to BKVN, retransplantation is a viable option. This study further characterizes BK nephropathy and subsequent retransplantation in the most expansive population of this type studied to date, geographically, temporally, and in magnitude.

Methods: The OPTN/UNOS database was used to identify patients who received kidney or kidney-pancreas transplantations between October 1, 1987 and December 31, 2018 that resulted in renal allograft failure attributed to BKVN (n=1587). This population was further divided into those who underwent kidney retransplantation (n=495) and those who did not (n=1092). Subject characteristics were summarized using means and standard deviations or frequencies and percentages, as applicable. Significance between groups was determined by independent samples t-tests and χ2 tests (α = 0.05.). Death-censored graft survival for various subgroups was estimated using Kaplan-Meier with Log-Rank to assess significance. All analysis was completed using SPSS Statistics 26.

Results: The cohort that was retransplanted after BKVN failure was significantly younger and had fewer prior kidney transplants, lower EPTS scores at failure, lower rates of delayed graft function and a greater proportion of living donors when compared to those who were not retransplanted. Allograft lifespan prior to BKVN failure was significantly greater in the population that was retransplanted than the population that was not. Among retransplants, delayed graft function or high KDPI significantly decreased allograft lifespan. The retransplanted allografts lasted significantly longer than the original grafts that had failed due to BKVN. Use of steroids for induction was found to not have a significant impact on graft survival when compared to a steroid-free regiment.

Conclusion: This study assessed trends in and characteristics of successful retransplantation after BKVN-associated graft failure, using the largest population of this type to date. Results may be used to both govern the treatment of patients who lose grafts to BKVN and reinforce the viability of retransplantation following BKVN-associated graft failure.

abstract_title: Effect of Affordable Care Act Implementation on Kidney Transplant Waiting List Makeup and Outcomes
author_block: M. L. Samoylova<sup>1</sup>, B. I. Shaw<sup>1</sup>, T. Risoli<sup>2</sup>, S. Peksoe<sup>2</sup>, V. Wang<sup>3</sup>, L. McElroy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Abdominal Transplant Surgery,Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Duke University,Biostatistics & Bioinformatics,Durham, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Medicine, Population Health Sciences,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) was enacted in 2010 and aimed to extend health insurance coverage to all Americans. Preliminary data indicate that the ACA has expanded insurance coverage and healthcare access, but has not necessarily improved disparities in access to subspecialty care. In this study, we aim to evaluate the effect of ACA implementation on payor demographics and outcomes for patients listed for kidney transplantation.

Methods: Data for all adult patients registered for the kidney transplant waiting list in the United States between 2007 and 2018 were abstracted from the Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients. For patients with multiple records, the first listing in the timeframe was used for analysis. Summary statistics for waiting list registrants and recipients were tabulated by era, defined as 2007-2010, 2011-2014, 2015-2018. We then performed multivariable competing risks time-to-event regression to estimate cause-specific hazard ratios of transplant and death or delisting on the waiting list to evaluate the effect of payor on waiting list outcomes over time.

Results: A total of 345,073 patients met the inclusion criteria. Compared to pre-ACA, the proportion of Asian and Hispanic patients on the waiting list increased over time (6.0, 6.9, 7.5% Asian per era, 16.4, 17.6, 19.1% Hispanic per era). Age at listing and BMI increased over time, while the proportion of patients on dialysis at time of registration decreased. The proportion of patients with Medicaid listed as their primary insurance increased from 7.4% to 7.8% and 9.8% over time, while the proportion of patients with private insurance remained relatively unchanged. Payor distribution and outcomes over time are listed in Table 1. Compared with the privately insured, waitlisted patients with Medicaid had an increased risk of death or delisting (Cause Specific HR 1.12 [1.09, 1.15], p<0.0001) and a lower likelihood of transplant. This trend persisted over time.

Conclusion: Despite its stated goals, the passage of the ACA in 2010 led to only a modest increase in the proportion of patients on the kidney transplant waiting list who received their insurance primarily through the Medicaid expansion. This effect is likely attenuated by variable implementation at the state level. Furthermore, disparities persist in the outcomes of Medicaid patients on the kidney transplant waiting list. Our further work will focus on understanding patterns of inactivation/delisting and outcomes of transplantation among Medicaid patients.

abstract_title: Fine Particulate Matter and Post-transplant Outcomes among Kidney Transplant Recipients
author_block: Y. Feng<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Jones<sup>2</sup>, N. M. Chu<sup>1,2</sup>, D. L. Segev<sup>1,2</sup>, M. A. McAdams-DeMarco<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg School of Public Health,Department Of Epidemiology,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) induces systemic inflammation, a well-recognized risk factor for cardiovascular disease and mortality in the general population and allograft dysfunction and mortality among kidney transplant recipients. Therefore, we hypothesize that air pollution is associated with adverse post-kidney transplant mortality and graft failure. Therefore, we sought to investigate the association between PM2.5 and these post-transplant outcomes among kidney transplant recipients.

Methods: Kidney transplant recipients who received transplantation between January 1st 2010 and December 31st 2016 were identified from the national registry of transplant recipients (Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients). PM2.5 concentrations for 2010-2016 were obtained from NASA’s SEDAC Global Annual PM2.5 Grids. Annual PM2.5 concentration at the year of transplantation was estimated at each recipient’s ZIP code. We accounted for demographics, socioeconomic status, recipient health factors, and transplant factors and estimated adjusted hazard ratios (95% confidence intervals [CI]) for all-cause mortality and death-censored graft failure (DCGF) using Cox proportional hazards regression with inverse probability weights.

Results: Among 96,109 kidney transplant recipients included in our study, the median age at transplant was 53, 37,435 (39.0%) were female and 45,772 (47.6%) were non-Hispanic White. At the end of follow-up, 14,260 recipients died and 2,395 recipients experienced DCGF. The median ZIP-code level PM2.5 concentration was 9.14 µg/m3 (IQR 7.56-10.69). After kidney transplant recipients living in areas with highest quartile of PM2.5 concentration (PM2.5≥ 10.69 µg/m3) had 1.09-fold (95%CI 1.02-1.15) higher mortality and 1.08-fold (95%CI 1.00-1.17) higher risk for DCGF when compared to their counterparts living in areas with lowest quartile of PM2.5 (PM2.5<7.56 µg/m3). PM2.5 associated mortality was highest among recipients with cold ischemia time >24hr (HR=1.18, 95%CI 1.02-1.35) while associated risk for DCGF was highest among recipients who received kidney from a donor with history of smoking>20 pack-years (HR=1.19, 95%CI 1.01-1.41).  

Conclusion: In this population of kidney transplant recipients, exposure to PM2.5 (≥10.69μg/m3), which is below the current Environmental Protection Agency standard for PM2.5 of 12μg/m3, is associated with an increased risk for mortality and DCGF. These findings imply the potential need for a lower standard for PM2.5 among the vulnerable population like kidney transplant recipients.

abstract_title: Ambient Air Pollution and Adverse Waitlist Events Among Lung Transplant Candidates
author_block: A. Hallett<sup>1</sup>, Y. Feng<sup>1</sup>, M. Jones<sup>2</sup>, E. Bush<sup>1</sup>, C. Merlo<sup>3</sup>, D. Segev<sup>1,2</sup>, M. McAdams-Demarco<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg School of Public Health,Department Of Epidemiology,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Pulmonary And Critical Care,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Air pollution has been repeatedly associated with cardiopulmonary disease and death in the general population. Among common pollutants, fine particulate matter (PM2.5) is particularly harmful due to its ability to penetrate deeply into areas of gas exchange within the lungs. PM2.5 exposure has been associated with clinical declines in persons with pre-existing pulmonary diseases, including the four most common indications for lung transplant (LT). LT candidates are particularly vulnerable to cardiopulmonary insult and experience mortality rates as high as 121.8 deaths per 100 waitlist-years. For those living in heavily affected areas, PM2.5 exposure may pose a barrier to achieving transplantation by increasing the risk of clinical decline and death. Here we seek to investigate the association between PM2.5 exposure and adverse waitlist events among LT candidates.

Methods: Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients data were used to identify LT candidates listed between 1/1/2010-12/31/2016. Annual PM2.5 concentration at year of listing was estimated for each candidate’s ZIP Code using NASA’s Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center Global Annual PM2.5 Grids. We estimated crude and adjusted hazard ratios for adverse waitlist events, defined as death or removal, using Cox proportional hazards regression. Potential covariates that were adjusted for included age at listing, sex, race, education, insurance, smoking status, blood type, and lung allocation score (LAS). The impact on demographic and clinically relevant subgroups was also explored.

Results: Of the 15,075 included candidates, median age at listing was 60, 43.8% were female and 81.7% were non-Hispanic white. Median ZIP Code PM2.5 concentration was 8.95µg/m3. When compared to those who were living in ZIP Codes with lower PM2.5 exposure (PM2.5 <10.53µg/m3), candidates living in ZIP Codes in the highest quartile of PM2.5 exposure (≥10.53µg/m3) had a 1.15-fold (95%CI 1.02-1.30) risk of waitlist mortality and a 1.17-fold (95%CI 1.01-1.36) risk of waitlist removal due to clinical deterioration. Higher PM2.5 associated risk of adverse waitlist events was observed among candidates with LAS≥45 (HR=1.45, 95%CI 1.18-1.77, pinteraction = 0.006).

Conclusion: Elevated ambient PM2.5 concentration was associated with an increase in adverse waitlist events among LT candidates. The association between PM2.5 concentration and adverse outcomes was strongest among persons with more severe lung disease as evidenced by LAS≥45. These results suggest that elevated exposure to PM2.5 reduces the likelihood of transplant among LT candidates, particularly among those with the most severe disease at the time of listing.

abstract_title: Standardizing Discharge Opioid Prescriptions in Kidney Transplant Patients Decreases Opioid Usage
author_block: M. E. Schwab<sup>1</sup>, H. J. Braun<sup>1</sup>, D. Quan<sup>1</sup>, N. Budanova<sup>1</sup>, M. Chavez<sup>1</sup>, K. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, N. L. Ascher<sup>1</sup>, R. Hirose<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Transplantation,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients are overprescribed opioids after surgery; this contributes to opioid misuse and diversion. Kidney transplant recipients are prescribed excess opioids at discharge relative to their inpatient opioid requirements, and recipients who continue to fill prescriptions after transplant have an increased risk of death and graft loss. This study sought to examine the impact of a protocol that standardized discharge opioid prescriptions on discharge opioid amounts and outpatient refills in kidney transplant recipients.

Methods: A discharge protocol was established at a high-volume transplant center: providers were asked to prescribe 0 pills to patients who required no opioids on the day prior to discharge, and 10 pills to those who required any opioids on the day prior. Chronic opioid users (n=44) were excluded. A retrospective chart review of recipients (March 2019-June 2020) was performed for demographic data, oral morphine equivalents (OME) on the day prior to discharge and at discharge, and outpatient refills. These data (Group 3) were compared to a historical cohort (Group 1), and a cohort who underwent a different opioid-reducing protocol (removal of patient-controlled analgesia pumps) (Group 2). Demographics were compared using descriptive statistics. Multivariable linear regression was used to evaluate predictors of OME at discharge. A subset of patients was surveyed at their first post-operative visit about their experience of pain.

Results: 270 recipients were included: 80 in Group 1, 96 in Group 2, 94 in Group 3. With the protocol, there was a significant decrease in OME at discharge (mean 87.2 in Group 1, 62.8 in Group 2, 26.6 in Group 3, p<0.001). The number of patients discharged on no opioids increased from 23.8% in Group 1, 37.5% in Group 2, to 60.6% in Group 3 (p<0.001). OME on the day prior to discharge did not significantly change. Lidocaine patch and acetaminophen use increased significantly (p<0.001). Being a patient in Group 3, of Asian descent, and lower OME on the day of discharge were factors significantly associated with decreased OME at discharge. Length of stay was not a predictor. Twelve percent of Group 2 and 2% of Group 3 patients received an outpatient opioid refill (p=0.02). Forty-two patients were surveyed: 88.1% agreed that they had been educated about the risks of opioids preoperatively; 82.9% reported their pain was as expected or better during their hospital stay; 90.5% said their pain was as expected or better after discharge.

Conclusion: An opioid reduction protocol targeting discharge opioids dramatically reduced the amount of opioids prescribed; most patients received no opioids at discharge after the intervention. Non-opioid adjunct use increased, and outpatient opioid refills decreased. Patients felt appropriately educated and counselled regarding their pain. We recommend standardizing opioids at discharge in kidney transplant recipients, with the goal of not prescribing any opioids.

abstract_title: Comparing the Inpatient Trajectory of COVID-19 Patients with and Without Solid Organ Transplant
author_block: T. Chiang<sup>1</sup>, R. K. Avery<sup>2</sup>, K. A. Marr<sup>2</sup>, D. B. Ostrander<sup>2</sup>, J. Garonzik-Wang<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Segev<sup>1,3</sup>, A. B. Massie<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health,Department Of Epidemiology,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Immunosuppression and comorbidities may place solid organ transplant (SOT) recipients hospitalized for COVID-19 at higher risk for adverse outcomes compared to other hospitalized COVID-19 patients, but actual degree of risk remains controversial.

Methods:  From a large single-center registry, we compared 25 SOT vs 1718 non-SOT patients with valid COVID-19 diagnosis admitted 3/1/20-6/17/20. SOT status was identified through inpatient diagnosis records. We compared hospital length-of-stay (time to discharge) and inpatient mortality using Fine/Gray competing risks regression. We compared trajectories of the WHO ordinal COVID-19 severity scale between SOT vs non-SOT using mixed-effects ordinal logistic regression, adjusting for severity score at time of admission. We compared greatest severity of illness (highest WHO threshold achieved) using ordinal logistic regression.

Results: SOT and non-SOT patients had comparable age (59 [51-66] vs. 60 [45-73]), sex (40% vs. 45% female), and race (Black 40% vs. 34%, Hispanic 28% vs. 25%). SOT recipients were more likely to have diabetes mellitus (72% vs. 35%), hypertension (88% vs. 55%), congestive heart failure (36% vs. 15%), and peripheral vascular disorders (28% vs. 8%) (all p<0.01). Disease severity was comparable in the two groups upon admission (OR = 0.26 0.55 1.17, p=0.12), though 7% of non-SOT and 0% of SOT required intubation immediately. SOT and non-SOT recipients had comparable maximum severity score (OR = 0.36 0.73 1.46, p=0.4), length of stay (sHR = 0.8 1.1 1.4, p=0.7), and mortality risk (2/25 vs 231/1718; sHR=0.1 0.6 2.4, p=0.5). SOT recipients had faster declining in severity over time (OR for increased severity over time: 0.77 0.82 0.88, p<0.001) (Figure), and shorter duration on oxygen therapy (3.7 [0.2-6.2] vs. 6.1 [2.4-12.5] days, p=0.01).

Conclusion: With proper management, history of SOT does not necessarily lead to worse COVID-19 outcomes. The trajectory of daily WHO ordinal scale demonstrates more rapid resolution of disease severity in SOT compared to non-SOT patients with COVID-19, with no evidence of increased mortality for SOT patients.

abstract_title: Flagging of Transplant Centers Associated with Increased Waitlist Mortality among Liver Candidates
author_block: R. Grant<sup>1</sup>, B. Shelton<sup>1</sup>, J. Locke<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery/Transplantation,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Previous studies have demonstrated decreased transplant rates among poor performing transplant centers meeting Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) flagging criteria. However, no studies have examined the risk of waitlist mortality in liver candidates listed at a low performance transplant center. Thus, we sought to evaluate the impact of center flagging for poor outcomes and risk of waitlist mortality and transplant in a contemporary cohort of liver candidates.

Methods:  68,500 adult (>18 years) liver-only candidates were listed between 06/18/13 to 12/21/17 in the SRTR. Flagging was defined using CMS criteria for 1-year patient and graft survival. Fine and Gray competing risk models in which flagging was a time-dependent variable were constructed to determine risk of waitlist mortality and likelihood of transplant associated with flagging after adjustment for factors contained in the SRTR waitlist mortality risk-adjustment model.

Results: Of the 123 centers evaluated, 28 (22.8%) were flagged at least once for low performance. Baseline demographics showed centers that were ever flagged had candidates that were more likely to be African American, Hispanic, and diabetic. After adjusting for demographics, flagging of a transplant center was found to be associated with 30% increased risk of waitlist mortality in liver candidates (adjusted HR (aHR): 1.30, 95%CI: 1.09-1.56). After accounting for the competing risks of waitlist mortality or removal from the waitlist, candidates were 15% less likely to be transplanted at a flagged center as compared to a non-flagged center (aHR: 0.85, 95% CI: 0.76-0.96, p=0.01) (Figure).

Conclusion: These data suggest that centers became more conservative after being flagged, resulting in higher risk of waitlist mortality and decreased likelihood of transplant. Further research is needed to determine if there is a disproportionate impact on vulnerable populations such as racial or ethnic minorities.

abstract_title: Lung Transplant Type & Donor Age in Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: A Single Center Experience
author_block: E. H. Ander<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Kashem<sup>1</sup>, H. Zhao<sup>1</sup>, N. Shigemura<sup>1</sup>, G. Sunagawa<sup>1</sup>, S. H. Brann<sup>1</sup>, E. H. Leotta<sup>1</sup>, R. Yanagida,<sup>1</sup>, Y. Toyoda<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Temple University,Cardiovascular Division/Department Of Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic interstitial lung disease that primarily affects people over the age of 50 with a mean survival time of approximately 3 years after diagnosis. IPF accounts for the largest proportion of diagnoses on the US lung transplant (LTx) list. As the demand for donor lungs far exceeds the supply, finding effective sources of donor lungs has become increasingly important. While the average age of LTx recipients and donors continues to increase, the effect of donor age on survival in patients with IPF is poorly understood. Similarly, there is no clear consensus whether single LTx (SLT) or double LTx (DLT) is preferable in patients with IPF. This study analyzed the independent and combined effects of LTx type and donor age on survival outcomes in patients with IPF. 

Methods: This study retrospectively assessed the survival outcomes of patients with IPF receiving LTx at a single institution over a period of 8 years (Feb-2012 to Mar-2020). Transplant recipients were grouped by SLT or DLT LTx type and donor lung age <50 or 50≥ years. Survival outcomes for each group were then measured using Kaplan-Meier survival analysis and compared by log-rank test. P-values less than 0.05 were considered significant. 

Results: Out of 742 LTx patients, 305 (41%) were diagnosed with IPF, of which 204 (67%) were SLT and 97 (32%) were DLT (the remaining 4 patients underwent either heart-lung transplant or single-sequential LTx). There was no significant difference in survival due to LTx type (p=0.368). Similarly, no significant difference in survival was found for patients with donor age <50 or 50≥ years (p=0.298). Of the grouped IPF diagnosed patients, there were 12 DLT and donor age 50≥, 35 SLT and donor age 50≥, 85 DLT and donor age <50, and 169 SLT and donor age <50. Kaplan-Meier analysis showed no significant difference in survival between the four groups (p=0.455), though DLT and donor age 50≥ had increased mean and median survival days comparatively. 

Conclusion: With ethical consideration for organ allocation, as the average age of the US population increases, donor lungs aged over 50 years are becoming an increasingly useful resource for LTx. Our findings at a single institution suggest that donor age and LTx type do not significantly affect survival outcomes. Therefore, SLT and donor lungs aged 50≥ years ought to be more readily considered as non-inferior options for LTx in patients with IPF.

abstract_title: Trends in Kidney Transplant Usage according to KDPI and KDRI across the KAS Eras
author_block: M. L. Jacobs<sup>1</sup>, R. Stratta<sup>2</sup>, A. Reeves-Daniel<sup>3</sup>, J. Rogers<sup>2</sup>, A. Farney<sup>2</sup>, G. Orlando<sup>2</sup>, C. L. Jay<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Wake Forest School of Medicine,Winston Salem, NORTH CAROLINA, USA <sup>2</sup>Wake Forest School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Winston Salem, NORTH CAROLINA, USA <sup>3</sup>Wake Forest School of Medicine,Department Of Nephrology,Winston Salem, NORTH CAROLINA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  In 2014, the Kidney Allocation Scheme (KAS) was implemented including the Kidney Donor Profile Index (KDPI), a donor quality metric stratifying kidneys across a 0-100% spectrum with 100% representing the highest risk of graft failure. The more granular metric could increase risk aversion for high KDPI kidneys.  Discard rates rose in the early post-KAS era and remain over 50% for KDPI>85% kidneys. If high KDPI kidneys are increasingly discarded, this could cause a KDPI drift where kidneys with the same donor factors would translate to higher KDPI percentages over time resulting in perceptions of “worse quality.” 

Methods:  Using national United Network of Organ Sharing data, we compared deceased donor kidneys transplants (DDKT) alone according to era: 2010-2011 (pre-KDPI, “Era 1”), 2012-2013 (pre-KAS; KDPI reported but not implemented, “Era 2”), 2014-2015 (early post-KAS; “Era 3”), 2016-2017 (“Era 4”), and 2018-2020 (“Era 5”).  We compared Kidney Donor Risk Index (KDRI; a composite estimate of relative risk of graft failure), KDPI (percentage normalizing the KDRI according to the prior year’s donors), and the individual donor factors in each era. 

Results: KDPI>85% were 9.3% of DDKT in Era 1, but declined to 8.9, 7.6 and 7.1% after KDPI reporting in Eras 2, 3, and 4 before rebounding to 9.8% in Era 5 (p<0.01). These time trends were reflected in both mean and median KDPI and KDRI (see Fig 1). Progressive decline through Era 1-4 with an increase in Era 5 occurred with donor age (>60 years: 9.0, 8.0, 7.4, 6.7 and 8.4% in Eras 1-5 respectively, p<0.01), diabetes (7.6, 7.9, 7.4, 6.7 and 8.0% in Eras 1-5, p<0.01), and hypertension (29, 29, 27, 27 and 29% in Eras 1-5, p<0.01). Donation after cardiac death (DCD) proportion (15, 17, 19, 21 and 26% in Eras 1-5, p<0.01), terminal serum Creatinine (mean±SD 1.14 ± 0.92, 1.15 ± 0.96, 1.19 ± 1.01, 1.25 ± 1.15 and 1.35 ± 1.29 in Eras 1-5, p<0.01), and Hepatitis C virus (HCV) seropositivity (2.5, 2.2, 2.9, 3.9 and 8.9% in Eras 1-5, p<0.01) progressively increased across each era.  We analyzed KDPI and KDRI removing the HCV component given recent improvements in curative therapies and ability to delineate true viremia, but found that era trends remained the same.

Conclusion: Differences in high KDPI kidney utilization were noted initially after KDPI reporting began, but have rebounded in the most recent era.  Trends were comparable in KDRI not supporting a drift .  There has been sustained increase in the utilization of DCD, higher Cr, and HCV seropositive donors over time.

abstract_title: Simultaneous Kidney-PancreasTransplantation in HIV-Positive Recipients
author_block: H. Resweber<sup>1</sup>, H. Curtis<sup>1</sup>, K. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, J. Panichella<sup>1</sup>, A. Di Carlo<sup>1</sup>, S. Karhadkar<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Temple University,Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the advent of anti-retroviral therapy in the treatment of HIV, mortality in HIV-infected individuals has become less due to complications from viral infection and more due to chronic issues such as organ failure and dysfunction. Organ transplantation has thus become a viable therapeutic option to treat diabetes and renal failure in HIV+ patients. Although transplantations involving organs like livers and kidneys into HIV-infected individuals have become increasingly common over the past decade, pancreas transplantation into HIV+ recipients is rarely performed. This is despite the fact that type II diabetes and insulin resistance remain a large problem for this population. 

Methods: Using the UNOS database and SPSS, we examined the 31 incidences of pancreas transplantation that have occurred in HIV+ patients in the US. All of these transplantations were simultaneous pancreas-kidney (SPK) procedures, with the first occurring in 2009 and the most recently recorded occurring in 2017. Subject characteristics were summarized using means and standard deviations or frequencies and percentages, as applicable. Significance between groups was determined by independent samples t-tests and χ2tests (α = 0.05.). Death-censored graft survival for various subgroups was estimated using Kaplan-Meier with Log-Rank to assess significance. All analysis was completed using SPSS Statistics 26.

Results: Compared to SPK in HIV-uninfected individuals, pancreas graft function was similar (80.6% vs 85.3%), type I diabetes rates were similar (83.9% for HIV+ vs 87.4% for HIV-), and pancreas graft survival was higher (583 days for HIV+ vs 533 days for HIV-). Similar rates of thymoglobulin induction were observed in both groups (54.8% for HIV+ vs 64.3% for HIV-), Simulect (22.6% vs 10.2%) and Rituxan (3.2% vs 0.7%) induction rates were higher in the HIV+ group. Reasons for pancreas graft failure in the HIV+ recipients included graft/vascular thrombosis (n = 1), anastomotic leak (n = 1), acute rejection (n = 2), and chronic rejection (n = 1), the graft/vascular thrombosis (3.2% vs 4.3%) and chronic rejection (3.2% vs 2.3%) occurred at a similar rate in the HIV+ and HIV- individuals, while the anastomic leak (3.2% vs 0.3%) and acute rejection (6.5% vs 1.7%) occurred at higher levels in the HIV+ recipients.

Conclusion: Similar to outcomes seen in kidney transplantation, pancreas transplantation provides a viable therapeutic option for treatment of diabetes in HIV+ individuals. Ovrall survival of HIV+ SPK recipients was much lower than their HIV-uninfected counterparts (647 days for HIV+ vs 1059 days for HIV-), but the successes in both graft function and graft survival provide an optimistic outlook for SPK transplantation in this demographic.

abstract_title: Differential Post-translational Glycosylation of Proteins in Papillary Thyroid Cancer
author_block: J. Broekhuis<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Li<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Lehoux<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, S. Duncan<sup>1</sup>, M. Nishino<sup>2,3</sup>, R. Cummings<sup>1,2</sup>, B. James<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Pathology,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Glycosylation is the post-translational process of adding carbohydrates to proteins and lipids.  Prior studies have identified altered glycosylation in many cancers and implicated these processes in dysregulated cell growth and migration. However, applications of glycomic analysis in thyroid cancer are lacking.  We aimed to evaluate the glycome of thyroid tissue to determine whether malignant and benign tissues are differentially glycosylated.

Methods: Fourteen tissue samples from seven patients with papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) were identified from our institutional Endocrine Surgery Biorepository, which collects paired benign and malignant tissues from patients with biopsy-confirmed thyroid cancer undergoing total thyroidectomy. After tissue homogenization and trypsinization, N- and O-glycans in tryptic glycopeptides were enzymatically and chemically released, respectively.  The released glycans were purified and permethylated prior to analysis by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization-Time of Flight mass spectrometry (MS). Reflective positive mode was used and a signal/noise ratio of at least 2 was considered. MS post-data acquisition analysis was made using mMass, and Student’s t-test was used to compare relative abundances of N- and O-glycans, with p<0.05 considered significant.

Results: All patients had pathologically confirmed PTC. Overall, cancer tissue exhibited N-glycans with higher masses and more complex structures. When compared to benign thyroid tissue, cancerous tissue exhibited a significantly higher relative abundance of N-glycans containing extra HexNAc (e.g. GlcNAc and/or GalNAc) (20.3% vs. 7.0%, p=0.047). There were no significant differences in relative abundance of high-mannose type N-glycans (20.8% vs. 29.6%, p=0.16), fucosylated (62.5% vs. 57.6%, p=0.26) and sialylated N-glycans (43.1% vs. 43.8%, p=0.47). Regarding O-glycans, the relative abundance of unmodified core-2-based O-glycans was significantly higher in cancer tissue (26.2% vs. 12.8%, p=0.027). However, the overall sialylation level of O-glycans was lower in cancer tissue (66.9% vs. 83.5%, p=0.032). Specifically, the relative abundance of di-sialylated O-glycans was lower in cancer (37.9% vs. 58.0%, p=0.015) while mono-sialylated O-glycans was unchanged (28.7% vs. 25.0%, p=0.18).

Conclusion: Our results demonstrate that there are profound and consistent N- and O-glycosylation differences between papillary thyroid cancer tissue and benign thyroid tissue.  Further investigation of these glycans and their functional pathways will elucidate their roles in oncogenesis and neoplasia. Additionally these altered glycans may provide diagnostic value in identifying more indolent versus aggressive subtypes of thyroid cancer.

abstract_title: Effects of glucose restriction on tumor growth and survival in a model of anaplastic thyroid cancer
author_block: B. Zhao<sup>1</sup>, A. Aggarwal<sup>1</sup>, J. Marshall<sup>1</sup>, M. Nehs<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC) is a rare but devastating malignancy without effective current treatments. Glucose is an essential nutrient for cancer growth that is preferentially metabolized through the glycolysis pathway in tumor cells, even in the presence of oxygen (Warburg effect). Inhibition of glucose metabolism has been shown to have anti-tumor effects in various types of cancer. This study aims to determine if disruption of glucose availability in vitro and in vivo can suppress tumor cell growth and prolong survival in a mouse model of ATC.

Methods:  The human ATC cell line 8505C was cultured in medium containing high (25 mM) or low (3 mM) concentration of glucose. Cellular proliferation was determined using a standard BrdU assay. An orthotopic xenograft model of ATC was generated via injection of 8505C cells into the thyroid glands of immunocompromised mice. Animals were subsequently provided with either standard chow diet (SD) (20% protein, 64% carbohydrate, 16% fat) or ketogenic diet (KD) (10% protein, 90% fat). SD control (N = 9) and KD treatment (N = 8) groups were monitored weekly for body weight and blood levels of glucose and ketones for up to 9 weeks. Tumors were harvested after animal death and measured using a digital caliper.

Results: Proliferation of 8505C cells in vitro was significantly diminished in the low glucose setting (1.4 ± 0.1 vs 2.0 ± 0.1 optical density units in high glucose medium; P = 0.01). Animals consuming KD had consistently higher blood ketone values throughout treatment compared to those given SD (1.5 ± 0.1 vs 0.7 ± 0.1 mM in week 4; P < 0.01 for all weekly time points). Blood glucose levels were decreased in the KD treatment group during the initial 2 weeks of treatment (68 ± 4 vs 131 ± 5 mg/dL in week 2; P < 0.01 for both time points), followed by normalization of glucose measurements to similar levels as SD controls for the remainder of the experiment. Mice in KD and SD groups exhibited similar rates of weight gain during the first 5 weeks of treatment, prior to the incidence of weight loss due to tumor burden. No difference in overall survival was observed in KD treatment and SD control groups (median survival 52 vs 53 days). Tumor sizes measured during necropsy were generally similar in KD and SD fed animals.

Conclusion: Glucose restriction alone significantly decreased in vitro growth of ATC but did not improve survival or reduce tumor size in an orthotopic murine model of ATC. This may be explained in part by the normalization of blood glucose values after an initial period of treatment in mice consuming a glucose restricted diet. Combination therapies including concomitant restriction of glucose intake along with pharmacologic inhibition of glucose metabolism may be more effective in the treatment of ATC and should be further studied.

abstract_title: Piperlongumine Suppresses Thyroid Cancer Proliferation in vitro and in Mouse Xenografts
author_block: D. M. Carmona Matos<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Van Ginkel<sup>3</sup>, R. E. Guenter<sup>1</sup>, Y. Shihab<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Whitt<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, T. Prolla<sup>3</sup>, R. Jaskula-Sztul<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>San Juan Bautista School of Medicine,Caguas, PR, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Genetics And Medical Genetics,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thyroid carcinomas are the most common endocrine malignancy. Though many patients respond to standard therapy and thyroidectomy, there’s a subgroup of patients for whom that is not the case. Patients with aggressive or recurrent malignancies may develop tumors that de-differentiate, lose capacity of radioiodine uptake and often metastasize proving difficult to treat. Natural compounds remain one of the best sources for potential therapeutic agents. Piperlongumine (PL), a piper amide produced by pepper plants, has been shown to have anticancer properties against breast, colorectal, renal, bladder and prostate cancer cells. The purpose of this study was to explore the anticancer therapeutic efficacy of piperlongumine in anaplastic thyroid cancer and Hürthle cell carcinoma in vitro andin vivo. 

Methods: Anaplastic (THJ-16T) and Hürthle cell (XTC.UC1) thyroid cancer cell lines were treated with PL. A neutral red assay was used to determine the IC50 values for all cell lines. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) formation after PL treatment was assessed by using a 2′,7′-dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) probe on cells pre-treated or not with N-acetylcysteine (NAC). Immunofluorescent analysis was used to visualize cell damage after PL treatment. Additionally, nude mice were used to establish subcutaneous xenografts of both XTC.UC1 and THJ-16T. Mice were treated with piperlongumine at 2.5 mg/kg and 5.0 mg/kg IP and compared to a vehicle control group. Lastly, a metastatic model consisting of IV injection of THJ-16T cells was also treated with PL. 

Results: PL demonstrated an IC50 of 3.08 uM against THJ-16T and 2.36 uM against XTC.UC1 cell lines. Immunofluorescence analysis of PL treated cells revealed increased nuclear instability in a dose dependent manner. The DCFH-DA probe showed ROS formation in a dose dependent manner in cells treated with PL. Additionally, treatment with NAC, an ROS scavenger, prevented PL induced cell death. The in vivo study demonstrated a 55 – 60% reduction in tumor burden for XTC.UC1 and THJ-16T xenografts treated with PL when compared to controls. Lastly, the THJ-16T metastatic mouse model exhibited a 25% increase in survival for mice treated with PL compared to our control mice.

Conclusion: PL suppresses proliferation in anaplastic thyroid cancer cells and Hürthle cell carcinoma cells in vitro by inducing ROS. Furthermore, in vivo studies using mice xenografts and metastatic models showed decreased tumor burden and increased survival in mice treated with PL. Our results suggest this naturally derived compound may be a promising therapeutic agent to treat patients with aggressive or recurrent thyroid cancers.

abstract_title: In Vitro Screening of Plant Extracts as Remedies for Insulin-Sensitivity in Peripheral Adipocytes
author_block: S. T. Sprenger<sup>1</sup>, T. Wldemariam<sup>2</sup>, J. Sprenger<sup>3</sup>, L. Chaturvedi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>California Northstate Unversity,College Of Medicine,Elk Grove, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>California Northstate University College of Pharmacy,Depertment Of Pharmaceutical And Biomedical Sciences,Elk Grove, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Saint George's University,College Of Medicine,Grenada, Grenada, Grenada
abstract_body:
Introduction: Type II Diabetes is characterized by insulin resistance in peripheral adipocytes. Treatment is complicated by poor compliance and stigma. Natural remedies are increasingly popular among patients. The botanicals Alma, Olive, Rosemary, Gotu Kola, Bitter Melon, and Artichoke attenuate lipid accumulation consistent with the Thiazolidinediones (TZD) class, which acts through agonism of the transcription factor PPARγ. Sumac was reported to possess insulin sensitizing effects in vivo. In this preclinical study,  the effect of these traditional remedies on expression of genetic markers for insulin resistance was investigated.

Methods: Aqueous extracts were derived from Alma, Olive, Rosemary, Artichoke, Gotu Kola, Bitter Melon, and Sumac. Toxicity was assessed using cell viability assays for 48 and 72 hours. Adipocytes were generated from murine 3T3-L1 preadipocytes using treatment for 2 days with dexamethasone, 3-isobutyl-1-methylxanthine, and insulin, and then followed by insulin alone for another 5 days. Adipocytes were treated with aqueous extracts starting on day 2. Oil Red O staining procedure followed by elution and spectrophotometric measurement was used to quantify the effect of extracts on lipid accumulation. Expression of genetic markers for insulin resistance and adipogenesis was measured using RT-PCR. The effects of the aqueous extracts were compared to the antidiabetic drug Rosiglitazone.

Results: No effect on 3T3-L1 proliferation was observed following treatment with the aqueous extracts from Olive, Gotu Kola, Bitter Melon, or Sumac (0.0-1.0 mg/mL). The extracts from Alma, Rosemary, and Artichoke decreased proliferation of 3T3-L1 cells at the concentration of 1.0 mg/mL at 48 and 72 hours. The extracts did not lead to significant changes in lipid accumulation (P>0.05). Plant extracts and Rosiglitazone significantly downregulated mRNA expression of adiponectin, perilipin, FABP4, and CD36. Attenuation of adiponectin expression ranged from 6.0x10-2±4.3x10-4 to 50.3±8.7x10-1 (Percent Change ± SE). Percent Change in perilipin expression was between 4.0±2.0x10-1 and 18.9±1.7. Percent Change in FABP4 expression was between 4.9±3.5x10-1 and 16.9±1.5. Percent Change in CD 36 expression was between 6.0-1±4.3x10-4 and 51.2±1.4.

Conclusion: Downregulation of genetic markers for insulin resistance and adipogenesis were observed for all extracts tested, verifying their antidiabetic activity. Increases in markers of adipogenesis is consistent with the fatty acid steal hypothesis proposed for TZDs. Future investigation should investigate the effect of these compounds on the expression of upstream transcription factors. The inhibitory concentrations should also be determined to facilitate comparisons of efficacy. Given the safety, demonstrable mechanism, and patient interest in these botanicals, practitioners should maintain an open mind to their therapeutic usage.

abstract_title: Citric Acid Metabolism and the Immunogenomic Tumor Microenvironment in Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma
author_block: D. Hanna<sup>1</sup>, A. Decubas<sup>2</sup>, J. Castro<sup>2</sup>, M. Rahim<sup>4</sup>, M. Wolf<sup>2</sup>, J. Beachle<sup>3</sup>, J. Rathmell<sup>5</sup>, N. Abumrad<sup>1</sup>, J. Young<sup>4</sup>, K. Rathmell<sup>2</sup>, N. Baregamian<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Section Of Surgical Sciences,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Division Of Hematology And Oncology,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Meharry Medical College,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University,Department Of Engineering,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>5</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Department Of Pathology, Microbiology, And Immunology,Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Patients with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) have excellent overall prognosis. However, their survival dramatically decreases with soft tissue or lymph node involvement or distant metastatic spread. Tumor progression anchored in tumor metabolism and its modulation of the tumor-infiltrating immune phenotype in the PTC tumor microenvironment (TME) remains largely understudied. The purpose of our study was to explore the immuno-metabolic impact of the citric acid (TCA) cycle metabolism in TME immune landscape and patient survival. 

Methods:  To examine TCA cycle metabolism in PTC, we performed targeted and untargeted metabolomics on PTC samples (20 untargeted, 10 targeted) and unrelated benign controls (8 untargeted, 9 targeted). To characterize the TME immuno-metabolic landscape of PTC, we generated a TCA cycle metabolic enzyme gene list using KEGG pathway and performed RNA sequencing analysis of 20 PTC samples to further correlate differential immunogenomic and metabolic enzyme gene expressions in the PTC TME. We used 2 different computational deconvolution platforms, TIMER2.0 (Tumor Immune Estimation Resource) and CibersortX, to correlate enzymatic and immune expression patterns. Significantly correlated TCA metabolic genes expressions and immune cell types were then analyzed for their impact on overall patient survival using The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA, PTC=500 samples) program.

Results: Untargeted metabolomics revealed key alterations in the TCA cycle and targeted metabolic flux studies  demonstrated atom percent enrichment of TCA cycle metabolites with significant enrichment of citrate in tumor samples when compared to controls. Mass isotopomer of citrate demonstrated a lower M+4/M+5 ratio in tumor samples, indicative of forward movement of TCA cycle and a component of active reductive carboxylation of α-ketoglutarate (α-KG) to citrate for biosynthetic purposes. Our immunogenomic profiling of sequenced PTC tumors identified significant correlations between TCA cycle metabolic gene expressions and higher recruitment of tumor-infiltrating dendritic cells and CD4+ T lymphocytes.  TCGA analysis of the PTC TME immune landscape showed that BRAF mutations, which confer a worse prognosis, were associated with significantly increased infiltrate levels of B cells, CD4+ T cells, macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells compared to wild-type BRAF tumors. TCGA analysis of impact of all TCA metabolic genes on patient survival identified ACO1, SUCLG1, and SDHC genes to be associated with worse overall survival. 

Conclusion: We observed key TCA cycle metabolite differences and a strong correlative relationship between metabolic enzyme gene and immune cell expressions in the PTC tumor microenvironment. Exploiting the complex interplay of tumor metabolism and its modulation of the immune landscape will provide new insights for emerging prognostic markers and future therapeutic targets in tumor progression and treatment of advanced PTC.

abstract_title: Pancreatic Infusion of Adeno-Associated Virus in Non-Human Primates to Treat Diabetes Mellitus
author_block: R. S. Kalsi<sup>1</sup>, K. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, M. Saleh<sup>1</sup>, G. K. Gittes<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Of Pittsburgh Of UPMC,Pediatric Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Currently, 10.5% of the US population has diabetes mellitus (DM), the 7th leading cause of death. Type 1 DM is an autoimmune disease that results in a loss of beta-cell mass. In contrast, type 2 DM is marked by insulin resistance, which causes a loss of beta-cell mass and subsequent beta cell dysfunction. Both populations have insulin deficiency. Gene therapy may treat DM by reprogramming alpha-cells into new beta-like-cells via forced expression of specific transcription factors: pancreas/duodenum homeobox protein-1 (Pdx1) and V-maf musculoaponeurotic fibrosarcoma oncogene homolog A (mafA). In toxin-induced and autoimmune genetic diabetic mouse models, a pancreatic intraductal infusion of adeno-associated virus (AAV)-CMV-Pdx1-mafA resulted in the formation of new beta-like-cells and normoglycemia. Moving forward, we aimed to replicate these results in a toxin-induced diabetes model in NHPs using a similar construct. 

Methods: Administration of streptozocin induces diabetes in NHPs by ablating the pancreatic beta cells. After an acclimation period and confirmation of diabetes, we proceed with surgery. We make a midline laparotomy, clamp the common bile duct, make a duodenotomy, cannulate the Ampulla of Vater, clamp the minor duct; pancreatography ensures cannulation of the common channel without spillage into the duodenum or flow into the common bile duct beyond the clamp. Upon completion of the infusion, we allow the virus to dwell for ten minutes. We then remove the clamps and the catheter and close the enterotomy, followed by closure of the laparotomy.  

Results: Over time, the NHPs required less insulin (see attached figure) and had increased c-peptide compared to their preoperative baseline, with some NHPs being nearly insulin-independent. Three separate NHPs underwent glucose tolerance testing (GTT) after streptozocin administration and then after the AAV infusion.  The GTT demonstrated a statistically significant improvement in the glucose homeostasis after intraductal infusion by 2-way ANOVA (p< 0.01). Immunohistochemistry revealed positive insulin, glucagon, and amylase staining, suggesting the formation of new insulin-producing-cells and normal exocrine tissue. 

Conclusion: The newly formed beta-like-cells can produce insulin and provide long term replacement of beta-cells. Thus, this targeted gene therapy may be a promising treatment for diabetes and easily translate to humans via ERCP.

abstract_title: Protein Kinase D Signaling Renders Resistance to mTOR Inhibition in Cancer Stem-like Cells
author_block: Y. Guo<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Guenter<sup>1</sup>, R. Jaskula-Sztul<sup>1</sup>, V. Dudeja<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. Ren<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>The University of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, ALABAMA, USA <sup>2</sup>The University of Alabama at Birmingham,Biomedical Engineering,Birmingham, ALABAMA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PNETs) are the second most common pancreatic malignancy. Many patients present with metastatic disease and current therapy options for advanced disease are rarely curative. Inhibitors of the mTOR pathway improve progression-free survival in patients with advanced PNETs, but many patients eventually develop resistance and recurrence. We have found that PNET cells highly express protein kinase D-1 (PKD-1), a signaling protein that plays a critical role in the maintenance of cancer stem-like cells (CSCs). Previous studies have shown that CD36 can regulate fatty acid metabolism in CSCs to promote disease progression and that ALDH1A1 is involved in CSC plasticity. We hypothesize that the plasticity of CSCs contributes to drug resistance in PNETs through PKD-1 signaling. 

Methods:   To test this hypothesis, we generated drug-resistant PNET cells through continual treatment with the mTOR inhibitor rapamycin. To define the molecular mechanisms by which PKD-1 signaling regulates CSC features, we inhibited PKD-1 pathway pharmacologically and genetically and determined the expression of CSC-associated genes using cellular and molecular approaches. Tumorsphere assays were used to elucidate mechanisms by which PKD-1 signaling regulates CSC function.

Results: Drug-resistant PNET cells significantly increased the expression of CSC markers: CD133, CD24, and ALDH1A1, along with the stemness-associated genes: CD36, Notch1, and Zeb1. In the meantime, PKD-1 expression was also significantly increased. However, inhibition of PKD-1 signaling was able to abolish LPA-induced expression of ALDH1A1, CD133, CD24, Notch1, and CD36. Moreover, knocking down endogenous PKD-1 expression significantly impaired the self-renewal potential of BON cells. 

Conclusion: Our study indicates that PKD-1 signaling may regulate the phenotype of CSCs in PNETs, promoting resistance to mTOR inhibition via modulation of metabolic plasticity of CSCs. Targeting PKD-1 signaling should provide insights into therapeutic strategies against drug resistance and cancer recurrence in PNETs.

abstract_title: Trauma Plasma Modifies Global Transcription Profiles Related To The Blood Brain Barrier
author_block: J. B. Hadley<sup>1</sup>, S. Mitra<sup>1</sup>, D. Trahan<sup>1</sup>, P. Stafford<sup>1</sup>, A. Stem<sup>1</sup>, P. Lutz<sup>1</sup>, E. E. Moore<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Silliman<sup>1,4</sup>, K. Jones<sup>1,3</sup>, M. Cohen<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>Denver Health Medical Center,Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine,Oklahoma City, OK, USA <sup>4</sup>Children's Hospital Colorado,Hematology,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The blood brain barrier(BBB) is a highly selective semipermeable membrane comprised of endothelial cells, astrocytes, and the extracellular matrix. During trauma, this BBB integrity can become compromised from direct brain injury, shock, or remote tissue injury. We hypothesize that there are specific genomic drivers of signaling pathways that directly affect the integrity of the BBB following severe injury.

Methods: Human cerebral endothelial cells and/or astrocytes were grown as monocultures or as co-cultures to replicate the BBB in vitro. The cultures were then incubated for 4hours with trauma plasma ex vivo from severely injured(ISS>15) and shocked(BD<-6) patients. RNA samples were prepared and sent for sequencing for RNAseq analysis. Sequence reads were processed with previously published protocols and significant gene lists were used for downstream pathway analysis.

Results:Plasma from severely injured and/or shocked patients induced changes in cell signaling depending if the cells were grown in mono-or co-cultures. The astrocyte monoculture had increased downstream signaling responsible for neutrophil extravasation from the vasculature, while the endothelial monoculture exhibited increased signaling involved in proliferation of endothelial progenitor cells and the migration of connective tissue(Figure1). When grown in co-culture, there was increased signaling responsible for endothelial cell maturation and angiogenesis. Lastly, the plasma elicited activation of NUPR1 transcription factor, which is directly involved in the response to cell stress in all cell cultures and could be a key mediator in the initiation and propagation of the response to traumatic stress.

Conclusion:Cell signaling pathways in an in vitro model of the BBB are distinctly different from the individual component monocultures. Crucial signals that are transmitted within and between the astrocytes and endothelium to maintain the integrity of the BBB during traumatic stress. Future studies will focus on enumeration of transcriptional changes and the inherent signaling cascades induced by severe injury and shock phenotypes.

abstract_title: Survival from bacterial peritonitis is dependent on a coordinated transition of macrophage phenotype
author_block: R. Keskey<sup>1</sup>, O. Zaborina<sup>1</sup>, J. Alverdy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Chicago,Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Following the intraperitoneal administration (IP) of a given bacterial inoculum, the immune mechanisms that regulate mortality rates (i.e LD50) among those mice that liver versus die  (i.e within-group mortality determinants) remain unknown. Here we hypothesize that within-group mortality differences following IP injection of Serratia marcescens are dependent on peritoneal macrophage phenotype transition during infection.

Methods: C57/B6 wild type mice were subjected to IP Serratia Marcescens at an LD60.  Body temperature was used to track the progression from infection to sepsis in addition to a 6 component sepsis score between 0-3 based on appearance, level of consciousness, activity, response to stimulus, eyes, and respiratory status. To define the role of macrophages in the LD60 response, macrophages were depleted with IP clodronate liposomes. Peritoneal macrophages were isolated using magnetic bead isolation. RNA was extracted from isolated peritoneal macrophages and RT-PCR was used to determine gene expression of M1 versus M2 specific genes.

Results:Survivors and non-survivors were clearly delineated by a reduction in their temperature (24.7°C v 30.7°C: non-survivor vs survivors, p < 0.01) and an increase in their sepsis score (13.9 v 2.0: non-survivor vs survivors, p < 0.01).  When mice were pretreated with clodronate liposomes, the LD60 dose of SM increased to 100% demonstrating that macrophages are required for survival. Comparison of macrophages gene expression between surviving and non-surviving mice demonstrated a significant increase in expression of M1, pro-inflammatory genes (IL-6, TNF, and NOS2) in the non-surviving mice.  The macrophages from surviving mice had a significant increase in ARG1 expression compared to macrophages from non-surviving mice (P<0.05). The increase in NOS2 and reduction in ARG1 seen in non-surviving peritoneal macrophages is likely a reflection of an increased M1 phenotype compared to M2.

Conclusion:In this study, presence of macrophages and their ability to appropriately transition from the inflammatory, M1 phenotype, to a pro-resolving, M2, macrophage phenotype discriminated between those that survived versus died following IP Serratia marcescen administration.

abstract_title: Implementation of Targeted Regional Optimization (TRO) in a Porcine Model of Hemorrhagic Shock
author_block: A. Lauria<sup>2</sup>, A. Ronaldi<sup>2</sup>, J. Polcz<sup>2</sup>, A. Kersey<sup>2</sup>, L. Leung<sup>1,3</sup>, D. Burmeister<sup>4</sup>, T. Rasmussen<sup>1,2</sup>, J. White<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Uniformed Services University Of The Health Sciences,Department Of Surgery,Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Walter Reed National Military Medical Center,Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Henry Jackson Foundation,Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>Uniformed Services University Of The Health Sciences,Department Of Medicine,Bethesda, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA) allows for hemodynamic temporization during severe, non-compressible hemorrhage. However, prolonged endoaortic occlusion contributes to morbidity and mortality due to distal ischemia reperfusion. Targeted regional optimization (TRO) describes a partial REBOA strategy with active compartmentalization of central aortic and cerebral pressure optimization, and regional subdiaphragmatic hypotension while maintaining targeted distal perfusion. This technique strikes the balance between hemostasis and tissue perfusion. Using the next-generation REBOA catheter, this study characterized the hemodynamics at specific targeted distal flow rates in a swine model of uncontrolled hemorrhage.

Methods: Anesthetized swine (68.6±0.9 kg) were subjected to uncontrolled hemorrhage initiated by liver laceration. Animals were randomized into 3 groups with TRO established at 300 (n=5), 500 (n=5) or 700 ml/min (n=4). Following a 90-min TRO phase, the animals received damage control perihepatic packing and were subsequently monitored for 6 hours (ICU phase). Pressor/fluids were provided to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP)>55 mmHg. Hemodynamic parameters (flow rates at common carotid artery, renal artery and suprarenal aorta distal to the endoaortic balloon; and MAP at common carotid and femoral arteries) were measured continuously.

Results: During TRO phase, distal aortic flow rates in all groups were tightly regulated and average percent deviation from the targeted flow was -0.54% for TRO300, -2.30% for TRO500, and -3.34% for TRO700. Femoral MAP in the TRO500 group was significantly higher than in the other 2 groups (p<0.001; TRO500=38.8±0.3 mmHg; TRO700=34.9±0.4 mmHg; TRO300=31.3±0.3 mmHg). Carotid flow rates gradually decreased during TRO phase, in which the flow rate trended lower in the TRO700 group. Carotid MAP remained supraphysiologic in the TRO300 group (109.2±0.3mmHg), whereas it was dampened and more physiologic at higher TRO (p<0.05; TRO500=97.9±0.5mmHg; TRO700=95.9±0.2mmHg). Renal flow rate was comparable between groups during TRO phase. Aortic and carotid flow rates decreased gradually during the initial ICU phase and reached a plateau at 1.5 hours. No differences in flow parameters were detected between groups. TRO700 group had a slightly lower femoral and carotid MAP than TRO300 and TRO500. TRO500 yielded the lowest renal flow rate among the 3 groups during ICU phase, but the differences did not reach statistical significance.

Conclusion: This study demonstrated technical feasibility of TRO at multiple targeted distal flow rates. With next-generation REBOA, flow past the endoaortic balloon can be precisely and accurately regulated with great fidelity to achieve TRO as a resuscitative strategy in the setting of hemorrhagic shock. Higher TRO (500 or 700 mL/min) resulted in less supraphysiological proximal blood pressure.

abstract_title: Injectable Tissue Factor-Targeted Peptide Amphiphile Nanofibers Carrying Prothrombotic Therapies
author_block: J. R. Rouan<sup>1</sup>, T. D. Clemons<sup>2,3</sup>, S. Willcox<sup>4</sup>, E. B. Peters<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Gillis<sup>1</sup>, M. K. Klein<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Karver<sup>2</sup>, L. C. Palmer<sup>2,3</sup>, T. A. Pritts<sup>5</sup>, N. D. Tsihlis<sup>1</sup>, S. I. Stupp<sup>2,3,6,7,8</sup>, M. R. Kibbe<sup>1,9</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery And Center For Nanotechnology In Drug Delivery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University,Simpson Querrey Institute,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Northwestern University,Department Of Chemistry,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Department Of Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>6</sup>Northwestern University,Department Of Materials Science And Engineering,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>7</sup>Northwestern University,Department Of Medicine,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>8</sup>Northwestern University,Department Of Biomedical Engineering,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Biomedical Engineering,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hemorrhage is a leading cause of death after trauma. Development of therapies to slow or stop bleeding after injury could help reduce morbidity and mortality in this population. Our goal is to develop an injectable therapy that targets specifically to sites of injury to deliver a prothrombotic agent. Our laboratory has previously demonstrated successful targeting to the site of bleeding using peptide amphiphile (PA) nanofibers that are targeted to tissue factor (TF). The goal of the current study is to design, synthesize, and characterize TF-targeted PA nanofibers that incorporate prothrombotic therapeutic options.

Methods: PA molecules were synthesized using solid-phase peptide synthesis and purified via high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with purity assessed by LC-mass spectrometry (LCMS). We co-assembled four TF-targeted PA nanofibers at previously successful targeting molar ratios with the maximum amount of backbone PA conjugated to one of two therapeutics: TXA and RGDS peptide. A polyethylene glycol spacer was added between the therapeutic and the PA to ensure the therapeutic did not interfere with nanofiber formation while remaining accessible to clotting factors in the blood. To confirm nanofiber formation, we performed both conventional and cryogenic transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in Hank’s balanced salt solution (HBSS) and HBSS with serum, respectively. To characterize secondary structure within the nanofibers, we used circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy. To confirm nanofiber formation at proposed in vivo administration doses, we assessed critical aggregation concentration (CAC) using a Nile Red assay.

Results: PA molecules were >95% pure as assessed by LCMS. Co-assemblies of all four TF-targeted PA nanofibers containing either prothrombotic agent were noted to form nanofibers by conventional TEM and this was confirmed by cryogenic TEM for six of the eight nanofibers. Characterization by CD spectroscopy showed expected peaks consistent with α-helix and β-sheet formation. Additionally, CAC measurements demonstrated that the TF-targeted PA nanofibers containing a prothrombotic agent formed fibers at concentrations ranging from 46.6±2.5 to 72.2±4.6 µM. These concentrations are 17-fold lower than the injection dose, indicating that these TF-targeted prothrombotic nanofibers will retain their shape when administered in vivo.

Conclusion: We successfully designed, synthesized, and co-assembled four TF-targeted PA nanofibers with two prothrombotic moieties and demonstrated nanofiber formation in buffer and serum at the proposed dose for in vivo testing. In the future, we plan to characterize the prothrombotic activity of each nanotherapeutic in vitro and ultimately test our most successful TF-targeted therapeutic nanofibers in vivo in our established rat liver hemorrhage model.

abstract_title: Dermal Microvascular Endothelium From Hypertrophic Scar is Less Permeable Than That From Normal Skin
author_block: A. D. Reese<sup>1,2</sup>, L. D. Kirkpatrick<sup>2</sup>, J. W. Keyloun<sup>1,2</sup>, L. T. Moffatt<sup>2,3,4</sup>, J. W. Shupp<sup>1,2,3,4</sup>, B. C. Carney<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Washington Hospital Center,The Burn Center, Department Of Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute,Firefighters' Burn And Surgical Research Laboratory,Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Department Of Biochemistry And Molecular And Cellular Biology,Washington, DC, USA <sup>4</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hypertrophic scar (HTS), a common complication of burn injury, has few prevention and treatment options due to a poor understanding of its pathogenesis. Fibroblast dysfunction leading to excessive collagen deposition has been implicated in scar formation and severity, however dermal microvascular endothelial cells (DMVECs) may also play an important role because of endothelial dysfunction’s (EnD) well-studied role in trauma and acute burn injury. Previous studies of HTS have shown partially or totally occluded vessels and local tissue hypoxia, which contributes to scar severity. This study uses immunofluorescence to determine microvasculature area density of normal skin vs HTS and a primary cell culture model to identify permeability in normal DMVECs and HTS DMVECs.

Methods: In a Duroc pig model, full thickness excisional wounds were created and formed HTS by day 98. Biopsies taken on day 0, representing normal skin, and day 98 scar were stained for smooth muscle actin. Immunofluorescence was used to identify microvasculature area density. Fibroblast?DMVEC co?cultures were derived from regions of normal skin and HTS. Each co-culture was positively sorted using magnetic activated cell sorting for microvascular cells with ulex europaeus agglutinin 1 lectin and negatively sorted for fibroblasts, creating a monoculture of DMVECs. Normal DMVECs and HTS DMVECs were cultured separately in transwell inserts to form confluent monolayers as determined by trans-endothelial electrical resistance (TEER) values >30Ω. On day 5, cell injury was induced in 2 of the 4 plates with 1µM Epinephrine and 1mM H2O2. Permeability was then assessed in each plate by applying a 40kDa FITC-dextran tracer in the apical well and measuring tracer diffusion across the monolayer via fluorescence spectroscopy. Average±SEM are presented with statistical significance determined by Student’s t-test with p-values <0.05.

Results: HTS had an increased area density of dermal microvasculature compared to normal skin (169.6 ± 20.5 vs 106.2 ± 10.4 vessels/mm2; p=0.03). Using a permeability index, HTS DMVECs without injury were 17.59% less permeable than normal DMVECs (p=0.002) to 40kDa FITC-dextran. After injury, normal DMVECs were 28.4% and HTS DMVECs were 18.8% more permeable than uninjured controls (28.4 ± 4.8 vs 18.8 ± 2.8; p=0.11).

Conclusion: HTS has more blood vessels than normal skin and HTS DMVECs have decreased permeability in an in-vitro permeability assay. After injury, both normal and HTS DMVECs are more permeable than their respective baseline measurements, however HTS DMVECs have a dampened response compared to normal DMVECs. This data supports that EnD plays a role in scar pathology because HTS DMVECs have both a discordant response to cellular insults and baseline differences in function.

abstract_title: Vital Signs And Central Hemodynamic Indices In A Hemorrhage and Volume Overload Resuscitation Model
author_block: L. H. Vaughn<sup>1</sup>, E. Wise<sup>3</sup>, K. Hocking<sup>1</sup>, B. Alvis<sup>2</sup>, C. Brophy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Surgery,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Anesthesiology,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Minnesota,Surgery,Minneapolis, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Volume status and fluid management dramatically impacts outcomes in surgical patients. Accurate fluid replacement is associated with decreased 30-day postoperative morbidity and mortality, whereas inadequate resuscitation can lead to systemic hypoperfusion and its sequelae and excessive resuscitation can result in pulmonary edema and increased ventilator requirements. While vital signs and central hemodynamic indices are used to guide fluid administration during surgery, there is a paucity of data regarding how these parameters change over the spectrum of volume states in the perioperative period.

Methods: An adult porcine model of controlled hemorrhage and volume overload resuscitation was used to continuously record vital signs: heart rate (HR), systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), mean arterial pressure (MAP), pulse pressure (PP), and pulse pressure variation (PPV); and central hemodynamic indices: mean pulmonary arterial pressure (MPAP), central venous pressure (CVP), cardiac output (CO), and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP). Blood was removed from a series of 8 adult pigs to a total of 400mL [representing 10-15% of total blood volume (class 1 hemorrhage)] and vital signs and central hemodynamic measurements were obtained after each 100mL of volume loss. Hemorrhaged volume was returned to restore euvolemia, then crystalloid was infused up to 2,500mL with vital signs and central hemodynamic measurements obtained after each 500mL infused. Linear correlations (R2) of the means of values from all 8 pigs at each of the volume states were determined.

Results: During hemorrhage, HR had little correlation (R2=0.22) with bled volume, while SBP, DBP, MAP, PP and PPV all demonstrated linear conformity with a R2>0.80, and all central hemodynamic indices demonstrated linearity with a R2≥0.98. During resuscitation, all vital signs demonstrated a linear correlation with a R2<0.800 and central hemodynamic indices, MPAP (R2=0.89), PCWP (R2=0.98), CVP (R2=0.93) and CO (R2=0.95) also demonstrated strong linear correlations. PCWP demonstrated the strongest linear correlation of any other parameter in detecting changes in both hemorrhage and volume overload (Figure 1).

Conclusion: This study confirms the superiority of central hemodynamic indices, particularly PCWP, relative to vital signs, in quantifying fluid status during hemorrhage and volume overload resuscitation. However, intraoperative use of PCWP is cumbersome, invasive, and may pose high and unnecessary risk to the patient. Thus, there remains a clinical need for a non-invasive, PCWP-equivalent surrogate for perioperative fluid management.

abstract_title: Non-Human Primate Polytrauma Hemorrhagic Shock Model Utilizing Human-Derived Blood Products
author_block: K. M. Ozuna<sup>1</sup>, L. E. Neidert<sup>1</sup>, S. Cardin<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Glaser<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Naval Medical Research Unit San Antonio,Expeditionary & Trauma Medicine,San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Currently, limited animal models for testing human-derived blood products (HDBP) exist due to xenocompatability issues. Old World non-human primates (NHP) are considered physiologically, immunologically, and genetically most similar to humans, generating interest as a potential animal model for testing blood-based resuscitation strategies. Ensuring compatibility with a pre-clinical animal model is necessary for clinical translatability. We investigated the xenocompatability of rhesus macaques with HDBPs following polytraumatic hemorrhagic shock.

Methods: Six adult male Chinese rhesus macaques were randomized into three treatment groups: 1. Human AB+ platelet-rich-plasma (PRP; n=2), 2. Human O negative whole blood (WB; n=2), and 3. Crystalloid (Lactated Ringer’s Solution - LRS; n=2). Baseline serum samples were collected from the subjects prior to the initiation of decompensated hemorrhagic shock. The serum and HDBPs were used for gel agglutination crossmatch and immediate spin tests. The in-vivo polytrauma model of pressure targeted and decompensated shock model was utilized.   After decompensation (T0), the designated pre-hospital resuscitation fluid was administered. At T60, all groups entered a simulated hospital phase with resuscitation, injury repair, and observation. After removal from anesthesia (T180), animals underwent continual observation for 24 hours (T1440) from end of shock. Survival time, complete blood cell counts, chemistries, and arterial blood gas parameters were analyzed. Statistical significance was determined by t-test and one-way ANOVA (p<0.05). 

Results: The gel agglutination and immediate spin tests demonstrated a 1+ agglutination in one of four PRP units and in both WB units administered. There were no significant differences in survival time between the three groups (PRP: 1319min, WB: 1440min, LRS: 1440min; p=0.46).
