Hemoglobin (HGB) and hematocrit (HCT) remained higher in the WB group compared to PRP and LRS group from T30 (HGB: 11.5g/dL v. 5.9, 8.7; p=0.020 and HCT: 36.05% v. 17.15, 25.85; p=0.017) through T180 (HGB: 12.35g/dL v. 8.45, 9.75; p=0.016 and HCT: 38.20% v. 24.55, 29.00; p=0.009). There were no significant differences in ALT or AST. At T60, total bilirubin (tBili) levels were significantly increased in both WB and PRP group compared to LRS (0.50mg/dL, 0.45 v. 0.10; p=0.04). There were no significant differences in potassium or pH levels between the groups. 

Conclusion: In-vitro results demonstrated slight agglutination with HDBPs and rhesus macaques in parallel in-vivo studies showed limited acute reactions. This preliminary study suggests there are no clinically significant xenocompatibility issues nor adverse short term outcomes in this model, supporting its use for human whole blood preclinical investigations. Further xenocompatibility validation in this NHP model with human-derived blood therapeutics should occur.

abstract_title: Validation of a novel In vitro platform for investigating Traumatic Brain Injury
author_block: C. Bolden<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Skibber<sup>3</sup>, S. D. Olson<sup>4</sup>, B. S. Gill<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Cox<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Center For Translational Injury,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Program In Regenerative Medicine,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is one of the leading causes of death and disability in the United States. TBI is a chronic disorder resulting from a heterogenous mechanical insult to the brain. This mechanical insult initiates a biochemical cascade of pathophysiological complications such as edema and neuroinflammation which severely impacts patient outcomes. Current experimental in vitro models attempt to mimic the complex pathophysiology of TBI, but often neglect the hemodynamic parameters that recapitulate in vivo TBI leading to a poor Blood Brain Barrier (BBB) phenotype. The development of a suitable in vitro TBI model will mimic pathogenesis by sequentially imposing the mechanical, metabolic, and inflammatory insults in a functional BBB in a high-throughput platform. This platform will allow for the independent modulation of the brain and blood compartments’ hydraulic forces, perfusion rates, and biochemical environments that have been neglected in previous models. Based on these parameters, we engineered a modular, dynamic platform around a Matrigel? coated Transwell? membrane. Our novel TBI platform utilized key BBB cellular components such as brain microvascular endothelial cells, astrocytes and mesenchymal stem cells (pericytes) arranged into either a direct contact coculture or triculture system.

Methods: Cellular layers were exposed to either a combination of Wall Shear Stress (WSS) (average of 4 dyne/cm2), and/or biochemical insult of tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-a, 5 ng/ml) or Cytochalasin-D (cD, 2.5 ug/ml). To mimic conditions of TBI, cellular layers were also exposed to an oxygen-glucose depleted environment followed by reperfusion (OGD/R). Transendothelial electrical resistance (TEER), FITC-Dextran extravasation (1, 7, & 15 kDa), and tight junction  immunofluorescence were used as validation markers of a BBB phenotype.

Results: Our results indicate that shear stress resulted in the enhancement of and maintenance of BBB phenotype through enhanced TEER in comparison to static condition in both the coculture and triculture BBB system. The triculture system achieved BBB characteristics including TEER up to 510 ? cm2 and a permeability coefficient (Papp) of 2.5 x 10-7 in 10 kDa FITC-dextran. Treatment with inflammatory insults TNF-a and cD caused a decrease in TEER over time, confirming the BBB phenotype of paracellular tightness. Glucose starvation with oxygen deprivation caused a decrease in TEER of the coculture system at the 2 hr timepoint and eventually recovered 4 hr after this metabolic insult.

Conclusion:Our findings suggest that our in vitro TBI platform is capable of initiating and/or enhancing the BBB phenotype over time to relevant in vivo characteristics. The goal in the development of our novel in vitro TBI platform is the potential refinement of current in vivo experiments, as well as the enhanced translation of preclinical results into clinically meaningful neuroprotective strategies for the future.

abstract_title: Bradykinin Causes Superoxide Anion Release in Neutrophils
author_block: A. Eitel<sup>1</sup>, M. Kelher<sup>3</sup>, E. Moore<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Cohen<sup>1,2</sup>, N. Vigneshwar<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadley<sup>1</sup>, M. Bartley<sup>1</sup>, M. Debot<sup>1</sup>, D. Kissau<sup>1</sup>, C. Silliman<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>Denver Health Medical Center,Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>Vitalant Research Institute,Denver, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs) are an integral part of innate immunity through eradication of pathogens and are key mediators in ARDS and multiple organ failure post-injury. Priming of PMNs causes adherence to the vascular endothelium and hyper-reactivity, such that agents that usually do not activate the respiratory burst cause PMN activation and release of reactive oxygen species (ROS), endothelial damage, and organ injury. Severe injury causes the release of many potential mediators which may act as a first event including circulating bradykinin (BK); and a second insult, such as bacterial infection, reperfusion injury, etc., will activate these primed PMNs, releasing ROS. We hypothesize that BK primes PMNs and a BK antagonist (HOE140) will inhibit priming.

Methods: PMNs were isolated from whole blood from healthy volunteers. PMNs were incubated with 31.2-1000 ng/ml of BK for 5 min at 37 º C, and activated with 1 μM fMLF. Priming, augmentation of the fMLF-activated respiratory burst, was measured by the maximal rate of O2– production by cytochrome C reduction. Pre-incubation with HOE140, a bradykinin receptor antagonist, followed by BK stimulation, assessed for inhibition. Statistical differences were determined via an ANOVA (p<0.05).

Results: Compared to vehicle controls BK primed PMNs at all tested concentrations (p=0.013), which was inhibited by HOE140 (81.4±33.3%) at the highest concentrations.

Conclusion: Severe injury causes the release of mediators, such as BK, priming PMNs and predisposing the patient to ARDS and MOF post-injury. BK, a component of the coagulation cascade, induces activation of innate immunity providing evidence for crosstalk between it and the coagulation system. This data also suggests HOE140 may be useful in inhibiting kininopathy caused by BK.

abstract_title: The use of neural networks image analysis as a surrogate for biopsy in volumetric muscle loss injury
author_block: G. Schumaker<sup>1</sup>, G. An<sup>1</sup>, C. Cockrell<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Vermont College Of Medicine / Fletcher Allen Health Care,Surgery,Burlington, VT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The process of wound healing after a Volumetric Muscle Loss (VML) injury is broadly characterized by extensive phases of degeneration, repair, and remodeling, culminating in fibrosis within the injured muscle and within surrounding tissues. In typical muscle repair, both the innate and adaptive immune response play a role in this healing through upregulation of genes expressed by M1 and M2 macrophages as well as CD4+ and CD8+ helper T cells. These genes, expressed as cytokine markers, can be used to characterize the extent of the immune response. Currently, quantifying the cytokine profile at a specific location in a wound requires the excision of tissue for subsequent analysis, a process which disturbs the wound and alters the future wound healing dynamics. In this work, we utilize convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to analyze wound images pre-biopsy in order to regress the relative up or down-regulation of the gene expression for TGFβ in order to elucidate phases of wound healing without disturbing tissue.

Methods: We have obtained a set of images of volumetric muscle loss injuries in a canine model. Tissue biopsies are samples from each of these injuries in a spatial grid over the injury. We have isolated a set of 81x81 pixel images of the biopsied tissue prior to its excision and subsequent analysis. We then annotate/label these images with the associated TGFβ expression (measured in pg/mg of tissue) at that specific site in the wound. We then regress the expression in TGFβ as a function of the pixels in the image (color and spatial distribution) using a CNN.

Results: The CNN is able to establish both relative relationships between the spatial concentrations of TGFβ in the same wound (e.g., TGFβ concentrations are greater at the wound edge than wound center), as well as accurate (within 10%) estimates of TGFβ expression in the global training set of pre-biopsy tissue images.

Conclusion: This project lays the groundwork for further research into the uses of image regression in analyzing other types of medical images. Of specific use to the area of surgery, CNNs, with the ability to recognize the levels of pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokine levels explored in this project, would be able to determine the stage of repair or disrepair in a VML wound, giving healthcare professionals a new perspective in clinical decision-making. Future experiments would be aimed at the sophistication of this workflow, with hopes that we can enhance the utility of CNNs for adoption in real clinical practice.

abstract_title: Unblocked Mobile Phones And Text Messaging In Patient Surveys: A Method For Increasing Response Rate
author_block: L. E. Peters<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Zhao<sup>1,2</sup>, H. Pearce<sup>1</sup>, G. Zhang<sup>2</sup>, S. Smith<sup>1,2,3</sup>, P. Pockney<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>John Hunter Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Newcastle, NSW, Australia <sup>2</sup>University of Newcastle,Faculty Of Health,Newcastle, NSW, Australia <sup>3</sup>Hunter Medical Research Institute,Newcaslte, NSW, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patient reported outcomes are becoming increasingly important in surgical quality in healthcare projects. There has been a continuing decline in health-related survey responses in the last 30 years, with most published data claiming between 20-60% response rates. A 75% response rate has been deemed necessary to ensure validity in a study; a very difficult target to reach. We have sought to design a methodology to increase the response rate of patient phone surveys using unblocked numbers and text messages for a quality in healthcare project.

Methods: For our project, patients were contacted via unblocked mobile phones one week after discharge from hospital. They were not made aware that they would be contacted for the project. If contact was not made after two consecutive phone calls on the same day, a text message was sent to the patient explaining the rationale for the call. If still no response by the following day, patients were then called once again with the same number. We recorded our response rate including at which stage in the method it occurred. The survey itself was always conducted via a call and could not be completed through text message.

Results: We attempted contact of 1112 patients. Though our method we achieved an 83.7% response rate. 74% of the patients responded to the first attempt at contact. A further 9.7% of patients were recaptured using text messaging and a call the following day. Of the 181 patients who did not participate the in study, 20 of them answered the call but did not wish to participate.

Conclusion: With this method, we were able to achieve a superior response rate of 83.7%. At our institution, patients are routinely called the day after discharge with a blocked number which achieves a response rate of 20-50%. We believe our high response rate can be contributed to two main factors: firstly due to the unblocked number which allows patients to directly return a missed call and may increase the likelihood of answering, and secondly the text messages which notifies the patients of the reason for the call, serving as a less intrusive method of communication. We have demonstrated the effectiveness in our centre for achieving a response rate greater than 75%. Validation in other centres is required to ensure reproducibility.

abstract_title: New, Parsimonious Tool to Predict Outcomes in Emergency Surgery – Comparing SURPAS to ACS-SRC
author_block: P. D. Rozeboom<sup>1,2,3</sup>, M. R. Bronsert<sup>2,3</sup>, C. G. Velopulos<sup>1,2</sup>, W. G. Henderson<sup>2,3,4</sup>, K. L. Colborn<sup>1,2,4</sup>, K. E. Hammermeister<sup>5</sup>, R. C. McIntyre<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Meguid<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Department Of Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Surgical Outcomes And Applied Research Program,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Adult And Child Center For Health Outcomes Research And Delivery Science,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Department Of Biostatistics And Informatics,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Division Of Cardiology,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The SUrgical Risk Preoperative Assessment System (SURPAS) offers an accurate, parsimonious risk assessment method to predict postoperative complications in a broad surgical population. SURPAS, which is integrated in the electronic health record (EHR), requires manual input of 5 predictor variables (3 variables are added automatically) to generate individualized predictions of 12 postoperative complications compared to national averages. However, SURPAS has not yet been assessed specifically in patients undergoing emergency surgery. Accuracy of SURPAS risk assessment was assessed and compared to the American College of Surgeons Surgical Risk Calculator (ACS-SRC) in a sample of emergency surgery patients.

Methods: SURPAS and ACS-SRC predicted risks of 7 postoperative adverse outcomes that are common between the two risk calculators (mortality, overall morbidity, readmission, UTI, cardiac, VTE, renal) were calculated for 1010 emergency surgical patients randomly selected from the ACS-NSQIP 2013-16 database; risk estimates were compared with known patient outcomes. Analysis of the data included Hosmer-Lemeshow (H-L) goodness of fit graphs and p-values, C-Indexes, and Brier scores.

Results: Results were similar between SURPAS and ACS-SRC for mortality, UTI, cardiac, VTE, and renal complications. The ACS-SRC tended to underestimate overall morbidity compared to SURPAS (H-L p-values 0.05 vs. 0.45). Both calculators tended to overestimate risk for readmission (H-L p-values 0.04 and 0.01).

Conclusion: Both calculators predicted mortality, UTI, cardiac, VTE, and renal complications well, but readmissions relatively poorly. SURPAS was better than ACS-SRC for predicting overall morbidity. Furthermore, SURPAS is integrated into the EHR and requires user input of only 5 variables.

abstract_title: Organizational Assessment of Health Literacy of an Academic Medical Center
author_block: G. Park<sup>1</sup>, D. Kim<sup>2</sup>, C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, L. M. Theiss<sup>1</sup>, I. C. Marques<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Gunnells<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Hardiman<sup>1</sup>, G. D. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Morris<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Idaho State University,Health Care Administration,Pocatello, IDAHO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Organizational health literacy has been identified by the National Academy of Medicine (NAM) as a key part of an effective healthcare system. Many health care organizations, however, fail to integrate health literacy principles into its structure. This study aims to assess the organizational health literacy of an academic medical center (AMC) through the perspective of the Department of Surgery and to identify areas in need of improvement.

Methods:  To assess organizational health literacy, the 10-item Health Literate Health Care Organization survey (HLHO-10) was administered to all the attending staff in the Department of Surgery at a single AMC from December 2018 to May 2019. The 10 items are based on the 10 attributes of a health literate organization as defined by the NAM. These include effective leadership, integration with healthcare system, employee training, patient inclusion, patient accommodation, clear interpersonal communication, easy access/navigation, media variety, informed consent, and clearly explained benefits/coverage.  Each item is scored on a scale from one to seven, with one being “absolutely not” to seven being “to a very large extent.” Data was analyzed to estimate the organization health literacy level of the AMC through the perspective of the Department of Surgery by each domain.

Results: Among the 118 attending physicians of the Department of Surgery who received the survey, 65 (55%) responded. The mean health literacy level of the AMC as rated by Department members was 3.84 out of 7.00. The domains “employee training” and “patient inclusion” scored the lowest with an average of 3.08 and 3.23, respectively. “Employee training” evaluates employee health literacy training with an emphasis on “expert educators” and progress monitoring. “Patient inclusion” assesses the involvement of patients in the development of health information and materials. Assessment of “easy access/navigation,” defined as access to health information and navigation within the healthcare facility, scored the highest with an average score of 4.98. Other scores are summarized in Table 1.                     

Conclusion: Opportunities for improvement exist in all domains of organizational health literacy. From the perspective of the Department of Surgery, employee training in health literacy and patient inclusion in health material development at the AMC scored the lowest. Major opportunities exist to address health literacy at an organization-level with several points of needed action.

abstract_title: Surgical Leadership Competencies for Hospital Network Expansion
author_block: A. Rajkumar<sup>1</sup>, A. Diaz<sup>2,4</sup>, K. R. Chhabra<sup>4,5</sup>, M. A. Byrnes<sup>4</sup>, P. Yang<sup>1</sup>, H. Nathan<sup>3,4</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University,Department Of Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan Institute for Healthcare Policy and Innovation,Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Today, many hospitals are part of a larger healthcare network. This evolution towards health system growth and consolidation has drastically changed the environment in which surgical leaders are tasked with maintaining a high standard of care within their departments. The objective of this study was to understand the most important competencies that surgical leaders used to navigate their hospital network expansion.

Methods:  In this qualitative study, we recruited 30 surgical leaders within the United States and Canada through an email sent via the Society of Surgical chairs. In-person or telephone interviews were conducted with the guidance of a semi-structured interview template. The interviews were coded through an iterative approach in MaxQDA and analyzed via thematic analysis to identify patterns and themes elicited amongst the interviews.

Results: We report on three key competencies surgical leaders leveraged within an expanding health system across multiple hospitals and satellite locations. First, surgical leaders fostered and recognized leadership skills amongst their faculty and staff. Second, surgical leaders navigated the tension and dynamics that exist between the goals of their department and the goals of the healthcare system. Third, in advancing their surgical department, surgical leaders invested into the people within their department and communicated a unifying vision and culture amongst their staff. Surgical leaders have recognized that investing in the human capital will ultimately lead to the synchrony between advancing the surgical-patient experience within an economically sound healthcare network.

Conclusion: As systems continue to expand and surgical departments grow across various hospitals and affiliated sites, surgical leaders are faced with the task of identifying a unifying vision and cultural theme among their department. Despite these challenges, surgical leaders have identified a unique opportunity to leverage their growing influence across the health system. The expansion of health networks has provided an opportunity for surgical chairs to invest in the people and culture of their department to further advance their network’s mission and needs.

abstract_title: Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Access to Local Anesthesia for Inguinal Hernia Surgery
author_block: J. B. Meier<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Stevens<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Berger<sup>3</sup>, T. Hogan<sup>1,4,5</sup>, M. Cullum<sup>6</sup>, H. Zeh<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Lee<sup>4</sup>, C. S. Skinner<sup>4</sup>, C. J. Brown<sup>7,8</sup>, C. Balentine<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Texas Southwestern,Department Of Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>VA North Texas Health Care System,Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Anesthesia,Durham, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Population And Data Sciences,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Edith Nourse Rogers Memorial Veterans Hospital,Center For Healthcare Organization And Implementation Research,Bedford, MASSACHUSETTS, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Division Of Psychology,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Gerontology, Geriatrics, And Palliative Care,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>8</sup>Birmingham/Atlanta VA Geriatric Research, Education, and Clinical Center,Birmingham, ALABAMA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Many studies have identified racial disparities in access to surgical care, but there have been few investigations of disparities in the use of different anesthesia modalities for surgery. Inguinal hernia repair is the most common general surgery operation in the US, and using local rather than general anesthesia for hernia repair may enhance postoperative recovery. Our study examined racial disparities in the use of local versus general anesthesia for inguinal hernia repair. We hypothesized that African American and Hispanic patients would be less likely than Caucasians to receive local anesthesia for inguinal hernia repair.

Methods: We analyzed data from 78,766 patients aged ≥18 years in the Veterans Affairs Surgical Quality Improvement Program database who underwent elective, unilateral, open inguinal hernia repair under general or local anesthesia from 1998-2018. We used multiple logistic regression to compare risk-adjusted use of local versus general anesthesia by race/ethnicity. We also compared 30-day postoperative complications among racial groups, and used a time series analysis to track trends in use of local anesthesia over the study period.

Results: In total, 17,892 patients (23%) received local anesthesia. When divided into groups by race/ethnicity, Caucasian patients more frequently received local anesthesia (15,009; 24%) compared to African Americans (2353; 17%) or Hispanics (530; 19%), p <0.05. After adjusting for confounding variables (age, comorbidity, functional status, and frailty), we found that both African Americans (OR 0.82, 95% CI 0.77-0.86) and Hispanics (OR 0.77, 95% CI 0.69-0.87) were significantly less likely to have hernia surgery under local anesthesia compared to Caucasians. These differences were present in each year of the study. Additionally, local anesthesia was associated with fewer postoperative complications for African American patients (OR 0.46, 95% CI 0.27-0.77), but not for Hispanic patients (OR 0.62, 95% CI 0.24-1.59).

Conclusion: Although the use of local anesthesia was associated with enhanced postoperative recovery for African American patients, they were significantly less likely to have inguinal hernias repaired under local than Caucasians. Addressing this disparity will require better understanding of how factors, including surgeon, anesthesiologist, and patient biases or preferences, may affect the choice of anesthesia modality for hernia repair.

abstract_title: Impact of Safety-Net Status in Cholecystostomy Tube Utilization in Acute Cholecystitis
author_block: E. A. Aguayo<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, M. Gandjian<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, K. Karunungan<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute cholecystitis is among the most common biliary pathologies, and is effectively managed with cholecystectomy. In select patients, percutaneous cholecystostomy tube (PCT) placement can provide temporary drainage of the gallbladder, allowing for stabilization and interval cholecystectomy. Prior studies have reported an association between safety-net hospital status and inferior clinical outcomes, often attributing these disparities to resource limitations. We aimed to determine the impact of hospital safety-net status on cholecystostomy utilization, mortality and readmissions following PCT placement in patients with Tokyo Grade III acute cholecystitis

Methods: All adults hospitalized for Tokyo Grade III acute cholecystitis were identified in the 2010-2015 Nationwide Readmissions Database. Hospitals were stratified into low-(LSH), medium- (MSH), or high- (HSH) safety-net tertiles based on the proportion of uninsured or Medicaid patients, and comparisons made between LSH and HSH. Categorical and continuous variables were studied using chi-square test and adjusted Wald test, respectively. Multivariable logistic regression was used to identify predictors of PCT utilization. The primary outcome of the study was PCT utilization, while secondary outcomes were in-hospital mortality and readmission at 30 days.

Results: Of an estimated 147,413 patients included for analysis, 27.5% were treated at HSH and 29.5% at LSH. Compared to those treated at LSH, patients at HSH were older (73.6 years vs 71.6 years, P=0.02) and more commonly received care in metropolitan teaching hospitals (75.0% vs 61.6%, P<0.001) and large centers (70.3% vs 57.3%, P<0.001). Patients treated at HSH more frequently received PCT than LSH (16.4% vs 14.7%, P=0.007), and less frequently underwent inpatient cholecystectomy (83.6% vs 85.3%, P=0.006). Mortality rates were similar at HSH and LSH (4.6% vs 4.7%, P=0.39) while 30-day readmissions were greater at HSH (25.2% vs 21.4%, P=0.009). After adjustment for patient and hospital factors, predictors of PCT use included HSH (adjusted odds ratio, AOR, 1.27, P<0.001), metropolitan teaching hospitals (AOR 2.23, P<0.001) and a history of chronic kidney disease (AOR 1.09, P=0.02, Figure). Among those receiving PCT, HSH was associated with increased odds of 30-day readmission (AOR 1.23, p=0.007).

Conclusion: Safety-net status is associated with greater use of PCT in patients admitted for Tokyo Grade III acute cholecystitis. Although there were no differences in mortality, patients receiving PCT at safety-net hospitals experienced greater readmissions. Efforts to address underlying disparities, such as access to care and resource availability, may improve care for those treated at safety-net hospitals.

abstract_title: COVID-19 Pandemic and the Cholecystitis Experience at an Urban Safety-Net Hospital
author_block: K. F. Valles<sup>1</sup>, E. Caron<sup>2</sup>, M. Y. Neufeld<sup>3</sup>, S. E. Sanchez<sup>2,3</sup>, T. S. Brahmbhatt<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Drexel University College of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston University School of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Boston Medical Center,Department Of General Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Benign gallbladder disease (BGD) is one of the most common reasons for emergency general surgery admission. There are over 700,000 reported cholecystectomies performed annually in the United States. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the novel SARS-COVID-19 outbreak a pandemic on March 11, 2020. The purpose of this study was to compare the number of cases presenting to our urban safety-net hospital and the severity of BGD admissions before and after the declaration of the pandemic and to compare trends to historic controls. We hypothesized that as a result of the pandemic declaration we would experience a decrease in the number of patients admitted but an increase in the severity of disease managed.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of BGD admissions from January 1st - May 31st in 2018, 2019, and 2020 at our institution. The rates of BGD admissions in two-week intervals before and after the pandemic declaration were compared against an average rate from historic controls. Difference-in-differences analysis was used to determine change in trends of BGD admissions post-pandemic. Additionally, the cohort was stratified by severity of disease based on Tokyo Guidelines. Finally, the odds of presenting with greater severity of disease after the pandemic was estimated using multivariate logistic regression.

Results: There was a significant difference in differences of BGD admission rates between 2020 and previous years (DID: -1.00, 95% CI: -1.82, -0.18, p=0.0168). The mean rate of BGD in 2-week intervals decreased from 5.2 to 2.67 cases after the pandemic declaration compared to previous years, where it increased from 4.3 to 6.0. After stratifying by severity, Tokyo I admissions decreased significantly after the pandemic declaration whereas severe cases (Tokyo II and III) did not. There was no significant difference in the odds of presenting with severe disease after the pandemic was declared (aOR: 1.00, 95% CI: 0.30, 3.38, p=0.9982).

Conclusion: From the time the WHO declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11, 2020 to May 31, 2020 there was a significant decrease in BGD admissions at our urban safety-net hospital. However, among those cases presenting to the hospital, there was no increase in the severity of disease based on the Tokyo classification. This data highlights that the pandemic impacted health care seeking behaviors for patients with milder disease while patients with severe disease continued to present to the hospital. Furthermore, this change in health seeking behavior did not lead to significantly worse disease among those admitted.

abstract_title: Family Perceptions of Palliative Care and Communication in the Surgical Intensive Care Unit
author_block: K. Par<sup>1</sup>, J. Grudziak<sup>1</sup>, K. Lavin<sup>1</sup>, M. Sten<sup>1</sup>, A. Huegerich<sup>1</sup>, K. Umble<sup>1</sup>, E. Twer<sup>1</sup>, T. Reid<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  While evidence demonstrates the benefits of palliative care for chronically ill patients, little data exists on palliative care for trauma and acute care surgery patients. Surgeon perceptions of palliative care may drive lack of use of specialty palliative care even though data show that patients and families in the SICU could have decreased length of stay, improved communication, and improved physical and emotional well-being with earlier integration of palliative care. This study evaluated family perceptions and experiences around palliative care in a Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU).

Methods:  Semi-structured interviews were conducted from February 1, 2020 to March 5, 2020 with five families of patients in the SICU at a single institution. Given COVID restrictions, the number of interviews was limited to a pilot study. The purpose was to understand experiences of palliative care conversations with the SICU team and determine preferences for educational materials on palliative and ICU care. 

Results: The three main themes deduced from the interviews included communication, team performance, and family awareness. All interviewees spoke about the importance of learning style with regards to their preference of modalities for learning about palliative care and their family members’ illnesses, citing written materials, speaking with a doctor or nurse, and speaking with a social worker as the top three preferred modes of information delivery. Eighty percent of interviewees also emphasized the importance of clear, honest communication with the families, as well as the care team’s inclusiveness of patients and families in decision making. Families want a general idea of the patient’s status or condition relayed early in the conversation to set expectations, followed by the details. While 80% of interviewees had participated in goals of care (GOC) meetings based on Advanced Care Planning notes, only 40% of the interviewees correctly understood that they had been part of a GOC conversation; Forty percent reported not having had a GOC discussion when they actually had participated in one, and 20% reported having a GOC discussion when they had not. Eighty percent of family members lacked understanding of the patients’ illnesses.

Conclusion: This study highlights the significance of frequent communication and goals of care discussions in the SICU, as well as the importance of incorporating a variety of educational material formats. Further studies are needed to fill the large gap in research regarding how SICU’s can integrate resources to help surrogates make end-of-life decisions.

abstract_title: OR Shutdown and Recovery: Restructuring the OR During the SARS-CoV-2 Pandemic
author_block: P. H. McClelland<sup>1</sup>, O. Cheng<sup>1</sup>, J. Hu<sup>1</sup>, J. Hunter<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Winkler<sup>1</sup>, R. Lee<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Zenilman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>NewYork-Presbyterian Brooklyn Methodist Hospital,Surgery,Brooklyn, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: During the 2020 SARS-CoV-2 outbreak in New York City, we and other hospitals canceled elective surgeries to increase hospital capacity for critically ill patients. We present data from our community hospital demonstrating how such restrictions affected operative case volumes between different surgical specialties, and how we recovered from it.  

Methods: Between March 17 and June 15, 2020, all elective surgeries were canceled. Operations were restricted to urgent and emergency surgeries during this time. All procedures performed during this shutdown (ORS) were recorded, as well as those 4 weeks before (PRE) and 4 weeks after (POST) for comparison. Volumes by specialty and level of surgical urgency were analyzed and compared between the three cohorts. Data is presented as mean ± SD (ANOVA) or percentages (χ 2 test).  

Results: A total of 2,475 cases were included in our analysis, of which 754 (30.5%) occurred during the 13-week shutdown. Overall case numbers dropped significantly during ORS and increased during recovery once restrictions were lifted (mean 245.0 ± 28.4 PRE vs 58.0 ± 30.9 ORS vs 186.0 ± 19.4 POST cases/week, p < 0.001). Although emergency surgeries comprised the majority of cases during ORS (26.4% PRE vs. 59.3% ORS vs. 31.5% POST, p < 0.001), the overall frequency of emergency cases decreased during this time (mean 64.5 ± 7.9 PRE vs. 34.4 ± 12.1 ORS vs. 58.5 ± 4.0 POST cases/week, p < 0.001). Open surgeries represented half of all surgeries throughout all three phases and remained relatively constant proportional to caseload (52.2-54.1%). By comparison, intravascular surgeries were proportionally increased during ORS, whereas minimally invasive and robotic surgeries were proportionally decreased (+7.6%, -3.4%, -3.0%, respectively, p < 0.001, see Fig. 1). General surgery saw the largest proportional increase of any service during ORS, followed by urology and neurosurgery (+9.5%, +3.0%, +2.8%, respectively).  In contrast, orthopedics, gynecology, and otolaryngology/plastics surgeries all decreased (-5.0%, -4.4%, -5.9%, respectively, p < 0.001).  Nearly all specialties recovered to pre-shutdown levels after the OR was reopened.  

Conclusions: Operative volume significantly decreased during the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak, and vascular/general surgery became the most active surgical services. Most cases recorded during this time were urgent and emergency in nature, although there were fewer emergency cases overall. We further observed a shift away from minimally invasive and robotic approaches in favor of open surgeries. This reallocation of resources may be useful for future crisis planning among community hospitals.

abstract_title: Variability in hospital costs for short stay emergent laparoscopic appendectomy
author_block: E. T. Bernard<sup>1</sup>, D. Davenport<sup>1</sup>, J. Parrish<sup>1</sup>, A. Bernard<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Kentucky,College Of Medicine,Lexington, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute care surgery (ACS) diagnoses make up 20% of all inpatient admissions in the U.S. and 25% of hospital costs (Knowlton). In order to inform cost reduction efforts, we sought to measure variability in hospital costs for short stay emergent laparoscopic appendectomy.

Methods: We queried our consortium database for adult and pediatric patients who underwent emergent laparoscopic appendectomy for appendicitis with length of stay ≤ 3 days. We extracted calendar FY 2019 direct costs (DC) by age group and diagnosis code for sites reporting at least 5 cases. Costs in the database are derived from actual charges multiplied by a site and cost center specific cost-to-charge ratio. Labor portions are scaled per site by the area wage index by VIZIENT. Sites were ranked by quintile of DC per case to provide confidentiality and blinding.

Results: In a total of 128 hospitals, the median number of cases per site was 35.5 (IQR 20 – 65) with a total of 6,585 cases analyzed. The largest cost centers by descending order included the OR, Med/Surg. Supplies, Routine Floor Care, Pharmacy, Emergency Room, Anesthesia, Laboratory, and CT Scans, with all others each less than 2% of total costs. The relation between OR costs and total costs is strong but not complete. The mean DC per case was $4,609 (SD 1,347). DC did not correlate with age, diagnosis code, nor total volume of cases reported by site.

Conclusion: Wide variation in cost of laparoscopic appendectomy in academic medical centers suggests potential for significant cost reduction. Strategic opportunities in cost reduction appear to lie outside the OR.

abstract_title: Association of Primary Language with Access to Elective Surgery for Diverticulitis
author_block: L. R. Maurer<sup>1</sup>, N. Perez<sup>1</sup>, E. Witt<sup>2</sup>, B. G. Allar<sup>3</sup>, T. Uribe-Leitz<sup>3,4</sup>, G. Peck<sup>5,6</sup>, R. W. Bergmark<sup>3,7</sup>, G. Ortega<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health, Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Harvard Medical School,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ,Department Of Surgery,New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>6</sup>Rutgers School of Public Health,Piscataway, NJ, USA <sup>7</sup>Harvard Medical School,Department Of Otolaryngology-Head And Neck Surgery,Brookline, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Language barriers can limit access to care for patients with non-English primary language (NEPL). The objective of this study was to examine the association between primary language and urgent versus elective admission type for colon resection in patients who underwent surgery for diverticulitis.

Methods:  Patients aged 18-90 years from the 2009-2014 New Jersey Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project State Inpatient Database (NJ SID) were included if they underwent a partial colon resection (with or without ostomy) for diverticulitis. NJ SID was linked with the Federal Information Processing System to include sociodemographic information. Primary language was dichotomized into NEPL versus English primary language (EPL), and further sub-categorized into Spanish NEPL versus non-Spanish NEPL. The outcome of interest was acuity of surgical admission, dichotomized into urgent/emergent versus elective. Multivariable analyses were performed, controlling for age, sex, race, year, insurance payer, income quartile, and Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI).  

Results: A total of 9,561 patients underwent surgery for diverticulitis, of which there were 594 (6.2%) with NEPL. Among NEPL patients, 301 (51%) were primary Spanish-speakers. Patients with NEPL and EPL were similar in age (median age 58 vs 59 years; p=0.51), sex (52% vs 53% female; p=0.46) and CCI (median 1 vs 1; p=0.55). Patients with NEPL were more likely to be uninsured (19% vs 5.6%; p<0.001), and more likely to live in a neighborhood below the 50th percentile for median household income (31% vs 13%; p<0.001). 60% of NEPL patients had surgery during an urgent/emergent admission (as opposed to during an elective admission), compared to 48% of patients with EPL (p<0.001). On multivariable analysis, NEPL was associated with increased likelihood of undergoing surgery during an urgent/emergent admission for diverticulitis (OR 1.53; p<0.001) compared to patients with EPL. On further analysis of NEPL subgroups, patients with non-Spanish NEPL had significantly increased odds of urgent/emergent surgical admission compared to patients with EPL (OR 2.36; p<0.001). The relationship between Spanish NEPL and presentation acuity did not reach statistical significance (OR 0.88; p=0.384).

Conclusion: Patients with NEPL are more likely to undergo surgery during an urgent/emergent admission for diverticulitis compared to their EPL counterparts. Our findings suggest that language barriers may contribute to disparities in access to elective surgery. These language barriers may manifest through disparities in referral patterns, provider-patient communication, and/or health literacy, and merit further examination.

abstract_title: Outcomes and Resource Utilization in Non-Elective Open vs. Laparoscopic Ventral Hernia Repair
author_block: J. Kim<sup>1</sup>, C. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, M. Gandjian<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  While the laparoscopic approach is widely accepted and used in elective ventral hernia repairs, open surgery remains the standard in urgent settings. This study compared the clinical and financial outcomes of non-elective open and laparoscopic ventral hernia repair using a nationally-representative cohort.

Methods:  The 2010-2017 National Inpatient Sample (NIS) was used to identify non-elective adult (≥18 years) hospitalizations for ventral hernia repair performed within two days of admission. International Classification of Disease 9/10th Revision codes were used to tabulate patient and operative characteristics. Trends were examined using nonparametric tests while Chi-square or adjusted Wald tests were used to compare categorical or continuous variables, respectively. Multivariable logistic and linear regression models were used to adjust for a multitude of covariates, including operative approach, time to operation, gangrene, obstruction, and requirement of bowel resection. Outcomes of interest were mortality, rate of routine discharge, total duration of hospitalization (LOS), and adjusted costs.

Results: Of an estimated 164,780 hospitalizations for non-elective ventral hernia repair, 22.9% utilized a laparoscopic approach. The proportion of laparoscopy exhibited a steady trend (23.9 in 2010 to 23.7% in 2017) with increased costs ($13,600 in 2010 to $16,700 in 2017, NP-trend<0.001) over the study period. Concomitant bowel resection was performed in 10.3% of open and 2.0% of laparoscopic cohorts (p<0.001). Patients who underwent an open repair were on average older (59.6 vs 57.4 years, p<0.001) and had higher rates of ischemic bowel (1.1 vs 0.2%, p<0.001) or obstruction (70.8 vs 66.3%, p<0.001) compared to laparoscopic. Patients undergoing open repair had increased rates of wound infection (2.3 vs 1.0%, p<0.001), sepsis (3.6 vs 1.4%, p<0.001) and prolonged mechanical ventilation (5.6 vs 2.3%, p<0.001). The laparoscopic cohort was discharged home more frequently and had reduced mortality, costs, and LOS (Table). After adjustment, use of laparoscopy was not associated with lower odds of in-hospital mortality, but was significantly associated with increased odds of routine discharge, and reduced LOS and costs (Table).

Conclusion: While patients receiving open repair appear to be more complex, their clinical outcomes remained comparable to those having a laparoscopic repair. Further study of hernia-specific factors not captured in the NIS is warranted in order to improve patient selection for laparoscopic ventral hernia repair in the non-elective setting.

abstract_title: Palliative Care Outcomes in Post-Surgical Patients Requiring Prolonged Mechanical Ventilation
author_block: J. House<sup>1</sup>, H. Jensen<sup>1</sup>, S. Karim<sup>1</sup>, K. Kalkwarf<sup>1</sup>, K. Sexton<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,Little Rock, ARKANSAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Palliative care consultations are increasing for critically ill patients and have been associated with improved outcomes and decreased cost in medical and surgical patients during their hospitalization. There is a knowledge gap on the effects of palliative care consultation on readmissions in post-surgical patients who require prolonged mechanical ventilation (MV). Thus, investigation into the fiscal efficacy of palliative care utilization within this group is warranted and we hypothesize that palliative care consultation will decrease length of stay and readmission.

Methods: The National Readmission Database was queried for persons between the years 2010 and 2014 who underwent a major operation (HCUP data element ORPOC=1) and required MV for over 96 consecutive hours (ICD-9-CM V46.1). Univariate and bivariate statistical analyses were performed with the outcomes of interest being total cost, length of stay, and readmission rates. For bivariate analysis, those that had a palliative care consultation were compared to those who did not. Linear regression modeling was then performed. All statistical calculations were performed using STATA (STATA Corp, LLC; College Station, TX).

Results: The palliative care group had more comorbidities (4.7 vs 4.3, p<0.001), suffered from more chronic diagnoses (8.6 vs 7.8, p<0.001), and were older in mean age (65 vs 59, p<0.001). Patients in the palliative care group were less likely to be discharged to home and mortality was higher (11% vs 1.2%, p<0.001). Palliative care was associated with decreased average cost ($94,369 versus $112,202.10, p<0.001), decreased length of stay (29.6 days vs 33.1 days, p=0.0031), but no significant difference was observed in the rate of readmission (24% vs 25%, p=0.75).

Conclusion: Palliative care offers benefits in terms of both healthcare resource allocation and quality of life for the critically ill patient. Our results support the efficacy of palliative care use within post-surgical patients requiring prolonged MV for inpatient outcomes.  Further work needs to be done to understand the finding that initiating a palliative care plan did not decrease the rate of readmission.

abstract_title: National Readmissions Database Characterization of Bile Duct Repair following Cholecystectomy
author_block: S. E. Hill<sup>1</sup>, H. K. Jensen<sup>2</sup>, R. J. Reif<sup>2,4</sup>, S. A. Karim<sup>3,4</sup>, K. W. Sexton<sup>2,3,4</sup>, K. J. Kalkwarf<sup>2</sup>, E. Giorgakis<sup>2</sup>, L. J. Burdine<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,College Of Medicine,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,Department Of Surgery,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,Department Of Biomedical Informatics,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,Department Of Health Policy And Management,Little Rock, AR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cholecystectomy is one of the most common surgical procedures in the United States, with over 90% of these procedures performed laparoscopically. A major cholecystectomy complication is an injury to the common bile duct (CBD). Bile duct injury incidence has been reported to be 0.3%-0.6%, with increased risk in laparoscopic procedures. Bile duct repair (BDR) following cholecystectomy is an expensive procedure, associated with higher healthcare utilization rates, cumulative cost, hospital stay, and occasional litigation. The true incidence, cost, and readmission rates of bile duct repair following cholecystectomy in the U.S. have been difficult to assess at a national level. 

Methods: The National Readmissions Database (NRD) was used to define the incidence, cost, and readmission prevalence of post-cholecystectomy biliary repair. In this retrospective cohort study, analysis of cholecystectomy patients (N= 1,768,725) was performed using STATA software, version 14.0 (College Station, TX). Patients were included based on a series of ICD-9 codes associated with bile duct repair. Individuals were organized into cohorts based on if they were readmitted following cholecystectomy or not. Patients were stratified based on if and when they required bile duct repair following cholecystectomy.

Results: Incidence of necessitated bile duct repair was 1.67%. Repair surgery doubled the length of stay and cost of the cholecystectomy. 2.27% of bile duct repair patients (N=671) were readmitted to the hospital. Double the proportion of patients in the lowest socioeconomic quartile were readmitted when compared with those in the highest socioeconomic quartile.

Conclusion: The National Readmission Database indicates the incidence of the bile duct repair following cholecystectomy is 1.67% with an average hospital stay of 10 days at a cost of approximately $33,390.48. The hospital ownership, or location did not impact the rate of BDR or readmission. Teaching hospitals had the highest rate of BDR. The socioeconomic status of patients, likewise, did not impact the rate of BDR. Patients in the lowest income quartile were twice as likely to be readmitted following BDR when compared with patients in the highest socioeconomic quartile. BDR is a rare but potentially impactful complication after cholecystectomy. Often iatrogenic in nature, various practices exist in documenting and billing for this procedure. To our knowledge, this is one of the few publications exploring the incidence and impact of BDR on a national level.

abstract_title: Investigating First Year Surgery Residents' Expectations of Demand, Control, and Support During Training
author_block: F. M. Ojute<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Lebares<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Department Of Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgery interns are at highest risk for attrition early in training, with significantly increased risk of developing depression during the first few months and high burnout, thereafter.Many efforts to address these issues have had limited success; in part due to our incomplete understanding of causation.Maslach frames burnout as the product of a mismatch between the expectation and reality of one's work. In occupational science, demand, control and support(or resources) are recognized as critical factors influencing worker satisfaction versus strain. In General Surgery residents realistic expectations of residency demands in regard to work hours and stress levels have been associated with increased likelihood of completing training. Nevertheless, little else in known about the expectations of in-coming general surgery residents, nor how expectations might vary by gender-identity or race. 

Methods: Using a constructivist grounded theory approach, we interviewed 14 incoming interns at our institution, 57% women,exploring expectations regarding work demands and control, personal and professional support, race/gender relations, and means of experience management. An interview script was developed guided by the Job Demand Resources model.Transcripts were manually coded through an iterative process involving discussion between researchers, comparing codes between participants and noting emergent codes; later analyzed using the software Dedoose.Thematic analysis was used to develop themes, framing our understanding of intern’s expectations.

Results:Four main themes emerged: past experience, rewards, challenges, and the desire to belong. Key Related sub-themes were uncertainty, stereotypes, and lack of preparation. For example: all PGY-1s expected to encounter sexism and racism based on past experience, but had little idea of how to defend themselves or be an ally within the bounds of  cultural stoicism; most expressed belief that previously effective methods of social support and self care wouldn't be possible during residency; a common challenge expressed involved “hidden curriculums” and “backroom judgements“. Feeling expressed varied from resigned and matter-of-fact, to fearful, and resentful.  Despite this, all interns expressed excitement at starting residency.

Conclusion:Our results suggest that expectations are influenced by past experience, resident shared mythology/stereotypes, level of program diversity, creating unprepared interns, and surgical culture. It is unclear exactly why interns express excitement about surgical residency after professing the culture as toxic and unreasonable, and this warrants further investigation into the surgical personality, surgical culture, and their intersection.

abstract_title: Predicting Cholecystectomy Operative Course from Gallbladder Inflammation
author_block: T. Ward<sup>1,2</sup>, D. A. Hashimoto<sup>1,2</sup>, O. R. Meireles<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Surgical AI and Innovation Laboratory,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Operative courses of laparoscopic cholecystectomies vary widely due to differing patient pathologies. Despite this variation, outcomes are assessed as if each procedure was equivalent. Efforts to address this disparity include scores measuring gallbladder inflammation, such as the Parkland Grading Scale (PGS), which scores inflammation on a scale from 1 to 5 based on the initial view of the gallbladder. The PGS has been prospectively validated to correlate to post-operative outcomes. We investigated if PGS led to variation of intra-operative outcomes, including operative duration (overall and per surgical phase), attainment of the Critical View of Safety (CVS), and inadvertent gallbladder injury during removal from the liver bed.   

Methods:  Laparoscopic cholecystectomy videos were annotated by one surgeon who labelled the timestamps for start and end of surgical phases, total laparoscopic duration (with intra-operative cholangiogram time subtracted), PGS, time the CVS was attained, and the timestamps of gallbladder injury during removal from the liver bed. Each video was also linked to the surgeon performing the case with an anonymized identifier. To analyze effect of PGS on overall and per-phase duration, we used a linear regression model, with the surgeon identifier as an interaction variable. We used this interaction variable because each surgeon has a different operative course due to their individual technique preferences and typical patients’ pathology (e.g.?more cholelithiasis versus acute cholecystitis). To analyze the PGS’s effect on attainment of CVS and gallbladder injury, we performed logistic regression with a generalized linear model, using the surgeon as an interaction variable for the CVS to account for surgeon technique preference.

Results: We analyzed 150 laparoscopic cholecystectomy videos performed by 22 surgeons. The videos had a median laparoscopic duration length of 37.2 minutes (1st-3rd quartile 23.0-54.5 min). Each point increase in the PGS led to a 6.39 minute increase in operative duration (R2 = 0.708, 95% CI 0.330-12.5, p = 0.039), 4.53 minute increase in active dissection time (R2 = 0.530, 95% CI 0.667-8.39, p = 0.022), 4.96 minute increase in time to first clip application (R2 = 0.600, 95% CI 1.34-8.58, p = 0.008), and 1.40 increased odds of creating an inadvertent hole in the gallbladder (95% CI 1.03 - 1.91, p = 0.0318). Increases in PGS did not result in increased time to remove the gallbladder from the liver bed (p = 0.273) and did not impact the odds of attaining a CVS (p = 0.380).   

Conclusion: Initial assessment of gallbladder inflammation with PGS is predictive of the intra-operative course. Initial gallbladder inflammation assessment could be applied to optimize operative workflow and generate per-surgeon and per-resident metrics for use in quality and safety improvements and education.

abstract_title: Predictors of 1-Year Mortality Following Gastrografin Challenge for Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction
author_block: R. B. Cohen<sup>1</sup>, S. Olafson<sup>1</sup>, M. Kaplan<sup>1</sup>, B. Moran<sup>1</sup>, P. Leung<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Einstein Medical Center,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With routine administration of Gastrografin (GG) in the management of adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO), it is important to characterize predictors of long term outcome following its use. The purpose of this study is to identify factors predictive of 1-year mortality following GG Challenge for ASBO.

Methods: A retrospective chart review from January 2016 to January 2018 identified patients who were diagnosed with ASBO by computed tomography (CT) and underwent GG Challenge. Patients were classified by 1-year survival. Patient factors, comorbidities, surgical history, features of GG administration, complications, and operative requirement were compared using chi-square or t-test. Multivariable logistic regression analyzed variables with P < 0.05.

Results: Of 134 patients identified, 123 survived at least 1 year. 11 patients were deceased within 1 year conferring a 1-year mortality rate of 8.21%. Non-survivors compared to ≥1 year survivors had a significantly higher age (77.18 vs. 65.76), proportion with congestive heart failure (CHF) (54.55% vs. 13.83%), time from admission to GG administration (45.36 hours vs. 26.48 hours), complication rate (63.64% vs. 19.42%), and operative requirement (45.45% vs. 17.89%) (P < .05). On multivariable logistic regression, CHF, any post-operative complications, and operative requirement created the best-fit model for predicting 1-year mortality (R2 = .321, P < .05).

Conclusion: Advanced age, presence of CHF, late GG administration, post-operative complications, and operative requirement correlated to higher 1-year mortality in our population of ASBO patients who received GG. In particular, CHF, having any complication, and operative requirement, considered simultaneously, were the most predictive of 1-year mortality.

abstract_title: COVID-19 and Emergency General Surgery at an Academic Medical Center - Where Did the Patients Go?
author_block: S. Gadomski<sup>1</sup>, G. J. Koenig<sup>1</sup>, C. McPartland<sup>1</sup>, A. Kohli<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Cohen<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Marks<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Thomas Jefferson University,Division Of Acute Care Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: During the novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic our institution suspended elective surgery on March 16. However, emergency general surgery continued with no changes in operative management of surgical diseases. We examined changes in appendectomy and cholecystectomy volume during the COVID-19 pandemic. We hypothesized that the pandemic would not affect the volume of cholecystectomies and appendectomies performed for acute disease.

Methods:  Using an administrative database, appendectomies and cholecystectomies performed by the Acute Care Surgery Service at an urban academic medical center in Philadelphia, PA between April and May of 2018-2020 were identified via CPT codes. March was excluded as a washout period. Case volume from 2018 and 2019 was averaged to establish a baseline. The baseline was then compared to its respective months during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Results: There were 161 appendectomies and 187 cholecystectomies performed between April 1st and May 31st of 2018-2020. Figure 1 shows the aggregate baseline for both procedures as well as the volume during COVID-19. The non-COVID data represents an average of case volume between 2018 and 2019 with standard error shown. The average volume per month decreased to 13 cases from 24 (-45%) in April and 21 cases from 27 (-22%) in May 2020. In April 2020, average appendectomy case volume decreased 26% while average cholecystectomy volume decreased from 14 cases to 6 (-57%). Cholecystectomy volume dropped by 24% and appendectomy by 17% in May 2020 from their respective baselines.

Conclusion: We saw a decrease in volume during our COVID-19 peak; a surprise given the acute nature of these disease processes. We did not note a difference in illness severity or an increase in non-operative management. As restrictions lifted in early June, appendectomy volume increased and overall volume approached historic averages. Additional analysis is required to elucidate the impact of COVID-19 on emergency general surgery volume.

abstract_title: Carcinoid Crisis During Surgery for Neuroendocrine Tumors: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
author_block: A. Xu<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Suz<sup>3</sup>, T. Reljic<sup>4</sup>, A. C. Are<sup>1</sup>, A. Kumar<sup>5</sup>, J. Strosberg<sup>1</sup>, B. Powers<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Denbo<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Fleming<sup>1</sup>, D. A. Anaya<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute,Department Of Gastrointestinal Oncology,Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine,Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute,Department Of Anesthesiology,Tampa, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine,Office Of Research,Tampa, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine,USF Health Program For Comparative Effectiveness Research And Evidence-Based Medicine,Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgery is the only curative option for patients with neuroendocrine tumors (NET) and is also indicated for debulking of unresectable liver metastasis. Intraoperative carcinoid crisis (CC), characterized by hemodynamic instability, is thought to be a common and potentially lethal complication, with preoperative octreotide often recommended as a prevention strategy. However, recent society guidelines raised concern regarding limited data on CC and the use of prophylactic octreotide. Our goal was to systematically evaluate existing evidence characterizing CC, and to examine the efficacy of prophylactic octreotide from published reports.  

Methods:  Following PRISMA guidelines, a systematic review and meta-analysis was performed. A systematic search was done using PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Library to identify published studies relevant to CC occurring during surgery for NET (2000-2020). Records were independently reviewed by two authors for study relevance and discrepancies resolved by consensus with a third reviewer. Eligibility criteria included studies of patients having surgery for well-differentiated midgut NET and/or NET liver metastasis, and reporting data on any of the following CC endpoints: incidence, risk factors, and prognosis, and on the efficacy of prophylactic octreotide. Meta-analysis was performed using random-effects restricted maximal likelihood models.

Results: The initial search produced 345 unique records. After screening and full-text review, 8 studies met inclusion criteria (n=943 operations). Hemodynamic instability was the primary feature used to define CC, with some variation and no standard definition across the studies. Similarly, for studies comparing use of prophylactic octreotide, regimens varied by dose and timing of octreotide administration. After meta-analysis evaluation, the pooled incidence of CC was 19% (95% CI [0.06-0.36]), with presence of liver metastasis (odds ratio 2.85 [1.49-5.47]) and male gender (0.58 [0.34-0.99]) found to be the only significant risk factors. The occurrence of CC was not associated with increased risk of postoperative mortality (1.19[0.13-11.02]), however it was associated with increased risk of major postoperative complications (2.12[1.03-4.35]). The use of prophylactic octreotide was not associated with decreased risk of CC on the pooled data (0.73[0.32-1.66]) or sensitivity analysis for studies that tested multiple regimens (preoperative octreotide: 0.70[0.30-1.59] and intraoperative octreotide: 0.82[0.36-1.85]).

Conclusion: We found that CC occurs frequently in patients having surgery for midgut NETs, specifically those with NET liver metastasis, and is associated with worse postoperative outcomes. Current data does not support the use of routine prophylactic octreotide. Future studies should focus on prospective evaluation of well-defined prophylactic protocols using a standardized definition for CC.

abstract_title: Does a two surgeon approach to robotic pancreatic resection improve outcomes?
author_block: J. Glasser<sup>4</sup>, J. Huston<sup>2</sup>, R. Shridhar<sup>3</sup>, K. Meredith<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Florida State University College Of Medicine,Gastrointestinal Oncology,Sarasota, FLORIDA, USA <sup>2</sup>Sarasota Memorial Institute for Cancer Care,Gastrointestinal Oncology,Sarasota, FLORIDA, USA <sup>3</sup>Florida Hospital Cancer Institute,Radiation Oncology,Orlando, FLORIDA, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida State University College Of Medicine,Tallahassee, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The expansion of robotic-assisted surgery is occurring quickly, particularly with resections of the pancreas. While many surgeons are proficient in open pancreatic surgery, few have been trained to perform pancreatic resections utilizing the robot.  Many high volume robotic pancreatic surgeons advocate starting a robotic pancreatic practice utilize a 2-surgeon (2S) approach.  However, little is known regarding the outcomes of the 2-surgeon approach.  The purpose of this study is to evaluate a 2-surgeon approach in application for robotic pancreatic resections. 

Methods: We queried a prospectively maintained pancreatic database to identify all patients undergoing pancreatic resection utilizing the robot from 2012-2019. The surgeon who instituted the database was involved in all the surgical procedures.  An additional surgeon was hired in 2017 and a 2-surgeon technique was adopted for all pancreatic resections. We then compared a single surgeon’s experience to a dual surgeon approach.  We compared operative times, conversion rates, morbidity, mortality, pancreatic leak and re-admissions. Statistical analyses were undertaken utilizing Chi-squared and Mann-Whitney U-test where appropriate. Significance was accepted with p<0.05.

Results: We identified 160 patients with a median age of 71 (24-91).  There were 91 males and 69 females.  The mean BMI and ASA was 27.4 ± 4.7 and 2.8 ± 0.6. There were 61 (38.1) adenocarcinomas, 44 (27.5) IPMN, 29 (18.1) neuroendocrine, and 26 (16.3) other.  There were 83 patients who underwent surgery by a single surgeon and 77 by a 2-surgeon technique.  The mean operative time was lower in the 2S approach 401 vs 194, p<0.001. Estimated blood loss was also slightly lower in the 2S cohort 125 vs 50, p=0.02.  The conversion to open was 4.8% in the 1S vs 1.3% in the 2S group, p=0.37. There were no differences in R0 resections p=0.5, re-operations p=0.11, or length of stay p=0.15.  Re-admission rates were lower in the 1S group 12% vs 24.7%, p=0.04.  There were no differences in overall or grade III-V morbidity between groups, p=0.07. The pancreatic leak rate was higher in the 2S group compared to 1S: 27.3% vs 10.8%, p=0.01.  There were no differences in mortality between groups, p=0.28. 

Conclusion: A 2-surgeon approach to robotic pancreatic resection does improve operative time, estimated blood loss with slight improvements in conversion to open procedures.  However, the morbidity, and oncologic parameters were not significantly different amongst the 2 groups.  Pancreatic leak rates however were higher in the 2- surgeon approach, but this may be related to differences in experience between the co-surgeons.

abstract_title: Lymphadenectomy in Open Vs Minimally Invasive Pancreaticoduodenectomy for PDAC
author_block: Y. Ashouri<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Bartz-Kurychi<sup>1,2</sup>, I. Ghaderi<sup>1</sup>, I. Konstantinidis<sup>3</sup>, F. B. Maegawa<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>3</sup>Texas Tech University Health Science Center,El Pase, TX, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Department Of Surgery/College Of Medicine/,Tucson, AZ, USA <sup>2</sup>Southern Arizona VA Health Care System,Department Of Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma commonly metastasizes to lymph nodes (LN) and adequate lymphadenectomy is a key component of pancreatic oncological resections. Minimally invasive pancreaticoduodenectomy (MIP) is increasingly being performed in the United States. This study aimed to compare the lymph node yield between MIP and open approaches.

Methods: The 2010-2016 National Cancer Database was utilized to identify patients who underwent laparoscopic, robotic or open pancreatoduodenectomy for pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Primary outcome was adequate lymphadenectomy, defined as retrieval of ≥ 15 LNs. LN yield was examined for MIP (laparoscopic and robotic) and open approaches.

Results: A total of 11888 patients were identified, of those 2172 (18.2%) underwent MIP. The conversion rate was 24.4% (n=531). The majority of the MIP cases were performed at Academic Cancer Programs (64.3%). Interestingly, 66.2% of the MIP cases were performed at facilities with less than 15 cases/year. Compared to open pancreatoduodenectomy, MIP was associated with higher odds of LN yield ≥15, with an adjusted Odds Ratio (aOR): 1.24, 95% Confidence Interval (CI): 1.06-1.39. There was no significant difference in the odds of positive margins (aOR: 0.93, 95% CI: 0.82-1.06) and 90-day mortality (aOR: 0.84, 95% CI: 0.67-1.06) between MIP and open approaches.

Conclusion: In this large population-based database analysis, MIP was independently associated with a higher LN yield than open pancreatoduodenectomy. No difference in rate of positive margins or 90-day mortality. These findings suggest MIP can be performed safely, while maintaining oncological standards. Further prospective data is needed to confirm these findings.

abstract_title: Robotic Resection of Klatskin Tumor: Outcomes of our Initial Resections Utilizing a Modern Approach
author_block: I. Sucandy<sup>1</sup>, K. Jacob<sup>1</sup>, K. Luberice<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Bourdeau<sup>1</sup>, V. Przetocki<sup>1</sup>, S. B. Ross<sup>1</sup>, A. S. Rosemurgy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>AdventHealth Tampa,Research,Tampa, FLORIDA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While minimally invasive techniques to treat other hepatopancreatobiliary tumors is gaining popularity, Klatskin tumor resection continues to be undertaken via ‘open’ approach due to difficult dissection in the porta hepatis and the need for a complex biliary reconstruction. We aim to evaluate our initial outcomes with robotic Klatskin tumor resection as a potential alternative to the ‘open’ approach.  

Methods: With IRB approval, all patients who underwent robotic resection of a Klatskin tumor were prospectively studied. Demographics, jaundice, ASA class, and perioperative outcomes were collected. Postoperative complications were defined according to the Clavien-Dindo classification, data are presented as median (mean ± SD).

Results:Eight patients who underwent robotic Klatskin tumor resection were included. Their median age was 75 (72 ± 8.2) years, BMI of 23 (25 ± 6.1) kg/m2, ASA Class of 3 (2.8 ± 0.5), and MELD score of 9 (11 ± 6.8). By the Bismuth-Corlette classification 3 patients had type 2 lesion, one type 3A and four type 3B. Median tumor size was 2 (3 ± 1.8) cm. Two patients (25%) underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy prior to surgical resection. All eight patients had preoperative stent placement. Estimated blood loss was 150 (175 ± 130.9) mL and operative time of 492 (466 ± 96.2) minutes.  There were no intraoperative complications or conversions to ‘open’. 6 patients had concomitant major hepatectomy (Table). Three patients developed postoperative complications (two bile leak, one perihepatic collection).  No patients required ICU admission, blood transfusion, or reoperation. On final pathology, seven patients had cholangiocarcinoma; one demonstrated a complete pathological response to neoadjuvant therapy. Negative margins were achieved in all patients. 7 patients received adjuvant therapy. No 90-day mortality occurred.

Conclusion: To our knowledge, this is the first U.S study evaluating this technique. Robotic resection for Klatskin Tumor is safe and feasible with favorable short-term outcomes. Robotic approach serves as a potential alternative to the conventional ‘open’ method.

abstract_title: Management of Gallstone Biliary Obstruction in the Nationwide Readmissions Database
author_block: T. H. Christensen<sup>1</sup>, A. Gongola<sup>1</sup>, H. Jensen<sup>2</sup>, S. Karim<sup>3</sup>, R. Reif<sup>2,3</sup>, K. W. Sexton<sup>2,3,4</sup>, A. Bhavaraju<sup>2</sup>, K. Kalkwarf<sup>2</sup>, L. Burdine<sup>5</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,College Of Medicine,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,Department Of Health Policy And Management,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,Department Of Biomedical Informatics Department Of Surgery,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,Division Of Transplant Surgery,Little Rock, AR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bile duct obstruction (BDO) due to choledocholithiasis can be treated using different procedural modalities, including endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), common bile duct exploration (CBDE), and percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC). ERCP is generally seen as the standard of care for BDO, with CBDE and PTC serving as viable alternatives when ERCP is unavailable. We used a retrospective cohort analysis to compare the outcomes of these three techniques in the clearance of biliary obstruction.

Methods: Using data from the Nationwide Readmissions Database (NRD) from 2010 to 2014, we identified 25,985 patients with a non-malignant etiology of biliary obstruction who received ERCP, PTC or CBDE. The NRD utilizes Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project’s (HCUP) State Inpatient Databases (SID) discharge data from 28 states, which accounts for 60% of the U.S. resident population and can be used to produce estimates on approximately 36 million discharges. Patient demographics, treating hospital characteristics, and patient outcomes were explored using this data.

Results: ERCP was the most common procedure for BDO (22518 patients vs. 1316 for CBDE, 964 for PTC). Patients treated by PTC had the most readmissions (8.9% vs. 5.4% for ERCP, 0.6% for CBDE, p<0.0001), longer LOS (9.325 vs. 6.400 and 7.729, p<0.0001), and higher total cost ($27,787 vs. $17,371 and $23,492, p<0.0001). Compared to CBDE, PTC was associated with significantly longer LOS (IRR=1.14, p=0.001) and a higher rate of readmission (OR=16.03, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Our results demonstrate that PTC is performed on patients with overall increased morbidity and is associated with worse outcomes when compared to ERCP and CBDE. In patients with BDO who cannot undergo ERCP, our data suggests that surgical exploration is preferential to percutaneous biliary drainage.

abstract_title: Comparative Outcomes for Trauma Patients in Prison and the General Population
author_block: A. B. Christian<sup>1</sup>, J. Mo<sup>1</sup>, A. Grigorian<sup>1</sup>, G. S. Lee<sup>3</sup>, M. Dolich<sup>1</sup>, T. L. Chin<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Schubl<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Kuza<sup>2</sup>, M. Lekawa<sup>1</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Department Of Surgery,Orange, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California,Department Of Anesthesiology,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Department Of Anesthesiology,Orange, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Prisoners are a vulnerable and ever-growing population with limited access to healthcare, and there are few contemporary studies that consider trauma patient outcomes within the prisoner population. Therefore, we sought to provide a descriptive analysis of prisoners involved in trauma and evaluate whether any healthcare disparities exist for this vulnerable population. We hypothesized that prisoner trauma patients have a similar risk of mortality and in-hospital complications compared to non-prisoner trauma patients.

Methods: The Trauma Quality Improvement Program (2015-2016) was queried for trauma patients based upon location inside or outside of prison at the time of injury. A multivariable logistic regression analysis controlling for age, injury severity score, comorbidities and initial vital signs amongst other known predictors of mortality, was performed to compare these groups for risk of mortality—the primary outcome.

Results: From 593,818 trauma patients, 1115 were located in prison. Compared to non-prisoners, prisoner trauma patients had no significant difference in mortality (5.1% vs. 6.0%, p=0.204). However, prisoners had a shorter length of stay (LOS) (mean days, 6.3 vs 7.8, p<0.001), shorter intensive care unit (ICU) LOS (mean days, 5.44 vs 5.89, p=0.004), and fewer complications, including lower rates of drug/alcohol withdrawal (0.4% vs 1.1%, p=0.030), pneumonia (0.5% vs 1.6%, p=0.004), and urinary tract infections (0.0% vs 1.1%, p<0.001).
