On multivariable analysis, prisoner trauma patients had a similar associated risk of mortality compared to non-prisoner trauma patients (OR 1.61, CI 0.52-4.94, p=0.409)

Conclusion: This study suggests that prisoner trauma patients at least receive equivalent treatment in terms of mortality, and in-fact have decreased LOS and some complications. Future prospective studies are needed to confirm these results, as well as explore other factors, which impact prisoner patient outcomes.

abstract_title: Identifying Factors Associated with Unplanned Trauma Readmissions in a Level I Trauma Center.
author_block: M. E. Mounsey<sup>1</sup>, A. Ata<sup>1</sup>, M. Applewhite<sup>1</sup>, M. Tafen<sup>1</sup>, L. Choi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Albany Medical Center,Department Of General Surgery,Albany, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma or other unintentional injury is one of the most common causes of death in the United States. With the high prevalence of trauma cases nationwide it is important to improve both the efficiency and outcomes of trauma services. Although trauma readmission rates are generally low, trauma readmission is indicative of both quality of care and level of acuity. Understanding predictors for unplanned readmissions could help prevent and mitigate their impact. We aim to identify factors that predict readmission among trauma patients.

Methods: We performed an IRB approved retrospective chart review of all patients over 18 admitted to our trauma service between 2016 & 2018. Patients who expired during the initial admission were excluded from analysis. From hospital records we were able to isolate all readmissions for included patients within 30 days of initial discharge. Each readmission was validated to ensure that it was related to the initial admission and classified based on reason for readmission. Univariate/multivariate analyses were performed.

Results: 9,081 patients were included with 906 readmitted within 30 days (9.98%). There were 1,050 total readmissions within this time period. Patients in the readmitted group presented at a significantly younger age (51.43 vs 56.09, p<0.001) with significantly higher BMIs (32.18 vs 27.57, p=0.002). Patients in the readmitted group were significantly more likely to be male (68.32% vs 60.81%, p<0.001). The most common reasons for readmission were fracture complications (25.5%), pain control (16.4%), sepsis or other infection (13.6%), and disease/symptom progression (11.9%). Initial injury type was significantly different between the groups with more readmitted patients presenting with penetrating injuries (p=0.035). Initial discharge disposition was also significantly different between the groups (p<0.001). There were no differences in ISS, GCS, or length of initial admission between the groups.

Conclusion: Our results suggest that age, BMI, gender, injury type, and discharge disposition are associated with unplanned trauma readmissions. These factors should be addressed when counselling and planning discharge.

abstract_title: No Difference in Mortality and Outcomes after Addition of Pediatric Trauma Center Within Two Miles
author_block: A. Naaseh<sup>1</sup>, A. Grigorian<sup>1</sup>, M. Lekawa<sup>1</sup>, M. Dolich<sup>1</sup>, S. Schubl<sup>1</sup>, V. Joe<sup>1</sup>, A. Qazi<sup>1</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of California, Irvine,Division Of Trauma, Burns, And Surgical Critical Care,Orange, CALIFORNIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pediatric trauma is the number one cause of death and disability in children, with an estimated 12,000 children dying from unintentional injuries each year. Prior studies demonstrate that higher volume pediatric trauma centers (PTCs) offer improved outcomes for pediatric trauma patients. A new Level-II (L-II) PTC hospital may reduce volume at an existing L-II PTC if opened within the same vicinity. This study evaluated pediatric trauma volume and outcomes at an existing L-II PTC after the addition of a new L-II PTC within a two-mile radius, hypothesizing no difference in mortality and complications. 

Methods: A retrospective review of patients ≤14 years old presenting to a single adult L-I and L-II PTC was performed. Patients from 2015-2016 (PRE) were compared to patients from 2018-2019 (POST) with the primary outcome of mortality using a paired-t-test and chi squared test. Year 2017 was used as a washout year due to the opening of the L-II PTC that year. 

Results: Compared to the PRE cohort there were less patients in the POST cohort (277 vs. 373). Patients in the POST group had higher rates of insurance coverage (91.3% vs. 78.8%, p<0.001), self-transportation (7.2% vs. 2.7%, p<0.01) to the hospital, and hospital admission (72.6% and 46.1%, p<0.001). There was no difference in patient demographics including age, sex, field and emergency department vitals, and presentations of penetrating trauma (all p >0.05). Patients in the POST cohort had higher rates of motor vehicle accidents (56.7% vs. 46.5%, p<0.01) and crush injuries (1.1% vs. 0%, p= 0.044). There was no difference in mortality (1.6% vs. 1.4%, p=0.866) trauma bay procedures (18.1% vs. 12.6%, p = 0.056), operations (12.6% vs. 8.6%, p=0.093), total ( 2 vs. 2, p = 0.719) and intensive care unit length of stay (LOS) (0 vs. 0, p = 0.871), ventilator days (0 vs. 0, p = 0.840), and transfusion of all blood products at 4 and 24 hours. All complications including acute respiratory distress syndrome, pneumonia/ventilator associated pneumonia, urinary tract infection, stroke, and bacteremia were also similar between the two cohorts (all p>0.05). 

Conclusion: After opening a second L-II PTC within a two-mile radius, there was an increase in patient admissions and self-transportation at the pre-existing L-II PTC. Despite a nearly 26% decrease in trauma volume, there was no difference in LOS, hospital complications, or mortality. Further studies are warranted to assess long-term outcomes at existing PTCs with decreasing volume due to new trauma centers to understand any long-term ramifications of opening new PTCs.

abstract_title: Impact of Ethnicity on Management of Farm-Related Injuries
author_block: C. M. Young<sup>1</sup>, S. Panjwani<sup>4</sup>, M. Cahan<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Department Of Surgery,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>UMass Memorial Medical Center,Division Of Minimally Invasive Surgery,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>St. Mary's Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Waterbury, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  There are no studies utilizing the National Trauma Data Bank (NTDB) to investigate trends of farm-related injuries among ethnic groups. Doing so may highlight healthcare disparities that could benefit from public health education and advocacy. We sought to investigate whether the ethnicity of farmers in the United States (U.S.) predicts for disparities in injury severity, initial presentation, management, and outcomes.

Methods:  A retrospective cohort study of the NTDB was performed including adult farmers in the U.S. who presented to the Emergency Department (ED) after experiencing traumatic injury during 2012-2016. Statistical analyses were performed to assess the differences in Emergency Medical Services (EMS) response and transport time, transfer rates, presentation to University or Level I trauma hospitals, Injury Severity Scores (ISS), length of stay (LOS) in the ED or hospital, being taken to the OR, mechanical ventilation, Intensive Care Unit (ICU), and mortality based on ethnicity.

Results: Of the 6,161 farm-related injury incidences included in this study, 23% were amongst Hispanics, and 77% were amongst Non-Hispanics. The distribution of sex was identical: 93% male and 7% female in each group. The majority of Hispanic patients were located in the West (51%), while the majority of Non-Hispanic patients were located in the Midwest (40%). Hispanic patients were more likely to present to a University or Level I trauma hospital (45% & 46%, respectively vs. 38% & 37% of Non-Hispanics). Both groups relied primarily on private insurance for payment (75% of Hispanics and 64% of Non-Hispanics). However, a greater proportion of Non-Hispanic patients had Medicare coverage (14% vs. 1% of Hispanics), while more Hispanic patients paid out-of-pocket (15% vs. 11% of Non-Hispanics). Non-Hispanic patients had longer EMS response times (21 minutes vs. 17 minutes for Hispanics) and total EMS transport times (88 minutes vs. 72 minutes for Hispanics). Non-Hispanic patients had a shorter length of stay in the ED (167 minutes vs. 184 minutes for Hispanics) and in the hospital (3 days (IQR=4) vs. 3 days (IQR=5) for Hispanics). Non-Hispanic patients were more likely to be admitted to the ICU (17% vs. 15% of Hispanics). ISS was higher in Non-Hispanics (9) than Hispanics (5). Transfer rates, being taken to the OR, mechanical ventilation, and mortality were similar in both groups. Multivariable analyses indicated small statistically significant differences between Hispanic and Non-Hispanic farmers with respect to EMS response, EMS transport times, and length of stay in the ED or hospital.

Conclusion: Fortunately, there exist marginal but clinically insignificant differences in the EMS response time, EMS transport time, ED LOS and hospital LOS among farm-related injuries, indicating a clinically equivalent level of care between Hispanic and Non-Hispanic farmers.

abstract_title: Predictive Ability of TRISS, ASA-PS, and NSQIP in Operative Trauma: a Prospective Multicenter Study
author_block: E. O. Yeates<sup>1</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup>, V. Gabriel<sup>1</sup>, X. Lou<sup>2</sup>, B. Ogunnaike<sup>2</sup>, M. Ahmed<sup>2</sup>, E. Melikman<sup>2</sup>, T. Moon<sup>2</sup>, T. Shoultz<sup>3</sup>, A. Feeler<sup>3</sup>, R. Dudaryk<sup>4</sup>, J. Navas<sup>4</sup>, G. Vasileiou<sup>4</sup>, D. D. Yeh<sup>5</sup>, K. Matsushima<sup>6</sup>, M. Forestiere<sup>6</sup>, T. Lian<sup>6</sup>, O. Hernandez<sup>1</sup>, J. Ricks-Oddie<sup>7</sup>, C. M. Kuza<sup>8</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Trauma, Burns And Surgical Critical Care,Orange, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Anesthesiology,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Burns, Trauma And Critical Care,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Miami,Anesthesiology And Pain Management,Miami, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Miami,Surgery,Miami, FL, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Southern California,Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Center For Statistical Counseling,Irvine, CA, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of Southern California,Anesthesia,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Historically, the prediction of trauma mortality and length of stay (LOS) have relied upon injury and physiologic data (e.g. Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS)), without including comorbidities. We sought to prospectively evaluate the American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status (ASA-PS) classification and the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) surgical risk-calculator (SRC), hypothesizing that they will improve the predictions for risk of mortality and LOS compared to TRISS alone.

Methods: A prospective, observational multicenter study (9/2018-2/2020) of trauma patients ≥18 years-old undergoing an operation within 24 hours of admission was performed.  Logistic regression models were performed with Brier scores and ROC area calculations and R2 and root mean squared error (RMSE) were used to evaluate the ability to predict mortality and LOS.

Results: From 4 Level I trauma centers, 1231 patients had a mean ISS of 13 and the most common ASA-PS was ASA II (36.1%). Blunt trauma accounted for 75.5% of traumas.  The overall mortality rate was 4.6%. The Brier Score and ROC for mortality were found with improving accuracy in the following order: ASA-PS (0.037, 0.885), NSQIP (0.035, 0.909), TRISS (0.030, 0.915), TRISS+NSQIP (0.023, 0.935) and TRISS+ASA-PS (0.029, 0.937). However, when comparing TRISS alone to TRISS+ASA-PS (p=0.07) and TRISS+NSQIP (p=0.38) there was no improvement in prediction of mortality. NSQIP performed best for LOS (R2: NSQIP 24.9%, ASA-PS 18.3%, TRISS 8.6%) (RMSE: NSQIP 14.65, ASA 15.27, TRISS 16.17). The addition of TRISS to NSQIP performed minimally better (25.2%, 4.651).

Conclusion: Despite lacking comorbidities, TRISS predicts mortality better than ASA-PS and NSQIP-SRC. TRISS mortality prediction is not improved by adding ASA-PS or NSQIP-SRC. However, NSQIP-SRC was the most accurate predictor of LOS.

abstract_title: Methamphetamine Use Increases Surgical Site Infections after Trauma Laparotomy
author_block: J. L. Weaver<sup>1</sup>, T. Costantini<sup>1</sup>, J. Lee<sup>1</sup>, L. Godat<sup>1</sup>, A. Berndtson<sup>1</sup>, L. Kobayashi<sup>1</sup>, J. Doucet<sup>1</sup>, S. Higginson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego,San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Taking methamphetamines (meth) causes significant vasoconstriction, which can be severe enough to cause bowel ischemia. Methamphetamines have also been shown to alter the immune response through changes in cytokine signaling, as well as macrophage and T-cell activation. These effects could predispose meth users to poor wound healing, increased infections, and other post-operative complications. The effect of meth use on surgical outcomes in trauma patients is not known. We hypothesized that methamphetamine users would have longer length of stay and higher rates of complications compared to non-meth users.

Methods: The trauma registry for our urban Level 1 trauma center was searched for patients that received an exploratory laparotomy for traumatic injury from 2016 to 2019. Length of stay (LOS) and ventilator days were compared using nonparametric statistics and reported as median and interquartile range. Age, injury severity score (ISS), and abbreviated injury scale (AIS) were compared using a Student’s T-test. A Chi Square test was used to compare gender, mechanism of injury, and rates of infectious complications. Significance was set at <0.05.

Results: Hospital LOS [8.0 (5-18) v 7.5 (4-15) days, p=0.73], ICU LOS [2.0 (0-5.0) v 2.0 (0-6.0) days, p=0.98], and ventilator days [0.0 (0-4.0) v 0.0 (0-3.0) days, p=0.95] were equivalent between meth positive and negative patients. Age (37.3±12.0 v 38.1±17.3 years, p=0.74), percent male (94.4% v 86.4%, p=0.11), percent penetrating injury (66.7% v 52.6%, p=0.18), and abdominal AIS (2.9±0.9 v 3.0±1.0, p=0.62) were equivalent between groups. There were no central line-associated infections in either group. Rates of ventilator-associated pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess requiring percutaneous drain placement, and unplanned returns to the operating room were the same between groups (see table 1), as were ISS and mortality. Methamphetamine positive patients had a significantly higher rate of surgical site infections (SSI).

Conclusion: Methamphetamine use is associated with an increased rate of SSI after trauma laparotomy. This could be related to microvascular disease and immunomodulation caused by meth use, though the mechanism is not known. However, other serious complications and mortality were not affected by methamphetamine use.

abstract_title: Cervical-CT Scans in Adolescent Blunt Trauma Patients: Are They Overutilized and Unnecessary?
author_block: B. Sharma<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Kolousek<sup>2</sup>, M. Mubasher<sup>3</sup>, K. Archer-Arroyo<sup>6</sup>, R. Smith<sup>5</sup>, J. Nguyen<sup>2</sup>, C. Butler<sup>2</sup>, S. R. Todd<sup>4</sup>, E. W. Childs<sup>2</sup>, R. Sola<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mercer University School of Medicine,Department Of Medical Education,Macon, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>Morehouse School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>Morehouse School of Medicine,Department Of Community Health And Preventative Medicine,Atlanta, GEORGIA, USA <sup>4</sup>Grady Memorial Hospital,Acute Care Surgery,Atlanta, GEORGIA, USA <sup>5</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>6</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Department Of Radiology,Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cervical spine computerized tomography (CSCT) scans are commonly used to evaluate traumatic injuries. Despite evidence showing a low incidence of cervical spine injuries on CSCT in pediatric, including adolescent, trauma patients, recent evidence demonstrates that adult trauma centers over utilize this imaging modality during the trauma evaluation of adolescent patients. The aim of this study is to review our trauma center’s use of CSCT in the adolescent blunt trauma population. We hypothesized that our level one trauma center will overuse CT scans.   

Methods: This is a retrospective review of adolescent (13-18 year old) blunt trauma patients at our urban adult level 1 trauma center from January 2016 to December 2019. We accessed our trauma database to identify patients < 18 years old that underwent a CSCT scan following blunt trauma. The primary outcome was the prevalence of positive findings on CSCT scan. Univariate Fischer-Exact analysis was used to evaluate the correlation between the national emergency x-ray utilization study (NEXUS) criteria and CSCT result. Individual components of the NEXUS criteria were assessed using multivariate regression.  

Results: Two hundred seventy-seven adolescent patients underwent a CSCT. Of those, 68% (189) were male, the mean age was 16.5±1.6 years old, and 56% (156) were African American. The most common mechanism of injury was motor vehicle collision (58%) and the mean injury severity score (ISS) was 16.6±11.6. Thirty-five patients (13%) had a positive finding on CSCT. Of those, only 3 (1%) required surgical intervention. Thirty-four (97%) patients with a positive CSCT also failed NEXUS criteria. Ninety-three (38%) patients with a negative CSCT met NEXUS criteria indicating a low suspicion for cervical spine injury. On multivariate logistic regression analysis, midline cervical spine tenderness (OR = 4.7; 95% CI: 1.9-11.9; p < 0.01), focal neurological deficit (OR = 5.5; 95% CI: 1.9-16.2; p < 0.01), and presence of a distracting injury (OR = 2.3; 95% CI: 1.0-5.0; p = 0.04) were independently associated with a positive CSCT. NEXUS criteria based on our data has a sensitivity of 97.1% and a specificity of 38.4%, which is comparable to the current literature.  

Conclusions: CSCT scans in adolescent blunt trauma patients are overutilized. There is a low positive CSCT scan rate among this population.  A quality improvement project focusing on the use of the NEXUS criteria to assess risk of cervical spine injury could potentially reduce the use of CSCT scans by nearly 40%.

abstract_title: Pre-hospital Whole Blood Does Not Improve Survival for Trauma Patients With On-Scene CPR
author_block: A. A. Smith<sup>1</sup>, M. Braverman<sup>1</sup>, B. Axtman<sup>1</sup>, C. P. Shahan<sup>1</sup>, D. Pokorny<sup>1</sup>, L. Barry<sup>1</sup>, H. Corral<sup>1</sup>, M. Shiels<sup>1</sup>, S. Schauer<sup>2</sup>, J. Bynum<sup>2</sup>, R. Schaefer<sup>3</sup>, E. Epley<sup>3</sup>, C. Winckler<sup>1</sup>, B. Eastridge<sup>1</sup>, S. Nicholson<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Jenkins<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio,Surgery,San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>US Army Institute of Surgical Research,JBSA Fort Sam Houston,San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Southwest Texas Regional Advisory Council,San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Hemorrhagic shock conveys significant mortality in trauma patients despite increasing advances in pre-hospital care. The benefit of whole blood transfusion in pre-hospital cardiac arrest has not been previously reported. The objective of this study was to determine if patients in cardiac arrest who received pre-hospital low titer O+ whole blood (PH-LTOWB) had improved survival in the trauma bay and also improved overall survival to discharge.

Methods: A retrospective review of 546 trauma patients receiving blood transfusions was performed from 2015-2019. Inclusion criteria included patients with documented prehospital cardiac arrest and patients were excluded if the full prehospital record was not available. Univariate analysis was performed.

Results: 40 (7.3%) patients had on-scene CPR with 11 patients receiving PH-LTOWB. Baseline demographics, ISS, AIS chest and AIS abdomen, and arrival pH were similar between groups (p>0.05). Higher AIS head was found in the non-transfused cohort (2.7+/- 0.3 vs. 3.9+/- 0.2, p=0.003).  EMS on scene time was significantly longer in the patients receiving PH-LTOWB (18.4+/- 1.6 vs 11.1+/- 1.4 min, p=0.006). Trauma bay mortality was similar with 63.6% (n=7) in the transfused group and 55.0% in the non-transfused group (n=22) (p=0.46). In-hospital mortality for the PH-LTOWB group was 81.8% and 100% for the non-transfused group (p=0.07).  

Conclusions: Pre-hospital blood is an important adjunct in the surgeon's armamentarium for the management of patients with hemorrhagic shock. In our study, we found no survival benefit in transfusing PH-LTOWB for trauma patients in cardiac arrest on the scene and with likely unsurvivable injuries. We also found a longer on-scene time for patients receiving blood transfusions. Blood should be reserved for patients with a survival benefit.

abstract_title: Using a Novel Machine Learning Approach to Predict Blood Utilization in Adult Trauma Patients
author_block: S. Tejiram<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Gilbert<sup>1</sup>, H. H. Rashidi<sup>2</sup>, J. M. Galante<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Davis,Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Sacramento, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - Davis,Department Of Pathology And Laboratory Medicine,Sacramento, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite massive transfusion (MT) activation, trauma patients may receive little or no blood products following presentation. Use of machine learning (ML) based prediction models may identify previously unconsidered factors predictive of transfusion need. Our goal was to use ML novel approach to identify parameters most predictive of blood transfusion need following MT activation.

Methods: Trauma patients who received MT activation upon presentation were reviewed from March 2015 to September 2019 and grouped by those who received blood (+) and those who did not (-). Parameters reviewed included demographics, injury characteristics, interventions (embolization or operative), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Revised Trauma Score (RTS), and blood product utilization. The automated ML platform MILO (Machine Intelligence Learning Optimizer) generated models using different parameter combinations and compared each model’s performance against the target’s (blood given or not) true prevalence through seven supervised statistical algorithms (Gradient Boosting Machine, K-Nearest Neighbor, Logistic Regression, Neural Network, naïve Bayes, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine).

Results: A total of 1,302 patients were included; 797 received blood products. The training data set [443 patients; 212 (+), 231 (-)] and generalization set [593 patients; 352 (+), 241 (-)] created a total of 350,811 models for analysis. The model with the highest F1 (0.802) included age, sex, cause and grade of injury, initial imaging, vital signs (SBP, RR, O2 Sat, HR), GCS, hematocrit (HCT), TXA administration, (+) FAST exam, intervention performed, ISS, and RTS. This model had a sensitivity of 71.9% [66.9%-76.5%], specificity of 92.5% [88.5%-95.5%], and positive predictive value (PPV) of 93.4% [90.0-95.7%]. A second model with a similar F1 (0.802) considered 75% of parameters after excluding sex, penetrating injury, FAST, and embolization location. This model had a sensitivity of 72.2% [67.2%-76.8%], specificity of 92.1% [88.0%-95.2%], and PPV of 93.0% [89.6%-95.4%].

Conclusion: ML analysis revealed several models with high accuracy for predicting blood transfusions by F1 score, high specificity, and positive predictive value. This was also maintained in models using a reduced number of parameters. Parameters most predictive of blood transfusion included age, cause and grade of injury, initial imaging, presenting vital signs and HCT, TXA administration, operative need, and both ISS and RTS. ML remains novel in the trauma setting and will require further optimization to best predict blood product utilization.

abstract_title: Fostering Hospital Resilience to Disasters: Lessons from a Tertiary Hospital in Nepal
author_block: M. Moitinho De Almeida<sup>1</sup>, I. Aujoulat<sup>2</sup>, D. P. Mahara<sup>3</sup>, D. Guha-Sapir<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Universit catholique de Louvain,Centre For Research On The Epidemiology Of Disasters, Institute Of Health And Society,Brussels, BRUSSELS, Belgium <sup>2</sup>Universit catholique de Louvain,Institute Of Health And Society,Brussels, BRUSSELS, Belgium <sup>3</sup>Tribhuvan University Teaching Hospital,Department Of Orthopedics,Kathmandu, KATHMANDU, Nepal <sup>4</sup>Tribhuvan University Teaching Hospital,Kathmandu, KATHMANDU, Nepal
abstract_body:
Introduction: Large-scale disasters are hazardous events that overwhelm a community’s capacity and typically require external assistance. With increasing threats from climate change, rapid population growth, suboptimal urbanization, and poverty, the human impact of large-scale disasters is likely to grow. “Resilient hospitals” have been increasingly recognized as a critical element of disaster reduction. While various frameworks of hospital resilience have been proposed, they mostly emerged from pre-disaster considerations, and have not incorporated evidence from post-disaster impact on hospitals and post-disaster resilience mechanisms. We aimed to investigate the impact of a high-magnitude earthquake in a tertiary hospital in Nepal, and its resilience mechanisms. Specifically, we studied the profile of admitted earthquake victims, analyzed differences in total hospital admissions, and examined staff experiences of hospital resilience.

Methods: We used a combination of quantitative data from routinely generated hospital records and qualitative data from semi-structured interviews with hospital staff. We described the profile of admitted earthquake victims to understand the burden to the hospital, and compared total admissions after the earthquake with a pre-earthquake baseline in terms of number, diagnostic category, and length of hospital stay. Finally, we used mixed deductive and inductive coding for the qualitative data to analyze hospital resilience. 

Results: Many of the injured who made it to the study hospital required surgical interventions and long hospitalizations. Being a tertiary hospital, it also received referrals of more severe cases, which posed additional strains. For six weeks, the average number of daily admissions decreased. During this period, the share of injury-related admissions was particularly high, and such admissions were particularly long. Admissions due to other conditions relatively decreased and were shorter than usual. We found that the hospital’s resilience was highly dependent on emerging adaptations in addition to pre-existing conditions. Operational aspects were the biggest influencers of hospital resilience. Since they were highly dependent on human behavior, individual resilience played a major role, and we found that hospital staff were conditioned by senses of safety, meaningfulness, and belonging. 

Conclusion: Hospitals should prepare resources and plan for their known disaster risks, but should also allow for a certain flexibility to innovative adaptions to emerging, unforeseen challenges. In addition, challenges faced by hospital workers should not be undermined, and supporting them will increase hospital resilience.

abstract_title: Cervical Spinal Cord Injuries: Geriatric vs Non-Geriatric Populations. Is Age a Risk Factor?
author_block: B. Davis<sup>1</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4,5</sup>, R. Grady<sup>4,5</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>4,5</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>4,5</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>4,5</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,4</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Broward Health North,Trauma Services,Deerfield Beach, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the growing geriatric population, there is a paralleled increase of spinal trauma in elderly patients. The aims of this study were to compare injury characteristics and outcomes between geriatric (≥65 years old) and non-geriatric patients who had a cervical spinal cord injury with neurological deficit (CSCIND).

Methods: This retrospective cohort study included 255 patients with CSCIND admitted to three Level 1 Trauma Centers between February 2015 and March 2020. Patients were separated and compared in two groups: 104 geriatric patients (GP) and 151 non-geriatric patients (NGP). Analyzed variables included: age, comorbidities, anticoagulation use, mechanism of injury (MOI), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) impairment grade, Neurological Level of Injury (NLI), Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) co-injury, incidence of vertebrae fractures, cervical spine procedures, hospital discharge disposition, and mortality.

Results: The GP group was significantly older than the NGP group (77.4 vs 44.1 years), and accordingly had significantly higher rates of comorbidities (85.6% vs 53.6%), dementia (10.6% vs 0.7%), and anticoagulant use (49.0% vs 7.3%), with all p<0.001 [Fig. 1]. Regarding MOI, the GP group was significantly more likely to get a CSCIND as a result of a fall (69.2% vs 25.2%, p<0.001), while the NGP group as a result of a motor vehicle accident (28.9% vs 62.9%, p<0.001). There was no difference in injury severity between the groups, as the ISS (20.6 vs 21.3, p=0.7), GCS (13.6 vs 13.1, p=0.3), and TBI co-injury (5.8% vs 6.6%, p=0.8) were all similar. Additionally, there was no difference in the distribution of ASIA grade (p=0.9) or NLI (p=0.3) between the groups. GP had a significantly higher incidence of vertebrae fractures (67.3% vs 50.3%, p=0.007), with cervical vertebrae fractured in 62.5% of GP versus 50.3% in NGP (p=0.06). Cervical spine procedures were performed equally often in both groups (64.0% vs 64.0%, p=1.0). Significantly more GP than NGP were discharged to hospice (16.3% vs 4.0%, p<0.001), resulting in a significantly higher mortality rate among GP (19.2% vs 6.0%, p=0.001). Of the GP who expired, 25.0% (n=5) had a Do Not Resuscitate order or an Advanced Directive in place.

Conclusion: Despite geriatric cervical spinal cord injury resulting from a lower energy trauma, the spinal injury severity was similar to non-geriatric trauma patients, even in the presence of more vertebrae fractures. Geriatric patients had higher rates of discharge to hospice and mortality, which can be attributed to their higher rates of underlying comorbidities and presence of advanced directives, as compared to their non-geriatric counterparts.

abstract_title: Increased Plasma Hyaluronan Levels are Associated with Trauma-Induced Coagulopathy
author_block: S. C. Walker<sup>1</sup>, L. Zheng<sup>2</sup>, A. R. Ashtekar<sup>2</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>2</sup>, J. D. Kerby<sup>2</sup>, J. R. Richter<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Acute Care Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Hyaluronan (HA) is a major component of the endothelial glycocalyx layer. Glycocalyx damage and HA shedding occur after injury, and trauma patients with high HA levels have impaired thrombin generation. However, the relationship between HA and trauma-induced coagulopathy (TIC) has not been evaluated. The goal of this study was to assess the associations between plasma HA levels, coagulation abnormalities and clinical outcomes after trauma.    

Methods:  Trauma patients (>18 years) admitted to our Level I trauma center with an ABC Score ≥ 2 were prospectively enrolled. Partial thromboplastin time (PTT), international normalized ratio (INR) and thromboelastography (TEG) parameters were recorded at arrival. New injury severity score (NISS) and clinical outcomes were obtained. Plasma HA levels were measured with an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay at 0, 12, 24, and 48h. HA levels were also measured in healthy controls (HC). TIC was defined as admission INR > 1.2 or PTT ≥ 36.5 sec. Comparisons of HA levels were assessed at each time point, and Spearman’s correlations were performed between 0h and 24h HA levels, coagulation measures and clinical outcomes. P-values < 0.05 were considered significant.  

Results: Forty-nine trauma patients and 25 controls were enrolled for study. Sixteen (32.7%) trauma patients were coagulopathic at admission. NISS did not differ between patients with and without TIC; however, HA levels in coagulopathic trauma patients were higher than non-coagulopathic patients at all time points and elevated above HC levels at 24 and 48h (Figure 1). At arrival, HA levels correlated with TEG R-time (Spearman’s rho = 0.395, p = 0.021), PTT (rho = 0.420, p = 0.003), and INR (rho = 0.405, p = 0.004). At 24h, HA levels correlated with total 24h blood product transfusion requirements (rho = 0.371, p = 0.010), intensive care unit length of stay (rho = 0.359, p = 0.012), and hospital length of stay (rho = 0.337, p = 0.019).

Conclusion: Shed HA is associated with coagulation abnormalities in trauma patients, which may contribute to worse outcomes. These findings highlight the need for additional studies to evaluate the mechanistic role of HA in TIC.

abstract_title: Impact of Frailty on Acute Outcomes of Thoracic and Abdominal Endovascular Aneurysm Repair
author_block: S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, M. Gandjian<sup>1</sup>, C. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Frailty has been associated with increased mortality and postoperative complications following endovascular repair of abdominal aortic aneurysms (EVAR). While coding-based frailty tools may readily identify at-risk patients, their utility has not been examined in EVAR or TEVAR (thoracic aortic aneurysm repair) at the national level. We aimed to characterize the differential impact of frailty on clinical outcomes and resource use following such procedures using a nationally representative cohort.   

Methods:   The 2005-‘17 National Inpatient Sample was queried to identify all adults undergoing EVAR or TEVAR. Patients were considered frail if they suffered from any of the frailty defining diagnoses in the Johns Hopkins Adjusted Clinical Groups based on International Classification of Diseases Revisions 9/10. Relevant patient and hospital variables were compared across groups using the chi-square test for categorical and adjusted Wald test for continuous variables. Multivariable regression models were used to identify independent associations with outcomes of interest which included in-hospital mortality, length of stay, non-home discharge and hospitalization costs. Predicted marginal effects were used to provide risk adjusted estimates with 95% confidence intervals.     

Results:   Of an estimated 489,219 patients, 86.8% underwent EVAR and the remainder TEVAR. The annual incidence of EVAR (21,568 in 2005 to 43,140 cases in 2017) and TEVAR (649 in 2005 to 7,230 cases in 2017) increased significantly over the study period (all NP-trend<0.001). The prevalence of frailty was lower in the cohort undergoing EVAR (4.5%) compared to TEVAR (8.9%). Frail patients were on average older (74.4 vs 72.0 years, P<0.001), more commonly female (31.2% vs 22.1%, P<0.001), and had a greater burden of comorbidities as measured by the Elixhauser Comorbidity Index (4.3 vs 3.3, P<0.001). After adjustment, frailty was independently associated with higher in-hospital mortality and non-home discharge rates for both EVAR and TEVAR cohorts (Figure). Frailty was also associated with higher predicted costs (EVAR: $51,300 vs $30,000, TEVAR: $100,500 vs $59,800) and longer lengths of stay (EVAR: 10.9 days vs 3.4 days, TEVAR: 20.4 days vs 9.5 days). Frailty had a greater marginal effect on mortality and non-home discharge rates in the setting of EVAR relative to TEVAR (Figure).   

Conclusions: Although frailty portends inferior outcomes for both cohorts, it imparts a greater detriment to those undergoing EVAR compared to TEVAR. Given the apparent impact of coding-based frailty determination, its inclusion in existing risk models may better inform shared decision making.

abstract_title: Impact of Hospital Safety-Net Status on Clinical Outcomes Following Carotid Artery Revascularization
author_block: A. D. Mandelbaum<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hospitals with a high safety-net burden have been associated with inferior clinical outcomes and increased resource use. However, there is a paucity of studies examining this relationship in patients undergoing carotid revascularization. We aimed to characterize the association of safety-net burden with outcomes and resource utilization in a nationally representative cohort of patients undergoing carotid interventions.

Methods: The 2010-2017 Nationwide Readmissions Database (NRD) was used to identify all adults undergoing carotid endarterectomy (CEA) and carotid artery stenting (CAS). International Classification of Diseases 9th and 10th Revision codes and the NRD data dictionary were utilized to tabulate patient and hospital characteristics. Using previously reported methodology, hospitals were classified as low- (LBH), medium-, or high- safety-net burden (HBH) based on the proportion of uninsured or Medicaid patients undergoing the above procedures. Multivariable regression models were developed to evaluate associations between safety-net burden and in-hospital mortality, postoperative stroke, length of stay, hospitalization costs, and 30-day readmissions.

Results: Of an estimated 540,558 hospitalizations for a carotid intervention, 28.5% were at HBH. Compared to LBH, a greater proportion of patients at HBH received CAS (18.7% vs 8.9%, P<0.001). Patients treated at HBH were more likely to be admitted non-electively (28.7% vs. 20.2%, P<0.001), have a higher burden of comorbidities (2.8 vs 2.6 as measured by Elixhauser Comorbidity Index, P<0.001) and have symptomatic presentation (11.0% vs 7.7%, P<0.001). HBH was associated with increased unadjusted rates of in-hospital mortality (0.8% vs 0.4%, P<0.001), stroke (0.9% vs 0.7%, P=0.03), 30-day readmissions (7.4% vs 6.2%, P<0.001) as well as hospitalization costs ($16,537 vs $14570, P<0.001) and length of stay (3.7 vs 2.9 days, P<0.001). Hospitalization costs increased significantly over the study period for both HBH and LBH as shown in Figure 1 (nptrend<0.001). After adjustment for patient and hospital factors, HBH remained associated with increased odds of stroke (AOR: 1.16, P=0.02, Ref=LBH) and 30-day readmissions (AOR: 1.12, P<0.001). Although HBH was not associated with mortality (AOR: 1.14, P=0.10) or length of stay (β: +0.02 days, P=0.76) after adjustment, it was linked to increased hospitalization costs (β: +$1,964, P<0.001).

Conclusion: High safety-net burden was associated with several adverse outcomes and increased hospitalization costs after carotid revascularization. Further studies are warranted to better delineate this disparity to alleviate healthcare inequality and improve outcomes at safety-net hospitals.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in Surgical Management and Outcomes of Acute Limb Ischemia in the United States
author_block: M. Gandjian<sup>1</sup>, S. Sareh<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, C. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, N. Bowens<sup>2</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Cardiac Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Division Of Vascular Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute limb ischemia (ALI) has been associated with significant mortality, limb loss, and resource use. Given the presence of socioeconomic disparities in management of chronic limb ischemia, the current study examined factors associated with utilization of revascularization procedures and amputation in patients with ALI and their associated clinical outcomes.

Methods: The 2005-2017 National Inpatient Sample was used to identify hospitalizations with a diagnosis of lower extremity ALI. Patient characteristics were tabulated using coding as defined by the International Classification of Disease 9/10. The cohort was categorized as White or non-White based on self-declared race. Nonparametric test of trends (NPtrend) was used to assess temporal changes while chi-square and adjusted Wald tests were used to compare categorical and continuous variables, respectively. Multivariable models were developed to identify independent association of covariate with outcomes which included odds of revascularization, amputations, in-hospital mortality, as well as duration (LOS) and costs of hospitalization.

Results: Of an estimated 869,540 admissions with ALI (59.7% White), 66.8% required revascularization, with open approach being performed more frequently compared to endovascular (61.4 vs 38.6%). Utilization of revascularization (65.8 in 2005 to 59.4% in 2017, NPtrend<0.001) and amputation (7.8 in 2005 to 7.4% in 2017, NPtrend=0.006) decreased significantly. After adjusting for relevant patient and hospital factors, non-White race, congestive heart failure, cancer, liver disease, and chronic kidney disease were all associated with reduced odds of revascularization (FIGURE, panel A). Factors associated with increased risk of amputation included peripheral vascular disease, chronic kidney disease, weight loss, and non-White race (FIGURE, panel B). Furthermore, non-White race predicted increased odds of several other outcomes, including amputation without attempted limb salvage (AOR 1.18, 95% CI 1.09-1.28), amputation after revascularization (AOR 1.34, 95% CI 1.25-1.43), hospitalization cost (β +$3,066, 95% CI $2,021-$4111), and LOS (β +0.99 days, 95% CI 0.69-1.30). However, non-White race was not associated with a significant decrement in the odds of in-hospital mortality (AOR 0.94, 95% CI 0.88-1.01).

Conclusion: We have demonstrated significant racial disparities in the surgical management of patients admitted to US hospitals for ALI. Non-White race appears to be associated with reduced odds of revascularization but increased rates of amputation. Future studies to identify underlying factors such as access to care and advanced presentation among non-White patients are warranted in order to provide optimal and equitable care.

abstract_title: Duration and Quality of Functional Independence Loss Following Vascular Surgery
author_block: M. M. DeAngelo<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Peacock<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Holeman<sup>1</sup>, M. Maloney<sup>1</sup>, J. Beckstrom<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Brooke<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah School of Medicine,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Physiological stress resulting from surgery can lead to loss of functional independence in older patients. However, it is unknown which specific activities of daily living are significantly impacted after surgery, and whether functionality is regained over time. The objective of this study was to prospectively measure changes in functional status among patients following major and minor vascular surgery procedures.

Methods:  Patients consented to undergo elective major and minor vascular surgery procedures at an academic medical center were prospectively identified between May 2018 and March 2019. Each patient’s functional status was assessed using the Katz Activities of Daily Living (ADL) index and the Lawton-Brody Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (iADL) index prior to surgery and was reassessed post-operatively at 2-week, 1-month, and 1-year time points. Wilcoxon signed-rank tests on individual components of ADL and iADL scores compared changes in patients’ ability to perform specific skills over time. Logistic regression models were used to identify independent predictors of functional decline at each time point.

Results: 126 patients (59% male; mean [SD] age, 61 [17] years) were assessed before and after minor (56%) and major (44%) surgical procedures. The ability to independently undertake ADLs (bathing, dressing, and toileting) and certain iADLs (shop, prepare food, and house-keeping) was significantly decreased at both 2-weeks and at 1-month (p< 0.05), but had returned to baseline at 1-year following surgery (Figure A&B). In comparison, patients experienced significant deficits in the iADLs of managing laundry, transportation, medications, and finances that never return to baseline at 1-year following surgery (p< 0.05, Figure B). Undergoing major surgery was associated with the greatest odds of decline in ADLs (OR:3.1; 95%CI: 1.0-8.9; P<0.001) and iADLs (OR:6.8; 95% CI: 2.5-18.6; P<0.001) at 2-weeks post-op, but the significance of this finding did not persist beyond 1-month.

Conclusion: Patients experience a loss in the ability to complete activities of daily living needed to remain independent in the month after vascular surgery, which is exacerbated following major procedures. While most functional skills are regained at one year after surgery, certain activities such as managing laundry, transportation, and the cognitive ability to manage finances and medications remains deficient. These data can help older patients and caretakers prepare for the types and duration of functional deficits they may be expected to incur after surgery.

abstract_title: Food Desert Status Increases Readmission and Wound Complication Risk After CLTI Revascularization
author_block: E. J. Smith<sup>1</sup>, B. Wu<sup>1</sup>, J. Lopez<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Ramirez<sup>1</sup>, W. J. Gasper<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Hiramoto<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Conte<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Iannuzzi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Vascular Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Living in a Food Desert (FD) has been associated with adverse cardiovascular outcomes; however, its impact on vascular surgery outcomes is unknown. This study hypothesized that FD status would be associated with readmission after revascularization for chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).

Methods: This study was a single-center retrospective analysis of open and endovascular CLTI revascularization operations for years 2013-2019. FD status was defined using USDA Food Access Research criteria by ZIP code with low-income and low-access. Low-access was defined as ≥33% of residents in the zip code living greater than 1 mile or 10 miles from the nearest supermarket, supercenter, or large grocery store for an urban or rural area, respectively. Bivariate analyses were performed as appropriate to the data. Binary logistic regression was performed assessing the association of FD status with unplanned 30-day readmissions.

Results: In total, 456 cases were included, of which 9.0% (n=41) resided in a FD. Patients in the FD cohort were younger (64.2 vs 70.8, p<0.01) and more likely to present with a partial ambulatory deficit (81% vs 65%, p=0.04). A FD was associated with higher rates of wound complications (51% vs 23%, p<0.01) and 30-day readmissions (39% vs 21%, p<0.01). Wound complications in the FD cohort were primarily new surgical incisions as opposed to index wound complications (24% vs. 10%, p<0.01).  On multivariable analysis, a FD was associated with increased odds of 30-day readmission (OR: 2.1 CI: 1.1-4.3 p=0.03) and overall wound complications (OR: 3.4 CI: 1.8-6.7 p<0.01) (Table). A FD was specifically associated with increased surgical incisional and index wound complications on multivariable analysis (Table). On sensitivity analysis controlling for the interaction of income status and low-access, low-access remained associated with each endpoint. Reasons for readmission in the FD were all due to wound complications (100% vs. 60% p<0.01).

Conclusions: Living in a Food Desert was associated with more than twice the odds of 30-day readmission after lower extremity revascularization or CLTI. This increase in readmission may be explained through increased wound complications. These findings suggest FD status may impact wound healing and supports considering access to healthy food as a potentially modifiable risk factor for unplanned readmission following CLTI revascularization.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in Native American and African American Patients Undergoing Amputation in Oklahoma State
author_block: S. Wyatt<sup>1</sup>, K. Kempe<sup>1</sup>, V. Pandit<sup>1</sup>, T. Hasenstein<sup>1</sup>, H. Kim<sup>1</sup>, S. Vang<sup>1</sup>, W. Jennings<sup>1</sup>, P. Nelson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine,Surgery, Vascular,Tulsa, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Studies have documented that African Americans (AA) with diabetes (DM) and/or peripheral arterial disease (PAD) have higher rates of amputation in comparison to their Caucasian American (CA). However, there are limited studies that have analyzed amputation rates in  Native Americans (NA).  As Oklahoma (OK) has the largest number of NA, the objective of this study was to determine if NA in Oklahoma have worse outcomes compared to whites, defined as major amputations for patients with DM and PAD.

Methods: We performed a one-year (2017) preliminary analysis of the Oklahoma State Inpatient Database and included all patients with PAD and/or DM. Patients undergoing amputation for trauma, patients with home zip codes identifying them as out-of-state, as well as patients missing critical variables were excluded. Patients were stratified based on race (NA, AA, and CA). The primary outcome was the incidence of major amputation (below- or above-knee) and to determine if racial disparities exist amongst the groups.

Results: A total of 136,358 patients with PAD and/or DM were included of which 1% (n=1394) underwent amputation. Of this group, 65.6% of patients had DM and 53.6% had PAD, 71.3% were > 60 years old, and 50.3% were males. NA were more likely to undergo amputation compared to CA (13.9% vs 7.3%, p=0.001). Figure 1 demonstrates the rate of amputation after controlling for  contributing factors, both NA and AA were independently associated with increased risk for amputation (1.4[1.1-1.9], p=0.02) and 1.6 [1.3-2.2], p=0.04).

Conclusion: Native Americans and AA races were at higher risk for lower extremity amputation compared to CA of those admitted with PAD/DM, highlighting racial disparities. Community outreach efforts are critically needed in these vulnerable populations

abstract_title: Results of Geriatric Co-Management of Older Vascular Surgical Patients in hospital
author_block: J. Thillainadesan<sup>1,3,4</sup>, V. Naganathan<sup>1,3,4</sup>, S. R. Monaro<sup>2</sup>, R. Kerdic<sup>2</sup>, S. J. Li<sup>1</sup>, S. Aitken<sup>2,3,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Concord Hospital,Geriatric Medicine,Concord, NSW, Australia <sup>2</sup>Concord Hospital,Vascular Surgery,Concord, NSW, Australia <sup>3</sup>University Of Sydney,Sydney, NSW, Australia <sup>4</sup>Centre for Education and Research on Ageing, and Ageing and Alzheimers Institute,Concord, NSW, Australia <sup>5</sup>Concord Institute of Academic Surgery,Concord Hospital,Concord, NSW, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Vascular surgeons are looking after older and frailer patients with multimorbidity, who experience higher rates of perioperative mortality and morbidity. Recent guidelines recommend proactive geriatrician consultation. Preliminary results of an Australian geriatric co-management service for older vascular surgery (Gerico-V) patients admitted to hospital are reported.

Methods: Data are from an ongoing prospective before-and-after evaluation study of consecutive patients aged ≥65 years admitted under vascular surgery at a tertiary academic hospital in Sydney, Australia. The control cohort (n=150) received usual care in which geriatricians were consulted reactively after the patient had developed complications. The intervention cohort (n=51) received a new co-management service where a geriatrician was embedded within a multidisciplinary vascular surgery team (Gerico-V). The geriatrician proactively saw all admitted vascular surgery patients aged ≥65 years and attended a weekly multidisciplinary meeting.

Results: Between February and October 2019, 150 consecutive patients (forming the control cohort) aged ≥65 years were admitted under vascular surgery with a mean (SD) age of 79 (7.7) years, 68% were male, 37% were emergency admissions, and 78% underwent operative management.  As per the Clinical Frailty Scale, 30% were frail and 37% cognitively impaired.  Post introduction of the Gerico-V model, 51 consecutive patients aged ≥65 years were admitted under vascular surgery from January to April 2020. This intervention group had a mean (SD) age of 81 (7.1) years, 65% were male, 55% were emergency admissions, 57% were operatively managed, 51% were frail, and 28% had cognitive impairment. Operative interventions were similar in the before and after cohorts, with endovascular intervention accounting for 51% and 46% of primary operations, respectively. Comparing outcomes before and after introduction of the geriatric co-management model of care, length of stay was similar (6.5 days vs 6.6 days), delirium was lower (10.0% vs 3.9%), inpatient mortality was lower (2.0% vs 0.0%), functional decline from admission to discharge was higher (19.0% vs 24.0%), and there were more discharges to a rehabilitation setting (8% vs 14%).

Conclusion: Older persons admitted to a vascular surgery unit have a high prevalence of frailty and cognitive impairment. Our preliminary findings suggest that the implementation of a multidisciplinary geriatric co-management model for vascular surgery patients reduces the incidence of delirium and mortality, without impacting hospital length of stay, but there was increased incidence in functional decline during the admission, which may be explained by earlier discharge to a rehabilitation facility.

abstract_title: Risk Analysis Index Does Not Predict Reintervention or Mortality in Aortic Aneurysm Patients
author_block: J. Man<sup>1</sup>, J. Xu<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Vascular Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Frailty scores are increasingly utilized to predict post-operative complications. The purpose of this study is to determine whether the administrative risk analysis index (RAI-A) can be used to predict re-intervention or mortality within 30 days in patients who undergo elective open or endovascular AAA repair.

Methods: The American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program database was used to query data from elective open or endovascular aortic aneurysm repairs from 2011-2018. The administrative risk analysis index (RAI-A) score was calculated for each patient. Multivariable regression analysis was performed to determine whether there were statistical or clinical significance for incremental increases of RAI-A for both the open and endovascular repair group. Outcome measures were reintervention or death within 30 days.

Results: Data from 4,106 and 11,733 patients who underwent open and endovascular repair, respectively, were included in the analysis.  The number of re-interventions within 30 days was 9.1% (375 out of 4,106 patients) in the open repair group and 4.0% (463 out of 11,685 patients) in the endovascular group. Thirty day mortality was 4.7% (192 out of 4,106 patients) in the open repair group, and 0.9% (109 out of 11,685 patients) in the endovascular group. RAI-A scores were calculated for each patient. The open and endovascular repair groups had median RAI-A scores of 7 (mean 8.31) and 9 (mean 9.51) respectively. There was no significant association between RAI-A scores and outcome measures in either group.  The C statistic of predicting 30 day reinterventions using RAI-A scores was 0.535 (OR 1.02) for the open repair group and 0.532 (OR 1.02) for endovascular repair. For predicting 30 day mortality, the C statistic was 0.626 (OR 1.07) in the open repair group and 0.701 (OR 1.09) in the endovascular repair group.

Conclusion: The RAI-A is not useful in predicting 30 day reintervention or mortality in patients who undergo elective open or endovascular AAA repair.

abstract_title: AAA Calcium Score Predicts Post-EVAR Sac Regression
author_block: L. Cao<sup>1</sup>, N. A. Spagnuolo<sup>1</sup>, S. Nielson<sup>1</sup>, K. Sugumar<sup>1</sup>, K. Cook<sup>1</sup>, A. Ratnathicam<sup>1</sup>, M. Wilderman<sup>1</sup>, M. Napolitano<sup>1</sup>, G. Simonian<sup>1</sup>, D. J. O'Connor<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hackensack University Medical Center,Vascular And Endovascular Department,Hackensack, NEW JERSEY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Quantification of coronary artery calcium has been shown to be a reliable and reproducible predictor of a variety of adverse outcomes in patients with coronary artery disease. Here we investigate whether the pre-op severity of aneurysm calcification assessed by calcium score is associated with the sac regression after endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) in abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) patients. 

Methods:  A retrospective cohort study was conducted among the AAA patients who underwent successful EVAR at a single academic institute affiliated hospital between 2014-2016. Patients who had the pre-op and post-op follow up CT angiogram in the same institute without any type of endoleak after the procedure were included. Patients demographic data were collected. Pre-op Calcium Score were calculated using Agaston method. The sac regression rate (mm/year) was determined based on maximal diameter of the AAA in pre-op angiogram and the most recent follow up angiogram findings. 

Results: In total, 21 male and 10 female patients were found in the chart system with the mean age of 78 years old (range 58 to 92). 27 patients (87%) were White, the mean Calcium Score is 5605.79 (range 28.6 to 22473), mean sac regression rate is 9.60 mm/year (range -52.14 to 71.14). Linear regression analysis showed that pre-op calcium score is a positive predictor of sac regression rate after adjustment of age, gender and ethnicity with a coefficient value of 0.002 (P=0.013).

Conclusion: In AAA, a higher pre-op calcium score is correlated with accelerated sac regression after EVAR. This may reflect that AAA with high pre-op calcium score will respond well to the EVAR procedure with greater sac regression.

abstract_title: Effectiveness of Randomization of Patient Characteristics in a Cluster Randomized Control Trial
author_block: M. A. Eid<sup>1,2</sup>, J. A. Barnes<sup>1,2</sup>, Z. Wanken<sup>1,2</sup>, J. A. Columbo<sup>1,2</sup>, E. L. Spangler<sup>4</sup>, B. S. Brooke<sup>5</sup>, H. Dosluoglu<sup>7</sup>, E. S. Lee<sup>7</sup>, J. D. Raffetto<sup>8</sup>, P. K. Henke<sup>9</sup>, G. S. Tang<sup>10</sup>, L. Mureebe<sup>11</sup>, P. Kougias<sup>12</sup>, S. T. Scali<sup>14</sup>, D. H. Stone<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Arya<sup>22</sup>, V. Halpern<sup>16</sup>, J. O'Connell<sup>17</sup>, D. Ihnat<sup>18</sup>, E. Tzeng<sup>20</sup>, P. Nelson<sup>19</sup>, P. P. Goodney<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Dartmouth-Hitchock Medical Center,Section Of Vascular Surgery,Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>2</sup>White River Junction VA Medical Center,Department Of Surgery And VA Outcomes Group,White River Junction, VT, USA <sup>3</sup>Dartmouth Medical School,Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>4</sup>Birmingham VA Medical Center,Department Of Vascular Surgery,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>5</sup>George E Wahlen Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Department Of Vascular Surgery Vascular Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>6</sup>Buffalo VA Medical Center,Department Of Vascular Surgeryepartment Of Vascular Surgery Vascular Surgery,Buffalo, NY, USA <sup>7</sup>Sacramento VA Medical Center,Department Of Vascular Surgery,Sacramento, CA, USA <sup>8</sup>VA Boston Healthcare System,Department Of Vascular Surgery,West Roxbury, MA, USA <sup>9</sup>VA Ann Arbor Healthcare System,Vascular Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>10</sup>VA Puget Sound Health Care System,Vascular Surgery,Seattle, WA, USA <sup>11</sup>Durham VA Medical Center,Vascular Surgery,Durham, NC, USA <sup>12</sup>Michael E. DeBakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Vascular Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>13</sup>Atlanta VA Medical Center,Vascular Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>14</sup>Malcom Randall Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Vascular Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>15</sup>VA Connecticut Healthcare System,Vascular Surgery,West Haven, CT, USA <sup>16</sup>Phoenix VA Health Care System,Vascular Surgery,Phoenix, AZ, USA <sup>17</sup>West Los Angeles Medical Center,Vascular Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>18</sup>Minneapolis Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Vascular Surgery,Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>19</sup>James A. Haley Veteran's Hospital,Vascular Surgery,Tampa, FL, USA <sup>20</sup>VA Pittsburgh Healthcare System,Vascular Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>21</sup>Southern Arizona VA Health Care System,Vascular Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA <sup>22</sup>VA Palo Alto Healthcare Systems,Vascular Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cluster-randomized trials differ from patient-level randomized trials because the unit of randomization is the “cluster”, such as the study site, rather than an individual patient. However, it is unknown if this will reliably produce similar groups for comparison.  Here we assess the distribution of patient-level covariates in a cluster-randomized trial of a decision aid for patients choosing between open and endovascular repair of AAA, the Preferences for Open Versus Endovascular Repair of AAA Study (PROVE-AAA).

Methods: We are performing a multi-center, cluster-randomized trial of a decision aid for patients choosing open or endovascular approaches when facing abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.  Concerns of “contamination” of study sites by exposure to the decision aid favored the cluster randomized design.  Randomization occurred at the level of the study site (n=22), where treatment sites had exposure to a validated decision aid and control sites did not.  Basic demographic data including common comorbidities and health status were collected on each participant enrolled. 

Results: A total of 238 participants were randomized; 110 into the control arm and 128 into the intervention arm. Examination of our demographic characteristics, as the patient level, demonstrated that our cohort was primarily male (99%), white (99%) and elderly (mean age >70y).  Patients were commonly obese (62%, mean BMI 33.2), had hypertension (87%), diabetes (32%) and had a previous myocardial infarction (32%).  Among all demographic and comorbidity covariates, there were no statistical differences between treatment and control groups at the patient level (Table 1), even though the level of randomization was at the site level. 

Conclusion: Our cluster-randomized trial of a decision aid for patients facing vascular surgery yielded equal distribution of covariates at the patient level.  Cluster randomized trials in surgery can be an effective alternative when patient-level randomization strategies are not possible.

abstract_title: Rates of Dry to Wet Gangrene Conversion Post Lower Extremity Revascularization
author_block: E. A. Deluca<sup>1</sup>, C. Latz<sup>1</sup>, A. Dua<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Vascular Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a paucity of data regarding the conversion rate from dry gangrene to wet gangrene after revascularization of the lower extremity. This study aimed to determine the rate of conversion from dry to wet gangrene within 30 days post procedure in patients who underwent endovascular or open revascularization for critical limb ischemia. Secondary aims included determining the time to conversion and associated risk factors with conversion.

Methods: A multicenter, retrospective review was performed utilizing the Partners Healthcare System’s Research Patient Data Registry (RPDR). All adult patients who had lower extremity dry gangrene that underwent a revascularization procedures (endo, open, hybrid) from April 2002 - March 2020 were included. Patients who had no lower extremity gangrene, a concurrent amputation with the revascularization procedure, or wet gangrene on initial presentation were excluded. Datapoints included demographics, comorbidities, type of revascularization, extent of gangrene, creatinine, HBA1C, time to amputation, time to conversion, and if a procedure was performed for wet gangrene in 30 days.

Results: Of the 1,518 patients identified who underwent revascularization, 201 (13.2%) patients met inclusion critera and served as our study cohort. There were 51 (25.3%) conversions from dry to wet gangrene of which 18 (8.9%) patients converted within 30 days post procedure. The mean time to conversion was 11.9 ± 8.2 days. A logistic regression was performed which identified coronary artery disease as a protective variable (AOR=0.30, P-value=0.024) with male sex (AOR=3.46, P-value= 0.065) and forefoot gangrene (AOR=3.18, P-value=0.060) trending towards being possible risk factors for conversion.

Conclusion: The rate of dry to wet gangrene conversion post revascularization is 9% within 30 days. The mean time of conversion is 11.9 ± 8.2 days. Possible risk factors include male sex and forefoot gangrene.

abstract_title: WIfI and Angiographic Predictors of Amputation Free Survival in Chronic Limb-threatening Ischemia
author_block: R. C. Browder<sup>1</sup>, J. Mayor<sup>1</sup>, A. Zulbaran<sup>1</sup>, M. Montero-Baker<sup>1</sup>, Z. Pallister<sup>1</sup>, J. Mills<sup>1</sup>, J. Chung<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Vascular Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Angiographic predictors (AP) of outcomes in chronic limb threatening ischemia (CLTI) are ill defined.  We quantified the effect of AP upon outcomes in the context of the Society for Vascular Surgery Wound Ischemia foot Infection (WIfI) classification.

Methods: A single-center retrospective review of consecutive endovascular interventions for CLTI via a multidisciplinary team was performed.  We obtained baseline demographics, comorbidities, procedural, WIfI and AP.  Specifically angiosome directed revascularization (ADR; direct, indirect via collaterals, and indirect without collaterals), Kawarada classification, pedal GLASS classification, pedal arch patency, and post-procedural wound blush were obtained.  We excluded limbs without infrapopliteal angiograms.  The primary outcome was amputation free survival (AFS).

Results: Over thirty months, 110 patients (60% male; median age 67 years IQR 59, 74; 117 limbs; median follow up 205 days IQR 63, 576) underwent 208 revascularizations and 67 podiatric procedures.  Eighty limbs (68%) were WIfI stage 3/4.  Ninety limbs (77%) were among diabetic patients, while 72 (62%) were among dialysis-dependent patients.   ADR by limb was direct in 35 (30%), indirect via collaterals in 37 (32%) and indirect without collaterals in 45 (39%).  Thirteen limbs (11%) had intact pedal arches after revascularization.  Wound-blush was achieved in 20 limbs (17%).  Limbs had the following Kawarada Classifications:  12 (10%) Class I; 34 (29%) class 2A; 23 (20%) class 2B; and 30 (26%) Class 3.  At last available follow up, 11 limbs (9%) had undergone major amputation and twenty patients (19%) were deceased.  One-year Kaplan-Meier estimates of AFS, survival, and limb salvage were 68%, SE + 5%; 80% SE + 5%; and 90% SE + 3%, respectively.  On univariate analysis, ADR (HR 1.7, 95% CI 1.02, 2.82; p=0.04), and WIfI Stage (HR 1.8, 95% CI 1.09, 2.97; p=0.04) met criteria for model entry.  Multivariable logistic regression revealed that only WIfI Stage independently predicted AFS (HR 1.97, 95% CI 1.01, 3.52, p=0.02).

Conclusion: Endovascular approaches to CLTI within a multidisciplinary team can achieve 90% limb salvage, albeit with a high procedural rate.  ADR best predicts outcomes among the angiographic variables studied.  In contrast to WIfI clinical stage, none independently predicts outcome.

abstract_title: A Qualitative Analaysis of Work Status and Age when Choosing Mode of AAA repair
author_block: Y. D. Hu<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Jones<sup>1</sup>, C. Sensenig<sup>4</sup>, K. S. Mehta<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Barnes<sup>2</sup>, J. Goldwag<sup>2</sup>, P. P. Goodney<sup>2,3</sup>, M. A. Eid<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisel School of Medicine,Dartmouth College,Hanover, NH, USA <sup>2</sup>Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Lebanon, NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA <sup>3</sup>White River Junction VA Medical Center,Department Of Surgery And VA Outcomes Group,White River Junction, NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA <sup>4</sup>Smith College,Northampton, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Endovascular repair of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (EVAR) is gaining in popularity over open surgical repair (OSR) as a result of lower postoperative morbidity/mortality and ever-improving techniques and technologies. The PReferences for Open Versus Endovascular Repair of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (PROVE-AAA) trial aimed to determine the efficacy of a validated decision aid to enable better matching between patient preference and their ultimate repair. As part of this study, we sought to determine the key factors influencing the decision making of veterans who are eligible for EVAR or OSR through qualitative, thematic analysis of survey answers to free response questions.

Methods: The PROVE-AAA trial enrolled 236 veterans from 20 centers in the Veterans Administration (VA) system. Veterans were asked a series of questions eliciting their information sources regarding either repair. Their employment status and preferred intervention was also recorded. Survey answers were transcribed, individually coded, and analyzed using conventional content analysis by a team of four researchers to generate common, non-overlapping themes for each question. Results were stratified by employment status and reported using standard qualitative methodology.

Results: 42 patients provided their source of information for OSR (17.8% of enrollees) prior to using a decision aid and 43 patients provided their source of information for EVAR prior to using a decision aid (18.2% of enrollees). When stratified by employment status, 81% of retired veterans were over 70 years old, while 58% of not-retired veterans were over 70 (p=.003). The most common responses for retired individuals and not retired (working, unemployed, and disabled) individuals involved participants receiving information for both OSR and EVAR from a vascular surgeon/professional or an unspecified MD/other health professional. Notably for both cases, patients also relied on information form non-MD medical staff and personal experience/research. Interestingly, retired individuals were more likely than not retired individuals to get information for EVAR. For respondents of both questions, the most commonly preferred procedure was EVAR. However, non-retired individuals were more likely than their retired counterparts to prefer OSR.

Conclusion: Patients of the PROVE-AAA study were more likely to be retired and more likely to rely on information from an unspecified MD/other health professional for EVAR. Though both retired and non-retired patients preferred EVAR the most, non-retired individuals were more likely to prefer OSR despite being younger and OSR’s need for longer post operative recovery.

abstract_title: Post-operative Delirium after Lower Extremity Bypass for CLTI: Associated Risk Factors and Outcomes
author_block: J. C. Iannuzzi<sup>1</sup>, K. Linderman<sup>2</sup>, E. J. Smith<sup>1</sup>, J. Nacario<sup>1</sup>, K. Covinsky<sup>3</sup>, L. C. Walter<sup>3</sup>, J. S. Hiramoto<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Conte<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Vascular Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Utah,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Geriatrics,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Delirium after vascular surgery is poorly described and known risk factors of cognitive impairment and depression are not included in major studies of this patient population.  We hypothesized that delirium after infrainguinal lower extremity bypass (LEB) for chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) would be common, associated with cognitive impairment and depression, and increased non-home discharge (NHD) in home dwellers.

Methods: This was a single-center retrospective review of patients who presented with CLTI and underwent LEB between April 2016 and October 2019.  Delirium was identified via chart review using previously described methodology.  Cognitive impairment and depression were identified by diagnosis codes.  Associations between delirium and baseline characteristics and post-operative outcomes were tested using bivariate analysis.  The independent association of delirium with NHD was tested using multivariable binary logistic regression.

Results: Delirium developed in 30 (35%) of the 85 patients identified. The median patient age was 70 (IQR 61, 81), 62% were Caucasian and 62% were male (all p>0.01). On bivariate analysis, increased delirium was associated with age > 79 years (47% vs. 22%, p=0.02), depression (43% vs. 22%, p=0.04) and cognitive impairment (33% vs. 4%, p <0.001); decreased delirium was associated with diabetes (37% vs. 60%, p=0.04), preoperative Plavix (10% vs. 36%, p=0.01), and preoperative ACE inhibitors/ARBs (23% vs. 55%, p=0.01). Post-operatively, delirium was associated with an increased length-of-stay (15.1 days [SD 20.7] vs. 5.8 days [SD 2.5], p=0.001), non-home discharge (63% vs. 31%, p=0.004) and increased post-operative complications (48% vs. 22%, p=0.01). Multivariable analysis for NHD showed delirium was associated with increased NHD (OR=3.2, p=0.04, AUC=0.80). Consultation for delirium occurred in 13 (43%) patients with delirium.  Pharmacy was most often consulted (10/13), although no changes to care resulted.

Conclusion: Delirium is common after LEB for CLTI and associated with increased hospital resources including increased length-of-stay, post-operative complications, and non-home discharge. No patients received specialty consultation for delirium management and no care was changed after pharmacy consultation only.  Future studies should address how delirium-prevention programs and specialty consultation may prevent or diminish delirium’s impact in high-risk patients after LEB for CLTI.

abstract_title: Identifying Gaps in Disease Knowledge among Patients with Peripheral Arterial Disease
author_block: N. C. Byskosh<sup>1</sup>, V. Pamulapati<sup>3</sup>, A. K. Vavra<sup>4</sup>, A. W. Hoel<sup>4</sup>, Z. Butt<sup>2</sup>, K. J. Ho<sup>4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Medical Social Sciences,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Vascular Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is a manifestation of atherosclerosis associated with diminished quality of life, increased risk of limb loss, adverse cardiovascular events, and death. Management of risk factors is a central tenet of PAD treatment. Poor patient understanding of risk factors impedes the adoption of recommended lifestyle or behavioral recommendations. Based on the high prevalence of advanced PAD, we hypothesized that patients with PAD have inadequate understanding of its risk factors and consequences. 

Methods: Over a 7-week period at a single center, we surveyed 72 consecutive patients in the vascular surgery outpatient clinic with a pre-existing diagnosis of PAD. The survey assessed demographic, socioeconomic, and clinical information. The survey also assessed knowledge of their diagnosis and its risk factors and outcomes. Additional clinical history was obtained from the electronic medical record. Survey results were summarized using standard descriptive statistics.

Results: A total of 64 patients completed the survey (ages 30-100; 36% women); 8 patients declined to participate.  Reported PAD symptoms included claudication (53%) and rest pain (47%). Most patients have had PAD-related surgery, including lower extremity (LE) revascularization (72%), major LE amputation (15.6%), and minor LE amputation (17%). Overall, only 64% patients correctly indicated that they had been diagnosed with PAD, a proportion which was not impacted by a history of revascularization or amputation. In contrast, patient history of diabetes mellitus, stroke, and heart attack were correctly reported in 95%, 92%, and 80% of patients, respectively. The relationship of diabetes, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and smoking to PAD was correctly identified by only 63%, 64%, 69%, and 56% of patients, respectively. Only 60-73% understood that PAD is associated with limb loss, stroke, myocardial infarction, and death. Most patients (81%) expressed a desire to learn more about PAD, and 74% preferred to learn about it from their physicians. The preferred modes of learning materials were paper (51%), web-based (40%), and patient education sessions (25%). Topics about which patients desired to learn were the causes of PAD (71%), treatment for PAD (62%), and behaviors and health conditions associated with PAD (62%).

Conclusion: PAD patients have major knowledge deficits about their disease. The stark difference between knowledge of PAD and related comorbidities highlights a critical deficiency in patient education, which in most patients persists even after major vascular surgery. This pilot study identifies key content and patient preference regarding mode of delivery for patient education materials. Future interventions to improve frequency and efficacy of the education provided by physicians to patients in this population could significantly impact the natural history of the disease and improve patient outcomes.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 Stay-at-Home Orders on Pediatric Appendicitis Presentation
