author_block: H. M. Story<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. A. Arshad<sup>1,2,3</sup>, E. I. Garcia<sup>1,2,3</sup>, B. N. Hegde<sup>1,2,3</sup>, M. D. Gable<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. Tartibi<sup>1,2,3</sup>, N. B. Hebballi<sup>1,2,3</sup>, K. Tsao<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Center For Surgical Trials And Evidence-based Practice (C-STEP),Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Memorial Hermann Hospital,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In response to the global COVID-19 pandemic, many patients have delayed medical care for fear of contracting COVID-19. These decisions may be further influenced by governmental Stay-at-Home Orders (SAHO) driven by increases in COVID-19 cases. We aimed to study the impact of such measures on pediatric appendicitis patients, hypothesizing that there would be a delay in care and an associated increase in severity of appendicitis at presentation.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study was conducted of pediatric (age<18 years) appendectomy cases for acute appendicitis at a tertiary-care pediatric hospital in a major United States city from 12/1/2019 to 6/30/2020. A countywide SAHO was enacted on 3/24/2020. Patients who presented before this SAHO were compared to those who presented after. Demographics, clinical presentation, operative details, and patient outcomes within 30 post-operative days were extracted from the medical record. Appendicitis severity was classified as perforated or not perforated (simple or gangrenous) based on the surgeon’s intraoperative diagnosis. Univariate and multivariable regression analyses (utilizing meaningful variable selection, P<0.2) were performed. P<0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Of 248 patients who underwent appendectomy, 135 (54.4%) cases occurred prior to the SAHO and 113 (45.6%) occurred after the order. Five patients were excluded; four for incidental appendectomy and one for failed nonoperative treatment at another hospital. Patients were similar by age, gender, race, weight, comorbidities and insurance status. Patient-reported symptom duration, Pediatric Appendicitis Scores, and admission white blood cell count (WBC) were similar between the groups (Table). The Post SAHO group had a higher rate of perforated appendicitis cases (42.5%) compared to the Pre SAHO group (23.7%), p=0.002, and had a longer median length of stay (Table). There were similar post-operative complications between the groups including emergency department visits, readmissions, surgical site infections, small bowel obstruction, and reoperations (Table). On adjusted regression analysis, Post SAHO presentation was still associated with a diagnosis of perforated appendicitis (OR 2.3, 95% CI: 1.3-4.0).

Conclusion: The global COVID-19 pandemic and subsequent regional lockdowns continue to have an impact on all areas of healthcare. This study shows that in pediatric appendicitis cases following a local SAHO, patients presented with a similar timeline of reported symptom duration, but had a longer hospital length of stay and over twice the odds of presenting with perforated appendicitis. Future disaster/pandemic preparedness strategies must account for such effects and disruptions in healthcare.

abstract_title: Infliximab as Rescue Therapy in Pediatric Severe Colitis
author_block: C. Dekonenko<sup>1</sup>, K. B. Briggs<sup>1</sup>, W. J. Svetanoff<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Fraser<sup>1</sup>, R. Puthumana<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Oyetunji<sup>1</sup>, S. D. St Peter<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Mercy Hospital-University Of Missouri Kansas City,Department Of Surgery,Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Infliximab has been shown to be effective in achieving clinical remission in patients with ulcerative colitis (UC) refractory to conventional therapy. However, there is conflicting data regarding its effectiveness as rescue therapy in acute severe colitis. Furthermore, most studies were conducted in adults, and pediatric onset of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is associated with more severe disease that may be less amenable to rescue therapy. We reviewed our experience with pediatric severe colitis and report outcomes following attempted rescue therapy with infliximab.

Methods: A retrospective review was conducted of patients with UC or indeterminate colitis who received rescue infliximab therapy at our institution from January 2000-January 2019. Rescue infliximab therapy was considered if a child failed non-biologic therapy or progressed to fulminant or toxic colitis. Primary outcome was failed rescue therapy resulting in colectomy. Secondary outcomes included number of admissions, antibiotic utilization, total parental nutrition (TPN) days, number of blood transfusions, imaging, number of laboratory tests, days of intravenous steroids, and length of stay. Statistical analysis was performed using STATA and a p-value of <0.05 determined significance.

Results: Thirty patients met inclusion criteria. The median age at administration of rescue infliximab treatment was 14.5 years [IQR 13, 17]. Rescue therapy with infliximab was successful in 33% (n=10), while 67% (n=20) underwent colectomy. Comparisons of clinical characteristics of those with successful infliximab rescue versus those who underwent colectomy are shown in Table 1. Children on maintenance steroids were less likely to have successful rescue with infliximab and require colectomy (p=0.03). Possibly indicative of rescue therapy failure, children requiring colectomy had a longer hospital stay (p=0.03), more abdominal radiographs (p=0.01), and were on a longer duration of antibiotics (p=<0.01) compared to children who were successfully rescued with infliximab. There was no difference between children successfully rescued with infliximab and those who required colectomy with regards to vital signs or lab abnormalities, specifically white blood cell count and electrolyte values.

Conclusion: Infliximab as rescue therapy is ineffective in two-thirds of pediatric patients with severe colitis and does not have the potential for long-term cure. A response is more likely when patients are not on steroids at the time of admission.

abstract_title: Evaluation of Patient-Level Factors Associated with Development of Hirschsprung-Associated Enterocolitis
author_block: A. R. Pecoraro<sup>1</sup>, C. Hunter<sup>1</sup>, T. Markel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Pediatric Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hirschsprung-associated enterocolitis (HAEC) is an inflammatory disease of the bowel in patients with underlying Hirschsprung disease (HD), and is the most frequent potentially life-threatening complication of HD. We sought to evaluate the clinical characteristics most associated with the development of HAEC, and to investigate risk factors for HAEC following pull-through operation. We hypothesized that patient-level factors such as comorbidities, higher level of care requirement at the time of operation, and age at operation would be associated with a higher prevalence of HAEC. 

Methods: A retrospective cohort study of the Pediatric Health Information System database for all patients with Hirschsprung disease who underwent a pull-through operation was performed. Preoperative and postoperative encounters for enterocolitis were considered. Statistical analysis was performed on this cohort utilizing logistic regression methods to identify cohort characteristics most closely associated with the development of HAEC. A p value of <0.05 was statistically significant.

Results: We evaluated 6221 patients with Hirschsprung disease who underwent a pull-through procedure. These patients were predominantly male (76.6%) and white (59.51%) with a primary mix of insurance payers between Medicaid (49.0%) and commercial (40.2%) insurance providers. There were 4487 separate encounters for enterocolitis. Comorbid congenital/genetic defects (OR=1.33, p<0.001) and Medicaid as primary insurance (OR=1.17, p=0.013) were positively correlated with HAEC encounters, while the presence of a neurologic/neuromuscular disorder was negatively correlated with HAEC (OR=0.7, p=0.045). Post-operatively, NICU stay during index operation (OR=0.017, p<0.001), “other” insurance – that is, specifically designated as non-Medicaid, non-commercial (OR=0.48, p=0.014) - and age at pull-through less than 1 year (OR=0.23, p<0.001) were negatively correlated with HAEC. We tabulated a total charge of $193,028,189.20 for all post-operative encounters, or $3,374.56 per patient-year. The most common diagnoses for subsequent inpatient admissions were: Hirschsprung disease (25.6%, average cost=$9235.74), HAEC (4.7%, average=$7399.21) and dehydration (2.8%, average=$8874.53). 

Conclusion: The diagnosis of HAEC remains nebulous, but several patient-level factors are distinctly associated with the development of this complication. Directed patient care initiatives may be utilized for those patients who may be at a higher risk of future HAEC admission. Further study is warranted to fully examine the burdensome nature of this disorder.

abstract_title: Parental Decision-Making Preferences for Urgent Pediatric Surgical Procedures
author_block: L. A. Shinkunas<sup>2</sup>, C. J. Klipowicz<sup>3</sup>, E. Ruba<sup>4</sup>, E. M. Carlisle<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Iowa,Surgery,Iowa City, IOWA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Iowa,Program In Bioethics And Humanities,Iowa City, IOWA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Iowa,Anthropology,Iowa City, IOWA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Iowa,Carver College Of Medicine,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Shared decision making, with an emphasis on patient autonomy, is advised in healthcare decision making.  However, shared decision making may be difficult to implement in urgent settings. We have previously demonstrated that when considering urgent operations for their children, parents prefer surgeon guidance as opposed to autonomous decision making.  Here, we interview parents of pediatric patients who have undergone urgent operations to gain a more nuanced understanding of decision-making preferences when parents engage in urgent surgical decision-making for their children.

Methods:  We identified parents of pediatric patients who had undergone surgery at a University based, tertiary children’s hospital in the past 5 years for cancer, an urgent operation while in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).  Parents were contacted and invited to participate in a 60-minute semi-structured interview.  Interviews were conducted with 12 parents of 12 pediatric surgical patients. Interviews were digitally recorded and transcribed verbatim.  Thematic content analysis was performed using a grounded theory approach.  An iterative approach to thematic sampling and data analysis was used.

Results: Thematic saturation was achieved after 12 interviews (4 cancer, 5 NICU, 3 ECMO).   All parents felt that their child had undergone at least one urgent operation.  11 patients were alive at the time of interview.  Five key themes emerged from these urgent operation scenarios: (1) Most parents felt that it was helpful to have a recommendation from their child’s surgeon; (2) All parents expressed that they did not feel like there was a decision to be made; (3) Most parents appreciated being provided a handout, brochure, protocol, or drawing as opposed to receiving only verbal information; (4) All parents defined shared decision making as “dialogue,”  “discussion,” or “having an option”  and generally felt as if they had shared in the decision making process with the surgeon despite feeling that there was no decision to be made; (5) All parents valued the opportunity to ask questions and viewed this as having a “valued voice” to advocate for their children.

Conclusion: When engaging in decision making regarding urgent surgical procedures for their children, parents want the surgeon to provide a recommendation.  Parents feel that engaging in dialogue or discussion with the surgeon defines shared decision making, and they believe that the opportunity to ask questions gives them a “valued voice,” even when they do not feel as if there is a specific decision to be made.  These key themes will be used to develop a decision-making tool that parents can use to more effectively engage in discussions regarding surgical decision making for their children.

abstract_title: Using Wearables to Assess Post-operative Pediatric Recovery Patterns in Appendectomy Patients
author_block: C. De Boer<sup>1</sup>, B. Many<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Bouchard<sup>1</sup>, S. Linton<sup>1</sup>, A. Figueroa<sup>1</sup>, S. Kwon<sup>2</sup>, H. Ghomrawi<sup>1</sup>, F. Abdullah<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgery/Northwestern University,Chicago, ILLINOIS, USA <sup>2</sup>Ann and Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago,The Smith Child Health Research Program,,Chicago, ILLINOIS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite nearly three million pediatric operations performed in the United States annually, normal post-operative recovery patterns remain difficult to define. Wearables that objectively and passively assess physical activity in real time represent a novel tool to assess postoperative recovery. Wearables data have been used to predict onset of complications in adults, but these devices may be particularly useful in pediatric patients for whom proxies may inaccurately assess recovery, resulting in untimely care. Currently little is known about acceptance and utility of wearables in children undergoing surgery. This pilot study aimed to examine the feasibility of using the FitBit®, a commercially available wearable that measures physical activity, to describe post-operative recovery in children after appendectomy, the most utilized inpatient surgical procedure in children, and determine the utility of accelerometer data to describe differences in recovery based on disease severity (complicated versus uncomplicated appendicitis).

Methods:  Children ages 3-18 years old undergoing appendectomy for acute appendicitis at our institution over a 4 month period were invited to participate post-operatively. Continuous minute-by-minute heart rate (to establish wear time) and step count data (to assess physical activity) were collected for 21 days after application of the wrist-worn FitBit® accelerometer immediately after surgery. Descriptive analyses of patient demographics and daily step count data were performed. Growth curve analysis was conducted to model trajectories of complicated versus uncomplicated appendicitis patient recovery courses indicated by daily step counts.

Results: Of 32 patients enrolled, 26 met the eligibility criteria and were included in data analysis. In this sample, 9 (35%) patients had complicated appendicitis and 14 (54%) were female; the mean age was 9.1 years (SD: 2.9). A total of 419 post-operative days were captured in these patients (range of 8 to 22 days per patient; median of 16 days). Daily step counts increased after surgery and were higher for uncomplicated appendectomy patients (Figure 1). The growth curve model showed that uncomplicated appendectomy patients had significantly higher recovery trajectories based on step count compared to complicated patients (p=0.01).

Conclusion: This pilot study has demonstrated that FitBit® use is feasible after surgery in children and can distinguish recovery trajectories based on disease severity in the immediate post-operative period. Establishing “normal” surgical recovery may lead to improved outpatient monitoring and earlier detection of complications.

abstract_title: Association between Neighborhood Socioeconomic Disadvantage and Complicated Appendicitis in Children
author_block: C. Bodnar<sup>1</sup>, R. Buss<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Somers<sup>1</sup>, A. Mokdad<sup>1</sup>, K. Van Arendonk<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Lower socioeconomic status (SES) has been linked to poorer outcomes for a variety of medical and surgical conditions among children. A higher risk of complicated appendicitis, often used as a surrogate for delay in care, has also been linked to lower SES. However, this finding has been inconsistent across individual children’s hospitals and has been reliant on inexact SES measures such as zip code-level median household income. The objective of this study was to measure the association between a more granular measure of SES and presentation with complicated appendicitis among children.

Methods:  Clinical and demographic characteristics for all patients treated for acute appendicitis at a large freestanding children’s hospital between 2015-2019 were reviewed. Patient home addresses were mapped to census block groups and linked to a neighborhood-level marker of SES called the Area Deprivation Index (ADI), which incorporates income, education, employment, and housing quality. Home addresses were also used to calculate travel time from patient home to children’s hospital. Multivariable logistic regression models were used to compare the likelihood of having complicated appendicitis across ADI while adjusting for confounders.

Results: During the study period, 1,671 children were treated for acute appendicitis, of which 638 (38.2%) had complicated disease. Compared to those with uncomplicated disease, children with complicated disease were younger (median age 10.3 [IQR 7.0-13.4] vs. 12.0 [IQR 9.4-14.8] years, p<0.001) and more likely to have public insurance (51.4% vs. 41.7%, p<0.001), live >60 minutes from the children’s hospital (17.1% vs. 11.8%, p<0.001), and have prior emergency department visits in the 30 days preceding diagnosis (8.8% vs. 4.5%, p<0.001). Children with complicated appendicitis disproportionately came from more disadvantaged neighborhoods (p<0.005), with 33% of those with complicated disease coming from the two most disadvantaged ADI deciles. Adjusted for age, gender, race, travel time, and insurance, the odds of perforated disease rose by 6% per increase in ADI decile (adjusted odds ratio [aOR] 1.06, 95%CI 1.01-1.10, p=0.01). Younger age and >60 minutes travel time were also strongly associated with complicated appendicitis. The association between ADI and complicated appendicitis remained among children less than 10 years old (aOR 1.08, 95%CI 1.00-1.16, p=0.04) and those living within 30 minutes from the children’s hospital (aOR 1.06, 95%CI 1.01-1.11, p=0.02).

Conclusion: ADI, a salient measure of neighborhood-level socioeconomic disadvantage, is associated with complicated disease among children presenting with acute appendicitis. As complicated appendicitis is often a proxy for delay in care, ADI may be a valuable measure of difficulty accessing timely surgical care among disadvantaged children.

abstract_title: Historical Trends in Post-Operative Opioid Prescribing Practices in Children
author_block: G. Thompson<sup>2</sup>, E. Blondeau-Lecomte<sup>2</sup>, V. Hoang<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Mustafa<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Larson<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup>, D. Neal<sup>3</sup>, R. T. Petroze<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida,College Of Medicine,Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Florida,Department Of Surgery/Statistics,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Increased public health awareness and legislation at the state and federal level aim to decrease opioid abuse, including affecting post-operative prescription practices. While children are affected by both direct and indirect consequences of the opioid epidemic, uniform protocols for opioid prescribing practices in children undergoing surgical procedures are often lacking. The goal of this study was to evaluate the patterns in the prescription of pain medication following common pediatric surgeries in order to identify targets for quality improvement.  We hypothesize that amounts of opioids prescribed has decreased in the wake of increased awareness, but that practice patterns are widely variable.

Methods: A single-institution retrospective review of pediatric patients (<18 years) was conducted.  Data were abstracted from 2012-2019 and entered into a RedCap database for appendectomy, umbilical hernia repair, inguinal hernia repair, circumcision, laparoscopic gastrostomy (+/- fundoplication), laparoscopic cholecystectomy, orchiopexy, and abscess or pilonidal drainage. Patients were excluded if discharged from a long-term ICU, hospital discharge >7 days postoperatively, conversion to major laparotomy, or chronic narcotic use. Variables included demographics, medical history, operative course and discharge medications. Univariate and multivariate analysis evaluated trends in opioid prescriptions with subanalyses performed to identify differences by race, gender, or insurance status. A linear regression model was created to model mean total opioid doses by time. Non-linear polynomial modeling with a 5-knot restricted cubic spine fit was developed to best show the change in prescription patterns over time.

Results: 1865 cases met inclusion criteria. Mean age was 9.3 years, and patients were predominantly male (61.5%), white (66.6%), and insured by Medicaid (63.9%). Average post-op stay was 1.5 days. 1157 patients were prescribed an opioid on discharge. Mean number of opioids prescribed (defined as total number of doses) decreased over time from 24 in 2012 to 2 in 2019 (p<0.001). All subcategories decreased, with hernia repairs showing the least amount of change. When controlling for other factors, time and procedure were both significantly associated with opioid dose (p<.0001). Time analysis showed a decrease in opioid prescribing from 2012-2014, plateau until 2017, and further decrease until 2019 (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Opioid prescription in post-operative patients decreased over time despite no pediatric-specific opioid prescribing protocols. This may be due to advocacy, awareness, or legislation, and the influence of these factors on prescribing practice requires further investigation.

abstract_title: Complication Timing, Failure to Rescue, and Readmission after Inpatient Pediatric Surgery
author_block: J. I. Portuondo<sup>1,2</sup>, S. R. Shah<sup>1,3</sup>, M. V. Raval<sup>4</sup>, N. N. Massarweh<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College of Medicine,Michael E. DeBakey Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Michael E. DeBakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Center For Innovation, Quality, Effectiveness, And Safety,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Complications are associated with postoperative mortality and readmission.  However, the timing of complications relative to discharge and the extent to which timing is associated with failure to rescue (FTR) and readmission after pediatric surgery is unknown.  A better understanding of when postoperative complications occur could inform quality improvement (QI) initiatives.

Methods: National cohort study of patients within the NSQIP–Pediatric database who underwent inpatient surgery (2012-2016).  Complications were categorized based on when they occurred relative to discharge:  only pre-discharge; only post-discharge; both. The main outcomes were FTR and unplanned readmission within 30-days.  The association between perioperative outcomes and the timing of postoperative complications was evaluated with multivariable logistic regression.

Results: Among 200,554 surgical inpatients, 27,726 (13.8%) had at least one postoperative complication.  Among patients with complications, 36.7%, 21.9%, and 40.6% had complications only pre-discharge, only post-discharge, and both, respectively.  FTR was highest among patients with pre-discharge complications (7.2%) and lowest among patients with complications both before and after discharge (0.1%).  Readmission was highest among patients with post-discharge complications (52.7%) and lowest among patients with pre-discharge complications (4.9%).  Relative to patients with no complications, pre-discharge (Odds Ratio [OR] 11.45, 95% confidence interval [9.78 – 13.39]) and post-discharge (OR 2.10 [1.36 – 3.22]) complications were associated with significantly increased odds of FTR.  By comparison, patients with complications occurring both before and after discharge had significantly lower odds of FTR (OR 0.12 [0.06 – 0.24]).  Post-discharge complications were associated with significantly increased odds of readmission (OR 23.01 [21.70 – 24.33]) as were complications occurring both before and after discharge (OR 1.92 [1.78 – 2.06]), although the magnitude of the effect was lower.  By comparison, pre-discharge complications were associated with a significantly lower odds of readmission (OR 0.88 [0.81 – 0.98]).

Conclusion: Among pediatric surgical patients, the timing of post-operative complications relative to discharge is differentially associated with FTR (pre-discharge) and readmission (post-discharge).  These differences suggest QI interventions directed at FTR should focus on patients during the index surgical admission while interventions directed at readmission should likely focus on patients undergoing operations associated with short length of stay, but high morbidity.  Furthermore, the effects identified in patients with complications both before and after discharge, suggest that improving pre-discharge education and post-discharge monitoring might represent opportunities to avoid potentially preventable readmissions or mortality.

abstract_title: Understanding Socioeconomic Challenges to Fetal Myelomeningocele Repair – A Cross-sectional Survey
author_block: A. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, E. Garcia<sup>1</sup>, P. Daghighi<sup>1</sup>, D. Donthula<sup>1</sup>, E. Bergh<sup>2</sup>, R. Papanna<sup>2</sup>, K. Tsao<sup>1,2</sup>, M. T. Austin<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Obstetrics, Gynecology And Reproductive Sciences,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In 2010, the Management of Myelomeningocele (MMC) Study (MOMS) trial showed significant improvement in neurofunctional outcomes for those infants who underwent prenatal versus postnatal myelomeningocele repair and it is now standard of care to offer fetal MMC repair to any pregnant woman and fetus who meet eligibility criteria.  However, fetal surgery is performed at a limited number of centers across the US.  In this study, we surveyed former fetal center patients diagnosed with MMC to determine potential barriers to undergoing fetal MMC repair versus postnatal repair.

Methods: We conducted a cross-sectional survey of former patients evaluated for MMC repair at a quaternary fetal center between 2012 and 2019. Patients who chose to terminate their pregnancy did not receive a survey.  The survey included questions related to sociodemographics, obstetrician and fetal center counseling, and the Decision Regret Scale, a validated tool to determine if patients had regret about their choice of MMC management.  The survey data was analyzed using descriptive statistics.

Results: Of the 189 surveys distributed, 76 patients (40%) responded and were included in the analysis.  Of the 76, 56 underwent prenatal MMC repair.  Respondents who underwent fetal MMC repair were similar to those who had postnatal repair in age, race/ethnicity, insurance status, household income, educational level, marriage and employment status (all p>0.05). More than 1/3 of respondents (36%) were influenced by social services in deciding between fetal and postnatal repair.  Respondents who underwent fetal repair were more likely to have their decision influenced by social support (91% vs 32%, p=<0.001), and partner/spouse and family support followed by social group support most commonly influenced their decision.  25% of respondents in the fetal repair group were influenced in their decision by housing availability.  The median out-of-pocket expenses to undergo the fetal center evaluation were $1,500 (550-3500) for fetal repair patients and $1,000 (200-1500) for postnatal repair patients (p=0.201).   5% of respondents (n=4) reported that financial barriers prevented them from choosing the best option for them and their baby.  Most (94%) reported that they made the right decision between fetal and postnatal repair; however, 3 respondents who underwent fetal repair reported that the choice caused them a lot of harm.  

Conclusion: While fetal MMC repair has been proven to improve outcomes in children with spina bifida, there remain socioeconomic challenges for pregnant women to undergo fetal MMC repair.  However, most respondents were happy with their decision between fetal and postnatal MMC repair.

abstract_title: Perforated Appendicitis During a Pandemic: The Downstream Effects of COVID-19 in Children
author_block: J. R. Esparaz<sup>1,2</sup>, M. K. Chen<sup>1,2</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1,2</sup>, S. A. Anderson<sup>1,2</sup>, C. A. Martin<sup>1,2</sup>, V. E. Mortellaro<sup>1,2</sup>, D. A. Rogers<sup>1,2</sup>, M. S. Mathis<sup>1</sup>, R. T. Russell<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's of Alabama,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Birmingham, ALABAMA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The World Health Organization declared the Coronavirus Disease-19 (COVID-19) a pandemic in March of 2020. Following this declaration, many states issued restrictions on travel, formal stay-at-home orders were put into effect, and hospital systems began cancelling non-emergent surgeries. During this time, we anecdotally noted that our pediatric surgery service was admitting more cases of perforated appendicitis. Therefore, we hypothesize that during the months following the COVID-19 pandemic declaration, more children were presenting with perforated appendicitis.

Methods: A retrospective chart review for all pediatric patients admitted at a single institution with a diagnosis of acute and/or perforated appendicitis defined by preoperative imaging and/or operative findings from October 2019 to May 2020 was performed. Interval appendectomies were excluded. COVID-19 months were designated as March, April, and May 2020, as these months had the highest active stay-at-home orders in place. Additional analysis of March, April, and May of 2019 was performed for comparison purposes. Analyzed data included patient demographics, symptom durations, white blood cell count, imaging findings, procedures performed, and perforation status. Post-operative perforation status was confirmed with pathology. Statistical analysis was performed.

Results: During the consecutive study period, 285 patients were admitted with the diagnosis of acute appendicitis with 95 patients having perforated appendicitis. The pre-COVID-19 group had 182 patients and the remaining 103 patients comprised the COVID-19 months. Demographics were similar between the two groups. Using univariate analysis, we identified a significant increase in number of perforated appendicitis cases in the three COVID-19 months compared with the preceding five months (45.6% vs 26.4%; p <0.001). A similar significant increase was identified when comparing COVID-19 months to the same months a year prior (p = 0.003). Lastly, the patients with perforated appendicitis presenting during the COVID-19 months had nearly twice the readmission rates than those from five months prior.

Conclusion: The declaration of the COVID-19 pandemic and its associated stay-at-home orders have had downstream effects on healthcare. Our review has demonstrated a significant increase in the number of children presenting with perforated appendicitis following the institution of these state ordinances. A delay or a reluctance to seek care due to fear of being exposed to the COVID-19 virus may result in more severe illness from appendicitis. These results demonstrate that further investigations into the issues surrounding access to healthcare, especially during this pandemic, are warranted.

abstract_title: Pilot Implementation of Opioid Stewardship Measures and PRO Assessments Using the NSQIP-P Platform
author_block: M. E. Ingram<sup>1</sup>, Y. Tian<sup>1</sup>, S. Kennedy<sup>2</sup>, W. Schaefer<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, D. Apley<sup>3</sup>, S. Mehrotra<sup>3</sup>, J. Holl<sup>4</sup>, M. V. Raval<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>American College of Surgeons,National Surgical Quality Improvement Program Pediatric (NSQIP-Peds), Ann And Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital Of Chicago,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Northwestern University,Department Of Engineering,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Center for Healthcare Delivery, Science, and Innovation, University of Chicago Medicine,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite increased awareness surrounding opioid stewardship, data to guide optimal postoperative opioid prescribing are lacking for children undergoing surgery.  The American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program-Pediatric (NSQIP-P) data collection platform offers a unique opportunity to gather information about current pediatric perioperative pain practices and opioid prescribing. Effectiveness of postoperative pain management can be assessed by patient surveys including PROMIS® measures.

Methods: In addition to the standard NSQIP-P data, a certified surgical clinical reviewer collected 24 novel data elements about perioperative pain practices for patients ages 5-18 years old undergoing surgery at a free-standing children’s hospital between February and June 2020.  Surveys about prescribed opioid use and pain-related PROMIS® measures were sent to patients and their parents, by email, on post-operative days (POD) 7 and 30.  Univariate analyses, Chi-square, and Wilcoxon Rank Sum tests were performed, when appropriate, to describe predictors of opioid prescribing and to assess effectiveness of pain management. 

Results: Of 588 patients selected for standard NSQIP-P data collection over the study period, we identified 292 patients (49.6%) for inclusion in our study.  Mean abstraction time of new variables decreased from 15 to 5 minutes per patient over the study period.  Of the 292 patients, 89 (31%) were prescribed opioids at discharge.   Factors associated with prescribed opioids included age (median 13.8y (11.4, 16) vs 11.6y (8.3, 14.6) p<0.001), undergoing spinal arthrodesis or pectus excavatum repair (p<0.001), and undergoing inpatient surgery (p<0.05).  Median morphine milligram equivalent (MME)/day prescribed was 45 (interquartile range (IQR) 30 MME/day) for those with opioid pills, and 23.7 for opioid liquids (IQR 14.7 MME/day).  Two patients (2%) received opioid prescriptions for >100 MME/day.  47 (17%) received pre-operative non-opioid pain adjuncts and <30% received regional or epidural blocks pre- or intraoperatively.  Survey completion was 15.7% (46) on POD 7 and 5% (15) on POD 30.  19 patients reported receiving an opioid prescription, and all 19 reported filling the prescription. Reported median worst pain score at POD 7 was higher for opioid users (U) [24 (IQR 62)] than for opioid non-users (NU) [3 (IQR 18), (p<0.05)];  median PROMIS® t-score for pain interference was not different between the two groups [50.9 (IQR 24) U vs 43.3 (IQR 14.9) NU, p=0.14].

Conclusion: The NSQIP-P platform is a feasible option for collecting data on pediatric perioperative pain management and opioid-prescribing practices. Second, postoperative PROs yield valuable information around effects of pain management practices.  Further investigation and expansion of this study is required to improve PRO response rates and inform optimal prescribing practices. This research was supported by NIH Grant: TL1TR001423

abstract_title: Understanding Current Approaches to the Management of Pediatric Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction
author_block: S. N. Acker<sup>1</sup>, J. Diaz-Miron<sup>1</sup>, R. Ignacio<sup>2</sup>, H. Thangarajah<sup>2</sup>, K. Russell<sup>3</sup>, K. Lofberg<sup>4</sup>, S. Shew<sup>10</sup>, L. I. Kelley-Quon<sup>6</sup>, A. R. Jensen<sup>7</sup>, J. Lee<sup>8</sup>, B. Padilla<sup>8</sup>, P. N. Peterson<sup>5</sup>, C. A. Smith<sup>9</sup>, K. Wang<sup>6</sup>, K. S. Azarow<sup>4</sup>, D. Ostlie<sup>8</sup>, Z. J. Kastenberg<sup>3</sup>, T. H. Inge<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Colorado,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>Rady Children's Hospital,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Primary Children's Hospital,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>4</sup>Oregon Health Sciences Univeristy,Pediatric Surgery,Portland, OR, USA <sup>5</sup>Denver Health Medical Center,Medicine,Denver, CO, USA <sup>6</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Pediatric Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>7</sup>UCSF Benioff Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgery,Oakland, CA, USA <sup>8</sup>Phoenix Children's Hospital,Phoenix, AZ, USA <sup>9</sup>Seattle Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgery,Seattle, WA, USA <sup>10</sup>Lucile Packard Children's Hospital Stanford,Pediatric Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In adults with adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO), water soluble contrast-based protocols have been used to guide management. The utility of such protocols in children is unknown. Our aims were to evaluate how pediatric surgeons integrate contrast-based protocols in their approach to ASBO in children and understand how surgeons make clinical and operative decisions. 

Methods: We administered a web-based survey using REDCap® to all practicing pediatric surgeons at nine children’s hospitals comprising the Western Pediatric Surgery Research Consortium. Questions queried surgeon management of pediatric ASBO including standard approach, knowledge of enteral water-soluble contrast protocols in adults, and attitudes towards incorporation of contrast-based protocols for pediatric ASBO management. The survey included three open ended questions. Two authors reviewed all open-ended responses. They identified themes for each of the three questions and used a conventional content analysis approach to categorize responses based on these themes.

Results: The response rate was 66% (67/101). Thirty-six surgeons (56%) reported practicing for >10 years. Overall, 93% reported peritonitis is an indication for operation. Surgeons in practice for >10 years were more likely to indicate peritonitis, elevated white blood cell count, or elevated lactate were indications for operative intervention compared to surgeons in practice for <10 years (p<0.05 for all three comparisons). Approximately half (55%) reported they use contrast-based protocols to guide ASBO management either routinely or occasionally.  Further details of protocol use are shown in Table 1. Five themes emerged when surgeons were asked why they used these protocols: to help with operative decision making (n=20), support of adult data (n=6), therapeutic benefit (n=4), to avoid unnecessary operation (n=3), and to standardize care (n=1). Three themes emerged when asked about the integration of adult-based data into pediatric practice: lack of pediatric specific data (n=5), compelling ideas presented in the adult literature are applicable to pediatric populations (n=33), and adult evidence should to be carefully adapted for pediatric populations (n=32).

Conclusion: Based on these data we conclude that: senior surgeons are more likely to use laboratory and peritonitis as indications for surgery; survey data can help to elucidate how pediatric surgeons incorporate adult based evidence into their practice and identify barriers to clinical research in pediatric surgery; wide variation exists in attitudes and factors used to make clinical decisions in children with ASBO; further studies of contrast-based protocols for ASBO management in pediatric populations are warranted.

abstract_title: The Laparoscopic Approach to Benign Pediatric Adnexal Pathology
author_block: A. Munoz<sup>1</sup>, C. Templeman<sup>3</sup>, M. A. Sacks<sup>1</sup>, K. Maselli<sup>3</sup>, C. Shin<sup>3,4</sup>, J. Baerg<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine,Pediatric Surgery,Loma LInda, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Western University of Health Sciences,College Of Osteopathic Medicine Of The Pacific,Pomona, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Southern California,Keck School Of Medicine,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Pediatric Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The challenge of pediatric adnexal pathology can be approached by understanding factors associated with oophorectomy.

Methods: After Institutional Review Board approval, a retrospective cohort study of females (age 1-19 years) with laparoscopic operations for adnexal pathology operated between June 2003 and June 2019, at two children’s hospitals, was performed. Malignancy was excluded. Changes in oophorectomy rates were compared between June 2003 - June 2011 (early) and July 2011 - June 2019 (late) time periods. Categorical and continuous variables were analyzed by Chi-square and t-tests, respectively.  Multivariable logistic regression evaluated for variable independence. Data were presented as mean and standard deviation.

Results: In 127 girls, 138 operations were performed. 150 adnexae were examined by a pathologist. 155 pathologies were identified (Table 1). Of the 138 operations, 41 (29.1%) were converted to open, associated with larger lesions, 9.1 (4.0) vs. 5.3 (3.2) cm; p<0.01. Eleven (8.7%) had bilateral pathology: 7/11 (63.6%) had bilateral synchronous mature cystic teratomas (MCTs), 2/11 (18.2%) had synchronous bilateral pathology, and 2/11 (18.2%) had metachronous bilateral lesions. Most adnexa were preserved (21/22, 95.5%). The oophorectomy rate was 26/127 (20.5%). Oophorectomy was significantly associated with younger age (p<0.01); pre-menarche status (p=0.02); imaging findings of calcifications (p=0.01) and solid components (p<0.01); and a pathologic finding of an MCT (p<0.01).   Male pediatric surgeons' oophorectomy rate was 4.4 times that of female surgeons (p = 0.01, 95% CI: 1.4-13.7).  Torsion, observed in 54/127 (42.5%), was not associated with oophorectomy (p=0.12) (Table 1). Post fellowship years (p=0.13), operation time of day (p=0.46), and comparison of early vs. late time periods (p=0.09) were not associated with oophorectomy.  Spillage was recorded in 21/138 (15.2%) operations, 6 converted to open (28.6%), but was not associated with oophorectomy (p=0.77). Logistic regression revealed that those who underwent cystectomy were 96% (OR .04, 95% CI: .01-.18) less likely to have an oophorectomy; however, those with a mature teratoma were 5.3 times (95% CI: 2.1-13.0) more likely to have an oophorectomy. 

Conclusion: For girls with benign adnexal pathology undergoing a laparoscopic approach, oophorectomy is independently associated with MCT or male surgeon. The ovary is more likely to be preserved if cystectomy is performed; therefore, we recommend cystectomy wherever feasible.

abstract_title: Implementation of an Evidence Based Accelerated Pathway for Children with Blunt Solid Organ Injury
author_block: S. Stokes<sup>1</sup>, E. G. Brown<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Jackson<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Leshikar<sup>1</sup>, J. T. Stephenson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Davis,Pediatric Surgery,Sacramento, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma is the leading cause of death in children. Blunt abdominal injuries occur in 10-15% of pediatric trauma patients, resulting in solid organ injuries which are often managed non-operatively. Blunt solid organ injuries have historically been managed with in-hospital bedrest for the grade of injury plus one day. Recent work has demonstrated that a shorter length of stay is safe, however this is not well studied in a dual trauma center setting. We hypothesized that implementation of an accelerated blunt solid organ injury protocol would decrease length of stay (LOS) and hospitalization cost without an increase in morbidity or mortality.

Methods:  A retrospective review of patients under 15 years of age presenting to a dual level 1 pediatric and adult trauma center between 2015 and 2019 with blunt trauma liver and splenic injuries was performed. Patients presenting prior to protocol implementation in April 2018 were compared to those who presented after implementation. Protocol patients were admitted to the ward or the intensive care unit (ICU) based on hemodynamic status and injury grade. Diet and activity were advanced based on hemodynamic status and abdominal exam. Patients were discharged when they were hemodynamically stable, tolerating a diet and had stable hematocrits on lab draws. Hospitalization cost data was available for patients presenting from 2016 onwards. The primary outcome was total hospital LOS. Secondary outcomes were ICU LOS, cost of hospitalization, readmission and mortality rates.

Results: 87 patients were evaluated, 67 pre-protocol and 20 post-protocol. There was no difference in age, injury severity score, liver injury grade or spleen injury grade between the groups. LOS was significantly shorter in the post-protocol group (2 days vs. 4 days, p=0.015). The ICU LOS was unchanged. There was a decrease in direct hospitalization cost per patient from $6,246 pre-protocol to $3,810 post-protocol (p=0.030). There were no deaths and no readmissions.

Conclusion: Implementation of an accelerated pathway for management of blunt solid organ injury in pediatric patients at a dual trauma center was associated with decreased length of stay and decreased costs with no increased morbidity or mortality.

abstract_title: Cost Effective Use of Lean Principles for Pediatric Appendectomies
author_block: A. Machchhar<sup>1</sup>, D. Chung<sup>1</sup>, S. Pandya<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Pediatric Surgery/Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  With an astronomical rise in healthcare costs over the past few decades, surgeons should find ways to provide high-quality clinical care without excess costs. Surgeons, however, often lack the necessary data to achieve this goal. Every part of a patient’s surgical experience is associated with costs unbeknownst to treating clinician. Standardization of surgical supplies have been shown to reduce costs. Herein, we sought to determine the variance in costs associated with laparoscopic appendectomy in a large tertiary pediatric hospital. 

Methods:  A single center prospective observational study of pediatric patients undergoing appendectomy was performed. 36 appendectomies performed by 11 faculty surgeons were directly observed. Surgical supplies and operative times were recorded. The actual cost per case was thus derived and correlated to clinical outcomes, such as complications and 30-day readmission rate.

Results: The average supply cost per case ranged from $353.23 to $1,122.22 with an average incision to close time ranging from 30 to 53 min. Increased complexity of the case (i.e., complicated appendicitis) had little to no bearing on the total supply cost, but often increased operative time. The variance between individual surgeon’s mean cost and that of the most cost effective surgeon calculated. This was then multiplied by the yearly case volume of the surgeon and the total cost savings calculated. This resulted in a cumulative potential cost savings of $379,047 at our center. There were no significant differences in outcomes between the most and least cost effective surgeons.

Conclusion: By adopting the lean methodology, surgeons can eliminate waste and transition to providing value-based care for patients undergoing this high-volume procedure. Reducing supply costs and operative times remain the best factors under surgeon’s control within the operating room. Implementing a standardized preference card for performing appendectomies can reduce cost without compromising patient outcomes.

abstract_title: Retrospective Review of Gastroschisis Epidemiology in Northern Ghana
author_block: C. Cotache-Condor<sup>1</sup>, A. Abdul-Mumin<sup>2,3</sup>, S. A. Owusu<sup>2,3</sup>, S. Tabiri<sup>4,5</sup>, E. R. Smith<sup>1,6</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor University,Department Of Public Health,Waco, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University for Development Studies,Department Of Pediatrics And Child Health,Tamale, NORTHERN REGION, Ghana <sup>3</sup>Tamale Teaching Hospital,Department Of Pediatrics And Child Health,Tamale, NORTHERN REGION, Ghana <sup>4</sup>University for Development Studies,Department Of Surgery,Tamale, NORTHERN REGION, Ghana <sup>5</sup>Tamale Teaching Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Tamale, NORTHERN REGION, Ghana <sup>6</sup>Duke University,Duke Global Health Institute,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Annually, an estimated 16,000 newborns are diagnosed with gastroschisis across Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), with mortality rates over 90%, compared to less than 4% in high-income countries (HICs). This study aims to describe the frequency, distribution, outcomes, and referral patterns of gastroschisis patients in Northern Ghana.

Methods:  This hospital-based retrospective study included data on all neonatal surgical conditions admitted at Tamale Teaching Hospital (TTH) Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) between 2014 and 2019. Descriptive statistics were performed in SAS and Excel. Flow maps of referral patterns and time travel calculations were performed with ArcGIS. Travel patterns were analyzed in two timepoints. First timepoint, from the patient’s home to a local hospital. Second timepoint, from the local hospital to TTH.

Results: From a total of 360 neonates admitted at TTH NICU for surgical conditions, 3.3% (n=12) were diagnosed with gastroschisis. Around 60% of the gastroschisis patients presented with low and very low birth weight and 90% were referred from other hospitals, traveling 4 hours, on average. In the first timepoint, all patients were admitted to a hospital within their region. In the second timepoint, about 50% of gastroschisis patients were referred from hospitals in the Upper East region (UER),  40% from hospitals in the Northern region (NR), and 10% from hospitals in the North East region (NER). Overall, only 35% of expected cases were reported. Discharge rates were very low for the patients from NER and UER, while the NR reported a 100% mortality rate. Around 90% of gastroschisis patients died during their first week of life.

Conclusion: There is a huge need for improving access to surgical care and reducing neonatal mortality related to gastroschisis in Northern Ghana. This study provides a baseline towards optimizing care for neonates with gastroschisis in Northern Ghana. Priority areas to improve gastroschisis outcomes may include special focus on management of small newborns, better communication channels between referring hospitals and TTH, increase access to available, affordable and safe transport for gastroschisis patients, and empowerment of community health workers to promote timely seeking of surgical care.

abstract_title: Repeat Delayed Contrast Enema for Treatment of Pediatric Intussusception
author_block: S. Radu<sup>1</sup>, S. Lin<sup>2</sup>, L. D. Le<sup>3</sup>, E. Fialkowski<sup>4</sup>, A. Zigman<sup>4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Oregon Health and Sciences University,School Of Medicine,Portland, OR, USA <sup>2</sup>Oregon Health and Sciences University,Department Of Surgery,Portland, OR, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital - The Woodlands,Micheal E. Debakey Department Of Surgery, Baylor College Of Medicine,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Oregon Health And Science University,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Portland, OR, USA <sup>5</sup>Northwest Permanente,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Portland, OR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ileocolic intussusception is a common cause of pediatric bowel obstruction, and without treatment can result in bowel necrosis and death. Contrast enema is successful in treating 75% of patients, and if initially unsuccessful, 34% may be reduced with repeat enemas. This has been reported to decrease need for bowel resection and reduce hospital length of stay and costs. We implemented and studied a delayed enema for intussusception protocol. Our aims were to assess repeat enema success rates and any difference pre- and post-protocol with respect to 1) intussusception recurrence, 2) surgical intervention and complication rates, and 3) length of stay. 

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of treatment and clinical outcomes prior to and following protocol implementation for repeat enema for intussusception at two tertiary pediatric referral hospitals.  The pre-protocol period was defined from 2/2013-2/2016, and the post-protocol period from 8/2016-11/2019. 

Results: There were 112 patients in the pre-protocol group, with 75 (67%) having successful reduction following the first enema. Of the 37 patients without successful reduction, 15 (41%) patients underwent repeat enema. Of these 15 repeat enema attempts, 4 were successful (27%). The post-protocol group included 107 patients, with 83 (78%) having a successful first reduction. Of the 24 patients that failed, 12 patients (50%) underwent repeat enema, of which 4 (33%) were successful. Compared to pre-protocol patients, post-protocol patients had less surgical interventions and a trend toward more repeat enemas for failed initial attempts. Pre-protocol, 16 patients had recurrent intussusception, with 31% (n=5) having recurrence during the index admission, and 69% (n=11) having recurrence after discharge (within 19 hours to 3 years). Post-protocol, 0 patients had recurrence during the index admission, and 8 patients recurred after discharge (within 2 days to 12 months). Despite less operative interventions, post-protocol patients had higher surgical complications including anastomotic leak, abdominal compartment syndrome and small bowel obstruction, however this increase was not statistically significant. The most frequent operation in both groups was laparoscopic manual reduction, followed by open resection. Average, but not median, length of stay was longer in the post-protocol group, primarily due to patients with bowel necrosis.   

Conclusion: Protocol implementation of repeat delayed enemas reduced need for operative intervention, with decreased intussusception recurrence during the index stay and increased initial enema success. We also observed increased complication rates, primarily in patients that underwent open resection.

abstract_title: Gastric Antral Web- Important diagnosis in the differenital for vomitting and failure to thrive.
author_block: A. A. Syed<sup>1</sup>, A. Bowder<sup>1</sup>, K. H. Wilkinson<sup>1</sup>, K. Somers<sup>1</sup>, A. Martinez<sup>1</sup>, S. Siddiqui<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Pediatric Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gastric antral web (GAW) is a mucosal redundancy that can cause a partial gastric outlet obstruction.  GAW represents an important reversible surgical cause of vomiting and failure to thrive (FTT) in children.

Methods: An IRB-approved single-institution retrospective review of patients with an endoscopic diagnosis of GAW who underwent antral web resection and pyloroplasty (AWRP) from January 2013 – December 2019 was performed. Primary outcomes extracted were Z-scores and vomiting frequency. Patients were classified as Responders (R- gained weight, vomiting resolved), Partial Responders (PR- gained weight, occasional spit ups) and Non-Responders (NR- no weight gain, continued vomiting).

Results: Forty-four patients (24 male) with median age of 100.4 months (range 1.8-220; 34 patients <60 months) were identified as having undergone AWRP during the study period. Complete data extraction was attained for 40 patients.  Twenty-one patients presented with FTT (Z-score <1.65), with an average presenting Z-score for cohort  of -1.75 (range -5.55 to 1.41) .  More than two-thirds of patients gained weight 3 months after surgical intervention (67.5%, n=27).  Complete symptom resolution (R) occurred in 42.5% of patients (n=17); 25.0% (n=10) showed weight gain with occasional vomiting reported; 32.5% (n=13) did not gain any significant weight and continued to exhibit emesis postoperatively.   The majority of surgeries (n=32) was conducted by two surgeons who represent our experts in this area, the R+PR =75.0% (n=24) for their collective patients.   On subjective report from primary caregivers, quality of life at the time of surgical follow-up improved in 34 patients’ families (85.0%).

Conclusion: GAW is an important diagnosis to consider in a child with persistent vomiting and failure to thrive. Outcomes appear dependent on surgeon experience and patient selection. More data is needed to understand which clinical and anatomic features of the disease are amenable to surgical treatment.

abstract_title: High Resource Utilization in Emergent vs. Elective General Surgery
author_block: D. L. Davenport<sup>1</sup>, C. F. Campbell<sup>2</sup>, E. Taylor<sup>3</sup>, A. C. Bernard<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Kentucky,Surgery,Lexington, KY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Kentucky,Graduate Medical Education,Lexington, KY, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Kentucky,College Of Medicine,Lexington, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: ~~We sought to better understand factors driving high resource utilization (HRU) in emergent general surgery (EGS) compared to same-day elective general surgery (SDGS) patients.

Methods: ~~General surgery (GS) procedures from the 2016 ACS NSQIP public use file (600+ hospitals) were grouped according to the first four digits of the primary procedure CPT® code. Groups having at least 100 of both SDGS and EGS cases were included (22 groups; 83,872 cases). HRU patients were defined as those who were in-hospital > 7 days, returned to the OR, were readmitted within 30-days, and/or had major morbidity likely to require an ICU stay. Independent patient and operative NSQIP predictors of HRU were identified through forward regression, p for entry < .05, for exit > .10.

Results:~~Of GS patients, 33% were HRU (27262/83872). The three highest HRU procedures (enterolysis, total colectomy, and enterectomy) comprised a higher proportion of EGS than SDGS cases (20 versus [v] 5%, p < .001). Secondary procedures with total work RVUs > 10 were more common in EGS (35 v 26%). The duration of operation was lower in EGS by 40 minutes on average after adjustment for procedure group and total primary and secondary procedure work RVUs. All of the remaining 37 independent patient and clinical HRU predictors were higher in EGS cases. These included preoperative SIRS/Sepsis (50 v 2%), ASA classification IV-V (31 v 5%), serum albumin < 3.5 g/dL (40 v 12%), creatinine > 1.2 mg/dL (28 v 12%), hematocrit < 38% (48 v 35%), and transfer from other facility (26 vs 2%) - all p’s < .001. Age > 70 years (35 v 25%) and disseminated cancer (6.3 v 4.8%) were more frequent in EGS cases (p’s < .001). After adjustment for 41 NSQIP patient, clinical and operative HRU risk factors, EGS patients remained more likely to be HRU except for readmissions (Table). EGS hospital death was roughly double that of SDGS after adjustment.

Conclusion:~~EGS patients experience higher death rates and utilize significantly more resources than SDGS patients above what can be adjusted for in the clinically robust NSQIP dataset. Distinctive payment and mortality quality assessment models are necessary for EGS.

abstract_title: Impact of Diabetes Mellitus on Patients with Solid Organ Injury
author_block: M. Alsuhaibani<sup>1</sup>, A. Alhumaid<sup>3</sup>, Z. Alshaer<sup>4</sup>, A. Alharbi<sup>5</sup>, I. Albabtin<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Prince Sultan Military Medical City,General Surgery,Riyadh, RIYADH, Saudi Arabia <sup>2</sup>King Abdulaziz Medical City,General Surgery,Riyadh, RIYADH, Saudi Arabia <sup>3</sup>King Faisal Specialist Hospital and Research Center,General Surgery,Riyadh, RIYADH, Saudi Arabia <sup>4</sup>King Fahad Medical City,Plastic Surgery,Riyadh, RIYADH, Saudi Arabia <sup>5</sup>King Abdulaziz Medical City,Anatomical Pathology,Riyadh, RIYADH, Saudi Arabia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma diabetic victims may behave differently in response to trauma and their course of treatment also tends to be more aggressive. The aim of this study is to investigate the impact of diabetes mellitus (DM) on morbidity and mortality in patients with post-traumatic solid organ injury.

Methods: Retrospective analysis of National Trauma Database Bank during the year of 2015. All adult patients who had solid organ injury; liver, spleen, or kidney injuries were included.

Results: The total number of patients experienced solid organ injury was 39,784. Male patients were predominant. Most of the patients aged between 21 and 30 years old. There were more males than females. DM was a pre-existing comorbidity in 6.9% of the total study population. The mean age of diabetic patients was 58 years, while in non-diabetic patients the mean was 38 years.  Diabetic patients showed significantly higher rate of post-trauma complication including acute kidney injury, pneumonia, sepsis, myocardial infarction, stroke, decubitus ulcer, and urinary tract infections. However, there was no statistically significant difference found in the development of pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, or surgical site infections. Intensive care unit stay and ventilation duration were longer in diabetic patients. The total mortality rate after solid organ injury was 8.1% for diabetic patients and 7.2% for non-diabetic patients (p = 0.008).

Conclusions: DM is associated with an increase rate of post-traumatic complication in patient who had solid organ injury. In addition, it leads to prolong and complex hospital course and raise the mortality rate.

abstract_title: Trauma Outcomes in the Super Morbidly Obese
author_block: A. M. Hudnall<sup>2</sup>, C. Mullins<sup>3</sup>, A. Palmer<sup>1</sup>, L. Dudas<sup>1</sup>, C. DeLa'O<sup>1</sup>, D. Grabo<sup>1</sup>, G. Schaefer<sup>1</sup>, J. Knight-Davis<sup>1</sup>, A. Wilson<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Bardes<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>West Virginia University,Division Of Trauma And Critical Care,Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>West Virginia University,Department Of General Surgery,Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>3</sup>West Virginia University School of Medicine,Morgantown, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Obesity is a growing public health concern in the US, with 40% of Americans classified as obese. The effect of obesity has been studied in trauma, but the outcomes of patient stratified as super-morbidly obese have not been documented. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of trauma patients with increasing body mass index (BMI).

Methods:  A retrospective analysis was performed at an ACS verified, level 1 trauma center. Data from all trauma activations over a 5-year period was collected and analyzed. Patients that did not have BMI data available, or were underweight (BMI<18.5) were excluded. Hospital and intensive care unit (ICU) outcomes, discharge disposition, and complications were collected and compared between strata of increasing BMI. ANOVA and Chi Square tests were utilized to determine statistical significance between groups, p<0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Enrollment included 16,459 patients, 61% male, median age 53. The majority sustained blunt injury (93%), mean ISS 9. Median BMI 27.6 (range 18.5-94.9), 6,059 (37%) were considered obese, and 241 had a BMI > 50. With increasing BMI came an increased hospital and ICU length of stay (p<0.0001), as well as need for mechanical ventilation and increased length of ventilation (p<0.0001). (Table 1) Increasing BMI was associated with increased chance of discharge to rehab or skilled nursing facility (p<0.001). The presence of any complication was also more prevalent with increasing BMI (p<0.0001), and those requiring CPR (p=0.02). Patients with BMI > 50 were twice as likely to have any complication (p<0.0001) compared to BMI < 49.9. There was a non-significant trend toward an increase in missed injury (p=0.07) with increased BMI.

Conclusion: Increasing BMI leads to longer hospital and ICU stays, more complications and a decrease in discharges to home. This holds particular relevance to our current healthcare system as the average BMI continues to rise along with healthcare spending.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Patients Transferred with Sepsis in the Surgical ICU
author_block: M. A. Ireland<sup>1,2</sup>, K. A. Gonzalez-Gallo<sup>3</sup>, M. E. Villarreal<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Wisler<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,Department Of Trauma, Critical Care And Burn,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Toledo Medical Center,College Of Medicine And Life Sciences,Toledo, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio State University,College Of Medicine,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sepsis in patients admitted to the surgical ICU is a complex disease with a high mortality.  Existing data suggests larger volume hospitals and academic medical centers may have improved outcomes in patients with sepsis and septic shock.  Critically ill patients with sepsis arrive to these hospitals directly or through interhospital transfers. We hypothesized that patients transferred to these large volume hospitals from other hospitals will have worse outcomes.

Methods: This retrospective cohort study examined patients admitted to The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center between January 2014 and July 2019 who were diagnosed with sepsis within 48 hours of admission to the surgical ICU. Patients were divided into two cohorts based on mode of admission: transfers from outside hospitals and non-transfers. Demographics and past medical history was obtained at admission to Wexner Medical Center. The primary outcome assessed was 90 day mortality from surgical ICU admission. Secondary outcomes included length of hospital stay (LOS), length of surgical ICU stay, days on the ventilator and discharge destination. Results were analyzed using a paired t-test of unequal variances. Significance was defined as α = 0.05.

Results: Based on our criteria, 1649 patients qualified for our retrospective analysis. 766 patients were identified as patients transferred from an outside hospital and 883 patients were non-transfers. Patients admitted directly to the medical center were more likely to have underlying medical comorbidities, including localized cancers and CKD (Charlson Comorbidity Index 1.49 vs 1.61, p=0.04).  Patients transferred in to the hospital had a higher mortality compared to those directly admitted (33.2% vs 21.2%, p<0.001).  Hospital LOS was slightly longer in the group directly admitted (25.3 vs 21.3 days, p<0.001). Dependent discharge was also more common in the non-transfer cohort (52% vs 47%, p=0.03).  There were no differences in surgical ICU LOS or ventilator days.

Conclusion: Overall, there is a significant increase in mortality in patients with sepsis admitted to surgical ICU that were transferred to Wexner Medical Center compared to those directly admitted. This finding is likely due to a combination of both patient and hospital level characteristics, which require further elucidation. This could be a result of increased complexity in these patients that requires transfer to a larger medical center, further suggesting that earlier treatment of these critically ill patients at high volume centers may improve outcomes. A delay in care that is inherent when a patient is transferred from one location to another, so future projects will evaluate distance traveled during transfer.

abstract_title: ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME FOLLOWING MILD TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY. A TRAUMA CENTER STUDY.
author_block: E. Yeung<sup>1</sup>, C. Wung<sup>1</sup>, R. Behm<sup>1</sup>, B. Cagir<sup>1</sup>, P. Granet<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Guthrie / Robert Packer Hospital,Surgery,SAYRE, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) after mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) can be associated with significant morbidity and mortality. This study is to evaluate the potential risk factors for and the impact on outcomes of mild TBI patients who developed ARDS.

Methods: A retrospective chart reviews were done for adult trauma patients with mild TBI (GCS 13-15) requiring admission at our center from 2012 to 2020. Patient demographic and clinical characteristics were compared between who did and did not develop ARDS (Berlin Criteria) during their index hospitalization. Multivariate logistic regression and Fishers exact test were utilized to identify independent predictors of the association with ARDS in adult mild TBI. 

Results: A total of 784 mild TBI patients were admitted during the time of interest; 34 patients developed ARDS during their index hospitalization. Patients who had ARDS were more likely to have AKI (35.2% vs 8.9%, p < 0.0001), sepsis (8.8% vs 0.7%, p = 0.003), rib fractures (26.5% vs 13.0%, OR = 2.4, p =0.03), use of anticoagulants (79.4% vs 43.0%, p < 0.001), deep vein thrombosis (11.8% vs 0.67%, p = 0.0003), transfusion during the first 4 hours upon admission (32.4% vs 14.1%, p = 0.01), IVF resuscitation during the first 4 hours  (58.8% vs 40.3%, OR=2.1, p <0.05), the first 8 hours (70.6% vs 49%, p = 0.01),the first 12 hours (70.6% vs 51.6%, p = 0.03) and  intubation upon the admission (38.4% vs 0.8%, p <0.0001). ARDS associated with mild TBI demonstrated a statistically significant increase in mortality during the index hospitalization (32.4% vs 2.13%, p < 0.0001).

Conclusion: ARDS after mild TBI can be associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Key risk factors identified include AKI, sepsis, anticoagulant use, DVT, transfusion in first 4 hours, IVF resuscitation in first 4, 8 and 12 hours and intubation upon the admission.

abstract_title: The Presence of an Established Primary Care Provider Prior to Injury and Outcomes After Trauma
author_block: C. J. McLaughlin<sup>1</sup>, J. Hess<sup>3</sup>, S. Armen<sup>2</sup>, S. R. Allen<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma, Acute Care, And Critical Care Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn State Children's Hospital,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The incidence of medical co-morbidities (such as hypertension, diabetes and obesity) is increasing in the general US population.  Those with pre-existing co-morbidities present treatment challenges to trauma surgeons after injury, often due to unrecognized or poor control of these conditions. It is unknown how many trauma patients have a primary care provider (PCP) prior to injury and how the pre-injury PCP relationship may affect outcomes after injury. We hypothesized that patients with an established PCP would have decreased hospital length of stay (LOS), fewer ICU days, and decreased in-hospital mortality when compared to a matched population who lack a pre-injury PCP.

Methods: From 2013 to 2019, the trauma registry of a rural Level 1 trauma center was queried for all patients greater than 18 years old (y/o). The presence of a PCP was extracted from each patient’s medical record. A case-control analysis based on age, gender, injury severity score (ISS), and mechanism was performed to create a cohort of patients with PCP’s and one without PCP’s. Differences in hospital LOS, ICU LOS, time on ventilator, and in-hospital mortality were studied. Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS and significance was defined as p <0.05.

Results: Out of 19,096 patients in the trauma registry, 34.7% had a PCP recorded. From this population, 2,162 patients with PCP’s had exact matches to trauma patients without PCP’s (n=2,162).Mean age was 54.2 + 21.2 years. 65.2% were male. Mechanism of injury was 96% blunt, 3.7% penetrating, and 0.3% burns. Average ISS was 10.9 +/- 7.6. Mean hospital LOS was longer in trauma patients with PCP’s than those without (5.8 +/- 5.7 vs. 4.9 +/- 6.3 days, p <0.01). There was no difference in ICU LOS between the two cohorts (3.0 +/- 3.8 days vs. 3.5 +/- 5.4 days, p = 0.86). Patients with PCP’s required significantly less ventilator days than trauma patients without PCP’s (1.1 +/- 4.2 vs. 1.7 +/- 4.9 days, p <0.01). In-hospital mortality was lower in the group with a PCP (1.6% vs. 3.6%, p <0.01).

Conclusion: Only 1/3 of trauma patients were noted to have a PCP prior to their injury. Pre-injury primary care was associated with increased length of stay, but fewer ventilator days and decreased mortality. Patients who suffer from known medical co-morbidities may be more likely to have a PCP prior to injury. However, those medical co-morbidities may contribute to longer LOS. Similarly, unknown medical co-morbidities in trauma patients without a PCP may go unrecognized until after their injury. Further prospective study of this relationship is indicated and may allow for improved strategies to promote primary care in populations prone to injury.

abstract_title: Hardware Infection from Surgical Stabilization of Rib Fractures is Lower than Previously Reported
author_block: M. V. Kashyap<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Kaye<sup>2</sup>, E. Catrell<sup>1</sup>, S. Cemaj<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Evans<sup>1</sup>, Z. M. Bauman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Omaha, NE, USA <sup>2</sup>Overland Park Regional Medical Center,Trauma And Acute Care SurgerySurgery,Overland Park, KANSAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical stabilization of rib fractures (SSRF) is an emerging therapy for the treatment of patients with traumatic rib fractures.  Despite the demonstrated benefits of SSRF, there remains a paucity of literature regarding the complications from SSRF, especially those related to hardware infection.  Currently, literature quotes hardware infection rates as high as 4%.  We hypothesize that the hardware infection rate is much lower than currently published.

Methods: This is an IRB approved, four-year multicenter descriptive review of prospectively collected data from January 2016 - January 2020.  All patients undergoing SSRF were included in the study.  Exclusion criteria included those patients < 18 years of age.  Basic demographics were obtained: age, gender, Injury Severity Score (ISS), Abbreviate Injury Scale-chest (AIS-chest), flail chest (yes/no), delayed SSRF > 2 weeks (yes/no) and number of ribs fixated.  Primary outcome was hardware infection.  Secondary outcomes included mortality rate and hospital length of stay (HLOS).  Basic descriptive statistics were utilized for analysis.

Results:A total of 238 patients met criteria for inclusion in the study.  Mean age was 58 ± 15.2 years and 70% were male.  Mean ISS was 17.3 ± 8.5 with a mean AIS-chest of 3.2 ± 0.5.  Flail chest (two consecutive ribs with two or more fractures on each rib) accounted for 32% of patients.  26 patients (10.9%) underwent delayed SSRF.  The average number of ribs stabilized was 4 ± 2.8.  When analyzing the primary outcome, only 1 patient (0.4%) developed a hardware infection requiring reoperation to remove the plates.  This patient was a delayed SSRF.  Zero patients in the acute setting developed a hardware infection.  Overall HLOS was 10.5 ± 6.8 days.  Three patients suffered a mortality (1.3%), all three with ISS scores higher than 15 suggesting significant polytrauma.

Conclusion:This is the largest case series to date examining SSRF hardware infection.  The incidence of SSRF hardware infection is very low (< 0.5%), much less than quoted in current literature.  Furthermore, in this study, no patient developed hardware infection when the SSRF was completed within two weeks of injury.  This is likely due to advances in the surgical technique through muscle-sparing incisions and minimally invasive SSRF. Overall, SSRF is a safe procedure with low morbidity and mortality.

abstract_title: A 5 Year Review of the Incidence and Costs of Automobile vs Pedestrian Accidents
author_block: J. Stover<sup>2</sup>, J. Gruner<sup>1</sup>, S. Ramirez<sup>3</sup>, L. Matherne<sup>4</sup>, D. Tatum<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Our Lady of the Lake Regional Medical Center,Trauma Specialist Program,Baton Rouge, LOUISIANA, USA <sup>2</sup>Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center,School Of Medicine,New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>3</sup>Dartmouth Medical School,Geisel School Of Medicine,Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>4</sup>Rhodes College,Memphis, TENNESSEE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pedestrian deaths and injuries are a very costly, but largely preventable, public health problem. Pedestrian injury costs more than $20 billion annually in the Unites States. Among states, Louisiana ranks as one of the worst for pedestrian safety, and the Baton Rouge region was recently ranked nationally as the 19th worst metropolitan area for overall pedestrian safety. The aim of the present study was to describe the patient population that presented to our trauma center in order to better understand who is at risk of poor outcome and which areas of the region are the most unsafe.

Methods:  Adult (18+) patients who presented to the emergency department (ED) from January 2014 - December 2018 were identified in the trauma registry using International Classification of Disease – Ninth Revision (ICD-9) mechanism of injury code 814.7 and ICD-10 codes V03.10XA and V04.10XA, which indicate automobile vs pedestrian. Accident locations were mapped to the nearest intersection using Tableau 2019.2.9. Poor outcome was defined as Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) < 4, which indicates severe disability, persistent vegetative state, or death.

Results: A total of 317 patients were included. The cohort was primarily male (70.3%), of median [interquartile range (IQR)] age 41 (27 – 55), and with median (IQR) Injury Severity Score (ISS) 10 (5 – 17). Median (IQR) length of stay was 7 days (3 – 13) and ICU stay 5 days (2 – 10). Most (59.6%) incidents occurred when the sun was down, most common injury was long bone fracture (54.6%) followed by polytrauma (> 1 injury) (41.3%). Median hospital cost per incident was $17,897 ($7,235 – $41,049). For the 42.3% with an ICU stay, median cost was $33,374 ($12,959 - $63,544). Medicaid/Medicare was the primary payer (51.1%), and 20.2% of patients were uninsured. Forty-one percent (n = 130) patients had GOS <4.  Increased age and uninsured status were significantly associated with poor outcome (P = 0.001 and P < 0.015, respectively).

Conclusion: Auto versus pedestrian injuries are an expensive, but preventable, public health problem. Those who are older and/or uninsured are at highest risk for poor outcome.
