Discrete areas of the Baton Rouge metropolitan area have higher incidence and should be examined from a safety infrastructure perspective in order to reduce morbidity and mortality of pedestrians as well as burden of cost to taxpayers.

abstract_title: A Survey of High-Risk Trauma Patients Regarding Bleeding Control and the Stop The Bleed Course
author_block: B. Van Winkle<sup>2</sup>, S. DiBrito<sup>1</sup>, N. Amini<sup>2,5</sup>, M. Levy<sup>3</sup>, E. Haut<sup>1,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Division Of Acute Care Surgery, Deprtment Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Sinai Hospital of Baltimore,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Emergency Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Anesthesiology And Critical Care Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>5</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgical Oncology,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Stop the Bleed (STB) was developed to educate the lay public about control hemorrhage techniques in hopes of reducing preventable trauma deaths. Studies have shown this training increases bystanders’ confidence and willingness to provide aid. However, one high-risk group might be better solicited to take the course: individuals who have been a victim of previous trauma. High rates of recidivism after trauma are well-established, with up to 44% of trauma patients having a history of a previous injury requiring hospitalization. Given this group’s risk for recurrent injury, we evaluated their attitudes towards STB concepts.

Methods: We surveyed trauma patients admitted to three urban trauma centers in Baltimore from 01/08/2020-03/14-2020. The survey was terminated prematurely due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Patients currently being treated on any inpatient trauma unit were offered to complete the survey via an electronic tablet. The survey contained 12 primary questions, with additional questions depending on the participants' responses. The survey asked about demographics, exposure to life-threatening hemorrhage and first aid training.

Results: 56 patients completed the survey. The majority of respondents had been hospitalized before (93%) and had seen severe bleeding (61%). A majority had never taken a first aid course (61%) nor had they ever heard of STB (84%). Most respondents indicated they would be willing to help someone with severe bleeding form a car crash (95%) or gunshot wound (93%). 

Conclusion: Many current trauma inpatients at urban trauma centers may not have heard about the Stop the Bleed course. Focusing STB education on patients at high-risk for trauma recidivism (potentially while an inpatient) may be beneficial to prevent deaths from hemorrhage in trauma recidivists.

abstract_title: Fall Prevention in the Primary Care Setting: A Survey Study
author_block: R. Barq<sup>1</sup>, C. Hung<sup>1</sup>, C. Prather<sup>1</sup>, M. Lypson<sup>1</sup>, S. Kartiko<sup>1</sup>, S. Kartiko<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>George Washington University School Of Medicine And Health Sciences,Center Of Trauma And Critical Care,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Falls are the leading cause of traumatic injury in older adults. While the risk and severity of falls increase with age, appropriate counseling and physical interventions have been proven to mitigate fall risk. Primary care providers can therefore play a major role in reducing the incidence of falls among their elderly patients. However, primary care providers may be limited by a number of factors including time, resources, and knowledge of risk reduction strategies. This study aims to determine the extent of elderly fall risk screening and counseling that occurs in the primary care setting, and to define limitations to its usage.

Methods:  A questionnaire was adapted from a previous survey study to explore the beliefs, knowledge, attitudes, and clinical practice regarding falls in primary care providers. Information about participant training background and patient population was also acquired. The questionnaire was distributed by email to 36 primary care providers at a level 1 tertiary urban medical center.

Results: The survey achieved a response rate of 58%. Adults over 65 make up most of the respondents’ patient population (57%; 25%-86%). All of the respondents agreed that patients over 65 years should be  assessed for fall risks. All respondents also agreed that evidence-based fall prevention programs can reduce the risk of falls in older adults who are at high risk; however, 43% of participants did not agree that they had the expertise to perform fall risk assessments. Furthermore, while 52% of respondents were aware of the Medicare reimbursement for fall risk screening, only 24% of respondents have billed for fall risk screening and only 5% of respondents agreed that they were adequately reimbursed for performing fall risk assessments. Lastly, only 57% of respondents agreed with the statement that they had time to perform fall risk assessments in their office.

Conclusion: The results of this survey exhibit that primary care providers are aware that evidence-based fall prevention programs can reduce fall risk and that all older adults should be assessed for fall risk. However, several barriers to performing these risk assessments in primary care clinics were uncovered. These barriers included provider’s perception of their lack of expertise to perform fall risk assessments, lack of time, and lack of reimbursement. Notably, a large proportion of survey respondents were not aware that they could be reimbursed for performing fall risk assessments.

abstract_title: Self Injurious Behavior in an Incarcerated Population: Clinical Outcomes and Risk-factors
author_block: G. I. Allen<sup>1</sup>, A. Zakaud-Dakaud<sup>1</sup>, A. Lawson<sup>1</sup>, E. Fox<sup>1</sup>, P. Drevets<sup>1</sup>, C. White<sup>1</sup>, S. B. Holsten<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Georgia,Department Of Surgery,Augusta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Self harm in incarcerated individuals represents a challenging social and surgical phenomenon.These individuals frequently have multiple readmissions with significant morbidity associated with the behavior.In this study we attempt to better characterize the forms, risk-factors, and select complications of self-harm in an prisoners admitted to a Level I Trauma Center.

Methods: We identified patients who were admitted to a level I trauma center’s Trauma/ACS service at least once from January 2017 to April 2020 for possible self-injury.Our institution admitted these patients from a state medical prison.Once included in the study,data was obtained with their entire clinical courses, relevant medical and surgical histories,outcomes,and the initiating risk-factors such as prior self-harm or psychiatric co-morbidities.

Results:We reviewed the records 25 of patients who were able to be identified as having been admitted to Trauma/ACS service or on which they were consulted for possible self-harm.24 patients were found to meet our pre-specified inclusion criteria.  These 24 patients resulted in a total of 258 emergency department encounters with 72% of visits directly related to self-harm (n=187.) All records reviewed were male prisoners.The average total number of self-harm admissions for each patient was 7.8 (95% CI, 4.5 - 11.1) with a range from 1 to 31 total admissions.The most common mechanisms of injury included foreign object ingestions (n=77) and self-stabbing (n=69.)In 73% (n=136) of encounters, procedural intervention was required. Exploratory laparotomy was required in 42% (n=10) of patients with a mean of 1.5 laparotomies per patient (95% CI, 0.5 to 2.6) and a range from 0 to 9 total.5 (20.8%)patients developed enterocutaneous fistulas during the course of the study, 100% of these patients had a history of exploratory laparotomy reflecting half of all patients with exploratory laparotomies and none without such a history.With respect to risk factors 21 (87.5%) patients had an established psychiatric history, while 9 (37.5%) had an established substance abuse history.Of patients with an established psychiatric history they had an average 8.6 encounters. Whereas those without an established psychiatric history had an average of 2 encounters (p=0.006).Additionally, those with prior self harm encounters had an average of 9.15 encounters.Those without a prior history of self harm who had an average of 1 encounter (p= 0.0004).

Conclusion:Our case series shows marked recidivism in prisoners that practice self-harm.Prior self-harm and mental illness are risk factors for self-harm.Frequently these will escalate requiring major abdominal surgery.Furthermore, with self harm recidivism, those patients that require exploratory laparotomies developed fistulas 50% of the time.Further research is required to better characterize if early intervention in mental health or substance abuse in this population can reduce the self-harming behavior.

abstract_title: The Effect of Occult Shock On Mortality In Elderly Patients With Traumatic Brain Injury
author_block: J. Sirody<sup>1</sup>, A. Moazzez<sup>1</sup>, S. Read<sup>1</sup>, J. Michel-Ruddy<sup>1</sup>, D. Kim<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harbor-UCLA,Depeartment Of Surgery,Torrance, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is common in the elderly and associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Current guidelines recommend a systolic blood pressure (SBP) of ≥110mmHg to prevent secondary brain injury. Prior research has shown that occult shock (OS), defined as an elevated lactate with normotension, is associated with adverse outcomes. We hypothesized that OS would be associated with increased mortality in elderly patients with TBI.

Methods:  This is a one-year prospective observational quality improvement study of elderly trauma patients (≥65 years) with isolated head trauma who had routine lactate testing upon arrival in the ER. We excluded patients with penetrating injuries or AIS score ≥3 in more than two body areas other than the head. Patients with OS (SBP ≥110 and lactate >2.2) were compared to those with normal perfusion (SBP ≥110 and lactate ≤2.2). The effect of OS was analyzed using bivariate analysis. Our primary outcome was mortality. Secondary endpoints were length of stay (LOS), ICU LOS, and discharge GCS.

Results: 106 patients met inclusion criteria. The mean age was 80 years old, 55% were male, and the median head AIS score was 4. The most common mechanism was a fall (76%) followed by auto vs. pedestrian (17%). There were no differences in mechanism or comorbidities between groups. Overall mortality was 15%. Comparing those with OS to those without (Table 1) there was no difference in discharge GCS or LOS. Patients with OS received significantly more crystalloids in the ER than those without.

Conclusion: In elderly patients with isolated blunt TBI, we found no differences in mortality, LOS, or discharge GCS between patients with an elevated admission lactate vs. those without. While avoiding hypotension in elderly TBI patients remains vital to avoid secondary injury, the routine use of admission lactate is not supported by the results of this study.

abstract_title: DYNAMIC CUSHIONING: A COMPLEX RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN OBESITY & TRAUMA PATIENTS UNDERGOING LAPAROTOMY
author_block: N. Tully<sup>1</sup>, M. Terry<sup>1</sup>, A. Tucker<sup>2</sup>, S. Dhanasekara<sup>1</sup>, C. Ronaghan<sup>1</sup>, R. Richmond<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center,Surgery,Lubbock, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>University Medical Center,Trauma Services,Lubbock, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Obesity is generally associated with worse outcomes in trauma patients. However, there is conflicting evidence regarding the effect that increasing BMI has over the short and especially long term on these patients. We hypothesized that increasing BMI has an initial protective effect, but ultimately ends in worse outcomes. Therefore, we sought to elucidate the effect BMI has on outcomes in trauma patients undergoing exploratory laparotomy.

Methods: A Level 1 trauma center registry was queried to include all trauma patients that underwent exploratory laparotomies between June 2015—April 2020. Demographic factors along with clinical details and outcomes were examined. Baseline characteristics of 3 patient groups defined by BMI categories (i.e., normal-weight, overweight, and obese) and complications were compared. Simple linear and logistic regression analyses were performed to examine the associations between BMI and each complication.

Results:Records of 206 trauma patients who underwent exploratory laparotomies were analyzed. There was no significant difference in demographics or injury severity score (ISS) between groups (Table 1). When each complication was regressed on BMI, significant positive effects were seen for ICU stay, hospital length of stay (LOS) and return to OR. More granularly, a per-unit increase in BMI conferred a log-odds increase of 0.056 in return to OR. These results indicated that BMI had a direct positive association with ICU LOS, hospital LOS and return to OR.

Conclusion: Our findings show that with increasing BMI, postoperative complications increase following laparotomy for trauma. As rates of obesity increase, trauma surgeons must be prepared to anticipate plans of care from patient presentation to well beyond discharge to cope with more complex postoperative and post-hospital clinical courses.

abstract_title: Burns in East Africa: a Scoping Literature Review.
author_block: F. Mukagaju<sup>1</sup>, L. Velin<sup>2,3</sup>, E. Miranda<sup>2,4</sup>, I. Shyaka<sup>1</sup>, Y. Nezerwa<sup>1</sup>, F. Ntirenganya<sup>5</sup>, C. Furaha<sup>1</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>6</sup>, L. Pompermaier<sup>7</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rwanda Military Hospital,Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Kigali, KIGALI CITY, Rwanda <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Lund University,Surgery And Public Health, Department Of Clinical Sciences Lund, Faculty Of Medicine,Lund, LUND, Sweden <sup>4</sup>University of Southern California,Division Of Vascular Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Teaching Hospital Kigali (CHUK),Plastic Surgery Department,Kigali, KIGALI CITY, Rwanda <sup>6</sup>Brigham and Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>7</sup>Linkping University,Department Of Hand Surgery, Plastic Surgery And Burns, And Department Of Biomedical And Clinical Sciences,Linkping, LINKPING, Sweden
abstract_body:
Introduction: Burns is a global public health concern, with the majority of the disease burden affecting low- and middle-income countries. The World Health Organization estimates that burns account for 180,000 deaths annually worldwide. In settings with limited resources, non-lethal burn injuries lead to severe long-term disabilities due to lack of or delay in accessing treatment. Understanding the epidemiology of burns specifically in East Africa would help the establishment of preventive measures and advocacy for improved access to early treatment.

Methods: Studies discussing the epidemiology of burns in East Africa were identified by searching PubMed / Medline (National Library of Medicine), EMBASE (Elsevier), Global Health Database (EBSCO), and Global Index Medicus (www.globalindexmedicus.net) on December 12th, 2019. Controlled vocabulary terms (i.e. MeSH, EMTREE, Global Health thesaurus terms) were included when available and appropriate. The search strategies were designed and executed by a librarian. No language limits or year restrictions were applied. 

Results: A total of 1,044 records were retrieved from the database searches, resulting in 897 unique records for screening after duplicates were removed. 87 records were reviewed at the full-text level and 40 articles from 6 countries published between 1993 and 2019 were included in the final review. The study scope was predominantly burns in general (n=16, 40%). Extracted data were sorted into three themes: burn population demographics, burn characteristics and risk factors; and treatment and outcomes. The total number of burn patients recorded was 44369, of which the mean proportion of males was 56%. The most common cause was scalds which accounted for 61% of all burn injuries, followed by open flame (17%). Mortality rate was reported in 16 papers (41%), ranged from 0 to 66.7%.The mean length of stay in hospital ranged from 8.5 to 60 days.

Conclusion: There is limited and variable data on burn epidemiology in East Africa, especially in adult populations and rural settings, as most existing literature focuses on sub-populations, such as pediatric trauma patients or tertiary hospital settings. More research on the epidemiology of burns is needed to harmonize the data and know the exact burden of burn injuries in East Africa, particularly among adult populations and in rural settings. Scalds and flames being the most common causes suggests that the majority of burns are most of the time preventable household accidents. Future interventions should be targeted at preventing accidents in the home, particularly related to cooking.

abstract_title: Clinical Outcomes of Bariatric Surgery in Patients with Crohn's Disease
author_block: A. Hsu<sup>1,2</sup>, T. Chiang<sup>1,2</sup>, G. L. Adrales<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health,BALTIMORE, MARYLAND, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A growing number of Crohn’s disease(CD) patients are struggling with obesity, paralleling the overall increasing obesity rate in the United States. Bariatric surgery, a direct intervention for weight loss, can address obesity effectively. However, there is a relative lack of large-scale longitudinal assessment for efficacy and safety of bariatric surgery for Crohn’s patients.

Methods: This retrospective cohort study used the commercial US Truven Health MarketScan Database from 2011-2017 to identify patients with the bariatric procedure. We categorized bariatric surgery (BAR) into sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and gastric bypass (GB) and analyzed the outcomes between CD  patients and those without Crohn’s (non-CD) after each type of surgery. We assessed complication rates for dehydration, Clostridium difficile intestinal infection, GI obstruction, other digestive complications after bariatric surgery, acute kidney injury, reintervention, or reoperation. Adjusted OR was calculated from the multivariate logistic regression model to evaluate complications at 30 days and 90 days. For further analysis, 1:4 matching based on age, gender, and comorbidities was conducted to verify the primary result.

Results: A total of 87,792 patients were identified in the SG group (257 CD patients vs. 87,535 non-CD patients) and 73,117 in GB (110 CD patients vs. 73,007 non-CD patients). The mean age of CD patients was 45.61 (±10.02) vs. non-CD patients as 43.5(±10.64), p<0.05*. CD patients had a higher risk of dehydration (4.28% vs. 1.49%, p<0.00*), infectious complications (2.33% vs. 1.31%, p=0.01*), and acute kidney injury (2.72% vs. 0.84%, p<0.00*) than non-CD patients within 90-days after SG surgery in both primary and secondary analysis. Both CD and non-CD patients had higher complication rates after GB than SG. All-cause readmission rates within 30- and 90- days are higher (p<0.05*) in CD patients than non-CD patients.

Conclusion: Sleeve gastrectomy for Crohn’s disease patients showed a relatively safe profile on the overall surgical outcomes since there was not an increased risk of some serious complications such as bleeding or cardiopulmonary events. However, the all-cause readmission rate is still higher among Crohn’s disease patients. In conclusion, given the relatively safe surgical outcomes profile, bariatric surgery should still be considered for eligible Crohn’s disease patients after an informed discussion of the risks and benefits.

abstract_title: Does the MBSAQIP Bariatric Risk/Benefit Calculator Hold Its Weight? An Assessment of its Accuracy
author_block: E. Hernandez<sup>1,2</sup>, D. Athanasiadis<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Christodoulides<sup>3</sup>, L. Petrucciani<sup>3</sup>, V. C. Osuji<sup>3</sup>, D. Stefanidis<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Bariatric And Minimally Invasive Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Accurate prediction of patient outcomes after bariatric surgery is desirable for the counseling of patients seeking surgical weight loss.  In August of 2019, the American College of Surgeons and the American Society for Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery released the MBSAQIP Bariatric Surgical Risk/Benefit calculator, an online tool that can predict bariatric surgery outcomes based on preoperative patient characteristics. The aim of our study was to assess the accuracy of this Risk/Benefit calculator in predicting our patients’ outcomes following bariatric surgery.

Methods: Patients who underwent primary laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) or laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) at our institution between 2012 and 2019 were included in this study. Patient characteristics such as age, sex, BMI, race, functional status, ASA, comorbidities at baseline, 30-day reintervention and reoperation rates, weight loss (expressed as difference in BMI, ΔBMI), and comorbidity resolution for diabetes mellitus II (DM-II), hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia (HLD), and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) 1 year after surgery were retrieved from our prospectively maintained database. Preoperative patient data were entered into the Risk/Benefit calculator and predicted postoperative outcomes recorded for each individual patient. To assess the tools’ accuracy, we compared actual outcomes of these patients with calculator predicted outcomes using sample t-test.  Subgroup analysis based on operation type was also performed. A p-value of <0.05 was considered significant. Analysis was performed using SPSS statistical software, Version 26.0 (SPSS Inc., Armonk, NY).

Results: During the study period 1455 patients had undergone a primary bariatric operation, of which 789 (54%) had follow up for at least 1 year (312 – 40% LRYGB and 477 – 60% LSG). There was no difference between the predicted and actual ΔBMI for LSG after one year (p=0.19) and a small difference (ΔBMI difference= 0.97) for LRYGB (p<0.001).  Comorbidity resolution was overestimated by the calculator for HTN, DM-II, OSA, and HLD ranging from 9%-17% for LSG and 17%-26% for LRYBG (p<0.001 for all).  There was no difference in risk estimate for 30- day reoperation or reintervention for LSG but a minor underestimation for LRYGB (1.3%-1.7%, p<0.001)

Conclusion: The MBSAQIP Bariatric Surgical Risk/Benefit calculator is an accurate predictor of 1-year weight loss and 30-day reoperation and reintervention in our patient sample. Comorbidity resolution, however, appears to be overestimated by the calculator. Bariatric surgeons should incorporate this calculator in the preoperative counseling of their patients and be aware of its limitations.

abstract_title: Gastric Bypass vs. Sleeve Gastrectomy: Does procedure type impact morbidity in transplant patients?
author_block: A. M. Fagenson<sup>2</sup>, M. Mazzei<sup>2</sup>, L. Swaszek<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Edwards<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mayo Clinic,General Surgery,Jacksonville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Temple University,General Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) has been associated with increased weight loss, but more complications when compared to sleeve gastrectomy (SG). Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery is being increasingly performed in patients with a history of solid organ transplantation with favorable results. However, a direct comparison between RYGB and SG has not been performed in patients with a history of solid organ transplantation. Therefore, the aim of this study is to determine the impact of procedure type on perioperative outcomes in this patient cohort.

Methods:  Patients with a history of solid organ transplantation were identified in the 2015-2018 Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery Accreditation Quality Improvement Project Participant Use File (MBSAQIP PUF) databases. Procedure type (SG vs. RYGB) was used to stratify patients. Propensity-score matching and multivariable logistic regressions were utilized to control for inter-group bias. Thirty-day outcomes study cohorts were compared by Mann-U-Whitney and Chi-square tests.

Results: Of 678 cases identified, 80% (N=542) underwent a SG and 20% (N=136) had a RYGB. Patients differed significantly (p < 0.05) by multiple demographic variables. After propensity-score matching, 136 patients in each cohort were identified and were similar at baseline (p > 0.05). Patients undergoing RYGB had increased overall morbidity (18% vs. 11%, p = 0.087) and bariatric-related morbidity (14% vs. 7.4%, p = 0.077). In addition, unplanned readmissions (16% vs. 8.8%, p = 0.067) and readmissions related to surgery (13% vs. 6.6%, p = 0.099) were higher in RYGB patients. Multivariable logistic regression revealed RYGB to independently increase the risk of overall morbidity (1.90, p = 0.021), bariatric-related morbidity (2.19, p = 0.016), unplanned readmissions (OR 2.41, p = 0.004) and readmissions related to surgery (2.20, p = 0.021) (Table).  

Conclusion: Patients with prior solid organ transplantation undergoing RYGB have increased morbidity and readmissions when compared to SG. Surgeons performing MBS should use caution when recommending RYGB in patients with prior solid organ transplantation.

abstract_title: Diabetes Mellitus Increases Risk of Gastric Cancer in Hispanic Patients: Analysis of HCUP Database
author_block: N. Owusu-Brackett<sup>1</sup>, S. Nah<sup>1</sup>, L. Bailey<sup>1</sup>, A. Ojeda Prias<sup>1</sup>, V. Helton<sup>1</sup>, M. Kitano<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio,Surgical Oncology,San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gastric cancer (GC) portends a poor prognosis and is more common in Hispanics in the US. Literature has shown racial disparities in presentation, socioeconomic status (SES), prognosis, and care; however, limited information is available on patient factors. In this study, we analyzed the Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project database (HCUP) to evaluate patient risk factors associated with higher incidence of GC in Hispanics.

Methods: Univariate and multivariate logistic regression analyses were conducted on HCUP database from 2011-2015. Patients were divided into two cohorts: Hispanics and non-Hispanic Whites (NHW).

Results: Of the 132,240,840 patients, 144,770 were identified with GC (0.11%).  GC (RR=1.34; p<0.001) and H. pylori infection (RR=2.09, p<0.001) were more prevalent in Hispanics. More Hispanic patients had Medicaid or no insurance (p<0.001) and were from lower SES based on median household income (p<0.001). Of the patients with GC, Hispanics presented at much younger age, with most profound differences seen between ages 30-40 (OR=3.17, p<0.001). Although diabetes mellitus (DM) was slightly more common in NHW, it was significantly higher in Hispanics with GC, especially in young patients in both sexes (OR=2.28; ages 40-50), males (OR=2.68; ages 30-40) and most strikingly in younger females (OR=3.26; ages 40-50). 

Conclusion: DM is associated with an increased risk of GC among Hispanic patients, especially in young adults.  Although SES and environmental exposures (e.g. H. pylori infection) may play a role in racial disparities, efforts to improve access to healthcare and lifestyle modification may help reduce racial disparities in GC.

abstract_title: The Impact of Hemoglobin A1c on Post-Operative Outcomes in Bariatric Surgery Patients.
author_block: N. Sridhar<sup>1</sup>, E. Hetzel<sup>1</sup>, T. L. Kindel<sup>1</sup>, J. Gould<sup>1</sup>, R. Higgins<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Surgery,Milwaukee, WISCONSIN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pre-operative hemoglobin (Hb) A1c levels ≥ 8% have been associated with increased post-operative complications in surgical patients. Given the prevalence and physiology of diabetes among bariatric surgery patients, attaining a pre-operative HbA1c < 8% can be a challenge. The purpose of this study was to identify the impact of pre-operative HbA1c on post-operative outcomes in bariatric surgery patients.

Methods: A retrospective chart review was conducted on diabetic patients who underwent primary bariatric surgery, including laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy, gastric bypass or gastric banding, at a single institution between the years 2013 and 2019. Diabetic patients were defined as those with a HbA1c ≥ 6.5%. Patients were divided into two groups based on their pre-operative HbA1c levels of < 8% and ≥ 8%.  Univariate analyses were performed to determine an association between pre-operative HbA1c levels and post-operative outcomes.

Results: There were 351 primary bariatric surgery patients in the study period, 270 with HbA1c <8%, and 81 with HbA1c ≥ 8%. The HbA1c < 8% group had an average pre-operative HbA1c of 6.5% ± 0.9 compared to 9.0% ± 1.0 in the HbA1c ≥ 8% group (p<0.001). Laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy was more frequently performed in the HbA1c < 8% group compared to HbA1c ≥ 8% group (49.3% vs 43.2%), versus the gastric bypass (50.4% vs 53.1%) and gastric banding (0.4% vs 3.7%) (p < 0.04). There was no statistically significant difference in any 30-day post-operative outcome between the two groups, including length of stay, overall complications, intensive care unit admission, hospital readmission, intraoperative complication, reoperation, return to the Emergency Department and mortality (Table 1). There was also no statistically significant difference in 2 week change in body mass index (4.7 kg/m2 ± 7.3 vs 5.3 kg/m2 ± 9.7, p=0.20) or 3 month change (8.3 kg/m2 ± 3.6 vs 7.4 kg/m2 ± 2.2, p=0.07) between the two groups. Post-operative HbA1c was significantly less in the HbA1c < 8% group both at the 3-6 month (6.0% ± 0.9 vs 7.4% ± 1.4, p<0.001) and 6-12 month (6.0% ± 1.1 vs 7.2% ± 1.4, p<0.001) post-operative follow-up.

Conclusion: This study demonstrated no difference in post-operative outcomes of primary bariatric surgery patients based on a HbA1c cut-off of 8%. This highlights that given the prevalence and physiology of diabetes in bariatric surgery patients, surgery can be considered and safely performed in patients with a pre-operative HbA1c ≥ 8%. Attaining a HbA1c < 8% may not be feasible for some diabetic patients without bariatric surgery.

abstract_title: Individual-Level Bariatric Surgery Barriers in the Veterans Health Administration
author_block: J. Murtha<sup>5</sup>, E. Alagoz<sup>2</sup>, C. Breuer<sup>2</sup>, A. Finn<sup>6</sup>, S. D. Raffa<sup>3,4</sup>, C. Voils<sup>1,2</sup>, L. M. Funk<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>William S. Middleton VA Memorial Hospital,Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery, Wisconsin Surgical Outcomes Research Program (WiSOR),Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>National Center for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention,Department Of Veterans Affairs,Durham, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Department Of Psychiatry And Behavioral Sciences,Durham, NC, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Wisconsin,School Of Medicine,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Bariatric surgery is the most effective weight loss treatment for individuals with severe obesity but <1% of U.S. adults and <0.1% of U.S. Veterans who meet BMI criteria undergo it. We previously characterized 8 barriers to bariatric surgery care at the health system level. Our objective was to identify patient and provider perceptions of individual-level barriers to undergoing bariatric surgery within the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) from the perspectives of Veterans with severe obesity, primary care providers (PCPs), registered dietitians (RDs), health psychologists and bariatric surgeons.

Methods:  We conducted semi-structured interviews with Veterans with severe obesity and providers, including PCPs, RDs, health psychologists and bariatric surgeons. Veterans were from two Midwest VA medical centers (VAMCs) and had either been referred for bariatric surgery or were participating in the VHA’s behavioral weight management program (MOVE!). PCPs, RDs and health psychologists were recruited from three VAMCs in the Midwest region, and bariatric surgeons were recruited from all 21 VA bariatric surgery programs. Participants were asked to describe their experiences with obesity care treatment within VHA. Interviews were audio recorded and transcribed. Four coders developed a codebook, which was applied to all interviews. Conventional content analysis identified individual-level barriers within Anderson’s Behavioral Model of Health Services Use, which has two general determinants: individual and contextual (e.g. systems). This analysis focused on the individual determinants, which describe how service utilization is influenced by an individual’s need, health behaviors, and predisposing beliefs or social structure.

Results: Thirty-three veterans and 40 providers (15 PCPs, 13 bariatric surgeons, 6 RDs and 6 health psychologists) were interviewed. Nearly three-fourths of Veterans were male, whereas nearly three-fourths of providers were female. We identified six individual-level barriers to undergoing bariatric surgery (Figure 1): lack of social support, fear of surgery and its potential outcomes, fear of change, difficulty adhering to required dietary changes, the perception that weight had not reached its “tipping point,” and patient characteristics influencing provider referral.

Conclusion: Veterans and providers reported that fears of surgery and concerns regarding adherence to required behavioral and dietary changes were barriers to bariatric surgery. Patient and provider education is needed to address patient fears of surgery and the belief that surgery is a “last resort.” Furthermore, patients must be empowered to change their personal health practices.

abstract_title: Perceptions on Incentivization as a Way of Promoting Weight Loss Following Bariatric Surgery
author_block: C. A. Vitous<sup>1</sup>, G. F. Chao<sup>1</sup>, A. P. Ehlers<sup>1</sup>, R. Ross<sup>1</sup>, J. Kullgren<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Ghaferi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Michigan Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for obesity, many patients struggle with insufficient weight loss or weight regain following their procedure. Incentive programs directed at patients have become increasingly widespread as a means to influence patient behavior post-operatively. Although evidence suggests great promise in incentive programs influencing short-term outcomes, data on long-term effects are lacking.

Methods: Using a qualitative study design, we explored the impacts of a pilot study examining the effects of a financial incentive program following bariatric surgery on sustained weight loss and postoperative follow-up. 22 semi-structured interviews were conducted with a reflective demographic of bariatric surgery patients who participated in this program from three medical centers across Michigan. The majority of participants were female (n=21), identified as white (36%) or black (41%), had private insurance (86%), and had an income above $25,000 (69%). Interviews sought to examine how patients perceived the value of the financial incentive program as well as barriers and facilitators to continued weight loss following surgery. Inductive thematic analysis was used to analyze the data.

Results: Data indicated that although participants found some value in participating in the financial incentive program, the majority asserted that the compensation did not significantly impact their behavior long-term. Three themes emerged as significant needs to address for bariatric surgery patients working toward sustained weight loss: (1) mental health, (2) dietary support, and (3) social support. As articulately captured by one participant, “I think if you take the people that are successful with this, they got their head around their eating, they're on some sort of a structure, and they're not allowing outside influences to dictate their life anymore. And I think that's the biggest key. We can shrink your stomach, we can do all kinds of things medically, but you can still gain weight [after] doing this.” It should be noted that individual-level factors such as internal motivations, comorbidities, and demographic characteristics were also found to be influential variables in patient experiences following bariatric surgery.

Conclusions: Although not without value, financial incentives on their own were not found to be a significant motivator for long-term weight loss following bariatric surgery. Data from this study suggest that more long-term support is needed in spaces of mental health, dietary support, and social support following bariatric surgery - with resources being tailored based on individual patient needs.

abstract_title: The Influence of Gender Inequality on Gender Mix in Bariatric Surgery
author_block: C. A. Pernat<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Acevedo<sup>2</sup>, D. C. Chang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Tufts University,Department Of Community Health,Medford, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the United States, approximately 80% of bariatric surgery patients are female, while obesity rates between genders are similar. We hypothesize these gender differences in bariatric surgery are influenced by women’s empowerment as reflected by gender inequality. This study aims to understand if there is an association between population-level measures of gender inequality and bariatric surgery gender mix.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of New York’s Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) between 2010 and 2015 was performed. Our study included New York State adult patients with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery. Gender inequality was measured with the United Nation’s Gender Inequality Index (GII) at the county level and was created with data from the Area Health Resources Files, New York State, American Community Survey, SPARCS, and Centers for Disease Control's National Center for Health Statistics. Multivariate logistic regression was performed, with the sex of the patient as the dependent variable and adjusting for relevant patient covariates.

Results: From 2010 to 2015, 71,364 bariatric surgical procedures were performed in New York’s 62 counties. Females made up 79.15% of the patient population. In the adjusted analysis, several patient factors were associated with an increased odds of female patient presentation, including Black or African American race, Hispanic ethnicity, older age, and Medicaid insurance. In addition, at the county-level, bariatric surgery patients residing in counties with the highest tercile levels of gender inequality were 11% more likely to be female than male (OR 1.11, 95% CI 1.06-1.16, p<0.01).

Conclusion: Population gender inequality is associated with the likelihood of women versus men to undergo bariatric surgery. Efforts should be made to increase the empowerment of women thus working towards gender inequality in the community. Furthermore, isolating clinical and societal influences in the bariatric decision-making process may be beneficial in decreasing gender differences in surgery.

abstract_title: Weight Changes During COVID-19 Quarantine and Its Potential Impacts on Bariatric Surgery
author_block: M. Blevins<sup>1</sup>, A. Borgatti<sup>1</sup>, G. Dutton<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Weight management has been suggested as a potential concern resulting from the COVID-19 stay-at-home orders. Potential weight gain could prove difficult to manage post-COVID. Individuals who are trying to lose weight may consider bariatric surgery, which is indicated for severe obesity and produces greater weight loss compared to standard non-surgical treatments. However, to qualify for surgery, individuals must first attempt to adhere to a diet and exercise program. The present study assessed weight management efforts of individuals with obesity who had been attempting to lose weight for at least 6 months prior to the state-mandated stay-at-home regulations. The study aimed to evaluate whether weight gain occurred during quarantine, and whether any demographic or psychosocial factors may predict weight gain during quarantine.

Methods:  The study looked at a total of 55 participants (90% female, mean age=49.8, mean BMI 37.4, 38.2% Caucasian) enrolled in a weight loss intervention. Eligibility criteria included a prior diagnosis of obesity (30-50 kg/m2, avg. 37.4) and prior randomization to the self-directed arm of a weight loss intervention. Participants completed a 6- or 12-month assessment before the lockdown and then completed a COVID-specific ancillary survey 1.5-2.5 months after lockdown. The COVID survey collected information on health behaviors, COVID-19 status, weight change, and demographics.

Results: In total during the pandemic, 14.5% of participants reported any weight loss, 27.3% of participants stayed the same, and 58% of participants reported weight gain, with 16.4% of participants gaining more than 10 pounds. Weight change was not associated with marital status, gender, age, race, income, or education (P> 0.05). Loneliness was a strong predictor of weight gain (R2=0.266, P< 0.05) and was an important factor during this time.

Conclusion: A majority of patients gained weight during quarantine, which could indicate a potential need for more bariatric surgery post-COVID. Loneliness may be especially predictive of weight gain or unsuccessful weight management during the era of COVID-19. During COVID-19, bariatric surgeons may want to consider loneliness as an important factor for considering sustained adherence to treatment recommendations. Consideration should be made regarding the psychosocial health of patients considering bariatric surgery, with potential interventions to decrease loneliness among those considering weight loss surgery.

abstract_title: Predictors of Conversion During Minimally Invasive Gastrectomy for Malignancy: Analysis of NCDB
author_block: K. A. Stahl<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Gusani<sup>3</sup>, E. J. Olecki<sup>1</sup>, R. Perez Holguin<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Hendricksen<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Dixon<sup>3</sup>, J. S. Peng<sup>3</sup>, C. Shen<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Division Of Outcomes Research And Quality,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Program For Liver Pancreas And Foregut Tumors,Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Use of minimally invasive (MI) approaches to gastrectomy for malignancy is increasing. The risk factors for conversion during laparoscopic and robotic gastrectomy are poorly understood. This study aimed to determine the impact of surgical modality (laparoscopic and robotic) on conversion as well as to identify other risk factors for conversion.

Methods:  A retrospective cohort study included patients with Stage I-III gastric cancer who had a MI gastrectomy from the National Cancer Database (NCDB) between 2010 and 2016. Chi-square and t-tests were used to examine subgroup differences between patients based on surgical approach. Propensity score weighting was used to evaluate factors predictive of conversion. Logistic regression models were used to control for covariates and identify factors associated with robotic and laparoscopic conversion. 

Results: The final cohort included 8,305 patients, with 1,246 robotic assisted and 7,104 laparoscopic gastrectomies. The overall conversion rate for MI gastrectomies was 11.6%. Conversion rates were 12.4% for laparoscopic approach and 6.9% for robotic assisted. After propensity score weighting, robotic assisted approach was still significantly associated with lower likelihood of needing conversion compared to laparoscopic approach (OR=0.426, p<0.001). Other factors predictive of conversion included African American race compared to white (OR=1.552 p=0.034), tumor size >5 cm compared to <2 cm (OR=1.580, p=0.028), and total gastrectomy compared to partial gastrectomy (OR=1.360, p=0.039). Tumor location in the proximal stomach were less likely to be converted compared to distal site (OR=0.622, p=0.017). 

Conclusion: Laparoscopic gastrectomies are associated with nearly two fold increase in conversion rate when compared to robotic assisted gastrectomies. Identifying specific risk factors for MI conversion will aid in the appropriate modality selection and a reduction in conversions.

abstract_title: Does Timing of IVC Filter Placement in Bariatric Surgery Patients Impact Perioperative Outcomes?
author_block: A. C. Spaulding<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Edwards<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mayo Clinic - Florida,General Surgery,Jacksonville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Mayo Clinic - Florida,Health Sciences Research,Jacksonville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) remains a safe and effective treatment for morbid obesity with a very low risk profile. Even though venous thromboembolism (VTE) is a rare complication after MBS (0.4%), VTE remains the most common cause of mortality in MBS patients.  While there is controversy about the use of inferior vena cava (IVC) filter in MBS patients, there is increasing consensus that its use is associated with more harm than benefit, including higher rates of DVT, PE and in-hospital mortality. The impact of a pre-existing IVC filter, compared to an IVC filter placed prophylactically in anticipation of MBS remains unclear. The objective of this study is to determine if the timing of IVC filter placement impacts perioperative outcomes in MBS patients.

Methods:  In this observational study, we used the 2015 to 2018 Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery Accreditation and Quality Improvement Program (MBSAQIP) databases to identify gastric bypass (RYGB) and sleeve gastrectomy (SG) patients who had an IVC filter at the time of RYGB and SG. Selected RYGB and SG cases were stratified by timing of IVC placement (pre-existing vs. prophylactic). Propensity-score matching (1:1, caliper distance = 0.1) was utilized to estimate probabilities of outcomes. Additionally, logistic regression analyses were performed to determine if IVC filter timing independently predicted mortality or morbidity after MBS. Statistical analyses were performed with StataMP version 16.  A p-value < 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Of 157,913 RYGB and 393,342 SG cases in the 2015-2018 MBSAQIP databases, 0.8% and 0.7% had an IVC at the time of MBS, respectively. Overall, annual prophylatic IVC filter use decrease in RYGB and SG cases. Propensity matching reduced biases between IVC filter cohorts by 62%-98% and 71%-98% for RYGB and SG cases, respectively. Bariatric-related morbidity was lower in RYGB cases with a prophylactic IVC filter (vs. preexisting) (16.3% vs. 10.6%, RR 0.9, p 0.047). However, overall morbidity (15.6% vs. 10.9%, OR 1.04, p 0.02), 30-day intervention (9.9% vs. 2.5%, OR 1.08, p <0.001) and bariatric-related intervention (4.1% vs. 2.0%, OR 1.03, p 0.001) were higher in SG cases with a prophylactic IVC filter. On logistic regression analyses, timing of IVC filter was not an independent predictor of overall (OR 0.97) or bariatric-related (OR 0.71) morbidity in RYGB cases, but non-Hispanic white race was (OR 1.4). In SG cases, the timing of IVC filter independently correlated with overall and bariatric-related morbidity (Table).

Conclusion: Inferior vena cava filter use as venous thromboembolisms prophylaxis in anticipation of metabolic and bariatric surgery is associated with significantly higher odds of overall and bariatric-related morbidity following sleeve gastrectomy.

abstract_title: Early outcomes of self-expanding metal stents for managing malignant gastroduodenal obstruction
author_block: S. G. Thrumurthy<sup>1</sup>, A. Zaidi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Epsom and St Helier University Hospitals NHS Trust,Surgery,Sutton, SURREY, United Kingdom
abstract_body:
Introduction: Malignant gastroduodenal obstruction (GDO) leads to malnutrition and limits quality of life. Self-expanding metal stents (SEMS) have gained favour over traditional gastrojejunostomy in the palliation of inoperable malignant GDO. This study aimed to assess the early and midterm outcomes of SEMS in this challenging group of patients.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent SEMS placement for malignant GDO at a British teaching hospital over a four year period. Data was obtained for the following parameters: Presenting features: age, site of malignancy (e.g. gastric, pancreatic), presence of metastasis or recurrence, initial symptom status. Procedural data: stent type (covered/uncovered), stent insertion route (per-oral or trans-gastric), anaesthetic type (sedation or local anaesthetic to pharynx only), concurrent or subsequent biliary stent insertion. Peri-procedural outcomes: technical success, change in symptom score, mortality (30-day), morbidity (30-day), length of inpatient stay. Late outcomes: mortality (>30 days), re-intervention rate, indications for re-intervention, follow-up duration.

Results: Forty patients with gastric (n=21), pancreatic (n=15) and other (n=4) malignancies underwent SEMS placement. Median age at initial presentation was 72 years (range 42-88 years). Metastatic disease was present in 7/40 (17.5%) patients, recurrent malignancy in 3/40 (7.5%) patients and metastasis/recurrence in 2/40 (5.0%) patients. Uncovered (n=36) and covered (n=4) SEMS were inserted via an endoscopic (n=25) or transgastric (n=15) approach. Biliary stenting was performed concurrently in 5/40 (12.5%) patients and subsequently in 2/40 (5.0%) patients. Technical and clinical success rates were both 92.5%. Median hospital stay was 5 days (range 1-26 days), with 2 procedurerelated complications (haematemesis and obstructive jaundice) and no procedure-related mortality. Follow-up ranged from 5 weeks to 89 months (median 29 months) and was complete in 35 (87.5%) patients. During follow-up, 2 patients (5%) died; reintervention was required in 6 (15%) patients, for SEMS blockage from tumour ingrowth (n=5) and biliary stent blockage (n=1). Median time from stenting to reintervention was 12.5 (range 8-72) weeks. The presence of metastasis or recurrent malignancy at presentation showed a significantly higher persistence of symptoms after stenting (Fisher’s Exact test p=0.002).

Conclusion: SEMS are effective in the management of malignant GDO to successfully re-establish enteral intake with minimal morbidity and mortality, and a short hospital stay. Surgical bypass should be preserved for cases in which SEMS placement is not successful or possible. Further research employing greater cohort sizes, including comparative studies, are warranted to further establish the specific indications and benefits of SEMS in the management of malignant GDO.

abstract_title: Implementation of an Enhanced Recovery After Surgery Program: A Qualitative Study
author_block: A. P. Ehlers<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Vitous<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Ghaferi<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Finks<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,General Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Enhanced recovery after surgery is an evidence-based care improvement process with demonstrated improvements in clinical outcomes. There are currently limited data on the effectiveness of enhanced recovery protocols following bariatric surgery. The Finding Useful Techniques to Upgrade Recovery Enhancement (FUTURE) program was designed to develop and implement interventions to bridge this gap. In this study, we sought to describe barriers and facilitators to implementation in a pilot study, with the goal of improving the protocol in advance of future rollout.

Methods:  We conducted semi-structured interviews with 3 bariatric surgery programs participating in a statewide quality improvement collaborative that had implemented the FUTURE protocol. The interviews were conducted in a focus group format including surgeons, advanced practice practitioners, and program coordinators. The interview guide included questions on every phase of implementation (Development, Pre-implementation, Implementation, and Conclusions). Thematic analysis using NVivo Pro (version 12.6.0.959) was used to analyze the data.

Results: Overall, respondents cited the desire to improve patient outcomes as a key motivation for participation. The main themes to emerge as facilitators included (1) buy-in, (2) staff education, and (3) hospital culture.  The main themes to emerge as barriers included (1) site specific challenges, (2) non-compliance of protocol by individual team members, and (3) interruptions to implementation. Participants emphasized the importance of having all team members aligned prior to Implementation as a key element during Pre-implementation. Ensuring buy-in and providing staff education helped achieve this. Having a smaller hospital with fewer team members was thought to create a positive and receptive culture that was beneficial during Implementation. Site-specific challenges, such as availability of specific medications, resulted in modification of the protocol during Pre-Implementation. Individuals who did not comply with the pathway created a barrier during Implementation. Suggested strategies to overcome this included ongoing reminders about the pathway, as well as individualized interventions in cases of disagreement. Interruptions to Implementation were experienced by all sites, either due to job turnover or COVID-19. The data indicated that participants felt positive about their participation in the FUTURE program, particularly regarding patient outcomes. 

Conclusion: Participants responded positively to their participation in the FUTURE program. These data highlight the need to consider both cultural and structural factors within programs and hospitals when implementing a multifaceted enhanced recovery program. These key insights are critical to the successful scaling of this intervention to other hospitals seeking to improve the safety, efficiency, and patient experience of bariatric surgery.

abstract_title: Long-term Clinical Outcome Of Laparoscopic Subtotal Partial Fundoplication (Lind procedure).
author_block: F. Mannan<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Akingboye<sup>1</sup>, C. Sellahewa<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Russells Hall Hospital,Surgery,Dudley, WESTMIDLANDS, United Kingdom
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication has been the gold standard for the treatment of gastroesophageal disease (GERD). However, other laparoscopic technique such as Toupet, Dor and Lind have also been reported to produce satisfactory clinical outcomes. Laparoscopic Lind procedure described as a 300-degree wrap has been reported to produce satisfactory clinical outcome with much reduced post-operative complication of dysphagia.  We aimed to analyse the clinical outcomes of patients who were treated with laparoscopic Lind procedure. The primary outcome was to assess the short term (3months) and long term (24months) symptomatic relief. The secondary outcome measure was to assess the short and long-term development of post-operative complication of dysphagia.

Methods: Our prospectively electronic database was retrospectively analysed; the clinical parameters considered included varied presentation of GERD symptoms, preoperative oesophagogastroduodenoscopy (OGD), 24 hr manometry, intra operative findings, length of hospital stay, failure rate of procedure, operative complications, patients satisfaction via a standardised telephone conversation and development of long-term complication. All patients underwent laparoscopic non mesh repair of the hiatal hernia with stratafix sutures and preservation of the short gastric vessels.

Results: A total of 76 patients underwent laparoscopic Lind procedure of which 47 patients were females (62%) with mean age of 58 SD +/- 15, and a median BMI of 25. Seventy-six patients (97%) had OGD and manometry as part of the pre-operative work.  The median DeMeester score and median estimated size of the hiatus hernia (HH) on OGD was 25 and 3cm, respectively. Thirty-seven (49%) of our study population had more than one significant medical comorbidity. Intraoperative complication of bleeding, atrial flutter occurred in three patients (4%).  In the initial 3 months follow up, 41% (n=31) experienced dysphagia; 26% ( n-20) gas bloating; 12% (n-9) retrosternal chest pain; 5% (n=4) epigastric pain and one patient developed port site hernia , which was repaired later. Only one patient has persistent GERD symptoms. The median length of hospital stay was 2 SD+/- 3 days. There was no 30 or 90 day mortality and none required redo surgery. At 24 months follow up 93% (n=71) of the patients were completely symptom free without any dysphagia.

Conclusion: Lind procedure is safe and feasible technique which has very low failure rate and with low post-operative complications of dysphagia on long term follow up.  We conclude that Lind technique can be safely performed as a day case procedure where proper logistics are in place.

abstract_title: Introducing a Bariatric Surgery Program at a Safety Net Hospital: Feasibility and Early Outcomes
author_block: T. J. James<sup>1</sup>, L. Hawley<sup>1</sup>, M. Rothschild<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Patel<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, S. F. Sener<sup>1</sup>, A. Dobrowolsky<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Southern California,Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Few bariatric surgery programs exist at safety net hospitals which often serve diverse populations. Obesity is more prevalent among racial minorities, but these patients are less likely to undergo bariatric surgery and often exhibit inferior outcomes when they do. We introduced a bariatric surgery program at one of the country’s largest public safety net hospitals serving a primarily Hispanic population. Here we describe our experience and early outcomes to lay groundwork for future studies investigating racial disparities in bariatric outcomes in a safety net environment.

Methods:  The program was modeled after the bariatric program at our academic hospital affiliate. Program-specific personnel were hired including a bariatric surgeon, nurse practitioner, dietician, and psychiatrist. A standardized clinical pathway was developed including a required preoperative educational seminar and postoperative care protocol. Electronic medical records were retrospectively reviewed for demographics, perioperative outcomes, one-year weight loss, and comorbidity reduction.

Results: 98 patients underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy from the program start in May 2016 to March 2019. 88 patients followed-up at one year. Most (84%) were referred from primary care clinics. 51% of patients were Hispanic and 16% were black. Hypertension and diabetes were present in 71.6% and 51.1% of patients, respectively. Initial preoperative BMI was 47.5 + 5.11 kg/m2.

Conclusion: We demonstrate that a bariatric program can feasibly be introduced at a safety net hospital with acceptable perioperative and one-year outcomes. Future work is needed to investigate the unique barriers this population faces in maintaining long-term weight loss and comorbidity improvement after bariatric surgery.

abstract_title: Integrating Telemedicine into a Surgery Department: Qualitative Analysis of Provider Perspectives
author_block: S. A. Hayek<sup>1</sup>, C. Lauer<sup>1</sup>, R. Shabahang<sup>1</sup>, E. Pica<sup>1</sup>, C. Martin<sup>1</sup>, M. Shabahang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Medical Center,General Surgery,Danville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Healthcare has made many technological advances over the past several decades. One of the most innovative adaptations of technology into healthcare is the use of virtual technology in clinical care. Telemedicine has the potential to overcome many barriers of access for patients and to increase the ability of physicians and other providers to interact with their patients. The purpose of this study is to better understand how key stakeholders within a busy department of surgery at a tertiary referral center view the integration of telemedicine in clinical practice today.

Methods: This is a qualitative study where semi-structured interviews were conducted with telemedicine stakeholders within a single department of surgery during April-June of 2020. These were then de-identified, and a crystallization/immersion process was used to identify important themes.

Results: A total of ten interviews were held with telemedicine stakeholders including providers, nurses, and administrative staff. Six major themes emerged including technology, barriers, patient catchment, convenience for both clinical staff and patients, adaptation of novel methods, and patient-provider rapport (Table 1). These themes show that key stakeholders see multiple different concepts as critical to the use of telemedicine in clinical practice today.

Conclusion: Telemedicine provides additional opportunities for practitioners and patients to interact and connect. Stakeholders of telemedicine within a single department of surgery are optimistic about the integration of telemedicine within healthcare today, especially in relation to the potential to increase market share and to make interacting with patients more convenient for all parties. There is some concern about the use of technology, perceived barriers to delivering care using virtual technology, and the effects on patient-provider rapport. Finally, the adaptation of telemedicine has been affected by the current worldwide events of COVID-19 making people more willing to embrace such changes but the long-term adaptation of this technology is yet to be understood.

abstract_title: Short, Laparoscopic Simulation Course May Reverse Skill Decay of General Surgery Research Residents
author_block: B. K. Roberts<sup>1</sup>, C. Nofi<sup>1</sup>, V. Patel<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Northwell Health North Shore/Long Island Jewish Hospital,Department Of General Surgery,New Hyde Park, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Hofstra University,Zucker School Of Medicine,New Hyde Park, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The number of general surgery residents pursuing dedicated years off of clinical training to complete research is climbing. Residents engaging in research may return to clinical duties with less surgical skill, a phenomenon referred to as “skill decay.” This study explored the role of laparoscopic simulation curriculum utilized to improve the technical skills and intraoperative performance of research residents. We hypothesized that a condensed, Fundamentals of Laparoscopic Surgery (FLS)-based simulation course could reverse technical skill decay in research residents prior to return to clinical duties.

Methods: Three laparoscopic FLS-based tested, simulation sessions were administered over a two-week span prior to the start of the clinical, academic year. Participants were residents returning from a two or three year research hiatus in two large, urban academic medical centers of one health system in New York. 

Results: Research residents improved in task-specific performance after completion of laparoscopic FLS-based simulation course. Residents performed basic tasks (Tasks 1-3) in a similar time frame, however with less tested errors after simulation training. Residents performed complex tasks (Tasks 4-5) in less time, and with greater accuracy after the simulation course. Confidence scores were greater for all tasks after the simulation course, with greater increase in confidence for more complex tasks. Residents believed that the simulation course had a positive impact on their intraoperative laparoscopic skills after returning to OR. Residents endorsed significant improvement in their confidence on the box trainer and in the operating room. Research residents agreed that the simulation course appropriately trained and tested their laparoscopic skills, was easy to understand, was explained in an appropriate way, was the appropriate length of time, and was useful for returning research residents to reverse potential skill decay.

Conclusion: Basic FLS-based laparoscopic simulation training can be utilized to significantly improve the technical laparoscopic skills, improve laparoscopic skill confidence, and potentially reverse skill decay experienced by research residents returning from gap years. Reasonably short and easy to institute training curricula can be utilized to ease the transition of research residents back to clinical, operative duties.

abstract_title: PICCing a New Team: Training of Surgical Residents for Access Teams During the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: H. Wady<sup>1</sup>, A. Tassiopoulos<sup>2</sup>, A. Kokkosis<sup>2</sup>, E. Gross<sup>3</sup>, S. Abdel-Misih<sup>4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stony Brook University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Stony Brook, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Stony Brook University Medical Center,Division Of Vascular Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Stony Brook, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Stony Brook University Medical Center,Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Stony Brook, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>Stony Brook University Medical Center,Division Of Surgical Oncology, Department Of Surgery,Stony Brook, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As the COVID-19 Pandemic infiltrated healthcare systems, a surge of critically ill patients began populating intensive care units (ICUs). Suffolk County’s (NY) number of cases swelled to as high as 6th nationwide and many of these patients required central venous access for resuscitative efforts. Orchestrated by the Division of Vascular Surgery, a dedicated line service team was created to aid in patient care and peripherally inserted central catheters (PICCs) were chosen as the preferred access method.

Methods: General Surgery residents, traditionally trained in central venous catheter placement, learned to place PICC lines. Once credentialed, these residents assisted in a hospital wide effort for reliable central venous access  in critically ill COVID-19 positive patients. The training process included a standardized protocol requiring a comprehensive online didactic PICC line course. After passing the course and attaining the fundamentals of safety and indications of PICCs, residents were trained by credentialed personnel on procedural techniques and supervised during their first two PICC line placements. This allowed for rapid mobilization of trained personnel to assist in line placement, with the added benefit of placing longer, more durable central access devices for supportive critical care.

Results: A recent survey sent to the general surgery residency class showed that 81% of respondents successfully obtained credentialing for PICC line placement. Of those that obtained credentialing, 95% of them did so during their rotations in COVID-19 ICUs and 66% felt that the process of learning the necessary technical skills was of low difficulty. These skill sets were transferred to surgical patients as 52% of residents continued placing PICCs on non-COVID patients who required central access. Table 1 highlights the volume of PICCs placed. Almost 52% of residents confirmed that their decision algorithm has changed since obtaining this training and that future consideration for obtaining central access would include factoring in the added benefits of PICCs versus traditional central venous catheters.

Conclusion: This expansion of traditional surgical training during times of stress on a healthcare system demonstrates the aptitude and commitment of surgical residents to continue to adapt to a changing environment, and to acquire invaluable technical skills for current and future patient care.

abstract_title: Academic Experience in Virtual Rounding and Education During COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: M. K. Kamel<sup>1</sup>, C. Nituica<sup>1</sup>, O. Mansuri<sup>1</sup>, J. McKenna<sup>1</sup>, J. Blebea<sup>1</sup>, F. Tuma<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Central Michigan University College Of Medicine,General Surgery,Mount Pleasant, Michigan, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: To cope with social/physical distancing and other COVID-19 pandemic control precautions, many surgical residency programs (including ours) have adopted a Declared Health Emergency (DHE) rotation to minimize exposure to the COVID-19 without compromising the quality of healthcare or training. We evaluated the experience and educational value of virtual education activities by reviewing the perceptions of the DHE rotation participants through survey questionnaire analysis.

Methods: The DHE rotation virtual educational activities at our institution included general surgery rounds, trauma rounds, grand rounds, morbidity and mortality sessions, journal club sessions, SCORE sessions, and Disaster and Emergency Preparedness course. Residents, nurse practitioners/physician assistants (NP/PA), and surgeons who participated in the DHE rotation were asked to complete a survey questionnaire describing their perception and experience.

Results: The survey response rate was 100% (faculty-n=13, residents-n=8, NP/PA-n=4). The majority participated in the virtual activities from hospital (n=13, 52%) or home (n=9, 36%) and used a laptop computer (n=15, 60%) or smartphone (n=5, 20%) to participate. The majority reported that virtual activities required minimal technical skills (n=17, 68%) and that the quality of audio-visual connectivity was good/excellent (n=20, 80%). Compared to the traditional in-person conferences before the pandemic, the majority reported that they participated in virtual clinical rounds more often or the same (n=22, 88%), that the overall level and quality of interactions between participants were the same or better (n=19, 76%), that they experienced disinterest/absentmindedness the same or less often (n=21, 84%), and that the knowledge gained during the virtual activities was the same or more (n=22, 88%). All respondents (n=25, 100%) reported that virtual meetings and conferences' educational objectives were met. The majority of the respondents agreed that hospital clinical rounds (n=16, 67%) and grand rounds/M&M (n=22, 88%) should be available in a virtual format when the pandemic is over.

Conclusion: The quality of education and knowledge gain during the virtual educational activities are equivalent to or better than in the traditional face-to-face activities. The use of technology in virtual educational activities is a practical and convenient approach to achieve the desired educational objectives during and potentially after the COVID-19 pandemic.

abstract_title: Perceived Discrimination Among Surgical Residents at Academic Medical Centers
author_block: J. A. Khubchandani<sup>1,2</sup>, R. B. Atkinson<sup>2</sup>, G. Ortega<sup>2</sup>, J. T. Mullen<sup>1</sup>, .. The PACTS Trial Group<sup>2</sup>, D. S. Smink<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Perceived discrimination, defined as stressful experiences of unfair treatment based on personal attributes, has been linked to adverse health outcomes. It is also well-established that Black, Native American, and Hispanic American residents are less likely to feel that they fit into their training programs, feel less comfortable asking for help, and are acutely aware of the occurrence of unfair treatment in the work environment. We sought to determine the everyday perceived discrimination (a measure of discrimination both in and out of the hospital) among surgery residents. 

Methods: This study is part of a randomized controlled trial across 8 general surgery residency training programs evaluating the Provider Awareness and Cultural dexterity Toolkit for Surgeons (PACTS), a curriculum designed to improve surgical residents’ cultural dexterity. Baseline demographic information was collected from residents enrolled at 5 of the sites in the study prior to undergoing any cultural dexterity training. To quantify perceived discrimination, we utilized the nine-item Everyday Discrimination Scale (EDS). Response options included never/less than once a year, a few times a year, a few times in a month, at least once a week, and almost every day. The EDS was coded using frequency-based coding. Higher scores represented greater perceived discrimination and these were collapsed into three groups reflecting low (0-12), middle (13-24) or high scores (25-36). Given the distribution of the data, we collapsed the middle and high groups. We then analyzed the data for associations of EDS scores with race, gender, socioeconomic data, and training level using Fischer exact tests and logistic regression models.  

Results: We analyzed the self-assessments of 179 residents. Of the resident sample, 51% (n=91) were men. Racial breakdown was 55% (n=98) White, 19% (n=34) Asian, 14% (n=25) Black, and 5% (n=9) Multiracial. 69% (n=98) grew up in zip codes with the highest median household income (MHI) quartile and 75% (n=134) had at least one parent with a master’s degree or higher. The median EDS score was 7, with scores ranging from 0-36. Once collapsed, 24% (n=43) fell into the mid/high EDS group. When controlling for other demographic and socioeconomic factors, resident race and MHI were significantly associated with EDS scores. Black residents were 5.8 times more likely to have mid/high EDS scores compared to their white counterparts (p = 0.002, CI 1.90-17.90). Asian residents were noted to be 1.48 times more likely to have higher EDS scores, but this did not reach significance (p = 0.442). 

Conclusion: Black surgical residents are more likely to report higher discrimination. With heightened attention to race relations in the U.S. and given the mental and physical health implications of perceived discrimination, it is essential to understand life experiences of surgical residents and ensure that they are given the support they need throughout surgical training.

abstract_title: AI-driven analysis of gender bias in general surgery residency program websites
author_block: D. A. Sarraf<sup>1</sup>, K. Kamena<sup>1</sup>, R. England<sup>1</sup>, V. Vasiliu<sup>3</sup>, J. R. Porterfield<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>Hadassah-Hebrew University Medical Center,Communication,Jerusalem, N/A, Israel
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Applicants use the internet to research residency programs. Most general surgery residency programs (GSRP) have publically viewable information online. Since general surgery is predominantly male[1], we conducted textual analysis with artificial intelligence (AI) to test whether gender-bias exists in written content of GSRP websites.   [1] https://www.aamc.org/data/workforce/reports/492560/1-3-chart.html  

Methods:  GSRPs (n=333) and directors (PD) were identified using the Association for Program Directors in Surgery website; information was cross-referenced with AMA FREIDA and ACGME databases current to January 1, 2020. Numbers of male and female residents, alumni, faculty, and program size were determined from GSRP websites and FREIDA. Webpage URLs (n=3206) were identified from GSRP homepages. Dept. chair and PD welcome messages (n=237; F=40, M=197) were collected. IBM Watson™ AI analyzed URLs and welcome message for sentiment, emotion, and tones. Machine learning was not conducted prior to analysis. Qualitative gender-neutrality in welcome messages was determined using a predefined gendered word-bank[1]. Messages were rated as strongly masculine, masculine, neutral, feminine, or strongly feminine. Statistical analyses were performed via IBM SPSS™. Gender differences in outcome measures were tested via an independent t-test.   [1] Gaucher D, Friesen J, Kay AC. Evidence that gendered wording in job advertisements exists and sustains gender inequality. J Pers Soc Psychol. 2011;101(1):109-28.

Results: AI detected no difference in sentiment or emotion (joy, anger, fear, disgust, and sadness) in GSRP websites directed by male and female PDs or in programs with more male residents, total residents, alumni, or faculty. Programs that had a greater positive sentiment displayed more joy (rp=0.542, p<0.01). Joy was weakly positively correlated with GSRPs that had a higher number of F faculty (rp=0.18, p<0.01) and total faculty (rp=0.18, p<0.01) as listed in FREIDA. An ANOVA conducted on message gender neutrality showed a significant difference between the number of authors in per neutrality group (F(4,928)=5.318, p <0.01). A Scheffe test showed a significant difference in average size between Strongly masculine text and meutral text (p<0.05), and between strongly masculine text and feminine text (p<0.05). Program sentiment was not correlated with welcome message sentiment. No difference was detected in sentiment, tone, or emotion between M and F authors. 

Conclusion: Qualitative results from welcome message analysis showed differences in gendered wording. However, an implicit male bias was not detected. We hypothesize AIs weak findings may be due to AI incompatibility or to the absence of machine learning. AI functions depend on predetermined algorithms which can be altered. Machine learning prior to analysis is being conducted for future studies to guide AI and better utilize its capabilities in analyzing bias.

abstract_title: Inguinal Hernia Repairs on the Chairman's Service: A Safe Educational Model in Resident Entrustment
author_block: M. E. Bosley<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Powell<sup>1</sup>, J. Meredith<sup>1</sup>, R. W. Randle<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine,General Surgery,Winston-Salem, NC, USA

abstract_title: The Effect of Wellness Initiatives on Well-Being and Burnout Symptoms in Surgical Residents
author_block: A. J. Counts<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Bernstein<sup>2</sup>, L. Konecny<sup>2</sup>, G. A. Sarosi<sup>1</sup> <sup>2</sup>A.T. Still University,Kirksville, MO, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida,Department Of Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Poor physician wellness and increased symptoms of burnout are associated with sub-optimal patient care, increase in medical errors, reduced physician health, and increased likelihood of abandoned or shortened surgical career.
