Although resident wellness is recognized as affecting provider health, engagement, and job satisfaction as well as patient safety and quality of care, the graduate medical education community continues to seek effective interventions to support resident physician wellness.  The purpose of this study is to better identify the effect of wellness programs on surgical resident wellness and prevention of burnout.

Methods: Qualtrics was used to collect responses to the Resident Wellness and Programming Assessment (RWPA).  Data was collected over a two-week period.  Participation was limited to a single response from each IP address, preventing collection of multiple responses from the same individual.  No identifying information was collected.  The final version of the RWPA used in this study consisted of the Brief Resident Wellness Profile (BRWP), the Physician Well-Being Index (PWBI), along with demographic data collection including gender and level of training. The RWPA included a section for respondents to indicate frequency of use of several provided wellness-supporting resources including: housestaff gym, refreshments provided in the resident lounge, same-day medical care on-campus; on-campus social events, off-campus social events, wellness didactic sessions, protected time away from work to attend to personal business (“wellness half-days”), and employee assistance program. 

Results: Analysis for the variable wellness indicated participation in wellness initiatives statistically significantly predicted wellness status, F(8, 22) = 2.424, p=0.048. Further analysis of the effect of individual wellness initiatives on wellness status indicated a statistically significant difference in wellness between residents who participated in off-campus social events, consumed snacks and drinks provided in the resident lounge, and participated in wellness didactics and residents who did not use these resources. No statistically significant difference was noted between participation groups for other wellness initiatives explored.  Analysis of the variable burnout indicated participation in wellness initiatives did not statistically significantly predict burnout status.

Conclusion: Although the graduate medical education community recognizes the need for effective wellness promotion and burnout prevention programs for resident physician, little is known about the effects of specific interventions on resident wellness.  This study suggests program- or institutionally-provided wellness resources may be effective in promoting housestaff wellness. Provided wellness resources do not appear to have similar effects on burnout in surgical residents.

abstract_title: Operating at all Levels: Association of Resident Training Year with Patient Outcomes
author_block: C. P. Fischer<sup>1,4</sup>, B. C. Brajcich<sup>2,4</sup>, M. E. Cohen<sup>4</sup>, C. Y. Ko<sup>3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Maywood, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>American College Of Surgeons,Division Of Research And Optimal Patient Care,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The optimal balance between graduated autonomy in surgical residency training and patient safety is a highly debated subject. With advancing postgraduate year (PGY), residents are afforded more operative autonomy, with the goal of being prepared for autonomous practice upon graduation. The effect of resident PGY level on patient outcomes has not been examined in large-scale, multi-institution study. Our objective was to examine the prevalence of association between resident training year and 30-day postoperative complications for four common general surgery procedures in a large national dataset.

Methods:  The National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) dataset was used to identify adult patients undergoing appendectomies, cholecystectomies, ventral hernia repairs (VHR), and inguinal hernia repairs (IHR) between 2013-2019. The Quality in Training Initiative (QITI), a corollary of NSQIP including trainee-specific information for a subset of participating hospitals, was used to identify cases in which general surgery trainees were involved. The primary outcome of interest was a composite of 30-day postoperative morbidity. The relationship between resident training year and morbidity for each operative type was analyzed with multivariable logistic regression models adjusting for clustering of patients and residents at the hospital level.

Results: In total, 167,719 patients from QITI participating institutions undergoing an appendectomy, cholecystectomy, VHR, or IHR were included. PGY1-5 general surgery resident involvement in each case type ranged from 83.0-92.8%; the remainder of included cases were performed by an attending alone. Raw rates of morbidity varied across operative types: appendectomy 3.3%, cholecystectomy 4.3%, VHR 6.0%, IHR 1.6%. After adjustment for covariates, operative risk, and clustering of patients, resident participation regardless of PGY level conferred no increased risk of morbidity in appendectomies and cholecystectomies when compared to attendings alone. VHR demonstrated increased likelihood of morbidity for PGY3 (OR 1.51, 95%CI 1.24-1.84), PGY4 (1.66, 95%CI 1.35-2.05), and PGY5 residents (1.58, 95%CI 1.31-1.91) when compared to attendings alone. IHR showed increased risk of morbidity in PGY4 only (OR 1.46 95%CI 1.04-2.04).

Conclusion: These results suggest that trainees of all PGY levels can participate in most general surgery procedures without compromising patient outcomes. Increased risk of complications in select procedures may stem from unmeasurable procedural difficulty, variable attending involvement, or increased surveillance of complications as residents advance in surgical skills. Review of such complications should be used as substrate for quality improvement education in surgical training. Further research should examine best educational practices to integrate quality improvement into training in order to best prepare residents for autonomous practice.

abstract_title: Gender, power, and implicit attitudes between surgical nurses and residents: a qualitative study
author_block: J. Woods<sup>1</sup>, J. Barrett<sup>1</sup>, A. W. Acher<sup>1</sup>, E. Alagoz<sup>1</sup>, L. C. Stafford<sup>1</sup>, C. Stahl<sup>1</sup>, P. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, T. Aiken<sup>1</sup>, S. Rivedal<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Gould<sup>1</sup>, S. Weber<sup>1</sup>, D. Abbott<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health,Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Historically, most surgeons have been men, and most nurses have been women. As more women become surgeons, however, the alignment between gender and power shifts, and the potential for new tensions arises. The purpose of this study is to explore how perceptions of gender and power influence cohesion between nurses and surgical trainees.

Methods: Six surgical residents, six surgical nurses, and five attending surgeons (both men and women) were given a series of vignettes detailing instances of interprofessional tension. They were asked follow-up questions about the role of gender on motivations and behaviors in these scenarios, to draw from their own experiences, and offer preventive strategies. In-depth interviews were conducted until thematic saturation was reached; following transcription, responses were analyzed via consensus coding by independent reviewers.

Results: Interviews revealed that some but not all residents perceived that female trainees were questioned more often by nursing staff, and that women were expected to invest more energy building relationships with the nurses than men. Most nurses preferred working with women, or residents of any gender who exhibited stereotypically female behaviors such as relationship building. Nurses expressed frustration with inappropriate behavior (poor communication, angry outbursts) when it was exhibited by residents of any gender, but felt less empowered to confront physicians who they perceived to be out of reach in the hierarchy—often, that meant men were not directly addressed. These patterns were reinforced when contextual factors (fatigue, acuity of the situation, personal confidence and approachability) were considered (Figure 1). Ultimately, effective communication was more hindered by these contextual variables in female-female interaction than male-female interaction, and trust and rapport were particularly essential for women in facilitating good communication. In most cases, the role of gender in these conflicts was subtle, but, psychologically taxing nonetheless, particularly as reported by women.

Conclusions: This type of interprofessional tension thrives when the resident and nurse do not know each other well and communication is poor. Particularly for women, building trust and rapport seems to protect against discord and encourage communication rescue. Improving lines of communication between women is, therefore, an indirect but targetable point of intervention that could improve cohesion and ultimately better patient care, whereas for male residents, nurses reported that a more common obstacle was resident approachability. Accordingly, interventions that level the hierarchy and hold men to the same interpersonal standards as women are key.

abstract_title: Resident Participation in Inguinal Hernia Repair is Safe but Increases Operative Time
author_block: A. R. Stevens<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Meier<sup>1,2</sup>, C. J. Balentine<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>VA North Texas Health Care System,Department Of Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:      Understanding how resident participation in surgery affects outcomes is critical for academic surgeons because we must balance resident independence and patient safety. The purpose of this study was to evaluate how resident participation affected outcomes for inguinal hernia repair, the most common general surgery operation in the US. We hypothesized that resident participation in hernia surgery would prolong operative time but have a minimal impact on postoperative complications.

Methods:       We conducted a retrospective cohort study of the Veterans Affairs Surgical Quality Improvement Program. We included 61,737 patients ≥ 18 years old who had elective, open, unilateral, inguinal hernia repair from 1998-2018. We used propensity weighting to compare postoperative complications and operative time for patients having surgery performed by an attending alone vs attending with a post-graduate year (PGY) 1, 3 or 5 resident.  

Results:      The cohort included 28,806 hernias (48%) repaired by an attending as the primary surgeon. Those cases were compared to 12,024 (19%) with an intern, 9,008 (15%) with a PGY-3, and 10,898 (18%) with a PGY-5 that were performed under attending supervision. Compared to cases performed by an attending alone, there was a slight increase in postoperative complications when residents participated. PGY-1 participation was associated with a 0.13% increase in complications (95% CI -0.11% to 0.38%, p=0.29) while PGY-3 participation  was associated with an increase of 0.3%, (95% CI 0.01% to 0.59%, p=0.04) and 0.4% for PGY-5’s (95% CI 0.69% to 0.11%, p< 0.001). By contrast, resident participation significantly increased operative time compared to cases performed by attendings alone. PGY-1 participation was associated with a 26 minute increase in operative time (95% CI 25 to 27, p<0.001), PGY-3 participation was associated with a 19 minute increase (95% CI 18 to 20, p<0.001), and PGY-5 with a 23 minute increase (95% CI 22 to 24, p<0.001).

Conclusion:      Resident involvement in inguinal hernia surgery was associated with a significant increase in operative time, but had only a minimal impact on postoperative complications. Since resident participation in hernia surgery is safe, surgical programs should focus on enhancing operative efficiency for residents.

abstract_title: Does Personality Testing of Surgical Residency Candidates Predict Match Results?
author_block: C. B. Cummins<sup>1</sup>, T. P. Williams<sup>1</sup>, B. D. Hughes<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Radhakrishnan<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch,Surgery,Galveston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multiple studies have demonstrated correlation between specific personality characteristics and workplace performance. Other high stress careers, like aviation, have utilized personality testing in applicant selection. Surgical training programs have demonstrated that personality testing may play a role in the identification of high-performing residents. We hypothesized that personality testing may be able to differentiate applicants who successfully matched into a categorical General Surgery position from those who matched into non-categorial positions.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of personality tests and NRMP Match results for all categorical general surgery residency applicants who interviewed at a single institution during the 2018, 2019, and 2020 Match. The Ten-Item Personality Inventory was used to describe the Big Five personality traits of extroversion, agreeableness, openness, conscientiousness, and neuroticism, with higher scores correlating to stronger association with that trait. The Grit Scale is a 12-item point scale with the maximum grit equivalent to a score of 5.  Applicants who matched into categorical general surgery positions and those who did not match into a categorical general surgery position (non-categorical), were compared using the Mann-Whitney U test. A 95% level of confidence was assumed (α=0.05).

Results: Personality testing results from a total of 375 applicants was evaluated, of which 265 were categorical and 110 were non-categorical. Analysis of the Big Five personality traits revealed that non-categorical applicants scored higher in openness than categorical applicants (p= 0.03). No significant differences were seen between groups in the traits of extroversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, or neuroticism. However, means for all traits were above the reported national average, possibly indicating a self-selected group of largely homogenous, highly motivated individuals. Although there was no statistically significant difference seen in grit score between the two groups, the comparison that non-categorical applicants had more grit than categorical applicants approached significance (p=0.08).

Conclusion: Of the Big Five personality traits, increased openness was significantly associated with non-categorical match. While increased openness is associated with spontaneity and creativeness, less openness is associated with data-driven pragmatism, which may be considered a more desirable trait in surgical residents. Additionally, a trend toward higher grit was demonstrated in the non-categorical positions, which could be related to previous studies which demonstrated lower grit scores as your career goals became more “in reach”.

abstract_title: Factors Influencing URM Medical Students Ranking of General Surgery Residency Programs
author_block: M. J. Smith<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Shehirian<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Richburg<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Iyengar<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Santos-Parker<sup>1</sup>, G. Kwakye<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Despite underrepresented minorities (URMs) making up 40% of the population, they comprise less than 7% of all academic surgeons in the United States. The 2020 General Surgery Residency Match demonstrates a variation in the number of URM interns, with >40% of URM interns in some programs, to none at others. This study aimed to identify factors that influence URM applicants’ decisions in ranking general surgery programs to inform institutions.

Methods: An 18-question survey was electronically distributed from June to July 2020 to incoming general surgery residents through targeted social media platforms and emails. Important themes were identified through a focus group of current URM medical students and PUBMED searches conducted from 2004 to 2020 combining the keywords URM+general surgery+residency. Descriptive statistics and Mann Whitney U tests were performed to determine significant factors.  

Results: 54 incoming general surgery interns completed the survey with a median age between 25-29, and 67% of whom were females. 31% of participants identified as URM. All participants rated the following factors as being very important in deciding upon their rank list order: 1) anticipated clinical experience 2) perceived morale of residents, 3) post graduate/fellowship opportunities, and 4) the feeling of being wanted at the program. URM general surgery interns were more likely to rate program benefits and finances, revisit opportunities, and post-graduate job opportunities higher than non-URM participants (p<0.05). URM participants also ranked diversity factors, like diversity of residents, diversity of faculty, and diversity and inclusion statements by programs, higher than non-URM participants (p<0.05). Additionally, women were significantly more likely to take into account the political climate at a program and the diversity of faculty and residents of a program (p<0.05).

Conclusion: These findings suggest that there is an increased importance of diversity training environment and long-term goals for URM applicants compared to their counterparts. It is important that residency programs consider this as they aim to attract more diverse applicants and create environments that best support their trainees.

abstract_title: Trends in General Surgical Resident Hepatic and Pancreatic Operative Experience
author_block: A. N. Levine<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Nordin<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Wach<sup>1</sup>, C. Cooper<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo,Buffalo, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Erie County Medical Center,Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Nonsurgical procedures and therapies have become increasingly common in the treatment of hepatic and pancreatic disease. This trend, along with resident work hour restrictions, has the potential to adversely impact general surgical resident operative experience. Previous studies have demonstrated limited resident experience with hepatopancreatobiliary operations, including complex cases specifically. We sought to examine recent trends in operative experiences among graduating surgical residents in liver and pancreatic resections, and to quantify exposure to these operations based on surgical trainee level.

Methods: We utilized American College of Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) case log reports over an 11-year period from 2008 to 2019. We examined reported total Liver and Pancreas case volumes, and specifically examined the following categories: hepatic lobectomy/segmentectomy, hepatic wedge resection/open biopsy, pancreaticoduodenectomy, and distal pancreatectomy. Cases were recorded as Surgeon Chief (SC) and Surgeon Jr (SJ). This period was divided into three groups (2008-2012, 2012-2016, 2016-2019), and change over time, as well as differences between each category, were analyzed and compared.

Results: Over this 11-year period, the overall number of liver cases increased significantly, from an average of 9.3 to 9.9 (p < 0.01); in contrast, the number of pancreas cases decreased from 11.6 to 10 (p < 0.01). These trends held true when broken down into SC and SJ groups. In each procedure category, there were more SC cases than SJ cases (p < 0.01). The average number of SC cases declined for wedge hepatectomies (1.2 v 0.7, p = 0.01), pancreaticoduodenectomies (4.0 v 3.4, p = 0.03), and distal pancreatectomies (2.1 v 1.7, p < 0.01), whereas SJ cases declined most notably among wedge hepatectomies (1.8 v 1.0, p < 0.01).

Conclusion: Over this time period, resident liver operative experiences increased, whereas pancreas cases declined, all in the context of increasing ACGME case requirements. Although advancements in non-operative management for various hepatic and pancreatic diseases offers significant benefit for patients, reductions in these operations decreases the surgical trainee’s exposure to relevant surgical anatomy and their understanding of the perioperative management of such complex cases. The association between these findings and the graduating residents’ ability to perform such operations autonomously remains unclear. Nevertheless, augmenting the resident experience in uncommon and complex surgical diseases may mitigate any adverse impacts of these trends.

abstract_title: Development and Implementation of a Surgery Podcast During the COVID-19 Outbreak
author_block: R. Anteby<sup>1,2</sup>, I. Amiel<sup>2</sup>, M. Cordoba<sup>2</sup>, D. Rosin<sup>2</sup>, R. Phitayakorn<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>The Chaim Sheba Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Ramat Gan, RAMAT GAN, Israel
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Podcasts are an increasingly common method to provide medical education. The 2019 coronavirus disease (Covid-19) pandemic dramatically reduced clinical exposure and learning opportunities for medical students. We sought to determine if a local podcast series could be created at a reasonable cost and then study its utilization for our regional medical students.

Methods:  We created a podcast series based on the Medical Student Core Curriculum of the American College of Surgeons / Association for Surgical Education. Episodes were available for free download or streaming on a designated website, as well as popular podcast platforms (Spotify, Apple Podcasts). Podcast analytics were used to measure public listeners and impact.

Results: Total development time was 81 hours at an estimated cost of $6340 USD. A total of 9 episodes were released between March 21, 2020 and June 30, 2020. An average of 9±3.3 hours (range 6-16) was required to generate each episode, including 3.3±1.3 hours (2-6) for content review and 5.8±2 hours (4-10) for audio production (recording and editing). An average episode ran for 33.67±4.5 minutes (28-42). Podcasts recorded a total of 2936 downloads, with an average of 164 and 258 downloads per episode in the first 7 and 30 days, respectively. The average daily downloads before the return of medical students to clinical rotations (March 21 - May 01 2020) was 48±58.3 (7-283;) compared to 16±7.4 after their return (1-38; p < 0.01). Listeners came from 34 countries, the three most common: Israel (86.5%), United States (2.87%), Hungary (1.82%). Estimated costs to produce a video based education series on the same topics would have been significantly more. 

Conclusion: Podcasts can serve as a cost-effective and quickly produced instructional method to supplement online learning. Further research is required to determine the efficacy of podcasts versus video-based education modules on acquisition and long-term retention of medical knowledge.

abstract_title: "Residents as Teachers" Workshops Designed by Surgery Residents for Surgery Residents
author_block: M. Kobritz<sup>1</sup>, L. Demyan<sup>1,3</sup>, A. C. Bolognese<sup>1</sup>, B. Kalyon<sup>1</sup>, V. Patel<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>North Shore University And Long Island Jewish Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Manhasset, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell,Hempstead, NEW YORK, USA <sup>3</sup>Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory,Cold Spring Harbor, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A core tenet of medical education is the expectation that senior residents will teach junior residents and medical students. However, many general surgery residency programs lack a formalized curriculum to equip trainees with necessary teaching skills. The objective of our study was to evaluate the impact of residents-as-teachers (RAT) workshops, and to assess adaptability from in-person to virtual delivery. We hypothesized that “teach the teachers” intensive courses would improve trainees’ confidence in their roles as resident-teachers. 

Methods:  The workshop curriculum was developed by residents to address four core topics based on a needs-assessment. Pre-COVID19, an in-person workshop for residents (PGY1-5) was conducted over two days, in 90-minute sessions. Post-COVID19, a virtual workshop for incoming residents (PGY1) was conducted with one 90-minute session. Topic fidelity was preserved between the two consecutive years the workshop was offered. The format was an interactive seminar consisting of lecture, small group discussion, and role-playing educational scenarios. Resident-educators were responsible for content and delivery; the program director and associate program directors served as facilitators only. A pre- and post-workshop survey was designed to evaluate residents’ confidence in four core topics. Using a 5-point Likert scale, residents and interns self-reported confidence in all four categories. A Wilcoxon test was used to compare quantitative data. 

Results: A total of 28 residents and interns and 29 interns only attended the in-person and virtual workshops, respectively. Pre- and post-workshop survey response rates were 100% and 96%, respectively. There was significant improvement in confidence in all areas following workshop attendance, except for "Teaching in the OR" (Table 1). In sub-analysis, there was a significant improvement in this category among incoming PGY1 residents post-workshop (p =0.000). The majority of PGY1 residents agreed that the workshop helped them transition into their new teaching role and strongly agreed that the resident-led workshop was effective. 

Conclusion: A resident-designed and resident-led RAT curriculum in general surgery is an effective way to improve residents’ confidence in teaching, and is well received by residents. Residents enthusiastically requested that the curriculum be integrated as a regular part of educational sessions. Given the importance of teaching medical students and junior residents in general surgery residency, we recommend the implementation of a RAT curriculum in general surgery residency and intern bootcamp. The workshop was well adapted to distance-learning format.

abstract_title: How Applicants to a General Surgery Residency Define Engagement
author_block: R. K. Shabahang<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Buonpane<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Young<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Hayek<sup>1</sup>, M. Shabahang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Health System,Danville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Employee engagement has been shown to be a crucial determinant of success across multiple industries, though its characteristics vary according to the needs and culture of each environment. The components of engagement have not yet been studied in a surgical residency, a formative workplace with arduous demands and dependence on multidisciplinary teams. The purpose of this study is to find out how applicants to a general surgery residency define engagement.  

Methods: This is a qualitative study where 91 interviews were conducted with applicants to a general surgery residency. During the institution’s standard interview process, applicants were asked how they define engagement. Responses were documented by a trained member of the study staff.  Qualitative content analysis was conducted by the research team. Research team members developed initial themes, individually coded the responses, and developed and defined the final themes using an iterative group consensus process.  

Results:  A total of 139 comments about engagement were available from 91 interviews. These responses revealed four themes: teamwork and community, motivation and productivity, common goal, and improvement. Teamwork and community consisted of responses such as “people want each other to succeed.” Motivation and productivity consisted of responses such as “showing up everyday and being willing to give 110%.” Common goal consisted of responses such as “others are committed to the same mission.” Improvement consisted of responses such as “Doing your responsibility and bettering the process in some way.”  

Conclusion:  Applicants to a general surgery residency define engagement through the lens of collective success and growth rather than personal achievement. In order to increase resident engagement, programs may consider focusing on and promoting collective causes, goals, and achievements.

abstract_title: The Chief Capstone Course: A Novel Resident Driven Curriculum for Graduating Chief Residents
author_block: E. R. Smith<sup>1</sup>, J. Yu<sup>1</sup>, L. Elmore<sup>2</sup>, B. Han<sup>1</sup>, B. Kushner<sup>1</sup>, P. Wise<sup>1</sup>, M. Klingensmith<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Washington University,Surgery,St. Louis, MO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Breast Surgical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  While much attention has been placed on preparing general surgery trainees with appropriate clinical knowledge to enter surgical practice, practical knowledge related to identifying and evaluating job opportunities, negotiating contracts, and running successful surgical practices are not emphasized in current residency curricula. Our program responded to the knowledge gap of professional development topics by supporting the development of a chief resident capstone course – a seminar series led by surgical attendings and designed by chief residents.

Methods:  A novel curriculum consisting of 5 sessions covering professional development topics was designed by our graduating chief residents through a consensus driven review process. The final curriculum represented perceived resident knowledge gaps on these topics. All nine chief residents in our general surgery program were invited to participate in these sessions. Session format was panel discussion led by surgery faculty with time for question and answer. One panel was led by an attorney and a member of our department’s business office. The sessions covered academic advancement, job search, transition to fellowship and practice, work-life balance, and contracts and negotiation. Residents were asked to complete a pre- and post-course assessment as well as evaluations for each session.

Results: In our pre-course assessment, 75% of participants stated that they had no or little confidence in the following topics:  identifying job opportunities, evaluating the quality of job opportunities, and contract negotiations. Eighty percent of completed evaluations found the sessions very useful (the highest rating). Attendance was excellent: an average of 8 of 9 total residents participated in each session. Narrative feedback from evaluations demonstrated specific appreciation for direct access to attendings’ candid insights and experiences on topics of professional development. Comparison of our pre- and post-course assessments demonstrated significant improvement in confidence around negotiating contracts, identifying mentors, and identifying research funding (p=0.038, 0.003, and 0.005 respectively).

Conclusion: The introduction of a novel resident driven curriculum to address professional development topics was well received by our graduating chief residents and was met with high session participation and engagement. Our experience demonstrates the importance of trainee “buy-in” to new curricula and that when possible, planning should directly involve stakeholder residents. To further improve the course, we will be collecting data from our graduates regarding topics of professional interest, as well as assessing those residents who participated for retention of knowledge and educational gaps.

abstract_title: Inhibition of DNA-PK Improves Response to Neoadjuvant Chemoradiotherapy in Rectal Cancer
author_block: M. G. Smithson<sup>1</sup>, R. Irwin<sup>1</sup>, K. Choi<sup>2</sup>, A. Ganguly<sup>3</sup>, A. Pepple<sup>3</sup>, C. S. Cho<sup>3</sup>, C. Willey<sup>5</sup>, J. Leopold<sup>4</sup>, K. Hardiman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Pathology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan,Radiology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Radiation Oncology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  44,180 Americans are diagnosed with rectal cancer annually. Treatment of locally advanced rectal cancer includes chemotherapy, chemoradiation, and surgery, but patient response to neoadjuvant therapy is variable. Complete response rates to chemoradiotherapy are 15-20%. Patients who have a complete response have improved outcomes. In some studies, surgery is being omitted from treatment for complete responders. There is a critical need to identify mechanisms of resistance to circumvent them. Radiation therapy causes double-strand breaks in DNA leading to cancer cell death if not repaired. DNA-PK is a complex involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. We found that phosphorylated DNA-PK (pDNA-PK) is increased in rectal cancer cells after standard of care treatment. We hypothesized that inhibiting this complex would improve treatment response. Peposertib (M3814) is a DNA-PK inhibitor and was chosen due to its clinical relevance and selectivity.

Methods:  We assessed the role of DNA-PK in the rectal cancer cell line SW837 and the immune competent CT-26 xenograft model utilizing a standard clonogenic assay, Western blotting, quantification of gamma-H2Ax staining, and measurement of treatment response. The three treatment groups were: standard of care (5-fluorouracil (5FU) (or its oral equivalent, capecitabine) with radiation) versus the DNA-PK inhibitor (Peposertib) with radiation versus Peposertib with 5FU (or capecitabine) and radiation. Peposertib was obtained through the National Cancer Institute, Cancer Therapy Evaluation Program. We implanted CT-26 cells in the flank of BALB/c mice and treated with drugs or radiation (2Gy per dose) 5 days per week for 2 weeks followed by a 1 week waiting period and tumor harvest. Tumor size was measured 3 times per week. A complete response was defined as no palpable tumor.

Results: 5FU and radiation treatment of rectal cancer cells increased pDNA-PK protein (1.63± 0.19-fold increase compared to vehicle, p=0.02) and increased H2Ax foci from 29± 12.8 % to 71.5± 6.5 % (p=0.056). In a standard clonogenic assay, Peposertib was found to be a potent DNA-PK inhibitor with a radiation enhancement ratio of 1.94. When Peposertib is added to standard of care treatment with 5FU and radiation in rectal cancer cells, the previously seen increase in pDNA-PK is abrogated (1.19-fold increase down from 1.63-fold increase). Balb/c mice with CT26 flank tumors treated with 100 mg/kg capecitabine, 2 Gy of radiation, and 50 mg/kg of Peposertib 5 days per week for 2 weeks showed a 38% complete response rate 1 week after completion of treatment compared with standard of care or other combinations which had no complete responses (N?8 mice per group; p=0.007).

Conclusion: When the DNA-PK inhibitor, Peposertib, is combined with standard of care treatment, response is improved in rectal cancer models. A clinical trial is ongoing to further explore the role of DNA-PK inhibition in rectal cancer treatment.

abstract_title: Depletion of Gut Microbiome Abrogates Tumor Promoting Effects of Smoking in Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: P. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, T. Jain<sup>1</sup>, V. Sethi<sup>1</sup>, S. Iyer<sup>1</sup>, P. Roy<sup>1</sup>, E. Bava<sup>1</sup>, M. Tarique<sup>1</sup>, J. Tao<sup>1</sup>, S. Kurtom<sup>1</sup>, U. Vaish<sup>1</sup>, B. Giri<sup>1</sup>, A. Ferrantella<sup>1</sup>, D. Edwards<sup>1</sup>, V. Dudeja<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Miami,Surgery,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Smoking is a known salient risk factor for pancreatic cancer (PDAC) but the mechanisms involved in tumor promotion is still a focus of active investigation. Our recent studies have demonstrated the role of gut-microbiome in PDAC progression. Interestingly, smoking also alters the gut-microbiota. Based on this, we hypothesize that smoking promotes PDAC progression via inducing gut-microbial dysbiosis.

Methods:  C57BL/6J, Rag1-/- mice (lack adaptive immunity) and CD8 -/- mice were randomized into four arms (controls, cigarette smoke exposure (CSE), antibiotics, and CSE + antibiotics).  Pre-exposure was given through smoking chamber for 4 weeks before subcutaneous KPC pancreatic tumor implantation. CSE was continued and tumors followed. In another experiment using KC mice (LSL-KrasG12D/+; Pdx-1-Cre), smoking analogue NNK was used to simulate smoke exposure and four groups were setup as above. Treatment was given for 2 months and animals euthanized. Additionally, smoke-naïve WT and Rag 1-/- mice underwent fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) from control or smoke-exposed mice with subsequent pancreatic tumor implantation.

Results: CSE and NNK significantly promoted tumor growth in KPC tumors and KC mice respectively. Depletion of gut-microbiome abrogated these tumor promoting effects. Mice receiving FMT from smoke-exposed mice had higher mean tumor burden than mice receiving FMT from control mice. CSE resulted in an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment (decreased CD8, CD4, activated dendritic cells; increased myeloid-derived-suppressor cells) which was reversed by gut microbiome depletion. Compared to WT mice, neither CSE nor FMT from smoke-exposed mice could increase tumors in Rag1-/- mice and CD8 -/- mice, suggesting that tumor promoting smoke-induced dysbiosis requires functional adaptive immunity. Stool analysis showed significant enrichment of genus Clostridium, Akkermansia and Anaeroplasma in smoke-treated mice. Stool metabolomics revealed significant enrichment of guanidine acetic acid, betaine and 4 hydroxy-butyric acid in smoke-exposed mice.

Conclusion: Our findings indicate a novel mechanism by which CSE increases PDAC progression through gut-microbial dysbiosis via adaptive immune-system modulation. These findings potentially unveil an untapped avenue for addressing the tumor-permissive effects of smoking by modulating gut-microbiome.

abstract_title: scRNA-seq Reveals IL1 Blockade Targets Pancreatic Cancer TICs to Improve Chemotherapeutic Response.
author_block: A. R. Dosch<sup>1</sup>, S. Singh<sup>1</sup>, X. Dai<sup>1</sup>, S. Mehra<sup>1</sup>, A. Bianchi<sup>1</sup>, I. De Castro Silva<sup>1</sup>, S. Srinivasan<sup>1</sup>, S. Banerjee<sup>1</sup>, N. Nagathihalli<sup>1</sup>, J. Datta<sup>1</sup>, N. Merchant<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami,Surgical Oncology,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Outcomes in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) have remained dismal due to resistance to cytotoxic chemotherapy. The emergence of treatment-resistant tumor initiating cells (TICs) has been shown to be a major contributor to these poor outcomes, yet therapies aimed at targeting this subpopulation are lacking. Our recent studies show that interleukin-1α (IL-1α) promotes a chemoresistant phenotype in PDAC by sustaining pro-inflammatory signaling cascades within the PDAC tumor microenvironment (TME). Therefore, the purpose of this study was to determine the efficacy of systemic IL-1 inhibition in reducing TIC subpopulations to improve the response to chemotherapy in a genetically engineered mouse model of PDAC.

Methods: Ptf1acre/+;LSL-KrasG12D/+; Tgfbr2flox/flox (PKT) mice were treated with the IL-1 inhibitor, anakinra (recombinant human IL-1 receptor anatgonist, 50 mg/kg BID), or vehicle control for 2.5 weeks prior to sacrifice. Single-cell cDNA library generation was performed using the 10× Chromium System. Expression matrices were processed using the R package Seurat 3.0 and clustered using AUC-based scoring algorithm. For survival studies, PKT mice were treated with vehicle, gemcitabine (10 mg/kg), anakinra, or combination therapy until moribund and tissues were further processed for downstream histologic analyses. To recapitulate the PDAC TME in vitro, immortalized PDAC cell lines were co-cultured with pancreatic fibroblasts to validate in vivo findings by qPCR and western blot analysis.

Results: Single-cell analysis revealed that anakinra treatment in PKT mice significantly reduced transcriptional levels of the TIC markers CD133+ (Prom1) and CD44+ (Cd44) within tumor cell subclusters. Furthermore, IL-1 inhibition decreased transcription of the canonical AP-1 signaling genes Fos and Jun downstream in the MAPK signaling cascade, which are critical nodes involved in the maintenance of the TIC phenotype. Combination treatment of anakinra with gemcitabine significantly reduced tumor weight (0.32 g vs 1.03 g, p<0.001) and improved overall survival (59 vs 47 days, p<0.0001) in PKT mice. Histologic analysis revealed a marked reduction in tumor fibrosis, decreased Ki67+ staining, and substantial reduction in the CD133+ TIC population of anakinra-treated tumors. qPCR analysis of tumor cell/fibroblast co-cultures demonstrated that anakinra treatment significantly reduced activation of the p65 NFκB and p38 MAPK cascades, resulting in a reduction in STAT3 pathway activation and decreased levels of the pluripotency markers Nanog and Prom1.

Conclusion: These findings demonstrate that IL-1 inhibition targets the chemoresistant TIC population to improve the response to gemcitabine in an immunocompetent, preclinical mouse model of PDAC. These data provide compelling translational evidence to explore anakinra in combination with chemotherapy to improve clinical outcomes in PDAC patients.

abstract_title: The Role of mTOR and PI3K in Anal Cancer Prevention in Mice
author_block: L. Gunder<sup>1</sup>, T. Moyer<sup>1</sup>, A. Auyeung<sup>1</sup>, M. Bean<sup>1</sup>, J. Chang<sup>1</sup>, M. Finlay<sup>1</sup>, M. Keating<sup>1</sup>, E. Carchman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Colorectal Surgery/General Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anal dysplasia/cancer are ever-growing health problems. Current therapies for anal dysplasia, to prevent anal cancer development, are ineffective and not well-tolerated. We have previously shown that both systemic and topical dual PI3K/mTOR inhibition can prevent anal cancer development in an HPV mouse model of anal cancer.  Our current study seeks to determine which of the two pathways (mTOR or PI3K) is more effective at cancer prevention using topical Sapansertib, an mTOR complex inhibitor, and Pictilisib, a PI3K inhibitor, in mice.

Methods:  K14E6/E7, mice that express HPV-16 E6 and E7 proteins in their epithelium, were used for these experiments. Based on our previous work with these transgenic mice, at 5 weeks of age, most mice have normal histology, at 15 weeks of age, greater than 75% of mice have low-grade dysplasia and at 20 weeks of age, greater than 75% have high-grade dysplasia. Thus, mice were started into the study at 5 weeks of age for normal histology, 15 weeks of age for low-grade dysplasia, and 25 weeks of age for high-grade dysplasia. Mice were treated locally at the anus with a topical carcinogen, (7,12-Dimethylbenz[a]anthracene (DMBA)) for 20 weeks, which promotes the development of progressive anal dysplasia to carcinoma.  For this study, mice at various ages were randomized into six treatment groups: control, DMBA only, topical Sapansertib (TAK) only, DMBA with topical TAK (DMBA+TAK), topical Pictilisib (GDC) only, DMBA with topical GDC (DMBA+GDC). The mice underwent weekly observations for anal tumor development. Fischer’s two-sided exact t-test was used to determine differences between treatment groups in tumor incidence at 20 weeks.

Results:None of the control mice or mice that received either TAK or GDC alone developed tumors, regardless of age when entering the study.  For mice starting with normal histology, those treated with DMBA alone 100% (27/27) developed overt tumors. Mice treated with topical GDC with DMBA had 100% (24/24) tumor development, like the DMBA only group (p-value=1). Only 40% (6/15) of mice treated with topical TAK and DMBA developed tumors (p-value<0.05). For mice starting with low-grade dysplasia, those treated with DMBA only 100% (16/16) developed overt tumors. 75% (15/20) of mice treated with topical GDC with DMBA had tumors (p-value=0.053) while only 40% (8/18) of TAK with DMBA developed tumors (p-value<0.05). For mice starting with high-grade dysplasia treated with DMBA alone 67% (12/18) developed overt tumors. Mice treated with topical GDC and DMBA had 86% (19/22) tumor development (p-value= 0.25) while 19% (3/16) of mice treated with topical TAK and DMBA developed tumors (p-value<0.05). 

Conclusion:Topical mTOR inhibition decreases anal cancer development in HPV transgenic mice, regardless of starting histology.

abstract_title: Deconstructing the Immune Contexture in Consensus Molecular Subtypes of Gastric Cancer
author_block: J. P. Kronenfeld<sup>1</sup>, L. Cao<sup>1</sup>, A. Dosch<sup>1</sup>, E. Vos<sup>3</sup>, D. Franceschi<sup>1</sup>, A. S. Livingstone<sup>1</sup>, V. E. Strong<sup>3</sup>, A. C. Lockhart<sup>4</sup>, W. El-Rifai<sup>1</sup>, N. B. Merchant<sup>1,5</sup>, J. Datta<sup>1,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Miami Miller School of Medicine,Division Of Surgical Oncology, Department Of Surgery,Miami, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center,Gastric And Mixed Tumor Service, Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Miami Miller School of Medicine,Division Of Medical Oncology, Department Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Miami,Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) has defined four consensus molecular subtypes in gastric cancer (GC-CMS): chromosomal instability (CIN), genomically stable (GS), microsatellite instability (MSI), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). While MSI and EBV subtypes are known to be immune-enriched and responsive to checkpoint immunotherapy, the immune contextures in CIN and GS subtypes are poorly understood. Using computational immunogenomics, we sought to identify novel immunologic vulnerabilities in GC-CMS.

Methods: TCGA gastric cancer specimens (n=226) were stratified into GC-CMS (CIN,n=112; GS,n=48; MSI,n=44; EBV,n=22). Leukocyte fractions and their association with CMS-specific genomic driver mutations were defined. Tumor-infiltrating lymphocyte (TIL) cluster/patch density were stratified by CD4+ and CD8+ T-cell proportions. Single cell immune deconvolution examined associations between 11 immune subpopulations and GC-CMS. Two independent gastric cancer datasets (n=202, 375) were used for validation.

Results: Leukocyte fraction, when normalizing for tumor/stromal fraction, was highest in EBV and MSI subtypes. Examining alterations in genomic drivers most strongly associated with relative leukocyte fraction across GC-CMS revealed distinct subtype-specific patterns. Compared with their non-mutated counterparts, mutations in KRAS (CIN/GS), RPL22 (MSI), and CTNNB1 (EBV) were significantly immune excluded (p-adj<0.001), while mutations in CDH1 (CIN/GS), PI3KR2 (MSI), and PTPRD (EBV) were significantly immune enriched (p-adj<0.001). While TIL cluster and patch density were similarly high in EBV and MSI subtypes, relative T-cell compositional analysis revealed a predominant CD8+:CD4+ ratio in EBV, but disproportionate CD4+:CD8+ infiltrate in MSI, tumors. On single cell deconvolution, EBV and MSI tumors were enriched in effector immune contextures-cytotoxic CD8+ T-cells, T-helper type-1 CD4+ T-cells, natural killer cells, and dendritic cells. CIN tumors demonstrated a regulatory contexture-regulatory T-cells, neutrophils, and T-helper type-17 cells-while GS tumors were associated with a tolerogenic contexture-M2-like macrophages, T-helper type-2 cells, and T-follicular helper T-cells (Figure). The correlation between these immune contextures and GC-CMS was validated in two independent datasets.

Conclusion: Deconstructing immune contextures in GC-CMS using computational immunogenomics reveals distinct subtype-specific genomic correlates of immune exclusion and enrichment. Tumor-infiltrating immune populations in CIN and GS subtypes differ broadly from those in EBV/MSI tumors. Targeting suppressive immune subsets in CIN and GS tumors, typically resistant to checkpoint immunotherapy, may yield novel therapeutic opportunities.

abstract_title: The role of ROR-γ t in modulation of the anti-tumor immune response in triple negative breast cancer
author_block: X. L. Baldwin<sup>1</sup>, N. Makhanova<sup>1</sup>, S. Downs Canner<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) has the highest immune infiltrate and tumor mutational burden of all breast cancer subtypes however, trials with checkpoint inhibitors (CI) have been modestly successful. Targeting regulatory T-cells (Tregs), in combination with CI, has therapeutic benefit in cancer. Tregs demonstrate plasticity and exist on a continuum of suppressive capabilities. Th17 cells have been shown to demonstrate conversion to suppressive Tregs in colon and ovarian tumor microenvironments.  The transcription factor ROR-γt is essential for Th17 cell lineage. We hypothesized that mice deficient in ROR-γt would demonstrate reduced tumor growth in a murine TNBC model due to altered Treg phenotype and/or tumor infiltration.

Methods: E0771 tumors were characterized by whole genome sequencing. 1x105 E0771 cells were implanted in mammary fat pads of C57/Bl6 (control) and RORγt-/- mice. Tumor volumes were estimated using calipers. Multicolor flow cytometry and rtPCR was performed from spleen and tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes at serial timepoints. Single-cell sequencing of fresh human tumors was performed using the 10X genomics platform to create barcoded cDNA libraries which were then sequenced on the Illumina NovaSeq 6000.

Results:The E0771 breast cancer cell line demonstrated a claudin-low (TNBC) gene expression profile. In RORγt-/-, growth of E0771 tumors was not different than control mice at 3 weeks, but RORγt-/- mice demonstrated accelerated growth at 2 weeks post-tumor implantation (Fig 1a). There were no differences in percentage of Tregs in spleens or tumor infiltrate by flow cytometry at 7, 14, and 21 days post-tumor implantation. At 3 weeks, there was a trend toward increased percentage of exhausted CD8+ T cells (CD8+PD1+) in the RORγt-/- mice, which corresponded to a point at which growth curves converged (Fig 1b). In the tumors of RORγt-/- mice, there was significantly reduced expression of checkpoint molecules Ox40 and CTLA4, but not PD-1 (as measured by rtPCR) at 3 weeks post-tumor implantation and reduced expression of CCR8, a marker of Treg associated immunosuppression. Spleens of tumor-bearing (but not naïve) RORγt-/- mice demonstrated significantly increased expression of Helios, a marker of Treg stability and suppressive capacity. Helios+ Tregs were found only in human TNBC tumors and not in hormone-receptor positive tumors. 

Conclusion:RORγt modulates anti-tumor immune response in murine models of TNBC, through altered expression of checkpoint molecules and transcription factors Helios and CCR8. Further studies to understand how RORγt impacts response to CI may provide insight into opportunities to develop new adjuncts to existing immunotherapies.

abstract_title: Identification of CD105+ Extracellular Vesicles as a Candidate Biomarker in Metastatic Breast Cancer
author_block: S. Halasz<sup>1</sup>, S. Blair<sup>1</sup>, K. Yeung<sup>1</sup>, J. Yang<sup>1</sup>, O. Cohen<sup>1</sup>, B. Eliceiri<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego,La Jolla, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Extracellular vesicles (EVs) released by malignant tumor cells can remodel the tumor microenvironment, travel through the bloodstream, and modulate the immune response. Thus, analysis of EVs from plasma is emerging as a possible cancer surveillance tool with some advantages over alternative liquid biopsy methods. The aim of this pilot study was to identify possible EV signatures corresponding with metastatic breast cancer.

Methods: Under an IRB-approved protocol for the analysis of patient plasma, samples were collected from participants with newly diagnosed or progressive metastatic breast cancer (n=16) and healthy volunteers (n=13). Plasma was processed using serial centrifugation yielding 50-150 nm EVs and analyzed with a bead-based multiplex (Miltenyi Biotec) for the detection of 37 distinct tumor-relevant epitopes and isotype controls. Mean fluorescence of EV epitopes meeting a preset minimum threshold of detectability was compared between the cancer patient and healthy control group using an independent samples t-test. Subgroup analysis was also conducted for metastatic breast cancer patients who were double positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER2 (ER/PR+HER2-, n=8). 

Results: In a survey of 37 proteins expressed on EVs, we detected CD105 in all plasma samples with a significantly higher mean fluorescence in patients with metastatic breast cancer compared to controls (p=0.04, Figure A). Subgroup analysis with inclusion of only ER/PR+HER2- breast cancer patients compared to controls revealed a similar pattern with higher significance (p=0.01, Figure B).  

Conclusions: We observed that CD105 is significantly increased on breast cancer patient EVs compared to controls. Given that CD105 is known to mediate angiogenesis and promote metastasis, EV-associated CD105 represents a potential biomarker for diagnosis and surveillance as well as a therapeutic target in patients with metastatic breast cancer.

abstract_title: Changes in Innate Immunity and the Bone Marrow Transcriptomic Response to Anemia After Blunt Trauma
author_block: L. S. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Apple<sup>1</sup>, K. B. Kannan<sup>1</sup>, D. B. Darden<sup>1</sup>, E. E. Pons<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Brakenridge<sup>1</sup>, P. A. Efron<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Mohr<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Florida,Department Of Surgery, Center For Sepsis And Critical Illness Research,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Severe blunt trauma is associated with severe systemic inflammation and neuroendocrine activation that is associated with erythroid progenitor growth suppression and persistent injury-associated anemia. Subsequent poor outcomes after trauma are related to both the presence of severe anemia and the need for transfusion. In this study, we hypothesize that the bone marrow transcriptome of blunt trauma patients is altered when compared to elective hip replacement patients and there is a distinct bone marrow response to anemia.

Methods: Bone marrow was obtained in a prospective observational cohort study from severely injured blunt trauma patients with a hip or femur fracture (n=52) and compared to the bone marrow of elective hip replacement patients (n=33) and healthy controls (n=8). RNA was isolated from bone marrow using a Purelink RNA mini kit. Direct quantification of gene counts using customized fluorescent probes was performed by NanoString Technologies. Data presented as log2 fold change relative to healthy controls with significance set at *p<0.05.

Results: When compared to both hip replacement patients and healthy controls, severe blunt trauma led to significant upregulation of genes encoding receptors known to have inhibitory downstream effects on erythropoiesis, including ferroportin, IL-6 receptor, and TGF-β receptor, as well as genes involved in the innate immune system including IL-1b and TLR4-mediated signaling factors (Figure). Trauma patients also demonstrated upregulation in IL-10 transcription which was not seen following hip replacement and has been linked to erythropoietin resistance as well as regulation of the immune response. Whereas, hip replacement patients had downregulation of genes encoding for IL-1b, IL-6, TGF-β, TNFα, and hepcidin (Figure) and there was no significant change in TLR4-mediated signaling factors.

Conclusion: Differences in the bone marrow transcriptomic response to anemia were identified following severe blunt trauma and elective hip replacement. These differences in the bone marrow transcriptome were related to the innate immune response as well as known inhibitors of erythropoiesis which may explain why blunt trauma patients have a suboptimal erythropoietic response to anemia which persists for months after injury.

abstract_title: Plant-Based Nutrition Preserves Anti-Inflammatory Colonic Macrophages in Murine Colitis
author_block: R. G. Ramos<sup>1</sup>, A. Bhattacharjee<sup>2</sup>, J. Tian<sup>2</sup>, B. Firek<sup>2</sup>, G. Wu<sup>2</sup>, M. Rogers<sup>2</sup>, A. Sheppeck<sup>2</sup>, T. Hand<sup>2</sup>, M. J. Morowitz<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg,General Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Pittsburgh Of UPMC,Pediatric General And Thoracic Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Although enteral formulas are the cornerstone of nutritional therapy in the ICU, little attention has been devoted to their contents or their effects on the immune system or the microbiome. Published results from our lab show that when compared to conventional enteral nutrition (CEN), plant-based enteral nutrition (PBEN) significantly decreases intestinal inflammation and preserves beneficial fiber-degrading anaerobes in the gut. We have also shown that germ-free animals on PBEN are not protected from colitis. With these results in mind, we hypothesized that PBEN improves outcomes in colitis via microbiome-mediated effects on macrophage function.

Methods: Six groups (n=4 per group) of C57BL/6 male mice were fed either CEN or PBEN for 7 days. On day 8, one CEN and one PBEN group began 4% Dextran Sodium Sulfate (DSS) while one CEN and one PBEN group underwent both DSS and macrophage depletion. Macrophage depletion was achieved by intraperitoneal clodronate injection and confirmed by immunohistochemistry. The remaining CEN and PBEN group received clodronate injections without DSS. Weight, stool consistency, and fecal occult blood were tested daily to calculate disease activity index (DAI). A t-test was used to compare mean values. Colonic lamina propria macrophages of animals on PBEN or CEN undergoing DSS and PBEN or CEN without DSS were analyzed with flow cytometery (LSRFortessa and FlowJo software). Surface expression of CD45, Ly6C, MHC-II, CD11b, CX3CR1, and CD11c was used to identify colonic macrophages. These macrophages were subjected to LPS stimulation and IL-10, IL-1, and TNFa were measured. In order to exclude the effects of adaptive immunity, we performed our 4% DSS model on two groups of Rag1 -/- animals (n=4) on either CEN or PBEN.

Results: PBEN but not CEN protected against colitis in mice lacking B and T cells (Rag1-/- ). However, PBEN did not protect against colitis in macrophage depleted animals (p <0.05). Flow cytometry of animals with intact immune function on DSS showed that when compared with CEN fed mice, PBEN animals had greater populations of anti-inflammatory P4 mature macrophages (CD11b hi, CX3CR1 hi, Ly6C lo, MHC-II+), moderately differentiated P3/P5 population (CD11b hi, CX3CR1 int, Ly6C lo, MHC-II+), and a statistically significant increase in IL-10 production.

Conclusion: Our results indicate that PBEN protects against gut inflammation, which is common during critical illness, via effects on both the gut microbiome and intestinal macrophages. It appears that PBEN but not CEN preserves monocyte to macrophage maturation and IL-10 expression in the lamina propria (Figure). Further translational research is required to study the impact of enteral formulas on clinical outcomes in human ICU patients.

abstract_title: Propranolol Administration May Improve Hippocampal-Dependent Behavioral Outcomes in a Murine Model
author_block: K. E. Singer<sup>1</sup>, M. C. Morris<sup>1</sup>, T. E. Wallen<sup>1</sup>, E. McGlone<sup>1</sup>, R. Schuster<sup>1</sup>, L. Friend<sup>1</sup>, L. England<sup>1</sup>, S. Stevens-Topie<sup>1</sup>, M. Goodman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Propranolol treatment has been shown to improve patient outcomes after traumatic brain injury (TBI). Non-traumatic models have shown that propranolol can decrease the accumulation of phosphorylated tau (pTau), a protein implicated in post-TBI encephalopathy. However, the role of propranolol following polytrauma has not been established. We hypothesized that propranolol administration after a combined injury of TBI and hemorrhagic shock would reduce the accumulation of pTau in the hippocampus and its adverse impact the on memory.

Methods: Male C57BL6 mice sustained a moderately severe TBI with an established murine weight drop model. Sham TBI mice were anesthetized without head injury. Hemorrhagic shock (HS) was induced immediately post-TBI to a mean arterial pressure of 25mmHg and sustained for 60 minutes. TBI/HS mice were then resuscitated with shed blood to baseline mean arterial pressure. Sham hemorrhage mice were cannulated at the femoral artery but not hemorrhaged. Following resuscitation, mice were administered propranolol 4mg/kg or saline control via intraperitoneal injection. At 30 days post-trauma, mice underwent a four-day Morris water maze training activity. Each mouse had 60 seconds to find the clear platform that was placed in a large water bath. This process was immediately repeated with the mouse being released from a second location in the water bath. Mice were retested on the water maze after a two-day rest. Mouse brains were then harvested for immunofluorescence.

Results: Immunofluorescence demonstrated increased pTau accumulation in the hippocampus of TBI/sham HS mice compared to sham controls. TBI/HS mice demonstrated significantly increased accumulation of pTau compared to TBI/sham HS, as well as non-TBI controls. TBI/HS mice treated with propranolol, however, showed a significant decrease in pTau accumulation (Figure). These results were recapitulated in the behavioral analysis, with sham/sham HS, TBI/sham HS demonstrating significant improvements in their time to platform identification. While TBI/hemorrhage mice did not improve their time to platform, TBI/hemorrhage mice treated with propranolol did (Figure).  

Conclusion: The addition of HS to TBI significantly increased the accumulation of pTau in the hippocampus and induced impaired memory performance. Propranolol decreased the accumulation of hippocampal pTau while improving swim test performance. Interestingly, hemorrhage alone was insufficient to produce hippocampal pTau, but showed impaired performance on the swim test, indicating global hypoperfusion of the hippocampus may produce a similar behavioral phenotype as shown in TBI without associated markers of encephalopathy.

abstract_title: Inhibition of PKA Signaling in the Liver Prevents Stress-Induced Hyperglycemia in Trauma
author_block: A. E. Garcia Whitlock<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Gavin<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Baur<sup>2,3</sup>, C. A. Sims<sup>4</sup>, P. M. Titchenell<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Institute For Diabetes, Obesity, And Metabolism, Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Physiology, Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Ohio State University,Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, And Burn, Wexner Medical Center,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Critically ill trauma patients are at increased risk of delayed death due to multiple organ failure (MOF). An intervention that may reduce MOF is controlling stress-induced hyperglycemia (SIH). SIH is a state of elevated blood glucose after injury or illness that is associated with MOF and mortality in critical illness and trauma. SIH is typically attributed to insulin resistance as maintaining euglycemia via exogenous insulin improves outcomes, however, other metabolic derangements in trauma likely contribute to the development of SIH. In particular, glucagon and epinephrine increase in trauma. Normally these hormones increase in fasting or stress to promote hepatic glucose production; and excess glucagon has been implicated in the pathogenesis of hyperglycemia in Type II Diabetes. Both factors activate protein kinase A (PKA) in liver which leads to the phosphorylation of several proteins involved in promoting hepatic glucose production. Thus we hypothesized that PKA signaling is increased in SIH and that inhibition of PKA in liver will prevent SIH.

Methods: We used an established mouse model of trauma known as fixed pressure trauma and hemorrhage (TH) to recapitulate SIH and evaluate PKA signaling in a baseline cohort of mice. This protocol includes laparotomy, bilateral placement of femoral artery catheters, and 90 minutes of hemorrhage-induced hypotension monitored via arterial line. Blood and livers were collected before and after 90 minutes hemorrhage (TH0 versus TH90, respectively). PKA signaling in liver was evaluated by Western Blot. The TH protocol was then repeated in mice bearing a liver-specific dominant-negative inhibitory mutant of the regulatory subunit of PKA (L-PKA-DN) so that signaling by PKA was suppressed in liver. GFP-injected littermates served as controls.

Results: Glucose and insulin increased at TH90 following trauma and hemorrhage consistent with SIH (n=11, p<0.0001). As predicted, hepatic PKA signaling increased at TH90 compared to TH0 in this baseline cohort. When hepatic PKA signaling was blocked via the PKA-DN mutation, L-PKA-DN mice had lower glucose levels overall and no longer exhibited SIH (Figure 1, n=6-7, p<0.0001). Namely L-PKA-DN mice average glucose was 95 mg/dL compared to 315 mg/dL in controls. Interestingly, L-PKA-DN mice still exhibited hyperinsulinemia at TH90.

Conclusion: This work demonstrates that PKA signaling is increased following trauma and hemorrhage and significantly contributes to SIH. Given both glucagon and epinephrine signal via PKA, future work will determine their relative contribution to SIH and whether blockade of these hormones, in particular glucagon, can be used in conjunction with insulin to reduce MOF and mortality in trauma via suppression of SIH.

abstract_title: Tranexamic Acid Modulates Innate and Adaptive Immunity in a Murine Model of Traumatic Brain Injury
author_block: C. B. Bergmann<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Singer<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Caldwell<sup>1</sup>, M. D. Goodman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Department Of Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Early post-injury administration of tranexamic acid (TXA) has been shown to reduce mortality in traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients. Previous work demonstrated that TXA reduced the numbers of post-traumatic splenic T cell populations after 24h. Currently, the characteristics of immunologic alterations upon 1) leukocyte activation and function, 2) myeloid and T cell numbers with and without TXA treatment following TBI are not well understood.  We hypothesized that TXA administration post-TBI modulates the immune response independently of injury itself.

Methods: Male C57Bl/6 mice were subjected to a concussive weight drop TBI of moderate severity (400 g weight, 2 cm height, n=5-10 per group). Saline control, 10 mg/kg or 100 mg/kg TXA was administered intraperitoneally 5 min after TBI. Whole blood and spleens were collected at 10 min, 1 h, 6 h, 24h, 7d or 30d after injury. Cell counts were obtained, and leukocytes were characterized using flow cytometry. Activation was assessed using CD11b, ICAM1 for myeloid cells and CD69 for T cells. Blood leukocyte TNF-α production was assessed by ELISPOT.

Results: When sham treatment was compared with TBI injured mice, the proportion of circulating neutrophils at 1h increased from 4.0% to 14.8%. Neutrophil and monocyte activation were not significantly changed. Blood leukocyte TNF-α production was decreased by approximately 2.5-fold at 6h. The administration of TXA after TBI increased neutrophil percentages at 24h from 1.9% to 8.7% but impaired their activation at 1h by decreasing the percentage of ICAM1+ cells from 55.0% to 45.7% and after 30d the MFI of CD11b from 74,638 to 42,139. The TBI injury alone compared with sham mice showed CD4 T cells were only transiently decreased in their activation at 6h as the percentage of CD69+ cells dropped from 62.2% to 47.1%. However, CD4 T cell phenotypes displayed higher percentages of effector type cells after 24h from 5.2% to 10.3% and after 30d from 5.0% to 16.1%. Notably, TXA administration after TBI activated CD4 T cells at 24h by increasing the percentage of CD69+ cells from 40.3% to 51.9% but did not alter the immune response at 30d. Interestingly, none of these differences were observed with higher TXA dose (100mg/kg).

Conclusion: Overall, these results reveal that following an initial neutrophil increase at 1h post TBI, innate immune activation is subsequently depressed. Overall T cell numbers are depressed at 6h after TBI but the effector phenotype remains elevated at 30d post TBI. More importantly, the results demonstrate that TXA in TBI injury accelerates the resolution of the innate immune response, while preventing T cell immune exhaustion. Although more studies are needed, these findings suggest that TBI patients receiving low dose TXA treatment may have a reduced pro-inflammatory response, while maintaining an effective T cell reservoir needed to combat potential subsequent infections.

abstract_title: Genetic deletion of ADAMTS13 increases the severity of acute kidney injury in a murine model of TBI
author_block: R. T. Russell<sup>1</sup>, L. He<sup>1</sup>, W. Cao<sup>4</sup>, L. M. Curtis<sup>2</sup>, A. Agarwal<sup>2</sup>, X. L. Zheng<sup>4</sup>, J. F. Pittet<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Pediatric Surgery/Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Nephrology/Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Anesthesiology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>4</sup>The University of Kansas Health System,Pathology And Laboratory Medicine,Kansas City, KS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Increases in plasma von Willebrand Factor (VWF) and decrease in its respective cleaving metalloprotease ADAMTS13 (A13) leads to microvascular thrombosis and has been implicated in multiple disease processes. We have recently demonstrated that pediatric trauma patients with severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) have markedly low A13 levels and increased mortality. To further understand the role of VWF/A13 axis on microvascular beds following trauma, we tested a hypothesis that acute kidney injury (AKI) would be more significant following controlled cortical impact (CCI) in those lacking A13.

Methods:  Wild-type (WT) and A13-/- mice underwent CCI to simulate severe TBI. Prior to and following head injury, transdermal glomerular filtration rate (GFR), renal injury markers normalized by creatinine (NGAL & TIM-1), and histologic assessments were performed. Standard statistical methods were applied.

Results: WT and A13 -/- mice have similar GFR,  urine and plasma NGAL and urine Tim-1 levels prior to head injury. Following head injury, A13 -/- mice showed significantly decreased GFR at 24 hours and significantly increased plasma and urine NGAL and urine Tim-1 levels at 6 and 24 hours following head injury (Fig 1, A-C). In addition, histologic sections of kidneys from both groups demonstrated a significant increase in composite injury score in A13 -/- mice at 6 and 24 hours following the head injury (p< 0.05) (Fig 1D)

Conclusions: Genetic deletion of ADAMTS13 is associated with a more severe AKI in a murine model of TBI based on functional GFR, renal injury markers, and histologic assessments of the renal function.

abstract_title: Rapid Immune Testing to Determine Source Control
author_block: C. Salyer<sup>1</sup>, P. A. Crisologo<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Caldwell<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Division Of Research, Department Of Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the intensive care setting, source control is a primary defense strategy against unchecked sepsis. However, it can be difficult to discern if adequate source control has been obtained.  The innate immune system is exquisitely sensitive to infection. Of the innate cells involved, neutrophils are specifically geared to respond to bacterial infection. It has been demonstrated that uncontrolled sepsis increases the number and function of circulating neutrophils. In contrast, T cell numbers and function are decreased. Here, we utilized two murine models of sepsis, one with and one without proper source control. We hypothesize that leukocyte populations and functions can be used to determine systemic infection and adequate source control.

Methods: Male outbred mice underwent 50% cecal ligation with a single 18-gauge puncture. Upon overt signs of sepsis, a subgroup underwent debridement of the necrotic cecum, abdominal cavity lavaged, and intraperitoneal antibiotics administered. At 24 hours, blood leukocytes were collected, enumerated by cell counter, and characterized by flow cytometry. Leukocytes were functionally interrogated for TNFa and IL-2 production by ELISPOT. Phagocytosis was assessed by using pHrodo labeled e. Coli. Blood CFUs were enumerated to confirm both sepsis and adequate source control between groups. One-way ANOVA was used for statistical comparison and p values of less than 0.05 were considered significant.

Results: Flow cytometric analysis demonstrated significantly decreased numbers of total and naïve circulating CD4 and CD8 T cells in septic mice as compared with source-controlled mice (p=0.001). Further, T cells from septic mice demonstrated an approximate 3-fold decrease in IL-2 production after TCR stimulation as compared to healthy and source-controlled mice (p<0.05). Although neutrophil numbers were not significantly different between all groups, neutrophil proportions and their phenotype in whole blood were significantly changed. Phagocytosis was significantly decreased in septic mice as compared to the source control group and untouched controls (p=0.0006). TNFa production was significantly increased in spot size, number, and ratio of change after LPS stimulation for source-control versus septic mice, and was no different than untouched controls. (p=0.01).

Conclusion: Here, we demonstrate that if source control is obtained in a timely manner, systemic immune function returns to that of a healthy subject. These observations may underly an expedient method to clinically determine adequate source control as well in aiding for introducing or terminating antibiotic support in the critically ill patient.

abstract_title: Trends and Burden of Firearm Injuries Among Children and Adolescents: A National Perspective
author_block: E. Toriah<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Hussein<sup>1</sup>, S. Taghavi<sup>1</sup>, P. R. McGrew<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine,Surgery,New Orleans, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite recent national attention on deaths from firearms, little information exists about children and adolescents who are hospitalized with firearm injuries. The objective of the current study was to determine the national frequency of firearm-related hospitalizations in the United States and examined clinical and demographic risk factors associated with readmission in this young population. 

Methods: The National Readmission Database (NRD) was examined from 2010-2017. Young patients ≤18 years old who survived their index hospitalization with any firearm injury were analyzed. Incidence and annual injury case-fatality rates were estimated. Causes, predictors, and healthcare burden of 30-days readmission were assessed.

Results: A total of 35,753 children/adolescents had firearm injury, with 86.8% male, and an overall incidence rate of 10.49 (95%CI=9.26-11.71) per 100,000. Across different age groups, 30,549 hospitalizations due to firearm injury (85.4%) were reported in adolescents over 12 years old with incidence rate of 60.51 (95%CI=55.19-65.84) per 100,000 patients, 6 times more than the estimates for toddlers and children (10.79; 95% CI=9.46-12.12). In-hospital mortality was reported in 1,948 cases (5.5%). Case-fatality was higher in males (44.4 per 1000, 95% CI: 39.5-49.4) than females (8.5 per 1000, 95%CI=6.3-10.7). Of those discharged alive, 1,616 (5.7%) had unscheduled readmission at 30-days, and nearly half of them (49.3%) were re-hospitalized in the first week. Multivariate analysis showed abdominal firearm injuries (HR=1.13, 95%CI=1.03-1.24, p=0.006) and length of stay less than a week (HR=1.27, 95%CI=1.04-1.55, p=0.016) were associated with higher risk of 30-days readmission. The median length of hospital stay was 7 days (IQR=4-14 days) at primary admission and 4.0 days (IQR=2.0-7.0 days) at readmission. Median total cost of hospital care for firearm-related injuries was $36,535 (IQR=$19,802-$66,443), 22% of which was due to readmissions. Cost associated with 30-days readmissions was $7,978 (IQR=$4,305-$15,202).

Conclusion: Whereas suicide has often been cited as a frequent cause of firearm related death, our findings suggest that assault is a primary contributor to firearm related admissions. Males were disproportionately affected in hospital admissions and in-hospital deaths, suggesting that this population may benefit from targeted preventative interventions.

abstract_title: Is Over Triage with Blood Okay? An Analysis of Minimal Blood Transfusions from the PROPPR Trial
author_block: R. B. Gelbard<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Kerby<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>2</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery/Trauma,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Surgery/Trauma,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Early identification and management of massive hemorrhage with blood improves mortality after severe injury. However, unnecessary exposure to blood products has been associated with a higher risk of complications. We sought to evaluate patient outcomes after early, small volume blood transfusion in the setting of presumed hemorrhagic shock. We hypothesized that over triage with even small amounts of blood would be associated with a higher incidence of complications.

Methods:  We performed a secondary analysis of the PROPPR trial. Trauma patients who were predicted to require massive transfusion and survived ≥ 72 hours were stratified according to units (U) of packed red blood cells (RBC) transfused: 1-3, 4-6, 7-9, 10-14, 15-19, and ≥20. Demographic and injury characteristics were compared among groups utilizing a chi-square and ANOVA for categorical and continuous variables, respectively.
