A Cox proportional hazards model stratified by ISS dichotomized at <16 and ≥16 was used to estimate hazard ratios for the association between RBC transfusion category and adverse events, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), multiple organ failure (MOF), acute lung injury (ALI), and mortality. Interactions with time were used to assessed the proportionality assumption of the Cox model, and models were adjusted for blunt injury mechanism, and pulse ≥120bpm at ED admission. 

Results: Among 553 included patients, 11.6% (n=64) were transfused 1-3U, 23.3% (n=129) 4-6U, 24.6% (n=136) 7-9U, 17.7% (n-98) 10-14U, 8.5% (n=47) 15-19U, and 14.3% (n=79) ≥20U of RBCs. Patients transfused 1-3U had the lowest mean ISS (p<0.0001). They were less likely to have blunt injury (p=0.0016) or head AIS ≥3 (p=0.0308), and more likely to have a chest (p=0.0443), abdomen (p=0.0099), or extremity (p<0.0001) AIS ≥3.  The proportion of patients in each group with an ABC score of >2 ranged from 60-70% (p=0.8). There was a significantly lower incidence of any complication in the 1-3U group (p<.0001): only 1/63 (1.6%) had VAP or ALI and 0 patients developed ARDS or MOF.  Compared to patients receiving >10U, those transfused 1-3U were less likely to have sepsis and ALI (p<0.05). Compared to patients transfused ≥20U, the 1-3U group had a lower risk of sepsis, AKI, ALI, and death (all p<0.05).

Conclusion: In the absence of highly specific, rapid tools for definitive diagnosis of hemorrhagic shock, early empiric transfusion is often based on clinical judgment and may subject patients to over triage with blood. Among patients meeting current clinical triggers for massive transfusion, receiving 1-3 units of allogeneic blood does not appear to be associated with adverse outcomes.

abstract_title: Open vs. Laparoscopic Repair of Traumatic Diaphragmatic Injury: A Nationwide Matched Analysis
author_block: O. Obaid<sup>1</sup>, M. Chehab<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, S. Asmar<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, M. Khurrum<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, B. Joseph<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Minimally invasive surgical techniques have become routinely applied in the evaluation and treatment of patients with isolated diaphragmatic injuries after trauma. However, there remains a paucity of data that compares the laparoscopic repair to the open repair approach. Our study aimed to examine patient outcomes after undergoing either of the two different surgical approaches.

Methods:  Adult (age ≥18 years) trauma patients presenting with diaphragmatic injury that required surgical repair were identified in the Trauma Quality Improvement Program 2017. Patients were excluded if they underwent any other surgical procedure of the abdomen or chest. Patients were then stratified into two groups based on the surgical approach: laparoscopic repair of the diaphragm vs. open repair. Propensity-score matching in a 1:2 ratio was performed based on patients’ age, BMI, vital signs at presentation, mechanism of injury, injury severity score (ISS), and diaphragmatic injury side and type. Primary outcome measures were in-hospital major complications (surgical site infections (SSI), sepsis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), acute kidney injury (AKI), and return to the operating room (OR)) and length of stay (LOS). Secondary outcome measure was in-hospital mortality.

Results: A total of 177 adult trauma patients who had a laparoscopic repair of their isolated diaphragmatic injury were matched to 354 patients who had an open repair. Mean age was 36 ± 15 years, 78% were male, and mean BMI was 28 ± 7 kg/m2. 68% of the patients had penetrating injuries with a median ISS of 22 [20-27]. CT imaging was done in 67% of the patients, with 71% presenting with left-sided injury and 21% having visceral herniation. Conversion from laparoscopic to open was reported in 7.2% of the cases. Patients with a laparoscopic repair had significantly lower rates of major complications (5.9 vs. 14.4%; p < 0.001), shorter hospital LOS (6[3-9] vs. 9[5-13] days; p < 0.001) and ICU LOS (3 [2-7] vs. 5[2-10] days; p=0.003). No difference was found in rates of in-hospital mortality (0.6 vs. 2.3%; p=0.130) between the two groups.

Conclusion: Laparoscopic repair of traumatic diaphragmatic injury was associated with decreased morbidity and a shorter hospital course, with a low conversion rate to open repair. Future studies remain necessary to further explore long-term outcomes of patients with such injury.

abstract_title: Using State Data to Predict a Single Institution Mortality for Patients That Fall
author_block: A. J. Young<sup>1,2</sup>, E. Kaufman<sup>1</sup>, A. Hare<sup>1</sup>, M. Subramanian<sup>1</sup>, J. Keating<sup>1</sup>, J. Byrne<sup>1</sup>, A. Helkin<sup>1,2</sup>, D. Scantling<sup>1</sup>, D. Poliner<sup>1</sup>, C. Sims<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Falls are the most common cause of injury-related death for patients older than 45.  We hypothesized that a machine learning algorithm developed from state-level registry data could make accurate outcome predictions at a level 1 trauma hospital.

Methods:  Data for all patients admitted for fall injury during 2009-2019 in the state of Pennsylvania were derived from the state trauma registry.  Thirteen variables that were immediately available upon patient arrival were used for prediction modeling.  Data for the test institution were withheld from model creation.  Algorithms assessed included logistic regression (LR), random forest (RF), and extreme gradient boost (XGB).  Model discrimination for mortality was assessed with area under the curve (AUC) for each algorithm at our level 1 trauma center.

Results: 180,284 patients met inclusion criteria.  The mean age was 69 years ± 18.5 years with a mortality rate of 4.0%.  The AUC for predicting mortality in patients that fall for LR, RF, and XGB were 0.797, 0.876, and 0.880, respectively.  The variables which contributed to the prediction in descending order of importance for XGB were respiratory rate, pulse, systolic blood pressure, ethnicity, weight, sex, age, temperature, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) eye, race, GCS voice, GCS motor, and blood alcohol level.

Conclusion: An extreme gradient boost model developed using state-wide trauma data can accurately predict mortality after fall at a single center within the state.  This machine learning model can be implemented by local trauma systems within the state of Pennsylvania to identify patients injured by fall that require greater attention, transfer to a higher level of care, and higher resource allocation.

abstract_title: Angiopoietin-2 Levels Correlate with Fibrinolysis and Predict Thrombotic Events after Trauma
author_block: D. M. Joiner<sup>2</sup>, R. P. Richter<sup>3</sup>, J. S. Richman<sup>4</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Richter<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Acute Care Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Pediatrics,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,General Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Plasma angiopoietin-2 (Ang-2) levels increase during states of inflammation and reflect an activated vascular endothelium. We have previously demonstrated that elevated plasma Ang-2 levels are associated with coagulation abnormalities in trauma patients with hemorrhagic shock, but the relationship of Ang-2 with fibrinolysis and thrombotic complications after trauma is unknown. The objective of this study was to evaluate the relationship of plasma Ang-2 with markers of fibrinolysis and thrombotic events (TE) following trauma-hemorrhage in a secondary analysis of data from the PROPPR trial.

Methods:  We included data from patients for whom hemostasis was achieved and admission Ang-2 measurements were available. Fibrinolysis was characterized by thromboelastography (TEG) lysis at 30 min (Ly30) and plasma levels of D-Dimer, plasmin-antiplasmin (PAP) and tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). Spearman’s correlations were assessed between Ang-2 levels and fibrinolysis at admission and 72h. TE were categorized as occurring within or after 3 days of injury. The predictive characteristics of TEG Ly30, TEG maximum amplitude, D-Dimer and Ang-2 levels for TE occurring within or after 3 days of admission were evaluated using a receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curve using admission and 72h measures, respectively. P-values ≤ 0.05 were considered significant.

Results: Of 680 patients enrolled in the PROPPR study, 478 were included for analysis. At admission, Ang-2 correlated with TEG Ly30, D-Dimer, PAP and tPA. Twenty patients had a TE within 3 days of injury, and admission Ang-2 levels were significantly elevated in these patients compared to patients without a TE. Only admission Ang-2 predicted TE occurring within 3 days with an area under the ROC curve of 0.631 (p = 0.048). Thirty-five patients had a TE more than 3 days after injury, and 72h Ang-2 levels were significantly greater in these patients compared to those without a TE. At 72h, Ang-2 levels inversely correlated with TEG Ly30 and correlated with D-Dimer, PAP and tPA levels. Ang-2 and D-Dimer levels at 72h predicted TE occurring after 3 days with an area under the ROC curve of 0.647 (p = 0.007) and 0.627 (p = 0.02), respectively. 

Conclusion: Plasma Ang-2 levels correlate with fibrinolytic mediators and fibrin degradation products and predict thrombotic complications after trauma. These findings also suggest that persistent endothelial activation corresponds with a phenotype of patients described by both low TEG Ly30 and ongoing fibrinolysis, which is associated with poor outcomes after trauma. Mechanistic studies are warranted to clarify the role of Ang-2 in mediating coagulation and fibrinolysis abnormalities observed in these patients that may contribute to TE after trauma.

abstract_title: "I Prefer to Stay Away": A Qualitative Study of Patient Opinions About Opioids Before Surgery
author_block: E. Johnson<sup>3</sup>, M. Yoshida<sup>2</sup>, A. Hallway<sup>2</sup>, M. Byrnes<sup>1,4</sup>, J. Waljee<sup>2,4,5</sup>, M. Englesbe<sup>2,3,6</sup>, R. Howard<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan Health System,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Opioid Prescribing and Engagement Network,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Michigan Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan,Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Michigan Health System,Section Of Plastic Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>6</sup>University of Michigan Health System,Section Of Transplant Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Prolonged opioid use after surgery is a common postoperative complication. Although recent efforts by surgeons and health systems have sought to improve opioid education for patients, it is unclear what preexisting beliefs patients hold about opioid safety and risk, or how strongly these beliefs influence the patient experience.

Methods:  We conducted semi-structured interviews with 21 patients who underwent one of five elective surgical procedures at our institution. Patients were purposefully sampled to select those with both high and low satisfaction postoperatively using a composite score of satisfaction, regret, and pain from an initial postoperative survey. Patients were asked about their knowledge and beliefs about opioids before surgery, and their perception of postoperative opioid-sparing pathways. Interviews were completed by phone and recordings were transcribed verbatim. Transcripts were coded iteratively by two coders using MAXQDA.

Results: Four themes emerged regarding patient perceptions about using opioids after surgery (Figure 1). First, there was widespread awareness of the opioid epidemic among the patients: “You’d have to be living under a rock not to know that this is an emergency crisis.” Participants largely framed opioid pain medications in negative terms, as “terrible, terrible medications” associated with addiction, abuse, and overdose. Second, patients had a priori intentions about using opioids after surgery. Some felt their risk of developing opioid dependence was low because of personal characteristics (“I don’t have what I consider to be an addictive personality”), while others intended to avoid opioids altogether: “Before surgery, my wife and I, we decided that I wasn’t going to go the opioid route.” Third, several participants discussed a personal or familial experience with addiction, which prompted the need to take extra precaution: “I’m an alcoholic, I don’t want to get on that stuff. I've had surgeries where I absolutely needed it in the past, and it was really hard to get off.” Lastly, patients felt that “information from other patients is really helpful” whereas information provided by the health system may not be useful because it is “so filtered and watered down [and] has to go through so many committees.”

Conclusion: Patients undergoing common surgical procedures often arrive at their surgical encounter with strong, pre-formed opinions about opioids. Importantly, education provided by the health system is not felt to be particularly useful to patients. Eliciting these preexisting opinions may help surgeons better counsel patients about safe opioid use after surgery.

abstract_title: Factors Associated with Amputation Rates among Limb Salvage Patients with Varying Health Insurance
author_block: D. S. Bidare<sup>1</sup>, N. R. Barshes<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies have shown that Medicaid coverage among patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) is associated with higher rates of primary amputation and worse long-term outcomes. The goal of this analysis was to identify differences and associations with amputation rates among patients with varying health insurance coverage that may explain the outcome disparities.

Methods: Publicly available data on Texas hospitalizations from 2008 to 2013 was used to identify patients who underwent treatment for foot complications. Patients were split into four groups by insurance provider: Medicaid only, Medicare only, Medicaid-Medicare dual-enrollment, and commercial insurance. They were then aggregated by metropolitan statistical area (MSA) of residence. Multivariate analyses were used to find patient and hospital factors associated with amputation rates. The Gini index was used to quantify the extent of centralization of care among hospitals.

Results: In total, 15,665 patients who underwent treatment for foot complications were included. Among these, 1,552 (10%) had Medicaid only, 5,366 (34%) had Medicare only, 5,238 (33%) were dually enrolled, and 3,509 (22%) had commercial insurance. Higher proportions of Medicaid and dually enrolled patients underwent primary amputation than Medicare and commercially insured patients (52%, 50% vs 42%, 40%; p<0.001). Medicaid patients were more likely to present with infection (50% vs 42%,42%,38%; p<0.01) and have longer hospital stays (13.0 days vs 10.3, 9.9, 10.1, p<0.01) than patients in other groups. They were also more likely to live in MSAs with more hospitals (14.1 vs 6.4, 6.5, 8.5; p<0.001) and more providers (19.3 vs 14.9, 14.9, 13.6; p<0.05) per capita. Medicaid patient care was more decentralized among a greater number of hospitals (Gini index 0.4 vs 0.58, 0.54, 0.58; p<0.001) and providers (Gini index 0.5 vs 0.69, 0.67, 0.67; p<0.01) than that of the other groups. Amputation rate for Medicaid patients was directly associated with presence of infection (p<0.01), proportion of patients categorized as black (p<0.001), and decentralization of care (p<0.01) (R2=0.57). Amputation rate for Medicare patients was directly correlated with hospitals per capita (p<0.001) and presence of gangrene (p<0.001) (R2=0.62). Amputation rates for the dually enrolled (R2=0.13, p <0.05) and commercially insured (R2=0.18, p<0.001) groups were directly associated with proportion of patients categorized as black.

Conclusion: Presenting more frequently with foot infections, living in regions with more providers per capita, and receiving care at larger numbers of low-volume centers rather than fewer high-volume hospitals appears to be contributing to outcome disparities between Medicaid patients and those with other insurance coverage. Racial disparity appears to manifest as increased amputation rates associated with patients categorized as black regardless of insurance type.

abstract_title: Duplex Ultrasound Criteria for Predicting In-stent Restenosis of the Superior Mesenteric Artery
author_block: J. R. Guitart<sup>3</sup>, V. Pamulapati<sup>1</sup>, S. Resnick<sup>1,2</sup>, K. J. Ho<sup>4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Radiology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Vascular Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) stenting is routine treatment for mesenteric arterial occlusive disease, but is often complicated by in-stent restenosis (ISR). Duplex ultrasound (DUS) velocity criteria have been established for predicting significant stenosis (peak systolic velocity > 275 cm/s) in the native SMA. However, these criteria may overestimate SMA ISR and potentially result in unnecessary reinterventions. This study aims to define DUS criteria for the prediction of SMA ISR using paired DUS and angiographic data.

Methods: We performed a retrospective single-center review of patients who underwent SMA stenting from 2016 to 2020. Postoperative CT angiograms (CTA) or traditional angiograms (TA) performed within 3 months of DUS were selected for inclusion. Maximum peak systolic velocity (PSV) and end diastolic velocity (EDV) in the stented SMA were recorded. For each TA and CTA, 2 independent reviewers measured the diameter of maximum stenosis and the reference SMA diameter with electronic calipers to calculate percentage stenosis. For CTA, measurements were obtained in axial, sagittal, and coronal planes. The plane demonstrating maximum stenosis was used for analysis. For TA, measurements were obtained in the lateral view.

Results: There were 48 paired DUS and angiographic studies (22 TA and 26 CTA). PSV and EDV were both higher in patients with >70% angiographic ISR (PSV: 547 cm/s vs. 331 cm/s, p < 0.001; EDV: 155 cm/s vs. 73.3 cm/s, p < 0.001) than those without ISR. Receiver operator characteristic (ROC) analysis demonstrated that maximum PSV on DUS was a better predictor of > 70% ISR than EDV (p = 0.047). Optimal DUS criteria for predicting 70% ISR were a maximum PSV of ≥ 450 cm/s (sensitivity=100%, specificity=97.2%, PPV=92.3%, NPV=100%) or EDV of ≥ 80 cm/s (sensitivity=91.7%, specificity=74.3%, PPV=60% NPV=97%). A criterion of combined PSV ≥  450 cm/s and EDV ≥  80 cm/sec also accurately defined high grade ISR  (sensitivity=100%, specificity=89%, PPV=75%, NPV=100%).

Conclusion: Our study is the first to use of multiplanar CTA in addition to TA to validate DUS criteria for SMA ISR. Results are concordant with the existing literature suggesting that DUS velocity criteria (PSV and EDV) for native SMA stenosis overestimate ISR. We found that the optimal PSV criteria of  ≥  450 cm/s demonstrated high sensitivity and specificity for the diagnosis of >70% SMA ISR and combined criteria (PSV ≥ 450, EDV ≥  80) showed similar accuracy. Ongoing studies seek to identify stent and imaging characteristics associated with false positive DUS findings which are associated with unnecessary confirmatory CTA or TA.

abstract_title: TEVAR for Aortic Dissection is Associated with Increased Complications, Mortality in CKD Patients
author_block: A. S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Ramirez<sup>1</sup>, D. S. Zarkowsky<sup>4</sup>, E. Lancaster<sup>1</sup>, W. Gasper<sup>2</sup>, V. I. Patel<sup>3</sup>, M. S. Conte<sup>1</sup>, J. Iannuzzi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of California San Francisco,Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of California San Francisco,Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery, Vascular Surgery Section, Veterans Affairs Medical Center,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>New York-Presbyterian/Columbia University Irving Medical Center,Division Of Vascular Surgery And Endovascular Interventions,New York, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Colorado School of Medicine,Division Of Vascular Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  TEVAR has improved morbidity and mortality for patients compared to open thoracic aortic repair.  Yet it remains unclear how chronic kidney disease (CKD) impacts TEVAR outcomes.  Our aim was to identify the association of CKD severity with 30-day postoperative outcomes and 1-year survival after TEVAR for uncomplicated dissection. 

Methods:  The Vascular Quality Initiative (VQI) database was queried for TEVAR performed electively for uncomplicated dissection in years 2014-2018.  Patients with undocumented preoperative creatinine were excluded. Renal function was determined by calculating GFR and categorized as normal/mild (CKD 1/2), moderate (CKD 3), and severe (CKD 4/5). Chi-squared, student’s t-test, and Kaplan-Meier analysis were used to compare baseline demographics and postoperative outcomes by CKD severity as appropriate to the data.  Adjusted analyses were performed using hierarchical cox proportional hazards model for the primary endpoint 1-year survival and secondary endpoints using mixed effects modeling.

Results: There were 712 patients who underwent elective TEVAR for uncomplicated dissection from 2014 to 2018.  Normal/mild CKD was present in 79% (n=564), moderate in 18% (n=129), and severe in 3% (n=19).  There were no statistically significant differences between groups.  Severe CKD was associated with increased total LOS 18.6 vs 10.0 vs 9.2 days (Beta 9.4, 4.9-13.9), increased risk of 30-day mortality 33.3% vs 4.2% vs 5.9% (OR 7.6, 1.7-33.2) and 1-year mortality 57.1% vs 13.2% vs 10.3%(OR 10.3, 2.2-48.9),  any complication 47.4% vs 25.6% vs 19.2% (OR 3.6, 1.4-9.0), MI 10.5% vs 0.8% vs 1.4% (OR 7.1, 1.4-36.7), leg ischemia 5.3% vs 1.6% vs 0.2% (OR 24.7, 1.4-427), AKI 55.6% vs 19.4% vs 12.9% (OR 8.3, 3.1-21.7), and new need for dialysis at discharge 16.7% vs 0.8% vs 0.2% (OR 95.3, 9.2-985.1).  Severe CKD was a significant risk factor for decreased 1-year survival (Fig. 1).

Conclusion: This study demonstrates that severe CKD in the context of elective TEVAR for uncomplicated dissection is significantly associated with decreased 1-year survival, and increased healthcare utilization through longer total hospital LOS, major complications, and new dialysis.  This study helps quantify the prognosis in this high-risk population informing patient selection and preoperative counseling in thoracic aortic dissection treatment.

abstract_title: Patient-Centered Preferences for Treatment of Intermittent Claudication among a Veteran Population
author_block: C. E. Kettering<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Reitz<sup>1</sup>, S. Myers<sup>1</sup>, M. Saleem<sup>1</sup>, P. Varley<sup>1</sup>, E. Tzeng<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Department Of Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Division Of Vascular Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>VA Pittsburgh Healthcare System,Surgery Service,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Peripheral artery disease (PAD) affects millions of Americans and is particularly prevalent among Veterans. PAD typically presents as intermittent claudication (IC), characterized as reproducible muscle pain with ambulation due to reduced lower extremity blood flow. Unfortunately, treatment for IC is limited due to poor compliance with lifestyle modification, limited medication effectiveness, and lack of durable symptomatic improvement with surgical revascularization. We assessed Veterans’ treatment preferences and willingness to participate in prospective studies that evaluate novel IC treatments.

Methods:  We administered a 9-item, in-person questionnaire to Veterans with IC at a VA vascular surgery clinic. The questionnaire was approved by experts in vascular surgery and qualitative research and was comprised of open- and closed-ended questions assessing i) IC symptoms, ii) prior and future treatment preferences, and iii) willingness to participate a clinical trial. Open-ended questions were analyzed for recurrent themes, and enrollment continued until thematic saturation was achieved. Responses to open-ended questions were summarized using descriptive statistics. Data from close-ended questions were analyzed with Chi-squared or Kruskal-Wallis testing

Results: We surveyed 48 Veterans with symptomatic IC (5/2019-12/2019). Of these, 46 (96%) reported bothersome IC symptoms and 30 (63%) reported daily activity limitations (DAL) due to IC symptoms. Ideal treatments were verbalized by 33 patients (69%), including oral medical (N=11 [23%]), topical (N=2 [4%]), physical (N=6 [13%]), and/or surgical (N=10 [21%]) therapies with 4 (8%) explicitly disinterested in a surgical intervention. When directly asked about their interest in medical therapy for IC, 42 (88%) were interested and 27 (56%) were willing to participate in a clinical trial evaluating such therapies. Among patients with DAL (N=30 [63%]), 28 (93%) reported difficulty performing activities of daily living and 5 (17%) noted difficulty with leisure activities. Those with DAL reported a shorter maximal walking distance (median blocks, 0.5 [IQR, 0-1] vs 4 [IQR, 2-5]; P=.001; Figure 1), but had similar verbalization of ideal treatments (N=17 [56%] vs N=14 [43%]; P=.5) and interest in clinical trial participation (N=16 [53%] vs N=14 [47%]; P=.6) when compared to those without DAL.

Conclusion: Veterans with IC report DAL due to IC symptoms, are most interested in medical interventions to improve their symptomatology, and are willing to participate in trials evaluating such therapies. Therfore, this patient-centered study indicates that future research and clinical trials should be directed at finding safe and effective pharmacological therapies to treat IC.

abstract_title: Effects of Statin and Antiplatelet Therapy on Mortality Rates in Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Patients
author_block: H. S. Boudreau<sup>1</sup>, J. Blakeslee-Carter<sup>1</sup>, Z. Novak<sup>1</sup>, E. L. Spangler<sup>1</sup>, A. W. Beck<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Vascular Surgery,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Statin therapy has been associated with improved clinical outcomes in patients undergoing treatment for vascular disease. Current guidelines do not address statin therapy in isolated abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in the absence of other atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ACVD). This study aims to describe the long-term mortality effects in AAA patients with and without ACVD who undergo AAA repair.

Methods:  A retrospective review of patients undergoing elective endovascular (EVAR) and open (OAR) in the Society for Vascular Surgery Vascular Quality Initiative between 2003-2020. Long-term mortality was evaluated based on the presence of statin medications at discharge and stratified by groups with and without concomitant antiplatelet (AP) therapy.

Results: 47,012 cases of AAA repair were identified: 85% EVAR and 15% OAR. Kaplan-Meier (KM) survival analysis for all cohorts are shown in Figure 1. EVAR patients on combined statin/AP therapy had significantly improved survival irrespective of whether they had a known ACVD. Combined statin/AP therapy was protective in Cox Regression analysis for the entire EVAR cohort (HR=.71, p<.001). In the presence of ACVD, patients on statin alone had improved mortality compared to those not on a statin (10.9±0.5 vs 10.5±0.4 years), but worse in comparison to those on combined statin/AP therapy (10.9±0.4 vs 12.2±0.2 years). In the absence of ACVD, patients on statin alone had improved mortality compared to patients not on a statin (8.7±0.5 vs 8.4±0.4 years), but worse in comparison to those on combined statin/AP therapy (8.7±0.5 vs 9.4±0.2 years). For OAR, combined statin/AP therapy had a protective effect across all subgroups based on Cox Regression (HR=0.67, p=.046). Based on KM analysis, OAR patients with ACVD on combined statin/AP therapy had significantly improved survival compared to isolated statin therapy (12.6±0.5 vs 10±1 years) and no medical therapy (12.6±0.5 vs 10.7±1 years). In KM analysis, OAR patients without known ACVD indications had no significant survival differences based on the presence of statin/AP therapy, but the presence of statin/AP was protective in Cox Regression analysis.

Conclusion: Statin therapy is associated with improved survival in AAA patients regardless of the presence of a known ACVD indication. Although we are unable to assess AAA patients in surveillance prior to repair using SVS VQI data, statin therapy appears to have significant survival benefits even in isolated AAA without ACVD. Addition of this recommendation to current treatment guidelines may be warranted.

abstract_title: Disparities in Kidney Transplantation in Mexico: The Role of Living Donors and the Private Sector
author_block: F. Lopez-Verdugo<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Sanchez-Garcia<sup>2</sup>, M. Mali<sup>1</sup>, A. G. Contreras<sup>3</sup>, R. R. Price<sup>1</sup>, M. I. Rodriguez-Davalos<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah,Center For Global Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>Intermountain Medical Center,Transplant Services,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>Instituto Nacional de Ciencias Medicas y Nutricion 'Salvador Zubiran',Department Of Transplant Surgery,Mexico City, CDMX, Mexico
abstract_body:
Introduction:  In Mexico, kidney transplantation (KT) has increased to counteract the burden of chronic kidney disease. We aimed to identify disparities in KT across the country and how these may have changed over time.

Methods:  Mexico’s National Transplant Registry was queried for adult KT performed between 2007 and 2019. Population and gross state income (GSI) per capita were collected from national census data. States were categorized into quartiles (1=low, 2=lower-middle, 3=upper-middle and 4=high) according to GSI per capita. KT rates per million population (KT/pmp) were calculated. A multiple linear regression model was performed to estimate the overall trend in transplant rates over time in each state. An interaction term was used in this model to determine whether transplant rates over time were different amongst GSI quartiles. Non-inferiority tests for independent proportions were performed to assess parity of KT rates between GSI quartiles in 2019.

Results: A total of 29,163 KT were performed. In 2007, KT rate was higher in the 4th GSI quartile (14.47 KT/pmp), compared to the 3rd (11.21 KT/pmp, p=0.001), 2nd (12.29 KT/pmp, p=0.045) and 1st (7.54 KT/pmp, p<0.001) GSI quartiles. Since then, KT increased at a rate of 1.06±0.15 KT/pmp per year (p<0.001) and rates were 2.90±0.50 KT/pmp lower for every decrease in GSI quartile (p<0.001). After accounting for the year-GSI quartile interaction, only the 1st GSI quartile demonstrated lower rates (–5.13±0.97 KT/pmp*year, p<0.001) compared with the 4th GSI quartile (Fig 1A). In 2019, KT rates in the 3rd (30.39 KT/pmp) and 2nd (25.67 KT/pmp) GSI quartiles were similar to those observed in the 4th GSI quartile (24.70 KT/pmp, both p<0.001 for non-inferiority), but the KT rate in the 1st GSI quartile remained lower (15.56 KT/pmp) compared with the 4th GSI quartile (p<0.001). Between 2007 and 2019 the proportion of living donor KT (LDKT, Fig 1B) increased in the 3rd GSI quartile (70.3% to 79.6%, p=0.001), remained stable in the 2nd (71.4% to 65.9%, p=0.147), and decreased in the 1st (77.3% to 67.5%, p<0.001). Similarly, the proportion of KT performed by the private sector (Fig 1C) remained stable in the 3rd (28.2% to 33.1%, p=0.144) and 2nd (20.0% to 19.8%, p=0.929) GSI quartiles, but decreased in the 1st (25.3% to 16.7%, p<0.001).

Conclusion: KT/pmp rates in the 3rd and 2nd GSI quartiles are now on par with the 4th GSI quartile. A contributing factor may be that LDKT and KT performed by the private sector remained stable over time in these quartiles while it decreased in the 1st GSI quartile. Public health policies in KT should focus on states in the 1st GSI quartile, as they continue to have significantly lower transplant rates.

abstract_title: Continuous Diffusion Of Oxygen Adjunct Therapy To Improve Scar Reduction After Cervicotomy
author_block: A. Zulbaran<sup>1</sup>, R. K. Mishra<sup>1</sup>, J. Suliburk<sup>2</sup>, B. Najafi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Division Of Vascular Surgery, Michael E DeBakey Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Division Of Endocrine Surgery, Dan L Duncan Comprehensive Cancer Center,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Dressing materials are known to influence post-operative surgical wound healing and scar formation (SF). A particular dressing that could promote wound hydration is key to ensure quick epithelialization and decrease excessive SF. In this study, we examined effectiveness of a novel dressing with add-on component of Continuous Diffusion of Oxygen (CDO) to reduce scar length post cervicotomy.

Methods:  A prospective randomized controlled trial was performed in patients undergoing cervicotomy, either for thyroid or parathyroid disease. Patients were randomized (n=1:1) to either control (CG) or intervention (IG) groups. The IG received a portable oxygen delivery system (TransCu O2®, EO2 Concept, TX, USA), whereas the CG received a standard dressing, for a 4-week period. Primary outcome was scar length reduction objectively assessed with an imaging system (Snapshot NIR, KENT Imaging Inc., Calgary, AB, CAN). General mixed model was used for analysis. The study was registered in Clinicaltrials.gov-Identifier: NCT03960463.

Results: Twenty-one patients were recruited (Age: 53 ± 16 years; 90% female; CG=9, IG=12). Five patients were lost to follow-up. There were no significant differences between groups for baseline demographics and clinical characteristics. At 4-week, scar length reduction was 40.4% higher in the IG compared to the CG (Cohen’s d=1.01, p=0.043, Fig. 1A). In addition, 88.8% of IG achieved more than 10% of scar reduction compared to the CG (28.5%, Fig. 1B). 

Conclusion: This is the first study to assess scar reduction with the use of CDO adjunct therapy after cervicotomy. Results suggest that advanced dressing using CDO may improve wound healing post cervicotomy including better outcomes for scar visualization. We speculate that reduced scar in the IG is due to tissue oxygenation and higher tissue moisture in response to CDO, which are known factors to accelerate healing. A larger sample is required to validate this observation.

abstract_title: Is General Surgery Program Reputation Associated with Resident Mistreatment and Burnout?
author_block: T. Naterwala<sup>1</sup>, M. C. Chia<sup>1</sup>, R. Khorfan<sup>1</sup>, E. Cheung<sup>1</sup>, C. Etkin<sup>1</sup>, J. Eng<sup>1</sup>, Y. Hu<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Bilimoria<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Surgical Outcomes & Quality Improvement Center,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago,Pediatric Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Burnout in surgical residents has been associated with lower quality of life, higher suicidality, and increased medical errors.  Moreover, residents who experience discrimination, harassment, or bullying are more likely to report burnout symptoms.  However, it is unclear if a program’s reputation is associated with the prevalence of these behaviors and the concomitant effects on resident wellness.  Our objective was to explore these relationships using Doximity reputation rankings.

Methods:  Doximity compiles publicly available rankings of U.S. residency programs based on a survey of practicing physicians.  Program ranks were obtained from Doximity’s website and stratified by quartile.  Resident outcomes were obtained from the 2019 post-American Board of Surgery In-Training Examination (ABSITE) survey.  Mistreatment was defined as reports of sexual harassment, gender discrimination, or racial discrimination.  Bullying was assessed using the Short-Negative Act Questionnaire.  A modified Maslach Burnout Inventory was used to assess feelings of burnout and personal accomplishment (PA).  Additional wellness outcomes included thoughts of attrition and suicidality.  All outcomes were modeled with clustered multivariable logistic regression, with adjustment for resident gender, relationship status, race/ethnicity, duty-hour violations, program size, and location.

Results: 6,956 residents (85.6% response rate) from 301 general surgery residency programs responded.  Residents in higher ranked programs were more likely to report gender discrimination (top quartile 46.6%, bottom quartile 34.3%, p < 0.001) and sexual harassment (top quartile 46.2%, bottom quartile 36.0%, p = 0.021), although rates of racial discrimination (p = 0.473) and bullying (p = 0.267) were not different.  Rates of both burnout (top quartile 48.1%, bottom quartile 33.1%, p < 0.001) and PA (top quartile 91.8%, bottom quartile 83.8%, p < 0.001) were higher at top programs.  There were no differences in reported thoughts of attrition or suicidality by Doximity quartile.  After adjustment, residents at top quartile programs were significantly more likely to report mistreatment (OR 1.56, 95% CI 1.04 - 2.32), burnout (1.46, 1.03 - 2.09), and PA (1.61, 1.01 - 2.57) compared to those at bottom quartile programs (Table 1).

Conclusion: General surgery residents training at top-ranked programs report higher PA than those at other programs.  However, they were also more likely to report mistreatment and burnout, even after adjustment for other resident and program characteristics.  Interventions to address resident burnout should be tailored to the environment and potential risk factors of each program, particularly for programs at risk for mistreatment.

abstract_title: Trends of Core Versus Subspecialty Operative Procedures Completed in General Surgery Programs.
author_block: N. Kapila<sup>1</sup>, F. Tuma<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Central Michigan University College Of Medicine,Mount Pleasant, Michigan, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: General surgery residency involves performing subspecialty procedures in addition to the core general procedures. However, the proportion of core general surgery versus subspecialty procedures during training is variable.  It is unknown whether this proportion is changing due to the increasing number of subspecialty training programs and fellowships. With more residents choosing to pursue subspecialty programs or fellowships, the scope of general surgery training might be altered. Examining the trends in core general surgery and subspecialty procedure distributions during general surgery residency training provides insight for future training planning.

Methods: Data was collected from the ACGME core general surgery national resident case log reports from 2007 – 2019. Descriptive and time series analyses were used to compare proportions of procedures performed per average resident in the core general surgery category versus the subspecialty category. Procedures of the individual subspecialties including Vascular, Cardiothoracic, Pediatric, Urology, and Neurology surgery were compared to general surgery. Additionally, F- tests were conducted to determine significance of the slopes of the trend. Descriptive analyses were performed to quantify proportions of procedures performed.

Results:The mean of the total procedures completed by the general surgery resident increased from 910.1 (SD=30.31) in 2007 to 1070.5 (SD=37.59) in 2019 (Figure 1), with annual average increase of 13.37 procedures. The number of General, Cardiothoracic, Plastic, and Urology procedures increased by 24.9% (166.9 procedures a year), 9.8% (3.5 procedures a year), 76.6% (11.1 procedures a year), and 19.3% (1.1 procedures a year), respectively. Conversely, Vascular and Pediatric surgery procedures reported by residents decreased by 7.6% (9.4 procedures a year) and 30.7% (11.1 procedures a year) respectively. The average number of Neurology procedures completed did not change at 1.1 procedures a year. F-tests revealed significant positive correlation in the trend lines for Total (p<0.0001), General (p<0.0001), and Plastic (p<0.0016) procedures and negative correlation in the trend lines for Vascular (p<0.0006) and Pediatric (p<0.0001) procedures.

Conclusion:The trend of procedures completed by a general surgery resident over the last 12 years verifies a steady pattern towards improving operative training opportunity. The increased subspecialty training programs and fellowships did not impact the operative experience of the general surgery programs. Future research to study the quality of operative procedures and outcomes are needed to evaluate the complete effect.

abstract_title: Assessing Career Advancement of Surgical Chairs
author_block: L. A. Wallace<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>2</sup>, F. Bello-Ogunu<sup>1</sup>, R. Xie<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of North Carolina at Charlotte,Charlotte, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gender and racial/ethnic inclusion is essential to best practices to academic surgical departments.  The purpose of this study is to track the career advancement records of surgical chairs in the United States (US) and identify disparities.  

Methods: We collected the demographics, geographic locations, and institutions of employment for surgical chairs in the US. Descriptive statistics were analyzed to identify the ethnic and gender diversity in surgical chairs belonging to the Association of Surgical Chairs in the US.

Results: There were 176 surgical chairs belonging to the Association of Surgical Chairs in the US.  Of those, 90% (158) were male and 10% (18) were female.  77% (136) were White, 14% (25) were Asian, and fewer than 10% were Black (8), Hispanic (6), or had unidentified ethnicity (1).  Among female surgical chairs, 67% (12) were White, 22% (4) were Asian, and 11% (2) were Hispanic.  Among male surgical chairs, 78% (124) were White, 13% (21) were Asian, and fewer than 10% were Black (8), Hispanic (4), or Unsure (1).  Of the institutions ranked in the US top fifty best hospitals: 75% (15) had male surgical chairs and 25% (5) had female surgical chairs.  Of those, 15 (75%) were White, 3 (15%) were Hispanic, 1 (5%) was Asian, and 1 (5%) was Black.  Of US Census regions, the majority of surgical chairs (38% or 66) were employed at institutions in the South region (17 states); 30% (52) were employed in the Northwest region (9 states); 21% (37) were employed in the Midwest region (12 states); and 12% (21) were employed in the West (12 states) (percentages subject to rounding).  The majority of female surgical chairs (44% or 8) were employed at institutions located in the South; 22% (4) were located in the West; 22% (4) were located in the Northeast, and 11% (2) were located in the Midwest.  The majority of male surgical chairs (37% or 58) were employed at institutions located in the South; 30% (48) were located in the Northeast; 22% (35) were located in the Midwest; 11% (17) were located in the West.

Conclusion: Females and minorities are underrepresented in leadership positions, and this study highlighted these disparities among surgical chairs.  Helpful next steps will include examining career advancement among surgical chairs, including the length of time from residency to becoming chair, and the publication records of surgical chairs.  This information will be valuable for studying trends and understanding the trajectory of this career path when considering ethnic, gender, and specialty diversity, variation in publication rates or subject matter over time.

abstract_title: General Surgery Residency Match In A USMLE Step 1 Pass/Fail World: A Retrospective Review
author_block: C. I. Lauer<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Buonpane<sup>1</sup>, S. Lane<sup>1</sup>, Z. Foreman<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Shabahang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Medical Center,General Surgery,Danville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The USMLE Step 1 has been used as both a licensing exam and a way for residency programs to evaluate applicants. It has had significant impact upon the match process over time. With the 2020 decision to make the exam pass/fail due to its unclear validity as an evaluation for future physician performance, programs will go through the match without the Step 1 score. We set out to better understand the effects of the exam score on our selection process, with the hypothesis that without the step 1 score, the ranking of our applicants would be significantly altered.  

Methods:  We performed a retrospective analysis of applications to a single General Surgery residency program with 4 categorial residents per year at a physician led, academic, tertiary care medical center from 2017 to 2020. Important applicant factors including USMLE Step 1 and 2, AOA status, science grades, clerkship scores, audition rotations, volunteer activities, research activities, letters of recommendation, and personal statements were given points and evaluated through our equation, the sum of which was used to create a rank list and offer interviews.  The standard deviation of scores was calculated with and without Step 1, and the distribution of scores compared. The range and average of applicants’ change in point scores were examined.  

Results: The applications of 653 students were reviewed. After removal of USMLE step 1 points, 40% of all applicants decreased in rank, 35% remained the same, and 24% increased. Specifically, 18.8% of the top 3rd dropped to the middle 3rd, and 11.7% of the bottom 3rd jumped to the middle 3rd, while the middle 3rd changed little (0.2% dropped and 0.9% jumped out of middle 3rd).  The points given for USMLE step 1 created a wider distribution of scores with a negative skewness, suggesting there were more applicants below the mean than above. After removing those points, applicants’ scores had a narrower distribution and skewness closer to 0, showing fewer upper outliers and more applicants near the mean.  

Conclusions: The USMLE Step 1 score significantly affected the evaluation of applicants, and the removal of it from the recruitment criteria tightened applicant rankings. The elimination of the USMLE Step 1 score in the assessment of applicants will allow for its replacement with variables that better reflect the core values of residency programs.

abstract_title: EFFECT OF COVID-19 ON SURGICAL TRAINING ACROSS THE US: A NATIONAL SURVEY
author_block: H. Aziz<sup>1</sup>, T. James<sup>1</sup>, D. Remulla<sup>1</sup>, L. Sher<sup>1</sup>, Y. Genyk<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Sullivan<sup>1</sup>, M. Sheikh<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Southern California,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 emerged as a global pandemic in 2020 and has affected millions of lives. Surgical training has also been significantly affected by this pandemic, but the exact effect remains unknown. We sought to perform a national survey of general surgery residents in the United States to assess the effect of COVID-19 on surgical resident training, education, and burnout.

Methods: An anonymous online survey was created and distributed to general surgery residents across the United States. The survey aimed to assess changes to surgical residents’ clinical schedules, operative volume, and educational curricula as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, we sought to assess the impact of COVID-19 on resident burnout.

Results: 1102 general surgery residents completed the survey. Residents reported a significant decline in the number of cases performed during the pandemic. Educational curricula were largely shifted towards online didactics. The majority of residents reported spending more time on educational didactics than before the pandemic. The majority of residents feared contracting COVID-19 or transmitting it to their family during the pandemic.

Conclusion: COVID-19 has had significant impact on surgical training and education. One positive consequence of the pandemic is increased educational didactics. Online didactics should continue to be a part of surgical education in the post-COVID-19 era. Steps need to be taken to ensure that graduating surgical residents are adequately prepared for fellowship and independent practice despite the significantly decreased case volumes during this pandemic. Surgery training programs should focus on providing non-technical clinical training and professional development during this time.

abstract_title: Influence of a General Surgery Clerkship and Factors Impacting on Medical Student Surgical Interest
author_block: K. Chan<sup>1</sup>, M. Wu<sup>2</sup>, A. Stirling<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Griffith University,School Of Medicine,Gold Coast, QLD, Australia <sup>2</sup>Bond University,Faculty Of Health Sciences And Medicine,Gold Coast, QLD, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: A growing body of international literature has shown that surgical interest amongst medical students has been steadily declining. Our objective was to assess the pre- and post-rotation understanding, knowledge and interest in surgery for a cohort of medical students and to evaluate how exposure to factors during their general surgery clerkship impacted on their surgical interest.

Methods: A survey was sent to penultimate and final year medical students from two South-East Queensland institutions who had completed at least 4 weeks in a general surgery clerkship. Survey items were expressed on 5-point Likert scales and assessed prior exposure to general surgery, pre- and post-rotation understanding, knowledge and interest in surgery. Exposure to factors experienced within the rotation were measured with 10 items, as was the perceived impact. Differences and relationships between pre- and post-rotation variables were tested with paired t-test and Spearman rank correlation. Univariate and multivariate logistic regression analyses were carried out to assess the effect of variables on interest in a surgical career.

Results: The response rate was 50.9% (160/314). There were statistically significant increases in self-ratings of surgical knowledge and skills (p<0.001) before and after the rotation, however there were no differences in interest in a surgical career (p=0.069). All correlations were positive between knowledge and skills in surgery and understanding and interest in a surgical career. There were statistically significant associations between gender and pre-rotation interest in surgery (,p<0.001), with female students being 56% less likely than male students in showing post-rotation interest (OR: 0.44,p=0.017). There was a large positive correlation between exposure to factors in the surgical clerkship and perceived impact (rs=0.77,p<0.001). Univariate logistic regression showed that having ‘surgeons as role models’, (OR:3.35,p=0.001), ‘scrubbing and assisting in theatre’ (OR:2.58,p=0.013) and ‘research opportunities’ OR:2.57,p=0.033) were the most influential rotation factors for increased interests in a surgical career. Multivariate logistic regression showed a high pre-rotation interest (OR: 7.35,p<0.001) and self-rating of post-rotation knowledge and skills (OR: 4.76,p=0.001) were significant external factors for higher interest in a surgical career.

Conclusion: Our study shows that a surgical clerkship can have a large impact on the career interests of medical students. External factors such as gender, lifestyle and personality traits can also play a role in surgical interest.  Educators can better promote the field of surgery by focussing on the factors that inspire early surgical interest amongst medical students. More studies are required to evaluate the quality, experience and impact of surgical education and surgical clerkships on medical students across different institutions.

abstract_title: Optimization of Sodium Iodide Symporter - Based Radioiodine Therapy for Cancer Treatment
author_block: C. J. LaRocca<sup>1</sup>, M. Robertson<sup>1</sup>, K. Jacobsen<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Morris<sup>2</sup>, M. E. Fernandez-Zapico<sup>2</sup>, J. Davydova<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Minnesota,Department Of Surgery,Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>2</sup>Mayo Clinic,Rochester, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Oncolytic viruses represent an emerging class of cancer therapeutics which have the ability to selectively replicate in cancer cells and express select transgenes at the local tumor site.  The Sodium Iodide Symporter (NIS) transgene can be inserted into the adenovirus genome to facilitate both anti-cancer therapy with radioactive iodine as well as real-time imaging to monitor viral replication and treatment effects.  One of the limitations to successful radioiodine-based therapy is the ability to minimize the efflux of iodine from the tumor cells; therefore, optimized regimens are needed to achieve the full potential of this therapy for extra-thyroidal malignancies.

Methods: Our research group has designed an infectivity-enhanced, selectively-replicating oncolytic adenovirus that expresses the NIS transgene from the E3 region of the adenovirus genome (OAd5/3-NIS).  The NIS-expressing viruses were tested in multiple in vivo models including a murine model with patient-derived pancreatic cancer xenografts (PDX) as well as in a murine lung cancer model to test the combination with radioactive iodine.  The adenoviruses were delivered via an intratumoral injection at a dose of 4x1010 viral particles/tumor.

Results: In the pancreatic cancer PDX model, a single intratumoral dose of the NIS-expressing adenovirus facilitated SPECT/CT imaging (using a technetium radiotracer, 99mTc) with the signal persisting for over four weeks following viral injection.  The OAd5/3-NIS treatment group demonstrated significant tumor regression compared to control groups and histologic sections of treated tumors at day 28 demonstrated staining for NIS.  When combined with the OAd5/3-NIS in a murine lung cancer model, radioactive iodine ( 131I, single intraperitoneal dose of 3.0 mCi) improved the overall therapeutic effect.  The combination therapy group provided significant tumor regression compared to monotherapy and saline control groups.  Interestingly, by day 18 following viral injection there was no evidence of continued radiotracer uptake in the tumors suggesting that efflux of 131I from the tumor cells contributed to the rapid washout of radioactive iodine.

Conclusion: The OAd5/3-NIS facilitates replication-dependent NIS expression that can be visualized through in-vivo imaging and its combination with radioactive iodine can yield a strong therapeutic effect in extra-thyroidal cancers.  Additional work in preclinical models is ongoing to investigate the optimal doses and timing of radioactive iodine administration to capitalize on the OAd5/3-NIS mediated expression of the NIS transgene.  These studies have built a foundation for a Phase I clinical trial designed to determine the maximum tolerated dose of intra-tumoral OAd5/3-NIS followed by two doses of radioactive iodine in patients with locally advanced pancreatic cancer.

abstract_title: Comparison of Immune Cell Infiltration Patterns in Treated and Untreated Tumors After Histotripsy
author_block: A. L. Pepple<sup>1,3</sup>, A. Ganguly<sup>1,3</sup>, A. Felsted<sup>1</sup>, R. McGinnis<sup>2</sup>, R. Hubbard<sup>2</sup>, A. Kevelin<sup>1</sup>, J. Guy<sup>1,3</sup>, H. Garavaglia<sup>1</sup>, J. Dib<sup>1</sup>, Z. Xu<sup>2</sup>, C. Cho<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan,Department Of Biomedical Engineering,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Ann Arbor VA Healthcare System,Research Service,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Histotripsy is a non-thermal focused ultrasound ablation modality that utilizes acoustic cavitation to mechanically disrupt targeted tissues. In the past, our lab has shown that histotripsy potentiates local and abscopal immune responses in both ablated and non-ablated tumors. We sought to better characterize these immune responses and hypothesized that local and abscopal immune infiltration patterns would differ over time.

Methods:  Immunocompetent C57BL/6 mice were inoculated with bilateral flank hepatocellular carcinoma tumors using 5 x 106 Hepa 1-6 cells suspended in PBS and matrigel. Tumors were measured every three days. Between days 8 and 10, unilateral histotripsy was performed. Mice were euthanized, and tumors were harvested at various time points after histotripsy treatment: early (6-24 hours), intermediate (3 days), or late (10-12 days). Immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence imaging of fixed tumor sections was performed, utilizing stains for immune cells and damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). Multiple fields of view were captured per slide, and Keyence BZ-X800 analysis and ImageJ software were used to calculate the number of immune cells or percentage of cells with DAMP release per field of view.  

Results: Imaging demonstrated differences in the timing of immune cell infiltration as well as differences in the types of immune cells infiltrating between treated and untreated tumors. In treated tumors, early inflammatory infiltration of neutrophils, monocytes, and myeloid cells was observed. By later time points, there was also significant natural killer and CD8+ T cell infiltration. In untreated tumors, the early inflammatory response was minimal; however, later infiltration of CD8+ T cells occurred in a similar magnitude to that of treated tumors. HMGB1 translocation in treated and untreated tumors was associated with areas of CD8+ T cell infiltration, indicating the possibility of immune-mediated tumor cell death.

Conclusion: Our data suggest that histotripsy treatment causes a rapid myeloid inflammatory response in treated tumors, followed by a lymphocytic response at later time points. This immune response is strong enough to induce abscopal intratumoral lymphocytic infiltration. We are currently investigating the subcellular consequences of histotripsy ablation that could be potentiating this immune response, along with the different mechanisms of cell death seen in tumor cells post-ablation.

abstract_title: Fluorescent Anti-MUC5A Targets Pancreatic Cancer in a Patient-Derived Orthotopic Xenograft.
author_block: M. Turner<sup>1,2</sup>, H. Hollandsworth<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Amirfakhri<sup>1,2</sup>, T. M. Lwin<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Lowy<sup>1</sup>, S. Kaur<sup>3</sup>, K. Mallya<sup>3</sup>, R. Hoffman<sup>4</sup>, S. Batra<sup>3</sup>, M. Bouvet<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego,Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Veterans Affairs San Diego Healthcare System,Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine,Department Of Biochemistry,Omaha, NE, USA <sup>4</sup>AntiCancer, Inc.,San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mucins, a family of epithelial glycoproteins, can demonstrate aberrant expression in certain types of cancer. Mucin-5A (MUC5A) is overexpressed early in pancreatic cancer making it a potential targetable biomarker. In the present study, we evaluated an anti-MUC5A antibody labeled with an infrared dye to target and label pancreatic cancer in a patient-derived orthotopic xenograft (PDOX) nude mouse model.

Methods: A MUC5A monoclonal antibody was conjugated to IRDye800CW (LICOR, Lincoln, NE) to synthesize MUC5A-IR800.  A high MUC5A expressing patient derived pancreatic tumor was identified by Western blotting. This tumor was established by surgical orthotopic implantation as a PDOX model. After 3 weeks of PDOX tumor growth, 50 mcg of MUC5A-IR800 was administered intravenously and in-vivo imaging was performed with the Pearl Trilogy Imager (LICOR, Lincoln, NE) with excitement at 800 nm.

Results: Western blotting demonstrated no MUC5A expression in normal pancreatic tissue and abnormal MUC5A overexpression in all 6 pancreatic cancer lysates tested. The highest MUC5A expressing tumor was established as a PDOX model. After IV administration of 50 mcg of MUC5A-IR800, the highest tumor to background ratio (TBR) in the pancreatic cancer PDOX model was obtained at 48 hours (TBR = 2.5). In-vivo imaging demonstrated clear contrast of the orthotopic tumors with minimal background signal. No toxicity was observed. 

Conclusion: MUC5A-IR800 provides distinct visualization of the PDOX model of pancreatic cancer with a TBR of 2.5 at 48 hours. These results suggest MUC5A-IR800 can be used clinically to improve the outcome of pancreatic cancer surgery. As MUC5A is overexpressed in early precursors of pancreatic cancer, this novel fluorescent probe is also promising for targeting of pre-malignant pancreatic lesions with subsequent resection under fluorescence guidance.

abstract_title: Multiplatform Analyses of Immunosuppressive Signature in Cortisol-secreting Adrenocortical Carcinoma
author_block: J. J. Baechle<sup>1</sup>, D. N. Hanna<sup>2</sup>, J. C. Rathmell<sup>4</sup>, K. W. Rathmell<sup>5</sup>, N. Baregamian<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Meharry Medical College,School Of Medicine,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Division Of Surgical Oncology & Endocrine Surgery,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Department Of Pathology, Microbiology And Immunology,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>5</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Division Of Hematology And Oncology,Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Nearly 50% of highly aggressive, but rare adrenocortical carcinomas (ACC) are hormone-producing. Recent immunotherapy clinical trials showed significant immunoresistance in cortisol-secreting ACC (CS-ACC). We aim to characterize this immunosuppressive signature within the tumor-infiltrating immune cell (TIIC) landscape of CS-ACC to decipher immunoresistance using comprehensive multiplatform computational immunogenomic analytic approaches. 

Methods:  The gene expression profiles of ACC tumors were analyzed and stratified by cortisol hypersecretion (N=33 CS-ACC) using The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) ACC tumor cohort (N=92). To estimate the TIIC subtypes for immunogenomic pattern analysis, TCGA genomic sequencing data was further deconvoluted with CIBERSORTx computational analytic platform. The Panther Classification System availed generation and selection of significant gene profiles related to immunological processes in ACC. The ACC gene interactions and clustering were assessed with Cytoscape platform. R programing was used to assess the prognostic value of each gene’s mRNA expression and DNA methylation. Survival analysis was performed using Cox regression models.

Results: Multiplatform deconstructing analytical assessment of ACC tumors reconstructed a complex immunosuppressive TME in CS-ACC with notably significant depletion of Tγδ cells, and increased infiltration of activated dendritic cells (DCa), resting mast cell and neutrophils. Of the 1,021 genes with significantly altered mRNA expression in CS-ACC, 45 (4%) were directly related to immunological processes, of which 44 showed decreased and 1 (CCRL2) showed increased mRNA expression levels in ACC tumor microenvironment (TME). Of these 45 gene hits, the mRNA expression of 19 (42%) were significant prognostic indicators with positive associations for both overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS) in CS-ACC. The DNA methylation of 5 genes associated with significant risk factors and negative associations for OS and DFS had identified GBP2, HLA-F, Jak3, SIRPA, TLR5 genes with altered primary prognostic expression signature in CS-ACC tumors. Significant increase in mRNA expression levels of immunosuppressive CCRL2 and decreased DNA methylation were also observed in CS-ACC tumors. The CCRL2 overexpression was also negatively associated with DFS.

Conclusion: Comprehensive multiplatform immunogenomic computational analyses of ACC tumors unveiled a complex immunosuppressive expression profile with direct impact on survival and poor prognosis in patients with CS-ACC. We identified several primary immunogenomic prognostic indicators and targets within tumor immune landscape of CS-ACC. These important findings will potentiate future studies focusing on identifying novel immunotherapeutic strategies to overcome the immunotherapeutic resistance in patients with CS-ACC tumors.

abstract_title: Zika Virus as an Oncolytic Treatment for Triple-Negative Breast Cancer
author_block: J. Mazar<sup>1</sup>, P. Phelan<sup>1</sup>, J. Brooks<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Westmoreland<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Nemours Children's Hospital,Biomedical Research,Orlando, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Despite intensive therapies, late stage breast cancers continue to have poor prognoses.  We propose the use of Zika virus as a means of treating these patients.  Previous work in neuroblastomas revealed that they are susceptible to Zika virus and the cell surface receptor, CD24, was required for tumor cell lysis.  Based upon these findings, we propose that Zika virus infection could be used as a primary or rescue therapy for patients with CD24-presenting triple negative breast cancer.

Methods:    We confirmed by qRT-PCR that CD24 expression was present in four late stage breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7, T47D, MD-MBA-468, & MD-MBA-231) and examined cell cytotoxicity after treatment with Zika virus.  Data was collected every day over an eight day period using fluorescence-based real-time detection assays for kinetic analysis as well as endpoint determination.  Cell survival was also directly correlated with examination by bright field microscopy.  In addition, the stable knock-down of CD24 by shRNA vectors was screened to determine if the loss of CD24 could be correlated with Zika-viral cytotoxicity.

Results: qRT-PCR confirmed that CD24 expression was present in all four breast cancer cell lines at levels comparable to those seen previously in neuroblastoma cells, predicting susceptibility to Zika virus-mediated cell lysis.  After treatment with Zika virus, significant increases in cell cytotoxicity were confirmed in as early as 4 days, increasing dramatically and plateauing by day 8.  However, greater susceptibility was witnessed in the two triple negative breast cancers (MD-MBA-468, & MD-MBA-231).  Examination by bright field microscopy confirmed these results.  Knockdown of CD24 in the triple negative cell line MD-MBA-231 was also confirmed to offer resistance to Zika-viral cytotoxicity.

Conclusion: The effectiveness of Zika virus in the treatment of human breast cancer cells correlates with results seen previously in neuroblastomas, with a rate of increase in cell cytotoxicity appearing even more rapid in triple negative cell lines.  Previously identified cells that expressed CD24 showed significant susceptibility to Zika virus-mediated tumor cell lysis, a result which is corroborated in triple breast cancer cells, further validating the potential for CD24 as a prognostic marker for Zika efficacy as a therapeutic treatment.

abstract_title: A first-in-class Hsp90β inhibitor targets cancer metabolism and immunomodulatory pathways.
author_block: C. Subramanian<sup>1</sup>, J. Zhu<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Mishra<sup>2</sup>, D. M. Lubman<sup>1</sup>, B. J. Blagg<sup>2</sup>, M. S. Cohen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Notre Dame,Notre Dame, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) is a molecular chaperone that plays a critical role in all the known hall marks of cancer. To date all Hsp90 inhibitors tested in clinical trials pan-inhibit all 4 isoforms of Hsp90 and have had toxicity issues clinically related to this pan-inhibition. To overcome the detrimental effects of pan Hsp90 inhibition our group has developed the first-in-class isoform-specific Hsp90β  inhibitor KUNB105 and have demonstrated the potency and efficacy of this inhibitor in targeting cancer cells. We hypothesize that a comprehensive mass spectrometry-based proteomic analysis of cancer cells treated with KUNB105 will identify key cancer-specific pathways that are uniquely targeted by Hsp90β isoform specific inhibitionto guide future translational studies. 

Methods:  Patient-derived cell lines, UMSCC22B and UMSCC108, were treated with IC50 values of KUNB105 for 24 hr. From the cell pellet, proteins were isolated, and enzyme digested with trypsin.  Tryptic peptides were labelled by iTRAQ 8-plex reagent. The labeled samples were analyzed by Orbitrap LC-MS/MS. Protein peaks were identified by TagIdent database search. The m/z values of the experimental protein were searched using UniPortKB/Swiss-Port database of Homo sapiens at a mass tolerance of 0.1% to account for experimental errors. Pathway enrichment analysis was carried out using DAVID, PANTHER, and STRING pathway tools.

Results: To evaluate the comprehensive estimation of proteins altered by HSP90binhibitor KUNB 105 treatment, we performed the global proteomic analysis by MS after treatment of HNSCC cells with KUNB105. The results from the MS-based proteomic analysis resulted in approximately 2890 differentially regulated proteins. Heat map analysis of the proteins with the greatest expression changes resulted in 15% of this cohort being differentially regulated. Statistically significant proteins (p<0.01 for each comparison) in treatment groups compared to the DMSO treated control group with the largest fold change were calculated using a Volcano plot. Functional pathway enrichment analysis of the significantly regulated proteins indicated targeted alteration of key pathways involved in cell-cell adhesion, protein folding, Wnt signaling, NF-kBpathway, glucose metabolism, cell cycle, apoptosis, and immune modulation (attached).

Conclusion: Proteomic analysis revealed that our novel first-in-class Hsp90binhibitor KUNB 105 targets innate immune response, cell cycle, and metabolism of aggressive HNSCC cells and has novel therapeutic rationale for cancer treatment. Further translational in vivo analysis including combination treatment with immunotherapy is warranted to better understand its ideal clinical applications as a novel cancer therapeutic.

abstract_title: Tumor-Intrinsic Cxcl1 Orchestrates Tumor-Stromal-Immune Crosstalk in Ras-p53 Cooperative Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: S. Mehra<sup>1</sup>, A. Bianchi<sup>1</sup>, A. Dosch<sup>1</sup>, X. Dai<sup>1</sup>, I. De Castro Silva<sup>1</sup>, S. Singh<sup>1</sup>, N. Nagathihalli<sup>1</sup>, N. Merchant<sup>1</sup>, J. Datta<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami,Surgery,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ras-p53 cooperative mutations, which define >60% of human pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), promote an immune-excluded tumor microenvironment. Ras-p53 murine models that phenocopy human disease encode a differentially expressed transcriptional program of immunomodulatory genes. Of these candidate genes, we explored the role of Cxcl1—a ligand for CXCR2 on the immature myeloid compartment—as a potential mediator of tumor-stoma-immune crosstalk in PDAC.

Methods: Mutations in TCGA human PDAC specimens (n=150) as well as 31 human PDAC cell lines were categorized as Ras-p53 cooperative or Ras-alone altered. IHC analysis was performed to evaluate patterns of Cxcl1 expression in human PDAC tissue microarray array (TMA) and PDAC genetically engineered mouse models KrasG12D/+;Trp53fl/+;Pdx1Cre (KPC) and LSL-KrasG12D (KC). CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing was used to silence Cxcl1 in KPC-derived tumor cells. The role of tumor-intrinsic Cxcl1 in impacting tumorigenicity and cross-talk with cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAF) and immune cells was evaluated.

Results:Cxcl1 was significantly overexpressed in TCGA PDAC vs. normal pancreas. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed progressive increase in Cxcl1 staining in Ras-p53 KPC compared with Ras-alone KC murine tumors, and with increasing tumor stage in human PDAC. Further investigation into the disproportionate stromal Cxcl1 signal in stage IV—but not stage II/III—PDAC prompted evaluation of Cxcl1 transcription in ductal vs. fibroblast progenitors in normal human pancreas at single cell resolution, revealing preferential Cxcl1 transcription in ductal, not fibroblastic, precursors. In vitro conditioning of KPC CAFs by exogenous Cxcl1 or pro-inflammatory IL-1α demonstrated that Cxcl1 is secreted by late-stage KPC CAFs under tumorigenic stress, but not by autocrine regulation. CRISPR/Cas9-mediated Cxcl1 silencing in KPC cells significantly reduced Mek1 and Stat3 transcription, and diminished tumor migratory potential. In 3D-spheroid co-culture systems with wildtype KPC CAFs, Cxcl1-silenced KPC cells decreased tumor-CAF proliferative kinetics in vivo. Examination of differentially expressed genes between Ras-p53 and Ras-alone human PDAC revealed interwoven transcriptional networks between tumor-intrinsic Cxcl1, stromal Col1a1, and immune Nos1/Nos3—immature myeloid markers. Indeed, on single cell deconvolution of immune cell populations in human PDAC, Cxcl1 expression strongly correlated with neutrophil, myeloid-derived suppressor cell (MDSC), and macrophage—but not activated CD8+/CD4+ T-cell—signatures, as well as CXCR2+ CD33+ MDSCs.   

Conclusion: Tumor-intrinsic Cxcl1 is a key modulator of tumor-stromal-immune crosstalk in Ras-p53 cooperative PDAC, with distinct effects on stromal signaling and immune infiltration. Targeting this immunomodulatory chemokine in Ras-p53 PDAC may represent a promising strategy to overcome inhibitory stromal-immune interactions in the PDAC tumor microenvironment.

abstract_title: Carfilzomib Inhibits Cell Proliferation by Downregulating AKT1 and E2F1 Genes in Human NSCLC Cells
author_block: H. T. NGUYEN<sup>3</sup>, M. CHATURVEDI<sup>2</sup>, T. WORDEMARIAM<sup>3</sup>, L. S. CHATURVEDI<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>CALIFORNIA NORTHSTATE UNIVERSITY,MEDICINE,ELK GROVE, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>UNIVERSITY OF NORTH DAKOTA,MEDICINE,GRAND FORKS, NORTH DAKOTA, USA <sup>3</sup>CALIFORNIA NORTHSTATE UNIVERSITY,PHARMACY,ELK GROVE, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  About 80% to 85% of lung cancers are non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). NSCLCs are relatively insensitive to chemotherapy drugs when compared to small cell lung cancer. The leading risk factor accounting for approximately 90% of cases is cigarette smoking. A chemotherapeutic drug-like Doxorubicin (DOX) is currently used for the treatment of recurrent small-cell lung cancer but has several limitations including life-limit dose. The Carfilzomib (CFZ), a second-generation irreversible proteasome inhibitor, has been approved to treat refractory multiple myeloma patients. However, it's anti-cancerous potential has not been fully elucidated in NSCLCs. In the current investigation, we aim to determine the anticancer efficacy and molecular targets of CFZ in human NSCLC cells.

Methods: Three human non-small cell lung cancerous (A549, Calu-1, and H1355) were cultured in RPMI-1640 medium with FBS at 37C in a humidified atmosphere. Cell viability was determined using the Cell Counting Kit (CCK-8). NSCLC cells were treated with vehicle control (DMSO) or various concentrations CFZ (0-1000nM), DOX (0-3.6µM), and a combination of both to measure the cytotoxicity and anticancer potential. Total RNA was extracted using GenEluteTM Universal kit and concentration and quality were measured using Nanodrop. High-Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit with RNAse inhibitor used to convert total RNA to cDNA. Genes involved in cell cycle regulation and signaling pathways were analyzed by quantitative-RT-PCR and relative expression performed using the delta-delta Ct method, also known as the 2–??Ct method. RPLP0 (Ribosomal Protein Lateral Stalk Subunit P0) was used as a housekeeping gene.

Results: We observed that CFZ significantly dose-dependently inhibited cell proliferation of all three NSCLC (A549, Calu-1, and H1355) cells at a 72-hour time-point in comparison to vehicle control (p<0.05, n=4 for each condition).  We further observed that CFZ was more sensitive to H1355 than Calu-1 and A549 cells. Nonetheless, DOX modestly but significantly inhibited the proliferation of H1355 and Calu-1 cells but had no cytotoxic effect on A549 cells.  Furthermore, a combination of both CFZ and DOX did not further enhance the rate of growth inhibition in comparison of CFZ alone in three NSCLC cells. CFZ, DOX, and a combination of both down-regulate AKT1, MMP-9 gene expression, and E2F1 transcription factor in A549 cells in comparison to vehicle control (p<0.05, n=4 for each condition). 

Conclusion: Novel second-generation proteasome inhibitor CFZ alone has high anti-cancer therapeutic potential in human non-small cell lung cancer cells by downregulating AKT1, MMP-9, and E2F1 genes. The overexpression of these genes is associated with the progression of cancer. Moreover, further in vivo experiments need to confirm to evaluate its antitumorigenic potentials before investigating the clinical trial.

abstract_title: Secreted Frizzle-Related Protein 2 Impacts T cell Function by Signaling through NFATc3.
author_block: D. I. Garcia<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Nasarre<sup>1,2</sup>, J. B. Seigel<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Chakraborty<sup>2</sup>, E. Hilliard<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Mukherjee<sup>1</sup>, M. Rubinstein<sup>1</sup>, M. Swiderska-Syn<sup>2</sup>, J. T. Yustein<sup>3</sup>, S. Mehrotra<sup>1,2</sup>, N. Klauber-DeMore<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical University of South Carolina,Surgery,Charleston, SC, USA <sup>2</sup>Hollings Cancer Center Medical University of South Carolina,Surgery,Charleston, SC, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Hematology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Secreted frizzle-related protein 2 (SFRP2) activates calcineurin/NFAT signaling in endothelial cells and has been found localized in multiple tumors. NFATc3 is involved in T cell regulation, and activation of NFATc3 increases CD38, which has been associated with impaired anti-tumor activity in T cells. We hypothesized that SFRP2 activates NFATc3 in T cells with downstream effects on T cell function.  

Methods: T-cells cultured in SFRP2 protein (30nM) and IFNg levels were measured on flow cytometry.
