Conclusion: While there is no single ideal ethical framework from which to approach de-implementation of low-vale health care practices, a health systems framework allows consideration of the systems-level factors impacting de-implementation. Framing de-implementation as a health systems issue with ethical implications empowers providers to think about new ways to approach potential roadblocks to the reduction of low-value care.

abstract_title: How Do Electronic Health Records Contribute to Provider Burnout? - a Systematic Review
author_block: J. A. Treffalls<sup>4</sup>, Q. Yan<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Zheng<sup>3</sup>, Z. Harbin<sup>4</sup>, P. H. Tolbert<sup>4</sup>, M. G. Davies<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio,Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery,San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>South Texas Medical Center,South Texas Center For Vascular Care,San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Fudan University,Shanghai Medical College,Shanghai, SHANGHAI, China <sup>4</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio,Long School Of Medicine,San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Stress related to usage of electronic health records (EHR) and health information technology has become the center of attention for provider burnout. However, there are few objective studies related to this topic. The aim of this study is to systematically review the effects of EHR usage on provider burnout.

Methods:  A systematic PRISMA-based literature search was performed. Original research investigating the association between EHR usage and physician burnout was included. Study quality was accessed using Medical Education Research Study Quality Instrument.

Results: Of 296 unique titles identified, 17 met inclusion criteria. The median sample size was 449 (total 87,183). Forty-four percent of the participants were male, 2.1% were not specified. Mean age of the participants was 53 years. Fourteen studies were cross-sectional studies, two were qualitative studies, and one used both methods.  For 15 studies with quantitative components, 12 used subjective provider-reported data, while three used objective EHR system generated data.  Burnout was assessed subjectively with various validated instruments. Insufficient time for documentation (odds ratio [OR] 1.98-2.81, P<0.001), EHR usage after hours (OR 1.46-2.9, P<0.05), and in-box message volume (OR 2.06, P<0.001) were the three most cited EHR-related factors associated with high burnout.

Conclusion: There are few studies that objectively assess the relationship between EHR use and provider burnout. Insufficient time for documentation, EHR usage after hours, and high message volume were the three most reported EHR-related characteristics associated with increased burnout in providers and should be the focus of efforts to improve EHR-related provider burnout.

abstract_title: Surgical Bundled Payment Target Prices are Improved by Accounting for Mean Reversion
author_block: B. Cher<sup>1</sup>, B. Gulseren<sup>2</sup>, A. Ryan<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,School Of Public Health,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) implemented the voluntary Bundled Payments for Care Improvement-Advanced program (BCPI-A) in 2018. Participating hospitals receive shared savings or are subject to penalties if their episode spending is below or above target prices set by CMS. The program’s current approach may set target prices too high for some hospitals, leading to savings that result from mean reversion in episode spending rather than meaningful practice changes.

Methods:  In this study, we compared the predictive accuracy of the current CMS methods of calculating target prices with an empirical Bayes approach designed to mitigate the effects of mean reversion.

Results: Compared to the traditional CMS approach, the empirical Bayes approach resulted in significantly more accurate episode spending predictions for 15 of the 21 clinical episodes examined. For 5 episodes, there was no significant difference between approaches. For 1 episode, the CMS approach outperformed the empirical Bayes approach. Across all episodes, prediction error averaged $7,494 for the empirical Bayes approach versus $8,657 for the current CMS approach. Greater differences in accuracy were observed for surgical conditions and for larger hospitals.

Conclusion: Effective alternative payment programs depend on the ability to determine how much variation in health spending and outcomes is due to variation in quality of care versus factors outside provider control. This is a challenging task because it is difficult to predict healthcare spending with available claims data. Empirical Bayes estimation has the potential to enhance BPCI-A by improving target price setting under the program.

abstract_title: Improving understanding using visualization in the informed consent process: Surgeons' perspectives
author_block: J. Panton<sup>1</sup>, D. Nakikj<sup>2</sup>, N. Gehlenborg<sup>2</sup>, G. Brat<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School,Department Of Biomedical Informatics,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The preoperative informed consent process represents a key ethical, moral, and legal component of the surgeon-patient relationship but is complicated by the lack of a uniform, consensus standard. Though several surgical risk calculators have emerged, whether these tools improve the informed consent process for surgeons remains unclear and their decision-making utility for patients is limited. To address these limitations, we created a data-driven, Visual Consent Tool (VCT) that leverages design-thinking, visualization, patient preferences, and a patient-centered user interface to facilitate the preoperative informed consent process. We aim to conduct semi-structured interviews with surgeons to obtain their feedback on the tool’s potential utility and efficacy.

Methods: To better understand surgeons’ experience obtaining informed consent and learn how our VCT might address the challenges they face, we conducted semi-structured interviews and demonstrated our prototype to obtain surgeons' feedback. We anticipate the participation of 30 academic surgeons across ten surgical subspecialties and multiple tertiary care medical centers. Interviews are transcribed, categorized according to key themes, and analyzed. Surgeons’ perspectives and feedback will be directly incorporated into the current phase of the design process and future iterations of the VCT will be deployed in a forthcoming pilot study.

Results: Preliminary findings of our study reflect the complexity of surgical care and patient management in the context of the Covid-19 pandemic and highlight the dearth of digital tools able to facilitate the provision of virtual care. Initial interviews indicate that surgeons appreciate the mobility of the VCT, its ability to be used for in-person and virtual visits, and its capacity to be used by residents and other members of the patient’s care team. Emerging themes include the importance of integrating patient-centered language, graphics, and visualization, and implementing enhancements that allow the tool to be used by patients and caregivers at home as well as alongside their provider in the office or during a telehealth visit.

Conclusion: Design-thinking is often reserved for entrepreneurial or public health spaces and key stakeholders -- patients and their medical providers -- are often excluded from the iterative product design process. Currently, few tools exist which are accessible to both patients and providers and leverage patient-centered language, preferences, or visualization. Our initial findings suggest that our design-centered approach is important to surgeons and a tool accessible by both patients and providers may be a valuable addition to the preoperative consent process.

abstract_title: A National Evaluation of Emergency General Surgery Outcomes Among Hospitalized Cardiac Patients
author_block: L. Tennakoon<sup>1</sup>, N. A. Hakes<sup>1</sup>, L. M. Knowlton<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Department Of Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  General surgical emergencies among cardiac surgery patients are increasingly common. With a large volume of patients undergoing complex cardiac intervention including advanced percutaneous procedures, bypass or aortic surgery, or receiving ventricular assist devices or heart transplants, intra-abdominal complications due to ischemic or septic physiology have been reported. Among a cohort of complex cardiac patients, we sought to characterize the incidence of emergency general surgery as well as define outcomes including mortality, length of stay and in-hospital costs.

Methods:  We queried the 2016 Nationwide Inpatient Sample (NIS) for adult patients (>18 years) with diagnosis of complex cardiac disease (post-operative from cardiac surgery or with signs of heart failure). We compared patient demographics, healthcare utilization and costs of those who underwent emergency general surgical operative intervention (GS-OR) (as defined by ICD-10-CM procedure codes) and those who did not (non-GS-OR). Outcomes assessed included mortality, cost of treatment, and inpatient length of stay (LOS). Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed. Weighted data are presented to provide national estimates.

Results: Among the 4.9 million adult patients with complex cardiac disease, 72,033 patients (1.5%) underwent general surgery operative intervention. Despite similar demographic and clinical characteristics, mortality was significantly higher in the GS-OR group (vs. non-GS-OR: 11.0% vs 5.1%, p<0.001). Mean LOS was nearly three times longer in the GS-OR group (14.2 vs. 5.8 days, p<0.01) and fewer GS-OR patients had a routine discharge home (31.5% vs. 46.0%, p<0.001). GS-OR patients were more commonly treated at large urban teaching hospitals (65.8% vs 63.3%, p<0.001) and mean costs were also higher in the GS-OR group ($43,886 vs $16,386, p<0.001). In adjusted GS-OR patients had a 2.4 higher odds of mortality (aOR 2.4, p<0.0001). Among GS-OR patients only, cardiac patients with a ventricular assisted device had 3.8 higher odds of mortality (aOR=3.8, p<0.001) if they underwent emergency general surgery.

Conclusion: Emergency general surgery on patients with underlying complex cardiac pathology continues to be associated with high mortality rates, particularly among patients with ventricular assist devices as destination therapy or bridges to transplant. Clinicians should have high index of suspicion for intraabdominal complications and those requiring emergency surgical intervention should be managed by experienced multi-disciplinary teams.

abstract_title: Covid-19 Reveals the Fragility of the Surgeon Work-Life Integration
author_block: C. W. Lancaster<sup>1</sup>, S. Landau<sup>2</sup>, E. Brooks<sup>2</sup>, R. Bergmark<sup>3</sup>, N. L. Berlin<sup>4</sup>, B. Blumenthal<sup>4</sup>, Z. Cooper<sup>3</sup>, E. Hwang<sup>5</sup>, E. Lancaster<sup>6</sup>, J. Waljee<sup>4</sup>, E. Wick<sup>6</sup>, H. Yeo<sup>5</sup>, C. Wirtalla<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Perelman School Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>Weill Cornell Medical College,New York, NY, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Surgeons experience tension between the demands of their personal and professional lives, due in part to the substantial time burden of surgical training and practice. The Coronavirus Disease 2019 (Covid-19) pandemic presented the surgical workforce with unprecedented challenges in both. As the pandemic progresses, and we enter into a more chronic phase, the ability to maintain stability in the home will become increasingly important. We sought to better understand the importance of household support for surgeons by examining the relationship between changes in household support during the pandemic and stress levels.

Methods:  A multi-institutional telephone survey of all surgeons practicing at five academic surgical institutions was conducted from 5/15-6/5/2020. It included basic demographics, training status, partnership status, household support, and surgeon stress level at the time of survey completion (measured using the validated Stress Numerical Rating Scale-11; scale 0, low, to 10, high). Generalized linear models were used to estimate the relationship between stress level and changes in household support during the pandemic, controlling for potential confounders identified in univariate analysis.

Results:  Of 529 surgeons contacted, 337 surveys were completed (response rate 63.7%; 49.3% housestaff, 50.7% faculty). Respondents had a mean age of 39.4 years. The minority (40.6%) were female. Age, training status, partnership status, and having children varied significantly between respondents who did not have support, who had a decrease in household support, and who had no change in household support (p<0.001 for all). See Table 1. After controlling for training status, partnership status, and having children, we found that a decrease in household support was associated with a stress level 0.7 points higher than respondents who did not experience a decrease in support (p=0.034). There was no significant relationship between having no household support and stress level (p=0.314).

Conclusion: The Covid-19 pandemic revealed the tenuous work-life integration that exists for many surgeons. In the same way that advanced practice providers have established a vital role as physician extenders, allowing surgeons to maximize their effectiveness in the workplace, we suggest that household support employees play an analogous, essential role as household extenders. One way in which health systems may be able to maintain the effectiveness of their surgical workforce is to provide logistical support to maintain a stable home environment, for example by providing access to collaborative pooled networks of surgeons with similar household extender needs, flexible onsite daycare, or assistance with homeschooling infrastructure.

abstract_title: COVID-19 Antibody Response in Healthcare Providers
author_block: L. S. Tufts<sup>1</sup>, M. Marin<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Divino<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Mount Sinai Hospital,Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>The Mount Sinai Hospital,Vascular Surgery,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Antibody titers are used as markers of prior infection and immunogenicity. Seroconversion rates among healthcare providers (HCPs) exposed to COVID-19 are unknown. In this observational quality control study, we aimed to determine antibody prevalence in HCPs deployed by the Department of Surgery to treat COVID-19 patients across the Mount Sinai Health System.

Methods: During March, April and May 2020, 208 surgical HCPs were deployed to treat COVID-19 patients. Electronic health records were reviewed to determine antibody status, which was determined by an in-house serum assay that detects COVID-19-specific IgG antibodies. An anonymous survey was sent to these HCPs to elucidate more details regarding unprotected exposures.

Results: 147 of the 208 (71%) deployed HCPs underwent antibody testing. 35 (31%) tested positive. 99 HCPs (48%) responded to the survey. 93 (94%) HCPs reported consistent n95 compliance. 83 (84%), 91 (92%), 85 (86%), and 77 (78%) reported consistent compliance with face shields, gloves, gowns, and an additional surgical mask, respectively. 49 (49%) reported at least one unprotected exposure. 10 (20%) reported five or more unprotected exposures. PPE shortage was the most commonly cited reason for PPE non-compliance.

Conclusion: To our knowledge, we are the first to report antibody generation among US healthcare workers caring for COVID-19 patients. Our seropositivity rate was 31%, in contrast to other hospitals in Massachusetts and Washington that have reported a 9-10% infection rate (1-3). The most important explanation for this is that New York had over three and over six times as many cases as Massachusetts and Washington, respectively (4). Other reasons include the universal PPE shortage in New York during the peak of the disease, which was supported by our survey results, and our incomplete knowledge of the pathogenicity of COVID-19. Limitations of our study include 71% of our deployed HCPs being tested for antibodies, 48% survey completion, and the inherent recall bias encountered in survey studies. In summary, COVID-19 antibodies were detected in 31% of the HCPs who were deployed by the Department of Surgery at Mount Sinai to treat COVID-19 developed antibodies. This was likely associated with the universal PPE shortage. 

References:  1. “Information and Resources for Media about COVID-19. By the Numbers.” Brigham and Women’s Hospital. June 30, 2020. https://www.brighamandwomens.org/covid-19/for-media 2. “COVID-19 Information for the Media.” Massachusetts General Hospital. August 5, 2020. https://www.massgeneral.org/news/coronavirus/information-for-the-media 3. “COVID-19 Patient Update.” Evergreen Health. 2020. https://www.evergreenhealth.com/patient-update 4. "Coronavirus in the U.S.: Latest Map and Case Count.” New York Times. August 6, 2020. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html#state

abstract_title: Surgeon Preferences to De-implementation of Preoperative H&P Preceding Low-Risk Ambulatory Procedures
author_block: A. Kawakibi<sup>1</sup>, P. Das<sup>1</sup>, A. I. Mansour<sup>1</sup>, A. E. Rios<sup>1</sup>, A. S. Baskin<sup>1</sup>, L. A. Dossett<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan Department of Surgery and University of Michigan Center for Healthcare Outcomes & Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA

abstract_title: Disparities in Access to Elective Surgery During the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: J. A. Lin<sup>1</sup>, H. J. Braun<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Schwab<sup>1</sup>, L. Pierce<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Sosa<sup>1</sup>, E. C. Wick<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of California San Francisco,Department Of Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated healthcare disparities, disproportionally impacting patients already suffering unequal outcomes due to social determinants. To conserve resources and decrease exposures, practices and hospitals have limited elective surgeries, leading to triage based on clinical prioritization. The impact of the pandemic and elective surgery triage on access to surgical care is unknown. This study examined access to elective surgery during the COVID-19 pandemic, with attention to disparities, at two key logistical points: case request and case scheduling.

Methods: We analyzed adult non-emergency case requests at an academic institution where case triage began on 3/9/20; surgeons were newly required to prioritize cases (low/normal/high, based on CMS Tiers 1-3) with service-specific guidelines. We compared patients in the COVID era (3/9-8/2/20, date of data extraction) vs control era (3/9-8/2/19). Zip code distance was calculated with R package ZipRadius. We used logistic regression to study predictors of failure to progress from case request to scheduling during the COVID era.

Results: Elective case requests decreased 27% from control (n=16,007) to COVID era (n=11,623). Ophthalmology requests decreased the most (37%); cardiac surgery requests the least (11%). Overall, mean patient age was 52 years in both eras; proportion of female patients decreased (53.8% to 52.6%, p=0.17); non-white race/ethnicity increased (42.8% to 43.3%, p=0.39). Limited English proficiency significantly decreased from n=1,424 to 947 (8.9% to 8.1%, p=0.03); public insurance significantly decreased from n=10,103 to 7,135 (63.1% to 61.4%, p<0.01); patients living >100 miles away significantly decreased from n=5,635 to 3,768 (35.2% to 32.4%, p<0.001). In the COVID era, 21% of case requests failed to be scheduled; Table 1 shows adjusted odds ratios (aORs). Non-white ethnicity and public insurance trended toward increased aOR of scheduling failure; older age trended toward decreased aOR of scheduling failure; as expected, normal/low priority significantly increased aOR of scheduling failure. In subgroup analyses, only priority was consistently significant. In high priority cases, non-white ethnicity trended toward increased aOR of scheduling failure.

Conclusion: The COVID-19 pandemic led to disproportionately fewer case requests for patients with limited English proficiency, public insurance, or >100-mile distance to our center. In patients with case requests, only surgeon-reported priority significantly predicted failure to schedule, with a trend toward increased scheduling failure in patients with non-white ethnicity or public insurance. Understanding these disparities is urgently needed for surgeons to address them.

abstract_title: Characteristics of Highly Successful Surgeon Inventors
author_block: B. Slatnick<sup>1</sup>, J. Ceremsak<sup>3</sup>, R. Crum<sup>1</sup>, A. Yang<sup>3</sup>, P. Truche<sup>3</sup>, K. Wu<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Durgin<sup>1</sup>, H. Kim<sup>1</sup>, F. Demehri<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Boston,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Department Of Neurosurgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard Medical School,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Surgeons are at the forefront of surgical device development. In this study we investigate characteristics of surgeons who hold a high number of surgical patents and evaluate the association between the number of patents held, publications, and revenue received from medical device companies.

Methods:  The 2019 list of Fellows of the American College of Surgeons (FACS) was cross-indexed with the US Patent and Trademark Office from 1993-2018. Surgical patents were defined based on Cooperative Patent Classification (CPC) code, selecting for codes related to surgical devices, implantables, dressings, and introducers. The top 1% of patent-holding surgeons were identified. Specialty, gender, academic rank, executive title, number of publications, total NIH funding, and total payments were collected. Payments included “general payments” from drug and medical device companies as defined by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Open Payments program between 2013 and 2019. Correlations between the number of patents, academic publications, and total payments were calculated using spearman's ranked test. Data was compared to a previously presented cohort that included all FACS patent holders.

Results: 2164 FACS surgeons were identified as holding one or more patents (median 2). 25 surgeons ranked in the top 1% with respect to total number of patents held (median 31; range 25-346). These surgeons hold 16% of total surgeon-held patents. Within the larger FACS cohort, 36% of patent holders are general surgeons, whereas among the top 1% of patent holders 96% are subspecialists. The top 3 specialties were orthopedic surgery (20%), cardiothoracic surgery (16%), and neurosurgery (16%). 96% were male, compared to 98% of the FACS cohort. 15 surgeons were publicly listed as founders/CEOs/CMOs of a medical device company. 10 had no academic affiliation. The median number of publications was 49 (range 0-796). 7 had NIH funding ranging from $22K-$8.1M. The median total payments received was $54K (range $0-$106M), for a total of $218M, of which 96% were royalties (Figure 1). There was a moderate positive correlation between the number of patents held and payments received (r=0.4, p=0.049). There was no correlation between the number of patents and number of publications (p=0.18).

Conclusion: The number of patents has been proposed as a metric of academic surgical innovation success. Surgeons with the highest number of surgical patents are largely characterized as subspecialists with executive company involvement, mixed academic productivity, and high royalty payments. An understanding of these highly successful surgeon innovators may help define pathways for surgeons interested in a career in innovation.

abstract_title: Crowd-Sourced Hospital Ratings are Correlated with Patient Satisfaction but not Surgical Safety
author_block: L. T. Synan<sup>1,3</sup>, M. A. Eid<sup>1,4,5</sup>, C. R. Lamb<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Wong<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Lebanon, NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA <sup>2</sup>Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth,Department Of Surgery,Hanover, NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA <sup>3</sup>Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth,Hanover, NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA <sup>4</sup>White River Junction VAMC,VA Quality Scholars Program,White River Junction, VERMONT, USA <sup>5</sup>White River Junction VAMC,VA Outcomes Group,White River Junction, VERMONT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ratings websites offer consumers the ability to compare products and services easily. Patient reviews/recommendations of hospitals are unsolicited and less structured compared to the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (HCAHPS) surveys. Here, we evaluated ratings on 3 widely used consumer ratings websites, HCAHPS scores, and their correlation with patient safety in a national cohort of academic medical centers.

Methods: We identified 356 US acute care teaching hospitals that sent 5,000-10,000 HCAHPS surveys in 2018, representing medium to large-sized centers. We collected patient satisfaction results for each hospital (based on the “Would you recommend” question) and post-surgical patient safety indicators (PSIs) from the publically available Hospital Compare website. We also collected hospital star ratings (1–5) from Facebook (n=281 hospitals; mean 375 reviews/hospital), Google (n=354; mean 326 reviews/hospital), and Yelp (n=295; mean 82 reviews/hospital). Differences in ratings were compared with paired t-tests. Concordance between ratings websites, HCHAPS scores, and a composite PSI were assessed with Pearson’s correlation coefficient.

Results: Mean Facebook ratings (3.8, IQR 3.6-4.1) were higher than those found on Google (3.2, IQR 2.7-3.5) or Yelp (2.5, IQR 2.0-3.1), with statistically significant pairwise comparisons (p<0.001).  Each exhibited positive correlation with the HCAHPS “Recommend Hospital” score (p<0.001). Yelp correlation strength (r = 0.54) was higher than Google (r = 0.51) and Facebook (r = 0.45). A linear regression model further demonstrated that Yelp (r2 = 0.29) was more strongly correlated with HCAHPS than Google (r2 = 0.26) or Facebook (r2 = 0.20) (Figure). No consumer-driven ratings platform exhibited correlation with the composite post-surgical PSI.

Conclusion: There appears to be wide variation between platforms in consumer ratings of hospitals, and ratings on Facebook are significantly more favorable than on Google or Yelp. These are independently correlated with HCAHPS scores. While the ratings may be informed by different variables, these findings suggest that unstructured consumer reviews generally reflect similar directionality as HCAHPS satisfaction scores, particularly patients’ willingness to recommend the hospital to others. It is not clear why Yelp reviews are less favorable, but the difference across platforms may be important for users to consider. Further, the consumer ratings platforms are not correlated with the composite post-surgical PSI, so online ratings may not reflect the safety of surgical care received.

abstract_title: National Trends in the Attitudes of Adults towards Health Insurance in the United States
author_block: V. Okunrintemi<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Tsilimigras<sup>2</sup>, B. A. Patrick<sup>3</sup>, F. Gani<sup>4</sup>, D. De Nicolas<sup>5</sup>, A. Z. Paredes<sup>2</sup>, T. O. Olorunsogo<sup>3</sup>, O. E. Daniel<sup>6</sup>, H. O. Momoh<sup>7</sup>, W. J. Leland<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine,Greenville, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>State House Annex Hospital, Abuja,Abuja, NIGERIA, Nigeria <sup>4</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>5</sup>Adventist Health systems,Hawaii, HAWAII, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>7</sup>St. George's University School Of Medicine,St. George's, St. George's, Grenada
abstract_body:
Introduction:  There has been a recent increase in healthcare coverage and a resulting decrease in the proportion of uninsured individuals in the United States (US). However, the perceptions and attitudes of insured and uninsured individuals towards their health insurance have not been well examined.We sought to evaluate trends in the perception and attitudes of adults in the US towards health insurance using a nationally representative dataset.

Methods:  In this retrospective cohort study using the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS) for 2006-2015, adults (>18 years) were queried in regards to the statements “I am healthy enough that I really don’t need health insurance” and “health insurance is not worth the money it cost” over time. 

Results: A total of 217, 943 individuals were identified, representing a weighted total of 232.2 million adults in the US. The proportion of individuals who agreed that they did not require health insurance increased over time from 12.0% in the years 2006-2007 to 15.3% in the years 2014-2015 (p<0.001). Similarly, the proportion of individuals who agreed that health insurance was not worth the cost increased from 28.2% in the years 2006-2007 to 29.2% in the years 2014-2015 (p=0.008). The trend was heterogeneous with older individuals, participants enrolled in government sponsored healthcare plans (Medicare and Medicaid), and individuals with chronic medical conditions (all p<0.05). 

Conclusion: Individuals were less likely over time to agree that health insurance was necessary or that health insurance was worth the additional cost. With the imminent changes to health insurance in the US, results from this study could inform policy makers in healthcare decision-making.

abstract_title: A Provider's Survey on Pain Management for Neonates with Gastroschisis
author_block: R. Bergeson<sup>1</sup>, N. Hebballi<sup>1</sup>, V. Gupta<sup>1</sup>, E. Garcia<sup>1</sup>, M. Austin<sup>1</sup>, K. Tsao<sup>1</sup>, E. Reynolds<sup>2</sup>, L. Li<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Pediatrics,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Pain management is a balance between treating pain and minimizing the risks associated with opioid use.  In a prior study, we demonstrated significant variation in the use of opioids for pain management in gastroschisis patients.  To further understand the variation, we evaluated clinicians’ perceptions of pain and compared clinicians’ pain management preferences for gastroschisis patients.

Methods:  We conducted a vignette-based cross-sectional survey of neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) attendings, NICU fellows, NICU nurse practitioners and bedside nurses and pediatric surgery attendings.  The survey consisted of four vignettes with the following surgical management strategies: 1) sutureless primary closure, 2) spring silo placement and serial reduction, 3) handsewn silo placement and serial reduction, and 4) sutured primary closure. Providers were asked to rate their impression of the infant’s pain experience on a Likert scale (0 no pain, 5 excruciating pain) and pain management recommendation at specific times during the treatment course.   Fischer’s exact test and Fleiss’ kappa were performed to assess the association and inter-group agreement on medications administered and perception of pain. 

Results: Ninety-six of 380 electronically distributed surveys (25.3%) were completed, with response rates of 73.3% (11/16) for NICU attending physicians, 60% (6/10) for NICU fellows, 65.2% (15/23) for NICU nurse practitioners, 17.3% (56/324) for NICU registered nurses, and 100% (8/8) for pediatric surgeons. For each clinical vignette, there was poor agreement (k<0) among all providers regarding the perception of pain, and there was significant variation in the perception of pain between provider types for each of the vignettes (Figure 1). Overall, morphine was the most commonly recommended pain management, followed by acetaminophen, but there was no significant difference in the pain management (opioid vs. non-opioid vs. no pain medication) recommended for all clinical vignettes.

Conclusion: There is a lack of agreement among providers’ perceptions of pain experienced by gastroschisis patients; however, there was no significant difference in the type of medication recommended for pain management.  A standardized perioperative pain management protocol may be beneficial in this patient population.

abstract_title: Prescription Opioids in Kidney Stone Formers Requiring Surgery; What are the Current Trends?
author_block: N. Singh<sup>1</sup>, W. Poore<sup>1</sup>, Z. Burns<sup>1</sup>, R. Oster<sup>3</sup>, D. Assimos<sup>2</sup>, K. Wood<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Urology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Medicine; Division Of Preventative Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Kidney stoneformers have acute episodes of severe pain and may be at increased risk of narcotics use.  Opioids are the most effective drug for the release of pain and suffering.  Alabama has 120.3 opioid prescriptions per 100 persons.  This study was conducted to determine if there are differences in opioid prescribing for kidney stone formers requiring stone removal procedures.

Methods: A retrospective review was performed from June 2013 - July 2019 at a tertiary medical center. Twenty five patients with recurrent cystine stones were randomly matched by age, gender, and procedure to 25 recurrent non-cystine and 25 first time non-cystine stone formers. Patients underwent ureteroscopic stone removal and percutaneous nephrolithotomy. Procedural opioid utilization and the amount prescribed at discharge was determined by medical record review. Opioids prescribed over this time span was determined by a query of the Prescription Drug Monitoring Program (PDMP) data base. Morphine Milligram Equivalents (MME) was used to standardize opioid utilization.

Results: Mean intraoperative opioid use over this 6 year period (17.6 MME) and during hospitalization (47.8 MME) was similar among all cohorts.  Opioids prescribed at discharge significantly decreased (mean MME ± SD), 216.8 ±  125.9 for 2013-2016 and 124.2 ± 106.1 for ± 2017-2019 ( p<0.001). Over this 6 year period, there were no differences in the number of discrete opioid prescribers between the 3 cohorts, mean 7.9.  Opioids prescribed within 180 days of stone removal was similar amongst all 3 cohorts, mean 3377.6 MME/patient.  Over this 6 year time period there was no difference in total  amount of opioids prescribed for each cohort, mean 27,987.8 MME.  Mean MME prescribed over the 6 years for the 45 who were opioid non-naive at initial stone removal was higher than the naive cohort, 45,783 ± 123,702 versus 1,295± 2,611 (mean ± SD), approaching statistical significance, p=0.059. The majority of prescriptions (56.4%) and MME prescribed (91.9 %) were from pain management and primary care providers.

Conclusion: MME prescribed for stone removal in an environment of high utilization has not declined and is not influenced by stone disease complexity. Prior opioid exposure had an impact. An opioid stewardship program resulted in decreased opioids prescribed by the surgeons conducting stone removal but had a negligible overall influence.  The latter is driven by other care providers.

abstract_title: The Cost of Quarantine: Projecting the Financial Impact of Canceled Elective Surgery on the Hospitals
author_block: S. Dasani<sup>1</sup>, S. K. Bose<sup>2</sup>, S. E. Roberts<sup>3</sup>, C. Wirtalla<sup>3</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Anesthesiology, Perioperative And Pain Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 in the United States resulted in a three-month cessation of elective surgery—a driver of hospital revenue—and placed patients at risk and hospitals under financial stress. The resumption of procedures requires strategic considerations that account for ongoing demand as well as the backlog of patients who were unable to undergo surgery. It is critical to understand the impact that elective surgery cancellations will have on hospitals’ financial solvency and ability to provide quality care. We sought to quantify the financial impact of elective surgery cancellations during the pandemic, simulate hospitals’ recovery times, and understand the implications of the CARES Act on hospital solvency.

Methods: Elective surgical cases were abstracted from the Nationwide Inpatient Sample (2016-2017). Time series were utilized to forecast March-May 2020 revenues and demand. Sensitivity analyses were conducted to calculate the time to clear backlog cases and match expected ongoing demand in the post-COVID period. Variables included pre-COVID capacity utilization, post-COVID starting utilization, and utilization growth rate. Subset analyses were performed by hospital region and teaching status. Given the intent of the CARES Act, results were interpreted in the context of specified hospital support.

Results: National revenue loss due to elective surgery cessation was estimated to be $22.3 billion (B). Recovery to market equilibrium was conserved across strata and influenced by pre- and post-COVID capacity utilization. Median recovery time was 12-22 months across all strata. Lower pre-COVID utilization was associated with fewer months to recovery. The benefit of a greater post-COVID monthly growth rate was diminished if post-COVID starting utilization rates were higher than baseline pre-COVID utilization rates.

Conclusion: Strategies to mitigate the predicted revenue loss of $22.3B due to elective surgery cessation will vary with hospital-specific supply-demand equilibrium. One response to the threat of financial insolvency has been to furlough medical workers but this strategy may portend greater risk in the long run. If patient demand is slow to return, hospitals should focus on patient recruitment. Rather than reducing operations and furloughing workers, aggressively pursuing marketing, investment, and patient recruitment opportunities may reduce health system risk, particularly as the handicap of pandemic-related losses is likely proportional regardless of hospital type and region. In contrast, if hospital capacity is constrained, efficient capacity expansion such as by hiring additional staff, scheduling cases on nights and weekends, pursuing mergers/acquisitions, and accelerating infrastructure investments may be beneficial. Finally, the CARES Act may inadequately buffer losses observed by rural and urban non-teaching hospitals, increase these institutions’ financial risk, and exacerbate care disparities.

abstract_title: Challenges to the Utilization of Interpreters Among Surgical Providers
author_block: P. D. Rollins<sup>1</sup>, E. Londoo<sup>1</sup>, R. M. Reddy<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with limited English proficiency (LEP) have higher rates of negative health outcomes. Medical interpreters help ensure accurate understanding of informed consent, perioperative management, and discharge instructions; however, they are frequently underutilized even when available. We hypothesized that more senior physicians or those with greater foreign language exposure would use interpreter services more consistently.

Methods: We conducted a survey of surgeons (trainees and faculty) from a single academic hospital. Participants were surveyed on their proficiency in languages, their annual need/use of medical interpreters, and barriers, if any, to using interpreters. Data were analyzed using Excel and SPSS.

Results: The response rate was 12.8% (97/755), with 54% being female, including 32 residents and 55 faculty (56%). Respondents interacted with LEP patients across a variety of inpatient and outpatient settings. Participants estimated a mean 16.33 annual encounters with LEP patients (SD 16.6). One-third of providers reported needing an interpreter more frequently than they actually used one, citing an average underutilization of eight encounters per year. There was a trend of faculty being more likely to use interpreter services consistently (p=0.0502). There was no correlation between proficiency in other languages and interpreter use (p=0.26). Providers who underutilized interpreter services more commonly listed patient preference for an ad-hoc interpreter (i.e. family or friend) as a major reason for underutilizing hospital interpreter services. Overall, the most common barriers were the wait time for an available interpreter and provider preference to avoid using a phone or video interpreter if in-person services were unavailable.

Conclusion: One-third of surgical providers surveyed reported underutilization of interpreter services for their LEP patients despite acknowledging their benefit. Even among providers reporting adequate utilization, time constraints were commonly cited as a major deterrent. In addition, many defer to their patients’ preferences to have a family member or friend interpret. This may have an unintended effect on interpretation accuracy and legality, which could lead to clinically important ramifications for both patient comprehension and provider liability.

abstract_title: Biases Within Clinical Validations of Molecular Tests for Thyroid Nodules: A Systematic Review
author_block: C. C. DiGennaro<sup>1,2,3</sup>, C. Lubitz<sup>1,2,3</sup>, V. Vahdat<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Institute For Technology Assessment,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Brookline, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Molecular diagnostic tests had a $9.9b market share in 2018, primarily comprised of infectious disease and genetic testing, but the development of advanced cancer diagnostic tests is projected to increase more rapidly than other market segments. While diagnostic tests do show benefits, including reducing unnecessary surgeries and hospitalizations, these benefits can be overstated with failure to account for inherent biases. As a result, the actual clinical validity of diagnostic tests may differ from reported values, indicating flawed guidance in decision making. We aimed to review and quantify the biases within validation studies of the commercially available molecular tests (MT) primarily used to evaluate cytologically indeterminate thyroid nodules.

Methods: A systematic literature review was performed using PubMed, EMBASE, and Web of Science to identify relevant articles. Studies which reported sensitivity, specificity, PPV, or NPV of diagnostic MTs were included. These statistics were extracted, and if necessary and where possible, calculated. Reviews and validations of non-commercial gene panels were excluded. Sources of bias in the validation process were identified via examination of the study methods. The PRISMA Preferred Reporting Items checklist (2009) guided the review process.

Results: Forty-five articles were assessed for adherence to 12 criteria meant to ascertain bias in patient selection, MT ordering and interpretation, and clinical context. Commercial MTs assessed included Afirma® Gene Expression Classifier (N=32 studies), Afirma® Genomic Sequencing Classifier (N=5), Afirma® Xpression Atlas (N=1), ThyroSeq® versions 1-3 (N=12), miRinform® (N=2), Quest Diagnostics® (N=1), RosettaGx Reveal® (N=2), and ThyraMIR® (N=1). Nine studies compared two MTs, and one study compared three. Studies included a median of 132 patients (range: 22-563). Of the articles assessed, 73% (33/45) reported exclusion criteria, 22% (10/45) reported pathology evaluation blinded to MT result, and 38% reported nondiagnostic MT results in their analysis. A weighted average of 57% of nodule diagnoses were verified via index test.

Conclusion: There is room for improvement in the reporting quality and in addressing methodological biases in clinical validation studies of molecular tests. We find high rates of potential selection, diagnostic review, and partial verification biases. Ethical concerns bar the universal verification of test results; therefore, future directions of this research include developing statistical methods to account for these biases and modeling clinical impacts of the advent of molecular testing for indeterminate thyroid nodules.

abstract_title: Professional Internet Presence Amongst Endocrine Surgeons in the United States
author_block: S. Raman<sup>1,2</sup>, T. Patel<sup>1,2</sup>, G. Taylor<sup>1,2</sup>, S. M. Kling<sup>1,2</sup>, L. E. Kuo<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University,Philadelpha, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Temple University,Department Of Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Social media is a useful tool for organizational and individual promotion. There is a wide range of social media adoption within medical and surgical specialties. The use of social media and other websites by endocrine surgeons has not been investigated. We undertook this study to (1) describe the use of professional webpages by endocrine surgeons through a professional internet presence (PIP) score; and (2) analyze surgeon characteristics associated with a robust PIP.  

Methods:  A publicly-available database by the American Association of Endocrine Surgeons was used to identify self-classified endocrine surgeons in July 2020. Surgeons in training or practicing outside of the United States were excluded. Surgeon sex and practice type (academic versus community-based) were noted. Each surgeon’s PIP was identified via Google search with the term [“physician’s first and last name”+“MD/DO”+“online platform”]. For each search, the search results were limited to the first 10 returns. Five social medial platforms (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn, and YouTube) were investigated for professional accounts, as were the presence of a non-institutional professional website, an active Healthgrades account (as determined by the presence of a care philosophy), and presence in YouTube videos uploaded by a party other than the surgeon. A PIP score was calculated for each surgeon by assigning a point to a professional presence on any of the eight platforms. Professional accounts were differentiated from personal accounts by the presence of medical degrees/titles and practice information. Univariate analyses and unpaired two-sample t-tests with equal variances were conducted to describe PIP scores and estimate the relationship between surgeon characteristics and PIP score.  

Results: 407 endocrine surgeons were studied, of whom 171 (42.0%) were female. There were 255 (62.7%) academic and 152 (37.3%) community-based endocrine surgeons. LinkedIn accounts were most common (n=216), followed by YouTube videos uploaded by a third party (n=178), Twitter accounts (n=107), active Healthgrades accounts (n=69), Facebook accounts (n=17), non-institutional professional websites (n=10), Instagram accounts (n=3), and YouTube accounts (n=3). PIP scores ranged from 0 to 5, with a median of 1 and mean of 1.48 (standard deviation 1.18) accounts. The mean PIP score for academic surgeons was significantly higher than community-based surgeons (1.62 ± 0.07 vs. 1.24 ± 0.10, p<0.01). There was no significant difference in mean PIP score between men and women.  

Conclusion: Self-identified endocrine surgeons practicing in the United States have low utilization of a professional internet presence. Because many patients use social media, professional ratings websites, or other web-based tools to identify physicians, endocrine surgeons may consider bolstering their professional internet presence to attract patients.

abstract_title: Machine Learning Detects False Negative Benign Thyroid Nodule Diagnoses
author_block: A. J. Idarraga<sup>1</sup>, G. Luong<sup>1</sup>, V. Hsiao<sup>1</sup>, D. F. Schneider<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Endocrine Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thyroid nodules are remarkably common - nearly two-thirds of US adults will show nodules on high-quality ultrasound, and 95% of these nodules are benign. However, a false negative diagnosis delays cancer treatment and can be psychologically devastating to patient and provider. The purpose of this study is to develop a predictive model using machine learning which can identify falsely benign thyroid nodule biopsies based on available clinical data.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective medical record review at one academic and one community center. ICD-9 codes identified patients with thyroid nodular disease; clinical information and notes were extracted from the electronic health record. Included patients were those with thyroid nodules evaluated by ultrasound, having received Bethesda II (benign) diagnosis following fine needle aspiration. We previously developed and validated natural language processing systems to extract nodule features from text cytology, ultrasound, and pathology reports. Features included nodule size, ultrasound features and TSH levels, along with demographic data such as age and biological sex. A nodule was considered benign if either all pathology reports were benign or all follow-up cytology reports were benign. Missing values were imputed using a Random Forest based iterative method (missingpy, Python 3.8). Tree-based, rule-based, and Bayesian models were generated with WEKA 3.8.4 using 10-fold cross validation and tested for predictive accuracy. Hyperparameter selection was accomplished using an automated iterative approach to maximize model specificity and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC ROC).

Results: A total of 579 subjects met inclusion criteria; 1.7% were ultimately diagnosed with cancer. Of all algorithms tested, a Random Forest method was able to achieve the best AUC ROC (0.949, Table 1) when predicting nodules as either cancerous or benign. Random Forest was also most effective at minimizing false positives when detecting cancer (Cancer True Positive Rate = 0.100, Cancer False Positive Rate = 0.000).

Conclusion: Machine learning can accurately identify falsely benign thyroid nodules. A Random Forest model performed well using readily available data obtained via standard evaluation of thyroid nodules. Importantly, the model minimized false positives as this would be crucial for clinical applications. Future studies will prospectively evaluate the model’s performance.

abstract_title: Sex Differences in Papillary Thyroid Cancer
author_block: C. I. Lee<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Handelsman<sup>1</sup>, O. Picado<sup>1</sup>, M. W. Jeraq<sup>1</sup>, Z. F. Khan<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Farra<sup>1</sup>, J. I. Lew<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Miami Leonard M. Miller School of Medicine,Division Of Endocrine Surgery; DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Thyroid cancer is the most common endocrine malignancy with papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) being the most common type. PTC is three times more common in women than in men. Despite this sex disparity in the incidence of PTC, the differences in clinical presentation between sexes remain unclear. Although generally thought to have a good prognosis, thyroid cancer in men appears associated with poorer outcomes than in women. This study compares the clinical presentation and pathologic features of men and women with PTC.

Methods:  A retrospective review of prospectively collected data for 1854 patients who underwent FNA of a solitary thyroid nodule and thyroidectomy between January 2010 and June 2020 at a single institution was performed. Of the entire group, there were 851 patients with PTC. Patients with benign thyroid disease and other thyroid carcinoma types were excluded. Factors including age, ultrasound features, FNA results, extent of surgical operation and final histopathology were then compared between male and female patients with PTC. Advanced features on final histopathology included extrathyroidal extension (ETE), lymphovascular invasion (LVI) and lymph node (LN) positivity. Descriptive statistics using chi-square and t-test statistics were performed to compare outcomes by sex.

Results: Of 1854 patients who underwent thyroidectomy, there were 851 (46%) patients with PTC of which 158 (19%) were men and 693 (81%) were women. Mean age of patients was 48 ± 14 years, and most were of Hispanic origin (n=579, 68%). Men had a significantly higher rate of radiation exposure relative to women (n=13, 8% vs. n=14, 2%, p<0.01). There were no ultrasonographic or FNA cytologic differences among sexes. Overall, 792 (85%) patients were treated with total thyroidectomy. However, thyroid lobectomy was more commonly performed among men compared to women (n= 38, 24% vs. n= 90, 13%, p<0.01). Men more commonly had aggressive pathologic features including ETE (n=36, 23% vs. n=118, 17%, p=0.10), LVI (n=74, 47% vs. n=236, 34%, p<0.01), and positive LN (n=73, 46% vs. n=249, 36%, p=0.07) compared to women.

Conclusion: More men than women with PTC have higher rates of radiation exposure and advanced features on final histopathology including ETE, LVI and LN positivity. Despite having similar sonographic and cytologic findings as women, men with PTC have more advanced disease at time of presentation that may explain their worse prognosis. Earlier and more vigilant screening of men to detect thyroid cancer might improve clinical outcomes.

abstract_title: Exploration of the Disease Burden of Papillary Thyroid Cancer in a Hispanic Population
author_block: C. Lalonde<sup>1</sup>, S. Snyder<sup>2,3</sup>, H. Reinhart<sup>2,3</sup>, M. Machiorlatti<sup>2</sup>, M. Romero Arenas<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>HCA Medical City Arlington,General Surgery Residency,Arlington, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Texas Rio Grande Valley,School Of Medicine,Edinburg, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Texas Rio Grande Valley,General Surgery Residency,Edinburg, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is limited research on the presentation and outcomes of papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) in the United States (US) Hispanic population, though socioeconomic status and ethnicity have been associated with disparities in diagnosis and treatment. We aimed to explore the disease burden of PTC in a predominantly Hispanic community at the US-Mexico border.

Methods: A single-institution retrospective chart review of patients diagnosed with PTC from November 2010-July 2019 was conducted. Medical records of patients who underwent thyroidectomy were screened; inclusion criteria were adult (18+) patients and PTC confirmed by surgical pathology including microcarcinomas (<1cm) cases. We excluded pediatric and non-invasive follicular thyroid neoplasms with papillary-like nuclear features cases. Oncologic stage was determined using the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) edition manual. Independent samples t-tests and chi-square tests were performed to test differences between groups.

Results: One-thousand four-hundred fifty-four patients underwent thyroid surgery in the study period, of which 418 (28.8%) had PTC and 412 (28.3%) met inclusion criteria. Most patients were female (n=355, 86.2%) or Hispanic (n=369, 89.6%). The mean age at surgery was 50.4 years (range 18-86). Most patients presented before age 55 (59.0%); though women were diagnosed earlier than men (50.0 vs 53.5 y: p = 0.1295) as were Hispanic patients in comparison to non-Hispanic patients (49.1 vs 61.6: p < 0.0001) The majority of patients presented at AJCC stage I (n=305, 74.0%) or II (n=23, 5.6%) PTC, however, there was no difference in stage at presentation for Hispanics and Non-Hispanics.  The average size of the tumors was 1.53 cm (range 0.1-8) with 184 patients (44.7%) having microcarcinomas. The size of PTC was larger for Hispanic than non-Hispanic patients (mean: 1.54 cm vs 1.35 cm; p = 0.3875), but the difference was not statistically significant. Central/level 6 or lateral neck lymphadenectomy was only performed in 161 patients (39.1%) and 92 more patients (22.3%) had incidental lymph nodes sampled. Thirty-nine patients (9.5%) had lateral neck disease. Nearly all patients ultimately underwent total thyroidectomy (TT) (n=395, 95.9%), including initial total thyroidectomy (n=310, 75.2%), thyroid lobectomy with immediate completion thyroidectomy (n=45, 40.2%), and staged completion thyroidectomy (n=40, 9.7%).

Conclusion: This largely Hispanic patient population with PTC had similar stage disease as the general US population. Nearly all patients underwent TT, which may represent prior American Thyroid Association recommendations for TT in all PTC >1cm, yet central neck lymphadenectomy was not routinely performed. Therefore, lymph node metastasis of PTC may not be adequately captured. Further research needs to be conducted to better understand the disease burden, surgical management, and outcomes of PTC within the US Hispanic population.

abstract_title: Endocrine Surgery Patients' and Providers' Perceptions of Telemedicine In the COVID Era
author_block: H. Zheng<sup>1,2</sup>, J. E. Rosen<sup>1,2</sup>, N. A. Bader<sup>3</sup>, V. Lai<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Washington Hospital Center,Endocrine Surgery/Department Of Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Telemedicine has become a key option to continue to health care delivery in the wake of COVID-19.  Little data exists on the patient perspective of its use- particularly those of endocrine surgery patients—or that of providers. The aim of the study was to assess endocrine surgery patients’ attitudes about telemedicine and how the COVID-19 pandemic may have influenced them, and to compare that to the perspectives of referring endocrinologists.

Methods: Patients seen in the office from a regional endocrine surgery practice between March 1, 2019 and February 1, 2020 were mailed surveys about their perspectives on the use of telemedicine.  Referring endocrinologists were emailed a link to survey in April 2020. All surveys were anonymous.

Results: 32 patients responded (response rate 6.5%).  The average age was 60.1; 81% were female; 41% were Black.  Most either used (81%) or were willing to try (91%) telemedicine.  Nearly all (93.7%) were either very comfortable or somewhat comfortable with new technology. 90.0% of the respondents had regular and easy access to the internet and a computer. Only 33.3% believed the assessment via telemedicine was as good as an in-person visit. Convenience (78.1%) and technological availability (56.3%) were the most cited reasons to try telemedicine; quality of care (46.9%) and personal connection (53.1%) were the most cited reasons for not wanting to try it. 68.8% said COVID-19 made them more likely to use telemedicine, 6.3% were less likely; and 25.0% were not affected.  Patients preferred telemedicine for follow-up visits to review normal results (84.4%) and pre-existing problems (75.0%), but not for new consultations (56.3%), follow -up visits to review abnormal results (53.1%) or a new problem (53.3%). Almost all (93.3%) would want to meet the surgeon before surgery.  Responses did not vary by age or race (p>0.05). Sixteen referring endocrinologists responded (response rate 6.4%).  The average age was 52.4; 62.5% were female.  About half (56.3%) had used telemedicine before and 50% were very comfortable with technology.  They cited convenience (62.5%) and technological availability (18.8%) as the main reasons to use it, and quality of care (26.7%) and personal connection (20%) as mains reasons not to.  37.5% thought virtual visits were as good as in-person ones.  They would be interested in telemedicine for follow-up of normal (93%), abnormal (81%) tests, and chronic conditions (81%), but not for new visits (87.5%).  Over two thirds reported that meeting the surgeon in-person preoperatively was important or very important.

Conclusion: Telemedicine is a mutually acceptable method for patients and their providers for endocrine surgery delivery, although in-person visits continue to have their place.  Telemedicine use may continue to expand after the pandemic as an important point of access for endocrine surgery.

abstract_title: Is Preoperative Imaging Necessary For Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism?
author_block: R. Wang<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Tertiary hyperparathyroidism (tHPT) is caused by unregulated parathyroid function, which develops after longstanding secondary hyperparathyroidism. Subtotal parathyroidectomy with 4-gland exploration is required to achieve surgical cure. While some surgeons advocate for pre-operative localization with sestamibi to detect ectopic glands, many do not. Therefore, we review our experience with use of preoperative imaging in tHPT.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of patients undergoing parathyroidectomy for tHPT between 2001 and 2019. Patient demographics, preoperative and postoperative calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, radiology reports, clinical notes and operative notes, and pathology were reviewed. Preoperative imaging was compared with intraoperative findings and pathology results. The primary outcome was cure of tHPT, defined as normal calcium level at 6-months postoperatively.  

Results:We included 220 patients with a mean age of 52±11, the majority of which were male (56%). Preoperative mean calcium and PTH levels were 10.6±1.1 mg/dl and 350±400 pg/ml, respectively. The two most common preoperative symptoms were bone disease (44%) and fatigue (33%). A minority of patients (22.7%) underwent preoperative imaging (15.9% sestamibi vs 10.0% ultrasound versus 3.2% both sestamibi and ultrasound). In this study, 57 (26%) patients had ectopic glands, with the most common sites in the thymus (66.7%) and thyroid gland (21.1%). The surgeons located 79% intraoperatively, without preoperative imaging. The reoperation rate for ectopic glands in the study population was 5.0% (n=11), and among these patients, 9 (80%) were localized on imaging prior to the re-operation. 99% patients in this study achieved normal calcium at 6-month follow-up. 

Conclusion:Most ectopic glands were successfully identified by surgeons during the operation without preoperative imaging. The reoperation rate due to ectopic glands was low. Routine pre-operative Tc-99m-sestamibi scan in patients with tertiary hyperparathyroidism is not necessary for localization of parathyroid glands.

abstract_title: Assessment of Accuracy of A Physician Ratings Website In One Metropolitan Area
author_block: T. Patel<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Raman<sup>1,2</sup>, G. Taylor<sup>1,2</sup>, S. M. Kling<sup>1,2</sup>, L. E. Kuo<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Temple University,Department Of Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients frequently use online physician ratings websites (PRWs) to identify physicians for care. PRWs provide basic physician information and publish anonymous patient reviews and patient ratings. However, the accuracy of PRWs is uncertain. We investigated the accuracy of Healthgrades.com, the most commonly used PRW, regarding reported board certification of endocrine surgeons in one metropolitan area, and identified predictors of high ratings and a greater number of ratings.

Methods: Data was collected from the website www.healthgrades.com in July 2020. The search term “endocrine surgery specialist” was used and the search was limited to a 25-mile radius around Philadelphia, PA. For each search result, data was collected on physician sex, board certifications, specialty, number of ratings, average rating, if comments were responded to, and if a self-description was provided by the physician. Descriptive statistics were performed to examine surgeon characteristics, Healthgrades ratings, and reported board certification. Board certification was confirmed via search with the corresponding American Board website. Accuracy of the Healthgrades board certification was noted. A kappa statistic was calculated to measure the accuracy of the Healthgrades website. Logistic regression was performed to identify predictors of board certification accuracy, higher than median number of ratings, and of higher than average ratings.

Results: A total of 300 physicians were identified using the search criteria. The cohort median age was 57.5 (interquartile range IQR 46.5-68.5), and 77% were men. Of the 300 physicians, 290 (97%) were otolaryngologists, 1 (0.33%) was a general surgery-trained endocrine surgeon, 4 (1.3%) were general surgery-trained physicians of other specialties (1 general surgery, 1 transplant surgery, and 2 breast surgery), and 3 (1.0%) were plastic surgeons. Of the 309 board certifications amongst the 300 physicians, 260 (87%) were accurately reported on Healthgrades; the kappa statistic for accurate board certification was 0.634. Logistic regression identified providing a self description as a predictor of inaccuracy. The median number of ratings was 4 (IQR 0-13). Provision of a self-description on the Healthgrades page was predictive of a higher number of ratings. The mean “average rating” was 4.0. Surgeon response to patient comments was predictive of higher-than-average patient ratings.

Conclusion: A wide range of surgeon types are identified as endocrine surgery specialists by the most commonly used PRW. The reliability of the Healthgrades.com board certification reporting was moderate. Increased surgeon involvement with the Healthgrades site was predictive of a higher number of ratings and higher average ratings but lower accuracy.

abstract_title: Recurrent nerve injury after total thyroidectomy: risk factor analysis of a targeted NSQIP dataset
author_block: D. A. Mahvi<sup>1</sup>, L. Saadat<sup>1</sup>, E. Whang<sup>1</sup>, N. Cho<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury is a significant complication after thyroidectomy. Understanding risk factors for RLN injury and the associated postoperative complications may help inform quality improvement initiatives. 

Methods:  The American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) thyroidectomy-targeted database was utilized for patients undergoing total thyroidectomy between 2016-2017. Univariable and multivariable regression were used to identify factors associated with RLN injury with an emphasis on use of intraoperative neuromonitoring (IONM).

Results: A total of 6538 patients were identified. The overall rate of RLN injury was 7.1% (467/6538). Of these, 4129 (63.1%) patients had IONM, with an associated  RLN injury rate of 6.5% (versus 8.2% without). African American and Asian race, parathyroid auto-transplantation, and lack of RLN monitoring were all significantly associated with nerve injury on multivariable analysis (p<0.05). Patients with RLN injury were more likely to experience cardiopulmonary complications, reintubation, longer length of stay, readmission, and reoperation. Patients who had IONM and sustained RLN injury remained at risk for developing significant postoperative complications, although the extent of cardiopulmonary complications was less severe in this cohort.

Conclusion: RLN injury is common after thyroidectomy and is associated with significant morbidity, despite best practices. Attention to preoperative characteristics may help clinicians further risk stratify patients prior to thyroidectomy. While IONM does not mitigate all complications, use of this technology may decrease severity of postoperative complications.

abstract_title: Subspecialty Market Share of Cervical Endocrine Surgery: A NSQIP Analysis
author_block: Y. Lee<sup>1</sup>, K. Pei<sup>2,3</sup>, F. Zheng<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Houston Methodist Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Parkview Mirro Center for Research and Innovation,Department Of Surgery,Fort Wayne, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Analyses of ACGME case logs have previously demonstrated an increase in exposure to thyroid and parathyroid surgeries over the past two decades for both general surgery and otolaryngology trainees, with otolaryngology residents logging more cases than general surgery residents. It is unknown if this training paradigm has resulted in changes in attending practice. This study examines trends in the performance of cervical endocrine procedures by surgical subspecialty nationally over the past 12 years.

Methods:  Thyroid and parathyroid surgeries were identified from the 2007-2018 American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program Participant User File (NSQIP-PUF)  using CPT codes. The NSQIP targeted thyroidectomy database from 2016-2018 was analyzed for specific patient outcomes related to thyroidectomy including hypocalcemia, laryngeal nerve dysfunction, and neck hematoma.

Results: The total number of thyroid and parathyroid surgeries abstracted into NSQIP, performed by both general surgeons and otolaryngologists increased from 2007 to 2018. However, the percentage of total surgeries performed by general surgeons decreased from 96.18% in 2007 to 56.72% in 2018 for thyroid surgeries, 98.37% in 2007 to 78.99 % in 2018 for parathyroid surgeries. From 2016-2018 targeted thyroidectomy NSQIP database, thyroidectomies performed by general surgeons were associated with an incidence of laryngeal nerve dysfunction of 6.6% compared to 5.6% for thyroidectomies performed by otolaryngologists (P=0.007). The incidence of hypocalcemia within 30 days of discharge was 6.7% for the general surgeon group and 5.9% for the otolaryngology group (p=0.030). There were no statistically significant differences between the two groups in the incidence of hypocalcemia prior to discharge (4.3% vs 4.5%, p=0.458), clinically significant hypocalcemia (4.2% vs 3.9%, p=0.307), or neck hematoma/bleeding (1.9% vs 1.8%, p=0.650).

Conclusion: Among NSQIP participating hospitals, an increasing percentage of thyroid and parathyroid surgeries are performed by otolaryngologists. Future endeavors may be needed to sustain and improve cervical endocrine exposure among general surgery residents to facilitate post graduate practice.

abstract_title: Effect of Carcinoid Tumor Surgical Resection on Patient Quality of Life: A Prospective Analysis
author_block: J. W. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, L. Olson<sup>1</sup>, C. Divino<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai,General Surgery,New York, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  For patients with carcinoid tumors, surgery can be potentially curative and significantly reduce carcinoid syndrome symptoms. However, recurrence is common even years after surgery, which can lead to a poor quality of life. Current non-surgical strategies to mitigate recurrent carcinoid syndrome include somatostatin analogs, which have many diverse side effects. As a result, maximizing quality of life becomes the focus for many care teams following surgery for these patients. Few studies in the United States have examined how quality of life changes in patients with these carcinoid tumors following surgical interventions. In addition, these studies were only cross-sectional surveys that examined quality of life at a single time point. To our knowledge, no study has analyzed quality of life changes in carcinoid patients in a prospective and longitudinal manner. This study aims to assess changes in self-reported quality of life in patients with carcinoid tumors following resection procedures.   

Methods:  We administered prospective, longitudinal quality of life assessments using a validated instrument, the 12-item Short Form Survey (SF-12). The SF-12 is a multipurpose short form survey that captures information on overall health-related quality of life, physical functioning, and mental functioning. For these subjects with carcinoid tumors, we conducted a baseline survey preoperatively and a 3-month post-operative survey, as possible if not lost to follow up. Paired t-tests were used to compare the quality of life ratings of the participants at the different time points with their own previous response as a reference. Subjects were consented for participation at the initial surgical consultation.  

Results: The SF-12 was administered to 6 patients who qualified for this study performed in a prospective manner. On question 11 of the SF-12, patients are asked how often they felt “downhearted and blue” in the last four weeks. The study participants reported feeling this way significantly less often three months following surgical resection than prior to the surgery (p = 0.046).  

Conclusion: Overall, patients displayed an increase in quality of life as reported on the SF-12 following surgical resection of their carcinoid tumors. This is most likely due to the cessation of carcinoid syndrome symptoms upon removal of the tumor and its subsequent neuroendocrine effects on the patients' underlying physiology.

abstract_title: Fine Needle Aspiration and the Bethesda System: Correlation with Histopathology in 1318 Patients
author_block: S. M. Linhares<sup>1</sup>, R. Handelsman<sup>1</sup>, O. Picado<sup>1</sup>, B. W. Whitfield<sup>1</sup>, M. Jeraq<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Farra<sup>1</sup>, J. I. Lew<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami,Division Of Endocrine Surgery, DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) in conjunction with the Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology (BSRTC) remains the main diagnostic standard in the evaluation of thyroid nodules. The incidence of thyroid nodule detection has been steadily increasing over the last few decades; therefore, determining with confidence which lesions require further surgical management is an important clinical consideration. This study examines the correlation of FNA to final pathology in a large series of surgical patients undergoing thyroidectomy after BSRTC adoption at a single academic institution.

Methods: A retrospective review of prospectively collected data of 1318 patients who underwent FNA of a solitary thyroid nodule and thyroidectomy from a single institution between 2010-2019 was performed. The cases were stratified into the 6 Bethesda categories: 1) Non-diagnostic (ND); 2) Benign; 3) atypia of undetermined significance/follicular lesion of undetermined significance (AUS/FLUS); 4) follicular neoplasm/suspicious for follicular neoplasm (FN/SFN); 5) suspicious for malignancy (SFM); 6) Malignant; and compared to the risk of malignancy reported by the BSRTC. FNA results were compared to the index thyroid nodule and incidental malignancy on final histopathology. In addition, demographics including age, sex and extent of surgical operation were analyzed along with predictive ultrasound factors associated with malignancy.

Results: Of 1318 patients who underwent thyroidectomy, the malignancy rate of the index thyroid nodule on final histopathology was 54%. When the incidental malignancies were included, the overall malignancy rate increased to 62%. When stratified by FNA Bethesda category, the malignancy rate was 31% in ND; 14% in Benign; 50% in AUS/FLUS; 62% in FN/SFN; 86% in SFM; and 98% in malignant patients on final pathology. Rate of papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) classical type was 43%, PTC follicular variant was 38%, follicular thyroid carcinoma was 3.4%, and medullary thyroid carcinoma was 1.7% in all malignant thyroid nodules. Among 345 patients with benign FNA, 82% of all nodules were ≥ 1 cm. Among 302 patients with malignant FNA, 82% of all nodules were also ≥ 1 cm. Overall, there was a false positive rate of 1.2% and a false negative rate of 14%.  

Conclusion: In this surgical series, patients with FNA of a dominant thyroid nodule after thyroidectomy had an overall malignancy rate of 54%. There was a 14% malignancy rate in patients with benign FNA results referred for surgical resection where additional factors such as family history of thyroid cancer, suspicious ultrasound findings, and/or history of radiation exposure may have influenced the decision for surgical resection. The additional use of genetic tests and ultrasound findings may help guide surgical evaluation. Overall, the majority of patients with AUS/FLUS, FN/SFN, and SFM results with underlying malignancy received the appropriate surgical resection.

abstract_title: Comparing Surgical Thoroughness And Recurrence In Thyroid Cancer Patients Across Race/Ethnicity
author_block: P. Crepeau<sup>1</sup>, K. Kulkarni<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Martucci<sup>2</sup>, V. Lai<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Washington Hospital Center,Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Radioactive iodine (RAI) ablation or therapy has an important role for certain differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC) patients. Remnant uptake, the volume of residual thyroid tissue prior to receiving RAI, may be a marker of the thoroughness of the surgical resection; a higher remnant is associated with a higher rate of recurrence. In the United States, outcomes disparities exist among ethnic/racial minorities with DTC.  They have worse survival and decreased access to high-volume surgeons, who have improved outcomes.
