The reason for this phenomenon is poorly understood.  Specific data about surgical thoroughness and recurrence rates for different races/ethnicities, which would help understand outcomes disparities, do not exist.  This study aimed to compare the amount of thyroid remnant as seen on remnant uptake across race/ethnicity, and evaluate its association with cancer recurrence.

Methods:  This was a retrospective analysis of adult patients with DTC who had postoperative RAI in 2017 and 2018. Thyroid bed remnant was calculated from the postoperative RAI scan and analyzed as a ratio of percent uptake to dose of RAI received (UDR) to control for varying RAI doses.  Patient charts, laboratory and radiographic studies were reviewed to assess for disease recurrence through 2020. Thyroid remnant, UDR, and recurrence were evaluated across race/ethnicity.

Results: 301 of 320 patients had race/ethnicity data and were included in the study: 58% were White, 25% Black, 8% Asian, 1% American Indian, and 8% were Hispanic. 76% were female.  Papillary thyroid carcinoma was found in 89% of patients, follicular thyroid carcinoma in 8%, Hürthle cell carcinoma in 1%, and 2% had unknown pathology.  Pathology subtypes (p=0.34), T stage (p=0.11), N stage (p=0.10), and presence of gross extrathyroidal extension (p=0.51) were the same across race/ethnicity.  Most surgeons were high-volume, although volume data were not available for all.  No differences in median percent uptake or UDR existed: median remnant was 0.67% for Whites, 0.47% for Blacks, 1.19% for Asians, 0.54% for Hispanics, and 0.1% for American Indians (p = 0.14); median UDR was 6.2 x 10-5 for Whites, 4.3 x 10-5  for Blacks, 8.4 x 10-5  for Asians, 5.3 x 10-5  for Hispanics, and 6.4 x 10-6  for American Indians (p = 0.198). We did not observe a difference in the recurrence rates: 8.8% for Whites, 16.9% for Blacks, 16.8% for Asians, 16.7% for Hispanics, 0% for American Indians (p = 0.46).

Conclusion: For patients largely cared for by high-volume surgeons, we did not observe disparities across race/ethnicity in oncologic thoroughness, as seen with remnant uptake and UDR, or in recurrence.  Expansion of this study to include longer follow-up and more patients cared for by surgeons of varying operative volumes may help provide additional insight into outcomes disparities among ethnic/racial minorities.  Our findings support further study into causes of access disparities to high-quality surgeons.

abstract_title: Tired of Being Ignored: Fatigue as a Presenting Symptom in Primary Hyperparathyroidism
author_block: K. B. Montgomery<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fatigue is a common presenting symptom in primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT). While fatigue alone is not a discrete indication for parathyroidectomy, it can have a significant detrimental effect on patient quality of life. The purpose of this study was to determine if there are underlying differences in demographic or disease characteristics in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism who present with fatigue compared to those who do not.

Methods: We reviewed a prospective database of 2197 patients undergoing parathyroidectomy for PHPT by three endocrine surgeons from 2001 to 2019. Data was abstracted from clinical and operative notes including patient demographics, laboratory data, and pathology reports. All patients in the database were divided into two groups based on the presence or absence of fatigue as a presenting symptom. Objective measures of disease severity, such as biochemical markers, clinical indications for surgical intervention, and surgical outcomes, were then compared between groups.

Results: Of the 2197 patients, 1379 (63%) reported fatigue as a presenting symptom. Mean age in years was 59 ± 0 for patients with fatigue compared to 61 ± 0 for those without (p = 0.078). Patients with fatigue were more likely to be of female gender (80%) compared to the No Fatigue group (76% female) (p = 0.046). Preoperative calcium was lower in the Fatigue group (10.8 ± 0.1 vs. 11.1 ± 0 mg/dL, p = 0.05). There was no statistically significant difference in preoperative serum parathyroid hormone levels between groups. Patients with fatigue had smaller parathyroid glands (581 ± 24 vs. 741 ± 43 mg, p = 0.001). Importantly, patients with fatigue had a higher incidence of multiglandular disease as the cause of their PHPT (37% vs 27%, p = 0.001) and were more likely to present with normocalcemic PHPT (28% vs 16%, p = 0.001). No significant differences in cure rate, recurrence rate, or history of nephrolithiasis were detected between groups

Conclusion: Patients with PHPT who report fatigue as at least one of their presenting symptoms present with more complex disease as manifested by a higher incidence of multiglandular disease, more normocalcemic PHPT, and smaller parathyroid glands. Despite this, surgical cure is equivalent to other patients. Therefore, parathyroidectomy should be offered to these patients.

abstract_title: Rescue Improvement Conference: A Novel Tool for Addressing Failure to Rescue
author_block: J. N. Ervin<sup>1</sup>, C. Vitous<sup>2</sup>, E. E. Wells<sup>2</sup>, S. L. Krein<sup>3</sup>, C. R. Friese<sup>3</sup>, A. A. Ghaferi<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan,Pulmonary & Critical Care/Internal Medicine,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Michigan,School Of Nursing,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Every year, over 150,000 patients die after elective surgery in the United States. Failure to rescue (FTR) is the phenomenon whereby delayed recognition and/or response to serious surgical complications leads to a progressive cascade of adverse events culminating in death. Rescue Improvement Conference is an adapted version of a traditional morbidity and mortality (M&M) conference, designed to address common contributors to FTR: ineffective communication and inadequate problem solving among clinicians. During each session, cases are reviewed by multiple stakeholders, capitalizing on their collective experiences to identify and implement multilevel improvements for the timely identification and treatment of post-operation complications. In this study, we sought to understand the acceptability and effectiveness of Rescue Improvement Conference.

Methods: We used both quantitative and qualitative data to evaluate Rescue Improvement Conference, a bi-monthly forum that was first introduced in our academic medical center in fall 2018. Conference effectiveness data were collected via survey and open-text responses after five Rescue Improvement Conferences between September 2018 and February 2020. Twelve surgical faculty and house staff also participated in semi-structured interviews to evaluate Rescue Improvement Conference.  Qualitative data were analyzed using thematic analysis.

Results:According to the survey data (N=140) conference attendees felt that the case presentations had educational value, there were clear takeaways, there was adequate time for discussion, the case discussion would inform their future practice, and that Rescue Improvement Conferences present actionable opportunities for improvement (see Table 1). The qualitative data supports the quantitative findings, and two additional themes emerged: novelty and conference moderation. Interviewees found Rescue Improvement Conference to be more interactive and more representative of diverse voices than traditional M&M. And while traditional M&M focuses primarily on individual decision-making, Rescue Improvement Conference focuses on multilevel problem solving among surgeons and clinicians from other departments and disciplines. Interviewees also appreciated moderators who were open to others’ opinions, kept the conference on track, and used rescue concepts and related frameworks to evaluate cases. 

Conclusion:Rescue Improvement Conference provides interdisciplinary stakeholders a forum to identify, discuss, and mitigate factors that contribute to FTR. We are currently using this feedback to further refine Rescue Improvement Conference in our institution, while also preparing to package it for implementation in other academic surgical departments.

abstract_title: Utility of Routine In-Person Postoperative Clinic Appointments After Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy
author_block: J. J. Squiers<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Blair<sup>1</sup>, J. Misenhimer<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Perryman<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Jacinto<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Rodriguez<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>John Peter Smith Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Ft. Worth, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Dallas, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Despite significant time commitments for both patients and surgeons, the utility of routine in-person clinic appointments after laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC) is uncertain. We aimed to evaluate the utility of routine in-person follow-up for all patients undergoing LC and predictors of non-routine follow-up encounters in these patients.

Methods: We retrospectively reviewed follow-up encounters for 665 consecutive patients undergoing isolated LC for benign indications at a safety-net teaching hospital from April 2018 through January 2020. Twenty patients converted to open cholecystectomy were exluded. All patients were routinely scheduled for follow-up in clinic 2-4 weeks after discharge. Follow-up was considered non-routine if the patient was readmitted within 30 days or if any of the following occurred at the clinic appointment: intervention performed (including wound care), new imaging/labs ordered, new medication prescribed, referral to ED, or malignancy on pathology. A multivariate logistic regression model was generated using backwards elimination based on the Akaike information criterion (AIC) to identify risk factors for non-routine follow-up.

Results: The scheduled follow-up appointment was attended by 452 (68%) patients, and the remaining 213 (32%) were “no-shows.” A total of 80 patients were readmitted or had non-routine clinic visits. Readmission occurred in 42 patients, with no differences between clinic attenders and “no-show” patients. Readmission occurred on mean day 9 after discharge and prior to scheduled follow-up in 83% of cases. The clinic visit was non-routine for 40 patients (6% of all patients; 9% of those attending clinic); reasons (not mutually exclusive) included: drainage of seroma (n=5), drain removal (n=3), new imaging (n=12), new labs (n=6), antibiotics for incisional cellulitis (n=2), pain medication prescription (n=13), referral to ED (n=2), and malignant pathology (n=1). Increasing age (+2% risk per year), diabetes, and chronic kidney disease were the strongest predictors of non-routine follow-up (Table). 

Conclusion: The incidence of non-routine postoperative course warranting further evaluation or intervention during follow-up clinic after LC is low, and nearly one-third of patients do not attend their follow-up appointment. Readmission typically occurred prior to routinely scheduled follow-up. Thus, routine in-person clinic appointments for all patients after LC may not be necessary. In an era of renewed interest in telehealth, prospective evaluation of a protocol for postoperative follow-up of LC patients via default telehealth visits (with selective in-patient follow-up for older patients and those with comorbidities) within one week of discharge is planned.

abstract_title: Crowdsourcing Complication Data Entry Using a Smartphone Application
author_block: L. S. Brubaker<sup>1,2</sup>, G. Van Buren<sup>1,4</sup>, S. Mohamed<sup>1</sup>, U. Ramamurthy<sup>3</sup>, A. L. Wood<sup>1,4</sup>, M. E. Navarro Cagigas<sup>1,4</sup>, W. E. Fisher<sup>1,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Michael E. DeBakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Center For Translational Research On Inflammatory Diseases,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Baylor College of Medicine,Department Of Pediatrics,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Dan L Duncan Comprehensive Cancer Center,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Surgical outcomes databases are powerful quality improvement tools. The methods used to identify and record complications have a critical impact on the usefulness of the data. We created a novel, HIPAA-compliant, web-based smartphone application (app) to enable prospective collection of complication data by crowdsourcing. We hypothesized that this system would provide more accurate and complete data than standard methods.

Methods:  An app was created to automatically download the surgery schedule from the electronic medical record. Attendings and residents were trained to use the app and used a mobile phone to input data at the bedside or in clinic as complications were identified. All members of the surgical teams had simultaneous access to the app and the ability to record complications. Complication data recorded in the app from July 8, 2019 to July 10, 2020 was retrospectively compared to complication data obtained from a hospital administrative database (AD) that is used for quality improvement. Analysis was performed using chi-squared tests for categorical variables and Cohen’s kappa to assess concordance between databases. A p-value of <0.05 was considered statistically significant. 

Results: Case data from 4,552 inpatient and outpatient cases from the acute care, bariatrics, surgical oncology, endocrine, colorectal, vascular, and transplant services was automatically imported into the app. The AD, which only captures inpatient cases, had case data for 1,314 of these cases. Of these 1,314 inpatient cases, there was a higher incidence of cases with at least 1 complication in the AD compared to the app (306 (23.3%) vs. 62 (4.7%), p-value <0.001). To assess concordance between the systems, the 62 cases with at least 1 inpatient complication recorded in the app were compared with those in the AD. The AD only captured complications for 37 of these cases (59.7%) and there was no agreement between the databases (Cohen’s kappa -0.403, p<0.001). Respiratory, GU, and ‘other’ complications were captured more frequently by the AD while hemorrhage/hematoma was recorded more frequently in the app (Figure 1). The AD captured 100% of respiratory and thrombotic complications that were reported in the app. The rate of agreement was lower for other complications (67% for cardiac, 50% for CNS, GU, and sepsis, 41% for hemorrhage/hematoma, 40% for GI, and 25% for wound), suggesting that complications considered important by clinicians (i.e. hemorrhage, wound infection) are frequently missed in the AD. 

Conclusion: Crowdsourcing complication data entry using an app is an innovative way to record clinically relevant complications. The app serves as a useful adjunct to existing ADs to more completely assess postoperative outcomes.

abstract_title: Variation in Postoperative Prescribing after General Surgical Procedures: A Physician Survey
author_block: G. Dennis<sup>1</sup>, L. E. Peters<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Zhao<sup>1,2</sup>, S. R. Smith<sup>1,2,3</sup>, H. Pearce<sup>2</sup>, P. Pockney<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Newcastle,Faculty Of Health,Newcastle, NSW, Australia <sup>2</sup>John Hunter Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Newcastle, NSW, Australia <sup>3</sup>Hunter Medical Research Institute,Newcastle, NSW, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction:  In Australia, the responsibility of prescribing discharge medications after surgical procedures differs between the public and private setting. In the public, the surgeons and their teams are responsible, while in the private sector the anaesthetist is typically the prescriber of discharge medications. We sought to investigate the differing practices of these two groups via physician survey.

Methods:  We emailed consultant general surgeons and consultant anaesthetists in our local district requesting participation in an online survey on their individual prescribing practices. We used local mailing lists from both public and private hospitals in the district to identify potential respondents. The survey requested information surrounding the routine discharge prescription practices after the following uncomplicated operations: laparoscopic appendicectomy (LA), elective inguinal hernia repairs (IH), and laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC). The study has been approved by the local ethics committee.

Results: 66 consultants responded to the survey, 38 anaesthetists and 28 surgeons. The anaesthetic cohort were more likely to prescribe opioids for all operations than their surgeon counterparts: LA 16.7% vs 34.3%, IH 30.8% vs 52.9%, LC 26.9% vs 70.3%. Despite this, only LC reached statistical significance (p=0.002). The mean quantity of opioids theoretically prescribed (in oral morphine equivalents) by each prescribing group likewise differed, with the anaesthetic cohort averaging higher quantities for all procedures: LA 7.8 vs 58.88 (p=0.024), IH 27.6 vs 52.73 (p<0.001), and LC 21.6 vs 73.13 (p=0.007).

Conclusion: This survey demonstrates that there may be a difference in prescribing practices between the surgeon and anaesthetic cohorts. Moreover because of the different settings of each of these prescribing groups (i.e. public vs private practice) patients may be receiving differing quantities of opioids in the private and public setting. While our study does not specifically look at the frequency and quantity of opioids prescribed to actual patients, it does highlight areas for potential change when dealing with the over-prescription of opioid medications after general surgical procedures. Further prospective studies are required to investigate the actual difference in prescribing between the public and private sectors.

abstract_title: Hospital Variations in Routine Preoperative Testing Prior to Low-Risk Surgical Procedures in Michigan
author_block: N. L. Berlin<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Metz<sup>3</sup>, J. D. Syrjamaki<sup>4</sup>, M. L. Yost<sup>4</sup>, B. Cheng<sup>4</sup>, H. Nathan<sup>2,4</sup>, L. A. Dossett<sup>2,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,National Clinician Scholars Program,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,School Of Medicine,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>Michigan Value Collaborative,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>Michigan Program on Value Enhancement,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Routine preoperative testing before low-risk procedures does not prevent adverse events and can lead to dangerous and expensive care cascades involving risky interventional diagnostic studies. Despite high-quality evidence and professional recommendations, routine preoperative testing is common. Eliminating unnecessary preoperative testing has thus become a critical opportunity to improve value-based surgical care. The objectives of this study were to characterize hospital variations in preoperative testing prior to common low-risk ambulatory surgical procedures in Michigan.

Methods:  A retrospective analysis of claims data from the Michigan Value Collaborative (MVC) was performed to identify patients who underwent lumpectomy, laparoscopic cholecystectomy, or laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair between January 1, 2015 to June 30, 2019. The MVC is a Blue Cross Blue Shield funded collaborative quality initiative comprised of 87 hospitals across the state of Michigan with prospectively collected data on patient demographics, perioperative care, and spending for patients undergoing surgical procedures. Preoperative tests included cardiac testing (i.e., EKG, ECHO, or stress tests), chest radiography, laboratory studies (i.e., CBC, BMP, coagulation tests), urinalysis, pulmonary function testing, and history and physical examinations performed within 30 days of the surgical procedure. We estimated rates of testing before the three procedures separately and together at the hospital level. Hospitals with fewer than 10 surgical procedures were excluded.

Results: The cohort included 10,026 patients who underwent lumpectomy, 22,072 patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and 10,513 patients who underwent laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. Among 42,611 patients, 37.9% (n=16,147) were male and 44.3% (n=18,896) were at least 65 years old. Mean rates of preoperative testing were 70.9%, 70.6%, and 57.0% for lumpectomy, laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair, respectively. There were wide variations at the hospital level in testing before each of the surgical procedures. For example, the rate of preoperative EKGs ranged from 0% to 82% for lumpectomy, 11% to 53% for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and 0% to 71% for inguinal hernia repair. The rate of preoperative chest radiography ranged from 0% to 60% for lumpectomy, 0% to 29% for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and 2% to 52% for laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. The rate of preoperative history and physical examination ranged from 75% to 100% for lumpectomy, 64% to 96% for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and 52% to 94% for laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. 

Conclusion: Wide variations and high rates of testing before low-risk surgical procedures at hospitals across Michigan suggest overuse of these services and represent an opportunity to reduce spending and improve patient outcomes. Further work is needed to understand the drivers of this variation.

abstract_title: Predictors for Tracheostomy in Patients with Cervical Spinal Cord Trauma.
author_block: R. Grady<sup>1,2</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>1,2</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,3</sup>, J. S. Lozada<sup>3,4,5</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1,2</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Broward Health North,Trauma Services,Deerfield Beach, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clinical factors included in the decision to tracheostomize patients after cervical spinal cord injury (CSCI) are an ongoing topic of debate. The goal of this study was to analyze patients with CSCI and neurological deficit to delineate variables predictive for tracheostomy.

Methods: This retrospective cohort study included 255 patients with CSCI and neurological deficit admitted to three Level 1 Trauma Centers between February 2015 and March 2020. There were 44 patients tracheostomized (TR) during their hospital stay who were compared to 211 patients who were not tracheostomized (NTR). Analyzed variables included age, mechanism of injury (MOI), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) impairment grade, Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for spine, Neurological Level of Injury (NLI), and the rates of cervical vertebrae fracture, facet dislocation, and paravertebral hematoma formation. Univariate and multivariable analyses were conducted.

Results: The TR and NTR groups were of similar age (52.5 vs 58.7, p=0.06) and experienced similar MOI (61.4% MVC, 27.3% fall vs 46.4% MVC, 46.4% fall, p=0.09). The TR group had a significantly higher ISS (31.3 vs 18.8, p<0.001) and lower GCS (10.3 vs 13.9, p<0.001) than the NTR group. The ASIA score distribution between groups was significantly different (p<0.001), with the TR group having a significantly higher rate of ASIA A and B scores (68.2% vs 15.2%) compared to NTR. Similarly, distribution of AIS spine score between groups was significantly different (p<0.001), with the TR group having a significantly higher rate of critical and maximal AIS spinal scores (65.9% vs 17.5%) compared to NTR. NLI distribution was not different between the groups (p=0.9), with the most common NLI in both groups at C4 (25.6% vs 27.1%) and C5 (25.6% vs 20.8%). Regarding vertebrae injury, TR patients had a significantly higher rate of cervical fractures (81.8% vs 49.8%, p<0.001) and cervical facet dislocation (38.6% vs 18.5%, p=0.003) than NTR patients [Fig.1]. Incidence of paravertebral hematoma formation was similar between the TR and NTR groups (34.1% vs 29.4%, p=0.5). Multivariable analysis found that only ASIA grades A and B were a significant predictor of the need for tracheostomy (p=0.003).

Conclusion: ASIA grades A and B, as spinal injury severity indicators, were found to be predictors of the need for tracheostomy following a cervical spinal cord injury with neurological deficit, while the neurological level of injury was not a predictor. Supplemental factors for tracheostomy consideration include the presence of cervical facet dislocation or cervical vertebrae fractures.

abstract_title: Impact of Delayed Surgical Management on 30-Day Mortality in Small Bowel Obstruction
author_block: A. Rugendyke<sup>1</sup>, G. Francis<sup>1</sup>, M. Holmes<sup>1</sup>, J. Gani<sup>1</sup>, P. Pockney<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hunter New England Health,Department Of Surgery,Newcastle, NSW, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Small bowel obstruction is a common indication for emergency laparotomy. In an audit of all emergency laparotomies performed on adults at four centres over a three-year period, small bowel obstruction was the most common indication for surgery, comprising 36.5% of 1111 cases. Significant variability was noted in the timing of surgical management, and there is a paucity of published evidence to support the hypothesis that delayed surgery has a negative impact on patient outcomes. The aim of this study is to determine whether delayed surgical management of small bowel obstruction is associated with a higher 30-day mortality rate.

Methods: Data was collected retrospectively from the medical records of all patients aged 18 years or older who underwent emergency laparotomy for small bowel obstruction at four hospitals between January 2016 and December 2018. The primary outcome measure was 30?day mortality, with patients grouped according to the timeframe from admission until surgery (<24 hours, 24-72 hours and >72 hours).   

Results: 337 patients underwent emergency laparotomy with adhesiolysis or bowel resection for small bowel obstruction. The overall 30-day mortality rate was 27/337 (8%). There was no difference in mortality between patients who had surgery performed in under 24 hours compared with those who had surgery within 24-72 hours (7.1% 30-day mortality for both groups, p=0.99). These two groups were therefore combined and compared with those who had surgery more than 72 hours after hospital admission. Patients who had a delay to surgery of more than 72 hours had a higher 30-day mortality rate (11.4%), although this did not reach statistical significance (p=0.24).

Conclusion: Among patients requiring emergency laparotomy for small bowel obstruction, a delay to surgery of greater than 72 hours was associated with higher 30?day mortality. Although this did not reach statistical significance, the findings from this relatively small cohort are consistent with published international data from the UK-based NELA audit. This suggests that there may be potential to improve the management SBO our healthcare system, as has been demonstrated internationally.

abstract_title: Fast-track non-elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy is safe and feasible
author_block: K. Jacinto<sup>1,2</sup>, J. J. Squiers<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Perryman<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Rodriguez<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>John Peter Smith Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Ft. Worth, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Dallas, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Ample evidence exists to support the safety of fast-track discharge following elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC), but there is currently no data available to support the safety of fast-tracking patients undergoing non-elective LC. We sought to determine whether fast-tracking patients undergoing non-elective LC is safe and feasible.

Methods:  We performed a retrospective review of 665 consecutive patients undergoing LC at a single teaching institution from Apr 2018 to Jan 2020. Subjects were divided into two groups: elective LC (ELC) and fast-track non-elective LC (FTLC). FTLC was defined as non-elective LC with total length of stay (LOS) less than 36 hours. Patients undergoing non-elective LC with LOS exceeding 36 hours were excluded. The primary outcome of interest was readmission within 30 days. Secondary outcomes included incidences of return to emergency department within 30 days, retained stone, bile leak, and wound infection. ELC and FTLC were compared with Student’s t and Fischer’s exact testing (p < 0.05 considered significant).

Results: Of 665 LC, 187 (28%) were elective and 478 (72%) were non-elective. FTLC included 122 (25%) of the non-elective LC. ELC had higher rates of hypertension and GERD, but otherwise preoperative characteristics were similar. On final pathology, chronic cholecystitis was predominant in both groups, but FTLC exhibited higher rates of acute cholecystitis (p < 0.001) There was no significant difference in the primary outcome between groups: readmission within 30 days occurred in 7 (4%) ELC patients and 4 (3%) FTLC patients (p = 1.0). There were no significant differences in any secondary outcome (Table).

Conclusion: With comparable post-operative complication rates to elective LC, fast-track non-elective LC can safely be employed in select patients.  Additional studies are needed to determine pre-operative predictors to prospectively identify appropriate patients.

abstract_title: Improved Outcomes of Elective Hernia Repair in Patients with Cirrhosis
author_block: A. Jackovich<sup>1</sup>, S. Gupta<sup>1</sup>, F. Sheikh<sup>1</sup>, W. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Alvarez-Downing<sup>1</sup>, D. R. Cummings<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Shapiro<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Merchant<sup>1</sup>, D. H. Livingston<sup>1</sup>, N. E. Glass<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>New Jersey Medical School,Surgery,Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cirrhosis has traditionally been seen as a contraindication to elective surgery.  Abdominal wall hernias are common in patients with cirrhosis and when associated ascites these hernias can sometimes become symptomatic, ruptured, incarcerated, or strangulated, and require urgent herniorraphy.  We reviewed management of cirrhotic patients who required herniorraphy at a safety net hospital to assess optimal management for these complex patients.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of patients undergoing hernia repair who had cirrhosis at an urban safety net hospital over a 3 year period. Patient demographics, cirrhosis characteristics, procedures performed, hospital course, and discharge disposition were abstracted. Patients with prolonged length of stay, death, or other complications were further reviewed to identify areas for improvement.

Results: There were 48 cirrhotic patients who underwent hernia repair.  The majority of patients were male (32) and the average age was 58.  Half of hernias were ventral/incisional, one third were umbilical, and the rest were either inguinal or other. Over half of patients presented for elective surgery, and were not admitted to the hospital postoperatively.  Most patients presenting emergently underwent open surgery, while nearly half in the elective group underwent laparoscopic hernia repair. There were a few major complications primarily pneumonia, and other post-operative infections; 1/3 of patients had prolonged lengths of stay >7 days; and one patient died.  The patients with prolonged lengths of stay were primarily in the emergency surgery group.

Conclusion: Most patients with cirrhosis had good short-term outcomes, and uncomplicated postop care.  With modern perioperative care, the perception of surgery as contraindicated in stable cirrhotics is unwarranted. As expected, patients requiring emergent operations had much worse outcomes and these data suggest that a more aggressive approach about fixing symptomatic hernias in cirrhotic patients early on is needed in order to avoid poor outcomes.

abstract_title: Abdominal/Pelvic CT Scans in Adolescent Blunt Trauma Patients: Are They Being Overutilized?
author_block: A. F. Kolousek<sup>1</sup>, B. Sharma<sup>1,6</sup>, M. Mubasher<sup>4</sup>, K. Archer-Arroyo<sup>7</sup>, R. Smith<sup>3</sup>, J. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, C. Butler<sup>1</sup>, S. Todd<sup>2</sup>, E. W. Childs<sup>1</sup>, R. Sola<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Morehouse School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>Grady Memorial Hospital,Acute Care Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>Emory University,Department Of Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>4</sup>Morehouse School of Medicine,Department Of Community Health And Preventative Medicine,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>6</sup>Mercer University,Department Of Medical Education,Macon, GA, USA <sup>7</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Department Of Radiology,Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Computed tomography (CT) scans are part of routine evaluation of pediatric patients following blunt trauma. Recent evidence demonstrates that adult trauma centers overutilize CT scans during the evaluation of pediatric and adolescent trauma patients. The aim of this study is to review the use of abdominal/pelvic CT scans (APCT) in adolescent trauma patients. The hypothesis is that the center has a high rate of CT usage and a low rate of positive CT scans within this population.

Methods: This is a retrospective review of adolescent (13 to 18-year-old) blunt trauma patients from an urban adult level 1 trauma center from January 2016 to December 2019. The trauma database was accessed to identify patients < 18 years old that underwent an APCT scan after blunt trauma. The primary outcome was the prevalence of positive findings on APCT scan.  Additionally, clinical risk factors concerning for intra-abdominal injury were collected, which included tachycardia, hypotension, abdominal or pelvic pain, abnormal abdominal or pelvic exam (tenderness, distension, "seatbelt sign), pelvic fracture on x-ray, abnormal FAST exam, elevated transaminases, microhematuria and a hematocrit < 30%.   Moderate to severe injuries were defined as those with an abdominal abbreviated injury scale ≥ 2 which includes injuries with a > 1% threat to life such as solid organ injury or bowel and bladder perforation. The correlation of clinical risk factors with intra-abdominal injury were analyzed using univariate Fischer-Exact analysis.  Variables with significant correlation (p value ≤ 0.05) were analyzed using multivariate logistic regression. 

Results: 251 patients underwent an APCT. Of those, 67% (167) were male; the mean age was 16.6±1.5 years, and 54% (136) were African American. The most common mechanism of injury was motor vehicle collision (61%) and the mean injury severity score (ISS) was 17.3±11.9. 97 (39%) patients had a positive finding on APCT.  Of those 25 (26%) had pelvic injury, 55 (57%) had intra-abdominal injury and 17 (18%) had a combination. Of patients with positive CT, 57 (59%) had a moderate to severe abdominal injury and 13 (13%) required surgical intervention.  Risk factors for intra-abdominal injury were present in 100% of patients with intra-abdominal injury and absent in 28% of patients without intra-abdominal injury.  On multivariate analysis abnormal abdominal exam (OR = 13.9; 95% CI: 4.8-40.1; p < 0.01) and elevated transaminases (OR = 7.4 ; 95% CI: 2.7-20.5; p < 0.01) were independent risk factors for intra-abdominal injury.

Conclusions: APCT appears to be overutilized in the adolescent blunt trauma population. Approximately one third of patients without intra-abdominal injury had no identifiable clinical risk factor prior to undergoing their CT. Future quality improvement projects focusing on identifying clinical risk factors prior to undergoing an APCT may reduce its use in adolescent trauma patients.

abstract_title: Smartphone Alerts for Early Trauma Team Activation: Millennial Technology in Healthcare
author_block: N. D. Goulet<sup>1</sup>, H. Liu<sup>2</sup>, P. Petrone<sup>2</sup>, S. Islam<sup>3</sup>, G. Glinik<sup>1</sup>, D. K. Joseph<sup>2</sup>, G. A. Baltazar<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>NYU Langone Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Brooklyn, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>NYU Winthrop Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Mineola, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>NYU Winthrop Hospital,Department Of Biostatics,Mineola, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early trauma team activation (TTA) allows an organized, multidisciplinary response to the care of the injured. Rapid data access through smartphone applications has reframed workplace procedure and policy, but its impact in the healthcare field remains unclear. Citizen is a free smartphone application that provides real-time alerts based on 911 dispatch data. Our primary objective was to determine whether these alerts occurred earlier than TTA times and emergency department (ED) arrival times.

Methods: Trauma registry data were extracted from a single level one trauma center from 1/1/2018 to 6/30/2019. Registry entries were compared to smartphone alert metadata from the trauma center catchment area during the same time period. Registry entries and metadata were matched according to mechanism of injury, date, time and location. Alert timestamps were compared to times for TTA and ED arrival. Percentage of time that alerts reported an injury earlier than registry times was computed along with exact binomial 95% confidence interval. Median differences between timestamps were presented along with interquartile ranges.

Results: Of 3684 registry entries, 209 perfectly matched smartphone alert metadata. Alerts were earlier than 96.1% and 96.2% of TTA and ED arrival times, respectively. The application reported events a median of 36 (24-53, IQR) minutes earlier than TTA times and 32 (25-42, IQR) minutes earlier than ED arrival times. Registry entries for younger males, pedestrian struck, motor vehicle collisions and penetrating trauma were more likely to match alerts (p<0.0001) (Table).

Conclusion: Smartphone applications may provide earlier notification of traumatic events therefore earlier TTA and mobilization of resources. This earlier notification may translate into more organized care and improved patient outcomes. Additional studies into the benefit of smartphone applications for trauma care are warranted.

abstract_title: Time to Interventional Radiology in Pelvic Fractures: Retrospective Review of a Level 1 Trauma Center
author_block: H. Joshi<sup>2</sup>, J. Gaughan<sup>3</sup>, A. Goldenberg-Sandau<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Cooper University Hospital,Trauma Surgery,Camden, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Cooper Medical School of Rowan University,Camden, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>Cooper University Hospital,Cooper Research Institute,Camden, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Definitive hemorrhage control is a critical step in decreasing morbidity and mortality from severe pelvic fractures. One step in the algorithm for treating pelvic fractures with active hemorrhage is by performing angiography and embolization of the pelvic arteries. Measuring the time to angiography for patients requiring embolization can be used to identify where system changes can be made to expedite the treatment of trauma patients.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective review (January 2012-December 2017) of adult patients (>17y) with pelvic fractures who arrived to our Level 1, urban trauma center. Data was collected on age, sex, race, injury severity score (ISS), presence of hemodynamic compromise (HC), initiation of massive transfusion protocol (MTP), time of arrival, time of CT scan, time to receive CT scan results, time to angiography, complications and mortality. Presence of hemodynamic compromise was defined as a systolic blood pressure <90mmHg and/or heart rate >120bpm.Time of arrival was categorized as day (0700-1859 hrs.) and night (1900-0659 hrs.), based on the Interventional Radiology (IR) attending rotation schedule. We used Wilcoxon Two-sample test to analyze the data and Wald Chi Square for single and multiple variable analysis using a p-value of 0.05 to evaluate significance.

Results:  A total of 1263 patients were identified with pelvic fractures, of which 78 (6.2%) requiring embolization by IR. Of the patient requiring embolization, the average time to angiography was 83 minutes (SD 117.37 minutes). The average time to angiography for patients arriving in the day was 58 minutes compared 108 minutes at night (p=.0208). There was no difference in time to angiography between patients with hemodynamic compromise with initiation of MTP and those who presented hemodynamically stable (HC+MTP, 70 min; hemodynamically stable, 85 minutes, p=.7193). Single variable and multivariable analysis of age, sex, race, presence of hemodynamic compromise and time to angiography did not influence the outcome of mortality.

Conclusion: Our data suggest that there was no statistically significant difference in time to IR between patient with and without hemodynamic compromise. However, there was a significant increase in time to angiography when comparing time of arrival at the hospital with an increased time during the night compared to daytime. Given the results, we can focus on creating ways to improve the significant difference in time to angiography.

abstract_title: Should Rib Fracture Patients be Transferred to High Acuity Trauma Hospitals?
author_block: A. C. Ferre<sup>1</sup>, C. W. Towe<sup>3</sup>, P. A. Zmijewski<sup>2</sup>, P. Ladha<sup>2</sup>, V. P. Ho<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Cleveland Clinic,General Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>MetroHealth Medical Center,Trauma,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>University Hospitals,Thoracic Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Among patients with severe traumatic injuries, transfer to specialized centers is considered the standard of care. The benefits of specialty treatment for rib fractures has not been shown. We hypothesized that patients with high risk rib fractures treated in high acuity trauma centers would have better outcomes than patients treated in other centers.

Methods: All rib fracture patients were identified via the 2016 Nationwide Inpatient Sample using ICD-10 codes; abbreviated injury scales (AIS) and Elixhauser comorbidity scores were also extracted. Chest AIS was grouped as mild (<=1) or severe (>=2). All patients with AIS>2 in any other body region were excluded. High acuity trauma hospitals (TH) were defined as hospitals which transferred 0% of neurotrauma patients; all other hospitals were defined as Non-trauma Hospitals (NTH). Poor outcome was defined as any patient who died, had a tracheostomy, developed pneumonia, or had a length of stay in the longest decile. Logistic regression with an interaction term for TH and chest trauma severity was performed.

Results: 29,780 patients with rib fractures were identified (median age 64 (IQR 51-79), 60% male), of which 22% had poor outcomes. 53% of patients were treated at TH. In unadjusted comparisons, poor outcomes occurred more often at TH than NTH (22.4% vs. 21.4%, p=0.03). However, after adjustment for other factors, severe chest trauma that was not transferred was associated with more poor outcomes (OR 1.6, <0.001). (Table1) Male sex, nonwhite race and more comorbidities were also associated with poor outcomes.

Conclusion: More than 20% of rib fracture patients have a poor outcome.  Mild chest trauma can be safely treated at NTH, but severe chest trauma outcomes are improved at TH. Development of transfer criteria for chest injuries in high-risk patients may help mitigate poor outcomes at hospitals who lack appropriate expertise.

abstract_title: No-Shows in the Trauma Clinic: Patient Factors Associated with Loss to Follow-Up
author_block: B. Bormann<sup>5</sup>, L. Ma<sup>3</sup>, J. F. Guzman<sup>5</sup>, J. Hatchimonji<sup>2</sup>, R. Xiong<sup>4</sup>, J. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, E. J. Kaufman<sup>1</sup>, D. N. Holena<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Division Of Trauma, Surgical Critical Care & Emergency Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Pennsylvania,College Of Arts And Sciences,PHILADELPHIA, PHILADELPHIA, USA <sup>4</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of General Internal Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>5</sup>Perelman School of Medicine,PHILADELPHIA, PHILADELPHIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patient loss to follow-up (LTF) after hospitalization for injury increases risk of complications. Identification of patients at risk for LTF prior to discharge would direct targeted interventions and may improve clinic attendance. We sought to develop a predictive model for LTF under the hypothesis that patient data available prior to discharge could be used to identify patients at risk for LTF.

Methods: We matched records from our institutional trauma registry with our electronic health record from 2017 to 2019. The primary outcome of interest was LTF, defined as absence from the first clinic visit after discharge.  We excluded patients who died and patients admitted in the last study month. We assessed patient demographic characteristics, injury diagnoses, severity, surgical interventions, and insurance status. Variables associated with LTF at p<0.2 in univariate analysis were included in a multivariable logistic regression model.

Results: We included 1,386 patients (mean (SD) age 41 (19) years, 71% black, 76% male, 57% blunt mechanism), of whom 293 (21%) were LTF. In multivariable analysis, factors associated with increased odds of LTF included Medicare insurance (OR1.55, 95%CI 1.02-2.41) and increased ICU days (OR1.09, 95%CI 1.02-1.16), while factors associated with decreased odds of LTF included laparotomy (OR 0.32, 95%CI 0.14-0.70), increased hospital days (OR 0.95, 95%CI 0.90-0.99), and higher abbreviated injury score severity (OR 0.77, 95%CI 0.57-1.04). Furthermore, only 24% of patients who missed their first clinic visit attended any subsequent clinic visit.

Conclusion: Using data available prior to discharge, it is possible to identify subsets of injured patients who are more likely to be LTF. Interventions should target these higher-risk patients. High-risk subsets of patients may be institution-specific. Replication of our methods should define the population at greatest risk for LTF at other institutions.

abstract_title: Beyond the O:E: Matching for Risk Adjustment in Penetrating Trauma Patients
author_block: J. S. Hatchimonji<sup>1</sup>, E. Kaufman<sup>1</sup>, R. Xiong<sup>1</sup>, P. Jenkins<sup>2</sup>, P. Reilly<sup>1</sup>, D. Holena<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Trauma center benchmarking conventionally employs observed:expected (O:E) ratios to standardize outcomes. This is imperfect, as key subgroups may be rare at a given center, and may not contribute substantially to benchmarking. We hypothesized that indirect standardization matching (ISM) could be used to evaluate the hospital mortality of patients with penetrating truncal injuries.

Methods:  We analyzed adult patients with a severe (abbreviated injury scale≥3) penetrating truncal injury from level 1 and 2 centers in Pennsylvania in 2019 using ISM, excluding centers with <10 such injuries. We evaluated match quality in the two highest-volume centers and evaluated hospital performance by assigning matched controls in a 1:2 ratio from the rest of the state based on age, sex, race, mechanism, transfer status, injury severity and pattern, presentation physiology, and a comorbidity index. Mortality rates were calculated and compared to that of matched controls for each hospital using the chi-squared test. The entire cohort was also evaluated using O:E methodology for comparison.

Results: There were 632 penetrating truncal trauma patients from 19 centers available for analyses. The quality of the match at the two highest-volume centers (144 and 123 patients, respectively) was good, with standardized mean differences for all characteristics less than 0.2 and the majority less than 0.1. Using ISM, we found one center with significantly lower mortality than its matched controls (relative risk=0, p=0.004). No hospital was significantly worse than expected. Of note, the high-performing center was not identified as such using traditional O:E methodology.

Conclusion: There were 632 penetrating truncal trauma patients from 19 centers available for analyses. The quality of the match at the two highest-volume centers (144 and 123 patients, respectively) was good, with standardized mean differences for all characteristics less than 0.2 and the majority less than 0.1. Using ISM, we found one center with significantly lower mortality than its matched controls (relative risk=0, p=0.004). No hospital was significantly worse than expected. Of note, the high-performing center was not identified as such using traditional O:E methodology.

abstract_title: The Impact of Vertebrae Fractures on the Outcomes of Cervical Spinal Cord Injury.
author_block: J. Wycech<sup>1,2</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>1,3</sup>, R. Grady<sup>1,3</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>1,3</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>1,3</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4,5</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Broward Health North,Trauma Services,Deerfield Beach, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The impact of cervical vertebrae fractures on the severity of neurological deficit in cervical spinal cord injury (CSCI) continues to be debated. The aim of this study was to characterize injury patterns and outcomes in patients with CSCI and cervical vertebrae fractures.

Methods: This retrospective cohort study included 255 CSCI patients with neurological deficit admitted to three Level 1 Trauma Centers between 2015 and 2020. 141 patients with cervical vertebrae fractures (CF) were compared to 114 patients without cervical vertebrae fractures (NCF). Analyzed variables included: age, comorbidities, body mass index (BMI), mechanism of injury (MOI), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for spine, American Spinal Injury Association impairment grade (ASIA), neurological level of impairment (NLI), paravertebral hematoma, facet dislocation, mechanical ventilation (MV), ICU admission, ICU length of stay (ICULOS), hospital LOS (HLOS), discharge disposition, and mortality.

Results: Cervical vertebrae fractures were present in half (55.3%) of CSCI patients with neurological deficit. Age, prevalence of comorbidities, and MOI were not different between groups. The CF group had significantly lower BMI (26.0 vs 27.9, p=0.007). ISS was significantly higher in the CF group (23.0 vs 18.5, p=0.007), and AIS for spine distribution was statistically different (p<0.001), with 35.5% of the CF group versus 14.0% of the NCF group having critical or maximal injuries. ASIA distribution between groups was also significantly different (p<0.001), with 36.1% in the CF group versus 9.7% in the NCF group suffering motor paralysis and having ASIA grade A or B [Fig. 1]. NLI distribution between groups was similar. Significantly more CF patients had cervical paravertebral hematoma (43.3% vs 14.0%) and cervical facet dislocation (35.5% vs 5.3%), both p<0.001. MV requirements were significantly higher in the CF group (48.9% vs 16.7%), with significantly higher number of patients requiring endotracheal intubation (23.4% vs 9.6%) and tracheostomy (25.5% vs 7.0%), all p<0.005. CF patients were admitted to the ICU significantly more often (84.4% vs 62.3%, p<0.001) and had significantly longer ICULOS (10.4 vs 6.3 days, p=0.006) and HLOS (25.9 vs 12.4 days, p=0.03). Mortality (16.3% vs 4.4%, p=0.002) and discharge to hospice (12.8% vs 3.5%) were significantly higher in the CF group.

Conclusion: CSCI patients with cervical vertebrae fractures had more frequent and severe neurological impairment. The presence of cervical vertebrae fractures was associated with longer hospitalization and higher ICU admission rate, mortality, and hospice discharge, and is an indicator for tracheostomy and a predictor for adverse outcomes.

abstract_title: Increased Intra-abdominal Abscess Occurs with Interrupted Fascial Closure Following Open Abdomen
author_block: L. E. Coleman<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Theodorou<sup>1</sup>, D. Anaya<sup>1</sup>, S. Mahdavi<sup>1</sup>, S. Zakaluzny<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Cocanour<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Davis,General Surgery,Sacramento, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Trauma patients undergoing damage control laparotomy are frequently left with an open abdomen (OA). While often physiologically necessary, there are many potential complications with OA, including formation of enterocutaneous fistula and intra-abdominal infection.  This study focuses on factors predictive of intra-abdominal abscess (IAA) development, specifically with regards to both fixed patient factors and modifiable operative factors. 

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of adult trauma patients admitted to a level 1 trauma center June 2016 - June 2019 who were initially managed with OA following damage control laparotomy. Patients who survived at least 7 days after surgery, allowing time for the development of IAA, were included. Univariate analysis of comorbidities, injuries, and surgical decision-making was performed. Subgroup analysis was performed on all patients who achieved fascial closure within three operations. Univariate factors approaching significance (p <0.20) were included in multivariate logistic regression. Six-month follow-up data was collected on development of enterocutaneous fistula (ECF) and ventral hernia.

Results: Ninety-one patients were included (79% male), with a median age of 40 years old (IQR 27-57). Twenty-four patients (26%) developed an IAA. All examined comorbidities had no significant association with IAA. The time to fascial closure was not significantly different between those who developed IAA and those who did not (50 vs. 45 hours, p= 0.42). Furthermore, receiving antibiotics throughout the entirety of having an open abdomen was not associated with IAA (58% vs. 61%, p= 0.8). Factors significant for IAA were abdominal AIS score (4 vs. 3, p= 0.03), interrupted facial closure (75% vs. 46%, p = 0.02), and any gastrointestinal (GI) injury (92% vs. 60%, p < 0.01). On multivariable regression, interrupted fascial closure (OR 3.8) and any GI injury (OR 7.4) remained significant. Within the subgroup who achieved closure within three operations, interrupted fascial closure was significantly associated with IAA (67% vs. 38%, p= 0.05). Follow-up data was available for 65 patients; development of an enterocutaneous fistula was higher in those with prior IAA (18.8% vs 0%, p=0.01). Ventral hernia was not significantly higher (25% vs 8.2%, p=0.09).

Conclusion: Comorbid conditions historically associated with higher rates of infection showed no association with IAA formation after OA. Furthermore, administration of antibiotics did not impact the formation of IAA. However, both GI injury and fascial closure using an interrupted technique were significantly associated with IAA. The association of an interrupted fascial closure with IAA is unexpected and requires further study.

abstract_title: Defining Clinically Significant Reduction in Opioid Morphine Milligram Equivalents after Trauma Laparotomy
author_block: C. M. Trevino<sup>1</sup>, W. Peppard<sup>1</sup>, K. Krueger<sup>1</sup>, L. Farnsworth<sup>1</sup>, H. Dong<sup>1</sup>, R. Morris<sup>1</sup>, A. Szabo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Surgery/Trauma,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The value of clinically significant reduction in morphine milligram equivalents (MME) of opioids after trauma laparotomy is unknown. A reduction in utilization of opioids theoretically reduces side effects, such as delayed return of bowel function, and may decrease length of stay (LOS) of hospitalization. We hypothesized improvement in clinical outcomes for pain, LOS, and time to bowel movement (BM) would be associated with measurable reduction in MME.

Methods: This is a retrospective study of 300 patients who underwent a laparotomy after traumatic injury. A clinically significant reduction in pain was defined as a 2-point decrease in Numeric Pain Score (NPS). Average daily MME use over the first 72 hours of hospitalization was measured. The clinically significant difference in opioid MME was defined as the difference in MME use associated with a clinically significant difference in a clinical outcome (pain, LOS, BM). This was estimated for each outcome using “inverse regression” as d/beta, where d represents clinically relevant difference in outcome, and beta is the slope of the regression line of the outcome on MME.

Results:Average daily MME was not associated with sex, age, race/ethnicity, or injury type, but trended higher with Injury Severity Score (ISS) (p=0.07). Adjusting for ISS, the clinically significant outcomes were average pain (p=0.034), time to first BM (p=0.002) and NGT (Nasogastric tube) duration (p=0.003) (Table 1). However, the clinically meaningful difference in MME was extremely large (464, 194, and 283 respectively).

Conclusion:A strong relationship between MME and clinical outcomes was not found (Figure 1) and meaningful effects are very large. It appears that clinical outcomes of pain, LOS, and return of bowel function are affected by many factors, and it is difficult to induce a clinically meaningful change only by manipulating opioid dose. However, patients with very high MME could be a target, where large reductions are theoretically possible.

abstract_title: Effect of Expedited Trauma Transfer Protocol: Right Place, Right Time
author_block: K. Devecki<sup>1</sup>, S. Kozyr<sup>2</sup>, M. Crandall<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Kerwin<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Ebler<sup>1</sup>, B. K. Yorkgitis<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Florida College of Medicine-Jacksonville,Acute Care Surgery,Jacksonville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Lee Memorial Hosital,Trauma,Ft. Meyers, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma patients may initially be evaluated at non-trauma centers. This may cause a delay in treatment, which could affect their outcome. Additionally, advanced imaging may be performed which may be suboptimal or unnecessary, increase time to transfer or unable to be viewed when the patient reaches a trauma center increasing the delays to treatment or need for repeat imaging.  Rapid identification and transfer to definitive trauma care, minimizing unnecessary delays should be the priority. With the development of an expedited trauma transfer protocol, we hypothesized there would be less advanced imaging prior to transfer and faster transfer to a Level 1 Trauma Center.

Methods: The trauma registry at a regional Level 1 Adult/Pediatric Trauma center was queried for transferred trauma patients over a 3-year period. Transferred trauma patients were compared prior to an expedited transfer protocol to after implementation. Demographics, mechanism of injury (MOI), injury severity score (ISS), CT scans performed prior to transfer, mortality, hospital and ICU LOS were compared using bivariate and multivariable regression statistics where appropriate.

Results:Transferred trauma patients were identified, 683 in the pre-protocol group and 821 in the post-protocol group, an increase of 16.8%.  There were no differences in age, sex, ISS, MOI, mortality, hospital or ICU LOS throughout the study period.  There was a significant decrease in time to transfer (263 seconds ± 222 vs. 227 ± 189, p <0.001) and CT scans performed prior to transfer (Head 47% vs 32%, C-spine 36% vs 23%, Thorax 22% vs 16%, Abdomen/Pelvis 24% vs 14%, all p-values <0.001). Interestingly, the rate of underinsured patients did not increase (21% vs 25%, p=0.05).  Risk-adjusted mortality and hospital LOS also did not change during the study period.

Conclusion:Implementation of an expedited trauma transfer protocol to a regional Level 1 trauma center improved time to arrival of definitive care and decreased advanced imaging done prior to transfer.  However, this did not affect mortality or LOS among transferred patients.  Interestingly, over the study period there was an increase in number of patients transferred without a change in ISS or underinsured rate. Further studies examining prehospital transport or hospital choice decisions and subsequent care provided at non-trauma hospitals for imaging, care rendered and transfer need further examination.

abstract_title: Predictors of Failure of Non-Operative Management of Geriatric Solid Organ Injuries
author_block: M. Hamidi<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, M. Chehab<sup>1</sup>, M. Khurrum<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, S. Asmar<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, B. Joseph<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The use of non-operative management (NOM) for geriatric solid organ injuries is increasing over time, but its safety and efficacy in this vulnerable age group remains questionable. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of NOM for geriatric abdominal solid organ injuries.

Methods:  We performed a 2014-2015 analysis of the Nationwide Readmission Database. We included all older adult (age ≥65 years) isolated blunt abdominal trauma patients (extra-abdominal AIS<2) with a liver, spleen, and/or renal injury. Patients who underwent operative intervention within 24 hours were excluded. Outcomes were failure of NOM and mortality within 6-months.

Results: We identified 4,421 patients: 28% sustained a liver injury, 46% splenic injury, and 29% renal injury. Mean age was 76±8y, 18% of injuries were high-grade, and 18% of patients underwent angioembolization. NOM failure rate was 10%, 7% occurring during index admission (2[1-2]d), while 3% within 32[22-32]d post-discharge. Splenic injuries had the highest failure rate (14%) compared to liver (10%) and renal injuries (2%) (p<0.01). Overall mortality was 14% (index-admission: 12%; readmission: 2%). Mortality was highest in the liver (19%), followed by spleen (13%), then renal (10%) group (p<0.01). Multiple factors predict failure of NOM. (Table 1)

Conclusion: One in ten geriatric solid organ injury patients had failure of NOM. Adjuncts such as angioembolization may be protective. Multiple predictors may facilitate patient risk stratification, improving selection of NOM candidates.

abstract_title: All's Well That Ends Well: Predictors of Discharge Destination Following Severe TBI
author_block: S. P. Stanley<sup>1</sup>, E. I. Truong<sup>1</sup>, B. S. DeMario<sup>1</sup>, H. A. Ladhani<sup>1</sup>, E. S. Tseng<sup>1</sup>, V. P. Ho<sup>1</sup>, M. L. Kelly<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>MetroHealth Medical Center,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Discharge destination after traumatic brain injury (TBI) should be based on a patient’s recovery potential but may be influenced by non-patient factors like regional or institutional practice patterns. We hypothesized that non-patient factors would influence discharge destination in severe TBI patients.

Methods: All patients in the ACS Trauma Quality Improvement Program 2016 data set with severe TBI, defined as head Abbreviated Injury Scale ≥3, were screened and categorized by discharge destination: home, rehab, skilled nursing or other care facility (SNF), and deceased. Logistic regression was used to assess factors associated with each destination; odds ratios and 95% confidence level are reported. Regressions were adjusted for age, gender, race, insurance status, GCS, ISS, penetrating trauma, region, neurosurgeon group size, teaching status, trauma center level, hospital size, and type of neurosurgical procedure.

Results: 75,690 patients met inclusion criteria. 51% were discharged to home, 18% to rehab, 16% to SNF, and 11% deceased. Mortality was similar across geographical region, teaching status, and hospital size. Southern patients were more likely to be discharged to home while Northeastern patients were more likely to be discharged to rehab (Table). Treatment by groups of 3 or more neurosurgeons was associated with SNF discharge as was treatment at Community (OR: 1.11 [95% CI: 1.04 – 1.17]) or Non-Teaching hospitals (1.18 [1.08 – 1.29]). Patients treated at larger hospitals (defined as those with a total bed number > 200) were both less likely to be discharged to rehab and more likely to be discharged to SNF.

Conclusion: Region, neurosurgeon group size, teaching status, and hospital size are significantly associated with variation in discharge destination following severe TBI. Regional and institutional variation in practice patterns may therefore play an important role in recovery for some patients with severe TBI.

abstract_title: A Three-Tier Activation System: Improving Geriatric Trauma Triage
author_block: A. Halevi<sup>1</sup>, K. Ho<sup>2</sup>, K. Khariton<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian Queens,Surgery,Flushing, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Weill Cornell Medical College,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The majority of trauma centers utilize a two-tiered trauma activation system based on physiologic derangement and mechanism of injury. Geriatric patients are especially at risk for poor outcomes due to frailty, anticoagulant use, and polypharmacy.  As part of an internal quality improvement (QI) project, we instituted a third trauma activation tier (Delta), triggered for geriatric patients with polypharmacy or anticoagulant use who did not meet traditional trauma activation criteria. A Delta activation triggers an immediate evaluation by a surgical resident. Our primary objective was to examine the effect of Delta activations on undertriage rates in geriatric trauma patients. Furthermore, we reviewed the effects of earlier identification and management for injured patients.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective review of the first two years after the establishment of the Delta activation system using the previous year, where these patients were assessed as trauma consults, as a historical control. All trauma patients over 65 were included. Outcomes included number of activations, time and location of disposition, and under-triage rates. Under-triage for Bravo and Delta activation was defined as death in the Emergency Department or admission to the operating room directly from the trauma bay.

Results: Under-triage rates for trauma consults (historic control) vs. Delta activations decreased from 15% to 2.2% (p <0.001).  Time to disposition for consults vs. Deltas decreased by 2.2 hours (p <0.001).  ICU admissions increased from 4.1% to 6.2% (p<0.001). Trauma Bravo activation rates decreased from 28% to 13% of all traumas (p <0.001). Under-triage rates were stable, from 9% to 9% (p>0.9).

Conclusion: A three-tier trauma activation system is effective in reducing undertriage rates and allowing for earlier identification of injury in geriatric trauma patients. Furthermore, this improves trauma team resource utilization by decreasing time spent in the ED.

abstract_title: Elevated K/iCa Ratio Is a Stronger Mortality Predictor Than iCa in Patients With Severe Hemorrhage
author_block: S. Ninokawa<sup>1</sup>, D. Tatum<sup>2</sup>, K. Nordham<sup>1</sup>, S. Taghavi<sup>1</sup>, C. Guidry<sup>1</sup>, P. McGrew<sup>1</sup>, R. Schroll<sup>1</sup>, C. Harris<sup>1</sup>, J. Duchesne<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine,Department Of Trauma & Acute Care Surgery,New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>2</sup>Our Lady of the Lake Regional Medical Center,Baton Rouge, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with severe hemorrhage managed with mass transfusion protocol (MTP) are at risk of post-transfusion citrate-induced hypocalcemia and hyperkalemia. While ionized calcium (iCa) has been shown to be a predictor of mortality in MTP patients, here we evaluate the interaction of potassium (K), ionized calcium (iCa), and the K/iCa ratio as predictors of mortality in patients with severe hemorrhage receiving MTP.

Methods: This was a retrospective review of adult trauma patients from 2014-2019 who received MTP within one hour of arrival to a Level 1 trauma center. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis was used to assess the predictive capacity of iCa and the K/iCa ratio on mortality. The coordinate points on the ROC curve were used to establish a K/iCa ratio cut-off value by optimizing the Youden index. To identify the effect of K/iCa on survival, Kaplan-Meier (KM) survival analysis and Cox regression models were used.

Results: Among 531 MTP patients, 146 met inclusion criteria. Patients who expired had higher K/iCa ratios than those who survived (median[IQR]= 5.7[3.8-7.2] vs 3.7[3.1-4.9], p <0.001). In the ROC curve analysis, the area under the curve (AUC) for predicting mortality by K/iCa (AUC=0.72 [95% CI 0.62 - 0.82], p <0.001) was larger than that of iCa alone (0.66 [95% CI 0.56 – 0.76], p <0.01). In the K/iCa ROC curve, an optimal cutoff value of 5.09 was identified, with a sensitivity of 63.2% and specificity of 78.7%. A KM survival curve revealed that high K/iCa ratio was a strong prognostic marker for mortality (p <0.001). Cox regression demonstrated a significant association between K/iCa ratio and mortality (HR 1.15, 95% CI 1.07– 1.23, p <0.001).

Conclusion: These findings demonstrate that an elevated K/iCa ratio in trauma patients managed with MTP is a better mortality predictor than iCa alone. During early MTP, K levels should be closely monitored in relation to iCa levels. Further validation of this prognostic marker is needed.

abstract_title: Can Trauma Patients Identify Injuries or Medical Teams?
author_block: B. S. DeMario<sup>1,2</sup>, F. Douglass<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Robenstine<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Como<sup>1,2</sup>, E. S. Tseng<sup>1,2</sup>, J. A. Claridge<sup>1,2</sup>, V. P. Ho<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>MetroHealth Medical Center,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma patients have high rates of recidivism and non-adherence, which may lead to poorer outcomes and further injury. However, these patients may not understand their injuries or who is caring for them, making recovery difficult. We hypothesized that trauma patients would not know 1) what their injures were or 2) which medical teams (MT) were involved in their care. We also hypothesized that 3) reported health literacy (HL) level would correlate with such knowledge.

Methods: We performed a prospective study of awake, alert, and oriented trauma inpatients >18 years admitted >2 days. Participants completed a survey to 1) identify injured body regions (IBR), 2) recall MT, and 3) complete a validated HL questionnaire in which they reported their comfort with understanding health information (Figure 1). MT included medical and surgical specialists, as well as allied health professionals. Participant surveys (PS) were compared with the medical record (EMR) for IBR and MT. We used Cohen’s kappa score to assess agreement between PS and EMR with κ<0.5 indicating poor agreement.

Results: Of 50 participants, 32% did not identify ≥50% of IBR and 8% did not identify ≥75% of IBR. Most commonly missed IBR were skin (32%, κ=0.2) and spine (20%, κ=0.5). 42% could not identify ≥50% of their MT and 28% could not identify ≥75% of MT. Most commonly missed teams were nutrition (72%, κ=0.0), occupational therapy (60%, κ=0.1), and social work (60%, κ=0.1). 50% of patients reported a HL score >15, indicating confidence in their HL.

Conclusion: Many trauma patients were unable to identify their injuries or care team members despite high self-reported health literacies. The discrepancy between patient knowledge and patient injuries demonstrates the importance of interventions to improve health literacy, which may help with downstream outcomes and prevention of further injury.

abstract_title: Perioperative Antibiotics Negatively Affect Burn Wound Microbiome Without Improving Outcomes.
author_block: J. W. Keyloun<sup>1,2</sup>, R. L. Ball<sup>1,2</sup>, J. R. Chen See<sup>4,5</sup>, M. A. Oliver<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Carney<sup>1</sup>, M. M. McLawhorn<sup>1,2</sup>, J. R. Wright<sup>4,5</sup>, R. Lamendella<sup>4,5</sup>, L. T. Moffatt<sup>1,3</sup>, J. W. Shupp<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute,Firefighters' Burn And Surgical Research Laboratory,Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>Washington Hospital Center,The Burn Center, Department Of Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine,Departments Of Surgery And Biochemistry,Washington, DC, USA <sup>4</sup>Juniata College,Department Of Biology,Huntingdon, PA, USA <sup>5</sup>Wright Labs, LLC,Huntingdon, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Burn patients are at high risk for wound infection. Early excision and grafting and advances in antimicrobial dressings have improved patient outcomes. The judicious use of systemic antibiotics to treat infected burn wounds and sepsis is essential for burn patients. However, the use of routine perioperative antibiotics is debated. Perioperative antibiotics may alter the patient microbiome and promote resistance without improving outcomes. The objective of this study is to investigate the effect of perioperative antibiotics on burn wound bacterial microbiome and clinical outcomes.    

Methods:  Patients with uncomplicated thermal burns of <10% TBSA expected to require a single grafting procedure were eligible for enrollment. Patients were randomized to receive a single dose of weight-based cefazolin on induction of anesthesia or no antibiotics, which is our standard-of-care. Blood, saliva, wound biopsies, and swabs were collected before and after wound excision for quantitative culture and microbiome (16S rRNA) analysis. Repeat samples were collected at the first dressing takedown (1-3 days post-grafting), and first follow-up visit postoperatively (7-10 days post-discharge).

Results: Demographics and injury characteristics are presented in Table 1 (n=28 patients). Median time between admission and operative intervention was 2 (IQR, 2-3) days. Patients who received antibiotics had significantly lower wound bed biopsy (0, IQR, 0-3.8x103 CFU/g vs. 7.0x104, 0-2.5x109 CFU/g; p=0.02) and swab (0, 0-0 CFU/mL vs. 4.2x102, 0-1.3x104 CFU/mL; p=0.001) bacterial cultures compared to patients who did not receive antibiotics. There was no significant difference between groups on wound bed or donor site bacterial cultures intraoperatively or at follow up. There was one intraoperative post-excision biopsy and one swab that was culture positive in the antibiotics and no antibiotics group respectively. Groups did not differ significantly in rates of graft loss, postoperative infection, or %re-epithelialization at follow-up. Linear discriminant analysis effect size (LEfSe) revealed 31 enriched bacterial taxa within the wound beds of patients who received antibiotics based on dressing takedown samples (LDA ≥ 2, p ≤ 0.05).

Conclusion: Early excision and grafting and topical antimicrobials are effective at reducing the risk of burn wound infection. Perioperative antibiotics reduce wound bed bacterial colonization at the first postoperative dressing change but do not alter clinical outcomes. Microbiome analysis suggests that a single dose of perioperative antibiotics alters the wound bed microbiome, which may result in the enrichment of pathogenic bacteria.

abstract_title: Maxillofacial Computed Tomography is Over-utilized in Pediatric Trauma Care
author_block: T. Calderon<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Chess<sup>1</sup>, M. Edwards<sup>4</sup>, D. S. Wakeman<sup>1</sup> <sup>2</sup>University of Rochester Medical Center,School Of Medicine And Dentistry,Rochester, NEW YORK, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Rochester Medical Center,Department Of Imaging Sciences,Rochester, NEW YORK, USA <sup>4</sup>Albany Medical College,Pediatric Surgery,Albany, NY, USA <sup>1</sup>Golisano's Childrens Hospital,Pediatric Surgery,Rochester, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: To minimize unnecessary radiation exposure in a vulnerable population liberal use of computed tomography (CT) scanning in pediatric trauma patients should be avoided. The need for maxillofacial CT scanning in addition to head imaging to diagnose facial fractures is unclear. We hypothesized that maxillofacial CT scanning is over-utilized at our institution and rarely identifies clinically significant facial injuries not seen on head imaging.

Methods: After IRB approval, we performed a single-center, retrospective study of patients identified from our trauma database. Subjects 18 years old and younger presenting to the hospital between January 2007 and December 2018 with both a head and maxillofacial CT scan were included. The following parameters were considered: age, date of injury, gender, injuries, indication for imaging, radiographic interpretation, and surgical intervention performed. A pediatric neuroradiologist interpreted the head and maxillofacial CT scans in a blinded fashion. Descriptive statistics were performed.

Results:  Of 63 cases identified with both head and maxillofacial CT scans, 48 patients (76%) had fully concordant reads, while 15 patients (24.0%) had an injury identified on maxillofacial CT not seen on head CT. Four patients underwent surgical intervention; all surgically significant injuries were identified on head CT, although 2 patients had their injuries better characterized by facial CT. Injuries identified on facial CT alone (not seen on head CT) included 4 nasal bone fractures and 10 orbital/ sinus fractures; all were non- or minimally-displaced and did not require surgical intervention.

Conclusion: Head CT evaluation is sensitive to screen for the majority of surgically significant facial fractures, eliminating the need for maxillofacial CT in most pediatric trauma patients. Facial CT scanning should be reserved for patients with suspected mandible fracture or extensive facial fractures requiring surgical planning. This approach would potentially reduce health care costs and radiation exposure in injured children.

abstract_title: Perceptions of Violence in Justice-Involved Youth
author_block: K. Reidelberger<sup>1</sup>, A. Raposo-Hadley<sup>1</sup>, J. Greenaway<sup>1</sup>, A. Farrens<sup>1</sup>, J. Burt<sup>1</sup>, L. Wylie<sup>2</sup>, G. Armstrong<sup>2</sup>, M. Foxall<sup>2</sup>, Z. Bauman<sup>1</sup>, C.
