Evans<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Nebraska Medical Center,Surgery,Omaha, NE, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Nebraska, Omaha,Criminology And Criminal Justice,Omaha, NE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Youth are tragically affected by violence.  Justice-involved youth are at particularly high risk for the effects of violence, as incarceration serves as a risk factor.  The objective of this study is to explore the risks and needs of justice-involved youth and identify channels for future hospital-based programming.

Methods: Four weekly focus groups were conducted by a credible messenger at the Douglas County Youth Center (DCYC) with former participants of Dusk 2 Dawn (D2D), a youth violence prevention program delivered at DCYC. 8 participants were prompted with preset interview questions in the domains of: basic awareness of violence, reasons for use of violence, responses to violence, awareness of protective and risk factors, participant experience with D2D, and future directions for youth programming in violence prevention. All focus groups were recorded and transcribed by a professional transcription service. A thematic analysis was performed by two independent coders to identify themes using Dedoose software.

Results: The 3 most frequently occurring themes involved topics on protection, identified 40 times; family, identified 36 times; and the challenge of overcoming violence, identified 31 times. These themes often overlapped with one another, demonstrating how complex and integrated youth violence is. Participants described violence as an everyday occurrence and addressed the severe lack of protective people and places, both in their communities and homes.

Conclusion: Providing a safe and judgement-free space for the youth to discuss issues of violence was beneficial for three reasons: 1) inclusion of youth perspectives allows violence prevention program to be tailored to specific needs, 2) participants were able to deeply reflect on violence in their own lives and consider steps towards positive change, and 3) open communication encourages trust building and collaborative prevention efforts between the hospital and community. These lessons, coupled with intensive case management, will best address the needs identified in this analysis.

abstract_title: Disparities in Healthcare Utilization After Traumatic Brain Injury
author_block: J. F. VanScoy<sup>1</sup>, K. Kalkwarf<sup>2</sup>, A. Bhavaraju<sup>2</sup>, S. Karim<sup>3</sup>, R. Reif<sup>3</sup>, H. Jensen<sup>1</sup>, K. Sexton<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arkansas,College Of Medicine,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Arkansas,Department Of Surgery,Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Arkansas,College Of Public Health,Little Rock, AR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Race has been demonstrated to impact trauma care. Ethnic minorities are less likely to receive post-traumatic brain injury (TBI) rehabilitation, TBI operative intervention, and are less likely to utilize outpatient clinical services after a TBI. A knowledge gap remains when examining pre and post-TBI utilization of these resources. We hypothesized that certain variables (age, gender, race, and type of insurance) play a role in healthcare utilization. We aim to study this relationship by examining percent change in cost as a measurement of healthcare utilization both before and after a TBI.  

Methods: Patients who had a moderate to severe TBI (Injury Severity Score ISS>9) between 2014 and 2015 were identified in the Arkansas All Payer Claims Database. Patients with no healthcare claims the year prior to injury were excluded from the analysis. Healthcare costs were collected one year before injury and one year after discharge.

Results: 5,684 patients with moderate to severe TBIs were identified, with an average percent cost increase of 27% post-TBI compared to pre-TBI. Age was inversely proportional to percent increase in cost. The lowest percent increase was found in ages 40-65 and 65+, with percent increases of 23.1% and 23.7% respectively, compared to 43% in population group 18-40 and 94.9% in patients <18 (p=0.023). Medicaid insurance was also found to be a predictor of a larger change in percent cost, with a 55.3% increase in percent cost (p=0.001). Both length of stay and severity of TBI were associated with an increase in percent cost. Each day spent in the hospital during the index admission led to a 5.44% incremental increase in post-injury healthcare costs (p<0.001). Injury severity scores >15 were associated with a 39.2% increase in percent cost compared to a 23.5% increase in patients with ISS scores 9-15 (p<0.001). Race and gender were not associated with any significant changes in percent increase. In Hispanic and Black populations, there was a percent increase of 29.7% and 18.3% respectively, compared to a percent increase of 28.1% in whites (p=0.983). In female populations, there was an observed percent increase of 24.0% compared to males, with a percent increase of 33.3% (p=0.086).

Conclusion: Healthcare costs increase for most patients after a moderate-to-severe TBI. There is a significant increase in percent cost in younger populations (<18 and 18-40), who likely utilize healthcare services less overall prior to their injury compared to older populations (40-65 and 65+). The larger change in percent cost in Medicaid patients likely indicates that they have fewer healthcare claims prior to their injury compared to patients with medicare and private insurance. Additionally, as expected, both length of stay and severity of injury were associated with significant increases in percent cost. In our study, race and gender were not associated with significant differences in increases in percent cost after TBI.

abstract_title: Evaluation of Injury Recidivism Using the Electronic Medical Record
author_block: P. J. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, M. N. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, L. Tanner<sup>1</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Traumatic injuries remain one of the leading causes of death in the United States. Patients who survive traumatic injuries but return to the emergency department with repeat injuries are part of a phenomenon known as injury recidivism. Numerous studies have described trends in injury recidivism using registry and survey data. No prior study has leveraged electronic medical record (EMR) data to characterize injury recidivism. The EMR is more comprehensive as it contains details of patients who visited the emergency department after injury but did not meet the criteria for inclusion in the trauma registry. Such injuries could be predictive of future recidivism. We therefore aimed to describe patterns of injury recidivism seen at a large academic medical institution that has a Level 1 trauma center using the EMR.

Methods:  A retrospective review was conducted of all injury-related encounters between January 2016 and December 2019. Encounter data including mechanism of injury and time to repeat injury was extracted from the EMR; trauma-specific characteristics (e.g., Injury Severity Score) were derived from the trauma registry. Manual review was conducted of all recidivistic encounters with <11 months between encounters. As a person could have multiple index encounters, a general estimating equation logistic regression (to account for clustering by person) was used to estimate odds ratios (ORs) for the association between recidivism and injury mechanism of the index encounter. Models were adjusted for age, race, sex, and insurance payor.

Results: Among 20,279 index encounters, 6.8% (n=1,387) had a recidivistic encounter during the study period, over half of which (n=807) occurred within the first year of the index encounter. Compared to those experiencing an unintentional injury, patients presenting with an assault injury had a 42% (OR 1.42, 95% CI 1.22-1.66) greater odds of returning with repeat injury (all-cause) and an over three-fold increased likelihood of a recidivistic assault injury (OR 3.06, 95% CI 2.35-3.99). For all-cause injury, when compared to unintentional MVCs, the three strongest associations observed for a recidivistic visit were blunt assaults (OR 2.53, 95% CI 2.03-3.15), falls (OR 2.10, 95% CI 1.76-2.52), and self-harm injuries (OR 1.80, 95% CI 1.00-3.23).

Conclusion: Our study found that patients with assault injuries have the highest odds of injury recidivism and assault-related recidivistic encounters. These results demonstrate the feasibility and utility of incorporating EMR data, and suggest that the development of targeted interventions focused on mitigating assault injuries, such as hospital-based violence intervention programs, should be considered in our region.

abstract_title: Differences in Prehospital care and Trauma Triage Time by Gender: a TQIP analysis
author_block: M. Nagalla<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Ingram<sup>1</sup>, Y. Shan<sup>1</sup>, A. Stey<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Surgical Outcomes Quality Improvement Center,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Differences in time to diagnostic and therapeutic measures by gender have been observed in medical acute care settings; published literature has further suggested these differences may contribute to disparities in outcome. Evaluations of process and outcome measures by gender for trauma have not yet been examined. We sought to investigate whether gender-based differences in triage time and time to definitive interventions existed for trauma patients in the United States.   

Methods: The 2013-2016 Trauma Quality Improvement Program (TQIP) database was examined to evaluate traumatic brain injury (TBI), intra-abdominal injury (IAI), pelvic fracture (PF), and femur fracture (FF). Patients were stratified by injury severity score (ISS) and injury type. Primary outcomes included time to venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis, time in prehospital care and triage, and time to intervention of specific injuries. Comparison of time to interventions by gender were conducted using Wilcoxon Rank sum tests.

Results: 1513 patients with TBI (0.2%), 24,206 patients with IAI (2.4%), 53,485 patients with PF (5.3%) and 184,295 patients with FF (18.3%) were observed over the study period.  Of patients with ISS >= 15, 67.7% were men and 32.3% were women, with the average age being 42.7(±18.0) and 48.4(± 21.2) years old, respectively. Women had a significantly longer prehospital time (median 51.0 min vs 48.0 min, p<0.05), emergency department (ED) length of stay (median 188.0 min vs 161.0 min, p<0.05) and an increased wait time for femur fracture fixation (median 2.0 days vs 1.0 day, p<0.05) compared to men. Time to VTE prophylaxis, time to angiography, time to TBI intervention, time to IAI intervention, and time to PF intervention did not differ significantly between genders (Table).

Conclusion: Gender differences exist for trauma patients in prehospital time, ED length of stay, and in time to femur fracture fixation. Further investigations into system processes contributing to these disparities may aid in increasing efficacy of care provided to trauma patients in the United States.

abstract_title: Race, Ethnicity, and Sex Disparities in Blood Alcohol Testing After Trauma
author_block: R. A. Jean<sup>1</sup>, D. Johnson<sup>2</sup>, K. Schuster<sup>2</sup>, R. Becher<sup>2</sup>, K. Davis<sup>2</sup>, A. Maung<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Division Of General Surgery, Trauma, And Surgical Critical Care,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The American College of Surgeons mandates that at least 80% of trauma evaluations be screened for alcohol use. Although there are multiple screening methods, the serum blood alcohol content (BAC) is a quantifiable measure that can be easily included with other routine lab testing. However, given the need for clinician discretion in choosing a screening method, it is unclear whether screening with BAC is applied uniformly to all sociodemographic groups. We studied the national practice patterns of obtaining a BAC across race, ethnicity and sex groups  

Methods: Utilizing the 2017 Trauma Quality Programs Participant User File (TQP PUF), we examined the rates of BAC screening in adults across different demographic groups including race, ethnicity, and sex. Adjusted multivariable logistic regression was used to determine the odds ratios for receiving a BAC based upon these demographic factors adjusted for hospital and clinical factors.  

Results: Of the 768,009 adult patients included in the study, 353,763 (46.1%) were screened with a BAC. Screening rates varied by age and injury mechanism with highest among motorcycle crashes, and lowest among falls. Overall, Asian, black, and "other” race had higher rates of alcohol screening than white patients, (p<0.001). Similarly, Hispanic patients were screened at higher rates than non-Hispanic patients. In multivariable logistic regression, Asian race was associated with the highest odds of being screened (OR 1.42, 95% CI 1.37-1.47) followed by other race (OR 1.24, 95% CI 1.22 – 1.27) in comparison to white patients. Men were also more likely to be screened (OR 1.44, 95% CI 1.43 – 1.46) than women.  

Conclusion: There are significant differences in the rates of BAC testing among trauma patients across multiple sociodemographic factors.  The propensity to obtain a BAC is disparate in terms of races and ethnicity, despite accounting for injury mechanism and substance use disorders. These findings may be suggestive of heightened scrutiny of racial and ethnic minorities by healthcare providers among patients injured by trauma.

abstract_title: Limb Salvage After Fasciotomy In Penetrating Vascular Extremity Injuries
author_block: S. S. Seng<sup>1</sup>, M. Sayegh<sup>1</sup>, M. Whitney<sup>2</sup>, S. Durgin<sup>1</sup>, A. Lozano<sup>3</sup>, D. Sienko<sup>4</sup>, A. Hanlon<sup>3</sup>, N. Martin<sup>5</sup>, A. Ratnasekera<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Crozer Keystone Health System,Surgery,Upland, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Drexel University,College Of Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Virginia Polytechnic Institute & State University,Statistics,Roanoke, VA, USA <sup>4</sup>Beyond Inference Statistical Consulting,Meadowbrook, PA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  One of the most devastating and feared complications of penetrating vascular extremity injuries is extremity compartment syndrome. Delayed or inadequate fasciotomy can lead to loss of function, muscle necrosis or limb loss. The objective of this study was to further delineate the association of fasciotomies and their timing in limb salvage after a penetrating vascular extremity injury.

Methods:  Using the Pennsylvania Trauma Outcome Study registry, a retrospective review of patients with penetrating arterial and/or venous extremity injuries from 2013 to 2017 was performed. Outcomes were compared in those with an early or late fasciotomy and those without fasciotomy.

Results: Of the 848 patients with penetrating vascular extremity injuries, 186 (21.9%) underwent a fasciotomy. Both injury severity scores (p<0.0001) and abbreviated injury scales (p<0.0001) were higher for those with a fasciotomy compared to those without. The femoral artery, femoral vein, popliteal artery, popliteal vein and ulnar artery were the most prevalently injured vessels in the fasciotomy cohort (p<0.0001). Those with a fasciotomy had a higher rate of amputation compared to those without (p<0.01). All of the patients who had an amputation after fasciotomy underwent a combined open and endovascular procedure and had a higher complication (p=0.0002) and mortality rate (p=0.0018) when compared to those without amputation. Additionally, those who had fasciotomy more than 7 hours after injury had a higher rate of amputations (p=0.029) and complications (p=0.029) compared to those who had fasciotomy less than 7 hours after injury. 

Conclusion: Patients who required fasciotomies following penetrating vascular extremity injuries had higher rates of complications, including amputation, especially when performed in a delayed fashion respective to the initial injury. Early fasciotomy should be considered, where appropriate, in penetrating vascular extremity injuries.

abstract_title: Hospital Experience Impacts Geriatric Trauma Patient Survival
author_block: E. Jeremitsky<sup>1</sup>, A. Khan<sup>1</sup>, R. Nahouraii<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Forbes Regional Hospital,Trauma,Monroeville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Geriatric Trauma (GT) has a increasing incidence in trauma centers. We sought to understand the relationship of a trauma centers geriatric experience and mortality outcome in moderate and severely injured patients.

Methods: National Trauma Data Bank (NTDB) from 2015 was used to examine trauma centers geriatric experience qualified into tertiles by percentage of geriatric admissions (age>65) to total number of trauma admissions. GT patients were also sorted by minor (ISS<8), moderate (ISS 9-15) and severely (ISS>16) injuries.

Results: Overall mortality is 6.5% with minor, moderate and severely injured mortality (2.2%, 4.4% & 15.6%), respectively. Table 1 demonstrates mortality by admit percentage. Multilogistic regression in minor injured patients showed upper third hospitals (>41.3% GT admissions) had improved survival OR .82 p= 0.025 CI .70- .97. Moderate injured GT patients showed no survival benefit by hospital admit %, while severely injured patients admitted to middle (30.9-41.2%) and upper third hospitals had associated decreased mortality OR .92 p= 0.013 CI .86-.98 & OR .83 p<0.001 CI .77-.89, respectively.

Conclusion: There are significant variations in GT mortality, especially noted in the severely injured GT patient. These patients appear to have a survival advantage when admitted to a trauma center that has a higher percentage of GT admissions. Whether this is by GT admission protocol, experience of physicians or a combination of both, lends credence to a dedicated GT center initiative for tertiary trauma referrals in the severely injured GT patient.

abstract_title: Autopsy in Trauma: An Underutilized Resource!
author_block: R. Huang<sup>1</sup>, N. K. Dhillon<sup>1</sup>, W. G. Lee<sup>1</sup>, H. A. Hotz<sup>1</sup>, D. R. Margulies<sup>1</sup>, G. Barmparas<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Cedars-Sinai Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   The purpose of this study was to characterize the utilization of autopsy for trauma deaths at an urban, level I trauma center and identify opportunities for optimization of this resource.

Methods: All autopsy reports from 2007 to 2016 of trauma patients were reviewed and categorized based on the level of autopsy examination performed, with A referring to a complete autopsy of a complex case and D referring to an external examination only. We hypothesized that autopsy is underutilized, potentially leading to underestimation of injury severity.

Results: During the 10-year study period, there were 614 deaths, with only 285 (46%) undergoing an autopsy. The median age was 45 years, 77% were male and the median ISS was 27. The most common mechanism of injury was gunshot wound (21%). Most deaths occurred in the ICU (38%), followed by the ED (35%). Of the autopsies performed, 33% were category A, 18% B, 1% C, and 46% D. Compared to all other autopsy categories (A, B and C), D autopsies were associated with a significantly lower injury severity score (26 vs. 37, p<0.01), although these deaths were equally likely to occur in the OR (12% vs. 15%, p=0.58).

Conclusion: The majority of trauma deaths at a level I trauma center do not undergo an autopsy and for those that do, most include only an external examination. Optimal use of this resource may result in improved estimation of injury severity and contribute further to the process of performance improvement and patient safety.

abstract_title: mKidney® System: A Novel Mobile Health Platform To Support Living Donor Follow-up Data Collection
author_block: C. Sidoti<sup>1</sup>, D. Segev<sup>1</sup>, W. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, M. Waldram<sup>1</sup>, A. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, M. Levan<sup>1</sup>, A. Massie<sup>1</sup>, A. Bingaman<sup>2</sup>, R. Forbes<sup>3</sup>, G. Edwards<sup>3</sup>, K. Warmke<sup>3</sup>, K. Centanni<sup>3</sup>, K. Smith<sup>3</sup>, M. Henderson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Methodist Specialty and Transplant Hospital,Texas Transplant Institute,San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Transplant hospitals struggle to meet Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) requirements for LKD follow-up. In the face of barriers such as cost, LKD inconvenience, and the burden of data collection, they lack the tools to improve LKD engagement. To address this critical health system failure, we built the mKidney® System based on input elicited from LKDs, transplant providers, and thought leaders in the field of transplantation.

Methods: Key features of the mKidney® System include a HIPAA-compliant patient-facing smartphone app and transplant provider-facing web portal, automated short message service (SMS) text messages, email, and push notifications, and data export functionality. We are conducting an ongoing randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the impact of the mKidney® System on rates of post-donation follow-up, in preparation for a fully-powered multi-site clinical trial (NCT03400085). Participants are randomized to the intervention (mKidney® System) or control arm (standard of care) using block randomization, and follow-up compliance is tracked over time (Figure). Follow-up compliance is ascertained through linkage to national registry data (SRTR).

Results: To date, our pilot study population includes 270 participants; of whom, 204 have 6-month donor follow-up available from the SRTR registry. Clinical follow-up required for compliance was completed by 96/98 (97.96%) of participants in the mKidney® arm vs 99/106 (93.40%) of participants in the control arm (Fisher exact p = .173). Required lab follow-up was completed by 90/98 (91.84%) of participants in the mKidney® arm vs 90/106 (84.91%) of participants in the control arm (Fisher exact p=0.135).  

Conclusion: Designed specifically to facilitate the collection and reporting of LKD follow-up data, the mKidney® System is a promising new solution to improve historically poor care management for LKDs in the US.?

abstract_title: Dysphagia Associated with Significantly Lower Post Liver Transplant Patient Survival
author_block: S. Atoa<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Kubal<sup>1</sup>, B. Ekser<sup>1</sup>, P. Mihaylov<sup>1</sup>, T. Wrightson<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Mangus<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Mangus<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Surgery, Transplant Division,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Post-extubation dysphagia is common in liver transplant (LT) patients who are increasingly elderly, frail and sarcopenic. Dysphagia places these patients at higher risk for aspiration, infection and re-intubation. Also, dysphagia delays the introduction of a regular post-operative diet, which contributes to ongoing malnutrition and hypoalbuminemia. This study evaluates a large number of LT patients to determine the impact of dysphagia on post-LT outcomes.

Methods: This study is a retrospective analysis of all LT patients at a single center over a 10-year period. Study variables included any need for a speech / swallow evaluation in the pre- and post-transplant period. From 2016 to 2020, each patient was assessed for frailty using a 5m walk test and CT measures of muscle mass. This subset of patients is analyzed independently for post-operative dysphagia. Outcomes include post-transplant length of hospital stay and early and late patient survival.

Results: There were 1315 first time LTs during the study period. There were 125 patients (10%) who required pre-LT swallow evaluation for dysphagia, and 361 (28%) who required post-LT evaluation. The incidence of post-LT swallow dysfunction was 23%, 7% mild/moderate and 16% severe. Predictors of swallow dysfunction included older age, higher MELD score, and worse sarcopenia. There was worse 1-year patient survival with increasing severity of dysphagia (95%, 94%, 87%; p=0.04). There was also increasing length of stay (8, 17, 29 days; p<0.001). Any dysphagia was associated with a 3x longer length of hospital stay (8 vs 23 days; p<0.001). The 5m walk test did not predict dysphagia, but patients with worse sarcopenia were more likely to have any dysphagia (p=0.07). Patient with any dysphagia had lower survival at 1-year (89% versus 95%, p=0.03) and at 10 years (by Cox regression).

Conclusion: Liver failure patients with dysphagia pre- and post-LT have worse clinical outcomes. Patients with dysphagia must be identified to implement protective measures to avoid aspiration and optimize peri-operative nutrition. Dysphagia is an independent marker for weakness and frailty in patients with liver failure.

abstract_title: Is the Switch to Interrupted Suturing Technique Worth It?
author_block: K. Montgomery<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Kashem<sup>1</sup>, H. Zhao<sup>1</sup>, N. Shigemura<sup>1</sup>, G. Sunagawa<sup>1</sup>, E. H. Leotta<sup>1</sup>, R. Yanagida<sup>1</sup>, S. Brann<sup>1</sup>, Y. Toyoda<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Temple University,Cardiovascular Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A significant and not infrequent cause of higher morbidity in lung transplant recipients is post-operative bronchial anastomotic complications. In a large cohort, this study investigated two surgical techniques (interrupted vs continuous sutures) during bronchial anastomosis and compared survival and occurrence of post-operative bronchial complications. 

Methods: Survival outcomes of 721 single-center lung transplant recipients over 8 years (Feb-2012 to Mar-2020) were compared by suturing techniques.  Continuous suturing technique was performed with 3/0 polypropylene suture on an SH needle. Interrupted suturing used the same technique for the membranous portion of the anastomosis and multiple interrupted 2/0 polypropylene sutures for the cartilaginous portion.  Clinical parameters and demographics were compared between groups. The two groups were compared for post-operative morbidity, including need for bronchial interventions or stent placement. Survival was compared using Kaplan-Meier curves and log-rank tests between groups. Cox regression analysis was run for statistical significances with different variables (p<0.05).

Results: Of the 721 patients, 429 received the continuous suture technique while 292 underwent interrupted. In the continuous group, post-operative bronchial complications occurred in 58 patients (13.5%), compared to 30 patients of the interrupted group (10%). Demographics and clinical parameters between the groups were: age (p=0.008), gender (p=0.643), race (p=0.268), etiology (p<0.001), lung allocation score (p=0.031), body mass index (p=0.676), single versus double transplant (p<0.0001), cardiopulmonary bypass on versus off (p<0.0001), surgical approaches (p=0.011) median length of stay 15 days for interrupted, 18 for continuous (p=0.017).  Post-operative complications (continuous vs interrupted) were: bronchial complications 58 vs 30 patients (p=0.187), usage of Veno-Venous or Veno-Arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation post-transplant 47 vs 18 patients (p=0.024). Kaplan-Meier curve showed better survival with interrupted suturing (p=0.0001). Cox regression analysis while controlling for significant variables showed interrupted was protective compared to running (hazard ratio=2.26 p=0.0009), confidence interval for continuous group (1.35,3.51), interrupted group (0.29,0.74). All other covariates did not significantly affect survival. 

Conclusion: Although both techniques showed reasonable post-transplant outcomes, our study demonstrated superior survival and relatively fewer complications when using interrupted suturing technique vs continuous during bronchial anastomosis. Further long-term study of similar groups with similar long-term follow up should be performed to validate this effect.

abstract_title: Kidney Transplantation from DCD Donors in Highly Sensitized Recipients
author_block: L. Rodrigues<sup>1</sup>, A. Diamond<sup>3</sup>, A. Di Carlo<sup>2</sup>, S. Karhadkar<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Temple University,College Of Science And Technology,Philadelpha, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Temple University Hospital,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Temple University Hospital,Pharmacy,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Highly sensitized (HS) patients experience longer wait times for kidney transplantation despite prioritization by the Kidney Allocation System. DCD kidneys have been shown to decrease wait times for most patient populations. However, the concern for increased rejection during DGF has caused hesitancy in using DCD kidneys in HS patients. In this study we evaluate the outcomes of HS kidney transplant recipients who received a DCD kidney. 

Methods: Kidney transplant recipients who received DCD organs from 2015-2018 were studied using the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) database. Patients were divided into three groups for data analysis; calculated panel-reactive antibody (cPRA) 0% (Group 1), 1-89% (Group 2), and 90-100% (Group 3). Data analysis was performed with the SPSS software. Survival analysis was performed using a Cox regression and Kaplan-Meier model.

Results: 7,854 kidney transplant recipients received DCD kidneys. Patients were divided into three groups: cPRA 0% (n= 4,598), cPRA 1-89% (n= 2,233), and cPRA 90-100% (n= 1,023). There was no significant difference in baseline characteristics. The mean KDPI in Group 3 was lower compared to other groups (51% vs. 50% vs. 44%; p<0.001). Rabbit antithymocyte globulin induction was used for most patients in each group (58% vs. 66% vs. 75%). The incidence of DGF was similar between the 3 groups (41% vs. 42%. vs. 43%; p= 0.45). A higher number of patients in Group 3 were treated for rejection within 12 months (4.2% vs. 4.1% vs. 6.1%; p=0.003). No differences in graft failure (7.1% vs. 7.1 % vs. 6.7%; p=0.905) and patient survival (95% vs. 95% vs. 96%; p=0.449) were noted between groups. A Cox regression model identified KDPI as a significant factor, independent of cPRA, impacting graft survival (OR 3.76; 95% CI: 2.61-5.41). 

Conclusion: DCD kidney transplantation provides HS patients with comparable long term graft survival with an acceptable incidence of treated rejection within 12 months. Notably, KDPI had a larger influence on graft survival than the recipient’s cPRA. This study supports an increased use of DCD kidneys in HS patients.

abstract_title: Perioperative Skeletal Muscle Index fluctuations in High-Acuity Liver Transplantation: Impact and Outcomes
author_block: J. L. Chong<sup>1</sup>, T. Ito<sup>1</sup>, H. Coy<sup>2</sup>, J. G. Guorgui<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Lu<sup>1</sup>, J. DiNorcia<sup>1</sup>, V. G. Agopian<sup>1</sup>, D. G. Farmer<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Raman<sup>2</sup>, R. W. Busuttil<sup>1</sup>, F. M. Kaldas<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Department Of Radiological Sciences,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: As recipient acuity has increased in liver transplantation(LT), efforts to better identify factors that impact outcomes and predict futility are ever more important. Sarcopenia has been suggested as a potential risk-stratification tool in LT. However, its impact in high-acuity LT recipients remains unclear. There are no studies examining the impact of perioperative sarcopenic fluctuations in LT. We hypothesized that perioperative sarcopenic change may impact patient outcomes. We sought to examine perioperative sarcopenia fluctuations on LT outcomes in a high-acuity patients.   

Methods: We retrospectively assessed sarcopenia by calculating skeletal muscle index (SMI) using patient height (m2) and cross-sectional area at L3 vertebrae (cm2) on CT scan. LT recipients with MELD≥35 at LT with a CT ≤30 days prior to LT and at 30-90 days after LT were included; patients with acute liver failure were excluded. The perioperative SMI changes (?SMI) were calculated from pre and post-LT SMI values. Patients were divided in two groups by median ?SMI value.  Cox regression was used to identify prognostic factors for patient survival. [481 LTs, MELD≥35, 2012-2018, single center]

Results: 88 LTs met inclusion criteria (median MELD 41.1). The median ?SMI was -5.0 (-29.4 - +21.1 cm2/m2) (fig A). 88 patients were classified into two groups: ?SMI<-5.0 (median ?SMI: -0.4, n=44) and ?SMI>-5.0 (median ?SMI: -9.2, n=44) (fig B). Recipients with ?SMI<-5.0 had significantly higher pre-LT SMI (35.4 vs 31.2 cm2/m2, p<0.001) and lower post-LT SMI (26.0 vs 30.8 cm2/m2, p<0.001). There were no differences in recipient or donor demographics. The ?SMI<-5.0 group had a significantly higher rate of early allograft dysfunction (40.9 vs 20.5%, p=0.037). No differences were seen in post-LT re-operation, re-intubation, bacteremia, and length of hospital stay. Patients with ?SMI<-5.0 had significantly inferior patient/graft survival (p=0.015, 0.017, respectively) (fig C). Multivariate analysis identified ?SMI<-5.0 (HR: 2.938, p=0.048), long cold ischemia time (≥9h, HR: 7.332, p=0.008), HCV (HR: 5.614, p=0.001), and tracheostomy after LT (HR:9.218, p<0.001) as negative prognostic factors for patient survival (fig D).

Conclusions: This analysis illustrates the significant impact of perioperative SMI decrease on LT outcomes. This suggests the importance of focusing not only on pre-transplant skeletal muscle volume, but also on perioperative changes in SMI and aggressively address continued Post-LT sarcopenia.

abstract_title: Simultaneous Liver and Kidney Transplants in Critically Ill Recipients
author_block: B. E. Chow<sup>1</sup>, M. Selim<sup>1</sup>, Z. J. Prebay<sup>1</sup>, J. Kim<sup>1</sup>, M. Zimmerman<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Hong<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Division Of Transplant Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Simultaneous liver-kidney transplant (SLK) is performed in cirrhotic patients with renal failure secondary to either chronic kidney disease (CKD) or sustained acute kidney injury (SAKI). We compared outcomes in patients who received a liver transplant to those qualifying for SLK.

Methods: We reviewed 219 adult liver transplants performed at our institution between October 1, 2012 and April 30, 2020. 79% were liver only (LT) and 21% were SLK. Patient characteristics and outcomes were analyzed. Median follow up was 34 months.

Results: The LT and SLK groups were comparable in age, gender, and liver failure etiology. SLK patients had higher MELD scores (40 vs 22, p<0.01) and longer pre-transplant ICU needs. Among patients who received SLK, the etiology of pre-transplant renal failure was 32% CKD and 68% SAKI (p<0.01). 94% of SLK patients required renal replacement therapy (RRT) at the time of transplant versus 28% in the LT group (p<0.01). Median time on RRT prior to transplant was longer in the SLK group at 28 days compared to 11 days in LT cohort (p<0.01). 72% of SLK patients received intraoperative RRT versus 27% of LT patients (p<0.01). At 1 year, 53% of surviving SLK patients and 57% of LT patients had normal kidney function (p=0.7). Liver graft survival was comparable in both groups. Patient survival was higher in LT group: 1 and 3-year survival of 92% and 80% versus 82% and 75% for SLK patients (p=0.04). 21% of SLK patients had a positive crossmatch. Among the 47 SLK patients, 5 (10.6%) developed death-censored renal graft loss: 60% were due to refractory rejection within 6 months of transplant, all with positive crossmatch, while 40% were secondary to post-transplant acute tubular necrosis.

Conclusion: High acuity cirrhotic patients are at increased risk of renal failure. Simultaneous liver-kidney transplantation achieves acceptable patient outcomes and graft survival in critically ill patients. Pre-transplant cross matching for SLK candidates may play a role in renal graft outcomes and warrants further investigation.

abstract_title: Living Donor Liver Transplant Addresses Ethical Concerns and Equalizes Recipient Outcomes
author_block: H. J. Braun<sup>1</sup>, D. Amara<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Shui<sup>1</sup>, R. Hirose<sup>1</sup>, P. G. Stock<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Roberts<sup>1</sup>, F. L. Delmonico<sup>2</sup>, N. L. Ascher<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>New England Donor Services,Waltham, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Travel to, and within, the United States (US) has created four groups of patients who compete for liver transplantation: 1) singly listed (SL) patients who are listed at one transplant center, 2) multiply listed (ML) patients who are simultaneously listed at more than one center, 3) non-citizen, non-resident patients (NCNR) who travel to the US temporarily, and 4) non-citizen, residents (NC-R) who travel to and reside in the US. ML, NCNR, and NC-R travel for transplant is legal, but these practices raise concerns about the ethics of deceased donor organ allocation and whether our transplant system upholds social justice. Living donor liver transplantation (LDLT) enables patients to undergo transplantation without drawing from the limited deceased donor pool, offering both an ethical and practical solution to the problems of travel for transplantation. This study compared graft and patient survival following liver transplantation among SL, ML, NCNR, and NC-R recipients of both deceased donor (DDLT) and LDLT.

Methods: All United Network for Organ Sharing liver waitlist (WL) candidates from January 1, 2003-December 31, 2017 were reviewed. Re-transplant candidates, pediatric patients, and patients listed for multiple organs were excluded. SL patients were those with a single listing. ML patients were those with overlapping listing dates prior to their initial transplant or WL removal date. NCNR and NC-R patients were defined by citizenship. Demographics were compared using ANOVA and chi square tests. Graft and patient survival were evaluated using the Kaplan Meier method and Cox proportional hazards models.

Results: 132,277 WL registrants resulting in 75,955 liver transplant recipients were included (4.2% LDLT). Donor type by travel group is shown in Table 1. Among all recipients, there were significant differences in both graft and patient survival (p-values<0.001), with NCNR and NC-R faring best and SL faring worst. In multivariable Cox models evaluating predictors of graft loss or patient survival, and including age, sex, MELD score, presence of hepatocellular carcinoma, travel group, education, insurance, race, and donor type, LDLT was significantly associated with decreased graft loss (HR 0.9, p-value= 0.006) and decreased death (HR 0.79, p-value=0.001). Among LDLT recipients alone, there was no difference in graft or patient survival when stratified by travel group (p-values=0.69 and 0.36, respectively). 

Conclusion: LDLT represents a small proportion of all liver transplants performed in the US and must be carefully monitored to protect against donor exploitation, however this data suggests a more expanded use of LDLT should be considered for all patients.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Kidney Transplantation in HIV Positive Highly Sensitized Recipients
author_block: H. Curtis<sup>1</sup>, K. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, H. Resweber<sup>1</sup>, J. Panichella<sup>1</sup>, A. Di Carlo<sup>1</sup>, S. Karhadkar<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Temple University,Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Since the introduction of highly active antiretroviral therapy in 1996, HIV+ individuals are living longer. However, living longer has led to higher rates of end stage renal disease, therefore, kidney transplantation has become of increasing interest in this demographic. Renal allograft survival in HIV+ patients has lagged behind that of comparable cohorts and has been associated with increased rates of acute rejection. Additionally, increased rates of positive cross-matches in these recipients has impacted organ utilization. This study focuses on outcomes of kidney transplantation in HIV+ patients who are highly sensitized as described by a PRA value 90%-100% and/or with a positive cross match.

Methods: Data was gathered from the 2018 UNOS database, in which a total of 1530 HIV+ patients who received kidney transplants were selected. PRA values were grouped to create sensitization levels: non-sensitized (0%), low (1%-50%), medium (51%-89%), and highly sensitized (90%-100%). A demographics table was created to compare characteristics and outcomes between the four sensitization groups. A separate demographics table was created for non-sensitized and highly sensitized groups who also had a positive cross match. Subject characteristics were summarized using means and standard deviations or frequencies and percentages, as applicable. Significance between groups was determined by independent samples t-tests and χ2 tests (α = 0.05.). Death-censored graft survival for various subgroups was estimated using Kaplan-Meier with Log-Rank to assess significance. All analysis was completed using SPSS Statistics 26.

Results: The median graft survival for all 1530 patients is 792 days. The median graft survival for the non-sensitized group is 738 days while the median graft survival for the highly sensitized group is 990 days. The corresponding Kaplan-Meier graph displays no significant difference in the survival curves of the four groups; furthermore the highly sensitized group is the highest curve. The median graft survival for the non-sensitized group with a positive cross match is 2031 days while the median graft survival for the highly sensitized group with a positive cross match is 1606.5 days. The corresponding Kaplan-Meier graph displays that the survival curve of the highly sensitized group is slightly less than that of the non-sensitized group. 

Conclusion: The results show that graft survival is comparable for the highly sensitized group compared to the non-sensitized group. Therefore, HIV+ patients with a PRA value >= 90% should not be excluded from transplantation nor considered at higher risk when compared to non-sensitized HIV+ patients. The highly sensitized HIV+ patients with a positive cross match did exhibit a lower median graft survival, however, when comparing both the non-sensitized and highly sensitized to the overall study population, both groups had significantly higher median graft survival. Therefore a patient with a positive cross match or a positive cross match and highly sensitized should not be excluded from kidney transplantation nor considered at higher risk when compared to non-sensitized HIV+ patients with a negative cross match.

abstract_title: Uremic Symptoms Before and After Kidney Transplantation
author_block: M. McAdams-DeMarco<sup>1</sup>, K. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, N. Chu<sup>1</sup>, X. Chen<sup>1</sup>, Z. Shi<sup>1</sup>, E. Rosello<sup>1</sup>, S. Kunwar<sup>1</sup>, P. Butz<sup>1</sup>, S. Norman<sup>2</sup>, D. Crews<sup>1</sup>, K. Greenberg<sup>1</sup>, T. Shafi<sup>1,3</sup>, D. Segev<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Mississippi,Jackson, MS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients living with kidney failure report a high burden of symptoms related to uremia which likely increases while on dialysis and decrease after kidney transplantation (KT) due to the restoration of kidney function. Uremic symptoms are an important patient-centered outcome that is unique to this population, yet pre- and post-KT changes in uremic symptoms have never been studied.  

Methods: We leveraged a 2-center prospective study (n=2,531) of KT candidates (5/2014-3/2020). Uremic symptom scores (0-12) were calculated using KDQOL-36 items (pruritus, anorexia, and fatigue), and categorized: minimal:0-4; moderate:5-8; severe:9-12. We also estimated the risk of waitlist mortality (competing risks regression; n=1,289), change in uremic symptom scores between evaluation and transplantation (n=195), and the post-KT uremic symptom scores trajectories (mixed-effects models; n=545). All models were adjusted for confounders based on our conceptual models.  

Results: At evaluation, 19.6% of candidates reported moderate symptoms and 4.5% reported severe uremic symptoms. Candidates with severe uremic symptoms were at elevated risk of waitlist mortality (aSHR=2.75, 95%CI:1.37-5.52). By KT, 10.3% experienced decline in uremic symptom severity, 17.4% experienced elevated severity, and 72.3% remained unchanged. The estimated average uremic symptom score was 2.49 points at KT, 0.82 points at 4 months (67% decline) and 1.15 points (54% decline) at 16 months post-KT; the score decreased 0.42 points/month (95%CI:0.36-0.47) during 0-4 months post-KT, while increased 0.03 points/month (95%CI:0.000-0.06) from 4 months through 16 months post-KT (Figure). All 3 of the individual uremic symptoms had significant declines in the first four months post-KT. The estimated pruritus score wat 0.80 at KT and declined to 0.04 at 4 month post-KT, reflecting a 95% decline at 4 months; patients reported a 65% decline in anorexia and 52% decline in fatigue.  

Conclusions: Among KT candidates, severe uremic symptoms were associated with a greater risk of waitlist mortality. In this first longitudinal study of these patient-reported outcomes, we found that uremic symptoms persisted while on the transplant waitlist and significantly declined in the first 4 months post-KT. Or findings on the improvement of uremic symptoms with KT can help inform the shared-decision making surrounding transplantation.

abstract_title: Providing Equitable Access: Language and Literacy Levels of Kidney Transplant Websites
author_block: R. Olmeda Barrientos<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Englesbe<sup>3</sup>, V. S. Valbuena<sup>3</sup>, J. R. Santos-Parker<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Riverside,School Of Medicine,Riverside, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery, Section Of Transplantation,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Health disparities exist for access to kidney transplantation, evident by a relatively lower number of underrepresented minority individuals both donating and receiving kidney transplants. Patients can have access to transplant centers through multiple interfaces, with online access to websites being one avenue. However, it is unknown if these websites provide equitable access to transplant center information. This study aimed to assess kidney transplant website language and literacy levels to determine how equitable they are to patients.

Methods:  United States kidney transplant center websites were identified from the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network. Language was assessed by surveying the transplant kidney homepage and subpages for transplant-specific, non-English resources, excluding interpreter services. Literacy levels of kidney transplant website content were assessed by two tests: readability ease via the Flesch Reading Ease test and grade level via the Flesch Kincaid Grade Level test. Kidney transplant center websites from the 11 regions in the United States were compared to determine if transplant centers reflect their population demographics. 

Results: 227 kidney transplant centers were identified in the United States. Only 17% (38/227) of all kidney transplant center websites provided resources in non-English. Region 4 (OK, TX) and 5 (AZ, CA, NV, NM, UT) transplant center websites provided the most alternative language resources (14/57), whereas region 8 (CO, IA, KS, MO, NE, WY) and 10 (IN, MI, OH) did not providing any (0/34). Non-English resources provided did not reflect the respective state demographics or languages spoken at home. The variety in Spanish-provided resources included education PDF files and videos; external links to third-party sites in Spanish; and integrated translation systems. The average readability ease for all websites was 38±12, ranging from 1 to 69 (scale 0-100, lower scores corresponding to greater reading difficulty). This matched grade level of kidney transplant websites, which averaged 12±2.2, ranging from 7 (middle school) to 20 (professional).

Conclusion: Less than 20% of kidney transplant center websites provide some form of educational resources in an alternative language. In addition, transplant center websites’ literacy levels are 5 grades above the national average reading level of 7th grade. This inequity in understandability and literacy of transplant center websites further widen the gap in access to kidney transplantation. We hope to provide recommendations and guidelines to improve transplant center websites accessibility to better equip patients and their families with the knowledge and tools to make informed decisions regarding their transplant care.

abstract_title: Kidney Transplantation During the COVID-19 Pandemic: A Markov Decision Analysis
author_block: R. A. Choudhury<sup>1</sup>, P. T. Kennealey<sup>1</sup>, D. Yoeli<sup>1</sup>, H. B. Moore<sup>1</sup>, T. L. Nydam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,Transplantation Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   It remains unclear whether elderly kidney transplant candidates should delay seeking transplantation until the current COVID-19 pandemic passes.  Large-scale prospective studies will be lacking in the immediate future.

Methods: A Markov decision analytic model (DATA 3.5, TreeAge Software, Inc, Williamstown MA) was create to estimate the impact of delaying kidney transplantation in the current pandemic setting.  Base case patients in the model were defined as older patients (> 65 years of age) as this describes the population which public health officials have ascribed with higher risk following COVID-19 infection. 

Results:  Based on an assumed COVID-related mortality rate of 5.7%, immediate transplantation was associated with superior survival relative to 3, 6, 9, and 12 month delayed listing strategy.  However, as significant uncertainty exists in regard the true COVID-19 mortality amongst the immunosuppressed transplant population, a sensitivity analysis was performed revealing that delay to transplant was a superior strategy only when the COVID-19 related mortality rate was >10%. 

Conclusion: The current model suggests that for the majority of kidney transplant candidates, the COVID-19 pandemic should not delay transplantation nor change standard transplant listing practice patterns.

abstract_title: Progress in Pediatric Transplantation: A Multi-Organ Intent-to-Treat Analysis
author_block: B. Hickner<sup>1</sup>, A. Anand<sup>1</sup>, N. Nguyen Galvan<sup>2</sup>, R. T. Cotton<sup>2</sup>, C. A. O'Mahony<sup>2</sup>, J. Goss<sup>2</sup>, A. Rana<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Student Affairs,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Division Of Abdominal Transplantation, Michael E. DeBakey Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For decades, transplantation has prolonged life for children with heart, liver, and kidney failure. Improvements in waitlist and post-transplant survival are well documented, but donor organ shortages and difficulties in predicting wait-times create persistent uncertainty for children and their families. An intent-to-treat analysis, measuring survival from listing to death regardless of whether a transplant is received, can provide a more patient-centered perspective through which progress can be examined. The primary aim of this study is to examine changes in intent-to-treat outcomes from 1987-2017 in children listed for heart, liver, and kidney transplant.

Methods: Retrospective analysis was performed on data from the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS), including 12,511 children listed for heart transplant, 15,574 children listed for liver transplant, and 16,256 children listed for kidney transplant. Patients were separated based on era of listing from 1987-1992, 1993-1998, 1999-2004, 2005-2010, and 2011-2017. The 2011-2017 era was used as the reference. For each organ, factors including patient age, weight, height, ethnicity, life support dependency, UNOS status 1 designation, and organ-specific diagnosis were subjected to a univariate Cox regression analysis of intent-to-treat survival. Variables significant in univariate analysis were included with era of listing in multivariate analysis.

Results: Results from multivariate analysis pertaining to era of listing are shown in Table 1. For all three organs, later era of listing was found to be associated with decreased risk of death. In the heart and liver portions of the analysis, listing in all four eras prior to the reference were found to be associated with increased risk. In the kidney portion of the analysis, listing in the era 2005-2010 was not found to be associated with increased risk of death.

Conclusion: Intent-to-treat survival is a function of waitlist and post-transplant survival in addition to transplantation rate. Significant progress has been made in prolonging intent-to-treat survival for children listed for heart, liver, and kidney transplant. This is in line with the significant efforts that have been dedicated to the treatment of end-stage organ failure and graft rejection as well as improvements in immunosuppressive therapy. Efforts to increase the donor-pool and minimize organ discard have also contributed to this success. Further organ-specific analysis is warranted to determine predictors of intent-to-treat survival in order to contribute to future progress.

abstract_title: Non-Invasive Evaluation of Liver Quality in Deceased Organ Donors
author_block: K. Frey<sup>1</sup>, C. McLeod<sup>1</sup>, J. Purvis<sup>1</sup>, R. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, J. Locke<sup>1</sup>, B. Orandi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Changes in UNOS liver allocation policy have led to broader sharing over greater geographical areas, ultimately increasing expenditures related to transplant surgical team travel to procure and assess donor livers for transplant viability. This points to the need to efficiently identify marginal livers that are viable for transplant, especially as rates of obesity, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, alcohol use, and hepatitis C continue to trend upwards. To this end, this study aims to evaluate the validity of existing non-invasive tests in predicting the extent of macrosteatosis in the deceased donor population.

Methods:  Deceased donor UNet IDs were utilized to link abstracted liver biopsy data from all donor liver biopsies in the 2010 to 2020 period to the SRTR and its extensive data on liver donors and recipients. Non-invasive tests were applied to the sub-populations of potential deceased liver donors in order to evaluate the validity of the NAFLD fibrosis score and BARD score at predicting liver macrosteatosis >30%. Lab test values obtained for the patient population were compared to their biopsy results for diagnostic accuracy.

Results: The NAFLD fibrosis score had a 60.1% sensitivity, 41.9% specificity, 12.2% positive predictive value, and 88.7% negative predictive value, while the values for the BARD score were 89.9%, 14.2%, 12.3%, and 91.1%.

Conclusion: Commonly used clinical scoring systems for fibrosis can be used in the evaluation of deceased donor livers with sufficiently high negative predictive value to identify viable livers for transplantation.

abstract_title: High Versus Low Frequency Domino Liver Transplantation Centers Demonstrate Similar Outcomes
author_block: J. Panichella<sup>1</sup>, H. Curtis<sup>1</sup>, K. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, H. Resweber<sup>1</sup>, A. Di Carlo<sup>1</sup>, S. Karhadkar<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Temple University,Surgery,Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For patients with TTR Amyloidosis, the only disease modifying treatment is an orthotopic liver transplant. However, because of the nature of the disease, the liver from this patient can then be safely donated to another patient in need. While current research already demonstrates the success of DLT and increase the donor organ pool for those in dire need of a transplant, the use of DLT in many transplant centers has been limited. Trepidation over outcomes and complications in low frequency DLT centers has discouraged hospitals from using this procedure. This study analyzes the performance outcomes (of the DLT recipient) of transplant centers with a high frequency of DLTs performed to that of centers with lower frequency of DLTs performed.  

Methods: United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS)/Organ Procurement and Transplantation (OPTN) Standard Transplant Analysis and Research (STAR) database was queried and analyzed with SPSS version 26 IBM.  Whole liver domino patients  were extracted from the living donor dataset of transplants performed between April of 1996 and January of 2018 (n=193). Quantitative data was recorded as a mean with a standard deviation, while qualitative data is recorded as a frequency and percentage of the population queried. A Kaplan-Meier curve was performed. High frequency centers were determined as those with more DLTs than the third quartile mark (>5.75 DLTs performed).

Results: Overall outcomes between low and high frequency DLT centers were very similar. There was no difference between types of centers in cardiac, respiratory, or renal failure as a cause of death. There was no difference in functional status at the last follow-up between the two types of centers. The Kaplan-Meier curve shows the allograft survival is similar between the two groups. Graft status at the time of the last follow-up showed 91.7% of grafts functioning in the low frequency centers compared to 86.5% of grafts functioning high frequency centers. Acute rejection and chronic rejection were shown to be a similarly low value between the groups (1.6% high frequency versus 1.5% low frequency). 

Conclusion: The outcomes of high frequency DLT centers are very similar— if not better than—those of the low frequency centers. This encourages hesitant centers to perform DLTs without fear of outcomes or complications. Continued analysis to show significance are underway.

abstract_title: Experiences of Women Trainees in Transplant Surgery
author_block: A. E. Gomez-Rexrode<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Santos-Parker<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Cassidy<sup>1</sup>, L. M. McElroy<sup>3</sup>, S. Waits<sup>2</sup>, V. S. Valbuena<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery, Section Of Transplantation,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Department Of Transplantation,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As of 2019, only 13% of transplant surgeons in the United States self-identify as women, highlighting a gender disparity in transplant surgery. While the gender gap is narrowing, the unique experiences of women trainees must be assessed and integrated into training and recruitment strategies to ensure meaningful progress toward gender parity in the field of transplant surgery.

Methods: A 38-question survey was distributed to candidate members of the American Society of Transplant Surgeons (ASTS) via the ASTS email listserv to assess medical school and residency training experiences and exposure to transplant surgery, as well as career and academic mentorship received as trainees. Descriptive statistics and Mann-Whitney U tests were performed to determine statistical significance.

Results: Of the 324 ASTS candidate members contacted, 94 (29% response rate) completed the survey and 37% of participants self-identified as women. In medical school, 61% of men and 48% of women had exposure to transplant surgery. At the start of residency training, men rated their interest in transplant surgery significantly higher with a median score of 6.5 (6) compared to women with a median score of 4.0 (6) (p<0.05) on a rating scale of 1 = not interested, to 10 = very interested. At the start of their senior/chief years of training, both men and women rated their interest in transplant surgery equally (10 [1] and 10 [2] respectively). Most women (53%) and men (57%) senior residents had greater than one month of clinical exposure to transplant surgery at their home program and qualified their operative experience as excellent or good (94%; 76%). Most women and men trainees also felt supported by the transplant faculty at their institutions, both in their dedicated research time (68%; 63%) and during their fellowship application cycle (74%; 78%).

Conclusion: To date, a gender gap persists in transplant surgery. Women trainees report less interest in transplant surgery in their junior years and the survivorship bias from the cross-sectional study design may underestimate the magnitude of this finding. Although this difference is not reported in their senior years compared to their male counterparts, early career engagement of women trainees may provide an avenue to reduce the current gender gap. Women trainees have similar training experiences, exposure to transplant surgery, and career and academic mentorship later in their training compared to men trainees. More organized and targeted mentorship, including supportive relationships with transplant surgeons early in trainees' careers and positive junior transplant surgery experiences, are needed to promote engagement in transplant surgery among women trainees.

abstract_title: Characterization of Cardiothoracic Surgeons Actively Leading Basic Science Research
author_block: H. Wang<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Bajaj<sup>1</sup>, A. Krishnan<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Heiler<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Williams<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Pickering<sup>1</sup>, K. Manjunatha<sup>1</sup>, M. Sanchez<sup>1</sup>, C. T. O'Donnell<sup>1</sup>, J. H. Boyd<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Cardiothoracic Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA

abstract_title: Robotic Surgery: Potential for Advancement in Resident Education
author_block: I. S. Schmiederer<sup>1</sup>, T. N. Anderson<sup>1</sup>, R. Shi<sup>1</sup>, L. E. Kearse<sup>1</sup>, J. Korndorffer<sup>1</sup>, J. Lau<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Robotic Surgery, though relatively novel, has been well-studied as a means of advancing minimally invasive technique with advantages that include enhanced visualization of the operative field and better ergonomics within confined spaces – arguably ideal factors for intraoperative teaching. This study aims to gauge potential for robotic advances in the context of surgical education by assessing resident perspectives of robotic surgical education and overall career utility.

Methods: General surgery residents from 3 residency programs of diverse hospital type and geographic location were surveyed using mixed-methods questions that addressed robotic surgery experience and intraoperative autonomy on the robot. Descriptive statistics were utilized.

Results: Forty-three categorical general surgery residents participated (RR=50.6%): 23.3% were senior residents (PGY4-5), 32.6% mid-level residents (PGY3), and 44.2% junior residents (PGY1-2). 58.1% (n=25) of all participants indicated anticipation that they would use robotic surgery in future careers, despite most (n=32, 74.4%) indicating that robotic cases only comprised 10% or less of their major cases in the past year. In terms of exposure and intraoperative experience, mid-level (n=4, 28.6%) and senior residents (n=4, 40%) indicated they actually had been able to operate a robotic console for an entire case up to this point, with equal numbers of single versus dual console operations.

Conclusion: Enhancements to the operative experience provided by the robot lend themselves well to advancing surgical education; though, perhaps due to the novelty associated with robotic surgery, strategies around robotic resident education and intraoperative autonomy lag behind other surgical approaches, as the proportion of cases may suggest. This pilot survey demonstrates that residents do anticipate utility of robotic surgery and seek experience by senior level. Using this information, further studies will evaluate best practices of robotic teaching toward autonomy, focused on the context of single versus dual console models.

abstract_title: Impact of the Vascular Early Specialization Track on General Surgery Trainees' Vascular Experience
author_block: M. Siah<sup>1</sup>, K. Chamseddin<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Modrall<sup>1</sup>, M. Kirkwood<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Department Of Vascular Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There are currently three accredited pathways to train vascular surgeons. In 2003, the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) approved the Early Specialization (ESP)Track (4+2) for general surgery residents pursuing a career in Vascular Surgery and in 2005 approved the integrated (0+5) vascular programs for matriculated medical students. Over the past decade there has been a shift in integrated vascular surgery residents outnumbering traditional 5+2 fellowships. Previous studies have shown that the integrated programs (0+5) have no negative impact on the vascular training experience of general surgery residents nor vascular surgery fellows. Currently no studies exist evaluating the impact of the Vascular ESP track. The purpose of our study is to examine if the implementation of the Vascular ESP track had a significant impact on the operative vascular surgery experience of general surgery residents at our institution.

Methods: Using the ACGME operative case log reporting system, we retrospectively collected the total cumulative major vascular surgery cases completed by all graduating chief residents at the completion of their residency from the academic years of 2003 to 2019. Only cases reported as “surgeon chief” and “surgeon junior” were included. We compared operative experience before and after starting our Vascular ESP track in July 2005.

Results: A total of 186 general surgery chief residents graduated from 2003 to 2019. Prior to starting the Vascular ESP between 2003 to 2005 the average major vascular surgeries cases logged by graduating chiefs was 85.6±9.91 (range, 64-112) amongst 24 graduates. From 2006 to 2019, the average cases completed was 110.8±21.9 (range, 56-372) amongst 162 graduates. (P 0.016). Interestingly, between 2003-2009 there was no significant difference in case volume however after 2009, there was a significantly increased number of reported vascular surgery cases by general surgery residents as seen by a 40% increase in case logs.

Conclusion: Similar to the Integrated Vascular surgery residency, after the institution of the Vascular Early Specialization Track, there was no negative impact on the operative vascular surgery experience of general surgery residents.

abstract_title: Improving Surgical Patient Education Materials Using Informational Design with Visual Elements
author_block: T. M. Duong<sup>1</sup>, J. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, M. Morris<sup>1</sup>, G. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, H. Karin<sup>1</sup>, G. Drew<sup>1</sup>, C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, L. Theiss<sup>1</sup>, I. Marques<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Significant opportunities exist to improve patient education materials (PEMs) as improved understanding correlates to better patient satisfaction and outcomes. Much of current surgical patient education materials (PEMs) are difficult to understand. We investigated and tested a method to improve surgical PEMs and understanding.

Methods:  We utilized informational design with a professional artist to iteratively re-design the PEM for one surgery: sigmoidectomy. The CARP technique was used (contrast, alignment, repetition and placement) to create a one-page PEM. We presented the new PEM to 12 patients and family members. Participants were administered surveys including the BRIEF health literacy instrument to compare and quantify understanding between old and new PEMs.

Results: Using informational design with CARP, a new single-page PEM was constructed to show the steps and strategies used to resect and reconstruct the intestines during a sigmoidectomy. We recruited 12 participants to test the new PEM: 8 patients and 4 family members. Participant age range was 17-83 years with an average of 51.2 years. 38% of patients had limited health literacy by BRIEF and 50% were female. All participants understood and preferred the new PEM. All participants agreed that everyone or most people could understand the new PEM (vs. old PEM). Only 3 out of 12 participants agree that the old PEM could be understood by most people. No patients thought the old PEM could be understood by everyone. Over 50% of all participants stated that the new PEM: 1) captured their attention 2) helped them understand the procedure 3) informed them on how to prepare for their surgery 4) broke down steps to clear up their understanding of the surgical journey and 5) avoided confusion.

Conclusion: Using informational design with CARP, a more acceptable and understandable PEM on sigmoidectomy was constructed. The new PEM was accepted and understood by all individuals including those with limited health literacy.

abstract_title: Research Experience of Academic Cardiothoracic Surgeons Who Start as Attendings in Private Practice
author_block: S. Bajaj<sup>1</sup>, H. Wang<sup>1</sup>, K. Williams<sup>1</sup>, A. Krishnan<sup>1</sup>, J. Heiler<sup>1</sup>, J. Pickering<sup>1</sup>, K. Manjunatha<sup>1</sup>, M. Sanchez<sup>1</sup>, C. O'Donnell<sup>1</sup>, J. H. Boyd<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Department Of Cardiothoracic Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Advancing from training to clinical practice, surgeons must begin their attending careers in private practice or academia. It is unclear, however, if surgeons can transition to academia if private practice is initially selected. Here, we examined the research experience of academic cardiothoracic (CT) surgeons who began their attending careers in private practice.

Methods: We created a database of all 992 academic CT surgeons at the 77 CT surgery training institutions in the United States in 2018. Data regarding professional history, research productivity, and National Institutes of Health (NIH) funding were obtained from institutional webpages, Scopus, and Grantome. Institutional rankings by NIH funding were obtained from the NIH Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools. Continuous data are presented as median with interquartile range and analyzed with the Mann-Whitney test. Categorical data are analyzed with Fisher’s exact test.

Results: 80/992 (8.1%) surgeons started their careers in private practice while 912/992 (91.9%) started in academia. Surgeons who began in private practice spent 7.0 [3.0-13.0] years in private practice, publishing 0.3 [0.1-0.8] papers per year during private practice and 0.8 [0.2-2.1] papers per year during their subsequent academic career (p=0.0020). The research backgrounds of those who began their careers in private practice versus academia were similar (Table 1). Surgeons who started in private practice were as likely to have earned a PhD degree (p=0.4232) and NIH funding at any point in their careers (p=0.2375) as surgeons who started in academia. During training, surgeons who began in private practice were also as likely to take dedicated time for research (56.3% vs 57.0%, p=0.9067) and co-author a basic sciences publication (50.0% vs 54.5%, p=0.4832). Furthermore, a comparable proportion of surgeons who started in private practice trained at a top-20 NIH funded institution for general surgery residency (p>0.9999) and CT fellowship (p=0.3398). Despite these similarities, surgeons who began in private practice published fewer total papers at the end of general surgery residency (2.0 [0.0-5.0] vs 4.0 [0.0-10.0], p=0.0040) and CT fellowship (3.0 [1.0-8.0] vs 7.0 [2.0-14.0], p=0.0001). Surgeons who began in private practice were also less likely to have published a paper in 2017 or 2018 (55/80 [68.8%] vs 807/912 [88.5%], p<0.0001) and to currently work at a top-20 NIH funded institution (17/80 [21.3%] vs 325/912 [35.6%], p=0.0097).

Conclusion: Transitioning from private practice to academia is an established pathway. Surgeons who begin as attendings in private practice exhibit a similar research background as those who begin in academia but are less likely to publish research.

abstract_title: Which Institutions are Most Preferred for General Surgery Residency by Top Candidates in India?
author_block: A. Ozair<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Singh<sup>1</sup>, A. Faruqi<sup>1</sup>, V. Suresh<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Sonkar<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>King George's Medical University,Department Of General Surgery,Lucknow, UTTAR PRADESH, India
abstract_body:
Introduction: Little work exists worldwide on the objective institutional preference of top medical students and graduates (MSGs) selected for surgical residencies, who represent the future of surgery. Since 2017, India has been having a single annual test for MSGs. Ranks here serve as the sole criterion for selection into residency at nearly all training institutions. The latter lack any say in selecting individual MSGs. High-ranking candidates on this exam, the national eligibility-cum-entrance test - postgraduation (NEET-PG), represent the best MSGs in India. However, no study has yet determined the institutions most preferred for general surgery training, for which there are 3663 positions annually available. Hence, we sought to determine the institutional preference for residency of top-ranking MSGs who chose general surgery via NEET-PG.

Methods: We utilized the Medical Council of India (MCI) database of accredited training institutions and the anonymized, publicly available NEET-PG database of rank list and seat selection from 2017-20. We analyzed data of the top-100 ranked MSGs who chose general surgery every year from the round-one seat-selection session during 2017-20. We correlated this to the data of the national ranking of healthcare institutions (NIRF) published annually by the Government of India.

Results: India currently has 331 accredited 3-year programs in general surgery, with median (IQR) number of seats being 10 (10). We found significant clustering of top 400 MSGs who chose surgery into a few residency programs (figure 1). The overall distribution was heavily skewed, with 53.5% of the top MSGs preferring residency at just 7 institutions. These were amongst the 39 that were represented in the choices. Despite the complete absence of visiting student rotations in India, we found that a select few institutions consistently were the most preferred across all years. We discovered that preferred institutions were overwhelmingly located in major metropolitan cities and their degree of preference did not correlate well with their institutional ranking. The 2 most preferred institutions were absent from the government rankings across all 4 years.

Conclusion: We report for the first time the objective institutional preferences of top MSGs for general surgery residency in India. With a lack of visiting rotations, MSGs lack the means to compare programs. Additionally, there exists a need to determine the best practices from the preferred institutions and incorporate them at others. Top MSGs definitively prefer training in large metropolitan cities even though the institution may not be highly ranked, indicating that location is perhaps a key factor in selection. A multicentric, pan-India survey is needed to determine the reasons behind these preferences.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 on Engagement in Virtual Global Surgery Education
author_block: N. Pawlak<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Peck<sup>2</sup>, N. M. Ruzgar<sup>2</sup>, B. M. Hauser<sup>3</sup>, G. GSSA<sup>4</sup>, A. Jayaram<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tufts University School of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Global Surgery Student Alliance,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The disruption in clinical education during the COVID-19 pandemic, while resulting in physical barriers to traditional medical education curricula, has increased interest in and opportunities for innovative virtual educational models. We assessed the impact of COVID-19 on student engagement (in the United States and internationally) in global surgery webinars.

Methods:  Thirteen open-access webinars were held by a global surgery nonprofit between October 2019 and July 2020 consisting of expert panels and addressing various global surgery topics. Webinars were divided based on pre- or post-pandemic declaration by the WHO (pre: 10/2019-02/2020, post: 04/2020-07/2020) and registration form responses were divided based on the registrant’s country of residence (US vs. non-US). The average differences in overall registration rates, diversity of countries represented, and US vs. non-US engagement were analyzed.

Results: Webinars following the pandemic showed an overall increase in average number of registrants, though this difference was not significant (63.0 vs. 118.3, p=0.15). The average number of US registrants was significantly higher than the average number of non-US registrants during the pre-pandemic era (40.3 vs. 22.7, p=0.01), a between-group difference that equalized during the COVID19 pandemic (76.3 vs. 41.3, p=0.08). Despite an average increase in non-US participants, the increase in countries represented was not statistically significant (15.7 vs. 19.7, p=0.49). Webinars addressing broad disciplinary topics had the highest number of registrants, including global neurosurgery (n=194) and global obstetrics/gynecology (n=202). Conversely, the webinar with the most non-US registrants focused on research editorials, a very specific topic in global surgery (n=101).

Conclusion: Global surgery webinars were free and highly attended by students from high-, middle-, and low-income countries. Webinars held after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic were associated with increased participation from both US and international learners, particularly among non-US participants.
