This suggests an increased interest in global surgery topics among students during the pandemic, as well as unique opportunities to increase international collaboration in academic global surgery.

abstract_title: Comparing the Learning Environment and Well-being between Vascular Surgery Training Paradigms
author_block: M. C. Chia<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Li<sup>1</sup>, E. O. Cheung<sup>2</sup>, J. S. Eng<sup>2</sup>, T. Zhan<sup>2</sup>, M. G. Sheahan<sup>4</sup>, Y. Hu<sup>2</sup>, K. Y. Bilimoria<sup>2</sup>, D. M. Coleman<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Division Of Vascular Surgery, SOQIC, Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,SOQIC, Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Section Of Vascular Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center,Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery,New Orleans, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Integrated residencies allow direct entry into surgical subspecialties, enabling residents to bypass general surgery residency and save two or more years in training.  Although the number of integrated residencies continues to increase, little is known about the impact of this new training paradigm on trainee wellness.  Our aim is to compare resident well-being between integrated (0+5) and traditional (5+2) vascular surgery training paradigms in the United States.

Methods: An optional, confidential survey was administered after the 2020 Vascular Surgery In-Training Exam.  Clinically-active integrated residents (PGY 4-5) and fellows (PGY 6-7) were asked their perceptions about aspects of their learning environment, as well as thoughts of leaving their program or changing to a different specialty within the past academic year.  Burnout was defined as experiencing any symptom of emotional exhaustion or depersonalization at least weekly, reported on a modified Maslach Burnout Inventory.  Bivariate comparisons were performed using Fisher exact tests.

Results: Of 313 survey respondents (89.7% response rate), 94 were integrated residents, and 219 were fellows.  Trainees were predominantly male (70.2%) and at academically-affiliated institutions (79.9%).  Integrated residents appeared less likely to report satisfaction with the decision to become a surgeon (84.7 vs 91.5%, p = 0.095) and more likely to report thoughts of changing specialty (12.4 vs 8.4%, p = 0.370), although we were underpowered to detect statistical significance.  Trainees in both paradigms were highly likely to report appropriate operative autonomy (84.8 vs 86.4%, p = 0.707), clinical autonomy (90.0 vs 89.4%, p = 1.0), and a sense of belonging in their program (83.8 vs 82.3%, p = 0.862).  Reported rates of burnout (44.4 vs. 42.6%, p = 0.791) and thoughts of leaving the program (9.9 vs 11.8%, p = 0.836) were similar between training paradigms.

Conclusion: Vascular surgery trainees in both integrated and traditional training paradigms had positive perceptions of their clinical, operative, and interpersonal experience.  Despite similar rates of burnout and thoughts of leaving the program, it is possible that integrated residents experience lower job satisfaction and increased thoughts of changing specialties.  As the popularity of integrated residencies increases, it is important to ensure that medical students have ample experience in surgical specialties to inform a possible career choice in an integrated pathway.

abstract_title: Esophageal Case Volumes for Pediatric Surgery Fellows: Is Operative Experience Adequate for All?
author_block: P. A. Shah<sup>1</sup>, M. P. Shaughnessy<sup>1</sup>, N. L. Maassel<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Cowles<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Yale School Of Medicine,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pediatric esophageal anomalies, such as esophageal atresia with or without tracheoesophageal fistula (EA/TEF), are rare and morbid conditions that require complex surgical care. We sought to characterize the esophageal operative training received by pediatric surgery fellows by quantifying the trend and distribution of esophageal surgery case volumes among trainees over the last 16 years.

Methods: The Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) annual case log reports for pediatric surgery training programs were queried from 2004 to 2019. Number of trainees and total case volumes for esophageal procedures were obtained for each year. Additionally, mean, standard deviation, median and minimum case numbers were obtained when available for specific esophageal procedures, including antireflux operations, EA/TEF repair, esophageal resection/replacement, and esophagomyotomy. The presence of monotonic trends in average case volume were determined using Mann-Kendall tests, with significance assigned for p<0.05. Coefficients of variation (CoV) were calculated to measure relative variation of case volumes between trainees.

Results: From 2004 to 2019, the number of pediatric surgery trainees increased by 75% (24 vs 42), and the average esophageal case volume per trainee trended downward (59.1 vs 39.5 cases; p<0.01). There was a significant downward trend for the average number of antireflux operations performed by trainees during this time period (48.9 vs 26.8 cases, p<0.01), whereas the average number of non-antireflux operations performed trended upward (12.6 vs 16.2 cases, p<0.01). The CoV for average case volume in 2004 compared to 2019 was 43% vs 62% for EA/TEF repair, 83% vs 143% for esophageal resection/replacement, and 100% vs 143% for esophagomyotomy. The minimum number of esophageal replacement/resection and esophagomyotomy operations performed by an individual trainee was zero for each year between 2009 and 2019; the minimum number of EA/TEF repairs performed in these years ranged from 0 to 4.

Conclusions: Esophageal surgery case volumes for pediatric surgery fellows have decreased over the past 16 years. Although the average number of non-antireflux esophageal procedures performed by trainees has increased over this time period, there is substantial and rising variation in case volumes between trainees. As such, operative volumes of these complex cases for individual trainees remain relatively low. Each year, there are fellowship graduates who are not exposed to certain esophageal operations. The rarity and unequal distribution of operative experience in esophageal surgery suggests that some pediatric surgery fellows may not achieve competency in performing these complex procedures.

abstract_title: Development of a Novel Scale to Measure Learning Motivation in Surgical Residents
author_block: A. M. Fatunmbi<sup>1</sup>, C. Buonpane<sup>1</sup>, K. Young<sup>1</sup>, R. Hoffman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Danville, PENNSYLVANIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Goal orientation (GO) is a psychological construct describing a learner’s intrinsic motivation for learning in three domains: mastery (M), learners strive to attain competence; performance approach (PAP), learners strive to demonstrate competence; and performance avoid (PAV), learners strive to avoid demonstrating incompetence. Research in disciplines outside of medicine has shown that a learner’s predominant type of GO can have adaptive or maladaptive (PAV) implications for knowledge acquisition, well-being and job satisfaction. A previously validated scale of GO, the Patterns of Adaptive Learning Scale (PALS), was developed to examine learning and motivation in children/young adults, and later adapted for surgical trainees (aPALS).  However, this scale did not appropriately capture all three domains in surgeons.  Therefore, the aim of this study was to develop a novel GO scale for use in surgical residents and compare to the aPALS. 

Methods: A novel GO scale, GGOS, was developed from the previously validated PALS score as well as informal focus groups. The novel GGOS scale consisted of 14 questions deliberately constructed to address the 3 domains, with responses recorded on a frequency scale (“during the past month”) ranging from “never (0), rarely (1), weekly (2), >weekly (3), and daily (4)”. A questionnaire including both the aPALS and GGOS scales was administered in person to all 24 general surgery residents in an academic surgical training program at the same. The psychometric properties of the aPALS were compared to those of the GGOS utilizing an exploratory factor analysis

Results:Twenty-four (100%) residents completed the survey. The median resident age was 30 years (IQR 27, 34) and 10 (41.7%) respondents were female. The Cronbach alpha of the aPALS was α=0.79 while the novel GGOS was α=0.83. The results of an exploratory factor analysis using the aPALS revealed 6 domains, whereas the GGOS measured three factors as intended.  Mastery had the best precision with 4/5 (80%) of the intended questions falling under the same factor during analysis. PAV and PAP were mixed together within the other two factors. Using the intended three domains, average scale scores for each domain were: PAV (1.2), PAP (1.8), and M (2.4).

Conclusion: The novel GGOS scale demonstrated better performance characteristics for measuring motivation in surgical residents than the aPALS. Further adaptation of the questions are needed to accurately compartmentalize PAV, PAP and M within the scale. Proper scale development is important, as this novel perspective on education and well-being may ultimately facilitate an improved and more efficient learning environment for trainees.

abstract_title: Applying Deep Learning to Provide Eye-Gaze Guidance for the Peg Transfer Task
author_block: C. S. Kulkarni<sup>3</sup>, T. Wang<sup>3</sup>, N. Lau<sup>3</sup>, J. Hartman-Kenzler<sup>5</sup>, S. E. Parker<sup>4</sup>, S. Rajamohan<sup>6</sup>, L. E. Barnes<sup>2</sup>, S. D. Safford<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Virginia,Engineering Systems And Environment,Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>Virginia Tech,Grado Department Of Industrial And Systems Engineering,Blacksburg, VA, USA <sup>4</sup>Virginia Tech Carilion Research Institute,Roanoke, VA, USA <sup>5</sup>Virginia Tech Carilion School of Medicine,Roanoke, VA, USA <sup>6</sup>Virginia Tech,Advanced Research Computing,Blacksburg, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Effective and efficient self-training is ever more essential as instruction time is limited by both resident work-hour restrictions and constraints of teaching faculty. Artificial intelligence (AI) may contribute to self-training by providing feedback that reflects behaviors of an expert. This study investigates a deep convolutional neural network to develop AI that can mimic eye-gaze behaviors of an expert performing a peg-transfer task that residents practice independently to achieve proficiency for the Fundamental of Laparoscopic Surgery (FLS) program. A machine learning model that can imitate the expert-gaze corresponding to how the trainee is manipulating the instruments and transferring pegs could be invaluable to guide trainees in developing visual attentional control.

Methods: A two staged 3D convolutional neural network called Coarse Attention to Fine-Grained Gaze prediction was adapted to train a gaze prediction model for the FLS peg transfer task. To collect data for training the model, 13 medical students were recruited to practice the peg transfer task until they reached the FLS performance criteria. A total of 779 trials of video recording and eye-tracking data were collected. The best performing 177 trials were divided into 124 training, 17 validation and 36 test videos for training and testing the gaze prediction model. These best performing trials represented performance and gaze pattern of proficient individuals to build a model useful for guiding novices.

Results: The final gaze prediction model was composed of 38 layers that extract spatial and temporal information from series of 16 video frames (i.e., .6s) as well as gaze location of every frame. For the test dataset, this model had an average angular error of 2.1 degrees (sd=0.275) and distance error of 88 pixels (sd=11) on a 1280x720 resolution monitor. The magnitude of the average error translates to a slight overlap between the fields of foveal vision (~2.5 degrees) for the predicted and actual gaze locations of the test dataset. Figure 1 presents an example of the predicted and actual eye gaze on one video frame.

Conclusion: This prediction model mimics the dynamic gaze behaviors of individuals proficient at the peg-transfer task with a sufficiently low error rate for guiding novices in directing their visual attention. This model is novel for the surgical domain in that the predicted gaze dynamically adjust to the trainee actions in real time (e.g., the exact peg being moved). Future research will focus on an end-to-end modelling of ego-centric gaze prediction specific to surgical tasks for improving accuracy and accommodating a wider range of visual scenes.

abstract_title: Expectation vs Experience: Resident Perceptions Regarding a New Colorectal Surgery Fellowship
author_block: A. E. Whitlock<sup>1</sup>, T. Cataldo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The addition of a new surgical fellow on service debatably decreases resident case volume, and though it is common notion that residents are resistant to new fellowships, general surgery residents have not been directly surveyed regarding this issue. This study aimed to assess resident expectations regardinging the addition of a fellow to the colorectal surgery service at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center and to reassess their attitudes toward the fellowship after completion of their rotation.

Methods: An IRB approved survey was administered to residents before starting the Colorectal Surgery service and administered again after the completion of the rotation. The results were compared using Chi-Square analysis.

Results: A total of 15 residents participated, with 9 completing each survey and 3 residents completing both surveys. 73% of participants previously rotated on service before the institution of a colorectal fellow, 27% were junior residents, 77% were senior residents. 100% of residents who completed the pre-rotation survey expected to have fewer operative cases, while only 56% reported fewer cases post rotation (X2(4, n = 18) = 8.44, p=.076). 56% of pre-rotation participants expected less autonomy in the OR, however only 22% reported experiencing this post rotation (X2 (4, n = 18) = 10.64, p<.05). 89% of pre-rotation participants expected the fellow to limit interaction with the attending, but only 11% reported experiencing this post rotation (X2 (1, n = 18) = 10.89 p< .05). Only 44% surveyed pre-rotation expected the presence of a fellow to improve their experience but 78% reported improved experience post rotation (X2 (4, n = 18) = 6.78 p=0.148). There was no difference in expected or experienced improvement of on-service education with a fellow (56%) (X2 (4, n = 18) = 0, p=1.0) or improvement of outpatient experience (22%) (X2 (4, n = 18) = 2.99, p=.558). 33% of pre-rotation residents expected the fellow to limit their inpatient decision making, 22% reported this post rotation (X2 (4, n = 18) = 4.51, p=.341). Finally, 33% of pre-rotation residents expected to experience fewer duty hour violations, while 67% experienced fewer duty hour violations post rotation (X2(4, n = 18) = 4.58, p=.333).

Conclusion: This study demonstrates that resident expectations regarding the addition of a Colorectal Surgery Fellow differs from their actual experience and may be more positive than anticipated. This is especially true regarding attending interaction, operative autonomy and possibly even number of cases. Though limited by sample size and low participant retention, these findings oppose common dogma regarding the negative impact of a fellowship on the resident experience and provide a unique insight into the resident perspective.

abstract_title: Surgical Oncology Fellowship Websites: A Comprehensive Analysis of Accessibility and Content
author_block: S. S. Rajan<sup>1</sup>, S. Anathasekar<sup>1</sup>, Z. Aryanpour<sup>1</sup>, S. Reddy<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The COVID-19 pandemic has greatly affected all aspects of healthcare, including medical training, throughout the world. Travel restrictions during the 2020-21 academic year will alter the surgical fellowship process for both the program and the applicant. With fewer site visits, applicants will need to find other resources to help compile rank lists. Institutional websites will play a larger role in this decision-making process. The objective of this study was to analyze Complex General Surgical Oncology (CGSO) fellowship websites for information relevant to resident applicants.

Methods:  The publicly available Society of Surgical Oncology (SSO) program directory was accessed for a list of accredited programs as of July 2020. Each program’s institutional webpage was accessed via Google® search and assessed for the presence or absence of 44 previously established content criteria.

Results: The 29 CGSO fellowships accredited by the SSO were examined. Each program was also accredited by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education. Within the SSO listing directory, each fellowship program has an individual webpage. The SSO webpage did not have a hyperlink to any of the institutions’ fellowship pages. A median of 15 total criteria were found on institutions’ websites (range, 6-33).  Only 17% (N=5) of the programs fulfilled at least 50% of the content criteria. The most common criteria identified was description of the fellowship program and program coordinator contact information, found on 100% (N=29) and 97% (N=28) of the websites, respectively. Only 12 criteria were found on at least 50% of program websites.

Conclusion: Online CGSO fellowship information is lacking. With fewer opportunities to showcase programs and recruit applicants during this academic year, programs should increase the content value of their websites.

abstract_title: Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on the Wellness of Faculty and Trainees in Surgery
author_block: K. Zhu<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Luc<sup>2</sup>, E. M. Corsini<sup>3</sup>, E. A. Gillaspie<sup>4</sup>, M. B. Antonoff<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of British Columbia,Faculty Of Medicine,Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada <sup>2</sup>University Of British Columbia,Division Of Cardiovascular Surgery,Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Department Of Thoracic And Cardiovascular Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Department Of Thoracic Surgery,Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early reports demonstrate that the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has had a negative impact on health and wellness. We sought to characterize similarities and differences the COVID-19 pandemic has had on the emotional, professional, personal and financial well-being of surgical faculty and trainees.

Methods: A web-based survey evaluating physician stressors and concerns related to the COVID-19 pandemic was distributed via social media. Study inclusion required respondents to be practicing surgeons or trainees preparing for careers in surgery (including fellows, residents, and medical students).

Results: Respondents included 117 individuals, among whom 68 (59%) were faculty and 49 (41%) were trainees. Both faculty and trainees experienced feeling negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic in terms of physical (73.5% vs 53.1%; p=0.022), mental (85.3% vs 65.3%; p=0.011), and occupational wellness (79.1% vs 52.1%; p=0.002). Faculty and trainees also reported increased financial stress associated with decreased income (58.6% vs 36.1%; p=0.034) and loss of work (61.8% vs 38.5%; p=0.049). Concerns about working from home (81.6% vs 81.8%; p=0.977) and potential adverse patient outcomes due to care delay (85.4% vs 76.1%; p=0.247) represented the top professional stressors for both faculty and trainees. Worry about family and friends (85.4% vs 87.7%; p=0.725) was the greatest personal stressor for both groups. The majority of respondents (91.2% faculty and 87.8% trainees) modified their home living situations in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. A significantly higher proportion of faculty respondents had reviewed or made their wills (45.6% vs 14.3%; p<0.001), whereas almost half of all trainees have made no advanced care or financial planning (49.0% vs 27.9%; p=0.020).

Conclusion: The COVID-19 pandemic has negatively affected the wellness of both surgical faculty and trainees, with many similarities in both personal and professional impact. In order to optimize surgical training, it is essential that we identify emerging stressors and implement programs to support faculty and trainees through the challenges experienced.

abstract_title: Impact of Nationally Scaled Trauma Training Program in Uganda: Key Insights from Qualitative Analysis
author_block: Z. Tang<sup>1</sup>, D. Kayondo<sup>6</sup>, S. Ullrich<sup>1</sup>, M. Namugga<sup>4</sup>, P. Muwanguzi<sup>4</sup>, G. Klazura<sup>5</sup>, M. Armstrong-Hough<sup>3</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Pediatric Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>New York University College of Global Public Health,Department Of Social And Behavioral Sciences,New York, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>Makerere University School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Kampala, KAMPALA, Uganda <sup>5</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Maywood, IL, USA <sup>6</sup>Mbarara University Medical School,Mbarara, MBARARA, Uganda
abstract_body:
Introduction:  There is a need for advanced trauma training in sub-Saharan Africa. The Kampala Advanced Trauma Course (KATC) is a context-specific training program developed in Uganda by local and international experts. In 2018, cohorts of healthcare workers participated in 5-day training courses that combined didactic learning, practical hands-on skill stations, and simulations. We aimed to evaluate the impact of the KATC program on trauma care and determine the barriers participants faced in applying skills acquired during training.

Methods:  We conducted semi-structured interviews with 28 attending physicians, physicians in training, and nurses who participated in KATC trauma courses over the previous year. We asked respondents to reflect on trauma management in their local settings, perceptions of barriers to care, feelings toward KATC training, and experiences incorporating KATC skills into daily practice. We transcribed and coded these interviews using an inductive grounded theory approach, then categorized emergent themes.

Results: Half (14) of participants were from national or regional referral hospitals. Most (23) worked at public hospitals. Participants explained that KATC exposed knowledge gaps, improved proficiency and confidence in management, and described successful outcomes in specific patients. Specific barriers to skill use included physical resource (i.e equipment)  constraints; and limited opportunities to practice or share skills with peers. These factors combined with the large volume of information delivered in the course also led to concerns about long-term knowledge retention. Participants described themselves as “islands of knowledge” in their institutions. Only one to three providers from each institution had the opportunity to receive KATC training, and this placed increased pressure on them to translate training into practice and lead team-based resuscitations. Themes were integrated into a model of KATC skill translation and transference (figure).

Conclusion: Qualitative analysis of a contextually-appropriate trauma course in Uganda showed that participants reported substantial benefit in fund of knowledge and skill acquisition. However, multiple barriers to translating skills to practice included lack of equipment, practice, reinforcement of knowledge, and being an “island of knowledge” within their facilities. Our plans to address these factors include team-based training at the level of rural facilities, improved educational resources after course delivery, and addressing physical resource gaps. This study illustrates the critical role of qualitative analysis in assessing impact of a trauma capacity-building initiative, and may be useful for other global surgery training initiatives.

abstract_title: Medical Student Perceptions of Procedural Learning in the Era of COVID-19
author_block: R. Bustos<sup>1</sup>, Y. Cai<sup>2</sup>, N. Jiam<sup>2</sup>, K. Wai<sup>2</sup>, J. L. Chang<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,School Of Medicine,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Department Of Otolaryngology- Head And Neck Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Novel Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic in the United States has had significant implications on medical student surgical education. A cornerstone of surgical education traditionally involves hands-on procedural and surgical learning. However, in this era, hands-on learning may confer viral exposure and transmission risk. As healthcare systems proceed with recovery from the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, it is crucial to understand medical student perceptions regarding their participation in clinical settings and their comfort in communicating concerns related to their participation. We thus conducted a survey of medical students at our institution to understand these issues.

Methods: University of California, San Francisco medical students of all years of training were invited to complete an anonymous survey between April 26 and May 10, 2020.

Results: A total of 241 medical students (37% of the student body) completed the survey; the vast majority (95%) of students were concerned about the impact of COVID-19 on their education. Of participants, 116 (50%) reported an interest in a surgical or procedure-oriented specialty and 54 (23%) were unsure of their medical specialty interests. Students reported varying levels of comfort interfacing with patients based on COVID-19 status. Of students on clinical rotations, 31% reported they would not feel comfortable participating in clinical encounters for COVID-19-positive patients. In comparison, 6% did not feel comfortable in COVID-19-negative encounters and 12% noted discomfort with asymptomatic patients with unknown COVID-19 status. Students reported they would be comfortable in interfacing with COVID-19 positive patients if supervised throughout the encounter (53%) or if the encounter did not involve an aerosol-generating procedure (56%). Students reported they are most comfortable voicing COVID-19 related concerns to their clinical rotation teams through anonymous surveys created by their peers (83% of respondents) and anonymous surveys created by clerkship directors (76%). Fewer students felt comfortable communicating their concerns through group or one-on-one discussions with clerkship directors (52% and 48%, respectively).

Conclusion: The COVID-19 pandemic has presented challenges to medical student surgical and procedural education paradigms. However, the majority of students desire to be involved in patient care regardless of COVID-19 status, though some may hold reservations in interacting with COVID-19-positive patients during aerosol-generating procedures or unsupervised procedures. Students feel most comfortable communicating their concerns through anonymous surveys, which should be considered by clinicians integrating medical students into their teams.

abstract_title: Ultrasound Curriculum in Surgical Resident Education Varies Among Subspecialities
author_block: Y. Lu<sup>2</sup>, K. Chemakin<sup>1</sup>, E. Schiff<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Ricci<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine,Bronx, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Montefiore Medical Center,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Bronx, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Ultrasound is a versatile tool that allows point-of-care diagnosis and image-guided procedures in many surgical settings. It is gaining popularity in medical training, however the adaptation of formal ultrasound curriculums among surgical subspecialties has not been universal. This study aims to assess the current state of ultrasound curriculum in surgical resident education by performing an analytical review of the recent literature. We treat the published literature as a surrogate for quantifying the degree of ultrasound training in effect across surgical subspecialties. The sparsity of literature in plastic and reconstructive surgery (PRS), despite the increasing number of published ultrasound applications in this field, suggests the need for further investigation.

Methods: A PubMed search using “surgery OR surgical” and “ultrasound OR ultrasonography OR sonogram” in titles and abstracts and “internship and residency” in MeSH terms was used to identify the literature from the recent 10 year 2010-2019 on ultrasound curriculum in surgical resident education. Articles without a reference to a specific ultrasound procedure, training modality, or a surgical-related speciality were excluded. Titles and abstracts were reviewed. The data was compared with the total number of on-duty residents in ACGME programs in 2019.    

Results: A total 227 articles were identified and, after exclusion, 117 articles were reviewed. Emphasis was placed on subspecialties with integrated programs, namely PRS, cardiothoracic, and vascular surgery. Anesthesia and emergency medicine constituted 36% and 22% of articles. General surgery made up 30%, and surgical subspecialities had minor contributions (TABLE1). A one-tailed z-test was applied to test if the percent of literature contribution under-represents or over-represents the proportion of on-duty residents in 2019 in a given specialty. While anesthesia made a significantly higher contribution (p<0.00001) in the literature and general surgery had a fair representation, PRS is significantly under-represented in the literature (p=0.029). During the same period of time, integrated PRS programs continue to increase in number and total number of residents nationwide.

Conclusion: An analytical review of the recent literature on ultrasound curriculum in surgical resident education was performed. When compared with the number of on-duty residents, the results demonstrated an under-representation in surgical subspecialty fields such as PRS. Given the growing interest among trainees to enter integrated subspecialty programs, there is a need for specialty-specific literature to critically evaluate and promote ultrasound training in subspecialty residency programs.

abstract_title: History of Depression is Associated with Worsened Postoperative Outcomes Following Colectomy
author_block: G. Q. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Canner<sup>1</sup>, E. Prince<sup>2</sup>, M. Stem<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Efron<sup>1</sup>, C. Atallah<sup>1</sup>, B. Safar<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Psychiatry & Behavioral Sciences,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Depression is a highly prevalent psychiatric disorder that has been associated with adverse outcomes in chronic disease. The relationship between depression and postoperative outcomes has previously been described, but data in colorectal surgery remains limited. The purpose of this study was to examine the impact of history of depression among patients undergoing colectomy.

Methods: Adult patients from the IBM MarketScan Research Databases (2010-2017) who underwent colon resection were included within the study and were stratified by whether or not they had a history of depression, defined by 1) a diagnosis of depression during the index admission, 2) a diagnosis of depression during any inpatient admission in the year prior, 3) a diagnosis of depression during any outpatient encounter in the year prior, and/or 4) a pharmacy claim for an antidepressant in the year prior. The primary outcomes were length of stay (LOS) and total inpatient hospital costs. Secondary outcomes included in-hospital mortality as well as postoperative complications. Statistical analyses performed included logistic, negative binomial, and quantile regressions. 

Results: Among 88,981 included patients, 24,244 (24.1%) had a history of depression. The mean postoperative LOS for those with and without history of depression was 6.51 and 6.98 days (p<0.001), respectively. The median total inpatient hospital cost was $29,041 and $29,135 (p=0.234), respectively. Compared to those without the diagnosis, patients with a history of depression were expected to have a significantly longer LOS (IRR=1.06, 95% CI [1.05, 1.08], p<0.001) and increased odds of in-hospital mortality (OR=1.37, 95% CI [1.08, 1.73], p=0.009), but no difference in cost (p=0.257), after adjusting for baseline demographic, clinical, and operational factors (Table). History of depression was also independently associated with increased odds of respiratory complication (OR=1.20), pneumonia (OR=1.18), and delirium (OR=1.99; all p<0.05).  

Conclusion: History of depression was present in almost one-fourth of a cohort of individuals undergoing colectomy, and was associated with greater postoperative mortality, longer LOS, and higher odds of postoperative complication. Findings from this large claims database raise further research questions on the effect of preoperative identification and treatment of depression on reducing morbidity in colorectal surgery.

abstract_title: A Systematic Review and Network Meta-Analysis on Treatments for Grade 1, 2 and 3 Hemorrhoids.
author_block: J. Jin<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Lee<sup>2</sup>, S. Bhat<sup>2</sup>, W. Xia<sup>1,2</sup>, A. G. Hill<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>South Auckland Clinical School,Auckland, AUCKLAND, New Zealand <sup>2</sup>University Of Auckland,Surgery,Auckland, AUCKLAND, New Zealand
abstract_body:
Introduction:   There are many treatments for early to moderate grade of prolapse for symptomatic hemorrhoids each with their own complications and risks. Interventional treatments for early to moderate grade hemorrhoids range from outpatient-based procedures to surgical intervention. The aim of this study is to compare the clinical outcomes and effectiveness for treatments of early to moderate grade hemorrhoids grade 1 to 3. 

Methods: Randomised Controlled Trials (RCTs) were identified by means of a PRISMA compliant systematic review using Medline, EMBASE and CENTRAL databases. Inclusion criteria were randomised controlled trial of a procedural intervention for hemorrhoids. Studies were excluded if the study population had grade four hemorrhoids. A Frequentist Network Meta-analysis was performed using netmeta and shiny package in R.

Results: Sixty-Three RCTs were identified including 7956 patients and 20 different treatments. There were few instances of inconsistency between direct and indirect comparisons. Recurrence of hemorrhoidal symptoms was reported by 37 RCTs, involving 6254 patients and 17 treatments. Suture mucopexy was ranked with the lowest recurrence, followed by open/closed hemorrhoidectomy, doppler guided hemorrhoid artery ligation (DG-HAL) with mucopexy, stapled hemorrhoidopexy, rubber band ligation, infrared coagulation and injection sclerotherapy. Post-operative bleeding was recorded in 37 trials involving 4442 patients. Open hemorrhoidectomy revealed the highest occurrence of post-operative bleeding, followed by radiofrequency coagulation, stapled hemorrhoidopexy and closed hemorrhoidectomy. Direct-current (DC) electrotherapy and bipolar coagulation had the lowest rates of bleeding. Pain on post-operative day 1 measured by a Visual Analog Scale was reported in 32 studies involving 2616 patients and 17 treatments. DC electrotherapy, DG-HAL with mucopexy and infra-red coagulation yielded the lowest pain scores, while closed hemorrhoidectomy, harmonic scalpel hemorrhoidectomy and diathermy hemorrhoidectomy were ranked with the highest pain scores. Patients who had undergone re-treatment, additional treatment or crossover was reported in 24 studies with 3310 patients involving 16 treatments. Diathermy hemorrhoidectomy, open hemorrhoidectomy, and Ligasure hemorrhoidectomy had the lowest numbers of reported additional or re-treatment, while bipolar coagulation, DC electrotherapy, injection sclerotherapy and infrared coagulation had the highest numbers of reported additional or re-treatment. 

Conclusion: Open and closed hemorrhoidectomies are associated with the highest pain scores with comparatively low recurrence. Suture mucopexy and DG-HAL with mucopexy are associated with both lower recurrence and reduced pain compared to other treatment modalities. The advantages and disadvantages of each treatment should be discussed with the patient before a surgical decision should be made.

abstract_title: Analysis of the Effect of Hospital By-Pass in Treatment Utilization and Survival for Colon Cancer Patients
author_block: J. YAN<sup>1</sup>, J. Yan<sup>1</sup>, H. Zhu<sup>1</sup>, R. Alterio<sup>1</sup>, M. Augustine<sup>1</sup>, M. Porembka<sup>1</sup>, S. Wang<sup>1</sup>, J. Mansour<sup>1</sup>, H. J. Zeh<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Yopp<sup>1</sup>, P. Polanco<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous research suggested that the hospital by-pass (HB) effect has a net positive effect on patient overall survival for certain malignancies. There is a lack of data regarding the effect of HB on colon cancer (CC). Our aim was to examine the effect of HB on treatment utilization and survival in patients with CC.

Methods: Patients with localized and regional colon cancer (CC) were identified in the Texas Cancer Registry-Database (1995-2016). Clinicopathological data, hospital factors, and receipt of optimal treatment (guideline-concordant) and overall survival (OS) were compared between hospital bypass (HB, bypassing closest hospital) and non-hospital bypass (NHB, going to closest hospital) cohorts determined by geospatial analysis (latitude/longitude data). Multivariable analysis (MVA) was performed to determine factors associated with increased probability of hospital bypass and mortality at 5 years

Results: We identified 43,557 patients with localized (L) and regional (R) CC. HB patients were more likely to be younger than 50 (L: 7.7% vs 6.1%, p<0.001, R: 12.2% vs. 8.7%, p<0.001), have private insurance (L: 22.9% vs 18.8, p<0.001, R: 23.6% vs. 18.9%, p<0.001), belong to low poverty index (0-5%) areas (L: 17.2% vs. 12.1%, p<0.001, R: 16.9% vs. 12.0%, p<0.001) and be treated at American College of Surgeons Commision on Cancer (ACS-CoC) accredited hospitals (L: 60.4% vs 30.8%, p<0.001, R: 61.5% vs. 31.4%, p<0.001) when compared to the NHB group. HB patients had better 5-year overall survival (L: 71.2% vs. 68.4%, p=0.021, R: 56.2% vs. 52.2%, p=0.005) and higher optimal treatment rates for regional colon cancer (67.0% vs. 64.7%, p=0.008). On MVA, factors associated with improved 5-year overall survival include HB status, age <50, private insurance, low poverty index, and treatment at ACS-CoC accredited hospitals (all p<0.01)

Conclusion: Colon cancer patients that bypass their local hospital are more likely to be younger, on private insurance and to be treated in ACS-CoC accredited hospitals. All these factors are associated with improved survival. Moreover, HB status alone is associated with significantly increased 5-year survival and increased receipt of optimal treatment for regional colon cancer patients. NHB may be a marker of an at-risk-population with limited access to specialized multidisciplinary cancer care.

abstract_title: Bowel Prep For Elective Hartmann Procedure: Analysis of National Surgical Quality Improvment Database
author_block: R. U. Kalu<sup>3</sup>, A. Tang<sup>2</sup>, C. Reickert<sup>1</sup>, A. Stefanou<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Henry Ford Health System,Division Of Colon And Rectal Surgery,Detroid, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Henry Ford Health System,Department Of Public Health Sciences,Detroid, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Henry Ford Health System,Department Of Surgery,Detroid, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The role of bowel preparation before colorectal surgery has evolved over time. Historically, preoperative bowel preparation was believed to reduce intestinal stool and bacterial burden, potentially reducing the rate of surgical site infection (SSI), anastomotic dehiscence, and perioperative morbidity and mortality. The choice of preoperative bowel preparation includes mechanical bowel preparation alone (MBP), oral antibiotic bowel preparation (OAP), or a combination of the two (MAP). Preoperative bowel preparation is also believed to protect the newly fashioned intestinal anastomosis. This presents a unique consideration in patients for which no anastomosis is planned. Currently the majority of the literature supporting MAP includes all colectomies or is limited to those patients who have anastomosis and excludes patients who underwent colorectal resection with primary colostomy (Hartmann procedure). While sometimes included in overall studies, this unique patient cohort has not been exclusively examined. These patients do not have anastomosis and therefore may not benefit as much from preoperative MBP or OAP.

Methods: Using the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) colectomy-targeted database, we aimed to evaluate the impact of different preoperative bowel preparations on short-term outcomes in patients who had elective colorectal resection with creation of end colostomy (Hartmann procedure). Primary outcomes evaluated included postoperative outcomes, particularly infectious complications such as SSI, wound disruption, Clostridium difficile colitis, and need for reoperation.

Results: Of the 5708 patients analyzed, 3088 (54.1%) received no preparation, 325 (5.7%) received oral antibiotic preparation alone, 1174 (20.6%) received mechanical bowel preparation alone, and 1121 (19.6%) received both mechanical and oral antibiotics (or dual) preparations. After propensity adjustment, the use of mechanical bowel preparation alone increased the risk of deep incisional SSI compared to no bowel preparation (odds ratio 1.85, 95% CI 1.07-3.18). In contrast, OAP and MAP decreased the risk of any SSI (odds ratio 0.42, 95% CI 0.28-0.65; and odds ratio 0.67, 95% CI 0.54-0.85, respectively), and superficial SSI (odds ratio 0.35, 95% CI 0.18-0.69; and odds ratio 0.46, 95% CI 0.33-0.64, respectively). OAP and MAP were also associated with significantly shorter length of stay. On multivariate analysis, OAP and MAP were predictive of fewer infectious complications and shorter length of stay, but not reoperation or readmission.  

Conclusion: The use of combined oral antibiotic and mechanical bowel preparation significantly reduces the rate of infectious complications compared to no bowel preparation in patients undergoing elective Hartmann procedure. Mechanical bowel preparation alone appears to be detrimental and should be abandoned.

abstract_title: The Power of Outpatient Botulinum Injections in Preventing Hirschsprung Associated Enterocolitis
author_block: W. Svetanoff<sup>1</sup>, K. B. Briggs<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Fraser<sup>1</sup>, J. Lopez<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Fraser<sup>1</sup>, D. Juang<sup>1</sup>, P. Aguayo<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Hendrickson<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Snyder<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Oyetunji<sup>1</sup>, S. D. St. Peter<sup>1</sup>, R. M. Rentea<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Mercy Hospital- University Of Missouri Kansas City,Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Botulinum toxin (BT) injections assist in temporarily relieving obstructive symptoms due to internal anal sphincter (IAS) achalasia in patients with Hirschsprung’s disease following surgical pull-through. The use of BT may play a role in preventing Hirschsprung associated enterocolitis (HAEC) episodes related to IAS dysfunction. Our aim was to determine the effect of scheduled outpatient Botulinum injections on the development of HAEC.

Methods: A retrospective review of children diagnosed with Hirschsprung’s disease between January 2010 – July 2020 was performed. The timing from pull-through to first HAEC episode and to first BT injection was recorded. Episodes of recurrent HAEC and timing to a recurrent HAEC episode was analyzed between patients who received outpatient BT injections and those who did not. A p-value < 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Eighty patients were included. Sixty patients (75%) were male, 15 (19%) were diagnosed with trisomy 21 and 18 (22.5%) had congenital heart disease. The median time to pull-through was 150 days (IQR 16, 132). Fifty-eight patients (72.5%) had short-segment disease, 7 (9%) had long-segment disease, and 6 (7.5%) had total colonic or small bowel disease. Seven patients (9%) had neither an episode of HAEC or BT injections and were not included in further analysis. Fifty-five patients (69%) experienced at least one episode of HAEC within 38 days (IQR 15, 283) following pull-through, with patients experiencing a median of 2 episodes (IQR 1,4). 54 (68%) had at least one outpatient BT injection. The median time to first BT injection following pull-through was 329 days (IQR 54, 807) with patients undergoing a median of two injections (IQR 1, 3). Twenty patients had scheduled outpatient Botox injections with obstructive symptoms prior to documented HAEC episode (median time from pull-through = 71 days), and only two subsequently developed HAEC (95 and 247 days from pull-through). In patients who experienced HAEC prior to their first outpatient injection (n=31), only 12 (39%) experienced another episode of HAEC requiring inpatient treatment. The median time to the next HAEC episode was 129 days (IQR 34, 406) following outpatient BT injection. In comparison, 28 patients had a recurrent episode of HAEC without BT injections performed. The median time to the recurrent HAEC episode was 36.5 days (IQR 13, 164), which was significantly shorter (p = 0.04).

Conclusion: The use of outpatient BT helps to prevent episodes of HAEC and also increases the interval between HAEC episodes. The use of scheduled outpatient BT injections to manage obstructive symptoms may be a beneficial Hirschsprung disease patients following pull-through.

abstract_title: Ostomy Reversal: Does Surgeon Specialization Matter?
author_block: M. O. Suraju<sup>1</sup>, P. Goffredo<sup>1</sup>, A. Hart<sup>2</sup>, A. Masson<sup>1</sup>, A. Nayyar<sup>1</sup>, P. McGonagill<sup>1</sup>, I. Gribovskaja-Rupp<sup>1</sup>, I. Hassan<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Department Of Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa,College Of Medicine,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Reversal of ileostomies and colostomies falls within the scope of practice of several surgical specialties. These procedures can be technically challenging, and complications rates can be as high as 45% depending on the type of ostomy. The impact of surgical subspecialty on outcomes in these patients has not been well studied. The aim of the current study was to compare short term outcomes of ileostomy and colostomy reversal by colorectal surgeons and non-colorectal surgeons (CRS and Non-CRS) utilizing our institution specific National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) database.

Methods: This retrospective study analyzed our tertiary care center specific NSQIP database for ileostomy and colostomy takedowns (CPT codes 44227, 44626, 44620,44625) between 2009 and 2020. Surgeon specialty was identified by chart review. Primary outcome of interest was overall complication rates for CRS and Non-CRS. Secondary endpoints were procedure duration, and length of stay (LOS).

Results: A total of 321 ostomy takedown procedures were performed: 22% end colostomy, 8% loop colostomy, 13% end ileostomy, and 58% loop ileostomy. Of these, 83% were performed by CRS. Mean age of the cohort was 52yrs (SD: ±15) and 46% were females. Mean BMI was 27(SD: ±6). There were more secondary procedures performed in the non-CRS (41%) as compared to the CRS groups (24%). There were no differences in demographic and clinical characteristics between patients operated on by CRS and Non-CRS. Overall complication rates were 20% and 16% for the CRS and Non-CRS groups respectively (Table 1). Infectious complications were the most common category of complications in both groups. After adjusting for available confounders, having an end ostomy reversed and a higher ASA class were associated with a higher risk of postoperative complications, however, surgeon specialty was not. Procedure duration was shorter for CRS but there was no difference in LOS between the two groups.

Conclusion: In this single institutional series, ileostomy and colostomy reversals were associated with significant postoperative morbidity. However, patients managed by CRS and Non-CRS surgeons had similar perioperative outcomes.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in the Surgical Management of Rectal Cancer
author_block: A. O. Arias<sup>1</sup>, E. Thompson<sup>1</sup>, E. Pefok<sup>1</sup>, A. Cruz<sup>1</sup>, R. Silva<sup>1</sup>, T. Estrada<sup>1</sup>, E. Krall<sup>1</sup>, C. Villa<sup>1</sup>, V. Nfonsam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,General Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Rectal cancer (RC) continues to be a significant burden in the United States despite all the advances made in prevention, diagnosis, and treatment. Multiple studies have shown that racial disparities do exist in the incidence of rectal cancer. However, disparities in the surgical management of the disease are less investigated. Abdominoperineal resection is a less desirable surgical option for most patients due to the fact that the patient has a permanent stoma that might impact their quality of life. The aim of our study was to elucidate if there are racial disparities in the surgical treatment options for rectal cancer.

Methods: We performed a 3-year (2016-2018) analysis of the American College of Surgeons-National Surgical Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database. We included all adult patients who underwent a low anterior resection (LAR) or abdominoperineal resection (APR) for the management of rectal cancer. Patients demographics were noted. Patients were stratified into two groups based on surgical intervention (APR vs. LAR). A multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed.  

Results: A total of 10,365 patients were analyzed and included in the analysis. The mean age was 49.65 years, 61.3% were males, 67.0% of the patients underwent a LAR compare to 33% that got an APR, and 60.9% had an American Society of Anesthesiologist (ASA) classification ≥ to 3. Race distribution included 79.4% White, 7.8% African American, and 5.3% Hispanic. Patients in the African American, American Indian (Alaskan Native), Asian, and Hispanic groups were more likely to undergo LAR compare to APR. On multivariate logistic regression, Native Hawaiians (or Pacific Islanders) had higher odds of undergoing APR compared to LAR for rectal cancer management.

Conclusion: Native Hawaiians (or Pacific Islanders) are more likely to have an APR than LAR.  African Americans, who normally have a higher incidence of rectal cancer, are do not have a higher chance of having an APR. Race appears to play a lesser role in the surgical management of rectal cancer.

abstract_title: Prognosis of Different Histologic Types in Patients with Stage II and III Colorectal Cancer.
author_block: Y. Z. Qwaider<sup>1</sup>, N. M. Sell<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Stafford<sup>1</sup>, H. Kunitake<sup>1</sup>, R. N. Goldstone<sup>1</sup>, R. Ricciardi<sup>1</sup>, L. Bordeianou<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Cauley<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Berger<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,General/GI Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a debate regarding the prognosis of the various histological types of colorectal cancer including adenocarcinoma, mucinous adenocarcinoma and signet ring cell colorectal cancers. Our aim is to determine if there are any differences in overall and disease-free survival between these three histological types in stages II and III colorectal adenocarcinoma.  

Methods: Data was retrospectively collected for all patients diagnosed with colon cancer who underwent resection at a single institution between 1/1/2004 through 12/31/2015. Patients with stage II and III colorectal adenocarcinoma, mucinous adenocarcinomas and signet-ring cell carcinomas were included in our analysis. Dichotomous variables were assessed using the χ2 test or Fisher’s exact test. Kaplan-Meire curves and log-rank tests were used for assessing the differences in survival between the groups. A Multivariable regression model was fit adjusting for histopathological diagnosis, age, stage, site, grade, ASA score, adjuvant chemotherapy and extramural vascular invasion.  

Results: A total of 1,173 patients were included in this analysis. Of those, 1090 patients had non-mucinous adenocarcinoma (93%) and 71 had mucinous adenocarcinomas (6%) and 12 had signet-ring cell carcinoma (1%). There was no association between histological type and gender, stage or anatomic site of tumor (p>0.05). However, signet-ring cell carcinomas were more likely to have extramural vascular invasion and high-grade dysplasia (p<0.001). There was a significant difference in overall and disease-free survival observed between patients with signet-ring cell carcinomas in comparison with mucinous adenocarcinoma and adenocarcinoma (p=0.008 and 0.001, respectively). When fitting a Cox regression model, signet-ring cell carcinoma (HR: 2.6; CI: 1.0-6.5; p=0.04) was an independent prognostic factor of poor overall survival, but mucinous adenocarcinoma was not (HR: 1.1; CI: 0.7-1.7; p=0.6).  

Conclusion: Patients with stage II and III colorectal signet-ring cell carcinoma had a significantly poorer prognosis compared to patients with mucinous and nonmucinous adenocarcinoma. Histologic type should be kept in mind when determining the treatment course of these patients.

abstract_title: Risk Factors for Readmissions Following Primary Fecal Diversion without Resection: a NSQIP Study
author_block: A. A. Hart<sup>1</sup>, P. Goffredo<sup>3</sup>, M. O. Suraju<sup>2</sup>, N. Allievi<sup>2</sup>, A. Masson<sup>2</sup>, A. Khan<sup>4</sup>, S. Ahad<sup>2</sup>, I. Hassan<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Carver College Of Medicine,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa,Department Of Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Minnesota,Department Of Surgery,Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>Raleigh General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Beckley, WEST VIRGINIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Due to a variety of intraabdominal pathologies, primary fecal diversion with an ileostomy or colostomy is sometimes necessary. Patients undergoing this procedure are at risk of increased morbidity and readmissions because of their new ostomy status and/or the underlying disease. The current study evaluated risk factors associated with hospital readmissions and the impact of perioperative morbidity among patients undergoing a diverting ileostomy or colostomy without resection.

Methods: Adult patients undergoing laparoscopic or open fecal diversion without resection [colostomy (CPT: 44188 and 44320) or ileostomy (CPT: 44187 and 44310)] where identified from the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program Participant User File (2016-2018). Primary end points were readmission within 30 days and pre- and post-discharge grade 3 complications. 

Results: Among the total cohort of 7864 patients, 26% had an ileostomy, while 74% underwent a colostomy. Of these, 54% were performed laparoscopically. The median age was 61 years (IQR:51-71), and BMI was 25  (IQR:22-30), with 51% of patients being females. The median length of stay was 5 days (IQR:3-9) and the readmissions rates were 20% and 14% for ileostomy and colostomy, respectively.  In multivariable analysis of the whole cohort, younger age, female gender, pre- or post-discharge grade 3 complications, and ileostomy were all independently associated with an increased risk of readmission (Table 1). Conversely, indications (colorectal cancer, diverticular disease, and Inflammatory Bowel Disease), surgical approach, and emergent surgery were not found to be significantly associated with higher readmission rates. Post-discharge grade 3 complications had the largest magnitude of effect for readmissions (OR:13.9, CI:11.14-17.22). Weight loss > 10%, ASA >2, and emergency surgery were independently associated with higher rates of post-discharge grade 3 complications. The risk of these complications was decreased by using laparoscopy.

Conclusion: In this large national cohort of patients, we identified high rates of readmissions among patients undergoing primary fecal diversion without resection. Ileostomy was independently associated with higher readmission rates. Post-discharge grade 3 complication was the strongest risk factor for readmissions, which in turn was associated with emergency surgery and patient comorbidities. These patients represent a high-risk group and should be considered for mitigating strategies.

abstract_title: Ostomy Skills Videos Improve Patient Comfort with New Stomas
author_block: D. J. Lazar<sup>1</sup>, P. Healy<sup>2</sup>, A. Mohamed<sup>2</sup>, R. M. Freeman<sup>3</sup>, C. M. Divino<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai Hospital,Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai,Department Of Clinical Innovation,New York, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai,Institute For Healthcare Delivery Science, Department Of Population Health Science And Policy,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Many patients with first time ileostomies and colostomies are at risk for stoma and ostomy-related problems post-discharge, including but not limited to dehydration, leaks, and skin issues that could lead to readmission or have a deleterious impact on quality of life. We implemented a multimodal ostomy self-care curriculum including in-person visits from enterostomal therapists and the American College of Surgeons Ostomy Home Skills Program educational videos in order to increase patients’ mastery in handling their pouches.

Methods:  Postoperative patients with new stomas at our institution underwent two or more personalized training sessions with enterostomal therapists and viewed the Ostomy Home Skills Program educational videos. Patients were given unlimited access to the videos as needed to achieve appropriate mastery of pouch-related skills prior to discharge. Patients completed the 22-item validated Stoma Self-Efficacy Scale prior to and following completion of the curriculum.

Results: 34 postoperative adult surgical patients with new stomas underwent the ostomy self-care curriculum and completed both the pre- and post-intervention surveys. Patients reported significant improvement across 100% of the 22 items (p<0.001) surveyed, with 88% of patients demonstrating overall improvement and 65% improving by at least 1 point on the 5-point Likert scale.

Conclusion: The implementation of a multimodal education and self-care curriculum for stoma management increases patients’ comfort and skill in managing their pouches and troubleshooting pouch-related complications. Further research is needed to determine if this translates to shorter postoperative length of stay, post-discharge ostomy-related complications and readmissions, or increased overall patient satisfaction.

abstract_title: Does Age Impact Outcomes of Stage IV Colorectal Cancer Patients Undergoing Liver Metastatectomy?
author_block: E. Pefok<sup>1</sup>, E. Thompson<sup>1</sup>, R. Silva<sup>1</sup>, A. Cruz<sup>1</sup>, M. Khurrum<sup>1</sup>, S. Asmar<sup>1</sup>, M. Chehab<sup>1</sup>, V. Nfonsam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,General Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The incidence of colorectal cancer (CRC) increases with age; however, despite younger patients making up only a small minority of CRC cases, studies have demonstrated that young patients are more likely to present with a more aggressive and advanced cancer. While staging at diagnosis and management of CRC are critical to mortality rates, the debate regarding whether young or older patients with metastatic CRC have better surgical outcomes after liver resection is still being deactively contested. The aim of this study was to examine the difference in short term surgical outcomes for early vs late-onset metastatic CRC patients undergoing liver resection.

Methods: A 3-year (2016-2018) analysis of the American College of Surgeons - National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) was performed. We included stage IV CRC patients with liver metastases who underwent liver resection. Patients were stratified into two groups, early-onset (<45 years) and late-onset (>45 years). Our outcomes measured were unplanned reoperations, hospital length of stay (LOS), 30-day complications,  30-day mortality, and 30-day readmissions. Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed.

Results: A total of 903 patients were analyzed of which 12.4% (n=112) had early-onset CRC and 87.6% (n=791) had late-onset CRC and underwent liver resection. Mean age was 58 years, 42.7% were males, 68.1% were whites, mean hospital LOS was 7days and 80.4% had ASA class >=3. There was no difference between the two groups in terms of unplanned reoperation (Early 4.5% vs Late: 4.4%, p=0.98), mortality (0.9% vs 0.9%, p=0.99), unplanned readmission (17% vs. 10.5%, p=0.12),  median hospital LOS (6 [5-8] vs. 6 [4-8], p>0.05), and 30-day complications (including; Surgical site infection, PE, DVT, Pneumonia, bleeding requiring transfusion, MI, and other complications). On regression analysis controlling for multiple confounding variables, no independent association was found between age and study outcomes including unplanned reoperation, 30days complications, mortality, and readmission,

Conclusion: Our study demonstrated that age alone is not independently associated with adverse short term surgical outcomes in stage IV CRC patients undergoing liver resection. The physiologic reserve of younger patients likely compensates for the outcome even though they might have more aggressive disease.

abstract_title: The impact of surgical approach on organ-space surgical site infections after colon resections
author_block: C. Potti<sup>1</sup>, H. Nasser<sup>1</sup>, A. Tang<sup>3</sup>, A. Stefanou<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Henry Ford Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Detroit, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Henry Ford Hospital,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Colon And Rectal Surgery,Detroit, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Henry Ford Hospital,Department Of Public Health,Detroit, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Organ-space surgical site infection (OSI) has been associated with increased length of stay, morbidity, and mortality after colectomy. The aim of this study was to evaluate the association between surgical approach (laparoscopic versus open) and OSI in patients undergoing colon and rectal resections using the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) database.   

Methods: The NSQIP database was queried for patients undergoing colectomies between 2011 and 2017 using Current Procedural Terminology codes. Patients were then divided into two groups based on approach: laparoscopic and open. Comparisons between the two groups were completed using standardized mean difference (SMD). Univariate and multivariate propensity score-weighted logistic regression models were used to evaluate the association between surgical approach and the occurrence of OSI. 

Results: A total of 90,417 cases were included in the analysis: 72,519 (80.2%) laparoscopic and 17,898 (19.8%) open. A total of 2,483 cases (2.7%) of OSI were reported. The laparoscopic approach was associated with lower OSI compared to the open approach (3.4% vs 7.0%; p<0.01). The laparoscopic group tended to be younger (60.8 ± 15.3 vs 62.4 ± 15.5 years; SMD=0.11) with a lower proportion of patients with American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) class ≥3 (49.3% vs 61.8%; SMD=0.25). Males represented 48.2% of the patients with no difference in sex between the two group. Operative time was longer in the open group (190.4 ± 105.1 vs 176.6 ± 84.3 minutes; SMD=0.15). After propensity score matching, the balance of a set of demographics, preoperative risk factors, and wound class revealed a successful match with all covariates having an SMD<0.10 except operative time (SMD=0.23). Multivariable analysis revealed the laparoscopic approach to have a lower association with OSI compared to the open approach (AOR 0.68; 95% CI 0.64-0.71; p<0.01). Moreover, oral antibiotic prep (AOR 0.69; 95% CI 0.64-0.73; p<0.01) and mechanical bowel prep (0.83; 95% CI 0.78-0.88; p<0.01) were associated with lower risk of OSI. On the other hand, several other variables such as higher wound class, preoperative albumin <3.5, prolonged operative time, ASA class ≥3, smoking, steroid use, dialysis were associated with increased risk of OSI. Compared to malignant indication for the colectomy, benign indication was not associated with increased risk of OSI.   

Conclusion: Compared to the open approach, laparoscopic colon resections are associated with a lower risk of OSI. This emphasizes the role of the laparoscopic approach when technically feasible in order to prevent this morbid postoperative complication.

abstract_title: Association of Lymphopenia with Length of Stay and Discharge Disposition in Chest Wall Trauma
author_block: K. E. Koch<sup>1</sup>, A. E. Troester<sup>2</sup>, P. E. Chevuru<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Lilienthal<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Galet<sup>1</sup>, P. McGonagill<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Minnesota,Minneapolis, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  While lymphopenia is thought to contribute to the immune suppression observed in critical illness, its role in the immunologic response to trauma has not been fully described. We assessed whether admission lymphopenia predicted outcomes in patients with blunt chest wall trauma (BCWT).

Methods:  This is a retrospective study of all trauma patients with a Chest Abbreviated Injury Scale (CAIS) ≥ 2 admitted to Trauma Surgery at our Level I Trauma center from July 2008 to June 2015. Patients with absolute lymphocyte counts (ALC) collected within 24h of admission were included. Exclusion criteria were death within 24 h, bowel perforation on admission, penetrating trauma, and burns. Demographics, injury characteristics, comorbidities, complications, and outcomes were collected. Lymphopenia was defined as ALC ≤ 1000. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to identify predictors of outcomes in BCWT patients with p<0.05 considered significant.

Results: Of the 3849 trauma patients with CAIS ³2, 1394 patients were included. Our cohort was 69.7% male, with a mean age of 51.4 years (18-100); 44.3% were lymphopenic. On univariate analysis, significant differences were noted on mortality, LOS, and discharge location (p < 0.001 for all); no difference was noted in infection between lymphopenic and non-lymphopenic patients (p = 0.185). In logistic regression, controlling for CAIS, age, and comorbidities, lymphopenia was associated with prolonged LOS (OR=1.187 [1.059–1.33] p = 0.003) and with discharge to home with healthcare (OR=1.886 [1.135–3.133], p = 0.014) or to another facility (SNF/rehabilitation facility/ACH) (OR=1.605 [1.242–2.074], p < 0.001).

Conclusion: Lymphopenia on admission is associated with longer LOS and discharge requiring increased healthcare support, suggesting longer recovery for lymphopenic BCWT patients. Routine lymphocyte count monitoring on admission in BCWT patients may provide important prognostic information.

abstract_title: Routine Deep Vein Thrombosis Screening in Asymptomatic Trauma Patients
author_block: D. Harris<sup>1</sup>, D. Corbin<sup>1</sup>, J. Gibson<sup>1</sup>, C. Hardman<sup>2</sup>, A. P. Ekeh<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Wright State University,Boonshoft School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery,Dayton, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Wright State Physicians,Surgery,Dayton, OHIO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Injured patients are known to have a high incidence of Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT) despite prophylactic measures. Increased rates of DVT is correlated with high rates of pulmonary embolism (PE) which is recognized to be a leading cause of death in trauma patients who survive beyond 24 hours. Routine screening for DVT in asymptomatic trauma patients is practice aimed at identifying thromboembolic events and initiating early treatment. We evaluated our trauma DVT screening protocol involving routine Duplex ultrasound at one week for patients still hospitalized at post trauma day 7 and weekly thereafter. 

Methods: All adult patients admitted to a Level I trauma center who had a least one positive Duplex Ultrasound DVT screen over a 70-month period (Jan 2013 to October 2018) were identified from the trauma registry.  Patients who received DVT screens earlier than one week or those that had superficial DVTs (eg peroneal or soleal clots) were excluded.  Patients who developed PEs from this group were identified. The status of chemoprophylaxis (enoxaparin or heparin) was also noted. 

Results: In the period studied, of over 20,000 trauma registry entries, there were120 patients noted to have positive Duplex ultrasound screens. After exclusions, 61 patients were included in the final analysis. (Males 77.0%) The mean age was 58.0 years (21.3).  Three patients (7.3%) with a DVT proceeded to develop a PE. Forty patients (65.6%) had chemoprophylaxis ordered prior to DVT diagnosis. Of those 40 patients, 3 developed a PE. The average number of ventilator days for the cohort was 6.8 and the average number of operations per patient was 2.2. Only 7/61 (11.5%) patients had a history of prior clotting disorder.  

Conclusion: Over a 70- month period, routine DVT screening at 1 week found thromboembolic events that required intervention that may otherwise not have been discovered. Some of these progressed to PE. Further evaluation of the practice of routine screening in asymptomatic trauma patient is needed.

abstract_title: Characteristics of Self-inflicted Injury among Suicidal Patients: Analysis of Nation-wide Trauma Registry
author_block: T. Nishimura<sup>1,2</sup>, H. Naito<sup>2</sup>, A. Nakao<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hyogo Emergency Medical Center,Department Of Emergency And Critical Care Medicine,Kobe, HYOGO, Japan <sup>2</sup>Okayama University Graduate School of Medicine, Dentistry and Pharmaceutical Sciences,Department Of Emergency And Critical Care Medicine,Okayama, OKAYAMA, Japan
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Self-inflicted injury is one of the most common causes of suicide. Extremity injury is thought to occur most frequently among penetrating injury, however, epidemiology among patients attempting suicide is unknown. This study aims to find the characteristics of penetrating self-inflicted trauma patients.

Methods:  This is a retrospective cohort study of Japanese nation-wide trauma registry (the Japan National Trauma Data Bank) between January 1, 2004 to December 31, 2017. Patients who attempted suicide with penetrating injury were eligible. We evaluated the occurrence of injury based on injury site (neck/face, chest, abdomen, extremity) as a dependent variable and aging as an independent variable using a generalized linear model and compare those groups with spline models.

Results: 4,576 trauma patients were eligible. Excluding patients with missing age, missing survival data, and missing abbreviate injury score, 4,183 patients were enrolled in this study. Common injury site is follows; abdomen 1772 cases (42.4%), extremity 1344 cases (32.0%), neck/face 1253 cases (30.0%), and chest 993 cases (23.7%).  The occurrence of neck/face injury, chest injury, and abdominal injury increased with age. On contrary, the rate of extremity injury decreased with age.

Conclusion: Among self-inflicted trauma patients, abdominal injury was most common injury, and neck/face injury, chest injury, and abdominal injury were related with aging. On the other hand, the rate of extremity injury decreased as patients’ age progressed.

abstract_title: Revisiting Pediatric Female Genital Trauma: Modified Onen's Classification & Management Algorithim
author_block: Z. Glaser<sup>1</sup>, N. Singh<sup>2</sup>, C. Koch<sup>2</sup>, P. Dangle<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Urology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,School Of Medicine,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pediatric female genital trauma(PFGT) is rare but potentially devastating and requires intervention to avoid long-term sequelae. Traditionally, evaluation and treatment under general anesthesia(GA) in the operating room(OR) is recommended. Alternatively, examination and repair under sedation in the emergency department(ED) may yield equivocal outcomes. Onen’s genitourinary injury score(GIS) objectively describes PFGT severity but may not correlate with the level of care warranted. The purpose of this study was to evaluate outcomes of PFGTs managed in the ED vs. OR, propose a modified Onen’s GIS scale, and introduce a treatment algorithm.

Methods: All patients treated at our institution from May 2009 to the present with associated ICD codes for PFGT were evaluated. Demographic, treatment and follow-up information was extracted from the electronic record. A cost analysis was performed.

Results: A total of 37 patients was identified; the median age of 6.4 years, 19(51%) presented within 6 hours of injury, and straddle injury(27,72%) was the most common mechanism. Injuries were predominately Onen’s GIS I-III(33,89%) with possible urethral involvement in 6(16%) patients. Sedation and repair in the ED were performed for 13(35%) patients vs. 24(65%) in the OR. The two cohorts did not significantly differ in Onen GIS severity (p>0.05), and no major complications were observed. The majority of the OR cohort 18(75%) did not initially undergo sedation and attempted repair in the ED. Concern for vaginal mucosa or urethral involvement was the most common reason to forgo sedation, but ultimately none of these patients were found to have a urethral injury, and 11(61%) could have been safely managed in ED under sedation using Onen GIS = Grade 3 without urethral involvement as a cutoff. A female-specific modification to Onen’s GIS Grade III to differentiate isolated distal vaginal mucosa(III-a) and deep vaginal mucosa and/or urethral involvement(III-b) is proposed, and a treatment algorithm was generated. The cost of services increased more than five-fold when taken to the OR. Repair in the OR was also associated with a greater than 35% increase in the cost of supplies and ancillary services. These differences did not account for the additional costs of anesthesiology and postoperative hospitalization.

Conclusion: Detailed evaluation and potential surgical repair under sedation in the ED as an initial step for all patients may conserve resources without compromising outcomes. Low-to-moderate severity PFGTs may be safely managed without GA in the OR with a significant cost-benefit.

abstract_title: Hear Hoofbeats? Think Head and Neck Trauma: A NTDB Review of Equestrian Related Trauma in the U.S.
author_block: K. Mutore<sup>1</sup>, J. Lim<sup>1</sup>, D. Fofana<sup>1</sup>, A. Torres-Reveron<sup>3</sup>, J. Skubic<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Texas Rio Grande Valley School of Medicine,Edinburg, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Texas Rio Grande Valley School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Edinburg, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Doctor's Hospital at Renaissance,Department Of General Surgery,Edinburg, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Equestrian related injuries account for 45% of sports related traumatic brain injuries in the United States. Equestrian related trauma causes more injuries than motorcycle or auto racing. Stratification of the injuries sustained in horseback riding accidents has only been described in papers detailing EMR review of single Level I trauma centers or a few regional hospitals. The aim of this study was to stratify the different types and severity of equestrian injuries on a national level.

Methods: A 10-year review (2007-2016) of the National Trauma Data Bank (NTDB) was conducted to identify injuries due to horseback riding. Injuries were separated into head and neck injuries (HNI), extremity injuries (EXTI), thoracic injuries (THORI) and abdominal injuries (ABDI). Variables or factors examined included:  ethnicity, intensive care unit (ICU) length of stay (LOS), hospital LOS, ED disposition and ventilator days. Logistic regression, chi-squared and Kruskal-Wallis tests were used to analyze the data.

Results: Nationally, 24,791 adults were injured in equestrian related trauma. In descending order, THORI accounted for 9,189 (37.07%) injuries, 6,560 (26.47%) suffered EXTI, 5,689 (22.95%) sustained HNI, and 3,353 (13.52%) experienced ABDI. HNI caused 237 (74.83%) deaths while 59 (18.03%) were caused by THORI. Riders were more likely to die from HNI compared to EXTI (OR, 55.93; 24.08-129.89 95% CI; p<0.001), or from THORI (OR, 7.18; 3.00-17.18 95% CI; p<0.001). HNI had the highest ICU LOS (mean,4.66;SD,6.18).

Conclusion: Annually, over 2,000 equestrian related injuries resulted in presentation to a trauma center in the United States.  While THORI were most commonly identified, HNI resulted in the highest mortality and ICU LOS. These results support the focus on prevention of HNI in equestrian sports.

abstract_title: NEISS Sports Related Humerus Fractures in the United States: Thrower's Fractures
author_block: A. Yu<sup>2</sup>, C. F. Janney<sup>1,3</sup>, D. C. Jupiter<sup>1,4</sup>, V. K. Panchbhavi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Texas Medical Branch,Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery And Rehabilitation,Galveston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Texas Medical Branch,School Of Medicine,Galveston, TEXAS, USA <sup>3</sup>Navy Medical Center San Diego,United States Navy,San Diego, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Texas Medical Branch,Preventive Medicine And Population Health,Galveston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Humerus fractures are a common fracture in the United States (US).
