The purpose of this study was (1) to compare estimated overall and age stratified incidence rates of proximal and distal arm fractures presenting to US emergency departments (EDs) using the National Electronic Injury Surveillance System (NEISS) between 2005-2009 and 2015-2019; (2) to compare humerus fracture locations stratified by age or sports-related trauma reported in the NEISS between these two periods.

Methods: The NEISS was used to obtain US estimates of proximal and distal arm fractures for the years 2005-2009 and 2015-2019. ED visits were identified using injury code (57: Fracture) and body codes (80: Upper Arm, 33: Lower Arm). Fracture rates were normalized using US Census Estimates and stratified by age for their respective periods. Case summaries were filtered for humerus fractures and further filtered for anatomic and non-specific (proximal, middle, distal third) fractures. Reported anatomic fractures were stratified by sports trauma and divided into non-impact and impact related trauma. Relative humerus fractures, inclusive of anatomic and non-specific locations, were stratified by age and compared between the two periods. Chi-squared test was used to compare fracture rates between the two periods. Statistical significance was set at P<0.05.

Results: During the two periods studied, participating NEISS EDs coded 47,066 proximal and distal arm fracture cases from 2005-2009 (1,450,335 injuries nationally; 95% CI 1,180,435 - 1,720,234), and 48,565 arm fractures from 2015-2019 (1,499,014 injuries nationally; 95% CI 1,147,809 – 1,850,219). There was a significant decrease (p<.0001) in proximal and distal arm fracture rates from 2005-2009 to 2015-2019; further, there was a significant difference in fracture rates between the two periods with respect to age group distributions (P < .0001). Proximal and middle third humerus fractures were bimodal in nature, with peak cases occurring between 10-14 years and 55 years and older (proximal third) or 60 years and older (middle third) for both periods. Distal third humerus fractures were right skewed, with peak cases for both periods occurring at 5-9 years. Bicycling, football, and gymnastics accounted for the top three sports related fractures, respectively, for both periods. Impact related sports trauma accounted for most fractures during both periods. Interestingly, non-impact related sports trauma consisted entirely of thrower’s fractures resulting in primarily midshaft fractures.

Conclusion: Proximal and distal arm fracture rates decreased and distributions differed by age between the two periods in the US. Proximal, middle, and distal third humerus fracture distributions differ by age but were similar between both periods. One major non-impact sports related trauma was high external rotational torque from pitching, suggesting possible precautions that may protect against thrower's fractures.

abstract_title: Altmetric Attention Scores, Relative Citation Rates, and Public Policy Inclusion for the Medical Literature
author_block: C. H. Mullins<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Ladowski<sup>1</sup>, C. Boyd<sup>1</sup>, D. Chu<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,General Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the advent of social media and the associated increase in connectivity between scientists and the lay public, the Altmetric Attention Score has been created as a way to measure these interactions between scholarly publications and media dissemination. Little is known, however, whether these types of media exchanges measured by Altmetrics may serve as a proxy for public engagement. As such, we have sought to determine whether or not an association exists between Altmetric scores and public engagement, as measured by article citation in a public policy document. 

Methods: The top 100 highest scoring articles in the medical and health sciences with respect to Altmetric Attention scores were selected from the years 2014 to 2016. Each article was then matched to an article from the same year and journal with the highest relative-citation-rate (RCR) for comparison. Bivariate analysis compared article groups with respect citation in a public policy document, open-access status, and funding status, as well as Altmetric and RCR scores. A multivariate model was then constructed in an attempt to correlate significant factors with public policy citation. Finally, a contour plot was generated in order to estimate the interaction between Altmetric Scores and RCR and their comparative effects on the probability of inclusion in a public policy document. 

Results:Of the 600 articles included in the analysis, 286 (48%) had been cited by a public policy article. The only difference that existed between cohorts was for funding status, with 55 articles (40%) in the RCR cohort having received funding compared to 81 (60%) in the Altmetric cohort (p=0.011). On bivariate analysis, both Altmetric score (p=0.0018) and RCR (p<0.0001) were independently predictive of policy citation. In a multivariate model, the interaction between Altmetric scores and RCR with respect to policy inclusion was significant (OR=1.22; 95% CI=1.08 to1.38) and a contour plot demonstrates that either high Altmetric score or RCR alone is sufficient to generate a high probability of policy inclusion.

Conclusion:Scholarly article citation by public policy documentation may serve as a novel means to explore public engagement in scientific research. In addition, journals that aim to impact public policy through article dissemination may benefit from engagement in social media avenues in addition to traditional citation pathways in order to encourage broader inclusion.

abstract_title: Sexual Dysfunction Following Urethroplasty; A Cross-Sectional Review.
author_block: N. Oyelowo<sup>1</sup>, A. Sudi<sup>1</sup>, A. T. Lawal<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Olorukooba<sup>2</sup>, M. Ahmed<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ahmadu Bello University,Surgery,Zaria, KADUNA, Nigeria <sup>2</sup>Ahmadu Bello University,Community Medicine,Zaria, ., Nigeria
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sexual dysfunction following reconstructive surgeries involving the urethra is a symptom that has a significant effect on a patient’s health-related quality of life and satisfaction despite a patent urethral lumen. The urethral stricture or its repair could affect the sexual drive, ejaculatory function, and erectile function of the patient. The mere obstruction of the urethral lumen could also lead to retarded ejaculation or anejaculation, especially in complete strictures. This may also contribute independently to a decreased sexual drive or weak erection. Similarly, dissection during urethroplasties may further affect erectile function post urethroplasties. The correlation between sexual function and urethroplasties in our patients is important as well as the possible determinants of the dysfunction in our post-operative patients. This may help in the choice of approach to the repair of the stricture and preoperative counseling of patients to achieve good patient satisfaction and relief of bladder outlet obstruction.

Methods: This was a cross-sectional study involving patients with urethral strictures scheduled for urethroplasties who willingly consented to study and were sexually active at presentation and postoperatively. Patients with posterior urethral stenosis or distraction defects, hypospadias, and comorbidities such as diabetes mellitus, chronic prostatitis that could affect erectile function were excluded.  The clinical data was documented on a study proforma as well as the type of urethroplasty performed.  These patients were interviewed and had the Brief Male Sexual Function Inventory administered preoperatively and 3 months postoperatively. Scores were calculated for each of the domains. Statistical analysis was done using descriptive, inferential, and multinomial logistic regression studies.

Results: A total of 45 men enrolled in the study. The mean age was 47±12 years. Most of the patients 29(64%) had post-inflammatory strictures while 16(36%) had post-traumatic strictures. Preoperatively, 2(4.4%),3(6.6%), 20(44.4%), and 31(68.7%) patients had poor sexual drive, erectile function, ejaculatory function, and overall sexual function respectively. While only a patient (2.2%) had a poor erectile function, 2(4.4%) patients had ejaculatory dysfunction and 2(4.4%) had poor overall satisfaction postoperatively. There was however an overall statistically significant increase in the mean postoperative scores as compared to the mean pre-operative scores in all the sexual domains. On Multinomial logistic regression analysis, only age( ≤50yrs) was a statistically significant variable in the sexual domain of sexual drive with a p-value of 0.028. The site and choice of treatment were however not statistically significant.

Conclusion: Sexual functions improve in the majority of patients after urethroplasties however, men <  50years should be counseled for sexual dysfunction before urethroplasty.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 on the Presentation, Management, and Outcomes of Acute Appendicitis
author_block: C. J. Puntasecca<sup>1</sup>, G. I. Gomez<sup>1</sup>, V. Toro Arana<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Titan<sup>1</sup>, M. Hawn<sup>1</sup>, J. Korndorffer<sup>1</sup>, J. Forrester<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Esquivel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,School Of Medicine,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted patients' access and utilization of non-COVID-19 related care, but specific impacts on acute surgical conditions are still unknown. We assessed effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on the presentation, treatment, and outcomes of patients with acute appendicitis.

Methods:  We performed a single institution retrospective chart review to identify and collect data for patients presenting to the emergency department (ED) with acute appendicitis between March and June in 2019 and 2020. We extracted data involving patient demographics, symptoms, severity, perforation status, treatments received, and post-operative courses. Relationships between variables were assessed by calculating r correlation coefficients and performing student T-tests and Chi-squared tests as appropriate.

Results: We identified 362 patients presenting to the ED with acute appendicitis, 183 (50.6%) and 179 (49.4%) patients in the 2019 and 2020 time periods, respectively. More patients were diagnosed on imaging with a perforated appendix at presentation in 2020 compared to 2019 (20.1% vs. 11.5%, p=0.01). Longer duration of pre-diagnosis symptoms was associated with an increased likelihood of a patient having a ruptured appendix (p=0.007) and of a patient being prescribed a postoperative regimen of antibiotics (p=0.03). Ruptured appendix diagnosis was associated with a higher Alvarado score (<0.001), need for surgical intervention (p=0.002), higher postoperative complications (p<0.001), and higher readmission within 30 days (p<0.001). Readmission rates to the ED following initial discharge increased from 4.37% in 2019 to 12.8% in 2020 (p=0.006).

Conclusion: Rates of persons presenting with appendicitis remain unchanged despite COVID-19. Severity rates of the disease, however, have increased during the pandemic, which may be due to delayed presentation.

abstract_title: Need for surgical therapy for SBO in a 'virgin' abdomen: time to challenge an old adage!
author_block: V. Hoang<sup>1</sup>, A. K. Malhotra<sup>1</sup>, G. C. An<sup>1</sup>, C. Colovos<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Vermont College Of Medicine / Fletcher Allen Health Care,Division Of Trauma & Acute Care Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Burlington, VT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Surgical teaching dictates that small bowel obstruction (SBO) in a patient with no prior abdominal surgery – ‘virgin’ abdomen (VA) – mandates prompt laparotomy. This is encapsulated in the adage ‘let the Sun not set (or rise) on an SBO’. The rationale is twofold: 1) etiology of the obstruction likely requires surgical therapy; and 2) the possibility of strangulation. However, SBO, even in VA, is often caused by conditions not requiring immediate surgery from adhesions, inflammatory bowel disease, etc. With high definition computed tomography (CT), it may be possible to determine the etiology of obstruction and the evidence of strangulation, and thus allow for a more selective approach to surgical exploration. The current study evaluates the accuracy of CT in determining the need for surgery for SBO in VA.

Methods:  Retrospective review of all SBO in VA managed by the Acute Care Surgery service at an academic medical center over a 3-year period (2017-19). Patients with SBO in VA were identified from the Emergency General Surgery registry. Patients with SBO caused by an external hernia or without a pre-operative CT were excluded. CT reports of included patients were examined to determine 1) surgical vs non-surgical etiology, and 2) presence/absence of strangulation. CT findings were correlated with operative findings in patients that underwent surgery, and with clinical course [mean follow-up 15 months (range 10-20)] for those that did not. True/false positives (TP/FP) and negatives (TN/FN) were determined and sensitivity, specificity and positive/negative predictive values of CT were calculated for etiology (surgical vs. non-surgical) and strangulation (present/absent).

Results: 26 patients were included. Based on the CT results, the etiology of SBO was: non-surgical 9 (TN 8; FN 1); colonic diverticulitis 3 (TN for surgical SBO); surgical 10 (TP 9; FP 1); and indeterminate 4 (surgical 1; non-surgical 3). CT evidence of strangulation was present in 1 (TP) and absent in 25 (TN 23; FN 2). 9 patients were successfully managed non-operatively, none requiring subsequent surgery, and 17 underwent surgery during the index admission. Accuracy of CT in predicting surgical vs non-surgical etiology and presence/absence of strangulation are presented in Table.

Conclusion: CT is highly accurate in determining surgical etiology of SBO in VA though lacks sensitivity for strangulation. Thus, in patients with no clinical evidence of strangulation a more selective approach to surgical management avoiding potential mortality and morbidity of non-therapeutic laparotomy is justified. It may be time to re-examine the surgical adage and ‘let’ the sun rise on an SBO in VA.

abstract_title: How Our Healthcare System Reacts to Natural Disasters?
author_block: Y. Chen<sup>1</sup>, G. Molina<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Kelleher<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Chang<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Cauley<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The impact of natural disasters and pandemic crisis, and their aftermath, on elective surgical volumes remains unknown. The goal of this study was to examine the impact of natural disasters, specifically Hurricane Sandy- a Category I hurricane that hit New York at the end of October 2012, on elective surgical volume.

Methods:  Observational study of the New York Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System database from 2011-2013 was performed. Three high-volume, elective surgeries were examined in New York City and Long Island hospitals: inguinal hernia repairs, bariatric surgery, and total knee replacement surgery. Weekly volumes in 2012, as percentages of total yearly volumes to accommodate differences in volumes between years, were compared to same weeks in 2011 and 2013.

Results: A total of 9,364 inguinal hernia repairs, 16,695 bariatric surgery, and 42,250 total knee replacement surgery were examined. There was a 61.7%, 71.8%, and 57.6% relative decrease, respectively, during week 44. The volumes of following weeks were not significantly different than trends observed in 2011 and 2013 (Figure).

Conclusion: Significant decreases in elective surgical volumes were observed during Hurricane Sandy; however, there was no above-average increases in surgical volumes in its aftermath. Our healthcare systems may be operating at near capacity, with little room to accommodate unexpected volumes. The short-term needs and long-term outcomes of patients affected during natural disasters should be examined. Our findings have important implications for modeling recovery after natural disasters when elective surgical cases might need to be delayed.

abstract_title: Operating Room Efficiency and the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: M. P. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, C. McLeod<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, D. K. Eads<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Russell<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Loats<sup>1</sup>, B. Carlisle<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Morris<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,General Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In March 2020, COVID-19 appeared in the United States requiring massive shifts in operating room (OR) management. Between March 18th and April 30th all elective surgeries were canceled at our institution. In May, we resumed any CMS Tier 2a and 2b and outpatient Tier 1 cases. From mid-March until present, all surgeon block times were suspended and cases scheduled on first come, first served basis. Traditionally, surgeon block time has been a cornerstone of OR scheduling, but this current pandemic presents the opportunity to re-evaluate. Is block time the most efficient way forward?

Methods: We collected all OR data from fiscal year 2019 until June 2020. Cases were stratified into two groups by dates performed: pre-COVID (May and June of 2019) with block time versus post-COVID (May and June of 2020) with no block time. Data was stratified by hospital location: main campus or satellite. Surgeries performed at our satellite center include outpatient and lower acuity inpatient surgeries. Operating room prime time is defined as 7 AM until 5 PM at the main hospital and 7 AM until 3 PM at the satellite center. Primary outcomes include average cases per day, case mix index (CMI), percentage of cases extending outside of prime time, and total overtime hours per month. Statistics included ANOVA for continuous variables to compare means and Chi-Square for categorical variables. All tests were conducted with an alpha level of 0.05.

Results: The mean cases per day in May and June of 2019 versus 2020 were not statistically significant at the satellite center (29.56 vs 31.75, p-value = 0.536) or at the main campus (78.46 vs 68.04, p-value = 0.167). Comparison of CMI in 2019 versus 2020 showed a significant increase at the satellite center (2.43 vs 2.62, p-value = 0.048) and a significant decrease at the main campus (4.97 vs 4.19, p-value = <0.001). When examining the proportion of cases extending beyond prime time, there was no significant difference at the satellite center (23.9% vs 21.1%, p-value = 0.104). However, at the main campus there was a statistically significant decrease in the percentage of cases extending beyond primetime in 2019 versus 2020 (19.6% vs 15.7%, p-value = 0.001). At the satellite center, total overtime hours per month in Oct 2019 – Feb 2020 was 300.6 hours per month vs 81.8 hours per month in May – June of 2020.   At the main campus, total overtime hours per month in Oct 2019 – Feb 2020 was 2,475 hours vs 832 hours per month in May – June of 2020.  

Conclusion: Our data indicates we are currently performing the same case volume more efficiently without the use of block scheduling as we reopen following the COVID-19 shut down.  Additionally, lower average overtime hours per month are seen in May and June of 2020 when compared to the six months leading up to the pandemic.  Future studies are necessary to understand the most efficient way to provide surgical care during and following the COVID-19 pandemic.

abstract_title: What is the accuracy of the ACS-NSQIP Surgical Risk Calculator in Emergency Surgery? A Meta-Analysis
author_block: C. J. Parkin<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Moritz<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Glover<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Royal North Shore Hospital,Department Of Surgery & Surgical Education Research And Training (SERT) Institute,Sydney, NSW, Australia <sup>2</sup>University Of Sydney,Northern Clinical School, Faculty Of Medicine And Health,Sydney, NSW, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: The American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) surgical risk calculator provides an estimation of 30-day post-operative complications including mortality. This tool has the potential to both aid in decision-making for patients and their families, but also aid in optimising management of high-risk patients. Whilst validated within the American surgical population, its utility internationally in patients requiring emergency surgery is not yet known. This study undertook a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess the calculator’s accuracy in predicting mortality in emergency surgery patients. According to the literature, this is one of first studies to perform a meta-analysis assessing the performance of the ACS-NSQIP calculator in an external patient cohort outside of the ACS-NSQIP database.

Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted between October 2019 to April 2020. The PubMed, Medline and Cochrane Databases were searched for relevant studies. The search strategy included studies from January 2013 to April 2020. There were no language restrictions placed. Reference lists of retrieved articles from these databases were used to identify further studies eligible for inclusion. Two independent reviewers screened a total of 402 records. 66 full-text articles were assessed for eligibility. Six studies were included in our final meta-analysis. A random effects model was used and fitted using restricted maximum likelihood estimation (REML). The O/E ratio was used to validate the calculator’s accuracy in predicting mortality. Heterogeneity was analysed using the I2 and Cochrane Q tests.

Results: Six studies were included in the meta-analysis, with a total of 1835 patients undergoing emergency surgery.  The summary estimate of the O:E ratio of the ACS-NSQIP surgical risk calculator in predicting 30-day post-operative mortality was 1.06 (95% CI 0.74-1.51). As expected there was significant heterogeneity between studies with a Cochrane Q of 11.96 (p = 0.04) and I2 = 57.5%. The forest plot analysis outlines the findings of the meta-analysis.

Conclusion: This meta-analysis has showed that that the calculator does have potential to be utilised in the multi-disciplinary care of patients undergoing emergency surgery. As the ACS-NSQIP surgical risk calculator is still reasonably new, there remains limited studies published in the literature attempting to externally validate its performance, accounting for this study's heterogeneity. As further studies publish their local results, further studies will be able to further delineate its true accuracy in international surgical cohorts

abstract_title: Effect of Timing to ERCP on Post-Op Complications in Choledocholithiasis in Safety Net Health System
author_block: C. Mooney<sup>1</sup>, A. Tang<sup>1</sup>, C. Cohan<sup>1</sup>, G. Beattie<sup>1</sup>, G. Victorino<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco - East Bay,General Surgery,Oakland, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While current management of choledocholithiasis has evolved to include endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), advanced endoscopy remains technically challenging and limited in availability. Our safety net health system requires transfer to a separate facility for advanced endoscopic procedures prior to definitive surgical management. While timing to cholecystectomy post ERCP has been extensively studied, the effect of timing to ERCP from day of admission on post-cholecystectomy outcomes remains unknown. Our aim was to evaluate if an increase in timing to ERCP leads to higher post cholecystectomy complication rates.

Methods:  A retrospective review of patients who received pre-operative ERCP for choledocholithiasis prior to cholecystectomy (laparoscopic or open) between 2016-2019 was conducted. Patient demographics, initial laboratory values, duration of symptoms, preoperative diagnoses, timing to ERCP from day of admission, timing between ERCP and cholecystectomy, and post-operative complications were recorded. Outcomes were analyzed using regression analysis.

Results: There were 87 patients who were identified. All patients had a preoperative diagnosis of choledocholithiasis and 28% (n=24) with at least one additional diagnosis. The mean days from day of admission to preoperative ERCP was 2.40 days (SD ± 1.47), and from ERCP to cholecystectomy was 1.86 days (SD ± 1.50). On univariable analysis, we identified male sex (OR 2.95, CI 0.88-9.96, p=0.08), WBC (OR 1.10, CI 0.98-1.25, p=0.12) and timing between ERCP and cholecystectomy (OR 1.31, CI 0.95-1.80, p=0.10) as potential confounders. After inclusion into multivariable analysis, timing to ERCP was not associated with the likelihood of complications (p=0.60).

Conclusion: An increase in timing from day of admission to ERCP was not associated with an increase in complications after cholecystectomy. As advanced endoscopic techniques continue to become more readily available, our findings suggest health systems can still utilize such services through other avenues such as inter-facility transfers without impacting health outcomes.

abstract_title: PRELIMINARY VALUE FOR MINIMALLY INVASIVE VS OPEN INGUINAL HERNIA REPAIR AT A TERTIARY MEDICAL CENTER
author_block: M. Abdelmasseh<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Iqbal<sup>1,2</sup>, V. Kadiyala<sup>3</sup>, J. Willis<sup>3</sup>, D. Melton<sup>1</sup>, K. Parks<sup>1</sup>, J. Sanabria<sup>1,2,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Huntington, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>Marshall Institute for Interdisciplinary Research (MIIR),Huntington, WV, USA <sup>3</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine,Department Of Informatics And Biostatistics,Huntington, WV, USA <sup>4</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine,Department Of Nutrition And Metabolomics/Proteomics Core Facility,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Hernia repair is one of the most common surgical procedures performed in the US with more than 1 million procedures each year and nearly 80% of them are to repair inguinal hernias. Healthcare policies are emphasizing on assessing the value of medical services to determine schemes connecting reimbursement to performance. we aim to assess the value and cost of inguinal hernia repair procedures and to determine their affecting variables in our institution at our institution.  

Methods:  Patients (>18yo) who underwent inguinal hernia repair were identified and their records were reviewed retrospectively (Jan-2010 to July-2016, n=609) and prospectively (Aug-2016 to Dec-2019, n=653) under IRB approved protocol. Value was defined as Quality/Cost and the quality of the procedure was assessed by analyzing post-operative complications using a standardized grading system where a score was given to complications grades starting with uncomplicated procedures=1, Grade 1=0.95, Grade 2=0.75, Grade 3=0.60, Grade 4=0.50, and Grade 5 (Death)=0.  Cost was defined as total hospital charges accrued for admission and re-admission up to 30days post-discharge which were then corrected for inflation at a 5% APR. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed using MATLAB software.

Results: A total of 1242 patients underwent open (58%) vs minimally invasive (laparoscopic 12%, or Robotic assisted 30%) inguinal hernia repairs, 81% of them were males. The mean age of all the patients was 54±16, mean BMI was 28±6, and 0.5% readmission rate. The unit value cost of uncomplicated outpatient laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair with no readmission was $25,165 (value unit=1). The mean cost of all procedures was $32,856; $27,424 (open) vs $39,797 (minimally invasive). Figure 1 shows the annual average of costs of open vs minimally invasive inguinal hernia repairs. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed for complications, cost, and value. Identifying the variables that affect the cost and value of the procedure was validated.

Conclusion: At our tertiary medical center, open inguinal hernia repair procedures appear to have lower overall cost and higher value than minimally invasive procedures.

abstract_title: Reversal Transfusions for Pre-Injury Anticoagulation in Traumatic Brain Injury Trauma Transfers.
author_block: N. Menzione<sup>1</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>1,2</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1,3</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1,2,3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As the number of patients on variety of anticoagulation agents increases, the question of efficacy and use of reversal therapy remains. It is of special importance in the cases of patients on pre-injury anticoagulation with traumatic brain injury (TBI) for whom the risk of intracranial bleeding is increased, and often further aggressive steps must be taken to reverse the effects of the anticoagulant. The goal was to analyze the role of reversal transfusions in TBI patients with pre-injury anticoagulation, antiplatelet or dual therapy transferred from an Acute Care Facility (ACF) to a level 1 Trauma Center (TC).

Methods: This retrospective study analyzed 484 TBI patients transferred to TC from ACF (2016–2019) who received anticoagulation, antiplatelet or dual therapy (ACAP). Patients were divided into two groups of: 211 patients who received reversal transfusions (ACAP-R) and 273 who did not receive reversal transfusions (ACAP-NR). Following variables were analyzed: age, Glasgow Coma Score (GCS), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Abbreviated Injury Score head (AISh), transfer timing, rate of repeat CT imaging, rate of craniotomy,  Intensive Care Unit (ICU) admissions, Hospital length of stay (HLOS) and mortality.

Results: TBI patients on pre-injury anticoagulation in both groups had similar age (ACAP-R: 81.9 vs ACAP-NR: 82.6), and GCS (13.9 vs 14.1), both p>0.4. ACAP-R patients were found to have higher ISS (16.5 vs 13.3) and head AIS scores with statistically significantly higher repeat CT scans (98.1% vs 90.8%), craniotomy rates (17.5% vs 3.3%), and increased ICU admissions (85.3% vs 53.0%), all p<0.002. Timing from ACF trauma consultation to TC arrival was significantly shorter in ACAP-R patients (1.6 vs 1.8 hours, p=0.002) resulting in shorter overall transfer time compared to ACAP-NR (3.4 vs 3.8 hours, p=0.03). The AISh analysis revealed a significantly higher incidence of AISh 5 in the ACAP-R group compared to the ACAP-NR patients [Fig. 1], which corresponded with higher craniotomy rates (17.5% vs3.3%, p<0.001), and prolonged HLOS (4.6 vs 3.2 days, p<0.001). Mortality was not statistically different between ACAP-R and ACAP-NR groups (16.1% vs 12.1%, p=0.2). In addition, multivariable analysis revealed that advanced age (≥65 years old), GCS and AIS head were significant predictors of mortality in the ACAP population.

Conclusion: Transferred traumatic brain injury patients on pre-injury anticoagulation who received reversal transfusions were more severely injured, had more surgical interventions, yet had comparable mortality to as TBI patients on anticoagulation without reversal transfusions, which may be attributed to the timely administration of anti-coagulation/anti-platelet reversal therapy.

abstract_title: The Association of Reoperation and Readmission in Selected ACS NSQIP General Surgery Operations
author_block: J. P. Davis<sup>1</sup>, F. E. Turrentine<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Smolkin<sup>2</sup>, T. L. McMurry<sup>2</sup>, R. S. Jones<sup>1</sup>, V. M. Zaydfudim<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia,Department Of Surgery,Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Virginia,Department Of Public Health Sciences,Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Unplanned reoperations and readmissions have been associated with increased morbidity and mortality. Few studies however, have explored the association of reoperation and readmission among general surgery patients. Our aim was to explore this relationship in select major abdominal operations. 

Methods:  American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS NSQIP) Participant Use Data Files from 2014-2018 were utilized. We assessed six groups of procedures, defined by ACS NSQIP targeted procedure codes for ventral hernia repair, colectomy, appendectomy, and proctectomy as well as small bowel resection and gastrectomy. Patients discharged < day 15 were included in the dataset. This time period was selected to reduce ACS NSQIP 30-day post-surgery follow-up bias.  Reoperations were defined as those occurring during the index hospitalization period. The primary outcome was unplanned readmission that occurred < 15 days from date discharged. Logistic regression models were used to examine variables associated with readmission for each procedure group. 

Results: A total of 748,156 patients were included: ventral hernia repair 36% (n=271,596), colectomy 32% (n=236,104), appendectomy 25% (n=186,560), proctectomy 4% (n=28,786), small bowel resection 3% (n=19,289), and gastrectomy 0.8% (n=5,821). Reoperation was independently associated with readmission for ventral hernia repair (OR 3.0, 95% CI 2.44-3.78, p<0.001), colectomy (OR 1.6, CI 1.44- 1.79, p<0.001), appendectomy (OR 3.0, CI 2.34-4.05, p<0.001), and proctectomy (OR 1.42, CI 1.11-1.82, p=0.005), see Figure. Other clinically relevant covariates associated with readmission were partially dependent functional status after  colectomy (OR 1.44, CI 1.32-1.56, p<0.001), proctectomy (OR 1.3, CI 1.04-1.63, p=0.02), ventral hernia repair (OR 1.9, CI 1.70-2.31, p<0.001), and small bowel resection (OR 1.3, CI 1.12-1.73, p=0.003); and ASA 4/5 classification for colectomy (OR 3.0, CI 2.64-3.46, p<0.001), proctectomy (OR 2.14, CI 1.51-3.02, p<0.001) ventral hernia repair (OR 8.7, CI 7.27-10.60, p<0.001), appendectomy (OR 3.07, CI 2.57-3.66, p<0.001), and small bowel resection (OR 4.9, CI 2.72-8.91, p<0.001). ASA 3 classification, age, sex, and emergency status were also associated with readmission for most procedures.

Conclusion: Heightened awareness of the association of reoperation, as well as partially dependent functional status, higher ASA classification, and emergency status, with readmission may improve patient care particularly for these abdominal operations.

abstract_title: 30 Day Clinical and Cost Outcomes for Synthetic vs. Bioresorbable Mesh for Ventral Hernia Repair
author_block: H. Arshad<sup>1</sup>, M. Plymale<sup>1</sup>, D. Davenport<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Roth<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Kentucky,Lexington, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Synthetic mesh material has been widely-regarded as the gold standard for ventral and incisional hernia repair (VIHR); yet mesh infection is estimated to occur in up to 10% of repairs over time. Bioresorbable (BR) mesh materials have been developed as an alternative to synthetic (Syn) mesh for VIHR, and are considered for use in patients with increased risk for postoperative complications. While acquisition costs of BR mesh is increased compared to Syn mesh, the long-term value inclusive of complication costs are not defined. In the present study, the purpose is to compare 30 day post-operative clinical and cost outcomes of VIHR patients dependent upon mesh type (Syn vs BR). 

Methods:  With IRB approval, a single-center retrospective review was conducted including cases of emergent and elective open VIHR performed between June 1, 2013, and May 31, 2018. The local National Surgical Quality Improvement Program database and medical record review contributed perioperative variables. Cost data was obtained from the hospital accounting system. Multivariable logistic regression assessed the effect of mesh type on wound occurrences. Multivariable linear regression assessed the effect of mesh type on total costs. 

Results: 432 ventral hernia repairs were performed (99 BR and 333 Syn). ASA Class ≥ 3 was more common in the BR group (69.7% vs 55%, p = .010), as was age (56.8 years vs 51.7 years, p = .001). Groups were similar in BMI, tobacco use, and incidence of diabetes. The BR group had increased incidence of prior abdominal infection (31.3% vs 19.5%, p = .019), preoperative open wound (6.1% vs 0.6%, p = .002), and CDC Wound Class > 1 (27.3% vs 5.1%, p = .001). Separation of components was performed more frequently in BR group (77.8% vs 44.4%, p < .001).  Multivariable logistic regression was used to assess the effect of mesh type on wound occurrences with resulting odds ratio for BR mesh relative to Syn mesh was 0.72 (95% CI 0.31 – 1.67, p = .719). Mean total hospital costs were greater for the BR group ($22,609; SD = $12,541) compared to the Syn group ($15,150, SD = $14,598) (p = .001) with the medical supply costs primarily accounting for the difference between groups ($9757 vs $3584, p<.001). Multivariable linear regression assessed the effect of mesh type on total 30-days costs with resulting exponentiated beta value for BR mesh relative to Syn mesh of 1.24 (95% CI 1.10 – 1.40, p < .001), or a risk-adjusted 24% increase in costs over the mean.

Conclusion: Bioresorbable and synthetic mesh hernia repairs can be safely performed with similar 30-day clinical outcomes. Bioresorbable mesh repairs incur more costs during the first 30 postoperative days, primarily related to supply costs. Further studies are required to determine the long-term impact of bioabsorbable mesh upon global hernia costs inclusive of recurrence and complications.

abstract_title: Percutaneous Cholecystostomy in the advanced elderly >85: Can it be definitive therapy?
author_block: W. Alswealmeen<sup>1</sup>, A. Osman<sup>1</sup>, J. McDonnough<sup>1</sup>, K. Panzer<sup>1</sup>, D. Golden<sup>1</sup>, Y. Goldman<sup>1</sup>, R. K. Josloff<sup>1</sup>, O. Kirton<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Abington Memorial Hospital,General Surgery,Abington, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Percutaneous cholecystostomy (PC) is a widely accepted alternative to surgery in critically ill patients or those deemed high risk. Interval cholecystectomy is offered as a definite therapy for acute calculous cholecystitis (ACC). We hypothesize that PCs might be used as definite therapy for cholecystitis in elderly.  

Methods: We reviewed an institutional retrospective database for patients who underwent PC placement between 2015 - 2019. Chi square analysis was used to compare different age groups.  

Results:  We identified 260 patients with ages between 28 and 103 years. Average age was 72.8.  26.5% of patients were under 65 (n=69) 48.4% over 85 (n=126) 25% between 65-85 (n=65). 11 patients were lost to follow up. ACC was the most common indication for PC. Majority of patients had ACC Tokyo grade I & II. Of patients >85 who had a drain, 29.1% went on to have surgery (n=16) compared to 54.5% of those <65 (n=36) (P value 0.011) For Tokyo grade I, regardless of age, 58.6% of patients went on to have surgery. Compared to 30.2 % and 11.2% in Tokyo grades II and III respectively. (P value 0.001) 64% of patients> 85, who had ACC grade I, 66.7% and 100% of patients with ACC grades II & III did not have surgery. This was statistically significant in Tokyo grades I& III ( P values 0.01& 0.04 respectively)  In older patients who did not undergo surgery only 33.3% went on to have PC removed n=13.(P value 0.044)  

Conclusions:  Percutaneous cholecystostomy tubes are used increasingly in elderly regardless of severity of cholecystitis. We noticed a trend in their use as definite therapy for ACC. This was statistically significant but further studies with larger number of patients are needed to evaluate it.

abstract_title: Impact of COVID-19 on the Presentations and Management of Cholecystitis and Symptomatic Biliary Colic
author_block: O. N. Farber<sup>1</sup>, A. Titan<sup>1</sup>, A. T. Fisher<sup>1</sup>, A. Kempinsky<sup>1</sup>, C. Wise<sup>1</sup>, V. Toro Arana<sup>1</sup>, M. Hawn<sup>1</sup>, J. Korndorffer<sup>1</sup>, J. Forrester<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Esquivel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,School Of Medicine,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in stay-at-home policies that may have impacted patients with non-COVID related illnesses. Hospitals have postponed procedures and concurrently, patients may have delays in seeking medical care. We sought to understand differences in the presentation, management, and outcomes of patients with biliary disease during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Methods: We performed a single institution retrospective chart review collecting data for all patients who presented to the emergency department (ED) with symptomatic biliary colic or acute cholecystitis between March and June of 2019 and 2020. We extracted data involving patient clinical factors, treatment, and outcomes. T-tests and Chi-squared univariate analyses were performed as appropriate for analysis.

Results: We identified 313 patients, 152 (49%) who presented in 2019 and 161 (51%) in 2020. In 2020, more patients presented with acute cholecystitis than in 2019 (50% vs. 35%, respectively, p<0.05). Mean duration of symptoms prior to presentation was longer in 2020 (4.2 days vs. 2.9 in 2019). More patients were admitted to the hospital in 2020 compared to 2019 (65% vs 49%, p=0.03). Although there was no significant difference in the proportions of patients treated surgically (52% in 2020 vs. 40% in 2019), significantly more patients received antibiotics in 2020 (66% vs. 52% p=0.02).

Conclusion: COVID-19 has impacted the severity and management of biliary disease at our institution. More patients presented with acute cholecystitis during the COVID-19 pandemic and fewer with biliary colic, which may be due to delays in seeking or accessing care.

abstract_title: PRELIMINARY VALUE ASSESSMENT FOR INCISIONAL HERNIA REPAIR PROCEDURES AT A TERTIARY MEDICAL CENTER.
author_block: A. Iqbal<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Abdelmasseh<sup>1,2</sup>, D. Melton<sup>1</sup>, J. Willis<sup>3</sup>, V. Kadiyala<sup>3</sup>, K. Parks<sup>1</sup>, J. Sanabria<sup>1,2,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Huntington, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>Marshall Institute for Interdisciplinary Research (MIIR),Huntington, WV, USA <sup>3</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine,Department Of Informatics And Biostatistics,Huntington, WV, USA <sup>4</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine,Department Of Nutrition And Metabolomics/Proteomics Core Facility,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Approximately 350,000 incisional hernia repairs are performed each year in the US. Healthcare providers, stakeholders, and policymakers are implying new strategies to emphasize the fee-for-value models instead of fee-for-service. We aim to evaluate the value of incisional hernia repair procedures and identify the factors that affect their cost.

Methods:  Clinical variables (v=81) from patients (>18yo) who underwent incisional hernia repair were retrieved from a Health System warehouse retrospectively (Jan-2010 to July-2016, n=424), and prospectively (Aug-2016 to Dec-2019, n=251) under IRB approved protocols. Value was defined as V=Q/C. Quality (Q) was assessed by grading surgical complications using a Classification System where Uncomplicated = 1 value unit, Grade 1 = 0.95, Grade 2 = 0.75, Grade 3 = 0.60, Grade 4 = 0.50, Grade 5 = 0 (death). Cost (C) was defined as hospital charges accrued for admission/re-admission up to 30days post-discharge and corrected for inflation at a 5% APR. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed using MATLAB software.

Results: 675 patients underwent open (47%) vs laparoscopic (53%) incisional hernia repairs over a 10-year period. The ratio between males and females was 38% to 62% respectively, with the mean age of 53±13, and mean BMI of 35±9. The unit value cost of uncomplicated outpatient laparoscopic incisional hernia repair with no readmissions was $40,110 (value unit=1). The mean overall cost was $57,234. The average/year costs of open vs laparoscopic incisional hernia repairs were described in figure 1. Univariate and multivariate analyses were calculated to predict the variables that affect the value and cost.

Conclusion: At our tertiary medical center, laparoscopic incisional hernia repairs have an overall higher value when compared to open procedures. Further studies are indicated to enhance the value for laparoscopic incisional hernia repairs and reduce their costs.

abstract_title: Impact of COVID-19 on the Presentation, Management and Outcomes of Small Bowel Obstruction
author_block: S. Wang<sup>1</sup>, V. Toro Arana<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Doyle<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Williams<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Titan<sup>1</sup>, M. T. Hawn<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Korndorffer<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Forrester<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Esquivel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University School of Medicine,Stanford, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients may delay seeking healthcare during the COVID-19 pandemic and shelter-in-place orders. Small bowel obstructions (SBOs) have a good prognosis with early intervention, but delays in surgical or medical management may lead to worse outcomes. This study investigated the impact of COVID-19-related precautions on the presentation, treatment, and outcomes of patients presenting to the emergency department with SBO.

Methods: A single institution, retrospective chart review was performed with data for all patients who presented with SBO to our institution’s emergency department (ED) between March 17-June 30 in 2019 and 2020. We extracted patient characteristics and clinical care data. T-tests and Chi-squared tests were performed as appropriate for comparisons.

Results: There were 243 patients presenting with SBO identified between March 17-June 30, 130 (53%) during 2019 and 113 (47%) during 2020. We found that patient volume dropped 42% between March 17-May 4 of 2019 (n=60) vs 2020 (n=35), directly following the implementation of the shelter-in-place order in our county. Patients presenting during this time period had significantly higher comorbidity scores than those in 2019 (4.1 ± 3.39 vs. 5.77 ± 3.85, p<0.05). There were no significant differences in ED severity scores between the two cohorts. The need for OR intervention between March 17-May 4 for management of SBO following presentation was relatively similar (22% vs 20%), however once the restrictions in shelter-in-place were eased (May 5-June 30) rates of surgical intervention were greater than 2019 (18% vs. 14%) . The rate of nasogastric (NG) tube placement, total length of hospital stay, and readmission for complications for repeat SBO in the 30 days following discharge did not differ significantly between the 2 groups (Table 1).

Conclusion: The shelter-in-place order, hospital policy, and other COVID-19-related precautionary measures in our county were associated with fewer patients presenting to the ED for SBO but had a limited impact on SBO management and outcomes. These orders may have caused people to delay time-sensitive care, but it is reassuring that it did not appear to impact outcomes.

abstract_title: Interdisciplinary Mortality Council Enhances Palliative Care Utilization in Surgical Patients
author_block: A. So<sup>1</sup>, P. Khetan<sup>1</sup>, M. Marin<sup>1</sup>, C. Divino<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>The Mount Sinai Hospital,New York, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Palliative care benefits patients with life-limiting illness or at the end of life. However, studies describe continued underutilization of palliative care services in surgery. In 2012, the Mount Sinai Hospital Department of Surgery established a monthly interdisciplinary mortality council of attending surgeons and the palliative care service. This conference discusses mortalities on the surgical service or within 30 days of surgery, focusing on decision-making processes, family involvement, and patient quality of life. Our study aims to characterize the impact of this mortality council on the utilization of palliative care services by surgeons.

Methods: This is a single-institution retrospective study of all mortalities (n = 789) that occurred on the surgical service or within 30 days of surgery between June 2005 and May 2019. Mortalities before 2012 and those during or after 2012 were classified into pre- and post-mortality council groups, respectively. Patient demographics and clinical characteristics were studied. Data was summarized as frequency (percentage) and compared using Chi-square or Fisher’s exact test as appropriate.

Results: There was a difference in utilization of palliative care services pre- and post-mortality council (9.5% vs. 19.1%; p < 0.0001). Palliative care referrals were not associated with emergent surgeries (p = 0.468), patient age (p = 0.189), or surgical subspecialty (p = 0.357).

Conclusion: Our data show that a dedicated mortality council consisting of surgeons and the palliative care service is a useful platform to increase the utilization of the palliative care consult service by surgeons.

abstract_title: Prevalence of Helicobacter Pylori in Patients Undergoing Upper Gastrointestinal Endoscopy in Ghana
author_block: C. Dally<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Lussiez<sup>3</sup>, B. C. Bredbeck<sup>3</sup>, K. Raghavendran<sup>3,4</sup>, G. Kwakye<sup>3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Kumasi, ASHANTI REGION, Ghana <sup>2</sup>Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology,Kumasi, A, Ghana <sup>3</sup>University of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>Michigan Center for Global Surgery,University Of Michigan,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) carries a significant individual-health and societal cost burden, accounting for over 300,000 deaths globally in 2013 alone. The mortality rate is considerably higher in countries with low resources due to multiple factors. Helicobacter pylori is a known risk factor for PUD and has prevalence rates up to 90% in developing countries. Unfortunately, diagnosis of this infection can place a significant financial burden on patients in resource-limited settings such as Ghana, where the cost of diagnosis and treatment of H. pylori is 640 Ghana cedi, versus 240 Ghana cedi for treatment alone (minimum daily wage 11.92 Ghana cedi equivalent to $2.16). The wait times for diagnosis via rapid urease testing can also be long. As such, identification of a subset of patients who can be safely treated with empiric H. pylori therapy is necessary.

Methods:  We conducted a retrospective review of 1067 consecutive patients who underwent UGIE at four centers in Kumasi, Ghana between 2012 and 2015. Data extracted included age, gender, region of referral, indication for UGIE, endoscopic findings and H. pylori testing results. Descriptive statistics and Chi-Square test were performed using Excel, with p<0.05 considered statistically significant.

Results: Of the 1067 patients who underwent UGIE, 60% were female. The average age was 44.5 years (range 9-95 years old). Patients seen at the four centers were from 12 of the 16 administrative regions, with 89% from the Ashanti region. 80% of patients presented with abdominal pain and/or dyspepsia. Of these patients, 438 (51%) were found to have endoscopic evidence of PUD/gastritis, 212 (25%) had normal findings and 19 (2%) had findings concerning for malignancy. 50% tested positive for H. pylori, 40% tested negative and 10% were not tested or results were unavailable. 51 patients presented with abdominal pain and/or dyspepsia as well as alarm symptoms, defined as vomiting, GI bleeding, weight loss or suspected malignancy. 7 (13.7%) of these patients were found to have malignancy on UGIE. Of the remaining 806 patients who did not concurrently present with alarm symptoms, only 12 (1.5%) were found to have gastric malignancy on UGIE. The difference in prevalence of malignancy between patient groups presenting with and without alarm symptoms is statistically significant (p < 0.001).

Conclusion: We found high rates of PUD/gastritis and H. pylori in symptomatic patients undergoing UGIE in Ghana. Empiric treatment for H. pylori in patients presenting for UGIE with abdominal pain or dyspepsia in the absence of alarm symptoms should be considered given the high prevalence of H. pylori and lower probability of malignancy in this population. Reserving UGIE and H. pylori testing for refractory cases could allow a significant number of patients to avoid the financial burden of diagnostic workup and for the reallocation of UGIE in a resource-limited setting.

abstract_title: Lasting improvements of a surgical infection prevention program: the sustainability of Clean Cut
author_block: M. R. Nofal<sup>1</sup>, T. N. Mammo<sup>5,6</sup>, N. Gebeyehu<sup>6,7</sup>, S. Kahsay<sup>6</sup>, A. Tesfaye<sup>7</sup>, S. Bitew<sup>6</sup>, M. Derbew<sup>5,6</sup>, T. G. Weiser<sup>3,4,6</sup>, N. E. Starr<sup>2,6</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston University,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Department Of Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Stanford University,Department Of Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Edinburgh,Department Of Surgery,Edinburgh, SCOTLAND, United Kingdom <sup>5</sup>Addis Ababa University,Department Of Surgery,Addis Ababa, ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia <sup>6</sup>Lifebox Foundation,New York, NY, USA <sup>7</sup>St. Peters Specialized Hospital,Addis Ababa, ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Surgical infections are a major cause of perioperative morbidity and mortality, particularly in low resource settings. "Clean Cut" is a six-month quality improvement program focused on reducing postoperative infectious complications through strengthening adherence to infection prevention standards embedded in the WHO Surgical Safety Checklist. After piloting the program in five Ethiopian hospitals, improvements were seen in each of the selected infection prevention standards as well as a reduction in risk of surgical site infections. However, long term sustainability of the program has not been assessed.

Methods: Eight Ethiopian hospital completed the Clean Cut program between 2015-2019. Adherence to Clean Cut standards were assessed during a month baseline period and continuously monitored afterwards, with 30-day outcomes obtained for all enrolled patients. Between 6-18 months after completion of the program, a two-week sustainability evaluation was undertaken at seven of eight hospitals using the same direct observation of infection prevention practices, which included six process measures: surgical safety checklist compliance, hand hygiene and skin preparation, instrument decontamination and sterilization, antibiotic prophylaxis, gown and drape integrity and sterility, and gauze counting. Compliance to a standard was assessed. For each observation, 100% of expected behaviors had to be performed correctly to be considered compliant to each process measure. Data were entered into DHIS2 and analyzed using Stata v16.1. ANOVA was used to assess differences between groups.

Results: From the seven hospitals included, a total of 3385 patient encounters were include, 738 from pre-implementation, 2184 post-implementation and 463 from the sustainability audit period. Between the pre- and post-implementation period, compliance with each infection prevention area improved significantly, with the exception of antibiotic administration. The sustainability audit period showed further improvement in use of the Surgical Safety Checklist (72 to 78%), surgical linen integrity (14% to 44%) and gauze counting (95% to 98%). The other three process measures showed some attrition in compliance but remained far above baseline.

Conclusion: The Clean Cut program has resulted in significant improvements in proper infection prevention practices in multiple Ethiopian hospitals with subsequent reduction in risk of surgical infection. This sustainability evaluation demonstrates the behavior changes made as a part of Clean Cut are persistent and in some cases continue to improve. Wider implementation and its study in different contexts is a valuable investment in improving patient safety and infection prevention behaviors over the long term.

abstract_title: Characterizing the Burden of Non-Adolescent Pediatric Trauma in Uganda: A Multicenter Study
author_block: H. S. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, A. Emmanuel<sup>2</sup>, P. Kayima<sup>2</sup>, M. Ajiko<sup>3</sup>, D. Grabski<sup>4</sup>, M. Situma<sup>5</sup>, N. Kakembo<sup>6</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>7</sup>, C. S. Sabatini<sup>8</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Institute For Global Health Sciences,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>St Mary's Hospital Lacor,Gulu, GULU DISTRICT, Uganda <sup>3</sup>Soroti Regional Referral Hospital,Soroti, SOROTI DISTRICT, Uganda <sup>4</sup>University of Virginia,Department Of Surgery,Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>5</sup>Mbarara Regional Referral Hospital,Mbarara, MBARARA DISTRICT, Uganda <sup>6</sup>Mulago National Referral Hospital,Kampala, KAMPALA, Uganda <sup>7</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Division Of Pediatric Orthopedic Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In 2013, approximately eight million children (≤19years old) died from injury-related mortality, with the majority of deaths occurring in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA). In Uganda, there is a paucity of granular epidemiologic data describing the burden of pediatric trauma. Detailed mapping of national patterns of injury is essential for resource allocation, surgical workforce planning and more. This study aimed to ascertain the burden of non-adolescent pediatric trauma across four hospitals in Uganda.

Methods: We performed a trauma-specific sub-analysis on a prospectively-collected pediatric surgical dataset across four hospitals in Uganda: Mulago National Referral Hospital (MNRH), Mbarara Regional Referral Hospital (MRRH), Soroti Regional Referral Hospital (SRRH) and St Mary’s Hospital Lacor (SMHL). Data were collected at each site during varying time periods between 2012 and 2019. Pediatric trauma patients aged 12 years or younger were included in the analysis. Descriptive statistics, including patient demographics, clinical features, management and outcomes, were performed in RStudio (Version 1.2.1335).

Results: Data was collected from a total of 693 pediatric trauma patients, across four hospital sites: MNRH (n=245), MRRH (n=29), SRRH (n=292), SMHL (n=127). The majority of patients were male (63%), with a median age of 5 [IQR=2, 8]. Patients travelled a median of 25km, 57.5km, 19km and 40.8km to reach MNRH, MRRH, SRRH and SMHL, respectively, and patients at MNRH were from the most varied regions across the country. Chiefly, patients suffered injuries due to falls (16.2%), road-traffic crashes (RTCs) (14.7%) and burns (10.5%). Across sites, patients most commonly incurred abdominal trauma (29.4%), contusions (11.8%) and burns (10.5%) (Figure 1). At SRRH and SMHL, 26.7% of patients had long-bone fractures, with a high prevalence of femoral fractures treated with traction. Overall, the majority of patients underwent surgery (55%) and recovered (95%), with no post-operative/treatment complications. Twelve patients died during the study timeframe, all at time of presentation or before surgical treatment was rendered.

Conclusions: In Uganda, non-adolescent pediatric trauma patients suffer traumatic injuries most commonly due to falls, RTCs and burns, resulting in high rates of abdominal trauma, long bone fractures and burns. Amidst surgical workforce deficits and resource-variability, there is an urgent need to cement robust long-term clinical data collection for ongoing pediatric injury surveillance. Up-to-date data regarding national patterns of injury is essential to inform future efforts to strengthen pediatric trauma care in Uganda.

abstract_title: Antimicrobial Resistance Patterns in Perioperative Prophylaxis of Transurethral Procedures
author_block: S. Kanake<sup>1</sup>, G. Rosen<sup>1</sup>, K. Murray<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Missouri,School Of Medicine,Columbia, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Timely empiric and prophylactic antimicrobial therapy are a critical part in achieving positive patient outcomes in almost every medical specialty. Antimicrobial selection is challenging as providers must use agents that have an adequately wide spectrum of action, while being weary of increasing antimicrobial resistance. The American Urological Association (AUA) has antimicrobial prophylaxis guidelines for patients undergoing urologic surgery. For transurethral procedures, AUA generally recommends the use of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) or cefazolin (CEPH) for perioperative prophylaxis. The most commonly isolated organism in infection after such procedures is Escherichia Coli. We sought to investigate the appropriateness of these empiric antibiotic choices through a nationwide sample of antibiograms.

Methods:  We searched for publicly available statewide antibiograms for every state. When differentiated, we preferentially used urinary antibiograms. If a state’s data was not publicly available, we reached out to the state Department of Health (or similar entity) to grant us access to this data. For states that were still unable to provide this data we used available data from flagship public medical schools within the state. 

Results: Twenty-one states had publicly available statewide antibiograms or provided us with similar data. For 12 states, we were able to substitute institutional data from a public medical school. The remaining 17 states have not responded to our query, denied us access, or do not collect this data and do not have available medical school data. Analysis of state antibiograms show considerable variability in antimicrobial resistance of urinary microbes. For E. coli, average susceptibility was 84% (range 58-94%) to 1st gen CEPH and 75.5% (range 62-90%) to TMP/SMX (Figure 1). 

Conclusion: Infection after transurethral procedure can be serious and proper perioperative antimicrobial prophylaxis has been shown to decrease this risk. We assessed the appropriateness of AUA guideline recommended empirical choices, TMP-SMX and CEPH, in the prevention of perioperative E. Coli infection. The predicted efficacy varies greatly among agents and amongst states. For example, North Carolina was the state with the lowest E. Coli susceptibility to CEPH at 58%. However, TMP-SMX is also a questionable choice here as only 72% of E. Coli isolates were susceptible to TMP-SMX. Overall, we show that there is significant geographic variability in antimicrobial susceptibility to AUA guideline recommended perioperative antibiotics for transurethral procedures, suggesting that either no empirical advice should be given or that another antimicrobial class may be preferred.

abstract_title: Perioperative Pregabalin In Ureteroscopy With Stent Placement
author_block: P. Hargis<sup>2</sup>, G. H. Rosen<sup>1</sup>, K. S. Murray<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Missouri,Department Of Surgery-Urology Division,Columbia, MO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Missouri,School Of Medicine,Columbia, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a 6% risk of new persistent opioid use for at least 3 months following ureteroscopy. In several settings, perioperative gabapentinoids have exhibited opioid sparing effects. In preparation for a randomized trial, we performed a retrospective analysis and a prospective pilot to assess the feasibility of studying perioperative pregabalin in ureteroscopy with stent placement. 

Methods:  After IRB approval we performed a retrospective chart review of eligible patients (Table 1) who underwent ureteroscopy with stent placement. We then performed a prospective pilot in this same patient population to evaluate the feasibility of using 300mg pregabalin just prior to ureteroscopy and stent placement. All these patients had a standardized post-op regimen consisting of diclofenac, mirabegron, belladonna and opium, and acetaminophen. We evaluated patient centered outcomes including pain scores and patient satisfaction after surgery and opioid use in the post-operative period. 

Results: The retrospective review of 13 patients found that all received an opioid prescription at discharge and 38% had a readmission or emergency room visit within 30 days of surgery.  The prospective trial enrolled 10 patients. Seventy percent were male with a median age of 37.5 years. Despite counseling to the contrary, 30% of these patients expected to need opioids after surgery. One hour after surgery, the mean (SD) pain score was 1.5 2.1 on a 1-10 visual analog scale. The only adverse effects reported more than once were pain (30%) and dry mouth (60%) post-operatively. All patients went home the day of surgery and no patient was prescribed opioids at discharge. One patient (10%) had emergency room visits leading to readmission within 30 days and was given opioids at that time.

Conclusion: Using a systematic approach involving several interventions including perioperative pregabalin, we were able to decrease discharge opioid prescribing from 100% to 0% in ureteroscopy with stent placement with no observed adverse effects. We will soon begin a randomized controlled trial to specifically evaluate the role of perioperative pregabalin in this setting.

abstract_title: Women Surgeons In Brazil: An Overview
author_block: J. Letcia Spadoa<sup>1</sup>, A. Luza Kolling Konopka<sup>1</sup>, C. Mozzaquatro De Assis Brasil<sup>1</sup>, J. Iaroseski<sup>1</sup>, S. Bueno Motter<sup>1</sup>, G. Rangel Brando<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Universidade Federal de Cincias da Sade de Porto Alegre,Porto Alegre, RIO GRANDE DO SUL, Brazil
abstract_body:
Introduction: The struggle of women for representation in Medicine is arduous. One of the first obstacles was the right to attend medical school. In recent years, there has been a consistent trend towards the feminization of Medicine in Brazil, with an increase in the number of women who graduated each year, so that, in 2017, 45.6% of medical professionals working in Brazil were women. However, despite the expressive growth in numbers, new challenges are faced by Brazilian female doctors, especially in surgical specialties. For this reason, the present work aims to draw a general overview of women in surgery in Brazil to better understand how far we are from gender equity in this area.

Methods: Publicly available data were collected to assess the prevalence of women in surgery and leadership positions in the surgical area in Brazil. It was assessed the prevalence of women: in 13 surgical specialties according to data from “Medical Demography”, in positions of professors of surgery among 32 Brazilian medical schools, in 163 leadership positions in 10 Brazilian surgical societies, and a position of authorship of 792 publications of the main Brazilian journal of surgery (CBC journal).

Results: In the analysis of 13 surgical specialties, 10 had female participation below 25% in 2018. The only ones with a percentage above 25%, but still below 50%, were: coloproctology, pediatric surgery, and mastology with 30.7%, 40.7 %, 49.3%, respectively. Among the 32 medical schools analyzed, 25 had professors from the surgery department listed on the school's website. At these universities, 383 professors of surgery were found, of which 340 (88.77%) were men and 43 (11.23%) were women. Only 3 universities (12%) had women as head of the surgery department, while 22 (88%) had this position held by men. In the analysis of 163 positions in 10 Brazilian surgical societies, only 14 positions (8.59%) were held by women. This under-representation of women is even more expressive in the highest positions (presidency and vice-presidency), as only 1 (5%) of these positions were held by a woman. In the research area, women represented only 27.8% of general authorship, 25% of the first authorship, and 21.8% of senior authorship.

Conclusion: It is perceived, in general, that the increase in the number of women doctors who graduated each year is not reflected in a greater insertion of women in surgical specialties. The path of women who choose to walk in surgery is full of obstacles, so that the proportion of women in leadership positions is low, whether in the heads of the surgery department of university hospitals, in the positions of Brazilian surgical societies and scientific research in Brazil. Thus, it appears that there is still a large gender gap in surgery and its subspecialties. Therefore, there is an urgent need for more studies to understand the causes of this situation and how we have evolved towards gender equity in Brazilian surgery.

abstract_title: Recording Patient Data In Burn Unit Logbooks In Rwanda - Who And What Are We Missing?
author_block: E. Miranda<sup>1,2</sup>, L. Velin<sup>1,3</sup>, F. Ntirenganya<sup>4</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>1</sup>, F. Mukagaju<sup>6</sup>, I. Shyaka<sup>6</sup>, Y. Nezerwa<sup>6</sup>, L. Pompermaier<sup>1,7</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California,Division Of Vascular Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Lund University,Department Of Clinical Sciences, Surgery And Public Health,Lund, LUND, Sweden <sup>4</sup>University Teaching Hospital,Department Of Surgery, Plastic Surgery Unit,Kigali, KIGALI, Rwanda <sup>5</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>6</sup>Rwanda Military Hospital,Kigali, KIGALI, Rwanda <sup>7</sup>Linkping University Hospital,LINKPING, LINKPING, Sweden
abstract_body:
Introduction: Systematic data collection in high-income countries has demonstrated a decreasing burn morbidity and mortality, whereas lack of data from low- and middle-income countries hinder a global overview of burn epidemiology. In low- and middle-income countries, dedicated burn registries are few. Instead, burn data are often recorded in logbooks or as one variable in trauma registries, where incomplete or inconsistently recorded information is a known challenge. The University Teaching Hospital of Kigali (CHUK) hosts the only dedicated burn unit in Rwanda and has collected data on patients admitted for acute burn care in logbooks since 2005. This study aimed to assess the data registered in these logbooks to evaluate the extent of missing data, and to identify possible factors associated with “missingness”.

Methods: All patient information recorded in the CHUK burn unit logbooks between January 2005 and December 2019 was analyzed using descriptive statistics. Statistical significance (considered at p-value ≤0.05) in the correlation of various factors and the presence of missing data was calculated using Fisher's exact test. Wilcoxon rank-sum test was used to test for differences in medians of continuous variables. Stata IC 16.0 was used for statistical analysis.

Results: In this study, 1,093 acute burn patients were included and 64.2% of them had incomplete data. Data completeness improved significantly over time. The most commonly missing variables were whether the patient was referred from another facility (n=381/1093, 34.9%) and information regarding whether any surgical intervention was performed (n=432/1093, 39.5%). Missing data on burn mechanism (p=0.008), burn degree (p=0.010), and surgical treatment (p=0.014) were associated with in-hospital mortality.

Conclusion: Missing data is frequent for acute burn patients in Rwanda, although improvements have been seen over time. As Rwanda and other low- and middle-income countries strive to improve burn care, ensuring data completeness will be essential for the ability to accurately assess the quality of care, and hence improve it.

abstract_title: Clean Cut Program: Antibiotic Prophylaxis Analysis in Ethiopia
author_block: V. Bajaj<sup>1</sup>, N. Gebeyhu<sup>6</sup>, M. Nofal<sup>8</sup>, A. Tesfaye<sup>6</sup>, S. Bitew<sup>5</sup>, T. N. Mammo<sup>4</sup>, T. Weiser<sup>3,5,7</sup>, N. Starr<sup>2,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston University,School Of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Department Of Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Stanford University,Department Of Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>Black Lion Hospital, Addis Ababa University,Department Of Surgery,Addis Ababa, ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia <sup>5</sup>Lifebox Foundation,Boston, MA, USA <sup>6</sup>St. Peter's Specialized Hospital,Addis Ababa, ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia <sup>7</sup>Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, University of Edinburgh,Department Of Clinical Surgery,Edinburgh, EDINBURGH, United Kingdom <sup>8</sup>Boston University,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical site infections (SSIs) are a major cause of perioperative morbidity and mortality, particularly in low resource settings. In Ethiopia, the pooled prevalence of SSI is 25% and reducing this burden is a priority for the Federal Ministry of Health. Clean Cut is a six-month quality improvement program focused on reducing postoperative infectious complications through strengthening adherence to perioperative infection prevention standards. While antibiotic stewardship is a key component of this, the patterns of postoperative antibiotic administration are not well known or studied. We evaluated the administration of postoperative antibiotics during the course of the Clean Cut program.

Methods: The Clean Cut program was implemented in 8 hospitals in Ethiopia from 2015 to 2019 including prevention strategies such as improved adherence to perioperative antibiotic prophylactic guidelines. Clinical data regarding the types of antibiotics administered, timing of administration, administration duration, complications, indications and SSI were collected by trained personnel via direct observation. Data were analyzed using Stata/IC version 16.1. Descriptive statistics, chi-squared and ANOVA tests were used where appropriate to determine differences between groups.  

Results: Of 3122 postoperative patient encounters at 8 hospitals, over half (51%) of patients received postoperative antibiotics, and about one third of antibiotic administrations were for postoperative prophylaxis. The most commonly prescribed antibiotic was ceftriaxone (38%), including for postoperative prophylaxis (67%), treatment course (92%) and infectious complications such as SSI (76%), pneumonia (50%) and UTI (50%). Other antibiotics such as ampicillin and metronidazole were also frequently prescribed both for prophylaxis and treatment.

Conclusion: While the Clean Cut program focuses primarily on perioperative antibiotic administration (i.e. just before skin incision), other perioperative infection prevention and control practices such as postoperative antibiotic stewardship provide opportunities for further quality improvement initiatives. The frequent use of ceftriaxone for postoperative prophylaxis likely does not follow local or societal guidelines and should be examined as part of a comprehensive infection control and antibiotic stewardship strategy. Further examinations of practices by surgical procedure, wound class, and known resistance patterns are ongoing.

abstract_title: Analysis of Pediatric Surgical Financing and Universal Health Coverage in Guatemala
author_block: K. R. Landrum<sup>1,3</sup>, E. R. Smith<sup>1,2</sup>, B. J. Hall<sup>5</sup>, R. Lou-Meda<sup>4</sup>, H. E. Rice<sup>1,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>Duke University,Duke Global Health Institute,Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor University,Robbins College Of Health And Human Sciences,Waco, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Gillings School Of Global Public Health,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>la Fundacin Desarolla Guatemala,Guatemala City, GUATEMALA, Guatemala <sup>5</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Duke Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric General Surgery,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The financing of surgical care for children in low- and middle-income countries poses several challenges for the implementation of Universal Health Coverage (UHC) and remains a major barrier to access to timely and high-quality surgical care. This study is an exploration of financing of surgical care for children and alignment with UHC frameworks in Guatemala with four aims: 1) describe financial streams and finance agents (i.e. institutional units operating financing schemes) for pediatric surgical care, 2) identify drivers (or precursors) for decision-making in surgical financing, 3) explore the presence of formal and informal patient fees for pediatric surgical care, and 4) identify surgical financing challenges and recommendations for improvement. Our hypothesis is that current financing mechanisms in Guatemala do not address key barriers to the provision of surgical care for children within UHC schemes. 

Methods:  We performed a qualitative analysis of the financing of surgical care for children in the public health system in Guatemala by surveying key informants (n=20) in the medical, financial, and political sectors. We interpreted qualitative results and dominant themes (Figure 1) in the context of national financing data and health system reports, and generated a set of recommendations to improve the financing of surgical care. 

Results: We found several macro-level challenges to financing for surgical care for children, including complex political contexts, health finance system fragmentation, and lack of earmarked funding for surgical care. Micro-level challenges include lack of provider agency in non-personnel funding decisions, as well as families functioning both as financing agents and beneficiaries. Although formal user fees are not used in Guatemala, informal fees for surgical services are common barriers to care. 

Conclusion: The financing of pediatric surgical care in Guatemala faces complex macro- and micro-level challenges that must be systematically addressed to advance UHC for children through increasing access to timely, affordable, and safe pediatric surgical care. Recommendations to improve surgical financing for children and improve alignment with UHC schemes include increasing use of technical financial data, strengthening national and local organizational structures for financing, reduction of informal user fees, and use of innovative financing instruments, such as resource pooling between health system actors.

abstract_title: Exploring Post-operative Outcomes in a Haitian Hirschsprung Disease Cohort.
author_block: G. S. Pierre<sup>3</sup>, P. Charlorin<sup>3</sup>, M. S. Crin<sup>3</sup>, A. N. Bowder<sup>1</sup>, V. Tomaselli<sup>2</sup>, L.
