Osnel<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Program in Global Surgery and Social Change,Harvard Medical School,Boston, MASSACHUSETTS, USA <sup>2</sup>Consulente Policlinico San Pietro,Pediatric Surgery,Bergamo, MILAN, Italy <sup>3</sup>Saint Damien Pediatric Hospital NPH,Pediatric Surgery,Port Au Prince, OUEST, Haiti
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The diagnosis of Hirschsprung's disease is clinical, radiological but above all pathological. However, in Haiti, due to a lack of specialized centers with qualified staff, and the lack of health education for the general population, patients arrive at the hospital at an advanced stage of the disease which can make the diagnosis and surgical treatment of the disease challenging. The aim of this study is to describe the outcomes for a cohort of patients who received an operation for Hirschsprung's disease in Haiti.

Methods: The pediatric surgery team at the only pediatric hospital in Haiti performed a retrospective study of all Hirschsprung operations performed between January 2017-January 2020. Patient data analyzed included demographic information, including driving distance from the hospital, pre-operative vitals, diagnostics and laboratory workup, type of operation, post-operative complications.

Results: Over the course of this study, 20 patients presented with Hirschsprung's disease and 14/20 (70%) were male. In our study 6 or 30% of patients lived within a 2-hour driving distance to the hospital. The median age at diagnosis was 2.57 (IQR 0.8,5.3). The most common presenting symptoms were abdominal distension (85%) and chronic constipation (80%). Only 2 patients had additional diagnosed congenital anomalies. All the patients received a contrast study and the main type of Hirschsprung’s diagnosed was of the rectosigmoid (65%) followed by short segment disease (25%). Pathological diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease was obatined before surgery in 40% of the cases. Half of our patients had a colostomy (50% right and 50% left) before the final pull through procedure, and the other half underwent an immediate primary pull through procedure. The Soave procedure was used for all the patients in which 55% had a differed (after 8 days) coloanal anastomoses. The other 45% had immediate coloanal anastomoses. The main complications of patients who received a colostomy was prolapse occurring in 60% of patients (4 right, 3 left). The main complications after the Soave procedure were pelvis abscess (25%), skin infection 20%, fistula 20% and enterocolitis 15%.

Conclusion: This is one of the few studies from Haiti exploring post-operative outcomes for patients with a diagnosis of Hirschsprung's disease. We saw a high postoperative rate of prolapse (60%) for patients who received colostomies prior to their final procedure and a quarter of our patients had pelvic abscesses after the Soave procedure. The treatment of Hirschsprung's disease has evolved considerably and thanks to intraoperative biopsies treatment without a colostomy or one step procedures are becoming more and more common in developed countries.  In Haiti, this in not always possible and colostomies are often used prior to the final procedure.  However as seen in our cohort postoperative complications remain high. Future work will be aimed at exploring how we can improve our postoperative outcomes.

abstract_title: Inclusion of Surgical System Strengthening in the Global Health Security Agenda
author_block: E. Moeller<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Truch<sup>1</sup>, A. Buda<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Reddy<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Ibbotson<sup>4</sup>, K. B. Park<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Meara<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Program In Global Surgery And Social Change,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami,Miami, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Hospital Boston,Department Of Plastic And Oral Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR),Geneva, -, Switzerland
abstract_body:
Introduction: Global public health security is defined as the activities required to minimize the danger and impact of acute public health events that endanger people’s health. The COVID-19 pandemic highlights the importance of surgical, anesthesia, and obstetric (SAO) care with over 28 million elective surgeries cancelled globally and a significant mortality burden. The pandemic also underlines the essentiality of SAO systems as surgical equipment, infrastructure, and workforce are reallocated toward pandemic mitigation. The purpose of this study is two-fold: 1) quantify the amount of global health security funding allocated toward SAO care, and; 2) assess the relationship between global health security funding and surgical system capacity in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).

Methods: A retrospective review of global health security funding disbursed between 2014 and 2020 was performed using the Georgetown Global Health Security Tracking database. Funding for projects with individual country recipients that were specifically allocated toward SAO care were identified. Funds distributed to NGOs or multi-country projects were excluded but represented only a small fraction of total funds. Project descriptions were searched for mentions of surgery, anesthesia or obstetrics using locale-sensitive character matching. Surgical capacity was analyzed using SAO provider density and SAO procedure volume. Two linear mixed-effects models were used to evaluate the association between SAO-related funding and both SAO provider density and SAO procedure volume, adjusting for GDP per capita. Multiple imputation was used for missing data.

Results: Between 2014 and 2020, US$230 billion was allocated for 78,404 global health security projects in 177 countries. Of those, 571 projects were related to SAO care across 86 countries, with US$1.56 billion committed and US$1.25 billion disbursed. Of funding committed to SAO projects, 41.6% of funds related to surgery were disbursed. There was no association between the amount of funding a country receives to support SAO care and its SAO capacity when adjusting for GDP per capita (p=0.66 for SAO provider density; p=0.84 for surgical volume).

Conclusion: Despite less than 1% of total global health security funding is allocated to SAO projects, the US$1.56 billion committed represents a substantial funding stream for SOA care in LMICs. This funding is vital in the context of constrained fiscal health expenditure due to the COVID-19 induced global recession. The high rate of non-disbursed funds may be due to the complexity of systems required for SAO care. A coordinated global funding mechanism, such as the Global Surgery Foundation (GSF), could improve the distribution of global health security funding aimed at improving SAO care. Ultimately, SOA-related funding should be expanded to ensure access to essential SAO care during the COVID-19 pandemic and to optimize national COVID-19 mitigation strategies.

abstract_title: Implementation of a Tablet-Based Electronic Trauma Registry in a Cuban Hospital: A Feasibility Study
author_block: C. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, A. Aguayo<sup>1</sup>, M. Larrea<sup>2</sup>, M. E. Schroeder<sup>3</sup>, C. M. Dodgion<sup>3</sup>, M. A. De Moya<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College of Wisconsin, Medical School, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Universitario Calixto Garca, Department of General Surgery, Provincia de La Habana, Cuba <sup>3</sup>Medical College of Wisconsin, Froedtert Hospital, Department of Trauma and Acute Care Surgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Globally, 5.8 million people die each year as a result of trauma, accounting for over 10% of the world’s deaths, with a higher mortality rate than malaria, tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS combined. Over 90% of these deaths occur in low- to middle-income countries (LMICs). A major contributing factor to the high trauma incidence and burden in LMICs is the inconsistent degree of injury surveillance initiatives in hospitals. Trauma quality improvement efforts are largely dependent on the development of accurate and reliable trauma registries. Routine clinical data collection can guide hospital and public resource allocations, improve staff preparedness and reveal potential areas for improvement in the management of trauma cases. However, the creation and maintenance of trauma registries and subsequent interventions in LMICs are often precluded by the lack or complete absence of trauma care monitoring tools. Hospital-based data collection has been shown to be an effective method of improving trauma surveillance in resource-limited settings. However, the effort and time required for the design and maintenance of large trauma registries can represent a significant challenge for hospitals in LMICs. A paucity of data regarding important determinants of trauma such as risk factors, patient outcomes and injury patterns can limit quality improvement efforts. Pilot programs in Uganda, Cameroon, Paraguay and Guatemala have shown promising improvements in traumatic injury data collection as a result of implementing electronic trauma registries.

Methods: We performed a needs assessment to determine whether a trauma electronic medical record application (T6 Platform) could be implemented at a major trauma center in Havana, Cuba. Ten focus group meetings were held with the leadership of general surgery and emergency medicine to discuss barriers and solutions to implement the T6 Platform. Site visits were also conducted by visiting medical students to better understand trauma team dynamics and patient flow through the emergency department.

Results: Recurrent concerns from a thematic analysis of focus group transcripts include: Time required for data entry at the bedside, lack of hospital WiFi for data storage and the need for paper records to comply with hospital policy. Feasible solutions to these problems include using medical students or nurses to scribe patient information into T6, setting up an internal hospital server for data storage, widening the compatibility of the app in mobile devices and continuing to print patient records concurrently. A simplified list of trauma documentation elements specific to this trauma center's needs that would facilitate data entry was also created.

Conclusion: Implementation of an electronic medical record for trauma patients is feasible provided significant pre-implementation changes are made to adapt the application to the current trauma team workflow.

abstract_title: Covid-19 Impacts on Surgical Procedures in Brazil
author_block: D. G. Mateus<sup>1</sup>, J. Iaroseski<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Czar<sup>1</sup>, R. R. De Jesus<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Linhares<sup>1</sup>, S. B. Motter<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Universidade Federal de Cincias da Sade de Porto Alegre,Medical School,Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil
abstract_body:
Introduction:   The COVID-19 pandemic changed the world and the health sector, in an away that is difficult to predict all the consequences. The circulation restrictions implemented to prevent the spread of the virus around the globe have already caused changes in the daily lives of hospital centers. One of them was the reduction of surgical procedures. This study aims to investigate the impacts of COVID-19 on the number of surgical procedures, both urgent and elective procedures, performed in Brazil, through a temporal analysis.

Methods:  Data on hospital production from the Unified Health System (DATASUS) were compiled for emergency surgeries and elective surgeries performed from January 2008 to May 2020, by SUS in Brazil. Using the IBM SPSS software, the minimum monthly values ??expected from the 149-month series were generated for each of the categories of procedures surveyed (p ≤ 0.05).

Results: The number of surgical procedures performed in Brazil, through the Unified Health System (SUS), between January 2008 and May 2020, was 52,464,767, with a monthly average of 352,112.53 procedures. 31,169,015 of the total number were urgent procedures and 21,295,752 were elective. The monthly average of urgent procedures was 209,188.02. The minimum expected per month, according to the series analyzed, was 205,805.58 procedures (p ≤ 0.05). However, in March, April, and May 2020, 203,780 , 154,069, and 99,261 emergency surgeries were performed, respectively. Among the elective surgical procedures, in the same period, there was a monthly average of 142,924.51. The minimum expected per month, according to the series, was 138,982.53 (p ≤ 0.05) elective surgeries. However, in March, April, and May 2020, 121,492, 34,485, and 28,424 procedures in this category were performed, respectively.   

Conclusion: The increase of COVID-19 cases in Brazil was followed by a decrease in the number of elective and urgent surgical procedures, with the biggest falls in elective procedures from April to May 2020. Some possible consequences for these events: negative impacts in patients who may suffer from worsening illnesses due to the lack of elective surgeries; for doctors in training, a lower volume of surgical procedures can affect the teaching and learning experience; the effects can also be reflected in the cost-benefit level for the health system, due to the lack of maintenance of the surgical volume, which is an important source of revenue for hospital centers. Thus, future studies will be needed to assess the consequences of this scenario, within surgery, to mitigate effects on the population served by the health system.

abstract_title: The Effect of the COVID-19 Stay-At-Home Order on Acute Care Surgery Presentations
author_block: R. Shenoy<sup>1,2,3</sup>, A. Araujo<sup>4</sup>, R. Dicker<sup>1</sup>, C. Juillard<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Veterans Health Administration, Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,National Clinician Scholars Program,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:             COVID-19 has upended the field of medicine. There are concerns that fear of exposure coupled with state-wide stay-at-home policies may have resulted in delays of care and worse outcomes, particularly for patients with acute care surgery (ACS) conditions. We aim to describe differences in disease severity at presentation for the four most common ACS diagnoses before and after the stay-at-home period and to analyze whether there is an associated difference in outcomes.

Methods:             Primary data collection for all surgery consults from a single institution’s emergency department (ED) for appendicitis, cholecystitis, small bowel obstruction (SBO) and diverticulitis during March-May of 2019 and 2020 was performed. Each patient was assigned anatomic severity grades using the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) anatomic grading scale. Primary outcomes were disease counts and severity. Postoperative outcomes were analyzed secondarily. Statistical tests of differences between years included Chi-squared, Fisher Exact, or Wilcoxon Rank-Sum tests.

Results:             Between March-May of 2019 (N=118) and 2020 (N=89), 207 patients were analyzed. Patient volume decreased by 25% from 2019 to 2020. Figure 1 demonstrates a 59% and 41% reduction in appendicitis and cholecystitis cases respectively, an increase of 29% in SBO cases, and an almost equal number of diverticulitis cases. A greater proportion of the SBOs were malignant in 2020 (9% vs 24%, p=0.12). The distribution of AAST descriptive grading (median: 1) or median length of symptoms prior to presentation (4 days, IQR: 3-6) showed no differences between years. While a significantly lower proportion of patients underwent an operation in 2020 as compared to 2019 (43% vs 58%, p<0.05), operation rates were not different after stratifying by diagnosis. For patients receiving an operation, AAST operative grades trended higher in 2020 (median 1 vs 2, p=0.07). There was no difference in length of stay, immediate or 30-day outcomes or ED or hospital readmissions between the years.

Conclusion:             While there was a decrease in the number of patients presenting to the ED for common ACS conditions during the stay-at-home period, there was no significant difference in overall disease severity. Those that did seek care and required an operation trended towards having more severe AAST operative grades, but had no differences in outcomes. Future work will combine data from multiple institutions and review trends prior to 2019. This early work demonstrates the influence of COVID-19 on patient behavior while suggesting that despite these changes, ACS outcomes have not worsened.

abstract_title: Increase in Penetrating and High-Level Trauma During COVID-19
author_block: K. Mazzolini<sup>1</sup>, J. Dzubnar<sup>1</sup>, A. Tang<sup>1</sup>, C. Cohan<sup>1</sup>, H. Kwak<sup>1</sup>, K. Banks<sup>1</sup>, C. Mooney<sup>1</sup>, T. Browder<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>UCSF East Bay,General Surgery,Oakland, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the age of COVID-19 and enforced social distancing, changes in nationwide patterns of trauma have been observed but are poorly understood. Our aim is to characterize traumatic injury mechanisms and activation levels in 2020 compared to years prior at our level 1 trauma center.

Methods: Trauma patients activated between 2016 and 2020 from the months of January to May were reviewed. Patient demographics, level of activation (1 vs. 2), and mechanism of injury were collected. Data from 2016-2019 was combined, averaged by month, and compared to data from 2020 using chi-squared analysis.

Results: During the months of interest, there were 992 trauma patients triaged in 2020 and 4,311 in 2016-2019. The rates of penetrating and Level 1 trauma activations in January, February, and March of 2020 were similar to average rates for the same months during 2016-2019. In April 2020, however, there was a significant increase in the rate of penetrating trauma compared to the prior three-year average (27% vs. 16%, p < 0.002) despite comparable numbers of patients triaged. Level 1 trauma activations in April 2020 also increased, rising from 17% in 2016-2019 to 32% in 2020 (p < 0.003). These findings persisted through May of 2020 with similarly significant increases in penetrating and high-level trauma.

Conclusion: In the months after COVID-19’s initial spread, there has been a perceptible shift in patterns of traumatic injury. This significant increase in penetrating and high-acuity trauma may implicate a change in population dynamics, demanding a need for thoughtful resource allocation – of both PPE and personnel – at trauma centers nationwide in the context of a global pandemic.

abstract_title: NAT and COVID-19: A Retrospective Chart Review Examining the Impact of Quarantine on Child Abuse
author_block: M. V. Platter<sup>1</sup>, D. Tamura<sup>1</sup>, S. Castle<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Valley Children's Hospital,Fresno, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  During the COVID-19 pandemic, many states issued unprecedented “Stay at Home” orders forcing parents and children to quarantine in their homes. Some reports during this time saw interesting changes in trauma patterns hypothesized to be the result of higher rates of non-accidental trauma (NAT) as parents and children sheltered in place. Early in the pandemic, studies from China demonstrated that people experienced increased levels of psychological distress when they were quarantined at home. Additional studies have shown that mental illnesses, such as anxiety and depression, in parents are associated with higher levels of child abuse. Thus, we hypothesized that children in California’s Central Valley would experience higher rates of NAT during the official California “Stay at Home” order as compared to the previous year.

Methods:  A retrospective chart review was performed using our institution’s Trauma Registry. Patients, ages newborn to 21 years old, who were admitted to Valley Children’s Hospital in Madera, CA, for suspected or confirmed NAT from March 2019 to June 2020 were selected for our study. We then looked at the rates of NAT from May 19 2020, when California’s “Stay at Home” order was officially placed, to May 30. We compared these rates to the same time period, March 19 to May 30, during the previous year. To further analyze the characteristics of NAT during these two periods, we also compared the age of patients, total length of hospital stay, length of stay in an intensive care unit, injury severity score (ISS), and type of injuries sustained. 

Results: Our study identified a total of 30 patients admitted for NAT between March 2019 and June 2020. Of those, eight patients were identified during the quarantine time frame, while 12 were identified in the same time frame from the previous year. Using an unpaired t-test, the means of the above stated categories were compared to determine statistical significance. The results showed that the average age of patients in the quarantine group was significantly higher, with a mean difference of 34.8 months (p=0.03, SD=14.82). For total length of stay, PICU length of stay, and ISS, we found no significant difference between time periods.    

Conclusion: Pediatricians have been concerned that the rates of NAT may increase during the COVID-19 pandemic due to the high levels of psychological distress in parents forced to quarantine with their children. However, our study found that children in California’s Central Valley were not susceptible to higher rates of NAT or more severe injuries during quarantine. While our data did not support our original hypothesis, it did show that the children admitted for NAT during quarantine were older than children from the previous year. This difference in age has not previously been reported, and future studies may be warranted to further examine this difference.

abstract_title: Firearm Purchases and Violence in California and Nationally Surrounding the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: M. R. Donnelly<sup>1</sup>, A. Grigorian<sup>1</sup>, K. Inaba<sup>2</sup>, C. M. Kuza<sup>3</sup>, D. Kim<sup>4</sup>, M. Dolich<sup>1</sup>, M. Lekawa<sup>1</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of California, Irvine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma, Burns And Surgical Critical Care,Orange, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Southern California,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Southern California,Department Of Anesthesiology,Los Angeles, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>4</sup>Harbor-UCLA,Department Of Surgery,Torrance, CALIFORNIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 was first reported in California (CA) on January 26, 2020. By the end of April, CA had the fifth highest cases in the United States (US). Furthermore, reports have suggested increased firearm violence during the COVID-19 pandemic. This study determined the impact of COVID-19 and shelter-in-place (SIP) orders on firearm purchases and violence in the US and CA, hypothesizing increased firearm purchases and violence.

Methods:  A retrospective (1/1/2019-4/30/2020) comparison of COVID-19 cases to firearm purchases, incidents, injuries, and deaths was performed. COVID-19 data was obtained from the Johns Hopkins University Databank, firearm purchase data from the National Instant Criminal Background Check System and firearm violence data from the Gun Violence Archive. Mann-Whitney U Tests were performed for firearm incidents, deaths, and injuries before (1/22/2020-3/18/2020) vs after (3/19/2020-4/31/2020) SIP orders in CA. Binomial logistic regression was performed comparing the mean difference (Δ ) for SIP vs non-SIP jurisdictions for February 2020 vs April 2020.

Results: Nationally, firearm purchases in March 2020 increased 33.6% vs February 2020 and 42.4% compared to March 2019. In CA, March 2020 had a 72.4% increase in the rate of firearm purchases (March 164,497 vs February 95,430) [Fig 1] and a 33.7% increase from March 2019. In CA, when comparing before vs after SIP, median firearm incidents were significantly greater after SIP (8 vs 9, p=0.046), whereas median firearm deaths (3 vs 4, p=0.97) and injuries (5 vs 3, p=0.34) were similar. However, nationally comparing SIP to non-SIP jurisdictions there were no differences in mean Δfirearm incidents, deaths and injuries (all NS).

Conclusion: Nationally, COVID-19 cases and firearm purchases increased during March 2020. In CA, firearm incidents showed an increase after SIP orders. However, nationally SIP orders did not affect firearm incidents, deaths and injuries.

abstract_title: A Three-Year Retrospective Trauma Registry Review at ALERT Trauma Center in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
author_block: A. Zhuang<sup>1</sup>, M. Ayehu<sup>3</sup>, H. Minalu<sup>3</sup>, A. Kefeni<sup>3</sup>, N. Starr<sup>2,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston University,School Of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of California San Francisco,Department Of Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>ALERT Trauma Center,Addis Ababa, OROMIA REGION, Ethiopia <sup>4</sup>Lifebox Foundation,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: According to the WHO, each year more than 5 million people lose their lives to injury-related deaths, of which over 90% occur in low and middle-income settings. Given the large burden of trauma in Ethiopia, both the international community and the Ethiopian Ministry of Health are motivated to improve local trauma care. ALERT Trauma Center is one of two designated trauma centers in Ethiopia and has maintained a basic trauma registry on patients presenting to the trauma unit since 2016. The objective of this study was to characterize patient demographics, injury type and severity, and outcomes to provide further context for improving care for the injured in Ethiopia.

Methods: A total of 12,816 deidentified records from the ALERT hospital trauma registry from September 2016-March 2019 were collected and reviewed. Patients were stratified by injury severity, “red” as the most and “green” as the least severe. Data were analyzed using Excel v16.39 and Stata v16.1. Descriptive statistics and chi-squared or t-tests of significance were used as appropriate to compare groups.

Results: Of the 12,816 patients included, median age was 27 (SD 15) and 74.9% (9,568) were male. Ten percent (1,329) of patients arrived by ambulance, 26.4% (3,299) by taxi, and 32.4% (4,039) self-presented. Of the 480 "red" patients, 31.6% presented by ambulance. After triage, 36.6% (4,187) of patients were sent to the waiting area, and 37.5% (4,291) to the resuscitation area. Soft tissue injuries (5,647, 52.1%) and fractures/dislocations (2,489, 23.0%) were the most common injuries. The majority (67.5%) of patients were stabilized and discharged and few (57, 0.5%) died in the ED. Data incompleteness posed a significant limitation, such as 99.7% of patients (12,776) missing information on the mechanism of injury.

Conclusion: Analysis of the first three years of the ALERT trauma registry highlights several areas of potential improvement. The small proportion of critically injured patients arriving by ambulance highlights gaps in the prehospital care system and opportunities for more robust ambulance services and communication networks to expedite patient transport. Furthermore, about a third of critically ill patients were sent to the waiting room after triage, emphasizing the need for staff trauma training and restructuring of triage systems so that patients are immediately allocated to the appropriate level of care on arrival. A more detailed trauma registry with information on physiologic data and interventions should be used in the future, and staff trained to improve data completeness. This registry will continue informing quality improvement programs as part of a national initiative to strengthen trauma care in Ethiopia.

abstract_title: Impact of Complications After Cytoreductive Surgery and HIPEC on Hospital Costs
author_block: A. M. Patel<sup>1</sup>, H. Zhu<sup>3</sup>, K. Li<sup>2</sup>, R. Alterio<sup>1</sup>, S. Wang<sup>1</sup>, H. Zeh<sup>1</sup>, P. M. Polanco<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Diego,Department Of General Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Department Of Population And Data Sciences,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cytoreductive surgery with hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (CRS/HIPEC) is an invasive procedure used to treat selective peritoneal malignancies. Despite high reported rates of postoperative morbidity, little is known regarding the impact of complications on hospital-costs (HC) for CRS/HIPEC procedures. 

Methods: We queried the HCUP-National Inpatient Sample to identify patients undergoing CRS/HIPEC between 2004 and 2013. HC were compared among patients with no complications (NC), minor (MiC) and major complications (MaC). Univariable analysis and multivariable generalized linear mixed models were used to describe associations of HC with patient and hospital characteristics.

Results: Of 993 patients that underwent CRS/HIPEC 428 (44.9%), 547 (55.1%) and 284 (28.6%) reported NC, MiC, and MaC respectively. Patients with MaC had a significantly higher HC when compared with NC and MiC group ($48,930 vs $37,120 vs $30,094, respectively, p<0.001). See Figure 1. Large and medium bed-size hospitals were associated with higher median costs than small bed-size hospitals ($35,803 and $31,072, respectively, vs. $28,345, p=0.005). Urban hospitals also had higher HC when compared to rural ($33,845 vs. $25,707, p=0.051). Race, payer status, hospital teaching status, and hospital volume were not significant predictors of elevated HC. In multivariable analysis adjusting for age, Charlson comorbidity Index (CCI), length of stay (LOS), number of procedures per patient (NPP), bed-size, and location, MaC and MiC were associated with a significantly higher cost (14.7% and 6.1% more expensive, respectively, both p=0.001) when compared to the NC group. The adjusted mean cost for a patient with a MaC was $34,899 (95% CI: $28,846-$42,222), with a MiC was $32,574 (95% CI: $26,931-$39,400), and the adjusted mean for a patient without a complication was $30,691 (95% CI: $25,373-$37,124). LOS, NPP and CCI were also associated with increased adjusted costs (all p<0.001).

Conclusion: We report the first adjusted hospital-cost analysis of complications after CRS/HIPEC using a major national database. As expected, postoperative complications have a significant impact on HC. MaC is associated with an overall increase in HC of over 60% in comparison with NC. When adjusted for CCI, LOS, and NPP, the increase of HC with MiC and MaC was 6% and 15% respectively.

abstract_title: PVE Versus Y90 for Future Liver Remnant Hypertrophy in Surgical Patients: the Fiscal Argument
author_block: J. F. Gould<sup>1</sup>, A. Acher<sup>1</sup>, P. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, C. Stahl<sup>1</sup>, T. Aiken<sup>1</sup>, S. Weber<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Abbott<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In patients with liver metastases/hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), portal vein embolization (PVE) and selective internal radiation therapy utilizing Yttrium-90 (Y90) are both used to induce hypertrophy in the future liver remnant (FLR) and increase eligibility for curative intent resection. Little is known however, about the financial burdens of each procedure. We sought to define the total cost of care for patients undergoing PVE and/or Y90 followed by curative intent hepatectomy.

Methods: A retrospective review of all adult patients undergoing PVE, Y90, and PVE/Y90 with hepatectomy was conducted between 2013-2020. Data for all relevant radiologic and surgical costs for both the index hospitalization and any readmission within 90 days was collected. Clavien Dindo Classification (CD) captured complication severity and Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) captured comorbidity burden. Total combined cost for liver directed therapy, surgery, and procedure-related complications was the primary outcome of interest. Fisher’s exact test, Chi-squared, and ANOVA were employed.

Results: Out of 25 patients, 18 were included in the final analysis; 72% (n=13) were male and the mean age was 59 +/- 14 years. Primary cancers included colon cancer (78%, n=14), cholangiocarcinoma (11%, n=2), and HCC (11%, n=2). Prior to curative intent hepatectomy, 12 patients underwent PVE, 3 underwent Y90 and 3 underwent both PVE and Y90. 61% (n=11) of the patients had a complication following either IR procedure or surgery. The mean cost was $36,254 ± $6,281 (standard deviation) for PVE patients, $83,292 ± 12,562 for Y90 patients and $127,934 ± 12,562 for Y90 + PVE patients. Bivariate analysis demonstrated that type of liver directed therapy, intraoperative blood loss, CCI, CD were associated with a statistically significant increase in cost.  Controlling for age, CCI, and estimated blood loss (EBL), multivariate analysis demonstrated that patients who underwent both PVE and Y90 prior to curative intent hepatectomy and those with CD > 4 had a statistically significant increase in cost (Table 1).

Conclusion: This is the first study to compare the cost of care for patients receiving PVE, Y90, or both followed by curative intent hepatectomy and demonstrated that patients who underwent both PVE and Y90 procedures prior to hepatectomy and those who had severe postoperative complications (CD > 4) had statistically significant higher cost. This study did not demonstrate a cost difference in Y90 versus PVE, however, validation with a larger dataset is needed.

abstract_title: Appendiceal Incidentalomas: Incidence, Radiological Characteristics, and Diagnostic Accuracy.
author_block: A. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, S. O'Connor<sup>2</sup>, D. Kane<sup>2</sup>, H. Mogal<sup>1</sup> <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Radiology,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Surgical Oncology,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Incidentally detected appendiceal abnormalities, herein termed appendiceal incidentalomas (AI), are an understudied entity with unknown prevalence of neoplastic disease. The primary aim of this study is to describe the frequency and radiologic characteristics of appendiceal incidentalomas. The secondary aim is to determine the accuracy of diagnosing AIs as neoplasms based on imaging.

Methods: Electronic health records for patients at a single institution undergoing abdominopelvic CT or MRI between 2000 and 2020 for non-appendix related clinical diagnoses with mention of appendix abnormalities in the radiology report, were reviewed and diagnosis at index imaging recorded (Fig. 1). Radiographic characteristics were blindly assessed retrospectively. Final surgical pathology diagnosis was the gold standard for diagnostic accuracy in patients treated surgically.

Results: Of 5,197 patients with an appendiceal abnormality, 485 (9.3%) were identified as AIs. Neoplasms were diagnosed radiographically in 16.5% (n=80), dilated appendix in 17.9% (n=87), and thickened appendix in 4.5% (n=22) (Fig. 1). Mucinous neoplasms were all well-circumscribed, with a mean diameter of 21.2 mm (SD ±11.7), mean wall thickness of 3.6 mm (SD ±1.5), and mean luminal fluid density of 18.5 HU (SD ±8.3). 27% had calcifications, and none had adenopathy, fat stranding, or peri-appendiceal fluid noted. Overall, 16% (77/485) of AIs were resected. 59% (47/80) of AIs radiographically diagnosed as neoplasms were resected; 68% (32/47) were pathologically confirmed—29 as mucinous and 3 as non-mucinous neoplasms. 7% (29/405) of AI without neoplastic radiological diagnosis were resected; 21% (6/29) were neoplasms at pathology.

Conclusion: Appendiceal incidentalomas are not infrequently detected in patients undergoing CT or MRI for non-appendix related clinical diagnoses, with a vast proportion being managed without surgery. Pathology-confirmed neoplasms are diagnosed radiographically with relatively high accuracy. Further studies are needed to analyze long term outcomes in patients with incidentalomas managed non-operatively as they may have important implications for clinical management and surveillance.

abstract_title: Approach to pediatric cancer patients in Brazil during the COVID-19 pandemic: a comparative study
author_block: C. M. De Assis Brasil<sup>1</sup>, A. K. Konopka<sup>1</sup>, D. S. Jnior<sup>1</sup>, G. Salzano<sup>1</sup>, I. B. E. Da Silveira<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Spadoa<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Federal University of Health Sciences of Porto Alegre,Porto Alegre, RIO GRANDE DO SUL, Brazil
abstract_body:
Introduction: In 2020, the pandemic scenario of Serious Acute Respiratory Syndrome caused by coronavirus-2 (SARSCoV-2) completely changed the dynamic of health services in Brazil, with the major share of available resources being directed to the treatment of affected patients. Furthermore, since the institution of social distancing as a preventive measure of contagion by COVID-19, many patients have avoided seeking medical assistance, both in primary care and in hospital emergencies. Thus, the risks related to the pandemic have imposed on the brazilian health system a possible impact on cancer screening, with evidence of reduced diagnosis and surgical treatments of pediatric cancer patients, the hypothesis that was verified in this study.

Methods:  Data from DATASUS (database of the Brazilian Unified Health System in Brazil) were analysed for the total number of cancer diagnosis in 2019 and 2020 and, afterwards, in the 0-19 age group, with an annual statistical projection calculated for 2020. In sequence, data on the total number and the daily arithmetic mean of oncologic surgical procedures in pediatric cancer in the same age group in Brazil, between the years 2018-2020, were evaluated in the same platform. Statistical analyzes were performed using the software IBM SPSS Statistics.

Results: In 2019, 515,733 new cancer cases were diagnosed in Brazil, with 15,214 of these patients aged 0-19 years. In 2020, the total number of diagnoses up to the 9th of July was 154,573, with only 3,983 of those cases belonging to the 0-19 age group. Based on these data, the total estimate of pediatric cancer diagnoses (0-19 years) for 2020, in Brazil, is approximately 7,632, showing a reduction of 49.83% in relation to the previous year. As for surgical treatment, during the year 2018, 2,624 surgeries were performed to treat pediatric cancer; during 2019, there were 3,391 procedures. The daily average of surgeries performed was 7.2 in 2018 and 9.3 in 2019. During the year 2020 until June 23, 716 surgeries were performed, with a daily average of 4.09 procedures, corresponding to a reduction 43.2% compared to 2018 and 56% compared to 2019.

Conclusion:The coronavirus pandemic has fully impacted health services, influencing management of pediatric cancer patients. The decrease both in diagnosis an in surgical treatments of pediatric cancer is multifactorial, and the COVID-19 pandemic is one of the factors to be considered. For some patients, this scenario may be associated with late diagnosis or failure to perform life-saving surgeries. Therefore, the need to intensify the diagnostic process is highlighted, with in-depth studies on the influence of COVID-19 in this context, since the postponement of cancer diagnosis limits the chances of treatment and cure.

abstract_title: Perioperative Measurement of Circulating Tumor DNA Informs the Prognosis of Gastrointestinal Cancers
author_block: P. J. Hsu<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Singh<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Turaga<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Chicago,Medical Scientist Training Program,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recurrence of gastrointestinal (GI) cancers after surgery often leads to poor quality of life and death after a short period of time. If detected early, cancer recurrence can be treated with chemotherapy or cytoreductive surgery. However, current techniques used to detect minimal residual disease after surgery lack sensitivity and have not been shown to improve survival.   Circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) and cell free DNA (cfDNA) are emerging as avenues to detect the completeness of surgical resection. As technologies to detect ctDNA/cfDNA improve, it is important to understand the relationship between these potential biomarkers and recurrence of cancers. We thus performed a systematic review and patient level meta-analysis to examine the current evidence regarding the utility of the change in ctDNA/cfDNA prior to and after tumor resection in informing the recurrence of GI cancers.  

Methods: A systematic protocol was registered at PROSPERO (CRD42020186096). Two independent reviewers systematically reviewed relevant articles on the PubMed database published between 1/1/2010-5/15/2020. Inclusion criteria were adults >18 years of age with GI cancer treated with curative intent surgery and measurement of ctDNA/cfDNA collected both before and after surgery. Exclusion criteria were case reports/series and studies of patients who had received chemotherapy prior to surgery, but after the preoperative ctDNA/cfDNA sample was collected  

Results: The search strategy retrieved 3873 articles out of which 1778 articles were reviewed for eligibility and 5 studies were included. Between the 5 studies, 57 GI cancer patients (20 gastric, 37 colorectal) had measurement of preoperative and postoperative levels of ctDNA/cfDNA (Figure 1). Median follow-up time was 36 months (IQR 19-44.5). Among patients with negative ctDNA/cfDNA levels before and after surgery (- to -), 85% (17/20) had no recurrence throughout the length of the studies. Among patients with positive ctDNA/cfDNA levels before surgery but negative levels after surgery (+ to -), 54.5% (12/22) had no recurrence throughout the length of the studies. In contrast, only 20% (3/15) of patients with positive ctDNA/cfDNA levels both before and after surgery (+ to +) had no recurrence throughout the length of the studies.  

Conclusions: Increased levels of ctDNA/cfDNA, either preoperatively or postoperatively, as well as the change in level of ctDNA/cfDNA may be correlated with decreased recurrence free survival. Thus, perioperative measurement ctDNA/cfDNA may be a useful tool for informing the prognosis and need for further treatment of GI cancers. Validation of these findings should be confirmed with a multi-institutional prospective registry study.

abstract_title: Trends in Multimodality Therapy for Locally Advanced Esophageal and Gastroesophageal Junction Cancer
author_block: W. R. Lightle<sup>1,2</sup>, J. I. Portuondo<sup>1,2</sup>, N. N. Massarweh<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Michael E. DeBakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is recommended by national treatment guidelines as the preferred multimodality therapy (MMT) for the management of patients with resectable, locally advanced esophageal or gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) cancer.  However, patient- and hospital-level trends in the utilization of various MMT approaches as well as the association between hospital practice pattern and patient survival have not been well-characterized.

Methods:  National cohort study of 11,620 patients with resected, locally advanced esophageal and GEJ cancer (i.e.: ≥cT2 and/or cN+) treated at 1023 hospitals within the National Cancer Database (2006 - 2015).  Patients were categorized as receiving surgery alone, upfront surgery followed by any form of adjuvant therapy, neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy, or neoadjuvant chemotherapy.  Because neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is endorsed by national guidelines as the preferred MMT approach, hospitals were categorized as high utilizers based on the proportion of patients treated (neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy for ≥75% of patients). Hospitals were also categorized as high MMT utilizers (any MMT for ≥75% of patients).  The association between treatment approach, hospital practice pattern, and overall risk of death was evaluated using multivariable cox shared frailty modeling. 

Results: Overall, 12.9% of patients were treated with surgery only, 10.9% with upfront surgery and adjuvant therapy, 68.7% with neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy, and 7.5% with neoadjuvant chemotherapy.  During the study period, the proportion of patients receiving neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (66.5% in 2006 vs 78.3% in 2015; trend test, p=0.02) significantly increased, while surgery alone (15.2% vs 7.0%; trend test, p=0.02) and surgery followed by adjuvant therapy (13.3% vs 7.6%; trend test, p=0.01) significantly decreased.  Mean hospital-level utilization rates of the various treatment approaches were unchanged over the study period.  Relative to patients treated with surgery alone, those treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy had a lower risk of death (Hazard Ratio [HR] 0.86, 95% Confidence Interval [0.76-0.98]).  By comparison, neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (HR 1.12, 95% [1.03-1.22]) was associated with a significantly increased risk of death.  Upfront surgery followed by adjuvant therapy was not associated with risk of death.  Care at high neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy utilizing hospitals and high MMT utilizing hospitals was not associated with risk of death. 

Conclusion:  Although neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is recommended for patients with esophageal and GEJ cancer, one in five patients are still treated with upfront surgery.  Furthermore, in the context of our current findings and ongoing uncertainty about whether neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy should be the preferred MMT approach, further studies are needed to define the optimal MMT approach for patients with locally advanced esophageal and GEJ cancer.

abstract_title: Neoadjuvant Multiagent Chemotherapy versus Neoadjuvant Radiation for Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: A. W. Brown<sup>1</sup>, A. Mohamed<sup>1</sup>, T. Fitzgerald<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tufts University School of Medicine-Maine Medical Center,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Portland, ME, USA <sup>2</sup>Maine Medical Center Cancer Institute,Scarborough, ME, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Although neoadjuvant multiagent chemotherapy has largely supplanted neoadjuvant radiation, no prospective randomized data exist to support this paradigm shift.

Methods:  Retrospective cohort study using the NCDB. The study includes individuals with localized pancreatic carcinoma who underwent resection. The analysis utilized Kaplan-Meier, logistic-regression, and Cox proportional-hazard models.

Results: The study included 7,846 patients; 1,553 received neoadjuvant radiation, and 6,293 received neoadjuvant multiagent chemotherapy. Median follow up was 23 months. During the study period, there was increased use of neoadjuvant multiagent chemotherapy and a decline in the use of neoadjuvant radiation therapy (p < .0001; r= 0.13). Overall, the groups were well balanced. However, individuals were more likely to receive neoadjuvant radiation if they were Black (OR 1.35; CI 1.09-1.69, p < 0.001), > 75 yo (OR 1.70; CI 1.25-2.31, p < 0.001), uninsured (OR 1.88; CI 1.20-2.94, p < 0.001), or from a low-income area (OR 1.35, CI 1.04-1.76, p < 0.0001). Neoadjuvant multiagent chemotherapy was associated with improved survival on univariate (28.5 vs. 23.9 months, p < .0001) and multivariate analyses (OR 0.79; CI .73-.85, p = 0.0002). Downstaging was similar between neoadjuvant radiation and neoadjuvant multiagent chemoradiation groups (44.7% vs. 39.0% respectively). Downstaging following neoadjuvant multiagent chemotherapy was associated with improved survival (HR 1.44, CI 1.31-1.58, p < 0.0001). However, downstaging following neoadjuvant radiation is not associated with a survival advantage (HR 1.11; CI 0.96-1.28, p=0.89).

Conclusion: Clinicians have rapidly adopted neoadjuvant multiagent chemotherapy for pancreatic cancer in the absence of prospective randomized data.  In alignment with this clinical intuition, neoadjuvant multiagent chemotherapy results in improved survival when compared to neoadjuvant radiation.  Although the rates of downstaging and complete pathologic responses are similar, response translates into increased survival only when the regimen includes effective systemic therapy.

abstract_title: Predictors of Adequate Lymph Node Assessment for Gastric Cancer in a Southeastern U.S. Population.
author_block: M. S. Kahl<sup>1</sup>, M. W. Tsao<sup>1</sup>, O. M. DeLozier<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Deneve<sup>1</sup>, D. Yakoub<sup>1</sup>, E. S. Glazer<sup>1</sup>, D. Shibata<sup>1</sup>, P. V. Dickson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Univeristy Of Tennessee Health Science Center,Surgical Oncology,Memphis, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous national studies have reported racial and socioeconomic disparities in gastric cancer (GC) care.  The purpose of the current study was to evaluate the performance of adequate lymph node (LN) assessment (≥15 LNs) during resection for GC within a healthcare system servicing a socioeconomically disparate, mostly non-White population in the Southeast United States.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study of patients undergoing curative intent resection for GC between 2003-2019 was performed.  Predictors of adequate LN assessment with relation to patient and tumor characteristics were analyzed with logistic regression.

Results: Among 202 patients who underwent resection for GC, 57 (28.2%) were White and 145 (71.8%) were Black or Hispanic. Adequate LN assessment was performed in 104 (51.5%) patients. On univariate analysis, younger age, non-White race, lower Charlson comorbidity index (CCI), male gender, higher AJCC stage, surgeon dictated intent to perform lymphadenectomy and receipt of neoadjuvant therapy were associated with adequate LN assessment (all p<0.05). Insurance status, income, date of diagnosis, obesity, surgical approach and tumor grade were not associated with adequate LN assessment (all p>0.05).  On multivariable analysis, non-White race (OR 2.64, 95% CI 1.31-5.31), CCI ≤4 (OR 2.11, 95% CI 1.12-3.97), stage III disease (OR 2.76, 95% CI 1.29-5.91) and surgeon intent (OR 3.48, 95% CI 1.86-6.52) were independent predictors of adequate LN assessment.

Conclusion: In the current study, non-White race and surgeon intent were notably significant predictors of adequate LN assessment. Future work is necessary to improve standardization and achieve higher rates of adequate LN assessment during resection for GC.

abstract_title: Impact of a Multidisciplinary Clinic on Hepatocellular Carcinoma Patients at a Safety-Net Hospital
author_block: S. Luu<sup>1</sup>, M. Fang<sup>1</sup>, C. Hsu<sup>1</sup>, E. Silberfein<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Surgical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Safety-net hospitals have historically cared for a disproportionate number of patients of low socioeconomic status, racial and ethnic minorities and patients with cancer. These innate challenges make safety-net hospitals important in understanding how to improve access to cancer care in order to fit the needs of vulnerable patients and ultimately improve their outcomes. The purpose of this study is to characterize the impact of the establishment of a multidisciplinary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) clinic at Ben Taub Hospital (BTH), a safety-net hospital in Houston, Texas.

Methods:  A retrospective chart review was performed to compare the demographic characteristics, clinicopathologic data, treatment strategies and outcomes of 304 patients diagnosed with HCC at BTH between January 2012 and December 2014 (group A) and 246 patients diagnosed with HCC between January 2015 and December 2017 (group B) after the establishment of a multidisciplinary HCC clinic.

Results: Demographics were similar between the two groups.  Group A had a higher percentage of patients presenting with multiple tumors (60% vs 53%).  Compared to group A, a smaller percentage of patients in group B presented with stage 2 disease or greater (59% vs 69%) and fewer presented with stage 4 disease (12% vs 31%).  Additionally, in patients with solitary tumors, the mean size of the tumor was larger in group A than group B (4.97 cm vs 3.98 cm).  Fifty-four (22%) patients in group B were seen and 37 of them (69%) treated in the multidisciplinary HCC clinic compared to 175 (58%) patients treated in Group A.  Treatments, including trans-arterial chemoembolization, ablation, resection, transplant, radiation and sorafenib, were similar between groups.  Of those patients that were treated, a higher percentage of patients in group A died of their disease (42% vs 30%) and were lost to follow up (62% vs 24%) compared to group B. 

Conclusion: Most patients with HCC presented to this safety net hospital with advanced disease, however, after establishment of a multidisciplinary HCC clinic, fewer patients presented with advanced disease, died of their disease and were lost to follow up. Screening programs and multidisciplinary teams to detect and treat HCC at an earlier stage continue to be essential for successful long-term outcomes in a resource strapped hospital with limited access to liver transplantation.

abstract_title: New Synoptic Operative Standards for Melanoma and Colon Cancer: Current Opportunities for Innovation
author_block: J. M. Soegaard Ballester<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Goodsell<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Ermer<sup>1</sup>, J. T. Miura<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>, N. N. Mahmoud<sup>1</sup>, P. Gabriel<sup>2</sup>, L. N. Shulman<sup>2</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Abramson Cancer Center,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The Commission on Cancer (CoC)’s new operative standards for 2021 will affect wide local excisions (WLE) for cutaneous melanoma and colon resections for colon cancer. Surgeons will be required to provide synoptic documentation of essential oncologic elements within operative reports. Prior to designing and implementing an electronic tool to support synoptic reporting, we sought to evaluate current documentation practices within our health system to understand our baseline compliance with the new standards.

Methods:  We identified melanoma WLE and colon cancer resections performed in our health system between 1/1/2018–12/31/2018 to ensure adequate follow-up. 100 sequential operative notes meeting CoC inclusion criteria were reviewed for melanoma, and 100 for colon cancer resection. 4 colon resections were excluded per criteria. Two independent reviewers evaluated notes for compliance with each CoC element. For WLE, 3 elements were evaluated: Breslow thickness, clinical excision margin, and dissection down to fascia. For colon resection, 2 elements were evaluated: tumor location and extent of lymphovascular resection. An operative note was considered 100% compliant if all required elements were documented. Descriptive statistics were performed in R, and a Kappa score was calculated to assess for interrater reliability (IRR).  

Results: All melanoma WLE were performed by a single surgeon; compliance was 98% (n=98/100). Missing elements were either Breslow thickness or dissection to fascia. In contrast, for the 5 surgeons performing colon cancer resections, compliance was 69% (n=67/96). The 29 noncompliant notes failed to specify the extent of lymphovascular resection. Compliance rates varied between the 5 surgeons; individual compliance rates were 39% (n=8/19), 63% (n=10/15), 70% (n=7/10), 76% (n=28/36), and 94% (n=15/16) (Fig. 1). For WLE, despite 96% agreement, as no records were rated noncompliant by both reviewers there is decreased utility of the IRR of -0.015. For colon, the IRR was 0.78. 

Conclusion: This study demonstrates heterogeneity in current documentation practices with varying rates of observed surgeon compliance with the CoC operative standards. At present the required documentation elements are interspersed within the operative report, which poses challenges to chart abstraction for evaluation, with resulting imperfect interrater reliability. This presents an exciting opportunity to innovate and improve compliance by introducing an electronic synoptic documentation tool.

abstract_title: Ethnic Representation in Genomic Studies of Gastroenteropancreatic Neuroendocrine Neoplasms
author_block: B. R. Herring<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The field of translational cancer genomics is growing at an exponential rate, bringing invaluable findings from the bench to clinical practice. Integrated genomics will be key to discovering areas of therapeutic susceptibility in gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine neoplasms (GEP-NENs), for which few effective therapies are available. However, not all populations are poised to benefit from these studies, as large-scale genomic analyses have consisted of mostly Caucasians. The goal of this study was to evaluate ethnic populations represented in genomic studies of GEP-NENs.

Methods:  Natural Language Processing (NLP) using the python package Pypdf4 was used to determine the frequency of the words “Race,” “Ethnicity,” “African American,” “Black” “Hispanic,” “Latino,” “Asian” “Native American,” “Pacific Islander” “Caucasian,” and “White,” in 75 published original research manuscripts performing sequencing on GEP-NENs gathered by a systematic review of the literature. Subject numbers by ethnicity were then evaluated following NLP.  

Results: 0/9 studies conducting epigenetic sequencing included any words evaluated, while 9/45 and 1/21 studies conducting whole genome/whole exome DNA or RNA sequencing studies did, respectively. DNA sequencing studies included 5.3% (12) African-American subjects (n=1, where n = # of studies reporting subject demographics), 0% Hispanic/Latino subjects, 27% Asian subjects (n=2), 0% Native American/Pacific Islander subjects, 8.3%  “Other” (n=3), and 90.6% Caucasian subjects (n=5) (p= <.001). The single RNA sequencing study included 5% “Other” and 95% Caucasian subjects. 

Conclusion: There is little representation of ethnic minorities in genomic studies of GEP-NENs. Inclusion of data on these populations is integral for understanding GEP-NEN biology, generalizing findings, and improving therapy.

abstract_title: Evaluation of Treatment Patterns in Patients with Angiosarcoma
author_block: A. B. Roitman<sup>1</sup>, L. Stockton<sup>1</sup>, M. Deng<sup>2</sup>, C. M. Julian<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Hopkins<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Reddy<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Farma<sup>1</sup>, S. Greco<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Department Of Surgical Oncology,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Biostatistics And Bioinformatics Facility,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Angiosarcoma (AS) is a rare subtype soft tissue sarcoma with overall 5-year survival around 35%. Multimodal treatment with surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy may be utilized, however evidence regarding the use and effectiveness of these treatments is poor. We evaluated the effect of perioperative treatments such as neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiation on recurrence-free (RFS) and overall survival (OS).

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of patients diagnosed with AS at our institution from 1991 to 2019. Patients with non-operative management were excluded. Patients were divided into three groups based on type of perioperative treatment: neoadjuvant (NAT) therapy, adjuvant (AT) therapy, or surgery only. Clinical and demographic parameters were compared between NAT, AT only, and surgery only cohorts using Wilcoxon rank sum or Fisher’s exact tests. Kaplan-Meier curves were used to estimate RFS and OS distributions. Multivariable Cox-proportional hazards models were used to compare RFS and OS between the groups adjusting for stage.  

Results: Of the 110 patients recorded, 48 patients received AT, 12 received NAT, and 12 received surgery only, of which the majority had angiosarcoma of the breast (38.9%), followed by head and neck (22.2%), soft tissue (20.83%), and viscera (18.06%). There were no significant differences between treatment groups in clinical and demographic parameters such as age, gender, grade, primary site, or stage. 47 patients experienced recurrence: 36 patients who received AT, 7 NAT patients, and 4 surgery only patients.  The median RFS (in years) was 6.2 for NAT, 1.3 AT only, and 4.3 for surgery. The estimated 5-year OS probabilities were 64.2%, 53.0%, and 66.7% in these groups respectively. In multivariable analysis, AT only patients had a statistically significant worse RFS as compared to surgery only patients (HR 2.34; CI 1.05-5.27, p-0.04), presumably related to selection bias. Clinical stage was the most important predictor of recurrence regardless of the type of perioperative therapy, with Stage 3/ 4 patients having over two-fold relative risk of recurrence compared to Stage 1/2/x patients (HR 2.34, CI: 1.06-5.17, p=0.0355 NAT vs. AT only; HR 2.45, CI: 1.23-4.89, p=0.01 for AT only vs. surgery). 

Conclusion: We found that the majority of AS patients received adjuvant therapy. Patients who received AT had the shortest RFS as well as higher recurrence rate. These findings may be explained by a lower rate of R0 resections in these groups. Our findings are hindered by the small sample size and duplicates in groups. Further research is needed to assess the relationship between perioperative therapy on surgical margin status as well as and RFS and OS.

abstract_title: Lack of Enteral Feeds Associated with Mortality in Premature Neonates with Necrotizing Enterocolitis
author_block: P. M. Jeziorczak<sup>1,2</sup>, R. S. Frenette<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Aprahamian<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children Hospital Of Illinois / OSF Saint Francis Medical Center,Pediatric Surgery,Peoria, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Illinois College of Medicine,Pediatric Surgery,Peoria, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neonates are a high-risk population in need of focused care. Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) remains a significant risk of morbidity and mortality. Recently, there has been an increased recognition of the importance of intestinal immunity and the impact of probiotics, antibiotics, enteral feeds and infection in NEC. The primary purpose of this study is to examine the impact of enteral feeds on the survival of premature neonates with NEC. The secondary goals are to assess the correlation between feeds and other health factors (bacterial infection, probiotics usage).

Methods: A retrospective review using the Vermont Oxford Network database for a Level IV NICU from January 1, 2013 to December 31, 2019 was performed. All neonates had a gestational age between 22-29 weeks, weighed at least 300 grams (n=653), and were treated for NEC (n=43). The cohort was subdivided into groups based on enteral feeding status at discharge: fed (n=571) and not fed (n=82). Data was analyzed using chi-squared analysis for NEC rate and Bacterial Infection while a fisher’s exact test was utilized for mortality rate and probiotic usage (*p<0.05 significant).

Results: The incidence of NEC in the population was 6.6% (43/653). Of the 43 neonates treated for NEC, 27 were enterally fed, while the other 16 were not (see Table 1). All 27 neonates with NEC that were able to achieve enteral feeds by discharge survived and had an infection rate of 22.2%. Meanwhile, all 16 neonates with NEC that were unable to achieve enteral feeds throughout their hospitalization died and had an infection rate of 62.5%. The usage of probiotics in the population was not significantly different.  

Conclusion: In conclusion, there is a significant impact of enteral feeds on NEC, survival and infection rates in premature neonates.  These findings support the impact of intestinal immunity and the microbiota in NEC. Given the limitations of the retrospective review, the profound survival advantage with enteral feeds reinforces the need for further study.

abstract_title: Pediatric Watersport Injuries
author_block: M. D. Hazeltine<sup>1</sup>, A. Singh<sup>1</sup>, J. Perugini<sup>1</sup>, R. J. McLoughlin<sup>1</sup>, M. P. Hirsh<sup>2</sup>, J. T. Aidlen<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Cleary<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Massachusetts Medical School,Department Of Surgery,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Massachusetts Medical School,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Worcester, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a paucity of data on watersport injuries in pediatric patients, with limited nationally representative studies. This study queried a national database to describe watersport related injury prevalence, mechanisms, and patterns.

Methods: We performed a cross-sectional analysis of the 2016 Kids’ Inpatient Database. Cases were patients age <18 years with an ICD-10 diagnosis code of watersport injury. These were compared to patients <18 years admitted for any other traumatic injury. Characteristics were analyzed using ICD-10 codes. Data were weighted for national representativeness.

Results: There were a total of 330 admissions. Compared to other trauma admissions, patients with watersport injuries were older (mean 12.6 vs 8.4 years, p<0.01), primarily Non-Hispanic White (72.8% vs 45.7%, p<0.01), with private insurance (68.3% vs 39.9%, p<0.01) and in the highest income quartile (36.9% vs 20.1%, p<0.01). Watersport injuries often occurred in summer (67.5% vs 26.9%, p<0.01) and required more major surgical procedures (69.8% vs 39.9%, p<0.01). The top three injuries were lower extremity fracture (27.8%), intracranial injury (19.8%), and extremity open wound (17.2%). The most common procedures were repairs of hip/femur fracture (15.2%), lower leg fracture (12.4%) and face/skull fracture (7.4%). The most common mechanisms were powered boat (23.5%), other watersport/watercraft (20.4%), and rowing, canoeing, kayaking, rafting, tubing (18.3%). Patients injured from powered boats were more often admitted to the ICU as compared to other watersport/watercraft and rowing, canoeing, kayaking, rafting, tubing (17.6% vs 4.0% vs 6.7%, respectively), and had a longer length of stay (8.7 vs 3.3 vs 5.0 days, respectively), as well as a higher mean number of diagnoses (7.5 vs 4.8 vs 5.1, respectively) and procedures (4.0 vs 1.6 vs 2.3, respectively).

Conclusion: Watersport injuries are a significant cause of injury often requiring a major surgical procedure. The most common mechanism was a power boat in the summer. Approximately one quarter had a head injury or lower extremity fracture. Future studies focused on boating safety may prevent these injuries.

abstract_title: Characteristics Associated with Pediatric Intentional and Unintentional Firearm Injuries
author_block: M. Madill<sup>1</sup>, S. Strotmeyer<sup>2</sup>, B. Gaines<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,School Of Medicine,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Pittsburgh Of UPMC,Division Of Pediatric General And Thoracic Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Firearm injuries remain a public health crisis. Approximately 19 children die or are treated for firearm injuries per day in the United States. Studies have shown sociodemographic differences between individuals injured intentionally versus non-intentionally. However, it remains to be seen whether differences exist within firearm injuries specifically, and which sociodemographic characteristics are most predictive of unintentional or intentional firearm injuries.

Methods: Patients 0-18 years-old treated for a firearm injury at a freestanding, urban children’s hospital between 2008-2018 were included (n = 160). Injuries from air-powered, gas-powered, and pellet guns, and non-penetrating injuries associated with firearms were excluded. Firearm injuries were identified in the hospital’s trauma registry. The registry was queried by free-text and external cause of injury codes. Injuries were dichotomized into intentional and unintentional. Sociodemographic variables were collected from medical and social work notes, and from online and social media sources. Characteristics between intentional and unintentional injuries were compared using Chi-square, Fisher’s Exact, and Mann-Whitney U-tests. Leveraging techniques from information theory, attributes of injuries and injured individuals were compared to determine which characteristics were most discriminative between groups.

Results: 160 injuries were identified (57 unintentional, 4 self-inflicted, 99 assaultive). Self-inflicted and assaultive injuries were grouped as “intentional” for analysis. Children injured intentionally were likely to be older (mean age: 13), Black, publicly-insured, live in a single-parent household, have a parent incarcerated, have problems at school, be involved in a gang, and have a prior psychiatric diagnosis (p < 0.05). Those injured unintentionally were likely to be younger (mean age: 10), White, privately-insured, and living in a dual-parent household (p < 0.05). They were less likely to have a parent incarcerated, have problems at school, be involved in a gang, or have a prior psychiatric diagnosis (p < 0.05). Comparisons between the groups on sex, mortality, removal of the child from the home, previous involvement with Child Protective Services, number of children living at home, parent employment status, alcohol involvement, positive CRAAFT score, and prior involvement in firearm trauma were not statistically significant.  Age, race, and insurance status were the most discriminative between unintentional and intentional firearm injuries. Sex, prior involvement in firearm trauma, and removal of the child from the home were least discriminative. 

Conclusion: Our study demonstrates sociodemographic differences between unintentional and intentional firearm injuries in children. However, these groups were similar across variables, including sex and prior involvement in firearm trauma. Thus, reduced firearm access for all children could decrease rates of both unintentional and intentional injuries.

abstract_title: Can we Predict Necrotizing Enterocolitis Totalis Preoperatively?
author_block: A. C. Barq<sup>1</sup>, V. N. Singh<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Larson<sup>1</sup>, R. Petroze<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Mustafa<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida,Pediatric Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a major cause for morbidity that predominantly affects premature neonates and has a spectrum of severity. A small proportion present with massive intestinal ischemia termed as NEC totalis (NEC-T) which carries almost universal mortality. Due to the relative rarity, there are very small series reported. The ability to distinguish NEC-T from NEC is limited and the purpose of this study is to try and understand factors that would help to predict NEC-T.  

Methods: Neonates with NEC were identified over a 9 year period. Data was collected from the day of diagnosis and for 7 days preceding. Laboratory, imaging, clinical, operative, and outcomes data were collected. NEC-T was defined as less than 10 cm viable bowel on exploration, while cases requiring surgical intervention were defined as severe NEC. The cohort was then stratified and analyzed to assess for predictive factors for NEC-T compared to other surgical cases.  

Results: A total of 210 patients had a diagnosis of NEC, with 150 (71.4%) treated medically. Severe NEC was noted in 60 cases that required any surgery, and 16 of those were found to have NEC-T. Twelve cases had less than 5 cm of viable bowel, while 4 had between 5 and 10 cm. Between the NEC surgical group and the NEC-T group, there was no significant difference in gestational age, birth weight, APGAR, laboratory data from the day preceding diagnosis, blood transfusions, breast milk use, antibiotic use, and day of life of NEC diagnosis. There was also no difference in pre diagnosis respiratory or cardiovascular failure requiring support. NEC-T cases had a higher number on >80% enteral feeds (68.8% vs. 38.6%, p=0.045), higher proportion on Medicaid insurance and increased number with distention at diagnosis (100% vs. 88%). NEC-T cases progressed from initial onset to needing surgery significantly quicker (1.88 vs. 7.0 days, p=0.03). Mortality was 100% for NEC-T and at a mean of 1.5 days from diagnosis, compared with 38% and 15.6 days for NEC surgery.  

Conclusions: NEC-T was uncommon, but uniformly and rapidly lethal in this single center series which is one of the largest. Gestational age in this series was similar to non NEC-T as was age at presentation. There was minimal clinical differentiation between NEC-T and the severe cohort other than more rapid progression of the disease, underlining the need for maintaining a high index of suspicion. Further analysis and multicenter studies would be helpful in creating diagnostic guidelines.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in Intentionality in Pediatric Firearm Injuries
author_block: M. V. Bradley<sup>1</sup>, R. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, M. Larson<sup>1</sup>, A. Gross<sup>1</sup>, M. Delva<sup>1</sup>, T. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Barksdale<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pediatric firearm injuries are the third leading cause of child death nationwide, and rates of pediatric firearm injuries have not shown significant improvement over the last decade. In the US, almost 20,000 children a year present to the ED for firearm related injuries with a rate of 23.9 injuries per 100,000 children. Previous research has shown that firearm injuries are more commonly intentional than unintentional. Younger children have the highest rates of unintentional injury. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the association between demographic factors and intentionality in pediatric gunshot wounds (GSWs). We hypothesize that our midwestern Level 1 Pediatric Trauma Center (PTC) provided care for more intentional than unintentional firearm injuries. 

Methods: This is a retrospective, single site study from an urban, midwestern level I PTC. The demographics of the metro area are 19.7% Black or African American, 71.7% Non-Hispanic White, and 4.7% Hispanic or Latino of any race. We reviewed charts for patients ages 0-17 who sustained firearm injuries from January 1, 2016-December 31, 2018. We queried the pediatric trauma registry and EMR using ICD10 external cause codes to identify GSW patients. Unintentional injuries are defined as GSWs that occur due to accidental discharge or without violent intent. Intentional injury is defined as discharging a weapon with violent intent, regardless of intended victim.

Results: Between January 2016 through December 2018, 110 GSW patients presented to our Level 1 PTC. Of these GSWs, 81 are categorized as intentional, 15 unintentional, and 6 did not have enough information to determine intentionality. There are distinct racial differences in intentionality. No White patients were victims of intentional injury; in contrast, 82% of Black patients were victims of intentional injury. Boys were disproportionately affected in comparison to girls in the number of  injuries, making up 79% of total injuries. However, rates of intentionality were approximately equal (Table 1). As age increases, both the total number of injuries as well as the rate of intentional injuries rises. Of note, two patients were shot twice and two patients were shot three times during the study period. 

Conclusion: There are significant racial disparities in both the number of pediatric GSWs as well as the intentionality. Black children are the victims of intentional gun violence at much higher rates than White children. Overall, higher rates of intentional than unintentional firearm injury aligns with previous research on this subject.

abstract_title: Children's Surgery Verification: Challenges with Data Acquisition for the Verification Process
author_block: S. A. Arshad<sup>1,2,3</sup>, D. Ferguson<sup>1,2,3</sup>, E. Garcia<sup>1,3</sup>, B. Hegde<sup>1,2,3</sup>, K. Danko<sup>3</sup>, J. Zurek<sup>3</sup>, A. Kawaguchi<sup>1,2,3</sup>, K. Lally<sup>1,2,3</sup>, K. Tsao<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Center For Surgical Trials And Evidence-based Practice (C-STEP),Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Memorial Hermann Hospital,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In 2017, the American College of Surgeons (ACS) established the Children’s Surgery Verification (CSV) quality improvement program, a set of standards to improve surgical care in children. The CSV Appendix 2 outlines 36 perioperative events/outcomes required for hospital verification and necessitates unique institutional mechanisms for data collection. Outlined is our process for meeting these requirements.

Methods: In 2019, our tertiary children’s hospital applied for Level 1 ACS CSV. We reviewed our sources and mechanism of data acquisition for Appendix 2 to meet the requirements for verification.

Results: Six data sources were utilized. The electronic medical record [Cerner] and hospital [variance] reporting systems were the primary sources for manual data extraction, comprising 26/36 (72%) variables required for CSV (Table). Four data points (11%) were obtained from preexisting department committees/reports (code review committee, blood bank report, extracorporeal life support report). Additional data points were abstracted from commercial data repositories utilized by our hospital (Vizient, Solutions for Patient Safety, Pediatric Health Information System). Many variables were cross-referenced against secondary sources for validation. The National Surgical Quality Improvement Program, which contains sampled patients and only eight relevant variables, was not sufficient as a primary data source and was instead used for data confirmation.

Conclusion: A multi-source approach allowed our institution to capture the variables required for ACS CSV application. However, almost all variables required manual extraction and/or confirmation. Automated data extraction systems for all of Appendix 2 do not exist, but would improve efficiency and accuracy.

abstract_title: Pain Balancing Measures after Pediatric Surgery
author_block: I. Minhas<sup>2</sup>, C. E. Stake<sup>1,3</sup>, S. Minhas<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Barsness<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Northwestern University,Feinberg School Of Medicine,Chicago, IL, USA
