abstract_body:
Introduction: In response to the opioid epidemic, many efforts have focused on reducing opioids. However, few data assess the impact of opioid reduction practices on managing pain in the postsurgical pediatric population. Balancing measures, defined as visits to the Emergency Department (ED) or communication with providers after surgery, may help clinicians identify patient cohorts where a decrease in prescribed opioids resulted in inadequate pain management after ambulatory surgical procedures. This study evaluates and describes balancing measures identified from a two-week postoperative visit of patients who only received non-opioid analgesics to manage postoperative pain in a pediatric tertiary care hospital.

Methods: IRB approved retrospective review of postoperative clinic template (opioid dotphrase) from 2/15/2018 – 11/8/2019 was used for analysis. Electronic health record (EHR) collected data included analgesic use after surgery, side effects and self-reported efficacy of pain management. Patients/caregivers reporting no postoperative opioids had their charts verified for accuracy. Charts were also reviewed for balancing measures (ED visits/communication with providers), medication changes or refills during the two-week time period between surgery and the post-surgical visit. 

Results: Opioid dotphrase review identified 541 postoperative patients who were not prescribed an opioid at discharge and were treated at home with non-opioid analgesics only. Only 55 patients (10%) reported visiting the ED and/or making a telephone call to their providers about postoperative pain. The most common age category communicating pain concerns in descending order were: late childhood (5-12 years), adolescents (13-17), early childhood (1-4) and infancy (<1 year old). The most common procedures where patients reported pain concerns in descending order were: laparoscopic appendectomy (n=14), circumcision (n=8), umbilical hernia repair (n=5), inguinal hernia repair (n=4), and laparoscopic cholecystectomy (n=4). Of the 18 patients who visited the ED between the time of surgery and the postoperative visit, 5 were admitted and 2 received morphine during that visit. None of the 55 patients with identified balancing measures had an addition of an opioid to their medication regimen. Interestingly, six (11%) of the balancing measures (all phone calls) occurred after the two-week postoperative visit and none of these patients reported pain at their postoperative visit. 

Conclusion: The majority of children using a non-opioid analgesic to manage postoperative pain did not have documented balancing measures related to inadequate pain management. Balancing measures are an important component to assess, as efforts to decrease opioid use do not conflict with efforts to treat pain in children. Identifying common surgeries with insuffiecnt postoperative pain management provides an opportunity to re-evaluate analgesic prescribing patterns to improve patient clinical outcomes.

abstract_title: Cytoreductive Surgery and HIPEC Improves Survival in Children with Peritoneal Metastatic Malignancy
author_block: K. Marulanda<sup>1</sup>, A. Marzinsky<sup>2</sup>, U. N. Maduekwe<sup>1</sup>, J. Cooper<sup>2</sup>, A. Hayes-Jordan<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of North Carolina,Department Of Surgery,Chapel Hill, NORTH CAROLINA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of North Carolina,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Chapel Hill, NORTH CAROLINA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Peritoneal metastatic disease is rare and often fatal in children. It most commonly occurs in tumors originating within the abdominopelvic cavity. Novel local control treatment strategies have been applied but prognosis remains poor with relapse rates of 70%. We have previously demonstrated the use of cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (CRS-HIPEC) to treat select pediatric patients. Here, we present results from our pediatric CRS-HIPEC program and examine outcomes in patients with disseminated peritoneal disease treated with CRS-HIPEC.

Methods:  We performed a retrospective study of children undergoing CRS-HIPEC for peritoneal disease at a tertiary referral center from July 2018 to June 2020. Primary outcomes were relapse free survival and overall survival (OS). Median OS was compared to OS in adult sarcoma patients with peritoneal metastases identified within the National Cancer Database (NCDB).

Results: A total of 21 patients (1 to 21 years) diagnosed with various sarcomas, as well as gastrointestinal and gynecological malignancies originating from the abdomen, retroperitoneum or pelvis were included. The most common malignancies were desmoplastic small round cell tumors (DSRCT) (43%), rhabdomyosarcomas (14%) and ovarian granulosa cell tumors (10%). Complete cytoreduction of gross disease was achieved in 81% of patients. Systemic chemotherapy was administered to 91% of patients, and 48% of patients received radiation before and/or after surgery. Complications were most commonly wound infections (25%), including one patient that required a wound vac, and urinary tract infections (19%) with one patient requiring ureteral stent placement for hydroureteronephrosis. The median follow-up period was 3.2 (2.0 - 7.1) months, during which 29% of patients had recurrence of disease. Of these, 33% had DSRCT. Median time to relapse was 3.3 (2.0 - 5.9) months after surgery. Recurrence was usually isolated to an extra-abdominal location (50%), although 33% of cases had an isolated intra-abdominal location and 17% had a combined intra and extra-abdominal component. There were no fatalities during the follow up period. In contrast, NCDB results showed that 16% (n=101) of adults with peritoneal metastases from abdominopelvic sarcomas died within 90 days of definitive surgery. None of these patients were treated with CRS-HIPEC and only 41% received any form of chemotherapy.

Conclusion: In this case series, we demonstrate that CRS-HIPEC is associated with improved overall survival in pediatric patients with peritoneal metastatic disease. Further analysis with a larger patient population is necessary to determine which disease characteristics are most responsive to this aggressive treatment approach.

abstract_title: Neonatal Circumcision Availability in the United States: A Physician Survey
author_block: U. Naha<sup>1</sup>, H. Aurora<sup>2,3</sup>, R. F. Walton<sup>2</sup>, I. Rosoklija<sup>2</sup>, L. M. Skibley<sup>4</sup>, E. K. Johnson<sup>2,3,5</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Illinois At Chicago,Urology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago,Urology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Urology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Pediatrics,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>5</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Center For Health Services And Outcomes Research,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For families who desire elective circumcisions for their sons, health benefits are greatest and procedural risk is lowest when performed in the neonatal period. However, a significant proportion of boys present to surgical specialists later in childhood for elective operative circumcision. This study aims to assess physician perspectives on access to neonatal circumcision at hospitals across the United States and to identify potential reasons contributing to disparities in access.

Methods: A cross-sectional survey about neonatal circumcision availability and practices was electronically distributed to physician members of the Societies for Pediatric Urology and American Academy of Pediatrics Section on Hospital Medicine. Hospital characteristics (teaching status, public vs. private, region) and circumcision practices (availability, specialties performing circumcision) were assessed. Associations between neonatal circumcision  availability and hospital characteristics were evaluated by chi-square tests and multivariable logistic regression. Qualitative analyses of free-text survey comments were performed.

Results: A total of 367 physicians responded (129 urologists [41%], 188 pediatric hospitalists [59%]). 86% (317/367) of respondents reported neonatal circumcision availability at their institution. Hospitals offering neonatal circumcision had more availability on weekdays vs. weekends. Only 21% offered the procedure 24 hours per day. Many specialties performed circumcisions including Pediatrics (74%), Obstetrics/Gynecology (57%), Pediatric Urology (54%), Family Medicine (31%) and Pediatric Surgery (31%). On univariate and multivariate analysis, the 50 hospitals who did not offer neonatal circumcision were more likely to be located in the Western region (odds ratio [OR] = 8.33; 95% confidence interval [CI]=3.1-25 vs Midwest), and in an urban area (OR = 4.2; 95% CI=1.6-10 vs suburban/rural), compared with hospitals that offered the procedure. The most common reasons cited for lack of availability were: not a birth hospital (N=22, 47%), lack of insurance coverage (N=8, 17%), and low insurance reimbursement (N=7, 15%). Institutional, regional, or provider availability (N=71, 68%), insurance and payment (N=13, 12.4%), and ethics (N=13, 12.4%) were the most common themes in the qualitative comments (Table 1).

Conclusion: Overall availability of neonatal circumcision varies based on hospital characteristics, including geography. Among hospitals who offer neonatal circumcision, temporal availability and specialty performing the procedure is also highly variable. This survey data will inform development of interventions designed to offer neonatal circumcisions equitably for families who desire the procedure for their newborn son.

abstract_title: The Role of a Photographic Atlas in Reducing Postoperative Circumcision Healthcare Utilization
author_block: L. M. McGee<sup>2</sup>, A. Benvenuto<sup>2</sup>, D. Cassidy<sup>2</sup>, C. Ferreri<sup>2</sup>, V. Gamsarian<sup>2</sup>, S. Daignault-Newton<sup>1</sup>, K. H. Kraft<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Urology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pediatric circumcisions can evoke feelings of anxiety and uncertainty for caregivers regarding postoperative care, particularly due to appearance or infectious concerns. This manifests as a high volume of calls to nursing staff as well as unanticipated clinic and emergency department (ED) visits. In order to mitigate unnecessary healthcare utilization, visual atlases have been developed to better prepare caregivers for the recovery process. The use of such atlases has previously been studied, yielding mixed results. Utilizing an increased sample size and extended study period, we hypothesize the implementation of a visual atlas will decrease parental anxiety in the postoperative period, resulting in reduced overall resource utilization.

Methods:  A photographic atlas demonstrating circumcision healing was used in postoperative consultation and given to caregivers for patients undergoing circumcision or circumcision revision from November 2019 to May 2020.  Data regarding patient demographics, postoperative telephone calls, and unanticipated presentations to clinic or the ED were collected prospectively and compared to a retrospective (no-atlas) cohort that did not receive the atlas between November 2018 and May 2019.

Results: The no-atlas cohort included 105 patients, and the atlas cohort included 80 patients. Both groups were similar with respect to age (p=0.56) and type of procedure (p=0.88). There was no statistically significant difference between the no-atlas vs. atlas cohort with respect to phone calls to clinic staff (15 [11.8%] vs. 11 [13.8%], p=0.68). Additionally, there was no statistically significant difference between cohorts with respect to unanticipated postoperative encounters (3 [2.4%] vs. 4 [5.0%], p=0.43).

Conclusion: The utilization of a photographic atlas as part of caregiver support for circumcision patients did not demonstrate a statistically significant reduction in either postoperative phone calls or unanticipated postoperative presentations. Clinically, there was a reduction in the absolute number of caregiver phone calls (15 to 11), albeit an increase in follow-up presentations (3 to 4). The lack of significant change in postoperative phone calls and encounters may be due to the already infrequent occurrence of these events following circumcision, as demonstrated by the no-atlas cohort. Adding to current studies that have yielded mixed results, our study evaluates the largest patient population to date. Although our results suggest that a different educational approach may be needed to reduce postoperative phone calls and encounters as a measure of parental concern, further studies are required to determine whether or not a photographic atlas is a valuable educational tool for caregivers following pediatric circumcision.

abstract_title: Intraoperative Ultrasound Use in the Management of Malignant Pediatric Liver Tumors
author_block: T. Malik<sup>1</sup>, R. Whitlock<sup>1</sup>, H. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, P. Masand<sup>1</sup>, S. Vasudevan<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Pediatric liver cancers, including hepatoblastoma (HB), hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), undifferentiated embryonal sarcoma of the liver (UESL), and metastases are treated with a combination of systemic chemotherapy and complete R0 surgical resection.  Accurate preoperative imaging including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is necessary to define tumor relationships with major vascular and biliary structures.  Intraoperative ultrasound (IOUS) is an established intraoperative tool for adult hepatic resections with limited use in children.  Having previously reviewed our experience with IOUS in pediatric liver resection showing a discordance of 21%, we sought to update our experience.

Methods:  We identified all children (<18 years old) with malignant liver tumors or hepatic metastatic disease who underwent hepatic resection at our institution between January 2016 and December 2019.  All patients underwent preoperative imaging either with computed tomography (CT) or MRI and results were compared to IOUS findings.  Operative reports and images of all patients were examined to determine disparity between preoperative imaging and IOUS findings.

Results: 31 patients were identified in total. These patients included twenty-four (77%) HB, two (6.5%) HCC, three (9%) UESL cases, and two hepatic metastatic Wilms tumor cases (6.5%).  The median age across all patients was 58.9 months. Of cases performed, there were six (19%) non-anatomical hepatectomies, fourteen (44%) standard hemi-hepatectomies, and twelve (39%) extended hepatectomies.  The median time between preoperative imaging and IOUS was 10 days (IQR: 5.25-23.5). Of the 31 patients evaluated with IOUS, five (16%) had discordant preoperative and IOUS imaging and six (19%) had an altered surgical plan due to IOUS findings. In one case, the MRI showed the presence of infectious nodules; however, these nodules were not seen on IOUS and a less extensive resection was performed.  In an additional case, the tumor was thought to abut the middle hepatic vein (MHV), however, IOUS revealed a 2cm margin from the tumor to the MHV and this structure was preserved.  In three cases, IOUS led to a more extensive resection due to the presence of disease outside of the involved segments identified in preoperative imaging.  In a final case, the preoperative imaging showed a segment 6/7 lesion with equivocal encroachment onto segments 5/8. The surgeon confirmed involvement of segments 5/8 with IOUS necessitating a formal right hemi-hepatectomy.

Conclusion: IOUS provides further delineation of tumor relationships to vascular structures that still has a significant discordance with preoperative imaging. Our study shows that in approximately 20% of cases, the surgical plan was altered with IOUS. We attribute the decrease in discordance to center experience and better MR imaging quality.  However, the standard use of IOUS should be highly considered for the surgical management of pediatric hepatic malignancies.

abstract_title: Incidence and Risk Factors for Persistent Gastrostomy Tube Use in Infants
author_block: A. Bahraini<sup>1</sup>, L. N. Purcell<sup>1</sup>, R. Koonce<sup>1</sup>, A. Marzinsky<sup>1</sup>, A. Hayes-Jordan<sup>1</sup>, M. Phillips<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Pediatric Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Intro: Gastrostomy tube (GT) placement is one of the commonest procedures performed in pediatric patients. Infant patients (<1-year-old) with high risk for feeding difficulties represent a substantial portion of pediatric patients undergoing gastrostomy tube placement. However, the length of gastrostomy tubes remaining in place and predictors of the ability to wean from gastrostomy tube use are not well-established. The aim of this study is to identify patient demographic and clinical factors associated with persistent gastrostomy tube utilization at 6 and 12 months following GT placement in infancy.

Methods: We performed a single institution retrospective review of patients ≤1 year-old who underwent GT placement from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2019 using National Surgical Quality Improvement Program-Pediatric (NSQIP-P) database. The medical records of infants identified in NSQIP-P were examined for evidence of persistent GT use at 6- and 12-months. Demographic and clinical characteristics of patients were reported. Multivariable logistic regression analysis was performed to identify factors associated with persistent GT use at 6 and 12-months after GT placement. Clincial and demographic predictors were selected a priori based on expert opinion, and included; corrected gestational age at surgery, sex, birth weight, American Society of Anesthesiology classification, NSQIP-P reported race, weight loss ≥10% (failure to thrive) prior to placement, percent of goal feeds taken orally at the time of placement, and length of stay as a surrogate for clinical complexity (p-value<0.05 used to detect significant association).

Results: There were 140 infants ≤1 year old identified in NSQIP-P during the study period who underwent gastrostomy tube placement. At 6-months and 1-year after surgery, 17 (12.1%) and 38 (27.1%) of patients were no longer using their GT. Eighty patients (57.1%) continued using their gastrostomy tube at 1 year, and 22 patients (15.7%) were lost to follow-up. Of the examined variables, only weight loss >10% prior to placement was associated with persistent GT use at 1 year (OR: 3.15 CI: 1.20, 8.25).

Conclusion:  GT placement is a common procedure in infants, especially in medically complex children. The odds of persistent GT use at 1 year increased with evidence of failure to thrive prior to surgery and suggests a period of time confirm the diagnosis of failure to thrive prior to GT placement may be associated with decreased GT utilization

abstract_title: Appendectomy by Pediatric Surgeons in North Carolina is associated with Higher Charge than General Surgeons
author_block: L. N. Purcell<sup>1</sup>, A. Charles<sup>1</sup>, A. Akinkuotu<sup>1</sup>, S. McLean<sup>1</sup>, M. Phillips<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The delivery of pediatric surgical care for acute appendicitis involves both general surgeons and pediatric surgeons. However, there is no data comparing healthcare charges for appendectomy based on surgical specialty. We sought to determine the differential cost of appendectomy based on general or pediatric surgeons.

Methods:  A retrospective review of the North Carolina Hospital Discharge Database (2013–2017) was performed in pediatric patients (≤18 years) who had surgery for appendiceal pathology (acute or chronic appendicitis, other appendiceal pathology). Bivariate analysis over the type of surgical provider (GS, PS, other specialty, and unassigned surgeons) was performed. Surgical costs were compared by provider type.

Results: Over the study period, 21,049 patients had appendicitis or other diseases of the appendix, and 6,790 (32.3%) had operations for appendiceal disease. Patients who were operated on by pediatric surgeons were younger (10 years (IQR 6-13) vs. 13 years (9 – 16 years), p<0.001). Acute appendicitis was diagnosed in 2,860 (44.3%) and 3,173 (49.2%) of the pediatric and general surgeon cohorts, p=0.008. Pediatric surgeons performed a higher percentage of laparoscopic (n=2,697, 89.4% vs. n=2,178, 65.5%) than open appendectomies (n=280, 9.3% vs. n=1,118, 33.6%) than general surgeons, p<0.001. The overall hospital charges were $28,081 (IQR: $21,706 – $37,431) and $24,322 (IQR: $17,906 – $32,226) for pediatric and general surgeons, respectively (p<0.001). Surgical charges where higher for pediatric than general surgeons, $12,566 (IQR: $9,802 – 17,462) and $8,051 (IQR: $5,872 – 2,331), respectively. When controlling for diagnosis, surgical type, emergent status, age, and surgical cost of appendiceal surgery, pediatric surgeons were $4,280 higher than general surgeons (95% CI: 3,874 – 4,687).

Conclusion: The cost differential between pediatric and general surgeons following operations for appendiceal disease is significant. The specific reasons for this difference are not clearly delineated in this data set and persist after controlling for relevant covariates. Time in the operating room is the most expensive cost unit in healthcare. The higher rates of laparoscopic surgery in pediatric surgery patients may be associated with longer operating room times.

abstract_title: Validating a Predictive Model for Abdominal Exploration after Blunt Abdominal Trauma
author_block: R. Lay<sup>2</sup>, A. Lamoshi<sup>6</sup>, Z. Chen<sup>5</sup>, M. Chess<sup>3</sup>, K. Bass<sup>4</sup>, D. Wakeman<sup>1</sup> <sup>2</sup>University Of Rochester,School Of Medicine And Dentistry,Rochester, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Rochester,Department Of Imaging Sciences,Rochester, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>University at Buffalo,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Buffalo, NY, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Rochester,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Rochester, NY, USA <sup>5</sup>University at Buffalo,Department Of Biostatistics, School Of Public Health And Health Professions,Buffalo, NY, USA <sup>6</sup>Cohen Children's Medical Center,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  There are no clear indications for abdominal exploration in children who sustain blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) other than the presence of free intraperitoneal air on imaging. We hypothesized that clinical and imaging factors could be used to build a model to predict the need for abdominal surgery in children with BAT. We aimed to validate a predictive model designed for this purpose.

Methods:  A retrospective chart review of pediatric patients under 18 years old from our institution’s pediatric trauma database who experienced BAT between 2011 to 2019 was performed. Patients with an abdominal/pelvic computed tomography (CT) scan without free intraperitoneal air were included. Subjects were required to have at least one of the following inclusion criteria: abdominal wall bruising, abdominal pain/tenderness, thoracolumbar fracture, presence of free fluid, and presence of solid organ injury. Pelvic fracture was also included in the current study. Statistical analyses were performed with Fisher’s exact test.

Results: Two hundred nineteen patients met all inclusion criteria; 26 (12%) underwent abdominal exploration. The need for surgical management was significantly associated with the presence of free fluid (p = 0.002) and thoracolumbar fracture (p = 0.001). Abdominal wall bruising, abdominal pain/tenderness, solid organ injury, and pelvic fracture were not significantly associated with the need for surgery. Patients with BAT due to motor vehicle collision were isolated as a subgroup; 12 of 63 (19%) underwent abdominal exploration. Within this group, surgical intervention was significantly associated with free fluid (p = 0.001) and thoracolumbar fracture (p = 0.011). A predictive model incorporating the 6 predictive factors had an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 0.75. 

Conclusion: The presence of free abdominal fluid on CT and thoracolumbar fracture may be predictive factors in determining the need for abdominal exploration in cases of BAT when there is no clear imaging indication for surgery. Further studies adding patients from other institutions’ databases are needed to determine which variables are important in validating a model to predict the need for abdominal exploration after BAT.

abstract_title: Necrotizing Enterocolitis in Premature Infants Versus Infants with Congenital Heart Disease
author_block: G. Frid<sup>1</sup>, M. Reppucci<sup>1</sup>, M. Paul<sup>1</sup>, O. Onuh<sup>1</sup>, B. Coakley<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine,Surgery,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a serious illness that occurs among two specific populations: preterm infants and term infants with congenital heart disease (CHD). Prior studies have suggested these may be the manifestation of two separate disease entities. We sought to evaluate if there are differences in disease characteristics between these two populations.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of all infants treated for NEC at our institution from 2011-2020 was performed. Demographic data, birth-related factors, information regarding CHD, clinical diagnosis data, treatment outcomes and complications were recorded. Patients with CHD who were born preterm and less than 1.5 kg were excluded. CHD patients whose sole manifestation was the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus were also excluded. Statistical analysis was performed using a student’s t-test for continuous variables and a χ2 test for categorical variables.

Results:  The charts of 107 patients treated for NEC were reviewed. Nineteen infants were found to have CHD. There was a wide array of congenital cardiac anomalies among these 19 patients, including valvular atresia (6), hypoplastic left heart syndrome (3), coarctation of the aorta (2), ventricular septal defects (2), total anomalous pulmonary venous return (1), patent truncus arteriosus (1), AV canal (1), transposition of the great vessels (1) and combined anomalies (2). These 19 patients were subsequently compared to 57 randomly selected preterm NEC infants (1:3 ratio) from the same time period. There was no difference in postnatal age at diagnosis (p=0.50), but, unsurprisingly, infants in the CHD group were statistically older at the time of diagnosis (42.39 weeks for CHD infants vs 31.13 weeks for preterm infants, p<0.001). There were no significant differences between intervention for disease (p=0.18), Bell’s staging criteria (.19), CRP level at diagnosis (P=0.81), incidence of recurrent NEC (p=0.67) or death within 90 days (p=.51) between the two groups. Laparotomy was performed for four (21.1%) of the CHD infants and 10 (17.5%) of the preterm infants. All four CHD infants who required surgery had colonic disease involvement, whereas only 50% of the preterm infants undergoing surgery had colonic disease.   

Conclusion:  Disease severity, time to diagnosis, and treatment outcomes were similar in both groups of patients. However, NEC was more likely to involve the colon among CHD patients than for their premature counterparts. This anatomical discrepancy may point towards a different disease pathophysiology affecting CHD infants who develop NEC as compared to premature infants.

abstract_title: Intraoperative Methadone Decreases Postoperative Opioid Use in Patients Undergoing Nuss Procedure
author_block: N. M. Froehling<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Martin<sup>2</sup>, V. P. Miles<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Byers<sup>2</sup>, J. Holcombe<sup>3</sup>, L. A. Smith<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee College of Medicine, Chattanooga,Department Of Surgery,Chattanooga, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Erlanger Health System,Chattanooga, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Tennessee, Chattanooga,School Of Nursing,Chattanooga, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pectus excavatum is estimated to occur in 1 in 300-400 live births. Complications resulting from an uncorrected defect are caused by increased pressure on the heart and lungs and may include: exercise intolerance, fatigue, heart arrhythmias and failure, respiratory infections, and body dysmorphia. The surgical correction of pectus excavatum by the Nuss procedure often results in significant postoperative pain. Pain management for these patients necessitates a multimodal approach often including opioids, NSAIDs, epidural or local anesthetic blocks, as well as mixed receptor medications such as ketamine and dexmedetomidine. The purpose of this retrospective cohort study was to investigate whether the use of intraoperative methadone in addition to multimodal analgesia would reduce the postoperative opioid requirement for Nuss patients.

Methods: A single-center, retrospective chart review was conducted for 31 patients who underwent the Nuss procedure between 2018 and 2020. Patients were placed in two groups; those who received multimodal anesthesia (MM, n=20) and those who received multimodal anesthesia with the addition of intraoperative methadone (MM+M, n=11). Data collected included demographic characteristics, total opioid consumption during admission (as morphine milligram equivalents (MME)), hospital length of stay (LOS), pain scores, and time to ambulation.

Results: The addition of intraoperative methadone to the multimodal anesthesia regimen of Nuss patients significantly reduced the total MME required during the hospital LOS (p=0.002). On average, the MM group received 59.60 MME per day (SD=38.83) while  the MM+M group received 19.69 MME per day (SD=27.90). When compared to the MM group (M=3.91, SD=1.04), the MM+M group (M=3.50, SD=0.76) had a non-significant decrease in average hospital LOS. There was no significant difference in average pain score (p=0.253), time to toleration of solid food (p=0.365), nor time to ambulation (p=0.162). The patients did not differ significantly in age (p=0.418) nor BMI (p=0.482). No adverse events encountered in either cohort were statistically significantly different. The MM+M group experienced respiratory depression in 25% of patients compared to 36% of patients in the MM group. This difference was not, however, significant (p=0.683).

Conclusion: Incorporating methadone into the intraoperative multimodal pain management of Nuss patients is associated with a significant decrease in total opioid MMEs required postoperatively without a significant change in average pain score nor hospital LOS. There was not a significant difference in either cohort with respect to complications to include postoperative nausea/vomiting or respiratory depression.  Adequate pain management prevents many grave postoperative complications to include pneumonia, oversedation or narcosis, falls, gastrointestinal bleeding, constipation, venous thromboembolism, and other hospital-acquired infections acquired during a prolonged admission.

abstract_title: Pediatric Subcutaneous Abscess: Still a Clinical Exam-Based Diagnosis and Treatment
author_block: I. Garcia<sup>1</sup>, D. H. Chung<sup>1</sup>, N. Gaines<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Pediatric Surgery/Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Subcutaneous abscesses occur frequently in the pediatric population, yet there is great variability in the approach to diagnosis and management, partly due to conflicting recommendations in the current literature. The vast majority of children’s hospitals do not have a standardized protocol for diagnosis and management of subcutaneous abscesses; this has led to inconsistencies in the work-up and treatment. We hypothesize that the current variability in diagnostic procedures and management leads to the use of imaging studies which often do not contribute to accurate diagnosis and treatment. We sought to review the diagnostic work-up and the management protocols for subcutaneous abscesses at a large tertiary pediatric hospital. 

Methods:  We conducted a retrospective chart review during 12 months period. Institutional IRB approval was obtained. We identified 201 encounters for patients <18 years of age using the ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM codes for subcutaneous abscesses at hospital admissions. The data points collected included demographics, recurrence/prior abscess treatment, hospitalization, presence of multiple abscesses, constitutional signs and symptoms, laboratory data including CRP, WBC, antibiotic regimen, and imaging studies. Statistical analyses were performed via Pearson c2 and McNemar’s test.

Results: Our results showed that only 13.6% of wound cultures led to a change in the antibiotic regimen. Blood cultures were positive in only 2.1% of cases. There were no differences in the overall successful drainage of abscesses with or without the aid of ultrasound study (85.7% vs. 88.9% respectively). Patients presenting with fever were more likely to be admitted than those without fever. Packing vs. interloop drain placement of abscess cavity after incision & drainage had no differences in clinical outcomes.

Conclusion: Our data indicate that many of the current diagnostic workup used for the evaluation and management of a subcutaneous abscess have little to no effect on clinical outcome. Findings from this study could lead to developing a standardized protocol, which would be more effective and cost-efficient without compromising the overall outcome in the management of pediatric subcutaneous abscesses.

abstract_title: Intraoperative Chest Drains versus Expectant Drainage after Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Repair.
author_block: A. N. Bowder<sup>1</sup>, K. Somers<sup>1</sup>, M. Arca<sup>2</sup>, S. Siddiqui<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Of Wisconsin,Pediatric Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Rochester Medical Center,Pediatric Surgery,Rochester, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Placement of a tube thoracostomy during repair of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia is controversial. Minimal data exists comparing the outcomes between patients who receive an intraoperatively placed chest drain (IOCD) and those that do not have drains (NoD) placed during repair of congenital diaphragmatic hernias.  In this study we compare postoperative outcomes between patients who underwent congenital diaphragmatic hernia repair with and without intraoperative chest drain placement.

Methods: A retrospective review of infants (age <28 days) who underwent congenital diaphragmatic hernia repair between 2004-2018 was completed. Demographic, operative, and post-operative outcomes were collected. We compared the number of chest tube days, number of ventilator days, days on narcotic pain medications, incidence of post-operative chylothorax, and pleural or patch infection between the two patient groups.

Results:There were 53 patients who underwent congenital diaphragmatic hernia repair. There was no statistically significant difference in estimated gestational age, weight, gender, or age at operation between patients who received an IOCD (25) and those who did not (NoD =28).IOCD patients had both more days of drainage as well as more postoperative chest drainage procedures than NoD patients.  Patients who received IOCD kept their index tubes for a median of 6 days, with an initial total of 111 chest drain days in the 25-patient cohort. Seven (28%) of these patients required a second chest tube placed for 101 additional chest drain days.  In contrast, only four (14%) patients in the NoD group required some form of chest drainage in the postoperative period.  These four patients kept their drains for median length of 4 days, with a total of 20 days of chest drain placement in this cohort. Patients who received IOCD were less likely to have prenatal diagnosis and prenatal surgical consultation and were more likely to have type A defects.  These patients also did not receive preoperative steroids, did not require closure with a patch, nor did they require temporary abdominal closure. Patients with IOCD also had fewer ventilator days (10 days) and shorter course of narcotic utilization (24 days) compared to NoD patients (12 and 35 days).  This difference was not statistically significant (p <0.08). There was no difference between the incidence of postoperative infections or chylothorax between each group.

Conclusion:In our study population intraoperative chest tubes were associated with more chest drainage days and an increased incidence of second chest drainage procedures; however, they were also associated with shorter periods on the ventilator and shorter durations of narcotic pain medication administration.

abstract_title: "Do You Need a Doctor's Note?" Factors Leading to Delayed Return to Work After Blunt Chest Trauma.
author_block: J. Portelli Tremont<sup>1,2</sup>, M. K. Bryant<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Reynolds<sup>1</sup>, C. Brittain<sup>1</sup>, Z. Patel<sup>1</sup>, P. Udekwu<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>WakeMed Health & Hospitals,Trauma,Raleigh, NORTH CAROLINA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Blunt chest trauma is associated with significant morbidity and proven alterations in pulmonary mechanics of the chest wall, which increases the risk of pulmonary complications and healthcare utilization and can lead to poor quality of life. However, long-term functional status for patients with blunt chest trauma is less well-known. Return to work (RTW) is a useful measure of rehabilitation outcomes and is a benchmark for functional recovery in trauma patients, but minimal data exist regarding RTW following traumatic injury.

Methods: Adult patients ≥ 18 years old who were admitted to a Level 1 trauma center following blunt chest trauma with 1) ≥ 3 rib fractures and 2) length of stay (LOS) ≥ 3 days from 2014-2016 were eligible for inclusion. An electronic survey assessing RTW was administered to patients after discharge. Patients were stratified as having delayed RTW (> 3 months after discharge) or self-reported worse activities-of-daily-living (ADL) function after injury. Survey data was combined with clinical data from the trauma admission. Unadjusted logistic regression models, Wilcoxon/Kruskal Wallis tests, and χ 2 tests were used to compare patient demographics, outcomes, and injury characteristics, where appropriate.

Results: Of 324 patients eligible, 79 (24.4%) completed the survey. Median time to RTW was 4.2 months (IQR 3.7,4.8). 15.4% of respondents had a change in employment status after trauma with 34 patients remaining employed compared to 45 patients prior to the trauma. Those patients with delayed RTW had higher odds of having a greater number of rib fractures than those with RTW ≤ 3 months (median 10 vs 7; OR:1.24, 95% CI:1.04,1.48, p=0.02) as well as a longer LOS (median 13 vs 7 days; OR:1.15, 95% CI: 1.04,1.30, p=0.01). Patients with stable ADL after trauma returned to work earlier than those reporting worse ADL (median 2 vs. 3.5 months, p<0.01). 23.6% of respondents took longer than 5 months to return to independent daily functioning, and 50% of respondents report limitations in daily activities due to physical health after discharge. Mechanism of injury, ISS, and need for tube thoracostomy were not associated with delayed RTW after trauma.

Conclusion: > 24% of patients who were employed prior to their injury were no longer employed after injury. The significant proportion of patients with poor physical health and functional status suggests ongoing burden of injury after discharge. Those patients with longer LOS and greater number of rib fractures may be at highest risk for delayed RTW after injury. Future studies should assess the impact of early clinical intervention on RTW and functional status following blunt chest trauma.

abstract_title: The Hilt of the Sword: Are Manubrial Fractures Dangerous?
author_block: M. Gomez<sup>2,5</sup>, A. T. Abid<sup>3,4</sup>, K. Yoshinaga<sup>3,4</sup>, A. L. Alayon<sup>3,4</sup>, R. Grady<sup>3,4</sup>, J. Wycech<sup>2,4</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>3,4</sup>, I. Puente<sup>2,3,4,5</sup> <sup>4</sup>Delray Medical Center,Trauma Services,Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Florida International University,Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine,Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Broward Health Medical Center,Trauma Services,Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Charles E Schmidt College Of Medicine,Boca Raton, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sternal fractures (SF) are rare and occur in 2% of patients with blunt injuries to the chest. There is scarcity of data related to the analysis of SF in relation to different parts of the sternum. The goal of this study was to delineate characteristics and to compare outcomes in patients with a manubrium fracture (MF) versus sternal body fracture (SB).

Methods: This IRB approved retrospective cohort study included 389 adult patients with radiologically confirmed SF who were treated at two level I trauma centers from 2015 to 2020. Patients were divided and compared based on types of SF: MF (n=103) and SB (n=286). Analyzed variables included: age, mechanism of injury (MOI), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), SF displacement, concomitant fractures of ribs, clavicle and vertebrae, retrosternal hematoma, sternal surgical intervention rates, tracheostomy rates, ICU admissions, ICU length of stay (ICU LOS), hospital length of stay (HLOS), and mortality.

Results: MF fractures were observed in 26.5% of patients with SF. MF mean age was 62.1 and SB was 61.2, with geriatric patients constituting about half of both groups (~50%). Main MOI in both groups was a motor vehicle collision (82%). Patients in both groups had similar ISS (14.2 vs 13.3, p=0.4) and GCS (13.9 vs 13.8, p=0.8). MF and SB had comparable rates of displaced fractures (20.4% vs 29.4%, p=0.1) and retrosternal hematomas (28.2% vs 25.2%, p=0.6). Concomitant fractures were significantly more common in MF than in SB (77.7% vs 61.9%, p=0.004) [Fig. 1]. Incidence of concomitant rib fractures was significantly higher in MF patients (58.3% vs 39.2%, p=0.001), with MF having higher rates of first and/or second ribs fractured (33.0% vs 13.6%, p<0.001).  Concomitant fractures of clavicle (12.6% vs 9.1%), scapula (2.9% vs 3.5%), and vertebrae (44.7% vs 37.1%) were comparable in both groups, all p>0.2. Rates of sternal plating (9.7% vs 11.2%), tracheostomy (8.7% vs 5.9%), ICU admissions (56.3% vs 54.5%), ICU LOS (8.2 vs 6.5 days), and HLOS (10.6 vs 9.7 days) were not statistically different between MF and SB, with all p>0.2. Patients in both groups had similar mortality rates (6.8% vs 8.7%, p=0.5) with at least half of the patients discharged either to home or to home with service. Only 15 patients had dual fractures (MF+SB), which corresponded to 3.7% of all patients with SF, and were not analyzed in this study.

Conclusion: Manubrial fractures are observed in approximately a quarter of patients with sternal fractures. Manubrium fractures are accompanied more often by upper rib fractures. Due to the location of the subclavian vessels and brachial plexus, caution should be exercised in patients with a manubrium fracture.

abstract_title: Advanced Prehospital Resuscitative Care: Can We Identify Trauma Patients Who Might Benefit?
author_block: A. Irfan<sup>1</sup>, K. Juneja<sup>1</sup>, P. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, S. Stephens<sup>1</sup>, R. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, W. Ward<sup>2</sup>, R. Hallmark<sup>3</sup>, Z. Qasim<sup>4</sup>, S. Carroll<sup>1</sup>, D. Reiff<sup>1</sup>, J. Holcolmb<sup>1</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Center Point Fire & Rescue,Center Point, AL, USA <sup>3</sup>Bessemer Fire Department,Bessemer, AL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Emergency Medicine,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Uncontrolled truncal hemorrhage remains the most common cause of potentially preventable death after injury, with many patients dying before hospital arrival. Earlier truncal hemorrhage control and blood product resuscitation at the scene or en route to the hospital may increase survivability in this patient population, and is therefore an attractive concept. Some systems have successfully implemented prehospital advanced resuscitation care (ARC) teams (staffed by doctors, paramedics, nurses, and/or certified registered nurse anesthetists) who provide these interventions to the specific patients who require them.  Early identification of such patients is key, and is reliant on consistent rapid decision making and communication. The purpose of this simulation study was to explore the feasibility of early identification of patients who might benefit from ARC, in a typical U.S. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) setting.

Methods: We conducted a prospective observational/simulation study at a level I trauma center and two associated Fire-Based EMS agencies over a 9-month period. The county the trauma center is located in has a population of 1.15 million, and is served by 43 EMS agencies and 15 911 call centers. The two participating EMS agencies were asked to identify actual patients who might benefit from the activation of a hypothetical trauma center-based ARC team. This decision was then communicated in real time to the study team, and the outcomes of these patients were recorded. Each EMS agency was served by separate 911 call centers and used dissimilar mechanisms to identify patients. 

Results: 63 patients were determined to require activation of the hypothetical team. The number of activations per months ranged from 2 to 15. There were no temporal trends. Simulated call-outs most commonly occurred in the evenings with the highest incidence of calls between 4pm to midnight. Of the 63 patients, 33 were transported to the trauma center. The most common presentation was with penetrating trauma. The median age was 27 years (IQR 24-45), 75% were male, and the median injury severity score was 11 (IQR 7-20). Based on patient injury patterns, treatment received, and outcomes, it was determined that 6 of 33 (18%) patients may have benefited from advanced prehospital intervention. On review, all six patients were deemed to have potentially benefitted from earlier transfusion; one may have been helped by a surgical airway; two by prehospital thoracotomy, and one by resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta. Three of the patients died en-route to or soon after arrival to the trauma center. 

Conclusion: The prehospital identification of patients who might benefit from ARC is possible but does face some challenges. Identifying strategies to modify or adapt existing processes may allow better utilization of the existing infrastructure and should be a focus of future efforts.

abstract_title: UNIVERSAL USE OF RH POSITIVE WHOLE BLOOD IN MASSIVE TRANSFUSION PROTOCOLS: WHAT DO WOMEN WANT?
author_block: R. Uhlich<sup>1</sup>, P. Hu<sup>1</sup>, R. Gelbard<sup>1</sup>, J. Jansen<sup>1</sup>, J. Kerby<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Use of O- whole blood (WB) for hemorrhagic shock has become more common, but logistical limitations prevent widespread adoption. Ubiquitous use of O+ WB could ease shortages as 40% of the population are O+ versus 8% O-. In women of childbearing age, alloimmunization is a risk, but evidence suggests this may be smaller than previously thought. Given the risks and possible benefits of O+ WB use, we sought to characterize the level of concern regarding the risks of emergent O+ WB in a healthcare worker population.

Methods: Surgical and nursing faculty and staff were electronically surveyed on the risks and benefits associated with massive transfusion and O+ WB in women of childbearing age. Answers were stratified by 5-point Likert scale then further grouped as likely to accept (likely or very likely) or refuse (unlikely or very unlikely) transfusion. Participants were compared by both gender and childbearing age [(15-50) vs (>50)] as important cohorts for differentiation.

Results: Ninety surveys were initiated with a 92% (83/90) response rate. Participants were 54% male (45/83)) and 46% (38/83) female. Of the female respondents, 81.5% (31/38) were of childbearing age. Both males (95%, 39/41) and females (89%, 33/37) were equally likely to accept transfusion (p=0.33). There was no difference if the risk of fetal harm was quantified at 1% (p=0.73) or 0.1% (p=0.51). 92% (34/37) of women were not opposed to transfusion with O+ WB, even if there were risk of future harm. Women of childbearing and non-childbearing age were equally likely to accept transfusion with risk of future fetal harm (27/30 vs 6/7, p=1.0).

Conclusion: More than 90% of women were amenable to use of O+ blood. Our single center study suggests that universal O+ WB for emergency transfusion is acceptable, increasing the available donor pool and the potential for greater distribution. National data is needed to confirm these findings.

abstract_title: Impact of Marijuana Use in Rib Fractures: A Nationwide Propensity-Matched Analysis
author_block: M. Khurrum<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, M. Chehab<sup>1</sup>, S. Asmar<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, N. Kulvatunyou<sup>1</sup>, B. Joseph<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burn And Emergency Surgery,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Rib fractures are common in the trauma population. Marijuana (THC) use is associated with low bone density and high bone turnover, increasing the risk of fractures following trauma. The use of marijuana also poses a significant detrimental effect on the trauma population. The effect of marijuana use in rib fracture patients is unknown. Our study aims to investigate the associations between recreational marijuana use and outcomes in trauma patients with rib fractures.

Methods: We performed a 2016-2017 retrospective analysis of the trauma quality improvement program (TQIP). All adult (age >18) trauma patients with rib fractures were included. Patients were stratified into two groups: chronic marijuana user (THC) and non-marijuana users (No-THC). A 1:1 ratio propensity score matching was performed adjusting for demographics, vital parameters, mechanism of injury, injury severity score (ISS), body regions abbreviated injury score (AIS), solid organ injuries, number of rib fractures, comorbidities, and smoking history. Outcome measures were in-hospital complications, in-hospital length of stay (LOS), and mortality

Results: Of the 145,416 rib fracture patients, 21,166 patients (THC: 10,583; No-THC: 10,583) were matched. The mean age was 38±15 years, 78% were males, 91% of patients had a blunt mechanism of injury, 73% had multiple rib fractures, and the median injury severity score was 30 [22-36]. The overall rate of in-hospital complications was 16%, and mortality was 4.8%. THC is associated with increased respiratory complications (2.8% vs. 1.6%, P<0.001) and unplanned intubation (2.3% vs. 1.7%, P<0.001), but not ventilator-associated pneumonia (1.9% vs. 1.7%, P=0.469). Overall in-hospital complications were higher in THC (16.4% vs. 14.9%, P=0.002) as compared to No-THC. In-hospital length of stay was significantly higher in THC (4.9 [2.1-10.8] vs. 4.0 [1.7-8.7], P<0.001). There was no significant difference in mortality between the two groups (4.6% vs. 5.0%, P=0.199).

Conclusion: THC use increases the risk of in-hospital complications in trauma patients with rib fractures. Cannabis use negatively impacts patient outcomes. Early identification and screening of cannabis in trauma patients with rib fractures is warranted and may improve their outcomes.

abstract_title: Influence of Insurance Status on Subdural Hematomas Management- An NTDB Analysis
author_block: J. E. Sullivan<sup>1</sup>, S. Panjwani<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Cahan<sup>1,3,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>St. Mary's Hospital,Waterbury, CT, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School,Department Of Surgery,Worcester, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>UMass Memorial Medical Center,Division Of General And Minimally Invasive Surgery,Worcester, MASSACHUSETTS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is major public health concern with a rising incidence in the United States. It is estimated that subdural hematomas (SDH) occur in 10% of head-injury patients, and in 5% of trauma patients overall. It is important to evaluate whether insurance and/or other social determinants of health play a role in treatment and outcomes of traumatic subdural hematomas.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of the National Trauma Data Bank (NTDB) 2012-2016 was conducted to identify associations between insurance status, treatment and outcomes for traumatic SDH in adults. To isolate patients with only subdural hematomas, anyone categorized as having a TBI with multiple types of intracranial bleeding were excluded from the study. Demographic characteristics such as age, gender, race, and region were evaluated. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, injury severity score, and presentation to a level one trauma center were considered. The primary variables of interest were surgical intervention or intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring. Secondary outcomes of interest were emergency department (ED) length of stay (LOS), hospital LOS, ICU admission, ICU LOS, and mortality.

Results: After inclusion/exclusion criteria was applied, the sample size included 68,687 adult patients. Overall, self-pay patients with a single diagnosis of SDH were younger, predominately male (73.1%; p<0.001), and more likely to be non-white compared to patients with public or private health insurance (62.4%; p<0.001 compared to publicly insured and privately insured, respectively at 79.5% vs 78.9%).  More specifically, black/African American SDH patients make up a large percentage of the self-pay category (15.5%; p<0.001) compared to publicly and privately insured (7.5% and 8.0%, respectively). Over 50% of uninsured patients are from the southern US region. After adjusting for age, sex, ISS, GCS, alcohol intoxication, and trauma center level, publicly insured patients were 1.86 (p <0.001) times more likely to undergo a craniotomy or craniectomy compared to self-pay patients. However, insurance status did not appear to impact whether a patient received ICP/EVD monitoring (OR 0.52; p= 0.118). There was no statistically significant difference in ED LOS, Hospital LOS, and ICU LOS.

Conclusion: Publicly insured patients have higher odds of undergoing surgical management for traumatic SDH’s compared to self-pay patients. Further studies evaluating this association are warranted.

abstract_title: Pre-injury Controlled Substance Use and Clinical Outcomes of Elderly Patients After A Fall
author_block: L. B. Gammel<sup>1</sup>, M. Leonard<sup>1</sup>, H. Wheeler<sup>1</sup>, H. Linh<sup>1</sup>, B. J. Burns<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>East Tennessee State University College of Medicine,Surgery,Johnson City, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Controlled substance use, particularly among the rising elderly population, places these patients at a much higher risk of falls, injuries, and hospitalization. This study examines the association between pre-injury controlled substance use and clinical outcomes of older adults after a ground level fall.

Methods: This is a single center retrospective review of registry data at a rural level 1 trauma center. We included all patients with ground level falls 60 years and older during a seven-year period from January 2011 to December 2017. Patients home medication list was analyzed to record any active controlled substances according to the Drug Enforcement Agency. Age, gender, controlled substance, total hospital days, total intensive care unit days, vent days, discharge status, discharge destination, and injury severity score were observed. Comparisons were analyzed using T-tests, Anova, Chi square, and logistic regression.

Results: 5930 patients were included. Almost half of the patients were taking controlled substances (45%), 67% of those were females. Total hospital days, Injury severity score and mortality outcome were not significant between groups. Intensive care unit days (ICU), days on mechanical ventilation, and discharge destination were found to be significant for patients taking controlled substances versus those not taking controlled substances. The mean length stay in the ICU was 0.5 versus 0.38 (P= 0.01). The mean length of vent days was 0.23 versus 0.12 (P= 0.01). These patients were also more likely to be discharged to short or long term care facilities versus patients not taking controlled substances (X2 (1, N= 5692,) = 12.61 P= 0.0003).

Conclusion: In our study patients 60 years and older taking controlled substances pre-injury experienced increased ICU stay, vent days and were more likely to be discharged to a facility when compared to those not taking controlled substances.

abstract_title: Impact of Mental Health Services on Violent Reinjury for Female Victims of Penetrating Trauma
author_block: M. Y. Neufeld<sup>1</sup>, M. G. Janeway<sup>1</sup>, L. M. Jackson<sup>2</sup>, E. G. Plaitano<sup>3</sup>, A. Garcia<sup>1</sup>, L. C. Allee<sup>1</sup>, T. Dechert<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Sanchez<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston University School of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Naval Medical Center San Diego,General Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Boston University,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Victims of violence face lasting mental health impacts following their physical injury. Additionally, many are exposed to violent reinjury. Women who have experienced a violent injury have been shown to be at higher risk for developing mental health conditions after trauma and are frequently trapped in cycles of interpersonal violence. To address this, our institution established a novel Community Violence Response Team (CVRT) in 2011, imbedded within the trauma surgery division, to provide mental health services to victims of violence. This study aims to describe the implementation of CVRT within its first 5 years specifically among female victims of violence-related penetrating trauma and determine its efficacy in decreasing violent reinjury in this population. 

Methods: Retrospective review of all female patients presenting to our urban level-one trauma center for violence-related injury from 2011 - 2015 (N=383). Sub-analysis included only those patients presenting after penetrating trauma (N=148). Demographic, index trauma, and CVRT service data were gathered from departmental databases. Hospitalization and reinjury details were retrieved from electronic health records. The relationship between receiving CVRT services and violent injury readmission within one year was evaluated with univariable and multivariable logistic regression.

Results: CVRT saw approximately 75% of known eligible female patients by year five of implementation. For our specific population of interest there was a significant negative association between receiving CVRT and violent reinjury readmission at one year [β=-0.77(SE 0.38) p=0.0403], with an approximate 80% decrease in the odds of violent reinjury as the cause for readmission within 1 year [OR 0.21, (95% CI 0.05,0.93)]. When adjusted for confounders including age and pre-existing mental illness, there remained a negative association, though it no longer reached statistical significance [b=-1.67(SE=0.87), OR=0.19(95% CI 0.03,1.04) p=0.0555].

Conclusion: Preliminary analysis demonstrates that female CVRT recipients with index violence-related penetrating trauma were less likely to be readmitted for violent reinjury at one year. Provision of long-term mental health care appears to have a positive impact on trauma-related outcomes, though further evaluation of CVRT over subsequent years is necessary.

abstract_title: Impact of Multimodal Pain Control on Inpatient and Outpatient Opioid Use in Trauma Patients
author_block: C. D. Philpott<sup>4</sup>, K. E. Singer<sup>2</sup>, A. Bercz<sup>2</sup>, T. Phillips<sup>4</sup>, D. Hanseman<sup>2</sup>, M. E. Droege<sup>4</sup>, M. D. Goodman<sup>2</sup>, A. T. Makley<sup>2</sup> <sup>2</sup>University Of Cincinnati,College Of Medicine,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>UC Health: University of Cincinnati Medical Center,Department Of Pharmacy Services,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Opioid abuse has become a crisis in the United States and several studies have indicated that perioperative opioid use can lead to addiction. Multimodal analgesia protocols have been implemented after trauma to reduce opioid usage. We investigated the impact of an updated multimodal analgesia protocol on inpatient and outpatient opioid usage for acute pain management in trauma. 

Methods:  A retrospective study was conducted of patients admitted to the trauma surgery service at an academic, Level 1 trauma center between September 2017-February 2018 (prior to the updated multimodal analgesia protocol; “early" cohort) and October 2018-April 2019 (after the updated multimodal analgesia protocol; “late" cohort). Cohorts were separated by 6 months to mitigate the influence of the summer season and allow for protocol establishment. Patients who required intubation were excluded. Charts were queried for demographic data, length of stay, injury severity score (ISS), and analgesic doses administered during hospitalization. An outpatient controlled substance registry was utilized to capture opioid oral morphine milligram equivalents (MME) and gabapentin prescriptions dispensed to patients in the 6 months after injury.  

Results: A total of 620 patients were eligible for inclusion (295 early, 325 late). No significant differences were appreciated in demographic factors including race, age, and gender; however, the late cohort had a median ISS of 13 (interquartile range [IQR] 9-17) compared to the earlier cohort ISS of 10 (9-17) (p=0.048). Intravenous hydromorphone usage decreased from 2mg (0-7mg) in the early cohort to 1mg (0-5mg) in the late cohort (p=0.02). Similarly, oxycodone usage decreased from 45mg (10-110mg) to 30mg (0-80mg) (p=0.01). Concurrently, gabapentin usage increased from 0 mg (0-0mg) in the early cohort to 400mg (0-1700mg) in the late cohort (p<0.01). Use of other non-opioid adjuncts, such as acetaminophen and methocarbamol also increased. Patients in the late cohort were prescribed statistically fewer MMEs than the early cohort at discharge (p<0.05). However, incidence of gabapentin prescribing increased significantly from 6.1% of patients in the early cohort to 16% of patients in the late cohort (p<0.01). No differences were noted between cohorts in opioid or gabapentin use at 6 months. 

Conclusion: Implementation of an updated multimodal analgesia protocol decreased hydromorphone and oxycodone use while increasing gabapentin usage both inpatient and outpatient. This suggests that while reducing opioid usage in-hospital is critical to reducing outpatient usage, multimodal pain protocols may also lead to a substantial increase in gabapentin prescriptions and continued utilization after discharge.

abstract_title: Alcohol is Not Associated with Increased Mortality in Adolescent Traumatic Brain Injury Patients
author_block: R. Algeo<sup>1</sup>, A. Grigorian<sup>1</sup>, C. Kuza<sup>2</sup>, T. Chin<sup>1</sup>, M. Donnelly<sup>1</sup>, A. Kong<sup>1</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine,Orange, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  It has been shown that adult patients presenting after a traumatic brain injury (TBI) with a positive serum alcohol screen may have improved neurological outcomes and mortality. However, there is a paucity of data regarding the association of a positive alcohol screen and outcomes in adolescent patients with TBI. We hypothesize that adolescent TBI patients with a positive alcohol screen on admission have improved mortality compared to those with a negative alcohol screen similarly to adults. 

Methods:  The Trauma Quality Improvement Program (year 2017) was queried for patients aged 13-17 presenting with a TBI (ICB-10 diagnosis) and a documented serum alcohol screen. Patients with missing information regarding the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score on admission and presence/absence of midline shift on imaging were excluded. A multivariable logistic regression analysis for mortality was performed.

Results: From 2,553 adolescent TBI patients with an alcohol screen, 220 (8.6%) were positive for serum alcohol. Patients with positive alcohol had a similar injury severity score to patients with negative alcohol (median 17 vs. 17, p=0.33). Compared to patients negative for alcohol, patients with a positive alcohol screen had an increased rate of GCS score of 8 or less on admission (45.4% vs. 38.1%, p=0.036). After controlling for covariates, adolescent TBI patients with positive alcohol screen were associated with similar risk of mortality compared to patients with a negative alcohol screen (p=0.50) (Table A).

Conclusion: Over 8% of adolescent TBI patients screened positive for alcohol on admission.  Contrary to adult data, this study demonstrates that adolescent TBI patients with a positive alcohol screen had a similar associated risk of mortality compared to patients with a negative alcohol screen. Future prospective research is needed to confirm our results.

abstract_title: UltraMassive Blood Product Transfusion: Could Machine Learning Model a Cutoff?
author_block: C. R. Ward<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Sikora<sup>1</sup>, F. Chea<sup>1</sup>, E. Moore<sup>1</sup>, J. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, R. N. Smith<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The primary objective was to determine survival after ultramassive transfusion of blood products (> 20 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) or whole blood (WB) within the first 24 hours of initiation) with machine learning. 

Methods: A retrospective chart review of patients hospitalized for trauma, GI bleeding and burns at an urban level 1 Trauma Center (May 2018-May 2020) with the above criteria was conducted. A predictive model was created using machine learning (ML) with the primary endpoint of all-cause mortality, and secondary endpoints of hours survival post transfusion, hospital length of stay (LOS), ICU LOS and mechanical ventilation days. Variables included injury severity score, Glasgow coma score, number of operations, total blood products, shock index, time in ED, mechanism of injury and if the patient was given TXA, FACTOR VII, DDAVP, PCC, or other procoagulants. P-value < 0.05 and R2 > 0.6 was considered significant. An interactive user interface of the model was then created to input individual data.

Results: One hundred and four patients were included, the majority being male (n=79, 76%), black (n=72, 72%) and traumatically injured (n=96, 96%) with a median age of 32 [IQR 25-75]. Median total units of blood products transfused = 66 [IQR 50.5-118.5]. No single variable independently predicted the study outcomes. Using ML, a 12-variable model for all-cause mortality resulted in a logistic regression accuracy score of 0.714-0.857. When modeling hours survived, hospital LOS, ICU LOS, and mechanical ventilation days, R2 values were 0.36, 0.36, 0.24 and 0.27. Overall mortality was 49% (n=51) with the majority of patients dying within 3 hours (Figure).

Conclusion: Number of transfused blood products alone does not predict mortality.  Rather, this 12-variable mortality risk calculator allows better prediction of survival, particularly in individuals who survive beyond the first 3 hours of massive transfusion.

abstract_title: Repeat Imaging of Blunt Hepatic Injuries: Standard Protocol or Physician Discretion?
author_block: K. L. Fletcher<sup>4</sup>, L. L. Perea<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Morgan<sup>1</sup>, B. W. Otaibi<sup>5</sup>, K. E. Bresz<sup>2</sup>, J. P. Hazelton<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Hospital,Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery,Lancaster, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Hospital,Research Institute,Lancaster, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Division Of Trauma, Acute Care And Critical Care Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>5</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early repeat imaging in the management of blunt hepatic injuries is used to identify potential delayed complications. Prior studies have suggested that routine follow up imaging is unnecessary, particularly in patients who are managed nonoperatively. Despite this, there is institutional variance in regards to the utilization and timing of repeat imaging in this patient population. This study examines the rate of delayed complications (pseudoaneurysm, increased hemoperitoneum, injury progression, bile leak/biloma, abscess, vascular thrombosis, fulminant liver failure, etc.) and subsequent intervention (operative or interventional radiologic) in patients with blunt hepatic injuries who undergo repeat imaging either due to a standard protocol or due to physician discretion.

Methods: A nine-year (2011-2019), retrospective, two-institution study was performed of adult patients (≥18 years) with blunt hepatic injuries. Patients were grouped based on whether repeat imaging was performed, and reason for reimaging: standard protocol (SP) or physician discretion (PD) based on clinical findings. The incidence of organ specific delayed complications and subsequent need for intervention was examined.

Results: Of 365 blunt liver injuries included in the study, 122 (33.4%) underwent repeat imaging [computed tomography (CT), n=116 or ultrasound (US), n=6]. A total of 50 (41%) patients had repeat imaging due to SP and 72 (59%) due to PD. The mean time to repeat imaging was shorter in the SP group versus the PD group (4.7 ± 6.3 days vs 7.6 ± 8 days, p=0.034). Complications were found in 30 (25%) patients undergoing repeat imaging, [SP n=10, PD n=20; p=0.395].  Interventions were performed in 12 (40%) patients with identified complications on repeat imaging [SP n=2, PD n=10; p=0.120].

Conclusion: Our data demonstrates that repeat imaging due to a standard protocol occurred earlier in a patient’s hospitalization than that performed due to physician discretion. One quarter of patients who were reimaged were found to have a delayed complication, with nearly half requiring intervention. Despite this, there was no difference in the incidence of clinically significant delayed complications or interventions between groups when compared by reason for scan. This suggests that it is safe to rely on physician discretion in prompting repeat imaging in blunt hepatic injuries.

abstract_title: Financial Triage in Medicine: Insurance Disparities and Burden of Care for Firearm-Related Trauma
author_block: D. J. Greenberg<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Barrett<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Hu<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Lukan<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Erie County Medical Center,Surgery,Buffalo, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo,Medicine,Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although medical guidelines have forbidden the denial of trauma care based on payer status, research has shown that a patient’s ability to pay can impact the entire supply chain of healthcare delivery. While the reasons for such disparities are multifactorial, the amortized cost of care, combined with lack of hospitalization reimbursement, presents with significant resource depletion and financial pressure to an institution, subsequently warranting alterations to current triaging practices. Our objective is to evaluate the impact of insurance status on injury burden, hospital resource utilization, and discharge disposition of trauma patients after a firearm-related injury.

Methods: This was a retrospective analysis of a local level 1 trauma center registry consisting of 1450 patients with firearm injuries between 2009-2019. Outcome measures stratified by varying categories of insurance type were as follows: Demographics, Injury Severity Score (ISS), Length Of Stay (LOS), Discharge Disposition, Mortality, Reimbursement Ratio, Procedural Quanitity. Statistical tests used were ANOVA, correlation, logistic regression, chi-square, paired t-test (P<0.05).

Results: Self-pay patients were younger (25.9 years), males (95.2%), black (81.2%), and more severely injured (ISS 17.9) when compared to Private (28.4 years, 60.7% male, 70.2% black, ISS 14.4) and Medicaid (27.1 years, 95.2% Male, 80.2% black, ISS 14.7) insured groups (P<0.05). Self-pay patients had shorter hospital stays (4.6 days) relative to privately insured (8.52 days) and Medicaid patients (10.42 days), (P<0.05). Differences were less pronounced when excluding those dead on arrival. Of those who survived to discharge, self-pay patients were least likely to be discharged with post-care service, followed by Medicaid and privately insured patients (P<.001). Inflation-adjusted costs of initial inpatient hospitalizations were proportionally highest among Medicaid, followed by self-pay, and privately insured patients (P<0.05). While private insurance made up 27.6% of the cases, it contributed over 50% of all reimbursement.

Conclusion: Payer status (and, by proxy, economic incentive) may explain disparities in the quantity/quality of care during inpatient and post-acute services. Future research must consider several points: Hospitals’ ability to obtain insurance coverage for those who die shortly after admission; Payer source definition and categorization; Procedural/Surgical intervention quantification versus quality; Longitudinal correlation of profitability inflection points and actuarial survival; Transitioning payment assessment/approval leading to discharge prioritization/delays.

abstract_title: The Changing Landscape of Penetrating Trauma in Older Adults: Racial Disparity and Increasing Volume
author_block: A. Elegbede<sup>1</sup>, A. McCormick<sup>3</sup>, A. Brandolino<sup>1</sup>, J. Streams<sup>2</sup>, T. DeRoon Cassini<sup>1</sup>, M. De Moya<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College of Wisconsin,Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery/Department Of Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery/Department Of Surgery,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Luther Midelfort Mayo Health System,Eau Claire, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The United States is projected to have significant growth of its older population over the next several decades, which will impact national healthcare delivery and annual expenditures. Currently there is little known regarding the incidence and outcomes of traumatic penetrating injury in patients 55 and older, as this population is at higher risk of morbidity and mortality after trauma. The objective of this study is to quantify the volume of penetrating trauma in older patients over time and compare two cohorts 10 years apart to characterize and visualize the demographic correlates significant within this population. We hypothesize that the incidence of penetrating trauma has increased in the last 10 years and that African American patients more likely to sustain penetrating injury.

Methods:  Trauma patients ≥ 55 years old were identified in the trauma registry of an urban, Level 1 trauma center from 2005 - 2017. Two cohorts were compared for trends, 2005 - 2007 (Cohort 1) and 2015 - 2017 (Cohort 2). Variables included: age, sex, ethnicity, ISS, LOS, ICU stay, mechanism of injury (MOI), intentionality, zip code, and mortality. Descriptive analyses were performed as well as multivariate logistic regressions. Maps for aggregated patient characteristics were created using ArcGIS with residency zip codes.

Results: 289 patients met inclusion criteria from 2005-2017, with increase in volume over time. For our cohort analysis, Cohort 1 included 50 subjects and Cohort 2 included 103 subjects. Comparison between both cohorts demonstrated decreased mortality over this time period (28% vs 12.6%, p  = 0.019). Gunshot wound (GSW) as MOI was significantly predominant in Cohort 1 whereas stab wound was more predominant in Cohort 2 (p = 0.024). For the entire population of patients, logistic regression analysis revealed that a greater likelihood of mortality is significantly associated with increasing age, GSW mechanism, suicide attempt, increasing ISS, and a longer ICU stay (p <0.01). Heat maps demonstrated a clustering effect of African American ethnicity and stab wound as the MOI (Figure 1).

Conclusion: The volume of older patients with penetrating trauma is increasing with a preponderance in African-American communities and a shift from GSW to stabbing as the MOI, which is associated with an improvement in mortality.

abstract_title: Factors Leading to Violent Death in the US Incarcerated Population
author_block: A. N. Moore<sup>1</sup>, H. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Velopulos<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver,GI, Trauma, And Endocrine Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Physical violence is pervasive in United States prisons and jails and can lead to violent death. The goal of this project is to characterize trauma-associated deaths of the American incarcerated population. We also sought to determine what proportion of victims received emergent medical care prior to death, hypothesizing that fewer incarcerated victims would receive higher levels of care.

Methods:  This is a report utilizing multi-state National Violent Death Reporting System data from the years 2015-2017, excluding states that did not collect data about hospitalizations following injury.  Deaths that occurred to incarcerated victims were compared to those who were known to be non-incarcerated. Level of care that the victim received was characterized by if the patient was seen by emergency medical services (EMS), in the emergency room (ED), or hospitalized prior to death, with the latter considered higher levels of care. For both victims of suicide and of homicide, propensity score matching (PSM) was used to compare the level of care received by incarcerated victims to non-incarcerated access with similar age, sex, race/ethnicity, weapon type, and state where the incident occurred. 

Results: There were 101,054 victims included in the analysis, with 1229 (1.2%) specified as incarcerated at the time of fatal injury. 64.4% of the included deaths were suicides, 23.1% were homicides, and 1.3% were due to legal interventions.
