Incarcerated homicide and suicide victims were more often male, and suicide victims were younger than the non-suicide population. For suicide, the proportion of minority victims was higher in the incarcerated population as compared to the non-incarcerated population, but the opposite was true of homicide victims. For the incarcerated population who died by suicide, hanging was the primary means, contrasted with 26.8% of non-incarcerated victims. Firearms were more commonly used in the non-incarcerated population for both suicide victims and homicide victims. After PSM, we found that incarcerated victims received higher levels of care after matching for suicide while there was no difference in level of care after matching for homicide  (Table). 

Conclusion: Contrary to our hypothesis, we found that incarcerated homicide victims received similar levels of care compared to non-incarcerated victims following lethal injury. Incarcerated suicide victims received higher levels of care. This examination shows that suicide deaths disproportionately victimize minorities during incarceration. Weapon types varied across groups with homicide weapons more varied, consistent with lack of firearm resources in the incarcerated setting. Our findings reinforce that violence prevention methods should be tailored to specific populations.

abstract_title: Using the Revised Trauma Score to Identify Patients Who Benefit from Whole Blood
author_block: B. J. Hazen<sup>2</sup>, J. Nguyen<sup>3,4</sup>, R. B. Gelbard<sup>2,4</sup>, C. J. Dente<sup>2,4</sup>, B. M. Tracy<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,Trauma, Critical Care, Burn,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>Morehouse School of Medicine,Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>4</sup>Grady Memorial Hospital,Acute Care Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Cold-stored, group O+ whole blood (WB) may provide a survival benefit compared to component therapy (CT) alone.  Using data immediately available during trauma resuscitations, we sought to determine which patients have the greatest survival benefit from WB. 

Methods:  We retrospectively reviewed patients from 2018-2019 who received emergency release blood products during their resuscitation.  We excluded patients < 16 years, women, and patients who died in the trauma bay. Propensity score matching was performed (1 WB: 2 CT) using age, mechanism (blunt/penetrating), and revised trauma score (RTS).  RTS combines respiratory rate, GCS, and systolic blood pressure.  Median time until death for all expired patients was determined; any patient who expired by the corresponding upper interquartile range time was classified as a mortality for analysis.  Recursive partitioning (classification tree analysis) was then used to split patients into groups with significantly different mortality rates based on the predictor variables of RTS and WB vs CT.  

Results: 141 patients comprised the matched cohort; 47 WB and 94 CT.  Median age was 33 (IQR 25-49) years, mean RTS 5.8 (1.9), and 58.9% had penetrating injury.  There was no difference in ISS between groups (26 vs 26.5, p = 0.71).  38 patients expired with a median time until death of 1 (IQR 1-5) days; 81.6% (31/38) died within 5 days of admission. Using 5-day mortality rates, recursive partitioning first split the cohort at an RTS of 4.3, then split the RTS < 4.3 group at transfusion type. Mortality was significantly lower for patients who received WB compared to CT alone (25% vs 60%, p = 0.04).  

Conclusion: Patients with lower RTS who received WB had a significantly lower 5-day mortality rate.  The RTS may be a useful tool to determine who benefits most from WB transfusion during civilian trauma resuscitations.

abstract_title: Blunt cerebrovascular injury in low energy cervical spine fractures: clinically significant?
author_block: M. Lung<sup>2</sup>, C. Galet<sup>1</sup>, M. Lilienthal<sup>1</sup>, D. Skeete<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Iowa,Acute Care Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Iowa City, IOWA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa,Carver College Of Medicine,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Clinical relevance of blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) involving low energy mechanisms of injury (LEMI) compared to high energy mechanisms of injury (HEMI) remains unclear. Herein, we evaluated BCVI clinical significance by assessing BCVI incidence and outcomes in patients suffering LEMI and HEMI.

Methods:  Medical records of adult patients admitted with cervical spine fractures between July 2015 and June 2018 were retrospectively reviewed. Patients with single spinous process, osteophyte, and chronic fractures were excluded. Demographics, comorbidities, injury, screening and treatment-related data, iatrogenic complications, and mortality were collected. Univariate analysis was performed. P < 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Four hundred and eight patients were screened for BCVI, of which 54 were positive. Compared to HEMI cases (n = 325), LEMI cases (n = 83) were mostly female (65.1% vs. 31.7%, p < 0.001), older (79.7± 13.8 vs. 52.3 ± 19.9, p <0.001), and already on anticoagulants (65.1% vs. 28.9%, p < 0.001). More LEMI cases presented fractures at the C1-C3 level (79.5% vs. 53.8%, p < 0.001). BCVI rates were similar (13.3% vs. 13.2%; p = 0.89). The vertebral artery was the affected vessel in all LEMI cases and in 90.7 % of the HEMI cases with no significant difference in BCVI grades. One HEMI case developed acute kidney injury because of BCVI screening. Four HEMI cases developed BCVI-related stroke with two related mortalities. No LEMI case developed stroke-related complications.

Conclusion: BCVI rates were similar in both groups using our institutional screening protocol. Most LEMI cases were on anticoagulants prior to injury and none developed BCVI-related stroke, suggesting that pre-admission antithrombotic therapy may replace BCVI screening in that population. Future studies are warranted to test this hypothesis.

abstract_title: Outcomes of THC Positive Trauma Patients with Traumatic Brain Injury
author_block: A. Ali<sup>1</sup>, O. Olubowale<sup>1</sup>, D. Tatum<sup>2</sup>, P. McGrew<sup>1</sup>, J. Duchesne<sup>1</sup>, S. Taghavi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine,New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>2</sup>Our Lady of the Lake Regional Medical Center,Baton Rouge, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a significant source of morbidity and mortality in the United States. Recent shifts in state legislation have increased use of recreational and medical marijuana. While cannabinoids and tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) have anti-inflammatory effects, whether pre-injury use of THC impacts severe TBI is unknown. We hypothesized pre-injury THC use in trauma patients suffering TBI would not improve patient outcomes.

Methods: The American College of Surgeons Trauma Quality Improvement Program (TQIP) was used to identify patients aged ≥18 years with severe TBI (Glasgow coma scale (GCS) ≤ 8) in 2017. Patients with missing drug screen information or positive for drug and/or alcohol use besides THC were excluded. Demographic variables and injury patterns were examined using Chi Square analysis for categorical variables and the Wilcoxon-Kruskal-Wallis test for continuous variables.  Multivariate logistic regression was used to determine if THC use was associated with clinical outcomes.

Results: A total of 4,426 patients that met inclusion criteria, of which 774 (17%) were positive for THC only. Compared to patients with no drug or alcohol use, THC+ patients were younger (median age 27 years vs. 54, p < 0.001) and more likely to be male (86% vs. 70%, p < 0.001), uninsured (20% vs. 12%, p < 0.001), nonwhite (38% vs. 26%, p < 0.001), and victims of assault (15% vs. 5%, p < 0.001) or firearm injury (19% vs. 7%, p < 0.001). There was no difference in initial GCS (median 3, p = 0.214) between the groups, although THC+ patients had significantly longer intensive care lengths of stay (median 6 days vs. 5, p = 0.01), days on a ventilator (median 5 days vs. 4, p = 0.04), and hospital days (median 9 days vs. 7, p = 0.01). THC+ patients had significantly lower mortality rates (42.9% vs. 51.5%, p < 0.001) and, although not statistically significant, fewer pulmonary embolisms (PE) (0.5% vs. 1.3%, p = 0.08), fewer strokes (1.2% vs. 2.4%, p = 0.05), and higher rates of ventilator-associated pneumonia (7.5% vs. 5.7%, p = 0.06). On multivariate analysis controlled for age, injury severity, method of payment, gender, race, and THC use, being THC+ was not associated with mortality (odds ratio (OR): 0.95; 95% CI: 0.78 – 1.14, p=0.56), but was associated with decreased odds of PE (OR 0.29; 95% CI: 0.09 – 0.76, p = 0.02) and stroke/cerebrovascular accident (OR 0.44; 95% CI: 0.20 – 0.86, p = 0.03).

Conclusion: Pre-injury THC use may be associated with decreased clot burden that leads to less PE and cerebrovascular accidents in patients with TBI. Further research in pathophysiological mechanisms related to THC use and TBI are needed.

abstract_title: 30-Day Readmission and Outcomes after Fenestrated versus Standard Endovascular Aortic Aneurysm Repair
author_block: J. B. Jennings<sup>1</sup>, J. Bath<sup>1</sup>, P. Singh<sup>1</sup>, T. R. Vogel<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Missouri,Division Of Vascular Surgery,Columbia, MO, USA

abstract_title: Understanding the Role of Frailty to Discharge Disposition after Major Lower Extremity Amputation
author_block: J. Heard<sup>1</sup>, K. Kempe<sup>1</sup>, V. Pandit<sup>1</sup>, T. Hasenstein<sup>1</sup>, S. Vang<sup>1</sup>, H. Kim<sup>1</sup>, W. Jennings<sup>1</sup>, P. Nelson<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine,Surgery, Vascular,Tulsa, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Discharge disposition in patients undergoing lower extremity amputation is complex. Frailty Syndrome has been shown to impact patient outcomes. We aimed to assess frailty and discharge disposition in geriatric patients undergoing amputation of the lower limb.

Methods: We conducted a 3-year retrospective analysis of the NSQIP-database (National Surgical Quality Improvement Program) including all geriatric (age≥65y) patients who underwent major amputation of lower limb (below or above knee). Non-home discharge (NHD) was defined as discharge to skilled nursing facility (SNF) or rehabilitation center (RC). Outcomes measure was NHD.

Results: A total of 4,158 patients (above knee: 43%; below knee: 57%) were included. Overall 60% had significant frailty indices (28% frail and 32% pre frail). Two-thirds required NHD (31% SNF; 36% RC). Frail and pre-frail patients were more likely to have a NHD. (Table 1) On sub-analysis, frail patients (OR [95% CI]: 1.3 [1.1-3.5], p=0.02) were more likely to be discharge to a SNF while pre-frail patients (OR [95% CI]: 1.2 [1.05-5.5], p=0.04) were more likely to be discharged to a RC independent of the type of amputation and insurance status.

Conclusion: Frailty Syndrome affects NHD in patients undergoing lower extremity amputation. Frailty should be incorporated as an assessment tool for disposition planning post lower extremity amputation. Assessing frailty can help optimize patient care and allocation of health care resources.

abstract_title: Short-Term Concerns Primarily Determine Patient Preference for Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Repair
author_block: J. M. Jones<sup>1</sup>, Y. D. Hu<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Sensenig<sup>1</sup>, K. S. Mehta<sup>3</sup>, J. L. Goldwag<sup>3</sup>, J. A. Barnes<sup>3</sup>, P. P. Goodney<sup>2,3</sup>, M. A. Eid<sup>2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Geisel School Of Medicine at Dartmouth,Hanover, NH, USA <sup>2</sup>White River Junction VA Medical Center,Department Of Surgery And VA Outcomes Group,White River Junction, VT, USA <sup>3</sup>Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center,Hanover, NH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Elective repair of abdominal aortic aneurysms may be performed through open or endovascular approaches, but the factors influencing repair-type preference are not well characterized. Here we performed a qualitative analysis of open-ended questions to better understand factors influencing patient preference within the Preference for Open Versus Endovascular Repair of AAA (PROVE-AAA) Trial.

Methods: PROVE-AAA enrolled 236 veterans from 20 centers in the Veterans Administration system. 21 veterans (9%) provided open-ended responses on the main factor influencing their preference, and 47 veterans (20%) provided responses regarding other aspects of care that influenced their decision (i.e. secondary factors). Transcribed responses were independently coded by a team of three researchers. These codes were compared and used to define a set of mutually exclusive themes in an iterative process via discussion and consensus agreement. At the final step, themes were categorized into four groups: Short-Term Concerns, Long-Term Concerns, Advice & Experience, and Other.

Results: Eight themes were identified for the main factor influencing patient preference for type of aneurysm repair. Patients most frequently described Short-Term Concerns (23) as their primary influence, with themes including Post-op Complications, Hospitalization & Recovery, and Intraoperative Concerns. A total of six patient responses were categorized as Long-Term Concerns (i.e. Survival), and only five responses indicated Advice & Experience as a primary factor. Seven patients listed multiple concerns.   Ten themes were identified as secondary factors influencing patient preference. The single most common theme was “None” (17). Responses categorized as Long-Term Concerns were more prevalent (20), which included codes such as Survival, Risk for Follow-up Interventions, and Durability of Repair, and Pre-existing Conditions.  As compared to primary motivating factors, there were fewer responses categorized as Short-Term concerns (13) and more responses categorized as Advice or Experience (10). Of note, one of the most prevalent themes encountered was an overall Lack of Information (10), which included statements regarding a desire for more information.

Conclusion: This qualitative analysis suggests that short-term concerns relating to the procedure and recovery are more often the primary factor influencing patient preference, while long-term concerns play a more secondary role. Vascular surgeons should consider this information when discussing repair options with patients in order to reach an optimal shared decision.

abstract_title: Traumatic Femoral Artery Injuries and Predictors of Compartment Syndrome: A Nationwide Analysis
author_block: S. Asmar<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, M. Chehab<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, M. Khurrum<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, B. Joseph<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Emergency Surgery, And Burns/Department Of Surgery/College Of Medicine,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The femoral artery is commonly injured following lower extremity trauma. If not identified early and addressed properly, it can lead to compartment syndrome (CS) and limb amputation. The aim of this study is to examine traumatic femoral artery injuries and identify risk factors for the development of lower extremity CS.

Methods:  Adult (≥18 years) patients who presented with traumatic femoral artery injuries were identified in the Trauma Quality Improvement Program 2017. Patients were stratified into two groups, those with evidence of lower extremity compartment syndrome (CS) and those without CS (NCS), for comparison. Multivariate regression analysis was performed to identify risk factors for the development of lower extremity CS.

Results: A total of 1,297 adult trauma patients with femoral artery injury were identified. Mean age was 36±15 years, 86% were male, and 68% had penetrating injuries. Median extremity abbreviated injury scale (AIS) was 3 [3,4], and median injury severity score (ISS) was 27 [22-41]. A total of 68 (5.2%) patients were diagnosed with CS of the lower extremity, 66 (97.1%) of those patients underwent fasciotomy and one (1.5%) patient eventually had an amputation. On multivariate regression analysis, concomitant femoral vein, femoral nerve, and popliteal artery injuries and early need for blood transfusions were independent risk factors for the development of CS (aOR 3.1, 3.8, 4.3, and 2.5 respectively). (Table 1)

Conclusion: CS following traumatic femoral artery injury is a relatively uncommon finding. Concomitant popliteal arterial injury should raise the concern for CS. Physicians must maintain a high index of suspicion and should consider prophylactic fasciotomy in the setting of injury to the femoral sheath.

abstract_title: Patients Treated for Pelvic Cancers are not At-Risk for Accelerated Growth of Aortoiliac Aneurysms
author_block: J. M. Allan<sup>1</sup>, Z. Novak<sup>1</sup>, E. Spangler<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Aortoiliac aneurysms (AIA) involve the loss of the mechanical integrity in the vessel wall due to a multifactorial pathology. AIAs are recommended to have prophylactic repair in medically fit patients for prevention of rupture when meeting size threshold of concern. Additionally, prophylactic repair of aortoiliac aneurysms may be indicated at sizes lower than usual thresholds in cases of accelerated expansion rates. Patients exposed to toxic substances may represent an at-risk population for more rapidly progressing vascular pathologies and aneurysm growth. The goal of the project is to determine if patients subjected to prostate and bladder cancer treatment have accelerated growth of aortoiliac aneurysms and compare the growth rates of populations receiving different treatment modalities.

Methods:  A retrospective chart review was conducted from a large, tertiary medical center consisting of a cohort of 284 patients who were identified as having a bladder or prostate biopsy in the years 2015-2019. Following exclusion of 120 patients with only a single computed tomography (CT) imaging scan, we identified 164 patients who received treatment for bladder (47) or prostate (117) cancer with 2 or more CT scans. CT images were analyzed for maximal infrarenal aortic segment and right and left iliac segment diameters prior to treatment and following treatment to determine growth rates. Cancer treatment regimens and demographics were recorded to differentiate between group and sub-group growth rates.

Results: Our cohort had a mean age of 65.7 ± 8.6, 6.8% female and 93.2% male, 52.5% white and 40% non-white, 70.6% hypertensive, 72% current/former smoker, 27% with diabetes milieus, 4% with COPD, and 49.1% on a statin. Median [IQR] imaging follow-up was 2.8 years [1.3-5.0] overall, 2.8 [1.6-5.6] in bladder cancer, and 2.8 [1.2-4.9] in prostate cancer. Interestingly, we did find high rates of baseline iliac ectasia (diameters in the 10-15 mm range) in 50% of the cohort (n=80) and iliac aneurysms (diameter>15mm) in an additional 46% (n=74) of the cohort, but low rates of AAA in the cohort (n=5, 3%). Iliac aneurysms prior to malignancy treatment were more common in prostate cancer patients (56% vs 22%, p<.001). Over the time studied, growth rates in infrarenal aorta (0.72 mm/year) or iliac segments (right common iliac artery (CIA), 0.55 mm/year; left CIA, 0.79 mm/year) did not exceed 1 mm/year. Patients undergoing treatment via combined radiation and chemotherapy trended toward a higher growth aortic rate of 1.92 mm/year (p=.66) than other malignancy therapies.

Conclusion: We did not identify accelerated aortic or iliac degeneration in patients being treated for pelvic malignancy. Our results are limited by size of the cohort and shorter duration of follow-up available to date. However, we identified a potentially novel, at-risk population with higher rates of baseline ectasia and aneurysms which warrants further studies on aneurysm growth.

abstract_title: Correlation Between Duplex vs Angiogram in Infrapopliteal Disease
author_block: M. Guerges<sup>1</sup>, K. Singh<sup>1</sup>, J. Deitch<sup>1</sup>, J. Schor<sup>1</sup>, M. Ayad<sup>1</sup>, J. Deitch<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Staten Island University Hospital,Department Of Vascular Surgery,Staten Island, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Duplex ultrasonography (DUS) is readily available and often used as the first diagnostic test for patients with PAD however because the examination is operator-dependent by nature it has obvious limitations. Ultrasound findings can often lead to performing unnecessary diagnostic angiograms. DUS is highly sensitive for evaluating femoral and popliteal segments however evaluation of the tribal vessels has not been well studied. Our aim was to correlate the accuracy of DUS compared to angiography of the infrapopliteal segments.

Methods:

Methods:   This was a retrospective study from August 2019 to January 2020 analyzing three segments (anterior tibial artery, posterior tibial and peroneal) in patients who received a duplex study followed by conventional angiogram within a 30-day period. All visualized segments were graded as normal, severe disease or occluded based on color flow, degree of calcification and velocities on duplex and compared to percent stenosis or occlusion on angiograms. All studies were evaluated by an independent, RPVI accredited, vascular surgeon. The data was described using frequencies and percentages for categorical variables and means and standard deviations for quantitative variables. Comparisons between duplex ultrasound and angiography for each segment were made using Bowker’s test for symmetry. All statistical tests were two-sided. P-values <0.05 were considered significant. All statistical analyses were performed using SAS software (Statistical Analysis Systems Inc., Cary, NC, USA).

Results: 57 patients were included in the study and a total of 171 infrapopliteal segments were analyzed, 23 were female while 24 were male, Mean age was 67 years. Comorbidities included, 47 patients (82%) with diabetes, 47 (82%) with hypertension, 24 (43%) were smokers and 21 (38%) had a history of coronary artery disease. All patients suffered from tissue loss. Segments which were not visualized by duplex were not included in the statistical analysis. Of the anterior tibial segments studied, 76% were read as normal on duplex while 25% were noted to be normal on angiogram. Of the posterior tibial (PT) segments, 74% were read as normal on duplex, while 19% were read as normal on angiogram. 84% of peroneal segments were read as normal on duplex and 21% were read as normal on angiograms.  The symmetry test was statistically significant (p<0.001) for all three segments (Anterior tibial, posterior tibial and Peroneal), thus indicating disagreement between DUS and conventional angiography (i.e. we reject the null hypothesis of no difference between the two methods in identifying patients as normal, severe, and occluded).

Conclusion:Although widely used as a tool in assessing peripheral arterial disease, there are significant limitations of DUS especially when studying infrapopliteal disease. Significant disagreements were noted in this study between DUS and conventional angiogram where normal disease seen on duplex was noted to be severe or occluded on angiograms.  This suggests that one must approach infrapopliteal duplex findings of peripheral arterial disease with caution. Clinical correlation with physical exam and history should always be taken into consideration to see if further tests are needed. Further studies, with larger patient population is warranted.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Cryopreserved Allografts for Limb Salvage in Chronic Limb Threatening Ischemia
author_block: K. Mehta<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Barnes<sup>1</sup>, M. Eid<sup>1</sup>, P. Goodney<sup>1</sup>, N. Zacharias<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center,Vascular Surgery,Lebanon, NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  In patients with chronic limb threatening ischemia lacking suitable autologous vein, cryopreserved saphenous vein allografts represent an alternative conduit for bypass grafting. The existing literature suggests that long term patency of such bypass grafts is limited, however their role in limb salvage remains uncertain. The purpose of this study was to examine patency and amputation-free survival of cryopreserved saphenous vein allografts used for infrainguinal revascularization.   

Methods:  We conducted a retrospective review of patients who had infrainguinal bypass with cryopreserved saphenous vein allograft conduit for critical limb ischemia from 2004 to 2019. The primary endpoints of the study were primary patency and amputation-free survival. Secondary endpoints included perioperative complications and technical cost. Primary patency and amputation-free survival were assessed with Kaplan-Meier analysis.

Results: During the study period twenty five cryopreserved saphenous vein allograft bypasses were performed in 22 patients (12 male; median age 69.5). Indications for surgery included rest pain (60%) and/or tissue loss (88%). Fifteen patients had prior ipsilateral failed bypasses and no patients had adequate ipsilateral autologous saphenous vein available. Distal targets included above or below knee popliteal artery (40%) or tibial vessels (60%). The median follow up was 16 months (range 0-58 months). The median primary patency of cryopreserved allografts was 0.51 years. The median amputation-free survival was 1.2 years (Figure 1). When cryopreserved vein allografts were used for tissue loss, successful wound healing occurred in 50% (11/22) of cases. Perioperative complications included four early graft thromboses (16%), two major adverse cardiac events (8%), and one amputation (4%). The 30-day mortality rate was 0%. The mean total technical cost of these procedures was $51,438 ± 28,856.    

Conclusion: The use of cryopreserved saphenous vein allograft conduit in patients with chronic limb threatening ischemia appears to provide reasonable limb salvage rates in patients without alternate conduit options. The poor patency rates and high technical cost, however, suggest that judicious use of these conduits when no superior alternative exists should be employed to ensure optimal patient benefit.

abstract_title: Coping with Surgical Delay in the COVID-19 Pandemic: A Qualitative Analysis of Patient Perspectives
author_block: M. Anderson<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Brown<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Corriere<sup>2,3</sup>, N. Osborne<sup>2,3</sup>, M. Byrnes<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan Medicine,Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Michigan Medicine,Vascular Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 disrupted nearly every aspect of everyday life and shattered normalcy for most individuals. The postponement of non-emergent surgeries due to the pandemic, further perturbed normalcy and prevented restoration of day-to-day function for many individuals. This qualitative study attempts to understand how individuals who experienced surgical delay coped with living with severe cardiac or vascular disease and uncertainty of when surgery might be rescheduled.

Methods: Utilizing a phenomenological qualitative design, we interviewed 47 individuals who experienced a postponement of cardiac or vascular surgery due to the COVID-19 pandemic at a single institution. Data were analyzed iteratively and informed by phenomenological research methods.

Results: Participants in our study discussed their cardiovascular surgeries as a medical event that would restore normalcy to their lives and “cure” their disease. Patients described the stress associated with living with severe cardiovascular disease and the consequences of untreated disease, such as “[My aneurysm] is getting larger. It will burst. That stresses the hell out of me.” Because surgery was postponed, most often with an indeterminate reschedule date, patients felt left alone to manage the stress and uncertainty of their disease in abnormal times without provider input. Patients attempted to manage their symptoms on their own because, “those symptoms don't go away just because the surgery got postponed. Matter of fact, I even started paying attention to it even more. Then it gets scarier.” One patient described it as “kind of like living in a glass box with somebody outside of it that you can see has a rock in their hand. And there’s nothing you can do about it…” Diversion and distraction from the seriousness of their condition was a strategy for coping with their condition. Patients turned to music and television, or as one patient commented, “to get my mind off thinking of it, I just…I have Alexa.” Finally, an overwhelming number of patients relied on higher deities, such as God or philosophies of life such as, “it is what it is” and “Faith in Jesus is what keeps me going, keeps me from jumping off a tall building somewhere.”     Discussion: The elimination of elective surgeries during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic may have latent consequences that extend beyond the physical health of those impacted by delays.  These results underscore the importance of not only considering the traditional healthcare outcomes of surgical delay but also the significant psychological effects on those who have their procedures postponed in the setting of the pandemic.

abstract_title: Vascular Surgeons' Social Media Presence on Physician Review Websites in the SAVS Region
author_block: W. Clothier<sup>1</sup>, Q. Yan<sup>1</sup>, K. Jensen<sup>1</sup>, R. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, A. R. Langley<sup>1</sup>, Z. Jiang<sup>2</sup>, C. Goei<sup>1</sup>, M. G. Davies<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio,School Of Medicine,San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Shanghai Medical College Fudan University,Shanghai, China
abstract_body:
Introduction: The internet has become a popular platform for patients to obtain information and review the providers they interact with. However, little is known on the digital footprint of vascular surgeons and their interactivity with patients on social media. We aim to understand the activity of academic vascular surgeons on physician rating websites.

Methods: Information on attending vascular surgeons affiliated with vascular residencies or fellowships in the Southern Association for Vascular Surgery were collected. Websites containing physician ratings were obtained via literature review and google search. Open access websites that contain either qualitative or quantitative evaluation of vascular surgeons within the SAVS region were included. Ranking agencies and closed access websites were excluded. Ranking scores from each website were converted to standard 5-point scale for comparison. Data analysis was performed using R.

Results: A total of 6238 quantitative and 967 qualitative reviews were written for 287 physicians (236 males, 82%) across 16 websites that met inclusion criteria out of 62 websites screened. Surgeons in the SAVS region had a median of 8 (interquartile range: 7-10) profiles across 16 websites with only one surgeon having no web presence on any sites. The median number of quantitative ratings for each physician was 17 (interquartile range: 6-34, range: 1-137) and the median number of narrative reviews was 3 (interquartile range: 2-6, range: 1-28). Vitals®, WebMD® and Healthgrades® were the only three websites where over a quarter of the physicians were rated, and those rated had more than 5 ratings on average. The median score for quantitative reviews was 4.4 (interquartile range: 4.0-4.9). Most narrative reviews (78.4%, 758/967) were positive, but 20.2% were considered negative; only 1.4% were considered equivocal. No statistical difference was found in the number of quantitative reviews or overall average score in physicians with versus without social media profiles. No physicians responded to patient rating or narrative reviews.

Conclusion: Vascular representation on physician rating websites is varied with the majority of vascular surgeons only represented on the top half of the physician rating websites. The number of quantitative and qualitative reviews are low. No surgeons responded to reviews. The activity of vascular surgeons in this area of social media is low and reflects a small digital footprint that patients can reach and review.

abstract_title: Acute Type B Aortic Dissection early in-hospital outcome at a Single Institution
author_block: A. M. Um<sup>1</sup>, F. C. Razalan-Krause<sup>1</sup>, G. Tefera<sup>1</sup>, C. W. Acher<sup>1</sup>, P. DiMusto<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Division Of Vascular Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute type B aortic dissection (ATBAD) is a life-threatening condition that requires early diagnosis and management.  The objective of this study is to better understand the current in hospital outcomes of patients with ATBAD.  

Methods:  This is a retrospective chart review of patients admitted with the diagnosis of ATBAD over a period of 10 years (May 2010 to March 2020). All patients with the diagnosis of ATBAD are generally admitted to the vascular surgery service.  Patients who presented with acute symptoms and had evidence of a type B aortic dissection on Computed Tomographic Angiography (CTA) were included in the study while patients who presented with acute type A aortic dissection, intramural hematoma or penetrating aortic ulcer were excluded.  Initial management for all patients included beta blockade and vasodilation. Surgical intervention was performed for malperfusion, persistent pain with refractory hypertension, rupture, and progressing dissection on CT.  Demographics, clinical presentation, radiologic findings, hospital course, length of stay and mortality were recorded for analysis.

Results: There were 59 consecutive patients.  The average age of the patients was 61 years and 70% were male.  Eighty one percent of the patients had history of hypertension and they presented with an average systolic pressure of 183 mmHg. The most common presenting symptoms were back pain (76%) and chest pain (72.3%) while abdominal pain (52.5%) and extremity pain (13.6%) were less frequent. Twenty two percent of the patients presented with complications, visceral malperfusion (10) and rupture (3). These patients required emergency surgery. The remaining 46 patients were initially medically managed however 21 of these patients subsequently required intervention within 30 days. Of these 21, 6 developed malperfusion after presentation, 12 had refractory pain and hypertension, 2 had progressive dissection changes on CTA, and one had concern for associated symptomatic aneurysm. During the first 30 days, 58% of all the patients underwent required surgery, primarily Thoracic Aortic Endograft in 26 patients. There were three deaths within the first 30 days, rupture in 1, retrograde dissection after stent graft in 1 and a third patient died the day of discharge probably due to rupture.  The average length of stay was 10.6 days (range 1 to 43).  Patients who required intervention averaged a length of stay of 13.2 days compared to patients without intervention averaging 6.4 days.   

Conclusion: ATBAD remains a serious condition.   While the initial medical management is successful in many patients, over 50% ultimately required surgical intervention during the initial 30 days.

abstract_title: Popliteal Artery Injury: A Surgical Approach for the Pediatric Population
author_block: M. Laswi<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Marsh<sup>1</sup>, S. Qureshi<sup>1</sup>, L. Lottenberg<sup>1</sup>, R. Borrego<sup>1</sup>, F. Azar<sup>1</sup>, M. Rueda<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Florida Atlantic University,Trauma Surgery,Boca Raton, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Lower extremity arterial injuries occur in approximately 0.39% of trauma admissions, with 22% of these cases involving the popliteal artery. Popliteal artery injuries have the highest rate of extremity amputation for traumatic arterial injuries in adults, with a reported rate of approximately 21%. A review of the literature shows the rate of amputation in pediatric trauma patients who sustain lower extremity injuries is also highest for those with popliteal artery injury. 

Methods:  The aim of this study is to evaluate pediatric trauma patients who sustained popliteal artery injury. A retrospective review was performed from April 1, 2005 to October 31, 2019. Primary endpoints included associated injuries, injury severity score, operative intervention, fasciotomy rates, and amputation rates. 

Results: A total of 10 pediatric trauma patients who sustained popliteal artery injury were identified. 80% of patients were male and the mean age was 14.1 years (rage 9-16). 70% of patients presented with blunt lower extremity injuries and 80% had associated orthopedic injuries in the ipsilateral limb. Mean injury severity score was 9.6 (range 9-13). Operative repair for popliteal artery injury was performed with either interposition synthetic grafts (30%) or vein grafts (50%). During initial surgical repair, 71% of patients with blunt injuries and 67% of patients with penetrating injuries underwent four-compartment fasciotomy. The rate of amputation was 30% for pediatric popliteal artery injury. 

Conclusion: Pediatric popliteal artery injuries are rare but potentially life-threatening injuries. Despite appropriate evaluation and limb-salvage interventions, these injuries can lead to significant morbidity. Blunt traumatic injuries, associated orthopedic injuries, and high injury severity score continue to significantly correlate with poorer outcomes and higher amputation rates.

abstract_title: Experience with the Introduction of REBOA at Two Midwestern Level 1 Trauma Centers
author_block: Y. M. Wong<sup>1</sup>, T. Wolff<sup>2</sup>, A. Lariccia<sup>2</sup>, C. Spalding<sup>2</sup>, C. Hardman<sup>1</sup>, A. P. Ekeh<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Wright State University,School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery,Dayton, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Grant Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Over the last decade, resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA) has been used increasingly for control of non-compressible torso hemorrhage in injured patients.  In spite of numerous studies to date, the optimal indications for REBOA are not clearly defined.  We report our experience with REBOA adoption at two level 1 trauma centers, following the training of our trauma providers, with the aim of identifying risk factors for mortality and complications of the procedure.

Methods:   We conducted a retrospective review of all trauma patients over 18 years of age who received REBOA on admission between 2016 to 2019 at two large Midwestern Level 1 Trauma Centers. Demographic data, injury mechanism, injury severity score (ISS), mortality, zone of balloon inflation, details of the procedure, level of the provider performing the procedure and complications were collected. Results are presented as percentages, median with interquartile range (IQR), or odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence interval (CI).  Factors associated with mortality were identified using logistic regression.

Results:  A total of 51 patients were identified for the study.  The median age was 41 (31, 57) and 69% were male.  Median ISS was 25 (20, 42) and 88% of the REBOA devices were placed for blunt trauma. The commercially available 7-French REBOA kit was used in all cases, with femoral access obtained percutaneously in 83% and with ultrasound in 27%. Attending surgeons placed 47% of the catheters, while the remainder were placed by the residents or advanced practice providers.  The majority of the procedures were performed in the trauma bay (71%), while the others in the ICU or OR (29%).  Overall mortality was 49%, with 53% mortality in blunt trauma and 17% in penetrating trauma.  Patient’s age had no effect on mortality outcome, nor did the zone of balloon inflation.  ISS greater than 25 and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) prior to REBOA placement were associated with increased mortality (OR 3.36, 95% CI 1.06-10.6, p = 0.04; OR 38, 95% CI 6.9-210, p < 0.0001, respectively). Complication rate was 14%, with two groin hematomas, two pseudoaneurysms, and three patients with thrombosis of the common femoral artery.

Conclusion:  REBOA can be safely introduced and performed by properly trained trauma providers (regardless of their level) in a new setting, with low complication rates. Mortality rate remains high, particularly in patients with high ISS and those who had CPR performed prior to the intervention. However, more studies are needed to better refine the indications for the use of REBOA.

abstract_title: Trauma Surgeon Controlled Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy: A Single Institution Review
author_block: J. Moss<sup>1</sup>, K. Harrell<sup>1</sup>, R. Maxwell<sup>1</sup>, D. Hunt<sup>1</sup>, S. Bhattacharya<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee Chattanooga,Surgery,Chattanooga, TENNESSEE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a sequela of trauma, often requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) traditionally managed by a nephrologist. Studies have described an inverse relationship between CRRT days and survival. This report describes a 10-year single institution experience with critical care surgeon controlled CRRT (SCCRRT).

Methods: Adult trauma patients undergoing SCCRRT from 2007-2018 were identified, excluding those previously on dialysis. Demographic, injury, and outcome data were compared between groups stratified by survival. 

Results: Forty-five patients underwent SCCRRT with a survival rate of 68.9%. Indications for CRRT included renal failure (55.6%), volume overload (13.9%), acidosis (11.1%), rhabdomyolysis (11.1%), and sepsis (8.9%). Age, gender, race, ISS, lactic acid level, vasopressor use, and operative intervention were similar between groups. Patients who survived had longer hospital length of stay (LOS) (38.1 vs. 18.5 days, p=0.004) and higher need for intermittent hemodialysis (IHD) (51.1 vs. 14.3%, p=0.009). On univariate logistic regression analysis, decreased admission creatinine (OR 0.28, 95%CI 0.08-0.98, p=0.05), increased hospital LOS (OR 1.08, 95%CI 1.02-1.14, p=0.01), and need for IHD (OR 8.31, 95%CI 1.58-43.62, p=0.01) were associated with increased odds of survival. Need for IHD remained significant on multivariable analysis. Kaplan-Meier analysis demonstrated significantly longer length of survival between patients on CRRT for ³7 days than those <7 days (log rank, C2=5.06, p=0.025).

Conclusion: SCCRRT takes a different approach in the treatment of AKI in trauma patients. Patients were on CRRT longer than previous reports, with ³7 days associated with longer length of survival. Patient need for IHD also significantly increased odds for survival.

abstract_title: Incidence of Red Cell Antibodies Following Massive Transfusion
author_block: H. C. Hairston<sup>1</sup>, H. Jensen<sup>1</sup>, L. Burdine<sup>1</sup>, T. Ipe<sup>1</sup>, K. Kalkworf<sup>1</sup>, R. Reif<sup>1</sup>, K. Sexton<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences,College Of Medicine,Little Rock, AR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   The frequency of antibody formation in patients that have undergone massive blood transfusions is unknown. Blood transfusions are considered first-line treatment for a number of conditions, however patients forming de-novo antibodies to antigenic stimuli during a transfusion is an unwanted by-product of the event. We sought to classify the magnitude of this phenomenon during massive transfusion protocols. 

Methods: Our institutional database was queried to identify all patients from 5/1/2014 (beginning of current electronic health record implementation) that received massive transfusion protocol, and multiple myeloma patients that received crossmatched blood. Antibodies were detected using a direct Coomb’s test on the patient’s blood post-transfusion. Multiple myeloma patients were selected as control because this group is frequently transfused as part of regular therapy. Descriptive statistics were performed using (STATA, College Town, TX) and categorical variables were represented as a percentage and continuous variables were presented as mean +/- standard deviation. 

Results: Of the 47 patients who received MTP, one patient developed antibodies at a rate (2.12%) significantly lower than the other two groups. The multiple myeloma patients had 36 antibody formers out of 593 (6.07%) and 4 multiple myeloma patients receiving massive transfusion formed antibodies out of 53 total  (7.54%).

Conclusion: These results suggest that repeated exposure to blood products may be a stronger predisposing factor for autoantibody formation than amount transfused into the patient in a single setting. Further research could follow up to determine how patient stability is a determining factor in autoimmunity and how that can be applied to future emergency transfusion guidelines.

abstract_title: Anticoagulation Is Associated with Increased Mortality In Splenic Injuries
author_block: B. Bhattacharya<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Becher<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Schuster<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Davis<sup>1</sup>, A. A. MAUNG<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Surgery,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Anticoagulation (AC) has been associated with worse outcomes after trauma in some but not all studies. In a recent, small (64 patients on AC) study, AC had no effect on mortality or length of stay (LOS) in patients with spleen and/or liver injuries.  To further investigate the effect of AC on outcomes in patients with splenic injury, we performed a study utilizing the Trauma Quality Programs Participant Use File (PUF)

Methods:  The 2017 PUF was used to identify adult (18+ years) with all mechanisms and grades of splenic injury. Demographics, comorbidities, hospital course and outcomes were compared between AC and non-AC patients (identified by the NTDS anticoagulant therapy co-morbid condition field which combines all anticoagulant agents).  

Results: 18749 patients with splenic injury were identified, 622 were on AC.  The AC patients were older (68 vs. 42 years, p < 0.001) but had comparable gender composition to non-AC patients.  Injury Severity Score (18.2 vs 22.5) and rates of serious (AIS ≥ 3)  injury Chest (43.1 vs 51.3%), Abdomen (50.5 vs 60.8%) and Extremity (11.1 vs 18.1%) were all lower in the AC group (p=0.001). Rates of serious (AIS ≥ 3) head injury were not statistically different between the two groups (14 .0 vs 17.4%, p=0.29) Similar percentages in each group (26.5 vs 26.4%) were transfused packed red blood cells (RBC) within the first 4 hours thus meeting the NTDS criteria for collection of further hemorrhage control data. Within this hemorrhage control group, the AC patients received fewer units of RBC (5.7 vs 8.0 units, p < 0.001) and FFP (3.9 vs 5.4 units, p < 0.001) in the first 24 hours but underwent angiography at similar rates (23.6 vs 24.5%, p=0.8).  Among those who underwent angiography, patients were however more likely to undergo embolization if they were on AC (89.7 vs 73.9%, p=0.04). Within the whole splenic injury cohort, rates of splenic surgery were comparable between the two groups (19.3 vs 21.5%, p=0.2). Median LOS was longer in AC patients (6.3 vs 5.6 days, p=0.002). Despite being less seriously injured, the AC patients had a higher mortality (13.3 vs 7.0%, p = 0.001). In a multivariable binary logistic regression, AC was an independent risk factor for mortality with OR 1.4 (95% CI: 1.1-1.9)

Conclusion: Anticoagulation is associated with increased mortality in patients with splenic injury.

abstract_title: Predictors of Mortality for Upper Extremity Penetrating Vascular Injuries (UEPVI)
author_block: J. Broecker<sup>2</sup>, M. Kochuba<sup>3</sup>, D. Skarupa<sup>3</sup>, J. Zhang<sup>3</sup>, M. Crandall<sup>3</sup> <sup>2</sup>Mayo Clinic - Florida,Department Of Surgery,Jacksonville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Florida College of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Jacksonville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Our objective was to determine the predictors of mortality among patients with upper extremity penetrating vascular injuries (UEPVI).

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of all UEPVI patients presenting to our Level I trauma center between 1986 and 2019. SPSS Statistical Software was used to perform bivariate statistics and multivariate logistic and linear regression analyses to determine the independent predictors of mortality and hospital length of stay (LOS) using the covariates race, age, gender, insurance status, ISS, mechanism of injury and ED disposition.

Results: Among 481 total patients, the majority were male (87%) Caucasian (52%), uninsured/underinsured (52%).  58% of injuries were caused by assault or self-inflicted, most commonly gun-shot wounds (23%) or stab wounds (22%). 60% underwent surgery for their injuries. The most common vascular procedures were primary repair of the artery (31%) or distal arterial ligation (21%). On bivariate analysis, female patients had a higher injury severity score (ISS) (mean 9.55 compared to 6.77, p=0.02), were more likely to go to the operating room (40.6% compared to 24.2%, p=0.02), but had a lower mortality (1.6% compared to 4.8%, p=0.009) compared to male patients. On multivariate analysis, older age (R 0.94, 95% CI: 0.89-0.99, p=0.03) and higher ISS (OR 0.79, 95% CI: 0.72-0.87, p<0.001) were both associated with increased risk-adjusted mortality. Lack of insurance/underinsurance (OR 5.17, 95% CI: 1.09-24.61, p=0.04) was also associated with increased mortality, though race was not (p=0.22).

Conclusion: Our retrospective analysis demonstrated that the majority of penetrating upper extremity vascular injuries are incurred by men and are associated with assaultive or self-directed violence. On multivariate analysis, older age, higher ISS, and lack of insurance or underinsurance were associated with increased mortality. Future studies should investigate preventive strategies aimed at reducing UEPVI among at-risk individuals identified in this study.

abstract_title: Pediatric Surgeon-Scientists Successfully Attain Research Funding from National Institutes of Health
author_block: G. Shankar<sup>1,2,3</sup>, M. Sadhukhan<sup>1,2,3</sup>, B. Xie<sup>1,2,3</sup>, U. M. Parikh<sup>1,2,3</sup>, K. L. Singampalli<sup>1,2,3,4,5</sup>, L. Masri<sup>1,2,3</sup>, M. Potturu<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. S. Keswani<sup>1,2,3</sup>, G. M. Rossmiller<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,The Laboratory For Regenerative Tissue Repair,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Rice University,Department Of Bioengineering,Houston, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Medical Scientist Training Program,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Academic pediatric surgeons primarily obtain extramural funding for their research from the National Institutes of Health (NIH). The R01 grant is viewed as an indicator of research independence, while the K-series awards support early-stage investigators with protected time for mentor-based research experiences. The goals of this study were to 1) investigate the types of grants successfully awarded to pediatric surgeon-scientists and 2) determine the utility of the K-series award in achieving research independence.   

Methods: In July 2020, the NIH Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools was queried for grants awarded to all current candidate and regular members of the American Pediatric Surgery Association (APSA) between 2012 and 2020. Resident and senior APSA members, as well as Ph.D. members, were excluded. K-series grants included K08 and K23. Grants indicating independent funding included R01, R21, R34, U01, U54 P01 and P50. Factors analyzed included: gender, institution, type of grant, number of publications per grant, amount of funding, and K-to-R grant transitions. Univariate and multivariate analysis were performed via SPSS, and significance was defined as p < 0.05.  

Results: Out of the current 1051 APSA members, 63 (6.0%) held NIH grant awards, for a total of 79 NIH grants awarded between 2012-2020, representing $96.8M in total funding. There were 13 K-series grants awarded in this interval, including 9 K08 grants and 4 K23 grants. During this time, 66 independent grants were awarded, with R01 grants comprising the majority (78.8%). Notably, there were an additional 10 renewals of grants awarded prior to 2012. To assess the transition rate of K-series awards to R awards, 18 K-series grants were analyzed, which included 12 K grants awarded between 2008 and 2011 which expired after 2012 and 6 K grants awarded between 2012 and 2015, which would have time to transition to an R award. Of these 18, 7 (38.9%) successfully transitioned to an independent grant. For these individuals, the mean time from the end of the K grant to the beginning of an R grant was 1.7 years. On univariate analysis, there was a significant difference in number of publications during the K award period between those who transitioned and those who did not (15.6 vs 9.9, p=0.04). No differences were detected based on sex, career stage, or degree held, and these factors were not significant predictors of success based on logistic regression.   

Conclusions: In recent years, pediatric surgeon-scientists continue to be successful in competing for national research funding, and, similar to historical data, do not depend on K-series funding as a path to independent funding. Compared to previous eras, there was a lower proportion of surgeon-scientists who successfully transitioned from a K to an R award, which may suggest that pediatric surgeons are either no longer using the K-to-R award mechanism effectively or are not being appropriately supported by their institutions.

abstract_title: The Evolution of Scientific Publications in Surgery over the Last Five Decades: Bibliometric Analysis
author_block: J. Hu<sup>1</sup>, E. Zheng<sup>1</sup>, J. Levine<sup>1</sup>, W. A. Guo<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo,Surgery,Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Academic surgery has been evolving rapidly over the past half century.  However, little information is available regarding the scientific surgery publications reflecting these changes. We hypothesize there has been a change in the fields of interest in the scientific publications in surgery. 

Methods: The Institute for Scientific Information Web of Science’s Science Citation Index Expanded was queried for articles, reviews and proceedings papers published in the top 5 highest impact factor journals (JAMA Surgery, Annals of Surgery, British Journal of Surgery, Surgery and Journal of the American College of Surgeons) from 1960 to present day. Abstracts and keywords were available from 1990 to present day, whereas titles were available from 1960 to present day.  Textual frequency analysis of paper keywords from 1990 to present day was conducted utilizing textalyzer.com to describe the most commonly appearing keywords. Co-occurrence cluster analysis of both keywords and abstracts from 1990 to present day, and titles from 1960 to present day, was conducted using software VosViewer to identify emerging trends of surgical research to determine related terms and their strength of relationships.

Results: There were a total of 68,257 articles, reviews and proceedings papers published from 1960 to present day in these five top journals. Textual frequency analysis of keywords from 1990 to present demonstrated a rise in papers referring to outcomes, quality and trials whereas there was a downward trend for studies relating to animals. Both keyword and abstract co-occurrence analysis identified changes in the fields of interest in the last decade including education, cost and performance clusters (Fig). Title co-occurrence analysis identified that research focus has shifted from case studies and reviews in the 60s and 70s to animal studies in the 80s and 90s to a more recent focus on outcomes analysis.

Conclusion: Substantial differences exist between decades of surgical research for fields of interest. Fields of study in “softer” sciences may have expanded in size the last several decades due to an increased focus on qualitative factors. Changing focuses reflect the ongoing development of new technologies from animal studies to cell lines to big data.

abstract_title: Impact of a Virtual Surgery Clerkship on Medical Student SHELF Exam Performance During COVID-19
author_block: J. Pang<sup>1</sup>, R. Pepin<sup>1</sup>, D. Maes<sup>1</sup>, M. Wang<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of New Mexico HSC,Albuquerque, NM, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: One of the pedagogical premises of undergraduate medical education is the importance of clinical experience and context for the consolidation of clinical knowledge. This approach is exemplified by the clerkship year, which utilizes an apprenticeship model to transmit clinical knowledge and skills to medical students, and is considered the essential clinical year of training. The global COVID-19 pandemic has dramatically transformed the current third-year medical school curriculum. Due to guidelines put out by the Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC) and public health agencies, there was an abrupt cessation of medical students in clinical settings followed by a subsequent transition to a virtual curriculum. At our institution, medical students were moved from the traditional curriculum of five 8-week clerkships and two 4-week clerkships to a split curriculum consisting of 6 months in virtual classrooms with 3-week clerkships and 6 months of in-person clinical clerkships. At the end of each virtual clerkship, students’ clinical knowledge is assessed by a high stakes National Board of Medical Examiners (NBME) SHELF exam. Through this study, we seek to examine the impact of a virtual curricular structure on SHELF exam performance during the virtual surgery clerkship in the setting of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Methods: We included all third-year medical students who underwent the virtual surgery clerkship through August 2020 (n=52) compared to those who underwent the traditional clerkship curriculum during the 2019-2020 academic year (n=82). Given that the scores between each administration of the clerkship exam can vary, we compared the SHELF exam percentile scores of students who completed the virtual surgery curriculum to those who completed the traditional curriculum.

Results: The average surgery SHELF exam percentile score of students following the virtual curriculum was 50±31 with a median of 46. Students who underwent the traditional curriculum had an average SHELF exam percentile of 46±29 with a median of 45.5. Student’s t-test was utilized for comparison of the percentile scores between the two groups of students, which demonstrated no significant differences in scores between the two groups (p=0.5).

Conclusion: Despite the abrupt transition into a virtual curriculum, our study demonstrates that a virtual curriculum is non-inferior to a traditional clerkship curriculum in regards to medical student performance on the surgery SHELF exam. Further comparisons must be made within the other clerkships that have also undergone a virtual transformation, as well as a comparison of clinical performance when the current third-year medical students complete the in-person clinical clerkships. This data suggests that a virtual curriculum can help students perform as well on the NBME SHELF exam as a traditional curriculum, and is a viable alternative in settings when in-person education cannot occur.

abstract_title: Do Interns Learn On the Job How to Obtain Proper Informed Consent for Surgical Procedures?
author_block: C. A. Cooper<sup>1</sup>, M. Lamb<sup>1</sup>, B. Quaranto<sup>1</sup>, J. Lukan<sup>1</sup>, J. Brewer<sup>1</sup>, S. Schwaitzberg<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo,Surgery,Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The process of obtaining informed consent is well recognized to be a critical surgical skill from a legal and ethical standpoint as well as the surgeon-patient relationship.  It has been well reported that the majority of surgical consents in training institutions are obtained by first year residents, but there is no consistent method for teaching nor assessing a trainee’s ability to obtain informed consent, leaving the majority of residents to learn the skill “on the job.”  We seek to quantify the effect that one year of clinical experience without a formal curriculum in informed consent contributes to a resident’s performance in obtaining informed consent from a standardized patient.

Methods: At the start of the academic year, PGY1 and PGY2 residents in an academic surgical training program were surveyed regarding their experiences and confidence in obtaining informed consent as well as their previous formal education on the topic.  Residents then attempted to obtain informed consent for right hemicolectomy from a standardized patient.  A checklist was used which was created based on a review of the literature and accounted for residents’ attention to the following components: indication for the procedure, description of what to expect, risks, benefits, and alternatives, as well as their attention to assessing comprehension from the patients and facilitation of decision making.  After excluding residents that had extra years of training, performance of PGY1 residents was compared to that of PGY2.

Results: Two of twenty-four residents reported having any prior education in informed consent and both of these were during medical school; no other residents recalled any previous education on informed consent.  The majority of PGY2 residents reported having each obtained over 50 informed consents.  However, there was no difference between PGY1 and PGY2 surgical residents in their overall performance or in any of the specific seven components assessed.  Components identified with exceptional need for improvement included a more thorough discussion of the benefits/purpose of the operation as well as suggestion of alternatives.  Further, all residents addressed some risks of the operation but both groups performed significantly worse in addressing procedure-specific risks as compared to general risks of an operation like bleeding or infection; for example, half did not discuss anastomotic leak as a risk for right hemicolectomy.

Conclusion: Our findings demonstrate that despite performing a large number of informed consents during their first year of training, PGY2 residents did not outperform their PGY1 colleagues who started less than a month prior.  This demonstrates that practice did not improve performance when lacking formal education or coaching.  A formal curriculum in the content, delivery and assessment of informed consent should be initiated upon arrival to surgical training

abstract_title: Women Enhancing Women: Assessing the Women in Surgery Committee Mentorship Program
author_block: M. Oppenheimer-Velez<sup>1</sup>, C. Sims<sup>1</sup>, H. Labiner<sup>1,2</sup>, J. McCoy<sup>1</sup>, N. Baxter<sup>3</sup>, H. Sanfey<sup>4</sup>, R. Kozar<sup>5</sup>, V. Litle<sup>6</sup>, S. Pories<sup>7</sup> <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, And Burn, Department Of Surgery, College Of Medicine,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ,Departement Of Surgery,New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Melbourne,Melbourne School Of Population And Global Health,Melbourne, Australia <sup>4</sup>Southern Illinois University School Of Medicine,Departement Of Surgery,Springfield, IL, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Maryland,Departement Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>6</sup>Boston Medical Center,Departement Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>7</sup>Mount Auburn Hospital, Harvard Medical School,Departement Of Surgery,Cambridge, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  One third of US surgical residents are women; but women occupy only 19.9% of full time faculty positions1. Mentorship has been identified as a key to career promotion and professional development. The Women in Surgery Committee (WiSC) of the American College of Surgeons (ACS) developed a mentoring program that matched young female faculty with more senior female surgeons for one year. We hypothesized that female senior mentorship will help junior surgeons achieve their career goals.

Methods: Pairs were based on specialty, needs basis (e.g. research, professional development, work-life balance) and geography. Over a year, each pair coordinated meetings based on individual preferences and needs. An exit survey was sent to all mentors and mentees 4-6 weeks after completion of the program. Participants were asked to rank statements about mentorship and the value of specific aspects of the WiSC mentoring program on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5). Summary statistics were used to evaluate demographic data. Participants were compared based on frequency of encounters (>4 times per year vs. <4 times per year) using a Mann Whitney test with significance at p< 0.05.

Results: We identified 62 mentor-mentee pairs across 15 surgical specialties. Survey return response rate was 81%. Participants were primarily assistant professors (63%) from academic teaching hospitals (74%). Overall, participants believed mentorship programs were essential for young surgeons (4.5 ± 0.9) and that limiting the program to female surgeons only added value (4.3 ± 0.8). When compared to those who met infrequently with their mentor, more engaged mentees were more likely to perceive the program and their mentors as beneficial (4.4 ± 0.9 vs 3.3 ± 0.9, p<0.001). Specifically, more engaged mentees found the program valuable for achieving career goals (4.3 ± 0.8 vs 3.3 ± 0.8, p<0.001), developing time-management skills (4.0 ± 0.7 vs 2.8 ± 1.0. p<0.001), setting expectations (4.5 ± 0.6 vs 3.3 ± 1.0, p<0.001), providing networking opportunities (4.1 ± 1.1 vs 3.4 ± 1.0, p<0.05), and developing professional skills (3.8 ± 1.0 vs 2.7 ± 0.8, p<0.001).  They were also more likely to recommend the program (4.5 ± 1.0 vs 3.7 ± 0.8, p<0.001).

Conclusion: The WiSC Mentoring Program provides a valuable opportunity for young female surgeons. Perceived benefit appears to be dependent on the level of mentoring engagement with those who meet frequently experiencing greater value.

Reference:1Aziz HD. 2018 ACS Governors Survey: Gender inequality and harassment remain a challenge in surgery. Bulletin of the American College of Surgeons. Available at: https://bulletin.facs.org/2019/09/2018-acs-governors-survey-gender-inequality-and-harassment-remain-a-challenge-in-surgery/. Accessed July 18, 2020.

abstract_title: Prestige, Race, and Sex: Do they Play a Role in Surgery Manuscripts Accepted for Publication?
author_block: R. N. Obiarinze<sup>1</sup>, S. Goyer<sup>2</sup>, S. Pereira<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Martin<sup>1</sup>, B. Corey<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>The University of Alabama at Birmingham,Birmingham, ALABAMA, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Wesleyan University,Fort Worth, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recent events in our country have led to renewed discussion on equality and inclusion among people of different racial, ethnic, and  socioeconomic groups. Since surgery remains one of the most competitive medical specialties, the concept of equal opportunity deserves investigation in this context. The purpose of this study is to determine the correlation between demographic factors and manuscript acceptance in a surgical journal.

Methods: All oral and plenary abstracts that were presented at the 2017 Academic Surgical Congress (ASC) were collected from the online program and evaluated for their publication status. Gender and race of the senior author were recorded from the authors’ online university profile. National ranking of the institution for research funding linked to the senior author was also examined from the National Institute of Health (NIH) website. Pearson Chi Square and Logistic Regression analysis were run on SPSS software to analyze the data.

Results: Of the 360 abstracts that were presented, 254 were subsequently published at 34 months following the conference. There was a positive correlation with manuscripts that were published and senior authors categorized as “White” (180/244) (p= 0.001) vs. senior authors of different races- “African American” (8/22), “Asian” (56/81) and “Hispanic” (3/3). There was no correlation between “Male” (198/282) vs. “Female” (47/70) senior authors and publication status (p=0.793). The national ranking of the institution associated with the senior author had no correlation with whether a manuscript was published (p=0.195).

Conclusion: Race may play a role in manuscripts that are published. Senior authors categorized as “White” are strongly correlated with manuscripts accepted for publication, over senior authors of a “African-American”, “Hispanic” and “Asian” nationality. Such a disparity may be linked to a lack of access among different races and may highlight the need for a level playing field, even among academic surgeons. Journals may want to consider blinding reviewers to authors’ names, institution, and other identifying factors.

abstract_title: The Top 100 Most Disruptive Randomized Controlled Trials In General Surgery
author_block: M. Williams<sup>1</sup>, M. Grunvald<sup>1</sup>, C. O'Donoghue<sup>1</sup>, D. Hayden<sup>1</sup>, A. Torquati<sup>1</sup>, A. Becerra<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The number of scientific publications is increasing exponentially. A paper’s significance is often determined by its citation count, though this may not reflect its actual contribution to scientific advancement. Using a validated bibliometric measure called the disruption score, we identified the top 100 most disruptive randomized control trials (RCTs) in general surgery. 

Methods: We included all RTCs published between 1954 and 2014 from The American Journal of Surgery, Annals of Surgery, BMC Surgery, JAMA Surgery (formerly Archives of Surgery), Journal of the American College of Surgeons, Journal of Surgical Research, Journal of Trauma and Acute Care Surgery, and Surgery, as well as surgery-specific articles from British Medical Journal, JAMA, Lancet, and New England Journal of Medicine, for a total of 3,436 publications. Using the equation developed by Wu et. al (Nature 2019) we calculated the disruption score for each publication, and selected the top 100. 

Results: The five RCTs with the highest disruption score are shown in the table. Among the top 100, the disruption scores range from 0.07 to 0.68. The number of citations range from 1 to 3,946. The correlation coefficient between citation count and disruption score is 0.12, indicating a weak correlation.

Conclusion: This project introduces a new method of identifying disruptive publications. A high disruption score suggests that a paper has displaced previous ways of thinking, thus shifting the paradigm at the time of publication. In our list, we noted the disruption score was weakly correlated with citation count, confirming that the score can identify unique characteristics contributing to a papers overall impact.  The most disruptive RCT on our list was a comparison of radical vs simple mastectomy. Most agree that the true landmark trial on this topic was NSABP B04, which has 612 citations since it was published in 2002. However, an impressive disruption score identifies Brinkley's and Haybittle’s earlier contributions to breast cancer treatment, and the dramatic changes that would occur in the following decades.   The highest citation count belongs the NASCET trial, the 9th most disruptive on our list. This is still a well-known landmark study in vascular surgery which solidified the role of endarterectomy in the treatment of symptomatic carotid stenosis.  In summary, the disruption score provides an additional method of analyzing scientific publications. Our top 100 list provides unique perspective on the history of surgical science, and we hope it will influence future surgeons on their path to discovery.

abstract_title: Prevalence of Advanced Educational Degrees Among Leaders in Academic General Surgery
author_block: C. L. Mullens<sup>2</sup>, R. J. Kirk<sup>2</sup>, L. Parascandola<sup>2</sup>, J. W. Marsh<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Borgstrom<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>West Virginia University School of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>West Virginia University School of Medicine,Morgantown, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:   Medical education offerings continue to evolve and create opportunities for medical students to pursue dual degree education. These educational endeavors provide important framework and formal education in ancillary fields directly related to surgery, which gives trainees and surgeons important and diverse perspectives on surgical care. This study sought to assess current prevalence of additional advanced degrees among leaders in academic surgery in order to determine whether or not there is an association between dual degree attainment and holding leadership positions within surgical departments.

Methods: The Association for Program Directors in Surgery (APDS) database was used to identify academic surgical programs, which comprised our study population. Each department of surgery website in the APDS database was interrogated for departmental leaders and their reported academic degrees.

Results: We identified 264 programs in the APDS directory, 229 of which were identified as academically structured programs. We identified 3,249 surgeons as holding leadership roles within their departments based on website position titles and affiliations. We found that 500 (15.4%) of these surgeons possessed advanced educational degrees in addition to their medical degree. Among those possessing such degrees, the most common degrees included PhD’s (172, 34.4%), MPH’s (96, 19.2%). MBA’s (75, 15.0%), MSc (70, 14.0%) DDS/DMD (26, 5.2%), and MEd (20, 4.0%). Chairpersons were significantly more likely to possess advanced educational degrees compared to other leaders in the cohort (p = 0.0116). Only 173 chairpersons were able to be identified in the cohort of collected leaders, of whom 35 (20.2%) possessed advanced degrees. MBA’s (12, 31.4%), PhD’s (11, 25.7%), and MPH’s (5, 14.3%), comprised the majority of chairpersons advanced educational degrees. Using program websites, we were only able to definitively identify 196 general surgery residency program directors, 26 (13.3%) of whom were identified as having advanced educational degrees. Exactly 1,000 department of surgery division chiefs were found to possess 168 advanced degrees (16.8%). Residency program directors and division chiefs possessed similar distributions of advanced degrees as chairpersons. The remainder of identified leaders (1,880 surgeons) largely consisted of vice chairpersons, fellowship program directors, fellowship directors, and administrative leadership roles and were responsible for 271 advanced degrees within the cohort (14.4% prevalence).

Conclusion: A relatively small fraction of leaders in academic surgery possess advanced educational degrees in addition to their medical degree. While perhaps valuable for understanding complexities and nuance of the healthcare system, possessing such formal training does not appear to be a key factor in one’s advancement and ascendance to positions of leadership in academic surgery roles.

abstract_title: Impact of Gender on Medical Student Teaching Evaluations of Attending Surgeons
author_block: S. L. Terranella<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Skertich<sup>1</sup>, C. Wakefield<sup>1</sup>, G. Gill-Wiehl<sup>1</sup>, L. Friedman<sup>1</sup>, A. Shah<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center,Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Competency-based evaluations play a role in the promotion of academic surgeons. Currently, there is a known disparity in the number of leadership positions held by female compared to male surgeons.  The aim of this study was to investigate the role gender plays in these evaluations by examining quantitative and qualitative differences in medical student teaching assessments of attending surgeons.

Methods: Medical student evaluations of all attending surgeons at a single institution over a ten-year period were retrospectively reviewed in this single-blinded study. Numerical scores of female versus male attendings were compared across 11 categories using Mann-Whitney U tests. Subjective evaluations were analyzed using NVivo, a qualitative data analysis software. Using an exploratory method, we identified prevailing themes within the comments, coded the evaluations based on these themes, and compared the coded comments based on gender.

Results: 3,337 evaluations of 52 attending surgeons (19 females, 33 males) were included over a 10-year period. Objective scoring of female and male attendings was comparable in 4 of 6 categories, with female attendings achieving significantly higher scores in the areas of “Enthusiasm” and “Clear Expectations” when compared to male attendings (Table 1). Four major themes were identified within the subjective evaluations, which included personality descriptors, statements on abilities as a surgeon, statements on abilities as an educator, and expressions of reverence. Although comments were largely comparable between groups, subtle differences emerged within several of the pre-determined themes. For example, students expressed stronger comments of reverence for male compared to female attendings, describing males as “department chair quality” or as an “indispensable asset” to the program. Critiques of female surgeons’ abilities as educators were more focused on lack of clear expectations whereas males were viewed as being abrasive and belittling.

Conclusion: In contrast to prior studies, medical student teaching evaluations of male and female attending surgeons were largely comparable across all categories. Findings from this study may reflect the improving gender balance within the field of surgery. Interestingly, female faculty scores were higher than male faculty scores in the areas of enthusiasm and clear expectations; however, subtle biases were observed within the subjective comments that reflected traditional gender stereotypes.

abstract_title: Understanding Publication Pressure in Surgical Research in an Academic Department of Surgery
author_block: S. P. Dugan<sup>1</sup>, K. McCawley<sup>1</sup>, J. Lee<sup>1</sup>, Y. Engeda<sup>1</sup>, D. Kendrick<sup>3</sup>, G.
