Kim<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan,Division Of Minimally Invasive Surgery,Ann Arbor, MICHIGAN, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Surgical Critical Care,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  We attempted to characterize the research environment in the Department of Surgery at our institution, which ranks among the top five among surgery departments nationwide in NIH funding. In gauging faculty’s perception of publishing research, we hoped to better understand their motivations, the extent they feel their research is supported by their institution, and the stress associated with academic productivity. Furthermore, we investigated whether responses differed significantly depending on faculty rank of respondents.

Methods:  A 26-question survey was sent electronically to all faculty with an active clinical practice in the Department of Surgery. The survey queried perceived level of departmental support for research, motivation for research, perception of research enhancing clinical care, and extent to which academic productivity serves as a personal stressor.  Survey participation was voluntary, and responses were anonymous. Faculty was split into two groups based on academic rank: senior defined as professors and junior defined as associate or assistant professors. The median answers provided by each group were then compared using a Welch Two Sample t-test; a p value less than 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: We received 39 completed surveys (response rate 38%). Using the initial analysis, junior faculty (n=24) were more likely to report that they conduct research for professional advancement, whereas senior faculty (n=12) reported that they conduct research for their own personal enjoyment (p < 0.01). Junior faculty were also more likely to state that publishing their research was a significant stressor, whereas senior faculty did not report similar stress (p < 0.01). There were no significant differences between faculty perception of institutional support for research, influence of colleagues’ research on personal research, and the enhancement of research on clinical care.

Conclusion: All surveyed faculty believe that academic research enhances clinical care (n=30), and 72% believe that academic research positively impacts patient perception of physicians (n=29). However, junior faculty seem to conduct research primarily for professional advancement and report greater stress associated with publishing when compared to established professors. Understanding the varied motivations for research and the publication pressures experienced by different groups may enable institutions to optimize resource allocation to better support junior faculty in their professional development.

abstract_title: Dedicated Wellness Time Decreases Absence on the Surgery Clerkship Without Hindering Performance?
author_block: N. Keric<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Smith<sup>1</sup>, S. Kaib<sup>1</sup>, P. Teran<sup>1</sup>, A. Feinstein<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Arizona College of Medicine- Phoenix,Phoenix, AZ, USA <sup>2</sup>Banner University Medical Center-Phoenix,Surgery,Phoenix, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As burnout amongst medical students progresses through training, we sought to impact this trend by incorporating a dedicated wellness time for students on the Surgery clerkship. 

Methods: Eighty-seven students in the third-year Surgery clerkship during Fall 2018 (39) and 2019 (48) were evaluated. Four hours weekly of dedicated wellness time was incorporated into the 2019 clerkship. Students were encouraged to use this time for self-care and study.  They were compared to a 2018 matching cohort, prior to the change.

Results: Absence requests decreased from 21 (54%) in 2018 to 11 (23%) in 2019.  The most frequent absence reasons in 2018 were for illness (67%), followed by conference attendance (19%).  In 2019, family events (36%) were most frequent followed by conference presentations (27%).  There was only one request for illness in 2019.  Mean shelf exams scores and clinical evaluations were similar between cohorts.  31% of student feedback mentioned wellness time as a positive experience.  Student comments regarding professionalism issues decreased by 27%.

Conclusion: Dedicated wellness time in a Surgery clerkship coincided with less overall student absence from clinical rotations due to illness.  The dedicated time did not appear to negatively impact shelf scores or clinical evaluations.

abstract_title: Analysis of Student Preconceptions of the Required Surgery Clerkship
author_block: H. Phillips<sup>1</sup>, L. Shinkunas<sup>2</sup>, C. Klipowicz<sup>2</sup>, E. Carlisle<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>Universisty Of Iowa,Bioethics And Humanities,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The medical school surgery clerkship is viewed by many students as demanding - often pushing them to their perceived physical and academic limits. Graduating medical students across institutions rate the surgery clerkship less favorably than non-surgical clerkships and report frequent mistreatment. General surgery programs have studied interventions to improve students’ experiences with limited success. Here, we assess students’ preconceived notions prior to the clerkship as well as perceptions after completion of the clerkship in an effort to gain insight into how clerkship leaders might dispel preconceived attitudes that may impact student experiences.

Methods:  This is a two-part exploratory study of medical students at a midwestern academic medical center investigating attitudes toward surgeons and the surgical clerkship. Part 1 involved three 60-minute focus groups with pre-clinical medical students. Focus groups were digitally recorded and transcribed verbatim. Emerging themes were captured through qualitative content analysis. Part 2 involved a brief online survey of students who had completed the clinical portion of their surgical clerkship. Descriptive statistics were tabulated. 

Results: 20 students participated in the focus groups. Societal stereotypes and comments from senior medical students informed perceptions of surgeons as “particular,” “focused," “confident," “hyper-competitive," “egotistical,” “maniacal,” or as having a “god-complex”. Students expressed concern about hostile work environments, unsatisfactory work-life balance, poor academic performance, and viewed surgeons as less “humanistic” than non-surgeons. Most students hoped to be integrated into the surgical team, develop suturing and physical exam skills, and learn management of post-operative patients. 12 (24% response rate) students have participated in the post-clerkship survey to date. 50% had no previous interaction with surgeons prior to their clerkship. Following their clerkship, students described surgeons as “intense,” “adaptable,” “creative,” “thoughtful,” “hard-working,” and “busy”. 50% of students expected to be treated poorly by surgical attendings but reported being treated well, while 25% had a similar interaction with residents. 50% anticipated being treated well by residents and/or staff and were treated well. Only 33% felt this way about attendings. 42% had a different opinion of surgeons after their surgery clerkship.

Conclusion: Pre-clinical students have pre-conceived notions of surgeons and the required surgery clerkship that may impact their educational experience and limit their satisfaction with the clerkship.  Addressing these concerns intentionally and preemptively with pre-clinical students or students early in their surgical clerkship may enhance the learning environment.

abstract_title: Student Opinions of the General Surgery Clerkship: A Comparison of University and Community Programs
author_block: S. Capone<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Lewis<sup>1,2</sup>, L. Milone<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brooklyn Hospital Center,Department Of Surgery,Brooklyn, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>St. George's University School Of Medicine,St. George's, St. George's, Grenada
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medical student education, particularly the core clinical curriculum, has recently been subject to change at multiple institutions. This has sparked a deeper look at the aspects of each clinical rotation as an attempt to create the best learning experience for the medical student. Variability between programs can lead to differences in student opinions of general surgery, leading to changes in residency applications. These differences may be more evident when comparing university-affiliated and community hospital training programs. Here we assess student and resident opinions of the general surgery clerkship and compare training programs between university-affiliated and community-based training hospitals.

Methods: A voluntary survey was provided electronically to current students and residents to assess their opinions of their general surgery clerkship. Demographic, hospital, and rotation data was collected and students who had not completed their rotation were censored.  To assess the quality of student education, respondents were asked to assess the frequency of educational and non-educational duties. Educational duties included operative experience and presenting to attending surgeons or senior residents on rounds. Non-educational duties included obtaining vitals, patient transport, and basic procedures (ie. venipuncture). Presence of a formal medical student education was based on the ACS/ASE Medical Student Core Curriculum. Respondents were also asked their subjective opinions regarding strengths and weaknesses of their rotation, along with their satisfaction of the rotation overall and with their education.

Results: Of the 108 respondents who completed the survey and their general surgery rotation, 36 were at university-affiliated hospitals (36/108, 33.3%) and 72 at community hospitals (72/108, 66.7%). 69 (61.1%) responses were from third year students, 25 (22.1%) from fourth year students, and 19 (16.8%) from general surgery residents (17 PGY-1, 2 PGY-3). Comparison of a medical student educational program showed no difference between community and university programs (69.0% v. 66.7%, p=0.81). There was no difference in the presence of hands-on training between community and university programs (54.9% v. 61.1%, p=0.81). There were no statistical differences between educational (84.51% v. 91.67%, p=.30) and non-educational activity (56.3% v. 61.1%, p=0.64) at community and university hospitals, respectively. Comparison of trainee opinions on the quality of their rotation shows a trend towards higher educational satisfaction at university hospitals v. community hospitals (6.22 v. 5.19, p=0.085), but no difference in overall enjoyment (5.56 v. 5.22, p=0.60) or 24 hour call requirement (50.0% v. 41.7%, p=0.42).

Conclusions: Despite no difference between hands-on training, educational and non-educational activity, or enjoyment, students showed a trend towards higher educational satisfaction at university-affiliated general surgery programs.

abstract_title: Factors Influencing Medical Student Entrustment with Supervised Procedures during Core Clerkships
author_block: D. C. Foote<sup>1,2</sup>, N. Matusko<sup>2</sup>, R. M. Reddy<sup>2</sup>, G. Sandhu<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beaumont Health System,Department Of Surgery,Royal Oak, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Student entrustment with participation in procedures has been decreasing over the past 25 years resulting in poorly prepared graduates for internship. While students wish to have more participation, they may not be equipped to optimize clinical experiences and promote involvement in procedures. This study explores factors associated with student entrustment in procedures with the goal of informing students of barriers to and facilitators of increased procedural participation in their clerkships.

Methods: In May 2016, students completing their core clinical year at a single medical school were surveyed on attitudes and participation in 90 procedures (e.g. cryotherapy, incision/drainage, paracentesis, central line placement, first assisting in surgery) across 6 core clerkships, with participation used as an objective proxy for entrustment. Entrustment scores were created incorporating procedural complexity. Procedural (anesthesia, emergency medicine, surgery and surgical subspecialties, obstetrics/gynecology) and nonprocedural (e.g. internal medicine, pediatrics, radiology, etc.) groupings were created based on reported specialty of interest. Scores were compared using independent t-tests and/or Pearson’s correlation coefficient.

Results: 138/210 medical students responded (66% response rate). Entrustment was not associated with gender (entrustment score of men versus women, 54.98±16.07 versus 52.22±13.57, p=0.275), race (p=0.516), or Myers-Briggs personality dyads (p=0.531). Greater entrustment was experienced by students interested in procedural specialties (56.90±14.11 versus 51.35±14.45 for nonprocedural specialties, p=0.028) and those with more positive attitudes towards procedures (r=0.182, p=0.032). 

Conclusion: Findings from this study suggest that students who demonstrate a positive attitude towards procedures and are forthcoming with their interests in procedural specialties engender greater entrustment from supervisors. Educators can highlight these behaviors to students to empower and enhance engagement among learners in the clinical environment.

abstract_title: Medical Student Career Choice: Who Is The Influencer?
author_block: K. A. Hao<sup>1</sup>, S. Fu<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Larson<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Mustafa<sup>1</sup>, R. T. Petroze<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Taylor<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida,Department Of Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The selection of career choice by medical students is influenced by many factors. Experiences during clinical rotations are key to decision-making. During rotations, students receive mentoring and supervision from attending and resident physicians, both of whom may profoundly influence the students’ perception of a specialty. Previous studies demonstrated the influence of attendings and residents on medical students’ career choices, but their respective influence is not yet established. The purpose of this study was to gain better understanding of the extent to which attendings and residents influence medical students’ career choices, specifically regarding general surgery and surgical specialties.

Methods:  An IRB-exempt 14-question survey was created using a modified Delphi technique, and piloted prior to distribution. This anonymous, voluntary, web-based survey was sent to rising fourth year medical students and new graduates at our institution. In addition to demographic information, respondents identified differences in the influence of attendings and residents on their career choice. Descriptive statistics were performed on demographics; 5-point Likert responses underwent non-parametric analyses (α = 0.05).

Results: The response rate was 21% (60/282). 57% were female. 43% (26/60) chose a surgical specialty (general surgery (GS), OB/GYN, plastics, orthopedics, neurosurgery, ophthalmology, urology, ENT); 9 students are pursuing GS. Residents and attendings combined had the greatest influence on all career selections (48%), followed by residents-only (28%) and attendings-only (23%); the trend persisted for surgical specialties. Residents were rated to be more supportive and approachable, more encouraging of students to pursue their specialty, involved students more, provided better feedback, and set fairer expectations compared to attendings. Attendings were rated to explain difficult concepts more clearly and had greater knowledge (p < 0.005). Attending (62%) and resident (57%) influence was cited by respondents who chose a different specialty than they intended to pursue when entering medical school. Attending (88%) and resident (100%) influence was cited amongst those changing their intended career to GS, as well as clarified misconceptions of the field (50%). Respondents pursuing GS rated residents more enthusiastic than attendings. GS attendings received more positive ratings for explaining difficult concepts, compared to other attendings.

Conclusion: This study demonstrates that while both attendings and residents are key influencers of medical student career choices, residents hold greater overall influence. Students choosing a career in general surgery and surgical specialties viewed the mentoring skills of residents in higher regard. These findings provide clinical educators with valuable insights to improve student experiences and career recruitment, and to drive institutional culture change regarding the clinical education of students.

abstract_title: General Surgery residency training over the past two decades: Are we still operating enough?
author_block: L. Kearse<sup>1</sup>, A. Zeineddin<sup>2</sup>, I. Schmiederer<sup>1</sup>, J. Lau<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Howard University College Of Medicine,Surgery,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Medical training has undergone many facets of restructuring over the past couple of decades, including the development of work hour restrictions and changes in management strategies. Adequate case exposure and volume is imperative to facilitate residents’ mastery of technical skills for independent practice. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the trends of general surgery residents’ case exposure and volume over the past two decades.

Methods:  The Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) Case Log Statistics Reports from 1999 to 2019 were reviewed. Case logs were grouped into defined case categories and level of postgraduate training. Descriptive analyses were performed.

Results: The total major average cases per resident increased by 10.7% (p<0.001). Although there was an increase in maximum vascular surgery cases, the average total vascular surgery cases performed by residents decreased by 40.3% (p<0.001). Evaluation of defined cases shows a decrease in operative trauma with an increase in nonoperative trauma, abdomen, and alimentary cases. Junior level residents also have seen a significant increase in exposure to critical care cases while chief residents’ exposure has remained relatively stable. No significant changes were noted in 2003 after the implementation of duty hour restrictions.

Conclusion: Evaluation of trends shows that residents, despite changes in duty hour restrictions and management strategies are still exposed to an adequate volume of cases. However, these trends do not necessarily depict the effect of specialized surgery centers, presence of fellowship programs, or correlate to resident autonomy. Future studies will attempt to assess residents’ perceptions of competency and autonomy, impact of specialized centers and fellowship programs, and effects on patient outcomes. Studies will also seek to evaluate the impact of COVID-19 on case volume and exposure during surgical training.

abstract_title: Using a Survey Tool to Track General Surgery Resident Readiness to Work During the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: C. G. Moses<sup>1</sup>, T. L. Bettis<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Porterfield<sup>2</sup>, B. L. Corey<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Gastrointestinal Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Beginning in March 2020, general surgery residencies across the United States have been increasingly impacted by COVID-19. It has become imperative to limit potential exposure of the resident workforce and identify those with known/potential disease exposure, symptom development, and perceived inability to attend work. Many residencies initiated a platoon scheduling approach, with select residents held in reserve to maintain their health. As electronic survey tools are an increasingly popular means of quickly gathering and storing data for a variety of purposes in surgical education, we hypothesized that the use of survey tools to track individual resident readiness to work would be an effective and useful means for collecting information about resident workforce status.

Methods: To assess the health and overall state of the resident workforce, a daily email check-in was created using the Qualtrics survey tool. This tool was designed to assess if residents were experiencing symptoms, felt they were able to work, or had questions or concerns about the state of resident operations. Participation was voluntary but encouraged.

Results: The survey was dispersed via email to each general surgery resident at a large academic center daily from March 26, 2020 to June 8, 2020. A total of 2,225 surveys were distributed to 58 unique recipients. 948 total responses were collected from 51 unique respondents. There were 14 total responses indicating a subjective inability to work, with 6 (42.9%) of those indicating at least one of the following symptoms: shortness of breath, fever > 100.4, myalgia, or cough.

Conclusion: The ability of surgical residency leadership to track the health status of individual residents and the resident workforce has never been more paramount than during the COVID-19 pandemic. Our study shows that an electronic survey tool can be used as an effective platform to track resident health status and readiness to work. Identifying further uses for electronic survey tools in surgical education may guide how resident wellness and health are followed in the future, and may have many other useful applications.

abstract_title: Trends in the Match for General Surgery, Surgical Subspecialty, and Integrated Programs
author_block: D. M. Vaysburg<sup>1</sup>, D. Kutz<sup>1</sup>, A. Kassam<sup>1</sup>, A. R. Cortez<sup>1</sup>, C. Morris<sup>1</sup>, R. C. Quillin<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Department Of Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: General surgery (GS) was once the gateway into a career in surgery. Over time surgical subspecialties (SS) birthed their own residency programs and more recently, integrated programs (IS) have come into existence. However, it is unknown what impact the presence of SS and IS programs have had on GS. Our objective was to evaluate and quantify match trends among applicants to GS, IS, and SS.

Methods: National Residency Matching Program reports from 2010 through 2019 were analyzed to evaluate trends between groups. IS included Plastic, Vascular, and Thoracic Surgery. SS included Otolaryngology, Orthopedic Surgery, and Neurosurgery. Groups compared were applicants per position, rankings per applicant and match rate.

Results: Over the past decade there was a median 25,820 (IQR 24402-27782) US graduates. Median number of GS applicants was 1298 (IQR 1270-1359), SS 1422 (IQR 1357-1477), and IS 290 (IQR 263-320). The proportion of graduates going into GS, SS and IS was 5.1% (IQR 4.9-5.1%), 5.6% (IQR 5.2-5.7%) and 1.12% (IQR 1.1-1.2%). Median applicants per position was 1.08 for GS, 1.86 for SS and 1.34 for IS (p<.0001). GS match rate was 72.8%, SS 77.7%, and IS 65.0%, (p<.0001). Median rankings per applicant was 10.5 (IQR 10.0-10.8) for GS, 10.9 (IQR 10.8-12.2) for SS and 10.1 (IQR 7.5-11.1) for IS (p=.01). Over time GS applicants increased 1262 to 1388 (+10%, p<.005) while positions increased 1077 to 1432 (+33%, p<.001), and applicants per position decreased from 1.17 to 0.97 (p=.003). Percent matched increased 70.1% to 75.8% (p<.003), and rankings per applicant increased 9.43 to 11.43 (p<.0001). For SS, positions increased 1127 to 1315 (+17%, p=.0001), but the number of applicants and applicants per position remained stable (p=.224, p=.07). The SS match rate did not change (p=.06), but rankings per applicant increased 10.55 to 12.27 (p=.0002). For IS, number of applicants increased 265 to 327 (+23%, p=.0001) as did positions (101 to 275, +272%, p<.0001). Applicants per position decreased 2.53 to 1.19 (-53%, p=.002). Percent matched increased 34.4% to 74.6% (+217.1%, p=.0005), and rankings positions per applicant 5.3 to 11.5 (+219.7%, p<.001).

Conclusion: From 2010 to 2019, GS and IS have experienced the highest percent increase in available positions, and GS remains lowest in applicants per position. This may be attributed to applicants who may have otherwise chosen GS now applying to IS.  Further work to better compare the competitiveness and attractiveness of surgical residencies is warranted.

abstract_title: Estrogen Receptor Beta Mediates Renal Ischemia Reperfusion Injury in a Renal Vascular Specific Manner
author_block: C. S. OBrien<sup>1</sup>, P. Hernandez<sup>1</sup>, Z. Wang<sup>1</sup>, G. Ge<sup>1</sup>, W. Hancock<sup>2</sup>, M. H. Levine<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Philadelphia,Pathology,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Renal Ischemia Reperfusion Injury (IRI) is a major contributor to early allograft dysfunction (EAD) in kidney transplantation. We previously demonstrated lower rates of EAD among female renal transplant recipients in the UNOS registry, and using a murine model, we showed improved IRI tolerance with administration of supplemental 17β-estradiol (E2). There are two isoforms of the estrogen receptor, estrogen receptor alpha (ERα) and estrogen receptor beta (ERβ), and expression of each isoform varies by cell type. We have shown decreased ischemia tolerance in ERα knockout mice (ERα-KO) but improved tolerance to ischemia in ERβ knockout mice (ERβ-KO). Given the therapeutic potential of manipulating the estrogen receptors with E2, understanding the role of the ERβ in renal IRI is essential. Here, we have used a transplantation model to assess whether the role of ERβ is intrinsic to the kidney or systemic, as well as tissue specific ERβ knockout models in vascular endothelium (Tie2-Cre) and renal tubular epithelium (Pax8-Cre).

Methods:  We transplanted kidneys from C57BL/6(B6) donor mice into B6 recipient mice, ERβKO kidneys into B6 recipients, and B6 kidneys into ERβKO recipients, followed by native nephrectomy. All groups subsequently underwent standardized renal IRI. In separate experiments, female Pax8-Cre (+) ERβ-/- mice and Tie2-Cre (+) ERβ-/- mice were subjected to warm renal ischemia along with female, B6 controls. Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and serum creatinine (Cr) were measured at 24-, 48-, 72- and 96-hours after surgery.

Results: ERβ-KO mice that received B6 kidneys (B6=>ERβKO) had significantly higher BUN and Cr compared to B6 mice that received ERβKO kidneys (ERβKO=>B6) (p<0.001) and significantly higher Cr than B6 mice that received B6 kidneys (B6=>B6) (p <0.05, Figure 1). Similarly, Tie2-Cre (+) ERβ-/- mice had significantly lower BUN (p<0.001) and Cr (p=0.03) compared to B6 controls. Pax8-Cre (+) ERβ-/- mice did not have a significant difference in BUN/Cr from B6 controls.

Conclusion: Transplantation of a kidney from a WT mouse into a ERβ-KO mouse exacerbates renal IRI, but whole-body deletion of ERβ from vascular endothelium is protective. Deletion of ERβ from renal tubular epithelium is not protective. These novel findings suggest that the protective mechanism of ERβ deletion is located both within the kidney and within the vasculature, suggesting that a functioning ERβ in the renal vasculature mediates the ischemia reperfusion injury. Further understanding of this pathway will guide development and understanding of therapeutics that effect the ERα and ERβ receptors.

abstract_title: Microsurgical Modulation of the Immune Response for Engineered Graft Neovascularization
author_block: P. C. Hancock<sup>1</sup>, S. V. Koduru<sup>1</sup>, M. Sun<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Ravnic<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Plastic Surgery,Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Success of engineered grafts continues to be limited by time to vascularization following implantation.  It has been appreciated that inflammation and macrophage accumulation are intricately involved with neovascularization in implanted grafts and engineered tissues. We recently described a simple microsurgical approach that can rapidly vascularize and perfuse an adjacently placed non-anastomosable collagen graft by creating a localized pro-angiogenic environment. We hypothesize that recipient vasculature micropuncture induces graft neovascularization by the rapid accumulation of inflammatory macrophages. 

Methods: The femoral artery and vein of Sprague-Dawley rats (N=10) were micropunctured (MP) at defined intervals using a 60 µm diameter prior to coverage with a Type I collagen scaffold. The contralateral limb served as a normal (non-MP) intrinsic control. Collagen grafts and the underlying vascular segment were explanted en bloc after 24, 48, and 72 hours. Thin sections were prepared for histologic analysis using both trichrome and immunofluorescence staining. Total cellular infiltration into the grafts was assessed per high powered field with endothelial cell (CD31/PECAM-1) and macrophage (F4/80) accumulation quantified. Western blot protein analysis was performed for confirmation.  Statistically significant differences were defined as P < 0.05 using the one-tailed Student’s t test.

Results: Collagen grafts overlying the micropunctured vessels demonstrated a highly significant (p < .001) increase in the % area of total infiltrated cells compared to non-MP control grafts at all time points (11.22 vs. 7.31 at 24 hours, 16.35 vs. 11.36 at 48 hours, and 23.49 vs. 17.78 at 72 hours). Macrophage accumulation followed a similar trend in MP grafts when compared to control grafts: 18.57 vs. 8.00 at 24 hours (p = .001), 30.67 vs. 15.17 at 48 hours (p = .014), and 33.71 vs. 27.64 at 72 hours (p = .075). This paralleled the increased levels of endothelial cells seen in MP grafts: 29.83 vs 8.00 at 24 hours (p = .002), 42.17 vs. 16.6 at 48 hours (p = .035), and 62.38 vs. 45.36 at 72 hours (p = .001). Western blotting corroborated these findings with 1.40-, 1.77-, and 1.36-fold increases of F4/80 and 2.35-, 2.69-, and 7.19-fold increases of CD31 in the MP grafts at 24, 48, and 72 hours, respectively.

Conclusion: Here we show that surgical priming of the recipient vasculature influences cellular infiltration and neovascularization of adjacently placed engineered collagen grafts. Macrophages play an essential role in graft vascularization; however, under normal circumstances their accumulation is slow and angiogenesis is delayed. With concurrent vascular micropuncture at the time of graft implantation these deficiencies are remedied.  Without causing significant injury to the recipient vasculature, this microsurgical tactic represents a novel approach in regulating inflammation for the benefits of engineered graft neovascularization.

abstract_title: Pre-Liver Transplant Alterations in Gene Regulation Correlate with Immune Dysfunction and Mortality
author_block: G. Panayotova<sup>1</sup>, A. Lemenze<sup>1</sup>, S. Simonishvili<sup>1</sup>, T. Ayorinde<sup>1</sup>, N. Aware<sup>2</sup>, L. Minze<sup>2</sup>, F. Paterno<sup>1</sup>, M. Ghobrial<sup>2</sup>, J. V. Guarrera<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Lunsford<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School,Division Of Transplant And HPB Surgery,Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Houston Methodist Hospital and Research Institute,Department Of Surgery - Transplant,Houston, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Early morbidity and mortality following liver transplant (LT) relates to infection and pre-transplant immune dysfunction (i.e. immune frailty) in more the 60% of recipients. We previously identified a pre-LT plasma biomarker panel, the immune frailty index (IFI), which predicts early post-transplant mortality due to immune dysfunction. While shift in T cell lineage and dysregulation of immune cell differentiation and maturation appear to contribute to pre-LT immune dysfunction, the genetic mechanisms responsible remain largely unknown.

Methods:  IFI was calculated from pre-transplant HCV viremia, Eotaxin, MMP3, and Fractalkine levels above median values, as previously described. IFI-high patients (score 3-4) were matched 1:2 with IFI-low (score 0-2) based on age, gender, and cause of liver disease. Blood collected from normal healthy volunteers served as control. Peri- and post-operative patient characteristics, labs, infectious complications, and survival were tracked. RNAseq was performed on PBMCs isolated at time of LT, and gene expression results were correlated with patient clinical outcomes. Gene enrichment analysis was performed using iPathwayGuide (Advaita Bioinformatics, Ann Arbor, MI).

Results: Pre-transplant characteristics were similar between patients. Two-year survival was significantly worse in IFI-high (56%, n=5/9) vs IFI-low (100%, n=18/18, p<0.01). IFI-high experienced more frequent early post-op infections (p=0.05) and higher incidence of early post-transplant pneumonia (p=0.02). IFI-high also had more positive cultures within 1yr (median 3 vs 1, p=0.04). Among IFI-high patients who died (n=4), 3/4 (75%) died secondary to immune-related complications (infection and recurrent malignancy). The fourth patient experienced graft failure secondary to non-compliance with immunosuppression. RNA seq of deceased patients demonstrated 23 differentially expressed genes. Analysis suggested pre-LT dysregulation of genes implicated in antigen-presentation, cancer and viral infection susceptibility, immune cell-related transcriptional motifs, and dysfunctional liver metabolism (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Dysregulation of immunomodulatory pathways can result in aberrant expression of genes related to competent immunity. This may direct pre-transplant immune dysfunction/frailty, and likely increases LT recipient susceptibility to infections and death. This phenomenon may account for a large proportion of early post-LT deaths. Further evaluation of these pathways may offer a potential novel target to interrupt pre-transplant immune dysfunction and improve LT outcomes.

abstract_title: Calcium Ion Channels Are a Potential Therapeutic Target in Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma.
author_block: A. Liu<sup>1</sup>, M. Lu<sup>2</sup>, Y. Guo<sup>2</sup>, K. Wood<sup>2,3</sup>, M. Lidsky<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Surgery,Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Duke University,Pharmacology And Cancer Biology,Durham, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>Duke Cancer Institute,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) is an aggressive primary liver cancer with a high mortality rate. There has been a 128% rise in ICC incidence over the past 40 years in the United States, potentially linked to increases in obesity and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. Because most patients are diagnosed with advanced or metastatic disease, only 20% undergo curative-intent resection, with the majority of patients treated with systemic chemotherapy. Unfortunately, current therapies are not highly effective, yielding a median overall survival less than 1 year. Here, we use a high-throughput, unbiased approach to identify candidate essential genes and potential new therapeutic targets in ICC.

Methods: CRISPR/Cas9 essentiality screens were performed on 5 ICC cell lines using a customized 2,400 gene library targeting epigenetic modifiers, DNA damage modifiers, genes commonly upregulated in cancer, the full kinome, genes with FDA-approved agents, and a series of universally essential (positive) controls and negative controls. Screen results were compared to the publicly available DepMap dataset to identify strongly essential candidate genes specific to ICC. We then focused on validating essentiality of two genes, CACNA1G and CACNA1A, using targeted gene knockdown by RNAi in paired cell viability and clonogenic assays in two ICC lines (RBE and SSP-25) and pancreas (PANC0327) and colorectal (CRC119) cancer cell lines.

Results: CRISPR/Cas9 replicate versus replicate plots of the log2-fold change in construct abundance between final (TF) and initial (T0) cell populations confirmed reliability of the screen. Relative log-depletion scores <-1.8 in at least 60% of samples was required for gene inclusion. Cross-referencing to DepMap yielded 75 genes that were strongly essential in ICC cell lines but rarely essential in other cancers, two of which were CACNA1G and CACNA1A. These genes were essential in 8% and 2% of cell lines in DepMap, respectively. Targeted gene knockdown by RNAi in RBE, SSP-25, PANC0327 and CRC119 lines resulted in cell death in the ICC lines but not the pancreas and colorectal cancer cell lines (Figure 1), which was validated using a second independent hairpin targeting each gene.

Conclusion: These data demonstrate that CACNA1G and CACNA1A are candidate genes of essentiality in at least two ICC lines, RBE and SSP-25. These genes encode voltage-gated calcium channel subunits alpha1G and 1A. Prior work demonstrates that combining a calcium channel blocker (CCB) and chemotherapy synergistically slows tumor growth in an explanted tumor mouse model of ICC. Given recent progress in using CCBs to modulate melanoma and lung cancer progression, these drugs may also be a therapeutic option for ICC.

abstract_title: Meta-Analysis on Transcriptomic Gene Expression in Vein Graft Failure
author_block: M. J. Zhu<sup>1,2,3</sup>, N. Momi<sup>1,3</sup>, M. K. Bhasin<sup>4</sup>, S. Kaur<sup>1,3</sup>, F. W. LoGerfo<sup>1,3</sup>, L. Pradhan-Nabzdyk<sup>1,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Vascular Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston University,School Of Medicine,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intimal hyperplasia (IH) has remained a common problem in the field of vein graft failure (VGF) with minimal clinical success. In recent years, few genomic studies have shed light on potential therapeutic targets for IH. Here, we aim to perform a meta-analysis on transcriptomic profiles to find a potential global signature for prevention and treatment of VGF.

Methods: We included two temporal transcriptomic studies: one on whole vein graft tissue (study1-PMID: 14981462) and the other on endothelial cells (ECs) and smooth muscle cells (SMCs) harvested from vein graft (study2-PMID: 22720046). A third study on aortic ECs exposed to wall sheer stress was also included (study3-GSE29376). Datasets were Robust Multichip Average (RMA)-normalized, and differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between vein graft vs control (study1,2) and pressure vs no pressure(study3) were elucidated using the limma-R package (p< 0.05 and log2 fold change (lfc)=1), represented by heatmaps. Additionally, for subtle genomic changes, Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) was performed (p<0.05 and FDR <0.3), and common enriched pathways were identified between the groups categorized into early (study 1,2 early time points plus study 3) and late (study 1,2 late time points) time-point groups. Genes from these common enriched pathways were derived by leading edge analysis (picked based on lfc =0.25 from DEGs analysis). Both, differential genes and GSEA based genes were subjected to the WGCNA based correlation analysis (z score <2 for non-conserved modules between graft and control). Further, cytoscape based interactive network analysis was performed, and the top 100 hub genes were identified (scored by centrality, stress, degree and closeness). Finally, genes associated with significant pathways from Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) were boxplotted to visualize the changes and patterns through studies 1, 2, and 3.

Results: The GSEA analysis demonstrated 16 common enriched pathways, primarily related to immune response, between early and late time-point groups. Further, WGCNA-cytoscape-IPA analysis revealed 113 genes with significant changes to gene expression between control and experimental groups. Visualization of the boxplot data suggested changes in gene expression for VEGFB, PTTG1, RCF4, JUN, EGR1, TCF4, and RHOBTB1 across all three studies.

Conclusion: Our analysis, comprising of diverse models (canine, bovine) and including hemodynamic sheer stress effects, whole tissue comparisons, and cell-specific contributions towards early and late stage VGF, has identified potential genomic signature comprising of 113 genes implicated in immune response, cell migration, proliferation, differentiation, and extracellular matrix remodeling, providing potential targets for future therapeutics to treat IH.

abstract_title: Deletion of Neu5Gc associated with increased rejection of pig renal transplants in baboons
author_block: C. Hansen-estruch<sup>1</sup>, J. Foote<sup>2</sup>, A. Jagdale<sup>3</sup>, T. Yamamoto<sup>3</sup>, H. Iwase<sup>3</sup>, D. K. Cooper<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,General Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Microbiology And Animal Resources Program,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Xenotransplantation Program, Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a known gap between the number of patients who medically require transplant and the number of organs available. Xenotransplantation can potentially address this gap. Initial setbacks due to hyperacute and acute rejection have been mitigated with pigs genetically engineered to knock out highly immunogenic xenoantigens. Now, pig-to-baboon life-supporting renal xenotransplant models have demonstrated long-term rejection free survival, bringing xenotransplant closer to becoming a clinical reality. In recent serological studies, knockout of one of the xenoantigens, N-glycolylneuraminic acid (Neu5Gc), has been shown to decrease human antibody binding but increase binding with baboon antibodies. Unlike humans, baboons naturally express Neu5Gc and it is postulated that deletion of this gene may lead to exposure of other antigens immunogenic to baboons. We wanted to explore the clinical implications of these findings in a previously tested pig-to-baboon transplant model.

Methods: The goal of this study was to compare the survival and graft histopathology in baboons receiving life supporting kidney transplants from pig donors who either expressed Neu5Gc (GTKO pigs, group 1) or did not express Neu5Gc (GTKO/CMAHKO termed Double KO or ‘DKO’ pigs, GTKO/CMAHKO/B4GALNT2 KO termed Triple KO or ‘TKO’ pigs, group 2). All donor pigs were also engineered to express genes previously shown to regulate coagulation and inflammatory responses. All baboons received a previously proven anti-CD40mAb-based immunosuppressive regimen. Histopathology was based on the BANFF scoring criteria where applicable and a number of histologic features were noted.

Results: Group 1 baboons (n=5) had a median survival time of 237 days with 2 kidneys revealing histopathological features of antibody-mediated rejection including vascular inflammation, fibrin thrombi formation, and immunoglobulin deposition in renal interstitial arteries and peritubular capillaries. Group 2 baboons (n=5) had a significantly shorter median survival time of 61 days with 4 grafts revealing features of antibody-mediated rejection.

Conclusion: Baboons receiving a xenotransplant from pig donors genetically modified to not express Neu5Gc have decreased survival time and appear more likely to mount an adaptive immune response than baboons receiving grafts from pig donors that express Neu5Gc. Given the serological studies showing reduced human antibody binding to pig cells that do not express Neu5Gc, the optimal pig for clinical trials would likely contain this mutation. The results of this study point more toward a limitation with the currently accepted pig-to-baboon xenotransplant model and should not impede clinical xenotransplantation.

abstract_title: C-GAS is Critical in Maintaining the Crosstalk Between Cell Death and Autophagy in Colitis
author_block: S. Khan<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Novak<sup>1</sup>, H. L. Mentrup<sup>1</sup>, K. Hrebinko<sup>1</sup>, T. R. Billiar<sup>1</sup>, K. P. Mollen<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Division Of Pediatric Surgery/Department Of General Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is spectrum of chronic and relapsing inflammatory conditions of the gastrointestinal tract. Although the precise mechanism of IBD has yet to be elucidated, key to this inflammatory process is the recognition of damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) by pattern recognition receptors (PRR). Cyclic-GMP-AMP Synthase (cGAS) is a recently discovered cytoplasmic PRR that senses both pathogenic and self-DNAs. cGAS has been demonstrated to promote cell death as well as autophagy, a cellular mechanism that removes dysfunctional cellular components by transporting them into double membraned vesicles for degradation. We hypothesize that cGAS plays a key role in intestinal homeostasis by maintaining the crosstalk between cell death and autophagy in IBD. 

Methods: We evaluated intestinal mRNA expression and protein levels of cGAS in patients with Ulcerative Colitis (UC, n=4), Crohn’s disease (CD, n=4), and controls (n=4). Subsequently, we performed a standard 7-day 2% Dextran Sulfate Sodium colitis model on cGAS KO (n=16) and WT C7/B6 mice (n=13). We assessed the disease activity index (DAI) scores comprised of weight loss, stool consistency, and bleeding. We evaluated the tissue via qPCR, western blot analysis, H&E staining, immunofluorescence (IF), and TUNEL assay. 

Results: We found significant increases in cGAS mRNA expression in patients with UC (p<0.01) and CD (p=.02). IF and WB demonstrated increased cGAS protein in IBD patients. Our results also demonstrate cGAS KO mice to have worsened severity of colitis compared to WT mice when subjected to experimental colitis. This was demonstrated by significantly higher DAI scores (p<.01), shorter colon lengths (p<.01), increased pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1ß(p<.01) and TNF-α (p<.01), as well as increased gross tissue damage seen with H&E staining. We report decreased expression of the key autophagy initiation protein, Beclin-1 (p<0.01), decreased autophagic flux demonstrated by decreased conversion of LC3-I to LC3-II (p=0.05), and increased levels of p-62 protein expression signifying disruption of autophagy in cGAS KO mice subjected to experimental colitis compared to WT mice. In our investigation of cell death via IF our data demonstrates significantly higher TUNEL staining (p<.01), as well as increased staining for RIPK-3 and p-MLKL signifying increased necroptotic cell death in cGAS KO mice subjected to DSS when compared to WT mice subjected to experimental colitis. 

Conclusion: CGAS has been shown to play a key role in the defense against pathogens as well as a stimulator of autoimmune inflammation. Our data suggest that cGAS plays a key role in maintaining the intestinal epithelial homeostasis during human IBD and murine colitis by regulating a homeostatic balance between autophagy and cell death.

abstract_title: A Structurally-Engineered Fatty Acid Prevents Parenteral Nutrition-Induced Liver Injury
author_block: J. Secor<sup>1,2</sup>, B. Cho<sup>1,2</sup>, L. J. Yu<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Pan<sup>1,2</sup>, V. Ko<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Puder<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Vascular Biology Program,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston Children's Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The prevalence of prolonged parenteral nutrition (PN) use among children in the United States continues to rise as survival for children with intestinal failure increases. Prolonged dependence on PN carries a dose- and time-dependent increase in the likelihood of developing intestinal failure associated liver disease (IFALD). IFALD is characterized first by cholestasis and subsequently can cause progressive liver failure requiring transplantation or lead to death. New therapies are needed to reduce morbidity and mortality for children with IFALD. SEFA-6179 is a fully-synthetic medium chain fatty acid engineered to maximize fatty acid-sensitive pathway signaling by limiting rapid intracellular metabolism. Here, we investigate SEFA-6179 in treating parenteral nutrition-induced liver injury in a murine model of IFALD.

Methods:  Eight-week-old, male C57BL/6 mice were fed chow as control or liquid PN in a model of IFALD. Mice on PN diet were administered medium chain triglycerides (MCT) as vehicle control or SEFA-6179 (264 mg/kg) via orogastric gavage every other day. After 19 days, mice were then sacrificed, and serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and liver histology were analyzed. A second experiment was performed using chow or PN diet, orogastric gavage with MCT or SEFA-6179, and the addition of intravenous tail vein injections with saline as control or soybean oil-based lipid emulsion (Intralipid) every other day. Liver histology and ultra-high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectroscopy (UHPLC-MS) of liver tissue were analyzed for lipid content.

Results: PN diet induced hepatic steatosis, as evidenced by intracellular lipid accumulation on histology (A, column 2). Treatment with SEFA-6179 prevented hepatic steatosis (A, column 4). PN diet caused non-statistically significant increases in serum AST and ALT which were reduced by SEFA-6179 (B). SEFA-6179 attenuated hepatic steatosis induced by concomitant administration of PN diet and intravenous Intralipid (C). On UHPLC-MS, liver samples from mice on PN diet with and without Intralipid exhibited significant increases in hepatic cholesterol esters and the pro-inflammatory, arachidonic acid metabolite 12-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid (12-HETE). These elevations were prevented by SEFA-6179 (D).

Conclusion: Treatment with SEFA-6179 prevents hepatic steatosis induced by PN alone and PN with concomitant intravenous Intralipid. SEFA-6179 attenuates PN-induced elevation in serum AST and ALT. The mechanism by which SEFA-6179 exhibits hepatoprotection may be through reducing hepatic cholesterol esters and the pro-inflammatory mediator 12-HETE. Treatment with SEFA-6179 has the potential to reduce morbidity and mortality in children with IFALD.

abstract_title: Expression of Programmed Death Ligand 1 in Drug Resistant Osteosarcoma
author_block: S. Szajek<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Skertich<sup>1</sup>, F. Chu<sup>1</sup>, M. Madonna<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center,Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Osteosarcoma is common childhood cancer with a poor prognosis when recurrent or metastatic with 5-year survival less than 30%. Prior studies suggest that multi-drug resistant tumors are more metastatic relative to their parental wild-type (WT) cells but the mechanisms have yet to be fully elucidated. Inhibition of the interaction between programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) and programmed death 1 (PD-1) has been successfully used for treatment of multiple advanced adult cancers, but has yet to be explored in pediatric solid tumors.  In this study, we investigated the expression of PD-L1 in osteosarcoma to determine the potential usefulness as a target for drug therapy.

Methods:  We used Human WT osteosarcoma (SJSA-1) cell line and created a doxorubicin resistant (DoxR) cell line via incubating WT cells with incremental concentrations of doxorubicin.  Resistance was determined by a 100-fold difference in half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC-50) on 3-(4,5-dimethyl-2-thiazolyl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) calorimetric assay. Matrigel in vitro invasion assays were used to compare invasiveness of WT to DoxR cells. Western blot assays were used to compare PD-L1 expression in WT and DoxR cells. Chi-square tests were used to determine significant difference in percent invasion.

Results: A DoxR cell line was successfully created with IC-50 of 1.8x10^5 compared to that of WT cells, 1.9x10^7. DoxR cells were significantly more invasive than WT cells (0.47 vs. Y0.07, p<0.001). Expression of PD-L1 was present in DoxR cells but not in WT cells based on Western blot assays.

Conclusion: PD-L1 is expressed in DoxR but not WT osteosarcoma cells and may be involved in the regulation of drug resistance and cancer invasiveness.  Further studies exploring the invasiveness and expression of PD-L1 with inhibition of the PD-1, PD-L1 interaction are needed to determine the possible utility as a target for drug therapy.

abstract_title: Blockade of CXCR4 Decreases the Migration and Invasion of Metastatic Hepatoblastoma Cells
author_block: R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, H. R. Markert<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Beierle<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Hjelmeland<sup>2</sup>, E. Mroczek-Musulman<sup>3</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Cell, Developmental And Integrative Biology,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's of Alabama,Department Of Pathology,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Up to 20% of hepatoblastoma patients have pulmonary metastasis at presentation, and the overall survival of these children may be as low as 25%. Metastatic hepatoblastoma continues to pose a significant treatment challenge, in part, because the precise mechanisms involved in metastasis are not yet fully understood. We have previously established human metastatic hepatoblastoma cell line variants that exhibited enhanced tumorigenicity and invasiveness along with increased phosphorylation of C-X-C chemokine receptor type 4 (CXCR4), a key regulator of tumor metastasis in various cancers. Using these metastatic hepatoblastoma cells, we aimed to assess whether the enhanced invasiveness in vitro is dependent on CXCR4. We hypothesized that CXCR4 blockade with the small molecule inhibitor AMD3100 would inhibit the migration and invasion of metastatic hepatoblastoma cells.

Methods: The human hepatoblastoma cell line, HuH6, and the metastatic variant, HLM, were utilized. Cells were treated with increasing concentrations of AMD3100 (0-30 µM) for 24 hours. CXCR4 cell surface expression was assessed by flow cytometry using an anti-CXCR4-PE antibody that competes with AMD3100 in binding to epitope 12G5. Migration was evaluated using transwell assays, and a layer of Matrigel was added to the upper chamber to evaluate invasion. Data were normalized to untreated HuH6 cells and reported as mean ± standard error of the mean. Student’s t-test was used with p≤0.05 determined significant.

Results: HLM cells had higher CXCR4 surface expression than HuH6 cells (57 ± 2 compared to 35 ± 0.5 percent in HuH6 cells, p≤0.001, Figure 1C, black bars). Treatment with AMD3100 decreased the percentage of cells labeled with the anti-CXCR4 antibody in both HuH6 and HLM cell lines (p≤0.05, Figure 1C-D), indicating blockade of the CXCR4 receptor and successful inhibition of the desired target. HLM cells exhibited enhanced migration and invasion at baseline compared to HuH6 cells (4 ± 0.3 and 3 ± 0.1 fold change, respectively, p≤0.01, Figure 1A-B, black bars), confirming a more invasive phenotype. AMD3100 treatment of both cell lines decreased migration and invasion in a concentration-dependent manner (p≤0.05, Figure 1A-B). AMD3100 at higher concentrations reduced invasion of HLM cells to levels comparable to those seen in treated HuH6 cells, indicating that CXCR4 contributes to the in vitro invasiveness of HLM cells.

Conclusion: Blockade of CXCR4 decreased the migration and invasion of metastatic hepatoblastoma cells, suggesting that CXCR4 inhibitors may be an effective therapeutic adjunct in the treatment of hepatoblastoma.

abstract_title: Class I Histone Deacetylase Inhibitor Therapy in the Treatment of Hepatoblastoma
author_block: R. S. Whitlock<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Srivastava<sup>2</sup>, R. Patel<sup>2</sup>, S. Larson<sup>2</sup>, S. Woodfield<sup>2</sup>, S. Vasudevan<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgical Oncology Laboratory,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Relapse/refractory hepatoblastoma (rHB) can have an overall survival of less than 50% with limited systemic treatment options. Targeted treatment strategies are needed for these children that cannot be cured with surgery alone.  Histone deacetylase inhibitors (HDACi) have shown promising results in the treatment of various malignancies. We sought to characterize HDAC gene expression in HB samples and determine the most effective HDACi strategy for HB. 

Methods: HDAC gene expression was screened in a cohort of 50 HB patients in comparison to six uninvolved liver samples with microarray analyses and further validated by quantitative real time polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) in several HB cell lines and pooled normal liver. Several HDACi agents that target different groups of HDAC genes including panobinostat (pan inhibitor), mocitinostat (HDAC1, HDAC2, HDAC3), entinostat (HDAC1, HDAC3), and romidepsin (HDAC2, HDAC3) were tested with cytotoxicity assays (MTT). Immunoblotting assays were used to assess changes in drug targets and induction of apoptosis (PARP cleavage) with cell lines.

Results:Patient tumor samples showed clear differential expression of HDAC gene expression, including strong upregulation of class I HDAC genes HDAC1, HDAC2, HDAC3, and HDAC4 with selective downregulation of HDAC10 & HDAC11 which was further confirmed by RT-PCR (Figure 1).  Overexpression of HDAC2 and HDAC3 was shown to be the most upregulated HDAC genes as compared to normal liver with statistically significant increases in HB cell lines HepG2, HepT1, B62, HuH6, and HB17 (p=<0.05).  Panobinostat (IC50 of 0.01-0.05 µM) showed strong effects in in vitro assays for viability while immunoblotting with panobinostat-treated cells showed an increase in acetylated histone H3 and H4 and an increase in cleaved PARP indicating cell death.  In vitro assays also demonstrated efficacy of HDACi mocetinostat (IC50 of .556-4.31µM), entinostat (IC50 of 3.06-10.91 µM), and romidepsin (IC50 of .001-.02 µM),

Conclusion:Class I HDAC gene expression, specifically upregulation of HDAC2, is significantly altered in HB as compared to normal liver and may serve as a marker of HDACi responsiveness for patients that do not respond to standard therapies.  Panobinostat and romidepsin showed strong preclinical in vitro efficacy suggesting that specific targeting of HDAC2 and HDAC3 may be a novel strategy for treatment development of rHB.

abstract_title: Reactivation of silenced ?-N-catenin induces retinoic acid sensitivity in neuroblastoma cells
author_block: R. A. Clark<sup>1</sup>, J. Qiao<sup>1</sup>, M. Newton<sup>1</sup>, S. Lee<sup>1</sup>, D. H. Chung<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Pediatric Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The high-risk group of neuroblastoma (NB) remains the most difficult to treat with frequent resistance to chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Epigenetic modifications in NB may attribute to refractoriness to multi-modality treatment regimens. We have previously found that α -N-catenin, a cell-adhesion protein, plays a tumor suppressor role in non-MYCN amplified NB by inhibiting the NF-κB signaling pathway. In addition, advanced-stage NB patients have decreased expression of the gene CTNNA2, which encodes for α-N-catenin. A subset of NB tumors that lack α-N-catenin are resistant to all-trans-retinoic-acid (RA). Recently, we demonstrated that re-expression of α-N-catenin enhanced sensitivity to RA. However, the mechanism of CTNNA2 silencing in NB remains unknown. Herein, we sought to determine the mechanism of α-N-catenin silencing in NB.

Methods:  Epigenetic modification occurs through DNA methylation or histone modification. In order to distinguish between methylation or histone modification, human NB cell lines SK-N-AS and SHEP, which lack endogenous α-N-catenin expression, and BE(2)-C cells that express α-N-catenin, were treated with 5-azacytidine (5AZ), a methylation inhibitor, and Trichostatin A (TSA), a deacetylase inhibitor. The expression of CTNNA2 and its downstream targets was examined with qRT-PCR and immunoblotting. Cell survival was measured with a CCK-8 kit assay

Results: Treatment with 5AZ did not induce α-N-catenin expression. TSA treatment induced CTNNA2 expression in SK-N-AS and SHEP cells and increased CTNNA2 expression in BE(2)-C cells. TSA treatment also increased the expression of the CTNNA2 downstream targets including: p21, p27, GADD45G and TNF-α. TSA treatment decreased cellular proliferation in all 3 cell lines. Treatment with RA and TSA, in combination, increased CTNNA2 expression and decreased cellular proliferation in RA-resistant cell lines, SK-N-AS and SHEP.  However, in the RA-sensitive cell line, BE(2)-C, there was no added benefit of combination RA and TSA treatment. In combination with RA, cellular proliferation of the SHEP cells was inhibited at a dose three-times less than TSA alone.

Conclusion: The expression of α-N-catenin is silenced in advanced-stage NBs; this was reactivated epigenetically by histone modification. RA and TSA synergistically induce CTNNA2 expression, and in turn, cellular differentiation, as well decrease cellular proliferation in NB. Combination therapy allows for significantly lower doses of RA and TSA. We conclude that α-N-catenin is a potential biomarker for response to RA therapy and that combination treatment with TSA and RA may improve survival among children with high-risk, RA-resistant NB.

abstract_title: Mismatch Repair Status Correlates with Survival in Young Adults with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer
author_block: D. M. Van Der Heide<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Turaga<sup>2</sup>, C. H. Chan<sup>1</sup>, S. K. Sherman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Department Of Surgery, Carver College Of Medicine,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Deficient mismatch repair (dMMR) correlated with worse survival compared to proficient MMR (pMMR) among metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) patients in a recent National Cancer Database (NCDB) study. Young adults with mCRC may have higher rates of dMMR, but its impact on survival in this population is incompletely understood. This study sought to assess patterns of MMR testing and survival among young adult mCRC patients in the NCDB, hypothesizing that dMMR correlates with worse survival.

Methods: Stage-IV colorectal cancers in patients ≤ 30 years old were identified in NCDB (2010-2016). Demographic and clinical features were compared between younger and older mCRC patients, and tested for association with overall survival. Stage-IV disease and absence of other recorded metastatic sites defined isolated peritoneal metastases. Fisher exact tests compared proportions and Cox models tested association with overall survival. 

Results: Of 124,587 stage-IV colorectal cancers, 1,123 patients were 30 years of age or younger. Young patients were less often white (59.1 vs 74.6%) and were more likely to have mucinous histology (16.4 vs 9.0%), high-grade tumors (28.7 vs 20.5%), rectal or rectosigmoid primaries (34.6 vs 26.9%) and isolated peritoneal metastases (28.5 vs 18.6%; p<0.001 for all). Although younger patients more often had MMR-testing (29.1 vs 16.6%, p<0.001), dMMR was found at similar rates in young and older patients (21.7 vs 17.1% of those tested, p=0.2).  Despite higher rates of adverse prognostic features, younger patients had better survival (median 20.7 vs 14.8 months, p<0.001). In young patients, primary site, race, sex, and KRAS status did not correlate with survival (p>0.5). Peritoneal metastases and mucinous histology showed some association with worse survival (p=0.06 for both). Significantly worse survival was observed in those with high-grade (HR 2.54) and right-sided tumors (HR 1.59, p<0.05 for both). Among young adults with MMR-testing, dMMR correlated with higher risk of death compared to pMMR (median survival 16.6 months vs 25.5 months, HR 1.63, p=0.01, Figure).  A multivariable model included factors with univariable p<0.1.  Grade, tumor location, and MMR status remained independently associated.

Conclusion: Deficient mismatch repair is a marker of poor prognosis in younger adults in NCDB with mCRC. Median survival was worse with dMMR by 8.9 months compared to pMMR patients. Despite higher rates of familial syndromes in young patients and recommendations for universal MMR-testing, over 70% of young mCRC patients had no MMR-status recorded. Increased MMR-testing in this population will identify patients eligible for immune therapy, which could improve outcomes in the future.

abstract_title: Inhibition of RAS Activity Delays Neuroblastoma Tumor Formation
author_block: M. Diyaolu<sup>1</sup>, V. Rajagopalan<sup>2</sup>, J. Zeki<sup>1</sup>, L. Wood<sup>1</sup>, R. Greathouse<sup>1</sup>, J. O'Bryan<sup>2</sup>, B. Chiu<sup>1</sup>, B. Chiu<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Pediatric Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical University Of South Carolina,Cell And Molecular Pharmacology And Experimental Therapeutics,Charleston, Sc, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neuroblastoma (NBL) is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children with poor survival rates for high-risk tumors. Although RAS genes are infrequently mutated in NBL, RAS activity has been implicated in NBL tumorigenesis. We hypothesize that RAS activity is required for NBL tumor establishment and inhibiting RAS can delay tumor formation. We tested this hypothesis on an orthotopic NBL xenograft model and developed NS1, a RAS monobody, that specifically inhibits HRAS- and KRAS-mediated signaling by targeting a critical allosteric regulatory site, thereby preventing RAS activation of downstream effectors. Monobodies are single-domain proteins of ~95 amino acids that achieve levels of affinity and selectivity similar to antibodies yet are insensitive to the redox potential of their environment.

Methods: We stably infected a NBL cell line SK-N-FI with a lentivirus encoded with doxycycline (DOX)-regulated NS1 expression construct that allowed for chemically regulated NS1 expression (and RAS inhibition) both in vitro and in vivo (SK-N-FI-NS1). Western blot was performed on SK-N-FI-NS1 cells to evaluate for suppression of RAS activity. Equivalent amounts of lysate were incubated with GST-RAF RBD (GST fusion-protein, corresponding to the human Ras Binding Domain of Raf-1) to pulldown active RAS. Orthotopic NBL xenografts were generated by injecting one million SK-N-FI-NS1 cells into the left adrenal gland of immunocompromised nude mice. After injection, mice received fresh water +/- DOX every other day for up to 2 months. Tumors were tracked with ultrasound twice weekly. Once tumors reached >1000mm3, animals were euthanized.

Results: SK-N-FI cells are not MYCN amplified, have low MYCN but high HRAS expression (Fig 1A). SK-N-FI-NS1 cells demonstrated a decrease in RAS activity after NS1 induction with DOX (Fig 1B). Mice that did not receive DOX induction began to develop adrenal tumor starting 13 days after adrenal gland injection with SK-N-FI-NS1 cells, while those treated with DOX did not until day 30 (Figure 1C). On post-cell injection day 34, all non-DOX animals had developed tumor, while only 60% of DOX-treated animals did.

Conclusion: NS1, a RAS monobody, is a powerful tool to assess the role of RAS in NBL. Induction of NS1 results in delayed NBL tumor formation, and this suggests that the RAS-MAPK pathway can be potential therapeutic targets for NBL treatment.

abstract_title: A Modified Eighth AJCC Staging System For Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma
author_block: X. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Tsilimigras<sup>2</sup>, A. Guglielmi<sup>3</sup>, L. Aldrighetti<sup>4</sup>, M. Weiss<sup>5</sup>, T. W. Bauer<sup>6</sup>, S. Alexandrescu<sup>7</sup>, G. A. Poultsides<sup>8</sup>, S. K. Maithel<sup>9</sup>, H. P. Marques<sup>10</sup>, G. Martel<sup>11</sup>, C. Pulitano<sup>12</sup>, F. Shen<sup>13</sup>, O. Soubrane<sup>14</sup>, B. G. Koerkamp<sup>15</sup>, I. Endo<sup>16</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Department of Hepatobiliary Surgery and Institute of Advanced Surgical Technology and Engineering, The First Affiliated Hospital of Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China,Xi'an, China <sup>2</sup>Department of Surgery, Division of Surgical Oncology, The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center and James Comprehensive Cancer Center,Columbus, OHIO, USA <sup>3</sup>Department of Surgery, University of Verona,Verona, ITALY, Italy <sup>4</sup>Department of Surgery, Ospedale San Raffaele,Milano, ITALY, Italy <sup>5</sup>Department of Surgery, Johns Hopkins Hospital,Baltimore, MARYLAND, USA <sup>6</sup>Department of Surgery, University of Virginia,Charlottesville, VIRGINIA, USA <sup>7</sup>Department of Surgery, Fundeni Clinical Institute,Bucharest, ROMANIA, Romania <sup>8</sup>Department of Surgery, Stanford University,Palo Alto, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>9</sup>Department of Surgery, Emory University,Atlanta, GEORGIA, USA <sup>10</sup>Department of Surgery, Curry Cabral Hospital,Lisbon, PORTUGAL, Portugal <sup>11</sup>Department of Surgery, University of Ottawa,Ottawa, CANADA, Canada <sup>12</sup>Department of Surgery, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, University of Sydney,Sydney, AUSTRALIA, Australia <sup>13</sup>Department of Surgery, Eastern Hepatobiliary Surgery Hospital,Shanghai, CHINA, China <sup>14</sup>Department of Hepatobiliopancreatic Surgery and Liver Transplantation, AP-HP, Beaujon Hospital,Clichy, FRANCE, France <sup>15</sup>Department of Surgery, Erasmus University Medical Centre,Rotterdam, NETHERLANDS, Netherlands <sup>16</sup>Department of Gastroenterological Surgery, Yokohama City University School of Medicine,Yokohama, JAPAN, Japan
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Validation of the updated 8th AJCC staging system for intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) has been limited and controversial. The objective of the current study was to improve the prognostic accuracy of the 8thedition of the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) staging system for ICC with the establishment and validation of a new staging system. 

Methods:  Data from an international multi-institutional database (1999-2017)(n=643) and the SEER registry (1975-2016)(n=797) were used as development and validation cohorts, respectively. A modified TNM (mTNM) was proposed by redefining the 8thAJCC T categories, and incorporating the recently proposed N status as N0 (no lymph node metastasis [LNM]), N1 (1-2 LNM) and N2 (>3 LNM), as well as adopting a new stage classification.

Results: The 8thTNM staging system failed to stratify patients with stage II versus IIIA, stage IIIB versus IV, as well as overall stage III versus IV relative to long-term overall survival (OS) in both databases (multi-institutional database: median OS, stage II 37.8 vs. IIIA 50.8 months, p=0.314; IIIB 18.9 vs. IV 17.0 months, p=0.256; III 20.7 vs. IV 17.0 months, p=0.058; SEER registry: median OS, stage II 33.0 vs. IIIA 88.8 months, p=0.636; IIIB 18.0 vs. IV 15.5 months, p=0.858; III 18.9 vs. IV 15.5 months, p=0.779) (Figure).Based on multivariable analysis, perforation of visceral peritoneum (HR 1.2, 95% CI 0.9-1.6, p=0.219) was removed from the T definition, whereas multiple tumors (HR 1.6, 95% CI 1.3-2.1, p<0.001), tumors with periductal infiltration (HR 1.7, 95% CI 1.3-2.3, p<0.001), as well as tumors involving local extrahepatic structures by direct invasion (HR 1.7, 95% CI 1.1-2.6, p=0.012) were defined as T4 in the new staging system. There was a monotonic decrement in survival based on the proposed mTNM staging classification among patients derived from both the multi-institutional (median OS, stage IA 101.4 months, IB 66.3 months vs. stage IIA 45.2 months, IIB 37.1 months vs. stage III 18.9 months vs. stage IV 16.4 months, all p<0.05) and SEER registry (median OS, stage IA 73.0 months, IB 85.1 months vs. stage IIA 46.0 months, IIB 24.5 months vs. stage III 17.7 months vs. stage IV 14.2 months, all p<0.05) datasets (Figure). On multivariable analysis, mTNM staging remained strongly associated with prognosis, as the hazard of death incrementally increased with each stage among patients in the two cohorts.

Conclusion: The modified 8th AJCC TNM staging system for ICC using the new T and N definitions improved stratification of patients relative to long-term OS versus the original 8thAJCC staging, and therefore should be considered for potential adoption in the next AJCC staging manual edition.

abstract_title: The Impact of Obesity and Severe Obesity on Postoperative Outcomes After Pancreatoduodenectomy
author_block: C. M. Lattimore<sup>1</sup>, W. J. Kane<sup>1</sup>, F. E. Turrentine<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Jones<sup>1</sup>, V. M. Zaydfudim<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia,Department Of Surgery,Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The epidemic of obesity is affecting care delivery and health outcomes across societal strata. The impact of obesity on postoperative outcomes including operation-specific complications, morbidity, and mortality remains understudied for patients undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy for benign and malignant pancreatic disease.

Methods: Patients who underwent pancreatoduodenectomy were abstracted from the 2014-2018 American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program PUF Targeted Pancreatectomy dataset and were included in the study. Patients were stratified into three BMI categories: non-obese (BMI 18.5-29.9); class 1/2 obesity (BMI 30-39.9); and class 3 severe obesity (BMI>40). Patients with BMI<18.5, ASA class 5 and emergency operations were excluded. Bivariable analyses tested associations between patient factors and 30-day postoperative outcomes including NSQIP-defined composite morbidity, mortality, delayed gastric emptying (DGE) and postoperative pancreatic fistula (POPF). Multivariable logistic regression models tested independent associations between patient factors and outcome measures.

Results: A total of 16,823 patients were included in the study: 12,234 (72.7%) non-obese; 4,030 (24%) obese; and 559 (3.3%) severely obese. Obesity and severe obesity were associated with younger age and lower rates of smoking (both p<0.001), however greater incidence of preoperative comorbid conditions: hypertension, diabetes, congestive heart failure, dyspnea, and higher rates of ASA class of 3 or 4 (p≤0.008). Both severe obesity and obesity were associated with a greater likelihood of post-operative complications when compared to non-obese patients, including POPF (29.3% vs 23.2% vs 15.5%, p<0.001); DGE (20.2% vs 17.5% vs 15.4%, p=0.001), composite morbidity (41.0% vs 38.2% vs 32.5%, p<0.001), and mortality (1.8% vs 2.2% vs 1.3%, p<0.001). After adjusting for statistically significant patient and procedural factors, obesity was independently associated with POPF (OR=1.51, 95%CI: 1.35-1.69, p<0.001), DGE (OR=1.18; 95%CI: 1.07-1.31, p=0.009), composite morbidity (OR=1.31, 95%CI: 1.21-1.41, p<0.001), and mortality (OR=1.80, 95%CI: 1.37-2.37, p<0.001), (Figure). Similar associations were observed between severe obesity and POPF (OR=2.11, 95%CI: 1.66-2.68, p<0.001), DGE (OR=1.50, 95%CI: 1.21-1.87, p<0.001), and composite morbidity (OR=1.51, 95%CI: 1.27-1.81, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Obesity and severe obesity are significantly associated with worse short-term outcomes after pancreatoduodenectomy. Preoperative counseling, consideration for weight management strategies, vigilant care coordination, and home monitoring programs should improve outcomes in this patient population.

abstract_title: ACA Medicaid Expansion Reduced Disparities in use of High Volume Hospitals for Pancreatic Surgery
author_block: A. Mishra<sup>2</sup>, D. DeLia<sup>1,4</sup>, A. Zeymo<sup>1,2</sup>, J. McDermott<sup>2,3</sup>, N. Aminpour<sup>2</sup>, S. Desale<sup>1,2</sup>, W. B. Al-Refaie<sup>1,2,3</sup> <sup>1</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute,Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute,Surgical Outcomes Research Center,Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Washington, DC, USA <sup>4</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center,Department Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Historically, Medicaid and uninsured surgical patients have been less likely to benefit from regionalized complex surgery at high-volume hospitals (HVH). Whether the Affordable Care Act (ACA)’s Medicaid expansion has decreased disparities in access to HVH for complex surgery remains unknown. This multi-state quasi-experimental study sought to evaluate the effects of this expansion on the utilization of HVH among Medicaid and the uninsured (MCD/UIS) for pancreatic surgery.

Methods: The State Inpatient Databases (2012-2017), American Hospital Association Annual Survey Database, and Area Resource File from Health Resources and Services Administration, were linked to examine 8,264 non-elderly adults (ages 18-64) who underwent pancreatic resections at 296 unique hospitals within nine expansion states (AZ, CO, KY, MA, MD, NJ, NM, NV, WA) and two non-expansion states (NC, FL). HVH thresholds were defined via Leapfrog of 20+ resections per year on average. Linear probability triple differences models were estimated to measure the impact of expansion on utilization rates of MCD/UIS patients relative to the privately insured in expansion versus non-expansion states over pre-/post-ACA.

Results: 39 hospitals were identified as stable HVH over time. Overall, adjusted pre-/post-ACA utilization rates of HVH for pancreatic surgery remained unchanged (66.3% vs. 66.4%, p=0.94). In expansion states and among the MCD/UIS populations, there was a significant increase in HVH utilization rates (pre- vs. post-ACA 48% vs. 55.4%, p=0.047). Prior to expansion, a gap was found in utilization of HVH between expansion states vs. non-expansion states among MCD/UIS patients (77% vs. 48%, p<0.0001), which was reduced after the expansion by 15.1% (p=0.001). Further, a pre-ACA gap between expansion vs. non-expansion states was larger for MCD/UIS relative to privately insured patients by 24.9% (p<0.0001), which was also significantly reduced by 11.2% (p=0.022) in post-ACA period. Triple differences models interacting payer, expansion state status, and pre-/post-ACA showed an increase in utilization of HVH by the MCD/UIS populations relative to the privately insured in expansion states (triple difference estimate +11.7 percentage points, p=0.022) (Figure). Utilization rates among the privately insured remained relatively flat post-ACA.
