Conclusion: This large quasi-experimental evaluation demonstrates that ACA’s Medicaid expansion increased utilization of HVH for pancreatic surgery among MCD/UIS surgical patients. Though it needs to be confirmed with patient outcomes, the ACA may improve pancreatic surgery outcomes via expanded access to HVH. These findings may be informative to non-expansion states that are considering expansion.

abstract_title: Early Right Ventricular Assist Device and ECMO Improves Outcomes in Severe COVID-19 ARDS
author_block: N. J. Smith<sup>1</sup>, M. T. Cain<sup>1</sup>, M. Barash<sup>2</sup>, L. A. Durham<sup>1</sup>, P. Simpson<sup>3</sup>, D. Wang<sup>4</sup>, D. L. Joyce<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Cardiothoracic Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Pulmonary And Critical Care,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Pediatrics,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>4</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Center For Advanced Population Science,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 has proven to be more than just a pulmonary disease with significant cardiovascular sequelae and injury. Mortality from COVID-19 often occurs from Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) with progression to Multisystem Organ Failure (MSOF) characterized by cardiogenic shock and right ventricular dysfunction. We hypothesized that right ventricular dysfunction is the primary determinant of MSOF and early Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) and right ventricular support utilizing a percutaneous Right Ventricular Assist Device (RVAD) could eliminate end-organ failure and reduce mortality.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of a single institution between March 1 and July 6, 2020 was performed of patients admitted to the intensive care unit with severe COVID-19 ARDS.  Non-intubated patients, those with acute renal failure, and age > 75 were excluded. Patients who underwent RVAD/ECMO support and those who were managed via invasive mechanical ventilation alone (IMV) were compared. RVAD/ECMO institution was attempted within 24 hours of intubation. The primary outcome was in-hospital mortality. Secondary outcomes included 30-day mortality, acute renal failure, length of stay, and duration of mechanical ventilation.

Results: 145 patients were admitted to the ICU with COVID-19 pneumonia. Thirty-nine patients met the inclusion criteria and met Berlin criteria for severe ARDS. Twenty-one received IMV-alone and 18 early RVAD/ECMO. Patient characteristics were similar. Treatment regimens were similar except for use of tocilizumab (23.8 vs 61.1%, p=0.025) and convalescent plasma (9.5 vs 66.7%, p=0.001) which were received more by RVAD/ECMO patients.  In-hospital mortality (52.4 vs 11.1%, p=0.008), 30-day mortality (42.9 vs 5.6%, p=0.011), and Kaplan-Meier cumulative mortality (Log-rank p=0.009) were significantly lower in RVAD/ECMO patients. No RVAD/ECMO patients developed acute renal failure versus 71.4% of IMV patients (p<0.001).). ICU (11.5 vs 21 days, p=0.067) and hospital (14 vs 25.5 days, p=0.054) length of stay were longer for RVADM/ECMO but not statistically significant. There were no RVAD/ECMO device complications. The duration of mechanical ventilation was shorter for RVAD/ECMO but not statistically significant (10 vs 5 days, p=0.44). The most common RVAD/ECMO complication was bleeding (25.0%).

Conclusion: Early RVAD support at the time of VV ECMO initiation for severe COVID-19 ARDS resulted in the elimination of secondary end-organ damage and improved survival when compared to patients treated utilizing invasive mechanical ventilation, with an insignificant trend toward shorter intubation. Management of severe COVID-19 ARDS should incorporate right ventricular support.

abstract_title: Palliative Surgery Outcomes for Patients with Esophageal Cancer: An NCDB Analysis
author_block: M. R. Coffey<sup>1,2</sup>, K. C. Bachman<sup>1,2</sup>, S. G. Worrell<sup>1,2</sup>, L. M. Argote-Greene<sup>1,2</sup>, P. A. Linden<sup>1,2</sup>, C. W. Towe<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Hospitals,Thoracic Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Many patients with esophageal cancer are not candidates for curative intent surgical resection given advanced disease upon presentation. Palliative Surgery (PS) can be performed, but the outcomes of PS have not been described. The purpose of this study was to describe the outcomes of PS in patients with esophageal cancer. 

Methods:  We used the National Cancer Database (NCDB) to identify patients with esophageal and gastroesophageal junction cancer who received PS, or other palliative treatments (P-other) (palliative radiation or palliative chemotherapy (without surgery)) from 2004-2015. Patients with missing follow-up data were excluded. The outcome of interest was overall survival. Characteristics of patients were compared between PS and P-other groups using rank sum or chi square. Survival differences between groups was performed using Kaplan Meier estimate and log rank test, and Cox proportional hazards model.

Results: 14,589 patients were included in the analysis, including 2,812 (19.2%) receiving PS and 11,777 (80.7%) receiving P-other (6,512 palliative radiation and 5,265 palliative chemotherapy). Relative to P-other, the use of PS decreased during the study period form 249/974 (25.5%) in 2004 to 168/1,600 (10.5%) in 2015 (p<0.001). PS patients differed from other forms of palliation in that PS patients tended to be older (70 vs 67 years, p<0.001), female (715/2,812 (25.4%) PS vs 2,449/11,777 (20.8%) P-other, p<0.001), more likely to be clinical N0 (812/2,014 (40.3%) PS vs 2,590/8,960 (28.9%) P-other, p<0.001) and clinical M0 (1,748/2,763 (63.3%) PS vs 2,949/11,544 (25.6%) P-other, p<0.001). PS patients were also less likely to be treated at an academic program (1,217/2,788 (43.7%) PS vs 5,883/11,610 (50.7%) P-other, p<0.001). Median overall survival in PS patients was 5.5 months and was worse than P-other (6.4 months, p=0.004). Cox proportional hazard modeling, however, suggested no difference between PS and P-other when corrected for age, sex, nodal status, metastases, Charlson score, histology, academic program, and private insurance (HR 1.03 (0.975-1.090), p=0.281) (Table).

Conclusion: Although similar to other palliative modalities, Palliative Surgery in advanced esophageal cancer is associated with poor overall survival. Palliative Surgery for esophageal cancer patients should be used sparingly given these poor outcomes.

abstract_title: Concurrent Lung Resection during Esophagectomy does not Increase Perioperative Morbidity or Mortality
author_block: D. C. Patel<sup>1</sup>, P. Bhandari<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Shrager<sup>1</sup>, M. F. Berry<sup>1</sup>, L. M. Backhus<sup>1</sup>, N. S. Lui<sup>1</sup>, D. Z. Liou<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Thoracic Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The impact of performing a concomitant lung resection with esophagectomy on short-term outcomes is not well characterized beyond case reports.  This study tests the hypothesis that lung resection at the time of esophagectomy does not significantly increase perioperative morbidity or mortality.

Methods:  The National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) database was queried for all patients who underwent esophagectomy with gastric conduit for esophageal cancer with and without concurrent lung resection between 2006-2017. Transhiatal esophagectomy patients were excluded.  Perioperative outcomes were compared between patients who underwent esophagectomy alone (EA) versus combined esophagectomy and lung resection (EL).  Predictors of perioperative morbidity and mortality, including combined surgery, were evaluated using multivariable logistic regression.

Results: Among the 6,225 patients who met inclusion criteria, 6,068 (97.5%) underwent esophagectomy alone and 157 (2.5%) underwent combined esophagectomy with lung resection. In the EL group, 20 patients had an anatomic lung resection while 137 patients had a wedge resection. There were no differences between the EA and EL groups with respect to age, gender, race, preoperative smoking status, major co-morbidities, functional dependency, and ASA classification.  Operating time for EL was longer than EA (median 416 vs. 371 minutes, p<0.01).  Median length of stay was 10 days for both groups.  Perioperative mortality was not significantly different between EL and EA patients (5.1% vs. 2.8%, p=0.08).  EL patients had higher rates of postoperative pneumonia (22.3% vs. 16.2%, p=0.04) and sepsis (11.5% vs. 7.1%, p=0.03), but major complication rates overall were similar between EL and EA (40.8% vs. 35.3%, p=0.16).  Combining lung resection with esophagectomy was not independently associated with increased postoperative morbidity (AOR 1.21 [95% CI 0.87-1.69]) or mortality (AOR 1.63 [95% CI 0.74-3.58]).  Predictors of major complications based on multivariable analysis include increasing age, dependent functional status, current smoker, COPD, cardiovascular disease, and ASA class 4-5.  Increasing age, black race, dependent functional status, COPD, and ASA class 4-5 predicted increased mortality, however, elevated BMI compared to normal BMI predicted lower mortality (AOR 0.68, p=0.03).  

Conclusion: Concurrent lung resection with esophagectomy does not increase mortality or overall morbidity but is associated with a higher risk of pneumonia beyond esophagectomy alone.  Surgeons considering combining lung resection with Ivor Lewis, McKeown, or thoracoabdominal esophagectomy should carefully consider a patient’s risk for pulmonary complications and consider pre-operative interventions to optimize their respiratory function.

abstract_title: Physical force and lung development: a new ex vivo model for congenital diaphragmatic hernia
author_block: S. Shibuya<sup>1,2</sup>, F. Michielin<sup>1,2</sup>, M. Z. Nikoli?<sup>3</sup>, N. Elvassore<sup>1,2,4</sup>, P. De Coppi<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Great Ormond Street Institute of Child Health,University Collage London,London, LONDON, United Kingdom <sup>2</sup>Zayed Centre for Research into Rare Disease in Children,London, LONDON, United Kingdom <sup>3</sup>Lungs for Living Research Centre, UCL Respiratory,University Collage London,London, LONDON, United Kingdom <sup>4</sup>Department of Industrial Engineering (DII),University Of Padua,Padua, PADUA, Italy
abstract_body:
Introduction: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is one of the most challenging developmental abnormalities complicated with pulmonary hypoplasia caused by compression of the lung by the herniated abdominal organs. Although the sequelae of pulmonary hypoplasia has been well investigated with established animal models, the mechanism of how physical compression alters the cascade of lung development has not yet been revealed at the molecular level. In this study, we evaluated the impact of physical force on lung branching morphogenesis in early gestation using a novel ex vivo model based on a state-of-the-art three-dimensional (3D) printing technique which mimics the mechanical compression observed in CDH.

Methods: Embryonic lungs were harvested from pregnant mice at embryonic day 12.5 (E12.5) and randomly assigned into two groups: control group and model group. Lung explants were placed in a drop of Matrigel in air-liquid interphase (ALI) condition. Chemically modified Polyethylene glycol (PEG) solution was applied on the explants, and a 3D structure surrounding the lung of the model group was created by selective crosslinking of polymers induced by a two-photon laser excitation. The samples were incubated over 48 hours after the 3D printing and compared between the two groups.

Results: Compressed lungs showed decreased branching morphogenesis resulting in decreased number of the terminal buds compared to the controls (21.5 ± 2.8 vs 28.9 ± 5.4, p < 0.001). Cell proliferation analysis with immunofluorescence demonstrated a lower proportion of Ki67 positive cells (12.2 ± 2.8 % vs 19.6 ± 7.1 %, p < 0.001) and increased expression of cleaved Caspase 3 (11.9 ± 3.5 % vs 3.8 ± 1.9 %, p < 0.001) in the model group. Moreover, compressed lung manifested thickened mesenchyme, quantified by a rate of the parenchymal area to the airway area, which showed significant difference between the model group and the control group (2.63 ± 0.59 vs 1.47 ± 0.18, p < 0.001).

Conclusion: We demonstrated delayed branching morphogenesis and altered morphology in the compressed lung model. This ex-vivo model is useful to dynamically evaluate how mechanical compression affects lung development, which may determine the severity of pulmonary hypoplasia of CDH. A clear understanding of the molecular pathways responsible for disease progression will pave the way for a more targeted and non-invasive therapeutic approach, thereby contributing to improved outcomes of severe CDH.

abstract_title: Quantifying Post-Surgery Opioid Use, Misuse, Diversion and Disposal Patterns in US Adults
author_block: E. D. Porter<sup>1</sup>, O. A. Sacks<sup>2</sup>, N. Ramkumar<sup>3</sup>, B. Sirovich<sup>1,3</sup>, R. J. Barth<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Dartmouth Medical School,Biomedical Data Science Department,Hanover, NH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Post-surgery prescription (rx) opioids may lead to opioid misuse and diversion, however there is limited data to support this assumption. This study quantifies post-surgery rx opioid use, misuse, diversion and compliance with disposal of unused pills.

Methods: A 40 question survey assessing post-surgery rx opioid use, misuse, diversion, and disposal patterns of unused opioid pills was developed and administered to participants using Amazon Mechanical Turk, an online crowd-sourcing worksite. The validated opioid risk tool (ORT) was used. Misuse was defined as taking post-surgery rx opioids in a way other than instructed by a provider and diversion was defined as having ever shared, sold, or had their post-surgery rx opioids stolen. Eligible respondents were US adults aged >17 years who had received a post-surgery rx opioid in the last 5 years. Respondents were excluded if they failed an internal validity check or were identified as a robot. Multiple regression analyses identified risk factors associated with post-surgery rx opioid misuse or diversion.

Results: 966 respondents met the eligibility requirements. Respondents were from all 50 states and demographics were similar to that of the US population. 52.2% were male and 78.6% self-identified as white. The majority of respondents were aged 30-39 years (42.7%) and had an associate’s or bachelor’s degree (55.6%). Overall, 34.4% of respondents were given a post-surgery rx opioid lasting more than one week and 7.6% refilled their rx after three months. Almost a third of respondents kept their unused rx opioids pills (n=299, 31.0%). Personal misuse of post-surgery rx opioids was reported in 34.5%. On multivariable regression, risk factors for misuse included working in healthcare, scoring either moderate or high risk on the ORT, experiencing an elevated mood after taking opioids, refilling the opioid rx, and keeping (not disposing) of any unused opioid pills (Figure 1A). Diversion of opioids was reported in 22.0%. Risk factors for diversion included working in healthcare, undergoing plastic surgery, scoring moderate or high risk on the ORT, experiencing an elevated mood, and keeping any unused pills (Figure 1B).

Conclusion: Within a sample population, a third of US adults reported personal misuse of post-surgery rx opioids and a fifth reported diversion. Almost a third did not dispose of unused opioid pills, which was associated with an increased risk for both misuse and diversion. Use of the ORT and asking patients if they experienced an elevated mood while taking opioids may help identify patients at risk. Efforts to improve proper disposal of unused pills may also reduce the risk of misuse and diversion.

abstract_title: Toward Remote Assessment Of Physical Frailty Using Sensor-Based Sit-To-Stand Test
author_block: C. Park<sup>1</sup>, A. Sharafkhaneh<sup>2</sup>, M. Bryant<sup>2</sup>, C. Nguyen<sup>2</sup>, B. Najafi<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Michael E. DeBakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center,Medical Care Line,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Assessment of physical frailty (PF) is recommended to evaluate risk of surgical intervention and track recovery post-surgery in older adults. Current PF assessment tools are resource intensive and unsuitable for remote assessment. Five times sit-to-stand test (5xSTS) could be a practical method for remote assessment of PF using tele-medicine. Although a few studies have demonstrated that 5xSTS correlates with PF, no study has reported whether 5xSTS can objectively quantify PF and frailty phenotypes. Acknowledging this limitation and recent efforts to shift from face-to-face to remote assessments, we investigated the effectiveness of 5xSTS with wearable sensors to identify PF and three key frailty phenotypes (slowness, weakness, and exhaustion) in older adults.

Methods: Eighty older adults (76.6±7.9 yrs) performed 5xSTS while wearing 5 wearable sensors (LEGSysTM, BioSensics, MA, USA) attached to the trunk, left and right thighs, and left and right shanks. Fried frailty phenotype assessment was used to assign them to a PF group (n=40) or non-PF group (n=40); PF was determined with presence of at least one phenotype. We defined six sensor-derived parameters to quantify PF phenotypes. Slowness was determined by 5xSTS duration (s5xSTSd), hip angular velocity range (HAVR), and knee angular velocity range (KAVR); weakness was determined by hip angular power range (HAPR) and knee angular power range (KAPR). Exhaustion was determined by coefficient of variation of vertical velocity range (CVVVR). In addition, we manually recorded 5xSTS duration (m5xSTSd) using a stopwatch. Between group differences were assessed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). Linear regression analysis was conducted to examine the agreement between the s5xSTSd and the m5xSTSd. Binary logistic regression analysis was conducted to evaluate the relationship between PF and the 6 sensor-driven outcome measures. Two PF-predictive models were built; model 1 used s5xSTSd, and model 2 used the 6 sensor-driven outcome measures as the independent variables. Area-under-curve (AUC) was calculated for the two models.

Results: Significantly lower HAVR (p<0.0001), KAVR (p=0.001), HAPR (p=0.002), KAPR (p=0.029), CVVVR (p=0.036) and significantly slower s5xSTSd (p<0.0001) and m5xSTSd (p<0.0001) for the PF group compared to the non-PF group were observed. An excellent agreement was observed between the s5xSTSd and the m5xSTSd (p<0.0001, r=0.93). Results suggest that Model 2 (sensor-derived metrics) has noticeably superior AUC compared to Model 1 (s5xSTSd) with AUC of 0.81.

Conclusion: Our study suggests that PF and the three key frailty phenotypes (slowness, weakness, and exhaustion) can be objectively quantified by 5xSTS with wearable sensors. Wearable sensor-based motor capability assessment holds great potential for remote assessment via telemedicine. Future study warrants to explore validity of sensor-based 5xSTS to remotely determine PF and risk of adverse outcomes post-surgery.

abstract_title: Content and Use of Long Talk in Outpatient Surgical Consults
author_block: T. C. Doan<sup>1</sup>, N. D. Baggett<sup>1</sup>, A. Buffington<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Zelenski<sup>2</sup>, E. Kalbfell<sup>1</sup>, F. Ljumani<sup>3</sup>, B. Hanlon<sup>4</sup>, J. Clapp<sup>5</sup>, R. M. Arnold<sup>6</sup>, M. L. Schwarze<sup>7</sup> <sup>7</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Division Of Vascular Surgery, Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Medicine,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Madison, WI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Department Of Biostatistics And Medical Informatics,Madison, WI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Anesthesiology And Critical Care,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Pittsburg,Department Of Medicine,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Collaborative decision making before major surgery is critical to support patient autonomy.  It is well known that physician talk consumes most of the discussion as they work to provide information. What surgeons say and how they say it impacts the patient’s ability to participate, but little is known about the length and content of typical surgeon talk in consultations. The objective of this study is to quantitate the length and categorize the content of long talk by surgeons during conversations about major surgery. 

Methods:  We performed secondary analysis on audio-recorded outpatient surgical consults between 43 surgeons and patients 60 years and older considering major vascular or oncologic surgery at 5 medical centers. We randomly selected 4 transcripts from each surgeon in the cohort. Each uninterrupted block of speech, or utterance, was quantitated by character length and content coded by at least 2 of 6 coders with discrepancies adjudicated through social moderation. The codes tagged utterances with typical elements of preoperative communication, e.g., risks, explanation of disease.  We characterized long utterances as those in the top 5% of character length: >562 characters, roughly 108 words or 30 seconds.

Results: We analyzed 169 transcripts (median length 21 min, range 5 to 61 min). Three surgeons had only 3 transcripts appropriate for inclusion. Long utterances ranged from 562 to 10,322 characters (roughly 30 sec to 9.2 min). Forty-one of 43 (95%) surgeons engaged in long talk in at least one consultation and 84% used long talk in at least half of their consultations. The range of long talk was 3 to 46 utterances per surgeon and 1 to 18 utterances per transcript. There was no association between surgeon specialty or location with long talk. Long utterances primarily contained descriptions of the patient’s disease and treatment and rarely included options or tradeoffs (Figure). Surgeons often covered multiple topics in their long talks (44% of long utterances covered 3 or more topics) without pause to let the patient or family contribute or ask questions. Within these long utterances, some surgeons used highly consistent phrasing among all patients while others broached a range of topics without recognizable patterns

Conclusion: In this multi-specialty, multi-site sample, most surgeons talk in an uninterrupted fashion at times during surgical consultation; however, the frequency of use of long talk varies between individuals. These long talks most often delivered technical information about disease and treatment. Although surgeons were engaging in information transfer, this presentation may make it difficult for patients and families to identify the salient issues related to surgical decision making.

abstract_title: Impact of Hospital Quality on Financial Performance among Private U.S. Hospitals
author_block: S. Enumah<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Chang<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  The impact of delivering high-quality care on hospital financial performance is uncertain. Some argue that higher-quality care may be too expensive and can negatively impact hospital finances and disrupt future care delivery. In contrast, advocates argue that higher-quality care ultimately leads to better clinical outcomes and improved financial health through increases in revenue and decreases in expensive complications.

Methods:  We performed an observational study of private US hospitals from 2013-2018 using quality metrics from Hospital Compare data linked with hospital characteristics from the American Hospital Association Annual Survey. Mixed effects linear regression was performed with fixed year effects and random hospital intercept effects. The dependent variable was total profit margin. Independent variables included the hospital's weighted average 30-day mortality rate, 30-day readmission rate, Patient Safety Indicator-90 (PSI-90) score (higher scores indicate lower quality), and hospital characteristics.

Results: Our sample included 11,247 hospital-years from 2,427 unique hospitals. The median hospital mortality rate was 12.3% (IQR 11.3 — 13.3) and the median readmission rate was 15.3% (IQR 14.7 — 15.9). The median PSI-90 score was 0.91 (IQR 0.80 — 1.02). There was some, but not consistent, association between higher mortality rates and higher hospital profit margins. In contrast, there were significant associations between higher readmission rates and lower profit margins (highest quartile with an adjusted difference of -0.60% compared to the lowest quartile) and between higher PSI-90 scores and lower profit margins (significant for all quartiles with an adjusted difference of -0.48% for the highest quartile compared to lowest quartile, Figure). 

Conclusion: Poor hospital safety quality and higher readmission rates may contribute to worse hospital financial performance. Hospital managers and policymakers should support investments to improve hospital quality.      Grant Support: (1) Association for Academic Surgery Trainee Research Fellowship Award: Health Services Research (2) National Institutes of Health T32 program: Grant Number T32DK007754

abstract_title: Cognitive Impairment Burden among Adult Kidney Transplant Candidates and Recipients at All Ages
author_block: X. Chen<sup>1</sup>, N. M. Chu<sup>1,2</sup>, A. L. Gross<sup>2,3</sup>, M. C. Carlson<sup>2,3</sup>, J. M. Garonzik-Wang<sup>1</sup>, S. P. Norman<sup>4</sup>, D. C. Brennan<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Segev<sup>1,2</sup>, M. A. McAdams-DeMarco<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health,Department Of Epidemiology,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health,Department Of Mental Health,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Medicine,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Kidney failure and reliance on dialysis can contribute to cognitive decline, yet the burden of cognitive impairment among adult kidney transplant (KT) candidates and recipients across ages remains unclear. This paper aims to explore the prevalence and risk factors of global cognitive impairment and executive function impairment among adult KT candidates and recipients across the age spectrum.

Methods:  A two-center prospective cohort study (2009-2019) consisting of 5199 KT candidates and recipients was leveraged. The Modified Mini-Mental State Exam (3MS) and the Trail Making Tests (TMTs) were applied at evaluation for candidates and at KT admission for recipients to measure global cognitive function and executive function respectively. The prevalence of global cognitive impairment (3MS<80) and executive function impairment (TMT>1.5 standard deviations above mean test time) were estimated by age. The risk factors for global cognitive impairment and executive function impairment were estimated using adjusted logistic regression. A Wald test was used to test the interactions of risk factors with age.

Results: The 3MS was measured among 3992 KT candidates and 1207 recipients, while TMT was measured among 2205 candidates and 327 recipients. The prevalence of global cognitive impairment increased with age among KT candidates, while the prevalence was lower among KT recipients and showed a U-shaped relationship with age; the prevalence of executive function impairment increased with age among both KT candidates and recipients (Figure 1). KT candidates and recipients who were older (>=65), Hispanic, and had lower educational attainment were more likely to show cognitive impairment. Male sex, Black race, and both types of dialysis were also risk factors for cognitive impairment among candidates. The burden of executive function impairment was higher among male and Black candidates and recipients; among KT candidates, older age, lower education, hemodialysis, and diabetes were also associated with executive function impairment. No differences were observed in the strength of these associations by age group in either cohort (p for interactions>0.05).

Conclusion: The burden of cognitive impairment is high even in young KT candidates and recipients and increases with age. Transplant centers should be aware of the need of screening for cognitive impairments for kidney failure patients at all ages and be aware that younger surgical patients with kidney failure may experience a high burden of cognitive impairment.

abstract_title: Performance of the Interhospital Transfer System for Emergency General Surgery: A Network Analysis
author_block: C. Y. TENG<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Davis<sup>2</sup>, M. R. Rosengart<sup>1,2</sup>, K. M. Carley<sup>3</sup>, J. M. Kahn<sup>2,4</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine,Surgery,PITTSBURGH, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine,Critical Care Medicine,PITTSBURGH, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Carnegie Mellon University,Computer Science, Engineering, And Public Policy,PITTSBURGH, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health,Health Policy & Management,PITTSBURGH, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Emergency general surgery (EGS) conditions are common and are associated with high mortality and costs. Interhospital transfers occur frequently for patients with EGS conditions. However, the network in which these transfers take place is not well understood, including the degree to which patients are systematically transferred to high-volume and high-performing hospitals. Using a network analysis approach, we examined the interhospital transfer system for EGS in the United States, focusing on the association between hospital-level factors and transfer patterns among hospitals within the transfer network.

Methods: We performed a retrospective cohort study of episodes of care with EGS conditions that involved interhospital transfers from an emergency department (ED) to an inpatient admission at a different hospital. We used all-payer claims data from the 2016 Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project State Inpatient and ED Databases in eight U.S. states. We defined EGS episodes as temporally adjacent ED and inpatient encounters that occurred in different hospitals, in which the inpatient encounter had an EGS diagnosis. In our network analysis, hospitals were nodes and transfers were directional ties between nodes. We then defined 3 variables at the hospital level: in-degree centrality (the number of ties directed to the node), out-degree centrality (the number of ties directed from the node), and centrality ratio (in-degree divided by out-degree centrality; in which higher values indicate more transfers accepted in relation to transfers sent). We then performed multivariable logistic regression in which the dependent variable was log-transformed centrality ratio and the independent variables were indirect (such as hospital size, trauma center designation, teaching status, EGS volume) and direct (risk-adjusted mortality and failure to rescue) measures of hospital quality.

Results: In 2016, 728 hospitals were involved in 48,446 transfers for EGS conditions. Median (interquartile range) number of transfers sent and transfers received were 106 (60.5-157) and 35 (8-136), respectively. Median centrality ratio was 0.23 (0.02, 1.09). In multivariable analysis, a higher log-transformed centrality ratio was associated with several indirect measures of quality, including more ICU beds, teaching hospital status, trauma center designation, and higher EGS volume (p<0.01). However, log-transformed centrality ratio was not associated with direct measures of quality, including risk-adjusted mortality (β= 0.49; 95% CI: -9.4, 10.4; p=0.92) and failure to rescue (β= -3.8; 95% CI: -10.2, 2.6; p=0.24).

Conclusion: The existing EGS transfer system consistently directs patients to well-resourced hospitals but does not consistently direct patients to hospitals with better clinical outcomes. Future research should identify specific opportunities for targeting transfer destinations in order to improve outcomes for transferred patients with EGS conditions.

abstract_title: Novel Trauma Simulation Course Enhances Hemorrhage Control Education for PA State Police Cadets
author_block: B. W. Otaibi<sup>1</sup>, D. G. Haas<sup>1</sup>, M. Lloyd<sup>2</sup>, A. E. Bollinger<sup>3</sup>, K. Patil<sup>2</sup>, A. Ssentongo<sup>2</sup>, J. R. Reed<sup>4</sup>, J. P. Hazelton<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine,Hershey, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,Division Of Trauma, Acute Care And Critical Care Surgery,Hershey, PENNSYLVANIA, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Hershey, PENNSYLVANIA, USA <sup>4</sup>Pennsylvania State Police Academy,Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Nationwide, Stop the Bleed (STB) courses have been offered as a means to equip learners with basic skills to control life-threatening hemorrhage. While the benefits of this program have been studied in the civilian population, less attention has been given to the outcomes of this training for first responders, particularly law enforcement officers. Our institution, an academic, Level-1 Adult & Pediatric Trauma Center, partnered with the Pennsylvania State Police (PSP) Academy in 2017 to create a novel Trauma Experience (TrEx) course to be completed by the PSP cadets. The TrEx course is a simulation based program designed to expose the cadets to a range of trauma scenarios which they may encounter during their career as as PSP troopers. 

Methods: Since the inception of the TrEx course, we have trained more than 1,100 graduating PSP cadets. We designed a REDCap based questionnaire aimed at identifying perceived strengths and weaknesses in the current trauma knowledge of PSP troopers as well as confidence in their ability to render aid to an injured victim. This survey was distributed to all active PSP troopers and included participants who had taken the TrEx course during their academy training (TrEx) as well as those who had graduated prior to 2017 and therefore only completed the standard STB course (STB).

Results: A total of 4,599 active PSP troopers received the email-distributed survey with 1,506 (32.7%) responding [TrEx n=243(16%), STB n=1,263(84%)]. Troopers who participated in the TrEx course were found to have provided medical care and used a tourniquet fewer times in the field than those who did not complete the course (both p<0.005). Despite having less overall real world experience, TrEx participants felt more confident in their ability to recognize scenarios in which a tourniquet should be used and in their ability to properly apply a tourniquet (both p<0.001). Furthermore, the TrEx group reported less perceived need for additional education regarding appropriate tourniquet use and application (p=0.032). Cohorts did not differ in confidence in their ability to recognize life-threatening bleeding (p=0.370).

Conclusion: These results demonstrate that the TrEx course created through the partnership of our Trauma Center and the Pennsylvania State Police Academy is more effective than standard STB training in increasing trooper confidence in both applying tourniquets and recognizing situations in which a tourniquet should be used. These data show that law enforcement officers should receive additional training in hemorrhage control beyond what the STB course teaches. Future initiatives should involve enhancing partnerships between trauma centers and law enforcement agencies in an effort to improve the ability and confidence of law enforcement officers to respond properly to a victim with life threatening hemorrhage.

abstract_title: Objective Measurement of Clinicians' Cognitive Load During High Fidelity Trauma Simulations
author_block: S. H. Park<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Alballa<sup>1</sup>, S. Goldberg<sup>2</sup>, B. Tayeb<sup>6</sup>, M. Bassurah<sup>1</sup>, E. Abahuje<sup>1,2,7</sup>, C. Pozner<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Yule<sup>3,4,5</sup>, R. D. Dias<sup>1,2</sup> <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,STRATUS Center For Medical Simulation,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Department Of Emergency Medicine,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Edinburgh,Department Of Clinical Surgery,Edinburgh, SCOTLAND, United Kingdom <sup>4</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>6</sup>King Abdulaziz University,Department Of Anesthesia And Critical Care,Jeddah, SAUDI ARABIA, United Arab Emirates <sup>7</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction:  Cognitive load reflects the balance between demand and available resources within working memory. Learning outcomes are related to the level of cognitive load imposed by teaching activities. Previous literature has shown that cognitive overload can negatively impact both learning and clinical performance. We investigated learners’ cognitive load during trauma team training (TTT) using an objective digital biomarker. 

Methods:  A 3-hour simulation-based interprofessional TTT program was conducted. Each session included an introductory lecture, pre-briefing, and 3 scenarios each followed by a debriefing session. Two scenarios involved only one trauma patient and 1 scenario involved multiple patients. Participants were ED nurses, emergency medicine and surgery residents. Each wore a heart rate sensor that detected continuous electrical heart signals, calculated interbeat intervals, and transmitted data via Bluetooth to a smart watch. Processing of raw data generated more than 40 heart rate variability (HRV) parameters. We chose the low frequency/high frequency ratio (LF/HF ratio), a validated proxy for cognitive load and calculated it using a 1-minute time window, allowing comparison across different roles, specialties and simulation phases. A mixed model analysis with repeated measures was performed, followed by Bonferroni adjustment for multiple comparisons.

Results: A total of 10 participants (2 surgery residents, 6 EM residents, and 2 ED nurses) were monitored during 4 sessions, totaling 12 simulated scenarios. Most participants were female (N=7, 70%) and the mean age was 31.4 + 5.2 years. There was a statistically significant difference of LF/HF ratio between the scenario and the debriefing phases: mean difference = 1.91; 95% CI = [1.28 – 2.53]; p < 0.001. Compared to single-patient scenarios, multiple-patient scenarios posed a higher cognitive load to learners: mean difference = 1.34; 95% CI = [0.35 – 2.32]; p = 0.008 (Fig.1).There was no statistically significant difference between leaders and followers, or between specialties. 

Conclusion: We used an objective digital biomarker (HRV) to measure cognitive load of learners during simulation-based TTT. Our findings revealed that cognitive load (LF/HF ratio) during simulation activities were higher than the average normal in adults (at rest). Cognitive load was also increased during all three scenarios compared to debriefings, and the highest in a multiple-patient scenario, suggesting that HRV is a sensitive tool to detect cognitive load in varying simulation phases and scenario difficulty. Future studies could use HRV to understand the relationship between cognitive load, performance and long-term skills retention.

abstract_title: Trends in Resident Case Numbers of Minimally Invasive and Open Inguinal Hernia Operations
author_block: T. L. Bettis<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Esparaz<sup>2</sup>, J. M. Grams<sup>3</sup>, B. L. Corey<sup>3</sup>, J. R. Porterfield<sup>3</sup>, A. D. Parmar<sup>3</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Division Of Gastrointestinal Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the expansion of minimally invasive techniques, there is a growing concern of inadequate resident exposure to conventional open operations during surgical training. This is most concerning for operations that might be performed infrequently at certain institutions but will be essential for independent practice, such as open inguinal hernia repair. We hypothesize that there has been an increased exposure to minimally invasive inguinal hernia cases with a concomitant decline in exposure to open inguinal hernia cases. 

Methods: We conducted a review of publicly available Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) case reports from 2003-2018. Both open and minimally invasive inguinal hernia cases were evaluated. Analyzed data included total and average case number for open and minimally invasive inguinal hernia repairs. Descriptive statistics as well as simple linear regression analysis for the overall cohort was performed to determine the trends in surgical cases. 

Results: From 2003-2009, there was an overall increase in the number of inguinal hernia repairs performed (open and minimally invasive) from 62,839 to 70,139 (p=0.04). From 2003-2018, the average number of minimally invasive inguinal hernia cases per resident increased from 11.9 in 2003 to 40.1 in 2018 (p<0.001). For open cases, the number of cases slightly decreased from 47.9 in 2003 to 46.3 in 2018. The slope coefficient was 1.97, meaning the number of minimally invasive operations per resident increased by an average of 1.97 per year from 2003-2018. There was no statistically significant change observed in the number of open inguinal hernia operations performed per resident from 2003-2018 (p=0.21) with simple linear regression.

Conclusion: Adequate exposure to a breadth of technical approaches continues to be an important topic in ACGME discussions for surgical residency. Our review has shown a national increase in the total number of inguinal hernia repairs performed and the number of minimally invasive inguinal hernia repairs performed in general surgery residency. Despite this overall increase, general surgery resident exposure to open inguinal hernia repair has remained unchanged. Future studies are needed to characterize resident and faculty perspectives on optimal training approaches in inguinal hernia repair.

abstract_title: Concurrent Validity Evidence for Entrustable Professional Activities in General Surgery Residents
author_block: M. Brazelle<sup>1</sup>, B. Corey<sup>1</sup>, J. Porterfield<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A subset of Entrustable Professional Activities (EPAs) have been developed for general surgery. Little evidence currently exists for their validity as a workplace-based assessment tool. In this study, we aimed to collect concurrent validity evidence for EPAs as a framework for assessment of general surgery residents compared to the current gold standard of ACGME milestones.  

Methods:  All general surgery residents at a tertiary care center were encouraged to complete EPA micro-assessments using a mobile app. EPA ratings were collected across 3 phases of care (pre-, intra-, and post-operative) for 5 clinical scenarios immediately following a clinical encounter using a numerical scale from 0-4. Milestone evaluations (scored 0-4) were performed bi-annually to assess competency advancement. Resident PGY level and case difficulty were also collected. Correlation between EPA and milestone scores was assessed with Spearman rank correlation, and multivariable regression was utilized to identify significant predictors of milestone ratings.  

Results: From August 2018-December 2019, a total of 320 micro-assessments were collected from 34 residents (70%).  EPA scores demonstrated developmental increases by PGY level (Figure 1).  Operative phase EPA scores were significantly lower than non-operative phase scores (2.04 ± 0.99 vs 3.70 ± 0.68, p,0.001). EPA scores demonstrated strong correlation with non-operative milestone ratings PC-1, MK-1, and ICS-2 (>0.55 for all, p<0.001) and moderate correlation with operative milestone ratings PC-3 and MK-2 (=0.41, p<0.001; =0.31, p<0.001).  When EPA scores differed significantly from respective non-operative milestone ratings, EPA scores were consistently higher. On multivariable regression, PGY level (0.36, p<0.001) operative phase (-1.69, p<0.001) , and case difficulty (0.11, p=0.04) were significant independent predictors of faculty entrustment ratings.

Conclusion: The correlation between EPA micro-assessment scores and respective milestone ratings establishes concurrent validity evidence for EPAs as a formative assessment in general surgery residents.  Operative phases of care were granted consistently less entrustment than non-operative phases. Further study is needed to determine how use of EPAs can enhance entrustment decision-making to better equip general surgery residents for unsupervised practice upon graduation.

abstract_title: Gender Differences in EPA Evaluations of General Surgery Residents
author_block: E. Padilla<sup>2</sup>, C. Stahl<sup>1</sup>, S. Jung<sup>1</sup>, A. Rosser<sup>1</sup>, P. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, T. Aiken<sup>1</sup>, A. Acher<sup>1</sup>, D. Abbott<sup>1</sup>, J. Greenberg<sup>1</sup>, R. Minter<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,General Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Performance evaluations play a critical role in career advancement and skill development for physicians, however evidence suggests that female physicians tend to receive lower faculty evaluations while underrating their own performance. Competency-based education frameworks such as Entrustable Professional Activities (EPAs) may help address gender evaluation bias in surgery by linking evaluations to specific, observable behaviors. This study evaluated the gender differences in both the faculty assessments of residents and resident self-assessments across 5 EPAs in general surgery. We hypothesized that female residents would under-rate their own performance and receive lower faculty evaluations compared to male residents.

Methods:  Within a single academic general surgery residency program, assessment data for five surgery specific EPAs was prospectively collected using a mobile application for 23 months. Bivariate comparison between male and female residents was performed using chi-square and student’s t-tests. The effect of gender on EPA evaluation scores was analyzed using multiple linear regression while controlling for faculty gender, PGY level, EPA type, faculty department, faculty years of experience, and phase of care.

Results: Of the 2,480 EPA evaluations, 1,230 were submitted by faculty and 1,250 were submitted by residents. 1,295 EPA evaluations were submitted for female residents and 1,185 were submitted for male residents (faculty and resident submission). Following multiple linear regression, faculty evaluations of residents were not impacted by resident gender (estimate = 0.09, p = 0.08). However, in resident self-assessments female residents underrated themselves by 0.29 (on a 0-4 scale) compared to their male counterparts (p < 0.001).

Conclusion: Faculty assessments showed no difference in EPA scores between male and female residents. Female residents underrated themselves by nearly an entire PGY level compared to male residents. Understanding female residents’ tendency to underrate themselves has important implications for surgical educators.

abstract_title: Resident Diversity in Academic Surgery is Associated with Interest in Global and Community Health
author_block: B. C. Bredbeck<sup>1</sup>, L. D. Delaney<sup>1</sup>, A. Lussiez<sup>1</sup>, G. Kwakye<sup>1</sup> <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The surgical workforce is growing more diverse, but there are persistent barriers to academic surgical advancement for those underrepresented in medicine (URiM). At the same time, academic surgical departments with dedicated resident development years offer an ever-widening menu of options for career development time.   Little is known about the academic interests of highly competitive general surgery applicants, including URiM applicants. With this in mind, we analyzed the academic interests of applicants selected to interview at an academic surgical program during the 2019-2020 interview cycle.

Methods: Highly competitive external applicants who were offered interviews at an academic general surgery program completed a survey on gender, race/ethnicity, and academic area of interest. Applicants expressing interest in global and community health were contacted for an explanatory semi-structured interview.

Results: 76 applicants completed the survey with a 100% completion rate. URiM applicants, who comprised 24% of the cohort, were significantly more interested in global and community health (OR 8.63, 95% CI 2.53-29.38, p=0.001). Education and professional development was popular accross all groups. There were no differences in declared interest by gender (Table 1).   Of 17 applicants who indicated an interest in global and community health, 8 completed an explanatory semi-structured interview; of these, seven were URiM. Key themes identified during the interviews included origin from an underserved international or community setting, strong interest in sustainable and mutually beneficial global partnerships, challenges in seeking out and identifying mentors in the field, and commitment to increasing diversity in surgery.

Conclusion: For programs aiming to recruit top applicants into a diverse residency cohort, focusing on academic development in both global/community health and education/professional development may strengthen the pipeline of academic URiM surgeons. Fostering mentorship in the field and establishing sustainable partnerships would address important barriers to pursuing global and community health work. URiM applicants interested in global and community health also noted that joining a surgical program committed to a racially diverse surgical workforce was a high priority.

abstract_title: Resident ACGME Case Logs: The Real Operative Experience?
author_block: R. Thanawala<sup>1</sup>, J. Engelbart<sup>2</sup>, J. Jesneck<sup>5</sup>, R. Rhee<sup>4</sup>, N. E. Seymour<sup>3</sup>, J. Shelton<sup>2</sup> <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery/Department Of Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa,Department Of Surgery,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Massachusetts-Baystate Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Springfield, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Maimonides Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Brooklyn, NY, USA <sup>5</sup>Firefly Lab,Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For optimal training of surgical residents, it is critical to construct an accurate, comprehensive understanding of trainee operative experience, which is approximated by surgical case logs. The ACGME implemented a competency based approach for surgical training through the Milestones project and requires residents to log surgical cases with credit only given to the primary CPT code. We sought to compare the operative experience of trainees under the current model of primary CPT codes vs. a more inclusive model with secondary CPT codes.

Methods: The case logs of 218 residents and 164,692 cases (11/2008 - 7/2020) were evaluated across 39 hospitals, 9 training programs, and 7 surgical specialities. We utilized a HIPAA-compliant resident education platform (Firefly) for tracking case assignments and operative case logs. We calculated the average number of procedures logged per case, both in aggregate and grouped by program year. Procedures were counted by primary and secondary CPT codes, to measure the difference in logged procedures that were not considered for residency credit.

Results: Capturing procedures and sub-procedures directly from the OR schedule was associated with 16% increased CPT codes per procedure (paired t-test, p < 0.00001), with the largest increase for senior residents. Residents performed significantly more procedures than the current model of primary codes recognizes for major credit. When grouped by ACGME-defined CPT area, the largest differences were observed for coronary sclerosis (51% additional CPT codes per case), peripheral obstructive cases (40%), 29%), and venous cases (26%).

Conclusion: In this multi-institution, multi-specialty attempt to clarify logging practices, surgical residents logged on average 16% more procedures than credited to them in the existing ACGME case credit allocation model of one primary CPT code per patient each day. This demonstrates significant under-reporting of resident surgical experience during training. Based on several resident interviews and preliminary comparison of assigned cases vs. logged cases (data not shown), the under-reporting is significantly larger than shown by case log data. Residents often forget to log cases, or fail to log secondary procedures, any procedures that are not classified for major credit by the ACGME, and procedures beyond their ACGME minimum requirements. Surgical education is transitioning to more procedural competency-based feedback and assessment. Consideration of crediting residents for all aspects of surgical procedure completed as a part of their training may help improve characterization of the quality of the trainee operative experience.
